title: Raja of Sri Lanka: A Prince Among Elephants
description: Raja, the most celebrated elephant in Asia, lounged flat-out in the cool muddy river with the insouciance of Mae West between scenes, dawdling his trunk like a limp wrist in the hot afternoon.

title: Bonds End Day Unchanged
description: Bond prices, which showed gains early in the day, retreated before closing almost unchanged in light trading.

title: Brennan Tied To Inquiry
description: First Jersey Securities and its once high-profile owner, Robert E. Brennan, are the primary targets of a grand jury investigation into charges of market manipulation and securities fraud.

title: U.S. ENVOY'S FAREWELL TO NICARAGUA
description: Like many American ambassadors, Harry E. Bergold keeps a large wall map in his office at the United States Embassy in Managua.

title: GORBACHEV URGES EXPANSION OF FAMILY FARMS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has called for a sharp increase in small-scale family farming to provide more meat, vegetables and other food. The move is seen here as a bid by the Soviet leader to buy time to get his sweeping economic reorganization under way.

title: Offering by Minnesota
description: A $200 million competitive issue of Minnesota general obligation bonds drew reasonably good interest from institutional investors yesterday despite a municipal market that was lethargic.

title: Cuba Is Mired in Angola, Top Defector Says
description: The Cuban Air Force general who defected to the United States in late May has broken his silence in a series of interviews that detailed widespread disillusionment within the Cuban military over its involvement in Angola.

title: If Seoul Is to Enjoy Democracy
description: South Koreans and their friends around the world can breath a bit easier now that a political compromise seems to have been reached in Seoul. But steady progress toward a more open political system and democratic rights is likely to be difficult.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Style page last Saturday about the American Craft Council fair in Springfield, Mass., misidentified a Connecticut crafts worker who made a series of baskets displayed at the fair. She is Kari Lonning.

title: CONNORS STAGES STIRRING REVIVAL
description: There is only one reason why he plays, Jimmy Connors says, and that is for the final victory, the one that enables him to walk away with the winner's check. But as he raised his arms in triumph on Centre Court today, reveling in the standing ovation given him by the usually reserved British crowd, there was a look on his face that suggested that after all these years, Connors understands better than most that there are some things money cannot buy.

title: BROADWAY MUSICIANS ON BROADWAY APROVE A 3-YEAR PACT
description: Broadway musicians have accepted a new contract that will allow producers to use highly sophisticated electronic synthesizers, called replicators, and curtail the practice of hiring nonworking players in exchange for guaranteed minimums in the size of orchestras in Broadway theaters for six years and increases in pay and benefits.

title: New Leadership Begins For Moseley Securities
description: The Moseley Securities Corporation is getting new leadership amid conflicting reports of disagreement among top executives over what direction the firm should take.

title: Judge Removed From Bench
description: A town justice from Franklin County was removed from the bench today by New York state's highest court and barred from holding judicial office. The court, the Court of Appeals, removed the Burke Town Justice, Lee Vincent, for mishandling funds and failing to promptly dispose of cases. He had held the part-time position since 1975. The removal of Mr. Vincent, who is not a lawyer, had been recommended last October by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct, a watchdog panel.

title: Texas Instruments vs. Japan
description: To survive in a world market increasingly dominated by the Japanese, such American semiconductor manufacturers as the Intel Corporation and Advanced Micro Devices Inc. have withdrawn to segments they think they can still defend. Others, including Motorola Inc. and the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation, are teaming up with their Japanese rivals.

title: U.S. Eurobonds In Steep Dive
description: THE prices of some $30 billion in Eurobonds issued under tax treaties with the Netherlands Antilles and Aruba plummeted yesterday as a result of Washington's decision to end those treaties.

title: HOUSE REJECTS OUTSIDE ETHICS PANEL
description: The House has rejected a proposal by four conservative Republicans to create a special commission to investigate what they termed the ''pattern of corruption'' in the House.

title: KEY RATES
ON THE MARK
description: Among the 10 female student-athletes named to the GTE Academic All-America team was Ilaria Rebay of Columbia, a mathematics major who ran on the cross-country and track teams. Rebay is a pre-med student from Manhattan who received 11 A-plus marks while achieving a 4.04 grade-point average, and ran the mile on the Columbia medley relay team at the Penn Relays that set a school record of 9 minutes 28.5 seconds. Also named to the team by the College Sports Information Directors of America was Regina Cavanaugh of Rice, the only woman to win three N.C.A.A. indoor track and field championships in one event, the shot-put.

title: A JULY 4 TOAST TO FOODS THAT MADE AMERICA GREAT
description: TRANSCONTINENTAL travelers have often remarked on the homogeneous nature of America's culinary landscape: Every town has its golden arches, surrounded by purveyors of fried chicken, tacos, pizza and fish nuggets. Fortunately, even as the blandness of franchised fast-food outlets replaced the distinctiveness of local fare, the faithful hung on - loyal and appreciative audiences remained for those luncheonettes, diners and drugstore counters that continued preparing their specialties, like Pepe's Pizzeria in New Haven, famous for its white clam topping, and Central Grocery in New Orleans, where the muffuletta, a round hero of meats, cheese and olive salad, is king.

title: Go, Go, Guggenheim
description: To the Editor:

title: House Resists Razing Of Embassy in Moscow
description: The House today rejected a Senate call to tear down the United States Embassy in Moscow, instead freezing the project until November while an alternative plan is developed for the electronically bugged diplomatic post.

title: WOMEN AND CONDOMS
description: To The Living Section Anna Quindlen's Life in the 30's column on women and condoms [ June 17 ] reminded me of the mid-1970's, when I was counseling women on birth-control techniques. I always touted the virtues of condoms coupled with a spermicide as an unbeatable method for birth control. As a bonus, this method offered protection against sexually transmitted diseases. It also required both partners to take responsibility for a shared experience and had no side effects, except for a rare allergic reaction. Yet women grabbed the pill as if it were a one-day-only sale.

title: Oriental Fruit Flies Prompt A Quarantine in California
description: The discovery of Oriental fruit flies in Hawaiian Gardens, a suburb here, will prompt the state to quarantine fruits and vegetables in parts of Los Angeles and Orange Counties, officials said today.

title: Crowd of 40 Seizes Rape Suspect
description: A suspected rapist armed with a hunting knife was chased down, encircled and captured by 40 residents of the Inwood section of Manhattan late last night after he attacked a woman in an elevator, the police said.

title: Payroll Perplexity
description: For working parents who hire a competent, trustworthy, full-time babysitter, the good news is that they can go off to work with less guilt. The bad news is that becoming employers, even of a single employee, renders them vulnerable to new entanglements with the Internal Revenue Service. Many try to avoid the bad news by paying the babysitter off the books. That's what one couple's friends told them to do with a woman they hired to care for their infant son.

title: Robert Hunsicker, Vicar of St. Paul's For 20 Years, Dies
description: The Rev. Robert C. Hunsicker, who served the parish of Trinity Church for 37 years, 20 of them as vicar of historic St. Paul's Chapel, died of a heart attack Saturday in Manhattan. He was 72 years old and a resident of Manhattan and Sandisfield, Mass.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Track and Field Record High Jump in Sweden: Patrik Sjoberg of Sweden broke the world high jump record yesterday by clearing 7 feet 11 1/4 inches on his third and final attempt at a Grand Prix track and field meet in Stockholm. Igor Paklin of the Soviet Union had set the record of 7-10 3/4 at the World University Games in Kobe, Japan, on Sept. 4, 1985. The hometown favorite ran a victory lap after his jump, and several hundred spectators spilled into the grounds, waving Swedish flags.

title: THE STATEMENT ON JUDAISM
description: Following is the text of the declaration on Judaism adopted yesterday at the Cleveland convention of the United Church of Christ:

title: BIRTHDAY JESTS AND GIBES FROM A MERRY M.F.K.
description: THIS Friday, July 3, M. F. K. Fisher will celebrate her 79th birthday. She is particularly happy about the date of her birth because, for one thing, it leads directly to one of her favorite stories.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Finance/New Issues column of Business Day yesterday, about new bonds sold by the Centel Corporation, misstated their maturity. It is 31 years.

title: TURMOIL AT WORLD BANK
description: Whatever popularity former Representative Barber Conable Jr., a Republican from New York, brought to the presidency of the World Bank seems to be eroding by the day. Mr.Conable is well along with his cost-saving plan to release 10 percent of the bank's staff of 6,000, and, predictably, some of those 10 percent look unkindly toward Mr. Conable.

title: THREE FREED WHALES TRACKED BY SATELLITE
description: The research ship that released three pilot whales off the coast of Nantucket on Monday has lost radio contact with the animals, but a satellite is continuing to track them, the New England Aquarium said here today.

title: Enact Workfare That Works
description: In this year of ''new consensus'' on welfare reform, the Reagan Administration offers an old proposal: Extend workfare requirements to every able-bodied adult recipient of welfare. The principle accords nicely with the consensus, but the Administration plan fails in its details. Another plan in Congress holds greater promise.

title: First Pacific Seeks Buyer for Hibernia
description: The Hibernia Bancshares Corporation said its parent company, the Hong Kong-based First Pacific Holdings Ltd., is looking for a buyer for the Hibernia Bank. Founded here 116 years ago, the Hibernia Bank was bought by First Pacific in December 1982 for $56 million. It now has $1.5 billion in assets, 800 employees and 35 branches in Northern California.

title: Tear Gas, and Plenty of It
description: The national police confirmed with statistics today what every resident of Seoul and other big cities had already sensed: a tremendous amount of potent tear gas was fired at anti-Government protesters who took to the streets in the last few weeks.

title: BUSH BACKERS RALLY AT CAPITOL IN ATTEMPT TO SHOW STRENGTH
description: Vice President Bush attempted a show of political strength today, mounting the steps of the Capitol at noon with 57 Republican House members who have endorsed his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: N.C.A.A. SESSION REBUFFS PRESIDENTS
description: College sports officials who oppose major changes in their programs showed their strength here today, defeating or deferring action on virtually every significant measure sought by a group of university presidents.

title: A DEBATABLE DEBATE
description: On Wednesday night Washington's political professionals will be staying in.

title: CONCERT: CHAMBER MUSIC
description: IN contrast to the ordered predictabilities of so many concerts like it, For the Love of Music's afternoon of chamber music at Merkin Concert Hall on Sunday came across as a kind of vivid urban sprawl. There were both the unexpected pleasures and the descents into junkiness one expects in such a neighborhood.

title: Metals Firm's Assets Frozen
description: The American Metals Exchange Corporation, a commodities firm accused of securities violations, has agreed to stop doing business temporarily, freeze its assets and turn over its operations to a court-appointed receiver, according to Federal court documents filed today.

title: Farmers' Prices Up
description: The prices that farmers received for raw products in June rose 1.6 percent from May and averaged 8.3 percent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Brazilian Debate: A President or a Premier?
description: The impressive lineup of people who favor keeping a presidential system of government under Brazil's new constitution include President Jose Sarney, his senior military commanders, the head of the majority party and the country's main opposition leader.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: A PHOTO FINISH FOR ALBANY'S LEGISLATURE
description: Here in the state's capital, the seasons have a peculiar rhythm. Just when everyone else is planning the menu for the Fourth of July picnic, the Legislature is preparing to get down to business.

title: BAKKERS LOOKING AT SITES FOR A NEW MINISTRY
description: The Rev. Jim Bakker and his wife, Tammy Faye, said today that they were looking at three locations for a new ministry while their lawyer battles for the PTL television ministry and its lucrative theme park, Heritage USA.

title: TOUR DE FRANCE: ANYONE'S RACE
description: Sean Kelly, Stephen Roche and Laurent Fignon, three of the favorites in the Tour de France bicycle race, agree that at the start in West Berlin Wednesday there will really be no favorite.

title: New York's Charter and Nonwhites
description: LEAD: Twenty years ago, the Kerner Commission in the aftermath of unprecedented urban rebellion and civil disobedience concluded that America was drifting toward ''two separate societies, one white, one black, separate and unequal.'' New York City largely escaped the black rage that swept through 100 cities - the inevitable result of the refusal of the powerful to grant justice and equity to the powerless.

title: WALTER J. LUDOVICO
description: Walter J. Ludovico, the city's longest-serving Councilman, died Monday at Crouse Memorial Hospital after suffering a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

title: GUIDRY OVERPOWERS JAYS
description: For one night, Ron Guidry reached back to his glory days. He is older now, and wiser, but the fastball and the slider no longer seem to overpower hitters as they once did. But Guidry had them again, just this one time, on a night when he tried to re-establish himself as a capable pitcher for the Yankees.

title: Federico Mompou, Spanish Composer, Dies
description: Federico Mompou, whose miniature, atmospheric songs and piano pieces were championed by such notable performers as Arthur Rubinstein and Montserrat Caballe, died early yesterday morning at his home in Barcelona, Spain, his wife reported. He was 94 years old.

title: Correction
description: The Food Notes column on June 17 gave incorrect prices for dried fruit at Zabar's. The prices were for a pound, not a half-pound.

title: THE MEMOIRS OF PIGPEN HUNT
description: Nobody in the spring of 1975 trained harder or weirder than Ron Hunt, who held the major league record for being hit by most pitches in one season, 50, in one career, 243, in one extra-inning game, 3, and for leading the league in being hit by pitches in consecutive seasons, 7.

title: Senate Backs Import Ban in Soviet Trade Deal
description: The Senate overwhelmingly approved import penalties tonight for the Japanese and Norwegian companies that diverted sophisticated propeller-milling equipment to the Soviet Union, enabling the Russians to make quieter submarines.

title: Advertising; Health Professionals Focus of Antidrug Ads
description: The Partnership for a Drug-Free America, the advertising industry's huge effort to dry up the demand for cocaine and marijuana, showed a new facet of the battle yesterday: ads aimed at enlisting health care professionals in the war.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: EACH June the end of the school year means classroom cleanup time for students and instructors at the Calhoun School on the Upper West Side. And, as she has done on such casual occasions for 20 years, Lil Lulkin, who teaches 5-year-olds at the private school, once again donned her 1960's camp work shirt with the peace symbol embroidered on the pocket. The shirt did not go unnoticed by her homeroom class.

title: GAS PRICE DROP REJECTED
description: State utility regulators today denied a request by the state's Consumer Counsel, James Meehan, to reduce the rates of the Connecticut Natural Gas Company by $9.3 million, despite an 11 percent drop in the company's cost for gas since 1984.

title: A DA VINCI OF DOUGH CLOSES BAKERY ON THE WEST SIDE
description: His relatives told him he needed a trade to emigrate from Hungary to America, so Louis Lichtman decided to become a baker. His first cake, a spongecake, was an epiphany.

title: BOXER IN HOSPITAL
description: Sherman Griffin, who won the United States Boxing Association cruiserweight championship from Jeff Lampkin on a split decision last Friday, was recovering today from gunshot wounds he received Saturday when, the police charge, he attempted to rob a couple at a motel.

title: WINE TALK
description: THOMAS JEFFERSON -wine collector, student of wine making and merchandising, grape grower and wine adviser to the first five Presidents (himself included) - pulled a decanter from his wooden traveling wine chest and poured us both an aperitif. He had granted a wide-ranging interview about foreign and domestic wines, his first in 161 years. The occasion was the 200th anniversary of his tour of French wine regions, from which he emerged the father of American connoisseurs.

title: ILLINOIS BACKS AIDS TRACING
description: The Illinois House passed legislation today that would require the State Department of Public Health to trace the sexual partners of people infected with the AIDS virus.

title: MOSQUITOES CAN CARRY AIDS VIRUS BUT NOT PASS IT ON, STUDY SAYS
description: A study by scientists collaborating with the National Cancer Institute has found that mosquitoes can retain the AIDS virus in their bodies for two or three days after ingesting infected blood, according to an insect expert associated with the study.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: STRIKERS WATCH NBC GO ON WITHOUT THEM
description: It was hot - 91 degrees - and humid and for the dozens of members of the striking union who picketed outside NBC headquarters in Manhattan yesterday, the misery of the weather was compounded by the frustration of knowing the show would go on without them.

title: Bill to Keep Apartments Off Market Is Rejected
description: A bill that would have kept 167,000 state-subsidized, moderate-income apartments from being transferred to the open market was rejected today by the State Senate's Republican leadership, virtually ending its chances for passage during the current legislative session.

title: CHRISTMAS IN JULY FOR OLD-TIMERS
description: A group of about 950 retired National Football League players who played all or most of their professional careers before 1959 are beginning to receive their first monthly benefit checks from a special owners program that will compensate them for the rest of their lives.

title: JUDAISM AFFIRMED IN CHURCH MILESTONE
description: The United Church of Christ yesterday became the first major Protestant denomination in the United States to declare ''that Judaism has not been superseded by Christianity'' and that ''God has not rejected the Jewish people.''

title: INSIDE
description: Rail Merger Is Upset Washington turned down a merger of the Santa Fe and Southern Pacific Railroads, ending a four-year effort.

title: FILM DIRECTORS START STRIKE VOTE TODAY
description: Negotiations between movie and television producers and the Directors Guild of America have come down to the wire.

title: 10 Men Accused of Treason Are Released in South Africa
description: A Supreme Court justice released on bail today 10 men who have been on trial since 1985 on treason and subversion charges relating to the outbreak of black township violence.

title: LIFE IMPRISONMENT ASKED FOR BARBIE
description: The prosecutor said today that Klaus Barbie had committed ''particularly inhuman'' deeds as Gestapo chief in Lyons and deserved the maximum penalty, life imprisonment.

title: Underground Water Used For Power
description: FOR decades, electric utilities and oil companies that were lucky enough to find very hot geothermal reserves on their land have operated small power plants that generate electricity from steam produced by the earth's natural heat. While the amount of power produced from such plants has been limited, it has enabled the companies to save millions of dollars in production costs.

title: ON BRINK OF DEFEAT, SHRIVER FINDS TOUCH
description: There was nothing left to do except play the point, Pam Shriver decided. Her concession speech was committed to memory, the tension actually dissipating as she took a deep breath and prepared to serve against Sylvia Hanika of West Germany.

title: America's Role As Net Debtor
description: LAST week the Commerce Department released what seems like an alarming statistic: The nation's foreign debt more than doubled last year, to $263 billion - well above the foreign debt of Brazil, Mexico and Argentina combined. Furthermore, by 1992 the American debt will have risen to $900 billion, many economists estimate.

title: HARVARD ON THE AIR
description: For a close look at the Presidential contenders, Harvard University plans to put all 15 of the Democrats and Republicans on public television, one by one, an hour each, on Sunday afternoons starting in October and ending just before the Iowa caucuses in February. Invitations went out only on Monday, so it is too early to say whether all will appear.

title: THEATER: 'PERFECT CRIME'
description: WARREN MANZI has the makings of a crackling thriller in ''Perfect Crime,'' playing at the Courtyard Theater. Its tension holds tight even while it ridicules conventions of the genre.

title: Transit Police Radios Have to Work in Subways
description: To the Editor:

title: FETAL TISSUE IMPLANTS IN BRAIN SEEN
description: Scientists at a conference here today said that they expected to experiment soon with transplanting fetal tissue, either animal or human, into patients' brains to replace the destroyed cells that account for Parkinson's disease.

title: Murdoch Buys British Tabloid
description: Rupert Murdoch added another newspaper to his international media empire today, buying Britain's financially troubled Today color tabloid for $60.8 million.

title: Advertising; United Jewelers Goes To Hively Agency
description: The Hively Agency of Houston, whose letterhead is adorned by a busy little bee, is now going to be doing the advertising for United Jewelers and Distributors, which will be spending $1.5 million.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: COMMANDER IN CHIEF: Franklin Delano Roosevelt, His Lieutenants and Their War. By Eric Larrabee. 732 pages. Harper & Row. $25.

title: Pessimism Sends Dow Down 28.38
description: The stock market gave in to growing pessimism yesterday and retreated sharply. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 28.38 points, to 2,418.53.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: THE SENATE
description: It may be an unlikely issue for one of the few Senators who is not a parent. But Christopher J. Dodd is emerging as a leading spokesman in Congress on families and children.

title: Rulers' Takeover of Voting System Imperils Haiti's Democratic Trend
description: After several months of progress toward democracy, the military Government in Haiti has seized control of the electoral process, provoking the most serious political crisis since the collapse of the Duvalier dictatorship 17 months ago.

title: KARL P. WEGENER
description: Karl P. Wegener, owner for almost half a century of the Arbor Inn restaurant in Rockville Centre, L.I., died of lung cancer on Monday in Mercy Hospital there. He was 82 years old and lived in Rockville Centre.

title: REVIVING EDUCATION SYSTEM: NEW PROGRAMS ARE SOUGHT
description: The Commission on the Year 2000 singled out education as the ''most important service'' determining New York City's future and suggested radical ideas on reshaping the deteriorated system.

title: ORIGINAL BOOS
description: When Doug Sisk of the Mets complained earlier this season that he, Darryl Strawberry and Howard Johnson had been unfair targets of booing at Shea Stadium, they sounded like the latest victims in a phenomenon that started 26 seasons ago, at the beginning of the Mets' existence. The first player to draw the wrath of the crowd was Jim Marshall, one of the 25 original Mets.

title: Bus Line Maligned
description: To the Editor:

title: BALLET: THE BOLSHOI, IN 'GOLDEN AGE'
description: What is it about the Bol-shoi Ballet that makes it easy to extoll its virtues - to forgive its sins, in other words? Very likely, the answer lies in this historic Moscow company's unsurpassed gift of communicating with its audience.

title: LAW IN MICHIGAN BARRING FUNDS FOR ABORTIONS IS RULED IN FORCE
description: Payments by the State of Michigan for abortions for indigent women were halted today by a judge who agreed with an anti-abortion group's interpretation of a new state law. The group had initiated the law with a petition.

title: CITY COUNCIL ENDORSES BILL ON CORRUPTION
description: An anti-corruption bill that would revoke the pensions of retired city officials convicted of crimes they committed while in office won unanimous endorsement yesterday by the New York City Council.

title: If Seen, Then Not Heard
description: To The Living Section:

title: TOP REAGAN AIDES PUSH GULF POLICY
description: Top Reagan Administration officials, seeking to overwhelm Congressional opposition to President Reagan's Persian Gulf policy, acknowledged the risk in escorting Kuwaiti vessels today, but argued that it is far more risky to do nothing.

title: OF BIKES AND SELLING STAMPS AND CALORIES AND KINGS
description: Several times a week, as dusk approaches, a startling apparition emerges from the royal palace on a blue bicycle with an extra-wide seat.

title: Gore to the Fore
description: With Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee in the Presidential race, we now have nine announced candidates, seven ''leaners,'' six drop-outs, and 432 commentators who differ on who's likely to win.

title: METS RECALL THE WAY TO RALLY
description: Maybe it was the fact that Dwight Gooden pitched nine innings with nine strikeouts and won for the fifth time in six starts. Or maybe it was just that the Mets found a way to keep their bullpen off the field, after all.

title: Allegheny Debt
description: Allegheny International Inc., the consumer products company, will trim its burdensome debts to less than $100 million by year-end and earn a profit in 1988, the chairman, Oliver S. Travers, said. The company had a loss of $164 million last year and $38 million in the 1987 first quarter. It ousted the former chairman, Robert J. Buckley, last year amid reports of extravagant management spending and financial losses and is defending against shareholder lawsuits and a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation. ''I expect that the company will have a loss for the full year, which will result from operating losses from our non-consumer businesses,'' Mr. Travers said at the annual shareholdlers meeting.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Northwest Airlines, a unit of NWA Inc., to Kolesar & Hartwell, St. Paul, for travel agent, meeting and incentive, and cargo advertising.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Mobil Corporation is offering $200 million of 8 5/8 percent notes, due in 1994, at a price of 99.209 to yield 8.712 percent, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: U.S. Again Bars Rail Merger
description: The Government refused yesterday to allow a merger of the Santa Fe and Southern Pacific railroads, ending a tortured chapter in takeover history.

title: Bomb Scare at the Met Delays Ballet's Opening
description: A bomb scare yesterday disrupted last night's opening of the Bolshoi Ballet's New York season, delaying the rise of the curtain by an hour and annoying thousands of balletgoers.

title: SOUTH KOREAN CHIEF AGREES TO DIRECT PRESIDENTIAL VOTE AND A DEMOCRATIC 'NEW ERA'
description: President Chun Doo Hwan approved sweeping democratic changes today, including direct presidential elections, and said he hopes they would usher in ''a new era of democratic development and mature politics.''

title: CATCH OF LIFETIME
description: For Bryan Spodek, life as a striped-bass fisherman may never be the same. In only his third time out on a fishing boat, the 10-year-old boy from Dix Hills, L.I., with a little help from his father, hooked a 37-pounder in Cold Spring Harbor on Sunday. The fish measured 44 inches in length, only 2 inches less than the boy's height. According to George Valentine, the owner of Four Winds Bait and Tackle Shop in Huntington where the fish was weighed and measured, the catch was one of the largest in an area where striped-bass size has been exceptional this year, including two more than 43 inches in length in the last 10 days. For a boy of 10, the catch is probably a record, but perhaps a curse as well. ''It's the catch of a lifetime,'' Bryan's father, Steve, explained. ''It's like going out with Bo Derek on your first date.'' Bryan could not be reached for comment; in the wake of his fishing triumph, he had left for a sleep-away camp.

title: DAVILA ENTERS PROTEST
description: Albert Davila was ahead on points on all three scorecards before he lost his bid for the North American Boxing Federation and California state bantamweight titles last Saturday because of a cut that he said came from a head butt by his opponent. Now he has officially protested the decision that declared Frankie Duarte winner by technical knockout.

title: HAGLER IN COURT
description: Marvin Hagler, upset by Sugar Ray Leonard in the middleweight title fight April 6, will fight to save his marriage, Hagler's attorney, Morris Goldings, said after the boxer made a court appearance yesterday outside Boston.

title: 6 States Pick Michigan For Radioactive Waste
description: Michigan was chosen today by six other Middle Western states to be the site of the region's first low-level radioactive waste dump.

title: Yeager's Mother Dies
description: Susie M. Yeager, mother of the aviator Charles E. (Chuck) Yeager, died Sunday after a long illness. She was 89 years old. Mrs. Yeager died in Putnam General Hospital at Hurricane, officials at Koontz Funeral Home in Hamlin said today. Mr. Yeager was a World War II hero and a test pilot who became the first man to break the sound barrier. He now lives in California. Mrs. Yeager is also survived by another son, Hal Yeager Jr.; a daughter, Tansy Cummings; two brothers, two sisters, seven grandchildren and 16 great-grandchildren.

title: Chrysler Incentives
description: The Chrysler Corporation has extended indefinitely its program of buyer incentives, adding several new models but dropping conventionally sized pickup trucks. The same schedule of low-rate financing will apply, a spokesman said, with the lowest rate of 3.7 percent for a loan of 24 months. But the alternative cash rebate incentives range up to $750, compared with a maximum of $1,000 previously.

title: GARBAGE STRIKE AVERTED WHEN PACT IS EXTENDED
description: A strike by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters against 135 garbage collection companies in 13 of New Jersey's 21 counties was averted today by an agreement to extend an existing contract on a day-to-day basis.

title: MARKET FOR FRENCH FRIES IS PROMOTED IN FAR EAST
description: After creating a world market for pizza, the Federal Government is now playing a major role in the international promotion of french-fried potatoes. Its target is the Far East.

title: FILM: 'BABY-SITTING'
description: IMAGINE the terrors that await nice kids from an affluent suburb when a series of mishaps forces them to visit downtown Chicago at night, with no better chaperone than their feisty blond baby sitter. This is what ''Adventures in Baby-Sitting,'' which opens today at the Baronet and other theaters, asks its audience to do. The kids meet such exotic types as gangsters, thieves and blues musicians, and everyone they encounter is delighted to make them the center of attention (the gangsters chase them; a car thief befriends them; the musicians invite them to sing). It's hard to know whether naivete this overwhelming is deliberate or accidental.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Once Upon a Time

title: Factory Orders Unchanged
description: Orders for factory goods were unchanged in May despite strength in civilian categories, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: O'CONNOR APPOINTS A NEW VICAR GENERAL
description: John Cardinal O'Connor yesterday named Msgr. Patrick J. Sheridan the Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New York, succeeding Bishop Joseph T. O'Keefe, who was appointed the Bishop of Syracuse two weeks ago.

title: MARATHON DELAY
description: Because of sponsorship problems, the America's Marathon-Chicago, scheduled for Oct. 25, has been postponed until next spring, which is good news for the New York City Marathon and bad news for the Boston Marathon.

title: SENATOR CONCEDES AD IN TV DRIVE WAS FALSE
description: United States Senator Robert Kasten Jr., a Wisconsin Republican, acknowledged today that a television commercial attacking a Democratic opponent last fall contained false information.

title: SEVERAL SITES IN JERSEY ARE WEIGHED BY NBC
description: The National Broadcasting Company is considering additional sites in New Jersey for its headquarters, including a major project being developed on the Hudson River in Jersey City, a network official and developers said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JULY 1, 1987
description: International A3-15

title: GRAND OL' SOFTBALL
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp's Supply-Sliders softball team trounced Senator Bob Dole's Oval Officers 8 to 2 Monday evening, but neither of the Republican contenders for President played. Senator Dole's crew showed some improvement over the game last year, when the Kemp folk won 21 to 5.

title: A.T.&T. Expects Larger Earnings
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said that it expects to post higher earnings in the second quarter than previously expected. Without being specific, A.T.& T.'s chief financial officer, Robert M. Kavner, told a group of of security analysts in Philadelphia yesterday that the company's results through May continued ''to be better than anticipated'' and that ''the second quarter is likely to show an improvement over the first.''

title: DANCE: CUBAN WINS GOLD MEDAL IN NEW YORK BALLET COMPETITION
description: YOUNG dancers from Cuba, China and Argentina won top prizes in the second New York International Ballet Competition, which concluded Monday night with a gala performance at the City Center. The competition, held every three years, attracted 46 dancers between the ages of 17 and 23, from 17 countries.

title: FILM: 'INNERSPACE,' A COMIC FANTASY
description: WHEN Mel Brooks, in his current ''Spaceballs,'' refers to a planned sequel called ''Spaceballs II: The Search for More Money,'' he is more or less joking. When the makers of ''Innerspace'' leave their film without a real ending, and instead with a plug for the sequel that has apparently been planned, they are not. It takes great confidence to think of a second film before the first is even finished; either that, or it takes great nerve. In any case, ''Innerspace,'' which opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, has all the brashness of a hit, if not all the luster.

title: The U.N. Today: July 1, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Resignation At Bank Leu
description: Arthur Fuerer, chairman of Bank Leu, is resigning, the Swiss bank said today. The bank has been linked to the scandal surrounding Guinness P.L.C., the British brewing company.

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: YOU have surely discovered by now that the microwave oven is useful for more than defrosting. If not, try now, with mussels.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1.Handyman's Special With Executive Tools, you will never be left in the lurch without a hammer or a nail - or a screwdriver, pliers, a saw or a knife. This handy miniature toolbox, only 4 by 4 1/2 inches, contains everything for quick repairs. It costs $17.50 at Jenny B. Goode, 1194 Lexington Avenue (81st Street) and 11 East 10th Street. 2.For Beach Travels This oversize canvas bag should hold everything you could possibly want to take to the beach. Made of dirt-resistant canvas and trimmed with tan leather, it closes with a zipper and comes in a choice of colors: yellow, green, royal blue, fuchsia and aqua. The bag is $19.99 and can be found in the luggage department at Abraham & Straus, 420 Fulton Street (Hoyt Street), Brooklyn. It is also at branch stores, except the one in Garden City, L.I. 3.Jewelry from India This bracelet, lightweight and brightly colored, is ideal for warm-weather dressing. Hand-painted in India, it comes in shades of blue and green on a white background. The price is $16. A matching necklace and earrings are also available. The jewelry also comes in other patterns. At Monsoon, 842 Lexington Avenue (64th Street). 4.Adorned in History ''We the People,'' begins this Echo silk scarf, a reprint of the Preamble to the Constitution. The lettering is red, the background white, the border blue. For $35, in accessories, on the first floor of Lord & Taylor in Manhattan, and at branch stores.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: SUMMER is the best of seasons for food preparation. An abundance of herbs - fresh thyme, tarragon, chives, chervil - are ready for picking just outside my kitchen door. And I find pleasure, too, in cleaning and firing up my much-used outdoor grills, of which I have two: one for wood and charcoal, the other heated by gas. For cleaning the grill, I have a substantial metal brush nearby and put it to use while the grill is still hot; the retained heat eases the job. Occasionally I wash the grill with detergent and water to eliminate any charred bits of meat.

title: BROOKLYN BOY, 7, IS CRUSHED WHILE PLAYING IN AN ELEVATOR
description: A 7-year-old Brooklyn boy was fatally crushed while playing an an elevator car last night in the apartment building where he lived, the police reported.

title: 2 New York Stations Shifting Radio Formats
description: Two New York radio stations are changing their formats today. At 12:01 A.M. WYNY (97.1 FM) switched from contemporary music to country music. And at 3 P.M., WHN (1050 AM), plans to change from country music to sports news.

title: CONCERT: AVE SOL, FROM RIGA
description: AVE SOL, a chamber choir from Riga, in the Latvian Republic of the Soviet Union, came to Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon with a generous selection of Latvian music and a smattering of Western and Russian pieces ranging from the 16th century to ours. The conductor, Imants Kokars, is also director of the Latvian State Conservatory, and he is an estimable program maker. The Sunday concert was perfectly enjoyable on the folkloric level that makes his group a popular touring attraction and musically stimulating at the same time.

title: SHIITES SAY 2 LIVE U.S. HOSTAGES HAVE BEEN SENT TO IRAN FOR TRIAL
description: Shiite Moslems here say that two American hostages have been shipped to Iran, apparently to face a revolutionary court.

title: Charter Oak-Nike
description: Charter Oak Partners, an investment partnership based in Westport, Conn., has purchased 6.1 percent of Nike Inc.'s nearly 23 million class B shares outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Charter said that it bought the shares of the Beaverton, Ore.-based athletic shoe and apparel concern for investment purposes. ''

title: 3Com, Microsoft Planning Software
description: The Microsoft Corporation and the 3Com Corporation said that they would jointly develop and market software to allow a new generation of personal computers to communicate with one another.

title: Canada's New $1 Coin
description: Thirty-five million new dollar coins became available for distribution today, the beginning of the end of Canada's $1 bill in a plan that the Canadian Government said would save millions in production costs. The new coins will be distributed through banks and trust companies, said Michael Francis of the Royal Canadian Mint. The coins have 11 sides, are gold-colored and show a loon on one side and Queen Elizabeth on the other.

title: In the Party Politics of Italy, Little Is Big
description: To the Editor:

title: WITNESSES SAY THAT MAFIA CONTROLLED TOWER CONTRACTS
description: Extensive testimony about the Mafia controlling construction of major buildings has come from witnesses at a racketeering trial in Manhattan.

title: DEAVER LOSES APPEAL TO DELAY PERJURY TRIAL SET FOR JULY 13
description: Michael K. Deaver lost a request today to have his perjury trial delayed, and he then turned to Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist with his appeal.

title: Columbia Arts School Selects a New Dean
description: The Columbia University School of the Arts has named Peter Smith to succeed Schuyler G. Chapin as its dean. Mr. Smith, director for 12 years of the Hopkins Center for the Creative and Performing Arts at Dartmouth College, will assume his duties on Sept. 1.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I clearly recognize the fact that regardless of the possible merits and demerits of a particular system, and irrespective of the preferences of any specific political parties, the general public has an ardent desire to choose the President directly.'' - President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea. [ A8:4. ]

title: BIRTHDAY PARTY FOR WASHINGTON POST CHIEF ATTRACTS 'ALL THE BIG NAMES'
description: By nightfall there was an elite traffic jam downtown of Rolls-Royces, Mercedes, Jaguars, Cadillac limousines, taxis and the Presidential motorcade. Tourists stood by with cameras, knowing something was afoot but not quite sure what.

title: RACING'S REWARDS
description: Two trainers, Leroy Jolley and Mack Miller, a jockey, Walter Blum, and two champion horses, Gallant Man and Real Delight, have been elected to thoroughbred racing's Hall of Fame in Saratoga, N.Y. Jolley has trained two Kentucky Derby winners, Foolish Pleasure in 1975 and Genuine Risk in 1980. Miller, who has trained 55 stakes winners since beginning his career in 1949, trained Assagai, Hawaii and Snow Knight, all champion grass horses.

title: Bank Curbs, Insurer Aid Approved by Conferees
description: Dealing a sharp setback to the Reagan Administration's policy of financial deregulation, Congressional conferees agreed tonight on legislation to permanently ban any new limited-service banks, which offer only partial banking services.

title: The Dog Bites Big Red
description: Trailways bus lines, which lost $14 million last year, is about to leave the driving to Greyhound. For $80 million, Trailways will sell many of its buses and terminals to the larger company, which has promised to maintain service to all 1,200 Trailways destinations for at least one year. After that, all bets are off. Greyhound would become the sole provider of bus service on most intercity routes, increasing its share of the national market from 60 to 80 percent. Greyhound argues that one profitable company would serve travellers better than two struggling ones. Its ability to raise rates on monopoly routes, the company claims, would be checked by competition from the same low fare airlines that pushed Trailways to the edge of financial collapse.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
ENHANCING TOFU
description: LEAD: TOFU, while not the staple of our diets many of its advocates had hoped it would be, is nevertheless a versatile, nutritious food. At the same time, it is something of a cipher in the kitchen.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Out-of-Town Ice Creams

title: Foes of Nuclear Plants Win Key Ally in House
description: Opponents of nuclear power plants in Shoreham, L.I., and Seabrook, N.H., have won the backing of a key Congressional leader for legislation that would effectively block operating licenses for the reactors.

title: KOREA'S PRESS AWAITS THE PROMISED FREEDOM
description: This country's tightly controlled newspaper editors thumbed their noses at their Government regulators the other day - they printed a picture of the opposition leader, Kim Dae Jung for the first time in more than two years.

title: Aiming 'Bullets' at Disease
description: MONOCLONAL antibodies -the ''magic bullets'' that can deliver therapeutic or imaging substances directly to the site of a disease in the body - were hailed as one of the most promising developments in medicine when they were introduced a dozen years ago.

title: G.M. Layoffs Set
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would lay off 3,000 hourly workers this week as it winds down production at two Detroit assembly plants scheduled to close Dec. 23. A spokesman for the Cadillac division said the Fleetwood and Clark plants would eliminate the jobs when they resume production on a single shift after a two-week retooling for model change-over, which begins Wednesday. During retooling, an additional 2,000 workers will be laid off temporarily.

title: PICK AN ANSWER
description: As part of their pursuit of fame, recognition and corporate contributions, Washington-based research organizations, i.e. think tanks, urge their scholars to stand ready to comment on major events. But it appears that no commentators for the American Enterprise Institute were quoted, presumably because they were not available, on June 2 when Paul Volcker said he would be leaving his post as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and Alan Greenspan was named to replace him.

title: Leading Indicators Rise 0.7%
description: The Government index designed to forecast economic activity rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in May, the fourth consecutive monthly increase, the Commerce Department said today.

title: NEW DEAL FOR MCADOO
description: Bob McAdoo, the 35-year-old former National Basketball Association scoring champion who said he planned to end his career in Italy, has mailed in a signed contract to Tracer of Milan to play his second season in Italy. McAdoo, a 13-year player in the N.B.A. with seven teams, including the Knicks and the Nets, led Tracer to a rare triple triumph this past season in the Cup of Italy, the European Cup of Champions and the Italian league title.

title: SOVIET GIVES CITIZENS POWER TO APPEAL CIVIL RIGHTS ABUSE
description: The Supreme Soviet enacted a new law today giving citizens, for the first time, the right of legal appeal against actions of public officials in violation of their rights.

title: ARTISTRY, SPUN OF SUGAR AND GREAT LOVE
description: ONCE, Serge Georges Sender made a birthday cake for Margot Fonteyn that had the ballerina at its center, sitting in a chariot surrounded by sugar swans and marzipan flowers. He has reproduced a life-size Balenciaga evening dress, in sugar, right down to the lace trimming.

title: Statistically, AIDS Poses Significant Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: MARYLAND ACTS TO LIMIT LAWSUITS BY THE POOR
description: Maryland is instituting a policy tomorrow that legal aid lawyers say will severely restrict access to the courts for the poor as well as the mentally and physically handicapped.

title: FINAL AGREEMENT REACHED IN ALBANY ON AN ETHICS BILL
description: Ending one of the most bitter disputes here in memory, Governor Cuomo and the leaders of the State Legislature announced agreement tonight on a broader and stricter new ethics code governing the behavior of hundreds of thousands of state and local government officials and state employees.

title: Guide to New York City's Future Recommends Sweeping Changes
description: A commission created by Mayor Koch made sweeping recommendations yesterday to confront poverty, crime, overdevelopment, inadequate schools and other problems in New York City.

title: Meese Remark on Standards For the Court Draws Laughs
description: Hundreds of people laughed Monday when Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said the Reagan Administration had no philosophical test for filling the Supreme Court vacancy created by the retirement of Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. After a speech on the Constitution to about 3,000 people at the Chautauqua Institution, Mr. Meese was asked by a member of the audience if the person President Reagan chooses to replace Justice Powell must oppose abortion.

title: FOR THE STRAWBERRY DEVOTEE, IT'S SUMMER ALL YEAR LONG
description: RHAPSODIZING about strawberries nearly 400 years ago an English writer said, ''Doubtless God could have made a better berry, but doubtless God never did.'' He was talking about strawberries. His reverent tone was obviously induced by the lusciousness of the berries, but, one wonders, was it exaggerated because they were available for so short a time?

title: Underwritings Shrank 8.7% in Second Quarter By JAMES STERNGOLD
description: A sudden surge in interest rates and unstable bond prices cooled the market for new securities underwritings in the second quarter from the sizzling pace of the previous year.

title: THE STAGE: EYEN'S 'POWER'
description: IN the same week that the hit musical ''Dreamgirls,'' book and lyrics by Tom Eyen, returns to Broadway for a summer run, Mr. Eyen's ''Power, Greed and Self-Destruction in America'' is concluding a brief reappearance at La Mama, where it was first produced in 1966. It is an apt coincidence, since the early work, subtitled ''Give My Regards to Off Off Broadway,'' is a cracked chronicle of a playwright's rise or fall from innovative theater to crowd pleasers with plots.

title: Canada's Parliament Rejects Move to Restore Executions
description: Parliament rejected by 21 votes today a motion to restore capital punishment in Canada.

title: Dome Requests Extension on Debt
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., the Canadian oil and gas giant that is trying to avert bankruptcy, asked its major creditors to extend debt waivers for two months while it tries to win their approval for a takeover bid by the Amoco Corporation.

title: C.O.M.B. Plans Merger
description: The C.O.M.B. Company and the Cable Value Network video shopping concern announced a definitive agreement to merge. C.O.M.B., which owns 50 percent of the network, would acquire the remaining interest in exchange for warrants to buy C.O.M.B. stock worth $289 million. The merged company will be called CVN Companies.

title: A SWIMMING POOL STOPS IN BROOKLYN 'LIKE A U.F.O.'
description: Flap, flap, flap. Here comes big Antoine McCrorey, 11 years old, flapping down the sidewalk in Bedford-Stuyvesant, wearing a swimming suit, goggles and swim fins - and looking for all the world like an escapee from the New York Aquarium, or maybe some other type of institution, the way people were looking at him.

title: E. Howard Molisani, Ex-I.L.G.W.U. Official
description: E. Howard Molisani, a garment-union official in New York City for 40 years, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Port Washington, L.I. He was 76 years old.

title: In Freehold, More Than Just Homes
description: FREEHOLD Township is one of the areas in central New Jersey that has seen its population balloon as home buyers in search of affordable housing pushed out from New York City and communities in northern New Jersey.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JULY 1, 1987
description: The Economy

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: GIRL, 5 years old, to mother:

title: Chairman and Chief Is Named by GCA
description: David R. S. Steadman has been named chairman and chief executive of the GCA Corporation. The Andover, Mass., company, which makes machinery for semiconductor production lines, has just gone through a refinancing that has given it room to maneuver.

title: ONE WOMAN, TWO LIVES, MANY MEMORIES
description: While Katharine Graham may love a party, the purpose of the glamorous affair held last night was to mark her 70th birthday, a milestone she says she would have preferred to pass with less attention.

title: James S. Lay Jr., 75, Retired U.S. Official at C.I.A. and N.S.C.
description: James S. Lay Jr., a retired Central Intelligence Agency official and former executive secretary of the National Security Council, died of Alzheimer's Disease Sunday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Perry Point, Md. He was 75 years old and lived in Falls Church, Va.

title: EUROPEAN PARLEY BREAKS UP OVER FARM SUBSIDIES
description: A meeting of Western European leaders broke up in disagreement tonight over plans to curb spending on farm subsidies, which are piling up huge surpluses of unwanted food.

title: KEAN PROPOSES POWERFUL SHORE AGENCY
description: Governor Kean announced a plan today to protect the rapidly developing coastal area by vesting broad powers over land use and environmental planning in a single state-dominated commission.

title: YANKEES CHOOSE 1,000 BOX SEATS AS ALCOHOL-FREE
description: A thousand seats will be set aside as a no-drinking section in Yankee Stadium, which seats 57,000 people, under an agreement announced jointly today by the Yankees and a state senator.

title: TOP MATCHES YESTERDAY
description: Ivan Lendl beat Johan Kriek, 6-3, 7-6, 6-2. Mats Wilander beat Emilio Sanchez, 2-6, 7-6, 6-3, 7-5. Stefan Edberg beat Jakob Hlasek, 6-3, 6-7, 6-1, 6-4. Jimmy Connors beat Mikael Pernfors, 1-6, 1-6, 7-5, 6-4, 6-2. Henri Leconte beat Andres Gomez, 7-5, 7-5, 7-5. Pat Cash beat Guy Forget, 6-2, 6-3, 6-4. Martina Navratilova beat Gigi Fernandez, 6-3, 6-1. Steffi Graf beat Jana Novotna, 6-4, 6-3. Chris Evert beat Rosalyn Fairbank, 6-2, 2-6, 7-5. Helena Sukova beat Raffaella Reggi, 6-0, 6-0. Pam Shriver beat Sylvia Hanika, 6-7, 7-5, 10-8. Gabriela Sabatini beat Natalya Zvereva, 6-0, 2-6, 6-4. Claudia Kohde-Kilsch beat Catarina Lindqvist, 6-4, 6-2.

title: SHUTTLE TO GET ESCAPE HATCH AND OTHER SAFETY FEATURES
description: The first space shuttle to be launched in the aftermath of the Challenger's explosion will have an escape hatch, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today. But it said no decision had been made on whether the craft would have the capacity to eject the crew safely in an emergency.

title: POLLUTION RULE IS OVERTURNED
description: A Federal appeals court today overturned a 1979 regulation by the Environmental Protection Agency that banned new factory construction without permits to allow discharge of pollution.

title: U.S. Said to Endorse Soviet Ideas For Compromise on Missile Cuts
description: The United States has responded favorably to an informal Soviet suggestion that could remove major barriers to a new accord on intermediate-range and short-range missiles, officials here said today.

title: RECORD FIELD READY AT HENLEY
description: The 143d rowing of the Henley Royal Regatta, which was first raced on this idyllic stretch of the Thames in 1839, begins Wednesday with a record entry of 371 crews, including a record 60 contenders from overseas.

title: The Real Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: LAW COVERING GENERIC DRUGS GOES INTO EFFECT IN NEW YORK
description: New York pharmacists will be required to fill prescriptions with lower-cost generic drugs unless physicians and dentists stipulate otherwise, under a state law that takes effect today.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: THE last time my home was burglarized was more than 10 years ago, when I was living alone in a small apartment in a faintly ominous warehouse district. The thieves took all of my jewelry. Some of it had belonged to my mother and my grandmother, and I wept when I saw the little velvet-lined boxes open and empty. They took all my electronic equipment, too. I thought ruefully of what a rotten housekeeper I was when I saw the pristine square surrounded by fluffy dust where my television had been.

title: Terms for Dozier
description: The Minnesota Vikings and their first-round draft pick, D. J. Dozier, the running back from Penn State, have agreed in principle to a multiyear contract. Dozier, who led the Nittany Lions in rushing for four years, is the first No. 1 or No. 2 selection by any National Football League team to agree to terms. The agreement calls for a two-year contract plus an option year. Dozier was the 14th pick over all.

title: IN TEXAS, THE TWAIN NOT ONLY MEET BUT MARRY
description: It is 25 hot, dusty miles from Paducah to the ranch. The road winds past brakes of cedar and clumps of lowing Brahman cows, turns into caliche and ends at a small white house behind a picket fence. It is not the kind of place one expects to find a great-granddaughter of Baron Paul von Gontard of Berlin, one of the leading figures in the Daimler automobile company, and a great-great-granddaughter of Adolphus Busch, a co-founder of Anheuser-Busch.

title: Bridge: Routine Fourth-Best Return Is Not Always Best Choice
description: The fourth-best opening lead, now abandoned by many experts, has great antiquity. It was described by Edmond Hoyle of England, the father of whist and its descendants, in his pioneering ''Short Treatise on the Game of Whist'' in 1742. But the other side of the coin, the fourth-best return, has had little attention from theorists.

title: The Pop Life
description: Mario Bauza's Music

title: REDS WIN AND WIDEN LEAD
description: Kurt Stillwell scored from second base on Tracy Jones's infield single in the bottom of the 10th inning tonight to give the Cincinnati Reds a 5-4 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: Florida Sets a Bad Precedent
description: Washington talks endlessly about balancing the budget. Tallahassee and most other state capitals have no choice. By law, they must cover current expenses each year. Florida's solution to a looming $520 million deficit is a sweeping new sales tax on services that has other state treasurers envious and taxpayers furious coast to coast. The revenue problem is real; the solution ill-conceived.

title: FACES QUESTIONING TODAY
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North delivered sets of his personal records to the Congressional investigative committees today, a day before he was to be interrogated for the first time about his central role in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Revolution 1987, Soviet Style
description: Mikhail Gorbachev means to make a new revolution in the Soviet Union. There should be no doubt about that now. Last week he announced plans to partially dismantle central planning and radically reform the subsidized pricing system. These have been at the heart of the Stalinist command economy. If pursued with vigor, these goals will entail a political turning inward, perhaps away from distracting additional challenges to Western interests.

title: HOLTZMAN SUES TO PREVENT JUROR DISCRIMINATION
description: A civil suit intended to prevent defense lawyers from excluding prospective jurors because of their race was filed yesterday by the Brooklyn District Attorney, Elizabeth Holtzman.

title: What's Wrong With the Big Bank Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: LOOKING FOR PLANET X: OLD CLUES, NEW THEORY
description: The two Pioneer spacecraft traveling far beyond the known planets have failed to find any evidence to support speculation that a 10th planet is out there somewhere, but that does not necessarily settle the matter, a space scientist reported yesterday.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Derrick Fenner of North Carolina, the leading rusher in the Atlantic Coast Conference last season, has been indicted by a grand jury in Prince George's County, Md., on murder and other charges connected to a killing May 23 believed to be part of a drug-sale conflict. . . . Tom Shupe, associate athletic director at West Virginia the last five years, will be named athletic director at Wichita State today. He succeeds Lew Perkins, who resigned in May to become athletic director at Maryland.

title: Pepsico's Bottled Water Advertising
description: REMEMBER in ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs'' how the little birdies help the heroine get ready for her day? One of them even fluttered about carrying a ribbon for her hair?

title: Technologies Gets Bids on Essex Unit
description: The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that it was evaluating offers for some of the operations of its Essex International Inc. subsidiary.

title: Rio Bus Fare Increase Is Revoked After Riot
description: Tens of thousands of people protesting an increase in bus fares rioted in downtown Rio today, battling police, looting stores and setting buses afire before the Government rescinded the increase late tonight.

title: Panama's Legislature Votes To End State of Emergency
description: Panama ended a 19-day state of emergency today and restored full constitutional freedoms.

title: 'WE MUST TRY TO FORESTALL POVERTY'
description: Following are excerpts from the conclusion of the report by the Commission on the Year 2000, which was appointed by Mayor Koch to study New York City's future:

title: MONTANA AIRCRAFT CRASHES IN CANYON
description: A small plane crashed in a canyon today while searching for another plane that went down Sunday with a Dallas bank president and three other Texans aboard, a state aviation official said.

title: BLACKS' SUIT AGAINST U.S. ON VOTING RESTORED
description: A Federal appeals court today reinstated a lawsuit that accused the Justice Department of conducting vote fraud investigations in order to discourage poor Alabama blacks from voting.

title: Kentucky Bonds Sold to Sallie Mae
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, reported yesterday that it had bought $41.4 million of taxable secured limited-obligations bonds from the Kentucky State Property and Building Commission.

title: WHITE HOUSE FLOATS A DOZEN NAMES FOR HIGH COURT
description: The White House sent top-level officials to Capitol Hill today to float the names of possible Supreme Court nominees before the Democratic and Republican Senate leadership.

title: U.S. SPOKE SOFTLY FOR SEOUL CHANGE
description: Reagan Administration officials today described a process of delicate maneuvering over the last few months to encourage the Seoul Government to accept a range of political initiatives.

title: FLOODWATERS CALLED CAUSE OF BRIDGE COLLAPSE
description: The collapse of a bridge on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in April was caused by floodwaters of the Schoharie Creek that scoured gravel and silt from around the bridge's footings, the former chief engineer of the Thruway Authority told Federal investigators today.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY SOUTH KOREA PRESIDENT
description: Following are excerpts from the speech this morning by President Chun Doo Hwan:

title: Meese Did Not Follow Ethics Law In Blind Investment, Official Says
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d acted outside the law in investing $60,000 with a financial consultant linked to the Wedtech Corporation, the director of the Office of Government Ethics said in a letter released today.

title: 'SIX DAYS PLUS 20 YEARS'
description: ISRAEL, an NBC News report says tonight, isn't really occupying the West Bank of the Jordan River; the West Bank is occupying Israel, and placing that small democracy's moral and political status in doubt. ''It all adds up,'' Tom Brokaw says, ''to an ominous future.'' The report, ''Six Days Plus 20 Years: a Dream Is Dying,'' will be seen tonight on Channel 4 at 10 o'clock.

title: MAN IS KILLED IN MYSTERIOUS EXPLOSION IN VILLAGE
description: A 35-year-old garage mechanic was killed last night in a mysterious explosion and fire in a taxi cab repair shop in Greenwich Village, the police said.

title: OFFER CITED IN 'PHANTOM' CAST DISPUTE
description: Negotiations between the Actors' Equity Association and the producers of ''Phantom of the Opera'' continued yesterday following a meeting of the union's governing council. The council authorized Alan Eisenberg, executive secretary of the union, to offer the producers terms under which Sarah Brightman, a British actress, would be allowed to re-create her role in the musical on Broadway in the fall, according to a source close to the meeting.

title: Pasta Talks Are Extended
description: The Reagan Administration postponed today its July 1 deadline for the European Community to end its subsidy of pasta exported to the United States, according to the office of the United States trade representative.

title: A TENANT HELPS A BURLAR GET IN, THEN STABS HIM
description: A burglar who got halfway into the window of a fourth-floor Queens apartment and then begged the tenant to help him the rest of the way in was arrested yesterday after the tenant stabbed him during a scuffle inside the apartment, the police said.

title: QUALITY FOOD CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 13
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $891,000 for the quarter and 6 months. The 1986 results are presented on a pro-forma basis to reflect a change in capital structure arising from the acquisition of the company in June 1986.

title: Family Ties: Dream House for 2, With the Children Nearby
description: THREE years ago Jean and Clarence Paul Petersen Jr., who had lived in a large house in Larchmont, N.Y., for almost 30 years, started thinking about their retirement. Their children were all married and they felt it was time to make some important changes.

title: MATSUSHITA ELECTRIC INDUSRIAL CO LTD (JAPAN)(N) reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The latest results are for a special 4-month and 11-day fiscal period from Nov. 21, 1986 through March 31, 1987, occasioned by the company's changing its fiscal year, which formerly ended each year on Nov. 20, to March 31, effective this year. Again, the year-ago period ended Nov. 20, 1986. The share earnings represent American Depositary Share (ADS) and each ADS represents 10 shares of common stock. The United States dollar amounts are translated at the rate of U.S. $1.00 equals 146 yen, the approximate rate on the Tokyo Foreign Exchange Market on March 31, 1987.

title: KEAN'S APPEAL AVERTS JERSEY GARBAGE STRIKE
description: A strike by unionized garbage collectors in northern New Jersey was averted early today after negotiators accepted an appeal by Governor Kean to continue contract talks.

title: KEY RATES
SALANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: b-After tax credits of $157,000 for the quarter and $299,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: LAIDLAW INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said the increase in 1987 third quarter and 9-month revenue is largely due to the previously reported acquisition of GSX Corp. in October 1986.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JULY 2, 1987
description: International

title: NATO Is Seeking a New Secretary General
description: Lord Carrington, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, is making plans to retire, and the alliance has begun the search for a new leader, according to Western diplomats.

title: GOLDMAN BAND REJECTS CONTRACT
description: Members of the Goldman Memorial Band voted 42 to 2 yesterday to reject a contract offer by the band's board of directors.

title: U.S. 'Dumping' Charged
description: The United States is among half a dozen countries accused by the synthetic fiber industry of ''dumping'' polyester on the European market at cut-rate prices, the European Community said today. The community's executive commission said it is investigating charges that American companies - together with those of Mexico, Taiwan, Rumania, Turkey and Yugoslavia - are selling synthetic fibers in Europe below production costs. The complaint, filed by an association of fiber producers, contended that imports from the six countries had risen from 17,400 tons in 1983 to 56,145 in 1986, and now represent nearly 15 percent of the European market.

title: Becor Might Get A Higher Offer
description: Bear, Stearns & Company said that it was studying whether to sweeten its $250 million bid for Becor Western Inc. The New York investment firm's $15-a-share offer, made with the Chicago-based ICM Industries, was topped last week by the Lynch Corporation, which offered Becor shareholders $16.50 a share in cash, or bonds and stock with a face value of $27.25 in the new corporation.

title: Conferees Agree on a Banking Bill
description: House and Senate conferees today agreed on a bill that will inject $8.5 billion into the depleted thrift deposit insurance fund, ban the hybrid banking institution known as the limited-service bank, and place a nine-month moratorium on banks' engaging in new areas of securities underwriting.

title: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Sharon Steel Loans
description: The Sharon Steel Corporation, operating under bankruptcy court protection, has won a fourth extension of a deadline for arranging private loans to accompany a $5.2 million Federal grant. An official for the Mellon Bank, meanwhile, said the bank would lend money to the troubled steelmaker provided its claim for repayment can be secured against the company's current assets, such as inventory, working capital or money owed by customers. United States Representative Thomas J. Ridge, a Pennsylvania Republican, said the Department of Housing and Urban Development had notified him that it would grant one last extension of the financing deadline, until July 15, two weeks shy of the date Mr. Ridge had sought.

title: BUSY LAW FIRMS' PROFITS LEAP
description: Many of the nation's leading law firms have had their most profitable year ever, fueled by a wave of corporate restructurings, the reaction of businesses to the new tax law and a jump in litigation.

title: CBS RENEWS 'WEST 57TH' FOR AUTUMN
description: ''West 57th,'' the CBS News magazine program that has had varying slots on the CBS schedule for more than two years, has been given an unconditional renewal for the fall season.

title: PACT FOR LAFONTAINE
description: The Islanders re-signed Pat LaFontaine and Gerald Diduck to multiyear contracts just before they would have become free agents. The Islanders maintained their policy of not disclosing details of the contracts.

title: ROSE CHANGES PLANS
description: Contrary to statements he had made in Los Angeles last weekend, Pete Rose, the manager of the Reds, said in Cincinnati Tuesday he did not know when he would start taking batting practice. Rose said Sunday he had planned to start taking batting practice this week, probably Tuesday, to get ready in case he would return to the roster.

title: Old New York, Re-created
description: WHEN Mark Bachman, left, a 34-year-old scenic artist for film and television, moved from Bakersfield, Calif., to New York City in 1982, he was awed by the street signs. ''They have mythic proportions,'' he said. ''When I see the Wall Street sign, I think about the stock market crash in 1929.''

title: Advertising; Avrett, Free Adds Renu Lens Cleanser
description: Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, already the agency for Bausch & Lomb contact lenses, has now been named to handle Renu, an enzymatic cleanser that removes protein from soft contact lenses.

title: PERJURY CHARGES DENIED AS AMERUSO TRIAL OPENS
description: A former New York City Transportation Commissioner, Anthony R. Ameruso, may have given ''technically incorrect'' answers to a commission investigating municipal corruption, but he did not commit perjury, his attorney told a judge yesterday.

title: New Chairman At Law Firm
description: John E. Merow became chairman of Sullivan & Cromwell yesterday, during one of the most tumultuous periods in the blue-chip law firm's 108-year-history.

title: KANSANS TAKE DRINK THEY BELIEVE SIGNALS AN ECONOMIC BOOM
description: Around this long-dry state today, Kansans with cocktail glasses uplifted were exorcising the ghost of Carry Nation, the fire-breathing temperance leader who put her stamp on the state's conscience and the slash of her ax on many a saloon.

title: Bridge: Death of Popular Competitor Leaves Vacancy in Title Play
description: One of the most successful and popular American women in bridge, Evelyn Levitt, died last week at the age of 67 when a lifelong goal was on her horizon.

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Dollar Up in Quiet Day While Gold Declines
description: By The Associated Press

title: REAGAN CITES HIS 'RESTRAINT'; CONFIRMATION FIGHT LOOMS
description: President Reagan announced today that he would nominate Judge Robert H. Bork to the United States Supreme Court, setting the stage for a bitter battle in the Senate over his confirmation.

title: NEW GUGGENHEIM PLAN DEBATED AT CITY HEARING
description: Critics and proponents of a revised expansion plan for the Guggenheim Museum debated Tuesday night whether the new scheme had gone far enough to limit its esthetic impact upon the distinctive spiral rotunda of the museum designed by Frank Lloyd Wright.

title: LIMITED BANKS' GIANT HURDLE
description: For a part of the financial services industry with only a tiny fraction of the nation's deposits, ''non-bank banks'' have certainly created a ruckus.

title: Crew Cuts Engines in Error, Sending Jetliner Toward Sea
description: A Delta Air Lines jet carrying 205 people plunged to within 600 feet of the Pacific Ocean on Tuesday, and the crew told investigators today that they had inadvertently shut down both engines.

title: SOUTHERN CO reports earnings for 12mo May 31
Genetics Gets Protein Patent
description: Genetics Institute Inc., a biotechnology company based in Cambridge, Mass., said yesterday that it had received a patent on a pure form of erythropoietin, or EPO, a naturally occurring protein that analysts say could become one of the largest-selling drugs produced by genetic engineering. The announcement sent

title: Advertising; Church's Fried Chicken Moves to Bloom
description: Church's Fried Chicken of San Antonio is taking its advertising account to the Bloom Agency in Dallas. The ad budget is $12 million, according to Robert H. Bloom, chairman of the parent Bloom Companies.

title: NIGERIA LEADER DETAILS PLAN FOR RETURN OF CIVILIAN RULE
description: President Ibrahim Babangida announced a political plan today to guide Nigeria from military rule to civilian democracy by 1992.

title: A MULTIFACETED CONSERVATIVE: ROBERT HERON BORK
description: Judge Robert H. Bork is a multifaceted man with a powerful and restless intellect. He is a committed conservative who has accused the Supreme Court of usurping the powers of elected officials in dozens of decisions, including those Court decisions that protect abortion rights.

title: New Philips Chip
description: Philips N.V. said it had made its first one-megabit semiconductor, a submicron SRAM, or static random access memory, chip. The development came as part of a $1 billion joint project with Siemens A.G. of West Germany. Aanalysts said that major American and Japanese companies were still likely to sell their chips first and dominate the market. But Philips asserted it would be among the first companies to produce the chips.

title: YANKS POLISH OFF JAYS IN 12TH, 6-1
description: The Yankees did not talk about a sweep when they arrived, but late today - after they had taken three straight from the Toronto Blue Jays and moved in front by three games in the American League East - they allowed themselves a small luxury.

title: 3COM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
NORTH QUESTIONED ON CONTRA AFFAIR
description: After seven months of silence, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North appeared before Congressional investigators today, for the first time, for questioning about his dealings with Iran and the contras in Nicaragua.

title: Whither Mrs. Dole?
description: Elizabeth Hanford Dole says she is not walking a delicate line.

title: Before You Buy That Old Table . . .
description: LEAD: AS summer deepens and flea markets and yard sales proliferate, here are a few words of advice for people who are looking for bargains in furniture.

title: IN THE NATIONTom Wicker; Judging Robert Bork
description: Hundreds of people in an audience at Chautauqua, N.Y., laughed out loud when Attorney General Meese told them President Reagan would apply no ideological test in choosing a replacement for Justice Lewis Powell of the Supreme Court.

title: Mack Debt Marks A Shearson First
description: Mack Trucks Inc. is offering $215.1 million of debt securities, backed by its loans on heavy and light trucks, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: THE 'FUSS' OVER MCGWIRE
description: When the switchboard operator at the Westin Hotel in Chicago was asked to put through a phone call to Mark McGwire's room at noon yesterday, she said, ''He has a 'Do Not Disturb' sign on.'' That's understandable. But for the Oakland Athletics' rookie with 28 home runs, the search for peace and privacy has only begun.

title: Judge Backs Pay Law Benefiting Lawmakers
description: A Federal district judge has upheld a law under which Congress was given a $12,100 salary increase this year despite opposition from both the House and Senate.

title: THE EXILE RETURNS, EMBODYING THE AGONY OF '73
description: In the Chile of 1987, Carmen Castillo seems to have come directly from another time. But she carries with her, in her blood and her loves, much of the country's anguished modern history.

title: KNICK WHO SERVES AND WAITS
description: On the fourth floor of Madison Square Garden, in the office where Brendan Malone has gone about his work, the board with the names of the highest choices in the recent National Basketball Association draft has been folded back into the wall.

title: SENATORS' REMARKS PORTEND A BITTER DEBATE OVER BORK
description: A bitter and largely partisan battle over the confirmation of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court appeared virtually certain today as key Democratic senators predicted a long fight with an uncertain outcome.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An Albany dispatch in some copies on Tuesday misstated the crimes covered in a bill proposed by New York's District Attorney Association. The bill would cover all bias-related assaults, not just racially motivated ones.

title: FORD CUTS ACCOUNTS AT JWT
description: The JWT Group, which is being acquired by Britain's WPP Group, is losing some of its assignments from the Ford Motor Company, its largest client. Ford had said it would restudy its agency relationships if JWT's management changed.

title: TRANZONIC COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Why U.S. Seafaring Fades Into Memory
description: To the Editor:

title: Financial Corp. Sees Big Loss
