description: The Financial Corporation of America said today that it expects a second-quarter loss of $150 million to $200 million, underscoring the severity and persistence of the problems plaguing the parent of the nation's largest savings and loan institution.

title: WHEN BRITISH PUSH COMES TO BROADWAY SHOVE
description: NOW that the dust is beginning to settle on the great ''Phantom of the Opera'' controversy pitting Actors' Equity against the English performer Sarah Brightman, one can't be blamed for asking what all the shouting was about. Several things were at stake, but ''Phantom of the Opera'' and Sarah Brightman, the nominal pawns in the struggle, were not particularly crucial among them.

title: EQUITY SETS TERMS FOR LETTING BRITON STAR IN 'PHANTOM'
description: The governing council of the Actors' Equity Association has given the producers of ''Phantom of the Opera'' a set of conditions under which it will allow Sarah Brightman, a British actress, to re-create her leading role in the musical on Broadway in the fall.

title: Cooper Shifts Management
description: The Cooper Companies, formerly Coopervision Inc., said today that Peter Riepenhausen, vice chairman, had been named chairman of the company's group that handles surgical products.

title: GENESEE BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
NELLIE OBENDORF
description: Nellie Obendorf, who along with her husband, Orville, survived almost two weeks in a Kansas snowdrift last April, died Saturday in a nursing home. She was 65 years old.

title: TWO BRONX SCHOOLS: STUDY IN INEQUALITY
description: At Public School 24 in the middle-class neighborhood of Riverdale in the Bronx, computers and special programs abound. The principal, David Rothstein, speaks enthusiastically of his teaching staff.

title: Kenya Reports Elephant Kill
description: Tanzanian poachers have killed at least 15 elephants in southwest Kenya in two months, the Government said today. The poachers were reported to be mainly members of a tribe in northern Tanzania operating in and around Kenya's Masai Mara national park. Many are said to be former soldiers in the Tanzanian Army and, it was asserted, are also involved in cattle rustling.

title: Governor Used His Popularity to Get Legislative Accord on Code of Ethics
description: With an agreement on a new government code of ethics, Governor Cuomo has scored perhaps the biggest victory of his term in office. He took on the Legislature as he never had before, not just rejecting a code he considered weak but, in effect, shaming lawmakers into accepting one that was much stronger.

title: 7 IN CONNECTICUT VYING FOR A SEAT IN CONGRESS
description: After 17 years of comfortably electing the same Congressman, the affluent Fourth Congressional District along Long Island Sound is facing a fractious contest in the heat of summer to choose a successor to Stewart B. McKinney.

title: NOVELIST'S PATH TO 'CROOKED HEARTS'
description: The Warren family that lived in the mind of Robert Boswell - and now lives in the minds of those who have read his first novel, ''Crooked Hearts'' - is a strange but compelling one.

title: Plan to End Partnerships' Tax Break Is Opposed
description: A Treasury proposal announced this week to end a special tax break for corporations that set themselves as up as master limited partnerships and sell their shares on stock exchanges met predictable resistance today from representatives of Wall Street and the partnerships.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Kevin Williams of the Seattle SuperSonics was fined $400 and placed on a year's probation, and charges against his teammate Dale Ellis were dropped yesterday in connection with a nightclub altercation last May in Houston. If Williams completes the terms of his probation, his record will be cleared. . . . Gene Banks, a forward for the Chicago Bulls, underwent surgery to repair a ruptured Achilles' tendon and could miss next season. . . . Earnie Shavers, a 42-year-old heavyweight who is attempting a comeback, said he planned to fight five more bouts before facing a top 10 contender in the World Boxing Council, World Boxing Association or International Boxing Federation rankings. ''I need at least another eight weeks of training to get my timing back,'' Shavers said after a three-round exhibition against Art Card, 26, in Akron, Ohio, Tuesday night.

title: No Retirement For IDS Head
description: Robert F. Froehlke started his retirement job yesterday -as president and chief executive of the $17 billion IDS Mutual Fund Group, a unit of the American Express Company.

title: SCS-COMPUTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FIGHTING APARTHEID DESPITE THE COST
description: This tiny nation, a former Portuguese colony made up of 10 volcanic islands scattered off the west coast of Africa, has hardly any trees, precious little fresh water and, so far as Government officials know, just two dentists in its entire population.

title: Day-Care Center For Sick Children
description: As a neonatal intensive-care nurse, Lisa Schwartz frequently saw the problem: parents of chronically ill youngsters could not find a day-care center for them.

title: PUBLIC FINANCING FOR CAMPAIGNS IN NEW YORK CITY ADVANCES
description: State leaders said they had agreed today on the need for legislation to provide public financing for candidates for top New York City offices.

title: IN NICARAGUA: WHAT TO DO TO THE POTATO
description: Several thousand Nicaraguans spent part of Saturday doing something that Nicaraguans don't often do. They ate potatoes.

title: Walter O. Heinze, 83; Former STP Chairman
description: Walter O. Heinze, former president of the International Latex Corporation and past chairman of the board of the STP Corporation, died of cancer Monday at his home in Green Valley, Ariz. He was 83 years old. Mr. Heinze was chairman of the board of Control Fluidics Inc., a research and development company and industrial-filter company, at the time of his death.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Bank Ltd., elected Dr. Heinz D. Zimmer director and vice chairman for global private banking.

title: Vocational Training Course for Gardeners
description: For many people, gardening is a labor of love, and for those who want to make it a full-time vocation instead of a part-time avocation, Longwood Gardens in Kennett Square, Pa., offers a two-year course.

title: Tony Webster Is Dead at 65; An Award-Winning TV Writer
description: Anthony (Tony) Webster, an Emmy-winning television writer for the ''Sid Caesar Show,'' ''Your Show of Shows,'' ''The Phil Silvers Show,'' ''Bob and Ray'' and more recently, ''Love Boat,'' died of cancer of the esophagus Saturday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 65 years old.

title: KEMP PROPOSES WIDE AIDS TESTS AND MONITORING
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp today offered a detailed policy for dealing with AIDS.

title: BROKEN HILL PROPRIETARY CO LTD reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $41,000,000 and $24,700,000 for the latest year and year-earlier period, respectively. Results are in Australian dollars.

title: South Korea Knows of Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Spotlight on Congress's Cemetery
description: On Friday, the local chapters of 20 patriotic organizations will gather at one of Washington's more obscure historical sites for what might be described as a family affair.

title: CHRYSLER ACTS IN FALSE MILEAGE CASE
description: Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, said today that the company had acted in a way that was ''dumb'' and ''unforgivable'' by selling cars that had been driven while their odometers were disconnected.

title: TOUGH STUFF
description: It has nothing to do with dollar signs, yet its mandatory use is called for in Herschel Walker's contract, Joe Montana would not consider a return to the football field without it and Dave Poulin of the Philadelphia Flyers needed a lot of it leading his team into the Stanley Cup finals against Edmonton.

title: THE 2 KIMS: CAN THEY KEEP A UNITED FRONT?
description: Through more than two weeks of street protests, strategy for anti-Government forces seemed to be directed largely by dissident clergymen and campus militants.

title: TUCKER SEEKS TO CUT MANAGER FROM PACT AND PURSE
description: Tony Tucker, the International Boxing Federation heavyweight champion, has taken one of his three managers, Alan Kornberg, to arbitration.

title: CLINTON IS POSED TO ENDER '88 RACE
description: Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who has been pondering a race for the Democratic Presidential nomination for months, is close to entering the crowded field, political associates said today.

title: BALLET: BOLSHOI IN GRIGOROVICH'S 'GOLDEN AGE'
description: WHAT is it about the Bolshoi Ballet that makes it easy to extol its virtues - to forgive its sins, in other words? Very likely, the answer lies in this historic Moscow company's unsurpassed gift of communicating with its audience.

title: Ex-Senator Scott's Wife Dies
description: Marian Scott, wife of Hugh Scott Jr., a former Senate Republican leader, died Tuesday of complications from a cerebral hemorrhage, officials said today. She was 87 years old. Mrs. Scott was admitted to Georgetown University Hospital about six weeks ago. Mr. Scott, 86, a Pennsylvnian who led his party in the Senate from 1969 to 1977, remained in stable condition at Bethesda Naval Hospital, where he was admitted Sunday after suffering a stroke.

title: OPPENHEIMER & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Tin Ceilings Prized For Style and Utility
description: ACCORDING to Mark Quitno, vice president of the W. F. Norman Corporation, tin ceilings were developed in the 1860's to cover up deteriorating plaster ceilings. Because they were practical, decorative and easy to ship, install and maintain, tin ceilings rapidly became popular.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
Judge Bork, the Senate and Politics
description: There's no getting politics out of a nomination to the Supreme Court. Political justice and a politicized judiciary are to be avoided, but picking a justice is a political act. That's why President Reagan's nomination of Judge Robert Bork will test the Senate. It has not only a right but a duty to scrutinize Judge Bork's philosophy every bit as carefully as his credentials.

title: Price of Milk: The Changes Hit Close to Home
description: Most New York City consumers don't know a Guernsey from a Holstein (to say nothing of a Jersey) but they have probably figured out by now that something has been happening to the price of milk (thanks to a New Jersey dairy).

title: PRESIDENTS FUMBLE ATHLETIC REFORM BID
description: The subject was sports, the agenda was money, but the reality was politics. That, in short, was how many participants saw the special convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association that ended here Tuesday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: On the Bounding Main

title: Calendar: Summer Classes and Crafts
description: Summer Classes, New York Botanical Garden, Mosholu Parkway at Southern Boulevard, Bronx; 212-220-8747.

title: DEMOCRATS HOLD PRESIDENTIAL DEBATE
description: The seven Democratic candidates for President sparred gently here tonight in the first major debate of the 1988 campaign. They fired salvo after salvo at President Reagan, but hardly a shot at each other.

title: 3 Freed Whales Are Reported To Have Traveled 51 Miles
description: The three pilot whales that were released at sea Monday have traveled 51 miles to the southeast, the New England Aquarium reported today.

title: PETTIBONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $500,000 from disposal of discontinued operations for both periods and an extraordinary loss of $248,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $1,404,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $8,843,000 and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $3,267,000. d-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $15,868,000 and a loss from disposal of discontinued operations of $29,138,000. Revenue represents net shipments.

title: 5 Guilty in Fraud Involving Self-Chilling Can
description: Five people were convicted on conspiracy charges today in a stock fraud involving a bogus company that said it had created a self-chilling beverage can. The authorities said investors had been bilked of about $2.4 million.

title: Q & A
description: Q. During the last water shortage I was a good citizen and did not flush the toilet after every use. But the bowl is now yellow and I cannot get it clean, even with vinegar or bleach. What can you suggest? A. The discoloration should come out with bleach or a good detergent, or a combination of the two. A product that usually works well is Zud; it is sold in many supermarkets and in plumbing supply outlets.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JULY 2, 1987
description: International A2-13

title: Vacationing by Car, Children in Tow; Keeping Sibling Revelry in Check
description: HERE are some hints from parents and children that might help families survive an almost interminable automobile trip:

title: NEWARK'S MAYOR TELLS RACE AND ETHNIC JOKE
description: Sharpe James, who yesterday completed his first year as Mayor of Newark, New Jersey's most populous city, found himself defending an off-the-cuff joke he made that had racist and ethnic overtones.

title: STAGE: 'I.D.,' COMEDY ABOUT IDENTITY
description: BILLED as a comedy, ''I.D.,'' by Gayden Wren, at the American Theater for Actors, is actually a series of sometimes related skits. A few are funny - a robot programmed to think like a man and a man hypnotized into thinking he's a robot debate about whether to turn off the power to find out which is the real robot; two women on a stalled elevator discover they are the same person; three plants wonder whether the enormous creature sprinkling water on them is intelligent enough to be communicated with.

title: HAITI LEADER MEETS WITH ELECTORAL PANEL ON CRISIS
description: Haiti remained in the grip of a political crisis today, but the drama shifted from the streets to a series of meetings as some civilian leaders began to call for the ouster of the military Government.

title: Markets Shut Tomorrow
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be closed tomorrow in observance of the Fourth of July holiday. Government offices will also be closed. Banks and many businesses will be open.

title: Shearson Seeks Inflation Hedge
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers is seeking to make a significant investment in an oil company or other energy concern as a hedge against an expected rise in energy prices and inflation, the brokerage firm's chairman, Peter A. Cohen, said.

title: Actors' Fund Benefit Will Aid Needy Artists
description: The Actors' Fund of America announced Tuesday that it would hold a gala benefit in Washington on Oct. 5 to restore money to its fund for helping people from the theatrical community in financial distress.

title: Occidental Sale
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said it had completed the previously announced sale of all of the stock of the United Gas Pipe Line Company and UER Marketing to the Lasalle Energy Corporation of Dallas for $482 million, plus two subordinated notes totaling $138 million. The operations sold were units of Occidental's Midcon subsidiary.

title: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 20
JUDGE WARNS YONKERS OF BIG FINES IF HOUSING INTEGRATION IS DELAYED
description: A Federal judge threatened yesterday to hold the city of Yonkers in contempt and to impose severe daily fines if it failed to submit a housing integration plan by mid-July.

title: WARD DISCLOSES A SECRET INQUIRY ON BLACK GROUP
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward, in a highly unusual move, revealed yesterday that the New York City Police Department's intelligence division was conducting an undercover investigation of a group of self-proclaimed black revolutionaries he called the ''New York Eight.''

title: Talkng Deals; Small Buyouts Are Booming
description: ON Wall Street, when the term leveraged buyout is bandied about, thoughts generally turn to such celebrated deals as the multibillion-dollar buyout of the Beatrice Companies or former Treasury Secretary William E. Simon's spectacular showing with Gibson Greetings Inc.

title: Yields Flat Or Up a Bit
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were flat or slightly higher for the week ended yesterday as they continue to move along the plateau they reached on June 17.

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
JORDAN LANDS ON THE FAIRWAY
description: Michael Jordan, who evokes oohs and aahs for spectacular airborne manuevers on a basketball court, drew similar reactions last week at a totally different sports venue - a golf course.

title: 2 Allied Units May Expand
description: Robert Campeau, whose Campeau Corporation acquired the Allied Stores Corporation in December, said he was considering expanding Allied's Brooks Brothers and Ann Taylor units to Europe and Canada.

title: CONAGRA INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect the acquisition of E.J. Miller Enterprises Inc. in January and Monfort of Colorado Inc. in May. The company said fiscal 1987 results include a first quarter after-tax provision of about $5 million for Frozen Food plant consolidation during the fiscal year. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 split of Conagra's stock effective Dec. 1, 1986.

title: Reactors' Foes Gain a Key Ally
description: Opponents of nuclear power plants in Shoreham, L.I., and Seabrook, N.H., have won the backing of a key Congressional leader for legislation that would effectively block operating licenses for the reactors.

title: National Aluminum
description: The National Aluminum Corporation announced price increases today ranging from 6 percent to 8 percent, following similar moves by other major producers. The company, a subsidiary of Pittsburgh-based National Intergroup Inc., said the changes are effective with orders received next Monday. The percentage increases will raise prices by 7 cents a pound for extrusions and 6 cents a pound for foil and common sheet.

title: CSX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest 6-month revenue reflects the inclusion of Sea-land, which was aquired May 31, 1986; the year-ago 6-month revenue only included Sea- land for one month.

title: Future of Mansions Concerns Newport
description: The sound of saws slicing mansions into condominiums breaks the golden stillness these days on Bellevue Avenue, the seaside street known as Millionaires' Row. The two-mile boulevard of opulent homes is shaded by beeches, oaks, chestnuts and black walnuts. But as developers turn some of these vast homes into apartments, another kind of shadow is being cast over the neighborhood and surrounding community of 35,000 people.

title: U.S. GESTURE TO SYRIA LINKED TO MOVE AGAINST ABU NIDAL
description: President Reagan's decision to send a special envoy to Damascus to explore improvement of relations was a response to Syria's closing of offices of the Abu Nidal Palestinian terrorist group, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Saudis Linked to Donations to Angola Rebels
description: A California business executive told a Congressional subcommittee today that the Saudi royal family provided millions of dollars to anti-Government rebels in Angola and told him it was at the behest of William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence.

title: Myriad Species In Fertile Pots Fill a Terrace
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago Monroe Pinckard found a cast-stone planter on the sidewalk near his new East Side apartment and thought it would make a fine container to put on his empty 18th-floor terrace. That planter is still around - somewhere - buried in the leafy tangle of several hundred species that now fill almost every inch of his sunny 10-by-50-foot terrace.

title: TOSHIBA WARNS ON JOBS IN U.S.
description: A ban on imports of Toshiba Corporation products by the United States would cut off more than $1 billion worth of equipment and could lead to layoffs of Toshiba employees in the United States, the head of Toshiba's American operations said today.

title: SCHEIB, EARL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Falls 8.77; Volume Is Moderate
description: The stock market continued to lose ground yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.77 points, to 2,409.76. On Tuesday the average fell 28.38 points.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Fire and Water; Bucks and Bangs
description: ''Wall-to-wall bang bang'' is a phrase television producers use to describe action-packed news footage from combat zones. It would also aptly describe New York's firecracker season.

title: CAMPBELL HONOR
description: The Houston Oilers said today they will retire jersey No. 34 worn by their former running back, Earl Campbell, on Aug. 13 at the Astrodome. Campbell led the Oilers in rushing in each of his first six seasons before he was traded to New Orleans Oct. 9, 1984. Campbell, 32 years old, retired last August, with 9,407 rushing yards.

title: British Insider Fined $40,000
description: Geoffrey Collier, the former head of securities at the British investment bank Morgan Grenfell & Company, was given a suspended one-year prison sentence and fined $:25,000, or about $40,000, today after pleading guilty to two insider-trading charges.

title: Everyone Under Oath?
description: Representative Paul E. Kanjorski, Democrat of Pennsylvania, was offended by admissions by Assistant Secretary of State Elliott Abrams that he had misled Congress about secret operations to aid the Nicaraguan rebels. And so the Congressman is preparing a bill that would require all House testimony to be sworn, abolishing the discretion that committees now have on whether to require withnesses to testify under oath.

title: A Computer Doesn't Need a New Tennis House
description: To the Editor:

title: Honda Exports To Japan Set
description: Honda of America said today that by early next year it would export its powerful Gold Wing motorcycles to Japan. The company said it was the first time a Japanese vehicle manufacturer would build models in America for its home market.

title: OFFICIAL SCORN FOR IMPORT BAN
description: The State Department said today that import penalties voted by the Senate against Japanese and Norwegian companies that sold sensitive technology to the Soviet Union were ''counterproductive'' and ''contrary to the spirit and practice'' of export control agreements.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DON'T TREAD ON ME: The Selected Letters of S. J. Perelman. Edited by Prudence Crowther. Illustrated. 372 pages.

title: U.S. GRANTS UPSTATE A-PLANT A LICENSE TO RUN AT FULL POWER
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted 4 to 0 today to grant a full-power operating license to a nuclear reactor in upstate New York that took 14 years to complete and is the most costly in the industry's history.

title: 3 Sentenced in Boston In I.R.A. Gun-Running
description: Three Massachusetts men who admitted smuggling seven tons of weapons and ammunition for the Irish Republican Army were sentenced to up to 10 years in prison today, and two were also sentenced for smuggling marijuana into the United States.

title: Reichhold Rejects Offer by Dainippon
description: Reichhold Chemicals Inc. yesterday rejected a $473 million hostile takeover bid from Dainippon Ink and Chemicals Inc. and said that it would explore other possible offers for the company.

title: Greenspan's Main Task
description: It has been suggested that the incoming Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, should continue the policies of his predecessor, Paul A. Volcker. But more of the same is not the answer to today's problems. Mr. Greenspan's main task is not to fight inflation but to restore a credible policy of growth so that the world can safely deal with the large-scale debt problems that the collapse of inflation left in its wake.

title: Kemp Draws Fire
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp, the upstate New Yorker who is a Republican Presidential aspirant, is drawing fire from his colleagues over a proposal to close the New York and Washington offices of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: The U.S. Treasury vs. the Antilles
description: Few Americans know that the Netherlands Antilles is a conduit for billions in loans from Europeans. Thus few Americans noticed this week when the U.S. Treasury terminated a tax treaty with the tiny Caribbean state and triggered panic selling in the $600 billion Eurobond market. The Treasury Department was right to crack down on the Antilles' collusion with U.S. tax cheats. But it was wrong to do so by breaking faith with foreign investors. Unless this heavyhanded action is redressed by the Treasury or Congress, it could sharply raise borrowing costs for American corporations.

title: Brooklyn's Stoops Are Ringside Seats On Urban Drama
description: LEAD: STOOP-SITTING. It's a strange sight for a lot of people who live outside Brooklyn, which considers itself the world capital of this century-old tradition.

title: Sprint Operators
description: The U S Sprint Communications Company said that it plans to offer 24-hour long-distance operator service to compete with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. U S Sprint said that its operators would provide a complete range of services including collect calls, person-to-person calls and call completion assistance, but at a discount. Analysts said the move makes U S Sprint more attractive to business and residential customers. U S Sprint, the nation's third-largest long-distance company, recently introduced ''800'' number service and private-line networks.

title: Democrats Fail in Senate Bid To Delay U.S. Escorts in Gulf
description: Senate Democrats tried to win support today for a resolution seeking a delay in President Reagan's Persian Gulf escort plans, but Republicans successfully blocked the attempt.

title: PARKE CUMMINGS
description: Parke Cummings, a humorist and author of books on sports, died yesterday at his home in Westport, Conn., after a heart attack. He was 84 years old.

title: FUGITIVE GUNMAN HELD IN A BROOKLYN SHOOTING
description: A man the police called a ''known terrorist'' who is wanted in connection with at least seven murders was captured late Tuesday by officers who chased him into a Brooklyn alley after a shooting, the police said.

title: Job Safety Shift in California
description: Safety enforcement at 600,000 California job sites shifted from the state to the Federal Government today in a move that critics say will make the workplace more dangerous for up to 14 million workers.

title: New York's Hard Climb Ahead
description: ''New York Ascendant'' - that is the optimistic title for the report of the Commission on the Year 2000, chaired by Robert F. Wagner Jr. The text makes clear that the ascent will be more like a mountain climber with a heavy pack than the carefree flight of a balloon.

title: Trinova-Tenby Link
description: The Trinova Corporation said today that its Sterling Engineered Products subsidiary had acquired the Fraser & Glass division of Tenby Industries P.L.C. of Britain. The price was not disclosed. Fraser & Glass produces injection molded plastic parts for the European automotive industry, particularly in Britain. Its customers include Austin Rover, Jaguar, Ford, Nissan and Honda, for which it makes such products as bumpers, wheel trim and under-the-hood plastic parts. Fraser & Glass is based in Brierley Hill, England.

title: Downey's Quiz
description: Representative Thomas J. Downey is convinced that most people talk a great deal about welfare but really don't know too much about it.

title: REPLIGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring charge of $17,261,000 for the quarter and year to account for the acquisition of technologies from Centocor Inc.; the year also includes an additional $500,000 charge from the early extinguishment of debt with a former officer.

title: 2 PARTIES IN KOREA BEGIN CAMPAIGNING FOR FUTURE POWER
description: The ruling and opposition parties began their separate campaigns today for future power, on a day when both sides spoke of a South Korean ''political miracle.''

title: BUILDING SPENDING RISES 0.3%
description: Construction spending rose a slight three-tenths of 1 percent in May as declines in government spending and residential construction dampened building activity, the Commerce Department said today.

title: America Needs A Literacy Corps
description: America prides itself on being an ''advanced'' nation, but its level of illiteracy mocks the term. At international gatherings, President Reagan, in common with most 20th century American Presidents, represents the country with the poorest literacy record of all the industrialized nations.

title: Judge Upholds Rowe's Fees
description: In a case that has been closely watched by the money market industry, a Federal judge in New York ruled yesterday that T. Rowe Price Associates Inc. did not charge excessive fees for managing the Rowe Price Prime Reserve Fund, a multibillion-dollar money market fund. In a 70-page opinion, Federal

title: TOUR DE FRANCE
description: They're Off: Jelle Nijdam of the Netherlands won the right to wear the leader's yellow jersey at the start of the 74th Tour de France by posting the fastest time in the prologue yesterday in West Berlin.

title: 'Crimes' by Israel Are Cited by Barbie's Lawyers
description: Defense lawyers in the trial of Klaus Barbie took the floor today and provoked an angry quarrel in the courtroom when they attacked Israel and other countries for committing ''crimes against humanity'' that, they argued, were ''more serious'' than those of Mr. Barbie himself.

title: Florida ZIP Codes Revised
description: A million Florida homes and businesses were given new ZIP codes today in the United States Postal Service's largest single set of code changes in one state. ''No other state is experiencing similar growing pains,'' said Woodrow Conner, Florida division general manager of the Postal Service. ''Our daily mail volume will double in the next nine years.'' About 2.5 million people were affected by the changes, the Postal Service estimated.

title: RAYCOMM TRANSWORLD reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $446,478 and an extraordinary loss of $930,826 related to the discontinued operations. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $612,397 and a tax credit of $58,821. Last year's figures have been restated to combine the accounts of Racomm Industries and Transworld Services, which were merged into the company on June 4, 1986. Lower revenues also reflect the reporting of revenues of Mainstream Engineering Co., a principal subsidiary, for only 11 months in fiscal 1987, compared with 12 months of such revenues in fiscal 1986.

title: Market Place; How Warrants Of Kidde Look
description: AFTER trading in a relatively narrow range for four years, shares of Kidde Inc. have raced to new highs in recent weeks. This advance stems from reports that the conglomerate will embark upon restructuring moves that would enhance shareholder value.

title: Florida Trustees' Chairman Accused of Buying Degrees
description: The Florida Institute of Technology's board of trustees will investigate a report by the Federal Bureau of Investigation stating that its chairman bought some of his college degrees through the mail, a board spokesman said today.

title: But Should We Trust Those Medical Tests?
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER 50 YEARS, WATERFRONT BOSS QUITS
description: Teddy Gleason, the iron-fisted boss of the New York City waterfront for 50 years, stepped down yesterday. As he bowed out, he declared, ''We got everything we fought for.''

title: Site of Killings to Be Sold
description: The City Council has voted to sell the site of the killing of 21 people in 1984 in a McDonald's restaurant, despite pleas by relatives of the victims that the property be turned into a memorial park. The Council decided Monday to sell the site, now a vacant lot, but to plan a a modest memorial to victims. On July 18, 1984, James Oliver Huberty killed them and wounded 20 other people. He was shot to death by a police marksman.

title: HIGH-TECH BROOKLYN COMPLEX APPROVED
description: Metrotech, a $770 million development of commercial offices and technology research proposed for 17 acres in downtown Brooklyn, was approved yesterday morning at the close of a Board of Estimate meeting that lasted nearly 24 hours.

title: HERS
description: LEAD: A YOUNG woman I know started her first year of college feeling hopeful. The horrors of high school were over. Like others before her, she had an airbrushed picture of college life in general and dormitory life in particular. She had a roommate she liked a lot. She found a boyfriend.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Fire and Water; Drained of Reason
description: Each year New York City's public beaches are declared open on Memorial Day. Why then do the city's public swimming pools stay empty until late June? Department of Parks and Recreation officials offer only leaky reasons.

title: ROYALS BEAT TWINS
description: Jim Eisenreich smashed a pinch-hit double off the center-field wall with one out in the bottom of the ninth inning tonight, scoring Buddy Biancalana from first base and giving the Kansas City Royals a 4-3 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: Bork Irked by Emphasis on His Role in Watergate
description: ''I get a little tired of it being portrayed as the only thing I ever did,'' Judge Robert H. Bork once said about his role at a critical moment in the Watergate scandals, what was widely referred to at the time as the ''Saturday Night Massacre.''

title: SURGEON ASSERTS HIS COMPLAINTS LED TO DISMISSIAL
description: A surgeon at Kings County Hospital Center said yesterday he had been dismissed for insubordination because he refused to perform surgery in an operating room infested with flies.

title: AUDIOVOX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
'BABY BELL' EXPANSIONS ARE VIEWED AS UNLIKELY
description: The seven regional ''Baby Bell'' telephone companies have almost no chance of persuading Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene to allow them to expand vastly by providing long-distance service, and only a slim chance of winning permission to manufacture equipment, lawyers and other telecommuniciations specialists maintain.

title: Allegis Expected To Lay Off 250
description: The Allegis Corporation will soon announce the layoff of about 250 executives in a drive to cut costs, company sources said. The sources also said that some top Allegis executives would be given more responsibility while others would be reassigned. The sources did not give details. The move is part of the new management structure being put in place by Frank A. Olson, who took over as chairman of Allegis after the ouster of Richard J. Ferris. Earlier this year, Mr. Ferris laid off about 1,000 middle managers in an effort to reduce costs.

title: NORMAN OUT IN CANADA GOLF
description: Greg Norman withdrew Monday from the Canadian Open, which begins Thursday at the Glen Abbey Golf Club, and Dan Forsman, who wanted to play, failed to submit his entry in time. Forsman, the winner of the Hertz Bay Hill Classic last year, played very well last week to finish tied for second, a stroke behind Paul Azinger, in the Hartford Open. Norman, who won the 1984

title: 2 LEADERS OF TOSHIBA RESIGN
description: The chairman and the president of the Toshiba Corporation, whose subsidiary has been found guilty of illegal sales of high technology to the Soviet Union, resigned today.

title: Capitalist of the Year
description: LEAD: If Forbes magazine had a Capitalist of the Year, I'd nominate Paul D. Herrlinger. He is the Cincinnati resident with the nervous condition who made what turned out to be a bogus takeover bid for the Dayton Hudson retail company. In so doing, he did much to demonstrate the genius of investment capitalism.

title: HOYT TO JOIN WHITE SOX
description: LaMarr Hoyt has agreed to sign with the Chicago White Sox, the team for which he won the Cy Young Award in 1983, although he is not expected to pitch for them this season.

title: Prices Rise in Mild Session
description: Prices of Treasury issues did an about-face yesterday and rose in mild trading, especially on instruments with shorter maturities.

title: CASH MACHINES IN MINNESOTA DISPENSING WELFARE BENEFITS
description: Some welfare recipients here are receiving monthly benefits through electronic cash-dispensing machines in a six-month experimental program that began Monday.

title: Brazil Freezes Some of Debt
description: Brazil, whose $111 billion foreign debt is the biggest of any developing country, said today it was suspending repayment of $1.05 billion of principal due this year to the Paris Club, a group of Western creditor nations.

title: VICEROY HOMES LTD reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: ISRAEL AND U.S. DISCUSS PLANE
description: Israel's Defense Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, met with Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and Secretary of State George P. Shultz today to discuss what assistance the United States might provide to Israel if the Lavi jet-fighter project is canceled.

title: PUBLISHING: COLORING BOOK PHOTOS
description: The practice of coloring black-and-white motion pictures has its counterpart in the book industry, where black-and-white photographs selected to appear on book jackets are tinted a variety of colors. Sometimes even black-and-white photos within the body of the book are colored, as is the case with a dozen photographs in ''Spanning the Gate'' by Stephen Cassady (Squarebooks Inc.), a history of the building of the Golden Gate Bridge.

title: First Boston, Goldman Get Ohio Facility Bonds
description: Cities and states issuing debt in the municipal market have increasingly sought to narrow the time between the announcement of a bond sale and the auction. These municipal issuers are seeking greater borrowing flexibility, similar to that of corporations, which can come to market when interest rates are attractive - almost at a moment's notice.

title: INSIDE
description: Costly A-Plant Licensed

title: PRAISE AND A SEMIFINAL SPOT FOR CONNORS
description: It really doesn't matter anymore whether Jimmy Connors wins Wimbledon. Whatever happens between now and Sunday evening is not going to detract from the showing he has made here thus far or alter the way this year's tournament will be remembered.

title: Bolshoi's 'Golden Age': At the Met and on A&E
description: While ticket holders are watching the Bolshoi Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House tonight, television viewers - at least those who receive the Arts & Entertainment Network -can watch the same ballet at home.

title: TOP OFFICIAL AND DEATH ROW FEAR TEXAS IS SHRUGGING OFF EXECUTIONS
description: Executions in Texas have become so routine, Attorney General Jim Mattox says, that he fears their deterrent purpose is being lost and that Death Row inmates fear they have been forgotten.

title: CLARK, J L MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
U.S. Studying Firm's Bonds
description: A United States Attorney and the Securities and Exchange Commisson are heading an investigation into $1.6 billion of unusual municipal bond issues underwritten last year by Matthews & Wright, a securities firm based in New York, several legal sources said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article and chart that ran in Business Day on Monday, surveying the performance of international stock markets in the second quarter, carried a series of inaccurate figures.

title: U.S. BERATES PANAMANIAN REGIME IN PRESSING FOR DEMOCRATIC RULE
description: In an effort to bring pressure on Panama's military to allow democratic rule, the Reagan Administration has lashed out in the past 24 hours against the leadership of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: BIG BEAR CO reports earnings for 13wks to May 30
description: Year-ago share earnings were adjusted for a 15 percent stock dividend paid in February.

title: Whim of Limestone: Ozark Cave Is Now a Real-Estate Listing
description: THE cave that John Dillon Hay ''built'' is a bit off the beaten track. You fly into Springfield, Mo., then drive two and a half hours or so south into the lush, remote wilderness of the Ozark Mountains of Arkansas. You go past Dogpatch, U.S.A, the Li'l Abner theme park, continue past the Full Gospel Church (watch for skunks around there), cross the Little Buffalo River, then head up the dirt-and-gravel road six miles or so, and there you are.

title: RUTH BRINTON PERERA
description: Ruth Brinton Perera, a founder of an association to help the wives of Japanese executives and diplomats adapt to life in the United States, died Sunday at the Lehigh Valley Hospital Center in Allentown, Pa., of injuries suffered in an automobile accident. She was 81 years old and lived in Kennett Square, Pa.

title: BAKKER SEEKING AN EXAMINER TO MONITOR PTL BANKRUPTCY
description: Lawyers for Jim Bakker, the former leader of the PTL Ministry, have asked a Federal judge to appoint an independent examiner to observe the new PTL management and its reorganization plans during bankruptcy proceedings.

title: HOUSTON REALLY WANTED BIGGER SHOW
description: This city wanted the Democratic National Convention and ended up with a debate tonight among the party's seven Presidential hopefuls. The organizers of the debate wanted the Republicans and ended up with the Democrats.

title: METS POUR IT ON AFTER RAIN LETS UP
description: The Mets brought their battle with the first-place Cardinals to a wet but rousing close last night when they rallied to beat St. Louis again, 9-6, and took the series, two games to one.

title: SENATE PASSES 1987 SPENDING BILL, PUTTING OFF DECISION ON EMBASSY
description: The Senate approved a $9.4 billion spending bill this evening, and an Administration official said President Reagan was expected to sign it.

title: ROACH, HAL STUDIOS reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a $3,451,646 loss from discontinued operations. c-After net from a minority interest of $1,542.

title: Producers Weigh Offer From Directors Guild
description: Producers considered a last-minute offer from the Directors Guild of America today as union members began a vote that could mean the first strike in the guild's 51-year history.

title: CONCERT: SEOUL BAROQUE ENSEMBLE
description: SEOUL, South Korea, is probably nearer to the German border today than was Vienna or Salzburg in 1750 -so rapid has the exchange of information between peoples become. Thus it was not very surprising for a group such as the Seoul Baroque Chamber Ensemble to pass through Merkin Concert Hall on Monday night and leave behind performances of European masters old and new that were not just imitative of a style but a natural part of it.

title: Peat Marwick Fills Key Post
description: The post of vice chairman for tax, a major position at Peat Marwick, has been filled by David C. Smith, a partner in charge of the tax department in the firm's Houston office, the accounting firm said.

title: 13 to Carry Testimony Of North and Poindexter
description: Channel 13 will carry the entire testimony of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter before the Congressional committee on the Iran-contra arms affair.

title: COMNET CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes minority interest of $331,000, or 13 cents a share. c-Net loss

title: Harriett Johnson, 79, A New York Post Critic
description: Harriett Johnson, music critic of The New York Post for 43 years, died of cancer Friday in La Jolla, Calif. She was 79 years old.

title: The U.N. Today: July 2, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Design for Storm Cellar Is Offered
description: An architect who remembered the root cellars where farm families used to take shelter from storms has designed a tornado-shelter kit for people who live in mobile homes.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: SINCE doorbell wiring systems run on low voltage, any amateur can safely and easily repair them without worrying about getting a dangerous shock or creating a fire hazard.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Judge Bork, widely regarded as the most prominent and intellectually powerful advocate of judicial restraint, shares my view that judges' personal preferences and values should not be part of their Constitutional interpretations.'' - President Reagan. [ A23:1. ]

title: STAGE: 'NEW MEXICAN RAINBOW FISHING'
description: THREE needy people come together one weekend in a fishing cabin in Jerry Stubblefield's ''New Mexican Rainbow Fishing.'' Well stocked with fifths of Jim Beam and cases of Coors, the cabin has been home to Ferlin, a folksy good-for-not-much, for 17 years. ''I never asked for nothin' except to be left alone,'' he says. But loneliness having gotten the best of this loner, he brings a younger man back to join him in fishing at his ''secret stream.'' . Thirty-five-year-old E. J., who is so innocent he sometimes seems to be retarded, has endured his own lonely existence at a men's shelter since Daddy was hanged for wringing Momma's unfaithful neck when E. J. was just a lad.

title: The Ceiling Fan: Updated and Popular
description: ''WE have people coming in here from the eastern end of Long Island who buy 10, 12, 15 fans at a time,'' said Steven Samuels, president of the Ceiling Fan Place in Huntington, L.I. ''They put them in every room of the house.''

title: AART DE JONG
description: Aart de Jong, an art dealer who in recent years helped to bring a new generation of artists to public view, died last Friday when he was struck by a van while riding a bicycle in Greenwich Village. He was 29 years old.

title: POLITICAL PRISONERS STILL A CONTENTIOUS ISSUE IN SEOUL
description: Now that President Chun Doo Hwan has agreed to sweeping democratic changes, Lee Kyong Eun wants her husband back.

title: Jordan Welcomes Waldheim With State Honors for Talks
description: Jordan gave Kurt Waldheim, the Austrian President, a 21-gun salute today when he arrived on his second official visit abroad after more than a year of denying assertions he had a role in deporting Greek Jews to Nazi death camps.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO FIND MINES MOORED IN LANES TO KUWAIT
description: About a dozen moored mines have been found by American specialists in shipping lanes to Kuwait in the last three days, according to Pentagon officials.

title: Vacationing by Car, Children in Tow
description: HERE it is summertime, and those signs of the season -the Mobil Travel Guide on the dashboard and the Ramada Inn Directory somewhere on the floor mats - herald that vast annual migration: the vacation excursion in the family automobile.

title: EVERT AND NAVRATILOVA TO PLAY IT AGAIN
description: There are not many Wimbledons in Chris Evert's future, opportunities to be a part of the two weeks that matter most in tennis. That was why one interested observer thought Evert was going about her task all wrong, wearing a frown for an occasion that demanded her best smile.

title: PAPERS PLAY UP DENG'S IDEAS, SIGNALING CHANGES FOR CHINA
description: A seven-year-old speech by China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, denouncing bureaucracy and ''feudal'' ideas within the Communist Party and calling for a measure of political change appeared on the front pages of newspapers today.

title: SUCCESSFUL LOSERS
description: Of the 15 pitchers who have lost the most major league games, four are active this season. Phil Niekro passed Gaylord Perry in May and is now in fourth place on the career list with 268 losses, only 45 fewer than Cy Young's total of 313. The 10 active pitchers with the most career losses, through Tuesday's games: Pitcher, team W L Phil Niekro, Indians 317 268 Don Sutton, Angels 315 247 Steve Carlton, Indians 328 234 Nolan Ryan, Astros 257 234 Tommy John, Yankees 271 213 Bert Blyleven, Twins 236 203 Joe Niekro, Twins 218 194 Jerry Reuss, Angels 196 163 Rick Reuschel, Pirates 168 159 Frank Tanana, Tigers 166 157

title: RAISED SPEED LIMIT VETOED IN MICHIGAN
description: Gov. James J. Blanchard today vetoed a bill that would have raised the speed limit to 65 miles an hour on rural stretches of interstate highway in Michigan.

title: EDUCATORS URGE TURN TO STUDIES ABOUT RELIGION
description: A panel of educators today called for an end to ''the curricular silence on religion'' that it says has permeated the classroom since the Supreme Court banished officially sanctioned prayer in public schools a quarter-century ago.

title: NATO Endures
description: To the Editor:

title: Rail Concern Is Blamed For Derailment in Ohio
description: A Federal Railroad Administration report released today said improper maintenance procedures contributed to the derailment of a railroad tanker last year that forced thousands of people to evacuate their homes for up to five days.

title: TOKYO FACES SERIOUS DROUGHT AS RESERVOIRS DROP TO LOWS
description: When a familiar water-heater advertisement urging people to take a daily shower disappeared from television screens this week and gift bottles of mineral water turned up on department store shelves, Tokyo residents got the message. The city is facing another drought.

title: Kahane Ends Refusal Of Parliament's Oath
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane took an oath of allegiance to Parliament today and thus restored his right to take part in parliamentary deliberations.

title: Geography Of Family Life
description: WILLIAM STERNE, a 50-year-old Boston executive, recently turned down a job in New York City that would have paid $20,000 more than he makes now.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Beneficial Corp., Wilmington, Del., said it had completed the previously announced sale of its Western National Life Insurance Co. to Conseco Inc. for $261 million.

title: Global Markets, Corrected
description: An article and chart in Business Day on Monday detailing the performance of major international stock markets in the second quarter carried incorrect figures on changes in their market value, both in dollars and in local currency.

title: JUDGE SMITH CONVICTED OF PERJURY IN QUEENS CABLE-TV INVESTIGATION
description: Justice Francis X. Smith, who supervised 50 state judges in Queens, was convicted yesterday of perjury and criminal contempt for lying about what was said at private meetings on the awarding of cable television franchises.

title: Genentech Pact
description: Genentech Inc., a biotechnology company based in South San Francisco, and Mitsubishi Chemical Industries, Japan's largest chemical company, said they had agreed to exchange marketing rights and to collaborate in research and development of pharmaceuticals. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Argentina's Alfonsin Has Lost His Way
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERON INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes $5.8 million, or $1.19 a share, of net non-recurring income principally from the sale of assets for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: LEGAL ADVISOR TO ARCHDIOCESE
description: Charles J. Tobin Jr., who as director of the New York State Catholic Conference for 25 years represented the state's bishops on issues such as divorce and abortion, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Albany. He was 71 years old.

title: Penney Reshuffles For a New Concept
description: Two months after it announced its headquarters move from New York City to Dallas, the J. C. Penney Company, the nation's third-largest retailer, said it was making its most sweeping executive restructuring in years in the headquarters and in the field, effective Aug. 1.

title: HARTMARX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
HBO'S 'NOT NECESSARILY THE NEWS'
description: NOT every attempted gag in ''Not Necessarily the News'' is necessarily funny, but the first program of a new edition of the series, which has been enlivening cable television since 1983, is definitely, defiantly newsy. Tonight, on HBO at 11 P.M., the show's four frantic reporters - Anne Bloom, Danny Breen, Stuart Pankin and Lucy Webb - concentrate on Washington, taking aim mostly at the right and scoring some palpable hits on such broad targets as television evangelists, principals of the Iran-contra affair and politicians who deal in bromides.

title: 20 YEARS AFTER A 'SUMMER OF LOVE,' HAIGHT-ASHBURY LOOKS BACK
description: It lasted but a moment, the ''Summer of Love'' that drew tens of thousands of young people to the Haight-Ashbury district of San Francisco in 1967.

title: Mutual Radio and Union Agree to a 3-Year Pact
description: Announcers and editors averted a strike early today by agreeing to a three-year contract with the Mutual Broadcasting System, according to Tom Powers, an attorney for the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.

title: Primerica's President Sees a Profitable Future
description: Kenneth A. Yarnell Jr., who brought Gerald Tsai Jr. and the American Can Company together, has been named president and chief operating officer of the company, now known as the Primerica Corporation.

title: Japan-Poland Car Pact Seen
description: A consortium of Japanese companies reportedly told the Polish Government today that it would finance the construction of a Daihatsu automobile plant in Poland. If a final agreement can be reached between the Daihatsu Motor Company and Poland, the plant would be the first Japanese car factory in Eastern Europe.

title: The Cause of Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: TIGHTER U.S. RULES PROPOSED FOR MUNICIPAL INCINERATORS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed tighter Federal controls on garbage incinerators and issued a study showing that pollution from such incinerators can cause cancer and other illness.

title: Advertising; Army's Special Ad For July 4
description: THE only Army recruiting TV spot you'll be seeing this summer will be the commercial that Young & Rubicam created as part of its presentation to win the account, which it did on Jan. 27.

title: Murdoch Backed
description: The British Government gave the publisher Rupert Murdoch permission to buy the loss-ridden Today newspaper from Lonrho P.L.C. for $:38 million, or about $61 million. Mr. Murdoch's News International P.L.C. announced the proposed acquisition on Tuesday, noting that it required the approval of Lord Young, the Trade and Industry secretary. Lord Young announced the Government's approval in Parliament, saying he would not refer the purchase to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission. Lord Young said the newspaper ''would not have lived'' if he had referred the acquisition to the commission.

title: IN BORK'S WORDS: ABORTION, DEATH PENALTY, GAY RIGHTS
description: Abortion

title: BULLPENS SPELLING TROUBLE FOR YANKEES AND METS
description: A year ago tomorrow, Dave Righetti started the remarkable streak that carried him to the major league record for saves. After failing to gain saves 9 times in 26 save situations, Righetti reeled off a string of 24 saves and 29 in his last 30 save situations for a total of 46.

title: '20/20' EXAMINES TORUBLE IN PALAU
description: PALAU is an island republic in the Pacific; it is also, ''20/ 20'' suggests, the victim of Washington intrigue. The United States Government, or at least one of its more roguish parts, has used underhanded and perhaps criminal methods to spread military bases. This is a good story - island paradise, sinister forces, chicanery and palm trees - but pay attention and it starts to unravel. ''20/20,'' on ABC at 10 o'clock tonight, seems fanciful.

title: SENATE OPPOSES OIL IMPORT FEE
description: The Senate deleted a provision in the trade bill today that would have allowed the President to impose an oil import fee to reduce dependence on foreign oil.

title: Insider Case Deal Seen
description: A prominent Israeli businessman who is a key figure in an insider-trading investigation has agreed to cooperate with the Government's efforts to prosecute a former executive of Merrill Lynch & Company, according to legal sources with knowledge of the investigation.

title: INADVERTENT ENGINE SHUTOFF PROMPTS F.A.A. ORDER ON BOEING 767'S
description: Prompted by an incident Tuesday in which a Delta Air Lines captain mistakenly shut down both engines of his Boeing 767 jet, the Federal Aviation Administration has issued an emergency order requiring a safety guard between switches to prevent a recurrence.

title: NUMBER OF NEW YORKERS WITH JOBS ROSE TO RECORD HIGH LAST MONTH
description: The number of employed New York State residents hit a record high in June, but the unemployment rate for New York City increased slightly, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Department of Labor.

title: The Uses of Heroin For Cancer Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Whales and People
description: The ships were due east of Nantucket and whales were on the sailors' minds, a familiar enough story. But last week, when the sailors set out from Boston, they aimed not at killing whales but at saving them.

title: Honoring Dulles
description: For two years, family and friends of the late John Foster Dulles, who was Secretary of State in the Eisenhower Administration, have been trying to raise $2 million for a memorial celebration next February on the anniversary of his 100th birthday.

title: PACT FOR JOEY MEYER
description: Joey Meyer has signed a new five-year contract as basketball coach at DePaul University, extending through the 1991-92 season. The 38-year-old Meyer led the Blue Demons to 28 victories and 3 losses last season, a school record for victories. DePaul advanced to the final 16 of the N.C.A.A. tournament before falling to Louisiana State. Meyer is the son of Ray Meyer, who coached the Blue Demons for 42 years.

title: FUGITIVE DIVIDES FRANCE AND IRANIANS
description: A diplomatic confrontation between France and Iran sharpened today as a Government spokesman confirmed that police officers ringing the Iranian Embassy here were looking for an Iranian whose testimony is sought in connection with a terrorist bombing campaign last year.

title: LaROUCHE INDICTED IN PLOT TO BLOCK INQUIRY ON FRAUD
description: Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the persistent Presidential candidate whose politics center on conspiracy theories, has been indicted by a Federal grand jury here on charges that he conspired to block an investigation of a $1 million credit card fraud by his campaign workers.

title: U.S. ACCUSES CHILE OF INACTION
description: The State Department accused the Chilean Government today of failing to take swift action in two noted murder cases and of a general tolerance of abuses by Chilean security forces.

title: U.S. APPEALS ORDER TO RELEASE ASTRONAUT TAPE
description: The Federal Government has appealed a court decision that would require it to release a tape recording of the astronauts' voices aboard the space shuttle Challenger before it disintegrated.

title: Al Hibbler at West End
description: Al Hibbler, a singer, will perform tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway at 114th Street (212-666-8750). Sets begin at 9, 10:30 P.M. and midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is no fourth set on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum tonight and tomorrow, a $5 cover and a $7.50 minimum on Sunday.

title: Streak Ends For Bedrosian
description: Glenn Davis hit a three-run homer off Steve Bedrosian with two out in the ninth inning tonight to give the Houston Astros a 7-6 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Time to Rehire Some Patco Air Controllers
description: To the Editor:

title: E-II Holdings Offering Both Debt and Equity
description: A $1.5 million debt issue by E-II Holdings Inc. was priced yesterday through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. as sole underwriter. E-II Holdings has a collection of independently operated businesses consisting mostly of the consumer product and food specialty subsidiaries formerly owned by the Beatrice Companies.

title: MICHAEL BENNETT, THEATER INNOVATOR, DIES AT 44
description: Michael Bennett, the most influential theater director and choreographer of his generation and the creator of ''A Chorus Line,'' the longest-running show in Broadway history, died yesterday morning at his home in Tucson, Ariz. He was 44 years old and had been suffering from lymphoma, a form of cancer, as a result of AIDS, his attorney, John Breglio, said yesterday.

title: Misjudging Gulf Risks
description: Top Reagan Administration officials admit there is risk in U.S.

title: British Developer Turns Attention to East Coast
description: Tony Grant is coming to New York to develop property with the benefit of having the deep pockets of the Ladbroke Group P.L.C., a big diversified British company, to dig into.

title: Anti-Military Protests Continue in Panama
description: Hundreds of people demonstrated against the military-dominated Government here today, and armed men set fire to a building owned by the publishers of the opposition newspaper La Prensa while riot police watched.

title: British Actress to Reprise Her Role in 'Phantom'
description: The producers of ''Phantom of the Opera'' agreed yesterday to terms set by the Actors' Equity Association that will permit Sarah Brightman, a British actress, to re-create her leading role in the hit London musical on Broadway.

title: BAKER SEES TOUGH FIGHT OVER BORK BUT SAYS HE DIDN'T OPPOSE CHOICE
description: Officials close to the White House chief of staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., said today that he had had some doubts about nominating Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court, but Mr. Baker himself said it was President Reagan's decision and that he had no objection.

title: Economic Scene; Limited Impact Of the Young
description: THE generation following the baby boom is finally coming of age, but without the expected economic impact.

title: Greyhound Deal Backed
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission gave temporary approval today for an affiliate of Greyhound Lines Inc. to operate Trailways Lines Inc.

title:
A THREE-STATE ROUNDUP OF HOLIDAY CELEBRATIONS;
Long Island
description: LEAD: Fireworks by the Gruccis, concerts by the jazz composer and pianist Dave Brubeck and the singer Roy Orbison, parades and re-creations of historical Fourth of July celebrations will mark the holiday weekend on Long Island.

title: Art: John Graham, A Brilliant Scoundrel
description: THE title of his retrospective at the Neuberger Museum in Purchase, N.Y., proclaims John Graham an avatar -tongue in cheek, no doubt, for the artist was more scoundrel than incarnation of a god. He was, too, the kind of European scoundrel that transplants so well in American soil, being as pragmatic as he was magnetic and all but omniscient on the subjects of art and culture.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: Assets of the nation's 384 money market mutual funds increased $524.6 million, to $236.15 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 96 institutional funds were up $353.8 million, to $64.54 billion. Assets of the 198 general-purpose funds were up $855.4 million, to $68.11 billion. The 90 broker-dealer funds decreased $684.6 million, to $103.5 billion.

title: Grumman Gets Big NASA Job
description: NASA said today that it had selected the Grumman Aerospace Corporation of Bethpage, L.I., for its biggest space station award to date - a contract worth up to $1.25 billion over the next 11 years.

title: Ballet: Debuts in Bolshoi 'Golden Age'
description: DURING the Bolshoi Ballet's current season at the Metropolitan Opera House, its first visit to the United States since 1979, New Yorkers will discover an entirely new young generation of principal dancers who have elicited great acclaim in Europe.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tour de France Piasecki Leads: Lech Piasecki, a Pole who rides for the Italian Del Tango team, was the leader of the Tour de France after yesterday's first two stages. Piasecki took the lead after the day's first stage, a 70-mile jaunt through the streets and parks of West Berlin, finishing sixth over all. His time of 2 hours 11 minutes 33 seconds, combined with his second place in the prologue Wednesday, put him atop the 207-man field in least elapsed time. He wore the leader's yellow jersey after the afternoon stage, a team time trial in which his team finished second. Guido Bontempi was second, 13 seconds behind, and Stephen Roche, third, 19 seconds behind. Rowing Princeton Payback: Princeton gained some revenge for American crews yesterday by beating the Vesta Rowing Club of London in a heat of the Ladies' Plate at the Henley Royal Regatta. On Wednesday, Vesta handed Penn's freshman heavyweights their first defeat of the year. Yale, which defeated a Dutch student rowing club, joined Princeton as the only American crews in the final of the Ladies' Plate. The biggest American loss of the day occurred in a heat of the Wyfold Challenge Cup for coxless fours when the Boston Rowing Club, the defending champion, was disqualified for going out of its lane. Golf Taylor Takes Lead: Nancy Taylor, a rookie on the women's tour, shot a four-under-par 68 to take a one-stroke lead after yesterday's first round of the Jamie Farr L.P.G.A. Toledo Classic. Taylor birdied three consecutive holes down the stretch on the 6,220-yard, par-72 Glengarry Country Club course to take the lead over Cindy Hill and Heather Farr. Taylor, a 27-year-old Californian, has made the cut in only four of 16 tournaments this year, with a best finish of a tie for 37th place two week ago in the Lady Keystone.(AP) Horse Show Hearsay Is Winner: Margie Goldstein of Miami rode Hearsay to a time of 51.626 seconds to win yesterday's Open Speed competition at the I Love New York Horse Show in Lake Placid, N.Y. Hearsay's time was more than a half-second faster than the 52.243 seconds turned in by Tender Seeker, ridden by David Raposa of Cazenovia, N.Y. A field of 43 horses attempted the 12-jump course with only 12 finishing without fault.(AP)

title: EX-PACER JOINS STAFF
description: Billy Knight, a former all-star forward with the Indiana Pacers in both the American and National Basketball Associations, has rejoined the N.B.A. team as a member of its front office. The 35-year-old Knight, who retired in 1986 after playing one year in France, will work with the Pacers in the area of community relations.

title: Eisenreich Helps Saberhagen to 14th
description: Bret Saberhagen, helped by Jim Eisenreich's three-run homer, won his 14th game of the season as the Kansas City Royals beat the Minnesota Twins, 10-3, tonight.

title: Octopus Shares Aid Charity
description: Paul Hamlyn sold his Octopus publishing company today and promptly announced he was giving away about $:50 million, or $80 million, of the profits to charity.

title: AMID RUBBLE, DREAMS FOR SQUATTERS
description: The people of the Mahabir enclave do not exist officially in the city, although one of them bled to death in a rickshaw the other day.

title: Not One Dole but Two
description: A biography is being written about Washington's ''power couple'' that its co-author says started out as two separate books.

title: Saudi Policy Reflects Self-Interest Above All
description: To the Editor:

title: MOET'S UNIT IN U.S. NAMES A PRESIDENT
description: Richard Q. Armstrong, who used to be in the ginger ale business, has moved on to champagne.

title: U.S. JUDGE TELLS POLICE TO PRESERVE INQUIRY RECORDS
description: A Federal judge yesterday barred the New York City Police Department from destroying or altering any records concerning its investigations of black radicals or its taping of a radio station primarily serving blacks.

title: Dow Soars 26.94 Points, to 2,436.70
description: The stock market rallied strongly yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 26.94 points and virtually erased its losses for the holiday-shortened week.

title: No Headline
description: ROOKIE GETS POLE

title: DEMOCRATIC CAMPAIGN VIOLATIONS
description: The House Democratic whip and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee admitted today that they had had violated campaign finance laws by accepting use of a private yacht and aircraft for political events.

title: BOWLING LESSONS WELL LEARNED
description: Dick Weber, who is in the Professional Bowlers Association Hall of Fame for winning 10 of the first 23 events the P.B.A. staged, from 1959 to 1962, does not compete much anymore. Silver-haired at the age of 57, he is the organization's Midwestern regional director, more concerned that tournaments in an eight-state area are run smoothly than in competing himself in televised national events.

title: THE USA TODAY STORY: NEUHARTH'S OBSESSION
description: In a move of unusual corporate candor, the Gannett Company has cooperated in the preparation of a book chronicling the tumultuous history of its USA Today, complete with tales of bitter infighting, costly mistakes and a furious struggle to keep the national newspaper alive.

title: AN EXPLOSION OF FESTIVITIES FOR A FABULOUS FOURTH OF JULY
description: IN a city fabled for its celebrations, no holiday weekend can compare with the Fourth of July's magnificent medley of outdoor festivities. A cacophony of fireworks and festivals brightens the skies and the streets. Music galore -from Sousa to symphonies - resounds in the parks. And as sleek jets soar above Coney Island, a flotilla of sailboats glides through New York Harbor.

title: Havana Building Collapses
description: Four people were killed and 15 were injured when a four-story apartment building partly collapsed in central Havana, the national news agency AIN reported today. President Fidel Castro went to the scene of the accident, which occurred Wednesday night in the old colonial part of the city. About 30 people lived in the building.

title: FILM: 'SLEEPWALK,' A FANTASY
description: ''Sleepwalk'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Caryn James's review, which appeared in The New York Times March 20. The film opens today at the Bleecker Street Cinema, at La Guardia Place, and the Carnegie Screening Room, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street.

title: Dining Out Guide: All-American
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AMERICAN HARVEST, Vista International Hotel, 3 World Trade Center (938-9100) - *(June 5, 1987) Traditional American themes - quilts, wooden carvings and still-life paintings - provide the decoration for the quiet and spacious dining room of this downtown restaurant. The seasonal menu includes as appetizers blue cheese tart with American grapes; salmon and spinach roll with herbed sour cream, and Charleston shrimp butter with penne wafers. Main dishes from the dinner menu are poached fillet of halibut with golden oak mushrooms; roast loin of lamb with fresh pea puree, and roasted Long Island duckling with farm cherries. Dinner entrees $18.95 to $27; prix-fixe dinner $31. Fridays, 7 to 10 A.M. and 11:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. and 6 to 10 P.M.; Saturdays, 6 to 10 P.M.; closed Sundays. The restaurant will be closed tomorrow. AN AMERICAN PLACE, 969 Lexington Avenue, near 71st Street (517-7660) -

title: U.S. Dismisses Health Official
description: The Deputy Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services for population affairs was dismissed today for refusing to carry out a superior's order to resume Federal financing for Planned Parenthood clinics.

title: The Senate's Right To Reject Nominees
description: LEAD: Every President tries to shape the United States Supreme Court to realize his special constitutional vision.

title: HOT-AIR BALLOON SETS FLIGHT MARK
description: Two adventurers lifted off today and headed out over the sea on a 3,400-mile trans-Atlantic flight in a huge hot-air balloon, a journey no one has completed.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: REMEMBER last year's historic hoopla on the Fourth of July, a day that found New York Harbor paved with fiberglass boats and the city packed with huddled masses yearning to glimpse the Statue of Liberty as it lighted up and turned a century old?

title: SMEAL, PRESIDENT OF NOW, TO STEP DOWN AND SEEK WOMEN TO RUN FOR PUBLIC OFFICE
description: Eleanor C. Smeal, the outspoken president of the National Organization for Women, has informed its leaders that, contrary to widespread expectations, she does not intend to run for another term in office this year.

title: N.B.A, IN PROTEST, CANCELS MEETINGS
description: The National Basketball Association today announced that its annual meeting would not be in Scottsdale, Ariz., Sept. 20-22, because of a controversy over the state's failure to observe Martin Luther King day as a legal holiday.

title: SMITH WINS BOXING SUIT
description: It took almost two years and a law-suit, but Lonnie Smith is finally going to be compensated for being shortchanged while wresting the World Boxing Council superlightweight championship from Billy Costello in Madison Square Garden Aug. 21, 1985. In winning a civil suit against his former attorney, Jack Solerwitz, and the promoters of the bout, Smith was awarded almost $3 million by a jury in Federal Court in Mineola, L.I.

title: What the Century Club Is Doing About Women
description: To the Editor:

title: It Wasn't Hatch
description: Before President Reagan announced Wednesday that he would nominate Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court, a crowd that had gathered for a hearing by the Senate Judiciary Committee had some idea of who the nominee would not be.

title: FROM A GYPSY TO BENEFACTOR OF THE STAGE
description: It was one of those rare occasions when the theater seemed to have gathered its past, present and future into one house on one night.

title: 'Star Trek' Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Bicycle Carriers Recalled
description: Certain child carriers for bicycles sold by Sears, Roebuck & Company are being recalled because the shoulder-harness buckle could disengage, allowing the child to fall out, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced Wednesday. The recall involves the Championship Deluxe Bicycle Child Carriers, sold nationally by Sears for about $40 from February to July 1986. The stock number 82595 was on the outside of the box. and the maker was D&R Industries Inc., the safety agency said.

title: One
description: Until he was 3, Michael Bennett DiFiglia was probably much like any other small boy. Then he took his first dancing lesson, and an astonishing man of the theater, Michael Bennett, was born.

title: 'TRUTH IN SPENDING' ASKED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan, seeking to revive his effort to reduce the growth in Federal spending, will urge Congress to require the preparation of statements assessing the economic impact of any new spending it proposes, White House officials said today.

title: Queens Rape Suspect Sought in New Attacks
description: Three women were sexually assaulted in Queens late Wednesday and early yesterday by an unidentified man who the police said was suspected of at least eight attacks on women in the area since June 14.

title: Demonstration in Panama
description: Panama's embattled strongman, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, has just given a classic demonstration of a dictator's abuse of democratic forms. If he meant to bolster his credentials as a popular leader, he has in fact further stained them.

title: I.R.S. SETS TIGHT RULE ON INTEREST
description: The Internal Revenue Service proposed regulations today that would require taxpayers to keep detailed records in order to deduct the interest they pay on loans used for investments and business expenses.

title: UNION CONFIRMS GOODEN MEETINGS
description: Officials of the baseball players' union met three times with Dwight Gooden last summer after rumors persisted that the Mets' pitching ace was taking drugs. But Gooden denied the reports, and also denied them when officials of the Mets raised the same question.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I told him that the Democratic Justice Party should not dream of remaining the ruling party. It must be ready to become an opposition party.'' - Kim Young Sam,the South Korean oppositionleader, describing aconversation with theruling party's chairman,Roh Tae Woo. [ A1:6. ]

title: Robert C. Ekins, Communist Who Fought 50's Conviction
description: Robert C. Ekins, a sculptor and Communist Party member who successfully appealed a 1950's conviction of advocating the violent overthrow of the Government, died Tuesday in the Hospital of St. Raphael. He was 79 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: BIANCHI SPEAKS OUT
description: After a second interview with the Knicks earlier in the week, Al Bianchi said yesterday by telephone from Phoenix that ''nobody has said anything to me.'' Bianchi's remarks came in response to reports that he would be named the club's director of player personnel next week. ''The job I interviewed for was director of basketball operations,'' he said. ''I left the talks with the feeling that the Madison Square Garden people are being thorough seeking out the right person.''

title: ZONING HAMPERS REVIVAL OF STATEN ISLAND BUILDING
description: The institutional structure at 1000 Targee Street in the Concord section of Staten Island seems jinxed. In its 14 years of existence, the four-story beige brick building, now a shell with its windows punched out, was lived in for only two years. Its inability to attract tenants has had nothing to do with its lackluster boxy design.

title: ESTONIAN SENT TO FACE DEATH IN SOVIET DIES IN A HOSPITAL
description: Karl Linnas, who was deported from the United States in April to face a death sentence in the Soviet Union as a Nazi war criminal, died today of heart and kidney disease in a Leningrad hospital, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported.

title: Cannon in Talks On S.E.C. Inquiry
description: Cannon Group Inc. said it is in settlement discussions with the Securities and Exchange Commission to resolve the agency's formal investigation. The inquiry includes an examination of Cannon's method of amortizing film costs. Some industry experts have charged that Cannon recognized costs too slowly for films that did worse than expected, thus inflating reported earnings.

title: Bridge; Blackwood Convention Is Problem If One Has Void
description: Since the world's most popular bidding convention was devised by Easley Blackwood in Indianapolis more than half a century ago, it has been a major success with a few minor problems.

title: Northrop Ousts Missile Executives
description: The Northrop Corporation, under criticism for irregular purchasing practices in its MX missile program, removed two senior executives from the division because of ''management lapses and errors in judgment.''

title: SOVIET TELLS PIANIST HE CAN EMIGRATE
description: Vladimir Feltsman, whose career as a pianist came to a virtual halt after he applied eight years ago to emigrate to Israel, said today that he had received permission to leave with his wife and son.
