title: No Headline
description: FRIDAY GRAND SIGHTS Anyone who has ever visited the Grand Canyon has experienced the awesome grandeur of the four-billion-year-old geologic wonder. The beauty and mystery of the canyon have been captured in a half-hour documentary film, ''Grand Canyon: The Hidden Secrets,'' which can be seen this month at the Naturemax Theater at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street. The film was directed by an Academy Award winner, Kieth Merrill, who spent 78 days on location, traveling by foot, mule, horse, raft and helicopter, to gather footage. Among the spectacular views are hidden waterfalls, the white-water rapids of the Colorado River, a mile below the canyon rim, as well as the immense Red Wall Canyon where seventh-century Anasazi Indians lived. The breathtaking scenery is enhanced by Naturemax's screen, which, at 66 feet wide and four stories high, is New York's largest indoor screen. On Friday and Saturday evenings only, a second feature, ''Chronos,'' will be shown. Billed as an unnarrated journey through Western civilization, ''Chronos,'' directed by Ron Fricke, displays time-lapse images of the Acropolis, the Pyramids, the Vatican, Rockefeller Center and other landmarks. Admission is $3.50 for adults, $2.75 for the elderly and $1.75 for children. The double feature is $5.50 for adults, $4.50 for the elderly and $3 for children. For a complete schedule and times, the number is 769-5650. OCEAN COMFORTS Most trans-Atlantic travelers nowadays cross the ocean by plane in a matter of hours. But during the 1920's, ocean liners were the way to go. The expanding postwar economy created a new class of wealthy Americans who paid premium prices to spend many days aboard luxury liners like the Normandie, the Queen Mary and the Rex. An exhibition at the South Street Seaport Museum transports visitors back to the era of these great passenger ships. Called ''The Great Liner: Trans-Atlantic Passage Between the Wars,'' the show depicts life at sea, and features photographs, a partial model of the Normandie, a place setting and glass panels from the Queen Mary, and a ticket agent's counter complete with steamship schedules, travel brochures and posters. The show, produced in cooperation with the Ocean Liner Museum, will run until Jan. 3, and can be seen daily between 10 A.M. and 6 P.M. at the Seaport Museum, 213 Water Street. Admission is $4 for adults, $3 for the elderly and $2 for children under 12. For information, the number is 669-9424. MOSTLY OPERETTA What Ginger Rogers and Fred Astaire did for dance on film, Jeanette MacDonald and Nelson Eddy did for operetta on the silver screen. The incomparable singing duo brought to life many great musicals in films that will be celebrated in a five-week festival, Mostly Operetta, at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. Highlighted will be all the movies the pair made together, including Victor Herbert's ''Naughty Marietta,'' Rodgers and Hart's ''I Married an Angel'' and Sigmund Romberg's ''Girl of the Golden West,'' as well as those in which they appeared separately, such as Franz Lehar's ''Merry Widow,'' with Miss MacDonald and Maurice Chevalier, and Romberg's ''Balalaika,'' with Mr. Eddy and Ilona Massey. Also scheduled are some rare films, including the 1929 ''Rio Rita,'' with music by Harry Tierney and starring Bebe Daniels and John Boles, and a seldom-seen Hitchcock gem from 1933, ''Waltzes From Vienna,'' starring Jessie Matthews and featuring music by Oscar and Johann Strauss. Admission is $5. Today the lineup includes ''The Merry Widow,'' directed by Ernst Lubitsch, 6 P.M.; ''Sweethearts,'' directed by W. S. Van Dyke 2d, 8 P.M., and ''Naughty Marietta,'' also directed by Mr. Van Dyke, 10 P.M. Tomorrow and Sunday those films will be shown at the same times, with another ''Merry Widow,'' directed by Erich von Stroheim, at 4 P.M. The festival will run through Aug. 6. For a complete schedule, the numbers are 598-7150 or 598-7171. SATURDAY 'MEMORIES OF DUKE' Another type of music on film is being celebrated at the Public Theater this month with free weekend showings of Gary Keys's 1980 documentary ''Memories of Duke,'' a tribute to Duke Ellington. When Ellington died in 1974, Leonard Bernstein said he was ''not only a remarkable composer and performer, but was in himself a significant chapter in the history of American music.'' The film follows the composer and band leader on a 1968 tour of Mexico, as he leads his musicians in some of the numbers that were his trademarks: ''Take the A Train,'' ''It Don't Mean a Thing if It Ain't Got That Swing,'' ''Mood Indigo'' and many others. Among the featured performers are Cootie Williams and Russell Procope, who also share their recollections of Ellington in interviews. The documentary can be seen Saturdays and Sundays at 2 P.M. through Aug. 2 at the Public, 425 Lafayette Street. Free tickets can be picked up at 1 P.M. on the day of the show. Information: 598-7150 or 598-7171. OUTDOOR MUSIC Summer is a time when New York City's parks reverberate with free concerts. One of the oldest participants in the outdoor music scene is the Naumburg Orchestra, which has offered free summer concerts since 1905. The group opens its 82d season Saturday at 8 P.M. in the Damrosch Park Band Shell at Lincoln Center. The program will include the Overture to ''La Gazza Ladra'' by Rossini, Bizet's ''Symphony in C'' and the United States premiere of ''Soldatenspiel,'' a short work by Leo Weiner, a contemporary of Bartok and Kodaly and a teacher of the conductor Sir Georg Solti. The program will conclude with the Third Piano Concerto of Prokofiev, with a guest soloist, Dickran Atamian, the first-prize winner of the 1975 Naumburg Piano Competition. Jens Nygaard, the orchestra's music director, will conduct. Information: 799-1259. REVOLUTIONARY SPIRIT What better way to celebrate Independence Day than to relive the city's Revolutionary War history, and what better place than at one of the city's oldest buildings, the Fraunces Tavern Museum? Built in 1719, the tavern is a bastion of history, having served, among other things, as the first offices of the New York Chamber of Commerce in 1768 and the site where George Washington bade farewell to his troops in 1783. Starting this weekend, the museum will house two exhibitions that examine life in late-18th-century America. ''Capital City: New York After the Revolution'' and ''After the Revolution: Everyday Life in America, 1780-1800'' will open on Saturday. The former will be on view for two years and the latter, a traveling Smithsonian Institution exhibition, until Oct. 2. On display will be many historic documents and artworks from the museum's permanent collection, including the only contemporary depiction of Washington's 1789 inauguration - Amos Doolittle's engraving ''Federal Hall -the Seat of Congress'' - swords by Colonial New York sword makers and Thomas Pritchard Rossiter's oil painting ''Signing the Constitution.'' In honor of the Fourth of July, the museum, at 54 Pearl Street, will be open Saturday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Regular hours are Monday through Friday 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Admission on Saturday is by suggested contribution of $2.50. During the week, the museum is free from 10 A.M. to noon, and by contribution afterward. Information: 425-1778. SUNDAY POTPOURRI Calalu is an eastern Caribbean stew made from a potpourri of local ingredients. It is also the name of a 12-piece band that plays music of many styles and ethnic groups. The ensemble will serve as the core group for the third annual free series Musica Para Hot Sundays, which opens this weekend at the Cuando Community Center, 9 Second Avenue, just north of Houston Street. Sponsored by Yomoma Arts Inc., the festival was created to bring together artists from many ethnic backgrounds, or, as one of the series's co-directors, George Agudow, said, to ''reach out to the many communities that make up New York and give musicians a chance to collaborate who otherwise might never get to play together.'' Along with Calalu - which is led by Eric Darton, the festival's other co-director - Sunday's program will include the Devastators, a group of teen-age percussion players directed by Ellen Haag; a jazz violinist, Jason Hwang, and Kwok Mang Ho, an environmental artist. Audience members are encouraged to take their own instruments and join in the music making, which begins at 2 P.M. Information: 675-8189.

title: George S. Wise Dead; Led Tel Aviv University
description: Dr. George S. Wise, philanthropist, educator and business executive, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach. He was 81 years old.

title: Italy's No. 1 Bank Marketing Notes
description: Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, Italy's largest bank, has become the first Italian issuer of medium-term notes in the United States. On Wednesday it began offering $500 million of notes on a continuous basis, with maturities ranging from nine months to 10 years. Salomon Brothers and Paine Webber are agents.

title: CHIEFS ON ONODAGA RESERVATION ORDER END TO SALES OF FIREWORKS
description: For a man who traffics in celebration, Ave Bucktooth is not feeling particularly jolly.

title: Unresolved Controversy
description: Even as he was being taken to the airliner in New York, Karl Linnas protested his innocence.

title: 'Richard II' Opening Postponed to Thursday
description: The opening of ''Richard II,'' the first of this summer's New York Shakespeare Festival productions at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park -scheduled for last night - has been postponed until Thursday because of this week's rain. Previews will continue, weather permitting, tonight through Sunday and next Tuesday and Wednesday at 8 P.M. Free tickets are distributed before each performance, beginning at 6:15 P.M., at the theater, which is near the park's 81st Street and Central Park West entrance. The play, which continues through July 19, is directed by Joseph Papp and stars Peter MacNicol.

title: FOR SANDWICH SHOP IN COURT COUNTRY, CASE CLOSED
description: Walter's was an insider's place.

title: DOCUMENTS SHOW OMISSION BY MEESE
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, in a 1985 document disclosing his personal investments to the Justice Department, failed to mention that on the day before the disclosure he had invested $60,000 with a financial consultant closely tied to the Wedtech Corporation.

title: Italian Festival Set for New York
description: ''Italy on Stage '87,'' a two-month-long festival next fall in New York City of Italian theater, music, films, painting and sculpture, was announced here yesterday by officials of the Italian Government.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PALE KINGS AND PRINCES. By Robert B. Parker. 256 pages. Delacorte Press. $15.95. PUSS IN BOOTS. By Ed McBain. 248 pages. Henry Holt. $15.95. WEEP NO MORE, MY LADY. By Mary Higgins Clark. 315 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: INSIDE
description: Soviet Denies Arms Report

title: Palau Balking at U.S. Compact
description: A new political agreement with the United States appeared today to be falling short of approval in a referendum, and the Government of this Pacific nation said it was laying off two-thirds of its employees as a result.

title: 'NOT SERIOUS STUDENTS'
description: No basketball players admitted to Virginia Tech from 1981 to 1986 have been graduated from the school, administrators said yesterday in releasing a report on an investigation into National Collegiate Athletic Association violations. ''In reviewing the academic records of basketball athletes, it is evident that most are not serious students,'' the report said. ''Individuals have been advised to take courses in order to remain eligible, not to make progress toward a degree.''

title: Market Place; Oil-Price Rise Propels Stocks
description: SANDI HABER SWEENEY, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, has a theory about oil-service and offshore drilling stocks: ''When crude prices improve, the investment community is willing to anticipate that a recovery in drilling activity can't be that far behind.''

title: SOVIET PROPOSES TALKS IN GULF WAR BUT IRAN IS REPORTED TO REJECT CALL
description: The Soviet Union has proposed to Iran that it join Iraq in holding a peace conference in Moscow to seek an end to their seven-year-old war, but Iranian officials have rejected the idea, Administration officials and Western diplomats said today.

title: Beauty Contest
description: Despite an impressive amount of beef, the Democratic Presidential candidates came out of their television debate in Houston looking like a cross between Bob Forehead and Max Headroom.

title: SOVIET DENIES MAKING OFFER ON MISSILES
description: The Soviet Foreign Ministry today denied a report that a Soviet official had informally offered a compromise proposal on the issues holding up an arms-control agreement on medium- and shorter-range missiles.

title: TWO ETHICS MEASURES PASS IN ALBANY
description: The Legislature tonight unanimously passed a bill that would require outside audits of the State Legislature, the Governor's office and the state court system, and also gave unanimous approval to the sweeping ethics legislation agreed to earlier this week.

title: For a Bipartisan Policy on Nicaragua
description: After seven years of acrimonious debate, it is painfully clear that the United States does not have a sustainable national policy toward Nicaragua. There is a very good chance that the cornerstone of current policy - support for the contras battling the Sandinista Government - will be repudiated, if not this year, then next. The time to devise an alternative policy is now, before the contra approach is scrubbed and we are left with no policy at all.

title: AT HIGH SPEED
description: Even casual auto racing fans are becoming blase about the fantastic lap speeds that Indy cars and Nascar stock cars post at oval tracks like Indianapolis and Daytona. Last fall, Rick Mears blazed around Michigan International Speedway, a high-banked two-mile oval, at better than 233 miles per hour.

title: IN DEMOCRATS' FIRST JOUST OF '88 RACE, ALL THE LANCES ARE TILTED AT REAGAN
description: The discussion was civilized, even good-natured. The result was muddled enough so that almost all the candidates went off thinking they had accomplished something. And for the time being, at least, the often fractious Democratic Party looked like the peaceable kingdom.

title: JOBLESS RATE AT LOWEST POINT SINCE '79
description: The nation's unemployment rate declined two-tenths of a percentage point to 6 percent in June, the Labor Department reported today.

title: U.S. KEEPS TAX STATUS ON ANTILLES
description: The Treasury Department gave in yesterday to pressure from Americans who own bonds of corporate subsidiaries in the Netherlands Antilles, saying it would ask Congress to allow interest on the bonds to remain exempt from withholding taxes.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: FIRST and Second Avenues in the 70's and 80's, Manhattan's other Little Italy, is abloom with colorful canopies over inviting windows, making it virtually impossible for the casual diner to sort out the exceptional from the forgettable. Violetta, an unassuming two-year-old restaurant, is the kind of place I have strolled by dozens of times without paying particular notice - that is, until some Italian acquaintances, finicky eaters all, began raving about it recently.

title: Democrats Pick Clear Battlefield on Bork, But Political Consequences Are Uncertain
description: In choosing ideology as the battlefield for the confirmation of Robert H. Bork, Senate Democrats have expanded a highly charged contest over the direction of the Supreme Court into a fight with high stakes for the party as well.

title: Connecticut
description: Fourth of July celebrations in Connecticut this year will include Highland Games, a symphony performance, a lobster festival and bicycle races, as well as traditional fireworks displays.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: The Attorney General; IS MEESE A TARGET OF POLITICAL ATTACK? OR IS HE CORRUPT? OR INCOMPETENT?
description: When Edwin Meese 3d arrived in Washington in 1980, he was heralded as a crisp manager and a fervent police enthusiast whose dedication to law and order was rivaled only by his loyalty to Ronald Reagan.

title: LEACH PITCHES ANOTHER AMAZING GAME
description: The blend of hitting and pitching that carried the Mets to the top last year has not been as awesome this season but it's getting there.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A Nose Is a Nose . . .

title: BRONX SURROGATE REMOVED OVER AFFAIR WITH AIDE
description: Surrogate Bertram R. Gelfand of the Bronx was removed from the bench yesterday by the State Court of Appeals, which cited his judicial misconduct during an affair with a law assistant and his ''evasive, incredible and false'' testimony about the matter.

title: Advertising; A Job Shift Back to Magazines
description: SITTING relaxed in a Hearst Magazines conference room yesterday, Alvin Hampel, who has just reached ''the big six-oh,'' recalled that some 52 years ago he sold Liberty magazine door-to-door. His first pay was a balsa glider, and when it broke, so did his heart.

title: A BRASH LABORITE QUITS FRONT ROW
description: Among his admirers, Denis Healey is sometimes called ''the best Prime Minister Britain never had.'' Detractors have characterized him as a political thug who, as one victim put it, ''could not see a belt without hitting below it.''

title: New Jersey
description: In celebration of the Fourth of July, New Jersey will offer a cacophonous weekend of classical concerts, marching bands and exploding fireworks. From Cape May in the south to Liberty State Park in the north, skyrockets will sporadically light up the skies. In addition, the usual variety of fishing, bathing and boating opportunities abound along the state's 127 miles of coastline.

title: SEOUL RIVALS MEET FOR THE FIRST TIME IN A SURPRISE VISIT
description: Two men who may oppose each other for the presidency met tonight to pave the way for negotiations on a new constitution.

title: From Bolshoi, 'The Dancer Who Jumps'
description: Irek Mukhamedov is one of the Bolshoi Ballet's most popular young stars. The 27-year-old dancer, who will appear at each performance this weekend at the Metropolitan Opera House, is said to epitomize the heroic style of Yuri Grigorovich, the Bolshoi's artistic director and chief choreographer. To many New York balletomanes, Mr. Mukhamedov is known simply as ''the dancer who jumps.'' And from his first moments on stage in Mr. Grigorovich's ''Golden Age,'' in his American debut on Tuesday at the opening of the Bolshoi's three-week season at the Metropolitan, Mr. Mukhamedov had clearly won the hearts of the eagerly applauding audience.

title: Westchester County
description: Old-time fiddlers and classical musicians will join national rodeo champions and costumed patriots to provide a memorable Fourth of July weekend in Westchester County.

title: Advertising; Doyle Graf Mabley To Handle Natori
description: Natori, a fashion house that is also involved in fragrances and home furnishings, has retained Doyle Graf Mabley as its ad agency. The billings could come to $3 million.

title: TOSHIBA, U.S. TALK ON EXPORTS
description: American lawyers for the Toshiba Corporation met with Pentagon officals today to discuss steps the company will take to improve its export control procedures.

title: Advertising; People
description: * William Lower has been promoted to executive vice president, creative director, at Wells, Rich, Greene/Chicago.

title: PHILADELPHIA COUNCILMAN AND AIDE GUILTY OF GRAFT
description: A City Councilman here and his senior aide were convicted of conspiracy and extortion today and of attempting to extort more than $1 million from the developer of what has been called the crown jewel in the city's effort to restore its dilapidated waterfront.

title: Art: Brooklyn Painters
description: THE first exhibition in which the Brooklyn Museum, under its present director, Robert Buck, provided a forum for the growing number of artists living or working in its borough was ''Working in Brooklyn -Sculpture,'' in the fall of 1985. The 10 artists - including Donald Lipski, Chris Macdonald, Tom Otterness, Judy Pfaff, Alan Saret, William Tucker and Christopher Wilmarth -could provide the foundation for a successful sculpture show anywhere.

title: WARD EXPLAINS TAPING OF A BLACK RADIO PROGRAM
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward and Mayor Koch told listeners of a talk show aimed primarily at black listeners yesterday that the police intelligence division had monitored the program only to learn of events in the black community that might require the deployment of police officers for public safety.

title: Jill A. Abramow Weds Bradley P. Gerla on L.I.
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., last night Jill A. Abramow, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Abramow of New York, was married to Bradley P. Gerla, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Gerla of Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi Chaim Etrog, assisted by Cantor David Benedict, performed the ceremony.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Independence Day is tomorrow, but closings vary. Following are holiday schedules for today and tomorrow:

title: Hugh Masekela
description: Hugh Masekela, a trumpeter, will perform with Kalahari, the band of African musicians that has been appearing on Paul Simon's ''Graceland'' tour, on Sunday night. They will play at midnight at the Limelight, 660 Avenue of the Americas, at 20th Street (212-807-7850). Tickets are $12.

title: STRONG LEADERS REQUIRED TO MEET YEAR 2000 GOALS
description: If the bold and imaginative ideas proposed for New York City schools by the Commission on the Year 2000 are to work, they will clearly require equally bold and imaginative leadership in putting them into effect, according to educators and Board of Education members.

title: TOP JAPAN PARTY FACTION SPLITS
description: As politicians in the governing Liberal Democratic Party begin to prepare for a leadership election in October, the party's most powerful faction, led nominally by former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka, has split into three groups.

title: BROADWAY
description: Theater In the Country It's nice to cross a bridge to somewhere when the thermometer in Manhattan soars, and it's even more pleasant when an evening of theater accompanies the cool breezes and the rustle of trees. Now is the time, and the playhouses within easy reach are geared and waiting, but before going into what's out there, a bit of happy news for early fall.

title: Yes, a Mission in Mongolia
description: When the United States opens a mission sometime next year in Mongolia, the venture will have some of the flavor of diplomacy as practiced in the last century, when envoys journeyed to exotic places with pack animals and bearers cleared the way with machetes.

title: Mimi Wallace Marries
description: The marriage of Mimi Wallace, a senior vice president and director of business affairs at Ted Bates Advertising in New York, to Elhanan C. Stone, executive vice president and general counsel of Ted Bates Worldwide Inc., took place yesterday at the Registry Office in Hamilton, Bermuda. Lionel R. Dowling, assistant Registrar General of Bermuda, officiated. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Jerome Kolberg of Hackensack, N.J., and the late Mr. Kolberg. The bridegroom is a son of Miriam Berlin of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and the late Dr. Moses J. Stone of Boston. Previous marriages for both bride and bridegroom ended in divorce.

title: NAVRATILOVA TURNS BACK EVERT AND FACES THE FUTURE
description: There is no longer a sharp edge to their rivalry, a feeling that one is standing in the way of the other. Now, there are more smiles across the net when Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert play, more animated behavior. And there are the inevitable congratulatory hugs when the matches are over, two tennis players taking comfort in the knowledge that they are growing old on the court together.

title: CORREECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch yesterday about a California businessman's charges on Saudi aid to the Angolan rebels included an incorrect reference to the Saudi response. The official Saudi response was given by Frederick Dutton, a Washington lawyer representing the Saudis, who said that the businessman had ''no credibility'' and that his allegations were ''junk and nonsense.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about a memorial ceremony at the Congressional Cemetery in Washington misstated the day of the event. It is tomorrow, not today.

title: ANOTHER MARINE IS ACCUSED OF SECURITY OFFENSES IN SOVIET
description: Another marine has been charged with security violations while serving as an embassy guard in Moscow and in Bern, Switzerland, the Marine Corps said today.

title: PATIENT RESUSCITATION BILL IS WITHDRAWN IN SENATE
description: A bill that would have set guidelines for when physicians should and should not resuscitate patients was taken off the State Senate floor during debate today when it became clear it would not pass.

title: Shareholders Clear VW Management
description: At a packed and sometimes heated annual meeting, Volkswagen A.G.'s stockholders voted approval today of the auto maker's senior managers, effectively absolving them of the foreign-exchange swindle that cost the company almost $260 million in losses.

title: STATION OFFERS PERSPECTIVE OF BLACK NEW YORKERS
description: From sunrise to sunset each day, WLIB-AM, a radio station oriented to the concerns of a large segment of New York's black community, becomes what David Lampel likes to call ''a crucible of black opinion'' as listeners call in to address issues in the news and questions posed by hosts and guests.

title: Summer At Modern Museum
description: Although open-air concerts abound at this time of year, one of the city's most intimate, under-the-skies musical series is the Museum of Modern Art's Summergarden. The sculptures of Rodin and Matisse, Picasso and Henry Moore provide a backdrop for 18 evenings of music in the museum's Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden. Beneath the lights of surrounding skyscrapers, the free Friday and Saturday night concerts begin their 12th season tonight at 7:30.

title: BOSTONIANS AWAIT A GLORIOUS FOURTH
description: Everyone who plans to attend the Boston Pops July 4 concert anticipates having a good time. But the handful who have been camping out in front of the stage for the last 10 days see it the other way around; they are having a good time anticipating.

title: No Headline
description: RANGER PITCHING IS A THREAT

title: Borg-Warner Deal Brings Financing
description: The Borg-Warner Holdings Corporation has filed a dual offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission: $600 million of senior subordinated debentures due in 1997 and $203.7 million of senior subordinated discount debentures due in 1999.

title: BLACK U.S. JUDGE ASSAILS D'AMATO OVER SUCCESSOR
description: The only black Federal judge serving in Brooklyn yesterday criticized Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato for recommending a white candidate to replace him when he retires in the fall.

title: GERMAN? YES, AND A TOUCH OF RUSSIAN
description: As a child in distant Soviet Central Asia, Larissa Grams was allowed to speak only German at home - more precisely, the Schwabisch dialect her forebears took to Russia two centuries earlier.

title: SYRACUSE SHIFTS FOOTBALL GAME
description: The Syracuse University basketball team, which lost to Indiana by 1 point in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship game last season, will open a 30-game 1987-88 schedule against North Carolina Nov. 21 in the Tipoff Classic at Springfield, Mass.

title: Substitute State Health Insurance for Medicaid
description: To the Editor:

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Ladysmith Black Mambazo, Central Park's Summerstage, Central Park Band Shell, near 72d Street (860-1335). Expect a crowd; this unaccompanied vocal chorus from South Africa has been stopping the show at just about every performance on Paul Simon's ''Graceland'' tour, and is more than capable of holding any number of listeners spellbound on its own. Rooted in Zulu choral traditions and Afro-Protestant hymn singing, Ladysmith Black Mambazo hits with the power and finesse of a kind of street-corner doo-wop big band. They're performing Sunday at 3 P.M.; admission is free. They will also be at the Ritz on Tuesday. * * *

title: BETHLEHEM PRICES
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced a new price schedule for sheet products that will mean about a 3 percent increase for hot-rolled products. A company spokesman, Bill Gignac, said the new price schedule, effective with shipments on Oct. 4, ''will be more indicative of production costs.''

title: DRIFTER CHARGED IN BLUDGEONING OF HIS PARENTS
description: A 20-year-old drifter was charged today with killing his parents, whose bodies were found Wednesday bludgeoned and badly burned in the backyard of their home in this peaceful Fairfield County town.

title: Yugoslav Debt Problems
description: The Yugoslav Government confirmed today that it was having difficulties repaying part of its $20 billion foreign debt. A Foreign Ministry spokesman, Aleksandar Stanic, said that repayment of about $200 million in principal to commercial banks would be delayed for two months. ''It is a question of temporary problems in repaying obligations that came due in June, arising from seasonal factors,'' Mr. Stanic said.

title: DRUG BAN FOR BENGAL
description: Stanley Wilson, a running back for the Cincinnati Bengals who scored eight touchdowns last season, has been suspended indefinitely by the National Football League for renewed involvement with cocaine. It is the second time that Wilson has been suspended for violating the league's drug policy. The former Oklahoma star was suspended in October 1984 and reinstated in May 1986 under strict conditions.

title: Prices Rise in Light Trading
description: Bond prices ended a holiday-shortened week on a positive note, registering gains of half a point or more yesterday on signs that economic activity remains relatively weak.

title: Licenses for Bicycles
description: To the Editor:

title: ASSETS BOESKY GAVE U.S. SAID TO LOSE VALUE
description: A court-appointed official has negotiated to sell assets handed over by Ivan F. Boesky in his settlement of insider trading charges for nearly $20 million less than they were worth at the time of the settlement last November, according to several legal sources with knowledge of the matter.

title: JUDGE GIVES TEACHERS JAIL TERMS AND SAYS STIKE CORRUPTED YOUTHS
description: Three months after an illegal six-day strike by teachers and other school employees in Lyndhurst, a judge is scolding 175 teachers, custodians and secretaries and sentencing them to three-day jail terms.

title: Allied-Signal Ordered to Pay
description: A Federal jury said today that Allied-Signal Inc. must pay the holders of the General Poly Corporation more than $70 million because of actions that the now-defunct plastic-bag maker says forced it to seek bankruptcy protection.

title: Eight-Part Series on 13, 'South American Journey'
description: ''I WAS looking into a continent still wild, lawless, volatile -delightful,'' Jack Pizzey says. He has just crossed the Andes; he is at the shore of Lake Titicaca, and we are only a minute or so into the opening of ''South American Journey,'' an interesting eight-part series that begins on Channel 13 Sunday night at 7 o'clock.

title: Bank Auditor Is Acquitted
description: A Federal court jury today found a former accounting firm for the Continental Illinois National Bank not guilty of failing to warn bank officials that they had bought bad loans from the Penn Square Bank. The bad loans nearly bankrupted the banking company, which needed a $4.5 billion Federal bailout to survive.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JULY 3, 1987
description: International A2-7

title: KEY RATES
Construction Machinery In Queens Exhibition
description: A two-month exhibition on large construction machinery has opened at the New York Hall of Science in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens, featuring weekend demonstrations, artworks and films related to the theme.

title: Jazz Pioneers Downtown And Uptown
description: ''PEOPLE have tried to build a better world, but they've failed because they didn't have a blueprint,'' Sun Ra once remarked. ''You can't tear something down, you know, unless you've got something better. I've got my equations, and these equations are valid. I'm not doing any of this on faith or on what I think. I'm not even dealing with intellect. You have to have this intuitive plan. There's a wilderness out there, and you've got to have some pioneers to go out and discover and achieve.''

title: Camping Out At Ecology Lab In the Catskills
description: For almost 40 years, Camp DeBruce has done its best to turn out ecologically sound children, but the news at lunch Wednesday was not good.

title: THE OLD MAN'S GAME
description: We root for old guys. We root for them not to leave us too soon - and many times, any time is too soon. They've been around and have become familiar and we've come, if not always to love them, to understand them, or appreciate them, or enjoy them.

title: U.S. SYPHILIS CASES RISE 23%
description: After declining for five years, syphilis cases in the United States increased 23 percent in the first quarter of this year, largely among heterosexuals, Federal health researchers reported today.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Lou Donaldson Quartet, Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, between 9th and 10th Streets (982-3260). Lou Donaldson is an alto saxophonist and singer who combines the distinctive features of two stars who were prominent in different generations of jazz. His saxophone is fired with memories of Charlie Parker as he flashes through sweeping lines that crackle with the musical fires lighted by Parker in the 1940's. When Mr. Donaldson sings, he retreats two decades to the 1920's where he picks up the conversational vocal style of Don Redman, who brought a glint of humor to his songs with his minimalist approach. However, Mr. Donaldson is constantly challenged within his own group by his pianist, the ebullient Herman Foster, who is so bursting with raw energy and enthusiasm that he seems constantly on the verge of winging right off the bandstand. With Jeff Fuller on bass and Fukisi Tianaka on drums, the quartet plays sets at 9 and 11 tonight through Sunday, with an added show tonight and tomorrow at 12:30 A.M. There is a $10 cover charge and a $7 minimum. * * *

title: QUICK FIXES FOR FAT KNEES
description: Women who genuflect to fashion on knees that are less than lovely are facing a dilemma as hemlines rise to heights not seen in two decades: How to wear the new short skirts without being called pudding knees, cottage-cheese knees and such?

title: Rampal, Ill, Cancels Engagements in July
description: Jean-Pierre Rampal, the French flutist, is suffering from the flu and bronchitis and has canceled his July engagements, all of which were in the northeastern United States.

title: SYRIA KEEPS DENOUNCING U.S. DESPITE MOVES TO END STRAIN
description: Syria is keeping up a war of words against the United States despite recent moves at ending the strains between the two nations.

title: 85 IOWANS SEE DEBATE AND PICK VICTOR
description: Senator Paul Simon scored heavily on arms control and taxes. Representative Richard A. Gephardt picked up the most voter support and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis was rated the best performer among the Democratic Presidential candidates.

title: 2 'Vicious' Prisoners Escape From the Nassau Courthouse
description: Two men, described as ''vicious'' by the detective who arrested them, escaped from the custody of the Nassau County Sheriff's Office yesterday while leaving the county court building in Mineola on their way back to jail.

title: Markets Closed Today
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be closed today in observance of the Fourth of July holiday. Government offices will also be closed. Banks and many businesses will be open.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE colors are as soft as a Mediterranean dawn, and the food, based on a recent sampling, can be equally alluring. Cafe Greco is a sunny new restaurant with a sidewalk cafe on Second Avenue near 71st Street that offers what it calls Mediterranean specialties - a little Italian, a little Greek, a little North African. Prices are right, too, with a three-course meal starting at about $25 (not including wine and tip). Plenty of good summer wines are available for $12 to $20. The chef, Tom Valenti, previously was sous chef at Gotham Bar and Grill on East 12th Street.

title: BACHE BRAVES A NEW WORLD
description: Prudential-Bache Securities has never before been a pioneer, but these days its energetic chairman, George L. Ball, is leading the brokerage firm on what he calls an expedition into Wall Street's most inviting frontier.

title: 2 NETWORKS TO BLACK OUT ADS IN FLORIDA TAX RIFT
description: The CBS and NBC television networks, in response to a request by three leading advertisers, agreed yesterday to black out certain national advertisements in Florida that their affiliates would normally carry, The move was viewed as a largely symbolic protest of the state's new 5 percent sales tax on service businesses.

title: MOROCCAN MISSES MARK
description: Said Aouita of Morocco ran the second-fastest mile in history at a grand prix track meet here today, covering the distance in 3 minutes 46.76 seconds.

title: A Triumph for All New York
description: Albany, home of ethics reform: It sounds like sarcasm but today it becomes truth. Pushed and cajoled by Governor Cuomo, New York's Legislature is catapulting the state to a promising new level of integrity in government.

title: MILITARY LEADERS IN HAITI YIELD ON PLANS FOR CONTROL OF ELECTIONS
description: In a dramatic effort to end the political crisis that has engulfed Haiti for the last 10 days, the military Government announced tonight that it was restoring control of the country's electoral process to an independent civilian council.

title: TRUMP WINS APPROVAL FOR 3D CASINO IN JERSEY
description: The Casino Control Commission ruled today that Donald J. Trump may proceed with plans to build and operate a huge new casino hotel in Atlantic City in addition to two he already owns.

title: Sale of Metromail
description: R.R. Donnelley & Sons said it had reached a merger agreement with the Metromail Corporation, a Lincoln, Neb., company that provides computerized marketing information and production services to direct-mail companies. Donnelley, the nation's largest supplier of printed materials, offered $282.7 million for Metromail. It said its proposed acquisition included an offer to purchase 9.5 million outstanding Metromail shares for $29.75 a share. Metromail's stock jumped $9.50 today, to $29.50, in over-the-counter trading. Donnelley's fell 12.5 cents, to $38.50, on the New York

title: 3 Killed by Tamil Land Mine
description: Three employees of a Government farm in northwest Sri Lanka were killed today when their jeep ran over a land mine set off by Tamil guerrillas, the Government said. The guerrillas are fighting for a separate Tamil state in the northeast area of the island nation. A statement said six Tamils were killed yesterday by security forces in separate incidents in the north and east.

title: Hudson Valley
description: If you would rather climb a mountain instead of watching the rockets' red glare or listening to firecrackers this weekend, the place to go on Sunday is the foot of Slide Mountain, the highest peak in the Catskills (elevation: 4,180 feet).

title: New Museum Director
description: The Smithsonian Institution has announced the appointment of Martin O. Harwit, a Cornell University astrophysicist, as director of its National Air and Space Museum. He succeeds Walter J. Boyne, who resigned last August to devote full time to writing. Mr. Harwit served as chairman of Cornell's astronomy department from 1971 to 1976 and serves now as professor of astronomy and as co-director of the history and philosophy of science and technology program.

title: SUMMER WEEKENDS: STRETCHING THEM OUT
description: Warren Owens likes at least two things about owning his own business. ''You can have your dog at work, and everyone has to be nice to it,'' he said. ''And you can leave early on Fridays in the summer to go to Block Island.''

title: CASE AGAINST BARBIE IS ATTACKED BY THE DEFENSE AS A TISSUE OF LIES
description: Klaus Barbie's principal defense lawyer said today that a guilty verdict would be a ''dishonor'' to French justice and to France itself.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JULY 3, 1987
description: Markets

title: IN A MANSION, ALLIANCES TO OVERCOME ADDICTION
description: In the limestone Renaissance Revival mansion on East 93d Street where Dwight Gooden recently spent a month in drug rehabilitation, substance abusers of different incomes, ages and attitudes forge incongruous alliances, uneasy at first, that are a key element of their recovery.

title: WHERE HAVE ALL THE 2-YEAR-OLDS GONE
description: Where are the 2-year-olds?

title: William Parker
description: William Parker, a bassist, will lead a group including Charles Gayle on saxophone tonight at 9 at El Bohio, 605 East Ninth Street, between Avenues B and C (212-260-4478), as part of its Jazz Arts Expo, which will include an exhibition of art by Romare Bearden and others. On Sunday at 3 P.M., Dave Sewelson, a saxophonist, will perform. A $5 donation is requested at concerts.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 1 about housing segregation in New York City and its suburbs misstated the racial makeup of Freeport, L.I. According to 1980 census figures, Freeport is not ''largely black''; its population is 64 percent white, 31 percent black and 5 percent other.

title: AN ERRATIC QUARTER FOR STOCK MARKETS
description: With its choppy swings, the second quarter gave fits to many individual and institutional stock investors.

title: Adams and Pullen
description: George Adams on saxophones and Don Pullen on piano, who played with Charles Mingus, will lead a quartet tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at Perry Street (212-255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: LESSON FOR DARLING: DON'T THINK
description: Ron Darling considered that he hadn't won a game in 10 weeks, groped for the reason or the rationale, frowned and said: ''Maybe you have to fail before you succeed.''

title: ON ROAD TO RECORD
description: Although he has been leading the Mets for less than three and half seasons, Dave Johnson is within reach of becoming the manager with the most victories in the franchise's 26-season history. With the team away from Shea Stadium until July 16, Johnson might achieve his club-record 340th victory on the road, where the Mets have won 57 percent of their games since he became the 11th manager in Met history in 1984. The managers and their records:

title: Turkish Civilians Challenge Role of Military
description: In ways that would once have seemed improbable, Turkish politicians and newspapers have begun to challenge both the authority and the competence of members of the country's military, an institution previously immune from such public questioning.

title: Susan Modlin Is the Bride Of Jay Solomon Markowitz
description: Susan Elizabeth Modlin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elihu Modlin of Hewlett Bay Park, L.I., and Jay Solomon Markowitz, a son of Fay Miskin of Brooklyn and Alan Markowitz of Woodmere, L.I., were married last evening at the Seawane Club in Hewlett Harbor, L.I. Rabbi Robert L. Rozenberg performed the ceremony.

title: SINDELAR POSTS 68 TO TAKE ONE SHOT LEAD
description: Joey Sindelar, one of the PGA Tour's long hitters, birdied the first three of four par-5 holes at the Glen Abbey Golf Club today and eagled the par-5 18th to take the first-round lead in the 78th Canadian Open.

title: AUCTIONS
description: THE Duke of Devonshire, owner of one of the largest art collections in the world, will sell 16 Old Master drawings, by Raphael, Veronese, Barocci, Lorenzo di Credi and Rembrandt, on Monday night at Christie's in London. The auction house estimates that the drawings will bring a total of $8 million.

title: CAPASSO ORDERED TO PAY EX-WIFE $6 MILLION
description: A state appeals court yesterday ordered the longtime companion of Bess Myerson to pay his former wife about $6 million as her share of their marital property.

title: NEW LIGHT ON 1787 AND WASHINGTON'S DOUBTS
description: George Washington was pessimistic. The Constitutional Convention was nearing an end and had been so contentious, he said, that more than once it had been ''upon the point of dissolving without agreeing on any system.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Woman of the Theater

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from San Francisco on Thursday, about the 20th anniversary of the ''Summer of Love'' in the Haight-Ashbury district, misstated the date of a concert and rally at Golden Gate Park that will conclude summerlong festivities. It is Sept. 12, not Sept. 21.

title: ZZZZ's Chief Said to Resign
description: Barry Minkow, the 21-year-old entrepreneur who founded the ZZZZ Best Company, has reportedly resigned from the fast-growing carpet-cleaning concern.

title: Departure at Maryland
description: David Gregg, the University of Maryland forward, will not return next year, the school has announced. Gregg was in the dormitory room June 19, 1986, when Len Bias collapsed and died of cocaine intoxication. Gregg recieved immunity from prosecution for testifying in the trial of Brian Lee Tribble, who was aquitted last month on charges he supplied the cocaine that killed Bias. Meanwhile, Charles (Lefty) Driesell, the Maryland coach who left in the wake of investigations following Bias's death, was named coach of the East basketball team at the United States Olympic Festival in August.

title: PHILS TOP ASTROS, RYAN, 2-1
description: Bruce Ruffin pitched a six-hitter over eight innings and Philadelphia beat Houston and Nolan Ryan, 2-1, tonight. The victory came before a crowd of 56,825, the largest in the National League this season, which was also treated to postgame fireworks.

title: DEBT ACTIONS MAY EFFECT BANK LOANS, DIVIDENDS
description: With leading banks setting aside additional reserves for losses on third-world debt, bank shareholders may end up with skimpier returns and both business and individual borrowers might find it harder to obtain loans, experts on the banking industry say.

title: $100 MILLION SAVING EXPECTED
description: In a move that is expected to save New York consumers $100 million a year, Governor Cuomo and the Legislature agreed today on a bill to end a half-century of restrictions on the milk sales in the state.

title: Dr. William L. Donn, Scholar At a Geological Observatory
description: Dr. William L. Donn, a researcher in climatology, geology and atmospheric physics, died Tuesday at his home in Grand View-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 69 years old.

title: U.S. AIDE TO FIGHT DISMISSAL IN ABORTION POLICY DISPUTE
description: A Federal official dismissed from her job for refusing to make grants to Planned Parenthood clinics said today that she would challenge her dismissal.

title: LANDFILLS AND MEANS OF DISPOSAL ARE ISSUES IN JERSEY TRASH TALKS
description: Dwindling landfill space and looming changes in trash-disposal methods have emerged as major issues in contract talks aimed at averting northern New Jersey's third garbage strike in six years.

title: JOHNSTOWN AMERICAN COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Japan Surplus Eases a Bit
description: The broadest measure of Japan's foreign trade surplus registered a modest decline in May from a year ago, the Government said today, showing signs that a strong yen may be helping reverse the United States-Japan trade imbalance.

title: Your Money; Loss-of-Income Insurance
description: DR. JOSEPH ADLER, a New York chiropractor, bought a disability insurance policy five years ago and has not filed a claim. Nevertheless, he is by no means unhappy about paying the annual premium.

title: AN AIR-CONDITIONER GUIDE, FROM B.T.U. TO E.E.R.
description: When the temperature reached 90 degrees last week, many New Yorkers went shopping for an air-conditioner.

title: BEEBA'S CREATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CELLULAR PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FACELIFTERS HOME SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes a $1,510,487 loss from discontinued operations. c-Net income and after net of $242,715 from discontinued operations. The company said it decided to discontinue its Chicago-based franchise, and the operations should cease on or around July 15.

title: The Odometer Connection
description: Chrysler got caught by a Federal grand jury with its monkey wrench on the odometer. It was doing a little test-driving of new cars with the mileage indicators disconnected. Illegal or not, that was crummy, and the company should have known it. Such deception fits the caricature of used-car lots. To do it on a product that is labeled and sold as brand spanking new is a tawdry breach of the public's trust.

title: BANK SUIT SEEKS NEW DOME BIDS
description: The Bank of Montreal, which is one of the largest creditors of Dome Petroleum Ltd., took legal action today to reopen bidding for the financially troubled Canadian oil company, which had agreed to be acquired by the Amoco Corporation.

title: America Has Lost Its Way
description: LEAD: I was born in the 1940's at the dawn of America's global prosperity. With the Great Depression and Great War behind us, the United States emerged as the pre-eminent global power. Indeed, over the next 40 years our economy propelled the world forward. At home, America set the pace for the world in inventiveness, in creating jobs, in raising living standards.

title: THE GAME OF PRICING FINE WINE
description: SOME things never seem to change; high wine prices in restaurants, for instance. Restaurateurs say they have to charge what they do to survive. But three times the retail price? Restaurants do not pay retail prices for their wines to begin with.

title: Polaroid Found Liable in Suit
description: The Polaroid Corporation has been found liable for damages in a class action suit involving allegations that company officials sold stock without disclosing information about the company's problems. A six-person jury in Federal District Court reached its decision Thursday after one day of deliberations. The amount of damages could reach $30 million. The total will be decided in a separate trial scheduled to begin next week.

title: Wilson Denies Report
description: Stanley Wilson, the Cincinnati Bengals' fullback who been suspended by the National Football Leage for a second time for cocaine use, has denied using the drug, according to a published report.

title: DANCE: CHO'S 'PANAMA'
description: Clearly a lot of work went into Cho Kyoo-Hyun's ''Panama,'' an ambitious mixed-media piece performed at La Mama Annex on Wednesday. Mr. Cho has woven an astonishing variety of theatrical elements into the 90-minute piece. And the performers of his Empty Hands group are impressive. Ultimately, however, ''Panama'' was a large and rather empty-seeming mystery.

title: PAGE AMERICA GROUP reports earnings for Year to March 31
PRESTO-TEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago 6 months' net includes a tax credit of $252,503. Sales include about $2.2 million in asset sales.

title: Joseph R. Strayer Dies; Historian and Author
description: Joseph R. Strayer, a medievalist and former chairman of the history department at Princeton University, died Thursday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center after an intestinal infection. He was 82 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: WORLCO DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $9,055 and $148,452 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: PRECISION AEROTECH reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $176,000 from the retirement of debt.

title: When Police Sow Suspicion
description: Worried about more racial violence after the Howard Beach incident last winter, New York City's Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward demanded better intelligence gathering in the black community. He got more than he asked for and black leaders now accuse the department of unwarranted surveillance and intimidation. The charges are exaggerated but the mistrust and suspicion need attention.

title: BUILDING MUSICAL BRIDGES IN THAILAND
description: In a practice room above the dirt and din of modern Bangkok, a small group of musicians, squatting on the floor with ancient instruments, produces the intricate patterns and delicate harmonies of traditional Thai music.

title: REAGAN VOWS TO ALTER BUDGET PROCESS
description: President Reagan pledged today to use the remaining months of his Presidency to pursue four ''essential economic freedoms'' that would alter Congressional spending and tax policies.

title: FARM WORKERS CONFOUNDED BY IMMIGRATION LAWS
description: Under the new Federal immigration law, three Haitian farm workers who came to this country a year and a half ago as boat people should be eligible for United States citizenship.

title: One of Two Suspects in Rape Is Recaptured After Escape
description: One of two ''extremely dangerous'' rape suspects who escaped from the police outside the Nassau County Courthouse was captured in Queens today after a woman telephoned an anonymous tip to the police, the authorities said.

title: Occidental Offer
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, in an effort to cut dividend expenses by $37.5 million annually, has offered to buy out its largest class of preferred shareholders and increase its outstanding common stock by nine million shares. Under the offer, which expires July 31, Occidental would exchange 1.5 shares of common stock for each share of preferred stock that pays a $6.25 annual dividend. These preferred shares were redeemable at the company's option for 1.25 shares of common stock, currently paying a $2.25 annual dividend. The move would mean a $14.5 million annual saving for Occidental, one analyst said.

title:
Patents;
Treatment for Tumors
description: LEAD: The Cetus Corporation, a genetic engineering company in Emeryville, Calif., received three patents this week on the necrosis, or destruction, of human tumors. The process is being used to purify proteins for clinical trials. Patents 4,677,063 and 4,677,064 were granted to David F. Mark and several co-inventors for the production of proteins that are toxic to tumors.

title: PROFFITT'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
A CALL TO SAVE TROPICAL FORESTS
description: An appeal for urgent international action to save the world's fast disappearing tropical forests was made here today by a group of third world political leaders, environmentalists and development experts.

title: BOXCAR SURVIVOR DESCRIBES ORDEAL
description: The only man who emerged alive from a locked, ovenlike boxcar described today how his 16 Mexican friends, flailing deliriously in the dark, collapsed and died one by one while trying to ride a freight train to jobs in Dallas.

title: FOOD LION INC reports earnings for 12wks to June 20
BAY FINANCIAL reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Net income The latest year and prior year include charges of $7,340,000 and $3,878,000, respectively, for depreciation and amortization on real estate; and provisions of $3,407,000 and $1,484,000, respectively, for possible investment losses. The company said revenues include gains on disposition of investments of $10,829,750 and $12,468,325 in the years ended May 31, 1987 and May 31, 1986, respectively.

title: COURT DATE IN AIRLINE PROTEST
description: An airline passenger charged with disorderly conduct for complaining about a flight delay in a manner the airline said made crew members fear for their safety has decided to take his case before a jury.

title: On Knowledge, Will And Birth Control
description: To the Editor:

title: VOILA! A MUSTACHE MAKES AN OLD MAN OF YVES MONTAND
description: A fake mustache deserves some credit for Yves Montand's acclaimed portrayal of a wily patriarch in ''Jean de Florette,'' the French film about greed and fate that opened recently at the Paris theater. The mustache, it seems, made him immediately at home in a part he initially rejected.

title:
Patents;
Processing of Metals For Space Shuttle Use
description: LEAD: A method of processing metals and alloys at high temperature and low gravity that was patented this week is planned for use on the space shuttles. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has provided funding for experimental operation.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JULY 4, 1987
description: Companies

title: L A GEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company had its initial public offering last July.

title: Goodyear Changes
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company plans to build a new plant and sell its retread machinery operations, the company said. The Long Mile Rubber Company, a Goodyear subsidiary based in Dallas, will build a plant at an undetermined site to help strengthen the company's position in commercial retreading, Goodyear said. The plant, which will produce patented, single-piece, injection-molded treads for commercial truck tires, is to begin operation in early 1988. Goodyear said it had also signed letters of intent to sell its Tire Equipment Inc. and Salisbury machine subsidiaries to the Steelastic Company of Akron, which supplies equipment to the tire industry.

title: BENIHANA NATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: The company said the latest year results were impacted substantially by advertising expenses related to the introduction of its oriental lites line of frozen food; the advertising costs for fiscal 1987 were $7,165,740.

title: AT BRONX COURTHOUSE, SPACE CRUNCH
description: At the Bronx County Courthouse, juries have deliberated in storage rooms, judges have conferred in coat closets and lawyers have appealed for relief from the tight quarters.

title: By PETER J. BOYER
description: Leaders of the Directors Guild of America, declaring themselves engaged in ''a struggle for the hearts and minds of the American entertainment industry,'' said yesterday that their members were prepared to strike after their decisive rejection of contracts offered by the television networks and Hollywood film studios.

title: EXPERT ON THE MIDDLE EAST HAS BEEN A LEADING PLAYER
description: Long before he became a noted expert on terrorism and Middle East problems, Michael A. Ledeen of Washington was a leading figure on the international bridge scene.

title: HADRON INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
CALLS GROW AMID VIOLENCE, FOR OUSTER OF HAITI'S RULERS
description: Despite the military Government's capitulation on civilian control of elections, calls for its ouster grew today amid new outbreaks of violence.

title:
Patents;
Process for Clinical Use Of Magnetic Bacteria
description: LEAD: Dr. Brian B. Schwartz, professor of physics at Brooklyn College, and Nancy Blakemore, a member of the technical staff at the Biomagnetech Corporation in Durham, N.H., were awarded a patent this week on the clinical use of magnetic bacteria. Patent 4,677,067 was assigned to the company.

title: LIFESTYLE RESTAURANTS reports earnings for 16wks to May 16
description: b-After a loss of $95,000 and income of $5,000, both from discontinued operations, for the 16 weeks and 28 weeks, respectively; and a gain from the sale of discontinued operations of $699,000 for both the 16 weeks and 28 weeks. c-After income from discontinued operations of $253,000 for the 16 weeks and $469,000 for the 28 weeks. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the disposal of the company's meat distribution operation.

title: HOSPITAL STAFFING SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax benefits of $51,000 and $84,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: SOVIET PLANNING BIG LABOR SHIFT OUT OF INDUSTRY
description: The Soviet Union plans to shift up to 20 million people from its industrial and agricultural work forces by the end of the century, using layoffs, mergers and a program of intense retraining, according to a leading Government economist.

title: ROBINS, RORER PUSH MERGER BID
description: The A. H. Robins Company and the Rorer Group said yesterday that they intended to merge, signaling a possible end to years of bitter legal fighting over Robins's liability for injuries caused by its Dalkon Shield contraceptive device.

title: CARDIAC RESUSCITATOR reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Cardiac Resuscitator Corp. is 78 percent owned by Emerson Radio Corp.

title: Kaisertech Deal
description: Kaisertech Ltd., the new holding company for the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation of Oakland, Calif., said it expects to buy the Chevron Corporation's half interest in the Harshaw/Filtrol Partnership on Aug. 1. A specialty chemicals company based in Cleveland, Harshaw/Filtrol had 1986 revenues of about $264 million and employs about 2,100 people at 19 facilities worldwide. Terms were not disclosed. The partnership was formed in 1983 by combining the Harshaw Chemical Company, then owned by Gulf Oil, and Kaiser's Filtrol Corporation. Chevron became a partner when it acquired Gulf in 1985.

title: Protection From Hate
description: Legislation on bias-related crime ought to be easy to pass: Who could oppose measures to curb violence based on prejudice? Governor Cuomo's bill, now before the State Legislature, was inspired by the Howard Beach incident and introduced five months ago. It would stiffen criminal penalties for such acts. That seems sensible, but the measure has encountered opposition on two grounds.

title: Amnestied Aliens Need Better Treatment
description: LEAD: The Fourth of July is a time for remembering America's immigrant heritage. It is also a time for serious thought about the message we want to send to America's future citizens.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, a calendar of summer classes and crafts in The Home Section on Thursday included a misplaced schedule.

title: Kurt Weill Premieres In Series in September
description: Several world and United States premieres of music by Kurt Weill will be featured during a five-part series devoted to the composer beginning Sept. 17 at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. The series will open the 1987-88 season at the concert hall.

title: Ratners Group Buying Sterling
description: Ratners Group P.L.C., Britain's biggest jewelry chain, will enter the lucrative American market by buying Sterling Inc., a leading American retailer, for a little more than $200 million.

title: STAR TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1.3 million for the quarter and year. c-Net loss The latest quarter and year periods have been revised.

title: CROWNAMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
Superconductivity May Not Revolutionize Our Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Campanis Comments
description: Al Campanis, who lost his job as player personnel chief of the Los Angeles Dodgers because of remarks about the qualifications of blacks for executive positions in sports, said yesterday that his dismissal would be worthwhile if the result was ''betterment of blacks.''

title: WHERE THE CAMPERS STRUT, AND FRET A LITTLE
description: The public-address system was booming, ''Good morning, it's wake-up time everyone,'' but none of the campers assembled for reveille at the flagpole. In fact, there was no flagpole. Nor did the campers stand at attention for the unfurling of the camp colors or the singing of the camp song. There are no camp colors. There is no camp song.

title: AMERICAN CLAIMS EVALUATION reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JULY 4, 1987
description: International 2-4, 28 Moscow called for a withdrawal of all foreign warships from the Persian Gulf and condemned the American military buildup in the region as an effort to establish ''military-political hegemony.'' Page 1 Moscow plans to cut its work force in industries and farms by up to 20 million people by the end of the century, using layoffs, mergers and a retraining program to streamline industry, a leading Government economist said. 1 Klaus Barbie was sentenced to life in prison for crimes against humanity, the first such conviction in France. The Gestapo chief of wartime Lyons stood motionless as the judge pronounced him guilty on all 341 items of the indictment. 1 Two balloonists jumped to safety as their disabled hot-air balloon went down within sight of the Scottish coast. The men were trying to make the first trans-Atlantic crossing in a hot-air balloon. 1 Opposition leaders warned that they will not negotiate with the South Korean Government on its promised democratic reforms until all political prisoners are freed. 3 Calls for ousting Haiti's Government grew amid new outbreaks of violence. The military Government capitulated on civilian control of elections, but failed to quell the violence. 4 A Cambodian princess holds court in the country's rundown capital, Phnom Penh. Mindful of propaganda, the Communist Government has given her a seat in Parliament and positions in six national organizations. 3 A South African church group has taken steps toward justifying the use of violence by guerrillas fighting to end apartheid rule. The South African Council of Churches endorsed the controversial statement. 28 In Panama, a strike was called by business leaders who said a pro-Government mob set fire to an important commercial complex in the capital Thursday. Many stores closed at midday to show support for the strike. 4 President Reagan's standing in the international community and his ability to achieve an arms control agreement with the Soviet Union have not been undermined by the Iran-contra affair, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said. 2 Eden Pastora is now a fisherman. It is an act of characteristically Biblical resonance by the former Sandinista and contra commander, whose grand gestures always seem more slaying than his battlefield maneuvers. 4 28 still confined in Teheran 2 A call to save tropical forest 28 National 5-7, 33 The survivor from a locked boxcar where 18 men died one by one in heat that probably exceeded 120 degrees told a story that was equal parts extraordinary nightmare and routine saga of life along the nation's border with Mexico. 1 A million dollars for a house? In and around several major cities, notably New York and Boston, the million-dollar house is no rarity, although it is still out of the reach of most house hunters. 1 Constitutional Convention records that had been unknown and unrecorded are being published by Yale University Press. They were unearthed in a 20-year search throughout the United States and as far away as Northumberland, England. 1 President Reagan will pursue four ''essential economic freedoms'' that would alter Congressional spending and tax policies in the remaining months of his presidency, he pledged. 5 An Air Force official defied an order from the President intended to stop unauthorized disclosures of secret information. A. Ernest Fitzgerald was warned to sign the agreement in 30 days or risk losing his security clearance. 6 Fiscal problems at Operation PUSH, the civil rights group that the Rev. Jesse Jackson has used as his springboard to Presidential politics, may prevent it from being able to continue its work, the group's auditor said. 5 Some B-1 bombers are operational after more than 10 years of dispute and, more recently, problems in development. About half of the 100 bombers scheduled to be delivered by April 1988 have been received. 5 The number of suicides decreases over holidays, according to a California sociologist's study. The study bolsters the belief among many behavior experts that the warnings of holiday suicides have been misplaced. 33 In a dispute over abortion policy, a Federal official said she would challenge her dismissal for refusing to renew grants to Planned Parenthood clinics. 6 N.E.A. president re-elected 5 Doctors hit insurance rates 6 Charges renounced, says Bakker 33 Court date in airline protest 33 Regional 29-32 2,,q>A bill to deregulate the milk industry has been agreed on by Governor Cuomo and the Legislature. The action could end a half-century of restrictions on the sale of milk in New York. 1 Difficulties in finding workers with the education and experience to meet requirements for entry-level jobs are becoming problematic in New York City, experts say. Such concerns, in light of the city's changing economy, have become pressing. 29 Sharpe James's first year in office as Mayor of Newark has helped the city achieve a new-found feeling of hope, many officials and residents believe. But Mr. James still faces serious problems. 30 New York bills on government ethics and accountability approved late Thursday by the State Legislature will not be signed by Governor Cuomo for at least a week, aides to the Governor said. 30 Overcrowding at a Bronx courthouse has caused hardships for judges, juries, lawyers and government agencies. It is agreed that some offices in the Bronx County Courthouse have to move, but there have been no volunteers. 31 News analysis: A panel's proposals could alter the way major municipal agencies conduct business. Some officials say the panel's report on New York City in the year 2000 could lead to changes in public policy, but others are more cautious. 29 Contract talks with trash collectors in New Jersey are focusing on dwindling landfill space and looming changes in trash-disposal methods. The talks are aimed at averting northern New Jersey's third garbage strike in six years. 29 In testimony about a bridge collapse on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, an engineer said that officials ignored his recommendation to add rocks as erosion protection around footings of the bridge. 32 Hasidim confront the secular 29 Illegal farm workers bewildered 31

title: MUSIC: ORIGINAL DIXIELAND JAZZ BAND
description: The place in jazz history of the original Dixieland Jazz Band, the group of five white New Orleans musicians who set New York on its ear in 1917 when it played at Riesenweber's Cafe on Columbus Circle, is based primarily on the widely held view that it was the first jazz group to be recorded. Musical merit or originality had been secondary considerations.

title: UAS AUTOMATION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

Patents;
A Way To Treat Myopia
description: LEAD: DR. DONALD PRAEGER of New York, who practices and teaches ophthalmic surgery, was granted a patent this week for a method and lens to be used in treating myopia, or nearsightedness.

title: Public Broadcast Group Elects Ledwig President
description: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting has elected Donald E. Ledwig president and chief executive officer. The vote, held Thursday, was unanimous.

title: 2 NEW YORK BILLS WOULD HOLD GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS ACCOUNTABLE FOR ETHICS
description: Aides to Governor Cuomo said today that he planned to wait until at least next week to sign two major pieces of legislation on government ethics and accountability that were approved late Thursday by the State Legislature.

title: Israelis Block Landing Of Guerrillas in North
description: Israeli troops foiled an attempt by Palestinian guerrillas to land in northern Israel today.

title: WARNINGS OF SUICIDES OVER HOLIDAYS ARE REPORTED TO BE MISPLACED
description: Mental health professionals often warn that patients are at an increased risk of suicide at the time of the major national holidays, such as the Fourth of July. But a California sociologist says the warnings are misplaced.

title: DOCTORS HIT INSURANCE RATES
description: Doctors protesting the nation's highest malpractice insurance rates have curtailed emergency services in South Florida and threatened to stop treating patients.

title: About New York; July 3d Languor: Memories of '86 And Leo's Liver
description: David Wolpers and your Lee Iacoccas may come and go, but Leo Steiner's patriotism never flags.

title: ROCK: BOSTON IN CONCERT IN BYRNE ARENA
description: The enormous popularity of Boston, which played the first of four sold-out concerts at the Brendan Byrne Arena on Wednesday, demonstrates the conservatism of commercial rock radio and the eternal adolescent need for reassurance.

title: Prof. Vaclav Cerny, Advocate Of Rights in Czechoslovakia
description: Prof. Vaclav Cerny, a founding father of the Czechoslovak Charter 77 human-rights movement, died in Prague, members of the movement reported today. He was 82 years old.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 38.

title: DARLING FAILS FOR 14TH TIME, 8-3
description: Faced with mounting internal dissension, the Mets held a team meeting before their game tonight as Manager Dave Johnson attempted to smooth things over.

title: INSIDE
description: Turmoil in Haiti Although the military Government has capitulated on civilian control of elections, calls for its ouster grew amid new outbreaks of violence that left eight more people dead. Page 4.

title: Beverly Cagan-Rogowsky Is Wed to Morton Eligator
description: Beverly Cagan-Rogowsky and Morton H. Eligator were married yesterday at La Panetiere in Rye, N.Y., by Rabbi Robert Fine.

title: INFLATION AND INVESTING DRIVE RISE OF THE $1 MILLION HOUSE
description: A million dollars for a house? Not so long ago, only movie stars and barons of industry occupied such places. But lesser lights of Hollywood and vice presidents of industry live in them now, as do doctors, lawyers, bankers and partners of accounting firms.

title: FRENCH COURT FINDS BARBIE GUILTY AND ORDERS HIM TO PRISON FOR LIFE
description: Klaus Barbie, the wartime Gestapo chief of this city, was convicted early today of crimes against humanity and was sentenced to life imprisonment.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Taiwan Cabinet Offers a Bill To End 38-Year Martial Law
description: The Cabinet today sent the legislature a proposal to end 38 years of martial law in what Prime Minister Yu Kuo-hwa declared was the beginning of a new era of democracy.

title: THATCHER DEFENDS REAGAN'S ABILITIES
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that she did not think the Iran-contra affair had undermined President Reagan's international standing and his ability to achieve an arms control agreement with the Soviet Union.

title: INTERNATIONAL CAPITAL EQUIPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $145,000. The company said the latest 9-month loss reflects an increase in the loss for the first six months from the $70,000 previously reported to $258,000. The adjustment reflects increased reserves against possible losses on certain equipment purchase commitments.

title: N.E.A. President Re-elected
description: Teachers gave a resounding mandate today to Mary Hatwood Futrell, electing her to a third term as president of the National Education Association and rebuffing an attempt to unseat the union's vice president.

title: MOSCOW PROPOSES FOREIGN WARSHIPS QUIT PERSIAN GULF
description: The Soviet Union called today for the withdrawal of all foreign warships from the Persian Gulf and condemned the American military buildup in the region as an effort to establish ''military political hegemony.''

title: Casey, Ex-Chief of C.I.A., Left $500,000 Estate to His Wife
description: William J. Casey, the former Director of Central Intelligence, left an estate worth more than $500,000 to his wife, according to papers filed in Nassau County Surrogate Court.

title: LITTLE PRINCE PRODUCTIONS LTD reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $596,194 from a jury verdict in litigation against Nederlander organization and a loss of $4,313 from reversal of a tax credit. c-Includes a tax credit of $9,627.

title: The Constitution as News
description: According to the Constitution's Bicentennial Commission in Washington, the nation's charter is not only being debated in this, its 200th birthday year. It's also being consumed. Eight million pocket-sized copies are already in circulation, two million from the commission alone. The Times publishes it today in our news columns in addition to our traditional Fourth of July facsimile of the Declaration of Independence.

title: BMW Sales Rise
description: The West German car maker Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G. said the popularity of its new ''7'' series of prestige cars helped increase sales 17 percent in the first six months of 1987 against the corresponding period last year. BMW said sales for the period rose to 8.92 billion West German marks, or $4.88 billion. BMW's supervisory board chairman, Hans Graf von der Goltz, said the Quandt family's 65 percent stake in BMW was not for sale. BMW shares have climbed recently on the sale rumors. Stock analysts have said possible suitors for BMW could include Honda, Toyota and Ford.

(AP) Rowing Henley's Third Day: At the 148th Henley Royal Regatta in England, the Canadian national entry in the Queen Mother Challenge Cup for quadruple sculls rowed to a quarter-course record time of 1 minute 49 seconds, eliminating the Vesper Boat Club. Steve Redgrave and Andy Holmes, the English defending champions in the Silver Goblets Challenge Cup for pairs without coxswain, set a course record of 7 minutes 18 seconds, defeating Justin Bohan and Brian O'Hara of Iona College.
