title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MRS. RANDALL. By Christopher T. Leland. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) Christopher Leland's second novel tells the story of the mysterious Mrs. Randall, a young woman with a past she must conceal from the small Southern town of Franksville. We see her through the infatuated eyes of her stepson, Gams Stevenson, whose observations include not only this femme fatale of a mom but all the details of small-town life in the early years of the century. Gams's curiosity deepens during the period of World War I, as the town is convulsed with jingoistic hysteria. When the bloodlust culminates in an act of mob violence against an innocent vagrant, the distraught Mrs. Randall has a miscarriage. Why is she so concerned with the vagrant? What are the details of her hidden past? These questions, and their answers, are unfortunately posed in a decidedly patchy style. Mr. Leland can produce beautifully cadenced prose, capturing, as Gams says, those ''moments . . . when instants grind suddenly slower and all that meets the senses is completely, simultaneously absorbed.'' But too often the author seems to have been stricken by creeping Faulkneritis. Things are always ''lambent'' or ''crepuscular,'' ''ineffable'' or ''unshriven.'' Paired with this precious vocabulary are the other appurtenances of the hillbilly Gothic: incest, patricide and mash whisky. The reader is no less relieved than Gams when he leaves the South for a career in the fledgling movie business as ''Steve Gambit,'' a second-tier contract player; his life (and the novel) then take an unexpected turn. In the end, ''Mrs. Randall'' manages to retain a compelling mystery, even if nearby Yoknapatawpha County casts a long and distracting shadow.

title: INTIMACY WASN'T PART OF THE DEAL
description: HIGH COTTON Love and Death on Wall Street. By Sherri Daley. 304 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

title: THE 80'S SEEN THROUGH A POSTMODERN LENS
description: TEN YEARS AGO THIS SUMMER Cindy Sherman moved to New York. Art has not been the same since. Then 23 and fresh out of college, where she had studied photography, Sherman began a series of pictures that would bring her phenomenal popular and critical success. Called ''Untitled Film Stills,'' and depicting the artist dressed up in a variety of guises, these unprepossessing black-and-white images helped usher in a new kind of art for the 80's - the self-conscious, intentionally ambiguous, pop-culture oriented practice that has become known as Postmodernism.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BEYOND FORGET: Rediscovering the Prairies. By Mark Abley. (Sierra Club Books, $16.95.) Hugh MacLennan, one of Canada's living natural resources, once described his country's literature as ''Boy meets girl in Winnipeg, and who cares?'' More recently, of course, Canadian writers - Robertson Davies, Margaret Atwood, Mordecai Richler, Farley Mowat, Alice Munro, Antonine Maillet and Mr. MacLennan himself, among others - have mesmerized millions of readers in many lands. And many Canadians, who have spent so many decades intensely relating to other lands - like Britain, the respected motherland, and the United States, the resented rich cousin - are just now beginning to explore their own country and their relationship to it. In ''Beyond Forget: Rediscovering the Prairies,'' Mark Abley gives an earnest account of his return to the broad Canadian prairies where he grew up, and of his wanderings from Flin Flon, Manitoba, to Forget (pronounced For-jay), Saskatchewan, with numerous stops along the way. This book, the research for which was financed in part by a grant from the Canada Council, is well-meaning. We learn about some interesting historical characters, and we read Mr. Abley's own ruminations, sometimes overwritten - ''I opened the back door onto the long grass and stood for a few minutes watching the implacable sun as it fell to a grapefruit-coloured rumour in the west.'' But his trek, in this first book, is disjointed. Much of it seems pointless. And the cumulative effect is, man meets prairie, and who cares?

description: Music will try to cool off the July night air this week. Enterprises big and small will be spread out among the city's parks and downtown open spaces. The New York Philharmonic is the busiest. It moves into Central park Monday night, conducted by Raymond Leppard, in a program that includes Handel's ''Fireworks'' music and the Strauss Horn Concerto (the Philharmonic's own Philip Myers is soloist). The same artists and the same music will be in Cunningham Park (Union Turnpike and 193d Street) on Tuesday night and on Wednesday at the Bronx's Van Cortlandt Park. The Philharmonic, with a different conductor (John Nelson), different music (Bartok, Berlioz and Tchaikovsky) and some added friends (the Salvation Army Band), makes its way to Heckscher State Park, East Islip in Suffolk County on Saturday. All four concerts are at 8 P.M There will be some outdoor opera, too -Vincent La Selva leading the New York Grand Opera at the Central Park Bandshell on Thursday in the familiar double bill ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and ''Pagliacci'' (by Mascagni and Leoncavallo, respectively). The nearest park entrance is at 72d Street, and curtain time (figuratively speaking) is at 7:30. For a contrast on a smaller scale, try Tuesday's recital by Richard Stoltzman, clarinet, and Bill Douglas, piano, at Lincoln Center's Damrosch Park at 7 -or perhaps Thursday's horn and piano evening at Bargemusic, Fulton Ferry Landing with William Purvis and Joseph Villa, beginning at 7:30.

title: Stage: Musical, 'Half a World Away'
description: IT is hard to see how it could miss, this evocation of Sholom Aleichem and his delightfully eccentric East European Jewish town, Kasrilevke, that has opened at the Jewish Repertory Theater. ''Half a World Away'' is done by people who obviously appreciate the humorist and his writings and who have a demonstrably good track record with this type of show. Yet miss is what it does, even if in a friendly, puzzling Kasrilevke way.

title: The Old West
description: To the Editor: We enjoyed the articles on the Old West (Travel, May 24), especially Andrew H. Malcolm's article, ''Where Wagons Heading West Left Their Mark,'' which brought back fond memories of our visit to that area two years ago. Register Rock and the ruts at Gurnsey are well worth the effort required to see them, as are nearby Scotts Bluff National Monument, Chimney Rock, Courthouse Rock and Ash Hollow.

title: Judiciary Joining City's Gallery of Corruption
description: WHEN it comes to scandals, New York's judiciary is emerging as a co-equal branch of government.

title: Data Bank: July 5, 1987
LIBERTY I. DONATION PLAN ASSAILED
description: The rangers who work at the Statue of Liberty say they are being pressed to solicit donations from visitors to make up for the elimination of the $1 entrance fee a few weeks ago.

title: Protecting the Jersey Shore
description: Governor Kean announced a plan last week to raise a governmental umbrella over New Jersey's 128 miles of beach, to which neighbors from New York and Pennsylvania have flocked in increasing numbers in recent years.

title: FOR COLLECTORS: CANCELLATIONS AND NEW ISSUES
description: THE United States Postal Service is offering collectors an opportunity to obtain 10 different pictorial cancellations on the new Capex wildlife stamps. Collectors can prepare their own covers and obtain the cancellations from individual National Parks or order a set on postal cards provided by the Postal Service.

title: Leaden Dollar
description: To the Editor:

title: Kennedy And Bork
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts is urging the Democratic majority in the Senate to mount a major ideological attack on President Reagan's nomination of Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court. But if they're wise they won't follow him down this stormy path.

title: LAURA KURLANDER ENGAGED TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence T. Kurlander of Manhattan and Latham, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Beth Kurlander to William Lourie Rittenberg, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin L. Rittenberg of Charleston, S.C. An Aug. 30 wedding is planned.

title: A Neighborhood Tour of Jakarta
description: Jakarta is kaleidoscopic Indonesia in the making, a city of multiple cultures and moods that can defy you one day and haunt you the next. For those who take the time to get acquainted, it is ''a city of serendipities,'' an Indonesian said; a city of neighborhoods that lead like stepping stones across hundreds of years of history.

title:
INVESTING;
A New Way to Bet on the Dollar
description: LEAD: Investors who want to speculate on the dollar can now buy foreign currency warrants on the American Stock Exchange. The warrants, which made their debut in June as part of a debt offering by the General Electric Credit Corporation, caught on quickly; Emerson Electric, Ford Credit, Sallie Mae and Xerox

title: CAN'T WE TALK THIS OVER?
description: IMPROPER BEHAVIOR By Elizabeth Janeway. 240 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $15.95.

title: POSTINGS: 'Buy-and-Fix-It' Loans; Novel Mortgages
description: To help revive its older housing stock, New Jersey is encouraging adventurous home buyers to take on ''handyman specials'' through a novel mortgage program.

title: HORSE-FARM FRAY NEARS RESOLUTION
description: LEAD: AFTER five years of legal and political wrangling, Asharoken Village is expected to settle a zoning dispute by allowing a horse farm to continue operating on the 440-acre Morgan Estate.

title: Headliners; Calling It Quits
description: Seventy-two years after he went to work on the docks and 25 years after he became president of the International Longshoreman's Association, Thomas W. (Teddy) Gleason has come off the waterfront. Mr. Gleason, who is 86 years old, announced last week that he was stepping down as head of the I.L.A. because of his age. The legendary labor leader was largely responsible for the longshoremen's iron grip on the Eastern seaboard docks, a grip upon which some blamed the decline of the port of New York. It was loosened only by the coming of container ships, which require vastly fewer workers to unload. But because of the guaranteed annual wage Mr. Gleason won for his members, hundreds of them collect as much as $32,000 a year for doing nothing. ''We got everything we fought for,'' Mr. Gleason said.

title: THE SOUNDS OF SUMMER
description: ABALMY SUMMER EVENING AT the Tanglewood Music Festival - seated comfortably in the Shed or stretched out luxuriously on the lawn, listening to great music played by the Boston Symphony Orchestra - counts as one kind of heaven for a lover of classical music. Tanglewood, which got under way this weekend and begins a four-year 50th-birthday celebration this summer, is America's prototypical summer music festival. It's not our oldest - Hollywood Bowl, where the Los Angeles Philharmonic holds forth, dates back to 1922, and this is the 52d summer the Chicago Symphony has played at the Ravinia Festival in suburban Highland Park. But Tanglewood, with its school and its grand tradition, can rightly claim to be the spiritual grandfather, the best example we have in this country of the ritualistic and spiritual origins of the festival ideal.

title: Volunteers Are Sought For Test of AIDS Drug
description: New tests on the AIDS drug AZT are scheduled to begin Monday at the University of Rochester Medical Center, but officials say they need at least 100 more volunteers for the trial.

title: Dr. Donna Rosen Marries A Fellow Dentist in Jersey
description: Dr. Donna Ellen Rosen and Dr. Jeffrey Alan Sedor, both dentists, were married yesterday at the Meadowlands Hilton Hotel in Secaucus, N.J. Arthur J. Simpson, a retired judge of the Appellate Division of New Jersey Superior Court, officiated.

title: Q and A
description: Part-time Occupants Question: We live in a rent-stabilized building that was recently coverted to a co-op. We own an apartment in Florida where we spend most of each winter and fall and where we pay property tax. We have always filed Federal, state and city income tax returns from our New York address and we continue to do so.

title: AN OLD-TIME FOURTH: FLAGS, FOOD , FUN
description: It was a day for old-fashioned things: musket fire and a concert on the village green, a thundering parade on Main Street, a picnic down by the river and, in the evening, cascades of fireworks across the black velvet sky.

title: Q and A
description: Egypt Question: For a visit to Egypt between January and March, when is the weather best? Do you know of any tours with a small group under the guidance of an archeologist? -R. R. E., Salt Lake City Answer: From November to early March, the cooler winter season, is the best time to visit Egypt. Anytime between January and early March is likely to be good, with temperatures in Cairo generally in the high 60's or low 70's but often with chilly nights. The second half of March brings the hot dry and often dust-laden khamsin winds from the desert. The winds irritate the eyes, nose and mouth, and almost all parts of Egypt can suffer from them. In the winter the weather is warmer in the south than the north, getting into the 80's and 90's but again with cool nights.

title: PROCEDURES FOR WOOD PRESERVATIVES
description: EVER since the Environmental Protection Agency banned certain wood preservatives in early 1985, there has been confusion about whether it is safe for do-it-yourselfers to use any of the chemical wood preservatives still on the market.

title:
MUSIC;
AT LINCOLN CENTER, A TIME FOR EXPERIMENTING
description: LEAD: THE PEOPLE WHO RUN LINCOLN Center are grinning from ear to ear these days. This summer, for the first time, every hall in the complex will be active, from the huge Metropolitan Opera House to the tiny Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, creating an unmatched concentration of summertime urban art. Lincoln Center is even taking a flyer on something new by presenting a two-week festival of the avant garde and a three-concert jazz series in Alice Tully

title: THE SLOW, STYLISH REDESIGN OF SNUG HARBOR
description: IT IS NOT AS FAMOUS AS THE FERRY and it has not aroused tempers the way the one-way toll on the Verrazano Narrows Bridge has, but the struggle over Sailors Snug Harbor must still be Staten Island's epic drama. This collection of Greek Revival buildings, constructed in the 19th century as a retirement home for seamen, was almost torn down in the 1960's by the home's trustees, who wanted to replace the great row of templelike buildings with a high-rise structure; the city designated the complex a landmark, at which point the trustees went to court. They won a round, then lost a round, and then the city ended up deciding that the best way out was to purchase Snug Harbor as a park and cultural center for Staten Island. Just doing that took five years of difficult negotiations, and they merely ended the curtain raiser: more than 15 years have passed since the city took title, and that has still not been enough time to get all of the buildings, many of which had deteriorated to the point of crumbling, back into shape. * * *

title: Ethnic Diversity and Uncle Sam
description: With their American flag T-shirts, red, white and blue streamers wrapped around a tree near their picnic table and their two flags flapping in the breeze - one for the United States and one for Puerto Rico - the Velez family stood out.

title: RAGE IN SEOUL COURT OVER THE SENTENCES FOR POLICE
description: A wall of guards stood between Park Jong Ki and the policemen who tortured his son to death. As a court pronounced the policemen guilty on Saturday, Mr. Park lunged at the guards in a futile, frantic effort to reach his son's killers. Behind him, screams of rage and grief echoed in the crowded courtroom.

title: 2 Bodies Found in Hudson
description: The partly decomposed body of a man and part of another body were retrieved from the Hudson River within an hour and a half yesterday afternoon, the New York City police reported. A spokesman, Sgt. Raymond O'Donnell, said the body of a middle-aged white man was spotted at 4:56 P.M. in the river downtown at West and Watts Streets. He said the victim was 6 feet tall, weighed about 160 pounds and was dressed in blue jeans and white sneakers but shirtless. A bag was over his head and green electrical cord had been tied around his waist and legs. Earlier, at 3:35 P.M., a human torso of undetermined sex was recovered from the river off the Boat Basin at West 79th Street, the sergeant said.

title: BEATLES' REAL MESSAGE
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ENTERTAINING ANGELS: A Guide to Heaven for Atheists and True Believers. By F. Forrester Church. (Harper & Row, $13.95.) Angels, according to G. K. Chesterton, are able to fly ''because they take themselves lightly'' - unlike the devil, who, in F. Forrester Church's words, ''fell on account of his gravity.'' Taking Chesterton's statement as his motto, Mr. Church (the son and biographer of Senator Frank Church and the pastor of All Souls Unitarian Church in Manhattan) has written an extended meditation on the lightness and geniality of angels, a logical sequel to his previous work of popular theology, ''The Devil & Dr. Church.'' An unreconstructed religious liberal, Mr. Church defines angels not as odd creatures with wings, but as ''little epiphanies of the divine amidst the ordinary.'' Angels can be distinguished by ''a touch of irony, a dash of anarchy''; they allow us to stand back from the deadening routine of modern living. As such, they have little to do with the often silly and unpleasant formulations of traditionalists, surveyed at length in Mr. Church's delightful chapter ''Heaven as Hell'' (Billy Graham's combat metaphors, for example, which depict angels as ''God's dynamite'' set against ''Satan's BB guns''). As long as Mr. Church exhibits the lightness and irony he admires in angels, his book remains airborne. Occasionally, however, ''Entertaining Angels'' becomes burdened with platitudes and pop commonplaces: ''The divisions within us spring from negative self-attitude based on experience.'' In these passages, the author demonstrates that the opposite of an angel is sometimes not necessarily a devil, but a ponderous preacher.

title: Music: Summergarden, At the Modern Museum
description: THE Museum of Modern Art opens its Sculpture Garden to music each summer, and this year - on the sensible assumption that people who frequent this museum ought to be apprised of what is current in music -the ''Summergarden'' series is being undertaken jointly with the Juilliard School and the director of its contemporary music ensemble, Paul Zukofsky. The series opened Friday evening with the first of nine interesting programs, each to be given twice.

title: Inexperienced Korea Takes Bold Step Toward Democracy
description: FOR all the drama and talk of political miracles, democracy did not come to South Korea last week. Nor is it likely to come next week or the week after. Korea - accustomed to centuries of royal dynasty, Japanese colonial rule and postwar division into a Communist North and a usually authoritarian South - will need a lot more time to develop the traditions associated with modern democracies.

title: Mammals of the Deep
description: WATCHING THE WHALES Produced by the Marine Mammal Fund, Fort Mason Center, Bldg. E, San Francisco, Calif. 94123. 30 minutes. $39.95.

title: TROLLING FOR FISH ISN'T ALWAYS A DRAG
description: ALTHOUGH it doesn't appeal to everyone, trolling is sometimes the only way to catch fish consistently.

title: 'North Country': A Gallic Flavor
description: So what if a marching band from St. Paul de l'Ile aux Noix plays ''God Bless America'' or a choir from Notre Dame du Mont Carmel de Lacolle sings ''Yankee Doodle Dandy.''

title: NAVRATILOVA WINS 6TH TITLE IN ROW
description: There is a certain comfort that Martina Navratilova takes in being at Wimbledon. The grass courts are like a security blanket to keep the doubts away. The women's singles final is an appointment she has been keeping for several years, each special in its own way. It is said that only the royal family has a permanent place on Centre Court, but Navratilova may force the historians to make an exception to the rule.

title: PATRICIA LEFEVERE WED TO DR. R. A. GARDNER
description: Patricia Lefevere, a special report writer for the National Catholic Reporter in Kansas, Mo., and Dr. Richard A. Gardner, a clinical professor of child psychiatry at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, were married yesterday at their home in Tenafly, N.J. An ecumenical service was performed by the Rev. Michael Slusser, a Roman Catholic priest and a professor of theology at Duquesne University, and Rabbi Charles Davidson of Yonkers.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: THE VOICE IN THE WELL Here's a fine account of how modern poetry works. It's Laurence Lieberman on W. S. Merwin, quoted in ''W. S. Merwin: Essays on the Poetry'' (University of Illinois), edited by Cary Nelson and Ed Folsom.

title: At Soviet Rock Concert, the Beat of Security
description: The Soviet Union staged a rock concert for peace here today with several American bands and enough soldiers and plainclothes security agents on hand to secure a small city.

title: Couple Held in Theft
description: A couple arrested on a Dublin-bound plane as it was being prepared for takeoff Saturday pleaded not guilty to conspiracy charges stemming from the theft of $500,000 from the woman's invalid employer, Dorothy Wirth, Thursday night. The woman, Barbara Joyce, 44 years old, an Irish-born United States citizen and her husband, John Patrick Joyce, 36, were each ordered held in $100,000 dollars bail.

title: Cindy Connolly Becomes Bride Of David Auth
description: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More was the setting in New York yesterday for the marriage of Cindy Ann Connolly, the daughter of Dr. C.Stephen Connolly of New York and Janet Arminio Connolly of New York and Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., to David Nicholas Auth, a son of Joseph Aloysius Auth of Longmeadow, Mass., and the late Evelyn M. Auth. The Rev. Charles Auth, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. James G. Wilders.

title: LOW BASS PUTS A SPEAKER ON HIGH
description: AT ANY GIVEN TIME, there are a few speakers that are widely acknowledged to approach the real sound of music more closely than the rest. Such models are usually sought out by professional recording engineers to monitor and evaluate their work. They are also coveted by knowledgeable audiophiles undeterred by cost in their search for the possible best. Among the small cadre of such speakers, the KEF Model 107 has recently gained prominence, along with the top models of such companies as B & W and ADS.

title: INSIDE
description: Paying for the Pope's Visit Catholic leaders are staging dinners, selling books and china and asking for donations to meet the $20 million cost of John Paul II's visit. Page 12.

title: MISS ROSEN, TUFTS ALUMNA, TO MARRY STEVEN S. STERN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Rosen of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Jane Rosen, to Steven Scott Stern, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Stern of New York.

title: PUBLIC SCULPTURE RUFFLES EAST HAMPTON SCENE
description: LEAD: THE installation of 13 pieces of sculpture on the grounds of the East Hampton Town Hall has created a dispute between the town's sizable artistic community and some residents who believe that government sponsoring of public art is inappropriate.

title: 6-METER SAILS BACK INTO VIEW
description: Each weekend on Long Island Sound, a small group of yachtsmen gather for any sort of racing they can organize. Sometimes they use hand-held radios to set an imaginary starting line between an anchored fishing boat and a smokestack on shore. Sometimes they simply spend their time trying out new sails, or speed-testing their boats.

title: Drug-Testing Measure Is Vetoed in Rochester
description: Mayor Thomas P. Ryan Jr. has vetoed a controversial bill that would have made Rochester the second municipality in the nation to regulate drug testing in the workplace.

title: D.E.P. GETS $42 MILLION, BUT A CRISIS IS SEEN FOR '88
description: LEAD: THE NEW state budget that was adopted last week gave Helen Fenske, assistant commissioner for natural resources in the Department of Environmental Protection, most of what she wanted -but only for the short term.

title: LILCO AND FOES HARDEN VIEWS ON CRISIS RESPONSE
description: LEAD: DIVERGENT views on how the Long Island public would respond to news of an accident at the Shoreham nuclear power plant were offered last week by the Long Island Lighting Company and officials of Suffolk County and New York State.

title: AT A DEALMAKER'S DELI, THE LOX COMES WITH YACHTS
description: IN April, Irwin L. Jacobs, the feared corporate raider and sometime greenmailer, became the nation's most unlikely delicatessen owner. He began pitching pastrami for a simple, although not necessarily obvious, reason. He did it to sell boats.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
HISTORIC PLAYLAND
description: LEAD: IN the 1920's, Rye Beach Amusement Park and neighboring Paradise Park attracted seedy, rowdy and raucous crowds. Rye residents petitioned the County Parks Commission to purchase and develop the land. The commission, according to county literature, set about creating an ''unequaled seaside public park to provide clean, wholesome recreation for the people of Westchester County''; in 1928,

title:
GARDENING;
DAY LILLIES AND IRISES: DIVIDE AND REPLANT
description: LEAD: HAVING just placed an order with a West Coast nursery for bearded iris, it came as a shock to read on the acknowledgement card that they would be shipped within a few weeks for planting. It isn't that I didn't know that they might arrive in late July, but rather I wondered how the season had gone by so fast.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
ART
description: LEAD: The Greek Temple Produced and directed by Hans-Joachim Hossfeld. Kartes Video. 54 minutes. $14.95. For pure information, this 1969 documentary is beyond reproach. The development of the Greek temple is admirably outlined with the use of models, drawings and location photography.

description: Elizabeth Anne Ruppel, a vice president in the retirement services department at Prudential-Bache Securities in New York, and Peter Charles Weinberg, a vice president in the financial advisory group of the Bankers Trust Company in New York, plan to be married Aug. 29.

description: Laura Elizabeth English, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. English of Chatham, N.J., was married yesterday to Charles Joseph Zmijeski, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Zmijeski of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Robert Drew Simpson performed the ceremony at the Chatham United Methodist Church.

description: THEY SAY HE'S A natural. He's got the Jack Kennedy hairdo, he's got the Jimmy Carter teeth, he's got the Ronald Reagan sincerity.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE you are, walking down the street thinking you look pretty wonderful, and you meet a friend who tells you you look pretty wonderful, and you begin to feel really wonderful. Then it happens. A few blocks farther on, another friend crosses your path, gives you a quick glance and announces that you're not looking so hot and maybe you've been working too hard.

title: MISS FLEMISTER TO MARRY REID WHITLOCK
description: Announcement has been made by Graciela Flemister of New York and the Rev. Carl E. Flemister of New York and Exton, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter Grace Angela Flemister to Reid E. Whitlock, the son of Valerie Whitlock of Charlotte, N.C.

title: THINKING ABOUT THE CRITIC
description: THINKING ABOUT THE PLAYWRIGHT Comments From Four Decades. By Eric Bentley. 364 pp. Evanston, Ill.: Northwestern University Press. Cloth, $38.95. Paper, $14.95.

title: A Pound of Brie, a Jug of Wine and Bargains
description: On a recent visit to Los Angeles, in between the requisite touring around town, my hostess-cum-driver pulled up at a scenic view in the Hollywood hills and produced a picnic lunch that would have done credit to Fortnum & Mason. There was a delectable pate, crusty bread, a French brie ripened to perfection and a bottle of deliciously dry white wine. Dessert was a choice of fresh fruit or killer chocolate cake. Impressed, I inquired as to the source of this magnificent spread.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE long-dormant Office of Public Participation in the state's Department of Environmental Protection was reopened late last month, a year after the fateful decision that convinced the department it needed the office.

title: Fred Astaire on the Stairway to Paradise
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Wilmington, Del.; Condo Tower Fails to Draw
description: THE market for high-rise luxury urban living is proving hard to establish in this corporate community of 70,000, the largest city in Delaware.

title: The Night the Satellite Flew
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago this week, Telstar I, an experimental satellite not much larger than a beach ball, was tossed into an awkward, elliptical orbit. By the standards of modern communications satellites, it was a crude device, functional for only a few minutes a day and capable of handling a limited number of one-way telephone and television signals.

title: LET'S NOT WRITE OFF LATIN AMERICA
description: LEAD: Brazil's unilateral decision in February to suspend interest payments on its debt brought about a chain reaction of events, including the decision by Citibank, followed by Chase Manhattan and other United States banks, to increase their loan loss reserves. Bank analysts, shareholders and Government regulators have praised the banks, and many observers seem to feel that at long last banks are taking their heads out of the sand and recognizing the inevitable.

title: A Shrewd Mitterrand Rises Above the Fray
description: AS the plotting and scheming about next year's presidential election begins, France seems to be edging back toward the system of shifting coalitions that many here thought had been eliminated when Charles de Gaulle created the near-monarchical presidency of the Fifth Republic in 1958.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think I will be recorded in history as a person who made a substantial contribution to the democratic development of this country.'' - Roh Tae Woo, chairman of the ruling party in South Korea. [ 8:1. ]

title:
DANCE;
EXPERIMENT IS WILLIAM FORSYTHE'S FORTE
description: LEAD: FOR WILLIAM FORSYTHE, ''manipulating the language of ballet to see how far it can go before its becomes unrecognizable'' is a guiding principle. While the artistic director of the Frankfurt Ballet - who is considered by many to be among the world's leading ballet choreographers - has a reverence for the past, it in no way inhibits his experimentation with what he calls ''the extremes of form.

title: 15 Wounded on West Bank In Bombing at a Restaurant
description: A bomb exploded in an Arab restaurant frequented by Israelis in the West Bank town of Kalkilya today, wounding 15 people, an army spokesman said.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: UNFAMILIARITY can put stars in your eyes. After decades of driving along Sunrise Highway and Merrick Road and North Village Avenue, I'm bored with them. The stores change, and occasionally a new building goes up, but the overall appearance seems pretty much the same.

title: The Big Push for Pentagon Dollars
description: AMID the roar and searing heat of metal-working machinery, Rosemary Ruiz watches carefully as workers at her company in Orange, Calif., hammer out aluminum parts for some of the nation's most sophisticated military aircraft and missiles. In another factory a dozen miles north of here, Oswaldo Llamas talks proudly about the cockpit canopies and windows his company has built for jets, including the U-2 spy plane.

title: Massachusetts Town Objects To Air Force Plans for Tower
description: About 200 residents have passed two resolutions against the Air Force's plan to build a military communications tower here that would be part of a nationwide network to be used in a nuclear war.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: CATHEDRAL OF THE AUGUST HEAT. By Pierre Clitandre. Translated by Bridget Jones. (Readers International/Persea, Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $8.95.) This first novel by Pierre Clitandre, a Haitian journalist now living in this country, is short but extremely ambitious. It combines elements of Creole folklore and naturalism with various modernist techniques in an attempt to express the collective consciousness of Haiti's poorest residents from the shantytowns of the late 1970's.

title: Time to Hang Up the Old Sports Cliches
description: AMERICANS are, on the whole, simple and direct people. We do not incline toward nuances or subtleties, in either our lives or our work. We opt inevitably for the concrete over the abstract. We are also extremely competitive, relishing opponents' losses as we boast of our own victories. For these reasons, sports are not only our favorite form of entertainment but the principal model and metaphor for our own lives.

title: FIVE NORTHERN TOWNS TO SELECT A TRASH SITE
description: AFTER months of grappling with residents' questions and opposition, seven northern Westchester towns are pushing ahead with plans to ease their growing garbage-removal problems.

title: LYNETTE BARD IS MARRIED
description: The marriage of Lynette Anne Bard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald V. Bard of Elkins, W.Va., and Tarpon Springs, Fla., to Paul Stuart Rix took place yesterday at the Davis and Elkins College Chapel in Elkins. The Rev. Meade Gutshall performed the United Methodist ceremony. The bridegroom, a computer consultant in New York, is the son of Mrs. John Merlini of Tonbridge, Kent, England, and the late Thomas Rix. The bride is design director for the Power Sportswear line, a division of Harvey Marcus Ltd. in New York.

title: 'DREADED' BIRTHDAY SPICES MUSICAL
description: PEOPLE who have chuckled over the verses of Judith Viorst - or who understand the trauma of turning 40 -may enjoy ''Happy Birthday and Other Humiliations,'' a new, bouncy musical with an all-female cast that uses the poems of Mrs. Viorst as a text for its songs and dialogue.

title: BLUEBERRY SEASON REACHES ITS PEAK
description: AT THE 4,000-acre farm of the Atlantic Blueberry Company here, 2,000 pickers and packers and 190 field and road vehicles are scurrying among the 1.5 million bushes, working against time to harvest one of agriculture's most highly perishable short-lived crops.

title: SCUFFING UP THE RULE ON ILLEGAL PITCHES
description: BOBBY BROWN, president of the American League, recently wrote a letter to Rick Rhoden, the Yankee pitcher, warning him that his suspected practice of scuffing the baseball in order to improve the movement of his pitches was a violation of major league rule 8:02. To wit:

title: MERICK HOME FOR THE AUTISTIC OPPOSED
description: LEAD: MUCH to the consternation of its Merrick neighbors, PLUS Group Homes Inc. of Uniondale is planning to open a home for 10 autistic adults at 1817 Willis Avenue. The neighbors have asked the Town of Hempstead to go to court to stop the project.

title: Shirley Released
description: ONE month after they signed him, the Kansas City Royals gave Bob Shirley, the former Yankee pitcher, his release and activated Bud Black, who had been on the disabled list after undergoing arthroscopic surgery on his knee. Shirley was signed by the Royals June 5 after he was released by the Yankees. He appeared in three games and gave up 12 runs in seven and one-third innings for a 14.73 earned run average.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: FRIDAY NIGHT JAZZ ON L.I.

title: MOVIES
description: It's Always Fair Weather Starring Gene Kelly, Cyd Charisse, Dan Dailey, Michael Kidd, Dolores Gray. Directed by Gene Kelly and Stanley Donen. 1955. MGM/UA Home Video. 102 minutes. $29.95.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: IN THE PARKS

title: A 'Nation of Tenants'?
description: As partner in charge of Coudert Brothers' Japan practice, Arthur M. Mitchell, an American, advises Japanese and American companies on the intricacies of doing business in each other's countries. Last week, Mr. Mitchell, who attended the International Christian University in Tokyo, spoke with Kyle Crichton, the Business Forum editor, about the rise in Japanese investment here.

title: Parents at Work
description: 'Men are changing in what they want to be a part of in their lives. It ought to be a macho idea: Real men support child care and parental leave. Put it on a bumper sticker. Real men care about their kids.'

title: ALBANIA PLANNING WEST GERMAN TIES
description: The Communist leadership of Albania, moving gradually out of a long period of self-imposed isolation, will establish diplomatic ties with West Germany this month, according to officials in Bonn and Washington.

title: A BAD WEEK IN THE 60'S BREEDS A COMEDY IN THE 80'S
description: TO A COUPLE OF OUT-OF-work actors fed up with city life, poverty and the drugged-out debauchery of London in the final days of the 1960's, the advertisement in the Sunday paper sounded enticing. ''Idyllic country retreat for hire,'' it read. ''Get away and soothe yourselves.''

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Wilmington, Del.; Condo Tower Fails to Draw
description: THE market for high-rise luxury urban living is proving hard to establish in this corporate community of 70,000, the largest city in Delaware.

title: FOR SPECIAL NEEDS
description: LAST month I had a chance to shoot two rolls of a remarkably speedy new color film, Konica SR-V3200. As the name suggests, it has an ISO/ASA rating of 3200. To put that speed in meaningful terms, it is a full five stops faster than garden-variety 100-speed film.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
A MOUNTAIN'S RIGHT TO BE
description: LEAD: I flinch at calling Charles Bowden a nature writer, a conservationist, an ecologist. As a writer he is so much more than the sum of his titles. His prose trembles with a raw and vital energy that I find missing from much current writing about the vital questions of wildness and wilderness. FROG MOUNTAIN BLUES (University of Arizona, $19.95) is part bitterness, part lament, a love story and a tragedy.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: ONCE, A LOTUS GARDEN: And Other Stories. By Jessica Saiki. (New Rivers Press/Talman, Paper, $7.95.) When you want to explain something that can't easily be explained, there is a kind of story you can tell, almost without plot, almost like a sketch. It is this kind of story Jessica Saiki tells in ''Once, a Lotus Garden: And Other Stories,'' her first collection.

title: Added Cost In Selling A Co-op
description: WITHIN the past year many sellers of New York City cooperative apartments have been finding out - to their chagrin - that a sizable chunk of the proceeds from a sale may have to be surrendered in taxes and fees. On a $500,000 apartment, for example, the new costs could come to $20,000 or more.

title: Miss Lawrence to Wed Marc D. Zegans
description: A Sept. 6 wedding is planned by Jennifer Faith Lawrence and Marc David Zegans, who received masters' degrees last month from Harvard University, she in business administration and he in public policy. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Eli S. Lawrence of Ambler, Pa., and Dr. and Mrs. Leonard S. Zegans of San Francisco.

title: Whistle-Blowers And the Law
description: Our law firm represents executives and managers who have been discharged by their corporate employers (About Men, ''A Whistle-Blower,'' by Don Rosendale, June 7). We hear Mr. Rosendale's story frequently. There are some things discharged whistle-blowers should know.

title: Ballet: The Bolshoi Offers a Program of Excerpts
description: THE Bolshoi Ballet played its trump card Friday night - it put a dazzling array of star-quality young dancers on display in one of its celebrated smorgasbord programs, and triumphed.

title: THEIR NEMESIS IN SEOUL
description: PRISON WRITINGS By Kim Dae Jung. Translated by Choi Sung-il and David R. McCann. 333 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $25.

title: MISHA DICHTER PREPARES FOR A CARAMOOR ANNIVERSARY
description: A SLIGHT breeze riffles the Waccabuc trees, a dog romps in the wooded yard and Misha Dichter, the pianist, looks like a happy man.

title: Fred Astaire on Video
description: The video cassette industry has not been laggard in putting the late Fred Astaire's films on tape. Most of them have been issued and reissued over the last few years and most are ''in print'' -if that is the proper term for video. However, as with all ''catalogue'' videos, as opposed to the latest releases, finding a particular title in a particular video store is more problematical. The following list of titles, drawn from the Video Source Book, covers most of the films that have been issued on cassette. It is organized under the names of the distributors, although none of them deals directly with the public; you'll have to order through your video store. The films in which Mr. Astaire, who died June 22, was teamed with Ginger Rogers are marked with an asterisk. As far as could be determined, the last Rogers-Astaire film, ''The Barkleys of Broadway,'' has not been released for home video.

title: PROBLEMS FOR AGRICULTURAL COLLEGE
description: THE University of Connecticut was established in 1881 as an agricultural school, but some Connecticut farmers say the school is now ignoring its roots.

title: The Pieces Are in Place For Affirmative Action
description: THE Rev. Jesse Jackson did not mince words. Unless baseball started hiring more blacks and more Hispanic people in managerial jobs on and off the field, he warned in May, there might be a boycott of major league games on the Fourth of July.

title: KAREN LOUISE BALDWIN PLANS TO WED RICHARD ERVIN ZIMMERMAN ON OCT. 3
description: Karen Louise Baldwin and Richard Ervin Zimmerman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ervin Zimmerman of Chapel Hill, N.C., plan to marry Oct. 3, the future bride's parents, Mrs. Frederic Houston Williams of New York and Cedric Benjamin Baldwin of Honolulu, have announced.

title: Notes On a Brief Campaign
description: Until I read Peter Tauber's article ''Notes on a Brief Campaign'' (May 31), I still had some lingering thoughts about Gary Hart's qualifications: could it be that we lost a good Presidential candidate because of a quirky love-nest situation?

title: RECALLING THE GHOSTS OF TRAINS GONE BY
description: LEAD: CHARLES NEESON of Yonkers is never quite sure when it might happen, just where. He will be inside B. Altman's department store at the corner of Bloomingdale Road and Westchester Avenue in White Plains, waiting patiently while Catherine, his wife of 42 years, browses in linens or housewares.

title: Barbie Found Guilty of Crimes Against Humanity
description: For many, the two-month trial of Klaus Barbie was also ''the trial of France,'' a forum for confronting old questions about the guilt of Vichy collaborators as well as of Gestapo torturers.

title: Senate Liberals Will Try to Block Nominee on Ideological Grounds
description: WITH the direction of the Supreme Court, the Reagan legacy and the Democratic Presidential nomination all in play, the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork portends the biggest ideological battle of President Reagan's second term. It will also be the major test of modern times on an issue as old as the Republic: Is the Senate's ''advice and consent'' role a mandate to reject a Presidential nominee to the Court because it dislikes his ideology?

title: Photography
description: The most obvious message of ''Portrayals,'' an exhibition of recent portrait photography at the ICP/Midtown gallery (77 West 45th Street), is that the single image no longer suffices. When it comes to portraying someone - even someone as recognizable and well known as the artist Alex Katz - it apparently helps to have a number of pictures competing for our attention. This is not only true of the portrait photographs of Neil Winokur, who brings us Mr. Katz in a totem of six images, but also of the work of Ellen Brooks, Nancy Hellebrand and JoAnn Verberg, whose pictures are divided into as many as six panels.

title: THE PURSUIT OF CORPORATE DEVELOPMENT
description: LEAD: TRANS WORLD AIRLINES, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines and Deloitte Haskins & Sells. In recent days each of these three companies has indicated that it intends to or is considering moving its Manhattan offices to Westchester County.

title: BACK TO SCHOOL
description: ''Puleeeze, Dad, get a move on! If you don't get your act together, you're going to be late for school.'' Reveille in a number of Westchester households next spring could sound something like that.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: REALISM, WRITING, DISFIGURATION: On Thomas Eakins and Stephen Crane. By Michael Fried. (Chicago, $29.95.) Despite its enigmatic and off-putting title, this pair of essays on two Americans, a painter and a writer, who at first glance would appear to have little in common except their ''realism,'' turns out to be incisive, revealing, frequently fascinating.

title: Gauging Value of an '87 College Degree
description: THE class of 1987 has now departed the campuses, to start jobs or to start looking.

title: PEACE BREAKS OUT ON TROUBLED METS
description: The dissension that surfaced on the Mets again here Friday will be put in the past, according to the three players involved - Darryl Strawberry, Lee Mazzilli and Wally Backman.

title: NOW HEAD SETS AGENDA
description: FOUR years after the publication of Betty Friedan's watershed ''Feminine Mystique'' in 1963, Ed Lesen was having a tough time carrying out his duties as a junior high school counselor in Brooklyn.

title: A Vote for Hill
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: KOREAN WAR: MEMORIES, BUT ...
description: NEARLY 34 years have elapsed since the end of the Korean War, but for Eli S. Belil, memories still linger.

title: Add the Pettys To Celebrity List
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A FEAST FROM THE CAN: HONORS FOR SPAM AT 50
description: Revelers here are paying tribute this weekend to a slice of Americana that somehow never made its way into a Norman Rockwell painting.

title: American Pie
description: TIME WAS, A COOK'S SKILL was measured by the lightness of her crust and the flavor of her fillings. Flaky crusts fell apart at a fork's touch, fillings bubbled through domed crusts or quivered under piles of meringue. ''Can she bake a cherry pie?'' was the ultimate test of a woman's skills. All that changed when pie-crust mix and frozen pies freed women from the kitchen. In restaurants, of course, Americans nibbled at dainty French pastries.

title: Win One for the Buddha
description: GEORGE PLIMPTON, patrician pyrotechnician, brilliant editor of The Paris Review, author of numerous volumes of what is called new journalism, has written a funny, knowing and poignant first novel that, like the split-fingered fastball, moves in ways finally astonishing to behold. Indeed, ''The Curious Case of Sidd Finch'' has precisely the properties of any superbly effective pitch - it describes a trajectory at once elegant and duplicitous, lulling the reader, dug-in and alert, into trusting what he thinks he sees, until the predictable turns mysterious, and suddenly what seemed simple is revealed as multilayered, oblique, unique, a pattern complete. It is called a strike.

title: THE HARTMAN DESERVES ANOTHER CHANCE
description: I HELPED kill the Hartman Theater, and I'm sick about it. I didn't pull the trigger; the Hartman Board of Trustees did that the first week of June.

title: ALL THINGS TO ALL JEFFERSONIANS
description: LEAD: THOMAS JEFFERSON A Strange Case of Mistaken Identity. By Alf J. Mapp Jr. Illustrated. 487 pp. Lanham, Md.: Madison Books. $22.95.

title: Making Arms
description: To the Editor:

title: Prohibition on Homosexual Ministers Faces a Test
description: The United Methodist Church, citing a church law passed three years ago, has begun the process of defrocking a minister because she has acknowledged she was a practicing lesbian.

title: ARMY CORPS ACTS ON WETLANDS
description: LEAD: AN attempt by two property owners to place debris and fill on wetlands in Suffolk County has caused environmentalists to intensify criticism that New York State pays inadequate attention to the East End's environmental concerns. Further embarrassing the Department of Environmental Conservation is that if these wetlands are saved from destruction, it will be because of the intervention of the Army Corps of

title: WIN ONE FOR THE BUDDHA
description: THE CURIOUS CASE OF SIDD FINCH By George Plimpton. 275 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $14.95.

title: BRITISH FURHISHINGS AT THE MET
description: BRITISH CABINETMAK-ers and silversmiths traveled an impressive distance between 1770 and 1840 - going from understated neoclassicism to unrestrained eclecticism. Artisans borrowed freely from the ancients, embellishing chairs, chests and candlesticks with scrolls, urns, sphinxes and winged griffins, all of which can be seen in a redesigned English decorative arts gallery at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: LISA JANE MELONE TO BECOME BRIDE
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Melone of Short Hills, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Lisa Jane Melone to Robert C. Cloughen Jr., the son of Mr. Cloughen of Boynton Beach, Fla., and Dolores Cloughen of West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: FROM ENGLAND
description: THE British are coming. Gieves & Hawkes, the Savile Row tailor, is planning to open about 30 shops throughout this country by fall. The sites have not been chosen yet. Suits, sport coats, dinner clothes, topcoats and overcoats will be produced by Hickey-Freeman in its Rochester plant. Suits will cost from $800 to $1,000, and for about 10 percent more they can be made to measure. The shops will also carry British-made accessories, including umbrellas ($95), shirts ($85), ties ($35) and watches ($480). More than 200 years old, Gieves & Hawkes began as a naval and military outfitter. Last year it dressed Prince Andrew for his wedding to Sarah Ferguson. Its styles are classic and traditional.

title: GOVENOR PONDERING CONSUMER MEASURE
description: A BILL that would make it more difficult to sue manufacturers when their products cause harm has been passed by the Legislature and sent to Governor Kean.

title: Accused of Killing Husband, A Jailed L.I. Woman Is Dead
description: A 71-year-old woman who was being held at the Nassau County jail on charges of killing her 76-year-old husband died of a heart attack today, the police said.

title: Next Week; How Should Mets Handle The Rifts on Their Team?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: The Old West
description: To the Editor: In April 1983 I took a research trip to Wyoming and visited many of the sites mentioned in ''Staking a Claim in the Old West of the Pioneers.'' I must say that my impressions were very different from those expressed in your paper.

title: Florida Doctor Action Cuts Emergency Care
description: Hospitals scaled back services after doctors protesting spiraling malpractice insurance rates refused to work in emergency rooms for the holiday weekend.

title: A Curfew for Karin
description: THE FIRST TIME SHE LEFT HOME, I thought it was a joke, but it wasn't. I am one of those divorced fathers - call me insecure, call me frivolous - who likes to make a jest of everything. So when my 17-year-old announced she was leaving to stay in the other (and pricier) part of town with a close friend of my ex-wife's, I quipped, ''Sure. If I'd known, I'd have bought you Louis Vuitton luggage.''

title: NET STARS CONVERGE ON LIVINGSTON
description: WHEN a 17-year-old amateur is playing in his first high-level tennis tournament against seasoned professionals, things may get a little out of focus for him.

title: WATER TO GO ANYWHERE UNDER THE SUN
description: WELCOME to the age of designer water. Designer water? It's a clear liquid that has bubbled up and landed right smack in our midst as a bona fide fashion accessory.

title: No Place Like Home, Even on a Yacht
description: WHEN Robert Walther returns home from work each day, his wife, Narissa, never greets him at the front door. Instead, she greets him at the gangplank.

title: People Stress: Day in the Life of A Hectic Haven
description: BY 11 o'clock on a typical weekend summer morning in Rocky Mountain National Park, all 820 campsites are filled. More than 1,000 people are clambering up Longs Peak, the park's highest mountain at 14,255 feet. About 500 visitors are filling the parking lot at Bear Lake and hundreds of others are arriving on a shuttle bus supplied by the National Park Service.

title: IN QUEST OF HAWAII'S AUTHENTIC HULA
description: KAU'I ZUTTERMEISTER SPOKE softly as she described the chants and classical hula of her Hawaiian ancestors: the retelling of knowledge seen, known and felt that travels through generations in oral and dance form. ''Chanting was the language of the gods,'' Mrs. Zuttermeister said.

title: PROCEDURES FOR WOOD PRESERVTIVES
description: EVER since the Environmental Protection Agency banned certain wood preservatives in early 1985, there has been confusion about whether it is safe for do-it-yourselfers to use any of the chemical wood preservatives still on the market.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: LIVES AND TALENTS The White Plains Public Library has acquired eight hourlong video-taped documentaries about noted artists and writers of the late 19th and 20th centuries. They will be shown at 1:30 P.M. Wednesdays beginning this week through Aug. 26 at the main branch, at 100 Martine Avenue.

title: Confederate Remains Found in Mass Grave
description: Remains of Confederate soldiers from Texas who died at the Battle of Glorieta Pass have been recovered from a mass grave, and plans are being made to return them to their state.

title: FORUM: 7 Democrats Grasp for the Distinctive Answer
description: SEVEN contenders for the Democratic Presidential nomination, all trying to stand out from the pack, met in Houston Wednesday night for their first substantive - and nationally televised - exchange of opinions on public affairs. The seven invited to take part - Bruce Babbitt, the former Governor of Arizona; Senators Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee and Paul Simon of Illinois; Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts; Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, and the Rev. Jesse Jackson - replied in mostly decorous fashion to needling questions from William F. Buckley Jr., the conservative commentator who is the host on the Public Broadcasting System's ''Firing Line'' program, and sympathetic ones from Robert S. Strauss, a former national chairman of the party.

title: Recent Sales
description: Commack $279,000 66 Harned Road 5-bedroom, 5-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, 1.3 acres, guest cottage, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000. East Meadow $175,000 2685 Lexington Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 32-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,800. Northport $590,000 48 Steers Avenue 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 3-year-old contemporary; wine cellar, central air-conditioning, in-ground pool, boat slip; taxes $7,000. Port Jefferson $725,000 29 Waterview Drive 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 4-year-old colonial; 3 fireplaces, in-ground pool, 3-car garage, 1.25 acres; taxes $7,800. Ridge $130,000 40 Ridge Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 9-year-old colonial; fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $2,300. Smithtown $223,000 3 Ingram Court 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old ranch; den with fireplace, finished basement, sun deck, loft, 2-car garage; taxes $3,900. OTHER AREAS River Edge, N.J. $225,000 786 Oak Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old contemporary; fireplace, hardwood floors, central air-conditioning, den; taxes $2,436. Thornwood, N.Y. $281,500 Bellview Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 17-year-old clapboard raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, in-law apartment, 0.32 acre; taxes $3,000. West Haven, Conn. $340,000 6 Woody Crest 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 85-year-old colonial; direct waterfront, remodeled; taxes $2,490.

title: Some Old Echoes In New Questions About Meese
description: Questions about the legality and propriety of the connections between Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and the Wedtech Corporation became more pointed last week with the release of a document suggesting that Mr. Meese has misrepresented his personal financial holdings.

title: POSTINGS: 27-Story Tower; Queens Condos
description: A condominium tower with amenities typical of expensive new apartment buildings in Manhattan is coming to Queens.

title: NEW YORK BACK-OFFICE JOB SURGE HAS PITFALLS
description: The New York region is spawning thousands of back-office jobs that provide new opportunity for young and relatively unskilled workers. But experts warn that this is a precarious boom: these are jobs that could be moved elsewhere, phased out through technology or cut abruptly in a business downturn.

title: SNEERING HIS WAY TO THE TOP
description: HIS BUTLER'S STORY By Edward Limonov. Translated by Judson Rosengrant. 346 pp. New York: Grove Press. $17.95.

title: JANINE M. LINDEN TO MARRY OCT. 24
description: The engagement of Janine M. Linden to Samuel Lewis Gordon Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gordon of Hartsdale, N.Y., and New Haven, Vt., has been announced by the future bride's father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. M. F. Mager of New York and Casey Key in Nokomis, Fla. The couple plan to marry on Oct. 24.

title: ATHLETE PICKS WORSHIP OVER GLORY
description: AS one of the team's best players, Maurice (Mo) Edwards could well have been one of Saturday's heroes for the Hartford Public High School football team for the last four years. Although he was a member of the team and practiced all week, he never played in a game on Saturday.

title: PROSPECTS
description: ESOP's Edge Up

title: U.S. AGENCY SEEKS WIDE RULE CHANGES ON NURSING HOMES
description: Under pressure from Congress, the Department of Health and Human Services is proposing a sweeping revision of Federal rules for nursing homes to improve the quality of care and the protection of patients' rights.

title: ROBIN GALLAGHER WED TO MATTHEW HOFFMAN
description: Robin Jane Gallagher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rayworth Gallahger of Scarborough, N.Y., and Matthew Thomas Hoffman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Peter Hoffman of Winnetka, Ill., were married yesterday at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Scarborough by the Rev. D.Williams McClurken. The bride, until recently a product manager for Nabisco Brands Inc., graduated from Tufts University and received an M.B.A. degree from the University of Chicago. Her father retired as president of the North American Reassurance Corporation in New York.

title: Ocean Pier Collapses; 16 in N. Carolina Hurt
description: A section of a pier jammed with revelers watching a Fourth of July fireworks show collapsed tonight, plunging about 40 people into the ocean and injuring at least 16, officials and witnesses said.

title: MCCULLOUGH IN 3-WAY TIE FOR LEAD IN CANADA
description: Mike McCullough, a 42-year-old native of Ohio now living in Arizona, has spent 16 years on the PGA Tour without a victory - longer than any other active non-winner.

title: 'Civilianizing' Seoul; Washington Delivers a Quiet Nudge
description: THERE was a heady feeling at the State Department last week as officials professed satisfaction with the role they played as South Korea moved toward democracy. For many policymakers, the euphoria recalled their good feelings 16 months ago after ''people power'' triumphed in the Philippines.

title: 125 ARE REPORTED KILLED IN ZAIRE TRAIN ACCIDENT
description: A trailer-truck crashed into a train at an unguarded crossing in southeastern Zaire this week, killing 125 people and injuring an unknown number of others, officials said today. It was believed to be the worst train accident in African history.

title: 'It's Incredible,' Barbie Says Of His Verdict and Sentence
description: Klaus Barbie, the wartime Gestapo chief here, found it unbelievable that he was convicted of crimes against humanity and sentenced to life in prison, a defense lawyer said today.

title: NEW AT CARAMOOR: JAZZ
description: THERE are certainly enough summer events to satisfy the most ardent music lover. Still, the warm weather sometimes brings out the wanderlust in us, and it might be well to consider two major festivals across the Westchester County border.

title: Artists and Profits
description: To the Editor:

title: Thriving Light Verse
description: To the Editor:

title: Still on the Outside Looking In
description: JOSE ARRIOLA is angry. It seems as if every time he turns around, he hears of another major corporation that wants to do more business with minority-owned companies. Or of another conference aimed at bringing minority businessmen together with corporate purchasing agents.

title: Correction
description: A dispatch last Sunday from Corpus Christi, Tex., about the convention of the League of United Latin American Citizens misstated the Hispanic percentage of the nation's population. It is 7.2 percent.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: OPEN ROAD: A Celebration of the American Highway, by Phil Patton. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $7.95.) Phil Patton's account of highway history is an ''intriguing'' and ''lovely little book,'' Karal Ann Marling said in The Book Review in 1986. The author deals with nostalgic roadside America as well as with ''roadways as expressive entities in their own right.'' But he is at his best, she said, on the subject of ''the mighty interstate, the coast-to-coast system of divided highways begun in earnest under President Eisenhower on the utopian model of the German Autobahn.'' BABY, IT'S COLD INSIDE, by S. J. Perelman. (Penguin, $6.95.) Parody is a nearly lost art, Eudora Welty said in The Book Review in 1970, and ''the only writer I know who can save it is the author of this book.'' In a collection of 32 pieces, most of them originally published in The New Yorker in the 1960's, S. J. Perelman sends up Joycean scholarship (''Anna Trivia Pluralized''), the humiliation of the American tourist in London (''Let a Snarl Be Your Umbrella'') and the medical profession in the person of Dr. Morris Prognose and his ''sumptuous'' assistant, Miss Bustanoby. The same publisher has reissued two more Perelman collections ($6.95 each). THE RISING GORGE displays ''a profound gift for derangement (or a gift for profound derangement),'' Gilbert Millstein said here in 1961. Subjects include a correspondence with the Busy Bee Cleaners, entitled ''Eine Kleine Mothmusik.'' THE SWISS FAMILY PERELMAN, a book of voyages including illustrations by Al Hirschfeld, is ''a gallimaufry of harrowing descriptions of battles with the elements, and with merchants, waiters, fellow-passengers, Mrs. Perelman, and customs officials, to name a few,'' Rex Lardner said here in 1950. THE MIND OF A MNEMONIST: A Little Book About a Vast Memory, by A. R. Luria. (Harvard University, $7.95.) The Soviet psychologist Aleksandr R. Luria (1902-77) describes the life and personality of a man (known as ''S'') who was found to have a literally limitless memory and whose burden was that he was able to forget things only by an act of will. In 1968, one reviewer said the work had an ''almost Kafka-like quality,'' and another found it ''fascinating and delightful.'' The same publisher has reissued THE MAN WITH A SHATTERED WORLD: The History of a Brain Wound ($7.95), Luria's study of a young soldier who suffers a catastrophic head injury and has to relearn almost everything. In 1973 one reviewer called it an intriguing and ''valuable review of the strange but precise working of the brain.'' Both are translated by Lynn Solotaroff. SOCIAL DISEASE, by Paul Rudnick. (Ballantine, $6.95.) Guy Huber and his fashionable wife, Venice, loft-living darlings of the club scene, have been voted one of the 10 most visible couples in New York, but tragedy strikes when Guy's parents insist he get a job. While Paul Rudnick's satirical first novel sometimes strains too hard for its one-liners, Emily Listfield said here last year, ''there are some good laughs to be had'' and the author has ''a fine ear for conversational parody.'' A MALE CHILD, by Paul Scott. (Carroll & Graf, $3.95.) His marriage over and his health broken, Ian Canning returns to postwar England from service in India and is rescued by a friend who invites him to his family's summer home. ''The most striking and vital feature'' of Paul Scott's novel, Isabelle Mallet said here in 1957, ''is its dialogue, which is excellent, believable and economical. Some of the book reads like a lively, well-constructed play.'' WORLDLY POWER: The Making of The Wall Street Journal, by Edward E. Scharff. (Plume/New American Library, $9.95.) This history of the nation's business daily and its place in American journalism is ''a spirited, highly readable narrative'' and the first book ''to come close to doing the modern Journal justice,'' reviewers said in 1986. Another publisher, St. Martin's, has reissued TRADING SECRETS: Seduction and Scandal at The Wall Street Journal, by R. Foster Winans ($4.95), the former Journal columnist convicted on insider-trading charges after leaking advance information from his ''Heard on the Street'' column. ''Mr. Winans tells us how humiliated he feels and how sorry he is for his deeds,'' Joanne B. Ciulla said here last year, ''yet the reader never really believes him and neither, apparently, did the judge.'' A DARK-ADAPTED EYE, by Barbara Vine. (Bantam, $6.95.) Barbara Vine (a k a Ruth Rendell) weaves a tale of obsession and mayhem as her heroine explores a bygone crime - the brutal murder for which her Aunt Vera was hanged three decades earlier. ''Rendell/Vine does a masterful job of unpeeling the layers of this grim, sad tale,'' one reviewer said in 1986. THE NEMESIS AFFAIR: A Story of the Death of Dinosaurs and the Ways of Science, by David M. Raup. (Norton, $6.95.) David Raup, a paleontologist and a professor of geophysical sciences, explores the theory of periodic mass extinctions, a scenario in which comets colliding with the earth wiped out prehistoric species at regular intervals of some 26 million years. The author's account of the evolution of the theory, Jonathan Weiner said in The Book Review last year, is ''clear, low-key and good-humored.'' MAYFLOWER MADAM: The Secret Life of Sydney Biddle Barrows, by Sydney Biddle Barrows with William Novak. (Ivy Books, $4.95.) The blue-blooded author shares her experiences running a tony ''escort service'' and later being charged with promoting prostitution. Florence King said in The Book Review last year that Sydney Biddle Barrows ''offers a highly explicit but tastefully written view from the 50-yard line of what may well be the only lull in the battle of the sexes.''

title: BEST SELLERS: JULY 5, 1987
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 5 MISERY, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) Injured and drugged, an author is held captive by a psychotic fan. 2 2 8 THE HAUNTED MESA, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $18.95.) Unraveling the mystery of Indian cliff dwellers who vanished centuries ago. 3 4 4 EMPIRE, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $22.50.) Turn-of-the-century Washington, seen from the point of view of a young woman newspaper publisher. 4 10 2 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 5 6 4 PALE KINGS AND PRINCES, by Robert B. Parker. (Delacorte, $15.95.) Spenser on the trail of a major cocaine ring based in a small New England town. 6 5 4 THE TIMOTHY FILES, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam, $18.95.) A Vietnam veteran turned detective checks out dubious entrepreneurs for Wall Street firms. 7 11 49 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The West tries to stave off the Russians in World War III. 8 7 22 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $18.95.) Nightmarish experiences befall a woman appointed Ambassador to Rumania. 9 3 16 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 10 9 4 MORE DIE OF HEARTBREAK, by Saul Bellow. (Morrow, $17.95.) The many-faceted relationship of the 35-year-old narrator and his uncle, a famous botanist. 11 8 8 HEIRESS, by Janet Dailey. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) Sisters vie for their father's affection and fortune. 12 14 3 SPHERE, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $17.95.) Four scientists explore the mysteries of an alien spaceship found on the floor of the South Pacific. 13 1 WEEP NO MORE, MY LADY, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Love and murder at a swank California health spa. 14 13 2 DIRK GENTLY'S HOLISTIC DETECTIVE AGENCY, by Douglas Adams. (Simon & Schuster, $14.95.) A private eye's search for a missing cat takes him on a trip through space and time. 15 12 23 THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) A fairy tale, complete with an aged king, two princes, an evil wizard and a mouse. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 10 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A critique of liberal arts education during the past 25 years. 2 5 31 A DAY IN THE LIFE OF AMERICA. (Collins Publishers, $39.95.) The nation on May 2, 1986, as recorded in pictures by 200 photojournalists. 3 2 8 HAMMER, by Armand Hammer with Neil Lyndon. (Putnam, $22.95.) The autobiography of the octogenarian industrialist and philanthropist. 4 12 54 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations from the television star and father of five. 5 4 3 EVERYTHING TO GAIN, by Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter. (Random House, $16.95.) The former first couple tell what they're doing to make the most of the rest of their lives. 6 3 5 CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) The information - geography, history, literature, politics - that you need to read with. 7 6 19 COMMUNION, by Whitley Strieber. (Beech Tree/ Morrow, $17.95.) A professional writer tells of the visits of ''intelligent nonhumans'' to his home. 8 11 13 HOLD ON, MR. PRESIDENT! by Sam Donaldson. (Random House, $17.95.) A White House television correspondent comments on his assignment. 9 8 13 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions in treating serious illness. 10 7 5 THE DIFFERENT DRUM, by M. Scott Peck. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) A psychiatrist's prescription for personal and communal peace. 11 15 12 THIS 'N THAT, by Bette Davis with Michael Herskowitz. (Putnam, $17.95.) The actress's memories and opinions. 12 * 14 2 LIFE AND DEATH IN SHANGHAI, by Nien Cheng. (Grove, $19.95.) China's Cultural Revolution as experienced by a wealthy woman accused of spying for the West. 13 25 A SEASON ON THE BRINK, by John Feinstein. (Macmillan, $16.95.) A chronicle of one season spent with the Indiana University basketball team. 14 1 THE SPY WORE RED, by Aline, Countess of Romanones. (Random House, $18.95.) Recollections of a woman from upstate New York who served as an undercover agent in Europe during World War II. 15 13 21 THE FATAL SHORE, by Robert Hughes. (Knopf, $24.95.) Australia, from penal colony to its gradual emergence as a flourishing nation. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 95 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 2 2 5 WOMEN MEN LOVE, WOMEN MEN LEAVE, by Connell Cowan and Melvyn Kinder. (Clarkson N. Potter/Crown, $18.95.) Why men are drawn to some women and desert others. 3 4 36 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS WITH WINE, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $16.95.) Recipes to be prepared at moderate cost. 4 5 3 SIBLINGS WITHOUT RIVALRY, by Adele Faber and Elaine Mazlish. (Norton, $14.95.) Ways to cope with bickering between one's children. 5 Y 14 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) The Second College Edition of a standard work, updated in 1982. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) GEORGE C. MARSHALL: Statesman 1945-1959, by Forrest C. Pogue. (Viking, $29.95.) The fourth and final volume of the five-star general's biography is, like its subject, thoughtful, mature, balanced and full of humanity and intelligence. THE TIDEWATER TALES, by John Barth. (Putnam, $21.95.) One of our most ingenious practitioners of the literature of self-parody has written a love story - marital, filial, domestic - that is also about love of a place and a country. WHO GOES FIRST? The Story of Self-Experimentation in Medicine, by Lawrence K. Altman. (Random House, $22.50.) A fascinating and original exploration of scientific self-experimentation, by a medical reporter for The New York Times. THE BLACK CLOTH: A Collection of African Folktales, by Bernard Binlin Dadie. (University of Massachusetts, Cloth, $20; Paper, $8.95.) These 16 stories, an exquisite fusion of entertainment and ethics, demonstrate the sophisticated taste for song, epic, pun, riddle and satire of African peoples south of the Sahara. MOTHER LOVE, by Candace Flynt. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.95.) An alcoholic mother and her three daughters are the center of this exhilarating, psychologically penetrating novel about first finding and then living one's own life. JAPANESE TALES, edited and translated by Royall Tyler. (Pantheon, $19.95.) Classics without English portfolio until now, these 220 short stories date from the 13th century or earlier. ''DEMOCRACY IS IN THE STREETS'': From Port Huron to the Siege of Chicago, by James Miller. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Deprived of an institutional memory, S.D.S. lives again in this account, which emphasizes the intellectual foundations of the Port Huron Statement, the charter document of S.D.S.

title: MUSIC: A TANGLEWOOD ANNIVERSARY
description: Art has been holding its breath at the Tanglewood music festival the past few days waiting for nature to make up its mind. Poised to celebrate the opening of its 50th summer season -with balloons, streamers, banners, candles and 10,000 cupcakes - this distinguished institution of American music had been trying desparately to wish all the wetness and dark clouds away. They left this morning, but not before one final authoritative downpour issued by the seemingly forgiving gods.

title: SEASONAL RIPOSTES FOR FLORIDA VISITORS
description: AS you probably already know, something strange comes over former New Yorkers who move down to Florida. With few exceptions, these transplants see everything wrong about New York and everything right about Florida. Even when they come to visit you to escape Florida's blazing summers.

title:
ART;
PRINTS: MEDIUM AIDS MESSAGE
description: LEAD: THE most highly regarded prints are those that make the special characteristics of their medium further the intended expression. This is the strong premise behind ''The Classical Print,'' a large and rich assembly of graphics on view at the Elaine Benson Gallery in Bridgehampton.

title: A Garage Sale To End All Sales
description: IT began in 1971 as a sale in a city garage in Evanston, Ill., and word of it spread. It was not long before the sponsors were claiming a world title.

title: LAURA MECKE AND LANGFORD MIDGLEY ARE MARRIED
description: At the Episcopal Church of St. James the Less in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday, Laura Kenly Mecke, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Mecke of Hartsdale, N.Y., was married to Langford Midgley, a son of Mary Edie Midgley of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and C.Edward Midgley of Irvington, N.Y.

title: When Main Street Belongs to the Japanese
description: FROM the surge of Japanese buying on Wall Street, to Fujitsu's attempts to buy Fairchild, to Mitsui Real Estate's purchase of the Exxon headquarters in New York City, it appears that something extraordinary is going on. There is. A Japanese ''investment wave'' is breaking across the United States, bringing the possibility of greater cooperation but also the threat of a further heightening of tensions.

title: PATRICIA KAVEE, LAWYER, TO WED
description: Patricia Mignon Kavee, a lawyer, and David Lockwood Melick, a loss-prevention consultant for the Liberty Mutual Insurance Companies in New York, plan to be married in September. Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Kavee of Riverside, Conn., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of David Marvin Melick of Union City, N.J., and Arden Davis Melick of Maplewood, N.J.

title: THE BLOSSOMING OF CIVIC COALITIONS
description: WHAT is this antediluvian phenomenon, the civic association? Why are such groups re-emerging like wildflowers across Long Island?

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE MUSIC: Reflections on Jazz and Blues. By Amiri Baraka (LeRoi Jones) and Amina Baraka. (Morrow, $22.95.) Before changing his name to Amiri Baraka, the poet and playwright LeRoi Jones had established himself as an eloquent jazz critic; his 1963 study, ''Blues People: Negro Music in White America,'' is a classic. ''The Music,'' which includes warm, jazz-inspired verse by his wife Amina and poetry, essays and a play on the subject of music and musicians by Mr. Baraka himself, constitutes another chapter in his intellectual odyssey. No one doubts his ideological convictions, but those who cherish the music yearn for his old expository talents. There's nothing wrong with a political edge to music commentary, but in these pages jazz and blues epiphanies suffer the weight of endless references to racism and monopoly capitalism. A politically impassioned artist like Gil Scott-Heron is lionized, yet we learn little about the true nature of his craft and gain no more than a glimpse into the personality of a man whose message has carried, despite the times. Such praise songs and political cant give the book itself a racist tone. This is sad in view of the author's musical insights, for there is a strength to Mr. Baraka's excavations of the roots of modern forms. In the essay ''The Phenomenon of Soul in African-American Music,'' for example, he perceptively focuses on jazzmen like Horace Silver, Clifford Brown and ''others [ who ] went back to the wellspring of black music, the African-American church.''

title: William Penn Mott Jr.: Searching for the Right Balance
description: THE long-held philosophy of the National Park Service - maintain the parks as much as possible as ''a vignette of primitive America'' - has come under increasing attack. Critics charge that a lack of active intervention in natural systems within the parks has led to a serious decline in animal species such as the mule deer of Yellowstone.
