Some critics also contend that the parks have been marred by an overemphasis on tourism and an underemphasis on broader problems such as development of lands adjacent to the parks. Some of the most stinging charges have come from Alston Chase, a former teacher of philosophy at Princeton who lives in Montana and who wrote ''Playing God in Yellowstone.'' William Penn Mott Jr. is director of the National Park Service. Philip Shabecoff, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, talked with them last week. Excerpts follow.

title: A Sense of Adventure and Then Some
description: There is the lurch of the dogs as the sled slashes through snow. There is that too-sharp turn and the sudden sensation of being scattered, along with the supplies, by the side of the trail. There is the bracing grip of a late-night dip through a hole in the ice of a northern Minnesota lake.

title: TOOTING THEIR OWN HORNS
description: LEAD: THE MUSIC MEN An Illustrated History of Brass Bands in America, 1800-1920. By Margaret Hindle Hazen and Robert M. Hazen. Illustrated. 225 pp. Washington: Smithsonian Institution Press. Cloth, $39.95. Paper, $19.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE SHOEBOX OF DESIRE: And Other Tales. By Allen Woodman. Illustrated by Ross Zirkle. (Swallow's Tale Press, 736 Greenwillow Run, Wesley Chapel, Fla. 34249. Cloth, $13.95; Paper,$7.95.) The 14 stories in this slim volume, accompanied by drawings, explore the idiosyncrasies of desire. Mr. Woodman's compressed, pithy form owes more to poetry than to traditional fiction; his best tales show the ways in which ''some life stories don't have a point.

title: TAKING THE RAP FOR BENEDICT ARNOLD
description: MAJOR ANDRE By Anthony Bailey. 200 pp. New York: Michael di Capua Books/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15.95.

title: Why Your Doctor Is a Group
description: Childhood memories are often exaggerated by the passage of time, but my memories of our family doctor, Henry Ludemann of the Katonah Medical Group, correspond precisely with opinions of him given in Martha Fay's article.

title: Days of Democracy
description: The need for dissonance - the marching music of democracy - was affirmed the other day in Moscow by, of all people, Andrei Gromyko, the Soviet President. Speaking to the Supreme Soviet, the former diplomat long known as ''Old Stone Face'' pleaded for dissent. He complained that debates ''were over-organized and in many ways a formality'' and had to change. ''The times, the large-scale renewal drive and the democratization of society, demand a precisely functioning mechanism of bringing out public opinion.''

title: GEPHARDT INTENSIFIES HIS CRITICISM OF DUKAKIS
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt has stepped up his criticism of a fellow Democratic Presidential aspirant, Michael S. Dukakis, saying the Massachusetts Governor overstates his effectiveness and has not proposed anything to reduce the nation's trade imbalance.

title: VALOR COULDN'T SAVE THEM
description: EMBATTLED COURAGE The Experience of Combat in the American Civil War. By Gerald F. Linderman. Illustrated. 357 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.50.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN HONEYMOONS
description: LEAD: LAST year, in the clear skies above California's Napa Valley, some 75 couples exchanged vows aboard hot-air balloons, beginning their honeymoons with a flight over lush vineyards and rolling hills. ''Two of our pilots are ministers, and we can also provide a witness if needed,'' said Kenneth Custis, director of ground operations for Napa-based Balloon Aviation

title: WHEN THE FOURTH OF JULY WAS A (DANGEROUS) BLAST
description: DON'T get me wrong: I'm a firm advocate of a safe and sane Fourth.

title: OUR JUDGMENTS ARE OFTEN BUILT ON SAND
description: THE OTHER DAY, WHILE RAN-sacking shelves for something completely different, I came across a recording of Berio's ''Sinfonia,'' a keystone work of the 1960's avant-garde that I remember having admired and reviewed glowingly when it came out. To refresh my memory, as they say in Washington, I played it through and found it still bracingly brash and inventive. Both the braininess and the stylistic nostalgia that I remembered were there. However, I was able to recapture little of an earlier excited feeling of being in the presence of a great new work - a masterpiece, to use a word that went out of style when the Victor dog was a pup. The letdown should not have surprised me - desperately few pieces from that disturbed decade retain any sort of shine today - but it did set me thinking about the evanescent qualities that persuade a listener to value one musical work more highly than another.

title: Cook, Executive, Married to Ms. Jacoby
description: The marriage of Justine dePeyster Jacoby, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Jacoby of Boston and Peterborough, N.H., to Douglas Simpson Cook, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Cook of New York, took place yesterday at the Unitarian Church in Peterborough.

title: Linnas Death Sentence Reportedly Commuted
description: The Soviet authorities commuted the death sentence of Karl Linnas, who had been convicted in absentia as a Nazi war criminal in 1962, before his death in Leningrad last Thursday, according to Mr. Linnas's attorney and his daughter, who arrived in New York yesterday.

title: RESIDENTIAL RESALES
description: Closings in the week ended June 20 MANHATTAN Carnegie Hill $515,000 1056 Fifth Avenue 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,700-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, manned elevator, dining area, Central Park views; maintenance $876, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Dwelling Sales) East Midtown $410,000 309 East 49th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,100-sq. ft. postwar condo; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, dining area; common charge $670, taxes $2,880 (Broker:

title: The Editorial Notebook; Me I Am!
description: I am the only ME I AM who qualifies as me; no ME I AM has been before, and none will ever be.

title: Sinking Too Much in the Navy
description: Matching naval forces to missions is no easy task, as the problems in the Persian Gulf make clear. This year, the Navy is spending $95 billion, a third of the Defense budget, toward its goal of a 600-ship fleet, but it has run into an embarrassing obstacle: Money.

title: Hurdling the Land-Use Review Process
description: A NEW apartment house is under construction in Harlem just a block from the campus of City College. The nine-story building, called Logan Plaza, is at 1425 Amsterdam Avenue, between West 130th and 131st Streets.

title: HUBERT SUMLIN: HIS BLUES ARE CAUSE FOR CHEER
description: DURING THE GOLDEN AGE OF Chicago blues, two men towered over the field: Muddy Waters and Howlin' Wolf. Both of them had succeeded in adapting the deep, acoustic blues of the Mississippi Delta to the big-city style of electric guitars and amplifiers. Both were dynamic, jubilant and occasionally foreboding performers. But when it came to leading a band, their approaches could not have been more different.

title: Gimme A Breakpoint
description: WE HAVE NOW reached breakpoint,'' President Reagan told the nation in a televised address. The word was obviously chosen with deliberation; later in the speech, while launching a crusade to hold down the deficit, he repeated the word that is not yet in most dictionaries and added his definition: ''The choice is now upon each of us - as I said, we've reached breakpoint; decision time.''

title: STREET CLASHES IN KWANGJU END LULL
description: The police clashed with demonstrators here this evening in what appeared to be the first significant confrontation since the Government announced major concessions this week.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: An Umbrella Is a Thing Of Infinite Variety Zip Jack Custom Umbrella is open five days a week as a showroom and factory outlet in Elmsford, where a portion of 9A south of Route 119 is known as South Central Avenue. The company has 37 years of experience making and marketing umbrellas with domestic woods and fabrics in cafe, patio, beach, golf, children's and doorman styles.

title: MS. BLUEMLE TO MARRY TODD PURDUM IN FALL
description: Tiffany Windsor Bluemle, who received a Master of Public Administration degree last month from the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, and Todd Stanley Purdum, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times, plan to be married Nov. 7. Robert L. Bluemle of Paradise Valley and Greer, Ariz., has announced his daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry S. Purdum of Macomb, Ill.

title: Whistle-Blowers and the Law
description: Don Rosendale is being sentimental when he states that corporations are ''male-bonding fraternities'' and that is why they reject whistle-blowers.

title: AN ODD PARK IN STRATFORD, FROM TWO UNUSUAL BROTHERS
description: LEAD: WHEN Stephen and David Boothe decided in 1914 to commemorate the 250th anniversary of their family homestead in Stratford, they began by turning their hay barn into a museum.

title: EXPERT WITNESSES: BOOMING BUSINESS FOR THE SPECIALISTS
description: In the back pages of one prominent law publication after another, a string of the same eye-catching classified ads appear.

title: THE PERILS OF PUTTING OLD DISKS ON CD
description: WHEN THE COMPACT disk was introduced in 1983, doomsayers predicted that, as the LP vanished, so would a vast catalogue of classic recordings in every genre. To a degree, their fears were understandable, since it had taken decades for many treasurable 78 r.p.m. recordings to find homes on LP. And with sonic purity now a selling point, it seemed likely that many older recordings were marked for extinction. Still, most record companies understood that buyers would want a mixture of fully digital disks and analogue classics. And they quickly realized that CD reissues could be big business - that there was a demand for them, and that they were extremely profitable. Their production costs, after all, had long since been amortized. And although many catalogue items had already descended into the mid-price and budget realms on LP, the CD's could be sold at full price. Many labels decreed that any recording with a respectable sales history in its vinyl life would rise again on CD.

title: SPLENDID GLASS
description: IN SUMMERTIME, THE GOOD TABLEWARE CAN OFTEN stay in the closet because less precious objects seem more appropriate for entertaining. Brightly colored glassware, which has been popular since the invention of blown glass in the first century B.C., is one solution. Early glass was always faintly colored - either green or brown, depending on the amount of iron. But since these shades were not considered pleasing, glass was deliberately decorated or colored in stronger tones, until the Venetian glassmakers of the 15th century discovered that oxide of manganese would decolor and clarify glass, making it completely transparent. Even with the invention of clear glass, colored tableware has remained popular. During different periods, some colors have been more common than others. In America, during the 18th and early 19th centuries, for instance, blue, amber, green and purple were considered fashionable. Later, as the Victorians embraced colors and textures in design, ruby and pink glassware began appearing in households. Today, in the right setting, any color goes.

title: Vietnam Reportedly Agrees To Meeting With U.S. Envoy
description: A Vietnamese official said his Government had agreed to a meeting in Hanoi with John W. Vessey Jr., President Reagan's special envoy, to end an impasse in talks over the fate of missing American sevicemen, The Washington Post reported in its Sunday editions.

title: SHE TOOK THE AIDS TEST
description: I AM A WHITE, heterosexual female who has never used intravenous drugs. I am 36 years old, divorced, and have never knowingly ''exchanged bodily fluids'' with a bisexual.

title: NEW YORK CITY OFFICIALS CITE 22 FOOD OUTLETS FOR VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 22 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: THE NAME IS THE GAME
description: A BRIEF TOUR OF THE CLOS Du Val winery in Napa, Calif., had just ended, and Bernard Portet, who runs the place, was putting together a little tasting that included his 1981, 1982 and 1983 cabernets and something called simply 1982 Reserve ''Don't ask me what the blend in the Reserve is,'' Mr. Portet said with a grin. ''I can't remember.''

title: EXPERIENCE COUNTS
description: BRIDGE is perhaps the only competitive activity in which octogenarians, and their seniors, regularly take part in open tournaments. Insufficient stress has been laid on the advantages the game offers to retired people, who usually need to maintain the level of social contact and brain activity that they were accustomed to in their working life.

title: WESTCHESTER OPINIONLITTLE LEAGUE, BIG SIGNIFICANCE
description: SITTING on our patio the other day, I remembered why grass doesn't grow in five spots in our back yard: home plate, first, second and third base and the pitcher's mound.

title: Slain Girl's Wounded Cousin Flags Down Car to Get Help
description: A 13-year-old girl with several bullet wounds scrambled up a freeway embankment and flagged down a motorist after being left to die in the desert with her raped and murdered cousin, the authorities said Friday.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
STATUS IS STANDARD EQUIPMENT
description: LEAD: ON summer weekends, Route 27 out to the East End resembles a parking lot: a parking lot in Stuttgart, that is. The only American cars on the road are garbage trucks and ambulances.

title: LAURA BECKERING ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. J. Beckering of Huntington, L.I., have announced the engagment of their daughter Laura Francina Beckering to George A. Cooke Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cooke of Bradenton, Fla. An October wedding is planned. Miss Beckering is a landscape architect at Abel, Bainnson & Butz in New York. Her fiance is a vice president and the senior counsel of film finance for Home Box Office in New York.

title: Bias Charges Cloud New York Boy's Return From Foster Care
description: A judge in Manhattan has awarded custody of an 11-year-old boy to his Christian mother, despite pleas from his Orthodox Jewish foster parents that the boy remain with them for at least another year.

title: THE LIFE OF A DANCER
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW DOES A PLAYER QUALIFY AS AN ALL-STAR?
description: The starting lineups for baseball's All-Star Game should be picked solely on performance in the first half of the season. That's why they play the game every year - to honor players who have performed like all-stars during the current season.

title: EIGHT IMPORTANT DAYS IN NOVEMBER: UNRAVELING THE IRAN-CONTRA AFFAIR
description: When Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North breaks his public silence Tuesday and testifies before Congress about the Iran-contra affair, much of the most dramatic questioning is expected to deal with seven critical days last November.

title: SAVING LAKE RONKONKOMA'S SHORES
description: AFTER decades of decline, Lake Ronkonkoma is undergoing a resurgence.

title: DID IT COME FROM OUTER SPACE?
description: LEAD: UNASSIGNED TERRITORY By Kem Nunn. 305 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $16.95.

title: LURE OF NORTH OUTWIEGHS ALIENS' FEAR
description: It was the economic disparities on the two sides of the Rio Grande that drove Miguel Tostado Rodriguez into the torrid boxcar in which 18 of his companions died Thursday in Sierra Blanca, Tex.

title: ONCE MORE, OPERETTA SINGS ITS HEAD OFF
description: A CZAR IN MUFTI WOOS A naive shopgirl over a brimming stein of brew in a generic Viennese beer garden.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Augusta, Me.; A Newcomer On Main Street
description: A NINE-STORY brick building is rising on Water Street in the heart of Maine's capital city, the first new building in the downtown area in more than half a century.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
AN INNOVATIVE MEDAL FOR AN IMAGINATIVE ARTIST
description: LEAD: INNOVATION distinguishes the career of Marc Chagall as well as the medal issued to commemorate the centennial of his birth. The medal was commissioned by the Judah L. Magnes Memorial Museum of Berkeley, Calif., and designed by Marika Somogyi.

title: MODEST EXTERIOR, TOP ITALIAN FARE
description: ITALIAN restaurants are the most common ethnic eating places on Long Island. With all that competition, it's difficult for any restaurant to stand out. La Bussola in Glen Cove is that standout.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
POOLSIDE
description: LEAD: SPLASH! Everybody into the water! It's Fourth of July weekend, and summer is officially here.

title: HUMAN-WAVE RAID LOSSES IRAN'S FAVOR
description: Some of Iran's senior religious leaders appear to oppose the ''human wave'' assaults in which thousands of ill-trained and ill-equipped Iranian troops cross the border to face ''martyrdom'' at the hands of the Iraqis.

title: WILL THE REAL IDENTITY PLEASE STAND UP
description: ''I think; therefore, I am'' - Rene Descartes

title: Zwanger Plans To Wed in September
description: Betsy Zwanger, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Zwanger of Massapequa Park, L.I., and Lawrence Polur, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Polur of Tampa, Fla., plan to marry Sept. 5, the future bride's parents have announced.

title: HISTORY LESSON ON THE FOURTH OF JULY
description: CHECK the standing in the American League West before today's games and note the team that is in first place. Recent history says that team will not be in first place at the end of the season. Look again and see if the team in third place is two or two and a half games from first. Recent history says that team could be in first place at the end of the season.

title: Headliners; Heartbreak
description: After 40 years of filling the Amsterdam Avenue air with the aromas of his baked goods, Louis Lichtman found the rent rising faster than his dough. Mr. Lichtman, a 75-year-old Hungarian immigrant whose shop at the corner of 86th Street was a West Side institution, fought back tears last week as an auctioneer gaveled off the shop's fixtures and equipment. Mr. Lichtman's son, Harvey, who took over the bakery in 1977, said he decided to close it after his landlord, eager to cash in on the West Side real estate boom, announced a 400 percent rent increase, from $1,300 a month to $6,500. ''I would have worked seven days a week for the landlord,'' said the younger Mr. Lichtman. ''I would never have seen my children.'' His father, who had continued to bake in the shop occasionally, said, ''I'm numb.''

title: The Continuing Hemline Saga
description: Shorts and miniskirts may be appropriate for play (Fashion, ''The Continuing Hemline Saga,'' by Carrie Donovan, June 7). However, women are being told to bare their legs not only at work but also in getting there (and this in winter, when such outfits are unfit for the cold and snow of city streets).

title: DR. ZACKSON PLANS TO WED
description: Dr. Hannah Judith Zackson will be married Sept. 27 to Andrew Robert Wolk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney M. Wolk of South Orange, N.J., her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Ephraim K. Zackson of New Hyde Park, L.I., have announced.

title:
DINING OUT;
IN PIERMONT, A SECOND XAVIAR
description: LEAD: TUCKED away in the charming little hamlet of Piermont, just two miles south of the Tappan Zee Bridge in Rockland County, Xaviar's now occupies the site of the old Theresa's. The chef and owner Peter Xaviar Kelly, who also owns Xaviar's in Garrison, N.Y., has given the place a classy new interior. The monochromatic eggshell ceiling and walls make a perfect backdrop for the Oriental rug centered on thick black carpeting, for lighting that gives the room a warm, subtle glow stated again by candlelight and for opulent pink roses in charming garden bouquets on every table.

title: Putting the PC Into Publishing
description: FOR the past two years, desktop publishing has meant Macintosh desktop publishing. But when Pagemaker became available for the IBM PC and its compatibles, the publishing outlook began to brighten for the MS-DOS world. The arrival of Ventura from Xerox and now a desktop publishing package from Software Publishing, a company known for programs that are both easy to deal with and relatively low in cost, seems finally to have brought choice as well as capability to IBM users desirous of joining the rush to deluge us all with newsletters and other printed paraphernalia.

title: Prince Charles Assails Government on Slums
description: Prince Charles, in veiled criticism of the Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, says that not enough is being done to relieve the plight of Britain's decaying inner cities.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN HONEYMOONS;
Getting the Marriage Off the Ground
description: LEAD: AS recently as three years ago, it was unusual to find a honeymooning couple on a rugged safari in Kenya or on a trek through the Himalayas. Not so any more, said Judi Wineland, president and founder of Overseas Adventure Travel, which arranges exotic tours and expeditions.

title: INCINERATORS NEED ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW
description: We greatly appreciate the information supplied in the recent article ''Hospital Incinerators Stir Concern.''

title: REDS GET 6 IN 4TH, TOP METS
description: With their squabling supposedly quieted, the Mets approached tonight's game in the hopes of concentrating on the job at hand - keeping pace with the division-leading Cardinals.

title: FAR TRUMPET IS HEARD ANEW AS CANDIDATES INVOKE J.F.K.
description: Twenty-four years after his death, John Fitzgerald Kennedy's words and ideas go forth once again as a new generation of Democratic Presidential hopefuls looks back for a bridge to the future.

title:
MUSIC;
IN CHESTER, A FESTIVAL ON A FARM
description: LEAD: THE Apollo Muses Center for the Arts is presenting the first of 10 ''Summer Sundays'' today. The full-afternoon programs will include concerts, workshops and a variety of events focusing on the theater and visual arts.

title: Trade in Doubt
description: THE Portland Trail Blazers might invalidate the trade that brought them Keith Lee, a forward from the Cleveland Cavaliers, in exchange for Jim Paxson, a guard. Dr. Robert Cook, the Blazers' team doctor, said Lee's physical examination in Portland did not go well, that Lee's knees were ''a high risk.'' The trade, announced last month shortly after the National Basketball Association draft, was contingent upon both players' passing physical examinations with their new teams. Lee had surgery on his right knee when he was 15 and has a history of tendinitis in his left knee, according to Dr. Cook.

title: INVESTING
description: LEAD: STOCKS of technology companies were among the stars of the first quarter, but the story was much different in the second. Many technology issues took a sharp fall in April, and in the past few weeks they were clobbered again.

title: MEKONG TOWN STRUGGLES TO RECOVER
description: A monument has risen a few steps from the ferry landing, where 17 years ago the trussed-up bodies of thousands of Vietnamese residents in Phnom Penh floated down the Mekong, shot by forces of the American-backed Lon Nol Government.

title:
GARDENING;
DAY LILLIES AND IRISES: DIVIDE AND REPLANT
description: LEAD: HAVING just placed an order with a West Coast nursery for bearded iris, it came as a shock to read on the acknowledgement card that they would be shipped within a few weeks for planting. It isn't that I didn't know that they might arrive in late July, but rather I wondered how the season had gone by so fast.

title:
GARDENING;
A MOSS LAWN DOESN'T NEED MOWING
description: LEAD: MANY gardeners disdain moss because it is considered a sign of poor, acid soil in need of lime, fertilizer or other alchemies of grass-growing. But in the right places, moss becomes a serene complement.

title:
IN THE REGION: LONG ISLAND;
They No Longer Say 'Manorville Where'
description: LEAD: TERESA MELNIK still sells freshly picked strawberries from the stand in front of her 17-acre farm on Eastport Manor Road in Manorville.

title: POST FUTURUM BLUES
description: THE RAT By Gunter Grass. Translated by Ralph Manheim. 371 pp. San Diego: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

title: Safe Adventure Begins at Home
description: Survivors of World War II downings of United States military aircraft over the desert said that it was not the water supply in the plane that saved them from death by dehydration but the water they drank before they took off.

title: REAGAN HINTS AT BORK NOMINATION STRATEGY: STRESS CREDENTIALS, NOT VIEWS
description: In his first public statement on Judge Robert H. Bork since nominating him for the Supreme Court, President Reagan today signaled the Administration's strategy in the fight over the nomination: to emphasize Judge Bork's qualifications as a scholar and judge while sidestepping a confrontation over ideology.

title: BAROQUE CONCERTS AT THE ATHENEUM
description: THE Aston Magna Festival, the oldest Baroque performance summer music festival in the United States, will give three Sunday afternoon concerts on instruments of the period, at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford on July 12, 19 and 26 at 3 P.M.

title: Soviet Disavows The Disavowable
description: Reagan Administration officials say they are waiting to hear more about what they described as an ''informal, disavowable'' Soviet suggestion for smoothing the way to a treaty limiting medium-range missiles. They say Col. Gen. Nikolai F. Chervov, head of the Arms Control Directorate of the Soviet General Staff, offered the suggestion several weeks ago to Maynard W. Glitman, an American arms-control negotiator. The existence of the informal exchange was reported from Washington last week and promptly disavowed in Moscow.

title: A Homecoming in Connecticut
description: Some journeyed from as far away as Louisiana and California. Others only crossed from Massachusetts or New York. Many simply ambled a few blocks to the city green.

title: Amy Gonseth Is Married
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration in Tarrytown, N.Y., yesterday Amy Elizabeth Gonseth, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Gonseth of Tarrytown, was married to Michael Anthony Meyers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Meyers of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. John G. Long performed the ceremony. The bride is manager of the client service department at a Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith branch in Manhattan. Mr. Meyers is a Merrill Lynch vice president.

title: HEALTHY, WEALTHY AND WORRIED TOO
description: THE EMBARRASSMENT OF RICHES An Interpretation of Dutch Culture in the Golden Age. By Simon Schama. Illustrated. 698 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $39.95.

title: Broadcast TV
description: On camera, Isaac Bashevis Singer's words come out like his short stories: handmade, wise and with a worldly twist. A one-hour program in the American Masters series, ''Isaac in America: A Journey With Isaac Bashevis Singer'' (Monday night at 9 on Channels 13 and 49), should be watched with a pencil and paper handy to take down his aphorisms before they fly off like some of his ethereal characters.

title: Father, not Son
description: To the Editor:

title: TURNING PAGES IN THE BOOK OF LIFE
description: SOMEONE must have taken our wall calendar down and put it on the table, then spilled a sticky substance on it and rehung it. The pages stick together now and, when pried apart, reveal that it is one dreadful-looking calendar, with dates obscured and pictures that look as though mashed potatoes had been thrown at them.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: 125TH STREET;
description: HARLEM'S busiest shopping strip, 125th Street, will be under siege for the next three years as construction crews rip it apart to remove trolley tracks, install new water mains and rebuild basement vaults.

title: IN Presidential Primaries, One Vote Isn't Enough; Winner Take All
description: To the Editor:

title: TOURISTS BACK IN EUROPE AS TERRORIST FEARS FADE
description: When the 105-member Spirit of America band marched on the lawn of the American Ambassador's residence here today playing ''The Star-Spangled Banner,'' the sense of national pride in the crowd was unsullied by any nervous glances.

title: A Vision of New York as It Reaches for the Next Millennium
description: IT was the most obvious thing for a city to do, but nothing like it had been done in nearly twenty years: last week, the Commission on the Year 2000 submitted to Mayor Koch its report on the future of the city, ''New York Ascendant,'' with an analysis of what New York is, where it is going, and what can and should be done.

title: McGwire Hits 29th to Help Top Red Sox
description: Jose Canseco drove in four runs and Mark McGwire hit his major league-leading 29th homer today as the Oakland Athletics held on for a 9-5 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: WHAT'S GOING ON AT EIGHTH SUMMERFARE
description: WITH all the steamy photographs and titillating blurbs in the Pepsico Summerfare brochures - referring to a performance of ''human sensuality'' by a ''sensual iconoclast,'' ''a compellingly sensual'' dance piece or a ''vibrant and sexy musical'' - is the eighth annual international performing arts festival in Purchase to be interpreted as a cornucopia of erotica for the intelligentsia?

title: ROSS'S TRIAL PUTS CAPITAL PUNISHMENT BACK IN SPOTLIGHT
description: THE imposition of the death sentence on Michael B. Ross, scheduled for tomorrow in Superior Court in Bridgeport, is likely to intensify the debate over the capital punishment law and set off an appellate battle lasting years, according to state officials and legislators.

title: PASSENGER MISSING FROM QE2
description: A passenger mysteriously vanished from his luxury cabin aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2, Coast Guard officials said yesterday. He was believed to have fallen overboard several hundred miles off Bermuda.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: GUARDIANS OF THE WEST. By David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $16.95.) ''Guardians of the West,'' billed as ''Book One of the Malloreon,'' is not about a battle between good and evil. It is about behaving well during an interim between battles and quests. The first book of Mr. Eddings's ''Belgariad,'' - a five-volume epic set in a medieval fantasy world and featuring the growth from childhood to kingship of the hero, Garion - was called ''Pawn of Prophecy.

title: Congressmen Abroad For Holiday Weekend
description: While most Congressmen return to their home districts for the Independence Day weekend, some were overseas on business.

title: Police Are Caught Eavesdropping
description: New York City was confronted last week by the unwelcome specter of the sort of racially motivated police surveillance that was thought to have disappeared years ago.

title: MIXING PUBLIC SERVICE, PRIVATE CAUSES
description: THOUGH he has traveled the world on business and as a United Nations delegate, Arthur Ross makes a point of spending his summers in East Hampton.

title: A PARTY FOR EVERY FAILURE
description: CROOKED HEARTS By Robert Boswell. 340 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
MUSIC
description: LEAD: The Barber of Seville Glyndebourne Festival Opera. London Philharmonic Orchestra. Home Vision. Stereo. 155 minutes. $39.95. Here is an excellent production, with a well-chosen ensemble, imaginatively directed for television by Dave Heather. The stage director, John Cox, opts for refreshing naturalism instead of the overplayed caricature so often seen.

title: MOBILE STATION TO OFFER CANCER TESTS
description: LEAD: SOMETHING new will appear in the parking lots of shopping centers, banks, apartment complexes and companies in the state this month. A blue-and-white 33-foot van equipped with what is termed the finest mammography equipment available will begin touring the state to provide low-cost breast examinations for an estimated 60,000 women a year.

title: EMILY ANN UHRY MARRIES R. B. RHEA IN CONNECTICUT
description: Emily Ann Uhry and Russell Boon Rhea were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Fox Uhry, in Morris, Conn. The Rev. Donald Wilson, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Jersey Discovers Pains and Perils In Office Growth
description: SOME days, the superhighways that crisscross Parsippany-Troy Hills in the heart of New Jersey's corporate countryside roar to a standstill. Route 80 backs up heading both east and west, and Route 287's four lanes of northbound and southbound traffic go nowhere fast.

title: AT 'AMERICA'S SOAPBOX,' FREE SPEECH HAS A LIMIT
description: Out on the grassy rectangle of Independence Mall this morning, as long lines snaked toward the Liberty Bell, pilgrims from near and far mounted what is called ''America's Soapbox'' to deliver free opinions on anything under the summer sun.

title: PTL Donors Seek to Expand Their Role and Oust Falwell
description: About 500 contributors to the troubled PTL ministry marched, chanted and prayed today for a greater role in the organizaton's affairs. Many of them called for the ouster of the Rev. Jerry Falwell, who took over the group from its founder, Jim Bakker.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
THREE-SPINE STICKLEBACK
description: LEAD: Gasterosteus aculeatus

title: Superhero?
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE FLOOD OF '64. By David Long. (Ecco, $16.95.) This collection of stories, set in the harsh, ungiving landscape of western Montana, is tough-minded and exhilarating. David Long's characters endure floods, snowstorms and brutal cold; they fall over the sides of cliffs and are presumed dead. Those who survive are lonely, wounded people who expect little from life and usually get just that.

title: DR. JUDITH HALPERIN TO WED IN OCTOBER
description: The engagement of Dr. Judith Halperin and Dr. Joel Neil Goldstein has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Stanley D. Halperin of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Menemsha, Mass., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Goldstein of New Rochelle, N.Y. An October wedding is planned. Dr. Halperin, a postdoctoral fellow in clinical psychology at McLean Hospital in Belmont, Mass., graduated from Yale College and received a doctorate in clinical psychology in May from the Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology of Yeshiva University. Her father is a partner in the New York law firm of Phillips, Nizer, Benjamin, Krim & Ballon. Her mother, Joan L. Halperin, a poet and a teacher, is an artist in residence attached to the Westchester Council of Arts in White Plains and a poet in residence with Poets in Public Service Inc. in New York.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate 1. Import Ban: Vote on an amendment to the omnibus trade bill that would have put a permanent ban on the imports of the Toshiba Corporation of Japan and the state-owned Kongsberg Vapenfabrik of Norway because they diverted advanced equipment to the Soviet Union, enabling it to make quieter submarines. Rejected 78 to 19, June 30. (The Senate then went on to approve an amendment that would ban the imports for two to five years.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
CARAMOOR TOURS
description: LEAD: ''It's exciting to walk through the House-Museum at Caramoor when tours in two or three different languages are being given,'' said Sue McKanna, the museum coordinator, whose job includes booking tours of Caramoor. ''The Rosens, who built the house, promoted internationalism of music - it was so important to them.

title:
ART;
ISLIP'S ADDITIONS
description: LEAD: THE seven artists featured in the exhibition at the Islip Art Museum are among those whose work has recently been added to the permanent collection. Before 1985, the museum did not own any artworks; it served as an exhibition space, in the manner of an art center or kunsthalle.

title: It's Not Just Another Cute Alpine Inn
description: LEAD: The Hotel Kobenzl is situated high up on the Gaisberg, a sylvan mountain overlooking Salzburg, a lot of southern Austria, parts of Bavaria, the face of the Grossglockner, the back of Berchtesgaden and the ski slopes of Tyrol. It is not the kind of cute country inn you stumble on while out for an afternoon stroll.

title: Risks in Co-ops On Leased Land
description: To the Editor:

title: PARENTS FIND PEACE AS TEEN-AGERS ROCK
description: Rock music reverberated through the ceiling, and in the room the parents came and went, speaking of Bryan Adams.

title: ROGER KENT MUMMERT ENGAGED TO MS. DWEIR
description: The engagement of Robin Alyse Dweir to Roger Kent Mummert, a son of Mrs. Frank Mummert of Lancaster, Pa., and the late Mr. Mummert, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Irv Dweir of Woodbury, L.I. The couple plan to marry Aug. 16.

title: REMEMBERING A 'FORGOTTEN WAR'
description: DAY BY DAY, SOUTH KOREA'S turbulence marches across current headlines and through the news broadcasts. Half forgotten is that war in the early 1950's that established a viable country and laid the foundations of its present prosperity. ''Korea: The Forgotten War,'' a two-hour independently produced documentary that can be seen locally on WABC-TV this afternoon at 2, should remind Americans of that war's victories and defeats. It should be no longer the ''forgotten war.''

title: KOREAN DECLARES 'SWEEPING' CHANGE IS THE 'ONLY WAY'
description: Roh Tae Woo, the chairman of the ruling party, who altered South Korean politics this week with surprising proposals for democratic change, said today that he had acted because he felt Koreans wanted ''sweeping, epoch-making, bold measures.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Auto Racing Allison Takes the Firecracker: Bobby Allison overcame an early brush that knocked him off the pace, charged into the lead with two laps left and beat Buddy Baker amid a crashing finish to the Firecracker 400 yesterday at Daytona International Speedway. As Allison's Buick crossed the finish line 1.5 seconds ahead of Baker's Oldsmobile in the 160-lap race, Ken Schrader and Harry Gant, both of whom were running with the leaders, crashed hard. After Schrader's car was tapped in the rear by Dave Marcis it went sideways and started up the banking, did a complete barrel roll, slammed into Gant's and knocked both cars into the wall. Both cars slid to a stop just past the finish line. Neither driver was injured. Meanwhile, Allison, 49 years old, came up with his third Firecracker 400 victory and the 83rd triumph of his Nascar career. He averaged 161.056 miles per hour in the race, which was slowed by four caution flags. Soccer Ecuador Fails to Advance: Eugenio La Rosa scored in the 42d minute yesterday and Peru held on for a 1-1 tie with Ecuador that put Argentina, the World Cup champion, into the semifinals in the Americas Cup tournament in Bueno Aires. Argentina will face Uruguay, the defending Americas Cup champion, which had a bye until the semifinals, on July 9 in Bueno Aires. Ecuador came into the match with Peru needing to win by three goals to advance to the semifinals. Chile upset Brazil, 4-0, on Friday night to reach the final four, and will face the winner of today's match between Paraguay and Colombia. The 10-nation South American soccer championship will conclude on July 12. (AP) Horse Show Shegogg Gains Finals: Riding Kandi, Craig Shegogg of Upper Saddle River, N.J., secured a place in the American Horse Shows Association hunt seat medal finals in October by winning his fourth qualifying event of the year yesterday at the I Love New York Horse Show in Lake Placid. Lara Kunkler of Worcester, Mass., placed second and Ashley Kennedy of Orlando, Fla., was third. Sloan Sherman of Providence, R.I., topped a field of 40 riders in the United States Equestrian team young rider medal class, riding Diamond Exchange. Boxing Coggi Takes Crown: Juan Martin Coggi of Argentina, the challenger, won the World Boxing Association junior welterweight title by knocking out Patrizio Oliva of Italy in the third round of their scheduled 15-round fight last night in Ribera, Sicily. The 25-year-old Argentine sent Oliva to his first defeat in 49 professional fights in Oliva's third title defense. Cycling Portuguese Wins Tour's Third Stage: Acacio da Silva of Portugal won the 131-mile third stage of the Tour de France, from Karlsruhe to Stuttgart, West Germany, yesterday in 5 hours, 27 minutes and 35 seconds. Erich Maechler of Switzerland finished second, two seconds off the pace, and a countryman, Jorg Mueller, was third, nine seconds behind the leader. Maechler took the overall lead with an aggregate time of 8 hours 31 minutes and 42 seconds. Mueller moved from 43d to second over all, 44 seconds behind Maechler.(AP)

title:
GARDENING;
DAY LILLIES AND IRISES: DIVIDE AND REPLANT
description: LEAD: HAVING just placed an order with a West Coast nursery for bearded iris, it came as a shock to read on the acknowledgement card that they would be shipped within a few weeks for planting. It isn't that I didn't know that they might arrive in late July, but rather I wondered how the season had gone by so fast.

title: OLDER ATHLETES SHOW IT'S NOT THE AGE, IT'S THE ATTITUDE
description: CONSIDERING that she did not become an athlete until she was 68 years old, Mary Haines of Newington has come a long way, in every sense of the expression.

title: Alston Chase: Saving Nature From Itself
description: THE long-held philosophy of the National Park Service - maintain the parks as much as possible as ''a vignette of primitive America'' - has come under increasing attack. Critics charge that a lack of active intervention in natural systems within the parks has led to a serious decline in animal species such as the mule deer of Yellowstone. Some critics also contend that the parks have been marred by an overemphasis on tourism and an underemphasis on broader problems such as development of lands adjacent to the parks. Some of the most stinging charges have come from Alston Chase, a former teacher of philosophy at Princeton who lives in Montana and who wrote ''Playing God in Yellowstone.'' William Penn Mott Jr. is director of the National Park Service. Philip Shabecoff, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, talked with them last week. Excerpts follow.

title: Woodrat (It's Handsome) Joins Endangered List
description: Despite the odium that its name evokes, the eastern woodrat has been officially declared an endangered species in New York entitled to the full protection of the law.

title: NEW MAGIC MAKES THE AUDIENCE APPEAR
description: STANDING SILENTLY IN A LAS Vegas boardroom, Penn & Teller, the new-wave co-conspirators, are facing the ordeal of their lives.

title: MAN, 39, SHACKLED FOR FIRST AID, DIES LATER AT A HOSPITAL
description: A 39-year-old man died late Friday at Harlem Hospital shortly after he was handcuffed by the police so an ambulance crew could administer first aid.

title: POSTINGS: What's in a Name?; Title Fits to a Tee
description: The names given to residential developments rarely bear any specific relation to their suburban locales; rather they tend to evoke a spurious sense of splendor or a hoked-up suggestion of rural life. But a new 266-unit condominium community called Rolling Greens in Rocky Hill, Conn., will indeed have rolling greens - as well as open fairways and sunken sandtraps.

title: Why Your Doctor Is a Group
description: In the article, Dr. James W. Hanway asserts that much of what is labeled medical malpractice involves ''honest mistakes made by decent doctors - and we are all human.'' As a lawyer specializing in the area of malpractice, I realize that most doctors are motivated by the desire to do good. The issue, however, is not the mental state of the doctor; it's the physical state of the patient. Death is no less painful because the doctor is a nice guy or because he didn't mean to do it.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: GWEN JOHN. By Susan Chitty. (Franklin Watts, $17.95.) Gwen John (1876-1939) was an English painter, the older sister of the better-known painter Augustus John. From this account, she appears to have been an eccentric, driven woman who led an unusual, principled and self-punishing life. When, early in her career, her father told her she looked like a prostitute in a painting - she worked as an artist's model - she refused ever again to take money from him, in effect choosing poverty for life. She traveled in France with another woman, earning money by sketching men in bars. Rodin was her lover for more than 10 years, and when his passion for her dulled and he took up with another, she contented herself with whatever attention he gave her. Through it all, she painted and drew, mostly women or domestic or interior scenes, often repeating the same subject in a series and refusing, on principle, to produce work for exhibition. While Susan Chitty, whose other books include biographies of Charles Kingsley and Anna Sewell, has done her research and provided a chronology of John's art production, this book fails to hold our interest. It merely presents the data, in a bewildering, almost comic prose style (''In all that crowd not one person spoke to her. Of all those footsteps not one stopped to say a kind word''). Gwen John's work and life await future writers - ones familiar, for example, with feminist theory, who will not be surprised, as was Susan Chitty, that ''there have been flattering references to [ Gwen John ] in several recent books . . . all of them, oddly enough, by women.''

title: Jazz: Bill and George Simon Swing Group
description: IN the slippery world of twilight jazz, where engagements are rare and usually ephemeral, the Bill and George Simon Swing Group is approaching its seventh anniversary of Wednesday sessions from 5:30 to 8:30 P.M., in a new location, its fourth. After starting at Maggie's, an East Side bar and restaurant, the band moved to larger quarters at Eddie Condon's on West 54th Street until it was closed and torn down, and then to Jimmy Walker's on West 55th Street, until the new cabaret laws limited the rooms to three musicians. Now the band has found a new home for its Wednesday sessions at the Red Blazer Too, 349 West 46th Street.

title: HATS ON!
description: ''THERE'S NO TRADITION WITH HATS ANYMORE.'' Burton Berinsky of Jay Lord Hatters, one of New York's premier hat makers, delivers his pronouncement ruefully. To hear him tell it, few men these days sport a Panama with the dash or conviction of a Victor Lazlo. But in case one should turn up, Mr. Berinsky is ready. ''This is my Casablanca,'' he says, briskly pulling from a shelf a ringer for the hat worn by Humphrey Bogart's suave rival in the film of the same name.

title: Albany Approves A Wide-Ranging Ethics Bill
description: After weeks of increasingly bitter dispute, the State Legislature last week passed one of the broadest, strictest ethics codes in the country.

title: CHERRY FARMERS WORRY AS PRICES FALL
description: The annual sour cherry harvest is here, but Lee D. Brown has not even set up his production line to wash, pit and pack the fruit he grows at his Cherry Ridge Farm overlooking the Hudson River.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Archive of Sound Opens in London After Facelift

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SITES: A Third Memoir. By Wallace Fowlie. (Duke University, $19.95.) Wallace Fowlie, now an emeritus professor of French literature at Duke University, is one of the most distinguished of American teachers, critics and translators. ''Sites,'' his third memoir, was preceded by ''Journal of Rehearsals: A Memoir'' (1977) and ''Aubade: A Teacher's Notebook'' (1983).

title: MOVIES
description: Union Station Starring William Holden, Barry Fitzgerald. Directed by Rudolph Mate. 1950. Kartes Video Communications. 80 minutes. $19.95.

title: RICHARD HARWOOD PLANS TO BE WED TO MISS WEBSTER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Webster of Allendale, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jacqueline Park Webster, to Richard Charles Harwood, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Harwood of Saratoga Springs, N.Y. A September wedding is planned.

title: STATE ASKS TO JOIN SUIT ON ROUTING ATOM-FUEL
description: FEDERAL District Court in Manhattan is to review on Friday a request by Connecticut to intervene in a suit in which New York City is seeking to force nuclear waste to be routed across Long Island Sound and Connecticut instead of through the city.

title: In Presidential Primaries, One Vote Isn't Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Debate at Duke Over $20 Million
description: THERE was joy at Duke University - and then some hesitancy -when an alumnus offered $20 million to the school to ''establish a research institute on the human future.''

title: AUGUST WEDDING FOR SUSAN LAMB
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Anthony Lamb of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Condie Lamb to Christopher West Bartlett, a son of Bishop Allen Lyman Bartlett Jr. of the Episcopal Diocese of Pennsylvania and Mrs. Bartlett of Philadelphia.

title: CANADIAN CREW DEFEATS HARVARD
description: Harvard's varsity heavyweight crew was eliminated today by the Canadian national team in a heat of the Henley Royal Regatta's oldest and most prestigious event, the Grand Challenge Cup.

title: INVOKING AMERICA: A GITCHE GUMEE MEMOIR
description: WHEN I was a kid growing up in a New York City slum, the public schools I attended put a lot of emphasis on memorizing. ''By the rude bridge that arched the flood,'' we chanted, and my blood tingled. Nothing in my experience, bounded by the Flatbush Extension or, later, by Southern Boulevard, connected me to that rural image I barely comprehended. What in the world was a rude bridge anyway? I was born in the U.S.A., as Bruce Springsteen has it, uneasy heir yet ardent adherent to the bragging neighborhood glories that spilled over on our fourth of July. Fear of firecrackers marred the great day, as did the boring speeches of local politicians. But there were magical fireworks after dark, and at the last, softly exploding sparklers rained on the hands of every kid on every stoop of every tenement on the block. The U.S.A. simply was the best, the greatest, the bravest and the freest.

title: STREETS OF SALES
description: LEAD: THREE HUNDRED and sixty-four days of the year, Main and Elm Streets in New Canaan are quiet and clean and so predictable you can find the town cat taking his morning repose in the sunny window of the children's clothing store.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
MUSIC
description: LEAD: Maria Callas: Hamburg Concert 1962 Sinfonieorchester des NDR, Georges Pretre, conductor. Kultur. 66 minutes. $39.95. Wearing a low-cut dress and sporting a bouffant hairdo, Ms. Callas looks and acts in this 1962 recital at the Musikhalle in Hamburg more outgoing than she does in a concert in Hamburg three years earlier, also released on video by Kultur.

title: HAITI PROTEST LEADERS REJECT CONCESSIONS
description: The leaders of the protests that racked Haiti this week said today that ''too much blood has flowed'' for them to accept concessions, and they vowed to redouble their efforts to topple the Government.

title: MISS PETERS PLANS OCTOBER WEDDING
description: Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Peters of Leamington Spa, Warwickshire, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter Nicola Ruth Peters to Jerrold Howard Temko, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Temko of Westport, Conn., and West Hebron, N.Y. An Oct. 17 wedding is planned.

title: Why Your Doctor Is a Group
description: Martha Fay speaks of the upward surge in malpractice suits in recent years, a surge commonly laid to the greed of patients and their lawyers. Yet, as a nonlitigious patient, I feel compelled to point out a possible correlation between this greater litigiousness and an increased emphasis on ''cost-effectiveness'' in medicine and a preoccupation with technology, office management and accounting. SUSAN N. FAULKNER Flushing, Queens

title: STACY B. VLADIMER MARRIED TO ROBERT A. MAGINN JR.
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston yesterday, Stacy Beverly Vladimer, a daughter of Mrs. Leonard Edwin Vladimer of West Hartford, Conn., and the late Mr. Vladimer, was married to Robert Allen Maginn Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Maginn of Dayton, Ohio. The Rev. Spencer Morgan Rice performed the ceremony.

title: MONTCLAIR THEATREFEST OFFERS STIRRING 'CABERET'
description: IT IS time again to come to ''Cabaret,'' or the ''Cabaret,'' as the title song goes. In October, just a month before the 21st anniversary of the musical's startling Broadway opening, a revival reuniting the original director, Harold Prince, and the original star, Joel Grey, will begin performances at the Imperial Theater, where once it played, but this time at a top ticket of $50.

title: KEEPING DIVERSITY IN THE THEATER DISTRICT
description: IN an 11th-hour effort to reshape more than a dozen skyscrapers envisioned for Manhattan's theater district, city planners have drafted several zoning amendments, including a mandate to set aside 5 percent of all new floor space for ''entertainment-related uses.''

title: Senate for Ban on Toshiba Exports
description: Senators, already stung by Japanese commercial exploits that have helped produce the towering United States trade deficit, found a new target for anger last week. They voted, 92 to 5, for a two-to-five-year ban on importing the products of Toshiba Corporation, a giant Japanese company that had illegally sold sophisticated machinery for making submarine propellers to the Soviet Union.

title: RECORDING LIVES OF L.I. BAYMEN
description: LEAD: WHEN Nancy Solomon, a folklorist, first came to Freeport a few months ago, hired by the local Arts Council to document the area's maritime traditions, ''the immediate reaction of many I spoke to was 'what traditions?' and 'what fishermen?' '' she said. ''The village seemed so consumed by professionals and commuters that most people thought it was all gone, the traditions as extinct as the men who practiced them.

title: Correction
description: A map May 24 accompanying an article on the Oregon Trail transposed the identification of two sites: Trail Ruts and Fort Laramie Historic Site.

title:
ART;
'POST-ABSTRACT ABSTRACTION' IN RIDGEFIELD
description: LEAD: IT almost makes no difference whether one likes the art in ''Post-Abstract Abstraction'' at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield, or agrees with the premise behind the show. What is beyond debate is that under one roof in rural Connecticut is the largest, densest gathering of the most controversial new art, what is often called ''the cutting edge,'' to have been mounted anywhere - even in the heart of Manhattan.

title: Why Your Doctor Is a Group
description: It's a man's world. We all know that. Those who wish to keep it so may well take heart from your cover photograph of the Katonah Medical Group, its front rows all men; the back rows almost all women.

title: On the Ball
description: DESPITE all the clamor about the livelier ball causing the large increase in home runs this season, one test of baseballs used in the major leagues this year showed that they are not much different from those used 10 years ago. ''They're essentially the same,'' said Roger Haller, president of Haller Testing Laboratories of Plainfield, N.J., after the tests, arranged by USA Today, were performed on 116 baseballs taken from every major league team. ''If anything, the modern batch is a little deader.''

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: WHITE BARN BENEFIT A preseason benefit performance at 7 P.M. next Sunday will be given for Lucille Lortel's White Barn Theater on Newtown Avenue in Westport. The production is ''The Enchanted Island of Yew,'' based on a children's fairy tale by L. Frank Baum, who is better known as the author of ''The Wizard of Oz.''

title: Headliners; Heartthrob
description: No matter where Hiroshi Itsuki performed during his 14-day North American tour, the Japanese crooner could be pretty sure at least 180 members of the audience would clap their hearts out for him. Mr. Itsuki, who is known as the Frank Sinatra of Japan, was trailed by 180 of his most devoted Japanese fans, mostly unmarried middle-aged women, who paid $5,500 each to make the trip. They heard him sing in Seattle, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Toronto before Mr. Itsuki arrived in New York last week for his debut performance here. After his show at Avery Fisher Hall - it was sold out several weeks in advance without the benefit of English-language advertisments - the 39-year-old singer rewarded his band of travelling followers with a not-terribly-intimate dinner for 181.

title: GAIL COONS IS ENGAGED TO BRIAN MACDONALD
description: Gail Elizabeth Coons, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Coons of Oak Beach, L.I., and Venice, Fla., and Brian Allen MacDonald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce MacDonald of Los Gatos, Calif., plan to be married Aug. 29, the future bride's parents have announced.

title: Teen-Agers Now Need Tax Planning 101
description: STUDENT wage earners who plan to spend the summer flipping burgers or bagging groceries will find their finances have been complicated by the new tax law: More of them may be subject to tax, and the tax bite may be bigger.

title: The Greening Of Brussels
description: The people of Brussels will tell you that their city has more green space than any other major European capital. A partisan view, perhaps, but an understandable one. In this city of parks, the biggest one -the 12,000-acre Foret de Soignes - is nearly six times as large as the sprawling Bois de Boulogne in Paris.

title: Medicine-Bashing Hurts Health Care
description: LEAD: Medicine-bashing has become a popular pastime that, unfortunately, has spilled over into the arena of public policy. Many serious problems confront the medical profession, including the patient-doctor relationship, issues of negligence, policing, cost containment and patient advocacy. But these should not overshadow the continuing investigations into the causes and possible treatments for the major illnesses confronting our society today.

title: LAND PROGRAM LAUDED
description: LEAD: IN 1985, New Jersey bought an acre of parkland for $1,485, but it ''rented'' an acre for only $13.27. The source of that bargain was the Open Lands Management Program, a pilot project established in 1984 to permit public access to privately owned open space.

title: The Continuing Hemline Saga
description: Bianca Jagger, Blaine Trump, Nancy Kissinger, Liza Minnelli, Grace Mirabella . . . this is your survey of real women? What about the rest of us - the lawyers, secretaries, assembly-line workers and mothers? BONNIE JEAN THOMAS New York City

title:
RECORDINGS;
THE MUSIC OF JOHN PAINE - NO APOLOGIES ARE NEEDED
description: LEAD: PERHAPS THE MOST SPINE-chilling opinion a composer can hear is that his music is ''derivative.'' Call his works ''interesting'' or ''rhythmically inventive'' or ''experimental'' or any other euphemism for ''dull,'' and at least he can go to sleep each night confident that his daily waste of time, manuscript paper, and possibly academic grant money is unfailingly pursued in the cause of original creativity.

title: IN WESTPORT, LIGHT MEALS FAST
description: WESTPORT is more fortunate than many towns in having a number of ''hangouts'' - casual places where you can go for a light meal at moderate cost without dressing up. One of the newest is Glynn's Cafe, in the center of town in a small house that has been like a revolving door to restaurants over the last 10 years or so. The site is so handy, one wonders why it has been less than hospitable to past eateries.

title: JELLIED SALADS, STAPLE OF THE 50'S, SHOULD NOT BE FORGOTTEN
description: DO you remember tomato aspic? Look into your cookbooks from the 1950's and early 1960's and you may find recipes for this once-popular jellied salad. Serious recipes called for fresh or canned tomatoes; the shortcuts used tomato juice.

title: Was Pinochet's Campaign Message a Dozen Killings?
description: THE killing of 12 people in a 20-hour period in Chile last month may not stand out in the annals of violence committed in conflicts between Latin American governments and guerrillas. But in a country where the Government is known to apply its violence with relative selectivity and expertise, the chain of deaths of the dozen presumed leftist rebels has special significance.

title: Great Swamp: Why a Pipeline?
description: LONG before the first Earth Day or the passage of landmark legislation protecting our environment, the Great Swamp in northern New Jersey was permanently protected as a National Wildlife Refuge.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Swing Vote From School

title: A Closed Revival House That May Itself Be Revived
description: WHEN the Thalia Theater closed in May many people thought the two-story building at West 95th Street and Broadway, which housed the famed revival house and a performing-arts center, would be demolished. It would have been a fairly typical tale of new development on the Upper West Side.

title: Why Your Doctor Is a Group
description: I took great pleasure in reading Martha Fay's article ''Why Your Family Doctor Is a Group'' (June 7). It is heartening to see that, despite the specter of malpractice suits and increasing third-party intervention, there is still ''a joy in the daily business of medicine ...,'' at least in Katonah. BARRY ROTHENHAUS Pleasantville, N.Y.

title: MADRID
description: Unseasonably cold weather this spring delayed the blossoms on the magnolia trees sprinkled about Madrid, but finally summer has arrived and residents and visitors are thronging to the many outdoor cafes (terrazas) that have proliferated in recent years.

title: Wedding Planned By Page Eastburn
description: Mr. and Mrs. William H. Eastburn 3d of Doylestown, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Page Eastburn, to Kevin P. O'Rourke, the son of Joan O'Rourke of Nyack, N.Y., and Pompano Beach, Fla., and Peter J. O'Rourke of Old Greenwich, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: Kansas Falls Off the Wagon
description: ''It's a great day,'' many Kansans said over and over Wednesday. For the first time in 107 years the sale of liquor by the glass in public watering holes was not, in many places in the state, a violation of law.

title: The Old Vaudeville
description: THE SEVEN LITTLE FOYS With Bob Hope (in photo, right), James Cagney, George Tobias, Milly Vitale. 1955. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 95 minutes. $69.95.

title: BROAD BRUSH, 3-10, WINS SUBURBAN, IN A BATTLE
description: Broad Brush dug in through the stretch to hold off Set Style and Bordeaux Bob and score a surprisingly narrow victory in the $387,100 Suburban Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Data Update: July 5, 1987
description: MEDIAN HOUSE PRICES

title: One From 77th Gets Prison Term
description: During his years on the force, Robert Rathbun, a 36-year-old police officer who served in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant district, received 50 awards including 29 citations for ''Excellent Police Duty.'' Last week, he was sentenced to a prison term of 3 1/2 to 10 1/2 years after being convicted in May on 37 counts of conspiracy, burglary, theft, misconduct and possession and sale of drugs.

title: RESEARCH CENTER IS SET FOR BUFFALO
description: The State University of New York at Buffalo will form an institute to study practical applications of recent developments in superconductivity.

title: AND THEY SAID IT COULDN'T BE DONE
description: SHOWDOWN AT GUCCI GULCH Lawmakers, Lobbyists, and the Unlikely Triumph of Tax Reform. By Jeffrey H. Birnbaum and Alan S. Murray. Introduction by Albert R. Hunt. 309 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title: A Father and Daughter Die in a Brooklyn Fall
description: A father and his 4-year-old daughter died early yesterday when the man, after a dispute with his estranged wife, jumped or fell from a Brooklyn apartment building while holding the girl, the police said.

title: INSIDE THE 'JACKET': ALL KUBRICK
description: STANLEY KUBRICK'S ''FULL METAL JACKET'' establishes its grip on the viewer's attention instantaneously, with an opening scene in which young recruits are shorn by an off-screen Marine Corps barber, while a corny, lulling song is heard in the background (''Kiss me goodbye and write me when I'm gone/Goodbye sweetheart, hello Vietnam''). The scene would be ordinary, even a cliche, were it not for the look on the young men's faces. In their eyes we see absolutely nothing: no apprehension, no bravado, not even blind obedience, only the emptiness of clay ready to be molded.

title: Recent Sales
description: Hackensack $114,900 980 Main Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old condominium apartment; newly renovated, wall-to-wall carpeting, modern kitchen; monthly maintenance $148, taxes $1,680. River Edge $225,000 786 Oak Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old contemporary; fireplace, hardwood floors, central air-conditioning, den; taxes $2,436. Rockaway $149,000 26 Delaware Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; patio, finished basement, fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $1,885. Springfield $165,000 188 Tooker Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; fenced yard, den, fireplace; taxes $2,086. Washington Township $276,000 24 Edgewood Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old ranch; hardwood floors, 2-car garage; taxes $2,877. West Orange $308,000 12 Stone Drive 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 28-year-old colonial; deck, formal dining room, fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $5,909. OTHER AREAS East Meadow, L.I. $175,000 2685 Lexington Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 32-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,800. Thornwood, N.Y. $281,500 Bellview Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 17-year-old clapboard raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, in-law apartment, 0.32 acre; taxes $3,000. West Haven, Conn. $340,000 6 Woody Crest 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 85-year-old colonial; direct waterfront, remodeled; taxes $2,490.

title: Clarinetist To Play At Free Outdoor Recital
description: Richard Stoltzman, a clarinetist, will play music by Bach, Schubert, Poulenc, Reich and others, Tuesday at 7 P.M. in Damrosch Park, Lincoln Center, as part of the Free Sunset Music Series sponsored by New York City and radio station WQXR.

title: DISPUTE OVER HIRING OF GIBBS GOES ON
description: LEAD: EDWARD M. GIBBS, the former deputy county executive, has been at work as a consultant to county government for more than a month now, advising on such things as low-cost energy, solid-waste disposal and tax reductions. But the dispute over his hiring, which resulted in a lawsuit, has not died down and is scheduled for at least one more round in court.

title: Thriving Light Verse
description: To the Editor:

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Erie, Pa.;
Preservationists Win a Round
description: LEAD: AN 11th-hour purchase of the historic Wright House by Erie's only independent regional bank has crowned a four-year campaign by local and state preservationists with success.

title: MISS BAINES TO MARRY STEPHEN W. SCHECTER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Baines of Stoke-on-Trent, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter Tracey J. Baines to Stephen W. Schecter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence J. Schecter of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. A September wedding is planned.

title: Fresh Air Fund Sends Children to Their 2d Homes
description: At the Port Authority bus terminal in midtown Manhattan one recent morning, the raucus chatter of children punctuated the usual rush-hour din. They were bound for the country - some to see spacious backyards and cows and chickens and long, winding roads for the first time - to spend from two weeks to all summer with Fresh Air Fund host families offering respite from city life.

title:
IN THE REGION: NEW JERSEY;
Vacation Area Becoming a Place to Work
description: LEAD: LAST month, the United States Life Assurance Company, with headquarters in Manhattan's Wall Street district, announced plans to relocate some of its operations across the Hudson River to a 480,000-square-foot complex planned in Neptune Township in Monmouth County.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Fort Wayne, Ind.;
A Golfer's Mecca
description: LEAD: TIMOTHY S. BORNE freely admits he is a golf fanatic. ''If I'm not working,'' the advertising executive says, ''I'm playing golf.''

title: TIME OUT FOR GOOD BEHAVIOR
description: TIME off to enjoy the holiday weekend. Questions/Answers LAWNS/MUSHROOMS

title: Unique Abigail Adams
description: To the Editor:

title: Rowdy Rivalry
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ALIEN LAW SHOULD KEEP LIBERTY'S SPIRIT
description: ON a recent trip to the Statue of Liberty with my 5-year-old daughter, I was reminded of the first glimpse my parents had of the New World on their separate arrivals from Europe. True to form for a typical 5-year-old, my child was not interested in the family history. Nor did Emma Lazarus's famous sonnet, inscribed on the Lady's pedestal, move her in quite the same way it had moved my consciousness as a child.

title: REFERENDUM ON JAIL IS URGED
description: WHILE county government leaders consider 59 recommendations contained in the latest task force report on prison overcrowding, the chairman of the Task Force on Corrections Overcrowding said last week that county residents would have to determine the future of their prison system.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN HONEYMOONS;
Forget the Suite, Rent the Island
description: LEAD: AN African safari is hardly everyone's idea of the perfect wedding trip. In fact, about 42 percent of American newlyweds want seclusion on their honeymoons, according to Modern Bride magazine. In their pursuit of the ultimate romantic fantasy, many are escaping to sparsely populated, privately owned islands, said Ruth Pacheco, a travel consultant with Liberty Travel in New

title: By MICHAEL BRENSON
description: LARGE INTERNATIONAL EXHIBI-tions of contemporary art have become a large international art problem. In Europe at the beginning of June there were four massive art events - Documenta 8, in Kassel, West Germany; the Sculpture Project in Munster, a few hours northwest of Kassel by car; a 10-year anniversary show surveying the art of the last decade at the Pompidou Center in Paris, and the annual art fair in Basel, Switzerland. Together they formed something like a new Grand Tour. But artists and tourists who took the Grand Tour of Italy in the 18th century surely did not look like art connoisseurs making the grand tour now. To see all these numb, bleary-eyed ''art lovers,'' scrambling through exhibitions automatically, almost on instinct, the pleasure and purpose gone, is to realize that something is wrong.

title: Superhero?
description: To the Editor:

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
GEOGRPAHY, UNIVERSALITY IN A LOBSTER POT
description: LEAD: OUR town is a cluster of 1,200 homes set on the 50-mile circumference that rings New York, and many of our breadwinners commute to the center of that circle. It is a high-stress world, and our green acreage presents itself as one of the rewards for succeeding in the commercial cauldron. Our local roads are scenes as well as throughfares, and ponds, shade trees and rock formations landscape the gardens of old clapboard houses that date from Colonial times.

title: A Humbled Toshiba Takes Its Lumps
description: Toshiba is quietly accepting the punishment meted out by the United States for the Japanese company's shipments of sensitive material to the Soviet Union. The day after the Senate backed a ban on imports of Toshiba products, the chairman of Toshiba, Shoichi Saba, and the president, Sugiichiro Watari, resigned. But such a ban, which would include the laptop computers gaining popularity in America, might be unconstitutional. A similar ban is being proposed in the House, and both would include products made by Kongsberg Vaapenfabrikk, a Norwegian state-owned company that also sold technology to the Russians.

title: SOUR TASTE TO METS
description: FRAGILE by nature, a strawberry requires gentle handling. It bruises easily. And once bruised, it quickly sours. ''It succeeds in a wide range of soils and situations,'' the Encyclopaedia Brittanica says, ''but it is very perishable and requires cool, dry storage.'' As if the Mets didn't know.

title: The U.S. House That Never Was
description: NOT all the United States Government's problems with new buildings have been in Moscow. Even more tangled has been the case of the Ambassador's residence that the State Department set out to build on the Nile River in Cairo.

title: D. R. Ventura Fiance Of Leslie R. Birnbaum
description: The engagement of Leslie Robin Birnbaum, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin M. Birnbaum of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Charlestown, R.I., to Douglas R. Ventura, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules C. Ventura of Port Washington and Shelter Island, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: YANKEES HOLD ON AND TOP RANGERS, 4-3
description: Willie Randolph, captain and surprising run producer, declined to assess the first half of the Yankees' season yesterday. ''I make assessments after the season is over - when the dust clears,'' the second baseman said. ''You have to do it over the course of the whole season. Are we going to stop here? No.'' With a 4-3 victory over Texas, the Yankees completed their first 81 games with a record of 51 victories and 30 defeats and a four-and-a-half-game lead in the American League East, pending the outcome of Toronto's game at Kansas City last night.

title: Star Qualities
description: To the Editor:

title: A FILM WRITER'S ROUNDABOUT ROUTE TO THE THEATER
description: LEAD: MANY PLAYWRIGHTS, HAV-ing made their mark on Broadway, have been lured West to make their money on movies.

title: 'Packin' Into the Bob' in Montana
description: No roads, no cars, no television, no hotels. Just us, our horses and mules trudging along ancient Indian trails deep into the forest wilderness, just as it must have looked to the Indians who migrated from Asia some 10,000 years ago.

title: THE LIFE OF A DANCER
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE CLUB GIVES YOUTHS PLACE TO BELONG
description: EVERY Saturday night hundreds of teen-agers throng the second floor of a century-old Greenwich church to be a part of the Cafe, a non-alcoholic video dance club. For many of them, the dancing and music that originally attracted them has become less important than the acceptance they find.

title: PRIMO LEVI: RECONCILING THE MAN AND THE WRITER
description: WHEN a writer commits suicide it is difficult not to reinterpret his books in light of his final act.

title: ILLS LINKED TO POOR LENS CARE
description: Improper contact lens care, including the use of homemade rinses, was apparently the chief reason for a number of rare eye infections reported last year, according to Federal scientists.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''We feel responsible for having troubled society.''

title: ANN BLUMENTHAL BECOMES THE BRIDE OF S.P. HEINEMAN
description: The marriage of Ann Marie Blumenthal, the daughter of Mrs. Albert H. Blumenhal of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Mr. Blumenthal, to Scott Philip Heineman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Heineman of Stamford, Conn., and Block Island, R.I., took place yesterday in Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Charles Davidson officiated at Wainright House.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: JULY 5, 1987
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 5 ACT OF WILL, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Bantam, $4.95.) Three generations of talented, ambitious women in England and New York. 2 1 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $3.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia. 3 2 THE EIGHTH COMMANDMENT, by Lawrence Sanders. (Berkley, $4.95.) The tale of a British secret agent and his father, a flamboyant con man. 5 2 MURDER IN GEORGETOWN, by Margaret Truman. (Fawcett, $4.50.) The mystery surrounding the death of a senator's daughter. 6 7 BARRIER ISLAND, by John D. MacDonald. (Fawcett, $4.50.) One man's effort to thwart a multimillion-dollar land swindle. 7 6 HEARTS AFLAME, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $3.95.)
