Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist.

title: HISPANIC REPORT LISTS 4 MAIN ISSUES
description: LEAD: HISPANIC people constitute the fastest-growing segment of the county's population but employment, housing and educational opportunities have failed to keep pace, according to a preliminary report by the county's Hispanic Advisory Board, which pinpointed these problems as the major ones facing the county's 48,000 residents of Hispanic origin.

title: U.S. Lashes Out at Panama Regime
description: The Reagan Administration took aim at Panama's military leadership last week. After anti-American demonstrations at the United States Embassy in Panama City, the State Department said the military had orchestrated them to counter American calls for democratic rule.

title: GRANDMOTHER LEARNS THE FORWARD PASS
description: THE blue football flew perilously near the table lamp.

title: AGNEW DEALINGS REVELAED IN LAWSUIT
description: A case now in the preliminary stages in Federal District Court in Brooklyn provides a rare glimpse of Spiro T. Agnew's activities as an international business broker since leaving the Vice Presidency amid charges of taking bribes and kickbacks.

title: POP FICTION FOR SMART GIRLS
description: I LIKE TO THINK THAT BEFORE I got paid to be a novelist, I was one of the best secretaries in New York. I wore lace-collared dresses, didn't smoke without asking permission and hardly ever called in sick. I typed flawless letters. And I made reservations - in the first-class sections of airplanes, on the concierge floors of fancy hotels. I made them so often at Manhattan restaurants that I knew by name and voice the gentlemen who answered the phone.

title: Students in China Turn Cynical and Apathetic
description: STUDENTS at the University of Science and Technology in Hefei recently pasted narrow scrolls of paper on dormitory door posts, ink-brushed with the following sentiment: ''We are indifferent to all affairs: state affairs, party affairs and world affairs. We turn a deaf ear to all sounds: the sound of wind, the sound of rain and the sound of reading.''

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
Bellerose
description: LEAD: THIRTY-EIGHT years ago, when Frank LoCicero and his wife, Marie, picked out a lot on 242d Street in Bellerose, Queens, for their new two-bedroom ranch home, builders were putting up such houses by the hundreds. The homes were intended for young veterans like Mr. LoCicero and their families.

title: LET THE BEACHES BE TRULY PUBLIC
description: I am writing this in regard to a growing problem that plagues Long Island, New Jersey and I'm sure other areas in our coastal United States. The problem is that of access to public beaches.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Investing column last week misstated the source of a fairness opinion for the 1986 buyout of the Easco Corporation. Easco had retained Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company to evaluate an offer of $20.50 a share, but no investment banker evaluated the final price of $17.50.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN HONEYMOONS;
Love in a (Poconos) Champagne Glass
description: LEAD: IN the old days, spending a week in a Niagara Falls hotel -within range of the thundering sound and misty air of the Falls -was considered by many as the ideal romantic honeymoon.

title: Panelized Construction Is Catching On
description: BUILDING a house in the standard way ''just doesn't make sense'' to Martin Curnan of Bedford, who has discovered he can build a house in three months by using panelized construction.

title: Susan Utley Engaged to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Dexter Utley 2d of Pound Ridge, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Susan Elizabeth Utley to Timothy Proctor Schieffelin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Jay Schieffelin 3d of Mount Kisco, N.Y. An Aug. 29 wedding is planned.

title: POSTINGS: At Battery Park City; Opulent Marina
description: ''St. Tropez wouldn't be St. Tropez if it weren't for the huge yachts in the center of town,'' said George Nicholson, a partner in Watermark Associates. The developer recently received the go-ahead from the Battery Park City Authority to concoct a similar tourist attraction in the Mediterranean mode for the mixed-use development on the Hudson in lower Manhattan.

title: WHEN BALLETIC DREAMS DOUBLE FOR REALITY
description: THE VERSION OF ''CINDEREL-la'' that Rudolf Nureyev has choreographed for the Paris Opera Ballet to Prokofiev's well-known ballet score, and that recently played to packed houses at the Metropolitan Opera House, is set in the Hollywood of the past. With a Cinderella who dreams of becoming a film star, who captures the heart of a leading man and who is under the tutelage of a producer - standing in as her fairy godmother - Mr. Nureyev's updated transposition has many original ideas.

title: JAZZ AND DANCE AT SUMMERFARE FESTIVAL
description: IT is not the oldest summer festival in Westchester, or the longest or the one in the most glamorous setting, but Pepsico's Summerfare at the State University of New York at Purchase continues to be one of the most innovative and imaginative. Not to mention busiest. More than 80 events in at least six performing spaces will crowd the schedule between Friday's opening and the final performances Aug. 2.

title: AT THE HEAD OF THE SENIOR CLASS
description: IN a pro-am outing not long ago, Greg Norman was in a group on the third tee that waited for the golfers ahead of them to move along. It seemed to be taking longer than usual.

title: Critics Fault Accountants For Not Blowing Whistles
description: WHEN the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City failed in 1982, threatening a national banking panic, it could scarcely console investors with a report from a certified public accountant giving it a clean bill of health.

title: REDOING THE GLOBE
description: LEAD: MORTAL RIVALS Superpower Relations From Nixon to Reagan. By William G. Hyland. 271 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: LENDL CLOSES IN ON ULTIMATE GOAL
description: Progress has come slowly, both on and off the court. What is remarkable is that Ivan Lendl has been able to rise to the top of men's tennis and hold his position while the learning process continues. He has been perhaps the least respected of recent champions, considered the interim No. 1 until the next natural comes along to capture the public's fancy.

title: PRISCILLA B. GALPIN TO MARRY KENNETH TWOMBLY AUG. 15
description: Priscilla Bliss Galpin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen K. Galpin of Southport, Conn., and Kenneth L. Twombly, a son of Ellen Brown of Burlington, Vt., and the late Louis Twombly, plan to marry Aug. 15, the future bride's parents have announced.

title: Keep the Radios Broadcasting to the East
description: LEAD: When Moscow announced recently that it would stop its jamming og Voice of America broadcasts, a Soviet spokesman denounced Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, for which it has intensified jamming efforts.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Spokane, Wash.; Walking on Air Downtown
description: TO fight off retail competition from three shopping malls, this city of 180,000 near the Idaho border has linked most of its downtown buildings to a network of sky bridges, and is looking to expand the system even more. While some cities have banned sky bridges, saying they are a threat to street-level activity, local officials say their sheltered street overpasses have kept business in the downtown area alive.

title: JULIA MEANEY TO WED STEPHEN OATWAY
description: The engagement of Julia Anne Meaney to Stephen Francis Oatway, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Carlyle Oatway of New Canaan, Conn., and Pomfret, Vt., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Jay Meaney of New Canaan. The couple plan to marry on Sept. 12.

title: PANAMA'S GOVERNMENT UNLEASHES DRIVE TO BLAME U.S. FOR TROUBLE
description: For 40 years, a bronze statue of Franklin D. Roosevelt has been smiling down at pedestrians along one of Panama's main boulevards. On Thursday, the statue was torn from its pedestal and smashed by anti-American demonstrators.

title: Where to Raft, Bicycle and Sail
description: Following is just a sampling of the many tour companies offering adventure programs in North America; some offer tours abroad as well. Outdoor- oriented programs are also offered by nonprofit organizations such as the Sierra Club.

title: DEMOCRATS PRESENT BOARD CANDIDATES AND OUTLINE ISSUES
description: COUNTY Democrats offered their slate of candidates for election to the Board of Legislators last week, along with a sampling of campaign issues and a pledge to wrest control of the legislative body from the Republicans.

title: Cable TV
description: Gifted pens are the sources of some rewarding film fare on cable this week - like Ernest Hemingway's ''Old Man and the Sea'' (1958), Wednesday at 2:30 P.M. on Cinemax. This simple tale of a grizzled Cuban fisherman battling a huge marlin (Life) is much better suited to the small screen than it was to the large one. The large screen magnified the artifices: cut-in reveries, a flashback sequence to youth and the obvious fact that many of the scenes were shot in a studio tank. We're closer on television to a great actor, Spencer Tracy, who's a soloist in a symphony. For Dimitri Tiomkin's trenchant music, like a Hemingway pulse, is the most eloquent aspect of the movie.

title: Alien Family: The Wait of a Lifetime
description: Early Wednesday morning Mario Marquez put on his best shirt, climbed into his old brown station wagon and drove two hours to St. Albans for the interview that would help shape the rest of his life.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Nudists vs. Birds In Rhode Island

title: JACKIE GLEASON: A YARDSTICK OF THE COMMON MAN
description: IT HAS NEVER FAILED TO REDUCE me to tears: Ralph and Alice Kramden exchange Christmas presents in ''The Honeymooners'' version of ''The Gift of the Magi.'' Ralph has hocked his bowling ball in order to purchase a suitable gift for Alice; she, in turn, gives him a bowling bag. They stare at each other, in that mythic Brooklyn flat - the unadorned table and chairs, the bureau, the icebox, the sink, as imprinted on our memories as the particulars of our own first homes, maybe more so - and for a moment there is embarrassment. Ralph is broke. He has had to pawn his bowling ball. But then a beam of light appears -an epiphany, if you will - and Ralph launches into a paean to the Christmas season: ''You know, Christmas is the greatest time of the year,'' he begins and proceeds to describe a holiday season of ringing church bells, friendly strangers, snow falling in the night - I begin to feel myself go - and finally the knowledge of walking home and of knowing that in that home ''there's someone you're nuts about, someone you really love'' - and I'm gone, a grown man crying at a 1950's sitcom for the 20th time.

title: Making Punishment Fit Crime in Drug Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: MY NEIGHBOR, MY ENEMY
description: MERON BENVENISTI lives in a sprawling old Jerusalem stone house in a mixed neighborhood of Arabs and Jews.

title: AOUITA AND CRAM ARE VICTORS
description: Said Aouita of Morocco and Steve Cram of Britain, the fastest middle-distance runners in history, won their respective races today but failed to come close to their world records during the Bislett Games track and field meet.

title: An Epic Struggle For Gold
description: Never have I seen anything that jolted me so (''An Epic Struggle for Gold,'' Portfolio by Sebastiao Salgado, Text by Marlise Simons, June 7)! The images of a human anthill, Dante's ''Inferno'' and an ancient Roman mine, worked by slave labor, assaulted me all at once. JAMES C. LEVIE Altamonte Springs, Fla.

title: Rubbermaid's Sad Succession Tale
description: THEORY has it that the best way for a chief executive to assure an orderly transition at retirement is to identify and groom an heir apparent a few years ahead of time so that he or she is comfortable with all aspects of the company when the critical time comes. If he has been running a division, bring him into headquarters. If she is strong in finance, give her manufacturing responsibilities.

title: VHS IMPROVES ITS IMAGE
description: UNQUESTIONABLY THE most far-reaching new video development seen at last month's Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago was a new version of the VHS format called Super-VHS - S-VHS for short. It represents a major improvement in picture quality attainable in the VHS format.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE DISHES were washed and dried. The urgent tasks that clog a weekend docket had been scratched off the list or forgotten until next week.

title: SUTCLIFFE WINS 11TH WITH 10 STRIKEOUTS
description: Rick Sutcliffe today became the first National League pitcher with 11 victories, and Bob Dernier went 3 for 4, including a homer, as the Chicago Cubs beat the San Francisco Giants, 5-3.

title: American Jews Are Voicing Their Disquiet
description: IN the months since the revelations about Israeli espionage in Washington, Israel's role in the Iran arms affair, and numerous embarrassing squabbles in the Israeli Government, officials here have been closely monitoring American opinion polls to see if these episodes have affected Israel's standing.

title: Rocky Mountain: Flora, Fauna -- and Trauma
description: Here are some factors in the balance of nature and people in Rocky Mountain National Park. Elk

title: An Epic Struggle For Gold
description: Sebastiao Salgado's stunning pictures of the Brazilian gold field at Serra Pelada show the stark intensity that can be achieved by black-and-white photography - a quality that the superficial intensities of color photography can never equal.

title: RABBI STAND-INS TO AID ISOLATED NEW ENGLAND JEWS
description: In rural New England, where Jews are few and rabbis are as scarce as kosher delicatessens, weddings, burials and other Jewish ceremonies are often presided over by lay people who must limp along with fragments of knowledge remembered from childhood days in Hebrew school.

title: Bombs Kill 10 in Pakistan
description: Three bomb explosions about noon at the city's rail and bus stations killed 10 people and injured about 50 today, the 10th anniversary of the coup that installed Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq as President. Officers said that the first bomb went off on a platform of the main rail station, and that a second exploded near a taxi stand outside. The state radio said the third exploded at the main bus station. No one claimed responsibility for the attacks.

title: ECONOMIC CALENDAR
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Producer Prices ... June

title: I.R.S. Shuffles Its Top Ranks
description: The Internal Revenue Service is reorganizing its top ranks, which will result in the promotion of Michael J. Murphy of Philadelphia to the No. 2 job in the agency. Mr. Murphy, who began his

title: Seoul Says It Freed 177 Political Prisoners
description: The Government today released 177 political prisoners, the first group to be freed under democratic changes approved last week by President Chun Doo Hwan.

title: MAKING IT TO EVEREST'S SUMMIT
description: When Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay made the first ascent to the summit of Mount Everest in May 1953, it was unthinkable for a woman to attempt such a feat.

title: ... WHILE THE JAPANESE RETHINK TRADE STANCE
description: A Japanese-American confrontation over the illegal sale of high-technology propeller-milling equipment to the Soviet Union by the Toshiba Machine Company has provoked a national debate in Japan on many international trade and security issues.

title: BORK COULD TILT LAW AT ONCE IF SEATED
description: An examination of cases pending before the Supreme Court suggests that Judge Robert H. Bork could begin tilting the law to the right on key social issues as early as the Court's fall term.

title: LIMELIGHT SHINES AGAIN ON SONNY CARSON
description: For years, Sonny Carson was synonymous with black protest, sit-ins and the struggle for community control of the city's schools.

title: FROM BOY WONDER TO MAN OF THE HOUR: PATRICK CASH
description: There are probably colleagues in Australia who would argue that some of the white hairs on Ian Barclay's head are a result of his dealings with Patrick Cash, the one-time temperamental teen-ager who overcame chronic injuries and bouts of bad humor to become the men's singles champion at Wimbledon today. Barclay has been Cash's coach for 11 years, spending much of that time ignoring the critics who said that Cash would never amount to anything on a tennis court.

title: Two Great Teachers
description: As economists, Arthur Burns and Walter Heller had fundamentally different philosophies, the one conservative and the other liberal. But as public servants, each brought skill, compassion and integrity to the making of national policy. Both died recently, having served Presidents, nation and their profession with a distinction that few economists can match today.

title: GOOD YEAR IN HOUSING NOW SEEN
description: In spite of the housing market's startlingly dismal showing in May, a number of economists and industry executives expect sales to be healthy through the rest of the year - just as long as there is not an unexpected jump in mortgage rates.

title: RANDOLPH: BIG BROTHER OF YANKEE FAMILY
description: HE was a young player with a new team. He was not a rookie, although one of the older players on the club, Thurman Munson, liked to call him that every so often. Just to needle the kid, just to see how much he could take around the batting cage.

title: ON EVE OF NEW HAITI PROTEST, BISHOPS PLEAD FOR RESTRAINT
description: With tension growing on the eve of a planned resumption of anti-Government protests, Haiti's Roman Catholic bishops appealed today for restraint and warned of ''the specter of anarchy and civil war.''

title: SMALL STUDIOS' TOUGH SEASON
description: The summer movie season has been a smash for some of Hollywood's big studios. Hits such as Paramount's ''Beverly Hills Cop II'' and Warner's ''Witches of Eastwick'' have spun turnstiles nationwide and pleased investors in the studios' parent companies, Gulf and Western and Warner Communications.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Has there ever been a major league game in which a team scored in every inning?

title:
Market Place;
Hedging Risk For Developers
description: LEAD: FEW, if any, real estate developers who have been in the business any length of time will forget 1981.

title: SPECTATOR AT FIREWORKS KILLED IN FALL INTO RIVER
description: A man watching the Manhattan fireworks display Saturday night from a friend's boat in the East River died after he fell overboard and his left arm was severed by a boat's propeller, the police said yesterday.

title: British Editor Retires
description: Lord Hartwell, chairman and editor-in-chief of Britain's Daily Telegraph and Sunday Telegraph newspapers, is retiring after a 30-year career, The Sunday Telegraph announced. He will be succeeded by Conrad Black, a Canadian businessman who owns a majority interest in The Daily Telegraph Ltd. Lord Hartwell, 76 years old, will remain a director of the company.

title: Siemens Cites Lower Profits
description: Siemens A.G., the West German electronics giant, said Saturday that profits for its current fiscal year would fall.

title: I.B. SINGER PROFILED ON PBS
description: Anyone who has seen Isaac Bashevis Singer perform in public knows he is a natural, delivering high wit in a down-to-earth way, answering questions from an audience as though they were plants for punch lines. By now, at the age of 83, he has been on the circuit so long that he has heard most of the questions - ''Do you believe in free will?'' - and has had plenty of time to hone his answers: ''We must believe in free will. We have no choice.'' It may be a routine, but it's a good one.

title: PAUL FROMM, CLASSICAL-MUSIC PATRON, IS DEAD
description: Paul Fromm, a German-born wine importer who became the most active and distinguished private patron of contemporary classical music in the United States, died Saturday at the Bernard Mitchell Hospital of the University of Chicago after a series of heart attacks. He was 80 years old and had lived in Chicago.

title: CHILDREN IN DEBT TO PARENTS
description: ''NEITHER a borrower, nor a lender be.'' Fine for Shakespeare to say, but then Shakespeare didn't have the down payment on a house to make or a parent willing to help him make it. Still, given the dicey issues of independence and control that often stand between parent and adult child, when money is added to the mix, psychologists say, caution is advised.

title: IN THIS 'GAME OF WAR,' THE RACE IS TO THE CUNNING
description: At midnight the heat of a Tuscan summer day is just passing. Usually the steep little streets of this hilltown are dark and empty. But just before the Palio, Siena is awake with expectations and plotting.

Mr. White continues as chief executive and was named vice chairman.

description: A black bow hung on City Hall in this central Mexican farm town that was home for seven of the 18 illegal aliens who suffocated in a boxcar in Texas.

Pitching, defense, speed and depth were attributes usually found in the opponent's dugout, a shortcoming that kept the Twins from serious contention in the American League

title: WHAT DO YOU CALL ART'S NEWEST TREND: 'NEO-GEO'... MAYBE
description: There was Abstract Expressionism, followed by Pop, Op, Color Field, Minimalism, Conceptual art and Neo-Expressionism. Each of the succession of trends that has characterized American art since the end of World War II has had its brand name. And yet the newest one - well established and shown at the hottest galleries -still has no real handle. Borrowing from Pop, Minimal and Conceptual art, and heavily involved with social theories, it is variously referred to as Smart Art, Post-Abstract Abstraction, neo-Conceptualism, Simulationism or simply Neo-Geo, short for ''new geometry.''

description: Having gathered more than three dozen family members in a White House reception room, the white-haired patriarch seemed suddenly to sense that this was the perfect occasion to explain why he did not become President.

description: Oooooh!

But in trying to justify big-time college sports at the National Collegiate Athletic Association's special convention last week, Frank E. Horton talked about how the attraction of football and basketball games provides spectators with the opportunity to visit campus museums.

title: Shortage of Workers Seen

description: With one of the most efficient winning rounds of the year on the PGA Tour, Curtis Strange captured the 78th Canadian Open by three shots today. He said the most rewarding part of his victory was that he virtually assured himself a spot on the 1987 United States Ryder Cup team.

According to Gilbert Cates, president of the Directors Guild of America, the producers have not yet responded to a guild counterproposal that was offered last Wednesday, and guild negotiators, who had expected to meet with the producers today, were left to wait outside the deliberations. ''They've been stringing us along,'' Mr. Cates said.

title: FIESTA GAL SHOWS SHE ISN'T OVERRATED

description: BBDO International, parent of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn and one of the reasons that Madison Avenue is synonymous with advertising, has left that fabled strip after 64 years to take up residence at 1285 Avenue of the Americas. At its new location, near 51st

title: BLACK RADICALS WERE KEY TOPIC IN POLICE SESSION
description: About 450 New York City police commanders received briefings on a group of self-proclaimed black revolutionaries as part of training sessions they attended in the last two months on how to deal with demonstrations and riots, police officials said yesterday.

title: FREER FARM TRADE BY THE END OF '88 SET AS REAGAN AIM
description: The Administration will announce on Monday that it intends to seek agreements by the end of President Reagan's term to phase out farm export subsidies and trade barriers to the agricultural products of the United States and other nations, officials said today.

title: GIANTS AND THE PADRES MAKE 7-PLAYER TRADE
description: The seven-player trade between the San Francisco Giants and San Diego Padres left both teams contending today that they had gotten just what they wanted.

title: TRUMP FEUD: BARBS SHOW DEEPER SPLIT
description: The feud between Mayor Koch and Donald J. Trump, viewed primarily as a personal spat between two powerful public figures, is more importantly a rupture in one of New York City's key economic-development partnerships, experts say.

title: ALGERIA MARKS 25 YEARS AND LOOKS TO ITS YOUTH
description: This North African nation today celebrated the 25th anniversary of its independence from France.

title: Say No to the Pharaonic Tank
description: The Defense Department has agreed in principle to let Egypt build a plant to produce the M1-A1, the most modern version of the U.S. Army's new main battle tank. Even though America, after the Camp David peace accords, became a principal source of arms for Egypt, co-producing the M-1 makes little sense either for Cairo or Washington. The M-1 embodies almost everything the U.S. Army knows about how to make tanks. None have yet been sold abroad. Letting the tanks be assembled in Egypt will inevitably hasten leakage of the secrets of their construction. The M1-A1, the latest version of the M-1, has a more powerful gun designed to defeat improved Soviet tanks that have not yet even been fielded. It is foolish for America to export its most advanced arms to countries that don't need them. Egypt plans to build 1,000 or more M1-A1's. Against whom are they to be deployed? America has no desire to see them used against Israel. As for Libya, Chad convincingly demonstrated last March at Wadi Doum that antitank missiles mounted on jeeps suffice to defeat Libyan tank forces. Unless Egypt expects a Soviet invasion, what military need justifies such a fleet?

title: Waite Reported Dead; Officials Doubt Rumor
description: A local newspaper reported today that the missing hostage negotiator Terry Waite had died of natural causes, but Lebanese and Syrian officials in Beirut discounted the report.

title: Bridge: A Deal in Wartime England Was Occasion of a Rare Bid
description: Very early in this century one of the inimitable English characters created by ''Saki'' considered the possibility of giving up bridge for a month, as a mark of respect to a deceased relative. He rejected the idea, and satisfied his conscience by bidding only in black suits for the same period.

title: YONKERS COUNCIL FACES HOUSING PLAN DEADLINE
description: When Oscar Newman began several months ago to look for sites in Yonkers for subsidized housing, a move ordered by a Federal judge to correct 40 years of housing segregation, he said he found little help from city officials.

title: OUTDOORS: CASTING ON STILL WATERS
description: HEAVY rain and his daughter Cathy's wedding caused Vic Pomiecko of Claremont, N.H., and me to modify our annual June trout-fishing excursion in northern New England.

title: THIS WEEK'S AUCTION LIMITED TO BILLS
description: Treasury sales this week are confined to the bill market, where the only activity will be centered on today's $13.2 billion auction of three- and six-month bills. The bulk of the proceeds will be used to pay off securities reaching maturity, with only $1.13 billion in new cash to be realized.

title: Calm Summer Is Anticipated
description: The calm that descended on the credit markets a few weeks ago could continue well into the summer, analysts and traders say, setting the stage for steady to modest declines in interest rates.

title: Blacks Settle Bias Suit Filed Against L.I.R.R. and 14 Unions
description: After 15 years of legal wrangling, the Long Island Rail Road has reached an out-of-court settlement in a class-action suit that had charged the commuter line and 14 of its unions with discrimination against blacks in hiring and promotion.

title: 7-ELEVEN OWNER IN $5 BILLION DEAL TO SELL COMPANY
description: The Southland Corporation, which operates the 7-Eleven stores, said yesterday that it would be taken over by a company owned by Southland's founding Thompson family in a deal valued at about $5.1 billion.

title: PATENT A VINDICATION FOR GENETICS CHIEF
description: Last week, when Genetics Institute Inc. beat its biotech rival, the Amgen Corporation, to get the first patent on erythropoietin, or EPO, many analysts and investors were surprised. And for Gabriel Schmergel, president and chief executive of Genetics, who has maintained a low profile for the Cambridge, Mass.-based company, the patent was a personal vindication.

title: IN THE ARCTIC TUNDRA, THUNDER OF OTTAWA'S MILITARY BUILDUP
description: More than four centuries after the English adventurer Sir Martin Frobisher found this place, new intruders are disturbhg the Arctic peace.

title: A Model of French Justice
description: According to the elaborate French procedure, the jury and the judges had to answer 341 specific questions on the guilt of Klaus Barbie. To 340, they said yes. The last question asked whether there were mitigating circumstances, and that answer was no. Then sentence was pronounced, permanent imprisonment for crimes against humanity.

title: Nancy Bess Edelstein Is Bride of Richard G. Spiro
description: Nancy Bess Edelstein and Richard Glenn Spiro, magna cum laude graduates of Princeton University, were married yesterday at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, L.I., by Rabbi Jack Tauber.

title: BITTERSWEET NEW YORK RETURN FOR N.A.A.C.P. CONVENTION
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People returned to New York City for its annual convention yesterday, with words of praise and criticism for the home the organization reluctantly abandoned one year ago.

title: RATINGS DISPUTE DELAYS TV AD SALES
description: A small beige plastic box known as a ''people meter'' has thrown the television networks' advance, or up-front, advertising sales into disarray, with negotiations at a virtual standstill between the three leading networks and the top advertising agencies.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Our Incredible Shrinking Language
description: LEAD: I recently sat through a graduation ceremony in which one of the speakers used the adjective ''incredible'' four times and its synonym ''unbelievable'' once. He was referring to the achievements of several individuals in the senior class and on the faculty during the academic year just ending.

title: Sale of Maker Of 'Mr. Coffee'
description: North American Systems Inc., which manufactures the ''Mr. Coffee'' automatic coffee maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired in a leveraged buyout through a partnership formed by McKinley Allsopp Inc. The terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: 'Glasphalt' To Sparkle On Streets
description: Next spring, three blocks in Brooklyn will glisten with a new kind of asphalt, known as ''glasphalt,'' that is 40 percent glass.

title: ON MIDDLE EAST POLICY, A MAJOR INFLUENCE
description: After several decades of growth in size and sophistication, the leading pro-Israel lobby in Washington, the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, has become a major force in shaping United States policy in the Middle East.

title: Ingrid D. Baker, a Teacher, and Dr. Jack Bloom Are Wed
description: Ingrid Daube Baker, the dean of students and a teacher of German at the Ridgefield (Conn.) High School, was married yesterday to Dr. Jack H. Bloom, a psychologist in Fairfield, Conn. Rabbi Joseph Glaser officiated at the couple's home in Fairfield.

title: Toward Bigger Money
description: The Fund for New Leadership, Washington's young and upwardly mobile political action committee for young and upwardly mobile Democrats, is showing signs of, well, age.

title: Panama's Strongman Must Go
description: LEAD: The United States must nudge Panama's strongman, Gen.

title: U.S. SETS TERMS FOR REASSESSING ITS ROLE IN GULF
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the White House chief of staff, said today that the United States might ''take a fresh look'' at withdrawing its warships from the Persian Gulf if the Soviet Union removed its naval vessels from the area.

title: POLITICAL ACTIVISTS WEIGH U.S. 'GREEN' MOVEMENT
description: Political activists representing a broad spectrum of ideological shadings have assembled here to raise a new Green political banner.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JULY 6, 1987
description: International 2-6 An end to farm export subsidies and trade barriers to agricultural products of the United States and other nations by the end of President Reagan's term will be sought, the Administration will announce today.

title: Creation Science Staggers Under Load of Ironies
description: To the Editor:

title: MANSELL REPEATS VICTORY IN FRANCE
description: Nigel Mansell of Great Britain won his second straight French Grand Prix today as Alain Prost of France missed another chance for a record 28th career Formula One victory.

title: Advertising; Katsoff Is Publisher Of Psychology Today
description: Sherwood (Woody) Katsoff, one-time publisher of Hearst's Science Digest, has become publisher of Psychology Today, now published by the American Psychological Association.

title: JAZZ: MARIO BUAZA ORCHESTRA
description: Mario Bauza and his Afro-Cuban Jazz Orchestra made a mightily musical tumult at S.O.B.'s on Thursday. Mr. Bauza, a Cuban reed man and trumpeter who played with Cab Calloway and Chick Webb before spending 35 years as musical director for Machito's Latin jazz orchestra, certainly knows how to mold a collection of capable musicians into a first-class band. His brass and reed sections were precise and sparkling, and his percussionists threatened to lift the bandstand with their intensely propulsive variations on Cuban rhythms. The music's energy and good humor were irresistible, but the exuberance never got out of hand; Mr. Bauza had everything under control at all times.

title: Odometer Shift Cited at G.M.
description: As many as 2,000 odometers on General Motors Corporation trucks and utility vehicles were replaced or turned back during the last four years to conceal mileage accumulated on the vehicles by managers, The Oakland Press reported today.

title: GROUP FOR RETIRED TO PRESS '88 HOPEFULS ON CONCERNS OF ELDERLY
description: The American Association of Retired Persons, whose 25 million members make it one of the largest nonreligious organizations in the country, is moving into Presidential politics for the first time.

title: Public Housing Returns Good Value for Money
description: To the Editor:

title: ERNEST BLOCH'S 'AMERICA,' AT WATERLOO
description: Ernest Bloch came to America from Switzerland in 1916 and became a citizen eight years later. As most immigrant composers do sooner or later, he conceived a musical response to his new home; in his case it was sooner -1926 - and the feelings American history aroused in him were perhaps somewhat undigested. ''America, an Epic Rhapsody'' is not frequently revived. Both the comparative neglect and the occasional flickers of interest (Leopold Stokowski's, for instance) were easy to understand when the Waterloo Festival Orchestra played the work here on its Independence Day concert under Gerard Schwarz.

title: FATE OF MUSEUM ON SLAVERY IN DOUBT
description: With a hand-stitched mouth and button eyes, a mammy doll made by a slave for the 16-year-old child of her master lies in a display case here, a mute reminder of the peculiar institution slavery once was.

title: YOUNG CAMBODIANS IN VERMONT TRY TO COPE
description: Libbet Downs tells the story of the Cambodian boy whose American foster parents took the light bulb from his room because they had run out of spare bulbs. The boy immediately stopped talking to his foster family and would not eat meals with them. The silence went on for weeks.

title: GEORGE E. SPARGO
description: George E. Spargo, former general manager of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority in New York City, died Saturday at the Miami Heart Institute. He was 84 years old.

title: Advertising; Ex-Chief Of DYR To Ogilvy
description: TWO days after his retirement from the DYR agency became official, Alexander Brody became president-international of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, the fifth-largest American agency.

title: 'THE UNTOUCHABLES': DE PALMA'S DEPARTURE
description: As Brian De Palma movies go, ''The Untouchables'' is kind of tame. Quite a lot of blood is splattered on various walls in the course of the film, but for the director of such movie milestones as the chainsaw execution in ''Scarface'' and the electric drill murder in ''Body Double,'' that's small change. Then again, this time someone else - namely David Mamet - wrote the script.

title: Give Campaign Reform a Chance
description: Mayor Koch and other members of New York City's Board of Estimate accepted $9 million in campaign gifts in 1985. Fully half the money came from only 175 donors - real estate developers, brokerage houses and others doing business with the city. One way or another, that kind of money inevitably purchases influence. A bill being pushed in Albany by Mr. Koch would reduce the corrosive effect of such money on New York City's politics. Though it would do nothing about the rest of the state, it still deserves passage.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: After 5 Stages, Swiss Leads Tour: Marc Sergeant of Belgium won the 70-mile fifth stage of the Tour de France from Pforzheim, West Germany, to Strasbourg, France, yesterday while Erich Maechler of Switzerland kept the overall lead. Another Belgian cyclist, Herman Frison, won the fourth leg of the race, a 47.4-mile course run earlier in the day from Stuttgart, West Germany, to Pforzheim. The two stages yesterday saw little change in the overall standing. Maechler, who took the lead on Saturday, retained the lead with a total time of 12 hours 55 minutes 15 seconds, followed by Joerg Mueller of Switzerland, 44 seconds behind. (AP) After 8 Grueling Days, a Victor: Inga Thompson Benedict of the 7-Eleven team won the Ore-Ida Women's Challenge, which ended Saturday after eight days and more than 300 miles of racing over desert, mountain passes and city streets in Idaho. She won despite not winning the final stage of the competition, a 30-lap race over a one-mile course in Boise. Benedict finished in an overall time of 12:01:35, 27 seconds ahead of Katrin Tobin, who rode for the Lowry's team.(AP) Horse Show Brown Wins Show-Jumping Trial: Buddy Brown of Oyster Bay, L.I., moved closer to his third trip to the Pan American Games with a victory in a show-jumping selection trial yesterday at the I Love New York Horse Show in Lake Placid. After completing the 17-jump 668-yard first-round course without penalty, 18 of 48 starting horses returned for a timed jump-off over the eight-jump 318-yard second-round course. Riding fourth in the jump-off, Greg Best of Flemington, N.J., turned in a fault-free ride in 38.382 seconds on Gem Twist, an 8-year-old gelding. Best's lead held through the next seven rides until Brown's clean ride in 35.983 seconds on Aramis, a 10-year-old German-bred gelding. The Pan American Games will be held in Indianapolis next month. Yacht Racing Stars & Stripes Loses: Philip Thomson skippered Australia's Steak 'n' Kidney to a 12-second victory over Dennis Connor's Stars & Stripes on a shortened course in the semifinal round of the 12-Meter world championships off Porto Cervo, Sardinia. In the other semifinal matches, Australia's Kookaburra II beat Britain's White Horse Challenge; New Zealand beat Sfida Italiana, and Bengal, another Australian boat, beat Entertainer 12 of Sweden.(AP) Dog Show Big Time for Jazzman: A barkless dog, Ch. Music City Serengeti's Jazzman, a basenji owned by Karen Jenkins and Margaret Gougelman, made himself heard yesterday at the 40th all-breed show of the Wallkill Kennel Club in Newburgh, N.Y. He was named best of 1,371 dogs on the grounds of the Temple Hill School. It was the 10th major award for the 3-year-old dog, the top-winning basenji in the nation. Boxing Suarez in an Upset: Lupe Suarez scored an upset unanimous decision yesterday over Juan LaPorte, the World Boxing Council's No. 1-rated super featherweight, in a bout at Las Vegas, Nev. The title is vacant. It was relinquished last month by Julio Cesar Chavez. Suarez is now 23-1 with 18 knockouts. LaPorte, a former W.B.C. featherweight champion from Brooklyn, is 29-8 with 15 knockouts.

title: BLUE JAYS SUFFER 8TH STRAIGHT LOSS
description: George Brett's single into center field scored Willie Wilson from second base in the 10th inning today as the Kansas City Royals beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 4-3. The Blue Jays lost their eighth game in a row and remained five games behind the first-place Yankees in the American League East. The Yankees lost to the Texas Rangers, 10-4.

title: BALLET: THE BOLSHOI, IN ''HIGHLIGHTS' PROGRAMS
description: The ''Highlights'' ballet program was popularized, if not invented, as a genre by the Bolshoi Ballet when the company from Moscow made its American debut in New York in 1959.

title: When Japan-Bashing Goes Too Far
description: Sales of submarine propeller equipment to the Soviet Union by companies in Japan and Norway rightly arouses Congressional fury. The crime was outrageous and the punishment by Tokyo and Oslo seemed paltry by comparison. But imposing American sanctions, as a Senate amendment to the trade bill would do, is not the answer. Cooperating to fix the damage, as now proposed by the two allies, is the correct start.

title: Young Artists
description: To encourage young artists, the Congressional Art Caucus sponsors an annual competition for high school students. Winners have their works exhibited at the Capitol.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WHEN RABBIT HOWLS. By the Troops for Truddi Chase. Introduction and epilogue by Robert A. Phillips Jr., Ph.D. 415 pages. Dutton. $18.95.

title: GOODEN ROCKED EARLY IN 7-5 LOSS
description: Despite his insistence that the Mets' off-field problems had been resolved, Manager Dave Johnson held another team meeting before this afternoon's game.

title: Tax Lawyer Negotiates For Netherlands Antilles
description: Stephen A. Nauheim, a Washington tax lawyer, has been spending his time trying to negotiate a new tax treaty between the United States and the Netherlands Antilles that affects the Eurobond market, bondholders and American corporations.

title: FOR NAVRATILOVA, VICTORIES GET SWEETER
description: She now shares the stage with Helen Wills Moody as the most successful Wimbledon champion of all time, with eight singles titles, and stands alone after winning her sixth in a row Saturday. But when Martina Navratilova returns to the tennis tour after a brief vacation at her home in Fort Worth, she will find Steffi Graf waiting to continue their joust for the No. 1 ranking.

title: CASH OVERPOWERS LENDL TO WIN WIMBLEDON
description: He is a rogue among tennis players, dashing in his familiar checked bandana, blunt to a fault, looking forward, he said, to the day when he will sit with his friends in a neighborhood pub, telling stories, getting fat on beer. But Pat Cash had another dream as well while growing up in Australia, one that was finally realized today on the dusty, pockmarked remains of a grass court at Wimbledon.

title: LaRouche Set to Surrender
description: Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the perennial Presidential candidate who favors conspiracy theories, said this weekend that his indictment by a Federal grand jury in Boston was a ''political dirty trick.'' But he said he would surrender to the authorities in the United States this week. He denied that he ordered his followers to impede an investigation of fraud.

title: FURY AND TURMOIL: DAYS THAT SHOOK KOREA
description: On Friday, June 19, after a night of violent demonstrations that saw riot policemen lose control of the streets to anti-Government protesters, President Chun Doo Hwan was ready to call troops into Seoul and other embattled cities.

title: The Graduate
description: Senator Wendell H. Ford, a Kentucky Democrat who never graduated from college, finally got a college degree the other day. Not only that, he was named commencement speaker and president of the graduating class - at the University of Hard Knocks.

title: Investment in Korea Up
description: South Korea reported a sharp rise today in foreign investments in the country during the first half of this year. The Ministry of Finance said investments increased more than fourfold, to $411 million, from the first six months of last year. Foreign investment for all of 1986 totaled $343 million, the Government said.

title: HONORS FOR DOBY
description: It was 40 years ago yesterday that Larry Doby followed Jackie Robinson to become the second black player, and first in the American League, to play major league baseball. Doby, now a New Jersey resident, is not being forgotten in his home state.

title: Sticky Situation
description: If a fan is ever lucky (or unlucky) enough to stand in a baseball team's dugout after a game, he or she may ask, ''Why are my feet sticking to the floor?''

title: YANKS' ARMS HAVE TOO SHORT A REACH
description: The Yankees' starting pitchers are giving Manager Lou Piniella a headache and the Yankees' relief pitchers tired arms. The result is a vicious circle that first-place teams shouldn't have to worry about.

title: SCOTT AND HATCHER HELP ASTROS TOP PHILS
description: Billy Hatcher had four singles, drove in one run and scored twice today as Mike Scott and the Houston Astros defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 8-2.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: 3 Women

title: INSIDE
description: Bork and the Social Issues

title: Miss Rosenblum Is Married to Philip N. Warburg
description: The marriage of Tamar Rosenblum, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Herbery Rosenblum of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., to Philip Neff Warburg, a son of Joan Melber Warburg of Greenwich, Conn., and the late James P. Warburg, took place yesterday at Temple Emanuel in Newton Centre, Mass. The bride's father, the rabbi of Temple Israel in Wilkes-Barre, performed the ceremony.

title: Don't Cast Kuwait as Villain of the Persian Gulf
description: To the Editor:

title: BURN VICTIM IN CHILE CONFRONTS ARMY
description: Carmen Gloria Quintana, back in Chile for the prosecution of the soldiers who she says set her afire during anti-Government protests a year ago, says the military prosecutor tried to prevent her from identifying the patrol leader.

title: Air Afrique Warns Debtors
description: The multinational airline Air Afrique is in grave danger of folding unless debts owed to it are paid soon, Auxence Ickonga, the director general, said at a shareholders meeting.

title: KINGMAN TO JOIN GIANTS' FARM CLUB
description: Dave Kingman, who is 58 home runs shy of the 500 mark, is ready to join the Class AAA Phoenix Firebirds in hopes of returning to the big leagues.

title: AS HOSPITALS CLOSE, RURAL AMERICA TRIES TO COPE WITH A VOID
description: The Knox County Hospital survived the terrible tornado of 1963, but it could not withstand the fierce winds of medical and economic change of the 1980's.

title: AN 'OLYMPICS OF THE MIND' DRAWS BLACKS
description: Seventeen-year-old Brian Hooker came away from last year's ''olympics of the mind'' with a gold medal in mathematics, a silver medal in chemistry, a new personal computer and the inspiration to continue pursuing academic interests.

title: ELLERY HUNTINGTON Jr.
description: Ellery C. Huntington Jr., a retired lawyer and corporate executive who was a United States liaison officer with Marshal Tito's partisans during World War II, died Thursday at Alexandria (Va.) Hospital. He was 94 years old and lived in Alexandria.

title: IN KWANGJU, RAGE AND NEW CYNICISM
description: Seven years have passed since his eldest son was killed by the police, but Chun Kae Ryang is not the type to forgive and forget.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There was one thing I wanted to do in my career and I did it today.'' - Pat Cash, Wimbledon champion. [ 17:6. ]

title: Why New York City Must Pay More Attention to Day Care
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 900 NUMBER AS AUDIENCE POLLSTER
description: Television is using the telephone as an instrument of audience opinion, asking for votes on everything from whether Bernhard Goetz is guilty, to who will win the Super Bowl, to whether a particular television pilot would succeed or fail, but opinion among television executives is divided. The ballots are cast by calling numbers with a 900 prefix; the opinion calls are counted rather than answered. To vote for the Denver Broncos, viewers dial one number. To vote for the New Jersey Giants, they dial another. There is a charge to the caller, usually of 50 cents, a percentage of which is given to the station, which pays nothing for the service.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JULY 6, 1987
description: Washington

title: OIL SHOCK CHANGING VENEZUELA
description: At an elegant reception here one recent evening, a local businessman looked delighted when a foreign visitor tasted a piece of cheese and nodded his approval. ''It's Venezuelan,'' the businessman interjected proudly. ''We make cheese now.'' In its television spots inviting the public to attend, the annual toy fair in Caracas added a twist to its message this year: The toys on display were all manufactured in Venezuela.

title: Panama Sends Envoy To Meet U.S. Aides
description: Panama has sent a special envoy here to meet with American officials in an effort to reduce tensions between the Reagan Administration and the Panamanian Government headed by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noreiga, according to Panamanian officials.

title: 2, Delayed Reaching Care, Die
description: Two people died here over the Fourth of July weekend after ambulance rides prolonged by hospital emergency room service cutbacks linked to Florida's medical malpractice crunch.

title: Advertising; Fall Debut for Premiere
description: Peter Eldridge, recently named publisher of Premiere magazine, a joint venture of Murdoch Magazines and Hachette, the French publisher, has announced that the first issue of the magazine of the movies will be its October issue, due on the newsstands Sept. 5. Its circulation rate base is set at 250,000, with four-color advertising pages selling for $9,500 and black and white at $6,750.

title: SLOWDOWN IN GROWTH REPORTED
description: The nation's industrial economy continued to expand in June, with increases in production, orders and employment, but the overall rate of growth was slower than in the prior two months, the National Association of Purchasing Managers said in its latest report, released today.

title: BERNARD U. TAYLOR
description: Bernard U. Taylor, a voice teacher who was a former chairman of the voice department at the Juilliard School of Music, died Saturday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MORE HOMELESS SEEK HARBOR AT AIRPORTS
description: The elderly man, stretched out on newspapers in a quiet corner of one of the arrival buildings at Kennedy International Airport, insisted that he was waiting for a sister-in-law who would be flying in soon.

title: CARNEGIE FUND HONORS DEEDS OF HEROISM BY 19
description: When Darrell Van Etten Sr. saw a man slumped at the wheel of a burning car, he moved instantly to save him, ''just as any other American, any other human being, would have done,'' he said.

title: SWEET GROWTH: WINERIES THRIVE IN FINGER LAKES
description: Outside this town near the western shore of Cayuga Lake, fresh paint shines on the new road signs that invite motorists to visit the Hosmer Winery.

title: Willie Nelson Plans A Benefit for Farmers
description: Willie Nelson, the country singer, told more than 25,000 people who attended his 12th annual Fourth of July picnic that his next project would be a third benefit concert for the nation's farmers.

title: JAPANESE TAKEOVERS 'A TRICKLE'
description: Enough conditions seem to be in place for a wave of Japanese takeovers of American companies.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET JOURNALISM EXPLORED
description: SPACE BRIDGES have their uses; ''U.S.A.-U.S.S.R. Space Bridge'' is an example. If nothing else, only one participant blows a kiss. Meanwhile, there is no group singing. This particular space bridge, on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, is more serious than that, and also more genuinely entertaining. It deals with a real issue: the difference between American and Soviet journalists. How do they do their jobs?

title: SOVIET AUTHORS TO PUBLISH IN U.S.
description: After years of false starts and dashed hopes, American publishers are again to begin publishing books from the Soviet Union - not books by emigre or dissident authors, but novels and short stories by authors who continue to live in the Soviet Union and who are relatively unknown in the West.

title: MARINE'S RAPE CONVICTION VOIDED AS COURT CALLS DEFENSE INADEQUATE
description: The nation's highest military court today reversed the conviction of a Marine Corps corporal for rape and attempted murder because his civilian lawyer fell ''far short of reasonable competence'' in not investigating the defendant's alibi.

title: London Stocks Spurt
description: Stock prices continued their record-breaking run today, with The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares up a strong 23.8 points, to 2,351.9. The recent rally has been fueled by overseas buying. A firmer British pound and a rise in British Government bonds have also helped stocks, dealers said.

title: 5 YOUNG LAWYERS WHO WOULD BE HEROS... AND A MARINE WHO WEARS A HERO'S RIBBONS
description: For talented young prosecutors, it is the best assignment since the fall of Richard M. Nixon.

title: INDIAN MUSEUM LEADERS SEEM DETERMINED TO LEAVE NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: Friend or Foe? Bullfrogs Can Tell
description: MALE bullfrogs can distinguish between familiar and unfamiliar bullfrogs by the pattern and location of their croaks, a biologist has found.

title: First Chicago Names Officer
description: J. Mikesell Thomas, senior vice president and treasurer of the First Chicago Corporation, has been named chief financial officer and executive vice president of the nation's 11th-largest bank holding company.

title: DREW INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes income of $135,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-Includes income of $265,000 for the quarter and a loss of $2,968,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Weather Report in the Late Edition on June 14 and 15 carried outdated figures for temperatures, precipitation and forecasts in most of the section on United States and foreign cities. Readers wishing corrected listings may write to the News Desk, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Carson Pirie Scott
description: The Mutual Shares Corporation, a New York-based investment firm, and a group of its affiliates have purchased the equivalent of 6.8 percent of Carson Pirie Scott & Company's 10.5 million shares outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mutual said that it had purchased the shares of the Chicago-based retailer ''for the purpose of investment'' only. Carson Pirie's stock had been volatile because of takeover rumors. Between May 27 and July 2, Mutual purchased 600,700 Carson Pirie shares for prices ranging from $48.50 to $51 a share. Mutual also holds 3,695 debentures, which it says are convertible into 93,544 Carson common shares.

title: McCall Pattern's Head Pleased by New Owner
description: The McCall Pattern Company has been through several ownership changes that were not all good for its business. But being sold to its new owner, a British company called the John Crowther Group, ''is probably the best thing that ever happened to us,'' said Robert L. Hermann.

title: A Piano Series At Rutgers
description: The Rutgers Summerfest Piano Institute will begin a three-week series of performances, master classes, individual instruction, panels and workshops on Monday. At 8 P.M., the Summerfest director, Ilana Vered, will head a group of pianists in a performance of works for multiple pianos by Mozart, Liszt, Brahms and Bartok.

title: CONVICTED KILLER IS PUT TO DEATH IN VIRGINIA
description: A man convicted of strangling and slashing the throat of an elderly neighbor and sexually assaulting her corpse was electrocuted today, the first execution in Virginia in almost a year.

title: Talking Business/with Currey of Greyhound; The Proposal For Trailways
description: The Greyhound Lines bus company, which is now owned by a group of Dallas investors, received tentative permission late last week to take over the money-losing Trailways Corporation, its main competitor. Greyhound had asked for quick approval, warning that Trailways was in poor shape and that if the Interstate Commerce Commission took its time there would be little of value to take over. The Justice Department at first opposed the $80 million bid, saying that combining the nation's only two national bus systems could raise serious anti-competitive problems. Later, however, it found that the acquisition was necessary because Trailways was on the brink of bankruptcy. Fred G. Currey, the chairman and president of Greyhound and a past president of Trailways, discusses the competitive effects of his company's bid. Q. Must Trailways be taken over quickly? A. According to the affidavits filed by its chief financial officer and its lead bank, which have been concurred in by the Justice Department, Trailways is a failed company. Frankly, without our intervention Trailways's collapse is imminent and inevitable. * * *

title: Savannah Police Suit Settled
description: A man wounded by two police officers in a confrontation last year outside a bank agreed today to settle his $8.7 million lawsuit against the city. Details of the settlement were not released immediately, but The Savannah Evening Press reported that Otis H. Parker will receive more than $700,000 from the city. Mr. Parker was shot three times outside a bank where his wife, Viola, was using an automatic teller machine. The Parkers said they thought the plainclothes officers were robbers. The officers said they identified themselves as police and fired only after Mr. Parker pulled a rifle on them.

title: KNICK COACH HUNT HITS SNAG
description: The issue of compensation has stymied the Knicks in their bid to hire Jimmy Rodgers as their coach, according to sources close to the negotiations. Unless the Knicks sweeten their offer, something the Boston Celtics do not expect, Rodgers will be back on the Celtic bench next season as K. C. Jones's assistant and the director of player personnel.

title: DYNAMICS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for 12wks to June 13
description: Revenue represents contract revenue.

title: New Charges Are Filed On Hijacking Suspect
description: New charges, including murder and air piracy, were filed today against a Lebanese man arrested in connection with the 1985 hijacking of a Trans World Airlines jet, a justice official reported.

title: AUTO JOB GUARANTEES SOUGHT
description: By Christmas David Sole expects to lose the job he has held for 16 years at the General Motors Corporation's antiquated Fleetwood plant in southwest Detroit. G.M. is closing the 70-year-old auto plant and laying off 3,000 workers as part of its effort to eliminate older, inefficient factories.

title: ROBERTSON BID RELYING ON CAUCUS AND FERVOR
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson's political advisers are basing his pending bid for the Republican Presidential nomination on a strategy that stresses gathering delegates in caucus states and counts on a strong showing among Southerners in the regional primary March 8.

title: AFGHAN AIR WAR: U.S. MISSILE SCORES ON RUSSIANS
description: Afghan guerrillas have been destroying Soviet and Afghan aircraft at the rate of more than one a day since the insurgents started using Stinger missiles supplied by the United States, according to State Department assessments and intelligence reports.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bank of Nova Scotia, Toronto, said it had agreed in principle to acquire up to 40 percent of the voting shares of the Consolidated Bank and Trust Corp. of the Philippines. Terms were not disclosed.

title: LESSONS FOR RUSSIANS ON NEW YORK STREETS
description: The four Soviet doctors were wearing their formal clothes when J. W. Canty, their American host, drove them to Tompkins Square Park. Mikhail S. Gorbachev's search for solutions to alcoholism in the Soviet Union - in the form of the first delegation sent to study drinking and drug abuse in the United States - was headed for the outdoor flophouse of the Lower East Side.

title: PAYING VICTIMS, FREEING PRISONERS
description: In the Middle Ages, restitution was a common way to settle a criminal case. The offender was ordered to do the victim's work, pay medical costs or give him money. Then the state grew more involved. Fines went to the king, not the victim. Restitution faded and survives largely as a vestige of old-time justice.

title: Q&A
description: Why do some people's body joints ache in bad weather?

title: Industrial Equity Sells Resorts Stake
description: Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., a unit of an investment concern controlled by a New Zealand businessman, Ron Brierley, has sold its entire 5.2 percent stake in Resorts International Inc. on the open market for $17 million. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Industrial Equity said that it had sold the 299,100 shares of the casino and resort hotel concern in three transactions, between June 19 and June 30, for an average price of $56.88 a share.

title: FBX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Suffolk Transfers Head of Its Bias Unit
description: The head of the Suffolk County Police Department's racial and religious bias unit began a new job yesterday after being transferred from the unit because of pressure from the Jewish community, the police commissioner said.

title: NEW-CAR SALES FOR JUNE DOWN 10.2% FROM '86
description: Last month's sales of new cars fell 10.2 percent from the June 1986 level, on a daily rate basis, American manufacturers and importers said today.

title: ZZZZ BEST TO FILE FOR CHAPTER 11
description: The ZZZZ Best Company said today that it would seek bankruptcy protection, and it accused its 21-year-old founder and former chairman of misappropriating $23 million of company funds.

title: Sallie Mae Issue
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, which generally issues short-term floating-rate notes each month, offered $250 million of the short-term securities through various securities dealers yesterday. Interest on the Sallie Mae floating-rate notes, which are due Jan. 14, 1988, was initially set at 55-hundredths of a percentage point more than the bond equivalent yield of the 91-day Treasury bill. The interest is reset the day after each weekly bill auction.

title: Diamond Sales Up in First Half
description: Diamond sales climbed sharply in the first half of 1987, carrying through on a recovery that started last year when inflation and the weak dollar helped the gem market out of its lows, according to industry sources.

title: California Growers Deal
description: California Growers Winery Inc. today said it had paid $35 million to buy a winery and 7,000 acres of grape orchards from the Getty Oil Company, making the winery company the largest combined vineyard owner and wine processor in the state. Getty's Paramount subsidiary, with holdings in Kern and Fresno counties, was the biggest vineyard owner. The farm holdings had been for sale since Texaco Inc. bought Getty in 1984. California Growers, a cooperative based in Cutler, Calif., was reorganized by CGW Partners and emerged from bankruptcy protection last year. The partnership includes Ardshiel Inc. of New York.

title: REDISCOVERING HISTORY OF CHINA IN RARE BOOKS
description: Zhang Jiaqu was moving slowly through the ceiling-high shelves of Chinese books in the New York Public Library when he spotted a 16th-century history of Nanjing that he recognized as rare and important.

title: CHARLES C. MACLEAN
description: Charles C. MacLean, a senior partner with the Manhattan law firm Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood, died of lung cancer Sunday at his home in Lloyd Neck, L.I. He was 80 years old.

title: Dinosaur Egg Fossils Found
description: Scientists have discovered nests of dinosaur eggs bearing unhatched, fossilized dinosaurs, the second such find in the world.

title: EVERGOOD PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Genoa Archbishop Resigns
description: Pope John Paul II accepted the resignation today of Giuseppe Cardinal Siri as Archbishop of Genoa and named Msgr. Giovanni Canestri to succeed him, the Vatican announced. Monsignor Canestri, 69 years old, was Archbishop of Cagliari, on Sardinia.

title: SOME VICTIMS' KIN SUSPICIOUS OF BOXCAR SURVIVOR
description: Families of some of the 18 Mexicans who suffocated in a boxcar say that the sole survivor helped recruit some of the group for the trip to Dallas, a Mexican state official said today.

title: MERCHANDISE IS MISSING FROM JAIL COMMISSARIES
description: Are the thieves thieves? Or are jailers perhaps responsible for $150,000 worth of merchandise that City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin says is missing from commissaries at city jails?

title: METS, BRAVES RAINED OUT
description: Somewhere between torrents, the Mets and the Atlanta Braves played one inning of baseball tonight. But it was an inning -and a game - washed away by rain, and now the two teams will play a twilight-night doubleheader Tuesday beginning at 5:40 P.M.

title: SPECIALIZED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The company said it earned an operating profit in the first quarter of 1987 and that it expects results to continue to improve for the balance of the year.

title: Chess; Shamkovich Posts a Victory The Gentle, Positional Way
description: Three Eastern grandmasters, Joel Benjamin of Brooklyn, Sergey Kudrin of Stamford, Conn., and Leonid Shamkovich of Queens, tied for first place in the Fifth Midwest Masters Invitational Tournament in Lincolnwood, Ill.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Armor Elevator Inc., Louisville, Ky., announced the promotion of William O. Lippman Jr. to president and chief executive.

title: Advertising; A Magazine Called Divorce
description: A lawyer, who while going through his own divorce wished for an information magazine on the subject, is in the midst of starting just such a publication.

title: Officer's Accuser Denounced as Liar
description: The lawyer for a suspended police officer on trial in the 77th Precinct corruption case argued in closing yesterday that the prosecution's main witness was a liar and that nothing he had said was corroborated independently.

title: TOUR DE FRANCE
description: Frenchman Wins Sixth Leg: Christophe Lavainne of France won the sixth leg of the Tour de France yesterday in 4 hours 12 minutes 57 seconds, while Erich Maechler of Switzerland retained the overall lead. The 105-mile leg between Strasbourg and Epinal, France, took the cyclists across passes in the Vosges Mountains. At points, the leaders were 8 minutes ahead of the pack. Maechler's overall time is 17:10:49. Lavainne is in second place, 36 seconds behind.(AP) Yacht Racing Stars & Stripes Loses Again: Kookaburra II, New Zealand and Bengal scored their second straight victories yesterday in the semifinals of the 12-Meter world championships off Porto Cervo, Sardinia, while Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes was beaten again. It is now impossible for the Americans to win a berth in the finals.(AP) Track and Field 100-Meter Victory for Christie: Linford Christie of Britain, the European champion in the 100-meter dash, captured the event in 10.03 seconds yesterday at the Hungarian Grand Prix track meet in Budapest. Marlene Ottey-Page of Jamaica took top honors in the women's 100 in 10.92. World-class athletes from 33 countries are competing at the meet, part of the Mobil Grand Prix series. In the hammer throw, Igor Mikulin of the Soviet Union won with a toss of 265 feet 10 inches. (AP) Tennis Gilbert and Curren Are Out: Two Americans, Brad Gilbert, who was seeded second, and Kevin Curren, seeded fourth, were eliminated yesterday by unseeded players in the first round of the Swiss Open in Gstaad. Jaime Yzaga of Peru defeated Gilbert, 6-1, 6-1. Guy Forget of France beat Curren, 7-6, 6-2. In other action, Karel Novacek of Czechoslovakia, seeded eighth, eliminated Wojtek Fibak of Poland, 6-3, 6-4, and Luiz Mattar of Brazil defeated Milan Srejber of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 5-7, 6-4.(AP) Upsets at Longwood: Francesco Cancellotti upset 13th-seeded Andre Agassi yesterday in the first round of the United States Pro Tennis Championships at the Longwood Cricket Club in Brookline, Mass. The 24-year-old Italian beat his 17-year-old American opponent, 6-2, 6-2. Horacio de la Pena of Argentina, seeded 12th, lost, 6-3, 6-1, to Claudio Panatta of Italy. Mel Purcell of the United States, seeded 15th, lost, 6-4, 7-5, to unseeded Libon Pimek of Czechoslovakia.(AP) Horse Racing Victory for Tinchen's Prince: Tinchen's Prince, one of two horses bred in New York in a field of six, won the $40,000 Nijinsky II purse at Belmont Park yesterday after Landing Plot, who crossed the finish line first, was disqualified and placed last. Carrying 115 pounds, including David Nuesch, an apprentice jockey, Tinchen's Prince was second by a neck to Landing Plot, who closed rapidly behind horses, then swerved to the inside. Both Nuesch and Mike Venezia, aboard the favored Moment of Hope, entered objections and Landing Plot was disqualified for impeding Moment of Hope.

title: NBC STRIKE DELAYS WORK ON AN ABC SHOW
description: A strike by NBC technicians affected another network today when at least 15 employees refused to cross picket lines for the ABC soap opera ''General Hospital,'' union and network officials said.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: SOME designers are taking a stand against the high cost of high-style clothing. ''Fashion is so expensive,'' said Randolph Duke. ''When a T-shirt costs $295, the price exceeds fairness. I think there should be a middle ground.''

title: Advertising; Lowe Marschalk Gets Antonovich Furs Work
description: Antonovich Furs announced yesterday afternoon that it was assigning its advertising creative work to Lowe Marschalk. Earlier in the day Jerry Della Femina, chairman of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, reported that the agency had resigned the Antonovich Furs account that was being handled by the Della Femina, Udell subsidiary.

title: MEESE LAWYERS ASSAIL ETHICS OFFICIAL ON WEDTECH STATEMENT
description: Lawyers for Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d attacked the director of the Office of Government Ethics today as they released documents detailing Mr. Meese's financial partnership with a consultant to the Wedtech Corporation.

title: ESCAPEE CAPTURED BY POLICE NEAR PRISON IN NEW MEXICO
description: A prisoner was recaptured today near a race track less than two miles from the penitentiary from which he and six others escaped Saturday. Hundreds of officers continued a search for the others.

title: BASEBALL GERIATRICS: JOHN VS. JOE NIEKRO
description: Tommy John thought the idea made sense. ''Joe and I should pitch Wednesday,'' he said, adding, ''the old son of a gun.''

title: Mrs. North Interviewed
description: Life Magazine declines to say who conducted an interview with Betsy North, the wife of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, in the new issue. The magazine will identify its reporter only as a ''friend'' of the North family who has a background in journalism and wishes to remain anonymous.

title: CAROLINA FREIGHT CORP reports earnings for 12wks to June 20
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Corrections
description: The text of the United States Constitution on Saturday rendered a word incorrectly in the last sentence of Amendment 14, Section 4. Or, not of, should precede emancipation; thus the sentence should read: ''But neither the United States nor any State shall assume or pay any debt or obligation incurred in aid of insurrection or rebellion against the United States, or any claim for the loss or emancipation of any slave; but all such debts, obligations and claims shall be held illegal and void.''

title: THE GOOD WOMAN OF BENXI, A SUCCESS
description: Guan Guangmei, former peasant and former meat counter clerk, is a ''phenomenon'' to her fellow Chinese.

title: OHIO MATTRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Peru Affirms Stand on Debt
description: President Alan Garcia, saying he will stand firm on a decision to limit foreign debt payments to up to 10 percent of Peru's export earnings, has announced new financial measures that include large wage increases.

title: Our Towns; Invoking Cicero So the Children Can Be Protected
description: A busy week for Superior Judge Paul R. Huot. The judge has been sentencing teachers to jail, about 30 a day. He is doing it for the children, he says.

title: INQUIRY SOUGHT ON CATTLE VIRUS LINK TO AIDS
description: Jeremy Rifkin, an outspoken critic of genetic engineering and other biotechnologies, today asked three Federal agencies to determine whether cattle viruses play a role in causing AIDS.

title: Warburg Pincus
description: An investment group led by Warburg Pincus Capital Partners, a New-York based investment firm, has raised its stake in Mattel Inc. to the equivalent of 20.1 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Warburg Pincus group said that it ''may from time to time acquire additional shares'' of the toy company, which is based in Hawthorne, Calif.

title: Chip Inquiry In Europe
description: The commission of the European Community said today that it was investigating charges that Japanese companies were selling semiconductors at unfairly low prices in the European market.

title: Advertising; Chevron Sets Move To Y.&R.
description: J. WALTER THOMPSON, San Francisco, is losing the retail advertising assignment for Chevron U.S.A., which is going to Young & Rubicam in that city. Billings are more than $20 million.

title: HAITIAN GENERAL STRIKE IS PEACEFUL AS SOLDIERS AVOID CONFRONTATIONS
description: Government soldiers who last week killed more than 20 protesters and wounded more than 100 others stayed off the streets today as anti-Government protests resumed around the country without violence.

title: PROBED MYSTERIES OF SPACE
description: Prof. Bengt Georg Daniel Stromgren, an internationally renowned astronomer and former director of the University of Chicago's Yerkes Observatory, died of heart failure Saturday at Hvidovre Hospital in Copenhagen. He was 79 years old and had been living and teaching in the Danish capital for the past 20 years.

title: BRONX SEES A LION, AND NOT IN ZOO
description: First the drive was made with a parent at the wheel, and eventually Gene Larkin drove himself. A half-dozen times each baseball season, maybe more, he would make the trip from the Larkin home in North Bellmore, L.I., to the Bronx to watch the Yankees. Yesterday, the parents and the son made the trip in separate cars because Larkin had a reason to arrive early. His parents were going to see the Yankees play the Minnesota Twins; their son was headed for a day of work.

title: WARHOL AND WARSHIPS
description: The purchase order was for $800 worth of spare parts for a submarine. But the package that was delivered to the Charleston Naval Base contained an Andy Warhol painting of Queen Elizabeth II.

title: ADIRONDACKS CAMP BLENDS BASKETBALL AND EVANGELISM
description: On a recent Thursday morning, the Rev. Dr. Tony Evans stood before his congregation - 100 adolescent boys wearing Jams and high-top leather sneakers - in the gymnasium chapel at the Camp-of-the-Woods basketball clinic.

title: G.O.P. SEEKS OUT TRUMP
description: New York Republican leaders, stung by the record re-election victory of Governor Cuomo last year, are already searching for a 1990 standard-bearer and have approached Donald J. Trump, a top Republican strategist said today.

title: Diamond Seeking Deal for Salt Unit
description: A family-controlled Michigan salt producer is narrowing its search for a buyer that can compete in an industry where the typical business has a capital-rich corporate parent, a company official said. ''Perhaps within the next 30 days we will know whether there is somebody out there who will be making us a firm offer,'' said Frank Hayes, vice president for finance at the Diamond Crystal Salt Company, a specialty foods and real estate conglomerate.

title: Mubarak Backed for 2d Term
description: President Hosni Mubarak was nominated today by Parliament for a second six-year term, with only minor political parties opposing him. The main opposition grouping, led by the Moslem Brotherhood and the Labor Party, which is Socialist, supported Mr. Mubarak but urged him to govern Egypt under strict Islamic law. Mr. Mubarak has held office since the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat in 1981.

title: Cellular Phone Pact
description: The Washington Post Company said it had agreed to sell its Florida cellular telephone properties to the McCaw Communications Companies. The Washington Post Company owns 100 percent of the Miami-Fort Lauderdale cellular system and about 13 percent of the Palm Beach system. The sale price was not disclosed, but The Washington Post Company said the sale was expected to produce an after-tax gain of about $110 million. McCaw Communications has other cellular operations in Florida.

title: U.S. FINES CHRYSLER $1.5 MILLION, CITING WOKERS' EXPOSURE TO PERIL
description: The Federal Government today fined the Chrysler Corporation more than $1.5 million, the largest penalty it has ever imposed for job health and safety violations.

title: CCR VIDEO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: SOUTHLAND'S MOVE TIED TO INVESTOR
description: Samuel Belzberg, the Canadian investor, touched off the $5.1 billion offer from Southland Corporation senior executives to buy the company, Wall Street professionals said yesterday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Two by Two

title: IN CHILE, THE POLITICS OF REGISTERING TO VOTE
description: To the Editor:

title: SUDDEN NURSE SHORTAGE THREATENS HOSPITAL CARE
description: Over the last year a sudden - and dangerous - nursing shortage has begun to hamper hospitals all over the country.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JULY 7, 1987
description: Companies

title: Tamil Rebels Kill At Least 20 In Raid on a Sri Lanka Camp
description: Tamil separatist guerrillas blew up a Sri Lankan army camp on the Jaffna peninsula today and killed at least 20 soldiers, the Government reported.

title: 300 MISSING
description: More than 300 people here feared to have drowned in northern Zambia after their river barge hit a sandbar in what police called a navigational error.

title: Quotation of the Day
