description: ''Lack of adequate safeguards and protection for workers dealing with substances as dangerous as lead and arsenic cannot be tolerated.'' - John A. Pendergrass of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, on ruling against Chrysler. [ A1:6. ]

title: PRAYER IS OFFERED FOR TUMBLING METS
description: The telephone rang twice before Dave Johnson answered it. The caller was phoning long distance, she said, to inform the Mets' manager that his problems would soon be resolved. She was offering a prayer.

title: Dainippon May Lift Bid for Reichhold
description: Dainippon Ink and Chemicals Inc. said today that it might increase its $52.50-a-share takeover offer for Reichhold Chemicals Inc.

title: SEARCH FOR KILLER OF 37 IN SEATTLE AREA CUT BACK
description: The authorities say they know a lot about the man given the name ''the Green River Killer,'' but that they do not know his identity or where to find him.

title: AFTER EIGHT LOSSES, BLUE JAYS WIN ONE
description: George Bell and Ernie Whitt hit consecutive homers in the fifth inning and Jimmy Key pitched a six-hitter for seven innings as the Toronto Blue Jays snapped an eight-game losing streak tonight, defeating the Texas Rangers, 6-4.

title: Judge Blocks U.S. Sale Of Low-Income Units
description: A Federal judge today blocked the Reagan Administration's planned sale of 257 Federal mortgages of low-income housing around the country, saying the effect on residents had been overlooked.

title: The Short Life of the Success Story
description: WHY don't the news media ever report good things about the schools?

title: CHANGE IN SHIFTS TO ADD RUSH-HOUR CABS
description: That most elusive of urban quarries, the rush-hour taxicab, may soon be more common.

title: U.S. ASSERTS BAKER MISSPOKE ON GULF
description: The White House and the State Department moved today to dispel the impression created over the weekend by the White House chief of staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., that United States warships could be withdrawn from the Persian Gulf in response to a Soviet pullout.

title: HOME WORKER GUILTY IN KILLING OF TWO WOMEN
description: A 28-year-old former home-care attendant pleaded guilty yesterday to the murder of two elderly, infirm women found slashed to death in their Bronx apartments last year. The victims had both been in her care.

title: BIONOMIC SCIENCES INTERNAIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $396,000 from the sale of assets and an extraordinary charge of $10,000. c-After extraordinary gains of $51,000 and $158,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: High-Level Shift at Northrop
description: In a move indicating the Stealth bomber is nearing production, the Northrop Corporation today named a high-level corporate official to the No. 2 spot in its secret Advanced Systems division.

title: ARCO Rating Rise Studied
description: The long-term rating on about $6.8 billion of debt issued by ARCO is under review for possible upgrading, Moody's Investors Service said yesterday.

title: LEADER OF CLUB FOR THOSE SEEKING WEALTH GETS LIFE TERM FOR KILLNG
description: The leader of a group of wealthy young men, the Billionaire Boys Club, was sentenced today to life in prison without possibility of parole on his conviction for murder.

title: FUTURE TENNIS KINGS FACE TURF QUESTION
description: In Boris Becker and Pat Cash, Wimbledon has provided men's tennis with two marketable personalities that the game may need if it is to remain popular in the post-Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe era, although Connors apparently plans to go along for the ride.

title: THE LATEST MCPHAIL
description: As a teen-ager he worked in the concession catacombs of Yankee Stadium, checking out the souvenir hawkers. Yearbooks, caps, T-shirts, dolls. In those years, Andy MacPhail earned about $25 a game. If the crowd was small and sales were slow, he would watch a few innings from the lower right-field stands. Last night he returned to Yankee Stadium with the Minnesota Twins, at age 34 the youngest executive vice president in the major leagues.

title: ALICE KAVOOKJIAN
description: Alice Kavookjian, a philanthropist and a prominent member of the Armenian community, died of heart failure Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 86 years old.

title: Market Place; Phelps Dodge's Turnaround
description: LAST July, when shares of the Phelps Dodge Corporation were selling at $16.875, J. Clarence Morrison of Dean Witter Reynolds recommended the stock to clients as ''a turnaround story.''

title: Ex-Chief at Gerber Is Back for a While
description: Carl G. Smith, former chief executive and chairman of the Gerber Products Company, was named acting chief executive of the baby food company yesterday.

title: HIGHER COST PREDICTED FOR SPACE STATION
description: A panel of experts convened by the National Research Council estimated today that the proposed space station would cost about $27.5 billion, the highest figure yet cited in an escalating series of estimates.

title: BEAM, DEVELOPMENT FOR BATTLEFIELD, DETECTS ON SET OF HEART ATTACKS
description: SCIENTISTS at the Georgia Institute of Technology say they have developed a radar device so sensitive it can detect irregularities in the beating of a heart up to 300 feet away.

title: Advertising; Sea World Penguin Pair Join Welcome to Scali
description: One does not generally think of the announcement of an advertising account assignment as a photo opportunity. But then how many accounts have the picture possibilities of Sea World of Florida?

title: Careers; Consulting Marked by Changes
description: MANAGEMENT consulting, a favorite career with its high salaries, is changing in many ways, a partner of a large accounting firm and the managing director of a consulting firm agree.

title: Books: Portrait in Prose
description: ROBERT LOWELL: Collected Prose.

title: Lisp Computer
description: Bolt Beranek & Newman Inc. said its BBN Advanced Computers Inc. unit had introduced Butterfly Lisp, the first large-scale, multiprocessor computer system based on the Lisp programming language. The Lisp language is used widely for the development of artificial intelligence programs, which attempt to emulate the human thought process in solving problems. The company said Butterfly Lisp would be priced at $12,000.

title: HECTIC ROUTE TO MOSTLY MOZART
description: ''It's a three-ring circus 24 hours before countdown,'' said William Lockwood, who was so busy he didn't even have time to straighten out his metaphors.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Alan V. Schwartz has been named executive vice president, chief operating officer and financial officer of Bernard Hodes Advertising.

title: Boy, 16, Found Fatally Shot In an Alley Near Hollis Home
description: A 16-year-old Queens youth was found shot to death in an alley near his home yesterday afternoon as the result of an ''ongoing dispute,'' possibly with another neighborhood youth, the police said.

title: SCIENTISTS FIND LONG-SOUGHT KEY TO HOW BLOOD CLOTS
description: THE master molecule governing the formation of blood clots has been isolated and cloned, ending a century-long effort to understand how blood coagulates and promising powerful new ways to combat major causes of death, including heart attacks, strokes and possibly even cancer.

title: A GLOSSARY OF RUSSIA'S THIRD REVOLUTION
description: As the West contemplates the unfolding of Russia's third revolution in this century, we must make as much of an effort to understand what is not happening as we make to understand what is happening.

title: Chicago Utility Audit Planned
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company, in an attempt to win regulatory approval to form a generating subsidiary of three nuclear power plants, agreed today to submit to an independent audit.

title: REAGAN URGES FARM CHANGES
description: The Reagan Administration today proposed a ''total phase-out'' over the next 10 years of agricultural subsidies around the world that affect the international trade of farm products.

title: U.S. Seeking Coffee Accord
description: In an effort to resolve differences between coffee-consuming nations and producers, the United States is ready to seek a compromise with Brazil and other producers to regulate the coffee trade, the chief United States negotiator, Jon Rosenbaum, said today.

title: HEALTHVEST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago results are not comparable because the company had only one month's operations following its initial public offering on May 29, 1986.

title: VETO OF AIDS TESTING BILLS IS URGED IN ILLINOIS
description: Health officials and gay rights groups are appealing to Gov. James R. Thompson to veto a measure that would mandate the testing for infection with the AIDS virus of prison inmates, hospital patients and couples seeking marriage licenses.

title: Leo D. Goulet, Leader Of Gerber Foods, Dies
description: Leo D. Goulet, president and chief executive officer of the Gerber Products Company, died Sunday after suffering a heart attack while playing golf near his home in Fremont, Mich. He was 61 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: Lobby's Skill a Model

title: COMSAT'S MERGER CALLED OFF
description: The Contel Corporation and Comsat yesterday broke off their proposed $2.4 billion merger.

title: THAT OLD BRILLIANCE AGAIN
description: Once again Messrs. Reagan and Meese are working the old brilliant-mind scam on the Senate. Last time they used it the aim was to get Justice Rehnquist the title of Chief Justice of the United States. Now the beneficiary is to be Judge Robert Bork, possessor of a mind so brilliant, we are told, that no one who loves justice can decently oppose putting him on the Supreme Court.

title: New Mr. Coffee Owner Has Dream Come True
description: John M. Eikenberg is the new Mr. Coffee.

title: LED LOCKHEED IN TURBULENT TIMES
description: Daniel J. Haughton, who rose from systems analyst to chairman of the board in 37 years with the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, died Sunday of complications from heart and gall bladder surgery at the Kennestone Hospital in Marietta, Ga. He was 75 years old and lived in Marietta.

title: PRO-ISRAEL GROUP EXERTS QUIET MIGHT AS IT RALLIES SUPPORTERS IN CONGRESS
description: The Reagan Administration notified Congress at 5:57 P.M. on Friday, May 29, of its intention to sell 1,600 Maverick antitank missiles to Saudi Arabia Within half an hour, lobbyists from the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, the only group registered to lobby Congress on legislation affecting Israel, were on the telephone to lawmakers about the proposal.

title: BLOCKING TRAFFIC
description: State Senator Roy Goodman of Manhattan declares it would be ''cruel and unusual punishment'' to raise New York City parking fines and penalties to $70 from a top of $50. Bowing to pressure from the Automobile Club of New York, Mr. Goodman withdrew as a sponsor of legislation to allow the increase, thereby killing any chance of action this year. It's a regrettable reversal.

title: RIVER CITY IS PLANNED FOR JERSEY
description: The biggest landowner on New Jersey's Hudson River waterfront has joined one of that state's most active builders in an agreement to develop a mini-city of residences, stores and 2.1 million square feet of office space on a milelong stretch of the waterfront in Weehawken, N.J.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Placed Ron Oester, second baseman, on the 15-day disabled list. Purchased the contract of Max Venable, outfielder, from Nashville of the American Association.

title: Gephardt v. Dukakis
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts seem to be trying to make the Democratic Presidential contest look like a two-man race - between themselves.

title: The Critical Questions
description: When Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North begins testifying Tuesday before the select Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair, investigators hope he can answer these critical questions:

title: Antilles Move Expected To Increase Offerings
description: More American companies than previously expected may soon be tapping the United States debt market for funds because of the Treasury's decision to end a 40-year-old tax treaty with the Netherlands Antilles next Jan. 1, according to some securities analysts.

title: TRACK TEAM PICKED
description: Carl Lewis, winner of four gold medals at the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles, and Jackie Joyner-Kersee, a Sullivan Award winner who set the world record in the heptathlon twice last year, top the list of athletes named to the United States track and field team for next month's Pan American Games in Indianapolis.

title: AT JACOB'S PILLOW FESTIVAL, ACCENT IS ON THE AUDACIOUS
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, under way in Becket, Mass., traces its roots to 1930, when Ted Shawn, the American modern dance pioneer, bought a hardscrabble farm in the Berkshire woods. Three years later, Mr. Shawn launched his Men Dancers company at the farm. The concept of an all-male troupe was audacious. But audiences soon began to flock to Mr. Shawn's weekly ''tea lectures,'' where, in the words of Liz Thompson, the festival's director, the dancers, ''dressed in white suits, served tea to the ladies and then undressed and performed for them in their dance belts.''

title: Bond Prices Gain Modestly
description: Bond prices ended modestly higher in slow trading yesterday, lifted by a stronger performance by the dollar on foreign currency markets.

title: Treatments for Sweating
description: People who sweat excessively may be helped by medication usually prescribed for heart patients or by exposing a hand or foot immersed in water to a mild electric shock, researchers say.

title: AGE NO BARRIER FOR THREE SISTERS
description: The gold medal 75-year-old Sylvia Swartz brought back home from St. Louis was not decorative jewelry. The great-grandmother from Forest Hills, Queens, won it for finishing first in her age division of the women's shot-put at the first United States Senior Olympics. The event, contested by 2,700 athletes over 55 years of age, was held last week at Washington University, the site of the 1904 St. Louis World's Fair.

title: London Project Loses Backers
description: Two important backers of a $4.8 billion project to build one of the world's largest office developments, in London's dock area, a part of the waterfront now undergoing redevelopment, have pulled out, sources close to the project said today.

title: Dow Off 7.17 on Inflation Concerns
description: The stock market fell yesterday, as small gains in the bond market and the dollar's firmness were not enough to overcome a growing concern about inflation.

title: Japan and Europeans Cautious on U.S. Plan
description: Japan and the European Community reacted cautiously today to the Reagan Administration's call for eliminating price subsidies and import barriers in agricultural trade, but Australia and several other key food-exporting nations welcomed the proposal.

title: HABLA ESPANOL
description: To the Editor:

title: Convicts Awarded $781,125 for Rights Abuse
description: The New York State Commissioner of Correctional Services violated the constitutional rights of 15 inmates in Duchess County when he transferred them to other prisons in 1980, a Federal jury in Manhattan held yesterday.

title: SANTA MONICA BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 20-percent stock dividend paid in February.

title: Decision Lost By Shearson
description: A Federal jury decided yesterday that three arbitration agreements between Shearson/American Express Inc. and a corporate customer were not binding.

title: ROYAL BUSINESS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a net gain of approximately $4.5 million from the sale of the business forms division.

title: Rig Count Up in Week
description: The number of working domestic oil and gas rigs in the United States this week rose to 872 from 813 in the previous week, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. The count totaled 672 a year ago, the oil toolmaker said.

title: Bridge; The Far East Championship Was Notable for Close Finish
description: Several international championships have been cliffhangers, hinging on the final deal or two, but the closest ever occurred last month in Shanghai, when the 30th Far East Championship ended in an exact tie after nine days of play in a nine-day round robin.

title: HOT ITEMS OF SUMMER
description: THERE'S nothing quite like a pile of computer magazines to help one pass the time at Dallas-Fort Worth airport. Here are some of the more obscure and bizarre items gleaned from half a dozen of the July issues. Batter Up!

title: Arizona Group Begins Drive For Recall of G.O.P. Governor
description: Opponents of Gov. Evan Mecham began a petition drive today seeking a recall election, saying the Governor ''has embarrassed Arizonans nationally'' with his statements and appointments.

title: Foreign Cars Up in Japan
description: Sales of foreign cars and trucks in Japan jumped 37.9 percent in the first half of 1987, to a record 44,456 vehicles, from 32,244 a year ago, the Japan Automobile Importers Association said today. The increase reflected a narrowed price gap between foreign and Japanese-made cars and lower loan rates provided by foreign car dealers, the association said.

title: 2 FOR THE SEESAW THAT PASSES FOR TURKISH POLITICS
description: In Turkey's great cycles of democracy and its suspension, two men who once wielded power, and who sparred as chaos seized their land, are waiting a recall to political life that may never come.

title: ACID SOIL
description: Acidity inhibits the binding of nitrogen-producing bacteria to plant cells, according to scientists at the University of Michigan. They said they feared that soil tainted by acid rain might hinder or halt the necessary synthesis of nitrogen in legumes, such as beans, peas and many forage crops. These play important roles in restoring nitrogen, a crucial nutrient for plant growth, to soils.

title: LEVIATION: SCIENCE BRINGS MAGIC TO LIFE
description: A PHYSICIST imagines that he is momentarily annoyed by the big conference table occupying the middle of his office.

title: DAVID E. WEINLAND
description: The Rev. Dr. David E. Weinland, a minister of the United Church of Christ who served as president of the Moravian Seminary and College for Women in Bethlehem, Pa., died of a heart attack Sunday. He lived in Southbury, Conn., and was 74 years old.

title: FOR CAMBODIA, STILL MISERY AND WAR
description: More than eight years after the Vietnamese invasion that freed Cambodia from destructive tyranny, the country has recovered enough only to live a drastically impoverished life under a less draconian but still oppressive regime.

title: European Notes In U.S. Market
description: The European Investment Bank, the European Community's bank for long-term finance, yesterday announced the beginning of a $500 million medium-term note program in the United States.

title: BRAIN DEFECT TIED TO UTTER AMORALITY OF THE PSYHCOPATH
description: PSYCHOLOGICAL researchers are finding evidence of fundamental differences in the brain that may lie behind the inhuman behavior of the psychopath.

title: 5 YOUNG LAWYERS WHO WOULD BE HEROS... AND A MARINE WHO WEARS A HERO'S RIBBONS
description: As Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's uniform declares his military service, its decorations encapsulate his career. Assuming he appears in uniform, they are certain to be on full display Tuesday when he raises his right hand and, for the first time, publicly answers questions about the Iran-contra affair.

title: FOOTBALL BUSINESS
description: Not only does a profitable big-time college football program help support other university varsity sports programs, the chances are good that it will also bring a hefty shot of economic properity to area business.

title: Israelis Demand Rabbi Raze Holocaust Memorial at Wall
description: The Jerusalem city authorities filed a lawsuit today against Rabbi Shlomo Goren, former Chief Rabbi, demanding that he remove a Holocaust monument erected on a yeshiva near the Wailing Wall.

title: ALL-STAR COACHES
description: Manager Dave Johnson of the Mets has chosen his National League coaches for next Tuesday's All-Star Game. They include three members of his staff and one former Met. Hal Lanier, manager of the Houston Astros, and Roger Craig, a former Met who is now manager of the San Francisco Giants, are the assistant coaches. The batting-practice staff, all from the current Met coaching staff, are Vern Hoscheit, the bullpen coach, Mel Stottlemyre, the pitching coach, and Bill Robinson, the batting and first-base coach. Gene Gieselmann of the St. Louis Cardinals and Mark Letendre of the Giants will be the trainers.

title: NEW VIOLENCE FLARES IN SEOUL AS POLICE HALT MARCH
description: Thousands of students clashed with the police today in the worst confrontation since the Government announced major political concessions a week ago.

title: European Jobless Drop
description: The average unemployment rate for the European Community fell to 10.7 percent in May, from 11 percent in April, according to Eurostat, the trading bloc's statistical service. Figures released today by Eurostat show that the total number of unemployed people in the nine member countries fell to 12.32 million people in May, from 12.69 million in April. Eurostat attributed part of the downtrend to seasonal factors, but noted that there had been particular improvement for young women. The average jobless rate excludes the newest members of the community - Spain, Portugal and Greece.

title: 16 Hurt in Stagecoach Crash
description: Sixteen people were injured today when a stagecoach operated by a concessionaire tipped over inside Yellowstone National Park. A park spokesman, Greg Kroll, said the stagecoach tipped over after the two lead horses of its four-horse team bolted and went off the road. He said four of those hurt were hospitalized with broken bones. One of the horses had to be shot because of hip injuries, he added. Stagecoach trips inside the park were halted pending an investigation of the accident.

title: WALTERS OPENS TALKS WITH SYRIA
description: Vernon A. Walters, the United States representative at the United Nations, arrived in Damascus today on a mission designed to repair American relations with Syria.

title: Man Shot for Playing His Radio Too Loud
description: A dispute Sunday night between three homeless men in Central Park over a radio that was being played too loud ended when one of the men shot another five times, a police official said yesterday.

title: 'Yogic Flying'
description: Followers of the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi will demonstrate a different kind of solution to international economic problems today in the auditorium of the World Bank, before officials of that organization and the International Monetary Fund. What they will demonstrate is ''yogic flying,'' a kind of hopping levitation that believers contend will ''put an end to violence and negative tendencies on earth, remove the basis of terrorism and war and create a permanent state of world peace.'' Specifically for today's audience, the activity is said ''to create world peace through economic self-sufficiency for every nation.''

title: SKIPPER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 14
description: b-Net loss and results include a pre- tax charge of $975,000 from the sale of three Zackly's Restaurants in Florida.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE ENCHANTED WANDERER. Selected Tales by Nikolai Leskov. Translated by David Margarshak. 300 pages.

title: Bill Signed in Connecticut Permits Drug Testing
description: As Gov. William A. O'Neill signed a bill permitting drug testing in the workplace, a top official in the labor movement in Connecticut said it should be used as a model by other states.

title: MONEY FOR POLITICS: ONE MAN'S RELENTLESS PURSUIT
description: Terry McAuliffe was rooting out checks, a grand here, a grand there.

title: WORD PROCESSOR QUEST
description: AT cocktail parties a question I'm often asked is ''What word processor do you use?'' Much to my questioners' disappointment - and I suppose often to their disbelief - my answer remains, ''A cheap ballpoint and narrow-lined yellow paper.''

title: Coca-Cola Division Buys Five Bottlers
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises announced it had purchased five Rainwater Coca-Cola bottling companies from the Coca-Cola Company. Coca-Cola Enterprises, the publicly traded bottling subsidiary, in which Coca-Cola holds a 49 percent stake, bought the companies for $173 million.

title: HOW TO JUDGE JUDGE BORK
description: Americans hold the Supreme Court in such reverence that they are sometimes persuaded, haplessly, to try taking the politics out of politics. As President Reagan's nomination of Judge Robert Bork to the Court reverberates, it becomes clear that this is such a time.

title: KEY RATES
UNATTENDANCE DAY
description: Last year in New York City, a friend recalls, she watched the Tall Ships from somebody's high-floored apartment. Then she walked along West Street, weaving her way through what was truly a million lovers of Liberty: walkers, watchers, picnickers. Many peered through the wire fences at assorted yachts. If anyone was envious he didn't show it. ''Way to go, Malcolm!'' she heard, and ''Have some champagne on me.'' But on that particular Fourth of July, envy was impossible. Rivers, as those who've read Huck Finn know, are deeply democratic, and so are fireworks. True, few New Yorkers got to sit in the V.I.P stands that day, but all had an unobstructed view of the Western sky.

title: SOME COLONEL NAMED NORTH
description: LEAD: Whenever I see the now familiar face of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, I am reminded of the time I first encountered him -before he was a household name and a pivotal figure in the dizzying construct of the Iran arms sales and the diversion of profits to the contras.

title: U.S. JUDGE LIMITS DETENTION PERIOD AFTER AN ARREST
description: A Federal judge has ruled that New York City can no longer detain arrested suspects for more than 24 hours without a court determining that there was probable cause for the arrest.

title: Advest Aide Is Suspended
description: The former head of the mutual funds department at Advest Inc., a Hartford-based brokerage firm, was ordered suspended today after the firm was censured for overcharging mutual funds customers on sales commissions.

title: THE FALL OF A SPARROW
description: The last pure dusky sparrow died recently in Florida, the sole survivor of a species that lost its habitat to humans bent on owning the sky. The once-thriving birds were elbowed aside by construction of the Kennedy Space Center. When they dwindled to five males eight years ago, extinction was guaranteed.

title: COMPAQ COMPUTERS GET SAME SYSTEM AS I.B.M.
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation, responding to the early success of a new line of personal computers from the International Business Machines Corporation, announced yesterday that its computers would use the same operating system.

title: U S Sprint Asks Rate Cut
description: The U S Sprint Communications Company said today that it had filed for an across-the-board rate reduction of 4.25 percent to keep its rates lower than those of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Networks Will Carry Washington Hearings
description: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair will be televised live beginning at 9 A.M. on Channels 2, 4, 7, 13 and 49, and on CNN. Other channels may pre-empt or interrupt programming for live or taped coverage.

title: NORTH: FROM 'NATIONAL HERO' TO RELUCTANT WITNESS
description: At a hearing of the House Foreign Affairs Committee last December, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North proclaimed, ''I don't think there is another person in America that wants to tell the story as much as I do.''

title: HOW TO REDUCE THE ANARCHY IN LEBANON
description: To the Editor:

title: AUSTRALIAN LEADER IN TOUGH RE-ELECTION FIGHT
description: When Prime Minister Bob Hawke called the national election that is scheduled next Saturday, he had some fairly grim economic news for the voters. They could expect more of the same from his Labor Party, he said.

title: RESORT: FENDI, ARMANI, VALENTINO
description: Giorgio Armani likes divided skirts, in thin silks or light wools, to go with his classic jackets. Karl Lagerfeld, in his ready-to-wear collection for Fendi, shows a lot of easy chemise dresses along with boxy jackets. Valentino's new clothes are snug and sexy, with belted waistlines and tilted hemlines.

title: PANAMA PROTESTERS INSIST ON OUSTER OF GENERAL AS KEY TO TALKS
description: Anti-Government leaders in Panama have rejected a call for compromise with the regime, insisting that they would agree to talks only to discuss the departure of the military commander, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: U.S. May Add Limits on Japan
description: The Defense Department may impose sanctions against two Japanese companies, C. Itoh and Wako Trading, for selling high-technology systems to the Soviet Union, U.S. News & World Report reported. The sanctions may include a suspension of authority to export certain defense-related equipment. Itoh is one of Japan's largest trading companies and Wako is a small concern, the magazine said in its July 13 issue.

title: HOME LOAN RATES RISE, BUT SLOWLY
description: Home mortgage rates rose in early June but at a much slower pace than the steep climb of early May.

title: ALIEN SANCUTARY MOVEMENT'S STATE UNCLEAR A YEAR AFTER COURT CASE
description: A year after eight church workers were placed on probation for helping to give sanctuary to Central American illegal aliens, there is disagreement over the status of the movement.

title: NATIONAL COMMUNITY BANK OF NJ reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings for 1986 have been restated to reflect a 4-for-1 stock split paid in May.

title: Teachers Unit Voices Its Opposition to Bork
description: The nation's largest teachers union has voted to fight the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the United States Supreme Court and to challenge efforts to make English the official language of the United States.

title: COURT AFFIRMS BAN ON LEADING ROLES FOR WOMEN IN SCOUTING
description: The Connecticut Supreme Court affirmed today the right of the Boy Scouts of America to bar women from leadership positions.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Dickie Thon, the Houston Astros shortstop who has been plagued by vision problems since being hit by a pitch in 1984, said he was not ready to retire but doubts he will ever play for the Astros again. Thon left the team Friday and returned to Houston because of his eye problems. ''I feel sad because I wish I could have done more for the team,'' Thon said at a news conference at the Astrodome. . . . Eamonn Coghlan, the only man to break 3 minutes 50 seconds for the mile indoors, was scratched from yesterday's Cork City track meet in his native Ireland, the meet's organizers said, and was scheduled to undergo minor knee surgery. He was planning to run in this year's World Championships, scheduled for Aug. 29 to Sept. 6, but the surgery may prevent it. . . . D. J. Dozier, the first-round selection of the Minnesota Vikings, became the first opening-round National Football League draft pick to sign since the April 28th draft. He signed a two-year pact with an option year. Published reports have put the contract at about $1 million. . . . The Portland Trail Blazers announced that on the advice of their physician, they have taken steps to rescind a trade in which Jim Paxson went to the Cleveland Cavaliers for Keith Lee, a forward. The physician said there was a high risk that Lee, a former Memphis State star, would suffer serious knee problems.

title: 'Star Wars' Isn't Here, and It's Far From Irrevocable
description: To the Editor:

title: HITTERS NO HELP TO A DEFT GUIDRY
description: Ron Guidry gave his manager what he wanted last night: nine quality innings. But Frank Viola, like Guidry a quality left-hander, wouldn't let the Yankee hitters give Guidry what he needed for a victory.

title: ONE FOR AUSTRALIA
description: Pat Cash, in upsetting Ivan Lendl on Sunday, became the first Australian to win the Wimbledon men's singles championship since John Newcombe took his third title in 1971. Cash, the 11th men's champion from Australia, ran his country's total of men's singles titles to 20. A total of 14 Englishmen have won 34 All-England titles, while 19 men from the United States have won the crown 25 times. Among other non-English winners, four men from France won seven times, Bjorn Borg of Sweden captured five titles, Anthony Wilding of New Zealand took four and Boris Becker of West Germany won two. The Australian winners in men's singles:

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC IN THE PARK
description: THE New York Philharmonic moved onto the Great Lawn in Central Park last night for a performance that drew a crowd estimated by the police to be 90,000, the largest for a parks concert so far this year. A pleasant, cool evening helped bring out the assortment of picnickers and music lovers who sprawled along the dusty baseball fields and scattered across the adjacent paths.

title: SURGERY FOR WALTON
description: Bill Walton, who has undergone foot surgery six times, forcing him to miss almost five National Basketball Association seasons, is scheduled to undergo a seventh operation today at Presbyterian Hospital in Whittier, Calif. Dr. F. William Wagner and Dr. Tony Daly, who have operated on the Boston Celtics' 6-foot-11-inch center in the past, will perform the surgery on Walton's right foot.

title: N.F.L. TV PACT UNDER SCRUTINY
description: The National Football League, the three major networks and at least two other television companies have received subpoenas as part of a Federal investigation into whether any antitrust laws were broken in negotiations over broadcast rights to league games.

title: Tinning Jury to Hear Testimony on Deaths
description: Reversing an earlier ruling, the judge in the murder trial of Mary Beth Tinning, who is accused of smothering her infant daughter, ruled today that testimony about the deaths of the woman's eight other children can be given at the trial.

title: Army Acts Against 8 In Recruiting Inquiry
description: Eight Army recruiters in the Chicago area have been relieved of their duties and nine others are being investigated in an inquiry into drug abuse and falsification of recruits' records, the Army reported today.

title: R.J. Reynolds Sells 2 Tobacco Brands
description: R. J. Reynolds Tobacco USA sold its Top and Our Advertiser smoking tobacco brands to Republic Tobacco Inc. of Chicago, a distributor of smoking tobacco and cigarette rolling papers. The sale, terms of which were not announced, completed Reynolds Tobacco USA's plans to sell its smoking tobacco and little cigar businesses, a decision announced in January.

title: U.S. NOT TOLD OF MONITORING OF BLACKS, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: One of the top Federal probation officials in New York City said yesterday that the New York Police Department had not informed him of any planned crimes by eight black radicals who have been under surveillance by police intelligence officers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JULY 7, 1987
description: International A2-11

title: INSURANCE SALESMAN SENTENCED TO DEATH IN THE SLAYING OF 4 GIRLS
description: Michael B. Ross, standing silently and without expression, was sentenced today to death in the electric chair for the murder of four teen-age girls in eastern Connecticut in 1983 and 1984.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JULY 8, 1987
description: International The Senate defeated, 55 to 41, an amendment to the trade bill that would restore Presidential discretion in deciding to grant relief to domestic industries hurt by imports. The limiting of Presidential discretion is one of the main provisions of the trade bill and one that the Administration has said could provoke a veto. [ Page D1. ]

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Birthday Presence

title: OLYMPIC PLAN DEFINED
description: The International Olympic Committee would cancel rather than move next summer's Olympics if political problems make it impossible to hold them in Seoul, South Korea, The Daily Telegraph, a London-based national newspaper reported yesterday.

title: F.A.A. NOMINEE URGED TO ADDRESS AIR DELAYS
description: Several senators today urged President Reagan's nominee to head the Federal Aviation Administration to deal immediately with the growing problem of airline flight delays, saying that otherwise, Congress would act on its own.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1.A Chocolate Zoo For a weekend house gift, consider this wide-eyed alligator. Its mouth is filled with Manon's gold-wrapped chocolate coins. The alligator is part of a collection of whimsical chocolate-filled animal boxes that includes a tiger, a bear, a zebra and a giraffe. The price is $25 at Le Chocolatier Manon, 872 Madison Avenue (near 71st Street). 2.Time Consuming If you happen to get hunger pangs while wearing this watch, you'll feel like biting into it. The watch looks just like a dark, tempting Oreo cookie. Made by In Time, the watch operates with a 1.5-volt battery and has a rubberized white band. The price is $15. A cheeseburger watch, complete with lettuce and tomato, is also available. In the Lee Bailey Shop on the ninth floor at Saks Fifth Avenue. Not available at branch stores. 3.Mozart on Key Lincoln Center's annual Mostly Mozart Festival is open for business, and so is the Mozart merchandising mania. Among the new items this season is this gold metal key ring. The loops at the top and the bottom operate with strong springs; pull them away from the center to insert keys. The price is $9.95 in the lobby at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: HEATED EXCHANGE: WERE FUNDS 'BEGGED FOR' OR 'OFFERED'?
description: Exchanges between Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and John W. Nields Jr., the chief House counsel, often grew heated at the hearings yesterday, as Colonel North passionately defended himself and his cause. These exchanges occurred during questioning about Colonel North's authority for his actions, and about the practice of soliciting money for the contras.

title: Washington Talk: Commission of Fine Arts; Arbiters of Monumental Taste
description: One cannot, it is said, legislate taste. But for most of this century, a little-known Federal agency has been at least regulating taste by judging the esthetic values of proposals for monuments, memorials and statues that seem forever to be springing up here.

title: A CAPTIVE JOURNALIST SAYS, ON A VIDEOTAPE, HE SPIED
description: A kidnapped American journalist appeared today in a videotape turned over by his captors, who said in a separate statement that he was under interrogation as an American spy.

title: Nields, 'Good Cop,' Chafes in Exchanges
description: John W. Nields Jr., the man who led off the questioning of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, typically plays the role of the ''good cop'' in the committee's interrogation of witnesses.

title: PRESIDENT BRINGS OUT CIVIC PRIDE
description: At Packy's Restaurant on Broad Street, Jean Pac, one of the owners, proudly remembers the day in the mid-1970's when a visiting Cardinal from Poland, who later became Pope John Paul II, dropped in for lunch.

title: NEW YORKERS ARE FASCINATED BY THE NORTH DRAMA
description: Something about the man, many New Yorkers said yesterday, compelled them to turn office time into clandestine sessions with their radios or covert missions to the display areas of appliance stores.

title: CALIFORNIA PASTIME COMING TO THE EAST
description: It may sound more like a southern California tribal ritual, or even the title of a low-budget movie, but beach volleyball is now established as a professional sport with a sizable crowd following. It is also moving East.

title: Ethics Code Approved After Postal Scandals
description: The Postal Service's scandal-plagued Board of Governors unanimously adopted an ethics code today. The action follows more than a year of investigations that have seen the vice chairman sentenced to prison and the chairman resign under a cloud.

title: TYSON IS CHARGED
description: Misdemeanor charges of assault with a deadly weapon (hands) and battery have been filed in Los Angeles against Mike Tyson, the World Boxing Council-World Boxing Association heavyweight champion. The charges stem from a June 21 incident in the parking lot of the Greek Theater, following a concert there.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Who's Responsible for 'Safe Sex'?
description: Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton, the advertising agency, recently unveiled three television commercials it made for the New York City Health Department promoting use of condoms to limit AIDS. One shows a woman handing a package of condoms to her daughter with the words ''If you're doing anything, you use one of these. You understand? 'Cause my baby is not getting AIDS.'' The second shows a woman putting on makeup, then dropping a condom in her purse. In the third a couple is kissing. The female hands the male a condom. He hands it back. An announcer says, ''And if he says no, so can you.''

title: GENENTECH LOSES PATENT
description: In its second major setback in six weeks, Genentech Inc., a leading biotechnology company, lost the British patent for what it expects to become its main product, tissue plasminogen activator. The Chancery Division of the

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Japanese Visit Delayed
description: Ever since the Reagan Administration imposed trade sanctions against Japan in April, a principal aim of Japanese foreign policy has been to get them removed.

title: PERKS, BUT NO POWER, BEHIND RED VELVET THRONE
description: In the cool silence of his mud-walled, 500-year-old palace here, Alhaji Shehu Idris, 18th Emir of Zaria, paused in conversation, searching for a word to define his link to his 2.5 million subjects.

title: BERENTER GREENHOUSE GETS H-O HOT CEREALS
description: Nutrition Industries of Cresskill, N.J., which specializes in the resuscitation of widely known but not necessarily healthy brands, has turned to the Berenter Greenhouse & Webster agency for help with H-O hot cereals.

title: DR. WERNER HENLE, VIROLOGICAL PIONEER IN CANCER RESEARCH
description: Dr. Werner Henle, a noted virologist who with his wife identified the first virus associated with cancers in humans, died of cancer Monday at the Bryn Mawr Hospital in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 76 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Executive Changes column of Business Day on Monday about the International Business Machines Corporation incorrectly described a promotion. David E. McKinney was named to head the corporate operations staff; he also joins the company's management committee and corporate management board.

title: CUOMO ASSAILS WHITE HOUSE ON ITS RECORD ON CIVIL RIGHTS
description: Governor Cuomo criticized the Reagan Administration's record on civil and human rights yesterday as a ''policy of chaos.''

title: NORTH INSISTS HIS SUPERIORS BACKED IRAN-CONTRA DEALS; ASSUMES REAGAN APPROVED
description: After more than seven months of silence, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North finally testified in public today and insisted, often in combative tones, that the secret operations he ran out of the White House were conducted only under orders from his superiors.

title: ERNA'S FOOD AND A VIEW IN THE SIERRAS
description: ONE of the most elegant and stylish restaurants in the nation is a little-known place nestled in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada some 3,000 feet above sea level, about 40 miles northeast of Fresno, Calif. I first learned of its existence during a recent visit to San Francisco.

title: M.A. HANNA SEEKS DAY INTERNATIONAL
description: The M.A. Hanna Company, a diversified metals and mineral products company in Cleveland, offered $45 a share, or about $315 million, to acquire the Day International Corporation. On the news, shares of Day jumped to $50 a share, before closing at $49.25, up $14.375, on the New York Stock Exchange today.

title: Kiwanis International Votes To Let Women Join Its Clubs
description: Kiwanis International, a service organization with clubs all over the world, ended a 72-year policy in a matter of minutes Tuesday with an overwhelming vote allowing its 8,200 clubs to admit women.

title: CORPORATIONS' CHANGES OF NAMES INCREASE
description: More United States corporations changed their names in the first half of this year than in any similar period for the last 18 years, according to Anspach Grossman Portugal, identity consultants of New York and San Francisco.

title: A YOGURT DRINK WITH CARIBBEAN ROOTS
description: HERE in the stark and sparsely populated region of Vermont known as the Northeast Kingdom, the closest thing to Hispanic cuisine is a glutinous taco in the frozen food section of the local grocery store. Still, this is the headquarters of La Vida Foods, the manufacturer of a yogurt drink called boruga that has seldom been found - until now - outside the Caribbean.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: I HAVE returned from the birthday party wars. My side lost. Balloons were broken, jelly sandwiches fell jelly-side-down on wall-to-wall carpets, the wine for the adults ran out. Two of the same dinosaurs were received as gifts (they were stegosauruses). There were whistles as party favors, in violation of human decency. All around us the battle raged. This is why the birth process is roughly commensurate to participating in a triathlon in hell: to prepare parents for the birthday parties. In the thick of one celebration I took a cleansing breath and then panted. It did not help. I realized the following:

title: 390 DEATHS FEARED AS BARGE CAPSIZES IN A RIVER IN AFRICA
description: Rescue teams said today that the death toll could be as high as 390 in the sinking of a barge in the Luapula River between Zaire and Zambia.

title: Graphic AIDS-Prevention Film Ready for Airing
description: A 27-minute documentary graphically showing ways of preventing AIDS will be distributed this week by a nonprofit organization that hopes the film will reach millions of Americans.

title: BLACK OFFICIALS SIDE WITH BARRY
description: Several groups of black elected officials charge in court papers that a Federal inquiry into possible contract corruption in the District of Columbia government is part of a widespread effort by the nation's ''white power structure'' to discredit black leaders.

title: MARYLAND JUDGE CASTS DOUBT ON PLAN FOR 2 NEW STADIUMS
description: A Maryland judge has cast a shadow over Gov. William Donald Schaefer's drive for a $200 million complex of two new professional sports stadiums in downtown Baltimore.

title: IN AUSTRALIA, ECOLOGISTS MAP OUT THE CAMPAIGN
description: In the midst of his current campaign for a third term as Prime Minister, Bob Hawke flew 3,000 miles to the northern tip of the continent to inspect a belt of pristine tropical rain forests.

title: North's Patriotic Lies
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver North, in his somewhat slippery opening testimony to the combined House-Senate committees, was absolutely clear and absolutely right about one point: Lies are the ''essence'' of covert operations.

title: AT LEAST 30 DIE IN WEST GERMANY IN EXPLOSION OF A GASOLINE TRUCK
description: A tank truck loaded with gasoline crashed into an ice cream parlor Tuesday night, blew up and set off other explosions, killing at least 30 people and injuring 29, officials said. The truck driver survived.

title: DRIVING IN STYLE
description: When Philippe de Henning and two driving partners won the C-2 class for lighter cars at the Le Mans 24-hour auto race in France last month, it might have been appropriate to describe the rookie's sixth-place overall finish in one of the sport's most grueling tests of skill and endurance as being achieved ''in fine fashion.''

title: ON FIRST DAY, SPOTLIGHT IS ON LAWYERS SPARRING
description: The public got its first glimpse today of the lawyerly street fighting that has rumbled for months over when and how Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North would tell his story to Congress.

title: Clinton to Decide Next Week
description: Gov. Bill Clinton will announce July 15 whether he intends to join the crowded field seeking the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination, his office said today. ''I'm talking about the central decision - to run or to drop it, to go or not to go,'' said his press secretary, Mike Gauldin. Mr. Clinton, in his fourth term as Governor, has been deliberating for weeks about whether to join the race.

title: LEAKING WATER HEATER KILLS 8
description: Eight people were found dead at a Memphis apartment complex, killed by carbon monoxide leaking from a hot water heater and spread by an air-conditioner, the authorities said today.

title: Wagner Wins 2d Term at Board of Education
description: Robert F. Wagner Jr. was elected to his second term as president of the New York City Board of Education yesterday. He said one of his goals in the coming year was to obtain a commitment from businesses ''to hire any student graduating from a New York City high school.''

title: START-UP'S CHALLENGE: RAPID GROWTH
description: THE Convex Computer Corporation struggled for more than three years before making money, using $32 million in venture capital.

title: Paris Warns of Break With Iran on Fugitive
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac warned today that France might break diplomatic relations with Iran if a fugitive hiding in the Iranian Embassy here does not testify on a series of bombings in Paris last September.

title: G.O.P. Senators Balk at Accord On Prison Space
description: A major legislative agreement on steps to relieve prison overcrowding was thrown into doubt late tonight by vigorous opposition from dissident Republican Senators who argued that elements of the legislation might grant early parole to dangerous criminals.

title: PARISH FINED $5,000
description: Robert Parish, starting center for the Boston Celtics, has been fined $5,000 for missing court appearances in a child-support case in Oakland, Calif. Alameda County Superior Court Judge Alice Sullivan held Parish in contempt Monday for failing to appear for hearings in the case in March 1986 and April 1987 and ordered him to spend five days in jail or pay a fine. He chose the fine.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday about the American Israel Public Affairs Committee misstated Jonathan S. Kessler's position with the Presidential campaign of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.. Mr. Kessler is deputy national finance director for the campaign.

title: Ballet: New Bolshoi Cast
description: ANOTHER night, another show. And it was certainly a very different show when the Bolshoi Ballet's Andris Liepa and Lyudmila Semenyaka stepped into the leading roles of ''The Golden Age'' Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: GLOBAL EFFECTS OF REAGAN FARM PLAN RAISE FEARS
description: The Reagan Administration's proposal to phase out subsidies and import barriers in agricultural trade could throw a large number of farmers out of work around the world, government officials and trade experts said today.

title: Rain Delays State Golf
description: Persistent rain delayed the start of the Michelob New York State Open tournament today at Grossinger's Hotel and Spa. As a result, 24 of the 147 competitors did not complete their rounds and will resume play early Wednesday by using Tuesday's pin placements.

title: RETREAT MAY BE CLUB'S LAST WITHOUT WOMEN
description: Members of the Bohemian Club, whose roster includes President Reagan and Vice President Bush, will gather at a sylvan 2,700-acre redwood grove 75 miles north of here on Friday for their 109th annual two-week retreat. It may be the last retreat without women as members or employees.

title: Yonkers Council Approves Housing Integration Plan
description: The City Council tonight approved housing integration measures demanded by a Federal judge who had threatened the city with a contempt of court citation and crippling daily fines.

title: PACIFIC UTILITY'S $250 MILLION ISSUE
description: A $250 million financing by the Pacific Gas and Electric Company was awarded yesterday to underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company in competitive bidding.

title: CHIEF OPERATING OFFICER IS NAMED AT CETUS CORP.
description: The Cetus Corporation, which is developing biotechnology-based pharmaceuticals, announced a change in top management yesterday.

title: Judge Blocks Sale of Federal Housing Projects
description: A Federal judge has temporarily blocked the Reagan Administration from selling nearly 300 federally subsidized housing projects to private investors on Wednesday.

title: FASTEST MILES
description: Said Aouita of Morocco came within 44-hundredths of a second of the world record for the mile run early last week at Helsinki, and his effort seemed likely to spur Steve Cram of Britain, the record holder, in the Dream Mile at Oslo last Saturday. But Cram, although he was two seconds ahead of the record pace after almost three-quarters of a mile, faltered and finished in 3:50.08, not even fast enough to rank among the 10 best miles: Time, runner, country year 3:46.32, Steve Cram, Britain1985 3:46.76, Said Aouita, Morocco1987 3:46.92, Aouita1985 3:47.33, Sebastian Coe, Britain1981 3:47.69, Steve Scott, U.S.A.1982 3:47.79, J.-L. Gonzalez, Spain 1985 3:48.31, Cram1986 3:48.40, Steve Ovett, Britain1981 3:48.53, Coe1981 3:48.53, Scott1982

title: Windfall for New York
description: To the Editor:

title: PROTEST MARCH AT HAITI PALACE
description: Several thousand Haitian protesters marched in front of the presidential palace here today as anti-Government strikes continued to paralyze the country.

title: 18 Arrested at Stony Brook
description: Eighteen students at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L.I., were arrested last night for refusing to take down tents they had set up on campus to protest student housing conditions. The students were issued summonses by campus police for obstructing governmental administration, according to Kevin Ireland, a university spokesman. He said the university's president, John Marburger, last week authorized a special task force to study campus housing.

title: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: ADVANCES
description: THE automated body welding line has come to symbolize the modern automobile assembly plant: clusters of robot arms moving like giant insects over bare metal car bodies with sparks flying from welding guns.

title: HANDICAPPED SENIOR GOLFER TO PROTEST BAN ON CARTS
description: Charles Owens, crippled for 35 years from injuries incurred in an accident in the military, says the United States Golf Association discriminates against senior athletes who are handicapped when it refuses to allow him to ride a golf cart in the Senior Open.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
A SHIRTTAIL KIN TO PAELLA
description: LEAD: ARROZ CON POLLO - rice with chicken - a traditional Spanish dish, is nutritious in its own right. The accompanying recipe, for example, calls for nothing but certified good stuff.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SARTRE: A Life. By Annie Cohen-Solal. Illustrated. 591 pages. Pantheon Books. $24.95.

title: Bridge: In September, National Unit Will Mark 50th Anniversary
description: Sept. 15 will be a notable date on the bridge calendar for three reasons, all connected with the American Contract Bridge League.

title: TV Reviews; 8 Women In 'Miles To Go'
description: ''MILES TO GO,'' tonight at 10:30 on Channel 13, takes eight women along a two-week wilderness trek in North Carolina and Georgia. The women, ranging in age from 27 to 72 years old, have had little or no wilderness training. From varying economic, social and cultural backgrounds, they learn to adapt to one another and the wilderness. But there is no great sense of triumph or warmth in their adaptation.

title: JERSEY SCHOOL STRIKERS WIN JAIL REPRIEVE
description: Jail terms were temporarily delayed today for 97 teachers and other school workers who staged an illegal strike last spring in Lyndhurst, N.J.

title: STOCK MANIPULATION CHARGED
description: One of the nation's biggest players in a fairly new industry - Pre-Paid Legal Services Inc. of Ada, Okla. -says it is being victimized by investors who have been manipulating its stock price.

title: Festival Latino Is Shifting Emphasis
description: The 11th Festival Latino in New York, featuring seven theatrical productions, a film festival and a free concert, will run from Aug. 1 through 23 at the Public Theater in Greenwich Village, the Delacorte Theater in Central Park and at the Metro Cinema on upper Broadway. The festival, which will include presentations from the United States, Latin America and Spain, has been produced by Joseph Papp and the New York Shakespeare Festival since 1984.

title: FIVE AGENCIES IN HYATT RACE
description: The five ad agencies selected to compete for the Hyatt Hotels Corporation's $8 million advertising account were announced in Chicago yesterday by Hyatt.

title: THE RESTAURANT GAME: A FRENETIC TALE OF SURVIVAL
description: FOR 10 years Zeus Goldberg presided over Woods, a popular restaurant on Madison Avenue in the 60's that managed to be elegant but not intimidating. Three weeks ago Mr. Goldberg presided over the restaurant's closing, watching from a barstool as an auctioneer disposed of dishes, cutlery and kitchen equipment.

title: PRESIDENT'S TRADE ROLE RESTRAINED
description: In one of the key tests for the future of trade legislation this year, the Senate tonight voted to limit Presidential discretion in deciding to grant relief to domestic industries hurt by imports.

title: PRESIDENT FIRM ON TAX STANCE
description: A Treasury official refused today to help Congressional tax writers narrow the list of options for raising $19.3 billion in taxes, citing President Reagan's opposition to new taxes. The official, Dennis Ross, the

title: CHERNOBYL TRIAL BEGINS IN SOVIET
description: Six former officials and technicians at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant went on trial today on charges of ''blatant violation'' of safety regulations that caused the world's worst nuclear accident.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JULY 8, 1987
description: International A2-10

title: LED THE MILITARY IN NEW YORK
description: Maj. Gen. Almerin C. O'Hara, a former commander of New York State's organized militia and former State Commissioner of General Services, died of prostate cancer Sunday at the Norway Nursing Home in Norway, Me. He was 76 years old and had lived for many years in Boynton Beach, Fla.

title: DARLING STOPS 2 1/2-MONTH SLUMP
description: Their seasons have stood in contrast. Terry Leach cannot seem to lose; Ron Darling could not seem to win. But tonight, the two Met pitchers merged at a critical point.

title: CALIFORNIA TAXPAYERS TO GET $1 BILLION IN REBATES
description: The taxpayer revolt ignited here almost a decade ago burned bright today for Californians who will get more than $1 billion in rebates under a budget signed by the Governor.

title: Women in Court
description: To The Living Section:

title: 'Promise' Wins Humanitas
description: ''Promise,'' a CBS television movie about a man who is forced to take care of his schizophrenic brother, and episodes of ''Family Ties'' and ''Kate and Allie'' were awarded the Humanitas Prize today for the 1986-87 television season.

title: The Witness File
description: Name: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North Age: 43 Position: Deputy director of the political-military affairs bureau at the National Security Council from 1981 until dismissed by the President on Nov. 25, 1986. Now he is on the staff at Marine headquarters in Washington. Role: Colonel North has been described as the chief operator in the programs to sell American arms to Iran and subsequently to divert profits to the Nicaraguan contras. He also helped set up and run a large-scale covert operation to supply weapons and provisions to the Nicaraguan rebels during the period in which United States aid was restricted.

title: Travels With Baby
description: To The Living Section:

title: Free at Last in the Milk Market
description: Overcoming bitter resistance from the dairy lobby, New York has finally agreed to phase out its Depression-era dairy licensing system. That's welcome news for milk consumers - mostly children, mostly poor - who stand to benefit from savings estimated at $100 million a year.

title: THOMPSON FAMILY OUTSIDE DALLAS MOLD
description: In Dallas, a city renowned for wealthy families, the Thompson family, which owns the nation's largest convenience store chain, 7-Eleven, does not fit the mold. The Thompsons are apparently one of the few families that made their fortune with no help from oil and gas, although they did later buy a big stake in Citgo.

title: The Star Witness
description: Oliver North began his long-awaited testimony on the Iran-contra affair by scolding Congress for insufficient loyalty to the Nicaraguan rebels. That story line ran throughout the appearance of the Marine lieutenant colonel who would be king or loyal servant, depending on whose testimony the Congressional committee will find credible. With the network cameras trained on him, Colonel North held tenaciously to the policy convictions that produced two whopping national embarrassments in Iran and Central America. He showed a studied indifference to the issues before the committees: law and accountability.

title: Advertising; MAGAZINE'S IMAGE CAMPAIGN
description: ON cable TV Sunday night, Changing Times magazine began its first image campaign to deliver the message that it is ''a magazine that helps you manage yourself and your money in a changing world.''

title: WINE TALK
description: TO finance some of the wines we'll look at today, bring what is in your wallet; to finance the others, bring a Rockefeller. Our tour d'horizon takes us through what I think are the first wines made by Greeks that do not taste of retsina (resin), through chardonnays under $10 and then to the wines of La Romanee, a crown jewel among Burgundy's vineyards.

title: GERBER LIFTED BY CONJECTURE
description: IN the midst of a search for top executives, the Gerber Products Company found itself the center of takeover conjecture yesterday. After jumping $4 on Monday, its stock rose $1.50, to $54, after selling at $55. The record price of $57.625 was set in April 1986 for the world's largest producer of baby foods.

title: About New York; Group Therapy For the Victims Of Space Aliens
description: Oh, sure, it's an enormous thrill and you do suddenly become the focus of attention at parties, but being abducted by aliens from outer space is not all it's cracked up to be.

title: INSIDE
description: Integration Plan Approved

title: Illegal Load Of Asbestos Discovered
description: Acting on a tip, city sanitation officials discovered more than 10 tons of asbestos late Monday and yesterday scattered over a Bronx parking lot and illegally stored in two trucks parked there.

title: An Air of Confusion Lifts Veil of Secrecy
description: Throughout the joint congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair, investigators and witnesses have taken pains to protect the identities of other countries involved in the case. It hasn't always worked.

title: Plastic Debris Poses A Threat to Wildlife
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Nutrition News

title: NAVISTAR PROGRAM IS SECURED BY LIEN
description: The Navistar Financial Corporation has established a $100 million Euro-commercial paper program to be secured by a lien on the company's accounts receivable, said Morgan Guaranty Ltd., the dealer and paying agent.

title: Club Med Returning To Ammirati & Puris
description: Club Med is returning to Ammirati & Puris, the agency that developed the line ''Club Med Vacation. The Antidote For Civilization.'' And its ad budget is $11 million. The antidote for agency management depression.

title: SMITHKLINE RAISES SIZE OF OFFERING
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation is offering $150 million of 8 3/4 percent notes due in 1994 at 99.70 to yield 8.808 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The offering was increased from $125 million because of strong demand.

title: PROTECTION FOR JOURNALISTS
description: Following is the portion of the New York State shield law that was interpreted yesterday in the Court of Appeals ruling:

title: Up the Line
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver North didn't walk the plank after all. In his first day of testimony before the Congressional investigating committees, he simply moved the question of responsibility for the Iran-contra affair ''up the line,'' as he said, into the Cabinet Room and the Oval Office.

title: JAZZ PHOTO PORTRAITIST
description: Robert Parent, a photographer who specialized in portraits of jazz musicians, died Sunday at Sloane-Kettering Memorial Hospital following an operation for a brain tumor. He was 63 years old and lived in New York.

title: AT WHITE HOUSE, THE TV IS TURNED OFF
description: As Administration officials tell it, the White House might have been the only place in the capital today where workers were not focused on the televised testimony of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North.

title: Health Care for All Is a Public Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW MET CASUALTY: DYKSTRA'S MORALE
description: The case of the unhappy center fielders is not likely to be resolved this season, Al Harazin, the Mets' executive vice president, said today, even though Mookie Wilson has asked for a trade and Lenny Dykstra has begun to express his unhappiness with sitting on the bench.

title: Let the U. N. Reflag Gulf Vessels
description: The specter of a widened conflict in the Persian Gulf raised by prospective United States reflagging of Kuwaiti ships and provision of safe transit for Kuwaiti cargoes on Soviet vessels leased to Kuwait has created consternation in Congress, queasiness among our allies and concern even in the Administration.

title: BOND PRICES CONTINUE CLIMB
description: Bond prices moved moderately higher in light trading yesterday, helped by another strong performance by the dollar on foreign currency markets.

title: DEATHS FROM AIDS SOAR IN NEW YORK
description: The number of New York City residents who died of AIDS last year was 2,650, up by more than 59 percent from the 1985 number, according to the City Health Department, which also noted a significant increase in AIDS deaths among women.

title: EVEN AT AGE 3, ROSE MADE MARK
description: Pete Rose was 3 years old when he connected solidly with a pitch served up by his father, Harry, and drove a hard rubber-coated ball to right-center field, over and out of the backyard ball field and against a glass window pane that promptly cracked in the kitchen of the Rose home on Braddock Avenue in Cincinnati.

title: ABORTION, BORK AND THE '88 CAMPAIGN
description: President Reagan's nomination of Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court is pushing the abortion issue back to the center stage of American politics by threatening to unsettle what has been an uneasy truce on the question for the last decade.

title: Highlights of the Testimony
description: President's role: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North said he never had a discussion with President Reagan about the use of profits from the sales of American weapons to Iran for the purpose of assisting the Nicaraguan rebels. But he assumed the President had ''authorized'' such use of the profits. Secret memorandums: a0> Colonel North said he wrote ''as many as five'' memorandums describing the Iran arms sales and seeking Mr. Reagan's approval for diversion of profits to the contras. But he said he never saw ''a single document which gave me a clear indication'' that the President had given his approval. In any event, he said, ''I think I shredded most'' of the memorandums. Shredding: Colonel North said there was no ''horrible, final, last-minute, last-ditch shredding'' of documents just before Justice Department officials began to investigate his activities in late November 1986. Rather, he said, he began shredding documents ''in earnest'' in early October 1986, when his covert operations began ''unraveling.'' False chronology: Colonel North said he knew, while preparing a chronology of the Iran-contra affair in early November 1986, that it contained false information. The inaccurate data, he said, came from Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's former national security adviser, and he said other senior officials also knew it contained falsehoods. Meese's knowledge: Colonel North said Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d was aware of the shipment of 18 Hawk antiaircraft missiles from Israel to Iran at about the time of the shipment in November 1985. However, Mr. Meese has said he did not learn of the shipment until nearly a year later. North's obedience: Colonel North said he ''never carried out a single act'' for which he did not have authority from his superiors. In 23 years in the armed services, he said, he never ''violated an order, not one.''

title: CORPORATE TENANTS IN QUEENS
description: WHEN 400 acres of vacant land surrounding the now dormant Flushing Airport in the College Point section of Queens was chosen by the city for development in the late 1960's, the idea was to bring jobs to the borough by selling manufacturers on the area's accessibility by truck to New England, Long Island and the rest of the city.

title: FOR FOLIES-BERGERE, 100 NAUGHTY YEARS
description: The Folies-Bergere, that legendary dream machine, is celebrating its 100th birthday with its first new show in five years: a splashy, glittering, utterly ephemeral extravaganza entitled ''Folies en Folie.''

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Waiting for Greenspan
description: Five weeks after the President named Alan Greenspan to succeed Paul A. Volcker as head of the Federal Reserve, the Senate Banking Committee has yet to receive the documents it needs to begin the confirmation process. When asked yesterday when a hearing would take place, a committee aide said it might be late next week at the earliest. And the reason for the delay? ''Something about his financial statement being real long,'' she said of the highly regarded, and obviously well-heeled, New York economist.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: DURING my childhood in France, it was necessary to wait for certain foods to come into season, be it asparagus, woodland strawberries or venison. Today, of course, there is almost no food that cannot be had both in and out of season. But I still look forward to fresh local foods that arrive without the benefit of several hours' travel by air: the first shad, for example, or the first soft-shell crabs; the first morels, or the first new peas and ears of corn.

title: 20.25 RISE PUTS DOW NEAR PEAK
description: LEAD: Led by energy issues and bolstered by foreign buying, the stock market staged a strong rally yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to a point just short of its record high.

title: BORK ON HIS EVOLUTION: FAR FROM THE NEW DEAL
description: Judge Robert H. Bork, whose nomination to the Supreme Court has spawned a bitter ideological battle between President Reagan and Senate liberals, said today that he was not asked his views or asked to make commitments on specific issues before Mr. Reagan chose him last week.

title: HOW TO GAUGE INFLATION RATE
description: SOME days, inflation seems worse than others.

title: Opera: 'Boris Godunov' in Washington
description: As the final step in a rehearsal process leading to the recording, starting Wednesday, of an album and film soundtrack, Mstislav Rostropovich and his National Symphony presented a concert performance of ''Boris Godunov'' Monday night at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. The nearly five-hour event had its failings and eccentricities. But, over all, it amounted to an overwhelming statement of Mussorgsky's masterpiece.

title: 'PEOPLE USED TO WALK UP TO TELL ME WHAT A GREAT JOB I DID'
description: Under questioning by John W. Nields Jr., the House committee's chief counsel, Lieut Col. Oliver L. North insisted yesterday that he believed his superiors knew about his actions. This exchange occurred during questioning about a false chronology.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: YOU'RE off to the great outdoors - maybe to hike, canoe, camp or fish. You've got your bird book and binoculars, a Swiss Army knife, a poncho, a canteen and enough dried food, you think, for three. But are you really prepared? Probably not. Indeed, according to a 1982 telephone survey, even the most experienced outdoors enthusiasts can be injured and not know what to do.

title: BERKELEY EGGHEADS TESTED
description: How does one drop a raw egg 80 feet onto hard concrete without having it, well, egg-splode?

title: GULF BAN OPPOSED BY 12 IN CONGRESS
description: In a severe blow to Congressional efforts to block the Administration's Persian Gulf strategy, 12 members of the House Armed Services Committee unanimously agreed today not to vote to block the Reagan Administration's plans to fly American flags on Kuwaiti oil tankers and to give the merchant ships naval escorts.

title: TENNIS
description: Sundstrom Upsets Leconte: Hendrik Sundstrom of Sweden upset top-seeded Henri Leconte of France, 3-6, 6-2, 6-4, in the first round of the Swiss Open in Gstaad yesterday. Mikael Pernfors of Sweden, seeded fifth, beat Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland, 6-2, 6-4, and Anders Jarryd, seeded sixth, also of Sweden, defeated Roland Stadler of Switzerland, 6-3, 6-4. Emilio Sanchez of Spain, seeded third,defeated Johan Kriek, 6-1, 6-4. Ramesh Krishnan of India, seeded seventh, was beaten by Ronald Agenor of Haiti, 3-6, 3-6.(AP) Yacht Racing Stars & Stripes Loses Again: Stars & Stripes, the America's Cup winner, suffered its third straight loss in the semifinals of the world 12-Meter championship off Sardinia yesterday. Bengal, skippered by Colin Beashel, crossed the finish line 6 minutes 25 seconds ahead of Dennis Conner's San Diego-based yacht, which failed to win a race in the semifinals. New Zealand won its third straight race, beating Kookaburra II of Australia to reach the three-of-five-race final against Bengal, an Australian boat that also won three races in the semifinals.(AP) Pyewacket Leads Race: Pyewacket, Roy Disney's Nelson-Marek 70, moved into first place in the Transpacific Yacht Race yesterday as the lead boats, pushed by 25-knot winds, passed the halfway point in the 2,225-mile race from Los Angeles to Honolulu. Pyewacket, of the Los Angeles Yacht Club, reported that it was 935 miles from the Diamond Head finish line. Citius, a Santa Cruz 70 from the Los Angeles Yacht Club, was two miles behind. Then came Bob McNulty's Blondie, another Santa Cruz 70 and also of the Los Angeles Yacht Club, and Pandemonium, skippered by Bill Packer of the Newport Harbor Yacht Club.(AP)

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Speaking Up for Hart
description: Senator Gore and five other Democratic members of the Senate Rules Committee - Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii, Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, Brock Adams of Washington and Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut - say the Federal Election Commission was wrong in its preliminary decision last month denying Gary Hart's bid for matching Government campaign money.

title: MCGREGOR IS OPTIONED
description: Scott McGregor, struggling with a 2-7 record and 6.69 earned run average, was optioned to Rochester of the International League Monday night by the Baltimore Orioles. ''This is not exactly what I wanted to do,'' said the 33-year-old McGregor, who had to agree to the move. ''But if this is my only option, I'm all for it.''

title: Washington Talk: Office of Government Ethics; Taking Lots of Heat From and About Meese
description: Almost a decade ago, in the aftermath of the Watergate scandals, President Carter signed the Ethics in Government Act, a bill designed to help restore the nation's faith in its highest officials by insuring that those officials were in fact deserving of the public trust.

title: Networks Will Carry Washington Hearings
description: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair will be broadcast live beginning at 9 A.M. on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on some local affiliates of PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service, including Channel 13 in New York and Channel 49 in Connecticut.

title: LIFE VS. LIVELIHOOD AT CHRYSLER PLANT
description: The Federal Government's finding that some workers were exposed to lead, arsenic and dangerous chemicals has aroused deep anxiety at the Chrysler Corporation plant here, forcing employees to weigh hopes for security against worries over health.

title: LONG-DISTANCE CALLS MAY GO UP IN PRICE IN NEW F.C.C. PLAN
description: The era of declining prices for long-distance telephone calls may be nearing an end.

title: NEVADA DISTRICT'S SCHOOL BONDS SOLD
description: In the tax-exempt market, Nevada's Washoe County School District offered $90.8 million of bonds yesterday through an underwriting group led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: After 50 Years, Soviet to Show Attic Full of Avant-Garde Art
description: For more than half a century, since Socialist Realism became the Soviet Union's only approved form of artistic expression, many abstract creations of Russia's rowdy artistic revolutionaries have been sequestered in a quiet attic of the State Russian Museum here.

title: SOUTHLAND SUITS FILED
description: The Thompson family, which plans to take the Southland Corporation private, said that some of its shareholders have filed suit to prevent the $5.1 billion leveraged buyout. The Thompsons declined to provide details, but said the lawsuits lacked merit.

title: BANKS WIN RULING ON EXPANSION
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld a Federal Reserve Board decision clearing the way for banks to offer both investment advice and brokerage services to institutional or wealthy clients.

title: GEORGE'S FIRST BLACK COACH
description: When John McLendon heard that George Steinbrenner had brought his name up as one of the examples that would demonstrate that there was no racism in his history, John McLendon was, he said, ''amused.''

title: FROM POLAND, EMIGREES ADD SPIRIT TO ARTS
description: Liliana Komorowka cannot forget a haunting scene from the evening of Dec. 13, 1981 - the day the Polish Government declared martial law and crushed Solidarity. Tanks and soldiers roamed the streets. At the Moscow Theater near her Warsaw apartment, the title on the movie marquee seemed to say everything, ''Apocalypse Now.''

title: FRANCE AND BRITAIN UNEASY WITH U.S. GULF POLICY
description: France and Britain, with considerable experience in the Persian Gulf, are watching the Reagan Administration's activities there with some anxiety while also offering Washington support for a United Nations Security Council resolution intended to put new pressure on Iran.

title: Albany Accord Reached On Increasing Pensions
description: Over the objections of Mayor Koch, legislative leaders have agreed to a bill that would supplement the pensions of thousands of state and city workers who retired before 1983.

title: Long Lines Make Miss Liberty a Five-Hour Outing
