description: A year after the spectacular reopening of the Statue of Liberty, visitors to the national monument are coping with long lines, few information signs and an elevator that has been less than reliable.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: Baez Finds Her Voice

title: TRAILING BY 8-1, PHILLIES WIN
description: Luis Aguayo broke an 8-8 tie with a 10th-inning double tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies rallied to defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 10-8.

title: OESTER CAREER IN DOUBT
description: Ron Oester, the Cincinnati Reds' second baseman who was injured Sunday on a take-out slide by Mookie Wilson of the Mets, is through for the season and faces a challenge to resume his career at all because of a devastating knee injury that involves ligament and cartilage damage. The surgery performed Monday on the 31-year-old infielder was described as a complete rebuilding of the left knee.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about a visit to the New York area by Soviet experts on alcoholism misstated the Soviet Government's policy regarding Alcoholics Anonymous. There is no official barrier to the group's activity.

title: Stage: 'Hard Times'
description: ''HARD TIMES'' is not one of Charles Dickens's big novels and may not be one of his best, but as demonstrated by the Berkeley Repertory Theater's dramatization on a welcome visit to Theater 890, it can generate plenty of vitality. Although the Royal Shakespeare Company's prodigious ''Nicholas Nickleby'' cannot have been absent from the mind of the director, Richard E. T. White, he has sensibly cut his aspirations to his cloth. Starting with a fluid adaptation by Stephen Jeffreys that is true to Dickens's language and spirit even as it condenses many episodes and heightens some effects, Mr. White whips the story along for three hours in an always coherent, often compelling way.

title: TV Reviews; In Shopping Games, the Bargain Is All
description: IT is a phenomenon, too big to be called just a fad. Some 25 home-shopping services across the country now operate on cable television. They sell; we buy. The transactions are matter of fact. Come now two programs that go a step further; it's not what you buy but how you buy it. One program has a bugle call; the other has flashing lights. Two cheers for giddy consumers. The programs are ''Home Shopping Game'' on CBS, Channel 2, weekdays at 9 A.M., and ''Bargain Hunters'' on ABC, Channel 7, weekdays at 11:30 A.M., although both are being pre-empted for the Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair. Loosely speaking, they're game shows. Contestants answer questions. The big kick, however, is supposed to be the bargains: a Cartier bracelet for $144.25 (applause); a hand-painted ceramic carousel, ''an heirloom for tomorrow,'' for $123 (more applause and shrieks). Call an 800 number and order; a credit card, check or money order will do.

title: Court Tells Michigan V.F.W. To Pay Tax on Sales of Cards
description: The Michigan department of the Veterans of Foreign Wars must pay taxes on part of the income it earned from selling Christmas cards to members, the United States Tax Court has ruled.

title: Rostenkowsi Recuperating
description: Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, was in good condition after undergoing an appendectomy Monday night in Chicago, the Illinois Democrat's office said today. ''The operation was routine with no complications,'' the statement said. ''Chairman Rostenkowski is planning to return to Washington next week.''

title: YANKS, DOWN BY 7, RALLY TO BEAT TWINS
description: The events of June 7 were making less and less sense as Joe Niekro fluttered successfully along at the Stadium last night. Niekro, the 42-year-old pitcher who was dispatched by the Yankees to the Minnesota Twins that day, went to the seventh inning with a seven-run lead against his former teammates. The two Niekros, Joe and Phil, seemed sure of adding a victory to their total of 535, a record for both brothers and deposed Yankees.

title: Poll Hints at Bork Support
description: Forty-nine percent of all Americans believe that a nominee to the Supreme Court should be confirmed by the Senate even though some senators disagree with his ideology, according to a poll for U.S. News & World Report. The telephone survey of 1,010 people was conducted June 30 and July 1, just before President Reagan nominated of Judge Robert H. Bork to replace Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. on the Supreme Court.

title: SIKHS SUSPECTED
description: At least 34 Hindu bus passengers were killed Tuesday night by suspected Sikh terrorists in the northern state of Haryana, raising the death toll in two nights of terrorist attacks to at least 72, officials said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: Two former executives of Refco International Futures have been awarded $30 million by a Federal District Court jury in Manhattan after they charged that the firm and its largest partner, Thomas H. Dittmer, had stolen the futures trading business that they had set up. Mr. Dittmer's lawyer said that he would appeal.

title: Tentative Contract Reached With Jersey Garbage Haulers
description: A tentative contract agreement was reached last night between union and management negotiators, ending the threat of a strike that had been called for 12:01 A.M. today by garbage collectors in 13 northern and central New Jersey counties.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Gore Offers to Debate
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. may have some explaining to do if a debate between Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri takes place.

title: Courts to Speed Up Arrest Reviews
description: Judges in New York City's criminal courts will review the probable cause for all arrests within 24 hours after a suspect has been apprehended, under an agreement reached yesterday between city officials and state administrative judges.

title: 15 HOPEFULS BACK PARTIES' DEBATES
description: All the current Republican and Democratic Presidential candidates have agreed that the two nominees will participate in the general election debates being sponsored by the parties, though they are free to appear as well in a rival series planned by the League of Women Voters.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ON the loveliest of early summer days Larry Peters decided to spend his lunch hour in Central Park. He found the perfect grassy knoll just off the entrance at 59th Street and Seventh Avenue. There, he stretched out, took off his shoes and settled down for a peaceful read. After half an hour or so he dozed off into a sunny sleep. When he awoke, he read a few more pages, assembled his belongings and discovered his shoes were gone. This was not the first time he had been robbed, and his immediate reaction was, understandably, anger. Then, pleasant fellow and New Yorker that he is, he sat back and began to laugh at the absurdity of the situation.

title: ATTRACTING EDUCATED FIGHTER
description: Boxing has long been the fast track for ghetto youth - a way for the kid with slim prospects to make his way in society.

title: THE COLONEL STATES HIS CASE: COUNTRY AND ORDERS ABOVE ALL
description: As the Iran-contra hearings resumed in Washington, the Congressional committees heard yesterday from Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. Here are excerpts from the testimony, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: PAIEMENT A PENGUIN
description: Looking for muscle to protect their star center, Mario Lemieux, the Pittsburgh Penguins announced the signing of the 12-year veteran Wilf Paiement, a right wing who became a free agent after scoring 20 goals and 17 assists for the Buffalo Sabres last season. Paiement has 354 goals, 452 assists and 1,718 penalty minutes in 923 games during his career.

title: Let's Stop Reneging on Our U.N. Dues
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: John Blauner has been promoted to senior vice president of FCB/LKP Targeted Marketing Services, the direct response and sales promotion division of FCB/Leber Katz Partners.

title: CORPORATE PRESSURES SLOWING GIFTS TO CHARITY
description: Corporate giving to charities is leveling off or even declining as oil companies and other traditional big contributors scale back because of restructuring pressures.

title: Extension on Shelf Life of Milk Looks Political
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: DR. FLORENCE HOLLIS
description: Dr. Florence Hollis, a professor emeritus at the Columbia University School of Social Work, died Thursday at Crosslands, a retirement community in Kennett Square, Pa. She was 80 years old.

title: Keep the Tax Cleanup Clean
description: There is a 503-page tax bill in the Congressional hopper this year, and it is just a postscript. The bill cleans up mistakes in last year's big tax reform law. Like every big tax revision, it had dozens of errors. With loophole lobbyists waiting to enlarge them, the trick will be to keep the cleanup bill clean.

title: AIR CRASH LAID TO FLAW IN CONTROL SYSTEM
description: A Federal board said yesterday that inadequacies of the system for controlling air traffic, rather than human errors, were the prime cause of the collision of an Aeromexico jetliner and a small private plane that killed 82 people near Los Angeles last August.

title: A Plane From Haiti Crashes Carrying 4 American Tourists
description: A small plane leaving Haiti with four American tourists and a Dominican pilot apparently lost its way and crashed at sea, but two passengers were said to have made it to shore, an American official said Tuesday.

title: MUSIC: MOSTLY MOZART, WITH ALICIA DE LARROCHA
description: BY the time Gerard Schwarz gave the downbeat last night to open the 1987 Mostly Mozart festival, one had begun to wonder if what was about to take place was a concert or an episode of the soap opera ''General Hospital.'' The flutist Jean-Pierre Rampal, scheduled to be one of three soloists on the gala opening program, canceled because of a bronchitis and flu attack. Marilyn Horne, after first ordering that she be listed in the program as a soprano in a pair of alto arias from Handel's ''Messiah,'' also dropped out, apparently afflicted similarly. William Lockwood, who directs the festival, announced these defections from the stage, looking rather shellshocked, but assured the audience that Mozart would show up.

title: LaROUCHE DENIES GUILT IN PLOT CASE AND RETAINS HIS PASSPORT
description: Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the frequent Presidential candidate, pleaded not guilty at his arraignment before a Federal magistrate here today on felony charges of conspiracy to obstruct justice. He was released on $20,000 cash bail put up by an 82-year-old supporter he had never met and a $200,000 unsecured personal bond.

title: BAUSCH & LOMB
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc., the Rochester-based eye-care company, said it had agreed to buy Pharmafair Inc. for $40 million. Pharmafair, based in Hauppauge, L.I., makes generic pharmaceuticals for eye and ear treatment. In its fiscal year ended March 31, the privately held company earned $18.4 million, a 55 percent increase from the previous year. Pharmafair, which employs about 300 people, will be run as a Bausch & Lomb separate unit by its founder, Assad Sawaya, and its current managers.

title: TAKEOVER BID FOR FERMENTA
description: Fermenta A.B., a troubled Swedish biotechnology company, said it had received a takeover offer from Trans-Resources Inc., a New York chemical concern.

title: FOR A SECRET STEW RECIPE, TIME IS RUNNING OUT
description: HAJJI GOLAM HOSSAIN admits he is getting a little tired of biryani, a Mogul mutton stew his family has prepared from a secret recipe for 110 years. ''But I believe in fate,'' he said, ''and my fate is to make hajji biryani in this shop, like my father and my grandfather, for as long as I live.''

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Those Canadian Subs
description: United States military officials -and military contractors - will be all ears today when Canada's Defense Minister, Perrin Beatty, elaborates on his country's new military strategy in a speech before the Ripon Society at the Park Hyatt Hotel.

title: TODD SHIPYARDS IN SHIFT AT TOP
description: The financially troubled Todd Shipyards Corporation said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Hans K. Schaefer, had resigned from those posts and taken a lesser role with the company.

title: TIME FOR MEMORIES ON ROAD TO PARIS
description: Just after a heavy rain ended this morning, a good five hours before the Tour de France was due to pass through this village, a policeman checked the highway for stray dogs. He returned every so often through the early afternoon.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS, INTEL IN CHIP ACCORD
description: Texas Instruments Inc. and the Intel Corporation said today that they had agreed to cooperate in developing semi-customized computer chips, one of the fastest-growing segments of the semiconductor business.

title: FORD UNIT MARKETING NOTES AT 8.23%
description: In the corporate bond market, issuers offered about $1 billion of new debt securities yesterday. Most of them were met by strong investor demand, traders said, with interest focusing on shorter-term, rather than longer-term, maturities.

title: Travels of a Diner
description: To the Editor:

title: Honduran Authorities Ban the Film 'Salvador'
description: The Honduran authoritites have banned the showing of the film ''Salvador,'' directed by Oliver Stone, on the ground that its grim portrayal of El Salvador's civil war threatened state security, according to government sources.

title: South African Blacks Still Need American Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have never carried out a single act, not one, in which I did not have authority from my superiors. I haven't in the 23 years that I have been in the uniformed services of the United States of America ever violated an order, not one.'' - Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. [ A1:6. ]

title: AS FAMILIES GO, SO GOES PICNICKING IN AMERICA
description: LEAD: SUMMER used to be the time when most American families would pack a basket some weekend, pile into the car and head for a park to savor some homemade cold chicken and potato salad along with each other's companionship. Summer is still picnic time, but picnicking seems to be losing its appeal, or so the latest data suggest.

title: JET LANDING IS 19 MILES OFF
description: Confused by thunderstorms and look-alike runways, two Delta Air Lines pilots set their jet down in Frankfort today when they meant to land in Lexington, 19 miles away.

title: FOR THE 'CAN DO' COLONEL, ADMISSIONS, NO APOLOGY
description: Through the smirks and winks and teary eyes, through the ''Peck's Bad Boy'' grins and the earnest altar-boy gazes, Oliver North seemed, as always, to be starring in his own movie.

title: Excerpts From Court Decision on the Shield Law
description: Following are excerpts from opinions by the New York State Court of Appeals yesterday in the case of Knight-Ridder Broadcasting Inc. v. Sol Greenberg, Albany County District Attorney. Judge Fritz W. Alexander presented the court's opinion, joined by Judges Richard D. Simons, Vito J. Titone and Stewart F. Hancock Jr. Judge Joseph W. Bellacosa presented the dissenting opinion, joined by Chief Judge Sol Wachlter and Judge Judith S. Kaye.

title: DANCE IS MORE THAN EXERCISE, NEW JERSEY YOUNGSTERS LEARN
description: FOR 25 years, children here have been stomping through the doors of the Center for Modern Dance Education and gliding out. Many are enrolled by parents eager for their children to receive a dose of culture. Others, children with disciplinary problems, are referred by counselors in the Hackensack public-school system.

title: Corrections
description: A dispatch on June 29 from Bnei Brak, Israel, about Israel's religious conflicts misstated the practice of Agudat Israel party members regarding military service. No Agudat Israel women serve in the army, but a small number of the party's young men do.

title: KIDDE STUDIES SALE OR RESTRUCTURING
description: Kidde Inc., maker of Farberware cooking utensils, Jacuzzi whirlpool baths and many other consumer, security and industrial products, said yesterday that it might restructure or sell all or part of the company.

title: EMPLOYEES CHALLENGING WORLD BANK'S CHANGES
description: Employees of the World Bank, lashing back at the bank's American president, have brought a class action suit against the institution to delay dismissals of hundreds of economists and other highly skilled professionals, the demotions of hundreds more and position changes for most.

title: Film: Vietnamese Side Of the War in 'Karma'
description: UNLIKE the Western-made films that have regarded Vietnam as a hellish, bewildering landscape, a terra incognita in which American soldiers are set adrift, Ho Quang Minh's ''Karma'' regards it as home. The Hanoi-born Mr. Minh, now a naturalized Swiss citizen, made his film in and around Ho Chi Minh City, as Saigon is now named, working with a Vietnamese cast and crew. Deserts and beaches are seen here more frequently than the predictable jungle scenery, and the film's psychic landscape is as unconventional, at least by Western standards, as its physical one.

title: Korean Riot Policemen Allow Peaceful March
description: Riot policemen moved back from the site of clashes with students on Monday, allowing thousands of university students to march peacefully today in honor of a student killed during a recent demonstration.

title: Delay the Bork Hearings
description: LEAD: The coming Senate debate over the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the United States Supreme Court is premature. The Senate should defer action on any nomination to the Court until the outcome of the Iran-contra hearings and the investigation by the independent counsel, Lawrence E. Walsh.

title: IS SEIZED
description: A 35-year-old wanted for jumping bail on a weapons charge was arrested in East Harlem yesterday after he ran two red lights and offered $20,000 to the two police officers who arrested him, authorities said.

title: NEW YORK COURT LIMITS PROTECTION TO CONFIDENTIAL NEWS MATERIALS
description: New York's highest court ruled yesterday that journalists' notes or other materials obtained from nonconfidential sources were not covered by a state law protecting news organizations from disclosing information gathered for a news article.

title: SOTHEBY'S SOUTH AFRICA
description: Sotheby's, the international auctioneering house, said today that it had sold its small South African operation to local management. Sotheby's Sougt Africa managing director, Stephan Weiz, said the sale was arranged after Sotheby's American owners became uncomfortable about the country's political situation. The company has operated in South Africa since 1968 with offices in Johannesburg and Cape Town and current annual turnover of $5 million. Terms of the sale were not given. The South African operation will keep the Sotheby's name for about one year befor changing it. The new name has not yet been decided.

title: Hunt for Colossus Yields Just a Lump of Rock
description: A quest initiated by a clairvoyant for one of the seven wonders of antiquity came to an abrupt end today when experts decided that a lump of rock, once thought to be part of the Colossus of Rhodes, was no more than, well, a lump of rock.

title: SEVEN EJECTED IN BEANBALL EXCHANGE
description: Andre Dawson and Benito Santiago were hit by pitches in a beanball exchange today during a game between the San Diego Padres and Chicago Cubs.

title: KEY RATES
'Dreamgirls' Invites Comparison
description: When Lillias White learned she would be starring on Broadway in ''Dreamgirls,'' her excitement was tempered by considerable apprehension.

title: OFFBEAT ART SPENDING SUMMER ON EAST RIVER
description: A temporary new sculpture garden is emerging amid the weeds and warehouses on the Long Island City waterfront.

title: Double Setback For Bilzerian
description: Paul A. Bilzerian, the financier, was barred late yesterday by a Federal district judge in Seattle from purchasing 4.1 million common shares of Pay 'N Pak Stores Inc. that would have given him control of the company. Shortly before Judge John C. Coughenour issued a temporary restraining order, Mr. Bilzerian's broker, Morgan Stanley & Company, canceled the order.

title: MAKE ROOM FOR LOPEZ
description: Having fulfilled the entry requirements for the Ladies Professional Golf Association Hall of Fame - being a member of the women's tour for 10 years and winning at least 35 official tour events including one major - Nancy Lopez will become the 11th to be inducted, July 20 in New York. Lopez, 30 years old, turned pro in July 1977 and has won 35 tour events, earning $1,796,933 in purses. The other Hall of Fame members:

title: KEY RATES
AT N.Y.U., PIONEERING BRAIN SURGERY
description: For the first time in New York, tissue was transplanted into a patient's brain yesterday.

title: CALIFORNIAN SEES RISE IN ASIAN GANGS
description: The Attorney General of California said today that the state needed Federal assistance to combat what he said was a growing law-enforcement problem posed by gangs of Asian immigrants.

title: BIDEN VOWS TO LEAD FORCES AGAINST BORK'S CONFIRMATION
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., chairman of the Judiciary Committee and a Democratic Presidential contender, assured opponents of the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork today that he would lead the fight against his confirmation to the United States Supreme Court.

title: LANDFILL IN QUEENS TO CLOSE BY 1991 UNDER AGREEMENT
description: Ending a dispute with the state that has lasted more than a decade, New York City officials have tentatively agreed to close one of the city's two remaining landfills by 1991.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
McLean Industries Chooses New Chief
description: LEAD: McLean Industries, the big American-flag shipping company that is in bankruptcy proceedings, has named Robert G. Truesdell 2d president and chief executive.

title: BIAGGI'S LAWYER MAY BE REMOVED BY JUDGE
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn told a defense attorney in the upcoming bribery trial of Representative Mario Biaggi that he might be removed from the case and called as a witness because of a public statement the lawyer made about Mr. Biaggi.

title: HOWE ON WAY BACK
description: The association governing the minor leagues has lifted its suspension of Steve Howe. Johnny Johnson, president of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, said that effective Sunday, he had lifted the suspension he imposed on Howe in May of last year when Howe showed positive in a drug test whilepitching for San Jose in the Class A California League.

title: Marriott's Net Rises by 22.6%
description: The Marriott Corporation said today that its second-quarter earnings rose 22.6 percent, to $63.9 million, or 47 cents a share, from $52.1 million, or 38 cents a share, a year ago.

title: IRAN-CONTRA HEARING AS TELEVISION DRAMA
description: ''WASHINGTON theater,'' Dan Rather said yesterday. ''It may not get much better than that.''

title: A Colonel Without Protection: North Builds a Fence Against Terror Attack
description: Under questioning by John W. Nields Jr., the House committee's chief counsel, Colonel North described the reasons for the installation of a security system at his home.

title: Chronology II
description: As Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North converts thousands of daytime television watchers into Iran-contra devotees, the National Security Archive has come up with a second edition of its guidebook to the intricacies of the scandal. ''The Chronology,'' in 920 pages, offers detailed background as well as testimony before the Congressional committee until Colonel North took the stand this week.

title: DANCE: THREE NEW WORKS AT NORTH CAROLINA FESTIVAL
description: The American Dance Festival's annual program by young choreographers and composers can usually be counted on to be one of the pleasant surprises of the summer dance season. Each year the festival permits three choreographers to collaborate with three composers on new works. One never knows what to expect of these ventures. But they are seldom dull.

title: Find an Alternative to Reflagging
description: The worst way to make policy is to compound error with error because, supposedly, there's no choice. That's exactly what the Reagan Administration proposes by going forward with reflagging and protecting Kuwaiti oil tankers. Yet the most that members of Congress seem willing to do is call for delay. And a group of House Armed Services Committee members limply say just what the Administration wants to hear, that reneging would have ''worse consequences than going ahead.''

title: G.M.A.C. WON'T CALL ANTILLES BONDS
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, a large issuer of Eurobonds, announced yesterday that it did not intend to call any bonds issued out of its Netherlands Antilles subsidiary. It was the first company to say publicly that it would not recall its Netherlands Antilles bonds.

title: Wirthlin's Winners
description: Who won the celebrated square-off last week among the seven Democratic Presidential contenders? Richard Wirthlin, polltaker for President Reagan and the Republican National Committee, said he regarded two participants as potentially formidable 1988 nominees: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware.

title: MEAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $900,000 and $1,400,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June.

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflects interest expense on the debt incurred to finance the recapitalization of the company, completed in October 1986. The company said net interest expense in the latest quarter and 6 month was $44.5 million and $88.7 million, respectively, compared with $5 million for the year-ago quarter and $9.1 million for the 6 months. The previously announced sale of the company's British subsidiary, Woodville Polymer Engineering Ltd., to the Dowty Group Plc of England for 35.9 million British pounds was completed; Woodville sales and operations are included in the company's 1987 second quarter results. The company said earnings and shares outstanding for the 1986 second quarter and 6 month have been restated to reflect the recapitalization, treating it as if there had been an 8.3913-for-1 stock split based on the exchange ratio for shares held in the company's retirement savings plan.

title: MICHAEL J. EAGEN
description: Michael J. Eagen, a former Chief Justice of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court, died Tuesday. He was 80 years old.

title: WATTS RECITAL POSTPONED
description: A recital by Andre Watts scheduled Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall as part of the Mostly Mozart festival has been postponed a week because of the pianist's bursitis.

title: Correction
description: The Food Notes column in The Living Section yesterday misstated the size of bottles of olive oil on sale at the Fisher & Levy catering shop. They are 17 ounces.

title: BANK OF NEW HAMPSHIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KNICKS FINALLY SIGN BIANCHI
description: It took an exhausting 80 days, involved a cavalcade of candidates and clandestine meetings throughout the country, before the Knicks made their first definitive move toward erasing their recent past.

title: PLAN ON RADON VOTED BY SENATE TO HELP STATES
description: A three-year, $31.5 million Federal program to help states detect and control radon contamination in homes and schools passed the Senate today.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Ex-Crocker Executives Reunited at Mellon Bank
description: LEAD: W. Keith Smith, who helped Frank V. Cahouet cut loan losses at the Crocker National Bank, has rejoined his old boss at the Mellon Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh to do more of the same.

title: ANTI-SIKH VIOLENCE IN NORTHERN INDIA
description: The Indian Army was called out today to halt Hindu reprisals against Sikhs in the northern state of Haryana after Sikh terrorists killed at least 72 people in attacks on Hindu bus passengers, Indian officials said.

title: GOT A HELMET? MAKE A LAMP
description: IT'S surprising what people want to make into lamps.

title: Tiny WPP's Dramatic Coup
description: THE successful $566 million bid late last month by the WPP Group P.L.C., a tiny British marketing company, for the world's fourth-largest advertising concern, the JWT Group, was a dramatic minnow-swallows-whale corporate tale. The deal was the most remarkable that Madison Avenue has ever seen, a daring and audacious move by WPP and its 42-year-old chief executive, Martin S. Sorrell.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Clash in San Salvador Reported to Injure 21
description: In the worst incident of street violence here in recent years, at least 21 people were reported seriously wounded by gunshots and clubs today when the police clashed with striking workers trying to force their way into a public building.

title: Help Lessens For 3d World
description: Developing countries received 15 percent less money from the rest of the world in 1986 as a result of a sharp cut in private bank lending and a drop in net export credits, according to the O.E.C.D.

title: A PATCH OF GREEN FOR HOMELESS MEN
description: TO a group of men without homes or jobs, eight rectangles of soil have provided a chance to enjoy a part of American life that they rarely experience. With the help of a nonprofit group called the Green Guerillas, these men, residents of a New York City shelter for homeless men on Wards Island, have planted flowers and vegetables next to the shelter.

title: POLICE KILL ROBBERY SUSPECT AT L.I. GAS STATION
description: A man suspected of robbing more than 20 Long Island service stations was shot and killed last night by police officers who chased him on foot after he attempted to hold up a station in Elmont, L.I., the Nassau County police said.

title: OFFICER CLEARED OF TAKING GRAFT IN 77TH PRECINCT
description: A 25-year-old police officer from the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn was found not guilty yesterday of taking money and crack from a drug dealer and then sharing in the proceeds from the sale of the drug.

title: STAINS PROVIDE A NEW LOOK
description: LEAD: THERE are several reasons -from drastic to subtle - for applying stain to wood. It can be used to unify the appearance of a surface made up of several kinds of wood. It can enhance furniture or subdue its less-appealing features. Stain can also be used to revive color or to simply to blend in repairs that require the replacement of wood.

title: Dinkins and Ferrer to Endorse Judge in Bronx Surrogate Race
description: Borough Presidents David N. Dinkins of Manhattan and Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx are to endorse today Judge Hansel McGee of Civil Court for Bronx surrogate.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about a documentary film showing ways to prevent AIDS gave an incorrect address for the film's producer, a nonprofit corporation called AIDSFilms. It is at 50 West 34th Street.

title: CHERRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Kennedy Cut in Car Crash
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy suffered minor cuts tonight when a large tree fell on the road in front of his car, an aide said. The Massachusetts Democrat had left a Senate session and was being driven to his residence in McLean, Va., when the accident occurred about 9 P.M. on the George Washington Memorial Parkway. The National Park Service police were investigating the accident. Neither Mr. Kennedy nor the driver of the car, identified as Michael Gavigan, an aide, required hospital treatment. Mr. Kennedy was treated at home for minor cuts, according to an aide who asked that his name not be used.

title: Dutch Artists Hunting Alternatives to the Dole
description: With the demise a week ago of the Pictorial Arts Scheme, about 2,000 Dutch painters, sculptors and other artists will have to sell their work themselves or find other jobs.

title: CBS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1 million and $6.7 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; gains from the disposal of discontinued operations of $4.6 million for the quarter and $3.3 million for the 6 months, and $11.8 million extraordinary losses for both quarter and 6 months.

title: Bond Prices Drop in Slow Day
description: Bond prices slipped in light, spotty trading yesterday, pushed lower on overnight profit taking by Japanese and European investors and a selloff in the bond futures pits in Chicago.

title: The Editorial Notebook: The Boarder Babies and the Priest; Father Fagan Struck A Better Deal For 'Little Guys'
description: On any given day in New York City, about 170 babies languish in public and private hospitals for lack of foster homes. This boarder baby crisis developed as city officials first failed to anticipate an explosive increase in the number of abandoned and drug-abused babies and then were slow to mount an aggressive recruiting campaign for foster parents.

title: Six Rail Workers Dismissed Over Failure to Fight Blaze
description: Six employees of the Southern Pacific Railroad who discovered a fire that eventually destroyed a railway tunnel in May have been dismissed because they did not stop and try to put it out, a railroad spokesman says.

title: U.S. Reported to Thwart a Marcos Coup Plot
description: The United States Government has uncovered information that Ferdinand E. Marcos was planning to instigate an armed insurrection in the Philippines this Friday in hopes of returning to power, officials said today.

title: Savings Bonds by Mail
description: Citing efficiency, the Treasury Department said today that it would begin experimenting this fall with mailing United States savings bonds to investors rather than delivering the bonds immediately upon purchase. The centralized distribution plan would begin as a pilot program in Ohio this October, the department said, and would affect only over-the-counter purchasers. Customers ordinarily buy their savings bonds at a bank or savings and loan association and wait to have them issued on the spot.

title: Alvin O'Konski, 83, Former Congressman
description: Alvin E. O'Konski, who represented Wisconsin in the House of Representatives for 30 years and was a co-author of the G.I. Bill of Rights, died of a heart ailment at his summer home here today. He was 83 years old and lived in retirement in Winter Park, Fla.

title: IN NO TIME AT ALL, BOTH PROPONENTS AND OPPONENTS ARE READY FOR BATTLE  Foes on the Left Strive for Unity
description: By the time President Reagan went before the television cameras last week to announce his choice for the Supreme Court, the campaign to persuade the Senate not to confirm Robert H. Bork was already well under way.

title: SCOTT'S HOSPITALITY reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Includes special gains of $2,814,000 and $8,031,000 for the latest and previous year, respectively. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split last August.

title: TRIAL DELAYS STATE REPORT ON CRIME
description: A state report on organized-crime influence in New York City's construction industry, scheduled to be released today, was delayed by Governor Cuomo yesterday after defense lawyers in a Federal rackteering trial in Manhattan said the report could taint the trial.

title: POP: SLEEPY LA BEEF
description: SLEEPY LA BEEF, who made one of his infrequent New York appearances at Tramps on Tuesday, is one of the living masters of the American honky-tonk vernacular. Like Jerry Lee Lewis, he is primarily an interpretive singer who transforms country, blues, rockabilly, gospel, soul and pop sources into expressions of his own larger-than-life personality. And he has a voice to match that personality - a huge, resonant, booming voice with a bass range deeper than Johnny Cash's, fluid phrasing and superb intonation. Thirty years in the honky-tonks have helped mold Mr. La Beef's voice into a powerful instrument, and early experience as a radio disk jockey has sharpened his elocution; in short, the man projects.

title: Lightning Launch
description: To the Editor:

title: DOW JUMPS 14.19, TO RECORD 2,463.97
description: The stock market surged ahead to another record close yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 14.19 points to close at 2,463.97. The previous high was 2,451.05 on June 25.

title: WALL ST. EYES ARE ON TELEDYNE
description: A lot of people are speculating these days that Henry E. Singleton, the savvy head of Teledyne Inc., is revamping his company's investment portfolio. Yet some analysts say they think the speculators are dead wrong.

title: STUDY CITES INCIDENCE OF CANCER NEAR POWER LINES
description: A study issued today by the New York State Health Department says that children with leukemia or brain cancer are more likely than healthy children to be living in homes where the exposure to the magnetic fields generated by electric power lines is high.

title: Death Toll Is Reduced In German Explosion
description: After sorting through the rubble of an ice-cream parlor leveled by a runaway oil truck and checking their lists of missing, officials said tonight that the toll was four dead, not the 30 or more originally feared.

title: Taking Some of the Guesswork Out of New York State's Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: Cherokee Have History Of Women Leaders
description: To the Editor:

title: Wheat Forecast Shrinks
description: World wheat production this year is now forecast at 518 million metric tons, 6 million less than was forecast last month and down 18 million from last year's harvest, the International Wheat Council said today. Estimates were lowered for Australia, Pakistan and the Soviet Union.

title: NORTH CONTRADICTS THE TESTIMONY OF OTHERS ON CONTRA AID EFFORTS
description: In the months that the nation waited for Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to speak, many predicted that he would ''fall on his sword'' to protect his superiors, colleagues and President Reagan.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: DOLLAR TOPS 150 YEN FOR 2D DAY

title: SUNTRUST BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that during the latest quarter it sold $28 million of its Latin American loans, reducing its Latin American loans outstanding to $130.7 million. The company also said it absorbed a loss of $9.8 million against its loan loss reserve from the sale of the Latin American debt.

title: The Trade-In Value of That Fourth Shuttle
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDS Suspicion Bars Surgery
description: A District of Columbia man who cut his foot badly on a rocky beach jetty was refused surgery at a Delaware hospital and taken by helicopter to a Washington hospital when he was unable to prove he did not have AIDS.

title: A CORNER WITH NEW COLOR
description: IT'S not a mirage: the southwest corner of 14th Street and Union Square is really enveloped in pastel-hued perennials and pink roses. This sunny oasis lights up the edge of one of Manhattan's busiest thoroughfares, and one of its newly restored parks.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH hot-melt glue guns have been available for almost 10 years, they were slow to catch on. In the past few years, new models that are far superior to the original versions have been introduced. So have adhesives and caulking materials that are much stronger and more versatile.

title: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt
description: THE BASKETBALL DIARIES. By Jim Carroll. 210 pages. Viking Penguin. Paper, $6.95. FORCED ENTRIES. The Downtown Diaries: 1971-1973. By Jim Carroll. 184 pages. Viking Penguin. Paper, $6.95. JIM CARROLL is a poet and rock musician in his mid-30's who grew up in several poor sections of Manhattan, the son and grandson of Irish Catholic bartenders. In the fall of 1963, when he was all of 13 years old, he began keeping a diary: ''Today was my first Biddy League game and my first day in any organized basketball league. I'm enthused about life due to this exciting event. The Biddy League is a league for anyone 12 yrs. old or under. I'm actually 13 but my coach Lefty gave me a fake birth certificate.''

title: BOTTLING VINTAGE SHIPS
description: GLENN BRAUN, top, has been putting ships in bottles for 15 of his 33 years. ''In the 1740's,'' he said, ''Europeans and Americans constructed miniature chairs and crucifixion scenes, but not ships, and put these into bottles. But during the 1840's - the era of the clipper ships, which have low, narrow hulls - people started building these ships so they would fit in bottles.''

title: LONG ISLAND YOUTH ORCHESTRA PLANS TRIP TO CUBA
description: After 10 years of writing letters to Fidel Castro without a reply, Martin Dreiwitz will lead his Long Island Youth Orchestra in a series of concerts in Cuba this month.

title:
A NEW ROOM IN THE HOUSE: THE AMERICAN BACKYARD;
OUTDOORS, ALL THE ELECTRONIC COMFORTS OF HOME
description: LEAD: TRADITIONALLY, most electrical devices have required a lifeline to household current. Over the past few years, however, for a variety of technical and marketing reasons, the term cordless has been appended to an increasing number of home-entertainment and communication products.

title: Administration Starts Contra Aid Push in Congress
description: The Reagan Administration has begun an intensive campaign to persuade Congress to renew aid to the Nicaraguan rebels this fall, even though officials concede that the contras still suffer from serious organizational problems, uncertain discipline and isolation in Nicaragua's sparsely populated north and east.

title: Shareholders Back Caesars Dividend
description: Caesars World Inc., no longer threatened by a hostile takeover bid, said its shareholders had approved its $942.4 million recapitalization plan. The plan, under which each share of stock receives a special $26.25 dividend, was approved by 79 percent of the 22.1 million shares voted.

title: NEW CALL FOR DRUG PROGRAM
description: The Dwight Gooden cocaine case, the most celebrated since the Pittsburgh cocaine trial of 1985, has prompted Frank Cashen to call for a joint drug program between the players and the clubs. Funny he should mention that. The players and the clubs had a joint drug agreement until the owners unilaterally killed it in October 1985.

title: Q&A
description: Q.I want to install insulation and a vapor barrier in the crawl space under the first floor of our house. How can I do this when nails from the hardwood flooring stick down through the subflooring and the cross-bracing between the floor joists prevents installation of foil-faced batts of insulation between the joists? A.If there is enough headroom the simplest solution is to install the insulation batts across the bottom of the joists, rather than up in the space between them (the vapor barrier should be on top).

title: AVANTEK INC reports earnings for 12wks to June 20
description: b-After losses of $198,000 and $620,000 for the 12 weeks and 24 weeks, respectively, both from discontinued operations.

title: N.B.A. TO PROMOTE EQUAL OPPORTUNITIES
description: The National Basketball Association and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People have agreed to work together to assure equality in employment opportunities throughout the league.

title: JERSEY HIGH COURT LIFTS BAN ON REMOVING RADIUM SOIL
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court today lifted a ban on the state's plan to move 5,000 barrels of radium-tainted soil from the yards of four Montclair homes to an Ocean County wildlife preserve.

title: RANDOM HOUSE TO BUY SCHOCKEN BOOKS
description: Random House agreed yesterday to purchase Schocken Books, the family-owned publishing house that was founded by refugees from Nazi Germany and that had Hannah Arendt as its first editor. When the agreement takes effect, Schocken -which owns worldwide rights to the works of Franz Kafka - will become an imprint of Pantheon Books, a division of Random House that was also founded in the 1940's by refugees from Nazi Germany.

title: FISHING LURE SETS RECORD AT AUCTION
description: Some fishing lures just catch fish. A Haskell minnow lure did more than that at an auction here: it caught the fancy of a buyer who spent a record $9,240 for the privilege of owning one.

title: British Price Airport Stock
description: The Government priced Heathrow and six other British airports today at more than $:1.23 billion, or about $1.98 billion at current exchange rates, in its latest sell-off of nationalized industries.

title: HERS
description: FOR months now I've been consciously searching for representations of myself in the media, especially television. I know I'd recognize this self because of certain distinctive, though not unique, features: I am a 43-year-old woman crippled by multiple sclerosis; although I can still totter a short distance with the aid of a brace and a cane, more and more of the time I ride in a wheelchair. Because of these devices and my peculiar gait, I'm easy to spot even in a crowd. So when I tell you I haven't noticed any woman like me on television, you can believe me.

title: LUCKY 7 AND 13
description: Considering that the game was played on the seventh day of the seventh month, some of the things that happened in the seventh inning of the Yankees-Twins game on Tuesday night at Yankee Stadium make a certain sort of numerological sense. Tommy John of the Yankees, who had won seven games, was hit hard by the Twins and left the game in the seventh when the Twins established a 7-0 lead. But in the bottom of the seventh, the Yankees scored seven times to tie the score at 7-7.

title: JMB Adjusts Cadillac Deal
description: The JMB Realty Corporation signed a definitive agreement for the previously announced acquisition of the Cadillac Fairview Corporation for $1.96 billion, or $60 million less than originally announced. In a jointly issued statement, the companies said that JMB would pay $34 a share (Canadian), or $25.70 (United States), in cash. In early May, JMB, the diversified Chicago-based real estate company, said it would pay $35 a share, or $26.25 (United States), in a combination of cash and notes.

title: Investor Raises Texaco Stake
description: Robert Holmes a Court, the Australian financier, told the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that the investment group he heads had increased its stake in Texaco Inc. to 7.4 percent, from 6.4 percent.

title: The Right to a Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Gas Spurs Evacuation Order
description: Twenty-one families remaining in a neighborhood north of here were ordered to evacuate Monday after officials found toxic hydrogen sulfide gas in a test well. The 179 families in Rawhide Village were earlier given until July 31 to move out of the area, which has been plagued for months by the seepage of hydrogen sulfide and methane gases.

title: House Panel Votes Subpoena Of 3 in Contra Drug Inquiry
description: A House subcommittee voted today to subpoena three Miami-based federal prosecutors in a largely secret investigation into whether Reagan Administration officials supported illegal drug and gun smuggling to benefit the Nicaraguan guerrillas.

title: Youmans's 1-Hitter Defeats Astros, 1-0
description: Floyd Youmans held the Houston Astros hitless until Kevin Bass's leadoff single in the eighth inning and finished with his second career one-hitter tonight as the Montreal Expos won, 1-0.

title: CITY OPERA: 'STUDENT PRINCE'
description: AS a drama, ''The Student Prince'' is insufferable: It pushes a few buttons about the headiness of college days, the pain of wanting what you can't have and so forth, concerns itself not a whit with such things as the exploration of character or the meaning of experience, and then sits back as Pavlov sat back, to watch the response. It would be insufferable as an operetta, too, if not for a handful of beautiful tunes that probe, indefinably, what the book ignores, and enact what the book merely indicates. One of them, the famous ''Serenade,'' is baldly interpolated as an excuse for a melody; it has nothing whatever to do with the story, but the sound of it has everything to do with how we respond to the story.

title: CELTICS ARE BEING UNFAIR TO RODGERS
description: As soon as Al Bianchi was finally knighted as general manager, Dick Evans, the Knicks' new president, predicted that a coach will be named in ''another two weeks.'' According to Evans, ''three or four candidates'' are under consideration. But he proclaimed firmly that his list no longer included Jimmy Rodgers, the Boston Celtics' assistant coach and director of player personnel. Or does it?

title: CONSUMERS CUT DEBTS BY $560 MILLION IN MAY
description: Americans paid off $560 million more in debt than they borrowed during May, the first reduction in consumer credit in nearly five years, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: PLAYER TRIES THE OPEN AGAIN
description: Except for a couple of poor 9-iron approach shots at Scioto Country Club's 15th and 16th holes in the final round last year, Gary Player might have won the United States Senior Open. As it was, the South African finished second to Dale Douglass by a single stroke.

title: STARLING TO BOX BRELAND
description: A brief search for a substitute opponent for Mark Breland ended yesterday when Marlon Starling was selected to fight the World Boxing Association welterweight champion in Columbia, S.C., next month. Breland was set to defend against the W.B.A.'s top-ranked contender, Tommy Ayers. But Ayers lost to Rollin Williams on June 30. Kathy Duva of Main Events Promotion, which will be promoting the fight, said Starling, the No. 2 contender, has agreed to fight Breland Aug. 22.

title: YANK HITTERS ROCK TWINS FOR 2ND GAME IN A ROW
description: Underneath the first-base stands in Yankee Stadium, the inhabitant of the manager's office is running out of metaphors. Lou Piniella's team scored 25 runs within 19 hours against the Minnesota Twins.

title:
GOING OUT GUIDE;
BEHIND THE CURTAIN
description: LEAD: ''Out of Eastern Europe: Private Photography'' is an exhibition by 30 photographers living in Eastern Europe, and is on display at the Grey Art Gallery and Study Center of New York University. The photographers, whose work is seldom seen here, are from East Germany, Hungary, Poland and Czechoslovakia.

title: Income Up, Ministry Says
description: Contributions to the Oral Roberts ministry lagged in April and May after the evangelist's widely publicized campaign to raise $8 million, his son said Tuesday, but income rebounded last month. ''Contributions are on the rise again, thank God,'' said Richard Roberts, the 38-year-old president of the Oral Roberts Evangelistic Association.

title: TWO SUSPECTS ARE SHOT IN BRONX COCAINE RAID
description: Two suspected drug wholesalers who promised to sell four kilograms of cocaine to plainclothes law-enforcement agents were shot last night in an aborted drug raid in the Bronx, the police said.

title: Latin America's Untouchables
description: Panama and Haiti have abruptly become the most visible battlegrounds in a hemisphere-wide struggle between civilian democrats and military leaders who defy accountability. The ''untouchable'' in Panama is Gen. Manuel Noriega, who rules through civilian figureheads. In Haiti, the junta leader is Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy. But those are not the only sites of the struggle. From Argentina to Guatemala, military officers increasingly treat elected leaders on sufferance - a reality swept from view by a Reagan Administration too eager to paint democratic gains in bold, sunny colors.

title: LOVE STORY BY THE POPE BEING MADE INTO A FILM
description: A love story written by Pope John Paul II 27 years ago is to have its film debut in Italy this year, starring Burt Lancaster, Ben Cross and Olivia Hussey, the Italian national broadcasting network RAI announced today.

title: WARNING BY KNIGHT
description: Bobby Knight, the Indiana basketball coach, delivered a harsh warning about drug abuse at the Five-Star basketball camp, which annually attracts some of the nation's top high school players to Robert Morris College, in Coraopolis, Pa.

title: HOWARD M. TEICHMANN, PLAYWRIGHT, DIES AT 71
description: Howard M. Teichmann, for many years a witty presence on Broadway as a playwright, biographer and raconteur, and the author with George S. Kaufman of the 1953 comedy hit ''The Solid Gold Cadillac,'' died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Lou Gehrig's disease) Tuesday. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 'DRAGNET' IN FIRST PLACE IN HOLIDAY TICKET SALES
description: A slow July 4 weekend at the box office cut into movie earnings, but ''Dragnet,'' the rowdy comedy starring Dan Aykroyd and Tom Hanks, still earned $7 million in tickets sold to remain in the No. 1 position after two weeks of release.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I sincerely believe that I did everything within the law. I made serious judgment errors.

title: MARRIOTT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 19
description: b-Includes non-recurring items which increased net by $5.8 million, or 4 cents a share, including a gain on the sale of a hotel in Santa Barbara, Cal., and charges for writedowns of cruise ships and hotel assets.

title: Thatcher's Second Revolution
description: In this city full of bookshops, perhaps the quaintest is the basement floor of a modern-looking store on Charing Cross Road. On the first floor there is the usual collection of novels, biographies, travel guides. But take the stairs down and suddenly - here is the world of radical kitsch.

title: Kemp's Finances
description: Gary Hart's widely publicized financial troubles have made the current Presidential contenders sensitive about their money management. Which helps explain why Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York called a news conference in New Hampshire yesterday to announce that his Republican campaign was no longer in the red.

title: 2 JETS NEARLY COLLIDE OVER THE ATLANTIC
description: Two jumbo jets with almost 600 people aboard came extremely close to colliding over the Atlantic Ocean around midday yesterday, Government and airline officials said.

title: North's View Is That of a Band of Patriots Opposed by a Hostile and Unreliable World
description: To the White House that Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North has pictured this week, the world was an arena of unrelenting ideological struggle. The White House itself, mesmerized by the struggle, was a place where major questions went unasked and where much of the rest of official Washington was dismissed as thoroughly untrustworthy.

title: POLICE AND DEMONSTRATORS BATTLE IN SEOUL
description: A vast anti-Government demonstration, perhaps the largest in South Korea's history, degenerated into open street battles with police today in the center of the capital.

title: Advertising; Behind CBS Move On Nielsen
description: CBS'S cancellation of its contract with A. C. Nielsen is generally viewed among agency media executives as a negotiating ploy by the television network.

title: DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS ASOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,400,000.

title: IMMIGRATION RULES ARE EASED FOR NICARAGUAN EXILES IN U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that it was easing immigration standards for the 200,000 Nicaraguan exiles in the United States, including those whose requests for asylum were turned down and who face deportation.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: A COLONEL'S SELF-ASSURANCE
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's description of his secret meetings in bathrooms, his purchase of leotards for his daughters, the poison pill he took along with him to Teheran provided another day of drama in the Senate chamber today.

title: Taiwan Steel Reversal
description: The International Trade Commission reversed itself today and voted, 3 to 2, that Taiwan was not dumping welded carbon steel pipe and tubing in America below the cost of production. It had tentatively ruled against Taiwan last November; today's reversal was based on new evidence.

title: MINISCRIBE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said it spent $4.3 million on new product development in the quarter, up from $1.7 million in the year-ago quarter.

title: NEW YORK'S PLAN TO SPEED UP TRIALS IS MISSING ITS GOAL
description: An ambitious plan by court administrators to reduce the backlog of cases in New York City courts by postponing judges' summer vacations has shown progress but is falling short of its goal, according to judges, prosecutors and private lawyers.

title: ROADWAY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 20
Maxtor Names Chief Executive
description: George M. Scalise, a prominent executive in the semiconductor industry trade battles, will leave that industry to become the president and chief executive of Maxtor Corporation, a maker of disk drives.

title: JACKSON SAYS RECORD SETS HIM APART FROM FIELD
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, seeking to sustain his appeal to black voters, declared yesterday that there was a clear distinction between himself and the six other Democrats seeking the party's Presidential nomination.

title: GRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss of $500,000 on disposal of discontinued operations.

title: HOUSE APPROVES DELAY IN GULF DUTY
description: In a symbolic move, the House today approved a measure to delay the Reagan Administration's plan to fly American flags on Kuwaiti oil tankers and to provide the ships with a naval escort.

title: Clarendon Offer
description: Clarendon Group Ltd. of Bermuda, owner of an insurance company that is trying to buy Argonaut Group Inc., another insurer, said that if it succeeded it would control the 10 percent of Kidde Inc. stock that Argonaut owns. But Clarendon said its interest in Argonaut has ''nothing to do with Argonaut's holding in Kidde.'' It described its interest in Argonaut as friendly and said it wanted to keep Argonaut's management.

title: WEDTEC ACCUSES EX-MEESE ADVISER OF FRAUD
description: The Wedtech Corporation accused the former financial adviser to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and an associate yesterday of submitting more than $315,000 in fraudulent bills to the company, including charges for personal trips to Las Vegas and Australia.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tour de France Van Poppel Wins Sprint: Jean-Paul Van Poppel of the Netherlands won the pack sprint in the eighth stage of the Tour de France at Epinay-Sous-Senart yesterday, but Erich Maechler of Switzerland retained the overall lead. Michel Vermotte of Belgium finished second in the 127-mile stage from Troyes with Johan Capiot, another Belgian, third.(AP) Tennis Forget Defeats Keretic: Guy Forget of France defeated Damir Keretic of West Germany, 6-3, 6-2, to advance to the quarterfinals of the Swiss Open yesterday in Gstaad. In another second-round match, Ronald Agenor of Haiti defeated Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia, 6-2, 6-3. All other matches were interrupted because of rain and will be completed today. (AP) Wilander Advances: Top-seeded Mats Wilander scored a straight-set victory yesterday in his opening match at the U.S. Pro Tennis championships in Brookline, Mass. Wilander gained his 6-2, 7-5 victory over a fellow Swede, Thomas Hogstedt, by rallying in the second set after Hogstedt jumped to a 5-2 lead. Jay Berger, seeded 10th, lost to unseeded Pablo Arraya of Peru, 6-7, 6-4, 6-3. Martin Jaite of Argentina, seeded fourth, defeated Barry Moir of South Africa, 6-4, 6-3, and Diego Perez of Spain, seeded 16th, downed Victor Pecci of Paraguay, 6-3, 6-1. Joakim Nystrom of Sweden, seeded fifth, defeated Roberto Saad of Argentina, 6-3, 6-2.(AP) Golf Baum Leads by 2 Shots: Mel Baum, an assistant pro at Radisson Greens Country Club near Syracuse, shot a five-under par 66 yesterday to take a two-shot lead into today's final round of the Michelob New York State Open. Baum, 30 years old, had an eagle, four birdies and a bogey on the 6,810-yard Grossinger's Hotel and Spa course for a total of 138. Bobby Heins of Old Oaks Country Club in White Plains, who shot 69, and Dan Spooner of Oneonta, who had a 68, were tied for second place in the $50,000 tournament, which awards $10,000 to the winner. Baum's 66 was a stroke behind the tournament record for a round, set by Mark Balen of Lackawanna in 1982 and Bruce Douglass of Winged Foot in 1985. Mike San Filippo of Ridgeway in White Plains, and four Long Islanders - Jonathan Rinkevich of Muttontown, Tony Saraceno of Woodmere in Inwood, Brad Worthington of Rockaway Hunt Club in Cedarhurst, and Jim Albus of Piping Rock - were at 141. Track Drechsler Loses in 100-Meter: Heike Drechsler suffered a surprise defeat in the 100-meters sprint but rallied to win the women's long jump yesterday at a meet in East Berlin. Performances at the meet, part of the Mobil Grand Prix circuit, were hampered by strong headwinds and cool temperatures. Drechsler was beaten by her East German teammate, Silke Gladisch, in the 100. Gladisch won in 11.15 seconds, 5-hundredths of a second ahead of Drechsler. But Drechsler, the world record-holder, overcame poor conditions to clinch the long jump. She soared 23 feet, 8 inches, 2 inches more than Helga Radtke of East Germany. Mike Conley won the men's long jump with a leap of 27-3 3/4. American runners finished 1-2-3 in the men's 200 meters, with Thomas Jefferson winning in 20.61, followed by Dennis Mitchell in 20.83 and Stanley Floyd in 20.91. Floyd also won the 100 meters in 10.45.(AP)

title: It's Far-Fetched to Call Powell a Moderate
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN DENIES 'PLOY' ON IRAN HEARING
description: President Reagan, responding indirectly to the Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair, said today that he was not seeking to divert attention from the inquiry by focusing on other issues.

title: CHEROKEE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
SONOCO PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 10.

title: INSIDE
description: Huge Rally in Seoul

title: G.E. EARNINGS ROSE 15.9% IN 2D QUARTER
description: The General Electric Company announced yesterday that earnings in the second quarter rose 15.9 percent on a 22.7 percent rise in revenues.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JULY 9, 1987
description: International A3-12

title: FEDERAL PAPER BOARD CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 20
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $8,217,000 for early redemption of 13 percent subordinated debts for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: LARGE LOSS AT MORGAN IN QUARTER
description: J. P. Morgan & Company, the parent of the nation's fourth-largest commercial bank, yesterday turned in what appeared to be its first disappointing earnings report in some time, announcing a $586.4 million second-quarter loss.

title: Laxalt Says Chances Depend On Avoiding a 'Kill' by Bush
description: Former Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada says that if he can avoid a ''quick kill'' by Vice President Bush in the early primaries next year, he will have a good chance of winning the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: 'TRUMPET KINGS,' ON 13
description: A PROFESSORIAL Wynton Marsalis guides viewers through jazz history as told by trumpet solos in ''The Trumpet Kings,'' part of the ''Jazz Tonight'' series, to be broadcast tonight at 11 P.M. on Channel 13. Unlike most jazz surveys, the program -written, directed and produced by Burrill Crohn - takes a hands-on, musician's perspective. It bypasses personalities and nostalgia to examine the ever-expanding technique of jazz trumpeters, from Louis Armstrong's half-valve glissando to Cootie Williams's plunger-mute effects and Cat Anderson's high notes with the Duke Ellington Band to the subtler pleasures of Dizzy Gillespie and Miles Davis.

title: Net Deposits Rose in May
description: Deposits at savings institutions exceeded withdrawals by $914 million in May, the first increase in net deposits since August, the Government said today.

title: AMREP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
A NEW BREED
description: When the original American Kennel Club stud book was issued in 1878, 10 breeds were listed and the first dog recorded was Adonis, an English Setter bred by George E. Delano, a student at Harvard.

title: SHOT-PUTTER SUSPENDED
description: The Norwegian Sports Federation has suspended Lars Nilsen, the Southern Methodist University shot-put star, from international competition after finding he tested positive for anabolic steroids, The Dallas Morning News reported yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JULY 9, 1987
description: International

title: Networks Will Carry Washington Hearings
description: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair will be broadcast live beginning at 9 A.M. on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on some local affiliates of PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service, including Channel 13 in New York.

title: WIFE OF DUKAKIS DISCLOSES ABUSE OF PILLS
description: When her husband found a bottle of her diet pills and confronted her in 1975, Kitty Dukakis told him she would stop using drugs. She tried but she could not. She just found better hiding places for her pills.

title: CBS NET FELL BY 14.1% IN 2D QUARTER
description: CBS Inc. reported lowered second-quarter earnings yesterday, citing the continued lackluster performance of its Broadcast Group. But analysts said the drastic cost-cutting program mandated by CBS's chief executive, Laurence A. Tisch, was beginning to pay off.

title: Software Units Plan to Merge
description: Two personal computer software companies said today that they had agreed to merge.

title: A CLASSIC EXAMPLE OF DIETING GONE AWRY
description: Kitty Dukakis was addicted to amphetamines for a quarter of a century, but experts say the doses she has described probably caused no significant permanent damage.

title: STAR ENTREPRENEUR'S FALL FROM GRACE
description: At the age of 21, Barry J. Minkow has experienced degrees of fame, fortune and notoriety that few people achieve in a lifetime. Having made millions of dollars from a carpet-cleaning company he started in his parents' garage six years ago, he became an entrepreneurial hero to many in Southern California.

title: MUSIC: MARION WILLIAMS SINGS GOSPEL
description: AS she has since her days with the Ward Singers in the 1940's and 1950's, Marion Williams brought gospel music to secular turf on Tuesday at Sounds of Brazil, and once again revealed one of the most magnificent voices in American music. Singing Ward Singers material as well as songs from her new album, ''I've Come So Far,'' Ms. Williams whooped and rasped, moaned and crooned, in the style that has influenced singers from Little Richard to Aretha Franklin.

title: Most Bylines Withheld From Washington Post
description: In what was described tonight as a protest by reporters over the lack of a union contract, most articles published in Thursday's issue of The Washington Post appeared without bylines.

title: Profits at Allegis Nearly Quadruple
description: The Allegis Corporation reported yesterday that its earnings in the second quarter had nearly quadrupled, to $73.4 million, or $1.29 a share, compared with a profit of $18.5 million, or 41 cents a share, in the second quarter last year.

title: ROBERT PILPEL
description: Robert Pilpel, who was active in Jewish and nonsectarian humanitarian organizations for many years, died of arteriosclerosis Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. A resident of Manhattan, he was 82 years old.

title: Snooker Debut Won by U.S.
description: A British vs. American match aimed at promoting the English game of snooker in the United States has ended in much the same fashion as a war between the same two nations two centuries ago. A leading American pool player, Steve Mizerak, has beaten Britain's top snooker player, Steve Davis, in a hard-fought three-day contest in St. Moritz, Switzerland.

title: BLACKOUT STARTS BUSHWICK'S RISE FROM THE ASHES
description: When the lights went out at 9:34 P.M., Kathy Casuso was still at the Marine Midland Bank in Manhattan where she worked nights as a proof clerk. She hitched a ride across the Brooklyn Bridge, hailed a gypsy cab and arrived home in Bushwick just in time to witness a scene that she did not immediately fathom but would never forget. There, not far from the Patchen furniture store, people were carrying chairs and sofas down Broadway in the dark.

title: INTEREST RISES IN CELEBRATING TIES TO SPAIN
description: Now that the nation has marked the dissolution of colonial bonds with England, some Americans are rebuilding their tie with another colonial past.

title: A NEW ROOM IN THE HOUSE: THE AMERICAN BACKYARD
description: LEAD: THE smell of steak on a grill, the thunk of a diving board, the sight of an inclined figure forcing a lawn mower around the yard -these are the traditional hallmarks of summer in the suburbs. But like all cliches, these have changed, although you might have scarcely noticed.

title: STATES MAY LOSE BILLIONS IF U.S. EXCISE TAXES RISE
description: Analysts predict that the states will lose billions of dollars in revenue if Congress increases Federal gasoline, cigarette and liquor taxes to reduce the budget deficit.

title: PADDLING IN SCHOOL: CUSTOM UNDER FIRE ANEW
description: When emergency room physicians at the south Georgia hospital saw the welts and deep purple bruises covering the thighs and buttocks of 12-year-old Brian Miller, they notified county officials about a possible case of child abuse.

title: ALL NEW YORK AUDITIONS AS A SET FOR TV'S 'EQUALIZER'
description: RICHARD BIANCHI stepped onto the roof of the abandoned warehouse. He looked at the blistered tar at his feet, the decaying wood of the water tower and the rusted walls of the building next door. ''It's beautiful,'' he said. ''Just beautiful.''

title: DARLING ADJUSTS AND WINS
description: Ron Darling did not need to be told that the hurdle he passed Tuesday night was vitally important. He had gone 76 days and nights without winning, a span of 15 pitching assignments, 6 losses, 8 games without a decision and untold misery for himself and the Mets. Then, finally, a victory. ''The team needs me,'' Darling said in a clubhouse that was nearly empty of players and celebration following a doubleheader sweep of the Atlanta Braves. ''My starts are not any more important than anyone else's on this team, but last year at this time I had nine wins and this year I have three. One of our strengths last season was the ability of the starting pitchers to win ball games, and we just haven't done it this season.''

title: The U.N. Today: July 9, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: THROWING ERROR IS COSTLY FOR METS
description: If the game turned on one play, if it could be reduced to its simplest terms, then perhaps it was this: Gary Carter, the Mets' All-Star catcher, did not offer enough help to a teammate in the seventh inning tonight.

title: Town Torn By Penalty For Teachers
description: The last few days have been rough for Lou Bilis, a police officer here, and his wife, Joy, a first-grade teacher at Columbus School.

title: BRONX WOMAN SHOOTS AT JUDGE
description: A Bronx woman, in a frenzy to recover less than $200 tied up in an estate, entered a Bronx judge's offices yesterday, told him, ''We're going to settle this here and now,'' and fired two shots at him.

title: ERRORS IN AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL REPORTED UP BY 50% IN JUNE
description: Errors by air traffic controllers increased 50 percent in June from the previous year, the chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board told a Senate subcommittee today.

title: TRADE BILL: SENATE TEST ON LAYOFFS
description: The Senate tentatively adopted a proposal this evening to require employers to give 60 days' notice of plant closings or mass layoffs. But opponents will move Thursday to strike the language. The outcome is uncertain.

title: ILLEGAL ALIENS FREED IN TEXAS FROM LOCKED RAILROAD TRAILER
description: Border Patrol agents freed 19 illegal aliens locked in a sweltering railroad trailer today, preventing a tragedy like the one that left 18 aliens dead in West Texas last week, officials said.

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
HALF OF ENGLAND WERE JOBS ARE AS RARE AS TORIES
description: Newcastle, once a proud center of the Industrial Revolution, now lies firmly in the half of Britain where the economic promise of Thatcherism has made few inroads and her Conservative Party none.

title: IN MALE-DOMINATED KOREA, AN ISLAND OF SEXUAL EQUALITY
description: ON certain mornings when the winds are right, the work songs of the haenyo, the diving women, waft upward from the rocky shores to the cliffs of Cheju Do, an island 60 miles south of the South Korean mainland.

title: CHANNEL 2 DECIDES NOT TO MOVE CBS NEWS
description: A plan considered by WCBS, Channel 2, to move the ''CBS Evening News'' out of its customary 7 P.M. time period in New York, which was vigorously protested by Dan Rather and his ''Evening News'' producer, has been abandoned, network officials said yesterday.

title: AIDS TESTS URGED FOR TRANSPLANTS
description: Transplant specialists are recommending that people in need of donor organs be tested for the AIDS virus before they are placed on waiting lists, a leading transplant surgeon said Tuesday.

title: Personal Use of Funds? 'I Never Took a Penny'
description: In response to questions that have been raised about his use of money from the covert operation in support of the Nicaraguan rebels, Colonel North offered his account of the transactions.

title: U.S. DOWNGRADES PRESENCE AT THIRD-WORLD FORUM
description: The Reagan Administration is downgrading its representation at a major conference of the world's rich and poor nations in what appears to be a further demonstration of displeasure with the United Nations system and third-world demands.

title: WHERE TO PUT IT ALL: UP-TO-DATE STORAGE
description: WEATHERPROOF most garden furniture might be; winterproof it's not. Fine finishes dull, plastic scratches and cushions fade with exposure to the elements.

title: U.N. May Open Files on Nazis
description: In a diplomatic victory for Israel, a majority of former members of the United Nations War Crimes Commission now favor opening the commission's files on Nazi war criminals to the public, United Nations officials announced today.

title: ISRAELIS BAR REDEFINING OF A JEW, POSING THREAT TO RULE BY SHAMIR
description: Parliament narrowly rejected three bills today that were aimed at redefining the official Israeli position on who is a Jew. The bills would have effectively denied the legitimacy of Reform and Conservative Judaism.

title: AFTER KARAJAN, A CLOUDY CRYSTAL BALL
description: After leading the Berlin Philharmonic for more than 32 years, Herbert von Karajan is showing signs of slowing down and speculation about a possible successor is growing.

title: Day 2: The President's Knowledge and the Ayatollah's Money
description: At the Iran-Contra hearings in Washington, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North was questioned for a second day yesterday, beginning with the issue of President Reagan's knowledge of his activities. Here are excerpts from the testimony, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: GLASS, ART POTTERY, BASKETRY
description: Crystal Blue Persuasion, Glass Workshop, 142 Mulberry Street (Grand Street); 212-966-1808.

title: THE FIRST HAVEN FOR MAN AND HIS AUTO
description: ON Dec. 12, 1925, by a side of the Pacific Coast Highway, at the bottom of an oak-spotted hill outside San Luis Obispo, Calif., the Milestone Motel -the first roadside hotel to call itself a motel - opened its rooms and garages to man and car.

title: 12 Catholic Dioceses in West Join in Self-Insurance Plan
description: Twelve Roman Catholic dioceses representing 1,000 churches in California, Nevada and Arizona have formed their own liability insurance company.

title: Yields Are Mixed
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mixed for the week ended yesterday. But interest rates are expected to continue moving slowly downward, said Robert K. Heady, editor of The Bank Rate Monitor.

title: UNREST IS SAID TO RISE AMONG THE YOUTH OF VIETNAM
description: Hanoi's official press has begun to lend credence to recent assertions by young boat people that alienation and protest among Vietnam's youth are on the rise.

title: LaROUCHE LINKS INDICTMENT TO HIS STAND ON THE CONTRAS
description: Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. said today that his indictment last week, on a charge of conspiracy to obstruct justice, was a result of a Government operation that included support for the Nicaraguan rebels and, he declared, efforts to destabilize the Governments of Mexico, South Korea and Panama.

title: Upbeat View On '87 Stocks
description: INVESTORS were cheered yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average, the most closely watched barometer of the stock market, rose 14.19 points, to 2,463.97, setting a record. Its previous closing high was 2,451.05 on June 25.

title: For True Security, 'True Zero,' Not 'Near Zero'
description: The Soviet Union has been talking publicly about concluding an agreement on intermediate-range nuclear forces in time for a possible summit meeting this fall. If the Soviets are serious about this schedule, they can do one thing in particular to help make it happen: move with us to global elimination of Soviet SS-20 and SS-4 missiles and American Pershing 2 and ground-launched cruise missiles. This ''true zero'' solution would significantly expedite negotiations and make verification a far less difficult concern.

title: Corrections
description: The Q&A column in Science Times on June 30 misstated the potential harmful effects of ultraviolet radiation in sunlight. Ultraviolet radiation at shorter wavelengths is more harmful than that at longer wavelengths.

title: TEACHING OLD PARENTS NEW WAYS
description: For grandparents who do not understand natural childbirth, a hospital here is offering a class to explain the method and teach them how to listen more and lecture less.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Don Aase, the Baltimore Orioles' reliever who saved a club-record 34 games last season, will have surgery on his right shoulder and will miss the remainder of the season. The 32-year-old right-hander has appeared in only seven games this season.

title: Foreign Currency Deals By 2 U.S. Companies
description: Financings yesterday by General Mills Inc. and Pepsico Inc. were among the first foreign currency denominated deals ever to be priced above par in the United States debt market. The deals were priced at a higher than current coupon level to accommodate major institutional customers that trade these securities on a current yield basis as opposed to a yield to maturity basis.

title: 2 Ejected in Brushback
