description: Cory Snyder hit a home run in the second inning and a two-run double off Dan Quisenberry with one out in the ninth to give the Cleveland Indians a 9-8 victory over the Kansas City Royals tonight after a brushback pitch led to player ejections for the second consecutive game.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May.

title: British Airways Shifts Agencies
description: British Airways is assigning the United States portion of its advertising account to Backer & Spielvogel. The budget should be between $16 million and $18 million. The agency is a subsidiary of

title: 1,000 NEW OFFICERS GRADUATE TO THE STREETS
description: At last, graduation day came.

title: Genetics Institute's New Heart Drug
description: Genetics Institute Inc. said it had developed a new form of tissue plasminogen activator, a drug intended to dissolve blood clots in heart attack victims. The Cambridge, Mass., company said the T.P.A. variant can remain in the bloodstream longer than the original product and can be given in a single, more effective dosage.

title: ALLEGIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: ALBANY REACHES ACCORD ON NEW PRISON MEASURE
description: The Republican-controlled State Senate voted 41 to 14 today to approve a bill intended to relieve overcrowding in state prisons, ending a deadlock that had threatened to delay the close of this year's legislative session.

title: AN AMERICAN IN LONDON PLANS A RESTORED GLOBE THEATER
description: Odessa, Tex., has one. So, too, do San Diego and Cedar City, Utah. London has, however, managed to survive for over 300 years without one.

title: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Olivetti's Computers
description: Olivetti, the Italian electronics, computer and office equipment company, said today that it would establish a new subsidiary, Prodest International S.p.A., for the home computer sector. The company plans to introduce its PC1 model in Italy this month.

title: Sun Introduces Work Stations
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. introduced a line of computer work stations yesterday that offers performance comparable to a minicomputer for one-tenth the price.

title: Putting Reins on Wall St.
description: The insider trading scandals, involving such prominent Wall Street figures as Ivan F. Boesky, Martin A. Siegel and Boyd L. Jefferies and investment firms such as Kidder Peabody and Goldman Sachs, have receded from front-page news.

title: FLEET FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge related to an increase in loan loss reserves of $40 million for Fleet National Bank. The additional reserves were allocated to Latin American loans. Combined with previously established reserves, Fleet's Latin American loan loss reserves total $57.5 million, or 50 percent of its $115 million in loans to the region.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about restructuring plans for Kidde Inc. incorrectly described the takeover bid by Clarendon Group Ltd. for Argonaut Group Inc. Clarendon and Argonaut called the proposal friendly.

title: No Headline
description: New York City will start offering confidential AIDS testing this summer to any city jail inmate who requests it, Mayor Koch announced last night.

title: SEAMAN FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in April.

title: Horror Film Defames Traditional African Belief
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK AIDS COST FOR 1991 IS PUT AT $2 BILLION
description: New York City is underestimating by half the projected cost of the spreading AIDS epidemic and is fiscally unprepared for its ''terrible consequences,'' State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday.

title: Armstrong Plans To Shut Tire Plant
description: The Armstrong Tire Company plant here will be closed in six months and 1,050 jobs will be eliminated because of unsuccessful attempts to cut costs, the company said. However, a union official said he still hoped to reach an agreement to avoid the shutdown.

title: U.S. Missiles Slide Off Road
description: A United States Army truck carrying four Patriot air-defense missiles slid into a ditch beside a small road today, but there were no injuries or damages, a spokesman said. The missiles are nonnuclear.

title: North vs. Others: A Sample of the Conflicts
description: ISSUE: ARMS SHIPMENT - One of the most important questions facing the committee is the nature of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3rd's weekend fact-finding mission last November. Mr. Meese was present when Colonel North proposed that William J. Casey, the late Director of Central Intelligence, make the false statement to Congress that no one in the Government knew about the Iran arms shipment of November 1985. Colonel North said Mr. Meese knew the truth within weeks. NORTH'S TESTIMONY - ''I do remember discussions which included the Attorney General subsequent to this event. I believe there was one that Mr. McFarlane referred me to in December... One of the issues that had already come up by then was a draft finding prepared in concert with Mr. Sporkin who was at the time the general counsel of the Central Intelligence Agency. I was led to believe or at least came to believe in 1985 that Mr. Sporkin had gotten the acquiescence or spport - either he or Director Casey - of the Attorney General in that November finding. The November finding specifically referred to prior actions.'' OTHERS' ACCOUNTS: Meese statement, released by his spokesman today - ''As to the arms shipments that took place prior to 1986, he did not learn about these until November 1986. The Attorney General was in no way involved with the November 1985 ''finding'' drafted by C.I.A. general consel Stanley Sporkin. . . . In fact, he did not know of any such November 1985 finding until a year later, in November 1986.'' ISSUE: CHRONOLOGIES - Another key issue is who ordered the falsification of chronologies to be used by the White House in presenting the Iran arms sales story. Colonel North attributes inaccurate statements about the November shipment to Robert C. McFarlane, the former National Security Adviser. NORTH'S TESTIMONY - ''As I indicated earlier, I had gotten that language from Mr. McFarlane.'' Q. So you got the language from McFarlane. He persuaded you it was appropriate to put it in. You put it in. A. Who is ''he?'' Q. McFarlane. A. Yes. OTHERS' ACCOUNTS - Mr. McFarlane testified that he assisted Colonel North in preparing the chronologies and that he acquiesed in some language prepared by others that he knew was ''technically wrong.'' He said, however, that it was Colonel North who directed the efforts of four to five people. He quoted Colonel North as saying: ''It looks to me like what we're putting together here will assure that the President isn't hurt by this.'' ISSUE: CARGO PLANE - The Reagan Admnistration repeatedly told the public and Congress that it had no connection with the cargo plane. Elliott Abrams, the Assistant Secretary for Inter-American Affairs, said this was because he had made a honest error and had not been told of Colonel North's role in the operation. NORTH'S TESTIMONY - Did he [ Abrams ] ask you whether you or the N.S.C. had any conn

title: OSLO WIDENS INQUIRY ON SHIPMENTS TO SOVIET
description: The Norwegian authorities investigating a state-owned company for its illegal sale of sensitive technology to the Soviet Union are now examining more than 150 other shipments to the Russians by the same company, the prosecutor in the case said today.

title: Chrysler Spending
description: The Chrysler Corporation plans to increase its capital spending by at least $1 billion through 1990 to cover new investment after the No. 3 auto maker takes over the American Motors Corporation, the company's vice chairman said. The Detroit News reported that Robert Miller, who heads the company's financial subsidiary, said the $1 billion was not as much as American Motors would have needed in that time if it had stayed independent.

title: NOW HEAD CRITICIZES DEMOCRATS AS BEING ALOOF ON WOMEN'S ISSUES
description: Eleanor C. Smeal, the departing president of the National Organization for Women, today assailed what she described as ''conventional wisdom'' that Democrats should be cautious, keep ''women's issues'' at arms length, and move toward the right for the 1988 Presidential election.

title: CAVENDISH EVENT DEPARTS FROM AMERICAN TRADITION
description: Players in Europe are accustomed to the idea of representing a club, a city, a county, a province or a country. The American tradition is individualist: players represent themselves and their friends at every level short of the world championship.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: RESURFACING AT SARATOGA
description: Saratoga race track, home to a history of upsets on sloppy tracks,will be resurfaced with a faster-drying, sandy cushion for the 24-day meeting that begins Aug. 5. The resurfacing, which was announced yesterday by officials of the New York Racing Association at a news conference, is being undertaken because of the track's poor drainage. It seems to rain perpetually during the annual August meeting, forcing many major events to be run in the slop. Now, the top inch of the 3 1/2-inch cushion will be removed and replaced with sand.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about June automobile sales included incorrect figures for light trucks. The total number of trucks sold in the month was 454,821, an increase of 10.3 percent from June 1986.

title: BROKERAGE TO MOVE 600 JOBS FROM NEW YORK TO JERSEY CITY
description: The brokerage firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette plans to move about 600 jobs from Manhattan to Jersey City in 1989, an official of the firm said today.

title: Penney Buys Stake In Women's Chain
description: The J.C. Penney Company has made an investment in the Stinu Corporation of Los Angeles, which operates the Units chain of women's specialty stores. Penney would become the largest shareholder in the company. The investment, for an undisclosed sum, is Penney's second in the specialty store field. The first was a 20 percent interest several years ago in Alcott & Andrews, which operates apparel stores for working women.

title: GIAMATTI ON BEANBALLS
description: The upsurge in home runs is at least partly responsible for an increase in beanballs this season, according to A. Bartlett Giamatti, the National League president. Giamatti said yesterday that the number of players being hit by pitches ''is very worrisome because baseball degenerates when this happens.'' He was interviewed by the Chicago radio station WGN-AM a day after a beanball exchange between the Cubs and the San Diego Padres resulted in a brawl and seven ejections.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Beneficial Corp., Wilmington, Del., a consumer financial services holding company, has elected David J. Farris to the new position of chief operating officer.

title: SCHOOLGIRLS BOOT WEMBLEY BARRIER
description: A group of soccer-playing schoolgirls from Cincinnati will fly to England on Saturday, headed for Wembley Stadium to break down some sports barriers that have stood for 64 years.

title: GOLDMAN BAND IN PACT WITH ITS MUSICIANS
description: Two weeks after the scheduled beginning of its 70th anniversary season, the Goldman Memorial Band reached a settlement with its players and immediately started rehearsing for a concert last night at the Damrosch Park band shell.

title: Kaiser Will Sell Chemicals Unit
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation has put up for sale parts or all of its industrial and specialty chemicals business. Kaiser was recently acquired by the British investor Alan Clore and has sold off several businesses in an effort to focus on its aluminum operations.

title: Bond Offering By Philadelphia
description: On the negotiated side of the tax-exempt market, Philadelphia is tentatively offering $185 million of general obligation bonds through two separate financings: one to raise new cash, the other to refund previously issued debt when interest rates were higher.

title: NORTH SAYS CASEY AIDED HIM ON SECRET CONTRA PROGRAM; CHALLENGES KEY OFFICIALS
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testified today that William J. Casey, as Director of Central Intelligence, helped him run the secret program to aid the Nicaraguan rebels and that many other senior members of the Government had been fully aware of what he was doing, ''although they may deny it.''

title: Ringside Seats
description: After the Cleveland Indians rallied late in each game against the Kansas City Royals to sweep a three-game series, one that had been marked by knockdown pitches and brawls, George Brett of the losing Royals, sounding as if he had enjoyed the experience, decided that the previously downtrodden Cleveland fans finally got their money's worth. ''If I came to the last three games, I'd be a Cleveland Indians fan for life,'' he said. ''As far as dollars spent for entertainment, these three nights would be the best $20 ever spent in Cleveland. It was the greatest three games we've played this year. It was like Rocky and Apollo Creed. Guys kept coming back and fighting each other.''

title: ROWAN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New Magazine
description: David Smick and Richard Medley, former Capitol Hill staff members who have made a dent in town running conferences on currency and debt and publishing a newsletter, say they are starting a magazine in the capital called The International Economy. They decline to disclose the provenance of the customarily substantial start-up funds that such ventures consume, but their staffing commitment appears serious.

title: STAGE: 'RICHARD II' IN THE PARK
description: NOTHING becomes Shakespeare's King Richard II more than his dethronement. The same could be said of Peter MacNicol's performance in the role, now on view in Joseph Papp's production at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

title: PROSECUTOR TELLS COURT DEAVER LIED TO SAFEGUARD SALE OF HIS BUSINESS
description: Michael K. Deaver lied to Congress about his lobbying business to protect his ability to make ''millions of dollars of income for relatively little work,'' the special prosecutor in the case said today.

title: A JURY TRIES A BACHELOR, BUT CONVICTS A HUSBAND
description: Allison Hamblat said ''I do'' yesterday. The jury said, ''Not guilty,'' ''Not guilty,'' and ''Guilty.'' All in the same courtroom, before the same judge.

title: WEIS MARKETS reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid May 22.

title: Rhoden Angry at Snub
description: Rick Rhoden, one of three American League pitchers with 11 or more victories, failed to make the league's All-Star team yesterday and blamed his absence on the scuffed ball controversy that surrounded him recently. A league official denied that the controversy had anything to do with it.

title: Tiffany in Munich
description: Tiffany & Company, the 150-year-old jewelry retailer, said that it would open its second European shop later this year in Munich, West Germany. Tiffany, with eight stores in the United States, opened a shop in London in September 1986 and plans more stores in major European cities.

title: Advertising; The Image Group Gets All of Cosmopolitan
description: The Image Group at Wells, Rich, Greene will do all of the advertising for Hearst's Cosmopolitan magazine, with billings in the neighborhood of $1 million.

title: ART: GAUGUIN IN BRITTANY IN QUEST OF PRIMITIVISM
description: GAUGUIN, the first major artist to pursue primitivism, went to the greatest extremes in the pursuing. As a result, his popularity has depended as much on the story of his pilgrimage to the ''real thing'' in the South Seas as on his work. Historians have undercut the myth by showing, for instance, that the master spent much of his time in Tahiti politicking. The Museum of Modern Art's ''Prints of the Pont-Aven School: Gauguin and His Circle in Brittany'' continues the process by dealing not with the loner in Polynesia but with the artist among other artists, making preliminary investigations of the primitive in his own country, by way of lithographs instead of paintings.

title: TURKEY TRIES TO STAY ALOOF ON WAR
description: Despite hostile gestures from both sides in the Persian Gulf war, Turkey is clinging to a delicate neutrality between Iran and Iraq, seeking to remain aloof from a conflict close to its borders and fearing that it might spread.

title: FILM: CAINE AND GEILGUD IN 'THE WHISTLE BLOWER'
description: A NUMBER of killings occur during ''The Whistle Blower,'' Simon Langton's film about a British spy ring. But there is only one gun to be seen here, glimpsed briefly in one of the film's last scenes, and for the most part it stays inside a drawer. ''The Whistle Blower'' eschews the usual equipment to be found in spy stories, and the usual attitudes too. While its intrigue plot is indeed suspenseful and tight, this film's real focus is on British society and its stratification. Mr. Langton, Julian Bond, the film's screenwriter (who also wrote ''The Shooting Party'') and an outstandingly fine cast explore these distinctions deftly.

title: 'WEREWOLF,' ON CHANNEL 5
description: WOULD you believe a fishing-boat captain werewolf? Would you believe a college-boy werewolf who wants to track him down? Apparently, he'll be doing it right through the fall season. ''Werewolf,'' on Channel 5 at 8 o'clock tomorrow night, is a two-hour pilot film for an upcoming half-hour series. Think of it as ''The Fugitive'' meeting ''The Incredible Hulk.''

title: In Re the Nofziger Predicament
description: In the spring of 1983, when Lyn Nofziger, a White House aide turned lobbyist, was asked for advice about making such a career move, he could hardly have been more upbeat.

title: YORK INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for 16wks to June 20
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $9,700,000, or 26 cents share.

title: An Opinion on Seoul
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Commitee, told a news conference at the World University Games in Zagreb, Yugoslavia, yesterday that the 1988 Summer Olympic Games would either be held in Seoul, South Korea, ''or there will be no Games at all.'' It was virtually the same thing Samaranch was quoted as having said last week in a London newspaper, but this time he added the observation that the political unrest in the South Korean capital had decreased greatly and that he was very confident the Games would be staged and be ''very successful.''

title:
Market Place;
Quick Trading Done for Meese
description: LEAD: WHEN Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d's lawyers released an analysis of their client's financial dealings recently, it included a rundown of ''day trades'' conducted by W. Franklyn Chinn, a money manager who set up a blind investment partnership with Mr. Meese.

title: Part of New Delhi Put On Curfew After Riots
description: The Indian authorities ordered a curfew in part of the nation's capital after anti-Sikh violence spread today to neighborhoods in the city's west, where mobs sought to set fire to Sikh temples, homes and businesses.

title: SAFETY-KLEEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 20
ARCHITECT OF SOVIET CHANGE
description: Abel G. Aganbegyan, a key architect of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's audacious new economic program, likes to travel. ''It's my passion,'' he said, reporting that he covers 150,000 miles a year crisscrossing the Soviet Union on economic missions.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: LEAD: IN the Poconos in Pennsylvania the summer benedictions that drifted up to the cloudy, cranky skies were of a sort familiar to most Americans.

title: 19 ARE INJURED AS 2 FERRIES COLLIDE IN HEAVY FOG ON L.I. SOUND
description: Nineteen people were hurt this morning when two ferryboats collided in heavy fog as they crossed Long Island Sound.

title: Saving Whales From 'Science'
description: In the last year, South Korea and Iceland have killed hundreds of whales for profit but in the name of science. Both countries have brazenly exploited a loophole in the international whaling treaty that allowed virtually unregulated killing of whales for ''scientific research.'' That loophole has now been closed by the International Whaling Commission.

title: GRUNTAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
SLOTNICK HURT IN ATTACK LEAVING HIS OFFICE
description: Barry I. Slotnick, the well-known defense lawyer whose clients have included Bernhard H. Goetz, was attacked yesterday outside his office in lower Manhattan by an unidentified man who fled on a motor scooter, the police said.

title: SEOUL PROTESTERS STAGE HUGE RALLY
description: Opponents of the Government showed their strength today with perhaps the largest demonstration in South Korea's history, followed by violent assaults on the Seoul city hall and clashes with police on barricaded streets.

title: Baum, in a Playoff, Wins State Open
description: Mel Baum, who qualified after another player defaulted, captured the Michelob New York State Open golf tournament today with a birdie on the second hole of a playoff against Brad Worthington.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: F.B.I. REFUSED TO AID NORTH IN APRIL '86
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation rejected a protection request by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North in April 1986 because it is barred by statute from providing such services for anyone except the President, the Attorney General and its own director.

title: Bianchi Gets Down to Work
description: Al Bianchi held his first meeting as the Knicks' general manager yesterday with Dick Evans, the president of Madison Square Garden Corporation and the Knicks, and Jack Diller, Evans's chief aide. The topic? Finding a head coach.

title: An F.B.I. Agent Is Shot In a Jersey Hotel Room
description: An agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation was shot yesterday while interviewing a man in a South Plainfield, N.J., hotel room, authorities said.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Henry Threadgill Sextet, Central Park Band Shell, midpark at 72d Street (860-1335). Three horns, cello, bass and two drummers make this the only sextet with seven members, but that's beside the point. Henry Threadgill's tunes offer wry ironies, blues feeling and structural clarity, warmth and scuttling swing. There isn't a more individual-sounding small band in jazz today. The group is performing tomorrow at 3 P.M.; admission is free.

title: Advertising; A Family Production For Revlon Shampoo
description: Joan Lunden, the co-host of ABC-TV's ''Good Morning America'' who is about to take her third maternity leave, has contracted to make a commercial after the baby comes for a new Revlon product called Care For Kids Mousse Baby Shampoo.

title: WASHINGTON FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (DC)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JULY 10, 1987
description: International A2-9

title: Jones and Thomson in Tie for Open Lead
description: Gordon Jones underwent arthroscopic surgery on his left knee on June 16. Thirteen days later, the 57-year-old professional golfer qualified for the 10th annual United States Senior Open using a golf cart to get around the Zanesville, Ohio, Country Club course.

title: Stocks Weaken; Dow Gives Up 12.76
description: Stocks weakened yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average retreated from the record high it set in Wednesday's session.

title: Hard Work, Big Rewards
description: Phil McConkey of the Giants just couldn't get away from 9-year-old Jose Diaz's one-on-one coverage yesterday during the opening clinic of the Mobil Big Apple Games, a citywide summer recreation program now in its sixth year.

title: Gephardt v. Kemp
description: Two contenders for different Presidential nominations have agreed to a debate on the issue of trade. Representatives Jack F. Kemp, Republican of upstate New York, and Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, will square off July 20 at the Drake University Law School in Des Moines.

title: Denny's Says No to Marriott
description: Denny's Inc. has spurned an $855 million buyout bid from the Marriott Corporation, but industry analysts said they were not convinced that the talks were over.

title: No Comeback For a Change
description: Just when the Yankees thought they had the White Sox right where they wanted them last night, an unusual development occurred. The Yankees didn't erupt with a late-inning come-from-behind rally and win the game.

title: BIG ADVANCE FOR 'INTO THE WOODS'
description: One of the happiest bits of news to hit Broadway - not to mention the producers involved - for a while is an advance ticket sale said to be more than $2 million for the new Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical ''Into the Woods.'' The advance came after the powers that be of the theater-party world heard some of the songs a few weeks ago. The musical, which had its first stage presentation last season at the Old Globe Theater in San Diego, is a just-under-$4 million sophisticated romp based on the Grimms' folk tales and what happens ''happily ever after.'' Rocco and Heidi Landesman, Rick Steiner and M. Anthony Fisher are producing. There's a two-week workshop going on now and the opening is scheduled for Oct. 22 at the Martin Beck Theater. 'Fences' Pays Off

title: Boland Amendments: What They Provided
description: During the period being examined in the Iran-contra hearings, United States Government aid to the Nicraguan rebels was governed by a series of legislative restrictions together known as the Boland amendments.

title: New Apple Unit
description: Apple Computer Inc. said that its new software subsidiary would be named the Claris Corporation, reflecting ''clarity and distinctiveness.'' Apple said in April that it planned to spin off its software sales effort into an independent company in which it would retain a minority stake.

title: MGM-UA COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income and includes for the 9 months a tax credit of $1,185,000. The company said the results from operations are not directly comparable and there are no share earnings for the year-ago periods because the company was a unit of MGM-UA Entertainment Co. through March 25, 1986.

title: Gorbachev or Not, Reform Will Stay
description: The Kremlin's newly approved package of economic reforms is, by Soviet standards, so radical that many strong voices in the West have predicted its failure even before Mikhail S. Gorbachev can begin implementing them.

title: Pinned to, and on, Colonel North
description: Oliver North is unwilling to call himself a hero. The six rows of decorations pinned to his uniform, he said yesterday, represent the heroism of marines who served under him. At the same time, he's also unwilling to have something much heavier pinned on him: the blame.

title: Ueberroth's Hiring Goal
description: Commissioner Peter Ueberroth pledged yesterday that baseball would surpass the other major sports in hiring blacks and other minority group members for high-level off-the-field jobs.

title: BAKER ASKS N.A.A.C.P. FOR FAIRNESS ON BORK
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the White House chief of staff, appealed to members of the N.A.A.C.P. yesterday not to judge Robert H. Bork, President Reagan's nominee for the Supreme Court, on a ''fragmented record, reflected in news clippings.''

title: RICHARD LANGENDORF
description: Dr. Richard Langendorf, a cardiologist credited with helping to perfect interpretations of the electrocardiogram, died Wednesday. He was 79 years old.

title: SENATORS SEEK BUDGET CHANGE
description: Democratic and Republican leaders in the Senate have agreed to try next week to give the budget-balancing law a mechanism to make spending cuts automatic. The Supreme Court struck down the original automatic mechanism.

title: RESIDENTS BALK AT PROPOSED CONNECTICUT EXPRESSWAY
description: Every weekday morning, thousands of back country commuters from here and a half-dozen nearby towns work their way down the winding rural roads that lead to an infamous 18-mile stretch of macadam known as Route 7. There they find gridlock in paradise. ''This is crazy,'' said Judy Moore, watching the vehicles stagger past her coffee shop hard by the Danbury-Ridgefield line on Route 7, a primary north-south road in the metropolitan area. ''It's worse than the Long Island Expressway.'' Loss of Homes Feared

title: At Washington Post, Byline Strike Goes On
description: For the second day, most articles published in Friday's issue of The Washington Post appeared without bylines because of a protest by reporters over the slow pace of negotiations toward a union contract.

title: DATA TRANSLATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
DI INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $15,163,591 on the exchange of securities. c-Net loss

title: MEESE TELLS PANEL HE DIDN'T VIOLATE U.S. LAW ON ETHICS
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, testifying for the first time about his involvement with the Wedtech Corporation, told a Senate subcommittee today that he never violated Federal ethics laws. He said a partnership he set up with an investment manager then employed by Wedtech ''involved no conflict of interest.''

title: A Few Surprises in All-Star Reserves
description: Sid Fernandez made it, but not his Met teammate Terry Leach. Dave Righetti made it, but not his Yankee teammate Rick Rhoden. And Rick Sutcliffe and Bret Saberhagen made it as expected when the pitchers and reserves were named yesterday for the All-Star Game Tuesday night in Oakland, Calif.

title: SAMUEL HOFFMAN
description: Samuel Hoffman, a senior partner at the law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, died Tuesday of cancer of the kidney at his home in San Jose, Calif. He was 80 years old. Mr. Hoffman, who specialized in corporate law, ''had tireless energy in negotiating creative acquisitions and business combinations,'' said Franklin Feldman, a senior partner at Stroock.

title: TOWER PANELISTS WATCHING FOR ANSWERS ON NORTH'S ROLE
description: Edmund S. Muskie, a member of the Presidential commission that investigated the Iran-contra affair, acknowledged today that Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's testimony had contradicted the panel's finding that he had operated virtually independently, but he added that he was not sure whether to believe him.

title: THE COLONEL PRESENTS HIS CASE: HIS BELIEFS, HIS WORK AND HIS GRIEVANCES
description: The committee allowed Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to present an opening statement, after a two-day delay, and he set forth his views on his White House service and the Congressional inquiries.

title: BURLINGTON NORTHERN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The year-ago second quarter and 6-month losses both include writedowns of $813 million in the oil and gas and railroad businesses; and the 6-months also includes a charge of $336 million for a railroad depredication accounting change. The company said the 1987 second quarter does not reflect income from the railroad business industrial development properties that were transferred to Glacier Park, the company's real estate management company, effective Jan. 1, 1987.

title: Borg-Warner Fees Total $48 Million
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation said it would pay $31.5 million in investment banking fees to Merrill Lynch Capital Partners regarding its $4.4 billion buyout led by Merrill. The Chicago-based automotive and industrial parts company also said it would pay an additional $16.5 million to its financial advisers. Merrill Lynch agreed in April to pay $48.50 a share for Borg, which is meet July 30 to approve the acquisition.

title: Kraft Offers Foreign Issue
description: A $175 million (New Zealand) financing by Kraft Inc. yesterday became the third foreign currency-denominated debt issue priced over par to be offered in the United States since Wednesday.

title: A WISH FOR A MUSICAL GLASNOST
description: ''There is now the possibility of true creative freedom,'' said Gennadi Rozhdestvensky about the effects of glasnost on his life and on the lives of fellow Soviet musicians. The husky, gregarious conductor spoke in New York earlier this week on his way from Moscow to the Tanglewood Festival in Lenox, Mass., where he will lead the Boston Symphony in concerts tomorrow, next Friday and July 18. He travels to the Ravinia Festival to conduct the Chicago Symphony on July 23 and 25.

title: McMahon Hits Stride
description: Jim McMahon, the Chicago Bears quarterback who had reconstructive surgery on his right shoulder surgery Dec. 12, has received the green light from Bob Gajda, who is supervising his rehabilitation.

title: Advertising; Fewer New Products
description: There was an unusual dip in the number of product introductions in June compared with June 1986, according to the DFS Dorland New Product News. The number usually increases from year to year. The figure was 684 this year, compared with 692 last year.

title: Note of Braggadocio Resounds at Hearing
description: Is there really something different about New York lawyers? Arthur L. Liman, the chief Senate counsel, apparently thinks so.

title: Concern About Takeover Bill
description: Three of New York's most prominent securities lawyers told a panel of the House of Representatives today that proposed tender offer legislation would have small effect on hostile takeover activity.

title: A SANCTUARY AND INDIAN SURPRISES
description: TIME stands still at the Cafe Pierre, that sanctuary of privilege in the Pierre Hotel where the ladies appear to have emerged from Town and Country magazine, the men wear year-round tans and European suits and the city's rough edges are upholstered with plush gray felt. For years the cafe was known as a glorified tea room, a polite and familiar place to take Aunt Sofie for dinner when she visited from Boston. But as other hotels began to upgrade their restaurants in recent years, the Pierre followed suit.

title: LONG ISLAND TOURNAMENT WILL BE PLAYED ELSEWHERE
description: By ALAN TRUSCOTT

title: BANPONCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said earnings for the latest second quarter and 6 months reflect the addition of $10 million to Banco de Ponce's reserve for LDC loans.

title: Jerry Livingston Dies; Wrote 'Mairzy Doats'
description: Jerry Livingston, the composer of ''Mairzy Doats,'' ''The 12th of Never,'' ''Talk of the Town'' and many other songs, died of a heart condition July 1 at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 78 years old.

title: NEW SUMMER STAPLE
description: Move over, margarita. The Bellini has arrived. In trend-setting restaurants around the city this summer - from Harry Cipriani and its recently opened spinoff, Bellini, to Ciao Bella, Il Palazzo, Island and Alo Alo - the insouciant, aggressively bronzed set is sipping this Italian aperitif, which combines peach juice and sparkling wine.

title: Taiwan Shift On Exporters
description: The Cabinet decided today to lift Taiwan's 38-year-old foreign exchange controls, removing a barrier that has kept the nation's massive foreign reserves from flowing to other countries.

title: TOURS OF ULSTER HOMES ALL DAY TOMORROW
description: Tours of stone houses dating back to the 1700's are to be held tomorrow between 10 A.M. and 5 P.M. in the town of Hurley in Ulster County.

title: NETWORKS TO GET MORE FOR ADS
description: Despite people meters and increased competition from cable and syndicated television, the three major television networks are expected to get healthy price increases for advertising spots now being sold for this fall's prime-time season.

title: Trailways Took a Direct Hit in Air-Fare Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Travel System for Europe

title: STAGE: 'DRAGONS' TRILOGY,' A CANADIAN PANORAMA
description: THE excitement of ''The Dragons' Trilogy,'' by Le Theatre Repere of Quebec, is so intense that only on reflection do its structural flaws bother one. The play, being presented at the International Theater Festival at the State University of New York in Stony Brook, L.I., spins through 70 years of Canadian life in a vivid whirlwind of spectacle, movement and music. The director, Robert Lepage, and the eight actors in the performance - six wrote the play -shatter the limits of theatrical expression at times, leaving one puzzled, but their effort is exhilarating.

title: HILL SAMUEL INVITES TAKEOVER BY SWISS
description: The Hill Samuel Group, the British merchant bank, said today that it was negotiating with the Union Bank of Switzerland about being acquired by Union Bank. Hill Samuel also said that its chief executive, Christopher Castleman, had resigned in protest over the talks.

title: Cardinals Win 8th in a Row; Lead by 9 1/2
description: Jose Oquendo's run-scoring single capped a four-run rally in the 10th inning tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals extended their winning streak to eight games with a 7-6 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

title: IN 1988, IT'S TRENDY TO TELL ALL
description: It was not surprising that Kitty Dukakis, the wife of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, a Democratic Presidential contender, decided to discuss her onetime addiction to diet pills in public. And that, politicians, political consultants and academics said today, may be the most remarkable fact about the way the 1988 Presidential campaign is developing.

title: FLOW OF ALIENS INTO U.S. RISES DESPITE NEW LAW
description: A rash of incidents involving illegal aliens, the worst the deaths of 18 aliens in a torrid boxcar in Sierra Blanca, Tex., has focused attention on an unexpected resurgence of illegal immigration along the nation's border with Mexico, immigration officials say.

title: 2 JERSEY JUDGES VOID JAIL TERMS IN SCHOOL STRIKE
description: A state appeals court ruled today that 110 Lyndhurst teachers and school workers did not have to go to jail for taking part in an illegal six-day strike last spring.

title: DORAN HOMER IN 9th SHUTS DOWN METS
description: Each night, the Mets seems to find a new way to lose, a new way to fall deeper into their unending misery. They have lost 40 games this season, and each one has been more improbable - and painful - than the last.

title: IMPORT DISCRETION
description: Despite the threat of a veto and the loss of business backing, the Senate today approved an amendment to the trade bill that would require 60 days' advance notice to employees and local communities of plant closings and mass layoffs.

title: Still Time to Act on Bias-Related Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: SHORT BOAT TRIPS FOR LOCAL SALTS
description: THE appetizers are served, the wine is poured and the band begins to play ''Anchors Aweigh.'' Suddenly the restaurant moves and, from across the water, the skyline of Manhattan starts to unfold.

title: Ready to Run
description: Because many American track and field fans knew Eamonn Coghlan had been experiencing tendinitis in his knees throughout the month of June, they feared that the Irish running star's immediate racing future, including the world championships in Rome from Aug. 29 to Sept. 6, might be in jeopardy. While Coghlan was on a trip to his native land, reports from Ireland said he had canceled a running appearance at the Cork City Games and undergone knee surgery in Dublin.

title: In Poll, Most Believe North
description: An ABC News poll conducted Tuesday, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's first day of public testimony, found that 58 percent of the 510 adults people questioned said they thought he was telling the truth. The poll, which was made public Wednesday, found that 35 percent said the colonel was lying and the rest had no opinion. The margin of error was plus or minus 5 points.

title: KOHLBERG IS RAISING $5 BILLION
description: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the leader in arranging leveraged buyouts, is creating what would be by far the largest fund to finance buyouts.

title: Wiser Heads in New Jersey
description: Common sense has finally prevailed in a dispute between striking teachers in New Jersey and a stubborn judge in need of a lesson in temper. A higher court has overturned jail sentences imposed by State Superior Court Judge Paul Huot on more than 100 teachers and other school employees who engaged in an illegal strike in March. Instead, the appellate panel wisely ordered the teachers to spend additional time in their classrooms.

title: ROLAND MAYCOCK
description: Roland Maycock, a retired senior vice president and general counsel of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died Sunday at his home in North Tarrytown, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 74 years old. Born in New York City, Mr. Maycock attended DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx, Harvard College and Harvard Law School.

title: Drop in Jews Leaving Soviet
description: A State Department spokesman expressed concern today that the recent level of Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union had declined to 796 in June, from 871 in May. Charles E. Redman, the Department spokesman, said Jewish emmigration had increased in each previous month this year.

title: WILLIAM O. SWEENEY
description: William O. Sweeney, a communications specialist known for his work in population control and family planning, died of cancer of the pancreas Saturday at the Devon Manor convalescent home in Devon, Pa. He was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BONDS DRIFT IN LIGHT TRADING
description: Bond prices drifted further yesterday in thin trading as traders shifted their gaze from the dollar and toward some growing hints of inflation.

title: A BROOKLYN TALENT SCOUT
description: THERE are only a few people in the art world who regularly spot new talent and then actually do something about it. Charlotta Kotik is one of them.

title: 'HAD MANY WORST DAYS'
description: As the afternoon session began, Arthur L. Liman asked Col. Oliver L. North about the day when he offered to resign from the National Security Council.

title: Israel Guards Its Rights in Iran Arms Case
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: THE GOLDMAN BAND
description: THE Goldman Memorial Band, back in place on short notice after a labor dispute was settled Wednesday afternoon, played its 70th-anniversary gala concert the same evening to an understandably sparse but warmly responsive audience at the Damrosch Park Band Shell.

title: A NEW-MUSIC FESTIVAL ROCKS WITH BANDS OF OUTSIDERS
description: DURING the next six days, more than 200 rock bands will be playing at clubs, concert halls, discotheques, even a record store, in and around New York City.

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $29,364,000, or 30 cents a share,from the first quarter sale of the company's 18.9-percent interest in South China Morning Post Ltd. c-Includes an after-tax gain of $31,358,000, or 32 cents a share from the first quarter sale of 2 million Continental Cablevision Inc. common shares.

title: PONCE FEDERAL BANK, FSB reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JUDGE REFUSES TO DELAY ORDER TO REVIEW ARRESTS
description: A Federal judge refused yesterday to give New York City 30 days to set up a system for the city's courts to review the probable cause of all arrests within 24 hours of the arrests.

title: ATLANTANS STRIVE TO PRESERVE A HOME FAR, FAR FROM TARA
description: Even then, some 60 years ago, Margaret Mitchell called the place ''the dump.'' These days the description is especially appropriate: The apartment building where she lived when she wrote ''Gone With the Wind'' is abandoned, its roof torn and sagging, its windows covered with plywood.

title: Kurdish Rebels Kill 20 In 2 Villages in Turkey
description: Kurdish insurgents killed 20 people, 11 of them children, in two villages in southeast Turkey Wednesday night, hours after Prime Minister Turgut Ozal urged the autonomy-seeking rebels to give up their struggle.

title: Chrysler Financial Offers 8 3/8% Notes
description: The Chrysler Financial Corporation is offering $200 million of 8 3/8 percent notes that are due in 1990 at a price of 99.93, to yield 8.40 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: U S SPRINT PRESIDENT QUITS POST
description: The president of the U S Sprint Communications Company resigned yesterday as the unprofitable long-distance telephone carrier announced that it would take a $350 million pre-tax charge against earnings in the second quarter.

title: STUDENT LOAN MARKETING ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COMMUNTIY BANK SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DINING OUT GUIDE: WITH MUSIC
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CHEZ JOSEPHINE, 414 West 42d Street (594-1925) - *(Oct. 31, 1986) Finding a spot to enjoy good music and good food in the same setting can be a problem in New York City, but the options are widening. This restaurant's delightfully racy decor leitmotif finds the sultry singer Josephine Baker in various stages of scanty dress - on the walls, on the menu cover and on the bathroom doors. Tuesday through Sunday evenings Lloyd Henderson and Lillette Jenkins, singers and pianists, provide the entertainment. The menu is French-American, and starter options include the house pate with onion puree; leeks in tomato vinaigrette, and deep-fried oysters with puree of fennel with lime. For a main dish, you might choose fried chicken and sweet-potato fries; cassoulet of lobster, shrimp, scallops and seafood sausage with black beans in a light herby broth, or Cajun-style blackened redfish. Entrees $10.50 to $19.50. Fridays through Sundays, 5 P.M. to midnight. GREENE STREET, 101 Greene Street (925-2415) - **(April 11, 1986) This dramatic multi-tier SoHo loft with a sky-high ceiling and a 60-foot-high mural depicting vintage New York scenes features a kitchen that harmonizes with the first-rate jazz and pop musicians who entertain nightly. The menu is well balanced and offers fresh, precisely tuned and attractively presented French-American dishes. Appetizer choices are smoked stuffed quail with marinated shiitake mushrooms; scallop ravioli with leeks and fennel in a tomato-butter sauce, and cold lobster sausage with artichokes, asparagus, tomato and herbed mayonnaise. Entree options include red snapper sauteed in white wine and Italian parsley sauce with baby carrots and spinach; loin of lamb marinated and roasted with eggplant and tomato Provencal, and baby pheasant in marjoram sauce with roast potatoes, onions and mushrooms. Entrees $18 to $25. Fridays and Saturdays, 6 P.M. to 12:30 A.M.; Sundays, noon to 8:30 P.M. LOLA, 30 West 22d Street (675-6700) -

title: Advertising; B.&S. Buys Rath Firm
description: Backer & Spielvogel, the agency for Wendy's International since mid-June, has acquired Rath Advertising, a supplier of merchandising, sales promotion and local advertising for the fast-food chain.

title: NEW YORK HELD NOT LIABLE FOR PAROLEE
description: New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that the state may not be held liable for paroling, and admitting to a state college, a prisoner who later murdered two students. The prisoner had previously been diagnosed as homicidal.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY CLASSICS, LIGHTENED Classical music - with a twist or two - comes to the Prospect Park Band Shell for the second weekend of the Celebrate Brooklyn performing-arts series. Paquito D'Rivera, a jazz saxophonist, will join the Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra, under the direction of David Amram, for a program called ''From Mozart to Monk'' tonight at 8. Tomorrow night at 8, Marisa Galvany, a soprano, and Harry Theyard, a tenor, will offer arias and duets from assorted operas, with Anton Coppola conducting. A lesser-known classical tradition will be presented Sunday evening at 8 by Jim Pepper and other Indian singers and dancers from Oklahoma. A $1 donation is requested. The band shell is near Prospect Park West and Ninth Street. In case of rain, the two Philharmonic concerts will be held in the Prospect Park Picnic House, near Prospect Park West and Third Street; the rain date for the Jim Pepper performance is Monday. Information: (718) 768-0699. UNION SQUARE AFLOWER Union Square Park, in the not-too-distant past a hangout for drug dealers and derelicts, has been spruced up considerably, and to celebrate its renewal, it will be blooming with flowers and entertainment for the next week. The first Union Square Park Full Bloom Festival begins today at 11 A.M. with a potpourri of jazz and juggling, comedy and tap dancing. The festival continues with the square's weekly Greenmarket tomorrow, and a concert of jazz, Caribbean and Asian music on Sunday at 2 P.M. And what flower festival would be complete without flowers? Thousands of marigolds, zinnias, roses and other colorful flora have been planted along the park's paths and around the statues of Washington, Lafayette and Lincoln. The fair continues through Thursday. The park is at 14th Street and Broadway; the number for information is 397-3177. TRAVELING VICARIOUSLY Armchair travelers have the opportunity to journey to Argentina, Brazil and other points south -all without leaving New York - thanks to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The museum begins a four-week, Friday-evening series of lighthearted travel-adventure films called ''Getting Away From It All,'' tonight at 8. The series begins with Irving Cummings's 1940 comedy ''Down Argentine Way,'' with Betty Grable and Carmen Miranda, and will be followed by ''That Night in Rio,'' ''A Weekend in Havana'' and ''Moon Over Miami.'' Films will be shown in the museum's Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, near the Fifth Avenue and 83d Street entrance. Tickets are $4, or $14 for the series. Information: 570-3949. SATURDAY BOTANICAL SHAKESPEARE Shakespeare seems to be popping up all over town this summer, and the Bard's newest venue will be the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, where ''The Taming of the Shrew'' is to be presented Saturday at 2:30 P.M. Additional performances are scheduled for subsequent Saturdays, July 18 and 25, and another Shakespeare comedy, ''All's Well That Ends Well,'' is to be performed on Sundays, this weekend, July 19 and July 26, at 2:30 P.M. Both plays are being done by the King's Men of the Kings County Shakespeare Company, a four-year-old Brooklyn-based theater company under the direction of Deborah Wright Houston. Performances are free and will be held outdoors at the Alfred T. White Memorial. Mats will be provided for the grass surrounding the stage. In case of rain, the actors move indoors to the garden's auditorium. The 50-acre garden is at 1000 Washington Avenue, and admission is free. Weekend hours are 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Information: (718) 622-4433. STATELY HOMES TOUR For the last 40 years, it has been a midsummer tradition in Litchfield, Conn., for historic houses to open their doors to visitors. This year's Litchfield Open House Tour is to be held Saturday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. in the village and nearby Milton. Five houses and several churches in the area, as well as the Litchfield Historical Society Museum and the Tapping Reeve House and Law School - said to be the country's first law school -will be included on the tour. Among the homes to be shown are the 1774 farmhouse called ''Goose Landing''; the 205-year-old Guild Tavern, which was once a gathering-place for thirsty travelers along the Hartford-Albany turnpike, and a modern house designed by Marcel Breuer. Tickets for the self-guided tour are $10, and registration will be held Saturday morning on the Litchfield Green beginning at 10. Information: (203) 567-9423. LATIN AMERICAN MUSIC Like many folk-music traditions, jibaro - the music of Puerto Rico's mountains - is a hybrid form with several cultural roots. Two concerts of this lyrical, Spanish-derived folk music will be presented Saturday afternoon in the Kaufman Theater of the American Museum of Natural History. Sexteto Criollo Puertorriqueno performs at 2 and 4 P.M., and Antonio Ramirez, an artisan born in Puerto Rico, will demonstrate the art of making cuatros -the guitarlike instrument used in most jibaro performances - at 1 and 3 P.M. in the museum's Blum Lecture Room. Another type of Puerto Rican music can be heard Sunday at 2 P.M. in Tompkins Square Park, at Seventh Street between Avenues A and B. The concert of African-influenced songs by Los Pleneros de la 21 will be preceded by a demonstration of how bomba drums are made. Additional concerts in the East Village park are to be presented on three succeeding Sundays. The rain date for all concerts is Aug. 9. The performances are part of the citywide series Musica Tradicional 1987, devoted to the musical heritage of Puerto Rico, Cuba and the Dominican Republic and sponsored by City Lore: The New York Center for Urban Folk Culture. The concerts are free, although the suggested admission to the museum -on Central Park West between 77th and 81st Streets - is $3.50 for adults and $1.50 for children. Information: 529-1955 or 769-5315. LOOKING BACKWARD Time travel has long been a popular fantasy, and this Saturday and Sunday, at least a semblance of that fantasy can be realized at Richmondtown Restoration on Staten Island. The first of three weekends of 19th-century American feasts are planned at the parklike, 96-acre complex of restored 17th- to 19th-century buildings. These historical repasts will feature menus, costumes and entertainment that would have been typical for a large, rural, middle-class gathering about 150 years ago. The festivities begin with 4 o'clock self-guided tours of the grounds, followed by wine, cider and biscuits served at 5 P.M. Diners will be seated at outdoor tables (weather permitting) about 6 for an evening of food and revelry. The menu includes spit-roasted rounds of roast beef, freshly churned butter and homemade preserves, and brick-oven-baked breads and pies. Musicians will perform ballads and bawdy songs, and games of the period will be played after dinner. Feasts are to be held also on July 25 and 26 and Aug. 8 and 9 at the restoration, which is at 441 Clarke Avenue, near Arthur Kill and Richmond Roads. The cost is $30 a person and reservations are required. Information: (718) 351-1617. SUNDAY NEW YORK AS A FILM SET New York City has often been called the greatest back lot in the world, and indeed, thousands of film makers have used the city's streets and buildings, parks and shops as settings for their movies. The New-York Historical Society will screen eight films this summer with settings in or near the city and, in two cases, upstate. One upstate setting will come in the first film, John Ford's ''Drums Along the Mohawk,'' which will be shown this Sunday at 2 P.M. The 1939 tale about Revolutionary War-era New York State will be followed on Sunday afternoons by such classic films as ''Heaven Can Wait'' (1943), ''Sweet Smell of Success'' (1957) and ''Breakfast at Tiffany's'' (1961). The films are free with museum admission, which is $2 for adults, $1.50 for the elderly and $1 for children. Continuing exhibitions at the society include the Neustadt collection of Tiffany lamps, paintings by Hudson River School artists and the Wagstaff silver collection. This weekend is the last chance to see the show on Jackie Robinson. The museum, at 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street, is open from 1 to 5 P.M. on Sundays, and from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays. Information: 873-3400. FEAST OF THE GIGLIO Imagine an 85-foot, 8,000-pound pyramid complete with a 15-piece band, carried by 100 men down the streets of Brooklyn. This otherworldly scene, which has been enacted for generations, is known as the dancing of the Giglio, and is one of the highlights of an annual Italian street festival in the borough's Williamsburg section, sponsored by Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church. The Giglio will be accompanied by a procession at 1 P.M. on Sunday near Havemeyer and North Eighth Streets, carrying an oversized rowboat honoring St. Paulinus, who returned to Italy in just such a one after his African captivity ended. The Giglio festivities are named for the flower - the lily - that were strewn to welcome him back. The 17-day feast, which also celebrates the 100th anniversary of the Brooklyn church, continues through July 19, and includes rides, games and countless stands selling Italian foods and gifts. On Sunday, the fair will run all afternoon and evening; weekday hours are about 7 P.M. to midnight. Information: (718) 384-0223.

title: U.S.F.L. Official To Weintraub Post
description: Harry L. Usher, cheif operating officer of the 1984 Olympics and commissioner of the United States Football League, is taking a position with a new division of the Weintraub Entertainment Group.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,050,000 for the quarter and $1,960,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $750,000 and $1,450,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: BOMBAY STREET CHILDREN SCAMPER TO FIND FUTURE
description: The beggar families rise up in the night from their sidewalk pallet as formidable nuclear units who badger and cling miserably to the legs of a passing potential benefactor.

title: 'I AM NOT LYING TO PROTECT ANYBODY, COUNSEL'
description: When the Iran-contra hearings resumed yesterday morning, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North was questioned by the House committee's deputy minority counsel, George Van Cleve, on various matters, including his dealings with an Iranian intermediary and false statements he has made. description: A Republican filibuster blocked Senate consideration today of a resolution seeking a delay in the Administration's plan to fly American flags on Kuwaiti tankers.

title: RUSSIANS FAULTED IN AFRICAN CRASH
description: A Soviet flight crew that ignored an alarm and descended in darkness caused the crash that killed President Samora M. Machel of Mozambique and 34 others, an international board of inquiry said today.

title: Ansa Is Acquired
description: Borland International Inc., a personal computer software company, acquired the Ansa Corporation, which makes the Paradox personal computer data-base program, for stock valued at $29 million. Ansa, a private company in Belmont, Calif., had revenues of $8 million last year from Paradox. Borland, founded in 1983, sells low-priced computer-language programs.

title: Two Legal Minds at the Hearings
description: Brendan V. Sullivan Jr. Attorney for Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North

title: DIRECTORS GUILD IN PACT WITH 'RAMBO' PRODUCER
description: The Directors Guild of America signed a contract today with Carolco Productions, an independent company that has made the ''Rambo'' movies, according to a spokesman for the directors union.

title: AFTER A DEATH, WORKERS TESTED FOR A SICKNESS
description: Hundreds of workers at a Federal office building in lower Manhattan are being screened for Legionnaires' disease after one of their co-workers died from the disease and another was hospitalized.

title: The Long Seventh Day
description: Anniversaries and ceremonials don't intrigue me as much as new things happening. So I didn't stop to think what the 20th anniversary of the six-day Arab-Israeli war meant until I read the article ''My Neighbor, My Enemy,'' by Thomas Friedman, in last Sunday's New York Times Magazine.

title: Don't Count the Gipper Out
description: LEAD: When the New York Giants followed up their Super Bowl victory with a White House visit, President Reagan said the triumph thrilled their fans. As for himself, he quipped, ''I don't have many fans anymore.'' White House aides, myself included, winced. It hurt to hear that from the man who was once the most popular President since Franklin D.

title: CHAMBER MUSIC
description: The Waterloo Festival presents an evening of chamber music performed by members of its faculty tonight at 8:30 in Richardson Hall on the campus of Princeton University. The program includes works by Bach, Rossini, Brahms, Beethoven and Bartok. Tickets are $10. Information: (800) 682-8080.

title: Indictment for Tax Evasion
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted a reputed organized crime figure for evading taxes on income from business he did with MCA Records Inc.

title: Our Towns; Stamping Out Sprinkler Abuse In Old Westbury
description: Suburbanites love to use water and there are no greater water users than the people of Long Island. While the average American uses 110 gallons of water a day, the average Nassau County resident runs 135 gallons. And this is just average. There are people on the Island, if they don't use 200 gallons, it's a bad day for them. In Roslyn, to pull your weight, you've got to use up 253 gallons daily; Sands Point, 272 gallons.

title: 2 MORE JETS IN NEAR-MISS OVER ATLANTIC
description: Two jets carrying about 180 passengers nearly collided over the Atlantic yesterday, less than 24 hours after a near-collision over the ocean threatened the lives of nearly 600 people on two other jetliners.

title: DIGITAL MICROWAVE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $144,570.

title: ADMINISTRATION ASSAILS BIDEN OVER DELAY ON BORK
description: The White House today accused Joseph R. Biden, the Senate Judiciary Committee chairman, of politicizing confirmation hearings on the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court. The comments came after a committee spokesman said the Delaware Democrat would lead the opposition to the conservative appeals court judge.

title:
TV REVIEW;
IRAN-CONTRA DRAMA: A CAST CHANGE
description: LEAD: IT may have been a stand-off; certainly it was a contest. Indeed, sports metaphors crept in. ''The committee is changing pitchers, so to speak,'' Dan Rather said just before the afternoon session. ''Arthur Liman is expected to throw hardballs.''

title: New York City Plans Competitive Note Sale
description: The City of New York plans a competitive sale of up to $1 billion of short-term notes between July 16 and Aug. 7, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: Terms from the Testimony
description: During the Iran-Contra hearings, legislators, lawyers and witnesses have used a number of code names (such as ''Country 1'') and phrases that have confused members, the audience and television viewers. Among them are: ''Take the Hit'': As the Iran-contra affair began to unravel, North said White House aides discussed who would take responsibility or ''the hit'' for conducting it, while protecting their superiors. ''Sit Room'': The White House Situation Room used by North for such activities as telephoning superiors for advice last November when the details of the Iran-contra affair began to emerge and the Justice Department began an investigation. ''Jenkins Hill Operation'': A term used by one committee member to jokingly chide the staff's confusing preparation of a large-sized graphic used to represent the Boland Amendment. The Jenkins Hill is bar and restaurant on Capitol Hill frequented by Congressional staff members. PROF note: Inter-office computer messages written and transmitted on the White House's I.B.M. Professional Office System computer system. ''Residuals'': Oliver North's preferred term for the profits from the Iran arms sales that were diverted to the contras. Country 1: Israel. Country 2: Saudi Arabia. Country 3: Taiwan. Country 4: China. Country 5: Believed to be South Korea.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 386 money market mutual funds increased $1.46 billion, to $237.61 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 96 institutional funds were up $516.8 million, to $65.06 billion. Assets of the 200 general-purpose funds were down $459.7 million, to $67.65 billion. The 90 broker-dealer funds rose $1.40 billion, to $104.89 billion.

title: POSTER ADS: CHEAP, FAST PUBLICITY
description: Long after midnight, when portions of New York City become the working domain of 24-hour deli clerks, the police, sanitation crews and prostitutes, James Rogers Jr. of Paramus, N.J., loads his blue El Camino with hundreds of advertising posters and heads to New York City.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE INVERTED JENNY: Mystery, Money, Mania. By George Amick. Illustrated. 250 pages. Scott Publishing Company/Amos Press Inc., 911 Vandemark Road, Sidney, Ohio 45365. $19.95.

title: Let's Get All the Lead Out of the Gasoline
description: To the Editor:

title: AUSTRALIAN TO DIRECT WADSWORTH ATHENEUM
description: The Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford has named Patrick McCaughey, an Australian, as its new director. Mr. McCaughey, now director of the National Gallery of Victoria in Melbourne, replaces Tracy Atkinson, who has retired.

title: INVASION OF TRASH FROM SEA OVERWHELMING COASTAL STATES
description: This morning's tide swept a bountiful harvest from the sea over Bolivar's beach: faded plastic bags, tangled ropes, rubber gloves, egg cartons, thousands of six-packs and soda cans, a plastic container of ''Milde Shampoo'' from Euro Drogist in the Netherlands and a rusty refrigerator.

title: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Pulling Life From a Soviet Attic
description: Going up to attics one sometimes finds family roots, and secrets. In attics a child discovers that great-grandmother was a quilter, father a boy clarinetist. Oh, what the Russians stand to rediscover as glasnost makes it possible for the first time in decades to explore the attics of the state museums. In those attics are not the dull works of Stalin's Socialist Realism, but a wonderfully wild and rowdy bunch of avant-gardists.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: MOZART AT CARAMOOR
description: The St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble is to present an all-Mozart program tonight, as part of the Caramoor Music Festival in Katonah, N.Y. The concert, in the Spanish Courtyard at Caramoor, starts at 9 P.M. Tickets are $20.

title: WEST GERMAN CHIEF AND WALDHEIM PLAN TRADITIONAL MEETING
description: After his visit to Pope John Paul II in the Vatican last month, President Kurt Waldheim of Austria has obtained an invitation to meet with President Richard von Weizsacker of West Germany.

title: Amoco Weighing A Dome Pullout
description: The Amoco Canada Petroleum Company said that it might ask to be released from its $3.87 billion agreement to buy Dome Petroleum Ltd. if a Canadian court orders Dome to consider other suitors. A spokesman for Amoco Canada, the Calgary, Alberta, subsidiary of the Amoco Corporation, said the company had made no decision yet, pending the outcome of the case.

title: ABC TO START DRUG TESTS
description: Capital Cities/ABC issued a memorandum to its employees yesterday informing them that beginning next month, candidates for full-time employment will be screened for drug use before being hired.

title: FILM: 'THE SQUEEZE,' A COMEDY-ACTION DRAMA
description: THERE'S nothing about Michael Keaton that says movie star. But Mr. Keaton, with his ordinary looks, permanent scowl and diffident manner, has in the past been able to carry entire films (most notably ''Mr. Mom'') with his quick wit and casual, smart-alecky delivery. He would certainly do the same for ''The Squeeze,'' which opens today at the Gemini and other theaters, if there were anything to carry. As it is, Mr. Keaton languishes half-heartedly in a colorful, expensive-looking comedy-action-romance-drama that's just about entirely empty.

title: JUDGE WHO WAS THURMOND AIDE CALLED A KEY CANDIDATE FOR F.B.I.
description: A Federal judge who once served as an aide to Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, has emerged as a leading candidate to become Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, according to people knowledgeable about the search.

title: EA ENGINEERING SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
90-1 Return for Investor
description: Reginald F. Lewis's first leveraged buyout was for a relatively small company, but it was a huge success. He cashed out with a 90-to-1 return. Mr. Lewis and his investors put up $1 million in equity and received $90 million on that investment in three years.

title: BOXCAR VICTIMS BURIED, AS MIGRATION GOES ON
description: As six young men were buried here, a week after they and a dozen other illegal immigrants from Mexico suffocated in the 120-degree heat of a sealed boxcar, seven men and women boarded the daily train to Ciudad Juarez, on the border with El Paso.

title: THE TRAMA OF BEING A KUBRICK MARINE
description: BEFORE being cast in Stanley Kubrick's new movie, ''Full Metal Jacket,'' Vincent D'Onofrio was a trim, good-looking athlete, a rugged 6 feet 3 inches tall and - with his full head of curly dark hair - the kind of man who makes women's heads turn.

title: HYCOR BIOMEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax benefits of $48,000 and $57,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: Remains of Pvt. Eddie Slovik Lost in Transit From France
description: The remains of Pvt. Eddie Slovik, the only American soldier executed for desertion in World War II, were reported missing by airline officials tonight as they were being returned from France for reburial in his native Detroit.

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $16,311,000 and $17,295,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and results for both periods include an estimated charge of $15.9 million from a decision to sell the flexible packaging division of Ludlow Corp. c-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $170,000 and $1,401,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary gain of $2,284,000 from replacement of a pension plan for the year.

title: SUMMERFARE: HOW TO GO AND WHEN
description: The Pepsico Summerfare begins tonight at the Performing Arts Center of the State University of New York at Purchase. Performances will be in Theaters A to E and the Choral and Recital Halls. To reach the center from Manhattan, take the West Side Highway to the Henry Hudson Parkway. Then take the Cross County Parkway to the Hutchinson River Parkway and continue to Exit 28 (Purchase); turn left and take Lincoln Avenue to Anderson Road; the campus is on Anderson Road.

title: ART: 7 OF WARHOL'S FINAL PAINTINGS
description: AMONG Andy Warhol's last paintings are the seven, all from 1986, on view at the Leo Castelli Gallery. They constitute neither a great show nor a merely average one, but they reveal Warhol proceeding with a reasonable facsimile of his early appropriational energy, plagiarizing himself in the process.

title: 1,591 Pages Fat
description: The Federal Government has not grown much under President Reagan, but the Congressional Directory for 1987-88, just published by the Government Printing Office, is the fattest ever. It contains 1,591 pages, 395 more than the last issue, printed in 1985.

title: DRUG LINKED TO INFANT DEATHS RESULTS IN FEDERAL INDICTMENT
description: A Federal grand jury in St. Louis today accused a drug manufacturer, a distributor and three people of misrepresenting the safety and the effectiveness of a drug that was used in treating premature infants.

title: Economic Scene; Latin Market Ebbs for U.S.
description: THE United States is slowly increasing its exports, whittling away at the nation's huge trade deficit. If that deficit is to be dissolved, however, buyers must still be found for tens of billions of dollars of new sales abroad. In the past, whenever American exports expanded, Latin America always stepped forward to purchase a big share of the additional goods. This time the Latin buyers are gone.

title: NORTH SAYS HIS SHREDDING CONTINUED DESPITE PRESENCE OF JUSTICE DEPARTMENT AIDES: SHADOW ON CASEY
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testified today that he continued to shred documents in his office one morning last November while Justice Department officials conducting a preliminary investigation for President Reagan worked 10 feet away reviewing other files.

title: Citicorp Plan On Antilles
description: Citicorp, a large issuer of Eurobonds, said yesterday that it would not call debt issued before 1984 by its Netherlands Antilles subsidiary. The announcement followed a statement by the General Motors Acceptance Corporation that it would not call its bonds. The United States Treasury

title: CITY TENNIS: IT TAKES EITHER MONEY OR TIME
description: New York is not a perfect place. Henry Miller knew this even before the alarm went off at 5:15 the other morning, and he groped for his tennis racquet. After only five days in the city, he had already waited in a movie line for one hour, searched for a parking spot for half an hour and, late one night, been forced to listen to a drill being driven into the pavement, or as Mr. Miller put it, ''right through the pillow and through my eardrums.''

title: UNITED AIR IN VENTURE IN EUROPE
description: United Airlines and three European carriers plan to announce today that they will build a $120 million reservation system intended to provide fuller information to travel agents in Europe and ultimately to improve flight service both in Europe and in the United States.

title: 2 Doctors Among 24 Seized In a Medicaid Fraud Inquiry
description: A nine-month undercover investigation culminated yesterday with the arrests of two physicians and 22 pharmacists and drugstore owners in New York City on Medicaid fraud charges including widespread drug violations and illegal medical practices.

title: New York City Keeps Trying to Evict Its Drug-Dealer Tenants
description: To the Editor:

title: Gaining on Paris
description: To the Editor:

title: Diner's Journal
description: IT is billed as Brooklyn's first wine bar, this cheerful and casual spot in the Park Slope section called De'Vine. Opened a year and a half ago by a former actress, Susan Garrett, it serves about 45 well-chosen wines by the glass, mostly in the $3-to-$5 range. California and France are best represented, along with a smattering of German, Italian and Australian labels. A full menu of terrines, salads, pastas and seafood is served in this cafe setting with an open hearth, tile tables and Art Deco paintings on the walls. De'Vine Restaurant and Wine Bar, 396 Seventh Avenue, at 12th Street, Brooklyn, is open 5 P.M. to midnight Wednesday to Saturday, with brunch from noon to 3:30 P.M. Sunday, and Sunday dinner 5 P.M. to midnight. Telephone: (718) 499-9861. * * *

title: TWO PORTIONS OF NEW YORK RENT STABILIZATION LAW ARE VOIDED
description: A judge in Queens has voided two sections of New York State's two-month-old rent stabilization code on the technical ground that they were not included in a draft proposal that was presented at public hearings last year.

title: Correa Suffers Fracture
description: ''That means I've been pitching with a broken arm,'' Edwin Correa, a Texas Rangers right-hander, said yesterday after X-rays revealed that he had been throwing with a stress fracture in his shoulder for about eight weeks. He was placed on the 21-day disabled list.

title: Value Shrinking Daily
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tour de France Van der Poel Wins a Slow Stage: Adri Van der Poel of the Netherlands yesterday won the Tour de France's 161-mile ninth stage, from Orleans to Renaze. Erich Maechler of Switzerland retained the overall lead. Many riders fell along the narrow roads of the Mayenne region of western France, and high temperatures made the stage the slowest yet. (AP) Yacht Racing Protest Brings Bengal a Victory: Bengal evened the best-of-three-race final series for the 12-Meter world championship yesterday after New Zealand was disqualified for making an incorrect start. The Australian entry raised a protest flag during maneuvering before the start of the race off Porto Cervo, Sardinia, in which New Zealand finished first by 2 minutes 7 seconds. (AP) Golf McCumber and Sieckmann Tied: Mark McCumber shot two birdies and an eagle on his first three holes en route to a six-under-par 65 and a share of the first-round lead with Tom Sieckmann yesterday at the $612,000 Anheuser-Busch Golf Classic in Williamsburg, Va. (AP) Okamoto Leads in Quebec: Ayako Okamoto of Japan birdied the first five holes on the way to a seven-under-par 65 and a one-shot lead yesterday in the first round of the $400,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association du Maurier Classic in Laval, Quebec.(AP) Tennis Wilander Advances: Top-seeded Mats Wilander overcame troubles with his serve last night to beat 17-year-old Franco Davin of Argentina 6-2, 6-2, and advance to the quarterfinals of the $239,000 United States Pro Championships at Longwood Cricket Club in Brookline, Mass. The 22-year-old Wilander, ranked second in the world, needed 90 minutes to beat Davin in a match that saw 10 service breaks in 16 games. Earlier, Andres Gomez of Ecuador, the defending champion, defeated Diego Perez of Uruguay, the 16th seed, 6-4, 6-4. (AP)

title: STOCKWELL IN DEMAND
description: ''Now I think I'm succeeding in starting a third career here,'' said Dean Stockwell.

title: Advertising; Merrill Promotion Hails Constitution
description: AS a way of supporting its many offices nationwide and giving them additional visibility, Merrill Lynch & Company will underwrite ''ratification parties'' in every state as part of the celebration of the Constitution's bicentennial.

title: AIDES SAY REAGAN IS VIEWING NORTH
description: President Reagan is ''fully aware'' of the testimony Lieut Col. Oliver L. North has given on Capitol Hill this week, but he will make no comment about it until the Congressional hearings are completed, probably next month, the President's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said today.

title: World Bank Assailed
description: A Reagan Administration official today criticized the sweeping reorganization of the World Bank as not tough enough. The official, who asked not to be identified, said that although a top-to-bottom reorganization of the 6,000-employee lending agency has caused widespread dissension and disruption in the bank, the 390 layoffs expected by the end of the year were ''peanuts.'' He also said the layoff-compensation arrangements are ''far too generous.''

title: Bank Aide Convicted In Girl's Hit-Run Death
description: A 26-year-old bank mortgage advisor was convicted yesterday of negligent homicide in the hit-and-run death of an Upper East Side high school student last fall.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When I heard the words criminal investigation, my mindset changed considerably.'' - Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. [ A1:4. ]

title: KEY RATES
BOYS MARKETS reports earnings for 12wks to June 14
description: The company said comparable results for the year-ago 6-months are not available because the first quarter of 1986 was reported by a predecessor company.

title: RUBBERMAID INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes $2,200,000 after-tax gain from the sale of the company's Canadian automotive products business.

title: Where No News Is Good News
