description: For a time, Lawrence E. Walsh, the special prosecutor investigating the Iran-contra affair, had to call home to Oklahoma City and ask his wife's permission to watch television.

title: FLORIDA NATIONAL BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-earlier second quarter and 6-month results are restated to reflect a change in pension accounting.

title: HOME SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said year-ago share earnings are not available.

title: Devils Sign Sauve
description: Letting their fingers do the walking through the free-agent lists, the Devils picked up some experienced goaltending yesterday and that enabled them to let one of their younger goalies get some experience in international play.

title: NORTH AND THE CHAIN OF COMMAND: WHEN TO BE A SCAPEGOAT AND WHEN NOT
description: In the third day of the Iran-contra hearings yesterday, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North was questioned about the day - last Nov. 25 - when he learned from a news conference that he had been dismissed. Here are excerpts from the testimony, as recorded by The New York Times. SUBJECT OF INQUIRY

title: Bid for Pay 'N Pak Is Placed on Hold
description: A hostile bid for Pay 'N Pak Stores Inc. was put on hold yesterday, and the West Coast home-improvement retailer appeared to have gained the upper hand in support of a management-led leveraged buyout.

title: WHERE A PANAMANIAN HERO'S DEATH INTERRUPTED THE DREAM
description: In this bustling farm town on Panama's fertile Azuero Peninsula, anti-Government sentiment is nothing new. It erupted dramatically in September 1985 after the killing of one of the town's leading citizens, Dr. Hugo Spadafora, an outspoken critic of the military.

title: West Germans Charge A Brother of Hamadei
description: The brother of Mohammed Ali Hamadei, the Lebanese hijack suspect, has been charged with kidnapping two West Germans held in Lebanon and with possessing explosives, a Government official said today.

title: HORNE AND UPSHAW
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra, conducted by Gerard Schwarz, with Marilyn Horne and Dawn Upshaw as soloists, performs works by Mozart, Vivaldi and Gluck tonight and tomorrow at 8 o'clock in Avery Fisher Hall. Tickets are $8 to $16. Information: 874-2424.

title: AMSOUTH BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JULY 10, 1987
description: Companies

title: WHERE TO FIND THE BOATS
description: Here is a sampling of the boat trips available in the metropolitan region. New York City CIRCLE LINE: Daily departures from Pier 83, near West 43d Street and 12th Avenue, between 9:30 A.M. and 4:15 P.M., and Sundays, Wednesdays and Thursdays at 7 P.M. The fare is $12 for adults and $6 for children. Information: 563-3200. STATUE OF LIBERTY: Daily departures from the Battery, every half-hour from 8:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. Round-trip fare, $3.25 for adults and $1.50 for children. Information: 269-5755. DAYLINER: Departures at 9:30 A.M. from Pier 81, 41st Street and 12th Avenue, to Bear Mountain, West Point and Poughkeepsie. Fare: $18 for adults, $14 for the elderly and $9 for children. Information: 279-5151. SEAPORT LINE: The Andrew Fletcher and the DeWitt Clinton. Daily 90-minute trips from Pier 16 at the South Street Seaport, at 1, 2, 3 and 4 P.M., as well as noontime luncheon cruises. (11 A.M. departures on Fridays, Mondays and Tuesdays.) Fare: $8 for adults and $5 for children; lunch cruises are $16.50 for adults and $13.50 for children. Information: 964-9082. Irregularly scheduled evening cruises with music are generally $12 to $15. Reservations and information: 406-3434. PIONEER: Departures at noon, 3 and 6 P.M., Thursdays through Sundays, and at 3 and 6 on Mondays and Tuesdays, from Pier 16 at the South Street Seaport. Fares: $16 for two-hour excursions and $21 for three-hour trips; $18 and $13 for the elderly, and $16 and $11 for children. Information: 669-9416. PETREL: Four or five daily sailings for weekday lunches and afternoon cocktails, as well as on weekends and in the evening from Battery Park. Fares: from $7.50 for 45-minute lunchtime trips to $17 for most afternoon and evening sails. Information: 825-1976. WORLD YACHT CRUISES: Luncheon sails, Mondays through Saturdays from noon to 2 P.M.; cost, $22. Sunday brunch trips at 12:30 P.M.; cost, $29.95. Daily, three-hour dinner cruises at 7 P.M.; cost $50 on Fridays and Saturdays, $45 on weekdays. Two-hour disco sails at 12:30 A.M.; cost, $15. Some sails leave from Manhattan, and others from Staten Island. Reservations and information: 929-7090. SPIRIT OF NEW YORK: Departures from Pier 11, near Wall Street. Lunch cruises, noon to 2:30 P.M. Mondays through Saturdays; cost, $21.60. Daily three-hour dinner cruises at 7 P.M.; cost, $44.30 on weekends and $40 on weekdays. Sunday brunch, from 1 to 3:30 P.M., is $27, and the Friday and Saturday moonlight cruises are $16.25 and go from 11:30 P.M. to 2 A.M. Reservations and information: 279-1890. MUSICRUISE: Periodic weekend evening departures from Pier 81, 41st Street and 12th Avenue. Tickets: generally $20. Information: 864-3000 or 956-5550. DOLLY MADISON: Charter sailings from Pier 11, near Wall Street. Information and prices: (718) 351-9395. BROOKLYN HEIGHTS FERRY: Continuous departures from Pier 11, near Wall Street, and Brooklyn's Fulton Landing, from 7:30 to 9 A.M. and from 4:30 to 5:30 P.M.; round-trip fare: $2.50. Information: (800) 262-8743. ROCKAWAYS FERRY: Weekday departures from 116th Street at 7:15 A.M. and Breezy Point at 7:30 A.M., with a 5:30 P.M. return from Pier 11 in Manhattan. Round-trip fare: $9. Information: (800) 262-8743. STATEN ISLAND FERRY: Continuous, daily departures 24 hours a day from the Battery in Manhattan and the St. George terminal in Staten Island. Fare: 25 cents from Manhattan; the boats are free from Staten Island. Information: (212) 806-6940 or (718) 390-5253. FERRY TO WEEKHAWKEN, N.J.: See New Jersey listing. FERRIES TO HIGHLANDS, KEANSBERG, KEYPORT AND BAYONNE, N.J.: See New Jersey listing for Direct Line. FERRY TO ELIZABETH, N.J.: See New Jersey listing. NEW JERSEY THE SPIRIT: Departures Fridays at 8:30 P.M. and Saturdays at 7:30 P.M. from Elizabeth, N.J.; cost $12 round-trip. Information: (201) 256-7410. WEEHAWKEN FERRY: Departures every 20 to 30 minutes between 7 A.M. and 9:50 P.M. weekdays from Pier 78, at West 38th Street and 12th Avenue in Manhattan, and Weehawken, N.J. Round-trip fare: $5. Information: (212) 564-8846 or (201) 902-8850. DIRECT LINE: Ferries between Highlands, Keansberg, Keyport and Bayonne, N.J., and Manhattan. Weekday departures on all routes and weekend trips from Highlands and Keyport. Round-trip fares: $6 to $19.50. Information: (800) 262-8743. ELIZABETH FERRY: Six weekday and five weekend departures from Elizabeth and Pier 11 in Manhattan. One-way fare: $6; $5 for the elderly. Information: (201) 351-9615. LONG iSLAND THE BRIDGEPORT AND PORT JEFFERSON STEAMBOAT COMPANY: Seven to nine trips daily between 6:30 A.M. and 9:30 P.M. from Port Jefferson, L.I., and between 8:15 A.M. and 11 P.M. from Bridgeport, Conn. One-way passenger fare: $8 for adults and $4.50 for children on weekends and $7 for adults and $3.50 for children on weekdays. For a car and driver, the fare is $25 on weekends, $22 on weekdays. A ''Mariner's Delight'' fare for those who make the round-trip without disembarking is $8 on weekends, $7 on weekdays. Information: (516) 473-0286. BAYSHORE TO FIRE ISLAND FERRIES: Service between 7 A.M. and 11 P.M. on weekends, to Kismet, Saltaire, Fair Harbor, Dunewood, Atlantique, Ocean Beach, Seaview and Ocean Bay Park. Round-trip fare: $8.50 for adults and $4.25 for children. Information: (516) 665-2115. SAYVILLE TO FIRE ISLAND FERRIES: Service to the Sunken Forest-Sailors Haven area of Fire Island National Seashore, between 7 A.M. and about 9 P.M. (midnight on weekends). Round-trip fare: $6.50 for adults;$3.50 for children. Information: (516) 589-0810. PATCHOGUE TO FIRE ISLAND FERRIES: Service to the wilderness area at Fire Island's eastern end 7 A.M. to about 9 P.M. (1 A.M. on Saturdays). Round-trip fares: $7.50 for adults and $4.50 for children. Information: (516) 475-1665. SHELTER ISLAND FERRIES: From Greenport every 15 or 20 minutes between 5:40 A.M. and midnight (1 A.M. on Fridays and Saturdays); the one-way fare: 50 cents for passengers and $3.50 for car and driver. Information: (516) 749-0139. Sag Harbor departures are about every 10 minutes between 6 A.M. and 1:45 A.M. One-way passenger fare: 50 cents; same-day round-trip: 75 cents; for car and driver, one-way fare: $4, $5 for a same-day round trip. Information: (516) 749-1200. FINBACK II: Whale-watching cruises at Montauk. Four-hour cruises at 8 A.M. and 1 P.M. Saturdays, Sundays and Thursdays through Aug. 16, and at 10 A.M. on other days. Cost: $25 for adults and $15 for children. Reservations required. Information: (516) 728-4522. ORIENT POINT TO NEW LONDON, CONN., FERRY: (The Cross Sound Line has curtailed its regular schedule because of an accident. For information on departures call 516-323-2525 or 203-443-5281.) One-way passenger fares: $7 for adults; $3.50 for children. Same-day round-trip fare: $10, $5 for children. For car and driver, the one-way fare is $20. FROM SAG HARBOR AND GREENPORT TO HADDAM, CONN.: See Connecticut listing for Yankee Clipper. CONNECTICUT YANKEE CLIPPER: From Haddam to Sag Harbor, L.I., and Greenport, L.I. Departures at 9 A.M. to Sag Harbor on Fridays through Tuesdays, and to Greenport on Wednesdays and Thursdays. Round-trip fare: $20 for adults, $10 for children. Information: (203) 345-4507. VOYAGER CRUISES: From Mystic. The Argia's six-hour sails, including buffet lunch, leave at 10 A.M. and cost $49 on Saturdays and $41 on Tuesdays. Three-hour voyages are made at 10 A.M. and 1 P.M. on the other five days of the week, for $25 on Sundays and $21 on weekdays. Two-hour wine-and-cheese sunset cruise departs daily at 6 P.M. Fare: $25 on weekends, $21 on weekdays. Two- and three-day cruises to Block Island or Sag Harbor, L.I., including all meals and accommodations in private, two-person cabins, cost $149 to $349. Charters are also available. Information: (203) 536-0416 or (800) 243-0882. KETCH MAJESTIC From Mystic. The boat, which can accommodate up to six passengers, can be rented with captain and crew, for $180 for three hours, $360 for six hours, and $210 for evening trips. Information: (203) 536-1943. OUT O' MYSTIC SCHOONER CRUISES: Eight-hour trips depart at 8 A.M. and cost $59 on weekends and $55 on weekdays. One-to-five-day voyages also offered. Information: (203) 536-4218 or (800) 243-0416. FERRY TO ORIENT POINT, L.I.: See Long Island listing. FERRIES FROM BRIDGEPORT TO PORT JEFFERSON, L.I.: See Long Island listing.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Freddie Jackson, with Ray, Goodman and Brown, Pier 84, 44th Street and 12th Avenue (249-8870). New York's most popular love balladeer, Freddie Jackson implores, cajoles and sweet-talks in a rough-and-ready style that may not be as refined as that of his fellow New Yorker Luther Vandross, but is nevertheless convincing. Mr. Jackson is a master of the cooing, long-lined melisma that constantly changes color, and in concert hits like ''Rock Me Baby'' are drawn out into elaborate vocal showpieces. Formerly the Moments, Ray, Goodman and Brown are masters of sweet post-doo-wop harmony interspersed with amusingly playful intragroup patter. Show time is tomorrow at 7:30 P.M., and tickets are $15.

title: GOLD MEDAL VIOLINIST
description: Ilya Grubert, winner of the gold medal at the 1978 Tchaikovsky Competition, will be the soloist in a performance of Shostakovich's First Violin Concerto, tomorrow night at 8:30 at New Jersey's Waterloo Village. Yoav Talmi will conduct the Waterloo Festival Orchestra. The program includes works by Glinka and Dvorak. Tickets, at $17.50 and $15, are available through TicketMaster, (800) 682-8080. Lawn seating at $10 is available the day of the concert. Information: (201) 347-4700.

title: A FALL GUY YES, A PATSY NO, A PRESIDENT'S SERVANT SAYS
description: He was willing to take the hit. He was ready to be dropped like a hot rock. He would play the ''fall guy,'' as he put it in tough-guy lingo, allowing his superiors to finger him on a scheme that was going down the tubes.

title: Senate Action on Angola
description: The Senate today rejected a trade embargo on Angola, proposed as an amendment to the trade bill by Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona. The 68-to-31 vote to table his amendment followed a sharp debate about the Administration's policy on Angola. Washington is sending millions of dollars in covert aid to rebels who are trying to overthrow the Marxist administration in Luanda. At the same time, Angola's main source of foreign exchange comes from the Chevron Oil Company, which owns about half of Angola's national oil company.

title: Pythagoras to the Rescue
description: Team Turmoil, listed in the National League standing as the ''Mets,'' or ''New York'' - Town Turmoil - were, as expected, in a high state of tension in the clubhouse.

title: Misha Dichter Recital
description: Misha Dichter, the pianist, will play Beethoven's ''Eroica'' Variations (Op. 35), Schumann's Sonata No. 1 in F sharp minor (Op.11), Four Mazurkas and the F sharp minor Polonaise by Chopin, and three Hungarian Rhapsodies by Liszt, Sunday at 5:30 P.M. in the Venetian Theater at the Caramoor Festival in Katonah, N.Y. Tickets, at $20, are available at the box office or through TicketMaster, 307-7171. Information: (914) 232-5035.

title: EQUITY APPROVES BRITON FOR 'ROAD TO MECCA'
description: The Actors' Equity Association agreed yesterday to allow the British actress Yvonne Bryceland to re-create her leading role in ''The Road to Mecca'' next season on Broadway.

title: ALBANY IN ACCORD ON COURT PROGRAM AND BUSINESS TAX
description: Moving toward the close of the main 1987 legislative session, Governor Cuomo and lawmakers reached agreement today on an array of key issues from restructuring corporate taxes to a $1.25 billion plan to rebuild the state's courts.

title: INQUIRY SOUGHT IN RANGERS' ROLE IN LIBERTY GIFTS
description: Senator Bill Bradley asked the Interior Department yesterday to investigate reports that park rangers at the Statue of Liberty have been pressed to solicit donations from visitors.

title: Johnson Says He's Sorry
description: Dave Johnson apologized to reporters today, saying that this season is ''the most frustrating I've ever spent in baseball,'' and admitting that he had lost control of his emotions and his players.

title: HOWARD V. FUNK
description: Howard V. Funk, who was superintendent of schools in Bronxville, N.Y., for 10 years, died of heart failure Tuesday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. He was 91 years old and lived in Tuckahoe, N.Y.

title: AUSTRALIA'S LIBERALS SLIP AS ELECTION DRAWS NEAR
description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 9 -

title: LAWMAKERS AGREE ON INCOME TAX CUT
description: Lawmakers in the State Senate and Assembly reached a tentative agreement today on a plan to reduce New York City's personal income taxes by $75 million, and to return to taxpayers another $230 million in excess revenues that the city would otherwise collect because of changes in the Federal tax code.

title: FIRST BANK SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest second quarter loss resulted from the June decision to add $160 million to its loan loss reserves because of recent developments affecting its credit exposure to less developed countries. The company also said net income for the latest quarter was reduced by the entire $160 million because the company did not recognize deferred tax benefits related to the action.

title: EX-UNIROYAL HEAD
description: George R. Vila, a former chairman and president of Uniroyal, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday in his Manhattan apartment. He was 78 years old and also lived in Sharon, Conn.

title: COMPUTER DESIGNED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary pretax gain of $575,698.

title: Aqueduct Parlay Plan: Profits Can Ride
description: Parlay betting, which the New York Racing Association proposes to implement this fall at Aqueduct, would be a strange addition to the parimutuel menu.

title: L.I. RESORT BUILT IN THE 20'S IS RESCUED
description: For more than half a century Montauk Manor, a 250-room fantasy castle with turrets and spires, has sat atop Fort Hill, one of easterly Long Island's highest points, as a monument of sorts to the giddy and opulent way of life of high society in the twenties.

title: 1,750 HOMELESS OFFERED CHANCE FOR NEW HOMES
description: Sixteen nonprofit groups have been selected to develop and operate housing for about 1,750 homeless people, the Koch administration said yesterday.

title: Trump's Stake In Golden Nugget
description: Donald J. Trump, the New York real estate developer, has a 4.9 percent interest in Golden Nugget Inc., the casino operator in Las Vegas. A secretary to Mr. Trump said he authorized her statement after The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that he owned the stock and might seek control.

title: A.M.C. Merger Data Sought
description: The Chrysler Corporation said that the Federal Trade Commission was seeking more information from Chrysler and the American Motors Corporation on their proposed merger.

title: S.E.C. Said to Expand Search for Bond Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has widened its investigation of the possibly fraudulent sale of municipal bonds to include about 60 issues, many of them marketed by major Wall Street underwriters, according to published reports. As much as $12 billion of securities may be involved.

title: SUMMERFARE GIVES DANCE ITS DAY, DON JUAN HIS DUE
description: THE Pepsico Summerfare festival, which opens tonight at the Performing Arts Center of the State University of New York at Purchase, has always been a place to see a wide range of dance. And dancegoers with a taste for the new and innovative could easily spend the entire weekend at the festival, which is devoted in its opening days to dance and to theater in which movement plays an important part. Ballet, modern dance and multimedia performance art from West Germany, Sweden, Spain, Canada, Mexico and the United States will jostle for space and time in the sprawling and hectic environment of the festival.

title: CLASSICAL SCULPTURE
description: BRITISH 18th-century taste in classical sculpture - both the type of works collected and the degree of restoration on most of them - will be tested in an auction of Greek and Roman art today at Christie's in London. The 14 ancient busts, statues and architectural elements, part of a collection of 45 pieces acquired about 1766 by James Smith Barry, are described by Christie's as the most important group of such classical works to be offered at auction since the early 1960's.

title: Last Call for Albany Housing Action
description: Despite its drive to go home, the New York Legislature has time today to move bills that would directly and indirectly alleviate the state's critical housing shortage.

title: To New Heights
description: Since 1866 when J. Wheeler of Britain used a pole to soar 10 feet off the ground, the world record in the pole vault has inched up over the last 121 years to nearly twice that height. Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union came within 3 inches of 20 feet June 23 in Prague with a vault of 19 feet 9 1/4 inches. The escalation of the pole vault world record, with the first man to clear each height:

title: ROAD TO GOOD WATER STREWN WITH FAILED PROJECTS
description: At daylight's first blush, the women of this tropical district for generations have begun the long walk to faraway rivers and streams to collect water for their families.

title: NEWS OFFERS BUYOUTS TO PRINTER
description: In a new phase in crucial labor negotiations, The Daily News has offered to buy out the lifetime contracts of up to 125 typographers for an annuity and insurance package that, the union said, is worth $110,000 a person.

title: The Question of Liabiliyty
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testified yesterday that a turning point for him in the Iran-contra affair was the press conference Nov. 25. at which Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d discussed, among other things, the questions of who knew about the diversions. Here is an exchange from that press conference.

title: Goldome Gets $92 Million
description: Goldome, the eighth-largest thrift institution in the country, said yesterday that it had received more than $92 million in orders for its stock from depositors and other residents of its service region. The offering ended last Thursday.

title: Networks Will Carry Washington Hearings
description: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair will be broadcast live beginning at 9 A.M. on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on some local affiliates of PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service, including Channel 13 in New York and Channel 49 in Connecticut.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Personal Computer column in Science Times on June 16 referred incorrectly to languages spoken in Equatorial Guinea. Fang is one language spoken there. The column also incorrectly described PC-Globe software's handling of the term GDP. It is in fact defined, in the database menu, as Gross Domestic Product.

title: Abortion Aid Cutoff Is Blocked
description: The state Court of Appeals issued an order today that blocked, at least temporarily, a new law cutting off Medicaid payments for abortions.

title: Sifton Moves to Knopf
description: Elisabeth Sifton, who has had her own imprint at Viking Penguin Books since 1984, has been named executive vice president of Alfred A. Knopf. While she will acquire and edit books for Knopf, she will not have her own imprint there. Sonny Mehta, Knopf's president, said Thursday that Ms. Sifton will begin her new job in late August.

title: VLSI TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: NORTH OUTDRAWS THE TOP SHOW ON DAYTIME TV
description: If the testimony of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North were a regularly scheduled soap opera, it would be the biggest hit on television. His appearances are attracting five times as many viewers as the most popular daytime show, ''General Hospital.''

title: Piquet Fastest In Race Trials
description: A tire blowout and a second-place finish behind Nelson Piquet of Brazil spoiled Nigel Mansell's homecoming today as Piquet, Mansell's teammate, posted the fastest first-session practice time for the British Grand Prix on Sunday.

title: Pilot Whales Still Together Off Nantucket, Trackers Say
description: Three pilot whales that were returned to the sea last month after eight months of treatment are still together, say researchers who are tracking the whales through radio transmitters on two of them.

title: FAIRCHILD TO REORGNIZE AND SELL MORE DIVISIONS
description: In a wide revamping, Fairchild Industries, the military contractor, said yesterday that it was raising funds, putting more divisions on the block, trimming its debts and planning to buy back stock.

title: CYCLISTS FAULT LIMITED USE OF BRIDGE
description: The Port Authority thought it was good news.

title: GROSSMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,141,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,361,000 and $15,857,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; and extraordinary losses of $750,000 for the quarter and $1,000,000 for 6 months.

title: Javier A. White, Head Of Law Firm in Harlem
description: Javier A. White, the managing partner of Stevens, Hinds & White, one of the most influential law firms in Harlem, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx. He was 42 years old and lived in Washington Heights.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jack Singer, general manager of the Class AAA Phoenix Firebirds, said yesterday that the San Francisco Giants had reached an agreement with Dave Kingman for him to play in Phoenix. The 38-year-old slugger was expected to sign a contract today. If he displays his former power, Kingman, who has 442 major league career home runs, may play later this season with the Giants. Singer said Kingman would be the designated hitter tonight when Phoenix plays the Calgary Cannons. . . . The Los Angeles Dodgers have signed Tito Landrum, a free-agent outfielder, to a contract through the 1988 seaason. Landrum, 32, who has a .258 lifetime batting average over eight seasons, was released last Saturday by the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Persuasive Orfeo
description: ORFEO ED EURIDICE Opera by Gluck. Libretto by Calzabigi. With Janet Baker, Elizabeth Gale and Elisabeth Speiser. London Philharmonic Orchestra and Glyndebourne Chorus conducted by Raymond Leppard. Produced at Glyndebourne Festival by Peter Hall. Sung in Italian with English subtitles. Home Vision. 130 minutes. $49.95.

title: Letter: On Wilderness Preserves; Alaska Has Withdrawn Its Fair Share
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Pound Astros, 7-3
description: The scores from St. Louis do not seem to interest the Mets anymore. The only race of importance now is one of respectability in the National League East. First place is too far from reality for now.

title: Knicks, Celtics: Talks at The Top
description: The negotiations for Jimmy Rodgers to become head coach of the Knicks took an unusual turn last week, reaching the highest level of the Knicks' and the Celtics' management: the chairman and chief executive officer of Gulf and Western Inc., Martin Davis, and the principal owner of the Boston Celtics, Donald Gaston.

title: MCA Reports Chief Is Better
description: In an effort to calm speculative stock trading, MCA Inc. said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Lew Wasserman, was recovering satisfactorily after surgery.

title: Telling the Truth?
description: NORTH

title: OFFER FOR PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN
description: Caroline Hunt Schoellkopf, by some accounts the country's richest woman, wants to own a shirt company.

title: Panama Policemen Prevent Anti-Government Gathering
description: Riot policemen sealed off a section of Panama's capital today to prevent anti-Government demonstrators from gathering for a protest rally.

title: Thai Officials Say Laos Turns To Marijuana to Help Budget
description: The Government of Laos is promoting cultivation and export of marijuana as a means to earn foreign exchange, according to Thai officials who have been monitoring narcotics in the region.

title: A Haiti Vacation Ends in Plane Crash at Sea for 4 Americans
description: Francis Randall, a 55-year-old history professor at Sarah Lawrence College, remembers that the light plane crashed into the darkened ocean with a ''terrific jolt.''

title: BUSH AGREES TO 4 DEBATES
description: Vice President Bush announced today that he would participate in four debates for Republican Presidential candidates later this year and in 1988.

title: HANDFUL OF BILLS IN ALBANY TOUCH EVERYDAY SITUATIONS
description: Of the 900 or so bills signed into state law each year, the vast majority go unnoticed by most New Yorkers - they are technical amendments or laws affecting only small groups or in some cases, only one person.

title: A Longer List
description: Johnny Morris, a rookie wide receiver with the Chicago Bears, made some strong statements about reported payoffs to schoolboy athletes by Southwest Conference members and about the integrity of the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday as camp opened for Bear rookies at the team's Lake Forest (Ill.) training headquarters.

title: White-Water Team Shoots for the Top
description: The white-water rivers of our nation - the swift ones made white by their rapids - have challenged recreational canoeists and rafters for years. The rivers, like the Youghiogheny in Pennylvania or the Penobscot in Maine, may be old, but new to them are the high-tech carbon fiber canoes and kayaks, carrying competitors in wet suits.

title: Greenspan Says He'd Sit Out Some Federal Reserve Votes
description: Alan Greenspan, President Reagan's nominee for chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, will not participate in regulatory decisions that directly affect J. P. Morgan & Company, one of the nation's most aggressive banking companies, according to a document he submitted to the White House and Congress.

title: A WORKERS' BEER GAINS STATUS
description: Almost overnight, Corona Extra has become the second-best-selling imported beer in the United States. But in the East, where Mexico's equivalent of Budweiser remains scarce, Corona fanciers are in for a long, dry summer.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tour de France Mottet Captures Yellow Jersey: Charles Mottet of France took the lead yesterday after finishing second in the 10th leg of the Tour de France cycling race behind Stephen Roche of Ireland. Roche captured the 54-mile leg, an individual time trial from Saumur to Futuroscope, France, in a time of 1 hour 58 minutes 11 seconds, riding at an average speed of 27.5 miles per hour. Jesper Skibby of Denmark placed third, 53 seconds off the pace. Mottet finished 42 seconds behind and took the leader's yellow jersey from Erich Maechler of Switzerland, who had led the standing since July 4. Mottet now leads by 47 seconds over all. (AP) Boxing Breland Defends Title: The World Boxing Association welterweight champion, Mark Breland, outpointed Venezuelan Juan Rondon in a 10-round nontitle match early today in Santa Margherita di Pula, Sardinia. The unbeaten 24-year-old from Brooklyn pounded Rondon with his powerful left hand, showing no effects from a March operation to fix a tendon. Breland knocked down his opponent late in the third round with a devastating right to the mid-section, but Rondon (19-4) quickly recovered and fought defensively for the rest of the bout. Breland entered his first fight overseas with a record of 17 victories, 12 by knockouts.(AP) Golf Okamoto Leads by 2: Ayako Okamoto birdied three of the last four holes yesterday, shot a three-under-par 69 and took a two-stroke lead after two rounds of the $400,000 du Maurier Classic in Laval, Quebec. Okamoto, whose 65 led after the first round, finished the first 36 holes at 10-under-par 134. Jill Briles, who shot her second consecutive 68, was alone in second at 136. Kathy Postlewait also had a 68 and was at 137.(AP) Putting Like a Dream: Tim Simpson, crediting a new approach to putting he said came to him in a dream, shot a six-under-par 65 today to take a one-stroke lead after the second round of the Anheuser-Busch Golf Classic. His two-day total was 132, 10 under par on the 6,776-yard Kingsmill Golf Club course. The 31-year-old resident of Dunwoody, Ga., said he did not want to divulge the specific nature of the dream ''because somebody might use it this week to beat me.'' Closest to Simpson at 133 were Tom Sieckmann, John Cook and Scott Hoch.(AP) Tennis Controversial Call: The defending champion, Andres Gomez of Ecuador, won a quarterfinal match from Jimmy Arias of the United States at the United States Pro Tennis Championships yesterday in Brookline, Mass., 2-6, 7-5, 7-6, after winning a disputed first point of the third-set tiebreaker. A lineswoman called Arias's deep shot to the left corner out, then reversed herself. After a 15-minute dispute, in which Gomez argued that he stopped going for the ball when he heard the out call, the point was ordered replayed. It was won by Gomez, who also won the next three points and took the tiebreaker. His semifinal opponent will be third-seeded Kent Carlsson, who beat a fellow Swede, Joakim Nystrom, 6-1, 7-5. Top-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden will play in the other semifinal Saturday after beating unseeded Tom Nijssen of the Netherlands, 6-2, 7-5. Wilander will meet either Martin Jaite of Argentina or Aaron Krickstein of the United States.(AP) Track and Field American Runs First: Butch Reynolds of the United States, making his first overseas appearance, won the 400-meter run yesterday at the I.A.A.F.-Mobil Track and Field Grand Prix meet in London. Reynolds stormed around the Crystal Palace track in 44.15 seconds, the second-fastest time in the world this year. Edwin Moses won the 400-meter hurdles in 47.94 seconds, the third-best time in the world this year and just below his 1987 best of 47.69.(AP) Horse Racing Java Gold an Easy Winner: Java Gold redeemed himself for a narrow defeat as a heavy favorite 11 days ago by scoring an impressive six-length victory over Johns Treasure and Personal Flag in the featured eighth race yesterday at Belmont Park. The lone 3-year-old in the field of just three covered the mile and a sixteenth on a dull track in 1:43 1/5, paid $4.20 as the second choice while winning for the third time in four starts this year.

title: Capital Drama: Lawyers Take Note
description: Did the House committee's chief counsel glower too much? Was his Senate counterpart too soft on the colonel and too tough on the President? Why has the defense attorney been so ill tempered?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JULY 11, 1987
description: The Economy

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 17.

title: TV: Perception of North the Key
description: It's perception that counts; who knows that better than elected officials? On television, the question in the Iran-contra hearing yesterday was not so much what the hearing was about; it was, what did it seem to be about? How was it playing on television? Senator David Boren dropped a hint on CBS the night before.

title: Pension Funds Start With Lower Wages
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Anti-Drug Effort Found Ineffective in Halting Supply
description: Federal law-enforcement agents are still seizing relatively little of the cocaine, marijuana and other illegal drugs smuggled into the United States, according to a Congressional report.

title: Chinese Find Tomb Figures
description: Archaeologists in northern China have found 1,700 terra-cotta warriors and horses from an imperial tomb believed to be more than 1,500 years old, the New China News Agency reported today. It said the figures depicted singers and dancers. China's most famous terra-cotta figures are life-size warriors and horses, believed to be more than 2,000 years old.

title:
Patents;
A Water Rescue Device
description: LEAD: A device for water rescue, invented for the Mobil Corporation of New York City, involves a crane mounted on a boat. A boom on the crane is connected to a float and a net that can support people in danger of drowning. Patent 4,678,446, which was awarded to Paul C. Dahan of Pittstown, N.J., says that existing rescue equipment, such as lifelines, rafts and life preservers, is often ineffective in heavy weather.

title: Texaco Stake 9.5% For Holmes a Court
description: The Australian financier Robert Holmes a Court said yesterday that he owns 9.5 percent of Texaco Inc. common shares, up from the 7.4 percent he reported just on Wednesday.

title: Man and Woman Found Slain In an East Village Apartment
description: A man and a woman, both described as Asian, were found shot to death yesterday afternoon in what appeared to be an execution-style slaying in the East Village, the police reported.

title: ISRAEL PACKEL
description: Israel Packel, a lawyer, educator and former state attorney general who served on Pennsylvania's Superior and Supreme Court benches, died Wednesday. He was 79 years old.

title: On Queensboro, The Cottonwood Grows Very Tall
description: The City of New York naturalist, insisting that he was not a contradiction in terms, consulted his field guide, which mentioned all manner of habitats for the eastern cottonwood tree, from streams in Quebec to sandbars in Florida, but nothing pertaining to this.

title: A Lesson of the Barbie Trial
description: LEAD: Within the dramatic legal forms of the French state trial of Klaus Barbie, time and experience were telescoped. That telescoping magnified the larger meaning of the trial of the Nazi who terrorized Lyons as Gestapo chief from 1942 to 1944.

title: New Calls Are Issued For Testing Of Poultry
description: IN the last 10 days several consumer groups have joined in urging the Agriculture Department to require that all fresh poultry and meat be labeled with cooking and handling instructions. A bill will soon be introduced in the Senate calling for random testing of poultry and poultry feed. And one consumer group has urged a boycott of poultry.

title: DEKALB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,700,000 and $2,500,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $100,000 for the quarter and $900,000 for the 9 months.

title: MOUNTING DELAYS HINDER ARREST SYSTEM
description: Every day, 24 hours a day, New York City shuffles people who are arrested but not yet formally charged with crimes from one criminal justice center to another like so many checkers.

title: DOW GAINS 4.78 POINTS TO 2,455.99
description: Stock prices rose modestly yesterday despite the release of what many traders said was positive news on inflation.

title: Directors Seek Talks To Bar Weekend Strike
description: Television and film producers and directors called for further talks today after a 16-hour, all-night negotiating session to try to avert a directors' strike this weekend.

title: TV: HAYLEY MILLS AS TEACHER
description: At 8:30 tonight, Hayley Mills plays a with-it sixth-grade teacher in ''Good Morning, Miss Bliss,'' which has all the marks of threatening to become a half-hour NBC series. Miss Bliss's students, whom we meet at the start of the new school year, are cute as buttons - a whole classroom of Indianapolis buttons. Except perhaps for a new boy who has troubles, and Miss Bliss is not the sort of teacher who can take the principal's advice to ''just teach, don't get involved.'' Not to worry. By 9 P.M., the kid is well adjusted again.

title: Landlord Told to Begin Sentence: 30 Days in His Squalid Apartment
description: A Beverly Hills neurosurgeon has been ordered to begin a sentence of 30 days' confinement in a vermin-infested apartment building for failing to improve conditions in four buildings he owned.

title:
Patents;
Improvement Made In Teller Machines
description: LEAD: An improvement in automatic teller machines, patented this week for the International Business Machines Corporation, is described as reliably dispensing old as well as new paper money. The top sheets are moved by friction feed from a stack of bills in a cassette, whether they are fresh or not.

title: Judge Upholds Special Prosecutor's Role on North
description: A Federal judge today upheld the authority of a special prosecutor to investigate the Iran-contra affair and to enforce a grand jury subpoena against Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. The judge, Aubrey E. Robinson Jr. of Federal District Court in Washington, ruled that the Justice Department had acted properly in granting a special backup appointment to the special prosecutor, Lawrence E. Walsh.

title: First U.S. Diphtheria Death Since '82 Occurs in Florida
description: A 16-year-old boy has died of diphtheria, the nation's first reported fatality resulting from the highly infectious disease since 1982, according to health officials.

title: JURY SETS POLAROID DAMAGES
description: A Federal District Court jury late today set damages in a class action suit against the Polaroid Corporation.

title: U.N. Group Meets Amid Anxiety
description: The seventh ministerial meeting of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development began deliberations today in an uncertain mood.

title: You Can't Keep a Good Concept Down
description: To the Editor:

title: PRODUCTION OF MISSLE APPROVED
description: The Pentagon announced today that it had approved initial production of the Air Force's newest air-to-air missile. It said tests had shown that the missile works and that its costs have stopped rising.

title: MOSCOW AND BONN ARE INCHING CLOSER
description: A six-day visit to the Soviet Union by President Richard von Weizsacker appears to have opened the way for a stepping up of high-level contacts between Moscow and Bonn, according to West German officials and Western diplomats.

title: PHOTO SATELLITES RESTRICTED BY U.S.
description: The Commerce Department today issued final regulations that give the State and Defense Departments the right to veto license applications for private ownership of satellites capable of producing high-resolution photographs.

title: In Australia Vote Today, Unions Are a Nonissue
description: During construction of a pedestrian mall in an Australian city recently, workers went on strike to protest lunchtime strollers' heckling them for not working hard enough. The laborers said if they were to tolerate the insults, they wanted extra pay. They got it and returned to work.

title: U.S. Links 3 to Boxcar Deaths
description: Federal charges were filed today against three Mexicans thought to be part of a smuggling ring linked to the deaths of 18 illegal aliens in a locked boxcar. One of the men was being held in El Paso, but the authorities believe the other two have fled to Mexico.

title: CONSOLIDATED PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company attributed lower earnings in the latest quarter to price reductions in the lightweight coated paper market.

title: Economy Lags but Race Is On in New Zealand
description: New Zealanders will vote Aug. 15 in a national election that, more than anything else, will be a referendum on the Labor Government's economic policies, dubbed ''Rogernomics,'' after the Finance Minister, Roger Douglas.

title: Your Money; A Tax Strategy For Investors
description: THE top tax rate for individuals will drop next year, and this is all the more reason to try to defer investment income into 1988.

title: In Support of a Human Rights Appointment
description: To the Editor:

title: CSC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Fed Panel Backed Slight Tightening
description: Federal Reserve policy makers voted by 9 to 1 at their May 19 meeting to tighten monetary policy slightly while leaving open the possibility for an increase in a key interest rate, according to minutes of that meeting that were released today.

title: And the Telegrams Pour In
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North has reported receiving thousands of telegrams, most of them supportive, since his testimony began this week. Here are some of them.

title: The Limits of Milton's Tolerance
description: To the Editor:

title: Mesclun: Latest in Salads
description: After you have discarded iceberg lettuce and even grown tired of bibb, Kentucky limestone, arugula and mache, what is left?

title: Greyhound Deal
description: The Greyhound Corporation said its previously announced acquisition of the routes and some assets of Trailways Inc. takes effect Monday with the official closing of the contracts. Greyhound said its chairman, Fred Currey, would meet with Trailways employees at the Trailways headquarters to discuss the impact of the merger on Dallas operations.

title: AN EVANGELIST AND NORTH
description: On Sept. 15, 1985, the day that Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North left for his secret mission to Teheran, the Marine officer confided to the Rev. Pat Robertson that he was going to Iran to seek the release of hostages, Mr. Robertson said today.

title: CONSTON CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to May 38
description: b-Includes about 5 cents a share attributed to a reduction in the Federal income tax rate under the 1986 Tax Reform Act.

title: The Big Show
description: To the Editor:

title: CATERPILLAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the drop in second quarter profits resulted principally because of a $34 million reduction in benefits from the LIFO accounting method. The company also said the LIFO reductions provided only a $1 million benefit in the latest second quarter, compared with a benefit of $35 million in the year-ago second quarter.

title: SAUDI HOLDS STAKE IN TRANSAMERICA
description: A company controlled by Suliman S. Olayan, a Saudi Arabian businessman, disclosed today that it owns 5.29 percent of the Transamerica Corporation, but disavowed any desire for a takeover.

title: Dukakis Ends AIDS Test Ban As State Insurance Aide Quits
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis has approved a policy that will allow insurance companies in Massachusetts to test for the AIDS virus, reversing an earlier ban on testing imposed by his insurance commissioner.

title: WESTERN STEER-MOM 'N' POP'S reports earnings for Qtr to May 22
Seeking a Lost Crown
description: Life began at 39 for Archie Moore when he won the world light heavyweight title in 1952. One of Moore's proteges, George Foreman, the former world heavyweight champion, hopes life will begin anew for him at the same age when he seeks to regain his title.

title: NATIONAL BANCORP OF ALASKA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Cards and Calls (and Cash) Pour In for North, a Hero to Many Americans
description: Expressions of support are pouring in. So are the flowers. And so is the cash.

title: New York Must Spend More on AIDS Education
description: LEAD: With little hope for a vaccine or cure for AIDS in the near future, there is only one way to control the spread of AIDS: education. In gay communities in New York City and San Francisco, education has already played a vital role in slowing the spread of the disease. But despite the pressing need for a widespread, intensive AIDS education effort, the city and state governments have so far allotted only a small amount of their AI

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Faults Soviet on Talks The Reagan Administration pointedly criticized the Soviet Union for what it said was a slowdown of arms control negotiations and preparations for a summit meeting. Page 3.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Paris dispatch in The Living Section on Wednesday about the Folies-Bergere misidentified a performer and incorrectly characterized her role in a new show. She is Bertice Reading, and she left the show on May 15. An earlier Folies-Bergere performer was also misidentified; she was Mistinguett. The article also misstated the name of an 1887 revue at the theater. It was ''Place aux Jeunes.'' The tradition of using 13-letter names for shows began after ''Place aux Jeunes.''

title: Rolls-Royce, G.E. Get Qantas Orders
description: Rolls-Royce P.L.C. and the General Electric Company received orders to supply engines to the Australian airline Qantas for its new long-range Boeing 747 aircraft. The British jet-engine maker said the airline had ordered four of the American-built Boeing 747-400's with Rolls-Royce RB211-524D4D engines and has options on a further 15. In Sydney, Australia, Qantas said it had ordered three CF6-80C2B6 engines from G.E., as well as spares for one Boeing 767-300ER aircraft ordered in April. Qantas said this was the first time it had ordered General Electric engines.

title: Japan Trade Surplus Falls
description: Japan's trade surplus fell 10 percent, to $6.61 billion, in June from its 1986 level, the Finance Ministry said today. The June surplus was down from $7.36 billion in June 1986, although it was up slightly from $6.41 billion in May.

title:
PLAYERS;
A 'Fat Little Kid' Has the Last Laugh
description: LEAD: Athletic glory is not supposed to be born like this, but Tony Meola admitted that his early brushes with soccer were a bit of a joke. ''I was about 6 years old and I loved the sport,'' he recalled, ''but I was a fat little kid who couldn't do the running, so they kept sticking me in the goal.''

title: Nippon Computer Deal
description: Nippon Telegraph and Telephone said today that it had signed an agreement to buy its fourth supercomputer from Cray Research Inc., the Minneapolis-based computer company.

title: Once Was a Time: Sharing the 60's
description: To everything there is a season.

title: 6 Workmen Killed In a Plunge to Deck Of Ship in San Diego
description: A crane-operated basket carrying 12 civilian shipyard plunged 30 feet onto the deck of a Navy ship today, killing 6 men and injuring 6. said.

title: UNITED VIRGINIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an $18 million special provision for loan losses, taken primarily for Latin American loans. The provision was partially offset by a pretax gain of $6.6 million from the settlement of certain pension obligations.

title: STUART HALL CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title:
Patents;
Loading Equipment
description: LEAD: A shovel-like device for loading and unloading materials such as coal or dirt was patented this week by Edwin Z. Gabriel, a consulting engineer in Ocean Grove, N.J. According to patent 4,678,220, the equipment will open and discharge its cargo once it touches an object below, such as a truck. It can also scoop up material.

title: Officer Suspended for Letting A Sex Film Be Shown in Jail
description: A correction captain who authorized the showing of a pornographic movie at the Bronx House of Detention for Men was suspended for a day without pay and may face departmental charges, the city's Department of Correction reported yesterday.

title: Lots and Lots of Rumors
description: It took 25 minutes instead of the usual five to negotiate the two furlongs from the parking lot to the press box at Belmont Park yesterday. There was little traffic, this being a twilight racing card with the first post still hours away. But the early birds were out and around, and every one of them wanted to stop and talk, to offer and to extract some helpful advice.

title: RAYTHEON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BANDAG INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Operetta: New Leads In 'Prince'
description: The New York City Opera shifted casts Wednesday night in its run of Sigmund Romberg's ''Student Prince.'' The two sets of singers will alternate in these performances, which continue through tomorrow.

title: E. GEORGE THIEM
description: E. George Thiem, an investigative reporter who twice won the Pulitzer Prize at The Chicago Daily News, died Wednesday. He was 90 years old. The Daily News, which closed in 1978, won a public-service Pulitzer in 1949 based on reporting by Mr. Thiem, who, along with Roy J. Harris of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, uncovered 51 newspaper employees secretly on the payroll of Gov. Dwight Green.

title: CPC INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a special gain of $126 million, or $1.53 a share, related to the company's restructuring program for both the quarter and 6 months. The company said the special gain resulted chiefly from the sale to Ajinomoto Co. of Japan of a 50-percent stake in CPS's subsidiaries in six Asian countries and CPC's 50-percent equity in a joint venture with Ajinomoto in Japan, along with sales of other investments.

title: Arias Plan Deserves Better From Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Vietnam Is Said to Plan To Keep Cambodia Role
description: A senior Communist diplomat in close touch with Vietnam's views strongly suggested in an interview here that Hanoi intended to keep firm military links with Cambodia even if it adheres to its announced intention to withdraw its troops in 1990.

title: Time to Talk Strategy With Moscow
description: Throughout the dispute over banning medium-range nuclear missiles from Europe, the cry has been ''We in Western Europe can't cut our nuclear strength - not when the Warsaw Pact is stronger in conventional forces.'' Yet Western leaders have been unwilling to foot the high bill for more men and weapons and unable to negotiate a new balance with the Soviet Union.

title: U.S. Issues Rise Moderately
description: Prices of Government securities rose moderately yesterday in response to a smaller-than-expected increase of two-tenths of 1 percent in June's Producer Price Index.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Garden Pianist

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Are you criticizing how well I did my shredding?'' - Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North.

title: U.S. SAYS SOVIET IS STALLING ON ARMS AND SUMMIT ISSUES
description: The Reagan Administration criticized the Soviet Union today for what it said was a slowdown of arms-control negotiations and preparations for a summit meeting.

title: Mellon Seeking Cut in Costs
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation's chairman, Frank V. Cahouet, today announced six-month hiring and salary freezes and told the bank's 18,000 employees that layoffs would follow in the company's campaign to slash costs.

title: Democrats and Women: Party Shifts Approach
description: Three years into the post-Ferraro era of Democratic politics, the party's Presidential candidates are campaigning for women's votes in a manner that has aroused debate and complaints from some women that feminism is being neglected.

title: TAX ABATEMENT TO BE RENEWED BY LEGISLATOR
description: Pressing to close the 1987 session of the State Legislature, lawmakers worked through the night and into this morning, reaching agreement on a renewal of New York City's J-51 real-estate tax abatement program, state economic development initiatives and a range of other outstanding issues.

title: British Inflation at 4.2%
description: Britain's annual inflation rate, as measured by retail prices, rose to 4.2 percent in June, one-tenth of a percentage point higher than the previous month.

title: Larger German Tax Cut
description: The West German Parliament passed a bill today to increase tax cuts scheduled for next year, which the Government hopes will help reduce world trade imbalances by increasing domestic spending on both foreign and local goods.

title: PILOT IN NEAR COLLISION OVER OCEAN SUGGESTED INCIDENT BE KEPT SECRET
description: A radio conversation among pilots after two airliners nearly collided over the Atlantic Ocean on Wednesday included repeated suggestions that the incident not be reported, officials close to an investigation of the incident said yesterday.

title: Opera: 'Cavalleria' in Park
description: Watching the New York Grand Opera struggle through ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and ''Pagliacci'' at the Central Park Bandshell on Thursday night made one wonder why opera doesn't stay indoors where it's safe. Granted the weather forecast (hot and steamy) fit the subject matter at hand, but there was simply too much to fight against. The catalogue is long: collapsing sets, a confused chorus, an underrehearsed orchestra, an out-of-tune organ, distortive amplification, a horribly humid night.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a sentence of the Food Notes column in The Living Section on Wednesday was incorrectly worded. The sentence, referring to a new food store opened by J. Bildner & Sons, should have read: ''Although Upper West Siders can find produce, cheeses, seafood and prepared salads in more variety and generally better condition in other shops nearby, and Bildner's stock of packaged groceries is limited, it is doubtful that there is a finer bakery in the area.''

title: PAXTON (FRANK) CO (O) reports earnings for Year to March 31
Cyprus Bomb Kills 2 in Car
description: A hotel owner and his 13-year-old son were killed today when a bomb exploded as the man started his car in Limassol, the police said. They said they did not know the motive behind the bombing, which was the second on this Mediterranean island in a month.

title: REPORTERS' RIGHTS: ALTERED INTERPRETATION OF NEW YORK'S LAW
description: In considering the scope of a New York statute protecting journalists' sources and materials from subpoena, a sharply divided Court of Appeals offered a glimpse into how judges can make new law by interpreting statutes in ways that legislators never intended. Assemblyman Steven

title: Day Accepts New Hanna Bid
description: The M. A. Hanna Company said today that the board of the Day International Corporation had accepted a sweetened takeover offer for about $336 million.

title: Casey Planned to Write Memoirs
description: Shortly before William J. Casey was hospitalized last December, his literary agent circulated a proposal for a book of memoirs.

title: War Ain't Peace Yet
description: Accepting the gift of an expensive security gate, for which he later submitted phony documentation, was ''probably the grossest misjudgment I have made in my life,'' Lieut. Col. Oliver North told the select Congressional committees.

title: Judge Says U.S. Officials, Honoring Constitution, Violated Protesters' Rights
description: A Federal district judge, declaring that the officials who control Independence Mall ''may not fully appreciate the reach of the First Amendment,'' found today that they had violated the free-speech rights of protesters at a ceremony honoring the Constitution's bicentennial.

title: FOOD SECTOR A KEY
description: In a highly encouraging report on inflation, the Government said today that the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods rose only two-tenths of 1 percent in June.

title: NORTH SAYS CASEY PROPOSED USING ARMS PROFIT FOR FUND KEPT SECRET FROM PRESIDENT  MANY ARE FOUND TO BELIEVE NORTH
description: By an overwhelming margin, the American people say they believe Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North is telling the truth about the Iran-contra affair, and most say that President Reagan is lying, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.

title: Zambia Death Toll Is Cut
description: Officials today sharply lowered their estimate of the number of people who died Sunday when a barge sank on a river crossing from Zaire to Zambia. The officials now estimate the total number of passengers at 250, 51 of whom were known to be dead, and about 190 of whom had swum to safety.

title: VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Retreat From Populism in Maryland
description: Gov. William Schaefer of Maryland threatens to withhold state funds for poverty lawyers unless they promise not to sue the state. Though clothed in humanitarian arguments, the move represents a retreat from statesmanship.

title: HIBERNIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding for the year-ago periods reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in May.

title: ANTHEM ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: The company said results are restated to coincide with the recent change in fiscal year-end to Dec. 31 from March 31. Share earnings do not reflect a 4-for- 3 stock split to be paid July 15.

title: John Hammond, 76, Critic and Discoverer Of Pop Talent, Dies
description: John Hammond, a critic, talent scout and record producer whose musical discoveries ranged from Billie Holiday to Bob Dylan and who had an extraordinary influence upon the history of American popular music, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76 years old.

title: KEY RATES
Judge Rules in Lawsuit On Building of Tower
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the landmarks preservation law in New York was constitutional, but that he must review a refusal to permit construction of an office tower on the grounds of St. Bartholomew's Church.

title: New A.C.C. Chief?
description: Gene Corrigan, who had strong ties to the Atlantic Coast Conference before becoming athletic director at Notre Dame in 1981, will be named the commissioner of the A.C.C. next week, The Atlanta Journal reported yesterday, quoting a source close to Corrigan.

title: Correction
description: A dispatch on July 6 from Amherst, Mass., about the first national conference of the American Green movement included a misstatement of the movement's position in West Germany, attributed to Jutta Ditfurth, a spokeswoman for the party there.

title: NUCLEAR DATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $6,000. c-Net loss and includes a charge of $3,000,000 for asset restructuring. The company said the decline in sales is due to the company's decision to reduce the level of custom-made automation activity and to concentrate on specific projects of higher margin potential.

title: Louvre to Seek Private Backing in U.S.
description: The Louvre will seek American corporate and private financing to help complete a decade-long project to renovate the museum and upgrade its conservation and exhibition facilities, according to Emile G. Biasini, the French official in charge of the expansion project.

title: L.I. JITNEYS AND NEWCOMERS' PHONE PREFIXES
description: Walk down Main Street's neatly swept brick sidewalks here, under a canopy of elm trees, past an array of colorful boutiques, and the travails of the city seem light years away.

title: Cox Breaks Foot
description: The St. Louis Cardinals, front-runners despite a number of injuries to their pitching staff, received another jolt yesterday when they learned that Danny Cox, a right-hander, suffered a broken bone in his right foot. Brian Bartow, a team spokesman, said that X-rays revealed a fracture of a bone behind Cox's little toe. Cox suffered the injury Thursday night when he was hit by a line drive by Mike Aldrete in the seventh inning of a game against the San Francisco Giants.

title: Film: 'Nerds in Paradise,' a Sequel
description: If you've seen one nerd - a four-eyed, egg-headed individual with a plastic pencil holder in his breast pocket and a song in his heart - have you seen them all? That is the question loosely posed by ''Revenge of the Nerds II: Nerds in Paradise,'' which opened yesterday at the Movieland and other theaters. And the answer is probably no, since this film is at least slightly more varied than the average fraternity-boy comedy.

title: Yanks' Homers Knock Off Sox
description: Unlike one day earlier this season, Scott Nielsen wore socks to the ball park last night, but the Yankees knocked them off. Joel McKeon had his socks knocked off, too.

title: Trash Barge To End Trip In Brooklyn
description: The 112-day odyssey of the Mobro, the world's most famous garbage barge, appeared to be over today as New York City agreed to burn its load at an incinerator in Brooklyn.

title: Iranian Businessman Derides North's Story
description: The Iranian businessman who Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North said proposed the idea of diverting Iran arms profits to Nicaraguan insurgents during a 1986 encounter in a bathroom has called that testimony ''the best joke I have ever heard in my life.''

title: WORLD CONTAINER reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Chip Orders Dropped in June
description: Orders for semiconductors weakened in June from May levels, and the book-to-bill ratio, a key index of the health of the industry, suffered its first substantial decline since last summer.

title: The Senate Helps Trade, but Not Enough
description: The Senate has taken three steps forward and one backward on important amendments to its trade bill. The forward steps, sponsored by Senators Bradley and Gramm, give the President essential flexibility in dealing with import competition. The bipartisan step backward, co-sponsored by the Senate leaders, Robert Byrd and Bob Dole, waters down the House's Gephardt amendment but remains misguided.

title: Fall in Grape Crop Seen
description: The California wine grape crop will be 10 percent lower than last year, according to a State Agriculture Department forecast. The department estimated the statewide crop at 1.9 million tons, citing reduced production in most grape-growing regions. The 1.9 million tons estimated this year is the same tonnage California growers actually harvested in 1984. A spokesman said the lighter crop was generally because of the damaging heat spell during May, when grape vines were in the delicate bloom stage.

title: JUDGE IN TEACHERS' CASE SEES DRIFT FROM RESPECT
description: Judge Paul R. Huot is clearly surprised by all the fuss over his jail terms for 110 Lyndhurst teachers and other school workers who defied his order to end an illegal strike last March.

title: Rodriguez Seizes Senior Lead
description: ''If you wanted to do a script for this, you couldn't do much better for the final two rounds,'' Arnold Palmer said today after the second round of the United States Senior Open. He was two shots behind the leader, Chi Chi Rodriguez, and a shot behind Gary Player.

title: After Nixon and Reagan, Young Republicans Face '88 With Uncertainty
description: The hottest-selling shirt at the Young Republican national convention here depicts a smiling Richard M. Nixon. ''He's Tan, Rested and Ready,'' the shirt reads. ''Nixon in '88.'' The nearly 800 delegates who have gathered here for a three-day convention that started Thursday have hardly begun a Nixon Presidential drive. But many of the youthful Republicans make it plain that they were looking to the past with considerable wistfulness and facing the future with some uneasiness.

title: The Tables Turned, Iran Panel Bickers As North Is Praised
description: Each day, the members of the Iran-contra committee have watched the yellow stack of telegrams on Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's table grow higher and higher.

title: MOVE TOWARD MILK PRICE RISE
description: A group of farmers representing 95 percent of the Northeast's dairy producers voted today to establish a new minimum price for milk, a move expected to increase milk prices this fall by about six cents a gallon.

title: RSI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $107,000 and $737,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $60,000 and $23,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Share earnings are adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split paid March 1.

title: Sowell Airs Letter To Todd Shipyards
description: The Dallas investor James E. Sowell, who holds a 9.9 percent stake in the Todd Shipyards Corporation, has listed several alternatives that he said the Jersey City-based naval construction, repair and overhaul concern should pursue ''as soon as practical.'' The list was part of a July 7 letter to the board of the financially troubled concern. The letter was contained in a filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Tipton to Be Sold
description: Tipton Centers Inc. said it had agreed to be acquired by Dixons Group P.L.C., a British consumer electronics retailer, for $9.50 a share in cash, in a deal worth $30.4 million. The transaction was unanimously approved by the Tipton Centers board, the companies said. Tipton, which has undergone a major expansion, runs 18 brand-name discount stores in the Midwest. It earned $2 million in 1986, up from $1.7 million the previous year. Sales in 1986, at $64 million, were up from $48.2 million in 1985.

title: Divestment Plan Is Approved
description: The United Methodist Board of Pensions has approved a plan to sell holdings in companies that do business in South Africa.

title: 'We Were Not Breaking the Law'
description: At one point yesterday, Representative Ed Jenkins, Democrat of Georgia, had a heated exchange with Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North about the plans for a continuing fund. Here are parts of that exchange.

title: Henry E. Hasiwar, 70, Dies; Labor Adviser and Executive
description: Henry E. Hasiwar, a onetime organizer of farm workers who became an oil company official, died of cancer of the lung and liver Wednesday at Misericordia Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 70 years old and lived in Yonkers.

title: Rock: Petty's 'Caravan'
description: ''Rock-and-Roll Caravan,'' a touring triple bill headlined by Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers, pulled into Madison Square Garden on Wednesday. It was a distinctly old-fashioned concert, circa mid-1970's, with casual staging and guitar-driven, noncomputerized songs that looked back to Bob Dylan and the Rolling Stones.

title: ELI LILLY & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: William Halstead, 84, Stereo Radio Innovator
description: William S. Halstead, an inventor who was a pioneer in stereophonic broadcasting, died of pneumonia Tuesday at Canoga Park (Calif.) Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Woodland Hills, Calif., a Los Angeles suburb.

title: SENATORS BACK TRADE RETALIATION
description: The Senate today overwhelmingly approved a trade bill amendment designed to require the Administration to take action against countries, such as Japan, that consistently deny access to American products.

title: Pvt. Eddie Slovik's Remains Are Found in San Francisco
description: The remains of Pvt. Eddie Slovik, which were lost on their way from France and then found in San Francisco, headed home to Detroit today, more than four decades after his execution for desertion in World War II.

title: OLIVE E. ANDREWS
description: Olive E. Andrews, a former director of women's activities for the United Hospital Fund of New York, died Tuesday at the Bethel Nursing Home in Ossining, N.Y. She was 90 years old.

title: North's Methods: Calling Up the Memory of Teddy Roosevelt
description: As Lieut Col Oliver L. North testified for the fourth day yesterday, Arthur L. Liman the chief counsel for the Senate committee, questioned him about the circumstances and goals of the Iran negotiations, and about the actions of his superiors. Here are excerpts from the testimony, as recorded by The New York Times. HOSTAGE RISKS

title: Stieb's 4-Hitter Blanks Royals
description: Dave Stieb pitched a four-hitter, and George Bell hit his 29th homer and drove in two runs tonight as the Toronto Blue Jays shut out the Kansas City Royals, 7-0.

title: Alcoa Planning Big Write-Off
description: The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday that it would take a $165.7 million after-tax charge against earnings for the second quarter. As a result of the charge, the company said it would report a loss for the quarter.

title: TOTAL SYSTEM SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Dance: A Salute To the Hula
description: The American Dance Festival brought four Hawaiian dance companies to Page Auditorium of Duke University on Thursday night. Watching ''Dance Hawaii: A Salute to Classical Hawaiian Dance'' was like making a voyage of discovery.

title: Reagan Bruises His Eyelid
description: President Reagan bruised his lower left eyelid while removing a contact lens, his physician announced today. Photographers noticed the tiny red bump when the President appeared at a meeting at the Old Executive Office Building. To answer queries, the White House released a written statement by its physician, Army Col. John Hutton: ''While removing the contact lens from his left eye, the President created a slight, superficial contusion (bruise) to his lower eyelid. The inside of the lid and eye are totally normal.''

title: AIDS Fear Spawns Ethics Debate As Some Doctors Withhold Care
description: Dr. Terence M. Schmahl, a heart surgeon at a Milwaukee hospital, and his wife, Karen, an anesthesiologist at another hospital in the city, were both concerned about contracting AIDS from the people they see every day.

title: Bridge; At 19, Woman From Queens Holds Potential for Stardom
description: If, as some predict, a young woman from Queens becomes a star in the game she is doomed to be last in any expert listing that is done alphabetically.

title: Koreans Testing Democracy's Limits
description: With all the talk of democracy in the air, 17 nurses at a hospital in the city of Taegu staged an overnight sit-in last week. They demanded that the hospital reinstate several dismissed nurses, raise everybody's wages and operate a shuttle-bus service at night.

title: SOUTHEAST BANKING CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a special provision of $85 million for possible credit losses in developing countries, which brings the total reserve for credit losses to $193.6 million, or 2.53 percent of total loans outstanding June 30. c-Net income The company said its primary capital ratio was 8.08 percent at June 30.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
Demonic Cackle
description: LEAD: ROBIN WILLIAMS LIVE Vestron Video. 65 minutes. $59.98.

title: Move Over, Vanna
description: On Wednesday morning Lieutenant Colonel North's attorney, Brendan Sullivan, scolded the committee for its slow pace in examining his client. Unless it was sped up, he protested, the colonel would have to come back next week.

title: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31

Patents;
An Aircraft to Launch And Retrieve Planes
description: LEAD: A vertical takeoff and landing craft, designed to launch and retrieve another plane, was patented this week for the Grumman Corporation of Bethpage, L.I. Patent 4,678,141 was granted to August C. Sarrantonio, a flight control group leader on the staff.

title:
Patents;
Electricity From a Gas Furnace
description: LEAD: AN electricity-producing natural gas furnace is being patented by Frank E. Wicks, adjunct professor of nuclear engineering at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y. Patent 4,680,478 will be granted to Dr. Wicks next week, and he has applied for patents in various foreign countries.

title: Memo Details How a Frustrated Reagan Pondered Ways to Get Aid to the Contras
description: President Reagan told his national security adviser in May 1986 that he was so frustrated by Congressional refusal to approve contra aid that he wanted ''to figure out a way to take action unilaterally to provide assistance.''

title: Faeroe Islanders Seek Ouster Of a U.S. Warship on a Visit
description: The Faeroe Islands asked Denmark today to order a United States frigate out of the islands' waters after the ship's officers refused to say whether it carried nuclear weapons, the Danish state radio reported.

title: Spinoff Is Named By Hospital Corp.
description: The Hospital Corporation of America said that the spinoff company that would buy 104 it its hospitals under the company's $1.9 billion reorganization plan would be called Healthtrust Inc. The 104 hospitals, with a total of 13,844 beds, are being sold in 22 states to Healthtrust, which, like the Hospital Corporation, will be based here.

title: MIDLANTIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a special $30 million provision for loan losses in response to developments related to the debt situation of developing nations. Share earnings are fully diluted. Year-ago results are restated to include the earnings of Midlantic Banks Inc. and Continental Bancorp Inc., which became subsidiaries of Midlantic in January 1987.

title: TREASURY EASES ANTILLES TAX MOVE
description: In an effort to quell an unexpected uproar in the Eurobond markets, the Treasury Department tonight retreated from part of its decision to cancel tax treaties with the Netherlands Antilles and Aruba by acting to prevent companies from redeeming their bonds.

title: CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid June 2, 1987.

title: ABBOTT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TOO MUCH OF A BAD THING
description: Sports, having already established itself as the opiate of the masses, now seeks to become their constant companion.

title: Japan Car Cutback Seen
description: Japan's car industry will shrink by 2 percent over the next three years because cheaper vehicles made in the United States will take some of its export market, a spokesman for the Industrial Bank of Japan predicted today. The decline would cost Japan's economy about 30,000 jobs over the next three years, he said. The bank spokesman said Japanese car makers operating from American factories would be the main competition. Vehicles produced in the United States would take advantage of the lower dollar to export to markets dominated by Japan.

title: Let's Have No Censorship on New York's Air
description: To the Editor:

title: War Games
description: To the Editor:

title: ON WARDS I., CENTER OFFERS ADDICTS WAY TO KEEP CHILDREN
description: Last year, social workers told Cheryle Davis that the child she was carrying might be taken away from her at birth.

title: McEnroe on U.S. Team
description: John McEnroe, who missed Wimbledon with a bad back, will play with the United States Davis Cup team for the first time since 1984 in its crucial match with West Germany next month, the United States Tennis Association announced yesterday.

title: Books of The Times; Cheerless Affairs
description: MUM AND MR. ARMITAGE. By Beryl Bainbridge. 144 pages. McGraw-Hill Book Company. $15.95.

title: Satirist Paints Soviet Future
description: Vladimir Voinovich says he fixed on the name for his latest novel, ''Moscow 2042,'' by sitting back and trying to predict how long the Soviet state could be expected to survive.

title: Tiffany in Munich
description: Tiffany & Company, the 150-year-old jewelry retailer, said that it would open its second European shop later this year in Munich, West Germany. Tiffany, with eight stores in the United States, opened a shop in London in September 1986 and plans more stores in major European cities.

title: Three Police Officers Slain In Siege at Michigan Motel
description: Three police officers were found shot to death before dawn today, about 10 hours after they were taken hostage by four heavily armed people in a motel here, the authorities said.

title: OF BEARS, BULLS AND BODY-BUILDERS
description: It was lunch time in lower Manhattan and seven Wall Street workers shed their shirts to the whistles, hoots and applause of an animated crowd yesterday.

title: SOLITRON DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JULY 11, 1987
description: International 2-8 2,,q>Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testified that William J. Casey, as Director of Central Intelligence, wanted to establish a ''stand alone'' fund that could pay for intelligence operations outside normal government control. Page 1 Americans believe Colonel North by an overwhelming margin. A New York Times/CBS News Poll found that most Americans say they believe that he is telling the truth about the Iran-contra affair and that President Reagan is lying. 1 Legislators erupted in frustration and anger, lashing out at their own lawyers and sniping at each other, as the popularity of Colonel North has grown and the Congressmen have been cast as the villains. 1 The duel between the lawyers at the Iran-contra hearings is part courtroom drama, part theater and part genuine exposition of the facts, all of which has attracted the interest of legal experts. 8 The special prosecutor's authority to investigate the Iran-contra affair and to enforce a grand jury subpoena against Colonel North was upheld by a Federal Judge. 8 Support and cash for Colonel North are pouring in from across the country.
