Contributions to his defense fund continue to mount, and money is also flowing to Colonel North's favorite cause: the contras in Nicaragua. 5 Contacts between Moscow and Bonn may grow after the six-day visit to the Soviet Union by the West German President, Richard von Weizsacker, West German officials and Western diplomats said. 3 Moscow has slowed arms talks and preparations for a summit meeting, the Administration said. But officialssaid they did not believe the slowdown threatened a new arms-control agreement on medium- and short-range missiles. 3 Military links with Cambodia by the Vietnamese will be kept even if Vietnam adheres to its announced intention to withdraw its troops in 1990, a Communist diplomat in close touch with Vietnam's views suggested. 2 South Koreans' demands have grown as they test the limits of democracy. But the demands may be more than President Chun Doo Hwan bargained for when he accepted a democratization package, and the military's patience may be wearing thin. 3 A trade measure was approved by the Senate that is designed to require the Administration to take action against countries, such as Japan, that consistently deny access to American products. 39 Thais say Laos turns to marijuana to aid budget 2 U.N. group meets amid anxiety 2 Asuncion journal 4 Unions a nonissue in Australian vote 4 Sagging economy affects New Zealand election 4 A Haiti vacation ends in a plane crash 4 National 10-12, 32 2,4.4,q>The Producer Price Index rose two-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Government said. It was the second small advance in as many months, and it continued to allay fears that the inflation rate was about to jump. 1 After two jets nearly collided over the Atlantic Ocean on Wednesday, suggestions were made by radio to the crew of a Continental Airlines jumbo jet that they refrain from reporting the incident, officials said. 1 Alan Greenspan will avoid decisions that affect J.P. Morgan & Company if he is named chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, according to a document he has submitted to the White House and Congress. 1 Some doctors require AIDS tests of their patients and are refusing to care for carriers of the virus. The medical community is divided in a debate over whether this is in keeping with the profession's ethical responsibilities. 1 A landlord will live with vermin for 30 days in an infested apartment building for failing to improve conditions in four buildings he owned. The Beverly Hills neurosurgeon will begin serving his sentence on Monday. 10 Officials violated free-speech rights of protesters at a public ceremony on the Mall in Philadelphia honoring the Constitution's bicentennial last May 25, a Federal judge ruled. 10 At the Young Republican convention, the nearly 800 delegates who have gathered make it plain that they are looking to the past with considerable wistfulness, and facing the future with some uneasiness. 11 The campaign for women's votes by the Democratic Presidential candidates is markedly different from that of their counterparts in 1984, and has stirred complaints from some women that feminism is being neglected by the party. 10 Heart disease and physical inactivity may have a link as strong as the links between heart disease and smoking or high blood pressure, Federal health officials said, following a two-year analysis. 10 3 police officers slain in Michigan 11 U.S. restricts satellite licenses 11 Dukakis approves AIDS testing 12 5 workers killed in fall at San Diego shipyard 12 Judge withdraws as candidate to head F.B.I. 32 Regional 33-36 2,3.2,q>People who are arrested face delays as New York City shuffles them from one criminal justice location to another. The toll of the process, which a Federal judge has ruled must be quicker, is paid by prisoners. 33 A garbage barge's odyssey is ending. New York City agreed to burn its 3,100-ton load from the barge at an incinerator in Brooklyn. 33 News analysis: The court decision about a state statute designed to protect journalists' sources and materials from subpoena offered a glimpse into how judges can make new law by interpreting statutes in ways that legislators never intended. 35 A drug treatment center for parents allows them to live with their children while they complete a program of counseling, group therapy and peer support. The center, Odyssey House, is on Wards Island. 33 Pushing to end the legislative session in Albany, state lawmakers reached agreement on a renewal of New York City's J-51 real estate tax abatement program, state economic development initiatives, and a range of other issues. 35 A judge who gave teachers jail terms for defying his order to end an illegal strike is surprised by the fuss about the sentences. Judge Paul R. Huot sentenced 110 Lyndhurst teachers and other school workers to jail. 34 Competing to be ''Mr. Wall Street,'' seven businessmen strutted and flexed in a body-building contest at Pier 11 near the South Street Seaport in lower Manhattan. 35 The talk of the Hamptons 33 Cyclists fault limited use of bridge 34 Move toward milk price rise 35 New York bills affecting citizens 35

title: North Testimony to Be Book
description: Pocket Books said yesterday that it would publish the testimony of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North within a week after he completes his appearance before the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair. Titled ''Taking the Stand,'' the mass-market paperback book will sell for $5.50. A minimum first printing of half a million copies has been scheduled.

title: CHARLES KING JR.
description: Charles King Jr., a corporate executive and management consultant, died of cancer Wednesday in Norwalk Hospital, Norwalk, Conn. A resident of Wilton, Conn., he was 67 years old.

title: It's Official, It's Cheap, It's Smuggled
description: On the narrow sidewalks of Palma Street, near the brightly uniformed soldiers who guard Paraguay's Pantheon of Heroes, about 30 young men try to catch the eye of passers-by with the glitter of their bargains - Rolex, Cartier and Omega watches that are all cheap because they are fakes.

title: OLD KENT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Net for 1986 is restated to reflect the acquisition, on a pooling of interests basis, of American National Holding Co. in July 1986.

title: Judge Withdraws as Candidate to Head F.B.I.
description: Adding to the list of candidates who have turned down the job, a Federal appeals judge from South Carolina withdrew his name from consideration as head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Music: Wind Instruments At Festival
description: Two summers ago, the Mostly Mozart Festival presented a ''Wind Spectacular'' that culminated in a grandiose performance of Handel's ''Royal Fireworks'' Music in one of its original orchestrations, with 24 oboes and a proportional number of other instruments. Thursday night, before an appreciative, sold-out Avery Fisher Hall, the festival repeated the idea with a wind program that again wound up with this sweetly elephantine statement of Handel's score.

title: Lack of Exercise Is Linked to Heart Disease
description: The link between heart disease and physical inactivity may be as strong as the links between heart disease and smoking or high blood pressure, Federal health officials said Thursday.

description: To the Editor:

title: ANYBODY HOME?
description: SPHERE By Michael Crichton. 385 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: HOTEL ASSOCIATION URGES CONCESSIONS IN NEW ROOM TAX
description: LEAD: AFTER five years of resistance, the county's hotel industry is preparing to deal with a room surtax. But industry leaders have not abandoned the hope that they can have a say in what form the new tax will take, and they would also like to secure some of the additional revenue for uses that help the industry.

title: Boxing Scoring
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'ALL MY SONS' IN WESTPORT
description: THE Westport Country Playhouse is now running plays for two weeks instead of one.

description: To the Editor:

title: Street Fashion; Hot Dots: The Dress That's Everywhere At Once
description: CALL it the Lunch Dress: it's seen most frequently on elegant women rushing to their midday appointments at one or another of New York City's best restaurants.

title: Mountains And Mystique
description: The reduction of one of our planet's more awesome natural wonders to something less than what it is began long before this recent attempt at geological emasculation so cogently described by Malcolm W. Browne (''Can You Top This?'' June 14). It was in 1863 that the (then) world's highest mountain was renamed by the British for one of their own, Sir George Everest, probably as a too generous reward for a lifetime of service in mapping the Empire. Sir George, after all, was merely a surveyor.

description: That Petrol Emotion: 'Babble' Polydor 833 132-1 Y-1; LP and cassette

title: Cambodia Reported Ready to Repatriate Refugees
description: A senior Government minister has declared that Cambodia is ready in principle to take back the bulk of the 275,000 Cambodians who have sought refuge in Thailand since the Vietnamese invasion of 1979.

title: ONLY ANKLE DEEP IN ADVENTURE
description: SOMETIMES EVEN FILMS ABOUT adventure, about discovery, about wondrous technological triumphs have a way of seeming small. It's a function of the particular universe that is being explored. If that universe is effectively no larger than, say, a suburban backyard, there isn't much to be unearthed no matter how energetic the digging. A film about a wild, mysterious creature from parts unknown cannot have much magic if all the creature (Harry) wants is to go home with an all-American family (the Hendersons), raid the refrigerator and lounge in the easy chair.

title: EUROPE MAINTAINS THE HIGH STANDARDS OF HI-FI
description: A EUROPEAN VACATION turned into a busman's holiday when it afforded opportunities to tune in on the audio scene in England and the Netherlands - two countries that have long been bastions of high fidelity.

title: Comings and Goings
description: THE Cleveland Cavaliers plan to fight attempts to void a draft-day trade that sent Keith Lee, a forward with the Cavaliers, to the Portland Trail Blazers for Jim Paxson, a guard. The deal reportedly was contingent on Lee's passing a physical examination administered by the Portland team doctor, and the Blazers contend that it's no deal since the condition of Lee's knees endangers his playing career. . . . The San Francisco Giants placed Bob Melvin, their first-string catcher, on the 15-day disabled list after he suffered a sprained right ankle in Friday night's loss to the Cardinals. Melvin collided with Jack Clark on a force play at home plate. . . Gary Matthews, a 37-year-old outfielder, has been traded to the Seattle Mariners by the Chicago Cubs for a minor leaguer to be named. He has 231 homers in 14 seasons. . . . Dr. D. Alan Williams, president of the Atlantic Coast Conference, has confirmed that Gene Corrigan, the athletic director at Notre Dame since 1981, would be recommended as the conference's new commissioner. Corrigan said he would serve in the post.

title:
FOOD;
A DIFFERENT BARBECUE
description: LEAD: PUNGENT AROMAS rising from the grill.

title: BRITISH THEATER'S CHANGING OF THE GUARD
description: WHILE NEW YORK THEA-TERGOERS were busy decrying the Anglicization of Broadway this spring, the London theater flew into a panic over the specter of ruthless Broadway-style economics in the West End. For the first time since World War II, four neighboring straight-play houses on Shaftesbury Avenue were bereft of tenants. This is the kind of theatrical vacuum one expects to find on West 45th Street, but not near Piccadilly Circus, where even plays with poor reviews and large casts have been known to linger for an entire season. Was London at last succumbing to the hit-or-flop mentality of the Great White Way? Were the megabuck musical spectaculars driving away serious drama, much as has happened in New York's commercial theater? Were costs and ticket prices spiraling out of control?

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in The Times Magazine last Sunday, ''Pop Fiction for Smart Girls'' by Rae Lawrence, described the writer's effort to have her first novel published while she worked as a secretary. When she began the novel, she had been employed for four years in that capacity at a real estate firm. The article left the impression that Ms. Lawrence had had no previous literary experience and was unfamiliar with literary matters. In fact her article manuscript originally mentioned that she had literary connections, which were unspecified.

title: On the Volga, Winter Is Far From the Mind
description: Soviet pop music poured from the open door of a parked bus and spilled over the mounds of construction sand that had become a temporary beach beside the Volga River.

title: Tampering With Art Is Hollywood's Art
description: To the Editor:

description: LEAD: PLAYGROUNDS. By Alan Gelb. (Putnam, $19.95.) Returning to the scene of his first novel, ''Columbus Avenue,'' Alan Gelb has located his third novel in and around a day care center on Manhattan's Upper West Side. ''This place is like a net,'' the woman who runs it explains to her newest recruit. ''We all form connections, and these connections .

title: Directors' Strike Called for NBC And 2 Studios
description: The 8,400-member Directors Guild of America said today it would begin a strike Tuesday morning against NBC, Warner Brothers and Columbia Pictures.

title: And Baby Makes Five Billion: U.N. Hails a Yugoslav Infant
description: The United Nations proclaimed an eight-pound boy born today as the five billionth human now living on the planet and began celebrations to welcome the baby, Matej Gaspar.

title: Dealing With a Hazard: Asbestos Guide
description: Given the growing concern - and confusion - over the best way to deal with the presence of asbestos in some 733,000 buildings nationwide, a publication put out by the National Institute of Building Sciences, called ''Model Guide Specifications: Asbestos Abatement in Buildings,'' might offer some assistance. The manual addresses the various approaches to dealing with asbestos, from maintenance and repair to removal.

title:
If You're Thinking of Living in:;
MARLBORO
description: LEAD: THE Township Hall in Marlboro is a large barnlike building recast from the original, which was used when this central New Jersey community was pure farm country.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: A LOOK AT WUSHU Wushu is the word for martial arts that are indigenous to China, and its most proficient American practitioner is probably Mark Salzman, who will give a demonstration at 7:30 P.M. Wednesday in the auditorium of the Yale Art Gallery on Chapel Street in New Haven.

title: PANAMANIANS PROMISE MORE PROTESTS
description: Opposition leaders today vowed to continue increasing their protests against Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, whose police resorted to tear gas and buckshot on Friday to reassert his authority.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: CRAFTS ON SOCIETY HILL

title: Classical Music
description: Mostly Mozart is in full swing this week, offering another encounter with Helmuth Rilling conducting Bach for those who liked (or missed) his Easter performances at Carnegie Hall. He leads the B Minor Mass with a good solo quartet Friday and Saturday at Avery Fisher Hall. Earlier, Tuesday and Wednesday, Frank Peter Zimmermann will play Mendelssohn's ''other'' violin concerto, the youthful one in D minor.

title: CIGARETTES ROLLED FROM THE BIBLE
description: TOWN SMOKES By Pinckney Benedict. 168 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Ontario Review Press/Persea. Paper, $9.95.

title: WHAT'S LEFT OUT OF LITERATURE
description: READERS of the essays in The Book Review have been recently familiarized, whether they like it or not, with the old debate on whether less is, in fact, more. Like so much literary debate, it is most interesting for what it deflects. That is to say, it is very American, and very contemporary, to see this as an esthetic issue, refusing to consider literature as taking place in a larger social and cultural framework, of literature having reference at all. (Am I alone, in reading the reviews in these pages, in feeling that the fiction - and social, political, and cultural nonfiction - seems not to be written by contemporaries in different genres, but by people from different planets? And more, that it seems a mark of intellectual distinction never to review the fiction in the context of the culture?) What happens then, if we ask the question: if this modern American fiction is so ''realistic,'' then what is it saying about the American reality to which it refers?

title: Don't Count Out Conservatism
description: If Irving Kristol is so sure that ''the basic conservative trend will persist,'' why does he see the need to advocate that it is ''time . . . to strike a bargain'' (''Don't Count Out Conservatism,'' June 14)? Methinks Mr. Kristol is whistling in the dark, trying to rally his ''new breed of conservative activists'' - his ''Force'' - before they lose whatever bargaining strength they may still possess. WALTER A. SHELDON Lido Beach, L.I.

title: How High 'Up the Line' Did the Memos Go?
description: WHEN Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North leaves the witness table this week, his place will be taken by Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser and the man Senator Warren Rudman of New Hampshire, a Reagan loyalist but one of the Iran-contra hearings' toughest questioners, expects to be ''by far the most single important witness.''

title: LURED BY THE MASTER
description: LEAD: THE FAMILY MASHBER By Der Nister. Translated by Leonard Wolf. 688 pp. New York: Summit Books. $22.95.

title: NOT WHAT THEY EXPECTED
description: SUMMERTIME By Maureen McCoy. 300 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $15.95.

title: Growing Up With Privilege and Prejudice
description: Karen Russell's article proves that she is aware of the problems still facing America today. Many black students on Ivy League campuses are oblivious to institutional racism. What about the decline in black enrollment at Ivy League law schools and in the numbers of black professors who are hired? Many students seem unaware of the long-range implications of these setbacks for blacks.

title: SAN FRANCISCO
description: New hotels are looming all along the San Francisco skyline. Two major hotels are scheduled to open soon, a third opened in May, five more are under construction, and a 388-room tower is being added to the San Francisco Hilton, the city's largest hotel.

title: TRUTH WAS THE LAST STRAW
description: CAUSE AT HEART A Former Communist Remembers. By Junius Irving Scales and Richard Nickson. Foreword by Telford Taylor. 427 pp. Athens: The University of Georgia Press. $24.95.

title: CONCERN TO SELL SOVIET MACHINES IN U.S.
description: RUSSIA Inc.? While it is generally acknowledged that the Soviet Union has a long way to go before it outsells the Japanese on world markets, observers say the the Soviet Union will begin producing goods for export in earnest during the next decade. The Soviet Union has already announced its plans to enter the United States automobile market in 1991 with its new compact car, Moskvich 2141, and next month a concern in Ardsley, the Earthworm Tractor Company, will become, it says, the first American company to sell Soviet-made construction equipment in the United States.

title: 40 Hurt as Circus Tent Collapses on Audience
description: A circus tent, battered by wind gusts, collapsed during a performance near here today, injuring about 40 people.

title: CHOOSING A CONTRACT
description: A SINGLE bridge deal is rather like archery: From a choice of possible targets you must select the easiest, and then you must contrive to hit it. Both stages of the effort may be difficult: Several targets may seem equally attractive, or unattractive.

title: At the Courthouse, the Barber Shop and the Drugstore, They're With North   In Alabama, Pride is Undisguised
description: Down at the Calhoun County courthouse, Charles F. Fuller, the chairman of the county commission, said he did not have much doubt about the way people here feel about Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North.

title: EROS MAKES WAR By Isabel Allende. Translated by Margaret Sayers Peden. 274 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.    FEW literary legends can compare to that surrounding ''The House of the Spirits,'' Isabel Allende's family-chronicle-cum-history of her native Chile. Her very first novel, published when she was in her early 40's, rose to best-sellerdom. Reviewers were indulgent. Here was a beautiful, humane, talented woman who happened to be the exiled niece of the martyred Chilean President Salvador Allende. The troublesome secret was that in prose and format the book was mostly imitation Garcia Marquez.   Happily, Ms. Allende is no longer the novice in ''Of Love and Shadows,'' a suspenseful thriller. Set in the terrorized Chile of Gen. Augusto Pinochet (himself an occasional character), it tells of the love that grows between Irene Beltran - feisty, innocent, marginally upper-class and a reporter for a women's magazine - and Francisco Leal, son of impoverished Spanish Republican exiles, an unemployed psychologist and sometime political activist who casually drifts into Irene's office as a freelance photographer. Together they cover a variety of beats, but something clicks when they start investigating Evangelina, a 15-year-old peasant girl and fabled miracle worker. During a brutal army search of her family's house, Evangelina, in a trance, singlehandedly lifts up a cruel lieutenant and hurls him out the door.   Soon thereafter Evangelina ''disappears''; through journalistic tips and footwork the hero and heroine locate the girl's corpse in an abandoned mine shaft, where bodies of dozens of the regime's opponents are also decaying. Francisco takes photos; word spreads; a scandal ensues. Then someone sprays Irene with bullets from a passing car. She survives in the hospital but is obviously marked for Government liquidation. With help from friends she and Francisco assume disguises, quietly flee Santiago and cross the Andes into Argentina, ready to fight the dictatorship from exile. ''We will return,'' they say. LOVE and struggle a la ''Casablanca'' - it's all there. Ms. Allende skillfully evokes both the terrors of daily life under military rule and the subtler forms of resistance in the hidden corners and ''shadows'' of her title, particularly in the churches or in simple unsung acts of solidarity. At the same time the author ably captures the voices of the regime's apologists - the complex lies and cliches of its proud male foot soldiers and the pat false phrases of its rich lady cheerleaders. A journalist herself, Ms. Allende renders with expert detail such offbeat worlds as the professional routines of a hairdresser, the range of types in a private nursing home or the operations of the Santiago city morgue. While her prose at times verges on soap opera, that is also one of its charms. She can just as deftly depict loving tenderness as convey the high fire of eroticism. And when you've successfully mingled sex and politics with a noble cause, how can you go wrong?   While the translation by Margaret Sayers Peden is at times awkward (for example, ''pythoness'' and ''chiromancy'' instead of ''fortune teller'' and ''palmistry'') and could use more colloqualisms and contractions, on the whole it's a supple piece of work.
description: OF LOVE AND SHADOWS

title: CORRECTION
description: An Associated Press dispatch last Sunday from Kinshasa, Zaire, about a train wreck in Zaire that killed 125 people omitted mention of a higher toll in a previous African train accident. At least 392 people were reported killed when a train plunged from a bridge in Ethiopia on Jan. 14, 1985.

title: CATHERINE HAMERSLEY WEDS
description: Catherine Van Kleeck Hamersley, the daughter of L.Gordon Hamersley of Southampton, L.I., and the late Elsey Van Kleeck Hamersley, was married yesterday to Mark David Helman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving J. Helman of Brookline, Mass. Annette Bellanti, a justice of the peace, performed the ceremony at the Endicott Estate in Dedham, Mass. Mr. Hamersley is a vice president of Douglas Elliman-Gibbons & Ives, a real-estate concern in Southampton. The bridegroom's father is a senior partner in the Boston law firm of Nutter, McClennen & Fish.

title:
DINING OUT;
THAI DISHES IN NEW ROCHELLE
description: LEAD: THOSE diners who have a mind to can still order, from Little Caesar's all but abandoned Continental menu, such items as escargots, clam casino, pasta dishes, duck with fruit sauce and veal cutlet, but they would be missing the better part of what this kitchen has to offer, the sprightly flavors of Thailand.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
THE OTHER SIDE OF THE EYE
description: LEAD: On the eve of the 20th century, the Norwegian artist Edvard Munch abandoned Impressionism and began making Expressionist woodcuts whose raw portrayal of anxiety was an accurate announcement of the new era. He depicted the human encounter - lovemaking, separation, suffering - in autobiographical images informed by what he called ''inner visions of the soul'' from ''the other side of the eye.

title:
ABOUT LONG ISLAND;
WASHINGTON SLEPT NEAR HERE
description: LEAD: THE more you think you know about any Long Island community, the better your chances are of a sudden second opinion. It can be the difference between day and night, and that is exactly what happened to me here.

title: ADVERSITY IS JUST AROUND THE CORNER
description: THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990 By Ravi Batra. 235 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: RANDI GOLDBERG TO WED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Goldberg of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Randi Sue Goldberg, to Steven Fredric Wasserman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Wasserman of Baldwin, L.I. Ms. Goldberg graduated last month from the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University and is to join the New York law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae in the fall as an associate. Her fiance, an associate at the New York law firm of Hartley T. Bernstein, also graduated from Cardozo.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: WINDHAM HILL CONCERT ''Mood music for the '80's'' is the phrase frequently applied to the records produced by Windham Hill Recording Artists. William Ackerman, steel-string guitarist and founder of the California record company, and Philip Aaberg, keyboard artist and composer whose work is recorded by Windham Hill, will make their only New York appearance at the Tarrytown Music Hall at 8 P.M. Saturday. Mr. Aaberg's contemporary perspective has been tempered by a rich background in classical music. He won a Leonard Bernstein scholarship to Harvard University and studied with Pablo Casals and Rudolph Serkin before embarking on a career in the music of the future. He describes the classical-contemporary duality of his music as ''part of a wave which is blurring the lines between so-called serious music and worldwide popular music.''

title: 3 FAIRS ON DEVOTEES' AGENDA
description: AMONG the perennial events on this month's crafts calendar are a number of weekend fairs both in New Jersey and within easy reach in Manhattan.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Company giving has to be related to the company's interests; not be a gift to the ballet because my wife likes ballet.''

title: SARAH CHUBB HAS WEDDING
description: At the Episcopal Church of St. John-on-the-Mountain in Bernardsville, N.J., yesterday, Sarah Caldecot Chubb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Chubb 3d of Bernardsville, was married to Pascal Emile Sauvayre, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Georges Sauvayre of Milan, Italy, and Montpellier, France.

title: Realignment for Bronx Democrats
description: Bronx Democrats, more a coalition than an organization, are split again, this time over the party's nominee for borough surrogate. Borough President Fernando Ferrer last week endorsed Judge Hansel McGee of Civil Court, the only black among four primary candidates, while the Bronx Democratic leader, Assemblyman George Friedman, has withdrawn his backing of the judge in favor of a newcomer.

title: Talking: Exteriors; Keeping A Home In Shape
description: THE exterior of a property - whether condominium, co-op or single-family house - is both image and protection. It makes the initial statement about that home, an impact brokers call curb appeal.

title: LAWS, PROCEDURES HELP GENERIC SALES
description: LEAD: WHILE the relatively low cost of generic drugs is giving Long Island's generic drug industry its greatest boost, other factors also are contributing to its well-being.

title: Las Vegas
description: To the Editor: We have just caught Kelly Davis's letter (Travel, May 24) and would like to point out one error: Las Vegas was not ''founded by merchants eager to profit from the trade streaming into the area via the Santa Fe Trail'' but first by the genizaros (Christianized Indians) from San Miguel del Bado on the Pecos River (about 25 miles from Las Vegas, N.M.), followed by several groups of colonial Hispanic settlers, who farmed and grazed their livestock on the Las Vegas Land Grant (which still exists). Many of the incoming Trail merchants lingered in the community, and along with some of the local people built up a major Victorian mercantile and residential treasure trove of architecture, which is being beautifully restored.

title: Fishing Lure Brings $9,240
description: Some fishing lures just catch fish, but the Haskell minnow lure has hooked a buyer who spent a record $9,240 to own the 4 1/2-inch, silver-plated copper device. The sale, at an antique fishing tackle auction here, broke the old record of $5,500 for a fishing lure. Robert S. Lang of Windsor, Conn., who helped set up the auction, said the lure, patented in 1859, probably sold for 50 cents when new.

title: PAY RAISES VOTED AS BITTER SESSION CLOSES IN ALBANY
description: Ending one of its most contentious periods in years, the New York State Legislature concluded its 1987 session at 5:51 this morning, passing a host of last-minute bills that ranged from a 33 percent pay increase for legislators to a restructuring of the state's economic development programs.

title: What Is to Be Done About the Bork Nomination; Conservatives, Wake!
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTH POPULARITY WON'T CURB PANEL, LEGISLATORS SAY
description: Members of the Congressional select committees say the favorable public reaction to Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's testimony does not lessen their determination to conduct an aggressive investigation into his activities and the Reagan Administration's policies on Iran and Nicaragua.

title: HOW BEAUTIFUL WAS HELEN OF TROY? WHAT HOMER NEVER TOLD US
description: LEAD: PICTURE, if you will, Jay Gatsby. Some friends to whom I put this request remembered Gatsby as being of average height and build, with brown hair and angular features. Others thought he was tall, broad-shouldered, with dark hair and a broken nose. Then again, he was on the short side, fair, slightly effeminate.

title: Fueled, Funded For a Record
description: For years, the father-and-daughter team of Dick and Kim LaHaie was a curiosity in the split-second world of professional drag racing - a shoestring operation competing head to head with million-dollar teams in a sport where poor guys usually go home early.

title: Missing Dolly
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTING
description: ANALYSTS who monitor stock purchases and sales by corporate insiders have been reporting levels of insider bullishness in recent weeks that in the past have often preceded major market upswings. The readings surprise some analysts, who note that insider buying tends to be heaviest around market lows, rather than after large advances. Since January, the Dow Jones industrial average has climbed more than 29 percent.

title: WATER, WATER ...
description: WATER. In spite of recent thunderstorms, the ground is dry. Containers such as patio planters, wooden tubs, troughs and window boxes need attention; also check soil around young shrubs, new perennials, flower beds and vegetables. Mulch after the ground is soaked. Use water-soluble fertilizers for tomatoes, peppers, eggplants, annuals and perennial divisions; nutrients dissolve quickly in water and are absorbed immediately by plants. Astilbes

QUEENS Maspeth $257,000 53-18 66th Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, brick, attached house; dining area, finished basement, common driveway, 18- by 90-ft. lot; taxes $1,255 (Broker: Century 21/ Metalios Real Estate) Springfield Gardens $119,000 183-20 145th Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family Cape Cod; large kitchen, den, finished basement, 1-car garage, 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $720 (Broker:

title: Making Safer Sex Safer
description: Much to its credit, the Food and Drug Administration is taking condoms seriously. The agency has embarked on a campaign of increased inspection and testing. Since April it has intercepted 15 shipments of defective condoms from Korea and four from Malaysia, and has sent letters to U.S. manufacturers asking them to focus attention on quality control.

title: A CROWDED SOUND CAUSES SAFETY FEARS
description: LONG ISLAND SOUND, a rich natural resource surrounded by a dense and rising population, is becoming too popular for some of its devotees' own good.

title: CHILDREN
description: Fables and Legends: Aesop's Fables, Volume One MCA Home Video. 30 minutes. $14.95. The idea here is to pretend that a group of children are lolling around a campfire while adults entertain them by reciting some of Aesop's legendary fables. We move from the reality of the woodsy scene to the animation of the stories - ''The Wolf in Sheep's Clothing,'' ''The Goose That Laid the Golden Egg,'' ''The Dog in the Manger'' and so on. Unfortunately, the approach doesn't work. The framing device comes across as contrived and artificial, the animated portions are presented with overly forced and saccharine expression, and the undistinguished music and visual imagery do nothing to enhance the stories. Having the adults repeat each fable's moral at the story's end is unbearably preachy and cloying, and the young listeners don't look as if they're having very much fun; the only time they seem to perk up is when somebody suggests breaking out the marshmallows.

title: Uneasy Umpire
description: THE National League umpire Billy Williams, who suffered a broken leg while calling a play at home plate last week, said he felt a little out of place sitting in a chair this time of year. ''Normally, I work seven days a week,'' Williams said. ''I work seven or more games, depending on if I work doubleheaders.''

title: Q AND A
description: University Tenant

title: SHORTAGES OF DORMS CONFRONT COLLEGES
description: COLLEGES throughout the state are scrambling to find ways to meet a housing shortage next fall, when students return to campus.

title: Music: Marilyn Horne in 'Orfeo edridice'and 'Orlando Furioso' Excerpts
description: MARILYN HORNE, who has been fighting a bad cold, canceled her scheduled Mostly Mozart appearance Tuesday and - so said a friend of the singer - nearly canceled Friday night's concert of Vivaldi and Gluck. This is reported for the edification of those who were present, who will have been congratulating themselves for catching Miss Horne at the very top of her form. She sang superbly, inimitably. Other singers should get so sick.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN ZOOS
description: IT is still the same ingredients - tigers and giraffes, hot dogs, sunshine and, with any luck, some penguins - that make up an ideal afternoon at the zoo. But the hot dogs may be free now, part of a new marketing ploy, and information about the sun may be plugged into a computer program for future attendance analyses. Even the penguins are doing something new: In San Francisco, if you are a special contributor to the zoo, they may join you for brunch.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE COLONEL'S DAUGHTER: And Other Stories, by Rose Tremain. (Owl/Holt, $7.95.) On the surface portraits of British decorum, Rose Tremain's characters harbor ''feelings of jealousy, anger, vengeance and loss, emotions so intense they constantly threaten to break through to the surface,'' Caryn James said in The Book Review in 1984. ''These may look like Barbara Pym people, but they are bitter from years of keeping a stiff upper lip. . . . Always there is a sense of impending psychic violence; this tension . . . gives the stories their originality and power.'' HOME: A Short History of an Idea, by Witold Rybczynski. (Penguin, $7.95.) This widely praised study of com-fort and domesticity and their meaning in our lives treats such subjects as intimacy and privacy, cleanliness, light and air, efficiency, style and substance. The author's ''defense of common comfort is a good one,'' William H. Gass said here last year, ''for between the polemical beginning and ending of his argument there is a book of great interest and instruction. . . . He tells the story of the development of the private dwelling from house to home, and he does it in a sensitive and balanced way.'' And he ''is particularly good at describing the effects . . . of invention - whether water closet, gas jet, electric lamp, window sash or whatever.'' SELECTED STORIES, by Robert Walser. Translated by Christopher Middleton and others. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $8.95.) These tales by the Swiss-born Robert Walser (1878-1956), who spent some 27 years in mental institutions, are ''to be read slowly and savored,'' Ronald De Feo said here in 1982, for they make up a volume, by a ''self-styled exile,'' that is ''filled with lovely and disturbing moments that will stay with the reader for some time to come.'' ENTRANCES: An American Director's Journey, by Alan Schneider. (Limelight, $17.95.) This posthumously published memoir by the theatrical director Alan Schneider (1917-84) is an ''outstandingly valuable, extremely well-written and excitingly readable autobiography,'' our reviewer, Martin Esslin, said last year. Schneider was most closely associated with the works of Edward Albee, Harold Pinter and especially Samuel Beckett (a memorable episode is Schneider's account of the doomed American premiere of ''Waiting for Godot,'' which opened in Miami, billed as ''the laugh sensation of two continents,'' starring Bert Lahr and Tom Ewell). SATURDAY NIGHT AT SAN MARCOS, by William Packard. (Grove, $7.95.) William Packard's novel, a satire on the world of writers' conferences, is fast and fun, portraying the writing industry with ''a sharp yet loving bite,'' Regina Weinreich said in The Book Review in 1986. ''Picture the pace of Jack Kerouac's 'On the Road' plus caricature worthy of Portnoy.'' ANATOMY OF A JURY, by Seymour Wishman. (Penguin, $6.95.) Seymour Wishman, in his study of the workings of the jury in our criminal-justice system, weaves ''information and statistics about the history, psychology and sociology of the jury into an often compelling narrative about a murder trial,'' Carol E. Rinzler said in these pages last year. LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $3.95.) The hero of this contemporary adventure thriller by Louis L'Amour is an American Indian test pilot who is downed in Siberia and captured by the Russians. The author ''brings the same colorful realism to this sweeping adventure that has made his westerns so beloved,'' one reviewer said last year. RAIN OR SHINE, by Cyra McFadden. (Vintage, $4.95.) Cyra McFadden's book is a reminiscence of her parents - her father, Cy Taillon, the dean of rodeo announcers, and her mother, Pat, a vaudeville dancer and trick rider. It amounts to a ''spare-parts monument to life in the West,'' Thomas McGuane said here in 1986. ONE TO COUNT CADENCE, by James Crumley. (Vintage, $5.95.) Set in the Philippines and Vietnam in 1962, James Crumley's novel has as its hero Slag Krummel, the new sergeant of a rough company of enlistees. The author ''has a faultless ear for filthy speech,'' David Dempsey said here in 1969. He found the book ''a compelling study of the gratuitous violence in men - and how it is unleashed by the frustrations of military life. It is a story of bars, brawls and brothels - and I don't know of any writer who has done it better.'' ISAK DINESEN: The Life of a Storyteller, by Judith Thurman. (St. Martin's, $9.95.) This life of Karen Blixen, the writer Isak Dinesen, is ''a fine achievement,'' Margaret Drabble said in these pages in 1982. ''Well researched, sympathetic, fair and imaginative, it tells the story of an enigmatic and at times infuriating woman. . . . Witch, sybil, lion hunter, coffee planter, aristocrat and despot . . . she steps forth from these pages with all the force of legend.'' HEART'S DESIRE, by Gwyneth Cravens. (Fawcett Crest, $4.50.) A death in the family has far-reaching effects on three generations of women in Gwyneth Cravens's novel. In The Book Review in 1986, Mark Dintenfass called it ''sad, funny, intelligent - why not just say glorious.'' THE MASTER TERRORIST: The True Story of Abu-Nidal, by Yossi Melman. (Avon, $3.95.) Born Sabri al-Banna in Jaffa in 1937, the man now known as Abu Nidal is widely considered the most dangerous international terrorist operating today. The Times correspondent John Kifner, writing in The Book Review last year, said Yossi Melman's biography ''makes a wealth of information on Sabri al-Banna available to the general reader for the first time, including his labyrinthine relationships with the Arab world.''

title: Long Day for Yanks
description: Bill Long was supposed to make a detour on the Chicago White Sox road trip and go to Buffalo yesterday. If he had followed his planned itinerary, he would have missed seeing Ron Guidry strike out 14 of his teammates. The Yankees, on the other hand, would not have missed Long because if he had gone to Buffalo, they might have capitalized on Guidry's effort and won the game.

title: PEACE IS OUR RESPONSIBILITY
description: AS the helicopter lands on the yellow scorched grass, green canvas covers blow off the battered and bloodied bodies. Soldiers dressed in green Army fatigues move swiftly and silently as they carry their dead toward the aircraft. Once all are on board, the helicopter takes off amid a spray of bullets. The soldiers are squeezed into the aircraft; some sit with their legs dangling out of the doors. They are silent.

title: White House Rethinking Its Outlook
description: White House officials say they mishandled their approach this week to the Congressional testimony of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and made themselves and the President look silly in the process.

title: TEST TUTORING LEADS TO A CAREER AS AUTHOR
description: JUST a few weeks ago, Samuel Brownstein handed his publisher the manuscript for the 14th edition of one of his 10 books in print. The sixth editions of two of his other books will be released by the end of the year. And Mr. Brownstein, who will say only that he is ''in my 70's,'' has more deadlines stretching into 1988.

title: GENERIC DRUGS: A ROBUST INDUSTRY GROWS ON L.I.
description: LEAD: WHILE Long Island has gained a reputation as a center for high-technology companies, another industry, one usually associated with New Jersey, has quietly but firmly planted itself here as well.

title: BOATING INCREASE TESTING MARINE POLICE
description: THERE will be a record number of boats on New Jersey's waterways this summer, a situation that makes industry officials smile but law-enforcement authorities scowl.

title: The Perfect Hamburger
description: Please remember Father's Day. The weather: no sun, rainy, high humidity. Guests: adults and children. The perfect solution: the perfect hamburger. I even froze the butter. I used the chopped fresh thyme, the parsley and basil from my own garden. Worcestershire, the only brand I know. Sorry, I didn't have the guts to try the anchovy fillets. I mixed the meat with the ingredients (of course, I made sure the meat was approximately 16 1/2 percent fat content). I even made sure the coals on the grill were white.

title: Personal System
description: To the Editor:

title: MARINES, UNEASY AT FIRST, NOW SEE NORTH AS HONOR TO CORPS
description: The Hawk Room, a lounge area at the basic training school for Marine Corps officers at Quantico, Va., has been crowded daily with off-duty second lieutenants following the Iran-contra hearings on television. After every testy exchange between committee counsels and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the Marine Corps battle cry rings out: ''Arugah!''

title: LYNDA J. JOHNSON BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Lynda Jane Johnson, the daughter of Mrs. Robert E. Bald of Ridgewood, N.J., and the late Dr. Philip Martyn Johnson, was married yesterday to Mark Anthony Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harley R. Miller of Quakertown, Pa. The Rev. Richard B. Anderson and the Rev. John E. Soleau, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Elizabeth's Episcopal Church in Ridgewood.

title: CRIMINAL IN MASSACHUSETTS HAVE NEW REASON FOR GLOVES
description: One May evening a Boston woman was raped in her home. Detectives arrived the next morning to investigate and recovered fingerprints from a glass jar of coins.

title: Reaching the Hard-to-Reach: Aid for Addicts
description: A man at 110th Street and Lexington Avenue tried to write his name on a sign-up list for a drug treatment program but his hand kept falling off the page.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANTS VS. DEER: WHAT WORKS
description: LEAD: WERE Walt Disney Studios to re-release the film ''Bambi,'' it would probably be picketed by suburban gardeners throughout the area. Just the mention of deer to a gardener from the outer suburbs is sufficient to elicit a response akin to that of a commuter who has been cut off in heavy traffic.

title: Series of Pit Bull Attacks Stirs a Clamor for Laws
description: When Raylene Smith sees a pit bull, she sees a killer. Her mind flashes back to the day two years ago when two pit bulls knocked her to the ground, tearing at her stomach, legs, arms and thighs.

title: Landlords Manipulate Market: Thoudsands of Apertments Deliberately Kept Vacant
description: SALES of new homes plummeted 14.9 percent in May, the biggest decline in five years, according to the latest Commerce Department reports. The reason for the decline, the department noted, was that first-time home buyers had been driven out of the market by rising mortgage rates. But those same economic forces, which for May pushed down the National Association of Realtor's affordability index - a measure of the feasibility of home buying for middle-class people - can also drive some of the poor into substandard or doubled-up housing, and prevent some of them from finding any housing at all. Nationally, low-income units have been disappearing at the rate of half a million a year, while salaries and public assistance levels have not kept pace with housing costs. The pressure is particularly acute in gentrified urban areas and in growing retirement or resort communities. Last week, concern that low-income families might be displaced from their homes led a Federal district judge in San Francisco to block the Reagan Administration's planned sale of 257 Federal mortgages on low-income housing around the country. Federal regulations on rents and types of tenant might no longer apply after such mortgages were paid off. When the Administration proposal was announced in April, Howard Cohen, a Boston lawyer who represents developers, noted that investors in his area would have a strong incentive. Apartments that go for $300 a month would command $800 on the open market, he said, adding: ''The people living in these units could not afford to pay open-market rents.''

title: Financing Housing For Affordability
description: In September 1984, Governor Cuomo announced new regulations for New York State that were supposed to induce banks to invest a billion dollars in poor neighborhoods. Federal banking regulations, however, made the program unworkable and it died.

title: CHUN FOE'S PLANS STIR SOUTH KOREA
description: Over the years, Korean governments have kidnapped Kim Dae Jung from Japan, sentenced him to death, effectively exiled him to the United States and put him under house arrest scores of times.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: JUDGING THE JUDGES OF 'BUSINESS CLIMATES';
Why North Dakota Can't Really Be No. 1
description: LEAD: EVERY spring, in what has become a familiar ritual, the Grant Thornton Company, a Chicago accounting firm, publishes an index ranking states according to their ''general manufacturing climates.'' Officials either crow with pride or promise to do better next year, depending on how their states perform.

title: HIS NO. 1 JOB IS TO STRENGHTHEN THE CITY OPERA'S ORCHESTER
description: IT SURPRISED MORE THAN A few people when Sergiu Comissiona was named music director of the New York City Opera a year ago.

title: WATERFORD FESTIVAL EXPANDS OFFERINGS
description: SUMMER MUSIC at Harkness Memorial State Park in Waterford, which was launched three years ago on the proverbial wing and a prayer, has turned into one of the most well-attended festivals in the state.

title: A Fresh Air Visit Offers New Tastes
description: Cinnamon toast topped the breakfast menu on Nancy Rosado's second day at the home of Rhu and Burrett McBee, and their 6-year-old daughter, Alice, devoured hers eagerly.

title: Sampling Florence's restaurants and hotels
description: LEAD: In Italy, many establishments, including restaurants, shut down for varying periods of time in August. It is essential to check before going. Restaurants

title: photo of scene from stage adaptation of ''1984'' (Jiri Zizka)
description: THE CARPET ON THE LIVING room floor had a black and white checkerboard pattern. Jiri Zizka still remembers watching his father use the carpet as a kind of graph paper, plotting the coordinates by which thousands of Prague citizens would take part in exercise demonstrations.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE MAN WHO OWNED VERMONT. By Bret Lott. (Viking, $16.95.) In chronicling the day-to-day life and thoughts of Rick Wheeler, a just-jilted soft-drink salesman in Northampton, Mass., this novel manages to capture ordinary life's poetic - and tragic - moments. Interspersed with the tired details of Rick's professional life (inspecting, ordering and displaying ''product'' in various local markets) are the anecdotes that enrich and validate the sometimes mundane reality.

title: Cabaret: Claiborne Cary in Varied Bill
description: CLAIBORNE CARY, a small, pert, unusually talented singer and comedienne, has arrived at Jan Wallman's, 49 West 44th Street, with the kind of brilliant cabaret act that does not happen overnight.

title: MOVIES
description: Falling in Love Produced and directed by Steven Paul. Screenplay by Steven Paul, Ted Allan, Susannah York. Starring Elliott Gould and Susannah York. 1980. Embassy Home Entertainment. 99 minutes. $24.95 ''Falling in Love'' is an obscure film that has returned like a ghost from its well-deserved grave. Harry (Elliott Gould) and Sue (Susannah York) are middle-aged, married, feuding Californians, on a trip back to the Bronx, where they met, loved and married as teen-agers during World War II. It's bad enough that Harry has hopelessly romanticized that era. What's worse is that the film is built on flashbacks that force us to sit through his saccharine, cliche-ridden memories: the gang of great guys he hung out with, his yelling Jewish Mama, his wealthy limo-riding in-laws. Mr. Gould does a lot of hokey voiceovers; Ms. York spends her time glaring at him and clenching her teeth; Michel Legrand's piano music tinkles pointlessly in the background. Michelle Pfeiffer, as the teen-aged Sue, looks as ethereal and detached as she does in ''The Witches of Eastwick,'' only younger. Let this film slip quietly away, and hope this time it stays dead.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: THE POLITICS OF READING >One of the benefits of democracy, says the novelist Walter Abish, is our freedom to ignore our novelists' politics, to read their books, if we please, simply as stories. He tells us how he conceives of politics in his own work in ''Alive and Writing: Interviews With American Authors of the 1980s'' (University of Illinois), edited by Larry McCaffery and Sinda Gregory.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ON BECOMING JERSEY FRESH

title: Threat to NATO Is Seen in Armor On Soviet Tanks
description: Thanks to an Israeli invention appropriated by Moscow's weapon designers three years ago, many Soviet tanks have become virtually invulnerable to the antitank weapons carried by American infantry and aircraft, United States military officials report.

title: Changing Styles
description: To the Editor:

title: BATTLING WITH UNRULY NATURE
description: SO seductive was the unexpected conspiracy of light and warmth that occurred during that spring weekend that some of my neighbors took to cavorting about half-naked out of doors. They weren't the only creatures to be distracted. The first ants of the season wandered into the kitchen, still sluggish, so easy to squash.

title: Superbanks
description: To the Editor:

title: In Israel, a Vote On Who Is a Jew
description: Two of Israel's bitterest disputes, the theological one over who is a Jew and the political one over control of Parliament, came head to head last week with results that put new strains on the coalition Government.

title: RECORDINGS
description: Silos: 'Cuba' Record Collect RC-22, LP only; Box 20845, Tompkins Square Station, New York, N. Y. 10009

title: U.S. Role in Gulf Seen as a Way to Regain Arabs' Favor
description: ONE morning last week, while Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North faced intricate questioning on Capitol Hill about the secret arms sales to Iran, a seminar of experts on the Middle East convened at the Brookings Institution to take up a question that Colonel North had not been asked. It had to do with the political and strategic situation in the Persian Gulf, and it was posed crisply by one of the experts, Anthony H. Cordesman, a former Director of Defense Intelligence Assessment in the Pentagon.

title: Australia Gives Labor Premier 3d Straight Term
description: Prime Minister Bob Hawke won a third term today, apparently increasing his legislative majority, and pledged to continue the Labor Party's restructuring of the Australian economy.

title: 'Collected Prose'
description: THIS may be Robert Lowell's most winning book. But ''Collected Prose'' should not be read straight through, nor taken in big gulps. Robert Giroux, faced with more than 40 pieces, nearly all short and scrappy, some incomplete, has sorted them by subject matter into three sections and an appendix. On balance this arrangement is probably the best possible. But it has disadvantages. If we want to know what Lowell thought of William Carlos Williams, we find him taking three bites at the cherry - in 1947, 1948, 1962; and whereas we are enlightened about how he changed his mind (the two bites at John Berryman, eight years apart, are very illuminating in this way), we are confused about how far his second thoughts canceled out his first. At any rate, it's only by sorting out the chronology that we can construct a narrative of Lowell's life in and out of, but mostly in, literature.

title: Dr. Anthony C. Cahan Wed To Mary Beth Hyer, Nurse
description: Mary Beth Hyer, the daughter of Mary Hyer of Amagansett, L.I., and John V. Hyer of Bedminster, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Anthony C. Cahan, a son of Mary Sykes Cahan of New York and Dr. William G. Cahan of New York. Justice Alvin Schlesinger of New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's mother.

title: Data Update
description: NATIONAL HOUSING TRENDS (In thousands of units, seasonally adjusted annual rates)

title: INSIDE
description: Woes Amid the Wealth Prosperity creates its own special problems, a report on the future of Fairfield County, Conn., warns.

title: BETH SMITH, THERAPIST, WED TO CHARLES KNIGHT
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Wheeling, W.Va., yesterday Beth Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Smith Jr. of Ridgewood, N.J., was married to Charles Knight, the son of Eva Knight of McMechen, W.Va., and the late Charles Knight. The Rev. Richard Smith, United Methodist chaplain at Community Mental Health in Clairsville, Ohio, performed the ceremony.

title: Boy Scouts Win: It's a Man's Job
description: Catherine N. Pollard sought to become a leader of boys because she likes teaching and sports, and because no one else would do it. But the Boy Scouts of America rejected her application, maintaining that its troops should be led only by men, and last week they were upheld by the Connecticut Supreme Court.

title: IMAGES OF THE JEWISH SOJOURN IN GERMANY IN THE LIGHT OF ITS TRAGIC OUTCOME
description: BY CURRENT STAND-ards, the exhibition ''Jews in Germany Under Prussian Rule'' is plain fare, a series of black-and-white montages that puts the emphasis on solid, point-by-point information. The New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue (where it can be seen through Aug. 22, before returning to West Germany), seems an appropriate home for such a show: Its effect is very much that of a picture book that has been cut up and hung on the wall.

title: Getting the Rhino Into the Computer
description: IS the gorilla in Seattle related to the one in San Antonio?

title: Headliners; Death for a Serial Killer
description: The appeals will take years and there is a possibility of a new trial. Nevertheless, a 27-year-old Cornell University graduate is now in line to become the first person to die in Connecticut's electric chair since Joseph (Mad Dog) Taborsky was electrocuted in 1960 for killing seven people in a robbery. Michael B. Ross, a sometime insurance salesman already serving a 120-year sentence for the murders of two young women, was sentenced to death in Superior Court in Bridgeport last week for killing four others. All four were kidnapped and two were raped. Prosecutors had contended that the law passed by the Connecticut Legislature in 1980, after the United States Supreme Court had upheld the legality of the death penalty under certain conditions, contained overly generous allowances for mitigating factors; the state's Chief Public Defender, Joseph M. Shortall, said the Ross case ''should put to rest once and for all the claims of the last three years that we have a death-penalty statute that makes it impossible to get the death penalty.''

title: Harold F. Cherniss, an Expert In Greek Philosophy, Is Dead
description: Harold F. Cherniss, a specialist in ancient Greek philosophy and professor emeritus at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., died June 18 at the Medical Center of Princeton after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

title: 39 FROM COUNTY JOINING CHORISTERS IN THE ROYAL FESTIVAL HALL
description: MEMBERS of the Westchester Chorale, the New Rochelle Chorale and the Pleasantville Cantata Singers will join forces with more than 200 other singers on July 19 in London's Royal Festival Hall to perform Verdi's Requiem, accompanied by the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra.

title: Commercial Property: Westchester Offices; 20% Vacancy Casts a Pall in Once-Booming Suburb
description: MORE than 250 employees of the Nynex Corporation, parent company of New York Telephone, will leave Manhattan this summer to work in an office complex in Westchester County. The scheduled departure comes within weeks of announcements from several other companies that are planning similar shifts.

title: N.Y. Courts Must Expedite Arrest Review
description: New York City said last week it would appeal, but prisoners' rights supporters were jubilant. A Federal District Court judge in Manhattan had ruled that a suspect arrested without a warrant must be released after 24 hours unless ''probable cause'' has been established.

title: Anti-Americanism Grows in South Korea
description: A ROAR of approval reverberated among the hundreds of thousands of protesters on Thursday as a handful of young men dashed into the Seoul Plaza Hotel and pulled down an American flag. ''Down With America,'' the crowd chanted a few minutes later as the flag was burned in the city's central square during what may have been the largest demonstration in South Korean history.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Islip to Tape Trash Trips IT will be candid camera soon for Islip's garbage. By the end of the summer, television cameras and a complete videotaping system will be installed at the town's landfill in Hauppauge.

title: Sonia Jones's 'Small University'
description: To the Editor:

title: Streetscapes: Graham Court; Grande Dame Tries to Regain Her Respectability in Harlem
description: IF Harlem has an equivalent to the Dakota, the famed apartment building on Central Park West, it is Graham Court, a full blockfront on Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard, from 116th to 117th Streets.

title: GRANGE, INSURED, BRINGING BACK FAIR
description: LEAD: THE Yorktown Grange Fair, a three-day celebration that combines agricultural exhibitions, professional entertainment and carnival-style amusements is returning in September after a year's absence.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Prices Also Attract At Joelian Gem Sale Joelian is a Mamaroneck costume-jewelry manufacturer and supplier to catalogue houses and retailers. A three-day sale at the warehouse from Friday through next Sunday is designed to clear discontinued lines, samples and overstock in necklaces, pins, earrings and bracelets, with prices at wholesale or below.

title: Captive Writer Appears on Tape
description: In a videotaped statement that was promptly dismissed by a White House spokesman as possibly made under ''coercion or perhaps even with torture,'' Charles Glass said last week that he had come to Lebanon to ''collect information for the benefit of the C.I.A.'' Before he was kidnapped June 17, the 36-year-old former Middle East correspondent for ABC News had told friends he was back in Beirut to work on a book about Lebanon's leading families.

title: Jazz: Dick Wellstood At Carlyle Bar's Piano
description: DICK WELLSTOOD, the pianist who was the stylistic model for the entertainment at Hanratty's on Second Avenue until the room dropped its music policy (it is now closed entirely), has found a new musical home, music policy (it is now closed entirely), has found a new musical home, if only for the summertime. At the beginning of the month he started his second year as the hot-weather pianist in the Bemelthe hot-weather pianist in the Bemelman's Bar of the Carlyle Hotel, 76th Street at Madison Avenue, where he will play Mondays through Fridays until September.

title: CONFIDENCE DOWN IN BRONX LEADERS
description: When Melvina Vandross, a social worker, tired of seeing drug dealers on the corner near her home in the Fordham Hill section of the Bronx, she first took her concerns to her State Senator. But when she felt he was not responding quickly enough, she turned to a local community group.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
49 AWARDS
description: LEAD: County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke was scheduled to be in Indianapolis this weekend -celebrating Westchester. Mr. O'Rourke is picking up 49 awards bestowed on the county for innovative and creative programs by the National Association of Counties, an organization that addresses issues facing counties nationwide.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Washington on June 28 about President Reagan's leadership misstated poll findings about his approval rating. A New York Times-CBS News Poll in March found that Mr. Reagan's approval rating had fallen 25 points, to 42 percent, since the first disclosures about the Iran-contra affair. Polls taken in April and May found that his approval rating had climbed back to the range of 46 to 50 percent.

title: AT VELCRO MILL, THE IDEAS KEEP COMING
description: Every week Ted Krantz, president of Velcro U.S.A., and Richard Kuhl, the vice president, get calls and letters from people around the country who say they have the ''ultimate Velcro idea.''

title: PRISONERS MAY PICK UP TRASH
description: LEAD: INMATES serving time in Suffolk County jails will be put to work by picking up roadside litter and sorting trash at recycling plants, if a bill before the Suffolk Legislature is approved Tuesday.

title: BUILDING RIGHTS SWAP URGED
description: LEAD: IN an unusual plan to increase office space at Mitchel Field, a developer is proposing to lease environmentally sensitive land from Nassau Community College, set it aside as a nature preserve and transfer its development rights to properties less than a mile away.

title: Rogue Colonel? Rogue Government
description: At one point during his week of testifying before America, Lieut. Col. Oliver North held his left hand aloft as if to pledge ''scout's honor.'' The gesture typified the performance. Indeed, for a time it seemed that the dazzling political theater would obscure the content of the Iran-contra scandal. Viewers swamped the joint investigating committee with entreaties not to rough up this articulate Eagle Scout-turned-Marine.

title: KAREN CROW WEDS CAPT. C. P. EVANS
description: Karen Lisa Crow, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lon Worth Crow Jr. of Coral Gables, Fla., was married yesterday to Capt. Christopher Paul Evans of the Army Medical Corps, a son of Dr. Alfred S. Evans of Madison, Conn., and the late Brigitte K. Evans. Bishop James L. Duncan, who is retired from the Diocese of Southeast Florida, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church in Miami. The bride graduated cum laude from Dartmouth College and received a master's degree in management last month from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Her father, who is retired, was president of the Southeast Mortgage Company in Miami.

title: The Book Clubs, Chapter 2
description: THE first suggestion of a sultry New York summer was already in the air when he arrived from Lisbon. But the youthful, elegantly dressed executive did not seem to notice. His mind was on other things: The takeover was complete; the family dynasty that had controlled the publishing empire for years had bowed out. Now, he was here to take charge of the key unit of the American company that had been won by the worldwide conglomerate. He knew he had a job to do. . . .

title: Quality Housing: Cons and Pros
description: To the Editor:

title: A Critic Mourned
description: To the Editor:

title: ABBY COHEN IS ENGAGED
description: Abby Cohen and Steven Lane Conn, rabbinical students at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America in New York, plan to be married in August. The future bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Cohen of Fair Lawn, N.J., who have announced her engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanford Conn of West Bloomfield, Mich. Ms. Cohen graduated from Bennington College. Her fiance is an alumnus of the University of Chicago.

title: CHRISTINE CRONIN WED TO CORNELIUS GALLAGHER
description: Christine Ruth Cronin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Green Cronin of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Cornelius Gallagher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent James Gallagher of West Islip, L.I. The Rev. William J. Winterrowd performed the ceremony at St. James the Less Episcopal Church.

title: DR. KATHERINE A. LINDBERG MARRIES WAYNE K. CANNER
description: Dr. Katherine Atwood Lindberg, a dentist, was married yesterday to Wayne Kendall Canner, an account manager in Atlanta for the General Electric Company. The Rev. Lawrence Provenzano performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church in Westerly, R.I.

title: A Defiant Tale of Evasive Actions
description: During a gripping week at the witness table, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North proudly gave his version of the Iran-contra affair. And at week's end, members of the Congressional committees said the stacks of laudatory telegrams piled several inches high on the table in front of the colonel had not lessened their determination to pursue their inquiry - although at times it seemed to have muted their tone. Highlights of the week's developments follow.
