A White House television correspondent comments on his assignment. 13 1 THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990, by Ravi Batra. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) An economist's dire predictions about the coming decade. 14 14 2 THE SPY WORE RED, by Aline, Countess of Romanones. (Random House, $18.95.) Recollections of a woman from upstate New York who served as an undercover agent in Europe during World War II. 15 * 15 22 THE FATAL SHORE, by Robert Hughes. (Knopf, $24.95.) Australia, from penal colony to its gradual emergence as a flourishing nation. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 96 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 2 2 6 WOMEN MEN LOVE, WOMEN MEN LEAVE, by Connell Cowan and Melvyn Kinder. (Clarkson N. Potter/Crown, $18.95.) Why men are drawn to some women and desert others. 3 4 4 SIBLINGS WITHOUT RIVALRY, by Adele Faber and Elaine Mazlish. (Norton, $14.95.) Ways to cope with bickering between one's children. 4 1 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) Ways to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 5 * 3 37 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS WITH WINE, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $16.95.) Recipes to be prepared at moderate cost. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE EMBARRASSMENT OF RICHES: An Interpretation of Dutch Culture in the Golden Age, by Simon Schama. (Knopf, $39.95.) A historian's deft moral examination (plentifully illustrated) of a tiny, newly independent, 17th-century Calvinist state adjusting its public conscience to cope with sudden, stupendous wealth. THE CURIOUS CASE OF SIDD FINCH, by George Plimpton. (Macmillan, $14.95.) What if a man, through Tibetan mystical training, could throw a baseball accurately at 168 miles per hour?

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
THE WETLANDS AND ROUTE 7
description: LEAD: THESE days I feel as if I should be walking around with my hair dyed green, waving a banner that says, ''I Speak for the Earth.'' I've become a party in a Department of Environmental Protection hearing, specifically the application of the Department of Transportation to trash several wetlands.

title: WHEN SHIPS WERE PALACES ON THE WAVES
description: HEROIC-SCALED HULLS dominate the boldly graphic posters at the entrance to ''The Great Liner: Trans-Atlantic Passage Between the Wars,'' an exhibition of nautical memorabilia that will be at the South Street Seaport Museum Gallery, 213 Water Street, through Jan. 3. The show's red-white-and-blue posters by A. M. Cassandre and others, depict the magnificent Normandie, the majestic Rex and the gracious Aquitania, conjuring up scenes of a half century ago when luxury liners, belching steam, disgorged and took on thousands of passengers weekly at Manhattan's West Side docks.

title: Court in Jersey Bans Builders' Payments To Repair Roadways
description: The State Supreme Court has struck down a Bernards Township ordinance requiring developers to help pay for road improvements even if they have no direct link to their new construction.

title: FIGHT BREWS ON TRUCK SITE
description: LEAD: THE State Transportation Commissioner's decision to put a truck weigh station in Greenwich has not ended the intense battles that surrounded the issue in Fairfield County for the past two years, according to Greenwich residents and officials. They said they will fight Commissioner J. William Burns's plan, possibly with a court suit.

title: Growing Up With Privilege and Prejudice
description: I would like to applaud your publication for printing Karen K. Russell's article ''Growing Up With Privilege and Prejudice'' (June 14) -not to mention making it your cover story. As a young black woman, I found her story truthful and straightforward without sounding bitter or militant. She closes her article by reflecting on the repercussions it may bring. I hope she realizes that many of her contemporaries will use her article as a source of inspiration against the odds. LANA WILLIAMS White Plains

title: Where the Mystical Meets the Bizarre
description: Everyone should have a favorite California freeway. Mine is Interstate 280, the scenic route from San Francisco to San Jose, not so much because it's well engineered or beautiful, although it is, but because to drive it is to experience repeated warps in time.

title: ALICE COMISKEY ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Campbell Comiskey of Watertown, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alice Campbell Comiskey, to Steven James Serenska, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Serenska of Middletown, N.J. Miss Comiskey and her fiance, both graduates of Williams College, plan an October wedding. The future bride is an account manager at A. C. Nielsen & Company in New York. Mr. Serenska is a manager in Arthur Andersen & Company's consulting division in New York.

title: A Shield, Needlessly Dented
description: Most judges observe a simple rule when interpreting a law: If it's clear on its face, don't dig into its history looking for some more subtle meaning. New York enacted such a statute in 1970, the first state law in the nation shielding journalists, their notes and unused film footage from prosecutors' subpoenas. In simple language the law prohibits holding news gatherers in contempt for refusing to disclose ''any news or the source of any news.'' That, alas, seems too simple for the Court of Appeals.

title: RECORDINGS
description: Of a Mesh: 'Broken' 109 Records, 109 St. Mark's Place, New York, N. Y. 10009

title: Indian Cemetery: Peace in Delaware
description: IT took two years, but the Delaware General Assembly finally passed compromise legislation that satisfies archaeologists studying unearthed human remains and Nanticoke Indians seeking to protect the dignity of their ancestors.

title: Thailand
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Simon Winchester's article ''Exploring Ayutthaya by Canal Boat'' (Travel, June 7). It brought back memories of my own trip to that idyllic spot 10 years ago. At that time there were no river boats to ''disgorge their invading armies of package tourists''; indeed, it took me several mornings of cajoling and humble pleading before I found a single Bangkok driver who was willing to take me there. On tha other hand, I am reassured to learn that the essence of Ayutthaya has not changed: that the three chedis of Wat Phra Sri Sanphet still cast their spell and that the ruins of Wat Chai Wattanarum remain mercifully unrestored and splendidly silent. LOIS WIEN New York

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about expert witnesses incompletely described Dr. David A. Crown's help in identifying the remains of Josef Mengele in 1985.

title: A Bank Battles Poverty
description: RABEA stepped out of her dirt-floored house, stamped one bare foot on the ground and snapped a smart salute. Rabea is so poor that she cannot offer a visitor a chair or protect her children from rain leaking though her thatched roof. But she is a proud borrower at an innovative rural bank. Like nearly 300,000 other landless Bangladeshis, she has managed, without collateral, to borrow enough to start a small business and slowly advance her family's standard of living.

title: Ben-Gurion's Zionism
description: To the Editor:

title: A Hepatitis Outbreak Hits Upstate New York
description: After large outbreaks in two nearby counties this spring, Onondaga County is facing its worst siege of hepatitis in at least six years.

title: POSTINGS;
description: For loft-aficionados with a talent for interior design but not necessarily carpentry, a new loft-style condominium project in Little Italy might offer the right ratio of raw to finished space.

title: Rockland Hires an Expert for Mountains of Paper
description: Hour after hour and day after day, Peter J. Scheibner must work, live and listen to his enemies.

title: IN HOUSTON, A SYMBOL OS CONFUSED AMBITIONS
description: FOR SOME YEARS THIS CITY HAS been American architecture's best weathervane - the place that shows, at least so far as commercial design is concerned, which way the wind is blowing. Houston is hardly a city of the avant-garde, but it is surely a city that loves to build, and it has a tradition of bombastic overreaching that has given its buildings a welcome energy, if not much subtlety.

title: RUSSIAN SAYS U.S. IGNORES ARMS BIDS
description: The Soviet Prime Minister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, today accused the United States and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization of failing to respond adequately to Soviet initiatives at the Geneva arms-control talks.

title: STARS IN THE PRESS BOX
description: THE 1987 MEDIAGUIDE A Critical Review of the News Media's Recent Coverage of the World Political Economy. Edited by Jude Wanniski. 374 pp. New York: Perennial Library/ Harper & Row. Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: Growing Up With Privilege and Prejudice
description: Karen Russell's article was interesting. However, I must criticize your choice of cover photograph. The ones of Karen Russell reading the newspaper or walking through the Harvard campus would have been more appropriate. I suppose you felt the picture of her listening to a radio was more descriptive of blacks than the pictures depicting intellectual pursuits. This is an example of the ''subtle racism'' mentioned in the article. ANNETTE P. MILLER Philadelphia

title: FOR A DEAN OF BOXING, THE LONGEST FIGHT
description: LEAD: THE 4204 Gyro is the lightest boxing bag in the world, a leather ellipsis slightly larger than a grapefruit and filled with air, dangling from a varnished circular slab. There's one in the basement of Stephen B. Acunto's rambling Mount Vernon home, and when the 69-year-old coach and state boxing official recently demonstrated it, the rapid polyphonic rhythm of the bag rebounding off flesh and wood almost resembled a musical composition.

title: BOATERS ON THE SOUND: THE MORE, THE RISKIER
description: LONG ISLAND SOUND, a rich natural resource surrounded by a dense and rising population, is becoming too popular for some of its devotees' own good.

title: TWO PIANISTS JOIN WESTCHESTER CHAMBER FESTIVAL
description: THE Westchester Chamber Music Festival is back for its third season at the Martha Guinsberg Pavilion in Crompond, with two world-renowned pianists leading the guest-artist roster: John Browning, who plays the Franck Quintet today at 4 P.M., with members of the resident Westchester Chamber Virtuosi (the Debussy Quartet and the charming String Trio by Jean Francaix complete the program) and Menahem Pressler, whose choice July 26 will be the Brahms A major Piano Quartet.

title: Tampering With Art Is Hollywood's Art; Of Deals and Properties
description: To the Editor:

title: Western Outpost of Festivals
description: As you drive in to Telluride, Colo., your eye is drawn to the peaks behind the town - Ajax, Telluride, Ingram. The purple-black of raisins and snow capped, they rise like softened pyramids more than 4,000 feet from the valley floor, and the floor itself is nearly 9,000 feet above sea level. Part of the San Juans, Colorado's youngest, largest, most southwestern mountain range and one of its most jagged, the peaks were formed by massive uplifts of the earth's crust, volcanic explosions and the resulting debris.

title: The Barge Stops Here
description: Although some people think New York City has enough of its own garbage to worry about, its officials have agreed to take on the world's most famous trash heap.

title: SEDUCED BY BOOKS, FROTHY ROMANCES TO TRUE ADVENTURE
description: WHEN I was growing up, reading was considered, by parents, as a necessary evil. It ranked above listening to the ''Make Believe Ballroom'' or talking on the phone, but below saving laundry instructions from new clothes or cleaning the bathroom. Most parents believed -naively - that a book wouldn't attack you in the back seat of a car.

title: STARGAZERS ARE LOSING SITES AT STATE PARKS
description: LEAD: THERE'S a new endangered species on Long Island: the amateur astronomer.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
'Last Call' for Oceanfront Dream Houses
description: LEAD: ''THESE are the last prime oceanfront lots on the East End,'' said Marc Lieberman, a sales associate with Agawam Realty in Southampton, as he drove down the newly paved stretch of Meadow Lane leading from Halsey Neck Lane to the Shinnecock Inlet County Park in Southampton Village.

title: THE UNFLINCHING EYE: PHOTOJOURNALIST MARY ELLEN MARK
description: LAST WINTER, MARY ELLEN MARK turned her fascination with autism into an assignment. At the Mothering Center in Greenwich, Conn., she stood among the mothers and children, photographing a therapy session.

title: CONSTANCE CULLEN BECOMES A BRIDE
description: The marriage of Constance Marie Cullen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Cullen of Douglaston, Queens, to James Edward Cavanaugh 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cavanaugh Jr. of Narragansett, R.I., took place yesterday at the Fordham University Church on the Rose Hill campus in the Bronx. The Rev. Gerard C. Reedy, dean of Fordham College, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: SUFFOLK POLICE: REFORM PRESSURE GROWS
description: LEAD: QUESTIONS about large overtime payments and the shake-up in the police bureau that investigates incidents of religious and racial bias strongly suggested last week that pressure is growing for reforms in the Suffolk County Police Department.

title: Powell on His Approach: Doing Justice Case by Case
description: Amid furniture marked with little yellow stickers for the movers, Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. sought the other day to sum up his approach to hundreds of hard cases over more than 15 years at the strategic center of the most powerful court in the world.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: The Perfect Hamburger
description: Your perfect hamburger is just the recipe our cardiac surgeons need to boost business (Food, ''The Perfect Hamburger,'' by Craig Claiborne with Pierre Franey, June 21). The ''21 Club'' burger weighs in with 85 grams of fat - about six and a half tablespoonfuls - of which 39 percent is saturated. Accompanied by 260 milligrams of cholesterol, this candidate will cushion many an executive artery. JOYCE A. NETTLETON Lexington, Mass.

title: ILLNESS, CANCER; PROGNOSIS, GOOD; REACTIONS, UNEXPECTED
description: SEVERAL months ago, my husband went to see a doctor about a puzzling pain in his lower right side. He returned with that diagnosis we all dread: probable cancer.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: RATIONING HEALTH CARE IN AMERICA: Perceptions and Principles of Justice. By Larry R. Churchill. (University of Notre Dame, $19.95.) Health care has always been rationed by the patient's ability to pay, by the ways specialized facilities are distributed and by professional preferences. More explicit rationing is under consideration in light of out-of-control medical costs, the temptation to spend on new technologies or on their development, and the financial burden on government.

title: Perspectives: 'Luxury' Decontrol; Lifting Regulation While Aiding the Poor
description: THE chapter on New York City's housing in the report of the Commission on the Year 2000 starts, ''No city can flourish without a strong, healthy housing market.''

title: BUDGET BUOYS TOURISM HOPES
description: RECORD spending, a new theme and increased activity by the state's 19 local tourism districts are generating more interest in Connecticut as a tourist destination, but how much tourism this translates into this summer remains to be seen, officials say.

title: MS. SLOMKOWSKI IS WED IN BOSTON
description: At the chapel of the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Holy Cross in Boston yesterday Theresa M. Slomkowski, assistant to the editor of the Boston Publishing Company, was married to Robert J. Manning, editor in chief of the company, a book publishing concern. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. Francis J. Lally and the Rev. Thomas J. Manning, the bridegroom's brother.

title: AT MOSQUE, MEDICINE WITH A MESSAGE
description: They begin gathering early each morning to wait for the doctors: women wrapped in traditional Islamic black veils, many with their faces tattooed in the style of Bedouin tribes; worn men wearing the conical felt hat of the Egyptian peasant, or fellaheen. They sit on the ground patiently under the shade of an awning in front of the mosque.

title: Finale in Albany: Politics, Pizza and Lots of Bills
description: It was labeled ''the session that wouldn't end,'' and thrashed about until almost 6 o'clock this morning, more than a week after it was supposed to fade away. In its wake were left, among other things, hundreds of empty soda cans, coffee cups and candy wrappers.

title: New Yorkers,
description: IT all boils down to whether people really want to hear the truth. They should want to hear it, they often say they want to hear it, but when it comes to actually hearing it, forget it.

title: A CONNECTICUT WEDDING FOR BETTINA MARIA BRETZ
description: Bettina Maria Bretz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hilbert Mohrhenn Bretz of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Marc Bernhard Terfloth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Boerries Herbert Terfloth of London and Montreal. The Rev. Dr. John W. Bishop performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: GROWING UP JEWISH
description: ''IRVING'S mother would like to say something to us about happiness,'' Irving's mother confides to the audience at the beginning of Israel Horovitz's comedy ''Today I Am a Fountain Pen,'' now at the New Studio Theater.

title: Slotnick Is Injured In Street Attack
description: Barry I. Slotnick, the highly visible defense lawyer whose clients include a number of Mafia figures, Bernhard H. Goetz and Representative Mario Biaggi, Democrat of the Bronx, last week was the victim of an attack that left him bleeding and bruised and with a broken left wrist.

title: Golfers Withdraw
description: SEVEN American golfers, including 1981 champion Bill Rogers and last year's top United States finisher, Gary Koch, have withdrawn from this week's British Open. Hubert Green, Hale Irwin, Joey Sindelar, John Mahaffey and Doug Tewell were the others who pulled out of the tournament. Rogers gave no reason for his decision, but Green, the 1977 United States Open and 1985 PGA champion, did, saying ''The current state of my game dictates that I must withdraw.'' Green has not won a tournament since the PGA two years ago.

title: Cuomo Finally Puts His 'Hamlet' Image to Rest
description: ASK state lawmakers to list the accomplishments of the 210th session of the Legislature and they will cite a tax cut, a program to rebuild New York City's transit system, a restructuring of the corporate tax code and a plan to allocate cheap upstate hydropower.

title: Investment Accounts Gain Favor as Way To Pay College Costs
description: An old-fashioned idea for financing college education is again winning converts: encouraging families to save and invest, rather than borrow, to pay for tuition.

title: OCEAN GROVE TO HEAR THE SOUND OF SOUSA MUSIC ONCE AGAIN
description: JOHN PHILIP SOUSA, ''the March King,'' who was not asked back to this seaside Methodist resort after he mocked Prohibition in the 1920's, will soon make a triumphant return here - at least in spirit - to the Great Auditorium.

title: COLLEGE FACULTIES FACING REFORMS
description: AT A RETREAT at Fairleigh Dickinson University here recently, members of the state's Board of Higher Education met to ponder their agenda for the next five years.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q & A;
ALVIN NOVICK
description: LEAD: ALVIN NOVICK, a biology professor at Yale University, set aside his academic research into neurophysiology five years ago and began a study of the social, political and ethical aspects of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, becoming a national advocate for sufferers of the disease. In his office on the Yale campus, Dr.

title: RECORDINGS
description: The Fleshtones: 'Fleshtones vs. Reality' Emergo Records, 225 Lafayette Street, Suite 709, New York, N. Y. 10012

title: ROBIN M. KEEFE IS MARRIED TO ROBERT F. LYNCH 3D
description: At St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn., yesterday Robin Mary Keefe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Manton Keefe of Norwalk, Conn., was married to Robert Francis Lynch 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lynch Jr. of Riverside. The Rev. Stanley Rousseau performed the ceremony.

title: 2d Request for Proposals: 2 Acres Jamaica
description: New York City today is once again putting out a request for proposals to develop a two-acre site in Jamaica, Queens, that can accommodate, within current zoning regulations, a commercial building of up to 490,000 square feet. The property, bounded by Jamaica Avenue, 160th Street, Archer Avenue and Parsons Boulevard, is part of the 10-acre Jamaica Center renewal area, which city and local officials hope will entice private commercial development in the area.

title: What Is to Be Done About the Bork Nomination; Under a Cloud
description: To the Editor:

title: Court's Ruling Of Shield Law
description: Many journalists have long argued that to insure the existence of an independent press they should be shielded from prosecutors who try to compel them to reveal the names of sources. In fact, some reporters argue that the First Amendment implicitly gives them this right. Similar protection has been sought for reporters' notebooks, tapes, films and other raw material used in gathering the news.

title: 'Summer Touches' For Whites Only
description: In the June 14 issue of The New York Times Magazine (which included Karen K. Russell's article ''Growing Up With Privilege and Prejudice''), there appeared a Beauty article, ''Summer Touches'' (by Linda Wells), which could have been titled ''Summer Touches for White Women Only.'' The third paragraph of the article divides women into two categories: those with ''a little bit of tan,'' and those with ''pale skin.'' Whether any of the advice in the article is valid for black women, too, goes unmentioned.

title: BEAUTY PAGEANTS VS. DEBATES
description: SIGH IF YOU MUST, BUT IT REALLY IS TIME TO worry about the Presidential debates for 1992. We know about the 1988 debates already. We know we are sure to have them because an incumbent President will not be running. A President is less likely to want to debate than a challenger; a President has more to lose. In 1988, however, the two major candidates will be forced to debate; indeed, they will be required to show eagerness - because they cannot afford to look chicken. This means that 1988 will mark the fourth straight election in which Presidential candidates debate on television. In the last three elections, there were questions about whether the candidates would debate; next year, there will be none. By 1992, debates will have the sanctity of tradition. An incumbent may have to take part, whether he wants to or not.

title: MEDICARE ADVICE: ACCESS IS EASED
description: LEAD: MEDICARE can befuddle both new and veteran beneficiaries, according to those who answer questions about the Federal health plan for the elderly and disabled.

title: Michael Markoe Schieffelin, a Student, Is Wed to Miss Speyer in Mount Kisco
description: Katherine E. Speyer, a daughter of Dr. Joseph F. Speyer of Willington, Conn., and Anne Mattison Speyer of Middletown Springs, Vt., was married yesterday to Michael Markoe Schieffelin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Jay Schieffelin 3d of Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. Jack Silvey Miller performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco.

title: Chatham Light Takes Pace
description: Chatham Light, the favorite, posted his sixth victory in as many starts in the final of the $518,000 Lawrence B. Sheppard Pace for 2-year-old colts and geldings tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

title: JAPANESE AT HOME ON L.I.
description: LEAD: WHEN the Standard Microsystems Corporation of Hauppauge recently flew in several Japanese engineers from its new Tokyo subsidiary for three months of training, it gave them the keys to the house.

title: Priests Increasing Rapidly in the Third World
description: Someday priests from Asia and Africa might have to look after Roman Catholics in countries that once sent off boatloads of missionaries, according to Vatican documents showing that the number of priests is rapidly growing in third world countries while declining in Europe and the United States.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: GOVERNOR KEAN got the wetlands bill he wanted, and although it is still being called a compromise in some quarters, its opponents are already considering a legislative strategy for amending the new law.

title: PAMELA DONOVAN MARRIES
description: Pamela Jane Donovan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Donovan of Morristown, N.J., was married there yesterday to John Andrew Gehret, the son of Dr. and Mrs. John F. Gehret of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Christopher Muldoon performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Assumption. Mrs. Gehret, a 1981 graduate of Dartmouth College, as is her husband, is the marketing services manager for Roure Bertrand Dupont, a fragrance company in Teaneck, N.J. Mr. Gehret is an assistant manager for Brown Brothers Harriman & Company in New York.

title: What Is to Be Done About the Bork Nomination; Liberals, Wake!
description: To the Editor:

title: A SPY IN THE HOUSE OF SAUD
description: THE SAUDIS Inside the Desert Kingdom. By Sandra Mackey. 433 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $19.95.

title: LISA Q. L. WAGNER MARRIED TO EDWARD RICE ELDREDGE
description: At the Congregational Church of Christ in Norfolk, Conn., yesterday Lisa Quinn Lovis Wagner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rodney Belknap Wagner of Brooklyn and Norfolk, was married yesterday to Edward Rice Eldredge, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Stuart Eldredge of Peterborough, N.H. The Rev. Bruce F. Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: CENTENARIANS: 81% ARE WOMEN
description: ALTHOUGH an informal survey of centenarians in the state may not be definitive, it did point up one fact - the vast majority are women.

title: MUSIC
description: Zoot Sims: In a Sentimental Mood Directed by Lennart Wetterholm. Sonet Films. Sony Video Software. 52 minutes. $29.95. The November 1984 recording session that is the basis for this film was one of the last Zoot Sims made before his death from cancer on March 23, 1985. But it is a testament to the tenor saxophonist's skill and professionalism that his performance is anything but infirm. Rather, this cassette shows off the effortless swing that listeners learned to associate with Sims, one of the major disciples of Lester Young.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Jacksonville, Fla.; A Lift Along The Riverfront
description: A $42 MILLION retail and restaurant complex called Jacksonville Landing opened last month on the banks of the St. Johns River here, and hopes are high that it will give the heart of this northern Florida city a needed commercial lift.

title: New England Ski Museum
description: To visit the New England Ski Museum in Franconia, N.H., is to take a quick course in the history of skiing in the United States with emphasis, of course, on the Northeast.

title: Cable TV
description: Bravo's Wednesday night double bill of Martin Scorsese dramas, ''Who's That Knocking at My Door?'' (1968) and ''Mean Streets'' (1973) affords cable viewers a rare chance to study the development of a major American director on his native turf. Most of the Scorsese features since - ''Taxi Driver,'' ''New York, New York,'' ''Raging Bull,'' ''King of Comedy'' and ''After Hours'' - have used New York as a background. But the early ''Who's That Knocking'' and ''Mean Streets'' held close to Manhattan's Little Italy, where Mr. Scorsese grew up, with a second-generation Italian youth (played by Harvey Keitel in both films) as the protagonist of each drama.

title: When You Write by Committee
description: Early in my writing career, I was approached by a film producer to convert Hemingway's ''Hills like White Elephants'' into a television script. Being neither a dyed-in-the-beard Hemingway fan nor an the answer toi the questu iiooonnnnthe advocate of television in its current guise as an entertainment medium, I reluctantly decided to part with a microportion of my soul in return for what promised to be sufficient remuneration to pay the rent for the better part of a year and then some.

title: REMEMBERING BENNETT WITH LAUGHTER AND LOVE
description: ''BEING SOUND IN MIND AND body and pure in heart, will you solemnly vow, promise, swear, pledge and affirm to perform all the duties, obligations, expectations, as they are construed and understood to apply to the term 'friendship' such as loyalty, fealty, mutual assistance, honesty, truthfulness and trust in all dealings, arrangements, both verbal and written, both spoken and unspoken, both at home and abroad, in all companies, at all hours, for all times, to set a shining example of integrity in human affairs, in contradistinction and toward the obliteration of backbiting, undermining, innuendo, opportunism, greed, the devil's larder of subtle seductions preying on man's weakness for aggrandizement at the expense and over the corpus of his fellow.

title: Appalachian Trail
description: To the Editor: As one who has hiked in the White Mountain Presidential Range for years, I was pleased with ''On the Appalachian Trail'' (Travel, May 17) but surprised at the recommendations for lodgings. The Mount Washington Hotel is elegant and beautiful, but going there to experience the ambiance of hiking the trail would be the equivalent of booking a suite at the Pierre to experience Bohemian life in Greenwich Village.

title: Jazz: Kevin Eubanks
description: KEVIN EUBANKS, a guitarist, is looking for the jazz side of jazz-rock fusion with the quartet he's leading through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South.

title: MARY ELLEN MONGILLO WED TO GEORGE SELBY
description: The wedding of Mary Ellen Mongillo to George Walter Selby took place yesterday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Hamden, Conn. The Rev. Daniel J. Johnson performed the ceremony. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Arthur Mongillo of Hamden, and Mr. and Mrs. George Selby of Wheaton, Ill.

title: LARRY BROWN SAYS OFFER WASN'T MADE
description: Larry Brown said yesterday that he had not been contacted again concerning the Knick coaching job despite reports that the team had shown renewed interest in him.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: ACROBATS AND MAGICIANS Although what the Chinese Golden Dragon Acrobats and Magicians of Taipei offer isn't new - the show has its roots in 200 B.C. - it certainly is exciting.

title: NEED FOR STOCKPILING WASTE DISPOSAL SITES
description: I applaud the initiative of Suffolk County Executive Michael A. LoGrande and the town supervisors in agreeing on the need for a countywide authority to deal with ash disposal, bypass material and recycling.

title: SHEILA M. MURPHY BECOMES THE BRIDE OF JAMES BUCKLEY
description: St. Mary of the Bay Roman Catholic Church in Warren, R.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Sheila Mary Murphy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Murphy of Warren, to James F. W. Buckley, a son of Judge and Mrs. James L. Buckley of Sharon, Conn., and Washington.

title: PLAINS AREA TO BE PRESERVED IS ECOLOGICAL HISTORY TEXT
description: LEAD: THE history of the Hempstead Plains is as rich as the soil beneath the prairie grasses that once covered 60,000 acres in Nassau County.

title: MISS SACHS WEDS DR. DANIEL MILLER
description: Marjorie Sachs, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Allan M. Sachs of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and Dr. Daniel Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Miller of New York, were married yesterday at the High Tor Vineyards in New City, N.Y. Judge Kenneth S. Rones of the Clarkstown Justice Court in New City performed the ceremony.

title: INTERNATIONAL MENU, ECLECTIC DECOR
description: THE Ship's Galley Restaurant on Main Street in Sag Harbor might look like a summer snack spot designed to attract tourists searching for burgers and brew, but it isn't.

title: A Step Back in Time With the Artisans
description: Anyone who has made the glittering crossing of the Ponte Vecchio in Florence recently might well have missed the big white tears painted on the bronze bust of that secular saint of the jewelers, Benvenuto Cellini. The consummate Renaissance man - goldsmith, swordsman, scholar and creator of the most beautiful saltcellar of all times - is in mourning, it seems. Although some blame the unkempt travelers who camp out on his bridge of dreams, others attribute Cellini's sadness to the plight of his descendants, the modern artisans of Florence.

title: BEAST HAS VINELAND ON ALERT
description: SOMETHING in this rural Cumberland County city, a place where farmland, businesses and tree-lined streets blend into the shadowy surrounding countryside, is indiscriminately slaying household pets and livestock by night.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Amityville $227,500 289 South Bay View Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old waterfront ranch; eat-in kitchen, dining room sunken living room; taxes $3,600. Bayport $235,000 106 Fairview Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; den, basement, office, enclosed porch; taxes $4,000. Blue Point $150,000 109 Division Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old colonial; dining room, family room, 4-car garage; taxes $2,800. Lake Grove $186,000 12 Sussex Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; family room, den, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $3,500. Levittown $144,000 17 Radial Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300. Rocky Point $88,500 66 Acacia Road 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old summer cottage; 1-room guest cottage, 100- by 100-foot lot; taxes $522. OTHER AREAS Brick Township, N.J. $113,000 595 New Jersey Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old Cape Cod; patio, hardwood floors, 1-car attached garage; taxes $1,248. Ossining, N.Y. $224,000 40 Lee Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 27-year-old frame split level; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage, walk to school; taxes $3,468. Madison, Conn. $270,000 91 East Wharf Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, circa 1890 Victorian; old moldings, walk to beach; taxes $1,337.

title: CARLTON PENAVERA-CABOT IS MARRIED TO CARLA PELLEGRINO IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: Our Lady of Victory Roman Catholic Church in Centerville, Mass., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Carla Anne Pellegrino and Carlton PenaVera-Cabot. The Rev. Robert G. McMillan performed the ceremony.

title: Exploring the Hill Towns of Tuscany
description: LEAD: A spate of shimmering days in late summer, when visibility seems endless and tourists are few, made imperative a long postponed trip to revisit some cherished hill towns. Tuscany and neighboring Umbria are at their best in that midseason before the grapes are harvested. The colors are intense, the sun still very warm, the nights cool.

title: AIR, LIGHT AND CITY PLANNING
description: To the Editor:

title: Reporter's Notebook: An Invitation From 'Fat Tony'
description: Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno, a powerful Mafia chief, was being escorted from the courtroom after a session in his racketeering trial when he suddenly approached a prosecutor to make a personal comment.

title: HER WIT AND HIS HEART MAKE A MOVIE TEAM
description: LIKE MOST MOVIE MAKERS, Frank Perry didn't stop to think how his latest film would fit into the body of his work when he began shooting it. He thought about how funny the script was. The movie, ''Hello Again,'' by Susan Isaacs, is the story of a Long Island housewife who dies and is brought back to life by her occultist sister a year later. She finds that her husband of 20 years has married her best friend (a fashion writer), moved to Manhattan and pursued the trendy celebrity life of a high-priced plastic surgeon.

title: For the Camper, No Dearth of Sites
description: CAMPERS in New Jersey can literally tour from site to site. More than 130 well-equipped campgrounds dot the state, from the mountains in the north to the southern shore.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
EXERCISE
description: LEAD: Senior Shapeup Produced by Creative Fitness. Yablon Enterprises. P.O. Box 7475, Steelton, Pa. 17113. 49 minutes. $29.95 plus $4 shipping and handling. This ''combination workout'' (sitting and standing exercises), intended for reasonably active people 50 and over, is a standard stretching and strength-building program that could be practiced by anyone of any age.

title: At The Courthouse, the Barber Shop and the Drugstore, They're With North   In Illinois, He Gets Hero's Reception and Is a Star at Soap Opera Time
description: If he sat down at the lunch counter in Your Corner Drug Store here, Col. Oliver L. North could straighten out all the commotion.

title: Don't Count Out Conservatism
description: In demonstrating that Reaganism has yet to run its course, Irving Kristol seems to take particular glee from the fact that Reaganomics, by running up a huge Federal debt, has foreclosed the liberal agenda for the foreseeable future. Has it occurred to him that Mr. Reagan's debt has also foreclosed any Government agenda? For a few years of ''morning in America,'' this Administration has squandered our Government's wealth, its economic power and its ability to respond with flexibility and ingenuity to future economic crises. WILLIAM W. ANDREWS New York City

title: DOROTHEA L. DIX: AN EARLY ADVOCATE FOR WORLD'S MENTALLY ILL
description: Dorothea L. Dix, author and teacher, humanitarian, healer and crusader for the poor and mentally impaired, was born in Hampden, Me., in 1802 and died in Trenton on July 18, 1887.

title: FOM NOANK TO THE WORLD, LOBSTERS BY THE BOX
description: LEAD: FORMER residents of New England may trade bone-chilling winters for beaches and palm trees, but they cannot seem to bid a permanent adieu to one feature. They still yearn for lobster.

title: HOW SHOULD THE METS HANDLE THE RIFTS ON THEIR TEAM?
description: The simple solutions to the Mets' current internal strife would be to trade this one, or fine that one, or just simply put a clamp on news media contact with all players. Yes, it would be simple - but it would deal only with the symptoms and not with the problem.

title: Headliners; A Hopeful Schools Chief
description: The mood was upbeat at the Brooklyn headquarters of the New York City Board of Education last week as Robert F. Wagner Jr. was elected unanimously to his second term as president. In the coming year, he said, he intends to obtain a commitment from businesses ''to hire any student graduating from a New York City high school.''

title: MISS FLANIGAN WED TO DR. MARC YLAND
description: Kathrynne Edwards Flanigan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur C. Flanigan of Riverhead, L.I., and Dr. Marc Joseph Yland, the son of Jos G. M. Yland of Doorwerth, the Netherlands, and Marianne Smoor of Wassenaar, the Netherlands, were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Riverhead by the Rev. Richard Adinolfi of the United Church of Christ.

title: WRITING A WINNING SITCIM: CAN THE CRAFT BE TAUGHT
description: SOMETIMES IT SEEMS THAT almost everyone in Los Angeles has an idea for a situation comedy. Waiters, secretaries, taxi drivers, masseurs and college professors happily confide in strangers about the script that they're writing during their off-hours. When the American Film Institute announced last summer that it would be holding a three-week workshop for comedy writers hopeful of breaking into television, the institute received scripts from 355 applicants for the 10 openings in the workshop. Even the bag lady who frequented the Hollywood neighborhood where the institute is situated came in with a script and her $25 application fee - in nickels, dimes and quarters. (The A.F.I. refused to take her money but did read her script; it was rejected.) Now, in the kind of wish fulfillment that keeps other novices' hopes alive, four of the writers who participated in that workshop have had their scripts filmed for a one-hour program, ''The American Film Institute Comedy Special,'' to be broadcast Wednesday night at 10 on NBC; the network funded the workshop. Dick Van Dyke acts as host, and John Larroquette, Jason Bateman, Susan Ruttan, Joel Brooks, Kaye Ballard and Glynn Turman are among the actors who worked for scale to appear in the sketches by the four writers.

title: Drunken Driving And a Murder
description: IT was just a year ago that Donald F. James - a distillery executive and ''an exceptionally fine person,'' in the words of a minister who knew him -left a company party in Louisville, Ky., after midnight and drove head-on into a murder indictment.

title: I PLEDGE ALLEGIANCE TO MYSELF
description: LEAD: THE ELIZABETH STORIES By Isabel Huggan. 184 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: Ballet: The Bolshoi's 'Raymonda'
description: ''RAYMONDA,'' which the Bolshoi Ballet presented for the first time Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House - with Lyudmila Semenyaka triumphant in the title role -was originally choreographed in 1898 by Marius Petipa for Russia's Maryinsky Ballet.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: AT THE LAB Have you seen any good atomic piles lately? Or whisper tubes? Or solar collectors? If you haven't, but would like to, the Brookhaven National Laboratory is the place to be Sundays throughout the summer. Today, as is its custom, the Upton-based lab, which was the site of the world's first nuclear reactor built for peacetime research (hence the atomic pile), starts its weekly summer tours.

title: NANTUCKET MAY OBTAIN LAND
description: Townspeople have authorized $6.2 million to buy a private water company that serves 70 percent of this island in a deal that could include 68 acres of undeveloped land.

title: TRANSIT BRIEFS
description: LEAD: THE roar of jet airliners leaving and bound for Newark International Airport is beginning to generate political noise and calls for new studies to explore ways to ease the problem.

title: Dr. Thomas F. Waddell, 49, A Founder of Gay 'Olympics'
description: Dr. Thomas F. Waddell, one of the founders of the Gay Games for homosexual athletes in 1982 and a sixth-place finisher in the decathlon at the Olympic Games in 1968, died at his home in San Francisco yesterday morning. He was 49 years old. His wife, Sara Lewinstein, said by telephone that Dr. Waddell had died of complications related to AIDS.

title: LESSONS LEARNED
description: BACK when hula hoops were de rigueur, shooting color-print film demanded extraordinary patience. One took a roll of exposed film to the corner drugstore, or put it into a mailer and shipped it off to Kodak, and waited. Some two, three or four weeks later, the prints and developed negatives would wend their way back.

title: Animals Trapped for Jersey Highway Project
description: Before getting down to roadwork here, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority has been practicing a little wildlife management.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ''AIR FORCE SPOKEN HERE'': General Ira Eaker and the Command of the Air. By James Parton. (Adler & Adler, $24.95.) Born the son of a Texas tenant farmer in 1896, Air Force Gen. Ira Clarence Eaker rose from humble origins to become one of America's aviation pioneers and air power leaders. Promoted to brigadier general one month after the United States entered World War II, he completed difficult wartime assignments, including command of the storied Eighth Air Force and the Mediterranean Allied Air Forces.

title: FOOD FOR THE HUNGRY
description: More than one million meals were provided for hungry people in the county last year, 63 percent more than in 1985, according to figures compiled this month by the Coalition for the Homeless in Westchester.

title: Tug-of-War at the Top Roils India's Politics
description: At any other time, Mithilesh Kumar Sinha would have been dismissed as an eccentric embarked on an impossible quest for the Indian presidency.

title: LAUREN J. HUDSON IS WED IN BOSTON TO R.D. RAABE JR.
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Boston yesterday Lauren Jean Hudson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F.Donald Hudson of Boston, was married to Roderick D. Raabe Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raabe of Tokyo and Chathamport, Mass. The Rev. John A. Cranston performed the ceremony.

title: Lasix and Racing
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ballet: New Casts in Bolshoi Program of Excerpts
description: THE ''highlights'' programs that have been presented by the Bolshoi Ballet during its season at the Metropolitan Opera House are both a blessing and a curse. Nerves and a go-for-broke attack can diminish that wonderful Bolshoi quality of engagement or total immersion in the dance, as they did in some of the new casting and new divertissements offered in performances on Wednesday and Thursday.

title: Plotting a Global Attack Against Farm Subsidies
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN has proved a master of the machinery of new ideas, some workable, some not, and the idea he proposed last week looked like one of the latter. Mr. Reagan asked the governments of the world, most of them popularly elected, to join him in bargaining away much of the aid they give the farmers who help keep them in power. The President's own Congress rebuffed his attempt nearly two years ago to cut back aid to agriculture, and now he presumes that all legislatures can collaborate in doing what his own would not.

title: Myers and Johnson Save Game for Mets
description: Think of it: 30 home runs, 30 stolen bases. It is one of baseball's most elusive and intriguing marks, a record that requires a blend of power and speed in one player.

title: Judge Blocks a Plan to Burn Barge's Garbage in Brooklyn
description: A State Supreme Court Judge has temporarily barred New York City from burning refuse from the garbage barge Mobro in a Brooklyn incinerator.

title: Getting a Seat At Paris Salons
description: Each year fashion writers converge on Paris in late January and late July to view the new summer and winter haute couture collections. After the initial showing, the 24 houses open their doors to the public.

title: SHAPING A NEW CONSCIOUSNESS IN SCULPTURE
description: ''SCULPTURE OF THE 80'S'' IS the messy title of a basically successful exhibition of work by 10 sculptors, all women, at the Queens Museum through next Sunday. One reason why Ileen Sheppard, the museum's director of exhibitions, chose the title was to try to oblige the public to approach the work primarily as sculpture.

title: IS COLLUSION THE NAME OF THE GAME?
description: ON MAY 1, RICH GEDMAN SWALLOWED his pride and signed a contract with the Boston Red Sox that will pay him $1.8 million over the next two years. Despite what appear to be lucrative terms, Gedman, a 27-year-old all-star catcher, felt cheated. He had become a free agent at the end of the 1986 season, but failed to receive a competitive offer from any team other than the Red Sox.

title: Mountains And Mystique
description: As a regular reader of Malcolm Browne's science acticles, I found his essay an amusing change. However, at the risk of finding myself grouped among his ''malicious bores,'' I must point out that K-2 is not the only name borne by the new contender for highest mountain. It also is commonly, albeit not officially, called Mount Godwin-Austen, after Col. Henry H. Godwin-Austen, a 19th-century English geographer who prepared the first map of the area. That surely is a less ''threadbare'' name than K-2, and even carries the snob appeal seemingly attached to hyphenated surnames. LAWRENCE E. RANDALL Highland Falls, N.Y.

title: LONG ISLAND FOLLOW-UP
description: LEAD: Bone Marrow Match A 33-YEAR-OLD Islip social worker who began a worldwide search for a bone marrow donor after developing leukemia more than a year ago has found his match.

title: Proprietary Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: The Changing Baseball, Through the Eras
description: The offense-defense balance in baseball has gone through distinct eras. Generally speaking, the period before 1920 is called the ''dead ball'' era, not only because the baseball itself was less resilient than later, but also because one ball, used and scuffed, was kept in play much longer during the course of a game, and because pitchers were allowed to doctor and discolor it in various ways.

title: JANE L. COLOMBO MARRIED TO PETER JEROME MCGUIRE
description: Jane Lauren Colombo and Peter Jerome McGuire were married yesterday at the Congregational Church of Manhasset, L.I., by the Rev. Thomas Roan, who was assisted by the Rev. John S. Hayes, a Roman Catholic priest. The couple's parents are Dr. and Mrs. Anthony T. Colombo of Locust Valley, L.I., and Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. McGuire of Aurora, N.Y.

title:
DINING OUT;
ITALIAN FOOD: WHY IT'S SO POPULAR
description: LEAD: IT MUST sometimes seem that we spend an inordinate amount of time writing about Italian restaurants in this column. However, given the large Italian-American population in New Jersey, it's no more unusual than to find reviewers in Texas writing about Tex-Mex food.

title: The American Approach: On AIDS, We Have More Answers Than Questions
description: AS AIDS has grown from a handful of mysterious cases in New York and California into a deadly worldwide epidemic, it has also become a vexing political issue. In forums ranging from local school boards to the White House, struggling officials debate what to do. For better or worse, they are devising policies that are increasingly inconsistent with one another.

title: 'SNOW WHITE' AT 50: UNDIMMED MAGIC
description: BEFORE STEVEN SPIEL-berg and George Lucas, before ''The Wizard of Oz,'' before all other animated cartoon features, there was Walt Disney's ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.''

title: A German Controversy: What To Do? Bavaria Has Some Strict Ideas
description: TO the accompaniment of a sensational and sometimes anguished debate, the southern state of Bavaria last month put into effect some of the stiffest AIDS regulations yet ordered anywhere in the world, including mandatory blood tests for prostitutes, drug addicts, prison inmates, applicants for civil-service jobs and some foreigners seeking residence in Bavaria. They also provide for isolating some AIDS carriers, at least in extreme cases.

title: FRATERNITIES ADMIT WOMEN INTO RANKS
description: ERIC B. TWOMBLY of Mystic joined Delta Psi, a social fraternity at Trinity College in Hartford, because that was the fraternity his father joined when he was at Yale 40 years earlier.

title: A Dissident Returns to Seoul From U.S. With Congressman
description: A dissident who has lived in the United States for more than four years returned to Seoul today with a Congressional escort.

title: ANN ELIZABETH JACOBUS IS WED TO V.J. KORDAHL
description: Elizabeth Jacobus, a daughter of George H. Jacobus of Delray Beach, Fla., and Elizabeth Jones Jacobus of Dallas, was married yesterday to V.James Kordahl, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Kordahl of San Francisco. The Rev. Douglas Verdin, a Methodist minister, officiated at the Edgartown, Mass., home of the bride's father and stepmother.

title: Medical Care Sharply Curtailed by Doctors' Protest in Florida
description: Protesting a steep increase in malpractice insurance rates, many physicians in the two most populous counties in South Florida have sharply curtailed their services since the beginning of the month.

title: RECALLING A ONE-OF-A-KIND GRANDFATHER
description: IT'S FUNNY, sitting around talking about the time that Grandpa ate live minnows. In fact, my cousin Barbara Jean mentioned that he didn't even clean them off; he just picked them up out of the net and swallowed them.

title: Judge Expected to Approve Plan To Integrate Housing in Yonkers
description: A Federal judge has indicated that he will accept the housing integration plan that the Yonkers City Council approved last week under the threat of a contempt-of-court citation and crippling fines.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANTS VS. DEER: WHAT WORKS
description: LEAD: WERE Walt Disney Studios to re-release the film ''Bambi,'' it would probably be picketed by suburban gardeners throughout the area. Just the mention of deer to a gardener from the outer suburbs is sufficient to elicit a response akin to that of a commuter who has been cut off in heavy traffic.

title: BOSTON LOSES PRIZE LOBSTER
description: A 30-pound giant lobster scheduled for display at the New England Aquarium here died after a fall from a scale, an aquarium spokeswoman said Friday.

title: A Livelier Ball? Let's Check the Statistics
description: IS the 1987 baseball juiced up or isn't it? An exceptional number of home runs flying over fences during the first half of this season has stimulated this discussion, which seems to arise every few years when scoring statistics fluctuate.

title: Jazz: Jungle Orchestra
description: THE original ''jungle band'' was the early Duke Ellington Orchestra that played exotic arrangements to match the ''jungle'' decor for the Cotton Club's legendary stage shows. Pierre Dorge and the New Jungle Orchestra, an 11-piece band from Copenhagen making its New York debut at Sweet Basil this week, deliberately evokes this tradition of ''chinoiserie,'' or cheerfully inauthentic exoticism in jazz.

title: Islamic Fundamentalism Gains in Egypt
description: Islamic fundamentalists are quietly gathering strength in Egypt, a troubled nation where the very rhythm of life is still set by the five daily calls to prayer from countless minarets.

title: Tent City: Scratching to Find Shelter for Nation's Homeless Families
description: SALES of new homes plummeted 14.9 percent in May, the biggest decline in five years, according to the latest Commerce Department reports. The reason for the decline, the department noted, was that first-time home buyers had been driven out of the market by rising mortgage rates. But those same economic forces, which for May pushed down the National Association of Realtor's affordability index - a measure of the feasibility of home buying for middle-class people - can also drive some of the poor into substandard or doubled-up housing, and prevent some of them from finding any housing at all. Nationally, low-income units have been disappearing at the rate of half a million a year, while salaries and public assistance levels have not kept pace with housing costs. The pressure is particularly acute in gentrified urban areas and in growing retirement or resort communities. Last week, concern that low-income families might be displaced from their homes led a Federal district judge in San Francisco to block the Reagan Administration's planned sale of 257 Federal mortgages on low-income housing around the country. Federal regulations on rents and types of tenant might no longer apply after such mortgages were paid off. When the Administration proposal was announced in April, Howard Cohen, a Boston lawyer who represents developers, noted that investors in his area would have a strong incentive. Apartments that go for $300 a month would command $800 on the open market, he said, adding: ''The people living in these units could not afford to pay open-market rents.''

title: A Country, Not a Lament
description: By the end of the first day, a journalist visiting Israel again is convinced that things have become so complicated that he knows nothing anymore and that there are no solutions to anything.

title: Knight Reflects on Former 'Family'
description: LEAD: RECENTLY, Ray Knight, the Orioles' third baseman whose baseball address for the previous three summers had been Shea Stadium, received a videotape of the 1986 World Series from his sister. Knight, who was the most valuable player in the Series, said that when he viewed his seventh-game home run, tears came to his eyes.

title: Keeping Heat on Panama's Military
description: Panama's military-controlled Government offered conciliatory gestures with little success last week. The civilian President, Eric Arturo Delvalle, broadcast an appeal for ''a truce in our passions'' aroused in five weeks of political turmoil. He called for a speedy investigation of ''grave charges'' of corruption, electoral fraud and political murder, which a former associate had leveled against the military commander, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Lean and Mean?
description: To the Editor:

title: Kyoto Has Fans For All Reasons
description: The dark old storefront of Miyawaki Baisen'an, with the silver, gold and vivid pigments of its sheaves of fans gleaming faintly from the dim interior, bespeaks a tradition that goes back over a thousand years, to the first flowering of classical Japanese culture. Heavy fans made of cypress slats held together with silk cords were part of the formal accouterment of the aristocrats who attended the imperial court during the Heian period (794-1185) and thereafter. Over the centuries the slats became thin ribs covered with paper, and the folding fan took on the form we know today.

title: The Trial Begins At Chernobyl
description: Chernobyl in the Soviet Ukraine has been a virtual ghost town since April 26, 1986, the day of the disastrous explosion of the nuclear reactor 11 miles away. Last week, a handful of people returned, not to live there, but to attend the trial of the men the Soviet Government says were responsible for the world's worst nuclear accident.

title: Why Business Is Barging Into the Classroom
description: IN Alabama a few weeks ago, the General Electric Foundation donated $1 million to upgrade the Lowndes County public schools.

title: MARKETING ART PRINTS
description: LEAD: ''THERE'S nothing wrong with having a large number of people enjoy quality art, even if it's not original,'' said the president of a company that produces limited-edition art prints that are sold by more than 1,000 galleries throughout the country.

title: ANDREA GODBOUT BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Andrea Godbout and John C. Gulla were married yesterday at the Tavern on the Green in New York by the Rev. Victor Marchioro, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Hartford Gets Blunt About Hiring Goals
description: WHEN the Connecticut Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities rejected an affirmative action plan by the State Veterans Home and Hospital Commission last month, it did not merely point out problems, return the paperwork and wait for a new proposal.

title: DRAFT RESISTER BEGINS A 3-YEAR TERM IN PRISON
description: Wearing a T-shirt bearing the words ''justice is a constant struggle,'' David Gillam Kerley, a 26-year-old law student at the University of Wisconsin, departed for Leavenworth Federal Penitentiary in Kansas on Friday to begin a three-year term for refusing to register for the military draft.

title: Remembering Mr. Lomax
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Slowing Down on Santorini
description: Coming to Santorini for a week had been something of a challenge. Could two Type A New Yorkers whose vacations usually involved skiing or doing something culturally serious (and one of whom had a very short attention span for lying on beaches) find happiness spending an entire week in Santorini, one of the Cycladic islands in the southern Aegean?

title: PROSPECTS
description: Global Market Growth

title: Army Auditors Urging Unit to Sell 3 Airplanes
description: Army auditors say the Corps of Engineers should sell three airplanes designated for use in emergencies because top officers of the corps had used the planes for expensive trips overseas.

title: PAIGE R. GILLETTE MARRIES LAWYER
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York yesterday Paige Renee Gillette, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Gillette of Palm Beach, Fla., New York and Southampton, L.I., was married to Thomas Carter Louthan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carter Thomas Louthan of Short Hills, N.J., and Wainscott, L.I. The Rev. C.Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: Data Bank: July 12, 1987
CROPSEY DEBATE
description: THE tempest over Jasper Francis Cropsey's tranquil ''View at Hastings-on-Hudson'' continued unabated last week as both sides in the dispute defended their positions and one - the Hastings Historical Society - began legal proceedings to prevent the sale of the painting.

title: WALTER E. KINGSTON
description: Walter E. Kingston, an authority on powder metallurgy, died of cancer of the liver on July 4 at his home in West Caldwell, N.J. He was 81 years old.

title: HARRY'S LUCK
description: HARRY HOPKINS Ally of the Poor and Defender of Democracy. By George McJimsey. Illustrated. 474 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25.

title: Keeping Southland All in the Family
description: Southland's decision to sell itself to its founding family keeps it out of the hands of such possible hostile bidders as the Belzbergs or the Dart Group. Instead, the company that operates 7-Eleven stores will be sold for about $5.1 billion to a company run by John P. Thompson, the chairman; Jere W. Thompson, the president and chief executive, and Joe C. Thompson Jr., a director. To take the company private, the brothers say they will sell most of its assets, except the convenience stores and its half interest in Citgo. Southland was founded in 1927 as an ice company. * * *

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Builders Deplore Curbs in Wetlands Law
description: LEAD: A TOUGH a new law to protect freshwater wetlands, signed by Governor Kean early this month, got a mixed reaction from New Jersey developers.

title: FIRE ISLAND GETS HELP ON EROSION
description: LEAD: YEAR-ROUND residents of Fire Island love the rugged wilderness of their barrier island. They fiercely resist such mainland amenities as asphalt roads and stone curbs. Rather than see the island's old dirt road from Kismet to Robert Moses State Park paved over, they prefer to dodge the potholes scoured out by rainstorms.

title: HOW-TO
description: Building Bookcases Woodworking Series. DIY Video Corporation, 5250 Seventy-Seven Center Drive, Charlotte, N.C. 28210. 40 minutes. $19.95. This cassette gives the viewer a good demonstration of the techniques involved in building an attractive bookcase - providing one has access to a well-equipped power-tool workshop. No allowance is made for the fact that most home workshops are not as well equipped as the one shown, and many of the techniques and accessories used apply only to those who own a Shopsmith combination tool (the manufacturer happens to be one of the sponsors of this cable TV show).

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE SEARCH FOR THE REAL NANCY REAGAN. By Frances Spatz Leighton. (Macmillan, $19.95.) If this is the unauthorized biography of the First Lady, one shudders to think what the authorized version will be like. Frances Spatz Leighton, a journalist and the co-author of ''My Thirty Years Backstairs at the White House'' and other books, is so sympathetic to Nancy Davis Reagan that she almost becomes one with her. During the 1980 Presidential campaign, ''poor Nancy'' hoped the press would be kind. ''Dreamer, she,'' the author writes, describing the furor that resulted when Nancy called homosexuality ''a sickness.'' ''Couldn't she please anyone? It was enough to make a girl cry. But then she remembered the saying that always made her stiffen her spine and fight on: 'A woman is like a tea bag. You never know her strength until she is in hot water.' '' The only place Nancy could escape the press was at the California ranch, where she and Ronnie strolled hand in hand, pointing out special places. ''Here lay Ronnie's dog, Fuzzy, who had been put out of his pain when the arthritis in his hips had become unbearable. Ronnie had been very sad about what had to be done. He had given Fuzzy all the treats he wanted one day, just at the end. Had Fuzzy understood?'' Fortunately for our heroine, and our author, there is life after the White House. ''Nancy will no doubt go back to lunching with The Group at Chasen's in Beverly Hills. She will keep the top designers busy. She will be able to buy whatever she wants, at whatever the price. . . . And weekends, she will still putter around the ranch with Ronnie.''

title: Warren Buffett's Pricy 'Bargain'
description: Is Warren Buffett, the master investor, worth two times book value? That seems to be the issue in valuing the conglomerate he oversees, Berkshire Hathaway Inc. The thinly traded shares were quoted last week at about $3,500, versus a book value around $2,600. But one investment adviser contends they should be worth $5,200.

title: COMING TO TERMS WITH THE ISLAND
description: IT is difficult for me to believe, but I am coming to terms with Long Island.

title: Turmoil in Haiti Stalls Political Progress
description: After more than three weeks of turmoil, a political stalemate has developed in Haiti with the troubled country's march toward democracy stalled and the fate of its presidential election in question.

title: Fairfield Finds Problems in Success
description: As the year 2000 approaches, Fairfield County faces growing problems tied to its fabled prosperity, particularly a labor shortage and a dearth of affordable housing, according to a report by an advisory group of 800 public and private leaders.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Allentown, Pa.: Peopling A Warehouse
description: LEAD: AMID grimy textile mills and neighborhoods of row houses, a warehouse once owned by Mack Trucks has been converted into a 161-unit apartment complex.

title: Growing Up With Privilege and Prejudice
description: Karen Russell's articulate indictment of racism in this country is right on the mark, and comes at an opportune moment, as we celebrate the 200th anniversary of our Constitution. I would disagree only with Ms. Russell's contention that the conservative movement under the leadership of President Reagan has resulted in a return to the old racism of the 1950's and before. It never really left us. WILLIAM C. STEBBINS Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Ahnahkaq Henson, 80, Dies; A Son of Explorer With Perry
description: Ahnahkaq Henson, the half-Eskimo son of the American polar explorer Matthew A. Henson, has died, relatives said today. He was 80 years old.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: JULY 12, 1987
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 1 WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) A rich orphan comes of age as she travels the world. 2 2 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $3.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia. 3 3 THE EIGHTH COMMANDMENT, by Lawrence Sanders. (Berkley, $4.95.) The theft of a priceless Greek coin brings a dynasty's scandals to light. 4 6 ACT OF WILL, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Bantam, $4.95.)
