These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: New York Inspectors Cite Food Outlets For Health Offenses
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 17 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Drysdale Brushes Back Pitchers and Batters for Beanings
description: DON DRYSDALE, thinking back to a different era in baseball, recalled how, one opening day, Jim Ray Hart of San Francisco went to bat for the first time and ''got it right in the coconut.'' The pitcher was Bob Gibson.

title: Changing Names
description: To the Editor:

title: THE TRASH THAT WON'T GO AWAY
description: One of the points that stands out most forcibly in the article ''Toxic Ash: Garbage That Won't Go Away,'' on June 21, is that garbage-to-energy plants are no cure for the trash that is slowly engulfing us.

title: Next Week; Who's Not In Hall of Fame Who Should Be?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Sports of The Times; Baseball, Beanballs And Thon
description: ANDRE DAWSON, like so many other batters who have been hit by pitches this season, got up from the Wrigley Field dirt last Tuesday and charged the mound. But three years ago, Dickie Thon didn't get up. He was carried off on a stretcher. He had been struck in the face by a fastball flung by Mike Torrez, then a Mets' right-hander. And now, finally, Dickie Thon has left the Houston Astros, the vision in his left eye still impaired.

title: How the White House Lost Its Big Bank Battle
description: WHEN word began to circulate on that muggy Thursday three weeks ago that Representative Jim Leach was the swing vote on a contentious banking bill, the calls started coming into his office.

title:
MUSIC;
WATERLOO PLANNING A PAVLION
description: LEAD: PERCIVAL E. LEACH, the president and co-founder of Waterloo Village, has announced plans for a performance pavilion to be constructed at the village.

title: BATTLE FLAGS RESTORED TO THEIR OLD GLORY
description: LEAD: TO the untrained eye, the tattered moldy battle flags may not look like much, but to Norman Stevens, a University of Connecticut graduate student, the strips of faded, sometimes muddied, silks speak eloquently of courage, honor and personal sacrifice.

title: Mayor, Councilmen Survive A Recall Drive in Galveston
description: Mayor Jon Coggeshall and four City Council members today survived a recall attempt sparked by a half-finished trolley sytem. Mr. Coggeshall survived by a 4,779-to-3,749 vote, while the four Council members fared about as well, City Secretary Patsy Poole said. The turnout was about 25 percent. The $12 million system is being built with Federal, state and private money. Supporters said it would help revitalize the aging resort. Opponents say it would benefit only a few and would delay repairs to other public facilities.

title: A NEW SMELL FOR SUCCESS
description: ONCE UPON A TIME, FRAGRANCES were created around elaborate tales of love and conquest.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A PROPOSAL TO SUPPORT THE OLYMPIC GAMES
description: LEAD: CONGRESS is considering a bill that would authorize gold and silver coins to commemorate the participation of U.S. athletes in the 1988 Winter and Summer Olympic Games. The bill is sponsored by Representative Frank Annunzio, an Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Subcommittee on Consumer Affairs and

title: Growing Up With Privilege and Prejudice
description: As a black man, what I find ironic is that Karen Russell displays a conk (straightened hair), admits to a ''white'' accent and tells us that she plans to use her talents for Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's campaign, and thus against the Rev. Jesse Jackson's.

title: Off-Duty Officer In Military Uniform Is Shot in the Head
description: An off-duty police officer wearing a Naval Reserve uniform was shot and critically wounded yesterday morning near his home in Queens, apparently as he was being robbed, the police said.

title: Dealings Broke No Law, Meese Says
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said last week that he had broken no Federal ethics law in his financial dealings. Confident, at times combative, he told a Senate hearing on Government ethics that he knew from the start that his investment partner had ''some connection'' with the Wedtech Corporation, but that he ''didn't pay much attention.'' There was ''no conflict of interest,'' he said, in his partnership with W. Franklyn Chinn, a consultant and director of Wedtech.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All roads now bypass North and lead to Poindexter. What he is going to say now is the mega-question.'' - Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois. [ 13:1. ]

title:
ART;
BRONX SHOW LOOKS AT ORIGINS OF FOOD IN ''NATURAL' SETTING
description: LEAD: EVERY time one attempts to categorize the Bronx Museum of the Arts, a new wrinkle appears. The museum sponsors several ''satellite galleries'' apart from its central location on the Grand Concourse, and the latest site is also the most unlikely: the executive offices of Krasdale Foods Inc. in the Hunts

title: Cardinals' Streak Is Snapped
description: Bob Brenly knocked in two runs with a homer and a single as the San Francisco Giants beat St. Louis, 3-1, snapping the Cardinals' nine-game winning streak.

title: Turkey's Westward Yearnings
description: IRRITATED by pressure from its NATO allies and beset by criticism at home, Turkey's civilian leaders are seeking to emerge from the shadow of the generals who seized power in the early 1980's, a process that seems ponderous, lonely and uncertain.

title: My Blue Heaven: What If Tenants In the Projects Owned the Place?
description: SALES of new homes plummeted 14.9 percent in May, the biggest decline in five years, according to the latest Commerce Department reports. The reason for the decline, the department noted, was that first-time home buyers had been driven out of the market by rising mortgage rates. But those same economic forces, which for May pushed down the National Association of Realtor's affordability index - a measure of the feasibility of home buying for middle-class people - can also drive some of the poor into substandard or doubled-up housing, and prevent some of them from finding any housing at all. Nationally, low-income units have been disappearing at the rate of half a million a year, while salaries and public assistance levels have not kept pace with housing costs. The pressure is particularly acute in gentrified urban areas and in growing retirement or resort communities. Last week, concern that low-income families might be displaced from their homes led a Federal district judge in San Francisco to block the Reagan Administration's planned sale of 257 Federal mortgages on low-income housing around the country. Federal regulations on rents and types of tenant might no longer apply after such mortgages were paid off. When the Administration proposal was announced in April, Howard Cohen, a Boston lawyer who represents developers, noted that investors in his area would have a strong incentive. Apartments that go for $300 a month would command $800 on the open market, he said, adding: ''The people living in these units could not afford to pay open-market rents.''

title: FOR THE CONSERVATION OF WATERFOWL
description: THE 1987-88 migratory bird hunting and conservation stamp is available from Postal Service philatelic sales outlets and many post offices. These stamps, known to collectors as ''duck stamps'' are issued annually by the Department of the Interior and must be carried by waterfowl hunters who are at least 16 years old. The new addition to this series depicts three redhead ducks.

title: 173 BEDS FOR ELDERLY APPROVED
description: FOR the first time in nearly a decade, state health authorities have tentatively approved a major increase in the number of nursing-home beds for the county.

title: CHINA'S CULTURAL CRACKDOWN
description: HARSHLY, AND WITH a dramatic suddenness, the climate of free expression that blossomed last summer and developed throughout the fall in China has chilled. Nearly all intellectual and creative life has been stifled by a renewed compulsory obeisance to Marxist and Maoist dogma. Young intellectuals and artists who just six months ago captivated foreign scholars and journalists with their refreshing candor now refuse to meet with them for fear of being singled out for criticism, or even banished to some remote province.

title: ANNE DAVIS BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in York Harbor, Me., Anne Mumford Davis, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard A. Davis of Villanova, Pa., was married yesterday to Jon Milton Peterson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton V. Peterson of Fairfax, Va., and York Harbor.

title:
RECORDINGS;
FROM RUSSIA, TREASURES NEW AND OLD
description: LEAD: THEIR AIMS MAY DIFFER slightly, but the coincidence is certainly happy: two American record producers - Sheffield Lab and Mobile Fidelity Sound Labs - have just issued an important series of recordings from the Soviet Union that will surely be remembered as landmarks in the discography of Russian music making.

title:
ANTIQUES;
MARITIME THEME IN PERTH AMBOY
description: LEAD: MANY PEOPLE harbor a dream of putting together a collection of items worthy of a museum. However, few have the means or the singular vision necessary to accomplish such a goal.

title: Pop Music
description: Alternative, independent, post-punk, new wave - whatever it's called at the moment, this is the week for it. During the day, music moguls, would-be moguls, producers, performers and disk jockeys will convene at the Marriott Marquis Hotel in New Music Seminar 8, with panel discussions and hobnobbing Sunday afternoon through Wednesday (for seminar information, call 722-2115). And with all those movers and shakers in town, more than 200 bands from all over the place will be performing.

title: SPAIN SHOWS MODERN ART IN A VINTAGE SETTING
description: IN THE DECADE OR SO SINCE FRAN-co's death Spain has undergone countless changes, but surely one of the most dramatic is in contemporary art. During this short time, the country has assumed a prominent place on the art world's map. Madrid has once more become the site of a bustling gallery scene and a stop on the tours of major international exhibitions. Barcelona has undertaken an ambitious public sculpture program. Spanish artists are showing abroad with increasing frequency and artists from around the world find ever more reason to journey to Madrid, Barcelona, Seville and Valencia.

title: MOVIES
description: The Lightship Starring Robert Duvall, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Michael Lyndon. Directed by Jerzy Skolimowski. 1986. CBS/Fox Video. 87 minutes. $79.98. Set in 1955, ''The Lightship'' is Jerzy Skolimowski's tale of the good, the bad and the innocent. A Coast Guard lightship picks up three men in a motorboat who turn out to be killers on the run. The gunmen seize the vessel, with the trio's loquacious leader (Robert Duvall) and the lightship's captain (Klaus Maria Brandauer) squaring off in this claustrophobic nether world. On board is the captain's teen-age son, who anxiously observes the deadly battle for possession of the ship and his very soul.

title: Sikh Terrorists Kill 72 in Attacks on Buses in India
description: Sikh terrorists killed dozens of Hindu bus passengers last week, touching off a new round of sectarian violence and challenges to Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Government. On Monday night, 38 bus passengers were shot to death and more than 20 wounded in the northern state of Punjab, where Mr. Gahdhi had dismissed the Sikh governor in May in an effort to restore public order. On Tuesday, 100 miles to the southwest, 34 more bus passengers were killed and 30 wounded in Haryana, a predominantly Hindu state situated between Punjab and New Delhi. Five hundred people have been killed this year in Sikh-related violence.

title: A Sailor' Club Rigged For the Computer
description: Sailors for whom the term ''user-friendly'' means access to a computer and a modem will find that the governing body of their sport, the United States Yacht Racing Union, is on line 24 hours a day to answer questions.

title: Generosity's Price
description: 'Ten years ago the pressures on me were to see that Champion did more for the community. But the world has changed. Today, greed is in and we are told greed and intolerance are good for the country and for the company. But I don't see it that way.'

title: Different Fortunes for Two Champions; METS' MOMENTUM IS A THING OF THE PAST
description: SWEET bliss, 1986. It was a season made for the movies, a summer full of cloudless days. The Mets were feisty and arrogant and unchallenged throughout baseball. They reveled in their curtain calls at home, they fought willingly, almost happily, on the road. And they won.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; The Radon Risk Brings a Surge in Testing
description: THE Harrisons have been concerned about radon. ''For the minimal cost and peace of mind, we decided to have our house tested,'' said Mary Ann Harrison.

title: Olympic Champion Wins Impressively
description: At the start of the seventh round of Meldrick Taylor's junior welterweight bout today against Irleis (Cubanito) Perez, Lou Duva, co-manager of Taylor, turned to a ringside spectator and said: ''Isn't he beautiful?''

title: ROBERT BOOKMAN WED TO KATHLEEN A. CARNEY
description: The marriage of Kathleen A. Carney, the executive director of the New York City Board of Standards and Appeals, to Robert S. Bookman, a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Goldfeder & Bookman, took place yesterday at the 24 Fifth Avenue restaurant in New York. Rabbi Terry Bookman, the brother of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Headliners; Confessional Politics
description: Asserting that ''the best policy is to be as straightforward as possible,'' Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, a Democratic Presidential candidate, stood by with less than his usual sang-froid last week as his wife, Kitty Dukakis, disclosed that she had once been addicted to amphetamines. She said her dependency started when she was 19 with a prescription for diet pills and lasted 26 years, though she had been free of it since seeking treatment five years ago. Among the benefits of recovery, she said, after pausing to wipe a tear from her husband's cheek, was increased enjoyment of her life: ''On drugs, you do not stop much to smell the roses.''

title: DINA A. MIGLIO MARRIES EDWARD ROJAS, LAWYER
description: At St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, L.I., yesterday, Dina Ann Miglio, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Miglio of Manhasset and Southampton, L.I., was married to Edward J. Rojas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eduardo Rojas of Miami.

title: LANESA L. WHITE WED TO DR. FRANK LEANA JR.
description: Lanesa Legvold White, a daughter of Mrs. Sam Legvold of Ames, Iowa, and the late Mr. Legvold, and Dr. Frank C. Leana Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leana of Watertown, N.Y., were married yesterday at the couple's home in Manhattan.

title: Recent Sales
description: Aberdeen $109,500 1303 Wellington Place 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 4-year-old condominium apartment; den, fireplace in living room, terrace; maintenance $77, taxes $1,500. Brick Township $113,000 595 New Jersey Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old Cape Cod; patio, hardwood floors, 1-car attached garage; taxes $1,248. Levittown, L.I. $144,000 17 Radial Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300.

title: MEDICAL LEAVE BILL: L.I. OPINIONS SPLIT
description: LEAD: THE Long Island business community appears split on proposed Federal legislation to require employers to offer medical leave for employees who have a serious health problem ar a young child or elderly parents to care for.

title: Roundup of Ripkens
description: THE Ripkens of Baltimore made baseball history last night when 22-year-old Billy joined 26-year-old Cal Jr. in the Oriole lineup managed by their father, Cal Sr. When Billy was brought up from Rochester Friday and started at second base alongside his brother, the shortstop, in last night's game against the Minnesota Twins, it marked the first time a father had managed two sons in the major leagues.

title: Bo Jackson's New Hobby: Football
description: Bo Jackson, the rookie outfielder for the Kansas City Royals, said today that he would like to play for the Los Angeles Raiders in the National Football League as a hobby ''like hunting or fishing.''

title: Making Arms
description: To the Editor:

title: Doing the Needful
description: LOOKING FOR A wife? The classified advertising section of The Hindustan Times in New Delhi offers a match with ''a beautiful homely girl'' from a good family. Set a time to meet, but if you're especially eager, you can always ''prepone'' the visit.

title: A DEFERENTIAL FATHER AND A SON WHO WAS DIFFERENT
description: MY father was a peasant.

title: Looking Forward to the Casino Society
description: THOUSANDS of pages have been written on the question of what American industry must do to become competitive in the world market, or at least in the American market. Experts usually tell us that we must learn to make desirable products of good quality at reasonable prices. The same experts, faced with the question: ''How do I become the major league batting champion?'' would undoubtedly reply: ''Strike the ball accurately into portions of the field where the opposition cannot intercept it.'' Easy to say, in other words, but hard to do.

title: What Is to Be Done About the Bork Nomination; Political Creationism
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Free Trip' to Las Vegas
description: A company in Queens, N.Y., National Listings Network Corporation, has been operating a ''free trip to Las Vegas'' telephone offer and making unauthorized charges to credit cards, according to the Better Business Bureau. The bureau says it has been obtaining refunds for consumers who have complained about the company, of 163-17 Depot Road, Flushing, since February 1986. But it said late last month that it had still been unable to halt the operation and had referred the matter to the New York State Attorney General's office and to other law authorities.

title: STYLIZATION GILDS THE BOLSHOI'S 'GOLDEN AGE'
description: IT IS A VERY DIFFERENT BOLSHOI Ballet - boasting a dazzlingly talented new generation of dancers - that has arrived on our shores for a two-month national tour, the first since 1979. Yet, it is also the Bolshoi, more than any other company, that fits the old French saying that the more things change, the more they remain the same.

title: Reagan Signs Bill on Spending
description: President Reagan today signed a $9.4 billion spending bill, voicing misgivings about many items but saying he did not want to hold up loans for farmers in the summer growing season.

title: THE QUICK KILL WILL KEEP THINGS LIVELY
description: QUICK, decisive victories are not worth a hundreth of a point more than long, slogging ones. But they do enliven your tournament.

title: HISTORY
description: American History, 1914-1929: Warring and Roaring MasterVision. New York, N.Y. (212) 879-0448. 60 minutes. $64.95. ''Warring and Roaring'' is a whirlwind, high-school-level historical tour of the United States during World War I and the 1920's -the ninth of 10 videotapes in McGraw-Hill's MasterVision series on American history. It is divided into two half-hour segments, chronicling America during the war and its aftermath, described variously as ''a time of growing conflict between those who could accept change and those who could not'' and one of ''rising prosperity and declining idealism.''

title: Chrysler Fined for Safety Violations
description: Just as Chrysler's chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, had finished apologizing for ''dumb'' and ''unforgivable'' behavior involving disconnected odometers, he had a new, potentially more serious problem to confront. Last week, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration fined his company more than $1.5 million for 811 violations, including willfully exposing workers to lead and arsenic. (By ''willful'' the Federal agency meant that the company knew of the exposure problems but failed to correct them.) The penalty was believed to be the largest the Government has imposed for job and safety violations, although it was only a fraction of the $1.4 billion in profits Chrysler earned in 1986.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Manteno, Ill.;
A New Lease On Life
description: LEAD: TO people in the Chicago area, the tiny town of Manteno was known for its mental hospital. But in 1983 Gov. James R. Thompson announced that state budget reductions would force the closing of the Manteno Mental Health Center.

title: NATURE
description: World of the Sea Otter A Production of Marine Mammal Fund. Fort Mason Center, Building E., San Francisco, Calif. 94123. 30 minutes. $39.95. Frolicsome, bewhiskered and great natural aquatic performers, sea otters have charmed an untold number of nature lovers who have observed them at play in the kelp beds off California's central coast. This short film basks in the star presence of these captivating creatures, which have an admirable supporting cast that includes condo-sized (and harmless) basking sharks, California sea lions, Brandt's cormorants and Medusa jellyfish.

title: Two Close Calls For Air Travelers
description: In May, looking apprehensively to the busy season, the National Transportation Safety Board warned of an apparent ''erosion of safety'' in the air traffic control system and a growing number of near-collisions.

title: ...AND INSECT THAT ATTACKS HEMLOCKS
description: LEAD: FROM the patio of the former Phipps mansion at Old Westbury Gardens, the eye is drawn to the stately hemlock hedges that rim the wide yard and the grassy walkway that stretches beyond. The hedge is ''one of the finest collections of clipped hemlocks in the East,'' according to Robert Bowden, assistant director of Old Westbury Gardens.

title: Limiting Your Liability for a Rental Car
description: SHOULD you buy accident coverage when you rent a car? Until recently, the answer for most people was no: Customers were only expected to pick up the first $500 of damage if they declined to pay the $5 daily fee for insurance coverage. ''It was a ridiculous price,'' to cover so small a risk, said J. Robert Hunter, president of the National Insurance Consumer Organization.

title: Priming the Jobs Pump
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A Travel Advisory item June 14 gave an incorrect telephone number for Vermont tourist information. The correct number is 802-828-3236.

title: DEBORA L. TOFFEY BECOMES THE BRIDE OF R. C. PUCKETTE
description: The wedding of Debora Lynn Toffey, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H.James Toffey of New Vernon, N.J., to Richard Charles Puckette, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles McDonald Puckette 4th of Scotia, N.Y., took place yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in Madison, N.J. The Rev. Nelson Thayer performed the ceremony.

title: IRAQ SAYS IT REGAINED GROUND
description: Iraq said today that its troops staged a surprise attack on Iranian forces during the night, reoccupying areas in the southern Iraqi marshes near the Majnoon oil fields.

title:
FOCUS: CINCINNATI;
Suburban 'Lakesides' Blooming
description: LEAD: IT's the still-hot end of a scorching June day in suburban Blue Ash northeast of Cincinnati. Not too far away from Shirley Stonehill's condominium, the cars move steadily under the harsh yellow parking lot lights of the corner shopping center.

title: Outdoors; Exploring Wildlife of China
description: ABC-TV's final Mutual of Omaha Spirit of Adventure Series for the season, ''Uncovering China's Hidden Wildlife,'' is a splendid production that serves to remind us that man, this planet's ultimate predator, now holds the fate of so many less fierce and less adaptable creatures in his hands.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANTS VS. DEER: WHAT WORKS
description: LEAD: WERE Walt Disney Studios to re-release the film ''Bambi,'' it would probably be picketed by suburban gardeners throughout the area. Just the mention of deer to a gardener from the outer suburbs is sufficient to elicit a response akin to that of a commuter who has been cut off in heavy traffic.

title: The Iran-Contra Hearings: Needless Muck
description: LEAD: A visitor from Mars - or from Europe - who tuned in the Iran-contra hearings might well wonder what on earth is going on here. What's the purpose? Why is the nation being put through this particular ringer by all these sanctimonious and solemn members of the House and Senate, with their hundreds of staff aides and lawyers and investigators and press-release writers, not to mention the armies of jostling reporters and cameramen and technicians and producers?

title:
GARDENING;
PLANTS VS. DEER: WHAT WORKS
description: LEAD: WERE Walt Disney Studios to re-release the film ''Bambi,'' it would probably be picketed by suburban gardeners throughout the area. Just the mention of deer to a gardener from the outer suburbs is sufficient to elicit a response akin to that of a commuter who has been cut off in heavy traffic.

title: 13 SHOW LATEST COLLAGE CONCEPTS
description: LEAD: THIRTEEN of the innumerable contemporary artists who use pasting techniques in their work are represented in ''Collage and Construction,'' the current exhibition at Temperance Hall Gallery in Bellport. Selected with the help of Joan and John Digby, authors of ''The Collage Handbook,'' the show illustrates some of the concepts behind recent work in the various media that constitute collage.

title: VICTORIA MORASH AND T. M. EVARTS WED
description: The marriage of Victoria Lee Morash, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell F. Morash of Lexington and Nantucket, Mass., to Thomas Morgan Evarts took place yesterday at the Follen Community Church in Lexington. The bridegroom is a son of Josephine Evarts of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and the late Maxwell Evarts. The Rev. Donald Cutler, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Polly L. Guild, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Sunday in the Zoo With Penguins
description: WHEN the San Francisco Zoo decided to put a new slant on its fund raising, it called in the penguins - and invited them to brunch.

title: Dance Festival in Durham
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance
description: Audiences can now enjoy scenery as well as choreography, as dancers take to the great outdoors and give concerts in all sorts of urban and sylvan locations. Holly Fairbank and Dancers will perform at the edge of the pond in Central Park between 100th and 103d Streets on Friday and Saturday at 6:30 P.M. Appropriately enough, Ms. Fairbank's work is called ''Pooldance.'' Perhaps some dance fans who attend her Friday program may remain in the park afterward, when Yves Musard, a French choreographer, and the Crowsfeet Dance Collective, which specializes in social-protest choreography, will present works at 8 P.M. at the Central Park Bandshell.

title: Two More Escapees Caught
description: Two escaped convicts were recaptured today, the police said. Michael Romero and John Schmidt were the third and fourth escapees captured since seven inmates pole-vaulted out of the state prison a week ago. Two teen-agers who were briefly held hostage by the pair today were freed after suffering minor injuries, the police said.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Laconia, N.H.: Building With Blocks
description: LEAD: IN the Lakes Region of New Hampshire, an area surrounded by woods in a state where lumbering is a major industry, Robert E. Shapiro says his company, the Omni Group of Braintree, Mass., can build high-quality houses at competitive prices by using prebuilt wood products imported from Sweden.

title: Public Campaign Financing: Close but No Cigar
description: IT was not for lack of trying that the Legislature adjourned this session without a bill changing the way New York City campaigns are financed.

title: Lake George Views: Adirondack Appeasement
description: Building in the 6 million-acre Adirondack Park in upstate New York can be a delicate undertaking. In many new projects, the Adirondack Park Agency can dictate exactly how much land remains untouched and which trees may be chopped down. ''It's a very difficult place to develop,'' said Peter J. Cornell, an executive vice president with the Galesi Group of Rotterdam, N.Y., a diversified company that does real estate development.

title: THE SURPRISES OF A ROADHOUSE
description: THE name Redding Roadhouse sounds as though it is telegraphing exactly the kind of tavern you'd find along a roadside. But the name is a bit of a put-on, and this new restaurant-cum-pub is considerably more interesting than the straightforward name leads one to expect.

title: In Sultry New York, Tourists Are Undaunted
description: On a sweltering day, when temperatures reached 93 degrees in Central Park and many New Yorkers fled for the beach, tourists nonetheless came in droves to the Visitors Center in Times Square.

title: ACOUSTICS AREN'T JUST TRIMMINGS
description: TESTY READERS OCCASIONALLY WRITE TO complain about what they perceive to be critics' obsession with the acoustical properties of concert halls. Why reiterate that Avery Fisher Hall's acoustics are glaring? they grumble. Or that Carnegie Hall may or may not be slightly better or worse or different from what it was before its renovation? Or that the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum of Art sounds dead? Or that the new Weill Recital Hall - soon to be tinkered with - is painfully raucous and harsh?

title: Hidden Cost
description: To the Editor:

title: IN ADDITION TO 9 LIVES, PET INSURANCE
description: LEAD: A PAINFUL dilemma faced J. Scott Henderson when his dog was ill: he, like many pet owners, had to choose between paying a large medical bill for his dog or having the pet destroyed to avoid a long and agonizing illness.

title: Sports of The Times; Odd Holiday For Doctor K
description: A young man in a light-blue summer suit was wearing, uncustomarily, spectacles, with blue rims whose color coordinated with his suit.

title: BE FRUITFUL AND MULTIPLY
description: THE BIRTH DEARTH By Ben J. Wattenberg. 182 pp. New York: Pharos Books. $16.95.

title: A MOVING REVIVAL OF 'ALL MY SONS'
description: THE Westport Country Playhouse in Connecticut is now running plays for two weeks instead of one. Practically speaking, this means you have six more days - tomorrow through Saturday - to catch up with one of the contemporary theater's most powerful American dramas, Arthur Miller's ''All My Sons,'' in a moving, intelligent production.

title: Abolish Medicare, Broaden Medicaid
description: The Reagan Administration's naivete in sending a limited ''catastrophic illness'' Medicare bill to Congress is now being graphically demonstrated. Lots of Congressmen want to turn it into a traditional legislative ''Christmas tree'' with goodies available for everybody. Hence the proposals to add drug benefits, increased home care and nursing home coverage, etc. The orgy may yet give us a national health insurance bill that would really bankrupt this country. The multi-trillion dollar national debt has been forgotten in the Congressional spoils rush.

title: IMPROMPTU TOPPINGS MAKE PIZZA AN EASY SUMMER TREAT
description: HOMEMADE pizza is one of the easiest dishes to make for weekend guests during the summer. If you have a food processor, the dough can be prepared in seconds. Of course, a couple of hours is needed for rising, but dough can be made beforehand, allowed to rise and frozen until it is needed.

title: 'WOP BOP ALOO' IN BRIDGEPORT
description: AT the Downtown Cabaret Theater in Bridgeport, they've built a repertory of representative musical ''decade shows,'' from ''Speakeasy'' (the tunes of the 20's) to ''Ticket to Ride'' (the sounds of the late 60's). A sampler of what hit the pop charts during the early 60's - and the late 50's - ''Wop Bop Aloo Bop Awop Bam Boom,'' a chaotic collage subtitled ''A Rock 'n' Roll Dance Party,'' had its premiere during the summer of 1984 and is now being revived, in revised form.

title: JUDITH MCCLURE WEDS DR. RICHARD HESSNEY
description: Judith Hiatt McClure, a teacher of business education at the Sleepy Hollow High School in North Tarrytown, N.Y., and Dr. Richard Charles Hessney, an associate editor of Reader's Digest in Pleasantville, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Old Dutch Church of Sleepy Hollow in North Tarrytown. The Rev. Gerald P. VanderHart of the Reformed Church of America performed the ceremony.

title: 'Quality Housing' Zoning Nearing a Vote
description: A MAJOR component of New York City's master plan to promote housing construction has been forwarded with broad, but not unqualified, support to the Board of Estimate, where it is scheduled for a public hearing on Thursday.

title: Provencal Fare Beyond Baumaniere
description: It's astonishing how two rather insignificant words - Les Baux - can conjure up such blissful, romantic images for generations of American travelers to France. For decades, travelers have been making gastronomic pilgrimages to Les-Baux-de-Provence, the tiny perched village that is home to L'Oustau de Baumaniere, the luxurious restaurant that has held on to its coveted three Michelin stars for more than 30 years.

title: Baltimore Mayor Opens Bid
description: Mayor Clarence H. (Du) Burns officially has begun his campaign to become the city's first black elected Mayor, six months after he was appointed to the post. Mayor Burns, a Democrat who was previously president of the City Council, was appointed in January when his predecessor, William Donald Schaefer, became Governor. He joins four other Democrats and three Republicans in the mayoral race. The primary is set for Sept. 15.

title: KATHERINE VOSSEN MARRIES
description: Katherine Vossen and Stephen R. Wilson, a correspondent in Rome for The Associated Press, were married yesterday in the Little Sanctuary of St. Albans School in Washington. Canon Charles Martin, headmaster emeritus of St. Albans, performed the Episcopal ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Luc Vossen of Brussels. Mr. Wilson is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wilson of Washington.

title: Schaffhausen's Mesmerizing Falls
description: The mightiest river cataracts in Europe, on the Rhine near Schaffhausen, Switzerland, are no match for Niagara Falls or nature's majestic waterworks in Latin America and Africa. Yet the Rhine Falls have attracted and awed visitors for centuries, and they still do.

title: Potato Chips With Hawaiian Crunch
description: The lowly potato chip is not rated very high on the ladder of four-star gastronomic delights. It is probably not rated at all compared with glistening Beluga caviar, translucent slices of smoked salmon, plump fresh foie gras and slivers of crisp black truffles. But on the island of Maui in Hawaii can be found a potato chip that can compete with the finest of foods and renders all other potato chips pedestrian.

title: The Dordogne
description: To the Editor: The article on hiking in the Dordogne (Travel, June 7) sounded very much like our own experiences along the Grande Randonnee system in France. First introduced to it through an earlier article (''France's Appalachian Trail'' by former Representative Henry S. Reuss, Travel, May 23, 1982), we have since hiked on many segments, but mostly in the southwest and in Brittany. That article opened up a new world for us in our travels.

title: The Biggest Farm Debt: $68 Million and Growing
description: ALL that is left of the Tex-Cal Land Management grape and almond farm lies behind an old winery near the San Joaquin Valley town of Delano, where acres of junked tractors, pickup trucks, earth scrapers and plows gather dust under a scorching sun.

title: Okamoto Shoots 66 To Increase Lead
description: Ayako Okamoto of Japan overcame 90-degree heat to shoot a six-under-par 66 today and take a six-stroke lead in the $400,000 du Maurier Classic.

title: Hands Up, S.D.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: WHY THE SKY IS BLUE
description: MEDITATIONS AT SUNSET A Scientist Looks at the Sky. By James Trefil. Illustrated by Judith Peatross. 208 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $16.95.

title:
GARDENING;
PERENNIAL GRASSES CAN BE PLANTED FOR ELEGANCE
description: LEAD: ORNAMENTAL perennial grasses are used to make dramatic statements in landscapes. They come in tufts, sweeps and bunches. Some droop at the tips to form fountains of green, while others stand stiff and straight, like pencils jammed into a jar. Heights vary from a foot to eight feet or more.

title: AN ELECTRONIC WATCHDOG CALLS WOLF, WOLF, WOLF
description: THIS is in part a tale of one family's efforts to seek an alternative to suburban living - an apartment in the city and a house in the country, for us, the best of two worlds. But it's really the story of how the introduction of computer technology into that environment can create an incongruous mix.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: RICHARD COBDEN: A Victorian Outsider. By Wendy Hinde. (Yale University, $30.) Through a remarkable combination of persistence, charm, intelligence and eloquence, the Manchester businessman Richard Cobden became an outspoken Member of Parliament and won fame that was to outlast him as an advocate of free trade at home and abroad.

title: A Pardon for North?
description: You have to give Colonel North credit - millions of it. He not only can shred the Constitution, but stand to gain by what's left of it. For even if the law catches up with him, he can always count on a Presidential pardon.

title: NURSING HOMES: A HAVEN, NOT A HORROR
description: NURSING HOMES used to be perceived as places where people were sent in order to wait to die.

title: Different Fortunes for Two Champions; GIANTS HAVE A QUIET OFF SEASON
description: TWO months ago, Phil Simms and Phil McConkey of the Giants were in Los Angeles to make a National Football League instructional video. So were such players as Eric Dickerson, Tony Dorsett and Todd Christensen.

title: Now Batting Against Jim Crow...
description: AS THE baseball season reaches its midpoint, it is time that we reflect on a player who literally changed the very face of the game.

title: FAMILIAR FESTIVAL OPENER
description: IN CELEBRATION of its 25th anniversary, the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's recent opening night was festive indeed, what with pre-performance parties - seven going on simultaneously in private homes nearby -and post-performance toasts and tributes held under an elaborately decorated tent on the Drew University campus, where the company is in residence.

title: North Wins The Public At Expense Of Superiors
description: AFTER all those months of waiting, all those months of television pictures of the mute marine ducking out of his house and into his car, Ollie North talked last week, and the nation liked what it heard. Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, most people concluded, was neither a nut nor a lone wolf but a classic specimen of manly rigor and character - not a national hero, as President Reagan had suggested, but not the villain that others had portrayed.

title: MORRIS MUSEUM FAILS ITS TEST
description: THE State Council on the Arts has the Jersey City and Morris Museums tied up, the first with the New Jersey Arts Annual, of which it is the sponsor, and the Morris Museum with the council's 1985-1986 Visual Arts Fellowship exhibition.

title: What Is to Be Done About the Bork Nomination
description: To the Editor:

title: Relevant Ignorance
description: WE ARE IN THE midst of another assault on dumbness. This one was ignited by evidence of amazing ignorance among young people. For instance, do you know about the recent survey of California college students? Half of them couldn't locate Japan on a map.

title: A RETURN TO THE LAND OF FAIRY TALES
description: THE LAST DECADES HAVE SEEN a revival of interest in, and enjoyment of, theatrical, balletic and operatic performances based on old-fashioned fairy tales. From the American Ballet Theater's recent ''Sleeping Beauty'' to the City Opera's 1986 staging of Massenet's ''Cendrillon'' to the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical ''Into the Woods,'' coming to New York in October, large and sophisticated audiences typically attend such spectacles and are enthralled by them. Many and varied reasons explain this predilection, among which only the most obvious is the pleasure derived from happy memories of childhood experiences that can now be enjoyed in an adult manner.

title: Sense and Criticism
description: To the Editor:

title: Street Parking By Credit Card?
description: AS Mayor Koch saw it, the coin-operated parking meter was doomed in New York, victim of a curse of riches. With 62,778 meters and a quarter buying as little as 10 minutes of parking in the streets, the city was hard put to keep the coin boxes from overflowing.

title: Undercard of Triplets
description: THE triplet brothers of Mike Weaver, a former heavyweight champion, get back into action today, forming the undercard for the Frank Tate-Troy Darrell United States Boxing Association middleweight title bout in Atlantic City. Floyd, Lloyd and Troy, are 12 years younger than their famous brother, Mike, who won the World Boxing Association title on March 31, 1980 by knocking out John Tate in the 15th round. Weaver held the title until Dec. 10, 1982, when he was knocked out in the first round by Michael Dokes.

title: Growing Up With Privilege and Prejudice
description: Karen Russell writes: ''How will I deal with racism in my life? I have no brilliant solution.'' I think Ms. Russell has asked a pertinent question and given the appropriate answer, because each time you're confronted with a blatant or subtle act of racism, hatred or bigotry, you are not sure of how you will react. The only certainty is that you will lose respect for that individual. The best advice is to be yourself and to enlighten the ignorant through your deeds and accomplishments. LYNDA D. WOODS Monmouth Junction, N.J.

title: Q. & A.: CLEANING GUTTERS, CAULKING CRACKS, REMOVING PAINT
description: Q. LIKE many other homeowners, I have a continual problem each fall with leaves and other debris accumulating inside the rain gutters around the outside of my house. I deal with this in the same manner as most homeowners do - by climbing up on a ladder and scooping all the debris out of the gutters. However, some of my gutters are quite high and for all practical purposes virtually inaccessible. I do have protective wire cages or guards over the downspout openings, but this doesn't seem to be enough because the leaves and twigs seem to accumulate along the entire length of the gutter. Is there any method you can suggest that I can use to protect or modify my gutters so as to eliminate - or at least reduce - this problem of leaves accumulating inside the gutters?

title: STEVE MARTIN REVISES 'CYRANO'
description: THE ROOMS IN STEVE MARTIN'S house flow into each other like tributaries joining a giant river.

title: Bork Opponents: N.A.A.C.P., N.E.A. And Biden, Too
description: The nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court was gathering opposition last week. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the National Education Association announced at their conventions that they would fight it, while liberal lobbying groups organized their mailing lists. And in a private meeting, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, the Judiciary Committee chairman and a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, told civil rights leaders he would lead the battle against Judge Bork in the Senate.

title: A Father's Pictures
description: IN ALL THE TIME I WAS GROWING up, I never heard my father speak about what it was like to have been at Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941. He showed us photographs instead. He had grown up in the Hawaiian Islands, traveled to New York City to study photography with Margaret Bourke-White, then returned to Hawaii as a Navy photographer. When the bombs fell, he witnessed the whole thing through a viewfinder, becoming one of the few to capture the onslaught on film.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
DINING OUT
description: LEAD: THE silver-haired woman circled the salad bar at the Sizzler Steak Seafood and Salad Restaurant in Yonkers. There were dozens of bowls piled high with fruit, cheeses and vegetables; vats of soup and spaghetti, even a stack of tostada shells served with spicy ground-meat filling. Onto her plate she ladled spinach with creamy ranch-style dressing, sliced tomatoes, corn relish, and a marshmallow-and-jello concoction known as ambrosia.

title: FIGHTING THE GREENHEAD FLY...
description: LEAD: THE greenhead fly is back.

title: Religion Notes; Indian Week-Bible Week Observance: a Conflict
description: When the National Council of Churches called on its membership recently to observe American Indian Week over the Thanksgiving holiday next November, it thought the matter relatively noncontroversial. The other day, however, an angry letter arrived at the council offices complaining that the observance ''raises a conflict that disappoints and saddens.''

title: On East Side, Bars Upset Residents
description: Once, the summer predawn hours on many streets in the East 80's were quiet, and a dog walker could stroll at 1 A.M. past the murmur of conversations winding down in bars and restaurants.

title: CORRECTION
description: A San Francisco dispatch on June 7 about efforts to restore native plants in California misidentified an area where the removal of eucalyptus trees has been proposed. It is Golden Gate National Recreation Area in Marin County.

title: SALES VIRTUOSO: Gene Tupper; Perfecting the Art of Selling a Steinway
description: EXCEPT for a brief Army stint, Gene Tupper has been surrounded by Steinways all his life. For 49 years his mother, Alice, gave piano lessons in Estherville, Iowa, on a series of used Steinway uprights. ''I always had a love affair with the Steinway,'' said the 61-year-old Mr. Tupper, recalling his early days of studying and teaching piano. As a young man he dreamed of performing, but recognized early on that ''I was too self-conscious to play before others.''

title: Bad Argument
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Misery on the Meatpakcing Line
description: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response from readers. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of the letters it elicits.

title: CRIME
description: Of recent debut mystery novels, THE INCURSION by Dirk Hanson (Little, Brown, $16.95) stands out. Many first novelists tend to write from their own background, and Mr. Hanson is no exception. He is a specialist in computer technology and has written a book about it, ''The New Alchemists.'' In ''The Incursion'' he sticks to the things he knows. His novel is an exciting and, in some sections, mesmerizing look at the geniuses, nerds, eccentrics and hackers of Silicon Valley. Basically it is about the new terrorism - computer terrorism.

title: ART, EVIL AND THE POET
description: LEAD: COLLECTED PROSE By Robert Lowell. Edited, and with an introduction, by Robert Giroux. 377 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: FUND TO STIMULATE AFFORDABLE HOUSING
description: THE county now has a green light from the State Legislature to open a $4 million coffer to communities that want to build affordable housing.

title: W. F. ALLMAN, WRITER, WED TO PATRICIA DILLON
description: Patricia Anne Dillon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Dillon of Newport Beach, Calif., was married at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Spring Lake, N.J., yesterday to William Foster Allman, a son of Martha O'Leary of Bay Head, N.J., and James J. Allman of Mountain Home, Ark.

title: Pregnant, Unmarried and Much in the Public Eye
description: Like a growing number of single professional women in their 30's, Liz Walker decided that, married or not, it was time to start a family.

title: A ONE-DAY-A-YEAR GLIMPSE INTO THE PAST
description: LEAD: ALMOST like Brigadoon, the mythical Scottish village that came to life just one day every 100 years, Johnsonville, a restored Victorian village in East Haddam, comes alive to the public one day a year.

title: A PROPOSAL: SEND OUT THE CLONES
description: FOR YEARS, I'VE BEEN wishing for a record that delivered quietude - one that wouldn't drown out ambient sound, but would tune out more din as I turned up the volume. Now, as science tiptoes onward, that device has been invented. It turns out to be not a record at all, but a computerized ''antinoise'' system that analyzes an offending racket and generates an equal but opposite racket in return, so that the two soundwaves cancel each other out. Hallelujah.

title: The Promise of a Global Farm Fix
description: While Congress backs into a policy of protecting failing industries, Reagan Administration officials are pursuing constructive fixes for America's trade woes. The President offers a plan for restoring trade leadership for America's largest and most efficient industry: agriculture.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: CLARKE & CATON, a Trenton-based architectural, planning and urban-design company, is coordinating a request for proposals for the development of five acres of land, most of it residential, abutting the Metuchen railroad station. The proposals are due by Aug. 14. Metuchen has been considering plans to redevelop its station area since 1980.

title: T-Shirts Crowding Bottles at Famous Boston Bar
description: In the old days, neighbors of the Bull and Finch on Beacon Hill would routinely drop by for a cheeseburger and a mug of draft beer. These days they complain to the management about the noise and exhaust from the tourist buses regularly depositing visitors at the bar that inspired the television series ''Cheers.''

title: Opera Orchestra Group Announces '88 Season
description: Leonie Rysanek, Aprile Millo, Gabriela Benackova, Mariella Devia and Samuel Ramey will sing with the Opera Orchestra of New York in concert versions of three operas during the organization's 1988 season. Eve Queler is the musical director.

title: FREDERIC SIEGEL, A LAWYER, AND BARBY KOGON TO WED
description: Barby Kogon, an account executive at the New York public relations firm of McGrath Power Associates, and Frederic J. Siegel, counsel to the New York law firm of Rosenthal Herman & Mantel, plan to be married next summer. The couple's parents are Dr. Paul and Dr. Lorraine Siegel of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and Mr. and Mrs. Allan A. Kogon of Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Seth, Not Death
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATURE WATCH;
CRANE FLY
description: LEAD: Tipula sp.

title: Q and A
description: Canadian Islands Question: Are there any places that provide lodging on the Queen Charlotte Islands of British Columbia? Do any airlines fly there? -N. J. L., Philadelphia Answer: The Queen Charlotte Islands, which, at the nearest point, are about 70 miles from Prince Rupert, British Columbia, have a few motels and lodges. There are six properties with a total of about 50 units in the town of Queen Charlotte. The Sandspit Inn in nearby Sandspit has 51 rooms, and in Masset on the north coast there are two lodges with a total of 35 rooms. The accommodations guide for British Columbia, which includes these places to stay, is available from the Ministry of Tourism for British Columbia (1117 Wharf Street, Victoria V8W 2Z2, Canada; 604-387-1642) and from the Canadian Consulate's Tourism Section (1251 Avenue of the Americas, New York, N.Y. 10020; 212-586-2400).

title: Player Cards a 67, Leads Seniors by 2
description: It seemed to Chi Chi Rodriguez and almost everyone else that it would be a two-man race between him and Gary Player in Sunday's final round of the United States Senior Open.

title: Saberhagen Wins 15th As Royals Defeat Jays
description: Bret Saberhagen pitched a three-hitter and won his 15th game of the season today as the Kansas City Royals beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 2-1.

title: The Stars Below
description: The middle-aged couple, sweltering through a night at the beach when the heat wouldn't stop, decided to go for a swim. Why not? They would hardly be missed by children and old folks long asleep. They put on bathing suits and slipped out onto the beach, sloppy and cool at low tide.

title: Now It's Glitter Mouse
description: ''I'VE been a Disney girl since I was a child,'' said Wendy Gell, a jewelry designer. ''I was planning on approaching Disney; before I had the chance, they came to me.''

title: HEATHER MITCHELL AND P.B. MURPHY MARRY IN CHICAGO
description: Heather Holden Mitchell, the daughter of Mary Ann Mitchell of Hunting Valley, Ohio, and Holden Charles Mitchell of Woodbridge, Conn., and Peter Bradford Murphy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Bradford Murphy of Little Silver, N.J., and Harwichport, Mass., were married yesterday at St. Chrysostom's Episcopal Church in Chicago. The Rev. George A. Hull performed the ceremony.

title: Dance of Life Wins Tidal on Late Rally
description: Dance of Life, unable to catch Theatrical in his last two starts, had a chance to shine in that rival's absence yesterday and scored a three- and-a-half-length victory over Uptown Swell and Duluth in the $176,400 Tidal Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE ORDER OF BATTLE AT TRAFALGAR: And Other Essays. By John Bayley. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $15.95.) This collection of literary reviews, by a dean of English letters, opens with several pugnacious essays against the excesses of literary theory - against the formalists, structuralists and poststructuralists for whom ''literariness is a substitute for experience'' and thus who, like Terry Eagleton, ''cannot drink beer without a stratagem.

title: INTEREST IN BALLOONING IS SOARING
description: PHINEAS FOGG traveled around the world in one, and Dorothy tried to take one all the way from Oz to her home in faraway Kansas.

title: TOBA AND ELICIA WEINSTEIN PLAN TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Abe Weinstein of Garden City, L.I., have announced the engagements of their daughters Dr. Toba Aliyah Weinstein, who is planning to wed Dr. Joel Marshall Siev in November, and Elicia Robin Weinstein, who is to marry Barry Ira Krosser next March.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: JUDGING THE JUDGES OF 'BUSINESS CLIMATES';
We Never Said It Was a 'Business' Index
description: LEAD: Since its inception in 1979, Grant Thornton's annual study of general manufacturing climates has generated controversy. And every year, as the partner in charge, I ask myself why. My conclusion is that the criticism reflects an acute lack of understanding about the issues facing manufacturers in an increasingly competitive global marketplace.

title: MOSCOW ON THE POTOMAC
description: LEAD: THE SOUL OF VIKTOR TRONKO By David Quammen. 350 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $17.95.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
DOCUMENTARY
description: LEAD: The Princess and the People A BBC-TV News presentation. Written and produced by Gordon Carr. Color. Home Vision. 51 minutes. $29.95. Princess Diana is clearly the star of Britain's royal family. Judging by the hysteria aroused by last year's whirlwind visit of the Prince and Princess of Wales to Washington, Americans are under her spell.

title: Supreme Moment
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JULY 12, 1987
description: International 3-14 2,5.5,q>The Iran-contra investigation will continue to be aggressive despite the favorable public reaction to Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's testimony before the Congressional committees, members of the committees said. Page 1 White House officials mishandled their approach to the Congressional testimony of Colonel North and, in the words of one official, made themselves and the President look silly in the process. 12 Many marines praise Colonel North for the way he has conducted himself in his four days of testimony before the select Congressional committees, while expressing reservations about his judgment. 12 Soviet tanks are almost invulnerable to missiles carried by American infantry and aircraft because of an Israeli invention appropriated by Moscow's weapon designers, United States military officials report. 1 Australia's Prime Minister won a third term, apparently increasing his legislative majority. It was the first time that a Labor Government in Australia has won three successive elections. 1 Islamic fundamentalists in Egypt are quietly gathering strength. The rise of fundamentalism, along with the Government's many difficulties, are almost constant topics of conversation among intellectuals. 1 Self-help, Muslim style 10 Protests against Panama's leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, will increase, opposition leaders said. They have begun to discuss alternatives for a post-Noriega regime, amid signs that the Government's coalition is weakening. 3 Kim Dae Jung may run for president of South Korea. But the possible plans of the opposition leader, whose civil rights have been restored, chill many people in the Government and military, as well as rivals in the opposition camp. 11 Most Cambodians living in Thailand who have sought refugee status since the Vietnamese invasion of 1979 would be taken back by Cambodia, an assistant to Prime Minister Hun Sen declared. 9 Political stalemate in Haiti 3 Priests increasing in third world 4 Urban oasis in Soviet city 6 Russian criticizes delay on arms 7 Tug-of-war roils Indian politics 8 National 16-18, 22, 26-29 2,,q>Justice Lewis Powell reminisced on 15 years at the strategic center of the Supreme Court in a rare, three-hour interview. He provided insights into how the Justices worked together. 1 Saving plans for college tuition are being revived by political and educational leaders. The proposals have been spurred by fears that students and their families are being forced to borrow too much to pay for a college education. 1 The pit bull is generating anger. Cities and states, frightened by a steady flow of horror stories about attacks on people, have rushed to enact legislation to ban or regulate the dogs. 16 In a protest, many Florida doctors in the state's two most populous southern counties have sharply curtailed their services. The doctors are protesting an increase in malpractice insurance rates. 16 A directors' strike was called against NBC, Warner Brothers and Columbia Pictures, to begin Tuesday morning. In response, the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers will bar the directors from work at other production companies. 16 A draft foe entered prison for refusing to register with the Selective Service System. David Gillam Kerley, a 26-year-old law student at the University of Wisconsin, got the harshest sentence among 18 cases prosecuted. 22 Regional 20-24, 29, 33-34 2,3.5,q>The Legislature's session ended in Albany, with the legislators passing a host of last-minute bills that ranged from pay increases for themselves to a restructuring of the state's economic development programs. 1 A noisy procession of young drinkers are disturbing the peacefulness of the Upper East Side, some residents say. But one bar has been the focus of complaints: Dorrian's Red Hand, which gained notoriety from the Robert E. Chambers Jr. case. 20 Fairfield County faces problems as the year 2000 approaches. The growing problems are tied to the Connecticut county's prosperity, particularly shortages of labor and affordable housing, a report says. 20 Trying to stem a hepatitis outbreak, Onondaga County is requiring all restaurant workers to wear protective plastic gloves. The county has had 54 cases of hepatitis A, a nonfatal virus, diagnosed since May. 24 An outreach program for drug users, the Association for Drug Abuse Prevention and Treatment, tries to educate addicts about the risk of AIDS and enroll them in drug rehabilitation programs. 20 An off-duty police officer was shot and critically wounded near his home in Queens in what the police said was an apparent robbery attempt. The officer, George Scheu, was discovered on Murray Street in Flushing by a neighbor. 22 Tourists' enthusiasm for sightseeing was not diminished by the hot weather. They came in droves to the Visitor's Center in Times Square , asking questions from the predictable to the bizarre. 21 Yonkers housing plan to be accepted 20 Albany finale: Odd scenes 21 Reporter's notebook: Mob trial 23

title: Transsexual Presses Bias Case in New Hampshire
description: The New Hampshire judicial system is considering its most unusual discrimination case thus far, a case involving a transsexual.

title: Door Opens Wider For Nicaraguans
description: It was a Nicaraguan woman whose case prompted the United States Supreme Court to vote in March to reject the Government's strict standard for granting asylum to aliens. Last week the Reagan Administration said it would ease the standard and delay deportation for all her countrymen in exile here.

title: Reason for a Residence For Secretary of State
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Brookfield, Mass.;
Aquino Land Sold for Condos
description: LEAD: THE family trust fund of President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines has sold a weekend retreat in this central Massachusetts town for development as condominiums.

title: Garden of Peace: A Big Step Closer
description: THE odds were against another monument for Washington. But Elizabeth Ratcliff, a former English teacher and the mother of five in Berkeley, Calif., had this harmless idea: no statues, no political statements; just a garden dedicated to peace. Who can vote against peace?

title: HARRIMAN SOCIETY LISTS GOALS
description: LEAD: AS they listened to the reminiscences of Kennedy-era New Frontiersmen at an inaugural dinner last March in Eastchester, the founders of the Harriman Society pledged to revive public participation in the political and policy-making process.

title: DRESSING FOR OPULENCE
description: LEAD: IN contrast to today's everything-goes dress, a nostalgia-provoking exhibition at the New Canaan Historical Society focuses on outer wraps - opulent evening jackets and robes worn during the 1920's and 30's. Called ''Enchanted Evenings,'' it covers that lighthearted time between the World Wars, a time when people dressed lavishly for theater, opera and parties.

title: HERBERT VAN INGEN 3D MARRIED TO CISSY WADE
description: Trudy Treanor Wade, the daughter of Trudy Crockett Wade of Atlanta and George Emmett Wade Jr. of Columbus, Ga., was married yesterday to Herbert Terrell Van Ingen 3d, a son of Mrs. and Mrs. Van Ingen Jr. of Greenwich, Conn.

title: TATTERED REMINDERS OF WORDS TO INSPIRE A CHILD
description: THERE they lie. Mute evidence to the destructibility of all things. Once they stood upright, their spines proudly declaring: ''Shelley's Poems,'' ''Tennyson's Poems,'' ''The Golden Treasury of Songs and Lyrics,'' by Francis T. Palgrave. There are others too, slowly deteriorating. The leather has disintegrated and the gilt lettering crumbled. The covers have come apart from the backs, leaving a mess of loose pages.

title: How the Call of the Wild Pays Off
description: DETROIT Zoo directors have a dream. They want the world's best chimpanzee exhibit. What they envision is a four-acre recreation of an African forest where a colony of 25 to 30 chimps can live in captivity as they would in the wild.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Brookfield, Mass.: Aquino Land Sold for Condos
description: LEAD: THE family-trust fund of President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines has sold a weekend retreat in this central Massachusetts town for development as condominiums.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Carlsson to Meet Wilander: Kent Carlsson of Sweden overcame a 4-3 deficit in the third set yesterday to beat the defending champion, Andres Gomez of Ecuador, and advance to the final of the United States Pro Tennis Championships. In a rematch of last year's semifinal, the third-seeded Swede beat the second-seeded Gomez, 7-5, 4-6, 7-5. In today's final at the Longwood Cricket Club, Carlsson will play top-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden, who rallied after being 2 points from defeat to eliminate fourth-seeded Martin Jaite of Argentina, 0-6, 7-5, 6-0 in last night's other semifinal. (AP) Masur Upset: Dan Goldie of McLean, Va., ranked 113th in the world, upset third-seeded Wally Masur of Australia, 6-2, 4-6, 6-2 yesterday in the semifinals of the Volvo Tennis-Hall of Fame Championships in Newport, R.I. Goldie, the 1986 National Collegiate Athletic Association singles champion from Stanford University, will play in the first Nabisco Grand Prix final of his career today against Sammy Giammalva of Houston. Giammalva, ranked 96th in the world, upset fourth-seeded Christo van Rensburg, of South Africa, 6-3, 6-1 in the other semifinal yesterday.(AP) World University Games Triple Gold Winners: Noemi Lung, a Rumanian swimmer, and Yuri Korolev, a Soviet gymnast, yesterday became the first triple gold-medal winners at the games. After six days of competition, the Soviet Union held a commanding lead with nine gold medals to four for the Rumanians and three for the United States. Korolev won the rings in the men's individual apparatus finals with 19.70 points. Lung collected her third gold in the women's 400-meter medley. In five finals yesterday, American swimmers collected just three silvers and two bronzes. (AP) Rowing East Germans Dominate: The East German men's heavyweight team dominated the final of the Prix de Rotsee races, winning three gold, three silver and one bronze medal in the eight categories of racing yesterday on the first of this two-day Lucerne International Regatta in Switzerland. The Soviet team won the glamorous end of the regatta, the eight with coxswain, as well as the quadruple sculls. The only event in which the Soviet and the East German teams were shut out was the pair without coxswain, which was won by Steve Redgrave and Andy Holmes of Britain. The only United States men's team to place yesterday was a Philadelphia Athletic Club entry in the four with coxswain, which finished third. Ann Martin, the United States lightweight woman's single sculler, won the only gold medal for the United States in yesterday's regatta, finishing first in the seven-boat final by 2.80 seconds, or a little over a boat length ahead of Britain's Carol Lucas. Tour de France Frenchman Gains Overall Lead: Martial Gayant of France won the 11th stage of the men's Tour de France cycling race yesterday and moved into the overall lead. Gayant took the leader's yellow jersey from a countryman, Charles Mottet, after finishing the 158-mile course from Poitiers to Chaumeil-les-Monedieres nearly 11 minutes ahead of the pack. Gayant was 10 minutes 48 seconds behind Mottet after Friday's stage.(AP) Italian Woman Wins Stage: In the women's race, Roberta Bonanomi of Italy won the third stage, crossing the finish line 45 seconds in front and taking the overall lead yesterday. Bonanomi finished the 45-mile leg ahead of Maria Canins of Italy, who took second place. Monique Knol of the Netherlands, the overnight leader, finished 38th, 3 minutes 43 seconds behind.(AP)

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ARE YOU LONESOME TONIGHT? The Untold Story of Elvis Presley's One True Love and the Child He Never Knew. By Lucy de Barbin and Dary Matera. (Villard, $15.95) Lucy de Barbin claims she carried on a secret 24-year affair with Elvis Presley and bore Presley's first child, a girl named Desiree. Ms. de Barbin, a clothing designer, and her collaborator, Dary Matera, a former editor and journalist, offer little hard evidence to support the assertions.

title: Jaguar Recalls 3,500 Sedans
description: Jaguar is recalling about 3,500 1986 XJ6 sedans in the United States for replacement of possibly defective microswitches that affect the cars' stop lights and cruise control mechanisms, said Jaguar Cars Inc., the New Jersey-based importer of the British luxury car. No reported accidents have been attributed to defective switches, Jaguar said.

title: Injured Rider Quits; Frenchman in Lead
description: Sean Kelly, who has been ranked among the leading professional bicycle racers in the world for the last three years and was an early favorite in the Tour de France, injured his left shoulder in a crash this morning and quit the race.

title: Boxing; Aquino Wins Decision
description: Lupe Aquino of Mexico won the World Boxing Council superwelterweight championship with a unanimous decision over Duane Thomas of Detroit.

description: In the afterglow of their latest victory, the Mets renewed their enthusiasm for a division race and a summer of hot pursuit. They spoke again about the St. Louis Cardinals and the nine games that still remain with the National League East leaders, and they seemed to thrive on the thought of a rematch.

The Editorial Notebook; How Japan Won the VCR Race
description: No product better embodies America's loss of industrial competitiveness than the VCR. Japanese and Korean companies have now produced 100 million video cassette recorders. Yet the VCR's predecessor, the video tape recorder, was a wholly American product, invented by Ampex in 1956. Why did American companies squander this rich opportunity?

title: Schools, Jobs and the Year 2000
description: The program, announced last year with much good will, was a credit to a Brooklyn neighborhood coalition and the New York State Bankers Association: Four New York City banks would hire 250 graduates of five troubled city high schools.

description: American diplomats have complained to the Israeli authorities that Palestinian-Americans visiting relatives in the occupied territories are being harassed, Israeli officials and Western diplomats say.

title: ROSENTHAL RALLIES FOR 2 SHOT VICTORY
description: Jody Rosenthal shot a six-under-par 66 today to come from six strokes off the pace and beat Ayako Okamoto by two strokes in the du Maurier Classic, one of the four major events on the women's tour. Rosenthal's 72-hole total of 272 set a tournament record.

description: Inflation is at a record 125 percent, Fernando Valenzuela is having an off year with the Los Angeles Dodgers, and several new soap operas have just gone on the air here. But Mexicans seem obsessed with a single question these days: Who will be the country's next President?

description: Eight stowaways have been riding the high seas in a legal muddle, stuck for six days on a cruise ship that makes daily round trips between Miami and the Bahamas.

description: Pope John Paul II told about 30,000 people who gathered in a mountain glade today that Christians have a moral obligation to protect the environment.

description: Slovenes are political realists, so no one here in their capital raises the subject of separating from Yugoslavia except to reject it.

description: Very few teen-age players have ever won a major New York team title. The number increased Saturday when 19-year-old Debbie Zuckerberg of Flushing, Queens, won the knockout title in the Nassau-Suffolk Regional Championships together with Phillip Martin, Allen Kahn and David Rosenberg, all of Manhattan.

BORK, AS SEEN FROM TWO ANGLES;
HIS JUDICIAL RESTRAINT IS A MYTH
description: LEAD: President Reagan has praised his Supreme Court nominee, Judge Robert H. Bork, as a ''powerful advocate of judicial restraint'' who believes that ''judges' personal preferences and values'' should not affect how they decide cases. Judge Bork's judicial record, however, demonstrates that he has little trouble taking ''activist'' positions to accomplish results that he prefers in specific cases.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HEMINGWAY. By Kenneth S. Lynn. Illustrated. 702 pages. Simon & Schuster. $24.95.

title: Sports of the Times; 'You Can Feel the Energy'
description: FOR more than half a century, the All-Star Game has been the barometer of the Yankees' season. To know how the Yankees were doing in any July, all anybody ever had to do was look at the American League team. In the beginning, Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig and Lefty Gomez dominated the All-Star rosters. When the Yankees were rolling to pennant after pennant, Joe DiMaggio, Bill Dickey and Phil Rizzuto were always in the All-Star Game, then Mickey Mantle, Whitey Ford and Yogi Berra. When the Yankees won the World Series again in 1977 and 1978, their All-Stars included Reggie Jackson, Thurman Munson and Graig Nettles.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: An Unusual Trio 9

title: Climber Killed in Oregon
description: Three climbers ascending Mount Hood fell into a crevasse Saturday, killing one man, seriously injuring another and forcing the third man, who was also injured, to crawl out for help, the authorities said. The climbers, who were roped together, fell into the fissure about 2:15 P.M. at about the 10,700-foot level after one of the men slipped.

MEDITRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STAGE: 'MORI EL MERMA,' WITH IMAGES FROM MIRO
description: Mighty peculiar creatures are disporting themselves at the Summerfare festival here. There are giants with heads of monsters, grotesque torsos, six-foot-long arms and feet to fit dinosaurs. There are also dwarflike inventions cavorting on pipes high above the stage; their faces might have come direct from designs by Joan Miro, and their whispers, squeals and elusive not-quite-words are what you'd expect to hear if Miro's bright free-form shapes were to leap to life. That's as it should be, since this is a ''carnival of masks'' painted by the Catalan artist.

title: IT'S THE SEASON OF THE HEAVY HITTERS
description: SOMETIMES they have done it in explosive spurts; at other times they have displayed devastating slugging over longer stretches. In a season that has been dominated by debates over the liveliness of the baseballs, they have caused people to overuse their calculators and computers in daily computation of projections for season totals of hitting statistics that grow like Jack's beanstalk.

description: American Airlines has offered a group of European airlines a model of its sophisticated Sabre computer reservation system in a deal similar to that concluded last week by United with three European carriers, according to officials close to the airline industry.

Business and the Law; Debating a Bill On Job Hazards
description: BUSINESS interests are deeply divided over a Congressional measure that would give workers greater notice about the hazards of their jobs. Though many opponents of the bill have applauded its goal of informing workers about hazards and creating a safer workplace, they fear more lawsuits.

title: Relentless Heat and Raising the Giglio

He was guarding a collection of goldfish swimming around in little bowls of orange and green water.

description: Everyone will help pay for the treatment of AIDS patients. The question is whether society will do so with higher health insurance premiums or, via Medicaid, with higher taxes. At least for now, the better way is insurance.

description: Life has become a doubtful proposition for the four million children caught in the crossfire of Africa's wars.

description: The yen's foreign-exchange rate against the dollar seems to have settled, Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa said in a weekend speech here.

Johanna G. Sherwood, a justice of the peace, officiated.

description: White gunmen shot and killed two members of the outlawed African National Congress guerrilla group and a female companion in Swaziland, South African news agencies said Saturday.

description: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair will be televised live beginning at 9 A.M. on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on some local affiliates of PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service, including Channel 13 in New York.

description: To the Editor:

title: Kuwaiti Hanging of 3 Shiites Is Reported in Beirut's Press
description: The Beirut press reported today that Kuwait had executed three convicted Shiite Moslem bombers whose release had been demanded by people claiming to hold American hostages here. [ Kuwait denied that the three men had been executed. Kuwait's Interior Ministry, in a statement carried by the Kuwait News Agency, said, ''There is no truth whatsoever to these claims.'' ] The Beirut press, in its reports today, quoted a newsletter published in Teheran by Iraqi political exiles. The report said the three men, two Iraqis and a Lebanese, were hanged at Kuwait's central prison in May. The Teheran newsletter named the Iraqis as Hussein Kassem Hassan and Bakr Ibrahim, and the Lebanese as Elias Saab.

title: Robin E. Hanna Bride Of Seth Mahlon Chilton
description: Robin Ellen Hanna, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Hanna of New York, and Seth Mahlon Chilton, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Neal W. Chilton of Lawrenceville, N.J., were married yesterday at the Burden Mansion in New York by Rabbi Martin Merin.

title: ROCK: FETCHIN' BONES, AT NEW-MUSIC SEMINAR
description: ''WELCOME to Hades,'' said Hope Nicholls of Fetchin' Bones, a Charlotte, N.C., quintet, to the sweltering crowd at a CBGB New Music Seminar showcase performance on Saturday. Nobody needed to be reminded of the heat, but Fetchin' Bones did offer the evening's most distinctive musical distraction. Miss Nicholls's wacky Southern Yoko Ono mannerisms, richly textured twin-guitar arrangements and an incisive, tightly-meshed rhythm section give Fetchin' Bones plenty of personality. So does the group's original material, a crazy quilt of rock, funk, rap and rhythm-and-blues, with plenty of dissonant guitar harmonies and surprising rhythmic suspensions.

description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May.
