TAYLOR DEVICES reports earnings for Year to May 31
MUSIC: ROZHDESTVENSKY CONDUCTS AT TANGLEWOOD
description: It has been said that artists make the most eloquent spokesmen for detente, a notion suggested by Gennadi Rozhdestvensky's appearance Saturday night at Tanglewood. The Soviet conductor, who led the Boston Symphony Orchestra in performances of works by Sibelius, Mussorgsky and Scriabin, brought to the music an easy command and a dramatic sensibility that prompted long standing ovations on a night when oppressive heat might have discouraged enthusiastic response.

title: ROBINSON MEMORIES
description: A group of eager 10-year-olds crowded around, trying to catch a glimpse of Jackie Robinson, the famous Brooklyn Dodger. ''Let me see,'' one shouted. ''Wait a minute, it's not your turn,'' another cried as they pushed and shoved.

title: POINDEXTER MEMO SAID TO DESCRIBE INFORMING REAGAN PLAN TO USE IRAN PROFITS
description: The chairman of the Senate Iran-contra committee said today that Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser, had written a memo saying President Reagan had been told of plans to use profits from the Iran arms sales for covert operations other than supporting the contras.

title: Mattingly's Numbers Are on the Rise
description: At season's end the past three years, Don Mattingly's name has been conspicuous by its presence among the American League leaders in a variety of offensive categories. One year he won the batting championship, another the runs-batted-in title. He has also led the league's hitters in doubles, hits, extra-base hits, total bases and slugging percentage. He has performed so impressively that he is generally considered to be the No. 1 player in baseball today.

description: President Reagan's nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court has liberal ideologues howling with fury. The central issue is already clear: Should a liberal majority on certain key issues be perpetuated, or should the Court evolve towards a conservative majority?

description: Some evenings, from the middle of Santiago, the sky appears a watercolor of pale pastels, and the snow-topped Andes are streaked pink and blue by the setting sun.

title: CONVENIENCE PAYS AT 7-ELEVEN
description: There is a distinct rhythm to each day, observed Kathie Jaroszyk. In the morning the clientele is mostly workers wanting a cup of coffee. Toward midday the lunch crowd arrives for soda, hot dogs or prepackaged sandwiches. In the afternoon children play video games. In the evening, traffic slows during the dinner hours but picks up as people come in to rent videotapes for the night or pick up snacks, beer or a box of diapers.

title: Horton Helps Cards Defeat Giants, 3-2
description: Ricky Horton won his ninth consecutive game dating back to last season, and Terry Pendleton hit a home run today as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the San Francisco Giants today, 3-2.

description: A group of 174 people who claim to be refugees from India arrived at a tiny fishing village in Nova Scotia off Canada's east coast today, Federal Immigration Minister Benoit Bouchard said.

description: Most Americans favor widespread testing for infection with the AIDS virus, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: G.O.P. Hopefuls Backing Away From Reagan
description: For the first time, Republican Presidential contenders have clearly but carefully begun to distance themselves from President Reagan.

title: BLACK GUERRILLAS AND WHITE FOES OF PRETORIA FIND COMMON GROUND
description: Members of a mostly white delegation of dissidents from South Africa found at a conference here that they had more in common with black exiles fighting to end white rule than they had expected.

title: VINER, E A HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss on the sale of the company's interest in Heck's Inc. of $2,359,000.

title: INSIDE
description: Pretrial Detention at Issue The debate over preventive detention of defendants is fueled by examples of both innocent defendants who were detained and dangerous defendants who were released. Page A13. Mozambique Policy Shift The Administration reportedly held low-level official talks with a representative of rebels in Mozambique, in a marked shift of policy. Page A3. Turmoil on Demjanjuk The five-month-old trial of John Demjanjuk, accused of being a Nazi war criminal, was thrown into turmoil by the announcement that his chief lawyer had been dismissed. Page A2. Unusual New Yorkers Rarer than a tree in Brooklyn? A New York bird of prey away from Wall Street? Page B1.

title: New Magazine on Care For the AIDS Patient
description: The first issue of AIDS Patient Care: a Magazine for Health Professionals is due to be published next week by Mary Ann Liebert Inc., a New York publisher.

title: DOCTORS' DILEMMA: UNIONIZING
description: Complaining of inadequate wages, poor working conditions and callous management, an unlikely group of workers in Minnesota is threatening to unionize: doctors.

title: Motta Open; Valvano Out
description: Dick Motta, the former Dallas Maverick coach whose name has often been heard in connection with the Knicks' coaching vacancy, said yesterday he had not been contacted about the job recently. Another candidate, Jim Valvano of North Carolina State, said last night that he was never offered the job and would remain the Wolfpack coach.

title: HUBCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain, after taxes, of $400,157, or 11 cents a share, on the sale of the 14th Street, Hoboken office; and an after-tax loss on the sale of securities of $413,773 resulting in a net increase of $256,384, or 7 cents a share. The company said the 1986 share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid August 1, 1986, and a 3 percent stock dividend paid January 2, 1987.

title: Blurred Lines for Lawmakers in Albany
description: The political and ethical practices of the New York State Legislature are being challenged as rarely before, raising questions that go to the heart of how the Legislature governs 17 million New Yorkers.

title: DIRECTORS' PROPOSED STRIKE BRINGS THREAT OF LOCKOUT
description: All members of the Directors Guild of America would be locked out if the guild carries out a threatened selective strike Tuesday, a spokeswoman for film and television producers said today.

title: Tour de France; Italian Ahead
description: Jutta Niehaus of West Germany won the fourth leg of the women's Tour de France in a sprint to the finish line, while Roberta Bonanomi of Italy kept the leader's yellow jersey. Jutta completed the 32-mile course from Castillon-la-Bataille to Bordeaux in 1 hour 13 minutes 44 seconds.

title: He Keeps Anonymity And Regains Suitcase
description: A man who spent 11 days in jail because he refused to identify himself, then had to picket a police station to get his suitcase back, has left town just as he arrived -anonymously.

title: Camper's Lament: 'I Hate It!'
description: Dear Mom and Dad, I hate it here. I hate the kids. The food STINKS. Come and get me - IM MEDIATELY. I want to go home!! Your son, Billy P.S. I have poison ivy ALL OVER!

title: Margeotes/Fertita Working for ASCAP
description: The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers switched its account to Margeotes/Fertita & Weiss a while ago but has just given the agency the O.K. to announce it.

title: Saatchi Gains From Isotoner
description: Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton is the beneficiary of a decision by Sara Lee Hosiery to consolidate the products of its Isotoner brand in one agency.

title: Enforce Litter Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An editorial yesterday overstated the percentage of respondents in a New York Times/CBS News Poll who think Lieut. Col. Oliver North acted on his own in the Iran-contra affair. The correct figure is 4 percent.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ''Star Wars'' managers have shifted their research in favor of a crash program for early deployment of a relatively unsophisticated, minimal missile defense, according to evidence dug out by Congressional researchers.

title: Dr. Thomas F. Waddell, 49, A Founder of Gay 'Olympics'
description: Dr. Thomas F. Waddell, one of the founders of the Gay Games for homosexual athletes in 1982 and a sixth-place finisher in the decathlon at the Olympic Games in 1968, died at his home in San Francisco Saturday morning. He was 49 years old. His wife, Sara Lewinstein, said by telephone that Dr. Waddell had died of complications related to AIDS.

title: BUTLER, JOHN O CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Strike Paralyzes Israel
description: About 450,000 civil servants staged a one-day strike today to demand higher wages and a shorter work week, paralyzing air traffic and silencing radio and television. The strike was called by Histadrut, Israel's largest trade union federation which represents nearly all of the country's civilian labor force of 1.4 million.

title: TAKING A PAGE FROM TWAIN
description: During his lifetime, Samuel Langhorne Clemens wore many hats - as an itinerant printer, a travel correspondent, a Mississippi River pilot, a gold and silver miner, a laborer in a quartz mine, a businessman and, as Mark Twain, journalist and author. But the role he never tired of was letter-writer.

title: 2 KILLED IN QUEENS AS GUNMAN IN CAR FIRES AT RANDOM
description: Nine people were shot, two fatally, by a gunman who fired randomly from a car as he sped by two locations used by drug dealers in Hollis and Springfield Gardens, Queens, last night, the police said.

title: ROYAL BUSINESS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $2,559,000 for both quarters; a tax credit of $1,907,000 and $2,268,000 for the latest quarter and 9 months, respectively; and a gain on extinguishment of debt of $467,000 for the latest 9 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $236,000 and $370,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a tax credit of $50,000 and $75,000 for the same periods, respectively.

title: Article 795487 -- No Title
description: Sales of Treasury securities this week are confined to the bill market, where today's $13.2 billion auction of three- and six-month bills is expected to raise $875 million in new cash, with the remainder used to pay down bills now reaching maturity.

title: In Talk With Polish Officials, Catholics Ask More Freedom
description: Catholic intellectuals urged Communist officials at a meeting to grant more political freedoms and hold talks with Lech Walesa, participants said today.

title: CURRENCY'S FALL FRIGHTENS LEBANESE
description: Lebanon was traumatized Friday by a sharp decline in the value of its currency, raising some fears that the country was on the brink of bankruptcy.

title: THE DANCE: PERRON AND CHUMA AT JACOB'S PILLOW
description: Increasingly, summer dance festivals seem to exist as much for participating artists as for audiences. Both the Jacob's Pillow and American Dance Festivals actively offer new, developing and even relatively established choreographers a place and the time to work away from the hectic world of dance in New York City. The work process is seen as more important, in this setting, than the product. And in work presented on Friday night at the Pillow by Yoshiko Chuma and Wendy Perron, two resident artists at that festival this summer, the yeasty opportunities afforded by such programs were clearly evident.

title: Indian Security Forces Kill 5 Described as Sikh Extremists
description: Security forces killed five suspected Sikh extremists they encountered while on patrol, and terrorists shot and killed two people, the police and news reports said Saturday.

title: New Law School Courses Stress Family
description: As concerns grow about surrogate parenthood, no-fault divorce and other issues that affect families, an increasing number of American law schools are reassessing and changing the way they teach family law. They are giving students more practical experience in casework and adding other disciplines, like sociology and economics, to their curriculums.

title: COTTO'S SLUGGING SPURS YANKEES
description: With his regular travels between Columbus and New York in the first half of the season, Henry Cotto has earned a spot on the Yankees' all-star commuter team. Cotto, in fact, likes the trip so much that even as he was enjoying his most glorious day of the season, he was planning yet another trip to Columbus.

title: Correction
description: A front-page headline and article Saturday on Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's testimony in the Iran-contra hearings misstated part of what he said about a plan by William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, for a secret fund for covert operations. A corrective article appears today on page A1.

description: Can laws pervent corruption?

title: Vision of Pig Farms Fuels Buying Spree in Midwest
description: Clifford L. Wolfswinkel always wanted to be a pig farmer.

Market Place;
Bell & Howell In the Spotlight
description: LEAD: WHEN Robert Bass, a Texas investor, announced on June 29 that he had acquired a 7.5 percent stake in the Bell & Howell Company, Wall Street began a frenzy of buying and selling that was expected to be followed by the emergence of a suitor for Bell & Howell, based in Skokie, Ill. But now, two weeks later, Mr.

title: Israeli Visa Policy on Arabs Keeps Families Apart
description: This summer, about 45,000 Arabs will cross the Jordan River on special visas that allow them to spend three months in Israel.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JULY 13, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-11 President Reagan was told of plans to use profits from the Iran arms sales for covert operations other than supporting the contras in a memo written by Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter, according to Senator Daniel K. Inouye, the Hawaii Democrat. Page A1

title: Salary Deviations
description: The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, has been looking at Federal executives' pay and has found a few anomalies.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, JULY 13, 1987

title: Yankees Get Trout In Deal With Cubs
description: The Yankees ended their sometimes desperate search for another starting pitcher yesterday, acquiring Steve Trout from the Chicago Cubs a day after he pitched his second successive shutout. Trout, who will be 30 years old July 30, will become the fourth left-hander in the team's five-man starting rotation.

title: ALLIED BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes after tax securities gains of $197,000, or 7 cents a share, and $572,000, or 19 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in December 1986 and a 5 percent stock dividend paid in June.

title: 2 NEW SMITHSONIAN MUSEUMS FOCUS ON ART OF ASIA AND AFRICA
description: Shortly before his death in May, Dr. Arthur M. Sackler had almost completed his latest benefaction, the creation of a museum of Asian and Middle Eastern art that would fill one of the few remaining voids in the Smithsonian Institution complex.

title: 6 Sri Lankan Soldiers Killed By Land Mine Blast in North
description: Six soldiers were killed by a land mine and Tamil separatists set fire to a school in northern Sri Lanka today, officials said.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; METAPHORS BY HEINZ
description: Senator John Heinz, a Pennsylvania Republican, is showing promise as a champion user of mixed metaphors. The other day, Mr. Heinz opposed a bill to impose a trade embargo on Angola. The bill would have obliged the Chevron Oil Company to pull out of Angola, and he said such a move would allow another country to take over Chevron's resources there, to the detriment of the United States.

title: WESTERN FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Labeling Plan Is a Regressive Pizza Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $2 million gain from the sale of the company's payroll-processing base and the sale of assets relating to a maturing leveraged lease. The company said the latest second quarter and 6 month includes pretax investment securities losses of $20,000 and $21,000, respectively, compared with similar pretax losses of $1,000 in the year-ago second quarter and $356,000 in the 6 month.

title: MBS TEXTBOOK EXCHANGE reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the increase in earnings resulted primarily from the acquisition of additional facilities with the proceeds of its second public offering in August 1986.

title: For Unemployment Workers, the Tables Turn >
description: For 12 years, Nona Payton worked as a claims clerk in unemployment offices. Soon, she will return - as a client.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: At the Shangri-La, Beverly Hills Seems Far Away
description: It has no valet parking, no doorman, no concierge, no room service, no restaurant, no bar, no swimming pool, not even a Jacuzzi or sauna. Yet the Shangri-La Hotel is just what its name implies - a secret haven for a growing number of celebrities who want to be alone in Los Angeles. They pass the word along to one another.

title: SURINAME'S FALL FROM PARADISE
description: Until a few years ago, milkmen made the rounds in this little country on the northeast coast of South America just as they did once upon a time in the United States. Bread was delivered, too. The stores were overflowing with canned goods, fine wines and cheeses, refrigerators, television sets and electronic gadgets. The schools and hospitals were excellent. Wages were good and jobs were plentiful. Nearly everyone who wanted a car had one, and a lot of homeowners trimmed their lawns with power mowers.

title: MT BAKER BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FINANCIAL SERVICES LINE IS ADDED BY BENETTON
description: After scoring major successes first in the manufacture and then in the retailing of casual clothes, Italy's Benetton group is diversifying into the realms of financial services and merchant banking.

title: DU PONT'S '88 GAMBLE: TWO STATES
description: On the basis of his lineage, schooling, appearance and political record, Pierre S. du Pont 4th is unlikely to be mistaken for a riverboat gambler. Yet he has committed himself to an all-or-nothing political gamble in his pursuit of the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Laurie E. Gottlieb Weds B. K. Moss
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., yesterday Laurie Ellen Gottlieb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Gottlieb of Lynbrook, L.I., was married to Bradley Kevin Moss, a son of Mrs. Edward Waxman of Cheltenham, Pa. Rabbi Harold I. Saperstein performed the ceremony.

title: 10 Years After New York Blackout: Lessons Learned
description: Ten years ago today, a power failure erased the glitter of New York's skyline, plunging the city into a blackout that triggered widespread looting and arson.

title: 2d Bid for Electrospace
description: Electrospace Systems Inc. received a second offer on June 12, the same day it got a bid from the Chrysler Corporation. Electrospace disclosed the second bid Friday at the request of the Securities and Exchange Commission staff, according to Robert L. Carrel, executive vice president of Electrospace. He refused to identify the second bidder. Electrospace, an electronic equipment manufacturer based in Richardson, Tex., told the S.E.C. that its board had ''rejected the interested party's proposal as inadequate in light of the Chrysler proposal.'' The second bidder had offered $25.77 a share. Chrysler initially offered $26 a share, but later raised its bid to $27.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Has the stadium in which the All-Star Game was played at midseason ever been the same one in which the World Series was played after the season?

title: Natalie Priest Is Dead at 68; Stage, TV and Movie Actress
description: Natalie Priest, a stage, television and film actress, died of cancer Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 68 years old.

title: Gunman Kills Seven In His Own Family And Then Himself
description: A man shot seven members of his family to death, possibly over a period of two days, and then killed himself when the police went to his home, the authorities said today.

title: U.S MEETS WITH MOZAMBIQUE REBEL FIGURE
description: In a marked shift of policy, the Administration has held low-level official talks with a representative of anti-Government rebels in Mozambique and is actively considering expanding such contacts, according to Government officials.

title: House Reception Mixed To Accounting Report
description: In a move to head off possible Federal regulations, a panel of accountants and other experts in financial reporting presented a series of recommendations today that they said would greatly reduce the incidence of undetected fraud in company reports.

title: U.S.-Soviet Radio Deal Is Denied By Wick
description: To the Editor:

title: Matthew Oshman, Lawyer, Marries Lisa Diller, Banker
description: Lisa Diller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred N. Diller of New York and Hewlett Harbor, L.I., and Matthew Oshman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Oshman of Hillside, N.J., were married last evening at the Water Club in New York by Rabbis Pinchas M. Teitz and Eleazar M. Teitz.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; THE BORK NOMINATION
description: Conservative supporters of Judge Robert H. Bork, President Reagan's latest nominee for the Supreme Court, are engaging in some second-guessing. It might have been better, they say, if the President had named Judge Bork to one of the Court openings that occurred when Republicans controlled the Senate and the President was in a stronger position to get his way on Capitol Hill.

title: Tiffany to Publish One-Shot 'Magazine'
description: As part of its celebration of its 150th anniversary, Tiffany, the fabled retailer, will publish a strictly upscale, one-shot publication in magazine format that will not cost it a cent. In fact, it will probably make some money because it will carry advertising - a lot of advertising.

title: No Headline
description: A subsidiary of a company controlled by Robert Holmes a Court has acquired 5.35 percent of Sears P.L.C., a British retailer that owns Selfridge's Department Store in Oxford Street, London. The holding was purchased by J. N. Taylor Ltd., a unit of Bell Resources.

title: Specialists Report on Dementia
description: No single test can determine the cause of the mind-robbing dementia that afflicts many older people, and doctors must take the time to do their own detailed evaluations of each patient, according to a committee of specialists assembled by the National Institutes of Health.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Wilander Takes U.S. Pro Title: In Brookline, Mass., Mats Wilander changed his patient approach in the first set to an attacking strategy in the second to defeat a fellow Swede, Kent Carlsson, yesterday at the United States Pro Tennis Championships. Wilander, ranked second in the world, recovered from a 4-2 deficit in the first set to win, 7-6, 6-1, for his second victory in the tournament in three years. It was the fourth singles title of the year for Wilander, seeded No. 1 here. Carlsson was seeded third. Carlsson's most hopeful moment of the match, played at the Longwood Cricket Club, came when he broke Wilander's serve to take a 4-2 lead in the first set. But after losing the tiebreaker, 7-5, Carlsson managed only 13 points in the second set as Wilander began rushing the net.(AP) Goldie Gets First Pro Victory: Dan Goldie, the 1986 collegiate singles champion, won his first professional title when he beat Sammy Giammalva, 6-7, 6-4, 6-4, in the final of the Volvo Tennis Hall of Fame Championships in Newport, R.I. (AP) Sanchez Wins Swiss Open: Emilio Sanchez of Spain, with a strong serve and deft volleys, beat Ronald Agenor of Haiti, 6-2, 6-3, 7-6, to win the Swiss Open in Gstaad. (AP) Belgian Title to Horvath: Kathy Horvath of the United States won the Belgian Open, defeating Bettina Bunge of West Germany, 6-1, 7-6, in Knokke-Heist. (AP) Auto Racing Mansell Edges Piquet: Nigel Mansell of England threw the Formula One auto-racing drivers' championship wide open yesterday with a victory over Nelson Piquet of Brazil at the British Grand Prix in Silverstone, England. Mansell chased his Williams-Honda teammate until the last two laps of the 65-lap race, then overtook Piquet and pulled away to win by almost two seconds. Piquet finished more than a lap ahead of Ayrton Senna of Brazil, whose lead in the drivers' championship was cut to one point. Alain Prost of France, current champion, retired and failed to pick up points. Senna, in a Lotus Honda, now has 31 points with nine races to go. Piquet and Mansell are tied with 30, and Prost, who drives a McLaren Tag, has 26.(AP) Ormsby in a Flash: Gary Ormsby of Ventura, Calif., won the Budweiser Summernationals Top Fuel drag-racing championship yesterday over Joe Amato of Old Forge, Pa. The race, at Old Bridge, N.J., was decided midway down the quarter-mile strip when the front wheels of Amato's dragster became airborne. Ormsby, who had qualified second in the 16-car field, posted a 5.34-second run in the final, at 268.89 miles per hour, while Amato, the season point leader, regained control of his car and coasted across the finish line. Amato, the 1984 Top Fuel champion, maintained his point margin over Dick LaHaie by defeating LaHaie, the fastest qualifier, in the semifinal round. Amato now leads the standing with 6,998 points; LaHaie has 6,506. Soccer U.S. Tops Ecuador: In Saint John, New Brunswick, last night, Ben Crawley scored six minutes into the second half and Mark Dulle stopped a point-blank shot in the final minutes, giving the United States a 1-0 victory over Ecuador in Group B of the under-16 World Cup tournament. Crawley headed a corner kick from Tim Gallegos into the right-hand corner of the net.(AP)

title: At British Open, Bright Outlook for an Englishman
description: KEN BROWN was a struggling and naive 23-year-old golfer when he began the final round of the 1980 British Open at Muirfield, Scotland, in second place. The slim Englishman was four strokes back of the leader and some people, maybe even more naive than Brown, felt that this was not an impossible obstacle to overcome.

title: SHELTON SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company converted to stock from mutual form in August.

title: You'll Need a Death Certificate for Your Last Car
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Latin Currency
description: A new currency to finance trade between Brazil and Argentina is expected to be created when Presidents Jose Sarney and Raul Alfonsin meet next week, according to Carlos Eduardo Freitas, a director of the Brazilian central bank.

title: PLAYER TURNS DUEL INTO ROUT IN U.S. SENIOR OPEN
description: What was expected to be a race between Gary Player and Chi Chi Rodriguez for the United States Senior Open title today quickly became a solo charge to victory by Player, who captured the championship by a record six strokes over Doug Sanders, with Rodriguez seven behind.

title: (Most of) Boston Awaiting Big Highway Project
description: This city's Central Artery, a grimy green elevated highway, has had few fans except for pigeons since it was built 30 years ago. A plan to replace the road with a new one underground will not only remove an eyesore but also help the bustling city avoid choking on its traffic.

title: UNITED SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: United Savings went public in June 1986.

title: ARIZONA GOVERNOR DISMISSIVE OF FOES
description: As if he did not have enough to worry about, Arizona's Governor, Evan Mecham, now faces a determined effort by a citizens' group to recall him from office.

title: Turkish Hypocrisy On Ending Torture
description: LEAD: Turkey's chief of police, Saffet Arikan Beduk, recently made a plea on behalf of torturers.

title: Sex Barrier Falls at State Bar Group
description: Maryann Saccomando Freedman says that if anyone told her two years ago that she would be president of the New York State Bar Association, ''I would have thought they were from the moon.''

title: Dr. Jonathan L. Held Marries Alyssa Licht
description: The wedding of Alyssa D. Licht, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Licht of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., to Dr. Jonathan L. Held, a son of Justice and Mrs. Gerald S. Held of Brooklyn and Oceanside, L.I., took place yesterday at the Licht home. Cantor David Benedict officiated.

description: b-Includes pre-tax gains of $534,000 from the sale of real estate and $766,000 on the sale of a portion of a business. Figures for 1987 include the results of Texas Industrial Services since January.

title: NEW TWIST FOR BOLIVIA ON ITS DEBT
description: Bolivia and its commercial creditors have amended their 1981 debt-restructuring agreement to allow the country to negotiate a repurchase of its $1 billion in outstanding loans.

title: Howe Signs Ranger Pact
description: The Texas Rangers signed Steve Howe today to a minor league contract with their Class AAA Oklahoma City farm club of the American Association.

title: WASHINGTON BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $12 million increase in the reserve for possible losses on loans in the company's international loan portfolio. c-Net income

title: Fire Department Keeps List of AIDS Victims
description: For the last two years, the Albany Fire Department has been compiling a list of residents with AIDS so that firefighters answering medical emergencies will wear rubber gloves and take other precautions in handling the patients.

title: Canadian Trade Talks
description: Negotiations on a free-trade agreement between Canada and the United States remain bogged down over Canada's insistence on immunity from retaliatory measures. After 14 months of talks and faced with a Congressional deadline of Oct. 4, Canadian and American negotiators say they are still far apart on major issues. The biggest snag is Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's demand for a method of settling disputes that would be binding on both parties and that would prevent punitive duties.

title: Brazil Output Weakens
description: Brazil's industrial output in June climbed a relatively weak 5.34 percent from a year earlier, the Government reported Friday.

title: European Interest Increases As North Implicates Others
description: Europeans seemed hardly interested in Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North when he began testifying last week, but interest rose sharply when he began implicating higher officials and lecturing Congress on foreign policy.

title: BARFIELD HIT LEADS BLUE JAYS PAST ROYALS
description: Jesse Barfield snapped a 2-2 tie with a run-scoring single in the seventh inning today and Jim Clancy had a career-high 11 strikeouts as the Toronto Blue Jays edged the Kansas City Royals, 3-2.

title: COATED SALES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Traders Fear Debt Deadline
description: A healthy dollar and weaker inflation helped calm the bond market last week but could not entirely erase the uncertainty of traders about whether Congress will extend the Government's debt ceiling before its expiration on Friday.

title: 'INDIA: END OF EMPIRE'
description: THE British flag over India was lowered 40 years ago. A new nation was born, but immediately fell into disorder. Why it did is the subject, more or less, of ''India: End of Empire,'' a three-part documentary series that began last week on Channel 13. Tonight's episode, ''The Muslim Card,'' at 11 o'clock, gives us a clue: recalcitrant politicians.

description: b-Includes a write-off of $1,753,491.

title: Search Service Stresses Fixed-Income Markets
description: Joseph S. Crisanti, a co-founder of a credit rating company well known on Wall Street, is starting a new business.

title: A Correction: Times Was in Error On North's Secret-Fund Testimony
description: On Friday, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testified that the Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey, wanted to create a secret fund to underwrite intelligence operations - an ''off-the-shelf, self-sustaining, stand-alone entity that could perform certain activities on behalf of the United States.''

title: 2 Men Are Shot Dead In Dispute With Youths
description: A 25-year-old man and a guest at his family's new home were shot to death after they chased a noisy group of youths away from a construction site near the house, the police said today.

title: OSHAP TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures for both periods are based on a translation rate of 37.37 Belgian Francs to the dollar, the rate on March 31. The results reflect the company's activities prior to the joint venture with Regional Investment Co.

title: TALKING TOUGH
description: The lightning-fast ring tactics and two-fisted flurries have merely enhanced boxing's self-appointed Macho Man. The tough image of 25-year-old Hector Camacho came from the fact that he grew up on the streets of Spanish Harlem.

title: Walsh's Task Viewed as Tougher Now
description: Federal law-enforcement officials and prominent defense lawyers say the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair could find it difficult, perhaps impossible, to obtain criminal convictions against Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and several other principals in the case.

title: Imperiled, Creatures Brave City
description: Up on the Throgs Neck Bridge, the rare peregrine falcon nests among beams and girders while traffic rumbles nearby.

title: TEXACO BID SPECULATION INCREASES
description: Robert Holmes a Court, the Australian financier who has accumulated 9.5 percent of Texaco Inc.'s common shares, might increase his holdings to as much as 15 percent in the near future, raising a question of whether he intends to make a tender offer for the giant oil company.

title: Paraguayan's Control Is Questioned
description: For the best part of three decades, Paraguayans could safely assume that everything important, unusual or even illegal that occurred here was part of one scheme or another by Gen. Alfredo Stroessner to perpetuate his dictatorship.

title: Collapse of Circus Tent Injures 44 in Wisconsin
description: A circus tent battered by winds collapsed Saturday afternoon, injuring 44 people as spectators scrambled for safety, officials and witnesses said.

title: The Contras in Costa Rica: A Tangled Tale Is Told in Lawsuit
description: Two American freelance journalists living here are at the heart of an unresolved lawsuit charging that a broad conspiracy surrounded Nicaraguan rebel activities in Costa Rica, including an assassination attempt, drug-dealing and gun-running.

title: Caterpillar Net Drops 15.1%
description: Caterpillar Inc., the world's largest manufacturer of earth-moving equipment, said that second-quarter profit fell 15.1 percent, but it expected earnings to improve for the year.

title: BANK OF DARIEN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $81,000 from securities. c-Net income d-Net loss The company said the loss for the latest second quarter was due primarily to a one-time expense of moving the bank to new headquarters, higher rent and addition of staff.

title: A FILM MAKER AND JOURNALIST
description: Peter Gimbel, a film maker and underwater photojournalist who filmed the sunken Italian luxury liner Andrea Doria and the great white shark, died of cancer yesterday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 59 years old.

title: Anatomy of the Skirmishing for a Veto
description: Senator Jake Garn entered the members' dining room on Capitol Hill and quietly began to collar as many of his 44 Republican colleagues as he could find.

title: RIDGEWOOD PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
For Deserter, Vietnam Is Past at Last
description: For Douglas G. Beane, 17 years of living under an alias in Australia was not enough to distance himself from the Vietnam War and the ostracism he felt after he deserted the Marine Corps.

title: A WRITER GOES IT ALONE AFTER 40 YEARS IN TEAM
description: After 40 years as a member of one of the most prolific writing teams in Hollywood, William Link is going it alone.

title: INTERSPEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $272,00 and $525,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: The Talk of Columbia County; In Rural New York, a Time of Ferment
description: These days it seems like everything is multiplying here in Columbia County.

title: Scars From '67 Riots in Newark Are Still Visible in Central Ward
description: The weeds grow waist-high in the vacant lots along Springfield Avenue here and children play amid shards of broken glass and rubbish that has turned foul in the heat.

title: Union Balks at Plan To Burn Barge Trash
description: A plan to resolve the fate of the garbage barge Mobro faced another obstacle yesterday when workers at a city incinerator in Brooklyn, citing possible health hazards, said they would not handle the trash.

title: Boxing; Tate (19-0) Wins a Middleweight Title
description: Frank Tate outboxed Troy Darrell today to win the vacant United States Boxing Association middleweight title in a unanimous 12-round decision.

title: MICROFRAME INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
VERTEX COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
The Persian Gulf and the Eve of Another War
description: To the Editor:

title: GIBSON, C R CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TRANSTECTOR SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Susan H. Adler and Avery E. Neumark Are Wed
description: At Congregation Shearith Israel in New York yesterday, Susan Hannah Adler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney G. Adler of Lawrence, L.I., was married to Avery E. Neumark, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Neumark of New York. Rabbis Louis Gerstein, Leo Jung and Ralph Pelcovitz officiated.

title: GATEWAY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said results were adjusted to reflect the 10-for-1 stock split which was effective Sept. 16, 1986, and the 5 percent stock dividend paid March 31.

title: On the Road With Iraqi Ambassador
description: When Nizar Hamdoon arrived in Washington nearly four years ago as Iraq's chief envoy to the United States, he spoke halting English and wore French, custom-made white suits with black shirts. Iraq was still on the State Department's list of countries that supported terrorism and, last among the Arab states, still had not resumed full diplomatic relations with the United States since the 1967 Mideast war.

title: SIGN OF TIMES AT TAJ MAHAL: BARBWIRE
description: The Taj Mahal, the classic monument to personal grief and architectural splendor, has become a barometer of India's smoldering ethnic vendettas.

title: British Paper Publishes Excerpts of M.I.5 Book
description: Britain's Attorney General said today that he would take legal action against The Sunday Times for publishing excerpts of a banned book on the country's secret service, M.I.5.

title: CAPTAIN CRAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TOKYO OFFICIAL PLANS U.S. VISIT ON TOSHIBA CASE
description: Japan's trade minister is expected to visit the United States this week to try to deflect mounting criticism over the Toshiba Machine Company's illegal sale of high-technology machinery to the Soviet Union.

title: 14 Injured in Jersey As Porch Collapses
description: At least 14 people were injured Saturday night when a wooden, second-story porch on which they stood collapsed and fell on people standing below them, the police said.

title: Pretrial Detention: 2 Sides of an Issue
description: For Ricardo Armstrong, there is the despair of trying to reunite his family after spending four months in a Cincinnati jail for bank robbery before being acquitted of the crime.

title: When Lights Went Out: New Yorkers Remember
description: Where were you when the lights went out? Yesterday, interviewed on the streets of New York City, some people remembered.

title: Grand Jury Is Said to Join Inquiry Into Military Contractor in Illinois
description: A grand jury is investigating the Sundstrand Corporation, accused by Government auditors of overcharging the Federal Government more than $130 million on a wide range of military contracts, according to a published report.

title: A WARNING ON SWAPS OF THIRD WORLD DEBT
description: The Group of 30, a study group of leading bankers and economists, has expressed concern over the burgeoning market in third world debt swaps, a business that major money center banks, primarily Citicorp, view as a way to reduce loans to developing countries.

title: Off Broadway Threatened by Dispute
description: The production of Off Broadway plays and musicals has been threatened by a contract dispute between the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers and the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers.

title: South African Prices
description: South Africa's wholesale prices were up moderately in May from a year ago but remained lower than the previous month's level, the Government said today. The producer price index rose 14.6 percent in May.

title: JOHN W. HUNTER JR.
description: John W. Hunter Jr., an editor for various New York business publications, died last week, apparently of a heart attack, in his Manhattan apartment. His body was discovered by a family member on Thursday when he failed to answer repeated phone calls. He was 55 years old. Mr. Hunter, a graduate of the Lawrenceville School and Yale University, was business editor of Look magazine and editor of its subsidiary publication, Insider's Newsletter, in the early 1960's. He was the founder and editor of Service 202, a Washington-based newsletter directed to the securities industry and in the mid-70's he edited Economic Week, Citicorp's economic newsletter. Recently he devoted himself to writing fiction.

title: New York City Cites Union League in Sex Bias
description: The New York City Human Rights Commission has formally accused the all-male Union League Club, long known as a staid bastion of Republican businessmen, of discriminating against women.

title: PIONEER HI-BRED INTERNAIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company attributed the drop in its latest 9-month results to what it estimated has been a 14-percent drop in U.S. corn acreage planted this year.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about airline crews involved in a near-collision over the Atlantic last week misstated the number of trans-Atlantic air routes between Britain and Ireland and Canada. There are six, as shown in an accompanying map on Saturday, not five.

title: Correction
description: A headline in some copies on Wednesday with the main Washington dispatch about Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's first day of Congressional testimony characterized part of it incorrectly. Colonel North said that he had written at least five memorandums intended for President Reagan outlining a plan to divert Iran arms profits to the Nicaraguan rebels and that he had sent the memos ''up the line'' to the national security adviser.

title: GULL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Dow Off 3.02; Technology Stocks Up
description: Despite a stunning surge in the technology sector, the stock market weakened yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average, off sharply much of the day, rallied to close only 3.02 points lower, at 2,452.97.

title: U.S. Mulls Aid in Steel Shutdowns
description: The Reagan Administration is considering helping steel companies shoulder the heavy cost of closing unneeded plants.

title: Delta Jet Onto Wrong Runway
description: A Delta Air Lines jet carrying 151 passengers landed on the wrong runway at Logan International Airport late Sunday night as another jet was preparing to taxi across the runway, officials said today.

title: New Taxi Regulations Bring First Summonses
description: With the first summonses against a largely uncooperative industry, the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission yesterday began enforcing new regulations governing gypsies, liveries and other nonmedallion vehicles.

title: ISAAC HERSH
description: Isaac Hersh, a former principal of New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn, died Sunday of Alzheimer's disease at the Krever Nursing Center in Miami. He was 80 years old and lived in North Miami Beach.

title: Accident Damages Remaining Atlas-Centaur
description: Four workers were slightly injured and a space rocket was severely damaged today when a work platform struck the booster stage on the launching pad and ruptured a fuel tank.

title: Accounts
description: Westin Hotels and Resorts, Seattle, to Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson, Boston, for the Plaza Hotel, New York.

title: TRUMAN J. NELSON
description: Truman J. Nelson, a historical novelist, civil libertarian and conservationist, died of congestive heart failure Saturday in Newburyport, Mass., where he lived. He was 76 years old.

title: A Top Treasury Officer Is Going to Law Firm
description: J. Roger Mentz, the Treasury's top tax officer and the point man on the Netherlands Antilles controversy, will join the Washington office of Cadwalader Wickersham & Taft, the New York law firm, in September. His deputy, O. Donaldson Chapoton, will probably succeed him.

title: Apple Net Up by 66% In Quarter
description: Buoyed by strong acceptance of its new products, Apple Computer Inc. today reported sharply increased sales and earnings for its third quarter ended June 26. The gains exceeded both the estimates of the company and analysts.

title: Westinghouse Earnings Up
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that its second-quarter earnings rose 10.3 percent, partly because of improved strength in its industrial and commercial divisions.

title: Steel Output Off 2.7%
description: Steel production fell to 1.649 million tons in the week ended Saturday, a decrease of 2.7 percent from the previous week's 1.695 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday. The industry's production amounted to 77.1 percent of capacity in the week, compared with 79.2 percent in the previous week. Estimated figures for the year to date showed production at 44.524 million net tons, a decrease of 5.3 percent from the 47.038 million net tons in the previous year. Production so far this year used 75.4 percent of capacity, compared with 69.1 percent a year earlier.

title: French Ship Is Attacked in Gulf, Raising Paris-Teheran Tensions
description: Tensions between France and Iran heightened today when a French container ship was attacked in the Persian Gulf by what France said were two Iranian gunboats.

title: No Reason for Optimism About Race Relations
description: To the Editor:

title: SSC&B:Lintas Sets Up Venture With Japanese
description: SSC&B:Lintas Worldwide, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has established a joint venture with Hakuhodo of Japan, which already has such a partnership with McCann-Erickson, another Interpublic company.

title: Daisy Schapiro Dies; A Child-Care Advocate
description: Daisy C. Schapiro, a lawyer and an early advocate of child care for working parents in New York, died of natural causes Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 93 years old.

title: Number of Mergers Falls
description: The number of mergers and acquisitions tumbled in the first six months of 1987, but the total dollar value continued to rise, according to a report by W. T. Grimm & Company, a research concern. Because of a 39 percent decline in the number of mergers - to 927, from 1,527 -there were fewer mergers taking place in the period than in any year since 1980. Despite this drop, the value of mergers soared 18.4 percent, to $91.3 billion, from $77.1 billion last year.

title: Hot Books for Hot Days
description: DALLAS, July 13 - Let's face it, sometimes it's just too hot to sit at a computer. The preferred alternative, dragging the computer to poolside, isn't always practical, unless one is planning to do floating point calculations. A nice compromise is to curl up by the pool with a six-pack of software and a good computer book.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Pandering to Jesse Helms in Africa
description: Anti-Government rebels in Mozambique recently kidnapped seven foreigners, including an American nurse. Only last month the State Department held that it would be ''a serious mistake'' to associate United States policy with these hostage-takers, whose terrorist deeds also include demolishing 718 clinics and attacking 12 CARE food delivery trucks.

title: Drake Bakeries
description: The Ralston Purina Company said it had signed an agreement to sell its Drake Bakeries Inc. subsidiary to a private group led by Drake management. The management team is supported by Rock Capital Partners L.P., a limited partnership of global investors. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. Ralston acquired Drake Bakeries from Borden Inc. for $115 million. That acquisition is the subject of an antitrust suit. A preliminary injunction was issued earlier this year prohibiting the integration of the Drake business into Ralston's Continental Baking Company subsidiary.

title: Casey Had 'Fall Guy' Plan As Early as '84, North Says
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North said today that the plan to make him the ''fall guy'' for the Iran-contra operations was first suggested by William J. Casey as early as 1984 when the White House began its secret support for the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Officials Link a Virginia Mayor to Hate Mail
description: Officials here said today that the fingerprints of Mayor James W. Holley 3d had been found on hate mail sent to community leaders, prompting members of the City Council to call for his resignation.

title: TV Anchormen Are Missing The Big Story of the Hearings
description: LEAD: In Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and the Iran-contra hearings, network television news has come up against its biggest test of the Reagan years -and it is failing thus far.

title: Jamaica Station Rebuilding Is Delayed Two Years, to '93
description: The renovation planned for Jamaica Station in Queens, a notorious bottleneck on the Long Island Railroad, will take two years longer than projected and run $107 million over its $213 million estimated cost, railroad officials said yesterday.

title: HEEKIN CAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 14
Staff Earns a Few Bruises As Governor Builds Team
description: Despite minor bruises, sunburn and sore muscles, Colorado's chief executive and his Cabinet and staff say they are delighted with their rugged weekend in the Rocky Mountains.

title: Queens Shootings May Be Tied to Drugs
description: The shooting spree that left two men dead and eight other people injured in Springfield Gardens and St. Albans, Queens, late Sunday may have been caused by rivalry among narcotics dealers in the area, the police said yesterday.

title: Studying Business History
description: AFTER years of neglect, business history courses are becoming popular, perhaps because of a belief that tomorrow's managers should not operate in a complex world without looking over their shoulders at the past.

title: Ford to Expand Plant in Louisville
description: The Ford Motor Company plans to spend more than $250 million to expand its truck assembly plant in Louisville, Ky., so that additional vehicles can be made there in the early 1990's, a Ford spokesman said. Kentucky officials, including Gov. Martha Layne Collins, visited a Ford vice president, Edward E. Hagenlocker, last week and promised at least $10 million in state aid to persuade Ford to expand the Louisville plant. The money would finance training programs.

title: Nation's Physical Plant an '88 Issue
description: The steady decay of the country's roads, bridges, sewers, and rail and water systems - a problem that flared as a major political issue in the early 1980's but then seemed to flame out - is coming back as part of the 1988 Presidential campaign.

title: PRESIDENT REPEATS DIVERSION DENIAL
description: President Reagan insisted today that he had never been told about any plans to use profits from the Iran arms sales to finance covert operations.

title: Correction
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the Convex Computer Corporation incorrectly described the prospects of a competitor, Floating Point Systems Inc. The company has made no statement about the outlook for sales in its fiscal third quarter, which ends July 31.

title: A Resignation At MacGregor
description: MacGregor Sporting Goods Inc. said yesterday that Herbert A. Rosenfeld had resigned as president, chief operating officer and a director.

title: DANA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Pediatrician Surplus Is Seen
description: The number of pediatricians is growing too fast and its members are not being paid enough for some services, including services to the growing number of poor children, according to a report in the current Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: HEALTH & REHABILITATION PROPERTIES TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The trust began operations in December.

title: U.S. Salutes Victor in Australia; Contrast to New Zealand Is Clear
description: In pointed contrast to its dissatisfaction with the anti-nuclear policies of New Zealand Prime Minister David Lange, the United States has made clear its satisfaction with the re-election Sunday of Prime Minister Bob Hawke of Australia.

title: Student-Loan Defaulters to Be Charged Fees
description: In an attempt to collect $5.9 billion in unpaid student loans, the United States Department of Education is notifying nearly a million defaulters this week that they must pay before Oct. 1 or be billed afterward for their loans plus the collection costs.

title: Italian Leader Selects A New Prime Minister
description: Italy's President today asked the Treasury Minister, Giovanni Goria, a Christian Democrat, to serve as Prime Minister over the 47th post-World War II Government.

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the decline in earnings was the result of increased production costs and increased selling and administrative costs. The company attributed the increase in sales to improved volume in most product categories.

title: FAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
Bill to Monitor City Contracts Voted by Panel
description: Two key anti-corruption measures appeared headed for different fates yesterday as New York City officials prepared to adopt a system to monitor municipal contracts but put off acting on a plan to restrict campaign donations.

title: Vatican Backs 3 in Bank Case
description: A senior Vatican official said today that he believed Archbishop Paul Marcinkus and two other Vatican bank executives were unwitting victims of the spectacular Banco Ambrosiano bank crash five years ago.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Cubic Corp., San Diego, an electronics company, will receive a $108 million contract to build and install five electronic pilot training systems to become operational between February and August 1989.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A New York First

title: USX Price Rise
description: The USX Corporation said it would raise the price of sheet steel used in autos, appliances and office furniture by 4 percent to 6 percent. The company's action reflects a relatively tight supply in the markets for steel products. But industry analysts said that whether the increase sticks or not could depend on the extent to which steel buyers are building inventory that was depleted during a six-month USX shutdown that ended earlier this year. The USS division of USX will add $25 per ton to the price of products that now range from $414 to $625 per ton. The higher price takes effect with shipments on Oct. 1.

title: For Heroin, Turkey Is Land Bridge to West
description: The agents trailed the suspect truck across Turkey as far as Switzerland. Then they moved in.

title: The Dance: 4 Premieres at Festival
description: Since 1984, the American Dance Festival has sponsored an International Choreographers Workshop that permits choreographers from around the world to attend the festival, take classes and share ideas. This year, four previous participants in the workshop - choreographers from Indonesia, India, Argentina and Spain - were invited back to create new dances for casts of festival students. The results were shown Sunday night at the Page Auditorium of Duke University.

title: China Food Oil Imports
description: A sharp rise in Chinese incomes and an improvement in diets have significantly increased China's demand for imported vegetable oils, making the country one of the world's largest importers of food oils, according to American statistics. The Agriculture Department recently released data with estimates that China will import a record 750,000 metric tons of foreign vegetable oil in the 1987-88 marketing year, up from only 60,000 four years ago. If the estimates prove correct, China would rank among the top vegetable oil importers in the world, surpassed only by India, Pakistan and the Soviet Union.

title: Pharmacists Are as Ethical as Physicians
description: To the Editor:

title: Few Traces of the Civil War Linger in Biafra
description: The Biafra babies are adults now.

title: Adoption of U.N. Peace Plan For Gulf Is Said to Be Likely
description: State Department officials said today that they were confident that the United Nations Security Council would approve a resolution this week calling for a cease-fire in the war between Iran and Iraq.

title: CERTAINTEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge for both the quarter and 6 months of $6.4 million related to two plant closings.

title: On Writing And Talking
description: MITZI, a first-grader, drew a picture of a cowboy and wrote: ''Once there was a cowboy. I hated the cowboy a lot. Do you like cowboys? But I like you a lot. Sometimes I like the cowboy. Tuesdays I like the cowboy. The end.''

title: GTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: b-Net loss

title: CHASE MANHATTAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflects the impact of the previously announced special addition of $1.6 billion to the reserve for possible credit losses which was made in light of recent developments pertaining to the debt situation of refinancing countries. c-Net income

title: Metro Datelines; L.I. Golfer Tees Off After Being Stabbed
description: A 77-year-old Long Island man was stabbed in the chest and hand Sunday by a robber, then went out to play golf before telling the police or seeking medical attention, the police said.

title: LIBERTY NATIONAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Committee's Turn: Speeches to North
description: The Iran-contra hearings featured several summations yesterday, some addressed by members of Congress to Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. Here are selections from those statements. SENATOR GEORGE J. MITCHELL, Democrat of Maine

title: World-Class Art Perks Up a Small City
description: A roomful of Rembrandts, Renoirs and van Goghs has sent ripples through this small city on the Connecticut River, from the Sweet Tooth Bakery to the Volleyball Hall of Fame.

title: ALLWASTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and 9 months include the results of Bryson Environmental, acquired last September, and the consolidation of the Allwaste Services companies.

title: ONEOK INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
First Chicago
description: The First Chicago Corporation is offering $100 million of 8 5/8 percent notes due in 1992 at a price of 99.70, to yield about 8.70 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. Noncallable before maturity, the notes yield about 80-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury notes of similar maturity. They are rated A-2 by Moody's and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Sharp Words on Immunity
description: Near the end of the Iran-contra hearings yesterday, Representative Jack Brooks, Democrat of Texas, became involved in an exchange with Colonel North's lawyer, Brendan V. Sullivan Jr., about grants of immunity from prosecution.

title: ELECTRO-CATHETER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Publisher To Acquire Variety
description: In a move that likely surprised the entertainment industry, the Cahners Publishing Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Variety, the trade publication known as the bible of the industry.

title: Seminar Attracting Music's Mixed Bag
description: The eighth New-Music Seminar, which started Sunday at the Marriott Marquis Hotel, is something like a convention. That is, the hotel is occupied by exhibition booths, audio-visual displays, panel discussions and people trying to read one another's name tags without being obvious.

title: In Bike and Barefoot Town, Speeders Zoom at 18 M.P.H.
description: It is another beautiful summer day here, the roads are clear and, as usual, traffic is limping along. The speed limit in this tiny seaside hamlet is 15 miles an hour, the lowest in New York.

title: Dress Code for New York Cabbies Is Step Toward Better Service
description: To the Editor:

title: As Deaver Trial Opens, Judge Closes Jury Selection
description: Jury selection in the perjury trial of the former White House official Michael K. Deaver began today, and the judge closed questioning of potential jurors to the public because, he said, he was concerned about their privacy.

title: The Occasional Cook
description: File this away on a recipe card for the year 2004. Margaret Collins, a research associate at the Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History, contributed an offbeat suggestion to the weekly staff bulletin at the institution, proposing that the ''emergence of 17-year cicadas should be regarded as a welcome opportunity to our gastronomic horizons.'' Far from shuddering over the insects that covered lawns this summer, Miss Collins suggested making a meal of them.

title: DMI FURNITURE reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $245,000 and $540,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: Resource Fund Strong in '87
description: MUTUAL funds that invest primarily in natural resource stocks - a traditional hedge against inflation - are gaining in popularity after a generally ho-hum year in 1986.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Dan Pasqua was named International League player of the week. Pasqua, a Yankee outfielder who was demoted June 24 to make room on the roster for Don Mattingly's return from the disabled list, batted .500 in seven games, hit 3 homers and 3 doubles and drove in 11 runs for the Columbus Clippers. . . . Von Hayes of the Philadelphia Phillies, who hit .593 last week, was named National League player of the week.

title: AFG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $14 million from the sale of stock in Gencorp. c-Includes a $1.5 million after-tax gain from the sale of securities. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in May.

title: Gimme a B, Gimme . . .
description: Opponents to the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court gave the Capitol a taste of creative sloganeering yesterday.

title: Sports People; Vitale Back in Form
description: Dick Vitale, the college basketball commentator for ESPN and ABC-TV, used boxing analogies yesterday as he described his condition after suffering a broken nose and foot and facial fractures in an auto accident in Bradenton, Fla. A Ford Bronco collided head-on with Vitale's Cadillac on Friday evening, according to the Florida Highway Patrol. Vitale's wife, Lorraine, was driving.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JULY 14, 1987
description: Companies

title: Costa Rica Journal; In the War on Want, Is There a Military Front?
description: The red clay roads, newly cut into the jungle, are still being smoothed by bulldozers. Logging trucks and farmers with their herds of cattle will not be far behind.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: COLLECTED STORIES. By Carson McCullers. 392 pages. Houghton Mifflin Company. Cloth, $18.95; paper, $10.95.

title: Metro Datelines; Magazine Buys Story From Jessica Hahn
description: Jessica Hahn has signed a contract to tell a national men's magazine ''the entire story'' of the sexual enounter that helped bring down the Rev. Jim Bakker, the television evangelist, Miss Hahn's lawyer said yesterday.

title: Charles Ludlam Is Eulogized By Friends From the Theater
description: About 1,000 people crowded the Second Avenue Theater last night to pay final tribute to Charles Ludlam, the playwright, director and actor and founder of the Ridiculous Theatrical Company, who died on May 28 at the age of 44.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Although He is regularly asked to do so, God does not take sides in American politics.

title: AT $30 MILLION, IS ANYONE WATCHING?
description: It was another milestone in international communications and satellite diplomacy, officials were boasting at the United States Information Agency.

title: Scouting; Happy Return
description: Last week at Flushing Meadows, Queens, Richard Trapp was in familiar territory, and the 40-year-old lawyer from Orlando, Fla., cashed in on his first opportunity to win the United States Tennis Association men's 40-and-over national hardcourt singles championship.

title: No Reason for Optimism About Race Relations; Commission Is Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Presidents(?) and Press
description: Presidents and the press have sometimes been at odds over the conduct of news conferences in the White House, and the Reagan Administration has come under fire for not holding enough of them. Now nine Presidential candidates, responding to a questionnaire from the National Press Foundation, say they would do things differently. The foundation said it asked 16 declared and prospective candidates, Republicans and Democrats, how often they would hold press conferences, if they would change the format, and if they would make their press secretaries privy to top-level decision-making.

title: U.S. Urges $110,000 Salaries for its Top Scientists
description: The Department of Health and Human Services has drafted a proposal to create a special corps of senior biomedical researchers who could be paid as much as $110,000 a year, a salary that would exceed those of Cabinet members by $10,500, an Administration official said today.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Why does scratching seem to relieve the itch of insect bites?

title: North's Testimony: 'Fall Guy' and Foreign Policy
description: As Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testified for the fifth day yesterday, members of Congress questioned him about the specific circumstances of the Iran-contra affair and about American foreign policy in general. Here are excerpts from the testimony, as recorded by The New York Times. THE 'FALL GUY'

title: Police Shoot Pit Bull Terrier After It Attacks 2 Dobermans
description: The police killed a pit bull terrier with five shots after the dog attacked two Doberman pinschers in an hourlong battle in which the Dobermans' owner said the pit bull ''just went crazy.''

title: Sundstrand Bills Disputed
description: The Sundstrand Corporation purportedly overbilled the United States by more than $100 million on military contracts, the Department of Defense said today.

title: Melville to Buy 25 Drugstores
description: The Supermarkets General Corporation has agreed to sell 25 Heartland and Pharmacity drugstores in Massachusetts and New Hampshire to the Melville Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. But Supermarkets General, which is currently involved in a leveraged buyout plan, said that proceeds would help pay debt. The company decided to sell the stores because it was not prepared to invest the additional capital required to make the stores dominant in their region, said Robert Wunderle, an economist for Supermarkets General.

title: Sports of the Times; Filling a Knick Cavity
description: The search for Judge Crater has been longer, the hunt for Dr. Livingstone was more dangerous, and the pursuit of the perfect martini more thirst-quenching, but the long, exhausting, frustrating 84-day quest for a head coach for the New York Knicks finally came to an end.

title: Rescuing an Ancient Egyptian Tomb
description: ONE of the more spectacular tombs of ancient Egypt, the 3,200-year-old burial chamber of Nefertari, Ramses II's favorite wife, has undergone emergency repairs by an international team of scientists and art restorers. They applied several thousand strips of gauze and rice paper to hold together the flaking wall paintings until a comprehensive restoration is begun on this imperiled monument of the ancient Pharaohs.

title: Controversy Amid All-Star Spectacle
description: This is supposed to be fun, right? It's the All-Star Game, a spectacle of pitching and power hitting, an extravaganza for the fans and a chance for baseball's biggest stars to strut and mug for the cameras.

title: U.S. Companies Fight Proposal to Ban Toshiba
description: American companies that would be affected by the Senate's proposed ban on the Toshiba Corporation's imports are making their way to Capitol Hill this week, seeking to convince lawmakers that a ban may do considerably more damage to American businesses than to Toshiba.

title: Textron-Gefinor
description: Textron Inc. said it had agreed to sell it Sheaffer Eaton division to Gefinor S.A. of Geneva for about $135 million. It said completion was expected by the end of August. Sheaffer Eaton makes writing instruments and stationery. The company said proceeds from the sale would be used to reduce the debt incurred in the acquisition of the Ex-Cell-O Corporation in September 1986.

title: Where Some Art Is a 'Monstrosity' Of Zoning Rules
description: One morning a month ago, Tony Mariani and Freddie Vassallo, the building inspectors here, were driving south on Bay Avenue, heading to work in their yellow Chevy station wagon. As they crossed Sixth Street, Mr. Mariani glanced left. ''I do a double-take,'' he said. ''I see a monstrosity.'' There in the side yard of a newly opened art gallery, facing the main street, was a 12 by 11 cartoon-style painting of a porpoise show.

title: Bolivia to Protect Lands in Swap for Lower Debt
description: The Bolivian Government agreed today to protect millions of acres of threatened tropical lowlands in return for a reduction of its foreign debt.

title: Shawn Becomes Farrar, Straus Editor
description: William Shawn, former editor of The New Yorker, has become a book editor for Farrar, Straus & Giroux, Roger W. Straus, president of the publishing company, said yesterday.

title: Scouting; Different Kind Of Policy Makers
description: A high school track star attempting the long jump slipped on a wet takeoff board and was injured. The official in charge of the event was sued, but a jury found that he was not responsible for the accident.

title: BOULEVARD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Transit Authority Seeks A Full-Service Agency
description: The New York Transit Authority is looking for a full-service ad agency. The total budget is about $2 million to cover media and production costs, and the agency will probably be asked to do a little image advertising (You think that's easy?) and a lot of schedule-change advertising.

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes the previously announced addition of $800 million to First Chicago's loan reserves covering loans to ''troubled country debtors.'' c-Net income

title: A Lighthouse In Maine Falls To Progress
description: The last lightkeeper at the 108-year-old Cape Neddick Light Station is done lighting its red beacon, chipping ice off its windows in winter and, with bell or horn, warning mariners away in summer fog.

title: Labor Unit Upholds A Policy to Examine Troopers for Drugs
description: Drug testing of state troopers when there is reasonable suspicion of on-the-job drug use was upheld today by a state labor mediation board.

title: McLouth Buyout
description: An agreement has been reached on an employee buyout of the ailing McLouth Steel Products Corporation under which workers would take a wage cut, the director of Michigan's Department of Commerce, Doug Ross, said. The proposal was presented at a news conference attended by representatives of the United Steelworkers union and of company owner Cyrus Tang. Mr. Tang is to receive 10 percent of a reorganized McLouth, while other private investors would receive 3 percent and employees - both union and management - would receive 87 percent of the new company.

title: Stop the Annual Insurance Raid
description: New York State employers who buy their workers' compensation insurance from the State Insurance Fund can blame Governor Cuomo for new premium increases of 7 percent. Taxpayers ought to blame him and the Legislature for playing carelessly with their money.

title: Directors and Producers Try to Avoid a Strike
description: The Directors Guild of America met with studio producers today to try to avoid a strike Tuesday morning that would disrupt most motion picture and television production.

title: Moscow's View on Eliminating Missiles
description: LEAD: Although the Soviet Union and the United States have come close to reaching an agreement to eliminate intermediate- and shorter-range missiles in Europe, there are still obstacles to signing such an accord soon.

title: House Passes a Smoking Ban on Some Flights
description: The House narrowly voted tonight to ban cigarette smoking on airline flights of two hours or less, then went on to pass a $26.6 billion transportation spending bill for the fiscal year 1988.

title: 'Midsummer Night' To Tour City Parks
description: A free outdoor performance of Shakespeare's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' will be presented by the Riverside Shakespeare Company on July 15 at 6 P.M. in Bryant Park, 42d Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas. The performance is part of a series that will run through July 26.

title: Commodity Fund Gains Soviet Help
description: The Soviet Union said today that it would join a United Nations plan for stabilizing world prices of raw materials, a plan that is supported by developing countries but spurned by the Reagan Administration.

title: Knicks, Ending 84-Day Search, Name Pitino Coach; He Leaves Providence to 'Fufill Dream'
description: Even after Rick Pitino withdrew from consideration for the only professional coaching job he ever coveted, he still hoped he would someday become coach of the Knicks, the team of his playground fantasies. But not even the young optimist, who gained national prominence in March by guiding Providence College to the Final Four, dreamed that the day would come so soon.

title: All-Star Notebook; Randolph Won't Sit It Out
description: Willie Randolph, the Yankee second baseman who was voted to a starting position for Tuesday's All-Star Game, is going against a request by the team's owner, George Steinbrenner, that he not play because he has a sore left knee.

title: Iran-Contra Hearings; President Repeats Diversion Denial
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 13 - President Reagan insisted today that he had never been told about any plans to use profits from the Iran arms sales to finance covert operations.

title: Rolls-Royce Plans New Jet Engine
description: The aircraft engine manufacturer Rolls-Royce, one of the big three of the industry, is planning to develop a more powerful version of its RB211-524D4D engine for a new generation of medium-range and long-range civil aircraft beginning in 1992, company sources said. They said the new derivative, called the Dash 700, was at the engineering design stage and still had to be approved by the board.

title: FASHION NOTES
description: IN the first weeks of July, southern Europe can seem like fashion summer camp as American designers, retailers, forecasters and photographers pour into its resorts for working vacations.

title: Airlines Offer Service Reports
description: Thirteen airlines offered today to make available monthly consumer information reports including records on delays, canceled flights and lost baggage.

title: Metro Datelines; Jersey Is Criticized Over AIDS Protocol
description: The state has done little to slow the spread of AIDS among New Jersey prison inmates by failing to educate them about the disease, provide blood tests on demand or segregate convicts who test positive from the general prison population, a lawyer argued yesterday in Federal District Court here.

title: Foote, Cone & Belding Buys Canadian Concern
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications has added to its Canadian empire with the acquisition of Ronalds-Reynolds & Company of Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver, which is billing about $95 million. Its addition to F.C.&B. brings that worldwide operation's Canadian unit to $177 million, putting it among the top three communications groups in the country.

title: Capital Gains Tax Changing in New York State
description: An agreement last week by New York State legislators will mean that most taxpayers in the state will pay a significantly higher capital gains tax this year, while some upper-income individuals will be taxed a bit less.

title: MBS TEXTBOOK EXCHANGE reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss Corrected from the editions of Monday, July 13.

title: A Discussion Of a Mercenary
description: At the Iran-contra hearings today, Colonel North was questioned about the activites of David Walker, a Briton who was involved in covert military operations against the Nicaraguan Government. Following is an excerpts from that exchange, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Results Plus
description: Tour de France

title: Crazy Eddie Ends Licenses
description: Crazy Eddie Inc. said it had ended license agreements with Benel Distributors Ltd., operators of the concession to sell recorded audio and video cassettes and records in Crazy Eddie stores. Benel, it said, is seeking protection from creditors under Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: Whistling Wagner
description: To the Editor:

title: The Ballet: New Cast In Bolshoi 'Raymonda'
description: ''RAYMONDA'' can be a ballet lover's dream. There is the richly melodic score by Glazunov. The ballet boasts a juicily operatic story complete with pauses for aria-style solos and duets. And in the stagings of the ballet that stay closest to what we know of the Petipa original, those dances have a crystalline classical purity offset by the colorful national and character dancing for which ''Raymonda'' is also celebrated.

title: Korean Premier and 8 Others Replaced
description: President Chun Doo Hwan replaced the Prime Minister and eight Cabinet ministers tonight in what officials described as an attempt to make the Government impartial in the period before national elections.

title: Poor but Dumb
