description: Do you look blank when they say ''William Shakespeare''? Wonder what in the world it means when people say ''Sweden'' and ''Einstein''? Have you ever been embarrassed because everybody laughed when you said: ''Elysian Fields? Wasn't he that movie comedian who drank like a fish?''

title: Sutcliffe Receives Clemente Award
description: Rick Sutcliffe of the Chicago Cubs received the Roberto Clemente Award today for baseball service on and off the field.

title: Spinal Injury Research Yields a Glimmer of Hope
description: SCIENTISTS building on work by generations of researchers are finally seeing signs of progress on one of medicine's most poignant challenges: the restoration of nerve function after spinal injury.

title: Anglo Weighs Worker Stake
description: The Anglo American Corporation of South Africa, the country's biggest industrial and mining conglomerate, said today that it was considering offering a stake in the company to its predominantly black work force.

title: Department Store Heir Is Charged in Slayings
description: The 24-year-old great-grandson of a Massachusetts department store magnate has been charged in the fatal shootings of two men.

title: Panel Said to Urge New Lunar Base
description: A study team headed by Sally Ride, an astronaut, will recommend a moon base as the nation's next manned space goal, the magazine Aviation Week & Space Technology reported today.

title: Sports People; More From Jackson
description: A spokeswoman for Richard Woods, Bo Jackson's lawyer, said yesterday that the Kansas City Royals' rookie outfielder will hold a news conference in Auburn, Ala., at 12:30 this afternoon. Jackson was expected to confirm that he would play professional football.

title: Nathan Perlmutter, Top Executive Of Anti-Defamation League, Dies
description: Nathan Perlmutter, the national director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith since 1979, died of lung cancer Sunday afternoon at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, where he was admitted July 8. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: People
description: * Steven E. Morvay was promoted to president of Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Direct.

title: Advanced Micro, Intel Post Profits
description: Two of the nation's largest chip makers, the Intel Corporation and Advanced Micro Devices Inc., reported improved results today as the semiconductor industry continued to rebound.

title: Wage Dispute Pits Tanker Crew vs. Officers
description: The 17 Korean crewmen of a Liberian-registered oil tanker that arrived here Friday from Saudi Arabia say that they have not been paid in three months and will not work until they are.

title: Scouting; Troubled Waters
description: Rick Pitino, the new head coach of the Knicks, becomes the 13th man in 41 years to take charge of New York's National Basketball Association franchise, where many a coach has foundered. The most successful of Pitino's predecessors was Red Holzman, who in two tenures won 613 games and two N.B.A. championships (in 1970 and 1973). Joe Lapchick, Neil Cohalan and Willis Reed were the only other Knick coaches to post winning career records.

title: KEY RATES
Ameruso's Trial on Perjury Draws to a Close
description: A former New York City Transportation Commissioner, Anthony R. Ameruso, was described by a prosecutor yesterday as a man driven by self-interest who ignored his lawyer's advice and lied under oath to hide his relationship with a company then doing business with the City Transportation Department.

title: Myriad Fashion Whims Of a St.-Tropez Summer
description: The fashion fanatics who descend on this Mediterranean port each summer are dead serious about casual clothes.

title: Ex-Cabinet Aide Admits Theft
description: A onetime top aide to Margaret M. Heckler, former Secretary of Health and Human Services, pleaded guilty today to improperly pocketing $55,300 in foundation and government funds while working for the Reagan Administration.

title: Chase, First Chicago Report Large Deficits
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation and the First Chicago Corporation yesterday reported big second-quarter losses, which were linked to the unusually large provisions for loan losses taken to account for troubled third world loans.

title: For Saudi Investor, Many U.S. Stakes
description: When shares of the Transamerica Corporation shot up last month, rumors ricocheted around Wall Street that the Primerica Corporation or the Ford Motor Company might be preparing a takeover bid.

title: Baseball Votes, Early and Often
description: Is Darryl Strawberry having an All-Star season? Does the Mets' outfielder really deserve to be a first-team National League selection? Does Tony Gwynn of the San Diego Padres deserve not to be?

title: Political Marketing; On the Air: $97 Million Spent in '86
description: Candidates for Congress spent more than $97.3 million in the 1986 elections to buy advertising on radio and television stations, or 24.3 percent of their total campaign spending of $400.4 million, according to a study made public today.

title: DESOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter income includes a gain of $2,931,000, or 74 cents a share, from the sale of its Orange, Cal., paint and detergent facility and an adjustment of the reserve for restructuring.

title: KRUEGER, W A CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 16. The company also said a significant portion of the sales increase in the first half is attributable to the Fullerton, Calif. division, which was acquired Nov. 9.

title: Waldheim Visit to Pope Troubles Catholics Also
description: To the Editor:

title: AAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
FEDDERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,800,000 for the quarter and $3,084,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits from continuing operations of $467,000 and $1,275,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; tax loss carryforward credits from spun-off operations of $471,000 for the quarter and $632,000 for the 6 months, and income from spun-off operations of $1,745,000 and $1,933,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-earlier results are restated for the spin-off of Nycor Inc.

title: Chevron Capital Sets Financing
description: Chevron Capital USA, yesterday offered $250 million of 9 3/4 percent sinking fund debentures due in 2017 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Issue for Thatcher: Her Overseas Role
description: As Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher prepares to depart for Washington, she is drawing up a predictable list of foreign policy concerns on arms control, the Middle East, protectionism and the effect of the United States' trade and budget deficits on the world economy.

title: FIRST UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains of $16.5 million and $17 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from discontinued operations; and an extraordinary loss of $2.6 million related to the repurchase notes for both the quarter and 6 months. The company said a special $25 million loan loss provision reduced its net for the latest second quarter and 6-month by $14.1 million, or 13 cents a share. The company also said its $58.5 million of loans to lesser developed countries are now covered by $28.9 million of reserves.

title: The Complex Interest Rules
description: WHEN the Internal Revenue Service proposed new regulations governing interest deductions earlier this month, tax practitioners were shocked by their complexity, and taxpayers were left confused. Tax professionals are still struggling to absorb the new record-keeping and procedural rules, and they wonder if the average taxpayer will ever be able to understand them, let alone keep up with the burdensome requirements.

title: LEGISLATORS MOVE TO TAKE SPOTLIGHT AT IRAN HEARINGS
description: The Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair reached out today, in full view of a national television audience, and tried to take back control of their hearings from the man who so dramatically dominated them last week.

title: A Jump on '88 Money
description: With the 1988 election season slowly drawing closer, the Democratic Party is trying to get a head start on the perennial game of catch-up it plays with the Republicans when it comes to fund-raising.

title: 'Cavalry,' 2d Episode In 'Men in Battle' Series
description: HOW is a war fought? What do men in battle do? ''Soldiers: A History of Men in Battle,'' a 13-part series, examines a rich subject. Weapons and tactics may change, but the Plains of Troy and the hedgerows of France are connected by essentials; soldiers ply a trade. In a way, it is only a job. ''Cavalry,'' the second in the series, looks at how the job was done when men rode horses. The episode, on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock, is fascinating.

title: Networks Will Carry Washington Hearings
description: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair will be televised live beginning at 9 A.M. on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on some local affiliates of PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service, including Channel 13 in New York.

title: NEW YORK CITY TO CROSS-CHECK INCOME TAX RETURNS WITH U.S.
description: The Internal Revenue Service and New York City agreed yesterday for the first time to share information in order to identify people and businesses that fail to pay taxes.

title: A Thriving Industry to Do the Pentagon's Work
description: Largely because of President Reagan's six-year military buildup, a mini-defense industry is thriving along the beltway that circles Washington like a concrete moat.

title: Networks May Rotate Their Daily Coverage
description: The three network news divisions, faced with intensifying interest in the Iran-contra hearings on the one hand and the loss of millions of dollars in advertising revenues on the other, are planning to cover the remaining weeks of the hearings on a rotating basis, according to several network executives. The alternating coverage could go into effect this week.

title: EMANUEL A. HONIG
description: Emanuel A. Honig, a past president of the New Jersey Bar Association, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Walkill Valley General Hospital in Sussex, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived in Hardyston Township, N.J.

title: Canada Seizes Freighter Believed To Have Put 174 Sikhs on Shore
description: Canadian Navy and Coast Guard vessels today chased and seized a Costa Rican-registered freighter that is believed to have illegally landed 174 Sikhs in a rocky cove on the southern coast of Nova Scotia on Sunday.

title: CBS INC. TO SELL MAGAZINE UNIT TO ITS EXECUTIVES
description: CBS Inc., which has undergone a significant restructuring in the last year, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell CBS Magazines for $650 million to a group led by the unit's senior executives.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JULY 14, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Cholesterol: Debate Flares Over Wisdom In Widespread Reductions
description: AS evidence continues to mount that high levels of cholesterol in the blood can increase the risk of heart attacks, a new debate is emerging over whether the average American should try to reduce cholesterol levels that have traditionally been considered ''normal.''

title: Swiss May Accept 60% of Hill Samuel
description: The Union Bank of Switzerland might be willing to settle for a stake of about 60 percent in the British merchant bank Hill Samuel Group P.L.C., the bank's chief executive-designate, Robert Studer, was quoted as saying. Mr. Studer told the Zurich newspaper Tages-Anzeiger that it was not certain that Union Bank was seeking 100 percent of Hill Samuel, a major presence in the British securities business.

title: ALBANY'S DISCREET BUDGET: A TOOL FOR POLITICAL ENDS
description: Once a year, with a quick vote and little or no debate, the New York State Legislature writes itself a check.

title: Convictions Voided In Fires That Killed 11
description: The state Supreme Court today threw out negligent homicide convictions in two fatal fires in which the owners of buildings had been found not to have installed smoke detectors.

title: AN ISOLATED GENIUS IS GIVEN HIS DUE
description: IN some ways, mathematicians are finally beginning to penetrate the mind of Srinivasa Ramanujan.

title: For the Black Professional, the Obstacles Remain
description: More than two decades after civil rights victories made equal opportunity in the workplace a matter of law, many black professionals say they still face formidable obstacles to success.

title: Oil Rig Count Up by 19
description: The American drilling rig count climbed by 19 last week, to a total of 891, against 663 working rigs at this time last year, Baker Hughes Inc. said today.

title: Murder Count is Thrown Out in Betting Case
description: Murder charges against a man said to be a major organized-crime figure were dismissed yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice who ruled that evidence suggesting that the defendant had prior knowledge of the crime and had been at the scene was insufficient to try him.

title: Japanese Bond Futures Boom in London Debut
description: London trading in Japanese Government bond futures - already the world's most active bond futures contract - got off to a spectacular start yesterday.

title: NASA Readies New Assault On Still-Mysterious Lightning
description: LIKE latter-day Ben Franklins sending aloft rockets instead of kites, a team of 30 scientists are preparing to take aim at thunderclouds this week to extract powerful bolts of electricity as part of a far-reaching study of the causes and effects of lightning.

title: Tangled Trades in Pay 'N Pak
description: New York Stock Exchange officials said yesterday that Morgan Stanley & Company did not appear to have the right to cancel a huge stock trade by the Florida investor Paul A. Bilzerian that would have given him control of Pay 'N Pak Stores Inc.

title: Metro Datelines; Murder-for-Hire Suit Dismissed in Court
description: A Federal judge has dismissed a multimillion-dollar lawsuit filed by a woman from Katonah, N.Y., who sought damages from her estranged husband because he tried to have her killed, purportedly to avoid financial obligations to her and the couple's four children.

title: Bridge; Swiss Team Titles Are Won At Nassau-Suffolk Tourney
description: The Nassau-Suffolk Regional Championships concluded Sunday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan with Swiss team play on two levels.

title: APPLE COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: The company said share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effected May 15, 1987.

title: SOVIET DIPLOMATS BEGIN ISRAEL VISIT, FIRST IN 20 YEARS
description: The first official Soviet delegation to visit Israel in 20 years slipped quietly into Tel Aviv Sunday night on a flight from Cyprus, Israeli officials confirmed today.

title: Whirlpool Net Off, Sales Up
description: The Whirlpool Corporation's second-quarter earnings fell 9.5 percent, to $47.4 million, or 65 cents a share, from $52.4 million, or 71 cents a share, a year earlier, the company reported today. Sales rose 5.7 percent, to $1.14 billion, from $1.08 billion. Whirlpool's chairman, Jack

title: Dance: Forsythe's 'Artifact' by Frankfurt Troupe
description: Imagine dancing cut off by a fire curtain that falls repeatedly with a thud, only to rise again on a completely new stage picture materializing out of blackness with cinematic fluency.

title: Players; Rookie Learns to Take a Bow
description: As soon as he stepped out onto the grass of the Oakland Alameda County Coliseum, children were calling his name and adults with electronic equipment were crowding all around. The children pleaded for Mark McGwire's autograph. The adults wondered - for the umpteenth time in the last few days - if this sudden new professional status has begun to sink in. He answered, again, ''Not yet.''

title: Tough Union Stance in Free-Agent Case
description: If an arbitrator finds that baseball's club owners acted in collusion against 1985 free agents, the Players Association proposes that those players be permitted to void their contracts, pursue individual damages, receive the difference between ''contract price and market price'' and be awarded punitive damages.

title: UNITED JERSEY BANKS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for year-ago quarter and 6 months are restated to reflect to reflect the company's December 1986 merger with commercial bancshares on a pooling of interests basis.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Drop
description: Treasury bond prices fell nearly a point in light trading activity yesterday as securities dealers sought levels that would attract more investor demand.

title: Catalogue Stresses Free or Low-Cost Software
description: CALL it what you will -voyeurism, daydreaming or just plain curiosity - people like to read catalogues. They have changed since the days when Sears, Roebuck & Company first mailed its free catalogues. The latest innovations are catalogues that are themselves sold, often through bookstores.

title: Jersey Haulers Win Increase
description: Garbage hauling companies in 13 northern and central New Jersey counties soon will be charging customers 1 percent to 2 percent more under an interim rate increase approved today by the Board of Public Utilities. The hauling companies applied for rate increases after a settlement last week on a three-year contract with Teamsters Local 945, which represents 2,500 garbage truck drivers and helpers who work for 130 hauling companies.

title: NCR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sports People; Fighting a Fill-In?
description: Promoters for Mark Breland, the World Boxing Association welterweight champion, said yesterday that they were searching for another fighter for a scheduled bout in South Carolina after being unable to reach an agreement with Marlon Starling.

title: Knicks, Ending 84-Day Search, Name Pitino Coach; Candidate List Wasn't Much Shorter
description: The chase for a Knick coach, which ended yesterday with the naming of Rick Pitino, was preceded by months of intrigue and guessing, thousands of miles of travel, secret discussions and late-night telephone calls.

title: Daimler's Chief Resigns After Company Discord
description: The 59-year-old chairman of Daimler-Benz A.G. said today that he would resign as its chief executive.

title: A Trump Presidential Bid?
description: A veteran Republican Party organizer in New Hampshire said yesterday that he will begin circulating nominating petitions for the developer Donald J. Trump in that state's 1988 Republican Presidential primary.

title: United Air May Get Chief From Within
description: The directors of the Allegis Corporation may stick close to home in choosing a president and chief executive for its United Airlines division.

title: A Day's Worth Of Questioners
description: Yesterday was the first full day of questioning of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North by individual members of the select committees. Here are the 13 who spoke. Senator David L. Boren D-Okla. Chairman of Senate Select Committee on Intelligence. Said he felt betrayed by the Iran-contra operation and by what he sees as misleading statements about the initiative to Congress. Representative Jack Brooks D-Tex. A defender of Congressional prerogatives. A tough questioner, most specifically of Assistant Secretary of State Elliott Abrams. Representative William S. Broomfield R-Mich. Though a supporter of the President, he has felt that Congress was ignored in the Iran-contra affair, yet has said he is pleased by what he sees as the President's interest in uncovering the facts. Representative Dick Cheney R-Wyo. A strong supporter of the Administration, Mr. Cheney challenged Senator Inouye's description of a memorandum from Colonel North to Admiral Poindexter. Senator William S. Cohen R-Me. Backed contra aid, but has been skeptical of the accounts given by some of the witnesses who appear before the committees. Representative Dante B. Fascell D-Fla. As chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, he quickly opened hearings after the initial diversion of funds to the contras was uncovered. Has voted in support of aid for the contras. Representative Thomas S. Foley D-Wash. A forceful critic of the Administration's policy in Central America, he found many of Colonel North's answers ''somewhat evasive,'' and his descriptions of his actions as deception of the Government. Senator Orrin G. Hatch R-Utah One of the Administration's most outspoken supporters. Has tried to depict each witness's testimony in the most favorable light. Senator Howell Heflin D-Ala. With a down-home manner, he has summarized the initiative as a tale of ''rogue elephants, Persian rug merchants, loose cannons, soldiers of fortune, privateers, believers, hostages and contras.'' Representative Henry J. Hyde R-Ill. Has preached against Congressional interference in foreign policy, using the Boland amendment as a favorite example. Senator George J. Mitchell D-Me. Has raised constitutional questions of accountability with witnesses who were members of Colonel North's private network and who say they were only following orders. Representative Peter W. Rodino D-N.J. Was a member of the Watergate committee 15 years ago. Has asked tough, challenging questions, often focusing on operational details and who authorized them. Senator Warren B. Rudman R-N.H. As ranking Republican on the Senate committee, he has been a forceful critic of the Iran arms sales and the diversion of funds to the contras. Senator Paul S. Sarbanes D-Md. Raised tough questions about the Administration's policy and has been very supportive of the questioning techniques used by the select committees counsels. Senator Paul S. Trible, Jr. R-Va. A low-key conservative, he has asked tough questions of Administration witnesses, though he has a voting record loyal to the President.

title: Post Cereal Introduces Ziploc Bag
description: FOR a cold cereal manufacturer whose name is not Kellogg, the fight is uphill all the way. And if better taste is not enough of a competitive weapon, then other consumer benefits have to be found.

title: U S Sprint Defends Fiber-Optic Outlay
description: Executives of the U S Sprint Communications Company and its parent companies defended the concern's spending on a fiber-optic long-distance network today, but said they now expected to significantly cut operating expenses.

title: SOVIET OFFERING TO SELL PHOTOGRAPHS TAKEN FROM SPACE
description: THE Soviet Union is stepping up plans to market photographs taken from satellites in space that have better resolution than those offered commercially in the West, according to Western space experts and Soviet officials.

title: Computer Memories Fund
description: Computer Memories Inc., a nearly defunct computer company that plans to merge with the producer of the film ''Platoon,'' has agreed to put $15.5 million in a settlement fund to settle a lawsuit, the company said today.

title: Pepper Has a Better Catastrophic Costs Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: ORACLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Year-ago per-share figures adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in March.

title: A Rare Setting for Lalique
description: A treasure trove of the jewelry of Rene Lalique - gathered from public and private collections - is on view in London in a gallery designed to recall the designer's elegant Parisian showrooms.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Help in Closing Mills The Government is thinking of helping steelmakers close some plants, finding that cheaper than bearing the pension costs if whole companies file for bankruptcy. Page D1. Attack on Tax Cheats The Internal Revenue Service and New York City agreed for the first time to share information to identify tax cheats. Page B1. Thatcher Plans U.S. Visit As Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher prepares to visit Washington, she is drawing up a list of foreign policy concerns. Page A3.

title: After Long, Costly Preliminaries, California Sex Abuse Case Opens
description: The prosecutor in a child molestation case presented her opening statement today after the longest, costliest preliminary hearing in California history.

title: Savings Unit Begins Offering
description: The Roosevelt Savings and Loan Association of St. Louis is offering $200 million of 8 1/4 percent mortgage-backed bonds due in 1990 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Patrick Wolff, 19, Is Victor In '87 Junior Championship
description: Patrick Wolff, a 19-year-old international master from Belmont, Mass., has won the 1987 United States Junior Invitational Championship held at the Manhattan Chess Club.

title: Swimmer Killed by Alligator In Spring at a Park in Florida
description: A 22-year-old swimmer was found killed by an alligator today in a spring at a state park about 15 miles south of here, the authorities said.

title: OSHA Gets Tough, at Last
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration flexed its muscles last week by imposing its biggest fine ever - $1.5 million - on the Chrysler Corporation. Citing 811 violations that endangered workers at Chrysler's plant in Newark, Del., John Pendergrass, the agency's administrator, described the fine as ''the only possible response to a totally unacceptable situation.''

title: Rock: Grateful Dead And Dylan in Concert
description: THE Grateful Dead relied on songs, not their famous free-form jamming, for their concert Sunday with Bob Dylan at Giants Stadium in the New Jersey Meadowlands. Performing two sets on their own, and a third as Mr. Dylan's backup band, the Dead set a new attendance record - 71,598 tickets - at the stadium. And while the crowd sang along, danced, clapped and celebrated as the Dead's loyal audience always does, the concert was an odd pairing.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: NO TELEPHONE TO HEAVEN. By Michelle Cliff. 211 pages. E. P. Dutton. $17.95.

title: Death in Alligator Attack Attributed to Drowning
description: State game authorities said today that an autopsy showed an 11-foot alligator that attacked a swimmer had pulled him under the water and drowned him.

title: Scouting; Bo Jackson's Pace
description: Bo Jackson seems certain, if he plays regularly, to break the major league record for strikeouts in a season. The Kansas City Royals outfielder has been fanning about 40 percent of his times at bat and could wind up with 221 strikeouts, smashing the record of 189 set by Bobby Bonds of the San Francisco Giants in 1970. Along the way, Jackson would break the American League record of 185 set last year by Pete Incaviglia of the Texas Rangers. Incaviglia should also strike out more than 200 times this season. The leaders in strikeouts with their projected totals for 1987: > Per Proj. Player, Team SO Game Total Bo Jackson, Royals 115 1.42 221 Pete Incaviglia, Rangers 107 1.29 205 Jim Presley, Mariners 102 1.18 189 Rob Deer, Brewers 95 1.30 195 Gary Pettis, Angels 93 1.07 171 Cory Synder, Indians 91 1.07 171 Jack Clark, Cardinals 88 1.04 167 Jose Canseco, A's 81 0.95 159 Larry Parrish, Rangers 78 0.96 151 Dale Murphy, Braves 78 0.90 146 Devon White, Angels 78 0.89 143

title: Northrop Loss At $15.4 Million
description: The Northrop Corporation reported a second-quarter loss of $15.4 million today, citing a previously disclosed $124.3 million write-down that analysts said was related to the classified Stealth bomber project.

title: Administration Faults Aspin's Gulf Disclosure
description: A leading Congressman drew criticism from the Reagan Administration today when he disclosed details of plans for United States escorts of Kuwaiti oil tankers after a briefing by Cabinet members.

title: GREECE'S PREMIER TURNS TO MOSCOW
description: Shortly after Washington's latest dispute with Athens erupted last month, the Greek authorities announced that Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou had exchanged letters with the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Lag in Retail Spending Tied to Income and Debt
description: Retail spending, which fuels most of the domestic economy, was virtually unchanged in June for the fourth consecutive month as debt-weary consumers continued to shun expensive purchases, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Economic Scene; The Shift From Forecasting
description: AMONG executive search firms, Handy Associates is a leader in recruiting professional economists for financial institutions and big corporations. But call Peter Vosburgh, the proprietor, and the first thing he says is that Handy isn't taking applications from economists seeking jobs.

title: Ban on Animal Sacrifice
description: Animal sacrifice for religious purposes is against state law, the Florida Attorney General Bob Butterworth said Monday, putting an Afro-Cuban church on notice that its religious practices could be restricted. He issued the advisory opinion, which does not carry the weight of law, after a church of the Santeria faith was established in the city of Hialeah and the City Council requested a decision.

title: Business Technology; A Chip to Speed Computers
description: THE dynamic random access memory, or dynamic RAM, has long been the center of attention in the semiconductor industry. It is the industry's largest-selling chip, the one in which the Japanese have made their strongest inroads, and the one that is perennially the focus of semiconductor trade tensions.

title: Legal Aid Society Files Suit To Close Shelter for Children
description: Asserting that dozens of children in need of foster care were being housed in overcrowded and unpleasant conditions, the Legal Aid Society filed suit yesterday to close one of the city's shelters for young children.

title: Canada Hunts a Second Freighter And Jails 2 Men in Sikhs' Landing
description: A second freighter was identified today as having been involved with the illegal landing of 174 Sikhs on the Nova Scotia coast, and two men were sentenced to prison terms for organizing the Sikhs' voyage.

title: Insider Prosecutor To Join Law Firm
description: Charles M. Carberry, who played an important role in the crackdown on insider trading, plans to resign as a Federal prosecutor Oct. 1 to join the law firm of Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue.

title: North Is Dismissed by Iran Panel With Criticism for Policy of 'Lies'
description: The chairmen of the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair dismissed Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North from the witness stand this afternoon with stinging rebukes for having taken part in what they said was a policy based upon lies.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Business People column last Thursday about McLean Industries misidentified its president and chief executive. He is Hobart G. Truesdell 2d.

title: Hurry Up and Vote
description: The Senate Commerce Committee yesterday held what is called in Congressional jargon a markup, the discussion and voting out of various bills. These things can drag on, but in this case the senators sweated out their business in almost no time. Literally.

title: SARA HENDERSON HAY
description: Sara Henderson Hay, author of six books of poetry, died July 7 at her home in Pittsburgh. She was 80 years old.

title: Scouting; Dialing a Winner
description: The Al Paul Lefton advertising agency, which won a Telly Award last year for its New York Offtrack Betting television advertisement that showed a customer transported magically onto the back of the horse on which she was betting, will be stressing special effects again this week in the shooting of another OTB ad. This one is a plug for its telephone betting accounts.

title: CORRECTION
description: The caption of an Associated Press picture yesterday about the opening of a child-molestation trial in Los Angeles misidentified the man with Peggy McMartin Buckey, a defendant. He was not her son, Raymond; he was unidentified.

title: Poison Candy Brings 40-Year Prison Term
description: A prominent anthropologist was sentenced yesterday to 40 years in prison for sending valentine boxes of poisoned chocolates to a Federal judge and to a professor.

title: STATE STREET BOSTON reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Advertising; International Economy Magazine Debut Is Set
description: David M. Smick, 33, and Richard H. Medley, 35, partners in Smick & Medley & Associates, Washington-based economic consultants, are now additionally co-publishers of The International Economy magazine, which will be published six times a year, It will be what they consider to be a much needed ''written forum for the international policy debate.''

title: Furman Selz Sale To Xerox Is Set
description: The Xerox Corporation, in a move to increase its presence in financial services, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Furman Selz Holding Corporation, the New York research, brokerage and investment banking firm, for $110 million.

title: New School Graduate Unit Rebounds
description: A decade ago, the graduate faculty of the New School for Social Research hit rock bottom.

title: MELLON BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a previously announced estimated loss of $500 million, as well as losses relating to Mellon's mortgage banking subsidiaries and acquired real estate, accruals for severance expense and an early retirement program, provisions for uncollectible amounts arising from the company's trust activities, a writedown in the carrying value of a foreign investment and a delay in the recognition of a previously announced gain on the sale of the company's interest in Network Finance Ltd. Quarter also includes a provision for possible credit losses of $533 million compared with $78.8 million in the year-earlier period. c-Includes a provision for possible credit losses of $708 million compared with $169 million a year earlier. d-Net income The company said its reserve for possible credit losses related to certain lesser developed countries was about 27 percent of the $1.6 billion in outstanding loans to these countries at June 30, 1987. Including prior writedowns on public sector loans, the company's reserve allocated to these countries was about 29 percent of outstanding loans prior to these writedowns. The company said latest quarter results also included significantly lower gains on the sale of investment securities.

title: Company News; Loss Is Wider For Kaisertech
description: Kaisertech Ltd., the holding company for the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, said today that it lost $389.1 million in the second quarter, compared with a loss of $30.6 million a year ago.

title: For Smokers, Ways to Quit Are Many, but Goal Is Elusive
description: LEAD: WITH more and more bans on smoking in public and in the work place and more and more nonsmokers adamant about their clean-air rights, smokers are coming under increasing pressure to quit. Nowadays a wide range of publications, programs and professionals are available to help smokers negotiate a life without cigarettes.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A Japanese company has not only damaged national defense, but has also committed a crime of betrayal against the Japanese people because of its actions.''

title: About New York; Vital Street Life: It's the Fine Art Of Schmoozing
description: ''This is an amiable day!'' said William H. Whyte, urban anthropologist, walking down the Avenue of the Americas during the lunch hour yesterday on one of his schmooze patrols.

title: Advertising; Business Month and Inc. Are Joined in Circulation
description: With yesterday's announcement that the Goldhirsh Publishing Group was about to offer advertisers ''America's Top Management Network,'' it became apparent what Bernard Goldhirsh had in mind when he acquired the flagging Dun's Business Month from Dun & Bradstreet last November.

title: Finance/Business; Home Loan Banks
description: A $2.5 billion financing by the Federal Home Loan Banks offers a $1.165 billion issue of 6.9 percent bonds due July 25, 1988; a $825 million issue of 7.8 percent bond due July 25, 1990, and $510 million of 8.375 percent bonds due July 27, 1992. The three bond issues are priced at par and offered through various securities dealers.

title: Korean Olympics Still Being Disputed
description: In an effort to ease the dispute between North and South Korea over the 1988 Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, the International Olympic Committee proposed today that North Korea be given two additional events, for a total of four.

title: Jate Lobell a 7-5 Choice
description: Jate Lobell's defeat last week has transformed the Meadowlands Pace into more than a one-horse race Friday night.

title: Company News; I.B.M. Falls Short Again
description: Falling short of Wall Street's optimistic projections, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that its profits in the second quarter had dropped 9.9 percent.

title: At Welfare Hotel, Tenants Group Gives Fragile Hope
description: In a place that conspires against hope, Thomas Reuter is trying to restore just a bit of it. The place is the Holland Hotel, by most measures one of the bleakest welfare hotels in New York City. And the fragile hope resides in the tenants' association begun by Mr. Reuter five months ago.

title: Radio Host Suspended For Insult to Lawmaker
description: A radio talk show host has been suspended for calling Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia, a ''moron'' on the air.

title: Election Official Indicted in Theft Of Board Funds
description: The chief of enforcement for the New York State Board of Elections has been indicted on criminal charges of stealing at least $1,425 from an account established to pay informers in election fraud investigations.

title: We Need an Election
description: One thing the Iran-contra hearings have demonstrated is that this country needs a Presidential election.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Rural Electric Cooperative yesterday tentatively priced $279 million of grantor trust certificates in five parts, for possible offering today through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers. The certificates, which are priced at par, are backed by promissory notes of the Soyland Power Cooperative, Illinois.

title: The Russians Aren't Trying to Be Just Like Us; Can He Succeed?
description: To the Editor:

title: F.A.A. to Investigate Training Of Delta Pilots After Mistakes
description: The Federal Aviation Administration plans to conduct a special inquiry into the pilot training procedures of Delta Air Lines following a recent series of pilot mistakes, an agency official said yesterday.

title: 20 Years After Rift, Greetings to Israelis In a Russian Accent
description: Every morning, the radio service of the Israeli Army invites a different personality to the microphone to open the day at 8 by pronouncing ''Boker tov, Israel'' - ''Good morning, Israel.''

title: Jackson Accepts Raiders Pact
description: Bo Jackson said today that he had agreed to a contract with the Los Angeles Raiders that would enable him to fulfill his dream of playing both professional football and baseball.

title: Ex-Top Aide to Hart Breaks His Silence, Cites 'Classic Error'
description: Gary Hart was a victim of his own decision to test fate and a press corps obsessed with candidates' personal lives, his former campaign manager said today.

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,066,000 for the quarter and $232,523,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $18,097,000 from discontinued operations. b-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,066,000 for the quarter and $232,523,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $18,097,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net income after a loss of $60,832,000 from discontinued operations. The company cited increases, from the year-ago quarter to the latest quarter, in its interest expense from $14.1 million to $19.2 million, and in its effective tax rate from 36 percent to 48 percent. They also cited a higher amount of debt due to capital spending for aircraft and equipment to expand and improve its operating system.

title: Health Dept. Urges Salaries Of $110,000 for Top Scientists
description: The Department of Health and Human Services has drafted a proposal to create a special corps of senior biomedical researchers who could be paid as much as $110,000 a year, a salary that would exceed those of Cabinet members by $10,500, an Administration official said Monday.

title: North, Minus His Slides, Makes Cause for Contras
description: The issue that has simmered just beneath the surface throughout the Iran-contra hearings -aid to the contras - broke into full public view today in a dispute over a slide show that was to be given by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. Congress has been split almost evenly on the contra subject for years, and today the fight was resolved with a compromise. Colonel North was permitted to give his lecture on aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, known as contras, but without his slides.

title: A Carpet And Some Nuts
description: Under questioning by Representative Jim Courter, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North gave this testimony yesterday about an attempt to give him a carpet.

title: Business People; Surprise Wall Street Resignation
description: One of Wall Street's rags-to-riches stories took an unexpected turn yesterday with the resignation of Lewis S. Ranieri, a vice chairman at Salomon Brothers who helped propel the firm to the top of the mortgage-backed securities market.

title: Finance/New Issues; Commercial Paper Rates Drop Again
description: Interest rates at Citicorp's regular auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper declined for the fourth consecutive week. The banking company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.5545 percent, down from 6.725 percent last week.

title: Summer Kitchens: A Share in Survival
description: IT happened on Fire Island several summers ago, in a house Rochelle Rachelson was sharing with several other people.

title: Company News; Mellon Has Big Loss; 2 Resign
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation turned in unexpectedly disappointing second-quarter results yesterday, and it disclosed that two top officers had resigned, apparently as part of a cost-cutting effort.

title: French Official Called By a Court in Teheran
description: Iran's Islamic Revolution Court has summoned the French consul to provide ''some explanations'' about allegations of expionage, the Teheran radio said today.

title: Mail Handlers Reach Tentative 3-Year Pact
description: The International Union of Mail Handlers today announced a tentative three-year contract agreement with the United States Postal Service.

title: An Experienced Voice Praises Hart
description: Richard Nixon told his old political foe Gary Hart that he understood how he felt. Especially on one subject.

title: KAYPRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge from reversal of tax loss carryforwards which increased the loss for the quarter by $322,000; and the 9-month includes a tax credit of $536,000. c-Net income d-Net loss

title: Sports People; Hearing on Trade
description: The National Basketball Association will hold a hearing in an attempt to resolve a dispute over a trade between the Portland Trail Blazers and the Cleveland Cavaliers. Portland traded Jim Paxson, a guard, to the Cavaliers for Keith Lee, a forward, on June 22 but later attempted to call off the deal, saying Lee had not passed a medical check by the Blazers' team doctor because of a knee problem. The Cavaliers objected to canceling the trade and requested the hearing, which has been scheduled for next Wednesday in New York.

title: 38 Arrested in Protest at Staten Island Site of Navy Port
description: Police officers removing anti-nuclear demonstrators who tried to block construction. They were protesting the building of a proposed port for the battleshipIowa and other Navy vessels. Demonstrators say the Iowa carries nuclear weapons. The Navy refuses to comment on the armament of ships. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr)

title: Ex-Chief of Intelsat Admits Fraud Guilt
description: A former top official of Intelsat pleaded guilty today, along with two brokers, to charges that they participated in a scheme to obtain $4.8 million in connection with rigging construction and financing contracts for the satellite consortium's new headquarters.

title: FARMLAND FADING UNDER CITY SPRAWL
description: City sprawl, highways and other nonagricultural uses are claiming American farmland at an annual rate that could involve acreage equal to the entire State of Missouri by the year 2030, according to a report by the Department of Agriculture.

title: Appeal Hearing Could Upset Selection for World Tourney
description: A hearing before the American Contract Bridge League's board of directors tomorrow in Baltimore could overturn the result of the selection process for the 1987 United States world championship team. The board will hear an appeal by Malcolm Brachman and his teammates on the semifinal playoff in Memphis in May.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about the renovation of the Jamaica Station of the Long Island Rail Road misstated both the original and the latest estimates of the project's completion date. The original estimate was 1997; the new projection is 1999.

title: MacFarlane Testifies: Praise for North and Covert Operations
description: Following are excerpts from Robert C. McFarlane's second appearance before the Iran-contra committees, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Bridge Pier Seen as Key To Collapse
description: Four months after a bridge on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway collapsed, investigators are focusing on what they call a potentially fatal omission made by Thruway Authority officials during the last major reconstruction of the bridge.

title: NORTHROP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The latest second quarter and 6 months both include a pretax charge of $124.3 million based on an increased estimate of final cost of a classified long-term research and development contract. The year-ago results included $39 million of expenditures on the F-20 program in the second quarter and $85 million in the 6 months. The company said the year-ago second quarter also included a loss provision for a classified program.

title: Side Issues Slow Vote on Trade Bill
description: The Senate today rejected today the Department of Commerce and the Office of the United States Trade Representative, which was proposed in the omnibus trade bill.

title: Advances; The New Pay Phone: It Even Talks
description: WHEN it comes to pay telephones, most consumers are conservative and happy with anything that works.

title: Tanya Z Nash, 89; A Carrer Dedicated to Helping the Deaf
description: Tanya Zolotoroff Nash, who retired in 1968 after 35 years as the executive director of the New York Society for the Deaf, died last Friday at the Interfaith Hospital in Brooklyn. She was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Notes From North Describe Meeting on Contra Support
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North told a meeting of mid-level Government officials last August that he was giving money to contra leaders and running an air resupply operation that used C-123 aircraft, according to handwritten notes he took at the time.

title: A Cast of Legislators
description: Members of the Iran-contra committees who had not been able to question Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North had their chance yesterday. Here are some who spoke. Representative Les Aspin, D-Wis. His work as chairman of the Armed Services Committee has caused him to be absent during much of the hearings. Representative Edward P. Boland, D-Mass. The name behind the series of amendments that limited United States involvement with the contras. Asked questions concerning adherence to the amendment. Representative Jim Courter, R-N.J. He has consistently supported the Administration's policy and tried to limit damage done to the Reagan Presidency. Representative Michael DeWine, R-Ohio Has for the most part been an Administration partisan, asking witnesses questions that enable them to state their own cases. Representative Lee H. Hamilton, D-Ind. Chairman of the House committee. Philosopher of the committee, summarizing what he sees as main themes. Supporter of strong Congressional involvement in foreign policy. Senator Daniel K. Inouye, D-Hawaii As chairman of the Senate panel, he has tried to keep the hearings as bipartisan as possible. Has quietly but firmly overruled the objections of Brendan V. Sullivan Jr., Colonel North's lawyer. Senator James A. McClure, R-Idaho. Strong supporter of the Administration. He has consistently sought to defend President Reagan by pointing to ambiguities in the Boland amendment and by asserting that no laws were broken. Representative Bill McCollum, R-Fla. Has spoken out against what he saw as unfair and biased questioning by Arthur L. Liman, the Senate counsel, of Colonel North, asserting that committee members should ask the most toughest questions. Senator Sam Nunn, D-Ga. Questioned the testimony offered by Colonel North in light of his admission that he lied to Congress. Representative Louis Stokes, D-Ohio Chairman of the House Intelligence Committee. Consistent opponent of the Administration's policy on Central America. Asked a witness whether Colonel North would be truthful during testimony.

title: Next Act: Poindexter's Predicament
description: Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter faces a quandary on Wednesday when he finally begins his testimony and faces questions about what he told President Reagan of efforts to funnel money, arms and other support to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Soccer Notebook; National Teams Facing 3 Major Tests
description: It was far away - in St. John, New Brunswick - and the 1-0 victory over Ecuador may have looked insignificant, but for American soccer, the victory in the under-16 World Cup Sunday was another important step in a growing national program that faces three major tests this year.

title: Notes and Bonds Up Slightly
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday as traders were encouraged by a drop in short-term rates and hints that the Federal Reserve was backing away from the modest tightening of policy it arranged in April and May.

title: Article 512087 -- No Title
description: A court-appointed receiver said yesterday that he cannot account for $412,000 that Dennis B. Levine gained from an illegal inside trading scheme.

title: Advertising; People
description: Christine Miller was named executive vice president/managing director at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos/New York. Casey Jones was promoted to vice president/management supervisor.

title: KAISERTECH LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $30 million. c-After income from discontinued operations of $2.4 million. The company said the latest quarter and 6 months results include previously announced pre-tax writedowns of $357 million consisting principally of the Electrical Products manufacturing business and idle and uneconomic primary aluminum-making capacity, and provision for the loss upon disposition of oil and gas properties. The company said the year-ago 6 months loss includes $18.9 million, primarily in equity in earnings, from adoption of FAS No. 87 and No. 88.

title: Company News; Lockheed to Sell Shipbuilding Unit
description: The Lockheed Corporation said today that it would sell its shipbuilding unit as the first step of a restructuring plan.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Sunday about tank warfare attributed a comment incorrectly to Dr. Joshua M. Epstein of the Brookings Institution. He did not say that the Army periodically raises fears about the capabilities of Soviet tanks simply to gain more money from Congress. Through the omission of a phrase, another quotation from Mr. Epstein also misstated his views.

title: Company News; Holmes a Court Seeks 15% of Texaco
description: Robert Holmes a Court yesterday asked for Federal clearance to increase his stake in Texaco Inc. to 15 percent.

title: Shultz Meets Helms and Dole On Mozambique Policy Rift
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz conferred today with two Senate Republicans who are critics of the Administration's policy on Mozambique, but both sides refused to give ground, officials said.

title: Tax Exemption for Nonprofit Hospitals Assailed
description: A key member of a Congressional tax-writing committee said today that the Federal tax exemption for nonprofit hospitals was probably unwarranted because they generally did not provide substantial amounts of charitable care.

title: North vs. McFarlane: The Conflicts
description: During the hearings on the Iran-contra affair, the Congressional investigating committees have heard conflicting testimony from Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and Robert C. McFarlane on several issues. Here are excerpts from the testimony:

title: Renewal in Tibet
description: To the Editor:

title: SQUARE D CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Theater Producers Back End of Contract Talks
description: Members of the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers, meeting yesterday afternoon in a special session, voted unanimous support of a decision by their negotiating committee to break off discussions with the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers on June 29.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: 8,600 Food Products

title: Rescuer Drowns in Hudson
description: A 31-year-old man drowned in the Hudson River off lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon while trying to save a woman who had jumped or fallen into the river near Jane Street, the police said. The unidentified woman was pulled from the river by two other men and was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital where she was listed in critical condition. The drowned man's name was being withheld until his family could be notified. The other men involved in the rescue were Jesus Ayala, 21, of the Bronx, and Maya Chavic, 30.

title: DIAMOND-BATHURST INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that latest quarter results were hurt by significantly lower sales of an explosion of its Antioch, California facility.

title: Sizing Up a Shakeup
description: The Administration generally supports the reorganization of the World Bank that its president, Barber B. Conable, is orchestrating, according to a senior official, but is ''concerned'' that it is not tough enough.

title: Knicks Players Know Their New Coach Well
description: In 1983, Rick Pitino was largely unknown outside the small fraternity of basketball coaches. Hardly anyone knew that he was so dedicated that on his wedding night he left his bride in a hotel room while he was interviewed for an assistant coach's job at Syracuse, and then postponed his honeymoon to make a recruiting trip.

title: NASA Says Ruptured Stage Of Rocket May Be Repairable
description: A rocket stage that was accidentally struck by a work platform may be salvageable because damage was limited to a ruptured hydrogen tank, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: Ali Is Examined By Mexican Doctor
description: A Mexican doctor who has pioneered a new transplant surgery for Parkinson's Disease patients said today that he had examined Muhammad Ali, who suffers from Parkinson's Syndrome, a milder form of the disease, and that the former heavyweight champion was considering undergoing the treatment.

title: KEY RATES
Company News; Greyhound Merger
description: Greyhound Lines Inc. signed final contracts to buy $80 million in assets from financially troubled Trailways Lines Inc. Greyhound agreed in the cash transaction to buy Trailways buses, terminals and garages, and operate some Trailways routes. Some workers will be laid off, said Fred Currey, Greyhound's president and chairman. The Trailways name will be retained, especially in areas where Trailways is the only bus service, he said. The transaction must be approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: The Dance: 'Mozartnu' and 'New Dance Matinee'
description: So many men and women, relatively speaking, were dancing nude or topless onstage at the Pepsico Summerfare festival's Sunday matinee that it was enough to make a fully clothed viewer feel overdressed.

title: National League Wins Improbable Game, 2-0, in 13
description: When the shadows had finally fallen across the field and the sun had disappeared quietly behind the walls of the Oakland Coliseum, only one notion seemed to fit the moment: The hitters would make this an All-Star Game to remember.

title: THE LAWYERS IN ALBANY: LAWMAKERS WITH 2 HATS
description: Some of the most influential New York State legislators and their top aides play an extraordinary dual role here, conducting the public's business while they work as members of law firms that represent clients affected by legislation or state regulation.

title:
Market Place;
Rally Pulls Dow Up 28.38, to 2,481.35
description: LEAD: The stock market moved sharply higher yesterday, buoyed by foreign and institutional buying, generally strong earnings reports and rumors that the nation's trade deficit would be smaller than anticipated.

title: MARINE MIDLAND BANKS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After the previously announced addition to its loan loss reserve of $400 million. c-Net income The 1986 results for the second quarter and 6 months were restated to reflect the company's investment in CM&M Group Inc. using the equity method of accounting. The company said the provision for loan losses amounted to $463,100,000 for the latest 6 months, compared with $77,900,000 a year-ago.

title: Questions for the Admiral
description: Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter will be questioned on a host of documents and testimony by others, including Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. These are among the questions he is most likely to be asked:

title: Company News; Rainier Bancorp
description: The Rainier Bancorporation, based in Seattle, said its stockholders had approved the company's merger with the Los Angeles-based Security Pacific Corporation. The agreement provides for the exchange of 1.3 shares of Security Pacific common for each of the 22.3 million currently outstanding shares of Rainier. Based on Monday's closing price of Security Pacific, the transaction is valued at $1.2 billion.

title: DAVID L. DIMMOCK
description: David L. Dimmock, former president of Bradley, Dimmock & Hungerford, a New York advertising agency, died of cancer last Wednesday at the Norwalk, Conn., Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived in Fairfield, Conn.

title: Outdoors; Tips on Choosing Proper Fly
description: A fly fisherman inevitably reaches the stage in which he must decide how much effort he should devote to study of the aquatic insects upon which trout feed.

title: 'Bonjour.' 'Bonjour.'
description: Keun Sun Choi, the president the Korean electronics company Goldstar, had just made a Washington luncheon speech in English the other day describing a new cooperative agreement between members of the Electronic Industries Association of Korea and the Electronic Industries Association of the United States.

title: William Overton, A U.S. Judge, Dies
description: Federl District Judge William R. Overton, who struck down as unconstitutional an Arkansas law that required public schools in Arkansas to teach a creationist account of the origin of life if they taught the theory of evolution, died today of cancer. He was 47 years old.

title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $8.5 million. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1.3 million and $4.3 million for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Clinton Decides He Won't Seek '88 Nomination
description: Gov. Bill Clinton announced today that he would not run for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination, ending weeks of speculation.

title: FLORIDA PROGRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OWENS-CORNING FIBERGLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $124.4 million and an after-tax gain of $83.1 million, or $2.01 a share, from the sale of the major components of the aerospace and strategic materials group. c-Includes a one-time charge of $14.3 million for fees associated with refinancing of bank debt.

title: Court Puts Off Move to Speed Arrests' Review
description: An appeals court decided yesterday to delay a lower-court order requiring judges to review arrests in New York City within 24 hours after the arrests are made.

title: Company News; Early July Sales Of Autos Off 12.4%
description: Domestic car sales totaled 165,909 in early July, a drop of 12.4 percent from the comparable period last year, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: Bargains in Rome? Luxury Items Might Be Best Buys
description: SOME visitors to Rome arrive anticipating the glories of the Sistine Chapel, the Colosseum and the Villa Borghese. Others contemplate the worldly delights of Fendi bags, Tanino Crisci boots and Pratesi linens.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: REMEMBER when sneakers were, well, just that -sneakers (or tennies in the Middle West)? White (sometimes red or navy) canvas tops with thin, smooth rubber soles and white laces. The shoes your mother always said were no good for your feet. The shoes you wore for nearly every activity: walking, running, tennis, volleyball, softball, sailing. Professional athletes had special shoes for basketball, baseball, football or soccer. Everyone else made do with sneakers.

title: Philharmonic: Central Park Concert
description: WELL away from retentive asphalt, scorchers like Monday have a way of yielding to the pleasantest of dusks. With the least cooperation from the breeze (and Monday's was a flawless specimen of continuous but gentle), the weather becomes the kind you would have if the weather were yours to dispose - and this at an hour when a stroll up Broadway might still feel uncomfortably muggy.

title: Winfield Hesitates, Is Lost
description: Dave Winfield of the Yankees rounded third base in the bottom of the ninth inning of the 58th and perhaps strangest All-Star Game. Across the infield, a possible double play was disintegrating.

title: Church in Philippines Urges Land for Poor
description: The Roman Catholic bishops of the Philippines are prepared to ask landowners to turn over lands voluntarily for distribution to the poor, without waiting for a possible law mandating a redistribution.

title: IC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $12.3 million on the settlement of certain pension obligations of a unit. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $2.1 million and $10.8 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Food Is A Main Theme at Park Concerts
description: SOME say it is becoming a lost rite of summer: lolling in the shade of an oak on a Sunday afternoon, dapper men in jackets and hats, women in summer finery and wicker hampers crammed with a tasty outdoor repast.

title: Maple Leaf Farms: The Ducks Stop Here
description: LEAD: THE picture is all very ominous, especially if you are a duck. Down drifting like snow through a warm Indiana sky. Truckloads of other webfeet, all heading to the same large factory-like building. And refrigerated trucks going the other way, full of boxes destined for supermarkets and food brokers.

title: HARRY J. FEENEY
description: Harry J. Feeney, director of press information for CBS from 1969 until his retirement early last year, died Saturday at his home in Forest Hills, Queens, after heart surgery. He was 69 years old.

title: Clinic in Ohio Starts Egg Donor Plan
description: A major medical center here is beginning a program to establish a pool of egg donors for couples unable to have children.

title: U.S. Finds It Made Little Progress in U.N. Voting
description: The United States has made little progress winning votes at the United Nations, despite assertions by Vernon A. Walters, the chief American representative, and other diplomats that the American position is improving, according to a report by the United States Mission.

title: The Russians Aren't Trying to Be Just Like Us
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE IN THE 30's
description: LEAD: SO I went to my best friend and I said, ''Did I buy anything at Park Lane Hosiery?'' And he said: ''Of course you did, you big buffoon. You bought leotards for our two little girls.'' And I said: ''We don't have little girls. We have little boys.'' And he said, ''Well, maybe that's where all those pantyhose in your top drawer came from.

title: Farm Aid 3 Concert Planned in Nebraska
description: Willie Nelson has signed a contract with the University of Nebraska in Lincoln to stage his Farm Aid 3 concert here on Sept. 19.

title: Swedes Suspect Submarine
description: Swedish Navy men have thrown hand grenades at what appeared to be an alien submarine in the sensitive Tore Bay military area, military authorities said today. On July 1, the navy fired depth charges at a submarine in Tore Bay and searched for it several days.

title: Pacific Telesis President
description: The Pacific Telesis Group today named Sam L. Ginn president and chief operating officer. He has been vice chairman of Pacific Telesis Group and president and chief executive of the Pactel Corporation, a subsidiary. Pacific Telesis said that Mr. Ginn, who is 50 years old, was being named president in anticipation of the retirement next year of its chairman, president and chief executive, Donald E. Guinn, 54. Mr. Ginn held a number of positions with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company before joining the former Pacific Telephone Company as a vice president in Los Angeles in 1978.

title: KEEPING THE PEACE UNTIL FALL
description: SHARING a kitchen in a summer group house is a three-month voyage of discovery.

title: Family to Stay On After Variety Sale
description: Syd Silverman was busy yesterday putting Weekly Variety to bed at its printer in Valley Stream, L.I. He has been editor since 1973 and will continue to be under the agreement to sell the concern to Cahners Publishing Company, a unit of Reed International of London. The value of the deal was not disclosed.

title: Downpour Provides a Cool, if Soaking, Respite
description: Pedestrians taking cover under a theater marquee yesterday as a thunderstorm pelted the pavement and dropped the temperature. New York city will get a reprieve from the rain today as sunny skies return. (NYT/Ruby Washington)

title: George W. Holt 3d, Producer and Director
description: George William Holt 3d, a theater producer and director, died yesterday in Montclair, N.J. He was 46 years old.

title: The Carrot and Stick in Foreign-Trade Relations
description: To win the economic battles of the future, America must address both sides of the trade equation - our failure to maintain a competitive economic environment at home and the removal of protectionism abroad.

title: HBO Buying Rights To Paramount Films
description: Home Box Office has signed an exclusive agreement for the pay-television rights to Paramount Pictures films released after mid-1988. The deal, which includes 85 films, is expected to last at least five years.

title: North's Final Day on Stand: U.S. Neutrality and Iran, Iraq and the Israelis
description: As the Iran-contra committees' hearings continued yesterday, the members of Congress heard final testimony from Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. Here are excerpts from the testimony, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Apple Opposes A Toshiba Ban
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it would suffer financially and competitively in the home computer market if proposed legislation banning imports of Toshiba Corporation products and those of its subsidiaries were adopted by Congress.

title: A Living Record Of Bolshoi's Past
description: The Bolshoi Ballet dances with a boldness and conviction that has had audiences cheering during its current summer season at the Metropolitan Opera House. But it is also living history, for among the dancers' coaches is Marina Semyonova, the first Soviet prima ballerina.

title: Lawyer Assails Investigators as Defense Opens in Sex Abuse Case
description: A defense lawyer told jurors in the McMartin Preschool case today that they must find the bad guys in a saga that provoked mass fears of child molestation.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: WHEN Peter Matthews first spotted the big gray goose, it was wandering along the shore near Atlantic Beach, L.I. Mr. Matthews looked around, waited a while, but no one came to claim it. So Mr. Matthews, who is a potter, scooped up the goose and carried it home.

title: McFARLANE DISPUTES NORTH ON KEY POINTS OF TESTIMONY; CHAIRMEN REBUKE COLONEL
description: Minutes after Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North completed six days of forceful testimony, Robert C. McFarlane returned as a witness this afternoon and directly contradicted parts of Colonel North's account, declaring that he had not authorized many of the colonel's secret activities.

title: Alexandre P Rosenberg, 66, Art Dealer and Book Collector
description: Alexandre P. Rosenberg, founding president of the Art Dealers Association of America and for many years a prominent art dealer in New York, died of a heart attack in London on Friday. He was 66 years old.

title: BARNETT BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
In a World of Concrete, Pockets of Pastoral Life
description: With its 20 million inhabitants, the capital of Mexico is the most populous urban center in the world. But scattered across this sprawling metropolis are 59 peasant villages struggling to hold on to their land and their distinctive but increasingly fragile way of life.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JULY 15, 1987
description: International A3-15 Robert McFarlane testified before the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair that he had not authorized many of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's secret activities, contadicting parts of Colonel North's account. Page A1 The committee chairmen rebuked Colonel North for having taken part in what they said was a policy based upon lies. After six days of testimony, Colonel North was dismissed. A1 Colonel North told some officials last August that he was giving money to contra leaders and running an air resupply operation that used C-123 aircraft, according to handwritten notes he took at the time. A12 The issue of aid to the contras, which has simmered beneath the surface throughout the Iran-contra hearings, broke into full public view in a dispute over a slide show that was to be given by Colonel North. A12 A Pakistani citizen was arrested in Philadelphia for trying to export material to Pakistan that could be used to make nuclear weapons. Officials said the arrest has major implications for United States policy toward Pakistan. A1 Two car bombs in Pakistan killed at least 72 people and wounded more than 250 in the worst bombings in years in that country. The bombs exploded amid crowds of shoppers in the heart of Karachi, the country's biggest city. A1 Toshiba was accused of betraying Japan by Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone for selling militarily sensitive technology to the Soviet Union. It was his strongest comment to date on the incident. A1 Israel's first taste of glasnost was, by all indications, a hit. After a Soviet delegation slipped into the country Sunday, many Israelis say they are excited at the prospect of ending their isolation from the Soviet Union. A1 Taiwan ended martial law and called the move ''a new milestone'' for democracy on the island. The Defense Ministry also announced the release of 23 prisoners. A3 Reporter's notebook: Panama boils

title: The Saddest Ending For the Wildest Show
description: The Texas Prison Rodeo, a half-century-old tradition billed as ''the wildest show behind bars,'' bit the dust Monday.

title: LUKENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an $8.9 million pre-tax gain from a pension settlement for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: U.S. Seizes Ship in Pay Fight
description: A Liberian-registered oil tanker whose crew of Koreans went on strike because they had not been paid was seized today by Federal marshals, pending payment of the seamen.

title: Reagan Vows to Speak Out After the Hearings Are Over
description: President Reagan continued today to avoid questions about the Iran-contra hearings, but he briefly allowed his growing frustrations over the testimony on Capitol Hill to slip out.

title: Advertising; New Publisher For The Nation
description: After a decade as publisher of The Nation, Hamilton Fish 3d is turning over the job to Arthur L. Carter, the former investment banker who is also major owner of the venerable magazine.

title: Reputed Figure in Mob Testifies at Murder Trial
description: A reputed Mafia figure, in a highly unusual move, took the witness stand at his murder trial yesterday to deny that he and two associates killed one New York City police detective and wounded another on a Queens street 18 months ago.

title: Laxalt Cites 'the Best' of Reagan But Notes Their Differences Too
description: Paul Laxalt said today that he was encouraged about his Republican Presidential campaign because he had found that ''people out there are thirsting for a candidate who will take them into the 90's with the best of the Reagan revolution intact.''

title: Pentagon Held Little Improved In Arms-Buying
description: More than a year after a Presidential panel recommended sweeping changes in the way the Defense Department does business, members of the blue-ribbon commission and many executives in the military contracting industry say that improvements have been slow in coming.

title: For the Poor, Trade Schools May Be Last Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: Supplements to Pensions Won't Break New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Col. North Bolstering Fund Effort
description: Conservative organizations, seeking to reverse a sharp, months-long slump in contributions, are sending out millions of solicitation letters to capitalize on the outpouring of public support for Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. Several Republican strategists said they could not remember a sudden mailing effort on the scale of the avalanche of solicitations precipitated by Colonel North's appearances before the House and Senate committees investigating the Iran-contra affair.

title: Company News; Western Company Sets Write-Down
description: The Western Company of North America said that it expected to take a $90 million writedown in the value of its on-shore petroleum services equipment during the second quarter. The company, a struggling independent oilfield services concern, said that the one-time reduction totaled about $60 million.

title: Report Says New York Paid U.S. More in '86
description: New York State paid the Federal Government $6.8 billion more in 1986 than it got back, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said today in his 11th annual report on the Federal budget and the state economy.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Larry Murphy, a defenseman who led the Washington Capitals in scoring with 81 points last season, signed a multiyear contract with the club. . . . The Buffalo Bills obtained Clint Sampson, a wide receiver, from Denver for an undisclosed draft pick. They also sent Charles Romes, a cornerback, to Kansas City for an undisclosed draft choice.

title: CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Figures for the latest quarter and 6-month reflect the results of operations of Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. from the May 1 merger date. The company said losses in the latest periods resulted from the previously announced $1.1 billion special addition to the allowance for loan losses related to loans to countries engaged in debt rescheduling. The company also said it wrote off $80 million of deferred tax benefits in connection with the special addition.

title: Market Place; Oil Stocks Retain Appeal
description: AFTER enjoying a bull market for nearly a year, oil stocks still draw favorable recommendations on Wall Street. Spurred initially by rising crude oil prices, the run-up has reflected corporate restructurings and, more recently, heightened tensions in the Middle East.

title: Boxing Notebook; Spink's Problem: Waiting for Tyson
description: Michael Spinks is in a bind of sorts.

title: Sports People; Mets Call Up Schulze
description: The Mets have called up Don Schultze, a right-hander pitcher, from their Tidewater farm club and have sent Jeff Innis, another right-hander, to Tidewater.Schulze, 24 years old, had a 9-1 record and a 3.07 earned run average for Tidewater. Innis was 0-1 with the Mets with a 3.31 earned run average in 10 games.

title: NAKASONE ASSERTS TOSHIBA BETRAYED JAPAN WITH SALES
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone today accused the Toshiba Machine Company of betraying Japan by selling militarily sensitive technology to the Soviet Union. It was his strongest comment to date on the incident.

title: Secret Deaver Jury Selection Is Appealed by News Groups
description: The perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver turned into a debate today over the First Amendment as news organizations appealed the judge's decision to conduct jury selection in secret.

title: Notre Dame Gets Smith's Library
description: The personal library of Red Smith, the late Pulitzer Prize-winning sports columnist, has been given to the University of Notre Dame by his widow, Phyllis Smith of New Canaan, Conn., university officials said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Musical Steel

title: Reporter's Notebook: Panama Boils
description: As anti-Government protests in Panama enter their sixth week, demonstrators are finding that they confront not only uniformed soldiers and the riot police, but also paramilitary squads of armed civilians.

title: FIRST WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reduced by $20 million due to a $50 million special addition to the loan-loss reserve, primarily to strengthen reserves for loans to less developed countries, and a $14.3 million gain on the sale of equity securities for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Concert: Chamber Music, With Emerson Quartet
description: THE cancellations that have beset this summer's Mostly Mozart festival affected Monday evening's chamber program at Avery Fisher Hall, but the resultant shifts led to some lovely performances. The hall was sold out, including a large number of stage seats, but the length of the program (over two and a half hours, not counting the preconcert recital) meant a fair degree of attrition. The festival seems to be adopting a part of the performance practice of 200 years ago that the early-music movement hasn't thought of, but it remains to be seen whether modern audiences will accept the marathon musical processionals that audiences demanded in Mozart's and Beethoven's day.

title: Job Rise Seen At Ford Plant
