description: The Ford Motor Company, confirming that it would spend $260 million to expand light-truck production at its Louisville, Ky., assembly plant, said today that the expansion could create 500 new jobs.

title: Pop: Madonna Benefit For AIDS at the Garden
description: MADONNA works hard to entertain her audiences. Her sold-out concert

title: Dumped on the Citizen's Doorstep
description: Calcutta, U.S.A. - it's an apt name for New York City in the summertime, as thousands of homeless and deranged people camp out on the streets. That sordid spectacle is made worse by the way the city has chosen to deal with the homeless.

title: HONEYWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $7.7 million and $17.9 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Sports People; Views on Olympics
description: Greg Foster says he would be reluctant to participate in the Seoul Olympics unless he is convinced that conditions would be safe for the athletes.

title: Artists' Sketches Slyly Satirize the Rich
description: Some of the works are slapstick, and some are subtle, but all of them are sly. The reason is, they are sketches and drawings by artists who are satirizing their own patrons - the rich.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: Exit the Police

title: Results Plus; Tour de France
description: Norwegian Wins 14th Stage: Following a slight change of course caused by fear of a terrorist attack, Dag-Otto Lauritzen of Norway won the 14th stage of the Tour de France from Pau to Luz Ardiden yesterday. Charles Mottet of France kept the yellow jersey of the overall leader. On the final ascent, Lauritzen, of the 7-Eleven team, managed to hold off Luis Herrera of Colombia. The Norwegian was timed in 5 hours 14 minutes 28 seconds in the 95-mile race. Herrera finished seven seconds later. Andy Hampsten of the United States, a teammate of Lauritzen, finished third, 53 seconds behind. Mottet's overall time is 61:36:54. Jean-Francois Bernard of France is in second place, 1:13 behind. Stephen Roche of Ireland is third, 1:26 behind.(AP) Longo Regains Lead: Jeannie Longo won the fifth stage of the women's race yesterday, a 28-mile mountain stage from Argeles-Gazost to Luz Ardiden, crossing the line alone to regain the overall lead. Maria Canins of Italy placed second, 1 minute 1 second behind, and Ute Enzenauer of West Germany was third, 2:40 off the pace. In the overall standings, Longo is 49 seconds ahead.(AP) University Games U.S. Wins 6 Gold Medals: Runners and swimmers added six more gold medals to the United States total yesterday in Zagreb, Yugoslavia. Lee McRae of Pittsburgh and Gwen Torrence of Decatur, Ga., won the men's and the women's 100-meter dashes and Patty Murray of Park Ridge, Ill., won the 10,000 meters. American swimmers ended the competition with three more golds, including a record in the women's 800-meter freestyle relay. The team of Mary O'Leary of Tucson, Ariz., Lisa Meyers of Mission Viejo, Calif., Cheryl Kriegsman of Los Angeles and Mitzi Kremer of Titusville, Fla., combined for a time of 8:09.52. That broke the mark of 8:20.51, set in 1985 by the Soviet Union. Alex Mlawsky of Sunnymead, Calif., finished first in the men's 1,500-meter freestyle in 15:23.22, and Tom Williams of St. Charles Ill., won the 50-meter freestyle, in 22.90. (AP) Soccer United States Loses, 1-0: At St. John, New Brunswick, Michel Bassole scored in the 58th minute yesterday when the United States. goalkeeper, Mark Dulle, dropped the ball in front of the net, giving the Ivory Coast a 1-0 victory over the United States in first-round play at the under-16 World Cup soccer tournament.(AP) Tennis Berger and Purcell Advance: Ninth-seeded Jay Berger, 36th in the men's tennis rankings after less than one year on the tour, and Mel Purcell, seeded 13th, advanced yesterday to the second round of the men's U.S. Open Clay Court tournament in Indianapolis. Berger, a 20-year-old from Plantation, Fla., rallied to defeat Claudio Panatta of Italy, 6-2, 5-7, 7-5 in a match that had been halted Monday by rain. Purcell, defeated Alvaro Jordan of Colombia, 6-3, 6-3. (AP) Shriver Defeats Jordan: Top-seeded Pam Shriver scored a 6-3, 6-0 victory yesterday over Kathy Jordan in the first round of the Virginia Slims tournament in Newport, R.I. Lori McNeil of Houston, seeded second, beat Peanut Louie-Harper of San Francisco, 6-4, 6-3, Terry Phelps of Larchmont, N.Y., seeded sixth, defeated Betsy Nagelson of Kapa Lua Bay, Hawaii, 6-3, 6-2, and Wendy White of Fort Worth, seeded eighth, advanced by beating Cammy MacGregor of Palos Verde, Calif., 6-3, 7-6.(AP)

title: About Real Estate; Warehouse Stores Adjust to New York
description: In a warehouse club, there is no carpeting under foot, there are no enticing product displays, and credit cards are not accepted.

title: Finance/New Issues; Bond Offering By Mississippi
description: A $56.7 million competitive bond issue by Mississippi is being offered through a group of underwriters led by the Chase Manhattan Capital Markets Corporation.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I HEARD one of my favorite anecdotes about food - no doubt apocryphal - many years ago when I came to this country. The story was set around the turn of the century, when the producers of canned tuna and the producers of canned salmon were supposed to have been engaged in a great merchandising battle.

title: Scouting; Dean of 'Tryout' Is Infielder, 61
description: The Empire State Baseball League was formed to give young ballplayers passed over by major-league organizations one last chance to prove they can play professionally. Last Friday, a 61-year-old second baseman, who also happens to be the dean of the Hofstra University Law School, decided it was time to give it one more try, too.

title: ALTERNATIVE FUELS BACKED IN CAPITAL
description: The growing use of methanol and other fuels as substitutes for gasoline received strong backing from the Reagan Administration today.

title: I.R.S. Gives Account Back to 9-Year-Old
description: The Internal Revenue Service seized a 9-year-old girl's $70.76 savings account Monday to pay her grandfather's back taxes, but her money will be returned, a bank official said today.

title: WHITE HOUSE EASES STAND ON BUDGET
description: The director of the Office of Management and Budget said today that the Administration could accept a plan to restore an automatic spending cut mechanism to the budget-balancing law and relax the law's deficit ceilings.

title: Soviet Pilgrims in Jerusalem
description: When officially atheist Moscow sends diplomats to examine ''church properties'' in the holy city of Jerusalem, suspicions fall on a more secular motive. For the first time in 20 years, Soviet officials are ''visiting'' Israel, and for the first time since 1972, the Israel radio's broadcasts to the Soviet Union are no longer being jammed.

title: Colonel North's Last Stand
description: The North hearings came to an end not with a whimper but a bang. The attorney Brendan Sullivan interrupted Chairman Daniel Inouye's closing statement to make a last effort to divert attention from Colonel North's actual deeds to something more savory - in this case, the colonel's new-found public support.

title: When You May Vote For More Than One
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruth Karen Hagai, 65, A Business Consultant
description: Ruth Karen Hagai, a business consultant, journalist and author who was known professionally as Ruth Karen, died of cancer Saturday at her Manhattan home. She was 65 years old.

title: On Bastille Day, Sniping On Political Barricades
description: As France marked Bastille Day today with a show of military might along the Champs-Elysees, there were subtle reminders of the fierce political struggle between President Francois Mitterrand, the Socialist head of state, and Jacques Chirac, the conservative Prime Minister.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MAHINES CORP (IBM)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: For the latest 6-month the company reported pre-tax earnings of $3,377,000,000, compared with $4,016,000,000 in the year-ago period. Revenue represents gross income.

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $37 million gain for both the quarter and 6 months resulting from the Georgia Gulf sale; and the 6-month also includes a pre-tax gain of $6 million from redemption of preferred stock.

title: Finance/New Issues; Ecolab Debenture With Sinking Fund
description: Ecolab Inc. is offering $150 million of 10 3/8 percent sinking-fund debentures due in 2017 at a price of par through a group of underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: 12 Miami Police Officers Indicted In New U.S. Effort on Drug Ring
description: A new Federal indictment unsealed today charges 12 Miami police officers with running a drug theft ring and some of the officers with plotting to kill trial witnesses.

title: More Boesky Holdings Seen
description: Firms controlled by Ivan F. Boesky held stock index futures contracts with a face value of hundreds of millions of dollars last November when the Securities and Exchange Commission charged him with insider trading, staff members of the Senate Agriculture Committee disclosed today.

title: Business Digest: WEDNESDAY, JULY 15, 1987
description: International Prime Minister Nakasone strongly criticized Toshiba Machine, accusing the company of betraying Japan by selling sensitive technology to the Russians. At the same time, the Japanese trade minister left for Washington to ease American anger over the incident, which Washington says has damaged U.S. security. [ Page A1. ] The Economy The Pentagon's business methods have been slow to change, even a year after a Presidential panel urged sweeping changes in the contracting process, according to members of the panel and industry executives. The Packard commission's proposals were meant to streamline the weapons-buying process. [ A1. ] Retail spending was virtually unchanged in June for a fourth month. [ D3. ] Domestic car sales declined in early July. [ D4. ] The Senate voted against a reorganization of the Commerce Department and the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative. [ D3. ] Intelsat's former chief pleaded guilty to charges that he took part in a kickback scheme to obtain $4.8 million. [ D5. ] Companies I.B.M.'s second-quarter earnings dropped 9.9 percent, stretching the company's string of profit declines into the fifth straight quarter. However, analysts said they expected I.B.M.'s earnings to rise strongly in the next six months. [ D1. ] Mellon Bank reported a disappointing quarter and disclosed that two top executives had resigned. Chemical also posted weak second-quarter results. [ D1. ] Lewis Ranieri, a vice chairman of Salomon Brothers, resigned. Mr. Ranieri had helped propel his firm to the top of the mortgage-backed securities market. There was speculation that he had a dispute with John Gutfreund, the firm's chairman. [ D1. ] A former top JWT official, Burton J. Manning, will return to head the J. Walter Thompson agency's worldwide unit, a person close to the agency said. [ D7. ] HBO gained the pay-TV rights to Paramount films released after mid-1988. Industry experts estimated that the deal, which Showtime had also sought, was worth at least $500 million. [ D1. ] Robert Holmes a Court plans to raise his Texaco stake to 15 percent, from 9.6 percent. [ D1. ] Xerox agreed to acquire Furman Selz, a research, brokerage and investment banking firm, for $110 million. [ D4. ] Markets Dennis B. Levine cannot account for $412,000 gained from illegal insider trading, according to a court-appointed receiver. The receiver's 35-page report provides a glimpse of the high life style of Mr. Levine before he fell from grace. [ D1. ] Ivan F. Boesky held stock index futures with a face value of hundreds of millions of dollars when he was charged by the S.E.C. [ D17. ] The stock market moved sharply higher, led by technology and auto stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 28.38 points, to a record 2,481.35. [ D8. ] Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly, helped by a drop in short-term rates. [ D15. ] The dollar rose against all major currencies. Most dealers squared their positions in advance of U.S. trade figures due today. In New York, gold rose 65 cents, to $447.15 an ounce. [ D16. ] Crude oil futures reached their highest levels since January 1986. [ D16. ] Technology Static RAM's are gaining stature. Compared with dynamic RAM's, static RAM's have drawbacks - higher cost, increased complexity and less capacity - but they operate faster. [ D6. ] Pay phones can now talk - and take change. The telecommunications revolution in pay phones reflects the effort of independent operators to compete with the Bell companies. Advances. [ D6. ] Today's Columns Economics departments have been broken up, or shrunk, at dozens of companies, not only as a cost-cutting measure, but also out of disillusionment with forecasts that have often failed to anticipate the twists of the nation's economy. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] The bull market for oil stocks is not over, thanks to company restructurings and Middle East tensions. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Sports People; LeMond Has Surgery
description: Gred LeMond has undergone an ap-pendectomy and will probably miss the cycling world championships in Austria in September. Ron Stanko, a spokesman for LeMond, who last summer became the first American to win the Tour de France, said LeMond was admitted to University Medical Center in Sacramento, Calif., on Sunday. He may be released from the hospital today. Stanko said that the appendectomy had forced LeMond to cancel plans to enter the Coors Classic ''and there's probably a 95 percent chance he will not be competing in the world championships because of it.''

title: Taiwan Ends 4 Decades of Martial Law
description: The Nationalist Government ended 38 years of martial law today and called the move ''a new milestone'' for democracy on this island still technically at war with the Chinese mainland.

title: Article 498687 -- No Title
description: A jury awarded $95 million in damages today to an 8-year-old boy after finding that his deformed arms were caused by Bendectin, a drug used in pregnancy to combat nausea.

title: Lawyer and Guardian Ask For Fees for Baby M Trial
description: The court-appointed guardian for Baby M has applied to the court for $140,000 in legal fees, and the lawyer for the couple with custody of the infant girl said today that he would file an application next week seeking $500,000 in fees.

title: Bankers Fight Loophole
description: The American Bankers Association today supported a bill to close a loophole that allows the creation of limited-service, or ''non-bank,'' banks. These competitors of banks avoid regulation as banks by making loans or taking deposits but not both.

title: 'A.F.I. Comedy Special,' With Dick Van Dyke
description: ''The A.F.I. Comedy Special'' presents 4 writers, 22 actors and maybe one and a half workable ideas. Actually, that may be a respectable number. As Dick Van Dyke, the host of the program, points out, some 3,000 ideas for series are submitted to a network each year; perhaps 3 of the 3,000 make it through a television season. The comedy special, on NBC at 10 o'clock tonight, shows why it's tough.

title: Why Should Congress Be Exempt From Truth-Telling?
description: It is ironic that in a culture in which objective truth is increasingly questioned and relativism thrives, the subject of the hour in politics seems to be the truthfulness of people in public life.

title: Sports of The Times; Big Trophy, Small Shortstop
description: In baseball's year of the big bat, the fans voted for a small glove. Ozzie Smith, who plays shortstop for the St. Louis Cardinals as if he were on a trampoline, was hitting eighth for the National League in last night's All-Star Game, but he was first with the fans. And the leader in the All-Star balloting with 2,254,409 votes was awarded a huge, heavy silver trophy.

title: At an Illinois Country Store, Nostalgia Sells Best
description: Joe Glisson's general store is a living piece of history, where folks stop by for soda fountain treats, penny candy or just a slice of Americana.

title: New Man at the Fed Needs Better Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: Company News; Women's Bank Is Recapitalized
description: The First Women's Bank, a 12-year-old institution with a rocky financial history, said yesterday that contributions from 70 prominent New York entrepreneurs have raised its capitalization to more than $35 million, from less than $4 million.

title: Don't Roll Over, Beethoven: A Classical Fight
description: For many classical music lovers, the announcement in 1974 that radio station WNCN-FM in New York was shifting its format to rock-and-roll was devastating.

title: Having Fun With Bracelets And Big Bags
description: 1. Wild Jewelry

title: Where Homosexuals Found a Haven, There's No Haven From AIDS
description: In the once-bustling Castro district here, empty storefronts are beginning to appear and ''for sale'' signs are adorning many of of the beautifully restored Victorian homes.

title: Finance/New Issues; Bank of Boston
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation yesterday began a public offering of $150 million of 9 1/2 percent subordinated capital notes due in 1997 at a price of par through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Noncallable, the notes yield about 1.14 percentage points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. The 10-year issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P.

title: BARRIER TO SLOW 'KILLER' BEES IS PLANNED BY US AND MEXICO
description: The United States and Mexico will sign an agreement this summer to create a barrier zone that could delay by a decade the arrival in Texas of Africanized ''killer'' honeybees, an official says.

title: INSIDE
description: Directors in Accord Film and television directors tentatively agreed to a new contract when producers gave up demands for rollbacks in royalties. Page C19.

title: PAKISTANI SEIZED BY U.S. IN A PLOT ON A-ARMS ALLOY
description: A Pakistani businessman has been arrested in Philadelphia on charges that he tried to export material to Pakistan that could be used in making nuclear weapons.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
Stir-Fried Freshness
description: LEAD: THOSE who would practice kitchen-sink cookery (everything in the pot but the . . . ) need to be especially skilled. That is because there is a surprisingly thin line between an audaciously composed dish and a mess.

title: Vallone Retracts Nominee After Protest
description: In a rare retreat, the New York City Council Majority leader, Peter F. Vallone temporarily withdrew his nomination yesterday of Joseph F. Lisa as chairman of the Health Committee, after protests by advocates of AIDS programs and gay rights.

title: North Wars
description: For six days, Oliver North won all of America's attention and some of its admiration for his bold and facile testimony about the Iran-contra scandal. He induced people to argue: Is he a scapegoat? A zealot? A hero? Meanwhile, the point of the scandal receded. Yesterday, in a few moments of simplicity and clarity, Representative Lee Hamilton brought attention back to a higher level:

title: Company News; Indiana Steel Plant
description: The Nucor Corporation, a North Carolina steel company, will build a $250 million steel mill that will employ 600 people in Montgomery County, Lieut. Gov. John M. Mutz said. Company officials have said that they hope to begin operations in the second quarter of 1989 at the new plant, which would convert scrap metal to sheet metal through thin-slab casting. Final details are being worked out on a financial incentive package for steelmaker, based in Charlotte, N.C., Mr. Munz said.

title: Directors Accept Pact as Producers Yield on Rollbacks
description: The Directors Guild of America reached a tentative agreement with movie and television producers today, halting the first strike in the union's history only five minutes before the picket lines went up.

title: Senate Panel Clears Bill Requiring Airlines To Report on Performance
description: The Senate Commerce Committee approved a bill today that would require airlines to post schedules more accurate than the ones now issued, which are rarely met.

title: Four Years of Overseeing the Troubled Thrifts
description: After more than four years as chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, Edwin J. Gray returned last month to private business. Rarely has Washington had such a controversial, headstrong and outspoken regulator, who within an Adminsitration given to loosening Governmental restraints on financial institutions, repeatedly pushed to impose new restrictions on the growth, accounting practices and business activities of the nation's 3,200 savings and loan associations.

title: Film: Tavianis' 'Babylon' Depicts Early Hollywood
description: THE rosy style of Paolo and Vittorio Taviani, with its radiant physicality and its intoxicating sense of magic, has most often been used to create cinematic folk tales (''The Night of the Shooting Stars,'' ''Chaos,'' ''Padre Padrone'') about Italian peasantry. It is considerably less at home in the Hollywood of 1916, the backdrop against which the Tavianis' ''Good Morning, Babylon'' unfolds. Never has Hollywood, a place more commonly viewed with cynicism and awe, been romanticized this rhapsodically. It took the Tavianis to view a tale of two immigrant stonemasons, who work on the sets for D. W. Griffith's ''Intolerance,'' as a parable concerning brotherhood, honor, filial loyalty and the very essence of art.

title: Company News; Gillette Stock Up On Jacobs Rumors
description: The Gillette Company's shares jumped $2.50 yesterday, to $43.875 -a new 52-week high on the New York Stock Exchange. Nearly three million shares changed hands, making it the second-most-active issue. Traders speculated that Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, was among the big buyers. They estimated that Mr. Jacobs, who has said that he had less than 5 percent of the common stock, might now have about 10 percent.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day last Thursday about the earnings performance of J. P. Morgan & Company misstated one effect of lower tax rates on the company. Morgan's net interest income, figured by assuming that all its interest is taxable, was reduced by the lower rates.

title: Advertising; Top Offcial Seen Returning to JWT
description: BURTON J. MANNING, former United States chairman of the J. Walter Thompson Company, will be returning as president and chief executive of the agency's worldwide operation, a person close to the company said yesterday.

title: WINE TALK
description: SLATE-COVERED hillsides, some at 60-degree angles, soar upward from the Mosel River in West Germany. Almost miraculously, wine growers climb them to tend riesling grapes that yield enchanting whites. Sadly, many importers and distributors trying to sell those and other premium German wines in the United States are so frustrated, they are climbing the walls.

title: Panel's Case: Bullets and the Rule of Law
description: Members of the Iran-contra committees continued their statements yesterday as Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North ended his testimony. Here are selections from those statements.

title: House Passes Ban on Smoking on Flights of 2 Hours or Less
description: The House narrowly voted Monday night to ban cigarette smoking on airline flights of two hours or less, then went on to pass a $26.8 billion transportation spending bill for the fiscal year 1988.

title: A Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article by Jeri Laber and Lois Whitman published on Monday misstated the chronological sequence of two events in Turkey. The lifting of martial law in Istanbul was followed by reports in the press and in Parliament of police torture.

title: Corley P. McDarment; Pressed for Air Safety
description: Corley P. McDarment, who became a hero to fellow Army Air Corps officers in 1934 when he was accused of insubordination for protesting flying conditions, died Monday of a heart attack in Rockledge, Fla. He was 95 years old.

title: Debt
description: Fuqua Industries is offering in the Euromarket $75 million of 6 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2002 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Chemical Bank International Ltd. The debentures are convertible into common stock of Fuqua at $41.625 a share. Common Stock

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Sports People; Smith Rejoins Royals
description: Lonnie Smith, who became a free agent last winter when he rejected a proposed cut from his $900,000-a-year contract, has rejoined the Kansas City Royals. No other team acquired Smith after he was unable to reach an agreement with the Royals, and he signed a contract with Kansas City's Class AAA farm team at Omaha. Smith batted .329 with 7 homers and 33 runs batted in at Omaha. There was no immediate report on the terms of his contract. In another move, the Royals traded Juan Beniquez, an outfielder, to the Toronto Blue Jays for Luis Aquino, a minor legue pitcher.

title: Networks Start System Of Rotation Tomorrow
description: The three major television networks said yesterday that they had agreed to rotate their daily live coverage of the Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair.

title: Poindexter Testimony: A Decrease in Drama
description: IT grows difficult on television.

title: COOPER TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WELFARE HOTEL CHILDREN: TOMORROW'S POOR
description: In the cavernous ballroom of the Prince George Hotel, four boys were shooting pool, talking as tough as any New York pool sharks. One wore just his shorts, and another's face was smeared with sweat. With the boys as old as 12, they might have seemed wise about the streets - except that two of them were sucking their thumbs.

title: Music: Two Concertos In Mostly Mozart Festival
description: TUESDAY evening's Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra program at Avery Fisher Hall - repeated last night -offered two concertos with two different and very talented soloists and a first-ever-at-this-festival performance of, of all super-familiar scores, Beethoven's ''Pastoral'' Symphony.

title: JOHN CRONIN
description: John Cronin, an interior designer, died of cardiac arrest Monday at his home in North Salem, N.Y. He was 54 years old.

title: SMITHSONIAN PUSHES ITS PLAN TO MOVE THE INDIAN MUSEUM
description: The Smithsonian Institution, in letters to members of Congress, has spelled out the first details of its proposal for a home in Washington for the Museum of the American Indian, whose possible move from New York City is being challenged in court by state and city officials.

title: PERFECTDATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said it will carry forward about $4,024,000 in tax credits against future earnings.

title: CB&T BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest periods include the results of First Camden Bancorp acquired in January and First Community Bancshares Inc. acquired in March. The year-earlier results are restated to reflect a pooling of interests.

title: The Iran-Contra Affair : General Secord Fights For the Last Word
description: Perhaps taking a cue from Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's assertive testimony before the Iran-contra committees, another figure in the affair has gone on the offensive against the panels.

title: Soviet Opening a New Jewish Route to Israel
description: The Soviet Union is opening an East European pathway for Jewish emigration Thursday by sending out at least four emigrants on a flight to Bucharest, Rumania, and ticketing them through to Israel, friends of the four said today.

title: Correction
description: An article on Sunday about young drinkers on the Upper East Side in New York City included an incorrect description from the State Liquor Authority for the status of the Zulu Lounge. The bar has not been cited for serving liquor to minors.

title: VIPONT PHARMACEUTICAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Correction
description: An obituary of David L. Dimmock yesterday misidentified the founder of the advertising agency of Bradley, Dimmock & Hungerford. The founder was Sam Bradley.

title: Israeli Inflation Up 1%
description: Israeli inflation rose 1 percent in June, resulting in a 19.5 percent increase in the cost of living for 12 months, the Central Bureau of Statistics said today. The June inflation rate was largely caused by price increases in public transportation, home maintenance and housing. The figure was up from six-tenths of 1 percent in May, but down from a 1.6 percent inflation rise for June 1986.

title: EX-PROSECUTOR, JAILED AS THIEF, WINS EARLY RELEASE
description: A former Federal prosecutor who stole cocaine and heroin from the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan won an early release from prison yesterday after serving 16 months.

title: Bomb Report Delays Cruise
description: Minutes after the ocean liner Nordic Princess embarked on a seven-day cruise to Bermuda yesterday, a man called the 911 emergency number and said a bomb on the ship was set to go off in 10 minutes. The the ocean liner returned to the Passenger Ship Terminal. A police spokesman, Officer Peter O'Donnell, said no explosive devices were found in a four-hour search.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: 53d Street Hoopla

title: Will the First Vacation End the Affair?
description: ON their first vacation together, David and Ellen Jacoby discovered which one of them packs lots of clothes; (he does, she does not). Who likes breakfast; (he does, she does not). Who dawdles in museums; (he does, she does not). Who sends lots of postcards; (he does, she does not). Who worries that the airline will lose the luggage; (they both do).

title: California Labor Panel a Target of Farm Union
description: Twelve years after it was created amid strikes, boycotts and violence in the lettuce fields and table grape vineyards of California, the state's Agricultural Labor Relations Board has itself become the target of a boycott.

title: Parents and Freedom
description: To The Home Section I read the article ''Family Ties: Dream House for 2, With the Family Nearby'' [ July 2 ] , by Suzanne Slesin with great amusement.

title: Aspin and Republicans in House In War of Words About the Gulf
description: Representative Les Aspin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, vigorously and angrily objected today to assertions by the Reagan Administration, and by his colleagues in the House, that he had disclosed classified details of plans to provide military escorts to ships in the Persian Gulf.

title: Saving Bork From Both Friends and Enemies
description: The nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the United States Supreme Court has drawn predictable reactions from both extremes of the political spectrum. One can fairly say that the confirmation is as much endangered by one extreme as the other.

title: FIRST MARYLAND BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SEACOAST BANKING CORP OF FLA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DPL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ST PAUL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-For the latest quarter includes a one-time pre-tax writedown of $869,000 related to the company's investment in the FSLIC secondary reserve, an action required by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board's decision to eliminate the FSLIC secondary reserve as of December 31, 1986; the year-ago quarter includes an after-tax charge of $723,000 from prepayments of Federal Home Loan Bank advances. Share-earnings figures are not relevant since the company went public May 15, 1987. The company attributed its income decline in the latest 6 months in part to an absence of non-recurring gains on sales of mortgage loans from portfolio and investment securities, which added $2.7 million to pre-tax earnings in the first half of 1986.

title: A Dress Code For Cabdrivers Wins Approval
description: The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission yesterday unanimously approved a dress code for cabdrivers.

title: PEOPLES BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the improvement in earnings is due to a 54-percent decrease in the provision for loan losses and a 3.6-percent decrease in non-interest expenses, and earnings were also favorably affected by the higher interest rate environment, resulting in an 8.3-percent increase in net interest income compared to the first quarter of this year.

title: Leaks as 'an Art Form'
description: During a discussion of the mechanics of shipping arms to Iran, Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter set forth his views on the problem of leaks of sensitive information.

title: 'I Wouldn't Lie To the President'
description: In the hearings yesterday, Admiral Poindexter was asked what he would have told the President if asked about the Iran-contra affair.

title: Fed Lets 6 Banks Offer New Security
description: The Federal Reserve Board today approved applications from six of the nation's largest bank holding companies to underwrite and deal in securities backed by consumer debt, such as credit card and automobile loans.

title: Greenspan Hearings Set
description: The Senate Banking Committee said today that the hearings on the nomination of Alan Greenspan as next chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, as well as those for David Ruder as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, would be held next week. Mr. Greenspan is to appear before the committee on Tuesday and Mr. Ruder is to appear Wednesday. After the hearings, the committee will vote on the nominations. Final approval has to be given by the Senate, which is expected to act before the August recess of Congress.

title: A.D.R.'s in London
description: Official trading in American depository receipts will begin in London Aug. 3. The London Stock Exchange has cleared the new market with British tax authorities, and its automated quotation system will be used.

title: BANK OF DELAWARE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 100-percent stock dividend to be paid in August.

title: ANDOVER TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Reflects losses from the Lori Lee Outerwear division of $250,000 for the quarter and $370,000 for the 6 months.

title: CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a provision of $510.1 million for loan loss reserves to less developed countries for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss d-Restated and adjusted down by $800,000 to reflect a real estate transaction. The company said during the latest second quarter $161 million in poor quality loans were transferred to the FDIC, bringing the total loans and other assets transferred since Sept. 26, 1984 to about $1.3 million.

title: Even At Vacation Time, Plants Want to Be Close to the Water
description: LEAD: WHILE a gardener is away on summer vacation, house plants, lawn and garden remain on the job. Untended, they might become dry in just a day or two, especially during hot spells. Here are some methods of keeping indoor and outdoor plants adequately moist for a week or more.

title: Old West Goes to Tokyo
description: A company in Montana is transplanting some of the flavor of the Old West to Japan by helping to build an authentic log building in the heart of Tokyo.

title: 'Ou Est ''Mona Lisa?,'' ' Or, Lost in the Louvre
description: The Louvre, for centuries the palace of French kings, is at the moment a royal mess.

title: AMRE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Suspect in Drug Case Is Slain by an Officer
description: An undercover Westchester County narcotics detective shot and killed a suspected drug dealer who pointed a revolver - which later turned out to be a fake - at the detective during a drug transaction yesterday, the Yonkers police said.

title: GLATFELTER, P H COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter and six months results reflect the May 1987 acquisition of Ecusta Corp. as follows: net income includes a gain of $2,530,000 and sales include a gain of $31,384,000. The year-ago quarter and six months share earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on April 23, 1986.

title: Lacking Parts, Armed Forces Cannibalize Costly Warplanes
description: Despite the vast military spending by the Reagan Administration over the last six years, the armed forces today are so short of spare parts that they must cannibalize some airplanes to keep others flying.

title: Hong Kong Bank Seeks Marine's Remaining 49%
description: The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, one of the world's largest banking organizations, offered yesterday to pay $677 million for the 49 percent of Marine Midland Banks Inc. that it does not already own.

title: EXCEL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company went public last September.

title: For Babies Who Travel First Class
description: WHEN an infant or a toddler goes traveling, a lightweight portable chair, bed or crib can provide a snug place for sitting and viewing the world, or just for dreaming.

title: MORRIS BRAM
description: Morris Bram, president and chairman of the board of the American Israel Numismatic Association, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Tamarac, Fla. He was 78 years old.

title: Winfield Brings Thrill in Twilight Zone
description: The man was taking bites out of a Popsicle. At the end of his hard day's night, Dave Winfield was not nibbling at the edges. At a time when most of his business colleagues were enjoying their long-awaited three-day summer vacation, Winfield achieved a certain distinction.

title: LITTLE, ARTHUR D INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: b-Includes a gain of $423,000, or 17 cents a share, from the sale of an investment associated with the company's venture activities in the United Kingdom and the proceeds from the settlement of a fixed-price contract. c-Includes a loss of 26 cents a share from the settlement of litigation.

title: A Jerusalem Diary
description: Discovered quickly that there is no such thing as a dull dinner party in Jerusalem. All you have to do if things get quiet is say one word: Sharon.

title: CANRAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest second quarter and 6-month include the effects of the acquisition of certain assets and the business of the Measurement Systems division of Page-Wilson Corp., effective March 29.

title: CHI-CHI INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: SOUTHINGTON SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank went public July 1986.

title: HOSPITAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said its latest six months earnings were reduced by $3.6 million, or 4 cents a share, reflecting its interest in Equicor, a 50 percent- owned joint venture of Hospital Corp. and the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the U.S.

title: BRIEFING: Casey's Memoirs
description: Staff members of the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra panel are considering filing a subpoena for a manuscript of memoirs left behind by William J. Casey, the Director of Central Inteligence who died last spring.

title: Cablevision to Add Adams-Russell
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Adams-Russell Company, a publicly held cable concern based in Waltham, Mass., for $474 million, or $43.075 a share.

title: CONSOLIDATED RAIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Inicludes a tax credit of $32 million. c-Includes tax credits of $39 million and $54 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Quasars Very Close Together Reported at Edge of Universe
description: From data collected at three observatories, astronomers have concluded that a pair of quasars on the outer fringes of the observable universe may be circling one another or in a collision.

title: DAUPHIN DEPOSIT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago second quarter and 6-month results were restated to reflect the adoption of Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement on pension accounting.

title: N.B.A. Talks Stalled
description: The National Basketball Association and its players union met yesterday for the first time since June 9. The meeting was described by both sides yesterday as ''nonproductive on the major issues.''

title: BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $10.9 million, or 39 cents a share, for fees and expenses in connection with takeover negotiations and litigation. c-Includes a gain of $8.6 million from the sale of a division.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: AMR Net Off; '86 Gain Cited
description: The AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, said yesterday that it earned $92.2 million, or $1.51 a share, in the second quarter, off 33.2 percent from $138 million, or $2.23 a share, a year ago.

title: Hall of Fame Adds a Window
description: The window that a 3-year-old Pete Rose broke with the first line drive of his life is going to be broken forever - but not at the old Rose home in Cincinnati.

title: Volcano Group Loses Appeal
description: The State Supreme Court has ruled that geothermal development of Kilauea Volcano does not interfere with worshipers of Hawaii's legendary volcano goddess, Pele. The decision came Tuesday in an appeal brought by the Pele worshipers, who opposed a Board of Land and Natural Resources decision three years ago designating 9,000 acres of the Kilauea Middle East Rift area on the island of Hawaii as a geothermal resource. The worshipers said that geothermal development would desecrate Pele's body by digging into the ground. The land board decided there was no indication that tapping the heat source had diminished the eruptive nature of Kilauea Volcano and the court agreed.

title: NBC Strikes Out in the All-Star Game
description: Corporate images, to the extent they exist and may be defined, are an unscientific mix of Madison Avenue hype and real-world achievement. The result is a human-like personality that outsiders often ascribe to a company and the mostly anonymous people who work for it.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JULY 16, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Poindexter, a Professorial Air and Detachment
description: Once it was a President who said ''the buck stops here.''

title: F.A.A. Opens Inquiry Into Delta's Pilot Training
description: Citing pilot error as a factor in a recent string of near accidents involving Delta Air Lines, the Federal Aviation Administration announced yesterday that it had begun a special investigation of the airline, with initial emphasis on pilot training and procedures.

title: ITT and United Technologies Profits Up Sharply
description: Two prominent conglomerates yesterday reported sharply higher profits in the most recent quarter. The ITT Corporation's net income soared 65 percent, while the United Technologies Corporation's net earnings more than doubled from last year, when the company took a large charge against earnings.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Game in Adirondacks Saw Contract Made With Skill
description: Most of those who headed out of New York City in the past week were no doubt thinking about sport, sun and socializing. But for some, a little rubber bridge was a satisfactory way to spend a warm evening or a wet day.

title: Poles Open a Mass Grave and an Old Wound
description: Polish foresters have found a mass grave that local people believe contains the remains of hundreds of relatives killed by Soviet troops at the end of World War II.

title: HUBBELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
McClatchy Studies Ownership Shift
description: McClatchy Newspapers, publishers of The Sacramento Bee and eight other dailies in California, Washington and Alaska, said that the corporation may convert to a publicly owned company by the end of this year. The company has been privately owned by the McClatchy family for 130 years.

title: Athletics Release Cey
description: Ron Cey, the 39-year-old third baseman with 316 home runs and 1,139 runs batted in during his major league career, was released yesterday by the Oakland Athletics. Cey, used mostly as a designated hitter by the Athletics, had a .221 average, 4 home runs and 11 runs batted in in 104 times at bat this season, his first in the American League.

title: JOB TRAINING BILL ADVANCES IN HOUSE
description: The House Education and Labor Committee approved its version of a new work and education program for welfare recipients today after two days of minor dispute between Democrats and Republicans.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Although I was convinced that we could properly do it and that the President would approve it if asked, I made a very deliberate decision not to ask the President so that I could insulate him from the decision and provide some future deniability for the President if it ever leaked out.''

title: ARISTECH CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny Beverage Corp., Cheverly, Md., announced the completion of the sale of its laundry services unit for $72.5 million. Allegheny refused to identify the buyer.

title: Leslie H. Arps Dies; A Founding Member Of Major Law Firm
description: Leslie H. Arps, a founding member of a leading corporate law firm who assisted three New York State investigative commissions, died of cancer of the pancreas yesterday at New Milford Hospital in Connecticut. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: COAST RV INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Texaco Rumor Lifts 2 Stocks
description: Shares of Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company advanced sharply on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday on the report that officials from both companies were meeting in closed session at the United States Bankruptcy Court in White Plains. Wall Street was guessing that the two companies might be close to announcing a settlement of their protracted dispute.

title: A Deportation Delay Backed
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved legislation to temporarily suspend the deportation of Salvadoran and Nicaraguan refugees from the United States until conditions in their home countries improved. The committee voted 9 to 2 to approve legislation sponsored by Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona, that would give 400,000 to 500,000 Salvadorans ''extended voluntary departure'' status. This is an indefinite suspension of deportation on a broad scale and not on a case-by-case basis as proposed in a defeated amendment.

title: Arctic to Arena
description: Last year, shortly after he graduated from Lehigh University with a degree in economics, Clarence Walton decided to forget football. He had been a 240-pound starter at nose guard for three years and had acquired a sense that football was a never-ending, time-consuming phenomenon.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tour de France Golz Wins 15th Stage: Rolf Golz of West Germany won the 15th stage yesterday, outsprinting Roland Le Clerc of France and Martin Earley of Ireland, but Charles Mottet of France kept the overall lead. Golz was timed in 3 hours 57 minutes 59 seconds for the 102-mile race from Luz Ardiden to Blagnac. Le Clerc had the same time as the winner, and Earley was four seconds behind. Mottet has an overall lead of 2 minutes 20 seconds over Jean Francois Bernard of France and 2:33 over Stephen Roche of Ireland.(AP) Longo Retains Overall Lead: Jeannie Longo of France remained the overall leader while Tamara Poliakova of the Soviet Union won the sixth stage of the women's race yesterday. The Soviet rider completed the 21-mile course from Plaisance-du-Touch to Blagnac in 45 minutes 45 seconds. Maria Canins of Italy was second, 23 seconds back, with Longo third, 52 seconds behind. In the overall standings, Longo is 20 seconds ahead of Canins.(AP) Boxing Bottiglieri Retains Title: Salvatore Bottiglieri of Italy retained his World Boxing Council junior featherweight title yesterday in Capo D'Orlando, Sicily, with a 12-round split decision over Alvaro Bohorquez of Columbia. Mickey Vann, the referee from Britain, scored the fight for Bohorquez, while Adrian Morgan, a British judge, and Bob Logy, a Belgian judge, scored the fight for Bottiglieri. (AP) Tennis Wilander and Carlsson Advance: Two Swedish players, Mats Wilander and Kent Carlsson, seeded No. 1 and No. 3, respectively, both earned second-round victories yesterday in the $375,000 men's U.S. Open Clay Court championships in Indianapolis. Wilander moved into the third round with a 6-1, 7-5 victory over Leif Shiras and Carlsson defeated Dan Cassidy, 6-3, 6-1.(AP) Kriek Beats Cannon: Top-seeded Johan Kriek and Wally Masur of Australia, seeded second, scored victories yesterday in the second round of the $125,000 Volvo-New Jersey championships at Newark Academy in Livingston, N.J. Kriek beat Shelby Cannon, 6-1, 6-4 while Masur rallied from a 1-3 deficit in the third set to win the final five games and defeat Jeff Tarango, 6-2, 6-7, 6-3.(AP)

title: DATACARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $689,000.

title: COMPLAINTS ON FLIGHTS INCREASING
description: The Transportation Department says it received nearly as many complaints about shoddy airline service last month as it did in the first six months of 1986.

title: KEY RATES
IP TIMBERLANDS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: All share figures are for Class A depositary units.

title: Former Bevill Head Guilty
description: The former president of the brokerage firm Bevill, Bresler & Schulman was found guilty today by a jury in Federal Court here of conspiracy and mail fraud charges in connection with the 1985 collapse of the firm. Authorities contend that the collapse cost investors more than $100 million.

title: White Knights: The Dark Side
description: IN corporate takeover contests, many besieged companies have turned to a buyer friendly to management rather than end up in the arms of the first bidder. The role of this so-called white knight, however, is becoming more and more suspect since the acquired company often is put through the wringer in any event.

title: A Banking Bill Worse Than No Bill
description: House and Senate staff members, along with an army of lobbyists, have been manuevering overtime to draft the most important banking bill in years. The product now emerging falls far short of what is necessary to meet a looming crisis in the thrift industry. The White House has indicated its unhappiness with the likely bill, and rightly so. If it should pass, it will richly warrant a veto. Passage would show that Congress is paying more attention to the lobbyists than the public.

title: Text of Key Amendment
description: Here are the text of the legislation known as the Boland amendment, and excerpts from testimony by Robert C. McFarlane, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and Rear Adm. John M Poindexter on its meaning The Amendments

title: U.S. Cancels Show in Beijing Over China's Demand to Cut It
description: The United States today canceled a planned exhibition of American portraits in China because the Chinese insisted that paintings of Golda Meir and Gen. Douglas MacArthur be removed from the show.

title: RAINER BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $58 million provision for loan loss reserves for possible losses in loans to developing countries. c-Net income. The year-ago results are restated to reflect the acquisition of United Bank.

title: New York City Seeking Bids for a Reduced Sale
description: New York City said yesterday that it would sell $600 million of revenue anticipation notes due June 30, 1988, in competitive bidding today.

title: Restoring the Pride of 2 English Gardens
description: LEAD: THE English national passion for gardening has been focused on rescuing and conserving great gardens of the past. Britain is the first country anywhere to have a Government-sanctioned register of its important historic gardens; it is being compiled by the garden historian Christopher Thacker.

title: Nixon, Dixon and Hart
description: Richard Nixon and Gary Hart have always been poles apart. Indeed, Mr. Hart managed George McGovern's 1972 campaign against Mr. Nixon and said revulsion with the Nixon Administration motivated his 1974 run for the Senate. Now a friend of Mr. Nixon has released correspondence that reveals an aspect of fraternity between the two men. It is a fraternity of denial of responsibility, of inability to say mea culpa.

title: BARD, C R INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Robert Francis, a Poet Hailed by Frost, Dies
description: Robert Churchill Francis, once described by Robert Frost as ''the best neglected poet,'' died Monday in Cooley Dickenson Hospital in Northampton. He was 85 years old. Mr. Francis had lived simply in a two-room home here for more than 40 years. In 1984 he received the Academy of American Poets Followship Award for distinguished achievement.

title: Music: 'Hexameron,' by 6 Composers, at Rutgers
description: ''Hexameron,'' a set of variations for six pianos by as many composers, which hammers away mercilessly at a theme from ''I Puritani,'' is among those 19th-century novelty items heard from time to time at gala events. It concluded the concert Monday evening celebrating the inauguration of the Piano Institute at the Rutgers Summerfest here.

title: Smuggler Ties Contras To U.S. Drug Network
description: A convicted drug smuggler from Miami told a Senate subcommittee today that he had directed a network of pilots who flew weapons from two airports in southern Florida to contra forces in Central America and returned with loads of cocaine and marijuana.

title: CAR BOMBS IN LEBANON KILL 12 AND WOUND 55
description: Two car bombs killed 12 people and wounded 55 today in Tripoli and Baalbek, two Moslem cities patrolled by Syrians, the police reported.

title: CUOMO URGES STUDY OF PLAN FOR FULL-TIME LEGISLATURE
description: Governor Cuomo today called for a study of the advisability of making New York's part-time Legislature a full-time body.

title: MICOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-earlier results are restated for May 10 acquisition of International Software Database Corp., which was accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chairman of Plenum Seeks Unlikely Target
description: An unexpected acquisition offer by the Plenum Publishing Corporation to buy Arthur D. Little Inc., the consulting firm, for about $128 million would unite two companies that appear to be quite different and that may be on a crash course culturally.

title: NEC Head Speaks Out
description: American companies should become more competitive in world markets instead of merely urging Japan to reduce its huge trade surplus single-handed, the president of a major Japanese electronics company said today. ''I hope the United States will do more than give unpalatable advice to other countries, that instead it will do more to improve its own competitiveness,'' said the NEC Corporation's president, Tadahiro Sekimoto. Mr. Sekimoto, head of the world's largest maker of computer chips, urged American companies to try harder to sell overseas and adapt to foreign business climates, including Japan's.

title: Metro Matters; Westway II: A Delay Costing $90,000 a Day
description: Six months is to the history of a West Side highway what a stop sign is to a motorist's crosstown commute: a momentary distraction in an otherwise hopeless pursuit.

title: Honeywell Net Up 50.4%
description: Honeywell Inc. said that its second-quarter net income jumped 50.4 percent, largely reflecting a cost-cutting program initiated last year in which 4.4 percent of the company's work force was trimmed. The Minneapolis-based military contractor and maker of environmental systems reported earnings of $54.3 million, or $1.21 a share, up from $36.1 million, or 80 cents a share, a year ago. The 1986 quarter, which was restated, included a $7.7 million charge for discontinued operations. Sales increased 18.8 percent, to $1.58 billion, from $1.33 billion a year ago.

title: FIFTH THIRD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Jim Hawthorne, 63, an Actor And Tenor, Is Dead of Cancer
description: Jim Hawthorne, a theater and television actor, died Monday of lung cancer in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 63 years old.

title: Washing Fragile Textiles By Hand
description: IN this age of the dry cleaner, there is still a place for hand washing at home. Many items, like fine lingerie and heirloom handkerchiefs, require that special handling. But hand washing is more than just applying elbow grease in a sudsy basin of water. Experts describe it as a gentle art.

title: At Least 42 Are Killed by Typhoon in Korea
description: At least 42 people were killed and 66 others were missing today after a typhoon smashed across the southern coast, demolishing settlements with 80 mile-an-hour winds, emergency officials said.

title: FIRST AMERICAN BANK & TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. The company said the latest quarter loss reflects a ''substantially increased'' provision for loan losses; they did not specify the amount.

title: Calendar: Golf, Stars And Terra Cotta
description: Miniature Golf: Sacred and Mundane Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street); 212-753-1722.

title: Concert: Washington Square Festival
description: RAIN could not prevent the Washington Square Music Festival from beginning its 30th season Tuesday evening. Even though the proceedings were moved indoors from Washington Square Park to the Loeb Student Center at New York University, a crowd of no fewer than 100 attended the concert, which began with a self-effacingly reluctant Parks Commissioner, Henry J. Stern, giving the orchestra a ceremonial downbeat. Henry Schuman, the program's real conductor, then stepped out and chatted with the audience, telling a joke and setting an appropriately friendly, informal tone.

title: The Highlights
description: John M. Poindexter took responsibility for authorizing the diversion of profits from the Iran arms sales to Nicaraguan rebels, and said he withheld the information from President Reagan.

title: AIDS POSING DILEMMA IN RIGHT-TO-DIE STRUGGLE
description: For two years, Thomas Wirth watched one of his closest friends wither away and die of AIDS. Mr. Wirth vowed he would never allow himself to suffer the same way.

title: WILLIAMETTE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-3 stock split paid in April.

title: AMERICAN TELEVISION & COMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago quarter and 6 months are restated to include Manhattan Cable Television Inc., which was transferred from Time Inc. to American Television in March. The company said that earnings for the latest quarter were affected negatively by higher interest costs, principally related to its recapitalization in conjunction with its initial public offering in mid-1986. The company also said its 1987 results include its share of the losses in Paragon Communications, a joint venture with Houston Industries Inc. formed as a result of American Television's role in purchasing part of Group W Cable during June 1986.

title: Yields Are Mixed
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mixed for the week ended yesterday, with little change from a week ago.

title: ZZZZ Best Halts All Operations
description: The ZZZZ Best Company, whose 21-year-old founder and former chairman, Barry Minkow, has been accused of fraud and linked to a scheme to launder money from drug deals, has ceased all operations. Herb Wolas, the lawyer who was appointed trustee for ZZZZ Best after the carpet-cleaning company filed for protection from its creditors last week, said the company did not want to incur further liabilities ''until we are sure we can make payments.''

title: Manila Is Winner In United Nations
description: Manila, last year's champion grass runner, began his campaign toward a possible Horse of the Year title with an easy 2 1/2-length victory tonight over Racing Star in the $150,000 United Nations Handicap at Atlantic City Race Course.

title: First Republic Has Big Loss
description: The First Republicbank Corporation said today that it had increased reserves for potential losses from loans to developing countries by $325 million in the second quarter, producing a loss of $313.2 million for the period.

title: Advertising; CBS Magazine Network Alters Rate Structure
description: The CBS Magazine Network, which tries to induce advertisers to use a number of the company's magazines in order to win a discount, yesterday announced that with the October issues it is changing its rates and rate base and introducing an expanded volume discount.

title: CROSSLAND SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $11,570,000 for the quarter and $30,363,000 for the six months. c-Includes tax credits of $11,973,000 for the quarter and $24,271,000 for the six months.

title: HUNT, J B TRANSPORTATION SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $73,240 on trade-in of equipment for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes after-tax gains of $364,827 and $635,319 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Teacher's Union Shows It Likes Republicans, Too
description: The National Education Association, which historically has aligned itself with the Democratic Party, has quietly begun an outreach program among Republican members in an effort to increase the organization's political leverage.

title: IRVING J. RIFKIN
description: Irving J. Rifkin, a chemist and former owner of chemical laboratories in Brooklyn, died Tuesday at the Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 83 years old and had resided in North Miami, Fla.

title: Diction in Providence
description: To The Home Section:

title: STRYKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effected in May. The 1986 results are restated to reflect the acquisition of Adel Medical Ltd. on a pooling-of-interest basis.

title: Released Panamanians Tell of Abusive Treatment
description: Anti-Government protesters said today that their movement may have temporarily been set back by abusive treatment in jail of demonstrators whom the Government held over the weekend.

title: 3 OF 25 DIE IN ARIZONA DESERT TREK AFTER CROSSING THE BORDER FOR JOBS
description: Three men died in a group of 25 trying to walk across 50 miles of searing desert, the authorities said today.

title: Discreet Charms Of the Old Farmhouse
description: A DRIVE through the flat potato fields of eastern Long Island or along the meandering country roads of New England confirms the popularity of the farmhouse, old or new. Newly built versions come complete with porches, silos and turrets. Older houses, reshingled or brightly painted, sit pristine on manicured lawns at the ends of gravel driveways. Despite their dark, low-ceiling rooms, rudimentary plumbing and inefficient heating, their nostalgic charms make old farmhouses a magnet; owners and new buyers want to preserve their old-fashioned airs.

title: Continental Illinois Deficit
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation, parent of the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company, said yesterday that it lost $476.9 million in the second quarter, almost entirely because of a $510.1 million provision for loan losses. The unusually large provision is to account for Continental's problem loans in the developing world.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Edmonton Oilers' star, Wayne Gretzky, the National Hockey League's most valuable player in each of the last eight seasons, has decided to play for Team Canada in the Canada Cup tournament, which begins next month. . . . Dick Schofield, the shortstop who has played in every California Angels' game this season, has a minor separation of his left shoulder and will be sidelined for one to three weeks. Schofield, who is hitting .235 with 8 home runs and 37 runs batted in, was injured as a baserunner last Sunday against Detroit while attempting to avoid a line drive from a teammate, Bob Boone.

title: WARD SAYS BLACKS HOLD HIM TO HIGHER MARK
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward, speaking to a group of black journalists, complained yesterday that blacks who are faulting his performance never criticized his white predecessors in the same way and were failing to give him credit for his achievements.

title: Rock: The Bad Brains
description: THE Bad Brains, who performed late Monday night at Club 1018, aren't just the best (and possibly only) Rastafarian hard-core-rock band. With power, noise, wild frenzy and pinpoint accuracy, they're a rock band whose visceral impact is absolutely state-of-the-art. Formed in Washington, D.C., and based since 1979 in New York, the Bad Brains have built a considerable following among hard-core fans, dozens of whom slam-danced and dived into the crowd Monday.

title: MOTOROLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Contrary Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: EQUIMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,258,000 for the quarter and $2,407,000 for the six months. c-Includes tax credits of 1,149,000 for the quarter and $84,000 for the six months. d-After a loss of $2,398,000 related to the investment portfolio restructuring.

title: Jury Selection Ordered Open In Deaver Case
description: A Federal appeals court today ordered the judge in the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver to conduct the jury selection in public.

title: Long-Blooming Salvias For Lasting Enjoyment
description: THE plants in a perennial garden are somewhat like friends. Just as there are people who remain close even though we see them only once a year, there are perennials that have a very brief season of bloom: they speak their hello, as it were, and then call it quits until next year.

title: Cris Carter Ineligible
description: Cris Carter, whose 168 career receptions are tops in Ohio State history, was declared ineligible for his senior season yesterday for accepting money and signing a contract with an agent. The Ohio State athletic director, Rick Bay, speaking at a news conference, said Carter admitted that on May 1, 1986, he had signed a representation agreement and a $5,000 promissory note with Lloyd Bloom and Norby Walters, agents of World Entertainment and Sports, Inc. In addition Carter received $150 a month for almost a year after signing the contract, which was postdated to Jan. 2, 1988. Bay said Carter looked upon the payments as a loan against future earnings but that it was still an infraction of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules, which carries a penalty of immediate ineligibility. In a statement, Carter said, ''I regret the actions I took that make it necessary for Ohio State to declare me ineligible. I did not realize at the time the consequences that would result or the pain I would cause.''

title: Tempted to Tell Reagan
description: During the hearings yesterday, Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter was extensively questioned on how much he told President Reagan about exactly how the contras were being financed.

title: AMERICAN LIST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
US TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net income of $2.9 million from a change in accounting for certain commissions and fees, which was offset by a $2.8 million charge related to a revised estimate of future revenue from a sublease on an office building.

title: Ballard to Play in Italy
description: Greg Ballard is leaving the National Basketball Association after 10 seasons to play with the Pesaro team in Italy, he announced through the Golden State Warriors' office yesterday. ''I feel that this is a very good opportunity for my family and particularly for our children, who will have an opportunity to become bilingual and to experience an Italian life style,'' he said. In the last season of his two-year contract with the Warriors, Ballard averaged 19.3 minutes, 4.1 rebounds and 7.1 points a game.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pretax loss provision of about $155 million, or 75 cents a share, for estimated contract losses at Norden Systems.

title: NORWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an additional allowance for loan losses of $204 million related to international loan exposures. c-Net income.

title: A Busy Season for Burglars
description: Summer might be the doldrums for many businesses, but it is a busy season for burglars because of all the homes left empty by vacationers.

title: Networks Will Carry Washington Hearings
description: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair will be televised live today beginning at 9 A.M. on the NBC television network, on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on some local affiliates of PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service, including Channel 13 in New York.

title: ALLIED BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said its non-performing asset total was $605.73 million on June 30, or 9.84 percent of loans and related assets, an increase from the $346.18 million reported a year earlier. As of June 30, 1987 total, 69.26 percent were real estate-related and 17.75 percent were energy-related loans and assets.

title: An Ancient Idea To Let In the Light
description: ''WE'VE been using shoji screens in Japan for 1,000 years instead of doors, to let light in,'' said Masami Kodama, a partner in Miya Shoji, a company that has sold shoji screens in this country for 40 years. ''Sometimes people use them to hide things,'' he said, ''such as a bed or clothes.''

title: Del Monte USA Names Successor to Its Leader
description: Del Monte USA said yesterday that Fernando R. Gumucio, its president, had been named chairman and chief executive officer. Succeeding Mr. Gumucio as president is A. Ewan Macdonald, who has been senior vice president of marketing for the San Francisco-based fruit and vegetable processor.

title: HILTON HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said its improvement in net income came despite a higher tax rate in the latest quarter, 36.1 percent against 29.4 percent last year.

title: HUFFY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New York Ambulances Are Fewer, And Are Slower Answering Calls
description: Plagued by a deteriorating and aging fleet of ambulances, New York City's Emergency Medical Services is under severe strain and on a few nights this summer has been able to use barely half the vehicles its guidelines call for, officials at the agency said yesterday.

title: Rock: Live Skull Plays In Seminar Showcase
description: LIVE SKULL'S wall of guitars made a powerful, pulsating clamor Monday night at CBGB, where the group was playing at a Homestead Records showcase for the New-Music Seminar. That much was familiar; the core of the group - Mark C. and Tom Paine on guitars and Marnie Greenholz on bass guitar - has been making gloriously musical guitar noise, sculpted from ringing overtones and the sizzle of harmonic interference patterns, since Live Skull's beginnings in the early 80's.

title: Witness Is Principal Target Of Grand Jury Investigation
description: Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter's lawyer said today that his client had been named the ''primary target'' of a Federal grand jury investigating the Iran-contra affair and that there was an ''imminent threat of prosecution.''

title: SCHENECTADY CHILD-SUFFOCATION CASE GOES TO JURY
description: After six weeks of testimony in the Schenectady County Court, seven men and five women were asked today to decide whether Mary Beth Tinning fatally suffocated her 3 1/2-month-old daughter, Tami Lynne.

title: Ex-Wellcome Chief Joins Drug Concern
description: William M. Sullivan, a former chief executive at Burroughs Wellcome, a leading pharmaceutical company, is taking similar duties at Exovir, a tiny pharmaceutical enterprise in the development stage.

title: BRANCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS (PUERTO RICO) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $503,000 for the writeoff of the secondary reserve. The bank went public in January.

title: Boesky Use Of Futures Is Cited
description: Large positions in stock index futures accumulated by Ivan F. Boesky before the announcement in November of his $100 million insider-trading settlement appear to have been used by Mr. Boesky to offset, or hedge against, possible losses on a giant stock portfolio he controlled, according to officials of the Commodities Futures Trading Commission.

title: Reagan Supported, but Still Vulnerable
description: Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter's assertion today that he had never told President Reagan about the diversion of Iranian arms profits to the rebels in Nicaragua gave the White House what it sought: evidence to corroborate Mr. Reagan's own declarations.

title: More Clubs Admitting Women
description: When Suzanne O'Hatnick was invited to join the Rotary Club in Baltimore last week, it came as a surprise.

title: Trade Gap Widens as Imports Mount, Led by Oil
description: The nation's trade deficit widened to $14.4 billion in May as imports climbed to the highest level on record, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: TESTIMONY GRATIFIES PRESIDENT; ADMIRAL ON STAND
description: Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter testified today that he personally had authorized the use of profits from the Iran arms sales to help the Nicaraguan rebels and had withheld the information from President Reagan to protect him from political embarrassment.

title: AMERITECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PARKER DRILLING COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said a big part of its losses results from its policy of taking full depreciation on its rigs, whether working or not.

title: Johnson and His Glass House: Reflections
description: ''ALL architects want to live beyond their death,'' said Philip Johnson, sitting in the living area of his Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., reflecting on why he has given it to the National Trust for Historic Preservation. ''There's room for 12 houses on the land - I'd rather preserve it than have a ticky tacky subdivision built. And I'd like to build up a national trust.''

title: CENTRAL BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank converted to stock form in July 1986.

title: AMID THE SHADOWS, SOME FINE BASEBALL
description: Now that the 58th All-Star Game is a memory, the lingering thought seems to be that it deserves to be played either in daytime or at night. Not both. But it would be incorrect to assume the contest was boring.

title: Poindexter Thanked By Released Hostage
description: A former hostage, David Jacobsen, left the audience during a break in the Iran-contra hearings today to shake hands with Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter and to thank him and Lieut Col. Oliver L. North ''for getting me out and keeping me alive.''

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about obstacles faced by black professionals omitted a passage about minority recruitment efforts by McKinsey & Company, the management consulting concern. McKinsey recently engaged James Lowry, a consultant who once worked there, and with his help has thus far hired one black executive and arranged to hire another, according to a company spokeswoman.

title: Saratoga Names City Opera To a Visiting Residency
description: The New York City Opera has been named a resident company at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center, the center and the company have announced. The City Opera will join the New York City Ballet and the Philadelphia Orchestra in regular annual appearances at the upstate New York arts facility, a joint statement said yesterday.

title: Yank Job for Chambliss
description: Chris Chambliss, who will be forever remembered for his 1976 playoff home run against Kansas City that won a pennant, returned to the Yankees yesterday in a nonplaying position. Chambliss will work primarily with minor league hitters and be involved in player development and evaluation of major league hitters as a scout.

title: EVANS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
Pakistan Links Afghan Agents to Bombings
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq on Wednesday linked opponents of Pakistan's support for Afghan insurgents to bombings that killed at least 72 people here Tuesday, although he acknowledged that no group had come forward to claim responsibility.

title: Income Up at Time Inc. And 2 Other Publishers
description: Time Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter net income rose 25.8 percent, citing cost-cutting at its magazine division and revenue gains in its cable operation.

title: Mortgage-Backed Market in Britain
description: The market for mortage-backed securities in the British capital market continues to expand, with $:500 million of new issues (more than $800 million worth) in the last four months, including a new $:100 million note offering by a subsidiary of Salomon Brothers.

title: Back Surgery for Orr
description: Louis Orr, the Knicks' forward, will undergo back surgery today to repair a herniated disk. The procedure will be performed by Dr. Mark Snyder at Christ Hospital in Cincinnati, where Orr grew up and still lives. Orr has been troubled by back pain throughout his career. Last season, it forced him to miss seven games. X-rays taken last weekend revealed the need for surgery. According to John Cirillo, the Knicks' spokesman, the 29-year-old Orr is expected to make a complete recovery and be ready for the opening of training camp Oct. 7.

title: FIRST FINANCIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring after-tax securities investment gain of $1.3 million and is after a $500,000 reduction in total operating costs. The bank also cited a latest quarter increase from a substantial reduction in interest expense which improved net interest income. All figures have been restated to reflect a 4-for-3 stock split in October 1986.

title: 3 OF PRINCIPALS IN DISTRICT LOSE THEIR POSITIONS
description: Three principals in the troubled Community School District 6 in upper Manhattan were dismissed yesterday by New York City's central Board of Education, which found that the process by which the principals were hired a year ago was based on political rather than educational considerations, officials said.

title: DUN & BRADSTREET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid last month.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
