description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $14 million, or 8 cents a share, on the sale of Southwest Forest Industries preferred stock. Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 100-percent stock split effective May 1987. Results for the latest periods include Hammermill Paper Company, which merged with International Paper in the fourth quarter of 1986.

title: BISHOP JOSEPH G. VATH
description: Bishop Joseph G. Vath, the leader of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Birmingham, died of a heart attack Tuesday night at University Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: Trivia Question
description: Who were the last two Americans to win heavyweight gold medals at the Olympics? They are George Foreman in 1968 at Mexico City and Henry Tillman in 1984 at Los Angeles. Foreman, the former world heavyweight champion on the comeback trail, has been offered a Sept. 5 fight with Tillman, according to Tillman's promoter, Dan Duva, and the match has been submitted for approval and purchase to the ABC-TV network. The 39-year-old Foreman has two knockouts since his comeback began in March. Tillman, 26, who holds two victories over Mike Tyson in the United States Olympic team box-offs, lost to Evander Holyfield for the World Boxing Association junior heavyweight title last Feb. 4.

title: Amid Gold Boom, Skittishness
description: It is hard to find an executive in the gold mining business in North America who does not believe that life right now is too good to be true. But whether that view means it is time to expand or time to bail out depends on whether the executive thinks the current gold boom will bring on the next bust.

title: Taiwan-Boeing
description: The Taiwanese Government, engaged in a campaign to spend $2.28 billion on American products, said it would negotiate the purchase of six Boeing Company 747-400 aircraft for $1 billion. The Government also said it planned to buy more aircraft later for $700 million.

title: Images From Japan By Artists in Glass
description: LEAD: FROM the bite-size cracked egg to the nine-foot fused vertebrae of the fish, the current exhibition of Japanese studio glass at the Heller Gallery surveys an emerging national style. This is the most extensive exhibition of Japanese studio glass ever held in this country, featuring 65 works by more than 35 artist-craftsmen.

title: REFUGEE FREIGHTER FOUND IN FLORIDA
description: A second freighter sought in connection with the illegal landing of 174 Sikhs on the coast of Nova Scotia was located today in Miami with no passengers aboard.

title: MCGRAW HILL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 Sides of Busing Push for New Seattle Plan
description: A widespread system of busing to achieve racial balance in schools that was instituted in Seattle 10 years ago has come under re-examination, and it may be cut back.

title: Rock: Skinny Puppy
description: START with the machine-driven, industrial-grade, metallic stomp of bands like Einsturzende Neubaten. Add crack-voiced chants and cackles by way of the Residents and Captain Beefheart. Deliver the resulting clangor from a junk-sculpture stage set, with gestures and contortions out of Jerzy Grotowski's Polish Laboratory Theater and Iggy Pop concerts, plus the stage blood and baby dolls from Alice Cooper's arena-rock shows. Throw in a few firecrackers, too. The result is Skinny Puppy - a Vancouver-based group whose first performance Tuesday at the Kitchen (but presented by its record company, not the Kitchen itself), opening a two-night stand, made ''pretentious'' a dire understatement.

title: US HEALTHCARE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Man Kills Himself After Slaying Wife
description: A 44-year-old Brooklyn man, the father of seven children, killed his estranged wife in an argument in the hallway of his apartment building yesterday morning and then killed himself, the police said.

title: COMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $36 million, or $2.03 per share, addition to the loan loss reserve.

title: SOUTHTRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Advertising; Manning Already Back At Work at Thompson
description: Burton J. Manning was already at work at the J. Walter Thompson Company yesterday, before the WPP Group could make an official announcement of his return and appointment as chief executive of the worldwide agency.

title: AERO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: AN INCOMPLETE EDUCATION. By Judy Jones and William Wilson. Illustrated. 656 pages. Ballantine. $24.95.

title: SLOTNICK STATEMENT IS DISALLOWED
description: A public statement by Representative Mario Biaggi's lawyer cannot be introduced into evidence at Mr. Biaggi's bribery trial, a Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday.

title: A Confession: Tearing Up a 'Politically Embarrassing' Finding by Reagan
description: The Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair heard from one of the most important witnesses, Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter. Here are excerpts from his testimony, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: GOODMARK FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Bo Jackson's 'Hobby'
description: To anyone who has ever stood on the sideline at a National Football League game, the noise of the collisions sounds more like an automobile crash than that of a ''hobby.'' But in explaining his decision to join the Los Angeles Raiders as a running back after his last baseball game as a Kansas City Royals outfielder this year, Bo Jackson described pro football as a ''hobby.'' At least for him. ''Like hunting or fishing,'' he said. Not quite. Trying to elude Lawrence Taylor or any other N.F.L. linebacker has never been found under any definition of a ''hobby.'' Stamp collecting is a hobby. When Bo was talking about pro football being a hobby, maybe he was really thinking of coin collecting.

title: COMMERCE BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Air Force Withholds MX Payments From Thiokol
description: The Air Force, disclosing a new problem with production of the giant MX nuclear missile, said it began withholding contract payments from Morton Thiokol Inc. today because of ''unsatisfactory workmanship practices'' on the weapon's first-stage booster.

title: Lawsuits Triple in Federal Courts
description: The number of lawsuits filed in Federal courts has nearly tripled since 1970, according to a recent report.

title: RANDOLPH OUT FOR ONE MONTH
description: The Yankees, who played without Don Mattingly and Rickey Henderson for most of June, will play without Willie Randolph for the second half of July and the first half of August. Randolph, who played in the All-Star Game despite having torn knee cartilage, will undergo arthroscopic surgery on his left knee tomorrow.

title: East German Plans Bonn Trip
description: Erich Honecker will become the first East German leader to visit West Germany when he goes there in September, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's office said today.

title: DICEON ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Includes income of $346,000, or 6 cents a share, from recovery of accounts receivable written off in a prior year by Symtron. The company said the year-ago results are restated to reflect the acquisition of Symtron Corp. in May.

title: IT NEEDS A TEAM
description: New Jersey has selected a 246-acre plot a mile and a half south of the Meadowlands Sports Complex as the site of a proposed 45,000-seat baseball stadium if the state attracts a major league team, officials said today.

title: PARK COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Hopes of Immigration Act Died in a Texas Boxcar
description: To the Editor:

title: Output Barely Rose in June; Backlog of Unsold Cars Cited
description: Production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities edged up slightly in June as strength in non-manufacturing areas helped offset a big drop in auto production, the Government reported today.

title: 2 IN '88 CAMPAIGN FAULTED ON FUNDS
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson and the Rev. Jesse Jackson were the only major Presidential hopefuls who did not file campaign finance reports today, prompting criticism from rival campaigns that they were hiding their finances.

title: BRAJDAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $178,300 for the latest quarter and $111,200 for the year-earlier period.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: HERE are some new products that should be of interest to homeowners and handymen. All-Purpose Vise

title: Pension Deal Is Called Illegal
description: The head of the Federal agency that guarantees pension plans asserted today that an agreement between the bankrupt LTV Corporation and its unions to enhance pension benefits for 100,000 workers was illegal and threatened the pension protection program for the entire nation.

title: KING WORLD PRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Upswing Seen In Components
description: A MAJOR rebound could be in store for distributors of electronic components, according to analysts who follow this highly fragmented industry.

title: Trade Data Send Dollar Tumbling
description: The dollar yesterday registered its biggest one-day decline since Paul A. Volcker resigned as chairman of the Federal Reserve on June 2, as currency traders reacted negatively to news from the Commerce Department that the nation's foreign trade deficit had widened in May.

title: Grand Jury to Hear Minister About Wife's Attack in Dallas
description: A Methodist minister will be called before a grand jury here to answer questions about discrepancies in his account of the night his wife was attacked.

title: Pan Am Unions
description: The joint labor council of Pan American World Airways said that it had retained Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to advise the group, which represents most of the major unions at the carrier, on alternatives for restructuring the airline. The council also said that it had directed Drexel to seek investors willing to put large amounts of capital into the company, which has an aging fleet and sold off most of its Pacific routes last year to raise cash.

title: MICROPOLIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Inventories: The Bulge Grows
description: Business inventories soared in May by the largest amount in three years, lifted by a backlog of unsold cars and a slump in furniture and appliance sales, the Commerce Department said today.

title: A Hermit in Boston Loses Bed and Bower
description: Bill Britt, a hermit, has lost his makeshift home on public land. The authorities removed his belongings Monday after a court order protecting his lean-to expired.

title: PLAN AIMS TO DOUBLE UNION SQ.
description: At a time when expansion of urban parks is rare, city and community leaders have agreed on a bold plan to double the size of Union Square Park by closing a street and eliminating parking areas.

title: SOCIETY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Delta Loyalists Alarmed And Bruised by Mishaps
description: The elderly woman from Mississippi telephoned Delta Air Lines's headquarters here this week, and, in a frail but polite voice, explained how she had flown no other airline but Delta for the last 33 years.

title: REEBOK INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
White House Remains Part of Clinton's Plan
description: Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas said today that he hoped to run for President some day, although he has ruled himself out of the 1988 Democratic race.

title: 'Nerds II' in First Place In Week's Ticket Sales
description: ''Revenge of the Nerds II,'' a comedy sequel about a bunch of misfits who go to Fort Lauderdale for a spring break from college, earned $7.9 million in its debut weekend to take first place for the week at the box office.

title: Contract Won By McDonnell
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that it plans to launch two satellites for a British broadcaster beginning in 1989 in what would be the first commercial use of its Delta rocket.

title: USAir-Piedmont Link
description: The Department of Transportation refused a request to speed up its antitrust review of USAir Group Inc.'s planned acquisition of Piedmont Aviation Inc. The department said it had decided that a full hearing on the bid, which would create the nation's seventh-largest airline, was necessary. ''As we stated in our instituting order, USAir's acquisition of Piedmont presents substantial competitive issues requiring careful examination,'' the department said. The department's Office of Public Counsel, which is charged with representing the public interest in department proceedings, backed quick approval.

title: HIPOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
New Supercollider Deadline
description: The Energy Department today gave states more time to submit proposals for construction of the $4.4 billion ''supercollider,'' a powerful atom smasher. Proposals to house the major scientific installation are now due Sept. 2 instead of Aug. 3. At least 20 states are believed certain to submit proposals.

title: 5 Actors, 22 Roles, In One Play
description: Although they change jackets or gowns, a cap or a shawl to play 22 roles, the five actors in ''Hard Times,'' the adaptation of the Dickens novel, remain clearly recognizable. But there is no mistaking their personae.

title: A $75 Million Sale By Northern Trust
description: The Northern Trust Corporation yesterday offered $75 million of 9 1/8 percent notes due in 1994 at 99.65, to yield 9.193 percent. Goldman, Sachs & Company heads the underwriters.

title: Two Cuban Diplomats Are Told to Leave U.S.
description: Two Cuban diplomats were told today by the State Department to leave the United States within 10 days, in response to what the department called an ''intolerable'' campaign against American diplomats in Havana.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflects a special addition of $135 million to the company's allowance for loan losses in recogntion of recent developments with respect to the international debt environment; and includes a pre-tax gain of $49 million from the sale of RMJ holdings. c-Net income

title: Catch as Catch Can This Year in Majors
description: When will baseball use designated hitters for catchers, and other statistical developments in the first half of the season:

title: FIRST COMMERCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes securities gains of $26,000 for the quarter and $937,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes securities gains of $14,000 and $90,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Paper Makers' Income Is Up
description: Two paper and forest products companies reported higher second-quarter earnings yesterday, citing continued high exports resulting from the declining dollar. The International Paper Company reported an 18.4 percent increase in earnings, while the Boise Cascade Corporation said its net income rose 12.5 percent.

title: CASH GRANTS ARE ORDERED TO HOMELESS
description: A judge in New York State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that single homeless men and women in city shelters were entitled to Medicaid and cash welfare grants.

title: North Korea Given Final Olympic Offer
description: The International Olympic Committee offered North Korea one more concession in what it said was its final proposal in trying to solve the problem of North Korea's demand to be co-host of the 1988 Summer Games.

title: RYAN FAMILY STEAK HOUSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split in May.

title: TIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $19 million from the previously announced sale of Time Inc.'s interest in USA Network. The gain was somewhat offset by the premium of $9 million after tax paid to refinance the company's long-term debt at more advantageous rates. The company said that each of Time Inc.'s core businesses contributed to the gain, with particularly strong performances from magazines and cable television. The company attributed the magazine gains to strong circulation and the benefits of a cost management program, while the improvement in cable television resulted primarily from continued subscriber gains.

title: The Presidency: Reagan and His 'Golden Oldies'
description: President Reagan has described his current package of economic proposals as ''golden oldies,'' a collection of Ronald Reagan's Greatest Hits.

title: No Pension Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: BOISE CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company attributed stronger 1987 6-month results to improved prices for most paper products and lumber. The company said income from its paper and paper products segment was well above that of the year-ago second quarter, and it attributed increases over year-ago levels to improved prices for uncoated white papers, newsprint, market pulp and containerboard, plus the contribution from new capacity gained when the company purchased its Jackson, Ala., pulp and paper mill last year.

title: DERBY SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JUDGE GIVES LINDENAUER 2-YEAR PRISON SENTENCE
description: Geoffrey G. Lindenauer, whose arrest for corrupt activities began the unraveling of New York City's worst municipal scandal in decades, was sentenced yesterday to two years in Federal prison and five years on probation for his crimes.

title: FIRST COMMERCIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Boxcar Survivor Freed
description: The only survivor of a bungled smuggling attempt in which 18 illegal aliens died has been released, according to Border Patrol agents. The survivor, Miguel Tostado Rodriguez, 21, had been held as a material witness by Border Patrol agents in El Paso. Agents found Mr. Tostado and the bodies of the 18 aliens, all from central Mexico, in a boxcar on July 2 in Sierra Blanca, 90 miles east of El Paso.

title: METS SETTING OUT TO OVERCOME THE ODDS
description: Act Two opens tonight in Shea Stadium, with Dwight Gooden pitching against Bill Gullickson of the Cincinnati Reds and with just 75 games left for the Mets to head off the great collapse of 1987.

title: Flooding in France Kills At Least 19
description: At least 19 people were killed when a flash flood swept through an alpine campground crowded with vacationers, many of them enjoying a long Bastille Day weekend, officials said today. In addition, twenty-eight people were listed as missing.

title: TELEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes equity in net of unconsolidated units of $46.5 million in the latest 6 months and $52.7 million in the year-earlier period.

title: DECEPTIVE CALM BEFORE BRITISH OPEN
description: There was no wind today under gray skies here as 153 golfers had their final practice round for the 116th British Open on the links of Muirfield. But not one of them believed that the still conditions would hold through the next four days.

title: DEPOSIT GUARANTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After trading account losses of $1,900,000. The company said earnings for the latest quarter were reduced by an $8.1 million addition to the reserve for possible loan losses to cover foreign credit exposure in Latin America. Results for all periods have been restated to reflect the acquisition of First Bank Capital Corp. on Dec. 31, 1986, and Security Financial Corp. on May 29, both of which were accounted for as poolings of interests.

title: Iraqi Jets Hit at Bases Of Iranian Speedboats
description: Iraqi jets hit tiny islands and offshore oil platforms used as bases for Iran's Revolutionary Guard speedboat fleet for the third straight day today as tensions mounted in the Persian Gulf.

title: Dow Up 2.39 After Seesaw Session
description: A stock market made nervous by disturbing news about the trade situation and oil prices had a seesaw session yesterday before closing mixed. While the Dow Jones industrial average managed to hit another record, broader market indexes retreated and more stocks fell than gained on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SUMMARY OF ACTIONS IN NEW YORK LEGISLATURE'S 1987 SESSION
description: The 1987 session of the New York State Legislature - its 210th - ended at 5:51 A.M. on July 11, with some of the most important bills not passed until the final 24 hours.

title: Rock: Steve Earle, at the Cat Club
description: AFTER 13 years as a Nashville songwriter, Steve Earle has found his own audience -one that's large and growing. He returned to New York for a show at the Cat Club late Tuesday night, a New-Music Seminar showcase.

title: BANK OF GRANITE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Generation Struggle Divides Protestants In Northern Ireland
description: The marching season is under way, with its annual parades intended to show the historic unity of the Protestant majority in this province of Britain.

title: BRIEFING: Meese's Holdings
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, already under investigation for actions he may have taken on behalf of the Wedtech Corporation, may soon have some explaining to do for another potential conflict of interest.

title: Gandhi Ousts 3 Rebels From Governing Party
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi ousted three prominent rebels from the governing Congress Party today. They included a cousin who was once a powerful aide.

title: COCA-COLA CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said year-ago figures are restated to report the results of Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. under the equity method of accounting.

title: KENTUCKY UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in May.

title: Becor Bid Raised
description: Bear, Stearns & Company said that it had increased its offer to acquire Becor Western Inc. to $16.60 a share in cash and notes, or an estimated total of $276 million. The board of Becor, a Milwaukee-based aerospace and mining concern, is scheduled to meet Thursday to consider the four separate offers that it has received. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Bear, Stearns said that it was offering $10.75 in cash, $4.25 principal amount of a senior subordinated debenture and $1.60 in preferred stock. Bear, Stearns said that Becor shareholders would receive 25 percent of the equity of the new company.

title: NCNB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Midland Bank Bars Bid for Subsidiary
description: Midland Bank, Britain's third biggest, said it had received and rejected an unsolicited offer from Morgan Stanley & Company to buy its stock-trading subsidiary, Greenwell Montagu Securities. ''Midland has assured its staff of its commitment to a major continuing interest in the equities market which lies behind the decision,'' a bank spokesman said.

title: Extra Special
description: The National League's 2-0 victory in 13 innings Tuesday night in Oakland, Calif., extended its unbroken string of extra-inning All-Star Game victories to eight. The American League held the lead at some point in six of the losses, but in the 24 extra innings comprising the streak has been outscored by the National League, 10-1, with its lone run unearned in 1961. Year, Score (Innings) Winning hitter Losing pitcher 1950, 4-3 (14) Red Schoendienst, homer Ted Gray 1955, 6-5 (12) Stan Musial, homer Frank Sullivan 1961, 5-4 (10) Roberto Clemente, single Hoyt Wilhelm 1966, 2-1 (10) Maury Wills, single Pete Richert 1967, 2-1 (15) Tony Perez, homer Catfish Hunter 1970, 5-4 (12) Jim Hickman, single Clyde Wright 1972, 4-3 (10) Joe Morgan, single Dave McNally 1987, 2-0 (13) Tim Raines, triple Jay Howell

title: TELEFLEX INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIRST FLORIDA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes securities gains of $726,000.

title: U.S. Pressing Pakistan on Export Plot
description: The United States is urgently seeking an explanation from Pakistan of an apparent effort by a Pakistani businessman to illegally acquire American materials for making nuclear weapons, the State Department announced today.

title: Q & A
description: Q. The marble tops on two outdoor tables are pitted and dull, and I want to restore them. Can I use a polish or a buffing compound?

title: DEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $138,000. c-Net loss

title: Where Clothes Make the Man
description: What should the well-dressed witness wear to a Congressional investigation?

title: NEWPORT PHARMACEUTICALS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
AMR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago second quarter includes a gain of $50.3 million, or 81 cents a share, from the sale of assets.

title: Hialeah Rebuffed On Racing Dates
description: A Florida appellate court today upheld the award of the lucrative middle-winter racing dates to Gulfstream Park, a change that Hialeah Park officials have said could mean the financial ruin of their track.

title: COMPUTER RESEARCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2.5-for-1 stock split paid last in June.

title: J. Rives Childs Is Dead; Authority on Casanova
description: J. Rives Childs, a former American diplomat, author and an authority on Casanova, died of a cardiac-pulmonary infection yesterday at the Windsor Nursing Home in Richmond, where he had lived for the last four years. He was 94 years old.

title: ITT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $28 million, or 18 cents a share, on the sale of Virgin Islands Telephone Co. for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes a gain of $50 million, or 33 cents a share, on the sale of the company's remaining shares of Abbey Life in the U.K.; a loss of $13 million on discontinued operations; and an extraordinary loss of $7 million on the redemption of high-interest debt issues for both the quarter and 6 months. Year-ago revenue restated because the company sold all of its telecommunications operations to a joint venture company with CGE of France. The company said Diversified Services results for the first half of 1987 were significantly ahead of last year primarily reflecting continued improvement in the domestic casualty business at the Hartford. In addition, Hartford's results were aided by ''fresh start'' tax benefits under the 1986 Tax Reform Act, of which $49 million was realized in the first six months of 1987.

title: The Albany Scorecard
description: After a legislative year marked by uncommon bickering, Governor Cuomo and the New York Legislature deserve credit for tangible achievements on taxes, ethics, transit, state prisons and milk - even as they leave behind much disappointment over pensions, courts, campaign finance, city jails and racist crime.

title: Brooklyn Memories
description: To The Home Section:

title: Administration Moves to Block Congressional Deficit-Cutting Plan
description: The Reagan Administration moved this week to stop Congress from achieving most of a $7.2 billion deficit-reducing proposal for the 1988 budget.

title: Prices Fall on Trade Report
description: Treasury bond prices fell more than a point yesterday, with all the decline coming early in the day in response to a larger-than-expected trade deficit in May.

title: Women in Power Are No Better Than Men
description: To the Editor:

title: PIP Printing Gets Kane Bid
description: Postal Instant Press, a franchiser of 1,100 instant printing centers, said it had received an unsolicited $77.3 million buyout bid from the Kane-Miller Corporation and plans to consider the proposal within the next two weeks. The bid comes after PIP adopted an anti-takeover measure last December and its founder and chairman, Bill LeVine, 67 years old, stepped aside as chief executive.

title: PFIZER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Message for Democrats
description: When the seven Democratic candidates sat down together on a stage in Houston recently, it was not only the first Presidential debate of the season, it was also a stark lesson in how the political landscape is being changed by the Iran-contra scandal.

title: Kylian's Dance Images That Flow Like Daydreams
description: JIRI KYLIAN'S choreography proceeds by sweeps and surges. That was certainly apparent in the ballets by him that the Netherlands Dance Theater brought to the Metropolitan Opera House last month.

title: TECHNITROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
London Office Development
description: Olympia & York, the Canadian real estate and resources group, is expected to announce Friday that it will join the Canary Wharf Development Consortium, a group planning to build one of the world's largest office developments in London.

title: REV. RALPH DENGLER
description: The Rev. Ralph Dengler, a Jesuit who was chairman of the department of communications at Fordham University, died of a heart attack Saturday at his residence on the university's Rose Hill campus in the Bronx. He was 56 years old.

title: Bush Won't Debate Sept. 2
description: Vice President Bush will not take part in a debate among Republican Presidential hopefuls that is scheduled to be televised Sept. 2 on the Public Broadcasting System program ''Firing Line,'' according to Warren Steibel, the producer of the program. Mr. Bush's campaign office said Tuesday that the Vice President would not appear because he would not have formally announced his candidacy by then, Mr. Seibel said.

title: Eliot Ness to Vanna White
description: President Reagan takes great glee in describing how decisively he will veto tax increases or spending bills. And he frequently reaches for a reference from pop culture to convey his determination.

title: The Witness File
description: Name Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter Age 50 Position National security adviser to the President from December 1985 until he resigned on Nov. 25, 1986, on the day the diversion of Iran arms sales proceeds to the contras was disclosed.

title: Howe Starts Comeback
description: ''I think the question has been answered if I can still pitch,'' said Steve Howe after throwing three hitless innings in his first appearance since being banned from baseball for drug abuse. After picking up the Oklahoma City 89ers' 5-4 victory over the Iowa Cubs Tuesday in American Association action, the left-hander said, ''I'm going to win wherever I'm at.'' The next stop might be the Texas Rangers, who signed him to a minor league contract last weekend.

title: REPCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: b-Includes tax credits of $6,000 and $11,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $3,000 and $40,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JULY 16, 1987
description: International

title: HERS
description: LEAD: WEEK after week, Henrietta comes to clean my house. Despite her good humor, I don't think she much likes this kind of work, but it is all she can get without a high school diploma. She is a soft-spoken woman of 33, the divorced mother of four children. She knows where their father is, but they never see him and he contributes nothing to their support.

title: Restoration Artisans Pool Their Skills
description: A century ago, legions of craftsmen built the stately Victorian homes that still line the hills of this city. Twenty years ago, flower children descended on the structures, many of them long neglected, and recast them in multiple hues of fluorescent paint. Today the great houses have come back into their own, and meticulous restoration artisans are at work on them.

title: GENETICS INSTITUTE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ADA M. SHEARON
description: Ada M. Shearon, a children's book editor, died of cancer Friday at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. She was 73 years old.

title: Congress Cool to Japanese
description: Japan's trade minister got a frosty reception on Capitol Hill today as he sought to repair political damage caused by the Toshiba Machine Company's illegal sale of sensitive technology to the Soviet Union.

title: Tube Rupture Releases Radioactivity in Virginia
description: One of thousands of stainless steel tubes carrying superheated water to a nuclear power plant steam generator ruptured today and a tiny amount of radioactivity escaped into the atmosphere, officials said.

title: BRIEFING: Beeping Madness
description: Senate Republicans recently replaced their electronic paging devices with a newer model because the old ones often didn't have enough range; they have even been blamed for causing some senators to miss roll-calls. But although the new devices are more reliable, a number of senators now complain that because the buttons on them are so tiny, they are difficult to operate, especially to turn off. Since the new devices arrived, many Republicans have been seen rushing onto the floor with their beepers beeping, and then fumbling to turn them off. One, Senator Christopher S. Bond of Missouri, found a more dramatic way to turn his off. He threw it on the Senate floor, stomped on it, then turned to a staff member and said: ''Bury it.''

title: Space Agency Names a Panel To Examine Rocket Accident
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today named a five-member board to investigate a launching pad accident that damaged a hydrogen tank on an Atlas-Centaur rocket.

title: Food and Agriculture Agency Has Been Catalyst for Third World
description: To the Editor:

title: VANGUARD SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Judge Rules Against 'Tilted Arc' Sculptor in Suit
description: A Federal judge ruled against Richard Serra Tuesday in a portion of a suit in which the artist contends that his reputation and career have been harmed by efforts to remove his sculpture ''Tilted Arc'' from a plaza in downtown Manhattan.

title: Ersatz Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: CAPE COD BANK & TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Immune System and Infertility
description: Problems in the immune system may be to blame for many cases of infertility in women, researchers at Mount Sinai Medical Center here said today. They said many women prone to fertility problems had a significantly higher incidence of abnormal blood factors called autoimmune antibodies.

title: 2 Factory Buildings Destroyed by Blaze
description: A fire destroyed two warehouse-factory buildings and damaged a third yesterday in the city's downtown area about eight blocks south of the entrance to the Holland Tunnel, the authorities said.

title: LEARONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Deniable Plausibility?
description: To the Editor:

title: CANANDAIGUA WINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
The Dance: A New Cast in Bolshoi's 'Raymonda'
description: LIKE all dance companies, the Bolshoi Ballet is not immune to injuries. Unfortunately, Natalya Bessmertnova, the senior ballerina on the company's current tour, has become the season's main casualty. After appearing in ''The Golden Age'' and the ''Spartacus'' excerpt of the ''Highlights'' program, she apparently pulled her Achilles' tendon.

title: Coke Is Up; Charge for 'Ishtar' Set
description: The Coca-Cola Company reported an 18.1 percent rise in second-quarter earnings yesterday, although its entertainment unit posted a deficit because of a $25 million charge related to the comedy film ''Ishtar.''

title: Advertising; Ted Bates And B.&S. Combine
description: THE long-expected merger of Ted Bates Worldwide and Backer & Spielvogel, both subsidiaries of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company of London, was announced yesterday. Carl Spielvogel, the 58-year-old chairman and chief executive of the smaller company, will carry the same titles at Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide.

title: ALLSTAR INNS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company went public in April.

title: Dr. John H. Northrop, Nobel Laureate, Dies
description: Dr. John H. Northrop, a 1946 Nobel laureate, died May 27 at his home in Wickenberg, Ariz. He was 95 years old.

title: Arms to Iran, Profits to the Contras: What the President Has Said
description: Nov. 13, 1986 ''The charge has been made that the United States has shipped weapons to Iran as ransom payment for the release of American hostages in Lebanon, that the United States undercut its allies and secretly violated American policy against trafficking with terrorists. Those charges are utterly false. The United States has not made concessions to those who hold our people captive in Lebanon. And we will not. The United States has not swapped boatloads or planeloads of American weapons for the return of American hostages. And we will not.'' Nov. 25 ''I was not fully informed on the nature of one of the activities undertaken in connection with this initiative.'' Jan. 27, 1987 ''Though we have made much progress, I have one major regret. I took a risk with regard to our action in Iran. It did not work, and for that I assume full responsibility . . . . We did not achieve what we wished, and serious mistakes were made in trying to do so. We will get to the bottom of this, and I will take whatever action is called for.'' Feb. 20 ''Try as I might, I cannot recall anything whatsoever about whether I approved an Israeli sale in advance or whether I approved replenishment of Israeli stocks around August of 1985. My answer, therefore, and the simple truth is, I don't remember -period.'' March 4 ''A few months ago I told the American people I did not trade arms for hostages. My heart and my best intentions still tell me that's true, but the facts and the evidence tell me it is not. As the Tower board reported, what began as a strategic opening to Iran deteriorated, in its implementation, into trading arms for hostages . . . . As I told the Tower board, I didn't know about any diversion of funds to the contras. But as President, I cannot escape responsibility.'' March 19 When asked about whether he could have forgotten about being told of the diversion of funds from the Iran arms sales to the contras: ''Oh, no. You would have heard me without opening the door to the office if I had been told that at any time.'' May 3 ''With regard to whether private individuals were giving money to support the contras, yes, I was aware that there were people doing that. But there was nothing in the nature of a soliciatation by my Administration, to my knowledge, of anyone to do that.'' May 13 ''There was no solicitation that I know of or anything of the kind. I did know, and had been informed, that he [ King Fahd of Saudi Arabia ] was helping, but I never brought it up.'' May 15 ''And here there's no question about my being informed. I've known what's going on there. As a matter of fact, for quite a long time now, a matter of years, I have been publicly speaking of the necessity of the American people to support our program of aid to those freedom fighters down there in order to prevent there being established a Soviet beachhead here in the Western Hemisphere, in addition to the one we already have in Cuba. And to suggest that I am just finding out or that things are being exposed that I didn't know about - no. Yes, I was kept briefed on that. As a matter of fact, I was very definetly involved in the decisions about support to the freedom fighters. It was my idea to begin with.'' May 27 ''I'm being portrayed as having, behind the scenes, violated the law and done all sorts of shady things to try and violate the Congress's restrictions on aid to the freedom fighters. And it just isn't true.'' July 8 ''I've got nothing to say until the hearings are over.'' July 15 When asked whether he was suprised by Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter's denials that the President was aware of the diversion of funds to the contras in Nicaragua: ''What's new about that? I've been saying it for seven months.''

title: Senate Votes to Repeal Special Oil-Profits Tax
description: The Senate voted early today to repeal the so-called windfall profits tax that oil companies have been fighting for seven years.

title: Ride Wanted: Purple Cow Going West
description: They start from the dairy country of Vermont and they look like cows, more or less, except for being purple and plywood, and for standing by the sides of roads all over America, trying to hitch rides from passing motorists.

title: The President As Avid Reader
description: During Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter's testimony, the former national security adviser was asked about access to the President and Mr. Reagan's reading habits.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Questions Pakistan The United States wants Pakistan to explain an apparent effort to illegally acquire American materials for making nuclear weapons. Page A3. Ruling on Deaver Jury Overruling the trial judge, a Federal appeals court said jury selection in the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver must be done in public. Page A16. Lindenauer Is Sentenced Geoffrey G. Lindenauer, whose arrest set off the recent corruption scandals in New York, was sentenced to two years in prison. Page B1.

title: Safety of Bus Doors Is Faulted in Report
description: Door safety systems on New York City buses failed at an ''unacceptable'' rate, according to a report released yesterday by the State Public Transportation Safety Board.

title: SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Share earnings reflect the 3-for-2 stock split, effective May 1987. The company said the results include the operations of a business purchased from Martin Marietta Corp. since the end of October. In the latest year the company initially adopted FASB No. 86 and, as required, capitalized certain product development cost. During the latest quarter and year, the company capitalized approximately $850,000 and $2,300,000 of development cost, respectively; or $440,000 and $1,200,000 after tax, or 7 cents and 19 cents a share, respectively, for the same periods.

title: Korea Opposition Chief Demands Premier's Ouster
description: Kim Young Sam, an opposition leader, demanded today that President Chun Doo Hwan replace the Prime Minister he appointed this week and warned that a fair election is unlikely.

title: CADE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,856,000.

title: Dakar Journal; For 60 Afrikaners, a Long Trek Into the Future
description: A balance of West African ritual and Senegalese hospitality provided the backdrop for a symbolic act here in the last few days: the acceptance of a white African tribe as a full-fledged part of Africa.

title: Washington's Course Worries Allies
description: As the United States embarks on a new policy initiative in the Persian Gulf, the testimony of former officials about the Iran-contra affair is being widely viewed among its European allies as a sign of chaos at the heart of the Reagan foreign policy machinery.

title: Trio at Waverly Jazz
description: The trio of Sirone on bass, Billy Bang on violin and Zen Matsuura on percussion is to perform tonight and tomorrow at Waverly Jazz, 147 Waverly Place (627-5601). Music begins at 10:30 P.M.; there is no cover or minimum.

title: The Message and the Medium of Oliver North; Misguided Officer
description: To the Editor:

title: Poland Says Bodies in Mass Grave Are Germans
description: The Polish Government's chief spokesman said today that an examination of remains in a mass grave in northeastern Poland had yielded evidence that the bodies were of German soldiers.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tour de France Surprise Winner: Regis Clere of France won the 16th stage of the Tour de France yesterday by more than 14 minutes, but Charles Mottet of Systeme U retained the leader's yellow jersey. Clere rode 118 miles of the 135-mile route from Blagnac to Millau, France, alone. Raul Alcala of Mexico placed second, 14 minutes 13 seconds back, with Jean-Francois Bernard of France, Stephen Roche of Ireland, Andy Hampsten of the United States and Pedro Delgado of Spain following. Maria Canins of Italy beat Jeannie Longo of France in the seventh stage of the women's event. Longo retained the lead. Canins won by a length on the 54.5-mile course from Valence d'Albigeois to Millau.(AP) Olympic Festival Blatnick Upset: Jeff Blatnick, a 1984 Olympic gold medalist in Greco-Roman wrestling, was eliminated by Morris Johnson in the first round of the United States Olympic Festival in Durham, N.C. Johnson will face second-seeded Craig Pittman in the final.(AP) Tennis Wilander Rallies: Top-seeded Mats Wilander struggled to a 7-5, 7-5 victory over Diego Perez of Spain yesterday in the third round of the $375,000 United States Clay Court tournament in Indianapolis. Unseeded Richey Reneberg moved into the quarterfinals against Wilander with a 7-6, 6-0 victory over Blaine Willenborg.(AP) Kriek Advances: Top-seeded Johan Kriek and second-seeded Wally Masur moved into to the quarterfinals of the $125,000 Vovlo Tennis-New Jersey Championships in Livingston, N.J. Kriek beat Rich Matuszewski, 6-2, 6-2, in 61 minutes. Masur beat Michael Kures, 7-6, 6-0. Third-seeded Paul Annacone was upset by Alex Antonitsch of Austria, 7-6, 2-6, 7-6. (AP) Golf 3 Share Lead: Amy Alcott, Cathy Marino and Sally Quinlan shot five-under-par 67's to share the first-round lead in the $300,000 Boston Five Classic at Ferncroft Country Club in Danvers, Mass. Alcott had six birdies. (AP) Iowan Shoots 63: David Rummells of West Branch, Iowa, shot a seven-under 63 for a one-stroke lead over Mark McCumber and Brad Fabel in the $500,000 Hardee's Golf Classic in Coal Valley, Ill. (AP) World Games U.S. in Semifinals: The undefeated Americans, paced by B. J. Armstrong's 15 points, coasted to a 93-83 victory over Canada and entered the basketball semifinals at the World University Games in Zagreb, Yugoslavia. Mike Powell won the long jump in 26 feet 10 1/2 inches, edging Paul Emordi of Nigeria, at 26-7 1/4. (AP) Soccer U.S. Loses: South Korea rallied for three goals to beat the United States, 4-2, in a Group B match last night at the under-16 World Cup tournament in Saint John, New Brunswick. The South Koreans advanced to Sunday's quarterfinal in Toronto against Italy, champion of Group A. The United States finished 1-2.

title: Iran's Immunity
description: In New York last year, an Iranian representative to the United Nations was arrested for shoplifting. Charges were dropped when he claimed diplomatic immunity. This year an Iranian consular official was arrested in Manchester, England, for shoplifting and other offenses. When the British Government ruled that the official's status did not qualify for immunity, Iran seized a British diplomat in Teheran and threatened to bring charges that could carry a death penalty.

title: Nutrasweet Faces A Senate Hearing
description: Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, said he would hold a hearing in September on health concerns about aspartame, the popular artificial sweetener marketed under the brand name Nutrasweet by the Monsanto Company. The hearing will be held by the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, which has jurisdiction over the Food and Drug Administration.

title: MARIJUANA TRAFFIC ON RISE
description: Near-record prices for marijuana in the United States have led to a sudden upsurge in shipments of marijuana from Colombia through Mexico, according to Mexican Government officials.

title: Pitino Names an Assistant
description: Rick Pitino made his first decision as the Knicks' coach yesterday when he named Stu Jackson, an assistant of his at Providence College, an assistant coach.

title: Channel 5 Offers 'Beans Baxter' in Trouble
description: Resembling a Frankenstein's monster more than the situation comedy it was meant to be, ''The New Adventures of Beans Baxter'' lurches onto Channel 5 tomorrow night at 8 in an hourlong premiere.

title: TW Services To Get Denny's
description: TW Services Inc. said today that it would acquire Denny's Inc. for $218 million in cash and the assumption of the restaurant chain's debt, making the deal worth $843 million.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: EARLY REAGAN. By Anne Edwards. Illustrated. 617 pages. William Morrow. $21.95.

title: Brooklyn Congregations Struggle to Repair Old Churches
description: Hundreds of the aging and once stately houses of worship that helped give Brooklyn the name ''City of Churches'' are in severe disrepair, with many congregations closing off parts of the buildings because they are unsafe.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: ''The Swinging Years of Benny Goodman,'' Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street (758-2272). Benny Goodman's influence on jazz clarinetists is evident from the number of them who, over the past 50 years, have drawn intentionally or unintentionally on Goodman's style and sound. Last fall, at a concert of Goodman's music by the American Jazz Orchestra, Walt Levinsky showed unusual perception and skill, both as an interpreter of Goodman's clarinet roles and as a conductor of arrangements by Fletcher Henderson, Eddie Sauter, Jimmy Mundy and Mel Powell - arrangements that highlighted the Goodman band repertory. Mr. Levinsky, a veteran of the Goodman band in its later years, is leading a 14-piece orchestra this weekend and for the next two weeks, a band that is reviving the sound and spirit of the Goodman era with such top-flight musicians as Warren Vache on trumpet, Urbie Green on trombone, Frank Wess on saxophones, Marty Napoleon on piano and Butch Miles on drums, as well as a one-time Goodman vocalist, Lynn Roberts. They play two performances tonight and tomorrow at 9 and 11. There is a $15 cover charge and a two-drink minimum.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FRIDAY STEPPING OUT IN BROOKLYN Celebrate Brooklyn, the spirited summerlong festival of the performing arts in Prospect Park, turns to dance this weekend. Several renowned companies, presenting works ranging from classical ballet to Irish step-dancing, will take the stage tonight, tomorrow and Sunday at 8 P.M. Love in its many forms dominates tonight's program as the Dance Theater of Harlem presents excerpts from ''Othello,' Katherine Healy and Leonid Kozlov perform a duet from ''Cinderella'' and Ron Brown's Evidence Dance Company does a work called ''Heat's On.'' Tomorrow, Laura Dean's Dancers and Musicians will be joined by Johanna Boyce and her Brooklyn-based troupe, the Calf Women. The Sunday program includes the Green Grass Cloggers from Southern Appalachia, Irish music and dance by Donny and Eileen Golden and jazz-accompanied tap dancing by Manhattan Tap. The free performances are in the band shell, near Prospect Park West and Ninth Street. Rain dates are Monday and Tuesday. Information: (718) 768-0699. CENTRAL PARK INSPIRATION Many an artist has been inspired by the vistas of Central Park, including Holly Fairbank, a Manhattan choreographer. Her inspiration came from the small pond at the park's wooded northwest corner, and the resultant work, ''Pooldance,'' will be performed tonight and tomorrow at 6:30 at water's edge. Four members of Ms. Fairbank's company - a movement chorus composed of six members of Veritas, a local drug-rehabilitation center - and several musicians will present the abstract 30-minute piece, which was commissioned by the Manhattan Arts Council. The free performances will nearly encircle the pool, which is near Central Park West and 100th Street. Rain date for both performances is Sunday at 6:30 P.M. Information: 222-5623. GREEK FOLKLORIC FESTIVAL Hundreds of miles may separate Greece and Cyprus in the eastern Mediterranean, but in New York, expatriate Greeks and Cypriots live together in Astoria, Queens. The music, dance and customs of these two cultures will be featured in the fifth National Heritage Folkloric Festival sponsored by the Cypriot Emigrants' Cultural Organization this weekend at Bohemian Hall, 29-19 24th Avenue in Astoria. Popular contemporary music from both countries will be performed tonight through Sunday by Chrispos Savva, a violinist, and Stavrinos Meletiou, who plays a string instrument known as the laoutu. Microcosmos, a Greek folk-music band, performs tonight and Sunday at 8. A movie about Messina and a one-act Cypriot play called ''George Comes to Astoria'' will also be presented tonight, and tomorrow a program about Cyprus will be followed by a mock village wedding. The hours will be 7 to 11 tonight, 4 to 11 P.M tomorrow and 7 to 11 P.M. Sunday. Admission is free. Information: (718) 274-4925 or (718) 626-7896. SATURDAY CHAMBER MUSIC IN CHURCH An upstate venue for music, the former Rhinecliff Methodist Church near Rhinebeck, N.Y., reopens Saturday with an 8 P.M. concert by a string trio from the Chelsea Chamber Ensemble. The bluestone church, built in 1859, has been transformed into an intimate, 150-seat concert hall that will be the site for periodic chamber music and other performances loosely grouped under the rubric Bluestone Concerts. Saturday's program by the ensemble includes works by Dvorak and Prokofiev. The hall is at Orchard and Corning Streets in Rhinecliff, a hamlet two miles west of Rhinebeck; tickets are $7. Information: (914) 876-3833. DANCE ALONG THE HUDSON Hudson River views and magnificent lawns and gardens are the backdrops for an afternoon of dance performances Saturday at Wave Hill, the park and cultural center above the Hudson in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. Marta Renzi and the Project Company, a post-modern dance group, will present several works on the grounds of the 28-acre former estate. The performances begin at 4:30 P.M., but visitors who arrive early can explore the gardens and Wave Hill's galleries, which are open from 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. ''Perceiving the Garden: Robert Irwin at Wave Hill'' is an exhibition on view outdoors and indoors at the Glyndor Gallery, and a small show called ''Japanese Iris'' is at the Wave Hill Gallery. Tickets for the performance are $9, which includes park admission. Wave Hill is at West 249th Street and Independence Avenue. Information: 549-3200. 'OPERETTA TONIGHT' The American musical theater has many devotees, yet few professional choral organizations have repertories devoted to the music of operettas and Broadway and Hollywood musicals. The National Chorale, directed by Martin Josman, is one such group, and its 24 members will sing at Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center at 8 P.M. Saturday in a program called ''Operetta Tonight.'' Highlights of the free concert include songs from ''Her Regiment'' and ''Sweethearts'' by Victor Herbert; Sigmund Romberg's ''New Moon,'' ''Desert Song'' and his little-known 1931 collaboration with Oscar Hammerstein 2d, ''Children of Dreams,'' and Rudolph Friml's ''Vagabond King.'' Running commentary on the works will be offered by Frederick Roffman, an operetta expert who is writing a Herbert biography. The concert is part of the chorale's summer series of 27 outdoor performances throughout the metropolitan area. Information: 333-5333. SUNDAY MOZART AND THE DANCE On Sunday, dances set to two Mozart compositions are part of the evening's Mostly Mozart proceedings. In a program that also includes excerpts from Rameau's ''Fetes d'Hebe'' and Rebel's ''Caracteres de la Danse,'' the New York Baroque Dance Company, under the direction of Catherine Turocy, will perform to Mozart's ballet music ''Les Petits Riens.'' James Richman will conduct the chamber ensemble Concert Royal. In the second part of the program, the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company will offer ''Concerto 622,'' set to the Mozart Clarinet Concerto in A (K. 622), and a new work called ''Of My Soul,'' set to Bach's Cantata No. 78. Ransom Wilson will conduct the Solisti New York and the Mostly Mozart Festival Chorus; Todd Levy is the soloist for the clarinet work. Tickets for ''Mozart and the Dance'' at 8 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall are $25, $18 and $12. The program will be repeated July 23. Information: 874-2424. DOWNTOWN WALKING TOUR Despite the recent tides of gentrification, the Lower East Side remains a living monument to Eastern European and Jewish immigration. This rich history can be discovered on a four-and-a-half-hour walking tour of the area beginning at 10:30 A.M. Sunday at Straus Square, at Canal and Essex Streets. The tour will include a talk about immigration history at the Eldridge Street Synagogue by Gerard Wolfe, the author of ''The Synagogues of New York's Lower East Side'' and a historian of New York City. The tour's fee, $15, will support restoration of the synagogue. Information: 777-4747. Another of New York's better-known historian-tour guides, Herman Storick, and his assistant, Bernard Cohen, will also lead two downtown walking tours on Sunday. New York Walk-About, Mr. Storick's company, offers two-hour historical introductions to the central portion of Greenwich Village at 11 A.M. and 2 P.M. The tours, which cost $6, meet at the southwest corner of Waverly Place and Avenue of the Americas. Information: 582-2015 or (914) 834-5388.

title: Moses Loses After Slip
description: Edwin Moses fell on a rain-slicked track today at the Paris International meet and lost a 400-meter hurdles race for the second time in six weeks.

title: Leetch Report Denied
description: The attorney for Brian Leetch denied a report published yesterday in The New Haven Register that the Rangers' No. 1 draft choice in the June 1986 draft had turned down a four-year $1 million offer from the National Hockey League team in order to play for the United States Olympic team next winter in Calgary.

title: The Crickets In Tribute to Buddy Holly
description: WHAT'S summer without a few crickets? In this case, we're talking about the Crickets - the musicians who backed Buddy Holly on his hit records and concert appearances. This weekend, the Crickets are playing a ''Tribute to Buddy Holly'' to open Summerpier, the South Street Seaport Museum's annual summer series of free outdoor concerts.

title: Fast Action Urged for Indian Museum
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan sharply criticized New York City officials yesterday for not moving quickly enough to find a new home for the Museum of the American Indian. He warned that unless a suitable location was found soon, New York might lose another priceless resource.

title: Economic Scene; UNCERTAINTIES OF TRADE GAP
description: PROPHECIES are based on ''imperfect knowledge,'' Oliver Wendell Holmes, the jurist, once observed. Yet ''every year, if not every day, we have to wager our salvation upon some prophecy,'' he said. And prophecies don't always come true.

title: NEKOOSA TO ACQUIRE OWENS-ILLINOIS UNIT
description: The Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the forest products holdings of Owens-Illinois Inc. for $1.15 billion.

title: The Message and the Medium of Oliver North; Such Bias!
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Summer Nationals, Belated End to a Contest
description: Players arriving here this afternoon for the summer national championships of the American Contract Bridge League found that post-mortems to one championship had been completed while other battles were in progress.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the withdrawal of Councilman Joseph F. Lisa's nomination as chairman of the New York City Council's health committee carried an erroneous and incomplete account of Mr. Lisa's reaction. In saying ''That's unfortunate,''

title: South Korea's Chief Should Go Now
description: LEAD: President Chun Doo Hwan's decision to accept certain reforms advocated by the opposition is a welcome beginning toward restoring democracy in South Korea. But agreement on the general principles of democratization, including selection of the next president through direct elections, is much easier than refining the principles into specific changes.

title: Klezmer in the Park
description: The Andy Statman Klezmer Orchestra, led by Mr. Statman on clarinet, is to play a free concert Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Central Park Band Shell, in the middle of the park at 72d Street. It is part of New York City's Summerstage series (860-1335).

title: WASHINGTON TALK: The Environment; Of Trees and Laws and Bad Raps
description: As F. Henry Habicht 2d sees it, the Reagan Administration's enforcement of the environmental laws, like Rodney Dangerfield, doesn't get enough respect.

title: The Issue Is Policy
description: A cartoon in Le Monde shows Rear Adm. John Poindexter on the tube saying earnestly, ''And I hid everything from the President.'' President Reagan, watching with delight, says, ''Oh thank you, that's really nice of you.''

title: Candidates Combat Summer Doldrums
description: The seven candidates seeking their parties' nominations in primary elections next Tuesday in the Fourth Congressional District are fighting summer more than each other.

title: U.S. Clears 2 Kuwaiti Ships
description: The United States Coast Guard today cleared the first two Kuwaiti oil tankers to fly American flags and be protected by American naval forces in the Persian Gulf. The White House said all that remained was for President Reagan to approve a date for beginning the convoy operations. The Administration has vowed to protect 11 Kuwaiti tankers from attack by Iranian forces.

title: Listen to the Needs of Deaf Children
description: LEAD: The Congressional Commission on the Education of the Deaf, having held hearings in five cities and with expert testimony planned later this summer, hopes to issue final recommendations later this year. Those recommendations must be submitted to Congress and the President by February. The commission should listen to the deaf community and recommend the revitalizing of residential schools for the deaf.

title: Justice Dept. Inquiry Said to Focus on St Germain
description: Representative Fernand J. St Germain, Democrat of Rhode Island, has become the subject of a criminal investigation by the Justice Department into large entertainment bills paid by a prominent lobbyist for the savings and loan industry, thrift industry lobbyists and lawyers close to the case said today.

title: BROADWAY
description: After Jackie Mason, Mort Sahl

title: BRIEF WORDS ON BEING 'GENERALLY AWARE'
description: Admiral Poindexter was questioned during yesterday's session about his conversations with high Administration officials in the period leading up to his resignation Nov. 25, 1986.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Manu Dibango, Beacon Theater, 74th and Broadway (399-4444 or 496-7070). When Manu Dibango, a West African saxophonist and band leader, played at the Apollo Theater in the early 70's, hot on the heels of his international pop hit ''Soul Makossa,'' he brought a formidable African funk band, with two bassists nailing down the bottom and rhythms that churned up an implacable groove. His recent recordings have been slicker, but the man always runs a tight ship, and his first New York concert in years promises to be memorable. Show time is 8 tonight; tickets are $18 in advance, $20 at the door.

title: Santa Fe Sale
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Robert McKee Construction business to the Jacobs Engineering Group Inc. The company did not disclose the price, but it said the unit had $274 million in revenue in 1986. The move was seen as Santa Fe's first step in its corporate reorganization, which was announced June 30 when the Interstate Commerce Commission refused to reconsider its rejection of the planned merger of Santa Fe's two railroads.

title: Olympic Hall Inductees
description: Two men and two women were inducted into the United States Olympic Hall of Fame in Durham, N.C., yesterday. The men were the former heavyweight boxing champion Floyd Patterson, the 1952 Olympic middleweight gold medalist, and Dr. Leroy T. Walker, The Athletics Congress president, who coached the 1976 United States track and field team. The women, selected by a poll of national sportscasters and sportswriters, were both swimmers.

title: Transamerica Income Soars
description: The Transamerica Corporation said today that its net income for the second quarter rose 53.6 percent, to $106 million, or $1.37 a share, from $69 million, or 88 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues rose 25 percent, to $1.95 billion, from $1.56 billion.

title: Dance: The Bolshoi's 'Giselle'
description: THE Bolshoi Ballet's brand-new production of ''Giselle'' is easier to admire than to love. Those who think they will be seeing the by-now traditional Bolshoi 1950's staging, with its memorably unabashed emotionalism, are in for a surprise.

title: Correction
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about changes in the capital gains tax in New York State misstated some rates. Under laws in effect through 1986, a New York City resident in the maximum bracket paid a Federal capital gains tax of 20 percent and additional state and city taxes that brought the effective rate to 25.93 percent. The article also misstated the top combined state and city rate, which now is 12.35 percent.

title: Beirut Holds Army Mechanic In Prime Minister's Slaying
description: A Lebanese Army mechanic was charged today in connection with the assassination of Prime Minister Rashid Karami last month.

title: Polls Find an Increase In Support for Contras
description: The American public is now about evenly split on whether to provide military aid for the contras, according to two national polls taken after Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testified in Washington and strongly urged such aid.

title: The War on Verbosity
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said yesterday that he had been making progress in his campaign to cut down on the bureaucratic and verbose language in Government communication. Memorandums reaching his office these days, he said, are rarely longer than a page or two. And as for use of the passive tense - a common bureaucratic crutch - that has been virtually eliminated, he said. ''We don't have stuff like 'It was decided,' '' Mr. Baldrige said, hitting a colloquial note.

title: Kano Journal; A Nigerian Shame: The Agony of the Child Bride
description: With a shy gesture, Rahinatu Umoru drew a veil across her face and, in the soft tones of her native Hausa language, unveiled the hidden agony of a Moslem child bride.

title: Colonel North Buttons
description: Two local entrepreneurs, Frank and Barbara Enten, say they have been doing nicely making and selling buttons that show Colonel North being sworn in before the Congressional committees and bear the legend: ''An American hero. Duty, honor, country.''

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: FROM the outside, Rio Mar looks like a frayed Latin shots-and-beer bar catering to butchers in the old West Side wholesale meat district. ''It's a great place,'' a usually sensible friend assured me. ''Nobody knows about it.'' With more than a little skepticism, I gave it a try.

title: City as Sculpture Garden: Seeing the New and Daring
description: THE outdoor sculpture season has begun to reflect the state of sculpture in general. The amount of outdoor sculpture continues to increase: there are currently four large shows. But as the cost of living and working in Manhattan continues to rise, more outdoor sculpture is being made and exhibited elsewhere: this season there is a significant shift toward other boroughs, particularly Queens. Thus, while this is a very good moment for sculpture, hardly anyone restricted to Manhattan would know it.

title: Irish Music Festival
description: More than 30 Irish and Irish-American singers, musicians and dancers are to take part in the annual Irish Music Festival tomorrow at 1 P.M. at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston, S.I. Among those to appear are Donal Lunny, a singer and song writer; Paddy Glackin, a fiddler; the Irish Tradition, a group from Baltimore; Christy Barry, a flutist and tin whistler, and James Keane, an accordionist. Tickets are $7.50 today or $10 tomorrow; those under 12, free. Information: 757-3318.

title: The Most Tragic Victims of AIDS: Thousands of Youngsters
description: In a sunny corner of a day-care center, the teachers gathered the children together, made sure everyone had a lap to sit on and told them that Carlos had died. The boys and girls looked at pictures of their 2-year-old classmate, talked of how they would miss him and asked whether the same thing would happen to them.

title: New York Plans to End Concrete Pact
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city plans to end its year-old contract with a private concrete company and seek a new supplier to start producing reduced-cost concrete to break a monopoly in Manhattan.

title: The Windmills of Eastern Long Island
description: Don Quixote tilted at them, van Gogh vividly captured them on canvas, and eastern Long Islanders are restoring and preserving them - windmills.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Political Memo; The Litmus Test: Use It or Confine It to the Lab?
description: If candidates want applause at either Democratic or Republican functions these days, all they have to do is mention the Strategic Defense Initiative or the Nicaraguan contras.

title: New York City Pleased With Sale
description: The $600 million competitive sale of New York City revenue anticipation notes yesterday left city officials pleased with the results.

title: Quartet in the Garden
description: A quartet of musicians - Paul Zukovsky, a violinist; Chris Bosco, a clarinetist; Joshua Gordon, a cellist, and Candace Bawcombe, a pianist -is to perform works by Satie and Messiaen tonight and tomorrow evening at 7:30 in the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art (11 West 53d Street). The performances are free. Information: 708-9850.

title: Offbeat Antics, All in Serious Fun
description: IS it outrageous? Imaginative? Unexpected? Then it's probably part of Serious Fun!, a distinctly offbeat festival that begins tonight at Alice Tully Hall and runs through Aug. 2.

title: Charles Stewart Dies; An Ex-Bank Executive
description: Charles J. Stewart, the first chairman of Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died Tuesday of cardiac failure at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 89 years old and also lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: North Errs on Leaks by Congress
description: LEAD: To justify the Administration's decision to hide the Iran-contra operations from Congress and to lie to keep them secret, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North in his testimony presented a tale of rampant leaks in Congress along with a Congressional attitude of hostility to covert actions. Add to these horrifying assertions the supposedly unwieldy and unsafe apparatus that exists for notifying Congress of covert actions, and no wonder the

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: An Infant Cinema

title: C.I.A. Taped Poindexter
description: Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter was secretly tape-recorded by the C.I.A. last year when he called William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, during a visit to Central America, according to testimony today in the Iran-contra hearings.

title: MONEY FUND ASSETS RISE
description: Assets of the nation's 386 money market mutual funds increased $948.4 million, to $238.56 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 96 institutional funds increased $1.19 billion, to $66.24 billion. Assets of the 200 general-purpose funds decreased by $244.2 million, to $67.41 billion. The 90 broker-dealer funds increased $5.7 million, to $104.90 billion.

title: Afghan Diplomat Accused Of Auto Attack on Woman
description: A high-ranking Afghan diplomat on his way to buy an air-conditioner at an appliance store in Queens has been accused of ramming a woman in a dispute over a parking space.

title: Colonel North in Movies
description: A popular topic of discussion in town these days is which actors should be cast in the movie or television mini-series that is almost certain to follow the Iran-contra affair.

title: Networks Now Rotate Coverage of Hearings
description: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair will be televised live beginning at 9 A.M. on the CBS television network under the new network rotation plan. The hearings will also be televised on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on some local affiliates of PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service, including Channel 13 in New York.

title: A WALL ST. SECTOR BLOSSOMS
description: On Wall Street, where quick action now rules over measured deliberation, and a meritocracy has replaced the gentleman's club, one of the last guardians of the old style has finally joined the fray.

title: Four Vivien Leigh Films In '3 Beauties' Festival
description: Four Vivien Leigh films will be shown this weekend as part of the seven-week retrospective featuring the work of Miss Leigh, Jean Harlow and Marilyn Monroe. The festival, called ''Three Beauties,'' is running at the Regency Theater, Broadway and 67th Street, At today's 8 P.M. screening of the 1945 film ''Caesar and Cleopatra,'' the director Anthony Harvey, who was an actor in the film, will appear. Completing today's double feature will be the 1936 feature ''Fire Over England.'' On Sunday, the films will be ''Storm in a Teacup'' (1937) and ''Sidewalks of London'' (1938).

title: Plight of Homeowners
description: To the Editor:

title: Art: 'Iliazd and the Illustrated Book' at the Modern
description: IN a quiet way, the Museum of Modern Art is doing precisely what it ought to do in mounting an exhibition called ''Iliazd and the Illustrated Book.'' Not only does it have an echo out of all proportion to its size, but it also introduces to the museum's huge public a man who lived the adventure of our century to the full.

title: DEATH TOLL IN CAMPSITE FLOOD IN FRANCE COULD SURPASS 35
description: Rescue workers today put the death toll at 30 in a flash flood that devastated a vacation compsite here Tuesday.

title: Security Pacific Posts Big Loss
description: The Security Pacific Corporation said today that, as expected, it had lost $172.4 million in the second quarter. This was the banking company's first loss since it began reporting financial results in 1974.

title: Gooden Starts the Mets' Great Chase
description: The Mets, nine and a half games down with 75 to go, began the great chase last night with flares and rockets and a seven-hitter by Dwight Gooden that buried the Cincinnati Reds, 9-0.

title: The Message and the Medium of Oliver North; The Other Telegrams
description: To the Editor:

title: Film: 'La Gran Fiesta'
description: IT'S 1942 and a big night in San Juan, P.R., where the casino is being turned over to the United States Navy. Among the guests at the farewell party is Jose Manuel, the son of Don Manolo Gonzalez. Jose Manuel's marriage to Rita, the daughter of Don Miguel de la Torre, is about to be announced. But Jose Manuel loves Raquel and has no sooner given the bad news to Rita than he learns that his father, Don Manolo, has been falsely accused by his partner, Don Antonio Jimenez, of being involved in anti-American activities. Jose Manuel can save his father from the clutches of ambitious District Attorney Vazquez only by getting the influential Don Miguel to intercede on the family's behalf. But that means giving up Raquel and marrying Rita. What will Jose Manuel do?

title: Clyde Beatty Circus Performing on L.I.
description: The bigtop of the Clyde Beatty-Cole Brothers Circus is to be up in Sayville, L.I., for performances through Sunday. More than 35 acts will be featured during the circus's stay at the Long Island Merchandise Mart, Sunrise Highway and Broadway. Shows are today at 4:30 and 8 P.M.; tomorrow at 1:30, 4:30 and 8:30 P.M. and Sunday at 1:30 and 4:30 P.M.

title: Comes a Knock: The Developers Want Your Yard
description: Up and down these suburban streets the friendly developers go, knocking on doors. They want to buy three or four nice homes in a row, tear them down and squeeze in a condominium. It's very profitable.

title: Richardson Plays But Team Forfeits
description: The Jersey Jammers forfeited their United States Basketball League game against the Staten Island Stallions tonight for using Micheal Ray Richardson, who was under suspension for fighting.

title: Mexico Challenging U.S. on Drugs
description: The Mexican Government is seeking a restructuring and broadening of agreements and programs it maintains with the United States to combat drug trafficking, according to Mexican and American officials here and in Washington.

title: Dance: Merrill Ashley and John Meehan at the Pillow
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, which since the 1930's has been America's most eclectic summer dance festival, turned its attention to ballet Wednesday night when two stars appeared as guests and a young ensemble displayed its versatility.

title: Eight Are Injured in Fire At Midtown Welfare Hotel
description: Eight people were injured, two of them critically, when a fire broke out yesterday in a welfare hotel in midtown Manhattan.

title: The Testimony: On the Boland Amendment and the President
description: In his second day of testimony yesterday before the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair, Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser, was asked about compliance with the Boland Amendment and other matters. Here are excerpts from his testimony, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: The Message and the Medium of Oliver North
description: To the Editor:

title: Racing Notebook; Manila May Get Next Test on the Dirt
description: How good is Manila?

title: Gridlock on Capitol Hill
description: Attending House and Senate hearings is an essential part of life for many Washingtonians. In fact, so many hearings are held that scheduling problems sometimes arise.

title: FINAL ROCKET PLAN IS CHOSEN BY NASA
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that it had chosen its final design for the space shuttle's new rockets and will heat O ring seals rather than use new materials to prevent leaks in cold weather.

title: Hill's Regrets
description: For Bob Hill, whom Rick Pitino has replaced as Knick coach, the announcement last Monday was bittersweet. Hill said he was ''happy for Rick,'' but he added that the Knicks ''haven't solved any problems.''

title: Rested Bakkers Plot Moves From Yacht
description: Far from the PTL television ministry in South Carolina, Jim and Tammy Bakker have spent the last few days here plotting their next moves from a different perspective: the deck of a yacht owned by their lawyer, Melvin Belli.

title: Walters Hopeful on Hostages
description: Vernon A. Walters, the United States representative at the United Nations, said today that he was optimistic that his recent discussions with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria would result in some movement affecting the fate of hostages held in Lebanon.

title: From Syracuse's Hope to an Indictment
description: He was this city's hope, a stubborn Democrat who overcame the odds and rose beyond Syracuse to become a spokesman for all of America's mayors.

title: RUSSELL P. WESTERHOFF
description: Russell P. Westerhoff, a former president and chairman of Ford, Bacon & Davis, an engineering, construction and management consulting firm, died of cancer Sunday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 82 years old and lived in Ridgewood.

title: Man Acquitted of Killing Officer
