description: A black man who admitted killing a white police officer and wounding a second was acquitted today of attempted murder and manslaughter.

title: Grand Jury to Look Into PTL
description: A Federal judge in North Carolina has ordered a grand jury to investigate the management of the PTL television ministry under its founder and former president, Jim Bakker, according to a published report.

title: B.F. Goodrich Lifts Profit 61%
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company reported a 61 percent increase in its second-quarter earnings, bolstered by gains in its core chemical, aerospace and defense units. Net income totaled $38.3 million, or $1.54 a share, up from $23.8 million, or $1.02 a share, a year before.

title: EX-MAYOR INDICTED IN SYRACUSE BRIBES
description: Lee Alexander, a Democrat who ruled Syracuse as Mayor for 16 years while earning a national reputation as a spokesman for the nation's cities, was indicted today on charges that he masterminded a scheme that brought him $1.5 million in kickbacks from city contractors.

title: U.S. FEARS SOVIET IMPERILS A SUMMIT BY STAND ON ARMS
description: Administration officials, frustrated and disappointed by recent Soviet attitudes toward arms control talks, say prospects for a fall meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, are fading.

title: Claudio Arrau, Pianist
description: The pianist Claudio Arrau is to be the soloist in a performance of Beethoven's Concerto in E flat with the Waterloo Festival Orchestra tomorrow evening at 8:30 at Waterloo Village in Stanhope, N.J. Gerard Schwarz conducts the program, which also includes Ibert's ''Escales'' and Piston's Fourth Symphony. Tickets are $10 to $17.50. Information and directions: (201) 347-4700.

title: Jim Morris Hails the Chief, Blithely
description: Standing behind a podium affixed with an undersized replica of the Presidential seal, Jim Morris, Ronald Reagan impersonator, is holding his nightly press conference in the Ballroom, a cabaret in Chelsea. Sucking in his lips and arching his eyebrows while narrowing his eyes to a grandfatherly twinkle, the 30-year-old comedian adds 40 years to his appearance. And when he speaks, his kindly, halting wheeze is indistinguishable from that of the President.

title: Muirfield Offers No Defense
description: Without the natural protection of strong winds off the Firth of Forth, Muirfield was defenseless today. Rodger Davis of Australia came within a shot of the British Open 18-hole record as he took a three-shot lead in the first round of the 116th Open.

title: ZAYRE TO TAKE BIG WRITE-OFF
description: In an unusual move, the Zayre Corporation, one of the nation's largest discounters, said it would take a $40 million write-off in the current quarter to cover markdowns and ''competitive repricing'' planned for its major division, the 340 Zayre discount stores.

title: Film: 'Eat the Peach,' Motorcyclists' Whimsy
description: PETER ORMROD'S ''Eat the Peach'' is a fictional film, but it's based on the kind of true story no one could ever invent. Mr. Ormrod, who formerly worked in television, came across a man named Connie Kiernan who had brought his dream to life in his own backyard, and taken his inspiration from ''Roustabout,'' the Elvis Presley movie. Mr. Kiernan, like Elvis in that film, was fascinated with the Wall of Death, this being a cylindrical track for motorcyclists who like to do their riding horizontally. There amid the car parts, the chickens and stray cats beside his house, he had to have one of his very own.

title: AIDS Is Focus of Koch Church Talk
description: Mayor Koch warned a gathering of black Baptist church leaders in Brooklyn yesterday that the burden of AIDS will fall most heavily on members of minority groups. He urged his audience to resist any effort to quarantine or discriminate against victims of the deadly illness.

title: Man Held in Aliens' Deaths
description: A man being held in Sonora, Mexico, will be charged with negligent homicide and smuggling undocumented farm workers out of Mexico in connection with a desert trek by 25 men and boys that left three dead, a Mexican prosecutor said today. The man, Manuel Partida Beltran, allegedly accepted $350 to $400 from each emigrant for setting up a 50-mile route for them from Los Vidrios, Sonora, to Aztec, Ariz., and then left them ''without food, without medicine, with only enough water for four hours.''

title: INSIDE
description: British Airlines to Merge British Air is to take over a rival, strengthening its position against the huge American airlines formed by mergers. But some discount fares could be lost. Page D1. Takeover String Continues Kohlberg, Kravis, which has spent $30 billion on companies, offered to buy Jim Walter, a builder of low-cost houses, for $2.03 billion. Page D1. NOW: Gains and Losses As the National Organization for Women convenes for the 21st time, millions of women take its ideals as a matter of course. Page A10.

title: A Wilderness Ramble in Brooklyn
description: Huge concrete slabs rest amid the tall reeds, eerie reminders of a long-ago plan to transform the south Brooklyn waterfront into a great harbor. Seagulls perch on partially submerged wood pilings where a 17th-century grist mill once stood. And, as children play on the ballfields north of Avenue U, an occasional speedboat pulls into the shallow, freshwater creek that bisects the wetlands of Marine Park.

title: The Message and the Medium of Oliver North; Reminded of a Song
description: To the Editor:

title: The Message and the Medium of Oliver North; Support and Believe
description: To the Editor:

title: Pratt & Whitney In Norway Deal
description: Pratt & Whitney, the American jet engine maker, and four Norwegian companies have signed a letter of intent to buy the jet engine division of Kongsberg Vaapenfabrikk, the financially and politically troubled state arms maker, the Norwegian Government said. Pratt & Whitney, a division of the United Technologies Corporation, would probably have a 20 percent interest in a new company, to be called Norsk Jetmotor A/S, with the Norwegian state holding a 30 percent stake.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
No. 2 Officer Quits Continental Illinois
description: LEAD: William S. Ogden, the No. 2 official at the Continental Illinois Corporation formally announced his resignation yesterday.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: NEW YORK woke briefly but energetically from its July social torpor this week, mostly to celebrate the French national holiday Bastille Day, which fell on Tuesday.

title: PHILIP MORRIS NET RISES 26.3%
description: The Philip Morris Companies yesterday reported a 26.3 percent increase in second-quarter earnings and announced a $1 billion stock buyback.

title: Xerox Bases Campaign On Documents Theme
description: Xerox will break its first corporate ad campaign in a couple of years on Saturday, during the coverage of the British Open golf tournament on the ABC-TV network. Then the print phase will start on Tuesday in The Wall Street Journal. The advertising will introduce the new theme line, ''We document the world.''

title: F.C.C. Freezes Channel Allocations
description: The Federal Communications Commission announced today a freeze in allocations of television channels in 30 major metropolitan areas until it could study whether to update its 46-year-old technical standards for television.

title: A Jersey Couple's Anguish in a Right-to-Die Case
description: Murray Putzer has been sitting in his home in West Caldwell, N.J., this week, watching the Iran-contra hearings on television. He is also slowly starving to death.

title: East German to Visit Bonn; Trip Reflects Shift by Soviet
description: A marked improvement in ties between Moscow and Bonn has set the stage for a milestone official visit to West Germany in September by Erich Honecker, the East German leader, according to West German officials and Western diplomats.

title: Major Setback to Reagan and Party Seen
description: In the view of a variety of politicians, political scientists and strategists from both parties, Ronald Reagan's Presidency will remain damaged for the rest of his term - and his party weakened - despite Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter's testimomy that the President was unaware of the diversion of Iran arms profits to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: CHILDREN WITH AIDS
description: The most pathetic victims of AIDS are the children, most marked at birth with a disease that both kills and stigmatizes.

title: TOUGHER AIRPORT SECURITY ORDERED
description: Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole ordered the Federal Aviation Administration today to get tougher with airlines if lax security is found at airport passenger checkpoints, imposing fines when necessary.

title: Women's Movement, Its Ideals Accepted, Faces Subtler Issues
description: As the 21st meeting of the National Organization for Women starts in Philadelphia today, NOW and other feminist organizations seem to be at an ebb, torn internally over difficult new issues and struggling to hold on to gains already made.

title: INDIA'S MILD NEW PRESIDENT: Ramaswamy Venkataraman
description: Ramaswamy Venkataraman, who emerged today with an overwhelming victory in India's presidential elections, is a veteran of India's independence movement and a skillful negotiator who won his country's biggest loan from the International Monetary Fund.

title: Punish Pakistan's Perfidy on the Bomb
description: The arrest of a Pakistani trying to violate U.S. export laws shows once again how tenaciously Pakistan pursues the bomb. It also prompts a familiar chorus of State Department lamentations about the apparent violation, Pakistani protestations of an innocent, peaceful nuclear program and U.S. demands for good Pakistani behavior from now on.

title: Shero to Coach In Netherlands
description: Rather than continue to offer dispassionate observations from a far removed radio booth, Fred Shero will return to the excitement and pressures of hockey up close, when he goes back to the bench this coming season. After a seven-year absence, Shero is resuming the profession that gained him fame and a good deal of notoriety.

title: Are Short Skirts At Home at Work?
description: As they try on short skirts, often for the first time in years, working women say they are asking themselves hard questions. The first questions usually concern how they look in short skirts. The next are about how and where to wear them.

title: Storm Kills 68 in South Korea
description: Rescue workers hunted for victims today after a typhoon provoked floods, mudslides and stormy seas that killed at least 68 people and left 101 missing along the southern coast.

title: North Lawyers Act to Appeal Supoena by Iran Grand Jury
description: Lawyers for Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North moved today to appeal a Federal judge's order that he comply with a grand jury subpoena obtained by the independent counsel investigating the Iran-Contra affair.

title: Losey's 'Don Giovanni'
description: Joseph Losey's film ''Don Giovanni'' is to be shown tomorrow at 5 P.M. at the Pepsico Summerfare festival on the campus of the State University College at Purchase. Tickets are $5. Information and directions: (914) 253-5949.

title: Earthworks
description: Bill Bruford, a percussionist, is to lead his band Earthworks tonight and tomorrow at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street at Mercer Street (228-6300). Shows are at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $12.50.

title: The Message and the Medium of Oliver North; It Can Happen Here
description: To the Editor:

title: Music on the Hudson
description: A all-Tchaikovsky program, conducted by Imre Pallo and including Diana Kacso, a pianist, as soloist, is to be presented by the Music on the Hudson festival tomorrow evening at 8:30 at Lyndhurst in Tarrytown. Tickets are $5. Information and directions: (914) 631-7766.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JULY 17, 1987
description: International

title: Financial Firm In Britain Sold
description: British and Commonwealth Holdings P.L.C., with interests in transport, hotels and finance, said today that it was buying Mercantile House Holdings for $:490 million, or $800 million.

title: Chamber Orchestra
description: The St. Bartholomew's Chamber Orchestra is to present works by Handel and Bach Sunday at 3 P.M. at St. Bartholomew's Church (109 East 50th Street). Tickets are $5. Information: 751-1616, ext. 226, 227.Z

title: Ambulance Proposals Released
description: Mayor Koch yesterday released recommendations from a draft report by a task force that has been studying slow response time and other problems within the city's emergency ambulance system. The move came on the same day that one of the members of the task force, City Council President Andrew J. Stein, resigned, complaining that the group had been inactive.

title: 12 Missing in Chile Flood
description: Flood waters have swept away a bridge north of Santiago, taking with it 12 people and raising to 16 the toll of missing people in five days of heavy rains in central Chile, according to the police. They said Wednesday night that a helicopter saved two people when the bridge collapsed at La Calera.

title: Executive Cited In Fraud Scheme In Mass Mailing
description: The president of a major mass mailing and bill collection company in New York City was accused yesterday of defrauding the Postal Service of more than $5 million in postage over 10 years.

title: Japan and 'Star Wars'
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and Ambassador Nobuo Matsunaga of Japan are concluding an agreement on participation by Japanese business and industry in the Strategic Defense Initiative.

title: U.S. Seeks the Deportation Of Accused Auschwitz Guard
description: The Justice Department instituted deportation proceedings today against a Massachusetts man who, the Government says, served as an Auschwitz concentration camp guard during World War II.

title: Dream Tax
description: Who says state lotteries are harmless fun? There's evidence to the contrary in a sobering new study by Charles Clotfelder and Phillip Cook, analysts working with the nonprofit National Bureau of Economic Research in Cambridge, Mass. Lotteries are a boom industry, they report. Betting has quadrupled since 1975, reaching $88 per person, or more than $20 billion nationwide. On average, about 40 percent of the money goes to government.

title: Filipinos File a $22.6 Billion Suit Against the Marcoses for Damages
description: The Philippine Government filed a $22.6 billion civil suit today against former President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his family, seeking damages suffered by Filipinos from what the suit called ''plunder of the nation's wealth.''

title: Japanese Agree to U.S. Demands On Controlling Technology Sales
description: Japan, stunned by American fury over the sale of sensitive technology to the Soviet Union by the Toshiba Machine Company, agreed today to demands that Tokyo clamp down on exports of such equipment to hostile countries, the Commerce Department said.

title: Film: 'Robocop,' Police Drama With Peter Weller
description: IF it's violence you're after, ''Robocop,'' now showing at the National and other theaters, gives full value. In his first American movie, Paul Verhoeven, a Dutch director (''Soldier of Orange''), doesn't let the furiously futuristic plot get in the way of the flaming explosions, shattering glass and hurtling bodies. Everything's constantly on the move in this movie full of camera tricks and computer tricks; if you glance away, chances are you'll miss somebody being blown away. Fortunately, the victims of the hand-held cannons that everybody shoots at everybody else take so long dying that you have plenty of time to enjoy their pain. When a baddie goes crashing into a toxic-waste tank, he not only staggers out looking hideous, but staggers on and on, getting hideouser and hideouser.

title: Raider Arrested
description: Jerry Robinson, a linebacker for the Los Angeles Raiders since 1985 and a former all-pro with the Philadelphia Eagles, was arrested for an investigation of driving under the influence of drugs early yesterday after a brief high-speed chase by sheriff's deputies, a police spokesman in Los Angeles said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JULY 17, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-8

title: 'The Doctors Wilde,' 2 Veterinarians
description: OH, those warm, wonderful married veterinarians! You wouldn't believe their crazy life. If it's not a tiger with a dental problem, it's a sea lion with no appetite. Mostly, though, on ''The Doctors Wilde'' it's an abused elephant named Katie. Someone wants to put her away. Will this happen? You can find out on CBS at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: In Union Square Park, Potluck al Fresco
description: In the shade of the leafy green trees that tower over Union Square Park, 25 New Yorkers sat down to a potluck supper, as if that were perfectly normal in a place occupied until recently by drug dealers and others who tend not to bake casseroles.

title: Hart to Talk at a Calmer Time
description: Gary Hart said today that he would discuss the collapse of his Presidential campaign ''when tempers have cooled and people are a little more objective about it.''

title: Solomonic Quartet
description: The Solomonic Quartet - Ahmed Abdullah on trumpet, Chico Freeman on saxophone, Wilber Morris on bass and Charles Moffett on drums - is to perform tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

title: Sidney Scheuer Dies; Ex-Textile Executive
description: Sidney H. Scheuer, former chairman of the board of the Scheuer Management Corporation and chairman of the National Committee for an Effective Congress, died last night at Roosevelt Hospital of injuries he suffered during a burglary in his Manhattan apartment last week. He was 94 years old.

title: JEFFREY S. CHILDS
description: Jeffrey S. Childs, a former Manhattan antiques dealer and art collector, died Sunday at the New York University Medical Center of complications caused by AIDS. He lived in Manhattan and was 41 years old.

title: KOHLBERG, KRAVIS BIDS FOR JIM WALTER
description: The Jim Walter Corporation, one of the nation's leading builders of low-cost houses, said yesterday that it had received a surprise takeover bid for $50 a share, or $2.03 billion in cash.

title: T.S. RYAN, A LEADER IN REPUBLICAN PARTY IN CONNECTICUT, DIES
description: Theodore S. Ryan, a former Republican national committeeman who was long active in Connecticut politics and in ski area development in Colorado, died Wednesday at his home in Lakeville, Conn. He was 82 years old.

title: Opera: Sellars's 'Giovanni'
description: YOU remember Mozart's ''Don Giovanni.'' That's the opera in which the Don Juan of the slums interrupts his singing of the Champagne Aria to take a heroin hit in the arm from his pimp and connection, Leporello. Donna Anna also requires a quick needle during her ''Non mi dir'' before she can launch into the coloratura section of that aria. Elvira, a Madonna clone, rolls back and forth across the stage like a bowling ball while making a hash of ''Mi tradi.'' And you certainly will recall how Giovanni sits on a stoop outside a slum building in what may be Spanish Harlem, enjoying his last supper (a Big Mac and fries) as a big-box radio pumps out those great 18th-century dance tunes. That, of course, leads up to the famous ''Stoned Guest'' scene in which the dissolute Don is pulled down into a sewer by a small girl, playing Lolita to his Humbert Humbert.

title: Greece Says Split With U.S. On Terrorist Group Is Ended
description: A dispute between the United States and Greece over charges that Greek officials had contacts with an Arab terrorist organization was settled today, a Government spokesman said.

title: U.S. Grand Jury Indicts Nofziger In Wedtech Case
description: Lyn Nofziger, the former senior political adviser to President Reagan, was indicted today on conflict-of-interest charges related to his lobbying on behalf of the Wedtech Corporation, a Government official and others close to the investigation said.

title: A.T.&T.'s PROFITS RISE BY 41.2%
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that second-quarter profits jumped 41.2 percent, helped by gains in its long-distance telephone business and early success in controlling costs.

title: Homes Rising Near 2 Old Beach Club Sites in Bronx
description: Ever since two lively beach clubs in the Castle Hill section of the Bronx were boarded up a few seasons ago, that part of the borough - a small peninsula washed by two creeks that feed into the East River - has slipped into desolation.

title: Film: 'Ping Pong'
description: FLAVORFUL glimpses of London's Chinatown - the back alleys of restaurants, a gambling den, a traditional funeral - promise something tasty from ''Ping Pong,'' but the main dish doesn't live up to the starters.

title: Music: A New Violetta in City Opera's 'Traviata'
description: THE New York City Opera's production of ''La Traviata,'' which began its run Wednesday evening at the New York State Theater, brought to the stage an outstanding young soprano in the role of Violetta. Marilyn Mims, making her City Opera debut, sang in a strong, fresh, flexible, pleasing voice, and her performance drew long rounds of well-deserved applause.

title: Who's Giving the Signals?
description: A key question has been: Was the baserunner running on his own, or did he get a signal from the third-base coach? And if he did, was it relayed from the manager? In other words, who called the shots?

title: Art: 'Generations of Geometry,' an Abstract Show
description: ''GENERATIONS of Geometry,'' an exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art's branch at the Equitable Center, covers over 50 years and several phases of American geometric abstraction, up to and including works from 1987 by artists who have only recently started to exhibit. Organized by Cheryl Epstein, M. Christine Hunnisett and Kimmo Sarje, all Helena Rubinstein Fellows in the museum's independent study program, this exhibition is topical, to say the least, and can be seen as symptomatic of several tendencies, some more cheering than others.

title: Despite Pledge, Texas Governor Agrees to Tax Rise
description: Gov. Bill Clements, who promised in his campaign that he would not raise taxes, has endorsed a compromise $38.3 billion state budget that includes new taxes.

title: Cowboys Release Hill
description: In a move seen as part of a shake-up after a 7-9 season, the Dallas Cowboys yesterday released Tony Hill, a wide receiver. Coach Tom Landry said that Hill, a 10-year veteran, had weight problems and had failed to show up for three weigh-ins this summer.

title: Salvador's Rebels Push Hard in Capital
description: In an openly declared effort to disrupt the Government, leftist rebels and their supporters have carried out increasingly violent street demonstrations and brought a halt to public transportation here over the last four days.

title: 6 NORTHEAST STATES SUE E.P.A. OVER LACK OF ACID RAIN CURBS
description: Six Northeastern states filed suit yesterday against the Federal Environmental Protection Agency in an effort to force the agency to curb power-plant emissions that cause acid rain.

title: Russians in Israel Play to an American Audience
description: The Soviet Union's diplomatic overtures to Israel are being viewed by American officials and outside analysts as part of an effort to lessen opposition in the United States, especially among Jews, to improved relations between Washington and Moscow.

title: The Message and the Medium of Oliver North; Unanswered Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Blinder, Robinson To Appeal Ruling
description: Blinder, Robinson & Company said that it would appeal a decision by a National Association of Securities Dealers committee to seek penalties against the investment company. The penalties were sought for purported improprieties in the pricing of securities and escrow of funds, the company said.

title: CAPACITY USE IN JUNE UP SLIGHTLY
description: The nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 79.7 percent of capacity in June, up modestly from the operating rate last year, the Government reported today.

title:
Market Place;
UPDATED STUDY OF DUAL STOCKS
description: LEAD: ADVOCATES of the one-share, one-vote rule got a boost yesterday. According to an updated study by the Securities and Exchange Commission, public announcements by companies of plans to issue dual classes of stock with unequal voting rights have had significant, negative effects on their stock prices.

title: Admiral Incredible
description: The Congressional committees have many questions to ask Rear Adm. John Poindexter about his role as national security adviser in the Iran-contra affair but one question rises to the top: Why should anyone believe him?

title: Toward a Beautiful Backhand
description: It has been five years since Lu Lesser of Berkeley Heights, N.J., was presented with a flexible, narrow, straight-line, classic diamond bracelet by her husband, Mike. ''Back then, it was just a bracelet to be worn with other diamond bracelets on dressy occasions,'' Mrs. Lesser said.

title: Correction
description: A calendar of lectures, tours and exhibitions in The Home Section yesterday misstated the site of an exhibit of terra-cotta panel designs. It is at the Municipal Art Society, 457 Madison Avenue, near 50th Street.

title: Merck Net Is Up 35.7%
description: Merck & Company said today that second-quarter net income rose 35.7 percent, exceeding analysts' expectations. The company earned $235.1 million, or $1.72 a share, up from $173.2 million, or $1.23 a share, a year ago. Sales rose 23.8 percent, to $1.25 billion, from $1.01 billion.

title: Reagan Won't Comment on Admiral
description: President Reagan refused to comment today on whether he had been deceived by Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter.

title: BRITISH AIR WILL BUY BRITISH CALEDONIAN
description: British Airways announced yesterday that it would take over its smaller rival, British Caledonian Airways, to increase its already formidable position as a worldwide carrier.

title: NICARAGUAN REBELS SAY THEY WON BIGGEST VICTORY OVER SANDINISTAS
description: The Nicaraguan rebels today claimed their biggest victory in the six-year war against the Sandinista Government.

title: CONGRESS MARKS BIRTH AT FETE IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Two hundred years from the day when the framers of the Constitution reached a critical compromise that led to the founding of Congress, 200 Representatives and Senators assembled at Independence Hall today to mark that pivotal national event.

title: IRAN THREATENING TO CUT FRENCH TIES
description: The quarrel between France and Iran worsened today as the Iranian authorities threatened to break diplomatic relations unless France removed its police guard from the Iranian Embassy here and the French Government refused to do so.

title: SHEARSON EDGES UP 1.7% IN QUARTER
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers Holding Inc., in its first quarterly earnings since going public earlier this year, reported a 1.7 percent increase in net income compared with a year earlier.

title: The Message and the Medium of Oliver North; Rhetoric Can't Hide It
description: To the Editor:

title: What Criminal Justice in New York Can Learn
description: To the Editor:

title: Albany Panel Censures Housing Department
description: New York State's administration of rent guidelines is ''chaotic'' and in such disarray that tenants and landlords are denied a fair hearing of rent disputes, a State Assembly panel concluded today.

title: Bonds Gain in Quiet Trading
description: Bond prices rose slightly yesterday, bolstered by the dollar's recovery from its sharp decline on Wednesday.

title: CURRY TRYING TO REPAIR REPUTATION
description: For the nearly 10 months he was the undisputed welterweight champion, Donald Curry was widely viewed as boxing's future superstar.

title: Times Raises Dividend
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it was increasing the quarterly dividend on its class A and class B common stock by 22 percent, to 11 cents a share, from 9 cents a share, effective with the Sept. 26 payment to shareholders of record on Sept. 8.

title: Placing a Winner
description: Angel Cordero Jr., who is currently riding at Belmont Park, needed only seven victories at the beginning of the card today to reach 6,000 for his career. Cordero, fourth on the career list of winning jockeys, would be only the fourth rider in history to reach the 6,000-victory plateau. The top 10 winning riders, according to The Daily Racing Form, through last Sunday's races, except for Cordero, whose figure is current, are: $ Jockey Winners Bill Shoemaker 8,678 Laffit Pincay Jr. 6,714 Johnny Longden* 6,032 Angel Cordero Jr. 5,993 Jorge Velasquezd 5,742 Larry Snyder 5,620 Sandy Hawley 5,153 WDavid Gall 5,101 Carl Gambardella 4,811 Eddie Arcaro* 4,779 *Retired. dVictories after Feb. 28 not available because he was racing in Europe.

title: Court Appeal Halts Fund By Robins
description: A Federal court said an appeal by a stockholder committee of the A. H. Robins Company could go ahead, temporarily holding up a $15 million emergency medical fund intended to help some Dalkon Shield claimants. The order by the Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit stops Robins from putting money into a medical fund for about 1,000 women who became sterile after using the birth control device.

title: Plisetskaya to Dance With Graham Company
description: Maya Plisetskaya, the senior ballerina of the Bolshoi Ballet, Rudolf Nureyev and Mikhail Baryshnikov will perform as guest artists with the Martha Graham Dance Company at an opening-night gala Oct. 6 at the City Center.

title: Sanwa Said to Agree To Buy Brophy, Gestal
description: In a transaction that could face significant political obstacles, Sanwa Bank Ltd. has agreed in principle to buy Brophy, Gestal, Knight & Company L.P., one of the two remaining primary dealers of Treasury securities not already owned by a larger organization, sources close to the deal said yesterday. They said the price was about $75 million.

title: KEY RATES
OIL MARKETS: UP, BUT UNEASY
description: Driven by concerns that the war between Iran and Iraq could disrupt oil supplies from the Middle East, world crude oil prices have moved above $22 a barrel in volatile trading this week. However, energy experts in the United States said yesterday that the market's fears have exceeded the realistic prospects of a cutoff of crude oil supplies or even of a substantial reduction in Middle East shipments.

title: 6 Americans Killed in Salvador
description: Six Americans were killed Wednesday night when their helicopter crashed on a mission to evacuate a wounded American military adviser, an American Embassy spokesman said today.

title: Fund Transfer by Conservative Is Challenged
description: Carl R. (Spitz) Channell, the conservative fund-raiser who pleaded guilty in April to illegally soliciting contributions for the Nicaraguan rebels, last year transferred more than $40,000 from one of his political action committees to another.

title: Mattingly Blasts 8th in Six Games
description: When his batting average was so low that the first figure had actually been reduced to a zero, the suggestion was made in the Yankee clubhouse that a picture of the scoreboard be taken when Don Mattingly stepped into a batter's box because the sight may never happen again.

title: Advertising; A GLOBAL VENTURE FOR Y.&.R.
description: YOUNG & RUBICAM'S two joint ventures with foreign agencies have been merged to form a three-way venture whose other partners are Dentsu of Japan, the world's largest agency, and Paris-based Eurocom, the largest agency on the Continent. Y.&R. is America's No. 1.

title: DEAVER TRIAL DELAYED FOR MONTHS AS DEFENSE APPEALS ORDER ON JURY
description: The perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver was postponed today for at least three months after defense lawyers said they would appeal to the Supreme Court an order requiring that the jury selection be conducted in public.

title: Adventures of a Sitter
description: WHEN Elisabeth Shue started baby-sitting, she was 10 years old and made 10 cents an hour. Thirteen years have passed, and Ms. Shue is still at it.

title: ADMIRAL RECALLS NO POINTED QUERY WHEN HE RESIGNED
description: Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter testified today that when he resigned last November, neither Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d nor Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, asked him who had approved the diversion of Iran arms profits to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I said: 'Mr. President, I assume that you are aware of the paper that Ed Meese has found, that reveals a plan to transfer funds to the contras. I was generally aware of that plan, and I would like to submit my resignation.' And the President responded and said that he had great regret, and that this was in the tradition of a naval officer, of accepting responsibility.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THE industrial underbrush of far-west Chelsea, dotted with squat brick warehouses and auto repair shops, is hardly the terrain where Manhattan's fashionable night owls congregate. If Larry McIntyre keeps up the good work, they soon will, for Chelsea Central is one of the best hidden bargains I have come across this year.

title: Milbury Retires Again
description: Saying he hoped to mold minor leaguers in his own hard-working style, Mike Milbury, a Boston defenseman, announced his retirement yesterday to become coach and general manager of the Bruins' farm team in Portland, the Maine Mariners of the Amerian Hockey League.

title: Fort Hamilton Tour
description: The military history of Brooklyn is to be explored tomorrow on a Fort Hamilton walking tour sponsored by the Brooklyn Historical Society. The two-hour tour begins at 1 P.M. at Fourth Avenue and 95th Street in the Fort Hamilton section. Admission is $5. Information: (718) 624-0890.

title: Pakistan Denies Any Link To Atom Arms Plot in U.S.
description: The Government of Pakistan denied today that it was involved in any way in an attempt to export a steel alloy from the United States illegally for possible use in making nuclear weapons.

title: Indians Win After Dismissing Corrales
description: Cory Snyder did his part today to make sure that Doc Edwards, the new manager of the Cleveland Indians, got off to a good start. Snyder's sixth home run in eight games and 20th of the season, a three-run shot in the first inning, helped to provide a 4-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

title: Questions On Municipals
description: An investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into the legal status of dozens of tax-exempt bond offerings has revived questions about whether local government financings should be more strictly regulated by some Federal authority.

title: Early-Music Ensemble
description: Aston Magna, the early-music ensemble, is to perform works by Lully, Buxtehude and Mozart tonight at 8 at the Bard College Chapel in Annandale-on-Hudson. Tickets are $8. Information and directions: (914) 758-6822.

title: 'New York 8' Member Is Held
description: A man identified by law-enforcement officials as belonging to a self-proclaimed black revolutionaries' group known as the ''New York Eight'' was arrested yesterday after a state trooper stopped a car he was driving near Monroe, N.Y., the state police said.

title: AUCTIONS
description: THE British state papers of the secret Treaty of Dover - the 1670 agreement between Charles II and Louis XIV that led to war between England and the Netherlands and might have ended British parliamentary rule and the Church of England - will be auctioned Thursday at Sotheby's in London.

title: Santamaria and Camilo
description: Mongo Santamaria, a percussionist, and Michel Camilo, a pianist, are to lead their groups in a Latin-jazz double bill tonight through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. through Sunday, plus a 1:30 A.M. show tonight and tomorrow. There is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $7.50 charge at the bar.

title: McClatchy Maps Future Of Family's Newspapers
description: The McClatchy Newspapers, publishers of The Sacramento Bee and eight other daily papers in California, Washington and Alaska, have been owned and operated by the same family for four generations. But, prompted by the recent sales of other privately owned newspapers in Detroit, Des Moines and Louisville, Ky., the family is now considering a public offering.

title: Dining Out Guide: Grilled Fare
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ARIZONA 206, 206 East 60th Street (838-0440) - **(Nov. 14, 1985) Offering a direct route to some of the best California- and Southwestern-style food around is this long, narrow East Side restaurant with undulating molded plaster walls, natural-wood floors and tables, and lovely arrangements of desert flowers. The limited menu features a number of grilled dishes, including appetizers of grilled lamb salad with artichoke, jicama and chayote as well as grilled scallops with pumpkin-seed sauce and salsa. Grilled main-dish options are swordfish with zucchini, tomatoes and salsa verde; lamb chops with summer vegetable ragout, and veal salad with summer vegetables and pepper sauces. Entrees $19 to $23. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 3 P.M. and 6 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. COASTAL, 300 Amsterdam Avenue, at 74th Street (769-3988) - ** (June 12, 1987) The Upper West Side's serious new fish house with a contemporary glass-fronted dining room and coastal mural might be a place to enjoy some grilled offerings. Among the choices is an appetizer of rare grilled tuna over succotash. Other options might be any of the grilled fresh fish of the day: mahi mahi, yellowfin tuna, Norwegian salmon, swordfish steak, grouper and halibut. Entrees $10 to $17.25. Fridays and Saturdays, 6 P.M. to 2 A.M.; Sundays, 6 to 10:30 P.M. JAMS, 154 East 79th Street (772-6800) - ** (Aug. 8, 1986) Colorful abstract art and an open kitchen contribute to the upbeat and breezy, casual atmosphere of Jams. The menu is beguiling and manageable in size, and changes daily. The kitchen specializes in grilling meat and fish dishes, and you might begin with seared tuna salad with curly lettuce and sesame seeds; grilled chicken marinated in roasted-peanut sauce, on skewers with eggplant and sesame. The grilled entree selections include corn-fed chicken with french fries; quail lacquered with plum sauce and soy on a bed of kale, and tenderloin of pork with straw-potato cakes and caramelized sherry-vinegar pork sauce. Entrees $23 to $32. Fridays through Sundays, 6 to 11 P.M. LA METAIRIE, 189 West 10th Street (989-0343) - *(Nov. 23, 1984) A warm and welcoming French bistro in the West Village, this charming neighborhood spot favors solid bistro food and grilled fish dishes. The owner often brings in special products from France when available, such as oversize fresh Mediterranean sardines that are charcoal grilled and drizzled with lemon. Other summer options include grilled tuna with pesto and coulis of red sweet pepper; grilled swordfish, and salmon with bourguignon sauce. Entrees $18 to $24. Fridays and Saturdays, 6 to 11:30 P.M.; Sundays 5 to 11 P.M. PETALUMA, 1356 First Avenue, at 73d Street (772-8800) - *(May 3, 1985) An expansive peach-colored multi-tier restaurant, Petaluma has a long bar and exposed kitchen. The menu features pizzas and a number of grilled items. To start, you might choose grilled spiced chicken with peanut sauce. Main-dish grilled selections include veal chop with rosemary potatoes; Atlantic salmon with steamed vegetables; swordfish with tomato and capers; red snapper with fresh herbs, and baby chicken with a light mustard sauce. Entrees $13.50. to $20. Fridays through Sundays, 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 5:30 P.M. to midnight. UNION SQUARE CAFE, 21 East 16th Street (243-4020) - **(Jan. 24, 1986) Designed on a human scale, the cafe is divided into a number of dining areas with different decors and a long, handsome bar as you enter. The food is genuine and eclectic. The menu, which straddles the border between France and Italy, offers some interesting grilled fare. A popular appetizer choice is grilled fresh-water prawns with red and yellow peppers and zucchini with lemon pepper aioli sauce. For a main dish, you might order grilled fillet of marinated tuna with pickled ginger and sauteed Napa cabbage; grilled fillet of salmon trout in a beurre rouge with saffron potatoes, or grilled duck breast with green olives, roasted garlic and artichokes. Entrees $16.50 to $22. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 3 P.M. and 6 P.M. to midnight; closed Sundays. What the stars mean, page C24.

title: Computer Bid Shift by Japan
description: In a move to defuse tensions over supercomputer trade, Japan's Government announced today that it was changing its bidding procedures for supercomputers.

title: City Dad, Country Mom
description: Two friends recently transferred to New York talked about the effects of the change on their families. One family chose to live in the city, the other chose to live in the suburbs, and they have reciprocal regrets. As their conversation shows, the grass is always greener; so is the non-grass.

title: North's Lies: 'Well Done'
description: During Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter's testimony, he was asked about his reaction to an appearance by his National Security Council staff subordinate, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, before the House Intelligence Committee.

title: Times Will Add $400 Million Plant in Edison, N.J.
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it planned to spend $400 million, its largest capital investment ever, on a new printing plant in Edison, N.J.

title: DOW TOPS 2,500, THEN EASES BACK
description: LEAD: The stock market yesterday continued its most recent surge - one that many on Wall Street find somewhat perplexing, even unnerving.

title: Film: Togetherness in 'Rita, Sue and Bob Too'
description: ''UNCEREMONIOUS'' does not begin to do justice to the manner in which Bob, Sue and Rita inaugurate their romance. ''Romance'' isn't exactly right, either. Sue and Rita have been baby-sitting at Bob's when his wife, Michelle, suggests he drive them home. Bob is more than accommodating. He takes these two teen-age girls to a deserted spot, begins leering at them and is more than a little amazed when they leer right back.

title: SOCIAL DEMOCRATS LEAD IN PORTUGAL
description: Economic good times have increased the chances of the right-of-center Social Democratic Party to gain a majority in general elections here Sunday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Thursday, about companies that distribute electronic parts, overstated the earnings that most analysts expect for Avnet Inc. Their consensus is that Avnet earned about 68 cents a share for the fiscal year, which ended June 30.

title: FIGGIE INTERNATIONAL HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sketches of the Principals In Nofziger-Wedtech Case
description: Lyn Nofziger

title: HUTTON, E F GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,698,000 and $4,361,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; a gain from the sale of discontinued operations of $51,630,000 for both periods; and a tax credit of $9,826,000 and $36,595,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes net from discontinued operations of $3,043,000. d-Includes net from discontinued operations of $6,129,000 and a tax credit of $5,200,000.

title: WHEELING-PITTSBURGH STEEL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $16,115,000 and $30,032,000 in lieu of income tax for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes for the quarter restructuring charges primarily for plant closings of $83,242,000.

title: Housing Starts Are Off Again
description: Housing starts fell in June for the fourth straight month, but housing industry economists remain optimistic on the outlook for the rest of the year, assuming mortgage rates do not jump again.

title: Hollings Accuses TV of Ad Overload
description: The sponsor of a bill to restore some regulation of the broadcast industry accused television executives today of using too many commercials and reducing news departments.

title: Did Reagan Know? Did Poindexter Tell?
description: Reagan

title: Trout Wants A Ring, Too
description: There can be no point in trying to pretend to have a normal childhood when baseball is growing into a passion and your father possesses a World Series ring.

title: Reviving the Rockaways: A Bitter Trail
description: After two decades of frustration and failure, New York City is trying again to redevelop two miles of oceanfront in Queens that is one of the nation's most conspicuous setbacks in an attempt at urban renewal.

title: Cholesterol Researcher Is Censured For Misrepresenting Data in Article
description: A leading scientist known for his investigations into the role of cholesterol in heart disease was censured yesterday by the National Institutes of Health for ''serious scientific misconduct'' and for misrepresenting data he published in a major medical journal.

title: Hollywood Gamble En Espanol
description: When ''La Bamba'' reaches theaters on Friday, Hollywood will be making its first real test of the Hispanic market for American films. In Miami, New York, San Antonio, Detroit, Los Angeles, San Jose, Calif., and 20 other cities with large Hispanic populations, the movie will be released in three versions: in English, in Spanish, and in English with Spanish subtitles.

title: SIGNET BANKING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $75 million addition to the loan loss reserve for loans to less developed countries which represents about 40 percent of its exposure in that area.

title: Japan's Efforts to Soften U.S. Anger on Toshiba
description: In its desire to quell American anger over a Japanese company's sale of militarily sensitive technology to the Soviet Union, Japan is taking steps that may seem extraordinary to Americans, but make perfect sense to Japanese.

title: COLECO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Nominee to Head the F.A.A. Is Confirmed by the Senate
description: The Senate on a voice vote today confirmed the nomination of T. Allan McArtor as Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration to succeed Donald D. Engen.

title: Racial Tension in Norwalk Simmers Over Deaths
description: Only blocks from the bars and bistros that line this city's newly renovated waterfront district, the streets are steaming with fear and anger and resentment.

title: FORT HOWARD PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ALUMINUM CO OF AMERICA (ALCOA) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax writedown of $141,800,000 for phasing out certain operations and an extraordinary loss of $23,900,000 to retire debt for both quarter and 6 months; and equity earnings of $17 million for the quarter and $31,800,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income and includes equity earnings of $16,400,000 and $6,700,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said the latest quarter and 6-month had foreign currency losses of $12,700,000 and $27,300,000, respectively; and the year-earlier quarter had foreign currency gains of $2,900,000 and the 6-month had foreign losses of $13,200,000.

title: Boeing to Add Jobs
description: The Boeing Company said it expected to increase its work force during the remainder of the year by 3,000 to 4,000 workers, bringing total employment to about 139,000. The company said most of the growth would be in the Seattle area, where it expects to increase its work force to about 87,000 by the end of the year, from the current 84,000. Boeing added about 5,300 workers to its rolls during the first half of the year. A Boeing spokesman said the increases come in response to gains in commercial orders and aerospace activity.

title: For One Day, Cyclists Put French Village on Map
description: The chances are that for the nearly 200 silent, sweating competitors who passed through this little mountain hamlet on today's leg of the men's Tour de France, Valleraugue was just another village, barely glimpsed as a strip of asphalt between two rows of narrow old stone houses on the long and arduous route of the world's most famous bicycle race.

title: Mother Guilty Of Murdering Her Daughter
description: Mary Beth Tinning was found guilty today of smothering her 3 1/2-month-old daughter with a pillow.

title: AZINGER LEADS BY A SHOT AT BRITISH OPEN
description: Rains came, but the wind was still so gentle that Muirfield continued to be unexpectedly easy today, according to Paul Azinger, the new leader after two rounds of the 116th British Open championship.

title: The Ethics Act At Issue
description: The Ethics in Government Act of 1978, which Lyn Nofziger is accused of violating, was intended to assure that public servants were held to high standards of conduct, avoiding conflict of interest.

title: When Bettors Are the Losers
description: THE daily double at Belmont Park yesterday paid $186. It would have paid $192.60 if the State Legislature had acted last week to reduce the parimutuel takeout from 17 percent to 14 percent. The measure enjoyed wide support from legislators and track officials, and Albany handicappers made it 3-to-5 to be passed into law.

title: Rev. William Coffin Is Said to Be Choice Of New Peace Group
description: The Rev. William Sloane Coffin, senior minister of the Riverside Church, is expected to announce his resignation at services tomorrow, according to church sources.

title: Music: A 'Giovanni' Reborn as 'Donna'
description: In the mood for a trip up to the Pepsico Summerfare and a radical rethinking of Mozart's ''Don Giovanni''? If so, your best bet this summer is probably a piece of music theater called ''Donna Giovanni'' by the Companias Divas of Mexico, which opened Thursday night and will be repeated Saturday at 9 P.M. and Sunday at 3:30 P.M. Compared with Peter Sellars' forced, grim and deliberately alienating staging of ''Don Giovanni'' - and the festival's Don Juan theme and close juxtaposition of these two productions begs for such a comparison - this sometimes nutty, sometimes risible but frequently sexy, brilliant and illuminating feminist revision of the opera is an altogether more gripping experience. And, one must add, one more faithful to Mozart's and Da Ponte's spirit.

title: Music: Carmaig de Forest
description: Carmaig de Forest, a singer-songwriter from San Francisco who was at CBGB on Wednesday and has been performing elsewhere around town, has a skinhead haircut, wears jeans that are ripped at the knee, and plays the ukulele. His recent album was produced by Alex Chilton, and his ad hoc backup band at CBGB included Will Rigby of the dB's on drums, Gordon Gano of the Violent Femmes on guitar, and Tony McMasters, bass; he's a songwriter other songwriters are listening to.

title: Music: 'Tosca,' at the City Opera
description: The New York City Opera had some very interesting things to say about ''Tosca'' in its first performance of the summer on Thursday night. Indeed, the company upheld Puccini's reputation for first-rate potboilers and did so with some eloquence. This is an opera whose inspiration is deceiving, one that moves with such swift melodrama and is supported by such inviting music that we tend to overlook the two-dimensionality of its characters.

title: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PIONEER-STANDARD ELECTRONCS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $254,815.

title: Moves Set by Comsat
description: The Communications Satellite Corporation said today it would sell its manufacturing businesses and dispose of two planned direct-broadcast satellites as part of a major reorganization.

title: INSIDE
description: Harsh Penalty for Scientist

title: CHAMPION INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes one-time gains totaling 89 cents a share from the sale of the company's investment in Stone Container Corp. and U.S. Plywood Corp. c-After $2,142,000 and $5,940,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, in preference stock dividends.

title: NEW SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JULY 18, 1987
description: International 2-7 The believability of John Poindexter was challenged by the chairman of the Senate committee investigating the Iran-contra affair. But the Republican vice chairman of the committee said he believed the admiral. Page 1 Many people think the President lied when he said he did not know that money from the Iran arms sales went to the contras, despite Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter's testimony supporting his account, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows. 1 Poindexter shows little regret 6 France cut off relations with Iran, and the two Governments banned each other's diplomats from leaving their countries. The French move was followed almost immediately by a threat in Lebanon to kill two French hostages. 1 In a legal victory for the Vatican, Italy's highest court today annulled arrest warrants accusing an American archibishop and two other Vatican bank executives of fraudulent complicity in the collapse of the Banco Ambrosiano. 2 News analysis: Tokyo is taking steps against a Japanese company for selling militarily sensitive technology to the Soviet Union. The moves may seem extraordinary to Americans, but to Japanese, they make perfect sense. 35 Three people were indicted in California on charges of illegally exporting to Pakistan sophisticated instruments and advanced computer equipment that can be used to make nuclear bombs. 3 A banned Soviet film was shown to restricted audiences at a Moscow film festival, and officials have promised its eventual release. The film presents a sympathetic portrait of Soviet Jews. 3 A joint French-West German force will be formed and kept outside NATO's integrated military command, the French and West German Defense Ministers announced. 4 Margaret Thatcher visited the U.S. and appeared to offer a message of reassurance about the President's international stature. ''Now more than ever we need American leadership,'' she said. 2 Quiet Jordanian-Israeli cooperation goes on each day via two Jordan River bridges and is one of the most important factors shaping Arab-Israeli politics. Neither side publicly admits the cooperation. 4 In tomorrow's elections in Portugal, economic good times have increased the chances of the right-of-center Social Democratic Party to become the first party to govern with a majority since 1974. 3 Cyclists put French village on map 3 Israel to study discrimination protest 4 National 8, 28, 32-33, 50 Lyn Nofziger has been charged by a Federal grand jury with having illegally lobbied Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d when he was Counselor to the President on behalf of the Wedtech Corporation. 1 A river swept away a bus and a van in the Texas Hill Country. The vehicles were full of teen-agers leaving a church camp. Two of the 43 persons aboard died, and eight were missing and feared dead. 1 A leading scientist was censured by the National Institutes of Health for scientific misconduct and for misrepresenting data. The scientist, Dr. Charles J. Glueck, is known for his work on the role of cholesterol in heart disease. 8 The stock market closed above 2,500 for the first time in its history, lifted by a rise in the dollar that encouraged foreign buyers and a continuing rush of good earnings reports. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,510.04, up 13.07 points. 35 Democratic Presidential candidates joined in pungent criticism of President Reagan, Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North for their roles in the Iran-contra affair. 8 Foes of a military nuclear reactor filed suit to delay its reopening and most of them want to shut it down permanently. If successful, the suit would delay the re-opening of theN-Reactor, which has been shut since January. 32 Members of NOW met in Philadelphia. The members were carving out the course the National Organization for Women will follow over the next two years and preparing to choose a new leader. 33 A recall of 22,000 ambulances was announced by officials from the Ford Motor Company. The ambulances are being recalled to fix fuel problems that have caused at least two dozen fires and 15 injuries, they said. 28 Postal Service contract talks stalled. Pacts with the two largest postal unions are scheduled to expire on Tuesday. If the two sides are unable to reach agreement by that time, an arbitration process could be invoked. 33 In licensing an artificial sweetener, the Food and Drug Administration followed proper procedures and is conducting adequate follow-up studies to monitor the safety of aspartame, the General Accounting Office says. 50 Verdict returned in magazine trial 33 Court-martialed Marine freed 33 Regional 29-31 Anthony R. Ameruso was convicted of lying under oath to a panel investigating governmental corruption. Mr. Ameruso was New York City's transportation commissioner from 1978 until his resignation last year. 1 More people are riding the subways, attracted by new, rebuilt and graffiti-free subway cars, the Transit Authority reported. The number of riders is the largest reported in more than a decade. 1 An oceanfront tract's redevelopment is being attempted by New York City. But a dispute about the type of housing that should be built is beginning to resurface, officials said. That dispute has impeded the project since the 1960's. 29 Eight Syracuse men pleaded guilty to conspiracy counts. The eight were charged in an extortion scheme said to be controlled by Lee Alexander, the city's former four-term mayor. 29 Mary Beth Tinning was found guilty of smothering her 3 1/2-month-old daughter with a pillow. The infant was one of eight of Mrs. Tinning's children to die over a 14-year period in mysterious circumstances. 29 Two men charged with racketeering were convicted by a jury in Federal District Court in Manhattan. The charges involved the Mafia's systematic extortion of payoffs in the construction industry. 31 Under a National Park Service plan, the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area, 69,629 acres of mountains and scenic gorges on the edge of the New York metropolitan area, will be kept largely pristine and undeveloped. 29 Racial tension in Norwalk, Conn., has been high since last year when two white police officers killed a black man wielding a rifle. ''It's still like an accident waiting to happen out there,'' one resident said. 30 Board of Estimate expects a long hearing on shelters 31 3 hurt in demolition accident 31 Coffin may head peace group 31

title: F.D.A. Handling of Research On NutraSweet Is Defended
description: The Food and Drug Administration followed proper procedures in approving the sale of the artificial sweetener aspartame and is conducting adequate follow-up studies to monitor its safety, the General Accounting Office says.

title: Quaker in Accord With General Mills
description: The Quaker Oats Company and General Mills Inc. said they had reached an agreement in a trademark dispute. In a suit filed in Federal District Court in Chicago, Quaker had complained about the use of its logotype on the back of a General Mills box for hot breakfast cereal. On the box, General Mills compared its cereal with Quaker's brand, asserting that the General Mills product had more vitamins. However, the Quaker logotype, a red-cheeked smiling man who has been a symbol for more than 30 years, was partly covered.

title: Dipper and the Discus
description: There was never any doubt among National Basketball Association players who competed against Wilt Chamberlain that the scoring and rebounding wonder is one of the strongest men on earth. Now the 51-year-old Big Dipper has announced that he is aiming to make the United States Olympic team as a discus thrower for the 1988 Games in Seoul, South Korea.

title: Nurse Shortage Is Not Sudden or Surprising; Largely Women's Work
description: To the Editor: As someone who has worked in New York City hospitals since 1978, I have seen over the last decade a steady decline in the number and quality of nurses in our hospitals. A nurse must work nights, weekends, holidays and, when staff shortages exist, double shifts.

title: Of Swords And Falling Men
description: Here are some of the things we now know:

title: CONTEL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Protection Against Sun Is Summer's Best Seller
description: What's hot at cosmetics counters this summer? Sun-protection products. ''The area is explosive,'' said Terry Hagerty, a vice president and the merchandise manager for cosmetics at Saks Fifth Avenue. ''La Prairie and Chanel brought out lines this year, and the older cosmetic companies are focusing more attention on sun products.''

title: GAF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $97.1 million from sale of Borg-Warner shares and $5.7 million in gains relating to the company's investment in Union Carbide for the quarter, and for the 6 months includes an extraordinary credit of $123,833,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $3.7 million and $89,474,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: PARLUX FRAGRANCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Comings and Goings
description: Billie Jean King, Stan Smith, Alex Olmedo, Bjorn Borg and Dennis Ralston will be inducted today into the International Tennis Hall of Fame in Newport, R.I. Oscar Johnson and Dorothy (Dodo) Cheney will be awarded special commendations in recognition of their outstanding contributions to the sport. . . . Louis Orr, the Knicks' forward, was reported ''recovering nicely'' from back surgery yesterday at Christ Hospital in Cincinnati to repair a herniated disk. . . . Anthony Weatherspoon, the fullback for Colorado, suffered multiple injuries Thursday in a motorcycle accident in Whittier, Calif. Officials at Whittier Presbyterian Medical Center, where Weatherspoon was taken after he lost control of his vehicle and slid down an embankment, said he was in fair condition with a fractured collarbone, dislocated hip and puncture wounds to the abdomen. . . . The Cleveland Browns released Brad Van Pelt, a 14-year linebacker who played 11 seasons for the Giants.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 11.

title: ROGERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Man Is Found Shot In Subway Passage
description: A man was found yesterday evening by the police with a gunshot wound to the head in a well-traveled subway passageway near Times Square.

title: AMERICAN PRESIDENT COS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Texas River Engulfs Bus and Van; Two Are Dead and 8 Are Missing
description: A raging, rain-swollen river in central Texas swept away a bus and a van full of teen-agers leaving a church camp today. Two of the 43 people in the vehicles died, and 8 were missing tonight and feared dead.

title: U.S. Issues Rise Moderately
description: Prices of Government securities rose moderately yesterday in light trading buoyed by the surge of the dollar to a four-month high against the Japanese yen.

title: Your Money; Gifts to Minors Offer Choices
description: ''MAKING a gift directly to a minor is a good way of dispersing funds for non-useful purposes,'' said Julian S. Bush, senior estate partner of the New York law firm of Shea & Gould.

title: New Fans for Diamonds
description: Diamonds, the world's hardest, most dazzling asset, are attracting a new wave of customers.

title: Israel to Study Protest About Discrimination
description: The Israeli Government has set up a committee to look into American complaints that some black Americans and Arab-Americans face discrimination when they try to enter Israel, a senior Foreign Ministry official said today.

title: Dr. George E. Murphy, Professor of Pathology
description: Dr. George E. Murphy, a professor of pathology at the Cornell University Medical College and chairman of the group responsible for the Upper East Side recreation complex known as Asphalt Green, died of cancer Wednesday at New York Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Herb and Cora Taylor, Publishers, Are Killed
description: Herb and Cora Taylor, publishers of books on diving, were killed Tuesday in the crash of a light plane near Lincolnville, Me. Mr. Taylor was 45 years old and Mrs. Taylor was 46. They lived in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: LOCKHEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NOXELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-The share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split to be distributed August 19.

title: SAVIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $912,000 and $1,516,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $296,000 and $76,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: A Split Decision
description: The six-member State Athletic Commission in California split its vote yesterday on the appeal filed by Albert Davila of the decision to stop his North American Boxing Federation bantamweight championship bout June 27 against Frankie Duarte. A seventh member of the commission was absent and because of the 3-3 vote, no determination was made and Duarte retained his title.

title: PHILIP MORRIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title:
Patents;
Pinpointing Cancer
description: LEAD: A linker that joins anti-cancer agents and radioactive isotopes to antibodies was patented this week for Immunomedics Inc. of Newark. The modified antibodies produced are used to pinpoint cancer for diagnosis and therapy. Boby M. Sundoro, director of chemistry for immunomedics, was granted patent 4,680,338 for the linker.

title: SOVIET TESTS NECLEAR DEVICE
description: The Soviet Union detonated a nuclear device today, its 11th underground test since abandoning a freeze earlier this year.

title: The Bork Question
description: Two old lions of the Washington bar and the Democratic Party have entered, on different sides, the steadily growing conflict over President Reagan's nomination of Robert H. Bork to replace Justice Lewis Powell on the Supreme Court. That suggests something about how the battle will be fought.

title: ETHYL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the second quarter results include income from investment gains of 2 cents a share in the latest period and 6 cents a share in the year-ago quarter.

title: NASHUA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GRACE, W R & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $625,000 for the quarter and net of $26,997,000 for the 6 months both from discontinued operations; and a charge of $1,584,000 for the quarter and a gain of $6,882,000 for the 6 months both related to tax adjustments. c-Includes net of $79,805,000 and $70,068,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from discontinued operations. The company said net from discontinued operations includes a gain of $26,200,000 in the latest 6-month on the March 1987 divestiture of Berman's; and a gain of $83,000,000 in the year- ago period on the sales of Grace's interests in Herman's and the Orchard and Home Centers West operations.

title: Article 526187 -- No Title
description: The Aluminum Company of America said today that special charges caused a $91.2 million loss in the second quarter in contrast to a profit of $53.3 million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: VERDICT RETURNED IN MAGAZINE TRIAL
description: A Federal jury in the bitter six-year legal fight over the sale of The Atlantic magazine found today that none of the five sellers in the case had committed fraud.

title: A Majority in New Poll Still Find Reagan Lied on Iran-Contra Issue
description: Despite Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter's testimony supporting the President's account, a majority of Americans still say that President Reagan lied when he said he did not know that money from the Iran arms sales was channeled to the Nicaraguan rebels, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: MOORE-HANDLEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CRAZY EDDIE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: Lautenberg Asks Curbs On TV for Children
description: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, proposed legislation today to require television broadcasters to present at least seven hours a week of educational programs for children.

title: NOLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $88,870, or 2 cents a share, from initial proceeds from the settlement of litigation.

title: GOODRICH, B F CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $10,500,000 and a chare of $3,100,000 from the extinguishment of debt for both periods. c-Includes a tax credit of $15,100,000 and $16,600,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Houston Officers Sue
description: Two Houston police officers have filed a lawsuit seeking $10.2 million in damages stemming from an incident last July that resulted in assault and battery charges against four Mets.

title: Suit Filed to Delay Reopening Of Military Nuclear Reactor
description: Opponents of a deteriorating military nuclear reactor filed suit yesterday to delay its reopening. Most of the plaintiffs would like to keep the reactor shut permanently.

title: Tanana Blanks Mariners
description: Alan Trammell had three hits, including his 14th home run, and Frank Tanana pitched a three-hitter to lead the Detroit Tigers to a 7-0 victory last night over the Seattle Mariners. Tanana (9-6) faced the minimum number of batters through seven innings.

title: Continental Plans Rise in Air Fares
description: Continental Airlines, falling in line with the nation's other major air carriers, said that it would increase one-way ticket prices $2 to $8, beginning Aug. 1. The decision by Continental, one of the airline units of the Texas Air Corporation, was expected. The Houston-based carrier cited rising fuel costs.

title: BAUSCH & LOMB INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that earnings in the second quarter were after special costs of 17 cents a share for the promotion and repricing of its saline solutions.

title: DENIES WRONGDOING
description: A Federal grand jury found that Lyn Nofziger illegally ''profited from the political reputation and influence'' he gained as a senior White House aide, according to an indictment unsealed here today.

title: Thatcher Visits Washington And Hails Reagan Leadership
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, bolstered by her recent election victory in Britain, made a one-day visit to Washington today and appeared to offer a message of reassurance to the American public about its President's stature.

title: PANEL'S CHAIRMAN SAYS POINDEXTER LACKS CREDIBILITY
description: Senator Daniel K. Inouye, the Democratic chairman of the Senate investigative committee, today openly challenged the believability of Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter's testimony on the Iran-contra affair.

title: KEY RATES
The Testimony: 'I Simply Didn't Want Outside Interference'
description: In his third day of testimony yesterday at the Congressional hearings in Washington, Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter was questioned further on his role in Iran-contra affair. Here, as recorded by The New York Times, are excerpts from his testimony.

title: Rise at Texas Instruments
description: Second-quarter net income of Texas Instruments Inc. rose to $62 million, reflecting a continued recovery in the semiconductor market, company officials said today.

title: Veiled Realities
description: SPIRITS and Other Stories. By Richard Bausch. 237 pages. The Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: ARCO to Press Oil Lease Claim
description: ARCO is seeking nearly $796 million in damages from California and Santa Barbara County because it was blocked from developing oil leases in the Santa Barbara Channel.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If the independent counsel wants my scalp, he will have to get it the old-fashioned way.''

title: Suitors for Texas Thrift Units
description: Several wealthy investors and financial institutions, including Citicorp, are exploring ways to acquire ailing thrift institutions in Texas, a prominent regulator of the industry in the Southwest said today.

title: France Breaks Iran Ties and Isolates Embassy
description: France severed relations with Iran today, and each country prohibited the other's diplomats from leaving.

title: ALEXANDER & BALDWIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said a major land sale completed in the latest second quarter added 53 cents a share to net income.

title: 'In the Name of Fairness,' a Sharp Rebuke
description: After several objections by Richard Beckler, Admiral Poindexter's attorney, over questions to his client, Senator Daniel K. Inouye, chairman of the Senate committee, made a statement about the fairness of the committee and the credibility of the witness.

title: Mattingly Cracks Another Homer, and a Record
description: The bottle of sparkling wine had been placed in an orange bucket at the corner of Don Mattingly's locker. It had been put there by a clubhouse attendant to commemorate an achievement Mattingly said he does not comprehend and was not attempting to reach.

title: Court-Martialed Marine Freed
description: A Marine whose conviction on rape and attempted murder charges was overturned by an appeals court earlier this month was freed from prison Friday, the Marine Corps said.

title: RIGGS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an addition of $32 million to loan loss reserves for lesser developed countries and those with recently restructured debt. c-Net income.

title: RALSTON PURINA CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss on early retirement of debt of $100,000 and $3,300,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months include a net gain of $209.3 million, or $2.87 a share on the sale of the company's domestic agricultural products unit. c-Includes a gain on the disposal of discontinued restaurant operations of $113,400,000, a loss of $13,500,000 on early retirement of debt, and includes a non-recurring charge of $24.5 million, or 32 cents a share, from the closing of a tuna cannery.

title: RJR NABISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $208 million and a loss of $80 million from early extinguishment of debt. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $23 million and $34 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: MERCK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Grand National Team Play Is Narrowed to Four Entries
description: Teams from California, Indiana, Louisiana and Pennsylvania competed in the semifinal stage of the Grand National Team Championship here today.

title: 2 Convicted of Racketeering In Mafia Construction Case
description: A jury convicted two men yesterday of racketeering charges involving the Mafia's systematic extortion of payoffs in the construction industry of New York City.

title: OXFORD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
Man Held in Aliens' Deaths
description: A man being held in Sonora, Mexico, will be charged with negligent homicide and smuggling undocumented farm workers out of Mexico in connection with a desert trek by 25 men and boys that left three dead, a Mexican prosecutor said Thursday. The man, Manuel Partida Beltran, allegedly accepted $350 to $400 from each emigrant for setting up a 50-mile route for them from Los Vidrios, Sonora, to Aztec, Ariz., and then left them ''without food, without medicine, with only enough water for four hours.''

title: Nurse Shortage Is Not Sudden or Surprising; AIDS Fear Takes Toll
description: To the Editor:

title: Scoop of Justice for Howard Johnson
description: Howard Johnson's vanilla, chocolate, coffee and strawberry ice cream are not really Howard Johnson's, a jury has ruled. They are Paul H. Beckner's. Coming coincidentally on the fifth day of National Ice Cream Week, the jury in Suffolk Superior Court found on Thursday that Howard Johnson's had misappropriated Mr. Beckner's secret formulas for four of its 28 flavors. The jury awarded his family $1.25 million, according to Stephen S. Young, the lawyer for Mr. Beckner's widow.

title: Ex-New York Commissioner Is Convicted of Lying to Panel
description: Anthony R. Ameruso, New York City's Transportation Commissioner from 1978 until his resignation last year, was convicted yesterday of lying under oath to a panel investigating governmental corruption.

title: No Pinochet, No Pinochetism
description: LEAD: A year ago, Chile made the headlines that South Korea is making now. Demands for democracy - specifically, constitutional reform to permit open and direct presidential elections - led to a general strike, the murder of a young man and some evidence that the military was being forced to reconsider its policy of repression and political exclusion.

title: Coke Plans Buyback of Shares
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it planned to buy back up to 40 million common shares, or about 10.6 percent of the total outstanding. The three-year repurchase plan would cost about $1.8 billion at current market prices.

title: Shelter Issue: Board Braces For Long Day
description: Democracy, as practiced by New York City's Board of Estimate, often takes peculiar twists and turns. The board's meetings routinely last 15 or 16 hours, winding up at 2 or 3 A.M. A meeting two weeks ago lasted 24 hours.

title: Peru Rebels Kill Policeman
description: Peruvian rebels shot dead a police officer in Lima today after a night of violence in which 10 bombs exploded in the capital and part of the country was blacked out. The police said that nine people were wounded in the attacks and that 500 people suspected of rebel activity, 10 of them believed to be members of the Maoist Shining Path guerrilla group, had been detained in the capital. Rebels shot dead Sgt. Fernando Llanos Clemente this morning.

title: Re-creating Hambone, Body Music of the Past
description: It is undeniably the speediest of the many star turns in ''The Comedy of Errors,'' playing these days at the Vivian Beaumont Theater. Yet, to Derique McGee, his hambone body-rhythm routine is never quite fast enough. ''I keep trying for that playing-card-in-the-bicycle-spoke sound,'' he said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: In the Far East

title: Postal Talks With 2 Unions Stall Over Settlement With a 3d
