description: Contract talks between the Postal Service and its two largest unions have broken off with the pacts scheduled to expire at 12:01 A.M. Tuesday.

title: Darling Dealt Complete Loss
description: Just when they seemed to be achieving noble things in their pursuit of first place, the Mets took a monumental tumble last night. Ron Darling was tagged for four runs in the ninth inning, including a two-out, three-run home run by Nick Esasky, and the Cincinnati Reds bushwacked the Mets, 5-2.

title: CROWN CORK & SEAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

Patents;
Treatment Of Genital Herpes
description: LEAD: A PREPARATION trademarked Alferon, which is reported to have proved effective for the relief of genital herpes in clinical trials, was patented this week for Interferon Sciences Inc., a biotechnology company in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: New World in Bid For Kenner Parker
description: The makers of Monopoly today found themselves in a real-life battle of high finance.

title: Repayment To Guinness
description: A High Court judge has ordered a former director of Guinness P.L.C., Thomas J. Ward, to return to the brewing company $:5.2 million, or $8.4 million, that he received during the company's takeover of the Distillers Company last year.

title: GANNETT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Jean Reavey Is Dead at 70; A Playwright and Librettist
description: Jean Bullowa Reavey, a playwright, died Monday at Northern Dutchess Hospital in Rhinebeck, N.Y. She was 70 years old.

title: Nurse Shortage Is Not Sudden or Surprising; Rewards Remain
description: To the Editor:

title: MCI to Match A.T.&T. Rate
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said it would match its long-distance rival by cutting its long-distance rates an average of 5 percent. The reduced rates will go into effect Aug. 1. The rate change was in response to a similar rate cut July 1 by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: North Carolina Arts Prize
description: John Cheek, a bass-baritone who has performed with opera companies in the United States and abroad, is this year's recipient of the North Carolina Prize for his outstanding work in the performing arts. The award, which carries a $10,000 grant, is given annually for excellence in the performing or visual arts to an individual born in North Carolina or residing in the state. The award's sponsors are four newspapers owned by The New York Times Company: the Times-News in Hendersonville, The Dispatch in Lexington, the Lenoir News-Topic and the Wilmington Morning Star. The presentation ceremony will take place in the fall.

title: Film: 'Jaws the Revenge,' The Fourth in the Series
description: Before we join the Brody family in the fourth part of the ''Jaws'' saga, here's what's happened in our story so far. Dad survived a few chilling shark attacks in the original ''Jaws,'' rescued his two sons from another great white in the tepid ''Jaws II,'' and let's not even think about the laughable ''Jaws 3-D.'' The question is: Why hasn't this family moved to Nebraska?

title: How Queens Judicial Candidates Were Chosen
description: To the Editor:

title: Teammate of Gehrig Watches Mattingly
description: On the night Don Mattingly shared the Yankee record of four grand slams in a season with Lou Gehrig and Tommy Henrich, he was watched by one of Gehrig's teammates on the 1927 Yankees.

title: ROPAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-The company said nonrecurring costs form the aborted acquisition of Buckhorn Inc. totaled about $290,000 in the quarter and $340,000 in the six months.

title: French-West German Brigade Is to Be Kept Outside NATO
description: A planned joint brigade of French and German troops will be headed by a French officer and kept outside the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's integrated military command along with the rest of France's armed forces, the French and West German Defense Ministers announced today.

title: Subways' Ridership Rises to 3.6 Million, Highest Since 1974
description: New, rebuilt and graffiti-free subway cars are luring people underground in numbers not seen in more than a decade, the Transit Authority reported yesterday.

title: To Naval Officers, Poindexter Performance Is a Puzzlement
description: When Navy officers are asked their impressions of Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter's performance before the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair, the response is slow in coming and usually accompanied by perplexed expressions.

title: 552 Days of Twilight?
description: A lame duck, Safire's Political Dictionary pronounces, is an officeholder whose power is diminished because he is soon to leave office. By that standard, President Reagan is no lame duck. He's not scheduled to leave office for 552 days. At the moment, however, to call Mr. Reagan a lame duck is almost an overstatement.

title: GILLETTE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Elaine Brody Is Dead at 64; Author and Music Professor
description: Elaine Brody, an author and professor of music in the Faculty of Arts and Science at New York University, died of cancer Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Nature Wins Over Development at Delaware Water Gap
description: The Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area, 69,629 acres of mountains and scenic gorges on the edge of the New York metropolitan area, will be kept largely pristine and undeveloped under a master plan adopted by the National Park Service.

title: NEWHALL LAND & FARMING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Olympia & York Moves Into London
description: Olympia & York, the giant Canadian real estate concern, announced today that it would take control of Canary Wharf, the 71-acre development along the Thames that is intended to expand London's financial services industry beyond the the City of London.

title: Guarantees That Collapse
description: NOTHING stands in the way of the consumer when it comes to finding the best deal. He or she is diligent, tireless, inquisitive, demanding. But often the consumer -overwhelmed by information, perhaps rushed and afraid that this ''best deal'' might slip away -reaches the point of taking the close-the-eyes-and-hope approach.

title: Soviet Gives Glimpse of Banned Film About Jews
description: In 1967, a Soviet film director told a tale of Jewish life, Jewish suffering, Jewish bravery and Jewish fatalism in a movie about a Red Army commissar who found herself living with a small-town Jewish family while civil war raged around them.

title: Ford Recalling Ambulances to Fix Fuel Problems
description: The Ford Motor Company has recalled as many as 22,000 ambulances to correct fuel problems that have caused at least two dozen fires and 15 injuries, company officials said today.

title: Taiwan Loosens the Reins
description: President Chiang Ching-kuo did not act impulsively in ending martial law on Taiwan: it's been in force for 38 years. So that everybody understands there are still limits, his Government imposed a new security law that continues key political restrictions. Nonetheless, the 76-year-old son of Chiang Kai-shek deserves a salute. Taiwan is finally moving from a closed political system, opening windows in a musty fortress.

title: Howard McGhee, 69, Is Dead; A Trumpeter and Composer
description: Howard McGhee, a trumpeter and composer and one of the pioneers of modern jazz, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: TRANSAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $15,617,000 and $33,980,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and for the quarter includes other gains of $8,260,000. c-Includes gains of $14,829,000. The company said certain amounts in 1986 have been restated to include the operating results of Fairmont Financial Inc., acquired in May 1987, in a transaction accounted for as a pooling of interests. The effect of the restatement was to increase operating income for the 1986 6 months by $3,287,000 and decrease earnings per share by l cent. Net income was increased by $3,335,000 and per share net was decreased by l cent in the 1986 6 months.

title: SHEARSON LEHMAN BROTHERS HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $27 million charge to cover potential losses on tin and non- recurring gains of $25 million from real estate transactions and the restructuring of a pension plan by Shearson's Boston co. unit. There are no share earnings for 1986 since the company was a wholly- owned subsidiary of American Express Co. at that time. Currently, American Express owns 60.6 percent of Shearson on a fully-diluted basis.

title: A West Side Voice on Television City
description: LEAD: NBC's search for a new home is the subject of a colorful melodrama now playing in New York City. The protagonists, Donald Trump and Mayor Koch, are squabbling over who can do more to save the damsel in distress -NBC - and win her for New York.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tour de France A Narrow Finish: Jean-Paul Van Poppel of the Netherlands outsprinted the pack yesterday to win the 17th stage of the Tour de France cycling race, but Charles Mottet of France retained the leader's yellow jersey. Van Poppel beat Guido Bontempi of Italy by the width of an inner tube at the end of the 148.5-mile route from Millau to Avignon. It was the second stage victory for Van Poppel, who beat Bontempi by the narrowest victory margin so far. He had won the eighth stage at Epinay-sous-Senart last week. The overall classification was barely affected after this leg. Mottet still leads Jean Francois Bernard of France and Stephen Roche of Ireland by more than a minute.

title: 8 Plead Guilty in Syracuse Kickback Case
description: Eight men charged in an extortion scheme said to have been controlled by Lee Alexander, the former Mayor of Syracuse, pleaded guilty yesterday to various conspiracy counts.

title: NYNEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Appeals Court Expedites Hearing on Walsh's Authority
description: A Federal appeals court has agreed to hurry its consideration of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's latest challenge to the authority of the Iran-contra special prosecutor, Lawrence E. Walsh.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Tuesday about New York State's legislative budget, and a related picture caption, incorrectly described the Legislature's television operation. The Legislature finances and maintains its own television-taping studios out of its operational budget. It is separate from Nyscan, a cable television channel that provides coverage of state government hearings and other proceedings.

title: BOWATER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax $6,381,000 loss on retirement of fixed assets. The company said sales and operating income for the latest quarter and 6-month include results of Star Forms Inc., acquired in December 1986. 1986 earnings for the quarter and 6 months have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for pension costs adopted in the fourth quarter of 1986.

title: Nurse Shortage Is Not Sudden or Surprising
description: To the Editor:

title: Leonard Wins Decision
description: Officials of HBO have decided to include Sugar Ray Leonard as part of the telecast tonight of the World Boxing Association junior middleweight title bout between the champion, Mike McCallum, and the challenger, Donald Curry, from Las Vegas, Nev.

title: SOUTHWESTERN BELL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid May 22.

title: U.S. Indicts 3 in the Export Of Equipment to Pakistan
description: Two Americans and a Hong Kong businessman were indicted today for illegally exporting to Pakistan sophisticated instruments and advanced computer equipment that can be used to make nuclear bombs.

title: Frugal Gourmet Wins Pace
description: Frugal Gourmet took the lead at the halfway point tonight and finished a neck ahead of Laag to capture the $902,500 Meadowlands Pace from a field of 12.

title: About New York; Dog Boot Camp: Giving Character To Screwballs
description: On Rudy! On Remy! On Roxie and Boomer! On Peek-a-Boo, Honey Bear, Scarlet and Scone!

title: Top Italy Court Annuls Warrants Against 3 Vatican Bank Officials
description: In a major legal victory for the Vatican, Italy's highest court today annulled arrest warrants accusing an American Archbishop and two other Vatican bank executives of fraudulent complicity in the billion-dollar collapse of Banco Ambrosiano.

title: Nurse Shortage Is Not Sudden or Surprising; A National Service Job?
description: To the Editor:

title:
Patents;
Anti-Viral Medication
description: LEAD: A team of 18 Russian inventors was granted patent 4,680,260 this week for a method of making medication described as useful in the treatment and prevention of viral infection. Production is made by cultivation of a strain deposited in a collection of microorganism cultures at the Soviet Union's Antibiotics Research Institute.

title: RUSSELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STONE & WEBSTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,700,000 and $5,400,000 from a change in accounting for pensions for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and also includes a charge of $1,113,000 from the writedown of drilling rigs and certain related equipment to estimated net realizable value.

title: Queens Man Is Slain In Mall Parking Lot
description: A 23-year-old Queens man was fatally shot in the parking lot of the Green Acres Mall here Thursday night in what the police described as a dispute between two families.

title: APPLIED MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $600,000 and $901,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $1,384,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Dance: Three Premieres by the Frankfurt Ballet
description: One can imagine the field day William Forsythe will have with the Iran-contra hearings. How language functions, how the same words are redefined to assume different meaning -these are issues that the 38-year-old American choreographer is exploring in the Frankfurt Ballet.

title: Smeal Is Hailed as NOW Assembles to Choose a New Leader
description: Eleanor C. Smeal, who is stepping down as president of the National Organization for Women, today dominated the opening of the group's convention here, exhorting delegates to double the number of women in Congress, back a female Presidential candidate and push for ratification of a proposed Federal equal rights amendment.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Company Briefs column of Business Day on Tuesday incorrectly characterized the ownership of the Metropolitan Broadcasting Corporation. The company is no longer a subsidiary of Metromedia, having been sold to a group of private investors in 1986.

title: The Connecticut Primary
description: Most of Fairfield County, Connecticut, will soon pick a successor to the late Stewart McKinney in Congress. A small vote is likely in the primaries next Tuesday and special election Aug. 18. Delay until fall would have been better. Now it's up to vacationing absentees, and voters at home, to make an extra effort.

title: MOLLIE GOLUB
description: Mollie Golub, former president of the Mizrachi Women's Organization of America, a Zionist organiztion now known as AMIT Women, died of pneumonia Tuesday in Maimonides Hospital. She was 85 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Dow Posts First Close Above 2,500
description: LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 2,500 yesterday for the first time in its history, lifted by a rise in the dollar that encouraged foreign buyers and a continuing rush of good earnings reports.

title: Senate Aids Sugar Refiners
description: The Senate today narrowly approved a provision in the omnibus trade bill that would give a $365 million break to a handful of American sugar refiners.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday about American reaction to the Australian election incompletely described New Zealand's status in the Anzus alliance. The United States announced last August that it was suspending military obligations to New Zealand under the Anzus treaty because New Zealand refused to allow port calls by American ships carrying nuclear weapons.

title: CENTRAL & SOUTH WEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Nicaragua Reports Repulsing Attackers In Northern Battles
description: Nicaragua said today that 27 rebels had been killed in attempts to capture three towns in a surge of fighting in the embattled north of the country Thursday.

title: The Clarinet Glissando Electrified the Hall
description: To the Editor:

title: UPJOHN CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split April 6.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $12.7 million and $21.8 million from tax benefits for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and also includes a pretax gain of $29 million and $138 million from patent litigation settlements for the same periods, respectively. c-Net loss and includes an extraordinary charge of $10.8 million from redemption of debentures. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid June 12.

title: AMERICAN TELEPHONE & TELERAPH CO INC (A T & T) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $175 million for a change in accounting for depreciation. The company said the quarter and 6-month ended June 30, 1986 were adversely impacted by a strike that was previously estimated to have reduced net income by about $140 million. The annual effect is estimated to have been $96 million, or 9 cents a share.

title: Florida Fruit Flies Controlled
description: State and Federal agriculture officials today announced that the battle against the latest infestaion of the Mediterranean fruit fly in Florida has been won.

title: Democratic Candidates United Over Iran Affair
description: Democratic Presidential candidates joined today in pungent criticism of President Reagan, Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North for their roles in the Iran-contra affair.

title: TEXACO CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Reform or Regulation for College Sports
description: College coaches and athletic directors run collegiate sports - and as big business. That was clear from the recent special convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The coaches and directors slapped down or eviscerated every proposal offered by the reform-minded Presidents' Commission. The message was that college sports aren't ready for reform.

title: A 15-Yard Span Over a Great Divide
description: Every morning around 9:30 a Jordanian soldier in a powder blue uniform carrying a small bundle under his arm walks to the middle of the Allenby Bridge, which spans the Jordan River.

title: Court Again Postpones a Plan on Garbage Barge
description: A State Supreme Court Justice in Brooklyn today continued to block a plan to burn the contents of the garbage barge Mobro and set a hearing on the issue for next week.

title: Low-Key Mood, and Little Regret
description: It was hard to discern at first, obscured by the admiral's mild manner and matter-of-fact tone and clubby pipe-smoking and gentle, dimpled smile.

title:
Patents;
Urdu Computerized
description: LEAD: Computer composition of script for the Urdu group of languages - which includes Arabic, Persian and Punjabi - was patented this week by Akeel H. Kizilbash of Karachi, Pakistan. The inventor serves in the Pakistani Air Force. According to patent 4,680,710, basic constituent elements of the characters are stored in a computer memory and are joined on command.

title: Just Call It Playing With Nuclear Matches
description: To the Editor:

title: New Curb Seen On East Bloc
description: Top officials of Cocom, the Western trade body, have made progress in tightening controls on sensitive exports to Warsaw Pact nations after a two-day meeting here, Cocom sources said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JULY 18, 1987
description: Markets

title: The Admiral's Week: Time Off for Church
description: Admiral Poindexter was asked by Richard Leon, minority counsel to the House committee, to describe a typical day when he was serving as national security adviser.

title: In New Haven, Pizza Is Serious
description: If you think pizzas come out of stainless-steel ovens or, worse, from cardboard boxes in supermarket freezers, a field trip to New Haven is in order - not just to see the old-fashioned coal-fired ovens, but because no city in the United States takes its pizza as seriously as New Haven. Natives are as proud of the city's role in introducing ''tomato pies'' to America as they are of Yale. There are constant arguments over the thinness of the crust, the quality of the cheese, the amount of oil, the acidity of the tomatoes. You have not met a pizza maven until you have met one from New Haven.

title: In the Dark About Movies
description: We love Vietnam War movies.

title: 'Pizza' Conviction Is Dismissed
description: The conviction of a defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug case has been dismissed because he was shot and could not attend the end of the trial.

title: Atsuko Chiba, 46; A Writer who Told About Life With Cancer
description: Atsuko Chiba, a Japanese journalist known for her candid pieces describing her battle with cancer, died of the disease July 9 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Three Hurt in Beam Collapse At Theater Under Demolition
description: Three workmen were injured yesterday morning when a steel beam collapsed in a movie theater they were demolishing in midtown Manhattan.

title: Driving in the Dark
description: To the Editor:

title: CHAMPION SPARK PLUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the year-ago results reflect non-recurring, after-tax charges of $5.4 million for certain product phaseout and manufacturing restructuring costs of the Devilbiss Co. division, prior-year tax assessments and related interest and the write off of an uncollectible overseas spark plug account receivable.

title: Librarian Is Charged In an Embezzlement
description: The suspended head librarian of the University of New Haven has been charged with six counts of larceny and tampering with evidence in connection with the embezzlement of more than $150,000 from the school, officials said.

title: NICOLET INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $9,428,000.

title:
Patents;
Surveying Planets From Spacecraft
description: LEAD: A system for surveying the features of a planet from a spacecraft has been patented for the Hughes Aircraft Company of Los Angeles. A sensor aboard the craft is to be directed at the planet and alternately against a field of stars, to facilitate an accurate aim. Signals received from the planet are to be analyzed for information on its features.

title: Wheels of Fortune
description: Rush hour was steamy and anxious commuters packed the bus, swaying back and forth as it played stop-and-go up Third Avenue.

title: U.S SUSPENDS SAVINGS BOND SALES
description: The Treasury announced today that it had suspended all sales of savings bonds, effective Saturday. Officials also said they would probably cancel a sale of other Treasury securities scheduled for Monday and might have to put off a sale planned for Thursday.

title: Dewey Warren
description: The insurance broker Dewey Warren Holdings P.L.C. said it planned to raise its stake in the merchant bankers Morgan Grenfell Group P.L.C. to 7.85 million shares, from 1.15 million. It also said it planned to start a rights issue for an unspecified sum. Buying 6.7 million shares would cost the company about $:33.2 million, or $53.2 million. Dewey is capitalized at about $:12 million.

title: THE SOIL IS RIPE FOR CONTENTMENT
description: I KNEW the earth so well when I was young; it was a constant friend. Its feel and smell were part of every day. I knew our yard - all one and a half acres of it - like the back of my hand. I could have walked it blindfolded then, and can still - some 30 years later - sketch it on paper in labeled detail. I did that a few years ago, and sent it to my mother on Mother's Day.

title: WHO'S NOT IN THE HALL OF FAME WHO SHOULD BE
description: Jim Bunning would be a Jim Dandy selection to the Hall of Fame. Since retiring in 1971, Bunning has been eligible for 11 years, but the first pitcher since Cy Young to win 100 games and fan 1,000 batters in each league has not received the honor he deserves. GIL RENBERG Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Art
description: Although some prominent younger artists, including Julian Schnabel, have looked hard at the paintings of Francis Bacon, there is a general feeling in the art community that the file on the 77-year-old English artist is now closed. Yet, it is clear from the show of Bacon's works at the Marlborough Gallery (40 West 57th Street, through July 31) that his pictorial intelligence is undiminished. And he has meant too much to postwar art to be written off without serious consideration of his achievement.

title: Deaths at a Prison Hospital Lead to Inquiries
description: A series of deaths at the Bridgewater State Hospital for the Criminally Insane has touched off a dispute in which correction officials, guards and relatives of inmates are trading accusations.

title: MOVIES
description: Sid and Nancy Starring Gary Oldman and Chloe Webb. Produced by Eric Fellner. Directed by Alex Cox. 1986. Embassy Home Entertainment. 111 minutes. $79.95. Home viewers who have not seen the movie before will have only an inkling of what provoked such critical enthusiasm for ''Sid and Nancy.'' Alex Cox's film about the violent, downward-plunging lives of Sid Vicious and Nancy Spungen does not benefit from being seen on a small screen. Faulty sound reproduction blurs the dialogue and too many of the scenes were filmed in dark interiors.

title: Is Our Choice Democracy or Covert Activities?; Vitality of Our System
description: To the Editor:

title: The Education of an Entrepreneur
description: WHEN I left M.I.T. 30 years ago to start a business, I'm not sure I could pronounce the word entrepreneur. Today, entrepreneur is a hot word. It's a challenging word, a fascinating word.

title: Connecticut Q&A: John H. Filer; 'WE ARE NOT A SELFISH SOCIETY'
description: JOHN H. FILER, the former chief executive of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, headed a commission 13 years ago that made a ground-breaking inquiry into philanthropy called ''Giving in America,'' and later studied a streamlining of Connecticut's government. Mr. Filer, 62 years old, has retired from Aetna and returned to private law practice, but philanthropy and government issues remain his concerns. He is the chairman of the Independent Sector, the nation's largest philanthropic coalition. Sitting in his office in a Hartford skyscraper, Mr. Filer reflected recently on the relationship among private business, government and the nation's 350,000 nonprofit organizations. Following are some excerpts from the conversation:

title: SUDDENLY, THE CONGRESS IS WORRIED ABOUT A BUDGET
description: REPRESENTATIVE TRENT LOTT of Mississippi, the House Republican whip, emerged from a meeting with the President on domestic issues last week to face a bank of microphones and a barrage of questions on the Iran-contra hearings. He fielded several and finally he snapped: ''Contrary to what might appear in the media, we still have a legislative agenda under way.''

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Easthampton, Mass.;
Rapid Growth Troubles Town
description: LEAD: WHEN a 41-acre farm here was sold to a developer last year for $193,000, local officials became concerned that the town was being developed at a rate faster than the water, sewer or school systems could manage.

LONG ISLAND SOUND;

The Rev. David B. Van Dusen performed the ceremony.

description: FOR little more than 22 months, Dorothy Tascoe's home has been a small furnished apartment in this, the town in which she grew up.

title: MIDLIFE MUSIC
description: I can sympathize with Marty Goldensohn and his struggle to keep up with music today (About Men, ''Midlife Music,'' June 21). It's easier when your kids are older and they play their own records; it also helps to drive two hours a day to work so that you can listen to all that new music in your car.

description: John Frum is coming, and so is Prince Philip. They will bring planeloads of such wealth as the world has never known and deposit it on the lip of the volcano that still snorts molten lava.

title: Rehabilitation Riles West Side Tenants
description: RESIDENTS of a newly rehabilitated brownstone at 61-63 West 104th Street in Manhattan threw a party for themselves last month and, giving in to their collective sense of humor, they turned on all the individual heating units in their eight apartments. The result: The building started to vibrate.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: GOVERNOR KEAN'S controversial proposal to create a Clean Ocean Authority is now a generally popular proposal for a coastal commission, but a major legislative battle could still loom over the details.

title: Dr. Peter W. Roome Jr. Is Wed to Marie Serrell
description: The wedding of Marie Mulhall Serrell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Machen Mulhall of Riverside, Conn., to Dr. Peter Willemse Roome Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roome of Greenwich, Conn., took place yesterday.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: DOMESTIC AFFAIRS: Enduring the Pleasures of Motherhood and Family Life. By Joyce Maynard. (Times Books, $17.95.) This well-organized collection of newspaper columns and essays on motherhood and family life will be familiar territory for anyone who has raised or is still in the process of raising young children.

title: Landslide Hits Italian Resort After Heavy Rains, Killing 7
description: A landslide caused by three days of heavy rain struck a mountain resort hotel today and killed seven people, the news agency Ansa said.

description: To the Editor:

title: ROMANTIC MUSICAL FILLS BILL
description: NAME a very romantic musical that takes place more than 100 years ago, has only a half-dozen characters and isn't very well known.

title: In the Green Hills of Cantabria
description: The green hills and grazing cattle may remind a visitor of Britain or Switzerland. It is Cantabria in northern Spain, however, nestled between the Basque country to the east and Asturias to the west.

title: Raising a Million for 'Les Mis'
description: AS theatergoers were raving about the hit Broadway musical ''Les Miserables'' earlier this year, the New York theater community was buzzing about another complex tale. This one told of Karen Goodwin, an industrial psychologist, and Elizabeth Williams, an art history professor, and how they got the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company to raise more than $1 million for the London and Broadway productions of 'Les Mis,' as it came to be known. The entrepreneurial spirit of Mutual Benefit's new president, Henry E. Kates, plays an important role in this story. So do some happy coincidences.

title: AIDS Case Barred by Airlines
description: An American diagnosed as having AIDS left today on a United States Air Force plane bound for the United States after commercial air carriers refused to fly him because of his illness.

description: While William J. Casey lived, the Reagan Administration had few figures of greater myth and mystery.

title: NARROW FEET MEAN ELONGATED ELEGANCE
description: Re: Topics, ''Two Feet and a Long Search,'' Opinion Page, June 14:

title: East End
description: To the Editor: Regrettably Matthew Reisz's excellent article on the East End's Jewish heritage (Travel, June 7) made no reference to any of the area's pugilists. The most famous was Daniel Mendoza, the fighting Jew from Whitechapel, who held the British heavyweight championship from 1791 to 1795. Weighing only 160 pounds, he consistently defeated heavier men by his speed and boxing ability. During the Regency period prizefighting enjoyed the patronage and protection of the gentry, and Mendoza was the subject of a portrait by Constable.

title: U.S. and Japan In Federation Cup
description: The defending champion United States will meet unseeded Japan in the first main round of the 1987 Federation Cup international women's team tennis competition, which runs from July 26-Aug. 2.

title: SUPPORT ON RISE FOR MIGRANT LABOR
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH their living and working conditions are still among the poorest in the state, migrant farm workers have gained support from a number of New Jersey residents and officials.

title: TAKEN FOR PATRICIANS
description: THE NEWTON LETTER By John Banville. 81 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $12.95.

title: Merkur's Hatchback Cousin
description: WHEN Ford Motor Company introduced its Merkur into the United States in 1985, the car turned a lot of heads. It wasn't so much that it was good-looking. It was just, well . . . mightily different.

title: BIRDMEN OF DAYTON
description: WILBUR AND ORVILLE A Biography of the Wright Brothers. By Fred Howard. Illustrated. 530 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: Opera: 'Cavalleria' and 'Pagliacci'
description: WHEN the customer asks for ham and eggs, it would probably be a mistake to put something fancier on the table. The New York City Opera therefore served up fairly unsurprising new productions of those inseparable dishes ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and ''Pagliacci'' on Friday evening. However, several of the company's singers came through with honor in both one-acters and, ultimately, the crude, unsheathed emotions of the Mascagni and Leoncavallo music did cut their way to the surface. The aim no doubt was to put this durable double-bill back into the repertory in respectable, workable stagings. If so, that was accomplished.

title: Stevenson Retires
description: AFTER winning three Olympic boxing titles and three world amateur championships, Teofilo Stevenson of Cuba has ended his career, according to a Cuban official, who said that the 36-year-old boxer was now an instructor and would not fight again. The official, who asked not to be identified, also told The Associated Press in Havana that Stevenson had been charged in connection with the death of a motorcyle rider in a traffic accident two months ago, but insisted that the incident had nothing to do with the boxer's decision to retire from international competition.

title:
GARDENING;
THE FINE ART OF PINCHING
description: LEAD: ONE of the most important practices used to train or control plants is the pinch.

title: BROOKHAVEN CONSIDERS BANNING PIT BULLS
description: LEAD: A PROPOSAL to ban pit bull terriers from residential areas in the Town of Brookhaven has aroused dog owners' concern.

title: CRAIGIN HOWARD BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Craigin Lee Howard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Calhoun Ludlow Harper Howard of Oak Bluffs, Mass., was married yesterday to James Glenn Salsgiver Jr., the son of Mrs. Salsgiver of Westport, Conn., and the late Mr. Salsgiver. The Rev. Francis B. Sayre, former Dean of the National Cathedral in Washington, performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title: A Boy Who Could Have Been Ours
description: WE are new parents, my husband, William, and I. Our little boy was born in November and he is magnificently healthy and happy. Since his birth, his father and I have discovered that we would drop almost anything to be with our son. Things we used to rely on for entertainment - like parties, brunches and cocktails - have become inconsequential. Now William claims his big thrill is feeding the baby banana rice cereal or whatever new food he's ready to try. (I believe him.) We've asked each other what we ever did with our free time before our son was born, and we have reached the conclusion that we must have been incredibly bored with the long stretches of hours we once had for leisure. Now the baby is front and center in our lives and takes care of all our extra minutes. We cannot imagine anything more important than him on the face of the earth and assumed that feeling of delight we have for our new son was shared by all parents for their children.

title: American Laboratories, Foreign Brains
description: HALF of the students in the classrooms of Andrew Frank, professor of mechanical engineering at the University of California at Davis, are foreigners. Sixty of the 400 scientists employed by the Pittsburgh-based Rockwell International Corporation are foreign.

title: POSTINGS: 186,000 Sq. Ft.; Danbury Square
description: Some developers think more is better when it comes to shopping centers.

title: INQUIRY SHORTENS LIST OF WITNESSES STILL TO TESTIFY
description: After Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter finishes testifying before the Iran-contra committees early next week, only five more witnesses are scheduled to appear before the hearings end, probably in early August.

title: Q and A
description: Balloon Mortgage Question: I bought a co-op apartment about four years ago and at the time I took a balloon loan from the sponsor of the co-op. The final payment will be due in October 1988. Last year I decided to change jobs and my new position is not working out as well as I had expected. My monthly income has declined and I am just able to make my mortgage and maintenance payments. I have about half of the cash due on the final payment. I understand that I do not qualify for a homeowner's equity loan. Can you offer some advice? S. S., Manhattan Answer: While most banks do not offer co-op owners home equity loans, Stanley Greenstein, vice president of Mortgage Clearing House, a Long Island mortgage referral service, said you have other options.

title: BOLD IRANIAN RAID ON FRENCH CRAFT HEIGHTENS GULF TENSIONS
description: AS United States Navy ships prepare to escort Kuwaiti tankers that will fly the Stars and Stripes in the Persian Gulf, the attack last week on a French container ship made clear some of the risks of challenging Iran. On Monday, two gunboats that the French believe were manned by Iranian Revolutionary Guards sprayed the merchant ship Ville d'Anvers with machine-gun fire for 20 minutes. By week's end, the two countries had broken off diplomatic relations. Yesterday, Iran accused all the French diplomats detained inside the French Embassy in Teheran of being spies and said they would be ''arrested'' and brought to ''Islamic justice.''

title: Next Week; Are Knicks Back on Track Now?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: TREKKING THROUGH DARKEST LONDON By Christopher Hope. 218 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95.
description: THE HOTTENTOT ROOM

title: Pakistani Accused Of Seeking Alloy to Make Atom Bomb
description: Arshad Z. Pervez, a Canadian citizen who was born in Pakistan, has been trying for months to buy a special steel alloy that could be used in making nuclear weapons, according to a Customs Service affidavit filed July 10 in Federal Court in Philadelphia. Mr. Pervez was arrested and accused of giving $1,000 to an undercover agent posing as a Commerce Department official as a partial payment to get an export license for the alloy, Maraging 350.

title: THE BLOODIEST BATTLE
description: William Manchester's article ''The Bloodiest Battle of All'' (June 14) was the most moving piece I have ever read on the nature of war, and, particularly, battle.

title: WHAT COMFORTS AIDS FAMILIES
description: There were missed opportunities in Lou Ann Walker's article. Another loss, secondary to the quick killer AIDS, is that many families are robbed of the time needed to respond to the information that a family member is gay. It is not uncommon for families initially to react with hostility toward a gay member, sometimes refusing to speak to him, disowning him, etc.

title: Competition Intensifies for Well-Located Buildings
description: AFTER amassing more than 100 hotels in small-city and suburban settings, Aircoa Holdings made its first move into New York City a few months ago. The Denver-based company took over a small, old hotel with a good address - the sort of establishment enjoying a lucrative revival in older cities throughout the country.

title: Correction
description: A Travel Advisory item May 24 incorrectly suggested that travelers could apply for passports at the Northeast Passport Processing Center on Varick Street in New York. Applications filed at court houses and post offices are processed at the center, but it is not open to the public.

title: Matching Wits With New York Fare-Beaters
description: The New York City Transit Authority, which estimates that it loses $100 million a year to fare-beaters, is tired of being taken for so many rides.

title: Cost Bringing Punishments Out of Prison
description: Seven days a week, Charles Marston loads his newly purchased van with carpentry tools and heads out to do home improvements. The hours are long, but he says: ''I'm scratching by. Life has never looked so good, and it sure beats jail.''

title: Tourist Misinformation
description: Picture a first-time visitor to New York City standing on the little traffic island in Times Square, studying the maps on the information kiosk. She is looking for a place to eat.

title: JENNIFER AIKEN, A TEACHER, MARRIES HOWARD FULTON JR.
description: Jennifer Ann Aiken, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert McCutchen Aiken of West Chester, Pa., and London, was married yesterday to Howard Duer Fulton Jr., the son of Mr. Fulton of Wilmington, Del., and the late Mrs. Fulton. The Rev. Dr. Robert M. Doss, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Aiken home in West Chester.

title: Q and A
description: Babies in Japan

title: THE BLOODIEST BATTLE
description: William Manchester's description of Marines booing John Wayne at the Aiea Naval Hospital in Hawaii is hard to believe. He claims that Wayne was a ''symbol of fake machismo we came to hate.'' Come now, that word was not used in 1945.

title: Is Our Choice Democracy or Covert Activities?; Power to Make War
description: To the Editor:

title: CYNTHIA A. CAREY AND C. B. LALONE WED IN MANHASSET
description: The marriage of Cynthia Ann Carey, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis J. Carey Jr. of Sands Point, L.I., and North Palm Beach, Fla., to Charles Bernard LaLone took place yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, L.I. The bridegroom is a son of Marie T. LaLone of Locust Valley, L.I., and Bernard H. LaLone of Locust Valley and Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Lawrence Costello performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Vincent Hart and the Rev. Mario Costa.

title: WHO'S NOT IN THE HALL OF FAME WHO SHOULD BE
description: Jacob Nelson (Nellie) Fox. When compared with other middle infielders, Fox clearly appears to belong in Cooperstown. Fox's .288 career average is better than those of (among others) Johnny Evers, Joe Morgan, Bill Mazeroski, Pee Wee Reese, Joe Gordon, Phil Rizzuto, Ernie Banks, Luis Aparicio and Maury Wills. One more argument for Fox is that he was already elected. Seventy-five percent of the writers' votes are required for election, and in 1985 Fox received 74.7 percent of the votes. The Hall, however, decided that a ''pure'' 75 percent was needed. The rule can be found nowhere in the election rules and is totally unfair. I don't try to suggest that Fox was the greatest infielder ever, but he was better than most. JOHN R. KELLBACH Ringwood, N.J.

title: RESIDENTIAL RESALES
description: Closings in the week ended July 4 MANHATTAN Chelsea $490,000 77 Seventh Avenue (14th St.) (Vermeer) 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,100-sq.-ft. postwar, penthouse co-op; 24-hr. doorman, large kitchen, 1,000-sq.-ft. terrace, 3 exposures; maintenance $799, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Kingman Associates) Gramercy Park $665,000 7 Gramercy Park 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. condo in a renovated prewar building; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, high ceilings, windowed kitchen, Gramercy Park views; common charge $800, taxes $3,468 (Broker:

title: WHO'S NOT IN THE HALL OF FAME WHO SHOULD BE
description: Thurman Munson's career statistics rival or surpass every catcher who has been inducted in the Baseball Hall of Fame, and on that basis alone, he has rightfully earned a place in Cooperstown. Munson's case, however, is strengthened by the intangibles that ordinarily weigh heavily in distinguishing the great from the good. Fiercely proud and determined, Munson played with pain and nagging injuries. Recognized as the premier clutch hitter of his era, Munson amassed a .373 career average in World Series play. A top handler of pitchers, Munson excelled in calling a ball game. In the eight years since his death, the American League has not seen a catcher of comparable talents. MIKE CERRA JOE CERRA Roselle, N.J.

title:
GARDENING;
THE FINE ART OF PINCHING
description: LEAD: ONE of the most important practices used to train or control plants is the pinch.

title: CHRISTIAN PUBLISHING INDUSTRY DOES A HARD SELL ON RELIGION
description: THEY call themselves ''God's retailers'' because they think of their bookstores as ministries as well as businesses. Last week, about 10,000 such entrepreneurs, who either sell or manufacture products ranging from leather-bound Bibles to ''Jesus Loves You'' Frisbees, gathered here in Orange County for the annual trade show of the Christian Booksellers Association.

title: Mayor vs. Mouse, Or Long Live TV
description: NOT often is New York's expansive Mayor upstaged. But a television cartoon character, Danger Mouse, threatened to pull off the feat in March, when the mouse's show was bumped from television to make room for a Sunday morning program featuring Mayor Koch.

title: INDIAN PLAN WORRIES SOUTHAMPTON
description: LEAD: THE dream of a Shinnecock Indian woman to build a Native American museum and cultural center has sparked a debate over zoning that threatens 347 years of relative harmony between the Town of Southampton and the Shinnecock tribe.

title: Land Is Bought for Preserve
description: Eight parcels of forested land in the Adirondack Mountains totaling 1,459 acres have been bought by New York State to be added to the State Forest Preserve, according to the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: VDT BILL: ALL EYES ON SUFFOLK LEGISBATION
description: LEAD: A SUFFOLK COUNTY bill to regulate video-display terminals, the basic computer tool for millions of employees in service and high-tech industries across the country, has touched off a controversy.

title: OIL PRICES AND IMPORTS RISE BUT GAS LINES ARE UNLIKELY
description: AFTER a long spell of glutted markets and sliding prices, American consumers suddenly find that nearly all the news about oil is bad: The average retail price of gasoline has climbed back up to $1 a gallon, inventories of crude oil and petroleum products have dropped to the lowest level for this time of year since 1973, and demand is rising twice as fast as most analysts expected.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
DRAMA
description: LEAD: Our Town By Thornton Wilder. Starring Hal Holbrook, Sada Thompson, Barbara Bel Geddes. MasterVision. New York, N.Y. 120 minutes. $74.95. Anyone who has studied drama is all too familiar with this 1938 Pulitzer Prize-winning play. Nothing much happens, certainly nothing extraordinary, which is why one critic once called it ''perilously close to banality.

title: INTRODUCING PLAYWIRGHTS TO TELEVISION CAMERAS
description: EACH summer, theater buffs flock to the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford to attend public readings of new stage plays being developed at the National Playwrights Conference there. Also developed at the conference are television works for which there are no public showings. Of the dozen playwrights whose works were selected for this year's conference, running from June 29 through July 26, two - Donald Drake and Richard Dresser - are developing plays for television.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A MIDSUMMER SALE OF UNUSUAL COINS
description: LEAD: FOUR coin dealers will join forces in Chicago next week to conduct Auction '87, one of the year's biggest coin sales. It is the ninth in a series of midsummer sales held under the joint auspices.

title: Mets Let Another Slip Away
description: How is this for blowing the opportunity: The Mets took the field last night knowing that the St. Louis Cardinals had already lost in San Diego for the second time in three days, and all they had to do was beat the Cincinnati Reds to jump one game closer to first place.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: LEAD: SLOWLY, SLOWLY IN THE WIND, by Patricia Highsmith. (Mysterious Press, $8.95.) In a dozen tales of suspense, Patricia Highsmith explores abnormal psychology, obsession and murder. ''Most jolt with a surprise ending and all shake up our comfortable expectations of reality,'' one reviewer said in 1985.

title: Ideology Plays Role In Suffolk Contest
description: THE Republican primary for the Suffolk County Executive nomination is shaping up as a case of ideology versus organization, according to Republicans on both sides of that struggle.

title: Supertitles in Concert
description: To the Editor:

title: South Korea Struggles to Find Its Future
description: FOR the moment, the streets of Seoul are quiet. The student and church radicals who led the demonstrations last month are on vacation or regrouping after winning major concessions. And economic growth, always a point of national pride, is still as lusty as ever.

title: The Buck Stops There!
description: For the first few days of Admiral Poindexter's testimony, the audience at the Iran-contra hearings was silent and even solemn. But by the end of the first week, when he explained that misrepresenting the truth to the Congress was no ''lie'' and concealing the facts was no ''cover-up,'' people began to laugh.

title: Tone Color in Audio Design
description: DIFFERENCES IN TIMBRE - or tone color - are the chief consideration in choosing one audio component in preference to another. This is particularly true of loudspeakers, phono cartridges and CD players, where subtle tonal shadings characteristic of a particular model may inspire delight or dislike.

title: Data Bank: July 19, 1987
Jazz in July
description: Here is the schedule of the 92d Street Y Jazz in July Festival. All programs begin at 8 P.M. This week: Tuesday - ''Stomp Off,'' with the Jim Cullum Jazz band and Vince Giordano and the Nighthawks playing the music of Benny Goodman in the 1920's, featuring Phil Bodner on clarinet. ''Stridemonster!'' with Carrie Smith, vocals, and Dick Wellstood and Dick Hyman, duo pianists.

title: Schroeder Can Qualify for U.S. Funds After Donations at NOW Convention
description: Representative Patricia Schroeder brought her undecided quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination to the National Organization for Women convention here today and walked away with enough money to qualify for Federal matching campaign funds, NOW officials said.

title: BICENTENNIAL FOR AN INTERNATIONAL TREATY
description: THE United States Postal Service and Morocco are celebrating the bicentennial of a treaty that marks 200 years of friendship between the two nations. The first day ceremonies were held simultaneously in Washington and Rabat last Friday.

title: THE CRUCIAL TASK OF TRAINING BROKERS
description: THESE are hectic times for brokerage firms, faced with intense competition in the financial marketplace. The barriers that once separated financial territories have been removed. Now brokerage firms, banks and insurance companies all are vying to sell the same customer a variety of financial products and services. With the securities industry growing at a record pace, brokerage houses are finding that both seasoned brokers and new recruits need more training than ever before to familiarize themselves with new products and current financial rules and regulations. It is 4:15 P.M., and in the White Plains office of Merrill Lynch, 50 brokers have gathered in the auditorium to hear a lecture on a current popular product: a single-premium whole-life policy. ''Six members of this group have just completed four-and-a-half months of training,'' said Bernard A. Taub, the 53-year-old vice president and manager of Merrill Lynch's three Westchester offices -in White Plains, Mount Kisco and Eastchester.

title: WHO'S NOT IN THE HALL OF FAME WHO SHOULD BE
description: The unjustly forgotten Ken Williams. When Williams roamed the outfield for the St. Louis Browns in the 1920's, they were not the bedraggled Brownies of lore, but one of the American League's better outfits. A Hall of Famer, George Sisler, played first base for those Brownies; no keeping him out of Cooperstown. Williams, their second-brightest star, deserves another look from the archive-keepers. MICHAEL HOROWITZ Kingston, N.Y.

title: SARAH ROBINSON IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eliot Robinson of Old Bennington, Vt., and Sarasota, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Mitchell Robinson to Kevin Michael McGarghan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward McGarghan of Burlington, Vt. The future bride, who graduated from the Buxton School and the University of Vermont, is animal-control officer for the city of Burlington. She is a great-granddaughter of the late Albert Kahn, the architect. Her fiance is an officer in the Burlington Police Department. An Aug. 29 wedding is planned.

title: SHOREHAM'S CRITICS IGNORE REALITIES
description: NEWSPAPER articles about possible blackouts on Long Island are reminiscent of the old Pearl White movie series, with one difference. Pearl White faced the same size villain, the same size hero and variations of the same size danger each week.

title:
FILM;
Britain's Emily Lloyd: Sweet 16 and a Smash
description: LEAD: CANNES AT FILM FESTIVAL time is notoriously prone to sudden crushes and intemperate crazes, and Emily Lloyd isn't the first unknown actress to have inflamed its talent spotters and celebrity hunters. Others, too, have spent their mornings evading the autograph sleuths, their afternoons being interviewed by the magazines, their evenings being feted by the famous.

title: LIFE BEFORE PROLIFERATION
description: STEMMING THE TIDE Arms Control in the Johnson Years. By Glenn T. Seaborg with Benjamin S. Loeb. Illustrated. 495 pp. Lexington, Mass.: Lexington Books. $24.95.

title: MOVIES, BOOKS AND THE REAL STORY
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOL SAID TO BE LAX ON AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: LEAD: AFFIRMATIVE-action practices in hiring and promotions at the Univerity of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey are said to come under fire in a new research report scheduled for review by the university's board of trustees on Thursday.

title: Reunions
description: To the Editor: ''Reunion Tactics for the Family'' (Practical Traveler, May 24) by Betsy Wade brought back fond memories of our family reunion last June when 58 of us from various parts of the world gathered at Quisisana on Lake Kezar, Me. We had perfect accommodations, ample facilities for family meetings, delicious food and cheerful service by a talented staff who entertained us nightly in a variety of musical programs.

title: MARTIN BREGMAN JUGGLES PROJECTS TO MAKE A MOVIE
description: THESE ARE FRUSTRAT-ing days for a movie producer. Hundreds of scripts are put into development by the studios, but nervous executives postpone the start of production as long as possible. When the day finally approaches for the studio to commit $15 million to film the script and another $10 million to market the film, the easiest decision is to drop the project. And so the producer who has nurtured the project for a couple of years must begin again shopping it around town, hoping that the end of the journey will not be another rejection.

title: 'NEW ROMANTIC LANDSCAPE' AT THE STAMFORD WHITNEY
description: REPRESENTED by artists as diverse as Blake and Goya, Delacroix and Caspar David Friedrich, Romanticism is easier to recognize than define. It's no easy matter to determine its life span either, for, though the movement didn't begin in earnest until the early 19th century, its spirit is visible in the mid-1700's, notably in the ''blot'' drawing of the English watercolorist Alexander Cozens.

title: A COUPLE SHARE ESTHETIC SENSIBILITY
description: LEAD: WHEN two artists are married to each other, they may or may not develop a creative union reflecting their conjugal life. Many artists shy away from too close an identification with the work of their spouses, while others go as far as possible in the other direction, working in collaboration and signing their pieces jointly.

title: Teams From South and West Play for National Bridge Title
description: Bridge teams from the San Francisco and New Orleans areas clashed here this afternoon in the final of the Grand National Team Championship.

title: A TAX RISE LOOMS DESPITE SOME GAINS
description: LEAD: DESPITE ending the last fiscal year with a $20.4 million surplus and winning permission from the state to begin collecting a new hotel tax, Westchester County officials are fearful that the 1988 budget may require another sizable increase in property taxes.

title: Temporary Order Keeps Woman Alive in Jersey Right-to-Die Case
description: A New Jersey Supreme Court justice today temporarily barred the family of a comatose woman from removing her feeding tube against the wishes of a nursing home.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate 1. Trade Reorganization: Vote to kill an amendment to the omnibus trade bill that would reorganize the Department of Commerce into the Department of Industry and Technology, and the office of the United States Trade Representative into the United States Trade Administration. Approved 73 to 21, July 14. 1 Connecticut Dodd (D) Y Weicker (R) Y Delaware Roth (R) Y Biden (D) A Maryland Mikulski (D) N Sarbanes (D) N Massachusetts Kennedy (D) N Kerry (D) Y New Jersey Bradley (D) Y Lautenberg (D) Y New York D'Amato (R) Y Moynihan (D) N Pennsylvania Heinz (R) Y Specter (R) Y Rhode Island Pell (D) Y Chafee (R) Y Virginia Trible (R) Y Warner (R) Y HOUSE 1.
