title: A Rule for the Rough Times
description: Craig Stadler's latest conflict with the rules of golf should never have happened. Most people here think the man known as the Walrus should have been aware of the rule he violated in the first round of the 116th British Open while trying to extricate himself from the haylike rough to the left of Muirfield's fifth fairway.

title: Thatcher Came To Praise Reagan
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was riding the high end of the seesaw last week as she flew into Washington to say a good word for Ronald Reagan, her ideological soulmate. ''Now more than ever we need American leadership and your President is uniquely able to give it and will give it,'' the British Conservative leader said.

title: Headliners; Out of Reach
description: The Italian Government is not a great enough authority to command obedience from the Vatican, according to a ruling last week by Italy's highest court. The court ruled for the Vatican in a case in which Italian prosecutors sought to extradite Archbishop Paul C. Marcinkus, the head of the Vatican bank, on charges of fraud related to the 1982 failure of Banco Ambrosiano. Ambrosiano went under when it was unable to collect $1.3 billion in loans to 10 shadowy companies controlled by the Vatican bank. Church officials agreed to pay $250 million to Ambrosiano's creditors, but denied any wrongdoing. In February, authorities issued warrants for the arrests of Archbishop Marcinkus and two other church officials who remained out of reach at the Vatican, straining relationships between the Italian Government and the Catholic city-state. The court ruled last week that the warrants were invalid because Vatican officials are not answerable to Italy. Said the American-born Archbishop, ''My faith in Italian justice has been restored.''

title: PIANIST RE-ENTERS AN INTERRUPTED CAREER
description: LEAD: A LITTLE over two years ago, Alicia Zizzo decided she was going to go for it, a career as a classical pianist. ''The recitalist is about as desirable as a toothache, and yet here I am excited about my new career and determined to make my mark,'' she said.

title: This Band Speaks for Lowbrows and Underdogs
description: COULD SUCCESS SPOIL THE RE-placements? Not if they have anything to say about it. On ''Pleased to Meet Me,'' the Minneapolis band's fifth full-length album (Sire 25557-1; LP, cassette and CD), the band declares, ''The sweet smell that they adore -I think I'd rather smother,'' and they describe themselves with ''one foot in the door/ the other foot in the gutter.'' In ''Shooting Dirty Pool,'' they tell a music-business type, ''Do yourself a favor/ get yourself a spine''; in ''I.O.U.'' they tell a deal maker, ''I want it in writing - I owe you nothing.''

title: RALPH LAUREN'S ILLUSION
description: Rather than fostering an illusion, Ralph Lauren is the one American designer who understands women and whose clothes fit our life style (Fashion, ''The Americans Who Lead,'' by Carrie Donovan, June 28.) What passes for creativity in the fashion reporter's ivory tower looks unwearable to us out here in the real world. If bodysuits and miniskirts aren't our bag, we can head for the nearest Ralph Lauren department and find comfortable timeless clothes in beautiful natural fabrics that suit any age group and almost any shape.

title: Trinkets but Still No Gold at Wreck
description: ABOARD THE SOSI INSPECTOR, off Massachusetts, July 15 - The cluster of plastic milk crates the divers sent up this afternoon from the wreck of the Republic contained a case of beer bottles from the second-class dining pantry, an ornate window from the first-class smoking salon and a cut-glass vase, intact and unmarked.

title: JAPAN PONDERS THE PRICE OF SOVIET TRADE
description: LONG after the discovery that the Toshiba Machine Company had illegally sold propeller-milling equipment to the Soviet Union, the aftershocks are still rattling Japan and increasing tensions with the United States. Virulent American reactions, including threats of bans on Toshiba imports and the smashing of a Toshiba radio by members of Congress, have forced the Japanese to face issues that had seemed remote, notably national security and its link to trade.

title: WHO'S NOT IN THE HALL OF FAME WHO SHOULD BE
description: Dick (Rowdy Richard) Bartell is long overdue for the Hall of Fame. His 18-year batting and fielding statistics combined are better than half the shortstops in the Hall of Fame, and Phil Rizzuto, too. He outhit Reese by 15 points. He dominated National League shortstops in the 30's by any measure. And he was a winner. His pepper and hustle were contagious. His credentials are in order. The veterans committee is out of order by ignoring him. NORMAN L. MACHT Thompson, Conn.

title: SHERYL GRAFF FIANCEE OF DR. J. S. SCHREIBER
description: Sheryl Lisa Graff, who graduated from the Harvard Law School in June, and Dr. Jonathan Scot Schreiber, a surgical resident at the New York University Medical Center, are planning a Sept. 13 wedding. Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Robert Graff of Woodmere, L.I., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Dr. and Mrs. Irving Schreiber of Rockaway, N.J.

title: Living in Luxury in Bangkok
description: After a few nights in one of Bangkok's best hotels, most people would willingly give up the familiarity of their own bed and pillow in exchange for the pampering: room service that never stops, impeccably attired staff that anticipates your every move, laundry wrapped in gift packages decorated with real flowers.

title: Fearing a Fuel Crisis, Burundi Turns to Peat
description: The Irish sent bog engineers; the Finns sold harvesters, and the Americans financed stove research.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN EMPLOYEE HEALTH PLANS
description: IN corporate offices around the country, the complaints about the high cost of medical care seem to be getting louder. Spending on medical care by private sources, mainly business, has more than tripled since 1975, to $140 billion last year, according to the Division of National Cost Estimates, a unit of the United States Department of Health and Human Services. Business now pays about 30 percent of the nation's annual medical bill, up from 25 percent 10 years ago.

title: They Changed With Seasons
description: Bo Jackson, who is playing major league baseball with the Kansas City Royals, signed last week to play pro football in the fall with the Los Angeles Raiders, once the baseball season ends. Many athletes who have tried in the past to juggle two sports look at Jackson's ambitious plans with understanding, encouragement, skepticism, apprehension or some combination of the above.

title: Dance Festival in Durham
description: To the Editor:

title: COUNTRY FARE IN A GARDEN SETTING
description: PEOPLE driving past Ma Chere in Woodmere no doubt notice the big red caboose in front and perhaps think of children's birthday parties, Cokes, burgers and Shirley Temples. But this is a French country restaurant in a garden setting.

title: Blackmun Is Recovering
description: Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the Supreme Court is recuperating from minor hernia surgery, and he canceled a speaking engagement scheduled for today, a Court spokeswoman said. The 78-year-old Justice had the operation in Rochester, Minn., after the Court term ended June 26, the spokeswoman, Toni House, said Friday night.

title: WHO'S NOT IN THE HALL OF FAME WHO SHOULD BE
description: In this era of superstars (with super statistics and super salaries to match), we tend to lose sight of the fact that the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown was originally intended to honor not only players of exceptional ability, but those of exemplary virtue and integrity as well. It is with this fact in mind that I state my case for the inclusion of Gil Hodges in the Hall of Fame. Hodges's statistics, while not of Ruthian magnitude, are nonetheless impressive, including 14 grand slams (long the National League record), 17 total bases in one game (also long the National League record) and the awesome, rarely achieved four home runs in a single game. Yet the real reasons for his enshrinement have little to do with his accomplishments with bat or glove. Instead, as any Hodges fan will tell you, Hodges belongs in the Hall because he was a gentle giant of a man, a quiet ex-Marine who owned the distinction of being such a fair-minded player that he was never ejected from a game. ANITA G. DENTE Brooklyn

title: PATRICIA TAGGART MARRIES IN JERSEY
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J., yesterday, Patricia Ann Taggart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Taggart of Oldwick, N.J., was married to James Latimer Bellis Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bellis of Bedminster, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla.

title: TILLING DOESN'T MEAN KILLING
description: GREEN THUMB, my anonymous tipster on botanical fertility rites of Long Island, called me the other day and he was hopping mad. He insisted that he had a message for the world, one that he thought might help stop the killing.

title: Jazz: Walt Levinsky Plays Goodman Swing
description: THE arrangements with which Benny Goodman established and maintained his standing in the jazz world during the Swing Era have been re-created by numerous groups, usually for nostalgic purposes, during the past 30 years. But they have rarely been heard in performances as crisply authoritative in the ensembles and appropriately personal in the solos as those by the 14-piece band led by Walt Levinsky, at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, through Aug. 1.

title: Boces Asks Expansion In Valhalla
description: LEAD: THE Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services has announced that the last of its 31 participating school districts voted approval of a $3 million building addition to its existing mid-Westchester campus in Valhalla. On Oct. 1, there will be a public referendum in the 31 districts on whether the project should be approved.

title: Jazz: Charles DeForest
description: CHARLES DEFOREST, an easygoing variant of Bobby Short who has been singing and playing piano in New York almost as long as Mr. Short, has moved into the Lounge at One Fifth Avenue (at Eighth Street) where he is performing in an open-ended run a repertory that is sometimes a challenging parallel to Mr. Short's songs and sometimes a venture into other areas, including his own provocative creations.

title: In Albany, Angry Legislators Bite Press
description: IN this year of strained relationships in Albany between Governor Cuomo and the Legislature and even between lawmakers themselves, few have been as strained as those involving the legislators and the press.

title: A Formidable U.S. Fleet Is Gathering
description: Sailors call the American guided-missile destroyer Kidd a ship of the ''Ayatollah class'' because four of the class were built for the Shah before Iran's revolutionary clergy toppled him. The ships wound up in the United States Navy, and today the Kidd is in the Persian Gulf to escort tankers past Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's forces.

title: President Says Support For Contras Is on Rise
description: President Reagan said in his weekly radio address today that support for the Nicaraguan rebels had dramatically grown as Americans learned the facts about Nicaragua.

title: SETTING THE PROPER SCENE
description: WE'VE HAD TWO MAJOR real estate deals made in our bar,'' Joe Silverberg confides. Coming as it does from a man in the business of selling suits, not spirits, that admission startles. But not much about Bigsby & Kruthers's lavish new two-story emporium in the heart of Chicago's financial district conforms to predictable notions of men's retailing.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: TURNCOAT: The Strange Case of British Sergeant Harold Cole, ''The Worst Traitor of the War.'' By Brendan Murphy. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) He was a dapper, blue-eyed six-footer with just the touch of eccentricity that, all Frenchmen were convinced, be tokened the British officer class.

title: 1,300 Who Help Rather Than Serve Terms
description: The biggest alternative sentencing program in New York City is run by the Vera Institute of Justice, a private group that conducts research and carries out programs in the criminal justice system.

title: Q. & A.: Ridding Marble of Rust
description: Q. I HAVE some beautiful marble steps leading up to the front entrance on the outside of my house.

title: Doubling the Square
description: Until 1976 when the city's first Greenmarket was set up in Union Square, drug peddlers perched on its fences like birds on telephone wires and the grass was trampled and strewn with litter. But the market brought in a new kind of customer - people looking for fresh vegetables, home-baked breads, local cheeses - and, suddenly, druggie's paradise became foodie's heaven.

title: ANOTHER PROBLEM ON WASTE IS LOOMING
description: WHILE the state wrestles with the public storm created by the problem of disposing of radon-contaminated soil and tries to convince some towns to accept a hazardous-waste treatment facility, another serious siting problem looms on the horizon.

title: CLEANING: ILLUSION, TRANQUILITY
description: I MAKE household special effects.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: GILLESPIE AND FRIENDS Dizzy Gillespie, the legendary jazz trumpeter whose puffed-cheeks trademark is the lament of high school music teachers everywhere, will perform at Monmouth Battlefield State Park Saturday afternoon and evening.

title: Wild Rice Harvest From Idaho's Lakes
description: Al Bruner dons ear protectors, sunglasses and a baseball cap, steps into his airboat harvester named Heron and roars away. It's August in St. Maries, Idaho, a tiny town just an hour and a half from Spokane, Wash., and the wild rice harvest is on.

title: A Times Sq. Cinema Nurtured By the 'Merchant of Menace'
description: IT is apparently the largest glass block facade in New York City, an unusual Art Moderne theater of blue and white glass with streamlined aluminum fins.

title: DISCREET MANEUVERS
description: THESE EXAMPLES MAY BE TOP-FLIGHT and top-priced, but they contain all the makings of the genre: a particular style of attire called discretion - better yet, deception - dressing. It has probably always existed, whatever the current fashion mode. But now, when clothes play such an overt role in pronouncing a woman's place in life or personal point of view, this deliberately discreet way of turning oneself out is even more intriguing. The idea is this: a woman gets herself up to look as if she will fade into the wallpaper or blend in with the rest of her secure crowd. She appears to demurely hide her natural assets or perhaps even imply genteel dowdiness. The effect, of course, is just the reverse. Men flock to the side of the supposed wallflower. Perhaps they are sure they will uncover the soul of a siren. Aileen Mehle, the society columnist known as Suzy, once wrote an essay in which she warned readers to watch out for the ''little brown wrens.'' The identities of the protagonists in that particular piece are not important, but their successors are having a field day cloaking their true high spirits in subtle, very subtle, camouflage. There are, for instance, devotees of the ''Miss Brody'' school of tweeds, classy casual clothes that evoke the spirit of the cinema's famous Scottish schoolteacher. Then there are intimations of proper schoolgirl garb, now made of sinuous silk instead of staunch gabardine. There are the indisputably correct ''insignia'' clothes that spell richness but in discreet letters. And a myriad of choices of evening dresses that cover from throat to ankle yet are heart-throbbingly pretty. Now, of course, there are many demure women who choose to dress in this way to display their true colors. But then again, can we ever be sure?

title: Lisa Paul to Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Rosenthal of Clearwater, Fla., and White Plains have announced the engagement of Mrs. Rosenthal's daughter Lisa Merideth Paul to Joel Andrew Levinson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Levinson of Delray Beach, Fla., and Marlboro, N.J. Ms. Paul, a daughter also of Robert Paul of Concord, Mass., is creative manager of special advertising sections for USA Weekend in New York. Her fiance is president of Lipp & Levinson Advertising in New York. An October wedding is planned.

title: WHAT DO THEY WANT?
description: MEN IN FEMINISM 288 pp. New York: Methuen. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $11.95.

title: A Love for Morgans Spurs a Trainer
description: When Lawrence Poulin returned to his home state of Maine after a disappointing year away, he had so little money that he had to use credit cards to pay his way back. He came home with his wife, their two children and a dream that one day he would be a respected horse trainer.

title: AT HOME WITH THE SUPERNATURAL
description: LEAD: SUGAR And Other Stories. By Antonia Byatt. 248 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $16.95.

title: MOVIES
description: About Last Night . . . With Rob Lowe, Demi Moore, James Belushi, Elizabeth Perkins. Directed by Edward Zwick. 1986. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 113 minutes. $79.95. Although only a year has elapsed since it was released, the romantic comedy ''About Last Night . . .'' now stands as a relic of another era: a time before AIDS-inspired fears, when easy sex typified by the one-night stand helped turn commitment into a dirty word.

title: Battling Tax Evaders, Finance Chief Wins Points With Koch
description: Mayor Koch had just completed a meeting with Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, in the Mayor's City Hall office one day last week. As he walked the Presidential aspirant out of the building, Mr. Koch was overheard mentioning two words that invariably bring a sparkle to his eyes, ''Abe Biderman.''

title: PROSPECTS
description: Competitive Labor Costs

title: Arizona's Canyon Of Waterfalls
description: LEAD: The trail drops sharply into Havasu Canyon. In a few moments modern Arizona is gone and magnificent vistas of the canyon unfold. A curtain of silence falls as the horses pick their footing along the narrow trail. The only sound is the sharp metal ring of their shoes striking stone.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: AMERICAN CHILDHOOD by David Willis McCullough. Little, Brown & Company. 405 pages. $19.95.

title: >A CONDUCTOR BEARING CLASSICS
description: LEAD: THE conductor Stephen Pomerantz is determined to break down what he calls ''that stone edifice people think of as classical music.''

title: Headliners; Overzealous
description: Who says the Internal Revenue Service is heartless?

title: COLONEL NORTH AND ZEALOTRY'S THREAT
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's televised testimony at the Congressional inquiry concerning his role in the Iran-contra affair reveals a person of total commitment and fervent dedication. His youthful good looks, and articulateness have come across exceptionally well on the television.

title: FRANCE PROPOSES 2 SIDES EVACUATE EMBASSY STAFFS
description: Seeking to calm the crisis caused by its breaking diplomatic relations with Iran, France suggested today that both countries agree to evacuate their respective diplomats and embassy personnel within five days.

title: Music-Making in the Key of Versatility
description: WHEN DICK HYMAN SITS down at the piano, nobody laughs. Those who are familiar with his work, however, will probably smile in anticipation, knowing they're in for a good time. It's not just that he is a marvelous jazz pianist and a gracious performer; they know that his idea of jazz - well, let him say it: ''I still believe in the fun of music. I still believe in music that can be beautiful and fun and pleasing.''

title: A Good Reason to Delay Reflagging
description: This week, the Reagan Administration will, in all likelihood, throw away its last slim chance to substitute diplomacy for unwise military operations in the Persian Gulf.

title: Susan Wenzell Becomes Bride
description: Susan Margaret Wenzell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan T. Wenzell of New York and East Jewett, N.Y., was married yesterday to Adam Alexander Waldron, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester A. Waldron of Pinehurst, N.C., at All Souls Church in Onteora Park, N.Y. The Rev. Peter Simon Mein performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
MUSIC
description: LEAD: Attila Opera by Verdi. Libretto by Temistocle Solera. With Evgeny Nesterenko, Maria Chiara, Silvano Carroli and Veriano Luchetti. Produced by Giuliano Montaldo. Nello Santi conducting the Chorus and Orchestra of Arena di Verona. Sung in Italian with English subtitles. Home Vision. 120 minutes.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: French Visas: Now No Photo Is Required

title: Pioneer Addiction Center Heals With Basic Methods
description: Nearly 40 years ago, when alcoholics had hardly anywhere else to go, an old white farmhouse here, staffed by a counselor, a handyman and a cook called Ma, opened its doors.

title: THE CONTRA LEADERS: A GUIDE TO THE OFF-SCREEN PLAYERS
description: AT the center of the political storm raging in the Senate Caucus Room in Washington is the so-called contra rebel army, which is fighting to overthrow the Sandinistas in Nicaragua. Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter have testified about how they secretly diverted money to the contras, whom they considered to be a bastion against Communist penetration of the Americas.

title: Nominee to Head the F.A.A. Is Confirmed by the Senate
description: The Senate on a voice vote today confirmed the nomination of T. Allan McArtor as Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration to succeed Donald D. Engen.

title: Don't Knock The Stadium
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
PERSONAL FINANCE;
Instead of a Cabin, a Condo Hotel Suite
description: LEAD: A New York printing executive, whom we shall call Carl Michaels, spent months looking around the Northeast for a vacation home. What he settled on, however, was a vacation suite - a three-bedroom unit in the Ascutney Mountain Resort, a hotel in Brownsville, Vt.

title: Of Cues and Such
description: Byrne's Standard Video of Pool & Billiards Premiere Home Video. (800) 972-5858, ext. 310. 60 minutes. $29.95.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the film page in this section last Sunday misidentified an actor in ''Adventures in Babysitting.'' The actor is Anthony Rapp.

title: Pierre Lardinois Dies at 62; A Dutch and Europe Official
description: Pierre Lardinois, a Dutch statesman and commissioner for agriculture in the European Community from 1973 to 1977, died Thursday, the Dutch Agriculture Ministry said Friday. He was 62 years old.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
NOT SO FAR AWAY, BUT IT'S A DIFFERENT WORLD
description: LEAD: THE waitress at the small Italian restaurant on Bayville Avenue put the spotted, much used menu in front of us.

title: The One Who's Left Behind
description: LEAD: After my father's parents made the trip to America from Eastern Europe, they decided they had traveled enough for one lifetime. In the 60-odd years they had left to live together, they made sure they never strayed very far beyond the borders of New York City. This resolve must have passed into their gene pool, because five out of their six children inherited their skeptical view of travel.

title: Adult Bookstore Roils Lindenhurst
description: WELLWOOD AVENUE in the heart of Lindenhurst, with its ice-cream parlors and delicatessens, the village hall, funeral home, church and railroad station, all in the space of a few blocks, gives the impression of Small Town, U.S.A. But residents of this otherwise placid South Shore community are mobilizing for battle against what they see as the coming of 42d Street in Manhattan.

title: CELEBRATING AN ENGINEERING TRIUMPH
description: LEAD: FOR a good many years, John Henderson has been enjoying the water that flows from the New York City system, but lately when he has a glass, either in Westchester, where he lives, or Putnam County, where he works, he says it tastes even better.

title: MISS YERKES TO MARRY ALAN GOLDSTEIN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Estile Yerkes 3d of New York and Fishers Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Tyson Yerkes to Alan Leslie Goldstein, the son of Bernard Goldstein of Phelan, Calif., and Francine Goldstein of Westlake Village, Calif. The couple plan to marry Aug. 7.

title: Gulf Duty: How Navy Gets Ready
description: Sometime within the next week, American warships are expected to begin escorting the first Kuwaiti tankers to fly the American flag through the Strait of Hormuz.

title: Repairing Co-ops and Condos
description: THE stone facade is cracking, the surface of the roof has blisters and there is dissension among the building's officers over exactly what to do.

title: WHO'S NOT IN THE HALL OF FAME WHO SHOULD BE
description: It seems appropriate to enter the name of Tony Oliva, the former Minnesota Twin All-Star and current coach, for consideration. As a player, Oliva fulfills all the criteria the veterans committee demands when considering someone for the Hall of Fame. In an abbreviated 15-year career, Oliva compiled a .304 average. Three times he won the American League batting title. A stylish and classic artist with the bat, a proven performer with the glove, Tony Oliva's career as a player was the embodiment of a consistent competitor and a winner on and off the field. STEVE PETAGINE White Plains

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
HEAVEN'S GATE
description: LEAD: What the tourist at the Cathedral of Chartres sees as dazzling unity is actually a progression of styles. Because the Royal (West) Portals survived a catastrophic fire that occasioned the rebuilding of the 12th- and 13th-century French cathedral, the doors capture a bold transition from somber Romanesque to the more rarefied, intellectual early Gothic style.

title: Ridership Is Up Underground
description: Though there were eight million subway riders in the Naked City 40 years ago, the New York City Transit Authority would be delighted to have daily ridership approaching half that number these days.

title: Chinese Celadon Seen in a New Light
description: CELADONS - CLAY works traditionally restricted to exquisitely crafted and shimmering jade-green Chinese ceramics of the 10th through 14th centuries - assume a new, larger image in a show at Asia Society Galleries, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, through Sept. 6.

title: 'Sugar'
description: The British writer Antonia Byatt chooses the leisurely, meditative mode of Henry James, E. M. Forster and George Eliot, whom she clearly reveres and whose presences are strongly felt in ''Sugar: And Other Stories,'' her seventh book. (''The Virgin in the Garden'' and ''Still Life'' are probably the Byatt novels most familiar to American readers.) Even to venture into that unfashionable territory -where a moral universe is presupposed and every act is laden with more, not less, meaning than it can readily bear - denotes a certain originality. Unlike the great realists, though, Ms. Byatt's gift is not so much in unraveling the complexities of the ordinary as in sensing its uncanny and nightmarish aspects. Her seemingly bland characters live in psychic infernos; the most dreaded fantasies come true; ghosts and witches turn up where a conventional author would present neurosis. The tone of the collection suggests a powerful late-Victorian intellect trained on 20th-century social and personal dilemmas. That peculiar stance gives some stories a fine timelessness and freedom; in a few cases it makes for too-tight control.

title: FUTURE ENGINEERS GETTING MORE HUMANITIES REQUIREMENTS
description: MANY engineering students have traditionally regarded humanities courses as educational frills. Recently, however, in an effort to prepare students to better deal with the social and ethical implications of their chosen fields, schools such as the Massachusetts Institute of Technology are increasing their emphasis on arts and social sciences.

title: Moscow Gets Cagey on Arms Control
description: ONE of the Administration's main preoccupations in recent days has been to try to figure out why the Russians have shifted into neutral gear on arms control. ''Nobody really knows what they are up to,'' one Administration official said. ''But there are a whole variety of possible motives.''

title: South Koreans in the U.S. Are Going Home
description: Kim Kyung Jae, publisher and co-author of a best-selling book on the South Korean security agency, plans to end 15 years' political exile shortly and join the opposition's election campaign in Korea.

title: Pick a Country, Buy a Mutual Fund
description: MUTUAL fund investors who want to venture into international waters typically consider two routes. They either buy a global fund, which invests in both American and foreign markets, or an international fund, which invests solely in foreign markets.

title: DEBRA S. RAUSCH ENGAGED
description: Dr. and Mrs. George H. Rausch of Weston, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Debra Susan Rausch to David Gene Feitler, a son of Friedel Feitler of Toronto and the late Dr. Ernest H. Feitler. Ms. Rausch is founder and president of Corporate Growth Resources, an executive search organization in Burlington, Mass. Her fiance heads United States operations in Shrewsbury, Mass., for the Cramaro Corporation of Stoney Creek, Ontario, a manufacturer of automatic tarpaulin systems for trucks.

title: Ballet: Ananiashvili As the Bolshoi's 'Giselle'
description: NINA ANANIASHVILI and Andris Liepa are relatively young dancers. And they were a very young Giselle and Albrecht in an enthusiastically received performance of ''Giselle'' on Thursday, presented by the Bolshoi Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: MICHELE J. EPLEY ENGAGED TO WED DOUGLAS R. BOND
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Marion Jay Epley 3d of Bronxville, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Michele Jean Epley to Douglas Randall Bond, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Minor Casey Bond of Williamsburg, Va. An October wedding is planned.

title: A Connecticut Vogue: Importing Old Barns
description: A barn shortage has struck Connecticut's countryside, forcing some wealthy landowners here to import their rustic dream houses from upstate New York and Vermont.

title: Rebel Offensive in Salvador's Capital
description: The Government of El Salvador knew all about the latest plot of the leftist rebels to undermine it. But last week, when the guerrillas sharply stepped up protests and sabotage in the capital of San Salvador, President Jose Napoleon Duarte appeared powerless to stop it.

title:
Outdoors;
Learning While on a Vacation
description: LEAD: IF you are looking for something new in active New England vacations, here are two programs that offer a chance to enjoy some great scenery and learn some new recreational skills.

title: Dance: The Crowsfeet Collective
description: ''LE JOUR et la Nuit'' was the title of a dance by Yves Musard that was performed on Friday at the Central Park Band Shell as part of the park's SummerStage festival. But the name could have served the entire program, for the eight pieces performed by the Crowsfeet Dance Collective had a daylight transparency and Mr. Musard's contribution tended toward the obscurity of a clouded night.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: World University Games U.S. Beaten in Final: Yugoslavia defeated the United States, 100-85, in the men's basketball final yesterday, and Rumania collected five gold medals in rowing in Zagreb, Yugoslavia. Drazen Petrovic, rated Europe's best basketball player, scored 35 points for Yugoslavia, which never trailed and had a 50-38 halftime lead. Mitch Richmond, a Kansas State guard, led the American team with 19 points. ''They are older, bigger and more experienced,'' said the United States coach, Mike Krzyzewski of Duke. The Rumanians had four women's and one men's gold in the rowing, dominating the finals with Italy, which collected three men's golds.(AP) Olympic Festival Louganis Takes Another Title: Greg Louganis of Boca Raton, Fla., the 1984 double Olympic gold medalist, had 13 perfect scores yesterday in winning the 3-meter springboard diving title for the fifth consecutive time at the festival. Louganis saved his best for last, accumulating six 10's from the seven judges on his final dive, a forward 3 1/2 somersault from the pike position. He had 40 scores of nine or better from 77 total marks in the 11-dive competition in Durham, N.C., and wound up with 703.86 points. Kent Ferguson of Boca Raton, the 1987 national indoor champion, finished second with 643.44 points. Mike Wantuck of Columbus, Ohio, was third with 619.80. (AP) Baseball U.S. Loses to Cuba: Rogelio Garcia, a 29-year-old right-hander, struck out 10 batters and pitched a six-hitter in a 7-3 victory for Cuba over the United States Friday night in Havana. The victory gave the Cubans a 2-0 lead in a five-game warm-up series for the Pan American Games next month in Indianapolis. Frank Thomas, an Auburn freshman, hit a homer in the third inning and the United States did not score again until the eighth, when sacrifice flies by Dave Silvestri and Scott Servais brought in the last two runs. The series resumes Sunday in Atemisa, about 100 miles from Havana.(AP) Fencing All-West German Final: Mathias Gey defeated Matthias Behr yesterday in an all-West German foil final of the world fencing championships in Lausanne, Switzerland. The bronze medal went to Federico Cervi of Italy, who beat Yohuda Carmi of Israel.(AP) Golf 3-Stroke Lead for Crampton: Bruce Crampton, the defending champion, shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday for a total of 132 to extend his lead to three strokes in the Syracuse Senior Golf Classic. Chi Chi Rodriguez, who had six birdies and matched Crampton's 67, was in second place going into today's final round. Peter Thomson, who won the tournament in 1985, was four strokes back after repeating his opening-round score of 68. Miller Barber was five strokes back, and Gene Littler and Jim Barber were six strokes off the pace.(AP) Morgan Ahead by 1: Gil Morgan came out of the pack yesterday to grab a one-stroke lead in the $500,000 Hardee's Golf Classic in Coal Valley, Ill. Morgan, a six-time winner on the PGA Tour, shot a seven-under-par 63 after beginning the third round six strokes behind Brad Fabel. Morgan was at 12-under-par 198. Kenny Knox, who had a 66, was alone in second at 199, and Fabel, Mark McCumber and Fred Wadsworth were tied at 200. Fabel slipped to a 71 yesterday while McCumber, winner of the Anheuser-Busch Classic last week, shot a 69 and Wadsworth shot a 68. Morgan had eight birdies and one bogey during a hot and windy round on the par-70 Oakwood Country Club course. Public Links Champion: Kevin Johnson of Pembroke, Mass., built an early lead and held on for a 10 and 9 victory yesterday over Jimmy England of Gastonia, N.C., in the United States Amateur Public Links championship at Glenview Golf Course in Cincinnati. Johnson won seven of the first nine holes in covering the front nine at two under-par.

title: Stop Smoking, Earn More Money
description: Richard Cullen, a packaging supervisor at the Adolph Coors Company, agreed to let his employer test him for health problems and then provide nutrition counseling to help him lose weight. His incentive? Coors will pay a higher percentage of his health claims than it will for his colleagues who refuse to participate in the company's ''wellness'' program.

title: Earl Schwulst, Banker, Dies at 90
description: Earl B. Schwulst, who in the 1960's led a New York City commission that recommended a city income tax and headed a study that assailed racial segregation in public housing, died Tuesday at the Carolton Health Center in Southport, Conn., after a long illness. He was 90 years old and lived in Southport.

title: Is Our Choice Democracy or Covert Activities?; Who Makes Us Proud
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: FORTY-TWO DAYS AND NIGHTS ON THE IBERIAN PENINSULA WITH ANIS LADRON. By Frederick Kaufman. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $15.95.) It would be nice to say that this first novel - describing the adventures in Spain and Portugal of four prep-school adolescents and Anis Ladron, their Spanish teacher, tennis coach, chaperon and guide - is a successful literary endeavor; it is not.

title:
TELEVISION;
'THERE'S THIS SCENE WHERE THIS GREAT PIANIST PLAYS ... '
description: LEAD: Tomorrow evening at 9, Channel 13 will present ''Rubinstein Remembered: A 100th Anniversary Tribute,'' a look back at the career of Artur Rubinstein, who died in 1982 at the age of 95. The hourlong program, part of the ''American Masters'' series, is a collage of film clips of the classical pianist in concert, home movies and reminiscences from his widow, his two daughters and musicians who had performed with him; it is narrated by his son, the actor, musician and conductor John

title: Koch on Accountability, Corruption and Judgment
description: EIGHTEEN months after they began, New York City's corruption scandals continue.

title: No Headline
description: SEVEN years ago a group of Herman Galvin's friends asked him to teach them Yiddish. As a result of that request, Mr. Galvin embarked on a labor of love.

title: Mostly Mozart Will Dance Its Way to a Birthday Party
description: TONIGHT AND AGAIN ON THURSDAY, Mostly Mozart will celebrate its 21st birthday with a first: The musicians will move to the floor and dancers will take over the stage of Avery Fisher Hall.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 'MARIN IN OIL' Although he made his reputation as a watercolorist, John Marin, one of the pioneers in American modern art, was also an accomplished painter in oils. In fact, from the early 1930's through his death in 1953 he devoted increasing attention to exploring that medium. And the results of his interest, said Klaus Kertess, the curator of the Parrish Art Museum, were precursors of the revolutionary American painting of the 1950's. Now, for the first time, a museum, the Parrish in Southampton, is focusing on those works, and with 50 paintings, done between 1913 and 1953 and assembled from leading museums and collectors, has created ''Marin in Oil.'' The show opens today and can be seen, through Sept. 20, from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Mondays through Saturdays, except Wednesdays, and 1 to 5 P.M. Sundays at the Parrish, on Job's Lane. ON THEIR TOES With something new, something old and something borrowed from Balanchine's repertory, the Eglevsky Ballet begins its summer park tour today at the Chapin Lakeside Theater in Eisenhower Park. The program, backed in East Meadow by the Merrick Symphony, includes Balanchine's ''Tarantella''; Act II of ''Giselle''; ''Twelfth Night,'' created by the company's artistic director, Michael Vernon, and the world premiere of ''Kick,'' a ballet set to Cole Porter music by Mr. Vernon. The performance is at 8 P.M. and will be repeated Thursday at 8:30 P.M. at Heckscher Park in Huntington; Friday at 8:15 P.M. at Morgan Park in Glen Cove, and next Sunday at 8:15 P.M. at Kennedy High School in Plainview. All the concerts are free, Audiences must bring their own seating. ALL THAT JAZZ As familiar as the phrase ''all that jazz'' may be, this week's outdoor park concert scene adds new meaning to that cliche. Almost every day or night, there's a jazz performance by some group someplace on the Island. It all begins today at 2 P.M. at the Bayard Cutting Arboretum in Oakdale, where, straying from its usual route, the Minnewaska Chamber Music Society jazzes it up. The concert is free, but there's a $1.50-an-adult parking fee.

title: AN INSECURE FUTURE FOR SOME BULBS
description: CATALOGUES are arriving from mail-order companies with colorful springtime pictures of hardy bulbs in bloom. Merchants are reminding gardeners to start planning for fall planting and to send their orders promptly. As is always true, those who are first with their orders get first choices.

title: A Big Stride for Super-VHS
description: EVER SINCE SUPER-VHS -the latest version of the popular VHS video recording format - made its American debut at the Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago in May, video fans have been awaiting the first independent tests of the new technology. Now the results are in.

title: In Tennessee, Officials Fight Over Portrait
description: Echoes of the Old South still rumble through this ''New South'' city sometimes. Recently they dislodged a portrait of Tennessee's Reconstruction Governor from a place of prominence in the State Capitol.

title: THE SOUND AND THE FLURRY OF WILLIAM FORSYTHE
description: THE RULE OF THUMB IS THAT a choreographer works best with his own company, the dancers with whom he is most familiar. There is no reason to doubt that the rule holds true as well for William Forsythe and the Frankfurt Ballet, the West German company headed by the American choreographer since 1984.

title: Dropping In
description: It was a gathering of eagles at the International Tennis Hall of Fame inductions in Newport, R.I., yesterday and, appropriately enough, Billie Jean King arrived at the ceremonies by helicopter. The 43-year-old King, who won a record 20 Wimbledon titles while virtually dominating women's tennis for most of her 20-year career, was honored along with four other giants of the game: Bjorn Borg, the five-time Wimbledon champion; Stan Smith, who won Wimbledon in 1972; Alex Olmedo, who led the United States Davis Cup team to a famous upset over Australia in 1958, and Dennis Ralston, another Davis Cup stalwart and Grand Slam doubles champion who now coaches Chris Evert and the Southern Methodist tennis team.

title: WITTY FIGURATIVE FORMS GIVE INSIGHT INTO CHARACTER
description: LEAD: FAMILIAR and usually friendly figurative forms dominate the art of two nationally known East Hampton artists, the painter-printmaker Gerson Leiber and the sculptor William King. Their insights into human character are individually strong, in recent examples on view at the Vered Gallery, yet the work proves to be compatible, even to the point of reinforcing the artists' independent goals.

title: MISS HIGGINS PLANS TO WED
description: The engagement of Barbara Olin Higgins to William Edward Epifanio 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Epifanio of Stamford, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William Waugh Higgins of Greenwich, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be. A September wedding is planned.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: YONKERS SALUTE A production of ''1776,'' the musical about the Declaration of Independence that won a Tony award, is the Asbury Summer Theater's salute to the 200th birthday of the United States Constitution. Nine performances are scheduled in Weyand Hall of the Asbury United Methodist Church at 167 Scarsdale Road in Yonkers. Curtain times are 8 P.M. Fridays and Saturdays and 4 P.M. Sundays through Aug. 8, with an additional evening performance on Thursday, Aug. 6.

title: A Thin Disguise
description: WE ALL WEAR DISGUISES. The simple act of dressing is a disguising. Clothes are disguises, beards, pitch of voice, what we say, what we keep secret. Costumes declare us, but disguises protect us from exposure. Wearing them, we blend in. Every salesman dressing for a client knows the drill, every young intern pulling on a white lab coat, every recent graduate struggling with an unfamiliar suit and tie.

title: Judith A. Hart Is Wed To Christopher Lavin
description: The marriage of Judith A. Hart, an associate in the law firm of Rucci, Gruss, Jex & Gleason in Darien, Conn., to Christopher J. Lavin, a real-estate developer in Wilton, Conn., and a partner in MCL Systems there, took place yesterday at the Wilton Congregational Church. The Rev. Robert Gormbley performed the ceremony.

title: WHO'S NOT IN THE HALL OF FAME WHO SHOULD BE
description: The late Branch Rickey is said to have defined five qualities that scouts should look for in a potential regular major league player: to be able to run, throw, field, hit, and hit with power. It is my contention that no player, excluding pitchers, should merit selection to the Hall of Fame unless he is outstanding in at least three of those five categories. Richie Ashburn is such a player. He played for 15 seasons for the Phillies, the Cubs and the Mets (1948-62). He hit .308 career, had 2,574 hits, scored 1,322 runs, walked 1,198 times, stole 234 bases, and struck out only 571 times in 8,365 times at bat. He also won two batting titles. It was Ashburn's misfortune to have been an exceptional center fielder in the same era in which Mantle, Mays and Snider played that position, as well as to have been a daring baserunner at the same time that the peerless Jackie Robinson roamed the bases. Twenty years are more than enough time to reverse an egregious injustice. SHELDON A. LISKER, M.D. Lafayette Hill, Pa.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: It WAS early morning, if 4:30 can be considered morning, and I was awake.

title: LIFE'S FINAL OFFER
description: LEAD: THE FORBIDDEN ZONE By Michael Lesy. 250 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95.

title: Stockholm
description: The Lake Malar Queen, as the Swedish capital with its waterways, bright summer lights and greenery is called, takes in 14 islands between the Baltic Sea and Lake Malaren, the lake's Swedish name. Parks and gardens, outdoor cafes and a network of ferries and sightseeing boats make it easy for visitors to spend much of their time outdoors.

title: Brooklyn Residents Sue Rose
description: ANGRY over what they perceive as a flawed environmental impact statement, a group of residents living near the Fort Greene Landmark District is suing to stop the $530 million Atlantic Center urban renewal project that civic leaders view as a mainstay for the redevelopment of downtown Brooklyn.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
PIT BULL BAN SOUGHT
description: LEAD: A 12-year-old girl playing near her home was seriously injured last year in Bedford by a pit bull that had escaped from a pen to which it had been confined after biting two women.

title: The Global March to Free Markets
description: IN Moscow, entrepreneurial comrades are running their own beauty parlors and auto repair shops, while in China many farmers are eschewing the communal system in favor of selling produce they grow themselves.

title: MISS PRIME PLANS AUGUST WEDDING
description: The engagement of Darcy Prime to Thomas Alexander Neville, a son of Emily Cheney Neville of Keene Valley, N.Y., and the late Glenn T. Neville, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Ruth M. Prime of Lake Placid, N.Y., and Theodore F. Prime of Essex, N.Y. The couple plan to marry Aug. 29.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BLOOD CRIES. By John Weisman. (Viking, $17.95.) Spies, terrorists, a hit team and lots of action; they sound like the ingredients of a thriller. But John Weisman's third novel uses them as a backdrop for the story of an assimilated American Jew's spiritual journey in Israel - from naivete to disillusionment, from faith to commitment. Jared Paul Gordon, a ''well-paid Jeremiah for a weekly news magazine,'' insists on writing the truth about Israel, no holds barred. But he feels guilty when his lover, a zealous Zionist, calls him a ''self-hating Jew'' who's playing into the hands of Israel's enemies. As the Promised Land draws Jared back to the faith of his forefathers, he begins to identify with Israel. But he sees a nation that has strayed from the ideals of its founders. The plot centers on Jared's discovery of a campaign by Jewish terrorists against Arabs in the occupied West Bank. Jared's vision may be painful to the Americans who view Israel solely as a righteous David besieged by an evil Arab Goliath. But Israel has had to make compromises to survive in a hostile world. And Jared wonders whether it has gone too far, ''moving slowly but inexorably toward the East.'' In the end, Jared gives up trying to reconcile his roles as Jew and journalist, and throws himself into ''a battle for the soul'' of Israel. Mr. Weisman has a tendency to overwrite and his plot stumbles here and there, but ''Blood Cries'' is an engaging, provocative and troubling book.

title: ON THE NAUGATUCK: SOCIAL SCIENCE AFLOAT
description: BENEATH towering highway bridges and past the backs of billboards, the procession of canoes made its way along the Naugatuck River, its occupants talking of Indians, colonial settlers and the bygone days when factories harnessed the river's power to transform Waterbury into a manufacturing center.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title:
ART;
Judaica From the Vatican That Speaks Volumes
description: LEAD: AN EXHIBITION OFFERING treasures from a thousand years of Judaica has just arrived in this country from Europe, and the unlikey source of the show is the Vatican. Since the Renaissance, the Vatican Library has been the repository of a vast store of Jewish manuscripts and a selection of them are now going on public display in a show that opened Friday in Miami and will travel throughout the United States before coming to New York in

title: PLAYWRIGHT EXAMINES ART WORLD
description: IN ''The Critic,'' a two-act play by B.H. Friedman that will be read at the Summer Solstice Theater Conference in Amagansett next weekend, Alistair Sharpe, the tragiheroic art critic and gallery director, becomes the victim of a lawsuit because of his passion for telling the truth.

title: Don Juan Legend Explored
description: THE thematic cement holding together a good many of the programs at this year's Summerfare Festival at the State University of New York at Purchase is the Don Juan legend. ''You'd have to be a true glutton to take it all in,'' conceded Christopher Hunt, the artistic director, ''but we will actually be having more than 20 presentations within 48 hours on the subject of Don Juan, including films, lectures and other special events.''

title: Bombing in London Wounds Leading Khomeini Opponent
description: A bomb exploded Saturday and wounded a leading opponent of the Iranian Government as he drove through a busy shopping area.

title: Police Shoot Brooklyn Man After He Threatens Woman
description: A police officer shot a Brooklyn man in his apartment early yesterday after the woman he lives with called the police and told them he was armed and had threatened to kill her and her 8-year-old son, the police said.

title: BAMBI CROWE PLANS WEDDING
description: Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Mrs. Crowe of Fort Myer, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bambi Crowe, to Lieut. Robert Jeffrey Lymburner, U.S.N., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Lymburner of Sherman, Tex. An Aug. 15 wedding is planned.

title: MS. STONE TO WED A. D. RICHARDSON
description: The engagement of Patricia Marty Stone to Alexander Dee Richardson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Merz Richardson of Chautauqua, N.Y., has been announced by Mrs. David McKendree Key Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Edward Durell Stone Jr. of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., parents of the bride-to-be. The wedding to be Oct. 17.

title: Closing Camp for Summer Stuns Scouts
description: CONTRARY to popular belief, Boy Scouts are not always prepared.

title: THE VALUE OF INTERNS IN THE WORKPLACE
description: Mary Jane Genova has done a disservice to interns - among whom I count myself - who find themselves working very hard for their temporary employers. Her ''Student Raid on Corporations'' perpetuates the untruth that student employees are nothing more than nepotistic dead weight.

title: PICTURES FROM THEIR NIGHTMARE
description: BEYOND WORDS Images From America's Concentration Camps. By Deborah Gesensway and Mindy Roseman. Illustrated. 176 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $24.95.

title: Recent Sales
description: Buchanan, N.Y. $160,000 279 Church Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 36-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, family room, aluminum siding, 1-car garage; taxes $1,452. New Rochelle, N.Y. $219,500 51 Emmett Terrace 3 bedroom, 1 1/2 bath, 50-year-old frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, sun porch, carport; taxes $2,416. Rye, N.Y. $301,000 21 Bennett Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old frame ranch; eat-in kitchen, paneled playroom, beach rights; taxes $3,643. Litchfield, Conn. $219,000 Milton Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 27-year-old Cape Cod; sun room, 1-car garage, 0.75 acre; taxes $1,330. Morris, Conn. $141,400 Straights Turnpike Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 23-year-old ranch; screened porch, central-vacuum system, 1.6 acres; taxes $1,338. Woodbridge, Conn. $252,000 10 White Oak Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old ranch; pool, 2-car garage, 2.7 acres; taxes $2,818. OTHER AREAS Wantagh, L.I. $165,000 32 Dome Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 36-year-old ranch; dining room, den; taxes $2,000. Chester Township, N.J. $325,000 513 North Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, fireplace, pool, 3.25 acres; taxes $5,371. Greenwood Lake, N.J. $218,000 Laurel Avenue 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 27-year-old ranch; 2 kitchens, dining room, walk to beach; taxes $3,387.

title: Bayreuth
description: To the Editor: It was a pleasant surprise to find the article on Wilhelmina, Margravine of Bayreuth (Travel, May 3). So far as English-language readers are concerned, this fascinating lady has passed below the horizon of visibility. She is not included in any recent encyclopedia (or any French or Italian one either) and there is not a single work by or about her in print in either this country or in England.

title: Jersey's Emphasis Shifts In Bid for Baseball Team
description: Until now, most of the talk about New Jersey's search for a major league baseball team has centered on attracting an existing franchise.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
NIGHT AND DAY
description: LEAD: OH, thank heaven for 7-Eleven.

title: JENNIFER LAW TO WED
description: The engagement of Jennifer Ann Law to John Cunningham Riley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Patrick Riley of Marstons Mills, Mass., has been announced by Patricia Rich Law of Camden, Ark., and Pascal Threadgill Law of Mobile, Ala., parents of the bride-to-be. Miss Law, an assistant vice president of the Shawmut Bank in Boston, and her fiance, an assisitant vice president of Kidder Peabody & Company in Boston, plan to marry Oct. 3.

title: Outcroppings in the Baltic
description: The Aland Islands, 6,500 granite outcrops and millions of pine trees, are sprinkled in the Baltic Sea between Finland and Sweden like a Viking raider's hastily discarded booty. The very name derives from the old Norse for water land, from which we get the English word island.

title: MICHELLE KENNEDY MARRIES
description: Michelle Tara Deborah Kennedy and Jonathan Christie Moffett, students at St. Michael's College of the University of Toronto, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament in Toronto. The Rev. Edward Boehler performed the ceremony. The couple's parents are Alfreda Kennedy of Toronto and Owen Kennedy of Scarborough, Ontario, and Mr. and Mrs. Warren Christie Moffett of Boston.

title: Bishops File Brief Against Surrogate Motherhood
description: New Jersey's Roman Catholic bishops have filed a brief with the New Jersey Supreme Court opposing the practice of surrogate motherhood and arguing that it violates the public policy of the state.

title: HOW SHE MET A GOD
description: THE FEMALE OF THE SPECIES By Lionel Shriver. 405 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: MUSEUM PROPOSAL IS JUST THAT
description: The article ''Museum Plan Again Opposed'' [ June 28 ] implied widespread opposition to the Heckscher Museum's revised expansion plans. I found the tone of this article inaccurate and misleading as to the actual status of the museum's expansion.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LEAD: EYES OF THE DRAGON By Margaret Leaf. Illustrated by Ed Young. Unpaged. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard. $11.75. (Ages 5 to 8)

title: COURT PILOT USES CAMP TO BUILD SUPPORT
description: LEAD: WHEN Mitch Buonaguro was named head basketball coach at Fairfield University in April 1985, his priorities went beyond turning around the school's failing program. Beyond winning games, said Mr. Buonaguro, he wanted to cultivate regional support for his team.

title: Jazz on Public Radio
description: To the Editor:

title: Notebook; LaRussa Working Wonders With the Athletics
description: TONY LaRUSSA, the manager who was viewed as unfit to serve as ringmaster for the Chicago White Sox circus last year, has a new role this season. He is playing magician with the Oakland Athletics. LaRussa has manipulated the Oakland pitching staff so deftly that the Athletics have become a legitimate contender in the most crowded of the four division races.

title: Company Subsidies for Staying Well
description: In each of the past three years, many employees of the King Broadcasting Company in Seattle have received checks for as much as $700.

title: No Headline
description: Is Our Choice Democracy or Covert Activities?

title: Colorful Flynn
description: The Sea Hawk With Errol Flynn, Brenda Marshall, Flora Robson, Claude Rains, Henry Daniell. Directed by Michael Curtiz. 1940. CBS/Fox Video 128 minutes. $59.98. There is something to be said for colorizing a foamy outdoor adventure like this. As English galleons attack marauding Spaniards, white sails and shipboard browns stand out against blue skies. An exotic Panama jungle, in one sweaty sequence, looke it. Gothic trappings of the Elizabethan court attain new splendor. True, at times ocean waters veer toward purple, then snap out of it. Human pallor is a stationary, standard pale pink. Fair enough.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: San Antonio;
Reincarnating The Hemisfair
description: LEAD: LIKE so many former world's fair sites, this city's Hemisfair has posed a problem since the 1968 World's Fair closed and its 90 downtown acres have remained largely a silent jumble of pavilions and dilapidated houses.

title: FINDING OUT WHAT'S PLAYING
description: In the recent article ''Theater Festival Opens Season'' I noted the observation: ''Generally, it takes tourism to make summer festivals viable. Long Islanders tend to go elsewhere for their summer entertainment.''

title: Vivienne R. Gould Weds Paul Schiffer in Houston
description: At the Holy Rosary Roman Catholic Church in Houston yesterday Vivienne Rosalie Gould, the daughter of Mayor Rosalie Santine Gould of McGehee, Ark., and the late Joseph Clayton Gould Jr., was married to Paul Alan Schiffer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ira Leonard Schiffer of Yorktown Heights, N.Y. The Rev. Clayton N. Gould, a brother of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Farms: For Migrants, No Peaches And Cream
description: LEAD: THE DOZEN or more work-weary men straggling back to their quarters on the Pioppi farm in Newfield one recent evening received visitors with friendliness and nonchalance, but said they did not want to reveal their names.

title: On Madison Avenue, a Building That Blends In
description: IN AN AGE IN WHICH PRETENSION has become the architectural norm, and the prima donna the expected presence on the landscape, No. 667 Madison Avenue stands out as reasonable, intelligent, and civilized. This is not one of the great buildings for all time, but it is certainly the right building for this time. At 25 stories this pale-gray granite tower is not overwhelming in size, and it does not have a knock-your-eye-out image to it. This is not a building that will make a lot of people stop and say ''wow.''

title: In Wind, Azinger Sails On
description: Finally the 116th British Open got a traditional storm, and it turned the Muirfield links into a fortress for the third round after the course had suffered two days of total surrender in calm air.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Easthampton, Mass.;
Rapid Growth Troubles Town
description: LEAD: WHEN a 41-acre farm here was sold to a developer last year for $193,000, local officials became concerned that the town was being developed at a rate faster than the water, sewer or school systems could manage.

title: New York Adds to List of Fish Too Tainted for Consumption
description: New York State has imposed new restrictions on eating fish caught in six rivers and lakes and in Long Island Sound because of danger from toxic chemicals.

title: Two New Members Elected To the Pulitzer Prize Board
description: Two new members have been elected to the Pulitzer Prize Board, the panel that oversees the selection of Pulitzer Prizes each year, the president of Columbia University, Michael I. Sovern, has announced.

title: THREE ACTRESSES TRY THE UNLIKELY
description: WHEN three enterprising young actresses start a small Off Off Broadway theater company, one would expect them to do original plays, experimental plays, even esoteric plays and perhaps rarely seen revivals.

title: 4 Killed in Ireland Air Crash
description: A light plane crashed en route from Cork to Dublin today, killing the pilot and all three members of a Dutch family aboard, airport officials said. The pilot's nationality was not known.

title: Ex-Mayor Called Head of Syracuse Kickback Ring
description: Lee Alexander, who served four terms as Mayor of Syracuse and six terms as president of the National Conference of Democratic Mayors, was pictured by Federal prosecutors last week as the ringleader in ''one of the largest'' public corruption cases in the country.

title: 'MENTORS' GUIDE TEACHERS
description: AFTER two years of small pilot programs, the State Department of Education is preparing its first large class of ''mentor teachers.''

title: An Unequal Battle Over 'Equality'
description: STATE REPRESENTATIVE PAUL JACQUES in Maine knows how it feels to be in a cat fight.

title: WHERE GLASNOST HAS ITS LIMITS
description: Of all Mikhail Gorbachev's new policies, that of ''openness'' (glasnost) has intrigued Western journalists most.

title: AIDS SHIFT SEEN TO DRUG USERS
description: LEAD: CONNECTICUT has joined New Jersey as the only states in which more than half of the diagnosed AIDS patients are drug addicts, their sex partners and their children.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pawtucket, R.I.;
A Tug to Lure Developers
description: LEAD: SINCE announcing an ambitious riverfront development plan nearly two years ago, Pawtucket city officials have had a hard time persuading developers to invest in it.

title: PROTECTING SWANS IS A PRIORITY
description: Gregory G. Chasko, the Department of Environmental Protection's Waterfowl Project leader, remarked in the June 7 article ''State Order to Kill Swans Challenged'' that Friends of Animals's efforts on behalf of mute swans amount to a ''publicity stunt.'' That's a cheap shot. When government officials break the law in advancing their own interests, it is a citizen's duty to go to the public.

title: Big Raid by Contras Produces Casualties But No Visible Gain
description: United States-backed Nicaraguan guerrillas killed nine Sandinista soldiers, three children and a pregnant woman Thursday but failed to capture their target here. It was their first major attack since the Iran-contra hearings in Washington focused American attention on their movement.

title: SITE QUESTIONS COULD UPSET HOUSING PLAN IN YONKERS
description: AN ''alternative'' housing-integration plan approved by the Yonkers City Council nearly two weeks ago and ''welcomed'' by a Federal judge seeking an end to segregation in the city appeared last week to be facing an uncertain future.

title: Head of C.I.A. Said to Plan Replacing 2 High Officials
description: William Webster, the new Director of Central Intelligence, has decided to replace the head of the Central Intelligence Agency's clandestine service and one of his senior deputies, according to a Congressional official.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALY;
THE NEXT TIME HE'LL TAKE THE CAR
description: LEAD: IT HAS always been his style to do dangerous things cautiously.

title: A Higher Penalty On Student Loans
description: Nearly one million people who are in default on their student loans are about to receive an ultimatum: Pay by Oct. 1 or be held liable for the collection costs later.

title: Train Robberies
description: To the Editor: Your readers may be interested in knowing of the latest method of robbing travelers on European trains. A friend reports that he and a companion had their daypacks ransacked while using them as pillows during a nap between Madrid and Barcelona. Both travelers awoke, startled and disoriented, to find the packs still under their heads but without various valuables. A conductor informed them that theives are now using ether or chloroform to anesthetize sleeping tourists, and that that was what had probably happened.

title: PUBLISHING GAMBLE IS PAYING OFF
description: AN ARTICLE entitled ''With Art and Craftsmanship, Books Regain Former Glory'' (The New York Times Magazine, Oct. 28, 1984) called attention to the re-emergence of small-press publishing in the United States.

title: HE LIKES IT HERE, MOSTLY
description: IN SEARCH OF MELANCHOLY BABY By Vassily Aksyonov. Translated by Michael Henry Heim and Antonina W. Bouis. 227 pp. New York: Random House. $15.95.

title: SUMMER CAMPAIGN TRAIL
description: FROM the town dumps to the beaches on the weekends and from the train stations to the shopping centers on weekdays, the candidates are everywhere these days, trying to find the voters and remind them that there are primary elections on Tuesday in the Fourth Congressional District in Fairfield County.

title: THE BLOODIEST BATTLE
description: Except for your editors' use of a picture of buddies from the 96th Infantry Division, William Manchester would have us believe that the Marines were the entire show on Okinawa. The truth is that Okinawa was that rare - perhaps only - time that the Marines and the Army invaded an island together and fought and died together throughout the campaign. For the record, four divisions went ashore that April 1 morning: 1st Marine and 6th Marine and the 7th and 96th Army Divisions.

title: SHELDON PENNOYER, AN ARCHITECT, WED TO PENELOPE G. BEAL, A MUSEUM AIDE
description: At the Chocorua Island Chapel at Squam Lake in Holderness, N.H., Penelope Gay Beal, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Beal Jr. of Lincoln, Mass., and Squam Lake, was married yesterday to Sheldon Kellogg Pennoyer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Geddes Pennoyer Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. F.Goldthwaite Sherrill, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: MAYORAL WHEELS
description: IT began as a joke, Mayor John Cesar of Brewster said last week, explaining what had led him to suggest to the members of his Village Board of Trustees that perhaps they could buy him a vehicle, or ''perhaps a pair of shoes.'' The problem was that the Mayor's aging car was ready for the junkyard.

title: NOFZIGER IS INDICTED
description: LYN NOFZIGER, a former senior political adviser and White House aide to Ronald Reagan, last week became the second member of the President's inner circle to be indicted as a result of inquiries into whether he too quickly, and therefore illegally, turned to private gain the influence he gained in public service.
