Ways to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 5 5 38 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS WITH WINE, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $16.95.) Recipes to be prepared at moderate cost. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) MEDITATIONS AT SUNSET: A Scientist Looks at the Sky, by James Trefil. (Scribners, $16.95.) With superb clarity, Mr. Trefil's third book of essays on physics delivers us the great natural laws that (for instance) make sunsets red and skies blue. A SCRAP OF TIME: And Other Stories, by Ida Fink. (Pantheon, $15.95.) The short stories in Mrs. Fink's first collection, derived from the experience of the Holocaust, speak in whispers of a world where everyday life was submerged in unthinkable horrors. THE ELIZABETH STORIES, by Isabel Huggan. (Viking, $15.95.) Wry, alarming stories in the voice of a girl confronting the helpless, disenfranchised world where the not-yet-adult live. THE SOUL OF VIKTOR TRONKO, by David Quammen. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Plots within plots and wheels within wheels spin smoothly and rapidly in this engrossing and tightly written K.G.B.-versus-Central Intelligence Agency spy novel. TOWN SMOKES, by Pinckney Benedict. (Ontario Review Press/ Persea, Paper, $9.95.) A 23-year-old West Virginian's intense, sometimes lyrical, always authentic short stories from the hindmost gullies and hooch-sodden hills of Appalachia. THE FAMILY MASHBER, by Der Nister. (Summit, $22.95.) A messianic Jewish sect in the Ukraine of the 1870's does duty as a subtle parallel to the Russian Revolution in this large-scale, ambiguous, morally inquisitive historical novel by the pseudonymous Yiddish writer Pinhas Kahanovitch (1884-1950). COLLECTED PROSE, by Robert Lowell, edited by Robert Giroux. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) A posthumous collection that allows the reader to reconstruct the development of Lowell's attitudes toward poetry and exhibits him on occasion as one of the most serious and most learned of critics.

title: Stuart Sherman Performs With Paradox
description: A MAN ARRIVES AT A RESTAU-rant on the top floor of a Tokyo hotel and strikes up a conversation with the bartender. The customer explains that on his way up to the 78th floor, he arbitrarily exited the elevator on the 25th floor and stood in front of Room 2538, where he had a vision of a man sitting by a window, reading a book. The customer then describes how the view of Tokyo by night can become a game of ''connecting the dots,'' and that when he connects all ''two thousand, five hundred and thirty-eight dots,'' or lights of Tokyo, it depicts the man by the window in Room 2538.

title: STATE WARNS OF LEAD IN DRINKING WATER
description: IN a campaign to reduce lead levels in drinking water, the State Health Services Department is sending a letter advising all day-care centers and schools to flush water lines daily.

title: POSTINGS: River Vale Reason; A Safety Factor
description: As suburban communities go, River Vale, N.J., is an easy sell. The Bergen County township, with a population of 9,700, has one traffic light, three golf courses and four and a half square miles of purely residential land. In addition, it was written up in ''Safe Places for the 80's,'' a 1984 Doubleday publication, as one of the most crime-free communities in America.

title:
FOCUS: CONVENTIONS;
Rivalry Heats Up In the West
description: LEAD: ASKED to evaluate the wisdom of building a $130 million downtown convention center in San Jose, Calif., a spokesman for the convention industry had a couple of questions of his own: ''Where is it? Isn't that somewhere near Los Angeles?''

title: MUSSELS STAR IN 4 WARM-WEATHER DISHES
description: FOOD for summer, especially for summer entertaining, requires planning in order to fulfill three necessary requirements. It must be appealing to serve and eat in warm weather, take advantage of abundant seafood and produce and be easily prepared in advance. If a recipe also provides the kind of leftover that can be turned into another effortless meal over the weekend, so much the better.

title: TENT PROTEST AT STONY BROOK
description: LEAD: TENTS have been springing up outside the administration building of the State University of New York at Stony Brook this month. As quickly as they appear, the campus police, acting on the orders of the university's president, John H. Marburger 3d, have been taking them down and arresting the student inside.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
CLEANING: ILLUSION, TRANQUILLITY
description: LEAD: I HAVE secretly taken up sweeping. A rather odd affinity, one might think, in this day of electric brooms, which I have tucked away in a closet, at least for now, anyway.

title: A City Beset by Drugs and Violence
description: ALL ITS LIFE, Miami has depended on image for survival. Over the years, it has hired some of the nation's most creative publicists to sell it to the world as a lotus land, a haven for middle-class hedonists, a place to make a fortune in real estate speculation, a city of intercontinental commercial excitement. For a long while, the salesmanship was effective.

title: HOW THE 'FRENCH STYLE' GOT THAT WAY
description: WE HAVE GOTTEN INTO the habit of throwing adjectives in the direction of French music - ''subtle,''

title:
MUSIC;
PRINCETON TO OFFER COLORADO QUARTET
description: LEAD: THE Colorado String Quartet will perform here Thursday at 8 P.M. as part of the popular Princeton University Summer Chamber Concert Series.

title: Sri Lanka President Meets Indian on Tamil Issue
description: A sudden burst of diplomatic activity between Sri Lanka and India this week has revived hopes of a fresh effort to end the Tamil separatist conflict.

title: VIRGINIE T. SOUBIRAN, A LAWYER, IS TO MARRY
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jean Marc Soubiran of Paris have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginie Terese Soubiran, to Theodore Edward Niedermayer, a son of Dr. George Huntas Niedermayer and Gretchen Sedam Niedermayer of Philadelphia. The couple plan to marry Sept. 12 in Paris.

title: Is Our Choice Democracy or Covert Activities?; Executive Order 12333
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Charleston, W. Va.;
New Identities For Old Faces
description: LEAD: WHEN the Charleston Town Center mall, three blocks west of the traditional downtown, opened in August 1983, several major buildings nearby were left vacant.

title: PROTECTING FACES FROM ERRANT PITCHES
description: The injuries during this baseball season to Andre Dawson and Joe Carter, both of whom were hit in the face by pitches, have left a lot of batters talking about what they can do to protect themselves better at the plate.

title: THE VALUE OF INTERNS IN THE WORKPLACE
description: Mary Jane Genova's essay, 'Student Raid on Corporations'' [ Opinion page, June 7 ] puzzles me. She relates that student interns at best contribute nothing and at worst impede productivity.

title: Low Savings
description: To the Editor:

title: Democratic Hopefuls Give Talk on Winning in '88
description: Democratic Presidential candidates lectured state party chairmen from all parts of the country today on how to win in 1988.

title: Clinic Plans Variation on Fertility Technique
description: As the permutations of artificially induced conception increase, plans for an egg bank have been announced by a major medical center in Cleveland.

title: IT TURNS OUT MEMORY LANE HAS POTHOLES
description: I WENT home recently - back to the town where I was born. Where I went to school. Where I was married. And where one of my children was about to be graduated from college.

title: The Costly Bargain Fare
description: Summertime is charter time, the season when economy-minded travelers reserve with their travel agents for trips to Europe and elsewhere at prices that even the plain-pipe rack airlines cannot match. The price is low because the charter organizer does not have a complex reservation system and high overhead and can make decisions fast. Sometimes the cheap ticket buys service equivalent to the best, but often enough it means seats crammed together, less-than-handy departure terminals, few, if any, in-flight amenities and unreliable flight schedules.

title: Data Update: July 19,1987
The Australians Stuck Together
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ROYALTY VISIT TO PUT SALEM IN LIMELIGHT
description: LEAD: WITH AN eye to Scandinavian trade and history, Governor Kean's 28-member New Sweden Commemorative Commission will be briefed at the State House Friday on the celebration next spring of the 350th anniversary of the landing of 400 Swedish colonists and a contingent of Finns in the Delaware Valley.

title:
IN THE REGION: LONG ISLAND;
Oceanfront Rezoning Troubles Builders
description: LEAD: ON almost every block along West Broadway and Shore Road, the two main oceanfront thoroughfares in Long Beach, banners and streamers announcing new residential developments flap in the breezes.

title: LAURA L. BROCK WEDS A LAWYER
description: At Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in New York yesterday, Laura Lindley Brock, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Brock of New York, was married to Robert Blakeman Smith, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Smith of Thornwood, N.Y.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A photograph on pages 18 and 19 in The New York Times Magazine today with an article about Miami purports to show the scene as police officers arrested drug smugglers who had been forced down after their plane failed to respond to the control tower of Miami International Airport. Actually, the photograph was taken about four years ago at the Homestead, Fla., Air Force base at the request of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation to illustrate an advertisement for a Westinghouse radar product. The photograph was supplied to The Times by the New York office of SIPA Press, an international picture agency with headquarters in Paris, which has acknowledged it erred. The photograph was included with other photographs showing United States Customs officers and Florida police officers taking action against drug smugglers. The photographs were accompanied by captions dated January 1986. The caption for the photograph purportedly showing the arrest of the smugglers did not indicate in any way that the picture had been posed. Rodger Garland, chief of the United States Customs air branch at the Homestead base, said that one of the people depicted as being under arrest in the photograph was a contract employee working for the Customs service and that the other was a Westinghouse employee.

title: AT THE HEARINGS, A WHIFF OF DEJA-VU
description: AS TELEVISION DRAMA OR vaudeville, the Iran-contra hearings send forth signals we have been trained to recognize in popular entertainment. No sooner does a character appear on our screens than the conventions of show business come into play. We can tell at once from what he wears and how he bears himself whether that fellow is to be trusted; we know from the way she smiles or licks her lips whether that woman is lying. In today's sitcoms, as in yesterday's melodramas, a lot of time is saved by this instant identification, the fast food of fiction.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
TRAVELERS' SHOTS
description: LEAD: Travelers from the county and surrounding areas heading for exotic corners of the globe can avail themselves of a new International Traveler's Health Service established recently at New York Medical College in Valhalla, in addition to the services offered by the county's Health Department. The new service - which provides immunizations against meningococcus, Japanese encephalitis and yellow fever (yellow fever shots are also given by the Health Department).

title: Research Triangle
description: To the Editor:

title: Compassion and Integrity
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: AFTER THE STORM. By Judith Richards. (Peachtree, $14.95.) Set in the waning days of World War II, Judith Richards's beautifully written novel, her fourth, centers on the summer of a sensitive 10-year-old boy who lives with his mother and younger sister on the fringe of the Florida Everglades. The story is about those people left at home to cope with the tense waiting and lonely separations of war.

title: Edberg Adds Charisma
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Is Our Choice Democracy or Covert Activities?; A Good Show
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
International Fare in White Plains
description: LEAD: AN omen of revitalization on a seedy strip of North Broadway, the beautiful Divan has had its door open almost three months.

title: Green Mountains of Vermont Abuzz Over Butter
description: Forget Oliver North. Forget the Iran-contra affair. A matter closer to home has set the placid Green Mountains abuzz and rocked Vermonters' already shaky trust in government and human nature.

title: NO POLICE, NO EXPENSE IN DANIELSON
description: THE last vestiges of the Danielson Police Department will go up for bids next Saturday when officials from throughout the state line up to view the equipment left behind when the officers were laid off.

title: WHAT WE CALL HOME
description: LEGACIES By Nancy Potter. 134 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. $11.95.

title: PIT BULL ATTACKS PROMPT A CALL TO STIFFEN LAWS
description: TWO months ago, an 8-year-old girl in New Britain was attacked by a pit bull that knocked her down, broke her leg and inflicted bites that required 47 stitches.

title: Headliners; In Harness
description: It seems that William Shawn found a friendly place to land when he was forced to bail out of his job as editor of The New Yorker last February. Mr. Shawn, who ran The New Yorker for 35 of his 79 years, has been hired by his old friend Robert W. Straus as a book editor for Farrar, Straus & Giroux. Mr. Straus, who has known Mr. Shawn more than 40 years, said last week that he had offered his friend the job shortly before Mr. Shawn left The New Yorker, but withheld a formal announcement at Mr. Shawn's request. The publisher said Mr. Shawn would edit ''as many books as he wants to do.'' One of Mr. Shawn's first projects for the publishing house took him to familar territory - he edited a work by Lillian Ross, a longtime friend and New Yorker contributor.

title:
INVESTING;
Bright View of Colonial Life
description: LEAD: Life insurers have been getting low marks from investors lately because of concerns that AIDS and proposed changes in accounting rules could depress earnings. But last Monday the shares of the Colonial Life and Accident Insurance Company jumped $2, to $27, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Red Sox Top Athletics On Homer in 10th, 5-3
description: Dave Henderson hit a two-run 10th-inning home run today after Jim Rice's two-out, two-strike homer had tied the score in the ninth to give the Boston Red Sox a 5-3 victory over the Oakland Athletics.

title: CREATIVE COUPLES: IS LOVE BLIND?
description: LEAD: HAVING USED CYBILL SHEP-herd to great effect in ''The Last Picture Show'' - the 1971 hit movie featuring the actress in her screen debut as a small-town teen-age temptress - the director Peter Bogdanovich proceeded to cast his protege and then-offscreen leading lady in a series of films, greeted predominantly by mixed reviews and empty theaters.

title: Padres Send Cards to Defeat
description: Chris Brown singled home John Kruk with one out in the 10th inning as the San Diego Padres posted a 4-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: New Toy for Boys of Summer THEY are truly the boys of summer. ''We have so many water toys, it's unbelievable,'' said 35-year-old Gary L. Shoemaker of Centereach. ''You know boys and their toys. Our wives were delighted when we started barefoot water-skiing because we didn't have to buy any more equipment. They're always wondering what we're going to come up with next.''

title: OPTOMETRIST HELPS THE SKILL OF VISION
description: ''YOU only can perform as well as you can see, and seeing is a learned skill,'' said Dr. Leon Revien, a Great Neck optometrist, who has used this principle as a basis for his visual skills program since its inception 15 years ago. Dr. Revien says he has improved the performance of more than 1,500 professional athletes, including football, baseball, hockey, golf and tennis players, as well as Air Force pilots and people with dyslexia.

title: Pig on the Loose Is No Poke
description: A fugitive pig is on the loose in town, setting off burglar alarms, breaking doors off hinges, stealing dog food and eluding the police.

title: DOROTHEA MATTHEWS WEDS
description: At the Helen Hills Hills Chapel at Smith College in Northampton, Mass., yesterday Dorothea E. Matthews, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Matthews of Ridgefield Park, N.J., was married to J.Richard Schneider, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Schneider of New Dorp, S.I. The Rev. John Webster of the United Church of Christ officiated.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
An Overreaction To the High Court's Ruling on Property
description: LEAD: RARELY has a decision of the United States Supreme Court evoked such immediate and outspoken reaction in the county as the recent ruling in the case involving the First English Evangelical Lutheran Church of Glendale, Calif. The ink was hardly dry when a number of land developers started making euphoric statements about the significant ''victory'' for the real estate community.

title: Jamaican Drug Gangs Thriving in U.S. Cities
description: A large number of Jamaicans in the United States and Canada, most of them illegal aliens, have created a widespread criminal organization involved principally in importing and distributing narcotics, according to Federal officials.

title: SHREDDING, EK-SETERA
description: ''Ek-setera'' need not be a ''general colloquialism'' to which we all have to adjust. It is a display of ignorance that could be cured if Latin were required - even one year of it - in high school. I had two. I don't use this to read Caesar or Virgil, or even the more difficult tombstones. But I sure know that ''et'' means ''and.'' In a world of uncertainty, such knowledge can be comforting. CAROL BECKER New Brunswick, N.J.

title: MELISSA AND JANICE CLEVELAND TO MARRY
description: Dr. and Mrs. Richard J. Cleveland of Boston have announced the engagements of Dr. Cleveland's daughters Melissa Carol Cleveland and Janice Lee Cleveland to Stephen Carol Bernhardt and Dana Stanley Washburn, respectively.

title: AMERICNAS FLYING MORE AND FEARING MORE
description: A GROWING number of experts have been warning of an ''erosion'' of safety in air travel. Although the low number of accidents that have occurred during the last two years would normally be reassuring, critics see several disturbing trends: The number of near-collisions and controller errors has sharply risen, while airline deregulation has resulted in cutbacks in safety and engineering staffs and the hiring of less-experienced pilots.

title: PERILS AT THE BEACH
description: FOR those on the East Coast, the dog days of July are best relieved by beating a path to the beach. There, ocean breezes cool the spirit and warm sands soothe the body. Since many such jaunts to the beach are with friends or family, there's a natural inclination to bring a camera along. What better time to record the family, after all, than when everyone is luxuriating in feelings of relaxation and relief?

title: PERFECTING WOMAN
description: PALOMINO By Elizabeth Jolley. 260 pp. New York: A Stanley Moss Book/Persea Books. $15.95.

title: Chewing on Words
description: PROFESSIONALS IN the world of food, like sportswriters and baseball players, have developed their own argot to precisely describe certain actions, ideas and objects. The locker room has been an idiomatic Vesuvius, spouting innumerable contributions such as ''to strike out,'' ''to hit a home run,'' ''bull pen,'' ''utility player,'' and so on, which have been adopted by everyone from rebuffed lovers to newspaper editors. Similarly, a food word now and then slips out from under the kitchen door and becomes part of the general English vernacular.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: CURTAIN UP ON SEASON

title: MISS FURTH IS ENGAGED TO THEODORE LEHRMAN
description: Dr. Hans G. Furth and Madeline B. Furth, both of Washington, have announced the engagement of their daughter Catherine Furth to Theodore D. Lehrman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert O. Lehrman of New York and Edgewater, N.J. A Sept. 6 wedding is planned.

title: Conviction Set Aside, Marine Free, for Now
description: A Marine whose conviction on rape and attempted murder charges was overturned by an appeals court earlier this month was freed from prison Friday, the Marine Corps said.

title: Anne Whiteman Marries a Banker
description: Anne Margaret Whiteman and Andrew Clark Brummer, 1985 graduates of Colgate University, were married yesterday at the Church of the Gesu in University Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Francis T. Dietz performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: JANET ROBYN PINSKY PLANS TO WED ALAN GINSBERG
description: The engagement of Janet Robyn Pinsky to Alan Justin Ginsberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Ginsberg of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joel Pinsky of Montreal and Stowe, Vt. A Sept. 13 wedding is planned.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: STOLEN GOODS. By Susan Dworkin. (Newmarket Press, $16.95.) Susan Dworkin, a playwright, likes dramatic effects; her first novel is pumped full of them. Disasters, misfortunes and crises punctuate this book like exclamation points. Chapter one ends with a car crash that kills Vartan Garba the day before his wedding; his fiancee, Anna Karavajian, is propelled to map out a plan for her life, for marriage was ''the only fate she had ever imagined.'' For several years she teaches math to Bronx eighth graders; then she joins Karavajian Press, her father's business in New York City. By age 37, Anna has become president and chief executive officer. Catastrophes such as stolen inventory and lost accounts plague the business, but Anna, a peppery and resourceful woman, remains in control. On business at an antiquated theater in Flushing, she meets Charles Borden, a divorced playwright. At once, Ms. Dworkin stages a scene that pitches Anna and Charles into pandemonium: a bizarre robbery resulting in more stolen goods. They survive the ordeal and become lovers. Their affair - predictably - is characterized by histrionics, as well as by genuine tenderness. Anna brazens her way through the suspicions, separations and indignant accusations that mark their relationship. Gradually, Anna and the rough-edged Charles allow themselves to be loved again. Throughout Anna's turbulent work and love life, her two sisters provide the ballast of sisterly attention and affection that keeps her on an even keel. Their scenes are full of flip, funny talk and plenty of singing, cavorting, arguing and consoling. Ms. Dworkin creates some fine moments when Anna's Armenian family gathers and supports its own. ''Stolen Goods'' provides light entertainment as it barrels along through the adventures of its frisky heroine. Too bad this fictional debut suffers from a gimmicky plot and overwrought prose.

title: GORBACHEV'S GAMBLE
description: SEATED BEHIND A LONG TABLE IN THE INTIMATE yellow and white Hall of Plenums in the Kremlin last month, Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev, General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, presided over a crucial two-day gathering of the party elite. Flanking Gorbachev were nine full members of the ruling Politburo; facing him, in the gradually elevated rows of cushioned seats, were the 300 members of the party's Central Committee, a body that has the authority to appoint - and remove - the General Secretary.

title: MOVIES, BOOKS AND THE REAL STORY
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
THE FINE ART OF PINCHING
description: LEAD: ONE of the most important practices used to train or control plants is the pinch.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Garbo in Central Park While he was writing about Proust's Madame Swann walking in the Bois de Boulogne, Wallace Fowlie himself used to relax by walking in Central Park at dawn. In ''Sites: A Third Memoir'' (Duke University), he describes a remarkable encounter during one of his strolls.

title: ROMEO AND JULIET OF UPPER MANHATTAN
description: FLORRY OF WASHINGTON HEIGHTS By Steve Katz. 206 pp. Los Angeles: Sun & Moon Press. Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $10.95.

title: An Olympics in New Y>ork? Yes, But Do It the Right Way
description: LEAD: LONDON, Paris, Berlin, Tokyo, Moscow, Rome. These are some of the great cities that have enjoyed the privilege of staging the Summer Olympic Games. Here are some more: Athens, Montreal, Mexico City, Stockholm.

title: WHO'S NOT IN THE HALL OF FAME WHO SHOULD BE
description: Who's not in the Hall of Fame who should be, under current rules? Nobody! Already, too many mediocrities (Rabbit Maranville?) have been enshrined. But if I had to bring up one possibility, perhaps Nellie Fox, certainly the best second baseman in history not represented by a plaque. Phil Rizzuto played a vital position on an admittedly great team on a reasonably regular basis for a little more than a decade. For that, the writers are supposed to genuflect to Rizzuto while continuing to slight the likes of Fox? RICHARD H. WITT East Windsor, N.J.

title: Sweeping Welfare Revision Plan Stresses Responsibility of Parents
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan today proposed a sweeping revision of the nation's basic welfare program, emphasizing parental responsibility rather than Government handouts. He expressed confidence that the two houses of Congress could reach agreement on the issue in the coming year.

title: State Plan On Growth Faces Debate
description: LEAD: WHEN the State Planning Commission begins its consideration this week of the latest draft of the State Development and Redevelopment Plan, its deliberations are likely to mirror the debate outside the commission on the plan.

title: CRACK IS LAMENTED AT EMOTIONAL VIGIL
description: ''Our children are in a very bad situation,'' the Rev. H. DeVore Chapman said yesterday from the pulpit of a Brooklyn church. ''They are hooked on drugs that have come straight from the pit of hell, destroying our families and communities.''

title: RETIREE EXPANSION OPPOSED
description: LEAD: THE proposed expansion of a planned retirement community in the Shoreham area of Brookhaven Town has been challenged by residents and the Superintendent of the Shoreham-Wading River School District, who insist that the expansion will increase the percentage of older people in the district to the point where future school budget votes will be in jeopardy.

title: 29 ESTABLISHMENTS CITED BY NEW YORK UNDER HEALTH CODE
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 29 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I understand what war is, but it is unjust to kill civilians like this.''

title: JAMES G. AUCHINCLOSS, A LAW STUDENT, AND KRISTIN MORRIS DELAFIELD ARE WED
description: Kristin Morris Delafield, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Delafield of New York, was married yesterday to James Gordon Auchincloss, a son of Bayard Cutting Auchincloss of Santa Barbara, Calif., and the late Mary Christy Pratt Williams. Cannon Gethin B. Hughes performed the ceremony at All Saints-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Montecito, Calif.

title: COZY AND SIMPLE IN FAIRFIELD
description: SMALL shopping center in Fairfield is the backdrop for a simple, softly lighted romantic new restaurant called Adrian's Brick Walk.

title: OUT OF THE WOODS
description: WHEN NOEL JEFFREY, A Manhattan-based interior designer, was asked to build a house in East Hampton, L.I., for clients for whom he had already completed a large apartment in the city, he jumped at the chance.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WITHIN NORMAL LIMITS. By Todd Grimson. (Vintage Contemporaries/Random House, Paper, $5.95.) Darrell Patterson, a doctor in his 30's, is the kind of guy who dislikes his 7-year-old son for crying and not being very good at sports, and who is proud when his wife cheats at tennis. Is this first novel a joke? A parody of yuppie selfishness? Initially, the unmitigated flatness of the first-person narrative seems as if it might be due to Darrell's prescription drug problem; he controls his moods by taking assorted uppers and downers, thereby losing any personality of his own and endangering his marriage. As an emergency room doctor, Darrell offers stereotyped descriptions of everyone he encounters, even though none of these people have any bearing on the story. Among his patients, there's Carol, who ''looks tough, very butch, like the prototypical lesbian that she is,'' a gay man who ''has a little mustache and is slender,'' and several hysterical and/or stupid female patients with ''female complaints'' (and it's clear Darrell doesn't like doing pelvics). Todd Grimson incorporates his own experiences working as an interviewer in an emergency room. The descriptions seem endless, and one or two scenes in the emergency room would have been more than enough to show the tedium and occasional ghastliness of the job. But all this ugliness, personal and societal, would have been fine if anything had happened in the novel - if Darrell had expressed an honest emotion to his wife, for instance, or confronted his drug problem. His marriage improves slightly, but by the end, Darrell is still a jerk who takes pills and is convinced that he's smarter than everyone around him. ''This is my life,'' thinks Darrell, in what's meant to be a great revelation toward the end of the book, ''imperfect as it is.'' But why do we have to read about it?

title: Land Beyond Land's End
description: Few places in the world are named as definitively as Land's End. That is where Cornwall, the land that forms the southwestern corner of Britain, tapers off to a rough point and dramatically abuts in a spectacle of high cliffs and crashing sea. It is not difficult to imagine that in a distant era the place might have been considered the edge of the world, with the sea abruptly dropping away a little to the west. And yet even in the mists of the Bronze Age it was known that just over the horizon lay the Isles of Scilly, a collection of some hundred rocks, six or eight large enough to be inhabited.

title: DO LIFEGUARDS DO WHAT THEY'RE PAID TO DO?
description: YOU'VE seen them on the beach before - bronzed, muscular bodies with sun-bleached hair sitting in lifeguard chairs. They wear dark sunglasses and white nose protectors, twirl a whistle around a finger and have ''Lifeguard'' stamped on all their apparel.

title: Rock: Andy Summers
description: ANDY SUMMERS became one of the most influential guitarists in rock as a member of the Police, the trio that dissolved in 1982. Now he has started his own band, which opened a two-night engagement at the Ritz on Thursday. With Mr. Summers as lead singer (joined by Nan Vernon on backup vocals), the band's set was divided uncomfortably between Police-style pop songs and more atmospheric material. Both revolved around repeating, minimalistic riffs - but Mr. Summers is much more effective as a guitarist than as a singer.

title:
IN THE REGION: NEW JERSEY;
At Smithville, a Mixed-Use Compromise
description: LEAD: FOR nearly six years, a coalition of state and national environmentalists has stalled construction of a huge mixed-use project in the Towne of Historic Smithville, a rural enclave in Galloway Township, 11 miles northwest of Atlantic City.

title: LYNNANN QUIGLEY TO MARRY
description: Mr. and Mrs. James F. Quigley of Holmdel, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lynnann Quigley to William V. Cuddy Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cuddy of Greenwich, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass. Ms. Quigley is an equities trader at the Y.M.C.A. Retirement Fund in New York. Her fiance is a commercial real-estate broker for the Rostenberg-Doern Company in White Plains. The wedding is to be in October.

title: Killer Marries in Prison
description: A former Tufts University professor who admitted killing a reputed prostitute four years ago has married in prison, according to his lawyer. William Douglas, serving an 18- to 20-year sentence for the March 1983 hammer slaying of Robin Benedict, was married at the state prison in Gardner on July 7, the attorney, Thomas Troy, said. Mr. Douglas, 45 years old, was divorced by his former wife after he pleaded guilty to manslaughter. His attorney declined to provide the name of Mr. Douglas's new wife.

title: THE BLOODIEST BATTLE
description: I was deeply affected by William Manchester's description of infantry combat on Okinawa. I also thoroughly enjoyed his account of the humiliation of that dreadful old phony, John Wayne.

title: A New Basketball League Puts a Ceiling on Height
description: There were tryouts yesterday for a new professional basketball league for the ''little'' guys - those 6 feet 4 inches and under.

title: 'POLITICAL THEATER' FOR CHILDREN
description: ONE day en route to Grand Central Terminal from Darien, Kay Arthur started to write a play. On the way back home, she finished it.

title: MUSIC
description: OperaFest A Gala Concert at the Zurich Opera With Jose Carreras, Mirella Freni, Nicolai Ghiaurov, Gwyneth Jones, Alfredo Kraus, Lucia Popp, Mara Zampieri and other artists. Video Artists International. 92 minutes. $59.95.

title: FILM MUSIC HAS TWO MASTERS
description: OH, THE POWER OF MUSIC TO stir the coals of memory - and, pace Noel Coward, it needn't be cheap music, either. Although 20 years must have passed since I saw Bo Widerberg's ''Elvira Madigan'' for the first and only time, the mood of that sweetly pathetic, sun-dappled Swedish film came stealing back the other evening as I sat listening to Alicia de Larrocha play the Andante from the Piano Concerto No. 21 at a Mostly Mozart concert. This has happened to me before during especially sensitive performances of this work and I invariably feel guilty. No doubt I should, a little.

title: Exploring the Curious Cult of the Corvette
description: It was an oppressively hot day in White Plains, and Guy Zani Jr. was driving one of his Corvettes with the roof down. ''I'm a little low now,'' he said. ''I've only got six Corvettes. Usually, I've got eight or ten. This one's a 1957. Some great-looking car, right?''

title: MILDRED MATESICH AND A JUDGE ARE WED
description: Mildred Mary Matesich, chief staff counsel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, and Judge Harry T. Edwards of the same court were married yesterday at St. Alban's Episcopal Church in Washington. The Rev. Cally Irish performed the ceremony. Martha Matesich was maid of honor for her sister, who was also attended by her children, Jessica and Andrew Seidman. Brent Hayes Edwards was best man for his father.

title: Broadcast TV
description: A trio of Hollywood classics will light up the home screen this week - first-rate dramatizations of major novels. John Steinbeck's ''Grapes of Wrath'' (1940) gets a prime-time run-off (for a change) Tuesday evening at 8 on Channel 55. And Channel 13 has ''The Heiress,'' from the retitled stage adaptation of Henry James's ''Washington Square,'' on Friday at 11 P.M. And for Sunday night owls, there is Charles Dickens's ''Tale of Two Cities'' (1935) on Channel 9 at 2 A.M.

title: N.F.L. Already Gunning for Jackson
description: Years ago, Bo Jackson's ambitious plan to play pro football immediately after this baseball season might have been greeted with indifference. In these days of longer and overlapping seasons and almost year-round football training, his plans, and his somewhat boastful announcement of them, have evoked near hostility.

title: IT'S MY STREET (AND DON'T CALL IT BUFORD)
description: I LIVE on Beaufort Street. (That's B-e-a-u-f-o-r-t.) It is in Orchard Hill, the Elmsford side, in unincorporated Greenburgh. It may be hard to find, but it should not be that difficult to pronounce. The people we bought our house from called it BO-fort, using the French pronunciation for ''beau,'' and we continued to do so, as our new neighbors did, too. But some of the merchants and older residents of the Elmsford area call it BU-ford, using the ''beau'' as in beautiful, and pronouncing the ''t'' as a ''d.''

title: A Dizzying Array Of Economic Data
description: The trade deficit widened in May to $14.4 billion, from $13.3 billion, as imports, led by oil, hit a record. Many economists had expected the trade gap to decrease a bit or stay nearly even, and the figures disturbed them, because it indicated that exports are not getting the chance to catch up. The dollar, which has started to fall from its lofty heights, had an effect as well, and if it continues to drop, the dollar value of imported goods will rise, and that could further widen the gap. . . . Business inventories jumped seven-tenths of 1 percent in May, to a record, as consumers bought fewer cars and less furniture. . . . Retail sales rose just four-tenths of 1 percent in June. . . . Housing starts fell seven-tenths of 1 percent in June, much less than recent drops. . . . Factory production rose two-tenths of 1 percent in June, and factories operated at 79.7 percent of capacity in June, unchanged from May but up a bit from a year ago.

title: 'THE BUCK STOPS HERE'
description: FOR more than seven months, since Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d disclosed that profits from the secret sale of American weapons to Iran had been secretly used to arm the Nicaraguan rebels, Americans have been trying to unravel the tangle, seeking in particular the answer to one key question: What did President Reagan know of the whole affair, and when?

title: Born of Strife And Controversy, A Lively New Art Museum Finds Itself A Niche
description: IN A CITY BLESSED WITH dozens of museums devoted to subjects as varied as pre-Colombian archeology and the paintings of modern artists such as Diego Rivera and Rufino Tamayo, it would not seem easy for a newcomer to the scene to establish a niche for itself. But in less than a year since it opened in October 1986, the Centro Cultural has successfully negotiated a series of obstacles, to emerge as perhaps the most adventurous and innovative cultural institution here.

title: I.R.S. to Help Nail City Tax Evaders
description: Searching parking garages for city residents hiding behind out-of-state license plates is one way to catch tax evaders, and in its recent crackdown the Koch adminstration has been willing to do even that. Now, however, New York City Finance Commissioner Abraham Biderman has a better tool. Last week, the city became the first in the country to win the right to look at Federal tax returns.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Governor's House Center of Debate

title: When Good Health Is Part of the Job
description: Montgomery Securities encourages good health by making sports an integral part of its culture. The joke around the San Francisco company, in fact, is that your annual bonus depends more on your performance on the company's athletic squads than on its investment team.

title: POSTINGS: 120 on the Hudson; Condos in A Factory
description: A late 19th-century factory complex that occupies a full block overlooking the Hudson River in Newburgh, N.Y., was, until recently, abuzz with the production of lawn-mower parts and security uniforms. But now the low-rise, rectangular, red-brick structure, on a two-acre site at the corner of Johns and South Williams Streets, awaits conversion into 120 condominiums, to be called the Commons at Washington Park.

title:
ANTIQUES;
RESTORATION MIRRORS STATEN ISLAND OF OLD
description: LEAD: WHAT was it like when time floated with the days and seasons and work was measured between sunrise and sundown?

title: MOVIES
description: Stand By Me Starring Wil Wheaton, River Phoenix, Corey Feldman, Jerry O'Connell, Kiefer Sutherland. Based on the novella ''The Body'' by Stephen King. 1986. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 87 minutes. $89.95. This rite-of-passage movie plays particularly well on the home screen, and kids like to see it again and again - which seems perfectly fine, even with its R rating (probably for strong language). Four early-adolescent boys in rural Oregon in the summer of 1959 find out by accident that the body of a missing youth, apparently hit by a train, is sprawled near a river more than 20 miles away. They set off on an overnight hike to find it. Along the way, they encounter a train on a bridge, leeches in a pond, a gang of toughs and a good deal of self-knowledge.

title: Dance
description: Drums, chants and the delicate tremor of ancient stringed instruments will echo through the woods of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., this week, with ''African Tradition and Heritage,'' an unusual gathering of dancers, weavers, musicians and artists from Africa. Four companies will participate in the program, which opens Tuesday and runs through Saturday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Sports section July 5 on the Henley Royal Regatta misidentified which Yale crew lost in the Ladies' Challenge Plate. It was the varsity men's lightweight.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JULY 19, 1987
description: International 3-15 After John Poindexter's testimony before the committees investigating the Iran-contra affair ends early next week, only five more witnesses are scheduled to appear before the hearings end. Page 1 The contras killed nine soldiers, three children and a pregnant woman, but failed to capture their target Thursday in their first major attack since the Iran-contra hearings focused American public attention on their movement. 1 France suggested to Iran that both countries agree to evacuate their respective diplomats and embassy personnel within five days. The move was a bid to calm the crisis caused by France's decision to break diplomatic relations with Teheran. 1 The U.S. plan to escort tankers to and from Kuwait that are flying the American flag is tailored to the relatively crowded waters of the Persian Gulf, officials say. 12 An anti-apartheid labor group in South Africa formally adopted the political program of black guerrillas fighting to end white rule. The group also committed itself to putting pressure on Pretoria to sign the Geneva Convention. 5 Vietnam agreed to U.S. conditions for a meeting with a special envoy to discuss the issue of missing servicemen, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said. But he warned that there might not be much progress. 3 Some Thai children from the U.S. have been sent to Thailand by their families under an program designed to strengthen their cultural roots. For eight weeks, the children experience what it means to be ''khon Thai,'' or a ''Thai person.'' 12 In Cambodia, the soft approach has been adopted by the Vietnamese-sponsored Government of Heng Samrin and his Prime Minister, Hun Sen, on sensitive issues in agriculture and religion, in an effort to make Communism palatable. 8 Army impatience hinted in Seoul 3 South Koreans in U.S. go home 6 Ethnic tension in Old Delhi 9 Britain reviews war-crime case 13 Casey left legacy of doubt 14 National 16-23, 30-32 A revision of the welfare program emphasizing parental responsibility rather than Government handouts was proposed by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. He expressed confidence that Congress could agree on the issue in the coming year. 1 Programs outside prisons for offenders are receiving growing support from foundations and other private groups. The programs include alternative sentences, detention at home and supervised detention in a halfway house. 1 Democratic Presidential candidates lectured state party chairmen from all parts of the country on how to win in 1988. For many of the officials, the speeches represented a chance to assess many of the hopefuls. 22 Patricia Schroeder was supported in her undecided quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination at the convention of the National Organization for Women. She received enough money to qualify for Federal matching campaign funds, officials said. 22 Six more bodies were found in Texas by searchers scouring a river downstream from where floodwaters swept away a bus and a van filled with teen-agers leaving a church camp Friday. With the death toll at eight, two youths remained missing and were feared dead. 16 Workers at a Hormel plant regained control of their union local 14 months after the union's international unit placed the local in trusteeship and removed its officers for refusing to end a strike. 23 Village fights fast-food outlet 16 Model addiction center thrives 16 Museum of Indian art in Santa Fe 19 12 voters discuss AIDS issues 22 Regional 24-25, 27-28, 33-35 2,,q>Trying to end free rides on subways in New York City, the Transit Authority will use new procedures and technology. But while these measures will make the transit system less porous, it will be far from impenetrable, officials said. 1 A new major league baseball team is becoming the focus of New Jersey's search to fill the stadium it wants to build near the Meadowlands Sports Complex. The search previously focused on existing franchises. 24 Surrogate motherhood was opposed in a brief filed by New Jersey's Roman Catholic bishops with the New Jersey Supreme Court. The brief argued that the practice violates the public policy of the state. 28 A barn shortage in Connecticut has forced some wealthy landowners to import their rustic dream houses from upstate New York and Vermont. ''Everybody wants to live in a barn, and there aren't any left,'' one barn importer said. 24 A plan to crack down on tax evaders has brought praise for Abraham Biderman, New York City's Finance Commisioner. Mayor Koch misses few opportunities to boast about Mr. Biderman's initiative against the underground economy. 25 A daylong prayer vigil was held at the Pilgrim Cathedral in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn to draw attention to problems plaguing the black community. A major focus was the use of crack, the highly addictive and smokeable form of cocaine. 24 Bridge team championship final 24

title: Two Against the Current, One With the Tide
description: BACK IN THE 1970'S A PHOTOG-rapher once described SoHo as ''the center of the center of the center of the universe.'' What he meant was that the streets around West Broadway were then the focus of the New York art scene, that the New York art scene was the focus of art in the United States, and that art in the United States was the focus of art internationally. For all its hyperbole - not to mention its geocentric and ethnocentric bias - the statement was, at the time, not considered flagrantly outrageous.

title: Minority Business
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE TO AID MIGRATING STUDENTS
description: LEAD: A TEEN-AGER had moved with his family so many times between Bridgeport, Puerto Rico and Massachusetts last year that Bridgeport school officials could not determine what grade he should be in.

title: SIKHS WADE ASHORE IN CANADA CLUTCHING ATTACHE CASES
description: AMID concern in Canada last week about the arrival of another boatload of illegal immigrants on the Atlantic coast, a story in The Toronto Star seemed illuminating. While the Government in Ottawa was reporting an avalanche of telegrams and telephone calls demanding that the 174 Sikhs who waded ashore from an aging freighter in Nova Scotia be sent home to India, the newspaper looked into the history of the 155 Tamils from Sri Lanka who arrived last August in similar fashion.

title: In NortH SALEM, A REALISM IN WHICH APPEARANCES DECEIVE
description: IT may be a cliche that appearances can deceive, yet it's always a surprise when they do.

title: Iran Announces Maneuvers In Persian Gulf Next Month
description: Iran announced today that marine, land and air forces would hold maneuvers in the Persian Gulf, the Strait of Hormuz and the Sea of Oman in August and said these were a warning to the superpowers.

title: OPENING TO ISRAEL?
description: ''WE came here to do a technical job only,'' said Yevgeny Antipov, the head of the first Soviet delegation to visit Israel since Moscow broke off relations after the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. But not many Israelis believed him. After all, the eight Soviet envoys, whose official mission last week was to survey Russian Orthodox properties, spent most of their time politicking, whether it was delivering the morning greeting in Hebrew on a popular radio program, posing in swimsuits for photographers, visiting the Israeli Foreign Ministry or inviting anti-Soviet protesters into their hotel room.

title: Is Our Choice Democracy or Covert Activities?; An American Hero?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Ali's Boxing Curse
description: In boxing more than in other sports, life is seldom easy for the great ones after they climb down from the ring for the last time. But for three of the best, champagne turned to vinegar. Joe Louis couldn't knock out the Internal Revenue Service auditors. Sugar Ray Robinson has been struggling with Alzheimer's disease, and Muhammad Ali is up against Parkinson's Syndrome. The irony is that, as youngsters growing up on the Detroit streets, Joe Louis inspired the original Sugar Ray, whose skill and style later inspired Ali.

title: Lovers Sentenced in Escape From Prison in a Helicopter
description: A prison escapee who hijacked a helicopter, flew into a Federal prison and spirited his lover to freedom was sentenced to 25 years in prison Friday.

title: INSIDE
description: Schroeder Collects at NOW Patricia Schroeder, who may run for President, addressed the NOW convention and got enough money to qualify for Federal funds. Page 22.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: TRAUMA AND MASTERY IN LIFE AND ART. By Gilbert J. Rose. (Yale University, $27.50.) In this provocative and scholarly book, the psychoanalyst Gilbert J. Rose explores the similarities and differences between psychoanalysis and art. The book begins by comparing the reactions of a murderer and of the Russian novelist Fyodor Dostoyevsky to similar childhood memories of seeing a horse beaten.

title: B. BRADFORD BARNES
description: B. Bradford Barnes, the Speaker of the Delaware House of Representatives, died Friday night apparently of a heart attack at Nanticoke Hospital, Seaford, Del. He was 55 years old.

title: SHREDDING, EK-SETERA
description: It is discouraging to see how William Safire has joined the ranks of other members of the press who revel in the humor of the involvement of Fawn Hall in the Iran-contra affair (On Language, ''Fawn Hall's Shredding, Ek-setera,'' June 21).

title: Pact Signed on Development Of Industrial Park in Newark
description: The signing of an agreement for the joint development of a new industrial park in Newark was announced yesterday by the city and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: TICK-BORNE DISEASE INFESTS SUFFOLK
description: LEAD: RESEARCHERS at the State University of New York at Stony Brook and physicians on the East End believe that Lyme disease has become a significant health problem in Suffolk County, and if its spread is not slowed, it may reach epidemic levels. Of the nearly 500 cases of Lyme disease reported in New York State last year, more than one-third were found in

title: McCallum Wins by Knockout
description: Donald Curry had the word ''REDEMPTION'' on the back of his black robe when he entered the ring at Caesars Palace Indoor Sports Pavilion tonight.

title: FOLLOWING PATHS TO ADVENTURE
description: LEAD: TWENTY-SIX years ago, two adventurous businessmen from Texas organized a research expedition in Mexico to recover Mayan artifacts from a sacrificial well. They had to use machetes to cut a path through the jungle, and they lugged diving equipment.

title: In Old Delhi, Ethnic Tension Haunts Market
description: Every evening, according to residents of the tiny lanes and narrow buildings that make up the historic and crowded walled city of Old Delhi, policemen in jeeps and on motorcycles drive along the main roads announcing the approaching curfew.

title: Recent Sales
description: Chester Township $325,000 513 North Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, fireplace, pool, 3.25 acres; taxes $5,371. Greenwood Lake $218,000 Laurel Avenue 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 27-year-old ranch; 2 kitchens, walk to beach; taxes $3,387. Linden $110,000 1603 Summit Terrace 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 45-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, 1-car garage, porch; taxes $1,168. Millburn $285,000 377 Wyoming Avenue 4 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; den, fireplace, open porch, 2-car garage; taxes $4,670. Randolph $251,000 11 Alexander Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 11-year-old contemporary; central A/C, brick patio, 2-zone heating, deck; taxes $3,288. Short Hills $525,000 58 Farbrook Drive 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 19-year-old expanded ranch; central A/C, basement, cathedral ceilings, fireplace; taxes $7,757. OTHER AREAS Rye, N.Y. $301,000 21 Bennett Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old frame ranch; eat-in kitchen, paneled playroom, beach rights; taxes $3,643. Litchfield, Conn. $219,000 Milton Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 27-year-old Cape Cod; sun room, 1-car garage, 0.75 acre; taxes $1,330. Wantagh, L.I. $165,000 32 Dome Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 36-year-old ranch; dining room, den; taxes $2,000.

title: Mattlingly Ties Home-Run Record
description: he announcement was made long before a record was considered a possibility. Don Mattingly had hit home runs in three consecutive games, merely another impressive statistic in a season that has grown from a struggle to a year that meets even his standards.

title: AT RUTGERS-NEWARK: AN EXHIBITION OF UNUSUAL SELF-PORTRAITS
description: LEAD: ''THE SELF PORTRAIT,'' now at the Robeson Center Gallery at Rutgers-Newark, drives home the realization that a video monitor can provide additional wall space, as it were.

title: North's Bicentennial Lesson
description: The testimony of Lieut.

title: DOUGLAS S. BAKER, BROKER, MARRIES ELLEN L. SCHREIBER
description: Ellen L. Schreiber, the director of business development for the Julien J. Studley real-estate brokerage and consulting firm, and Douglas S. Baker, a real-estate broker with the Williams Company, were married yesterday. Judge Barbara G. Zambelli of the Mount Vernon (N.Y.) City Court officiated at Estherwood in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: LISA ROBINSON IS ENGAGED TO MARRY JOHN J. HELMER
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul Vincent Robinson of St. Charles, Ill., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Bingham Robinson, to John Jeffrey Helmer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Horton James Helmer of Stamford, Conn.

title: photo of Ernest Hemingway and his father, Clarence Edmonds Hemingway, in 1928 (From ''Hemingway'') (page 25)
description: HEMINGWAY By Kenneth S. Lynn. Illustrated. 702 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.95.

title: ARMY IMPATIENCE IS HINTED IN SEOUL
description: As the drama of speeches and sit-ins and tear gas moves in the direction of democracy, an unspoken question is whether the military might decide to participate with a veto rather than a vote.

title: Mount Kisco Awaits Arrival of T.W.A.
description: WHEN Trans World Airlines moves its headquarters in October from Manhattan to the Village of Mount Kisco, which covers only 2.5 square miles and has a population of 8,500, the airline will be the largest business there.

title: 5 City Officials Are Indicted In Illinois Voting Rights Case
description: Five municipal officials, including the Mayor and all three City Council members, were indicted Friday on felony charges resulting from the settlement of a lawsuit over voting rights.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
THE HOLD BUTTON: MUSIC TO THE EAR IT IS NOT
description: LEAD: REMEMBER the good old days of the busy signal? Today, through the magic of technology, we have that marvelous invention, the hold button. This allows our previous impassable call to go through, but only to a holding stage.

title: Verbatim; Questioning the Press
description: ' What you said about the media needed to be said. They demand to ruthlessly question the ethics of anyone else. But when anyone else dares to question their ethics, they hide behind the shield of freedom of speech. They refuse to make the distinction that philosophers throughout the centuries have made between freedom and license. ' Richard M. Nixon in a letter to Gary Hart, written three days after the Democrat denounced the press as he quit the Presidential contest, and made public last week.

title: WHAT COMFORTS AIDS FAMILIES
description: Lou Ann Walker's article ''What Comforts AIDS Families'' (June 21), raised a major ethico-legal issue in the mental-health field. Moreover, by omission, it misinforms on a topic that is currently reshaping professional ethical conduct throughout the country.

title: PATRICIA GROARK WEDS BURKE P. MCCORMACK
description: Patricia L. Groark and Burke Patrick McCormack, vice presidents of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, were married yesterday at Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in Yonkers. Msgr. John J. Foley performed the ceremony.

title: Astaire's Achievements
description: To the Editor:

title: Animals of an Urban Zoo
description: AS a child, she remembered seeing cutout animals decorating the walls of the pediatrician's office.

title: Economic Everest Awaits The Next President
description: With the campaign for the White House under way, it is worthwhile to consider how the next President might promote American economic interests in a world dramatically altered by powerful market forces and shifts in the economic strengths of nations.

title: TREATING OBSESSIVE DISORDER
description: SUFFERERS of the neuropsychiatric ailment obsessive-compulsive disorder are turning to a two-year-old clinic at the Connecticut Mental Health Center in New Haven.

title: Danger in the Gulf: How U.S. Navy Girds for Escort Duties With Tankers
description: When the first Kuwaiti tankers to fly the American flag pass through the Strait of Hormuz, probably in the next several days, they will be escorted by American warships assigned to see them safely past an avowedly hostile Iran.

title: A Team Approach To Treating Pain
description: LEAD: ''IN 1986, almost $20 billion was spent in the United States alone in an effort to relieve pain - largely the sort of pain for which no satisfactory reason can be given.'' Dr. Joel Haber, the executive director of the newly established Pain Clinic at the County Medical Center in Valhalla, went on to say that a high percentage of that money was wasted on pain-killers -''analgesics that provide limited, short-term relief - and on testing, which often reveals little if any of the cause.

title: Winning One For the Homeless
description: The lack of a private abode should not make a person ineligible for public benefits in New York City, the New York State Supreme Court ruled last week.

title: Strawberry's Other Side
description: WHEN Darryl Strawberry was a rookie four years ago, a veteran catcher on the Mets observed the 21-year-old's ability to crunch a baseball, to fly around the bases, and to fling a throw from the right-field corner with the power of no one, perhaps, since Clemente.

title: NANCY E. O'NEILL PLANNING TO WED
description: A September wedding is planned by Nancy Elizabeth O'Neill and Douglas Barrack Kelly. Mr. and Mrs. Bernard James O'Neill of Redding, Conn., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Ray Kelly of Hudson, Ohio.

title: Miss Bryant Has Wedding
description: Heather Corbally Bryant, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Wallace Bryant of Lexington, Mass., and John Matthew Jordan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt Matthew Jordan of Fort Wayne, Ind., were married yesterday at the Harvard Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frank Moore Cross Jr., a Presbyterian minister and a professor of Hebrew and Oriental languages at Harvard.

title: A CLASSICAL BONANZA AND GERSHWIN
description: IF you're especially fond of Mozart, Beethoven and other classical composers of that era, this is your week. The bonanza starts today at 4 P.M. when the Quartetto di Venezia plays Boccherini's charming 1804 String Quartet at Music Mountain, filling out the program with two Italian rarities of the 1920's, Malipiero's ''Rispetti e Strambotti'' and the ''Doric'' Quartet of Ottorino Respighi. Music Mountain's resident Manhattan String Quartet then returns next Sunday at 4 P.M. to present Schubert and Bartok, plus Mozart's Piano Quartet in E flat, with Abba Bogin the guest artist. For reservations, call 496-1222.

title: Palmer Hits Jackpot
description: A one-day holdout may have cost him three free meals at the Kansas City training table, but Paul Palmer, the record-breaking ground-gainer from Temple, wasn't exactly wasting away. During the holdout, Palmer signed a $1.35 million four-year contract that includes a $450,000 signing bonus and a $175,000 starting salary.

title:
DINING OUT;
WHERE SMALLNESS PAYS DIVIDENDS
description: LEAD: IN THOSE rash and, perhaps fortunately, fleeting moments when we food writers think of opening a restaurant of our own, this is the kind of place we often envision:

title: WHEN IMPULSIVENESS LEADS TO VICTORY
description: IT is understandable that a player who has a rare opportunity to take part in a world championship should have a feeling of euphoria when he sits down and that may lead to impulsiveness or disaster. It can also lead to triumph as it did on the diagramed deal from the Epson Worldwide Bridge Contest in May. The contest was sponsored by the Japanese computer corporation and organized in France under the auspices of the World Bridge Federation.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
HEALTH
description: LEAD: Larry Hagman's Stop Smoking for Life Directed by Eugen Tanasescu. Lorimar Home Video. 60 minutes. $14.95.

title: TIMOTHY JAMES CASEY WEDS CECILY J. PASCHAL
description: Cecily Jay Paschal, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Paschal of Purchase, N.Y., was married at the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church yesterday to Timothy James Casey, a son of Mrs. Robert Dillon Casey of Highland Park, Ill., and the late Mr. Casey. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Donald W. Poole, assisted by the Rev. Robert E. Lee, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: 'Ironweed' Is Nourished By Kindred Souls
description: ''IRONWEED,'' THE PU-litzer Prize-winning novel by William Kennedy, seems to belong to Albany as much as the ghost of Mayor Corning. But, in a quirk of the movie business, the book took its first step toward the screen on a beach in Brazil, where Hector Babenco, the director of ''Kiss of the Spider Woman,'' read it and was moved by it.

title: FESTIVAL CELEBRATES MISUNDERSTOOD POLKA
description: TO many people, the polka is a fast-paced, frenetic dance, indigenous to Poles and those of Polish descent, who alternately whirl and jump around to rousing tunes that to the uninitiated sound remarkably alike.

title: SOVIET CALLS THE TUNE IN A DUET SET IN GERMANY
description: IN dealing with West Germany, the Soviet Union has traditionally reached for the carrot and the stick, seeking to lure the pivotal country of the NATO alliance eastward and then beating up on it when it failed to respond with sufficient docility. Yet these conflicting impulses have bedeviled Moscow's efforts to come up with a coherent German policy.

title: WHO'S NOT IN THE HALL OF FAME WHO SHOULD BE
description: Richie Ashburn belongs in the Hall of Fame. He led the National League in batting in 1955 and in 1958. He was an outstanding clutch hitter. He was fast on the bases. He covered the outfield in superb fashion. ALFRED NUSSBAUM Brooklyn

title: 'Alive From Off Center' Continues to Seek Out Innovative Video
description: ELIZABETH STREB SOARS through the air in perpetual flight, her gravity-defying dance created as much by video artistry as by choreographic skill.

title: How County Fared in Albany
description: LEAD: IT has been more than a week since the State Legislature adjourned, but Assemblyman Gordon W. Burrows of Yonkers said he was still ''holding his breath.''

title: GUIDEBOOK TO ARMAGEDDON
description: A WORLD BEYOND HEALING The Prologue and Aftermath of Nuclear War. By Nicholas Wade. 190 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $15.95.

title: THE ULTIMATE RESILIENCE OF THE DEFENSE
description: IT is quite extraordinary that two of the greatest geniuses of the mating attack, the former world champion, Bobby Fischer of the United States, and the present world champion, Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union, have chosen to be spokesmen for the defense in the case of the Poisoned Pawn Variation of the Najdorf Sicilian.

title: Jennifer Wentzel And C. F. Gulden Exchange Vows
description: The marriage of Jennifer Lee Wentzel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan R. Wentzel of Bronxville, N.Y., to Charles Frederick Gulden, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Gulden Jr. of Rye, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Reformed Church of Bronxville. The Rev. Dr. Robert Bedingfield performed the ceremony.

title: Cambodia's Few Concessions to a Harsh Life
description: ''Our farmers' rice is sold to the free market,'' said Kong Som Ol, Cambodia's Minister of Agriculture.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'BEST OF CONNECTICUT' ART A substantial exhibition of contemporary art opens with a reception from 1 to 5 P.M. today at the Connecticut Gallery in Marlborough, remaining through Aug. 23. ''The Best of Connecticut,'' an all-media show, is dedicated to Reuben Nakian, the Stamford sculptor who died last year.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: GRACE: The Secret Lives of a Princess. By James Spada. (Dolphin/Doubleday, $17.95.) Just five years after Grace Kelly's sudden death, James Spada's principal revelation in ''Grace: The Secret Lives of a Princess'' is that despite her demure exterior, she was no stranger to passion. Denied the emotional support of her father, who emerges as a bigoted domestic tyrant, she invariably became involved with older married co-stars, including William Holden, Gary Cooper and Ray Milland.

title: Minnesota Hormel Plant Gains Union Control
description: Workers at the flagship plant of Geo. A. Hormel & Company have regained control of their union local 14 months after the union's international unit placed the local in trusteeship and removed its officers for refusing to end a strike.

title: Quality Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: JULY 19, 1987
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) A rich orphan comes of age as she travels the world. 2 3 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $3.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia. 3 1 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The West tries to stave off the Russians in World War III. 4 4 THE EIGHTH COMMANDMENT, by Lawrence Sanders. (Berkley, $4.95.) The theft of a priceless Greek coin brings a New York dynasty's scandals to light. 5 2 A MATTER OF HONOR, by Jeffrey Archer. (Pocket, $4.95.) Nazi intrigue and a family secret that could change the course of the cold war. 6 7 ACT OF WILL, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Bantam, $4.95.) Three generations of talented, ambitious women in England and New York. 7 4 MURDER IN GEORGETOWN, by Margaret Truman. (Fawcett, $4.50.) The mystery surrounding the death of a senator's daughter. 8 2 STRANGERS FROM THE SKY, by Margaret Wander Bonanno. (Pocket, $3.95.) James Kirk re- encounters the Vulcans in a ''Star Trek'' novel. 9 13 THE WITCHES OF EASTWICK, by John Updike. (Fawcett, $4.50.) Three women and a devilish stranger concoct a curse that haunts a small New England town. 10 11 A PERFECT SPY, by John le Carre. (Bantam, $4.95.) The tale of a British secret agent and his father, a flamboyant con man. 11 2 NOBODY LIVES FOREVER, by John Gardner. (Charter, $3.95.) James Bond on the trail of the kidnapper of his devoted housekeeper. 12 * 2 STALLION GATE, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Ballantine, $4.95.)
