Anecdotes and ruminations by the television star and father of five. 3 195 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 4 21 N

title: Britain to Review Citizenship in War-Crimes Case
description: The Home Office plans to review the citizenship status of a man reported to be a Nazi war criminal who lives in Scotland, according to a Government spokesman and representatives of a Los Angeles-based organization that investigates war crimes.

title: NO MATCH FOR LENIN
description: ALEXANDER KERENSKY The First Love of the Revolution. By Richard Abraham. Illustrated. 503 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $29.95.

title: 38 Youths From U.S. Cultivating Cultural Roots in Thailand
description: Guy Suesuntisook has Pop-Art Bermuda shorts and an American passport.

title: Agents To Face Stringent Regulation
description: In an effort to insure proper representation of players by agents, the Major League Baseball Players Association will issue regulations this week that, among other things, will prevent agents from tying clients to long-term agreements. Agents will also be required to provide full disclosure of the financial dealings between them and their clients, as well as submit to audits, if requested.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: LIGHT YEARS: An Investigation Into the Extraterrestrial Experiences of Eduard Meier. By Gary Kinder. (Morgan Entrekin/Atlantic Monthly, $18.95.) This earnest but silly and sloppy book is entirely devoted to Eduard Meier, a one-armed, uneducated, down-and-out caretaker who lives in a small Swiss village outside Zurich and who was a celebrity in U.F.O.

title: 'New Look' Kabuki
description: THE WELL-KNOWN CONFLICTS in contemporary Japan between traditional values and modern ways are being expressed in all walks of life, even in the world of the classical theater, a stronghold of artistic conservatism. A frequent discussion in Japanese theatrical circles is whether traditional drama can be meaningful to modern audiences. For young people, classical theater (Kabuki, Noh and Kyogen) has lost its appeal, and what was once looked upon with reverence is now viewed as archaic, irrelevant to the present time. Many classicists, however, strive to preserve the purity of Japanese culture by clinging to centuries-old conventions.

title: Midwest Village, Slow-Paced, Fights Plan for Fast-Food Outlet
description: People in this unsullied resort village on Lake Michigan are doing all they can to keep a quaint old cafe that serves homemade muffins and zucchini soup from becoming a fast-food place that sells Big Macs and Chicken McNuggets.

title: Venice
description: To the Editor: In Q & A (Travel, May 31), a reader asks if Tintoretto's painting ''Paradise'' has been reinstalled in the Doges Palace in Venice. Stanley Carr correctly answered that it was reinstalled in the palace in 1985 after two and a half years of restoration work.

title: Rehoboth, Del.
description: To the Editor: Travelers who take the advice of Robert McG. Thomas Jr. to vacation at Rehoboth Beach (Travel, May 31) ought to visit the Island Field Museum on the edge of the Delaware River near Milford, Del., on their way to Rehoboth. The site houses an exhibition of an excavation of a cemetery of Delaware's pre-Indians, Indian being a term coined by Columbus and therefore not suitable for earlier peoples, as a curator of the museum informed me. There used to be skeletons on display, but as of July 1, no skeletons at all; they've been put out of sight because of a protest by Delaware's Nanticoke Indians who feel the bones, which may be those of their ancestors, should not be on public display. Still, the exhibits are great, and the site, along the marshes of the Delaware River near its mouth, is picturesque.

title: A PIVOTAL WEEK
description: As Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North left the witness table, the Iran-contra committees tried to take back control of their proceedings, lecturing the new national celebrity about patriotism, freedom and democracy. When the week ended some members were questioning the veracity of Colonel North's superior at the National Security Council, Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter. Highlights of the week's developments follow.

title: Herring
description: To the Editor: In response to the letter of Benjamin P. Van Inwegen (Travel, June 7), here is the name of at least one substitute for Marshall's Scottish brand herring - Brunswick (Connors) Kippered Snacks (Herring Fillets) - bought at D'Agostino's in New York at 79 cents for the 3.25-ounce tin. They are packed at Connors Bros. Ltd., at Black's Harbour, New Brunswick, Canada EOG 1H0. Perhaps your nostalgic reader can persuade a local merchant to stock them.

title: DANA E. MORTON PLANS TO WED ROBERT EMERY
description: Dana Elizabeth Morton and Robert Langworthy Emery plan to be married Aug. 22. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee E. Morton of Shrewsbury, N.J., who have announced her engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Emery of Rumson, N.J.

title: PETTY TYRANNIES ARE THE WORST
description: VACLAV HAVEL Or Living in Truth. Edited by Jan Vladislav. 315 pp. Boston: Faber & Faber. $22.50.

title: North Testimony Now a Book
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's testimony last week before Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair was sometimes explosive. But a book of that testimony arrived at area bookstores yesterday with little more than a thump.

title: Street Fashion; Madonna Still Calls The Sartorial Tune For Fans
description: SO what's up these days with the Madonna set? When seen during the singer's tour two years ago, her fans, mostly a bit under teen-age, displayed a penchant for lace skirts, fingerless gloves, out-from-underwear and piled-on bracelets and necklaces. Pretty funky, and not surprising, because that's what Madonna was wearing.

title: Don't Complicate Arrests With Paper
description: Law enforcement officials seem ready to respond in a needlessly limp way to a Federal court decision requiring that an arrested person in New York City be brought before a judge within 24 hours. If that's not possible, the decision requires at least a sworn statement from the police and prosecutor. That's just how officials expect to comply. If they do, the decision will, perversely, prompt new paperwork and more delay.

title: Wilander and Carlsson in Clay Final
description: Top-seeded Mats Wilander defeated his fellow Swede and doubles partner, Joakim Nystrom, by 6-4, 7-5 today in a semifinal match of the United States Clay Court Championships.

title: Turning Prisoners Into Helpers
description: UP to 15,000 people a day phone the State Department of Motor Vehicles offices in New York City for information. But two years ago, callers were more apt to get a busy signal than information.

title: ST. GEORGE
description: CHARLES STERLING thinks his apartment in Staten Island's St. George section may have the best view around. New York Harbor is nearby. There are the freighters, tugs and the yellow and blue ferryboats he knows so well. To his right is Brooklyn, to his left the Statue of Liberty and straight ahead are the skyscrapers of that other island.

title: AIDS Roundtable: 12 Show Concern Over Tests, Morality and Politics
description: The 12 people who gathered around a table to talk about AIDS and its effect on the 1988 elections were clear about several things: they were scared, they wanted the Government to do more and they expected that politicians would duck the issue.

title: SURPRISE CHALLENGE SOUGHT IN CUP RACE
description: A return to an America's Cup series the way it once was, with massive sailboats such as the 125-foot J Class boats competing for yachting's oldest trophy, forms the nucleus of a challenge filed by a New Zealand yachtsman. If approved, the proposal would shut out syndicates from other challenging nations.

title: MAKING THE GRADE
description: FROM WOLFGANG Puck to Alice Waters, America's leading chefs have become superstars. But today's food lovers are never satisfied with the tried and true: they are always on the prowl for the next star, the latest trend. This year, the hunt became an organized competition when Manhattan's Citymeals-on-Wheels program held a sophisticated version of the Pillsbury Bake-Off. More than 100 chefs from all over the country responded, and eventually professional judges conducted a blind tasting to choose 16 who cooked for the James Beard dinner in New York several weeks ago.

title: Death Toll at 8 In the Flooding Of Texas Bridge
description: Searchers found six more bodies today in the Guadalupe River, and the authorities disclosed that the church camp bus and van filled with teen-agers leaving a church camp Friday were washed away as they tried to skirt the churning waters.

title: Horse Maneuvers
description: It's been almost two years since a limousine and a horse-drawn carriage collided on West 49th Street, injuring four tourists and causing the horse's destruction. That episode spurred a movement to extricate carriages from city traffic once and for all. Yet to date, nothing has been done.

title: TRANSIT BRIEFS
description: LEAD: THREE programs providing transportation services for the elderly, the disabled and people living in the state's rural areas will be financed for another year by NJ Transit.

title: Forcing Buildings to Respect the Hills
description: IN his autobiography, Frank Lloyd Wright took a gentle swipe at one of the most enduring symbols of a free and boldly individual America: the house on a hill.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE DREAM SLEEPERS.

title: Taiwan Ends Martial Law
description: President Chiang Ching-kuo of Taiwan last week lifted the martial law that was imposed 38 years ago by his father, Chiang Kai-shek.

title: Sports Cliches
description: To the Editor:

title: TIPS FOR KEEPING THE CROPS COMING
description: REPLANTING will be important to keep vegetable patches productive. Beans have finished; reseed rows. Chard seed goes where spinach and early lettuce have grown. Beets and carrots replace radishes. Broccoli, Chinese cabbage and head lettuce seedlings that were started indoors can be transplanted to individual pots; they will be set outdoors later this month. Use the hose or watering can for tomatoes; soak plants and mulch to keep soil cool and prevent blossom-end rot. Use water-soluble fertilizer on window boxes, tubs, planters. Keep annuals groomed by removing faded flowers promptly. Buddleia

title: Emergency Aid for City Ambulances
description: New York City's Emergency Medical Services, a department that dispatches city-owned ambulances to more than 39,000 seriously ill or injured people each month, is showing weakened vital signs.

title: ERIK SCHWARZ IS WED TO ELIZABETH TANNER
description: Elizabeth Tanner, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Stetson Tanner of Plattsburgh, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Erik L. Schwarz, a son of William H. Schwarz of New York, and Tita Bergendahl of Minneapolis. The Rev. Dr. Earl Johnson Jr. performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: How to Cash A. Phonybill
description: Two young women bought hundreds of dollars' worth of clothes and got $581 in change after employees of two stores in this central Ohio city had failed to notice that a $1,000 bill bore the phrase ''A. Phonybill.''

title: Sending Graphics Over the Wires
description: MANY people use their personal computers regularly to send documents over the telephone lines. I file my weekly columns by moden, for example. Nevertheless, personal computer communications remains a relatively slow-growing stepchild of the electronic revolution.

title: Homeless Criticize Voucher Delays
description: ''SOCIAL SERVICES pays $707 a week for me to stay at the Coachman Hotel,'' said Diana Immediato. ''That's almost $3,000 a month.'' ''I could rent a whole house for less than what they're paying for me to stay in one room,'' she went on. ''It's rough. We have two double beds for me and my three kids.''

title: BEHIND THE PLIGHT OF PART-TIME TEACHERS
description: The plight of the part-time instructor in the state community college system [ ''The Sorry Success of a Part-Time Teacher,'' Opinion page, June 21 ] is the result of three factors:

title: THE BLOODIEST BATTLE
description: William Manchester errs when he says Brig. Gen. Anthony C. McAuliffe did not say ''Nuts'' in response to the German demand for surrender at Bastogne.

title: Unclassic Sweaters From Scotland
description: In the Scottish workshop where Joy Baszucki designs her handmade sweaters, there isn't a tweedy-looking crew neck or a cable-stitched cardigan in sight. If you have a strand of pearls just waiting to grace the neckline of a pastel pullover, cross her name off your list. But if you like sophisticated lines, brilliant colors that you would never think of putting together but that somehow look exactly right. If, above all, you would wear a sweater so noteworthy that friends - even strangers - might ask where you had found it, Kotki Dwa Knitwear, 67 Giles Street, Leith, Edinburgh, is a place to look into.

title: Blue Bird
description: To the Editor:

title: Vocal Technique
description: To the Editor:

title: Groovy Rolls to Impressive Victory in Tom Fool
description: Only a dull racing surface and a punishing package of 128 pounds kept Groovy from setting his third consecutive track record yesterday, as the nation's leading sprinter scored a 6 1/2-length victory in the $114,000 Tom Fool Stakes.

title: Labor Federation Backs Anti-Pretoria Rebels
description: South Africa's biggest anti-apartheid labor federation today formally adopted as a ''guiding document'' the political program of black guerrillas fighting to end white rule.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''They've thrown everything but the kitchen sink at the market this week. North, Poindexter, miserable balance of trade figures, a bond market that's gone no place. And yet we've gone into record highs.''

title: The Biggest Mystery In the Cosmos
description: ''LET ME BE CLEAR,'' SAID DR. Roger Lynds in a telephone interview from the Kitt Peak National Observatory in Tucson, Ariz. ''We don't know what they are.'' The astronomer was referring to the largest objects yet observed in the universe - two luminous blue arcs, hundreds of trillions of miles long, some three times the expanse of our own Milky Way.

title: Theater
description: Wide-eyed and hollow-cheeked, with the spooky, melodramatic delivery of an seasoned teller of ghost stories, David Cale is an enthralling writer-monologuist whose one-man show, ''The Redthroats,'' transmutes everyday experience into Gothically surreal prose poetry.

title: Gilberto Freyre of Brazil Dies
description: Gilberto Freyre, an internationally acclaimed sociologist and prolific author, died of a brain hemorrhage today, his doctor said. He was 87 years old.

title: LOVING CHILDREN ENOUGH TO SAY NO
description: EVERYONE from the First Lady to the classroom teacher has quickly adopted the ''Just say no'' to drugs theme. There is no finer example for our children than to see the strength and unity of the American people from every walk of life rallying together in a crisis situation.

title: Hanoi Said to Agree to Meet on Missing
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz confirmed today that Vietnam had relented and agreed to American conditions for a meeting with a special envoy to discuss the issue of missing servicemen.

title: WHO'S NOT IN THE HALL OF FAME WHO SHOULD BE
description: I should like to add my name to those urging the election of Dick Bartell to the Hall of Fame. Statistics, of course, are subject to many interpretations, but Bartell's should be carefully considered. They are in many instances better than those of half the shortstops in the Hall, both for hitting and for fielding effectiveness and range. Most particularly, his 442 doubles are more than those of any Hall of Fame shortstop except Wagner and Cronin, as well as more than those of such sluggers as Sisler, Cepeda, Slaughter and Stargell. I'd say it's time to include him in this distinguished company. ADOLPH SUCHSDORF Sonoma, Calif.

title: JANE HAUSNER IS WED TO THOM DAUGHERTY
description: At the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park yesterday Jane Whitman Hausner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel Hausner of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and Thom Daugherty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Daugherty of Whitehall, Md., were married by Justice E.Leo Milonas of the Appellate Division, First Department, of State Supreme Court.

title: Richard M. Rossbach, A Broker and Author
description: Richard M. Rossbach, a stockbroker and author, died of complications of lymphoma and leukemia on Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Corrigan Responds
description: GENE CORRIGAN, the Notre Dame athletic director, sharply denied a report that Notre Dame had concocted a story that injuries would cause Alvin Miller, a wide receiver, to miss the 1987 football season. The report said the story was to cover the fact that Miller signed a contract with a sports agent and thus forfeited his eligibility.

title: MOVIES, BOOKS AND THE REAL STORY
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Hoboken Offices; Bank Restoration
description: When it was built in 1890, the Northern Renaissance Revival structure at the corner of Washington and Newark Streets in Hoboken, N.J., was a grand office building with a bank on the ground floor and professional tenants above.

title: New Museum Of Indian Art In Southwest
description: Ask an anthropologist about the origin of American Indians, and the response is likely to be a dissertation on carbon dating and the Bering Strait. Ask a Navajo, and the answer will be that they came from the underworld.

title: Snow White Is No Feminist
description: SNOW WHITE IS A DRIP, AND I SAY THAT WITH fondness and respect for one of the best-loved children's films of all time. Of all the things we remember so fondly, from the starchy collar on Snow White's gown to the way the dwarfs' bulbous little noses poke over the foot of her bed, the heroine's personality is hardly this classic's greatest selling point. Snow White, after all, is first seen cheerfully scrubbing the stairs of her stepmother's castle, surrounded by a squad of tweeting white birdies. She then goes on to clean up the seven dwarfs' cottage, cook their dinner and badger them into washing their faces and hands. Aside from her great daintiness and her credentials as a fervent housekeeper, Snow White has no distinct personality. She exists only to be victimized by her wicked stepmother - a far more interesting character - and to wait for Mr. Right.

title: A HILLBILLY WHO WOVE A ROCK-AND-ROLL SPELL
description: ON A COLD SATURDAY night in late January 1956, a seismic shock flickered across American television screens as Elvis Presley gyrated into national consciousness for the first time. To a sheltered 14-year-old boy growing up in a New Jersey town not unlike Springfield, the sanitized suburban paradise of ''Father Knows Best,'' this loose-limbed hillbilly greaser, with his pudgy-lipped sneer, shiny hair, flapping legs and hiccupy grunt, had the impact of an extraterrestrial visitation.

title: P. D. Bennett Wed To Miss Putnam
description: Katharine Lawrence Putnam, a daughter of Mrs. Roger D. Masters of South Woodstock, Vt., and Augustus Lowell Putnam of New York, was married yesterday to Peter Dudley Bennett, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Bennett of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. William N. Peabody, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the South Woodstock Community Church.

title: HEATING UP AT THE COOLER
description: WHERE ALL THE LADDERS START By Ron Loewinsohn. 223 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $17.95.

title: THE SUN NEVER SETS ON THE ENGLISH NOVEL
description: ''HE would have preferred not to speak to his own kinsmen in English which was after all a foreign language.'' So writes the Nigerian novelist Chinua Achebe of the title character of his 1966 novel, ''A Man of the People.'' But he does speak in English, and not only because ''speeches made in the vernacular were liable to be distorted . . . in the press,'' but also because some members of his audience ''did not speak our own tongue and he did not wish to exclude them. They were all citizens of our great country.'' For in Nigeria, a country the British created out of what Mr. Achebe describes as ''hundreds of autonomous communities'' - and almost that many indigenous languages - English has by default become the ''national language.'' It stands as the only way in which Nigeria's ''many peoples [ can ] talk to one another . . . the one central language enjoying nationwide currency.'' And out of that currency, the English language itself began in the 1950's to be enriched by Mr. Achebe's own novels, the plays of the 1986 Nobel laureate Wole Soyinka, the compelling fictions fashioned out of Yoruba legend by Amos Tutuola.

title: France's Socialist Presidents
description: To the Editor:

title: The Winds of Asia
description: It is hot, muggy and rainy here and any day the streets may be filled again with riot and tear gas. But it is a wonderful time to visit Seoul. The city has the tang of liberty, clear and heady.

title: Dance: Holly Fairbank, in the Park
description: CENTRAL PARK was the star of the show Friday evening when Holly Fairbank presented ''Pooldance'' beside the pool in the park, between West 100th and 103d Streets. The work, which lasted slightly more than 20 minutes, was performed by Holly Fairbank and Dancers and members of Veritas, a drug-free therapeutic community, to music by Julie Lieberman played on amplified violin and guitar by Ms. Lieberman and Michael Mallen.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SLICK. By Whitey Ford with Phil Pepe. (Morrow, $16.95.) In baseball, cheaters can prosper. Some of the game's greatest pitchers have used a dollop of spit or a nick in the ball's cover to produce erratic flight patterns that give them an edge over batters. In ''Slick,'' Whitey Ford's autobiography, the Yankees' premier pitcher during the final period of their dynasty in the 1950's and 60's describes how, after experimenting unsuccessfully with the spitter, he perfected the mud ball.

title: Music: Bach Mass In B Minor
description: THE Bach B-minor Mass appeared at Avery Fisher Hall Friday night like a sudden interruption to Mostly Mozart's usual pleasant, smoothly flowing course. Bach's soberness may have seemed a little removed from the graceful and ingratiating repertory around which most of this summer festival is planned, but the concert hall is still an appropriate place for this great construction. In practical terms, Bach's idealized version of the Latin mass fits neither the Roman nor the Protestant liturgies but exists instead as a summation of all the sacred polyphony before it. Needless to say, it has been an admonishment for what followed.

title: The Joys of Ad Land
description: WOULDN'T IT BE great to get out of America and go live in Ad Land? I thought about it again the night of the awful storms. Awful, awful storms. They flattened the corn and brought so much water down the creek that the fences washed away.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: New London, N.H.;
Housing Active Empty-Nesters
description: LEAD: FOR years, Ann and Charles Stites made pleasure trips to New Hampshire. So it wasn't too surprising when they decided to move a year ago to the state from Flemington, N.J. They chose New London, a prosperous community of 3,000 with a growing reputation as a home for active empty-nesters.

title: DICRON ARAM BERBERIAN
description: Dicron Aram Berberian, an abstract expressionist painter and a leader in international aid for Armenians, ia, died of cancer Monday cancer at St. Peter's Hospice in Albany. He was 46 years old and lived in Easton, Md.

title: Without the Playground, Mothers Meet at the Office
description: ''HOW to Nurture and Maintain a Family Culture When You Work All Day, Your Mother Lives in Omaha and Your Housekeeper Comes from Ethiopia'' was the topic and it drew an eager audience. The Working Mothers Forum of the Washington Women's Bar Association was in session.

title: Where Odysseus Played
description: LEAD: ''Play golf'' - a brochure on Corfu states - ''where Odysseus played.'' There is a course on the Greek island among the swamps of the central plain where the frogs sing ''Brek-kek-kek-kek-coax-coax,'' just as they did in the chorus of Aristophanes' play. But if Odysseus ever reached Corfu on his long way home to Ithaca, he would have played beach ball with Nausicaa and her maidens.

title: THE VERDICT ON CREATIONISM
description: LEAD: H. L. MENCKEN, who attended the Scopes ''Monkey Trial'' in 1925, wrote of William Jennings Bryan, counsel for the supporters of Tennessee's anti-evolution law: ''Once he had one leg in the White House and the nation trembled under his roars. Now he is a tinpot pope in the Coca-Cola belt and a brother to the forlorn pastors who belabor half-wits in galvanized iron tabernacles behind the railroad yards.

title: Private Matters, Public Talk
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Music: Ravinia Players With Mostly Mozart
description: WITH their performance of Schubert's ''Trout'' Quintet, the Ravinia Institute Players shifted the tone of Thursday evening's concert from serious to sassy. Until then the proceedings, part of the Mostly Mozart Festival in Avery Fisher Hall, had been, with one exception, distinguished by performances of intensity and restraint.

title: CHILDREN LEARN TO TRY HARDER AT FRESH AIR FUND CAMP
description: Gate 6 of the bus terminal at the George Washington Bridge was packed with 130 children waiting expectantly for the 8:30 A.M. bus to Fishkill, N.Y.

title:
WINE;
FEWER BARGAINS FOR ITALIAN BRANDS
description: LEAD: A SURVEY of area shops and restaurants offering Italian wine reveals that sales of most brands remain brisk, in spite of two major scandals last year involving tainted products. However, based on a series of recent samplings of locally available bottles, bargains are more difficult to find compared with a year ago.

title: A Metamorphosis for Old Williamsburg
description: PROPPED on pillows in his apartment in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, Tim Pratt, a soft-spoken poet and freelance writer, explained his recent migration from the East Village.

title: MAKING IT ON THEIR OWN
description: LEAD: ORPHANS Real and Imaginary. By Eileen Simpson. 259 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $16.95.

title: Sinclair Lewis's Secretary
description: To the Editor:

title: IN MUSICAL 'CHICAGO,' CRIME PAYS
description: THE Bob Fosse, Fred Ebb and John Kander musical ''Chicago,'' which had its premiere on Broadway in 1975, still manages to bring life to daily newspaper stories of political corruption and covert activities. ''Chicago,'' currently receiving a strong production at Theater Three in Port Jefferson, is a bitter show about murder, greed, corruption and treachery in Chicago circa 1920.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IF there's one thing Janet Hersh hates it's friends who ask ''What's new?'' True, it sounds innocuous, but Ms. Hersh and a number of other single women know the code. ''What's new?'' really means ''Who are you dating?'' or, for that matter, ''Are you dating?''

title: Spouses Who Ask Too Much
description: WHAT Kate Buckley, a 38-year-old New York City executive, remembers most about her 10-year marriage is the social obligations and household chores her husband expected her to handle.

title: MERIDIAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that year-ago results have been adjusted to include those of First National Bank of Pike County which it acquired in the 1986 fourth quarter.

title: New N.A.S.D. Chairman
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers said Friday that James M. Davin had been elected chairman, succeeding Joseph R. Hardiman, who will become president of the association on Sept. 1. Mr. Davin, managing director of the international equity department at the First Boston Corporation, has been vice chairman of finance for the association. Mr. Hardiman was elected president in June.

title: Bridge; Two Major Team Titles Won In Play at Summer Nationals
description: Two major team titles were decided here Saturday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, and there were three groups of winners.

title: Advertising; Saatchi Sells Stake, Buys Consulting Firm
description: It was announced in London last week that Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., the British-based holding company with a lot of holdings, had sold its 7 percent interest in the WPP Group P.L.C., which is acquiring the JWT Group, the parent of J. Walter Thompson.

title: Newsweek Says North Was a Source of Leaks
description: Newsweek magazine says in its current issue that Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North leaked details to the magazine about the interception of the terrorists involved in the Achille Lauro operation, although the colonel complained at the Iran-contra hearings that revelations by Congressmen about the mission had compromised sensitive intelligence.

title: UNITED CAROLINA BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Prior year figures are restated.

title: Tigers Winning With Surprising Twist
description: AS the Detroit Tigers prepared to resume the season following the All-Star Game break, Sparky Anderson knew what had to happen if his team were to challenge the Yankees and the Toronto Blue Jays for the American League East championship.

title: Dianne and David Zolotow Remarry in Massachusetts
description: Dianne Walsh Zolotow and David Mitchell Zolotow were remarried yesterday at City Hall in Newton, Mass., by Edward English, the City Clerk. The couple, who were divorced in 1983, were attended by their daughter Clea and their son Jason.

title: Reagan and His Ranch
description: President Reagan is planning his annual summer visit to his California ranch, in the Santa Ynez mountains overlooking the Pacific Ocean. Last summer the President spent three weeks there. This time he will extend that a bit, leaving Washington Aug. 13 and returning 24 days later, on Sept. 6. Mr. Reagan last visited his ranch at Easter, and White House officials say that in itself more than justifies the ''extended'' break this summer.

title: URBAN LEAGUE CHIEF TELLS '88 HOPEFULS NOT TO IGNORE BLACKS
description: The president of the National Urban League warned 1988 Presidential candidates tonight that they could not afford to ''neglect or ignore'' black voters.

title: The Prado to Lend Velazquez Works To the Met in '90
description: As part of a continuing and accelerating collaboration between the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Prado in Madrid, a remarkably large and important group of paintings by Diego Velazquez is to be lent by the Prado to the Met.

title: GRAINGER, W W INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $11,314,000 on the sale of motor manufacturing operation.

title: Pop: Roberta Flack
description: ROBERTA FLACK, unlike so many pop-soul singers, has never tailored her music to cater to the trends of the moment. The singer-pianist, who appeared Saturday at the Beacon Theater, had her first major hit in the early 70's with a Scottish folk song, ''The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face,'' arranged as a semiclassical dirge. Later, with the late Donny Hathaway, she helped to invent a style of pop-soul love duet - one more refined than traditional gospel-based call and response - that others have since formularized.

title: Twins Defeat Jays Behind Schatzeder
description: Dan Schatzeder pitched three and two-thirds innings of shutout relief and Tom Brunansky hit a homer and singled to drive in three runs today to lead the Minnesota Twins to a 7-6 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: WHAT'S IN A STREET RENAME? DISORDER
description: Herbert L. Sedler, president of Paper Enterprises Inc. at 271 Walnut Avenue, looked out his window one day and found that Walnut was no longer Walnut. Not only that, it wasn't even an avenue.

title: Driesell Enjoying Coaching Revival
description: With the nation's best college players preparing for the Pan American Games or having participated in the World University Games, the basketball talent at the United States Olympic Festival is largely undeveloped.

title: Frenchman Climbs Into Lead
description: The Tour de France entered its final week today by shaking out the leadership during a time trial up Mont Ventoux in Provence.

title: FRISCH'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Comsat Reorganization
description: The Communications Satellite Corporation said Friday that it would dispose of its manufacturing operations and its two direct-broadcast satellites and that it would restructure the remaining operations. The reorganization will result in a charge of $90 million against second-quarter earnings, the company said. In addition, Comsat has set aside $8 million after taxes for anticipated losses until it has disposed of the dicontinued operations. The divisions to be sold include Amplica Inc., a manufacturer of microwave components for military contractors, and two product lines. The sale of these businesses accounts for nearly half of the write-offs. Comsat also said it would write off $3 million of previously deferred costs associated with the termination of the Contel deal.

title: DOMINION RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lady Rama Rau Dies at 94; Led Family Planning in India
description: Lady Rama Rau, a pioneer of family planning in India and a leader of the world family planning movement, died of kidney failure Sunday in a hospital in Bombay, India, her daughter said. She was 94 years old.

title: MUSIC: TCHAIKOVSKY NIGHT
description: Tchaikovsky's gifts to music are great, though we have been less kind to him in return. The beautifully played evening of his music Saturday night at the Caramoor Festival witnessed both our gratitude for his generosity and, perhaps, our abuse of it, as well.

title: NBD BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an after-tax reduction of $32.4 million, or 69 cents per share, due to the company's increase of $54 million in its provision for possible credit losses.

title: Words . . . Stop . . . Lots of Words
description: His bosses don't object that Joseph W. Seaman works near a television set tuned in to the Iran-contra hearings. Somebody might say something that could prompt Americans to send telegrams of support or criticism, and Mr. Seaman's officemates would be up to their ears in work again.

title: KAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Connecticut Wedding For Sandra Greenstein
description: At Congregation Mishkan Israel in Hamden, Conn., Sandra Hope Greenstein, a daughter of Mrs. Herbert Hershenson of Woodbridge, Conn., and George Greenstein of Hamden, was married yesterday to Dr. David Goodkind, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Goodkind of Roslyn, L.I.

title: NOW BRACING TO STOP BORK
description: The buttons worn by dozens of representatives to the National Organization for Women convention said simply, ''Shred Bork.''

title: NEW ENGLAND SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank converted to stock ownership last August.

title: HARTFORD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After adding an additional $8 million to its reserves for loans to developing countries, and an additional $2 million as a resreve against an investment in Allied International Corp., in which the company has a one-twelfth interest.

title: CARPENTER UNION OFFICIAL IS LINKED TO EXTORTION PLOT
description: Allegations that a high-level carpenters' union official extorted more than $200,000 from contractors have been presented to a New York State grand jury that is hearing evidence about widespread corruption in Manhattan's construction industry, according to law-enforcement investigators.

title: MILLER, HERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
The Right - and Wrong - National Security Advisers
description: LEAD: In one of the most forthright statements made during the Iran-contra hearings, Representative Dante Fascell, the very sensible chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, suggested that no military officer should ever again hold the positions occupied in the Reagan Administration by Col. Robert C.

title: SPELMAN'S COLLEGE'S FIRST 'SISTER PRESIDENT'
description: Arrayed above the fireplace in the formal dining room of the president's residence at Spelman College in Atlanta are the pictures of four white women and two black men, the first six presidents of the institution during its 106 years of existence. ''And then there's the blank space for me -there where the nail in the wall is,'' said Dr. Johnnetta B. Cole. ''You don't have to work all that hard at it to see this as some sort of a metaphor for our history - for how long a journey it has been for black women.''

title: Tribute to Lopez, Finally
description: Nancy Lopez qualified for the Ladies Professional Golf Association Hall of Fame on Feb. 8 when she won her 35th career tournament. But her induction was put on hold.

title: JEFFERIES GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that a writedown stemming from the default of a note on real estate it sold in 1983 contributed to the earnings decline in the latest quarter and 6 months. The company also cited trading losses, special incentive commissions paid to its sales force during the quarter and legal and administrative costs associated with a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of the company as additional factors.

title: ROBERT A. OLSON
description: Robert A. Olson, a soil scientists and teacher, died Saturday of injuries suffered in a car accident. He was 70 years old.

title: DIVERSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $1,000 loss from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $9,531.

title: HOUSING NEEDS WILL GET WORSE, STUDY PREDICTS
description: Unless major new initiatives are begun, New York City by the year 2000 is likely to need 372,000 housing units more than it will have, a report released yesterday concludes.

title: BAIRNCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INSIDE
description: France-Iran Tensions Rise

title: WISCONSIN POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Year to June 30
Triumph for Blacks' Bakery
description: When 2.15 million shares of Lebowa Bakeries Ltd. start trading here on Wednesday, it will mark the first time a black-controlled company has been listed on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange.

title: On New York Civil Service: The City Can't Afford Bigger Pensions
description: To the Editor:

title: FAMILY AND FRIENDS MOURN VICTIMS OF SWOLLEN TEXAS RIVER
description: A clergyman told 300 mourners squeezed into a small church today that ''God has opened his arms'' to teen-agers killed Friday by a flash flood that engulfed them while they were away at a church summer camp.

title: Advertising; D.M.B.&B. Is the Choice Of California Sea World
description: Sea World of California has selected D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles of Los Angeles to handle its $4 million account.

title: DIEBOLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Woman Killed as Train Hits Car in Connecticut
description: A 28-year-old woman was killed today when her car was hit broadside by a southbound Amtrak train and thrown about 190 feet, the police said.

title: A Pit Bull Attacks An Off-Duty Officer
description: An off-duty police officer was attacked by a pit bull early yesterday morning in the basement of a Bronx apartment building.

title: White House Humor
description: One school of thought in the White House is that humor can counteract the effect of daily disclosures in the Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair.

description: The company said it did not write off its $16.1 million interest in the FSLIC secondary reserve fund during the second quarter.

description: The company said results for the latest second quarter and 6-month include a pretax loss of $3.3 million, representing the net effect of a writedown of certain venture capital investments and a gain on the sale of several properties. The company also said results for the year-ago second quarter and 6-month include a net pretax gain of $4 million from the sale of a sawmill in Northern California and investment writedowns.

description: The company went public in December.

title: Faldo Wins Open
description: Nick Faldo of England, who turned 30 Saturday, today received the finest gift a golfer could imagine when Paul Azinger of the United States, who led by three shots at the turn, virtually handed over the 116th British Open title.

title: Jersey Woman, 82, Is Fatally Stabbed
description: An elderly New Jersey woman was found fatally stabbed in an upper Manhattan apartment.

description: The company said because of a temporary decrease in line printer shipments and the termination of the discontinued accounts receivable programs, which previously had been classified as revenue.

description: A sensational favorite and an implausible long shot won stakes races for sprinting fillies yesterday at Belmont Park.

Cultural Drag Racing
description: Race cars get old fast. Last summer Don Garlits's ''Swamp Rat XXX'' was brand-new from the Florida shops of Don Garlits, the drag-racing legend, and setting 270-mile-per-hour speed records on the nation's drag strips.

title: SOME IN CONGRESS EXPRESS SUPPORT ON PARDONS FOR EX-REAGAN AIDES
description: A prominent Republican Senator on the Iran-contra committees said today that he would support a Presidential pardon for both Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter before any possible criminal prosecution was announced.

title: Lincoln Vote Safe
description: To the Editor:

title: ZIEGLER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Defeat of Curry Changes the Picture
description: Forget Mike Tyson. If Mike McCallum's lightning-stroke victory over Donald Curry here Saturday for the World Boxing Association junior middleweight title was any indication, the real action in boxing over the next year is likely to be in the middle-range weight classes.

title: Business and the Law; More Potency For Poison Pills
description: Amid rumors that MCA Inc. might be ripe for a takeover, the directors of that entertainment conglomerate last Thursday adopted a new type of poison pill designed by the same lawyer who invented the original version four years ago.

title: COFFIN RESIGNS TO PRAISE AND CRITICISM
description: There were tears and tributes - and one or two hurrahs - yesterday as the Rev. William Sloane Coffin stepped up to the pulpit of the Riverside Church and announced his resignation as the senior minister. Dr. Coffin said he would work full time for nuclear disarmament.

title: SPY CASE: TRACING COLLAPSE
description: The charges evoked the specter of treason among the elite Marine Corps guard in Moscow: two marines escorting K.G.B. spies through recesses of the United States Embassy, silencing alarms as they went.

title: Wilander Beats Heat, Carlsson
description: Mats Wilander of Sweden, breaking service four times in a shaky first set, outlasted the heat and his countryman Kent Carlsson for the second straight week and won the United States Clay Court Championships today, 7-5, 6-3.

title: EASTERN GAS & FUEL ASSOCITES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income of $1.6 million from Eastern Gas' 15-percent interest, acquired in March 1987, in Peabody Holding Co., in exchange for Eastern's coal operations. Year-ago second quarter and 6-month results include income of $3.8 million and $7.6 million, respectively, from Eastern Gas' former coal operations; and $318,000 for the quarter and $2.9 million for the 6 months in equity earnings from its Algonquin Energy Inc., unit, sold in July 1986.

description: Revenue represent service provided.

FLOODS AND LANDSLIDES KILL 14 IN ITALY
description: Torrential rains unleashed floods and landslides across a swath of northern Italy this weekend, killing at least 14 people and isolating dozens of Alpine villages, civil defense authorities said today.

title: Red Square, Just Off Wall St.
description: ''When you live among wolves, you must howl like a wolf,'' Lenin wrote in 1921, justifying business partnerships with the ''imperialist bandits'' of the West as indispensable to Russia's economic resurrection from the ravages of revolution and war.

description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Ogilvy Gives Reasons For Action in Its Stock
description: The rumor mills of Madison Avenue and Wall Street were working overtime during the last couple of weeks about the sudden increase in volume in Ogilvy Group stock. Another takeover in the wind? Ogilvy management, among the more interested parties, said it resulted from its decision not to buy the JWT Group, its winning of a sizable piece of Ford business overseas and its strengthening of management, which has led a number of analysts to issue buy recommendations. That's all it takes.

title: DOLE AND HER HUSBAND GAIN FAVOR IN ALABAMA
description: Elizabeth Hanford Dole and her husband came to Huntsville over the weekend.

title: MAN ARRESTED IN KIDNAP OF PREGNANT WOMAN
description: A 19-year-old man was arrested yesterday and charged with kidnapping a pregnant woman and her baby son as they waited outside a Brooklyn drug store for the woman's husband to return with medicine for the child, the police said.

title: EUROPEANS ATTACK TRADE BILLS
description: Leading officials of the European Community attacked the House and Senate trade bills this weekend calling the measures protectionist and saying Europeans could retaliate.

title: NOW LEADER: BORN FEMINIST - MOLLY YARD
description: Molly Yard, who was elected Saturday to guide the National Organization for Women through politically critical times, described herself today as a born feminist and the spiritual descendant of Eleanor Roosevelt.

title: Bidding for the Stars
description: After years of dreams, delays and heavy investments of money and manpower, a high-stakes competition among aerospace companies to build the nation's first permanent outpost in space is coming down to the wire.

title: U.S. IS IN DECLINE, NICARAGUAN SAYS
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that the Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair showed ''the decomposition of the so-called democracy in the United States.''

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Jack Clark of the St. Louis Cardinals had 86 runs batted in before last week's All-Star Game. Is that the most a player has ever had before the midseason break?

title: HEALTH CARE PROPERTY INVESTMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Jerseyans Can Adopt Streams
description: To improve water quality, the state of New Jersey has instituted a program allowing residents to ''adopt'' lakes, streams, rivers - and even sections of the Atlantic Ocean.

title: PRESIDENT MAY SEEK MORE CONTRA AID
description: White House officials said today that, partly based on public response to the Iran-contra hearings, the Administration was convinced that President Reagan now had a stronger case to seek more aid for Nicaraguan insurgents.

description: The company said the latest 9-month includes $11,160,000, or 43 cents a share, related to an after-tax gain on the sale of properties.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Advanced Polymer Systems Inc., Redwood City, Calif., a maker of plastic pill capsules, has named John H. Williford president, chief executive officer and a director.

title: Food for Thought
description: ''Murderburgers'': That's what students called the chopped beef, half-frozen or charred, routinely served up in New York City school cafeterias. And the cafeterias' reputation for inedible food - students' names for fish and various stews are unfit to print - drove youngsters to patronize junk-food outlets near schools.

title: NEW GUARDIAN OF FIRE ISLAND'S SHORE
description: From Alaska to the Virgin Islands, Noel J. Pachta has proven a successful mediator between man and Mother Nature. As the new superintendent of the Fire Island National Seashore, however, he faces some of his toughest bargaining ever.

title: KNOGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
GANDHI OUSTS A LEADING CRITIC, A RIVAL, FROM THE RULING PARTY
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi tonight dismissed Vishwanath Pratap Singh, the former Finance Minister who has emerged as a potential rival, from the governing Congress Party, a move that is likely to have far-reaching repercussions on Indian politics.

title: New HBO Pressure On No. 2 Showtime
description: When Home Box Office announced last week that it had won the coveted rights to 85 films from Paramount Pictures, the big question was not whether the deal would hurt Showtime, HBO's archrival in pay-television movies, but how badly.

title: Arthur Young Audit Faulted
description: A California jury has found the accounting firm Arthur Young & Company ''professionally negligent'' in its audits of the Osborne Computer Corporation, which is now defunct.

title: Stage: Ayckbourn's 'Bedroom Farce'
description: ONE of the pleasures of an Alan Ayckbourn play is watching a peculiar situation grow inexorably and often hilariously out of control. In ''Bedroom Farce,'' for example, now enlivening the Interart Theater, a young, unclothed hostess finds herself trapped under a mound of her guests' overcoats. A man, immobilized with a bad back, has to reach a book that has fallen to the floor. Another is consigned to a bathroom with a copy of ''Tom Brown's Schooldays.'' How Mr. Ayckbourn contrives to get his people into such states and persuade us to believe that they are reasonable is a secret of his comic flair.

description: THE National Dairy Board in Arlington, Va., will move its cheese-promotion account to DDB Needham Worldwide of Chicago, from D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles of Chicago, and its children's milk-promotion account to Scali, McCabe, Sloves of New York, from McCann-Erickson of San Francisco.

description: b-After a writeoff of its share of the FSLIC's secondary reserve of $1 million, or 26 cents a share.

title: NEW YORKERS LEARN TO PROTECT THEMSELVES AT GUN SCHOOL
description: David Scott says he is ''not into macho stuff.'' He became a vegetarian 12 years ago because ''I don't believe in killing animals.'' He practices yoga. He spends several months every year at a retreat in upstate New York where he does nothing but meditate.

description: International A2-8, D12

title: RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. AND KUWAITIS CLEAR GULF MINES LINKED TO TEHERAN
description: Naval experts from the United States, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait finished clearing mines today that Iran was thought to have laid in a deep-water channel to Kuwait's main oil terminal, the Kuwaiti Defense Ministry said.

title: Outdoors; The Case for Handlines
description: THE handline is to the saltwater angler as the cane pole is to his freshwater counterpart, an utterly simple item of equipage that for certain kinds of fishing is as efficient and as much fun to use as the most expensive rod and reel.

title: BIOSENSOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
C.I.A. Reaffirms It Will Make No Senior Personnel Shifts
description: William Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, will abide by his previously stated plans to make no decisions on personnel changes before the inquiries into the Iran-contra affair are completed, a C.I.A. spokeswoman said today.

title: The Anti-Drug Drive
description: Meanwhile, the Reagan Administration, aided by private industry, is linking its anti-drug campaign to the start of school in the fall. On Wednesday its chief spokesman against drug use, Nancy Reagan, will lead a White House forum that starts a campaign to persuade 10 million schoolchildren to sign ''just say no'' pledge cards before school starts.

title: Schoenberg Scorings Set for Viennese Series
description: Several American premieres of chamber works transcribed in the early 1900's by the composer Arnold Schoenberg will be included in the programs of a four-part Viennese series beginning Sept. 12 at 8 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Boxing Ramirez Regains Lightweight Title: Jose-Luis Ramirez of Mexico regained the World Boxing Council lightweight title last night in Saint-Tropez, France, winning a unanimous 12-round decision over Terrence Alli of Guyana. The victory gave Ramirez the title that he held from November 1984 to August 1985, but lost to Hector (Macho) Camacho. Camacho was stripped of the title last April after failing to defend it in the stipulated time.(AP) Auto Racing Fittipaldi Wins Despite Collision: Emerson Fittipaldi overcame a last-lap collision with Danny Sullivan yesterday to win the Molson-Indy in Toronto. Fittipaldi, in a Chevrolet-powered March, held a lead of 3.23 seconds going into the final lap, but suddenly came upon the slower-moving cars of Michael Andretti and Scott Goodyear and found Sullivan behind him. Both leaders got past Goodyear and Andretti, and Sullivan attempted to pass on the inside. Fittipaldi pinched Sullivan into the concrete barrier and Sullivan spun and then stopped. The leader was able to straighten his car and beat Sullivan to the finish by 8.35 seconds.(AP) Earnhardt Catches Kulwicki: Dale Earnhardt passed Alan Kulwicki on the final lap yesterday to win the Summer 500 Nascar race at Pocono International Raceway in Long Pond, Pa.(AP) Marathon Terzi Wins in San Francisco: Mehmet Terzi of Turkey captured the San Francisco-Audi Marathon yesterday, finishing in 2 hours 14 minutes 7 seconds. Eileen Claugus of Sacramento was the women's winner with a time of 2:39:02.(AP) Track and Field Moses Beats Harris: Edwin Moses charged past Danny Harris and won the 400-meter hurdles in 48.08 seconds yesterday in the Adriaan Paulen Memorial meet at Hengelo, the Netherlands. Harris finished second in 48.60, and Kevin Young was third in 48.94. Moses had won 122 straight 400-meter hurdle races in the past decade before having his streak stopped last month by Harris. (AP) Americans Finish Strong in Zagreb: The United States won six track finals yesterday to finish at the top of the gold-medal count at the World University Games in Zagreb, Yugoslavia. The Americans had 26 gold medals; the Soviet Union, 25. (AP) Tennis Another Tournament to Sanchez: Emilio Sanchez of Spain defeated Ronald Agenor of Haiti, 5-7, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday to win the $170,000 Bordeaux Grand Prix tennis tournament in France. It was the second tournament victory in a row for Sanchez, who last week defeated Agenor in Gstaad, Switzerland.(AP) Mecir vs. Gunnarsson: Top-seeded Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia and Jan Gunnarsson of Sweden advanced to the final of the Mercedes Cup Grand Prix tournament in Stuttgart, West Germany, yesterday with straight-set victories. Mecir defeated his countryman and Davis Cup doubles partner, Tomas Smid, 6-3, 6-3. Gunnarsson, seeded 13th, eliminated Carl-Uwe Steeb, 6-4, 7-6.(AP) Biathlon Third in a Row: Russ Jones, a 32-year-old postman from Collingswood, N.J., won his third straight race in the Goldome New York Biathlon Series yesterday, taking the Staten Island portion of the competition. He finished a 3-mile run, a 20-mile bicycle race and another 3-mile run in 1 hour 24 minutes 59 seconds. He had also won races in the Bronx and Queens. The first woman to finish was Beth Nelson, 32, from East Harwich, Mass., who completed the event in 1:33.24. Olympic Festival More Gold for Louganis: Greg Louganis won the 10-meter platform diving title yesterday for the sixth straight time. Louganis, who now has 12 festival golds, had three perfect scores of 10 yesterday in Raleigh, N.C. In nearby Greensboro, Brian Boitano missed in his fourth attempt at a quadruple jump in competition, but his overall performance helped the West win the men's long program in figure skating.(AP)

title: Philadelphia Hours Set
description: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange said, it would begin trading currency options in the evening in mid-September. The extra session would run from 7 P.M. to 11 P.M. Sunday through Thursday.

title: RULING PARTY IN PORTUGAL WINS CLEAR MAJORITY
description: The governing Social Democratic Party was swept back into office in national elections today with a large increase in its popular vote, giving Portugal its first majority Government since the establishment of democracy in 1974.

description: Rising inventories of unsold new cars will probably lead to more sales incentives this fall and to lower rates of production next year, according to auto industry analysts.

description: President Reagan tentatively plans to name a homosexual to a Federal advisory committee that will investigate the AIDS epidemic, Administration officials said today.
