description: Companies

title: Two Charged With Assaulting Georgia Civil Rights Marcher
description: Two brothers were arrested here today and charged with assaulting a civil rights marcher in January, the most serious charges to result from two violent demonstrations in this all-white community.

title: PHILIPS INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Birdie on 18th Gives Geddes a Victory
description: Jane Geddes, the defending champion, sank a 4-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole today to beat Donna White and Judy Rosenthal by one stroke in the $300,000 Boston Five Classic.

title: Rainier's Chief Resigns Posts
description: G. Robert Truex Jr. has resigned as chairman and chief executive of the Rainier Bancorporation. The company's president, John D. Mangels, will take over those posts, while Jon Christoffersen, president of the Rainier Bank subsidiary, will become president of the holding company as well.

title: Rick's Cafe to Open On Repertory Stage In the Catskills
description: For a few weeks this summer, a rustic enclave in the hills above this Catskill town will be transformed into wartime Morocco, and one can be certain that in the neighborhood taverns down the road, more than a few glasses will be lifted with a wink and the admonition, ''Here's looking at you, kid.''

title: STANDARD FEDERAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $241,000 and $10,964,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and for the 6 months also includes a prepayment penalty of $358,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $14,970,000 and $35,640,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Standard Federal Bank went public in January.

title: AMY CARTER IS REPORTED DISMISSED FROM COLLEGE
description: Amy Carter, the daughter of Jimmy Carter, has been dismissed from Brown University for failing to keep up with her course work, The Providence Journal reported Saturday. She is a sophomore.

title: CTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $351,000 and $815,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-Includes income from discontinued operations of $7,549,000.

title: TV Networks Resume Rotation on Hearings
description: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair will be televised live beginning at 9 A.M. on the ABC television network under the network rotation system. The hearings will also be televised on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on some local affiliates of PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service, including Channel 13 in New York.

title: Mets' Lineup Changes Pay Off
description: He wasn't exactly reaching for the panic button, but Davey Johnson shuffled the Mets' lineup yesterday, anointed Darryl Strawberry as his new cleanup hitter over Gary Carter and said, ''For us to come back in the second half, we've got to get everything we can from Darryl.''

title: Pennzoil Plan Will Seek $4.1 Billion From Texaco
description: The Pennzoil Company plans to file a proposal today in Bankruptcy Court that would allow it to submit a reorganization plan under which Texaco Inc. would pay Pennzoil $4.1 billion.

title: Carol J. Weil Wed To David Medine
description: Carol Juliet Weil, an associate in the Indianapolis law firm of Baker & Daniels, and David Medine, an associate professor of law at Indiana University, were married yesterday at the Beverly Hills, Calif., home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Max Harry Weil. Professor Medine's parents are Ruth Medine of New York and the late Dr. Myer Medine. Rabbi Fred Krinsky officiated.

title: CROWD SEIZES CRIME SUSPECT
description: A robbery suspect was arrested on the Upper West Side yesterday after several passers-by and a man he is said to have slashed across the forehead chased and captured him, the police said.

title: McCrory Chief Said to Weigh Quitting Over Rift
description: Stephen L. Pistner, whose annual remuneration of $2.5 million makes him one of the highest-paid retailers in the nation, may soon resign as chairman and chief executive of the McCrory Corporation, the giant variety-store chain, according to executives close to the company.

title: FRANCE STEPS UP SECURITY IN ITS IRAN RIFT
description: France today stepped up security measures around the world for its ships, planes and armed forces as it braced for a long confrontation in the war of nerves with Iran.

title: Chile Develops 'Stockholders' Culture'
description: Workers at an iron ore deposit and pellet plant operated by the Pacific Steel Company 300 miles north of Santiago recently asked the general manager to give them a report on profits and investments this year.

title: Now France at Irangate
description: France in its turn is learning the wages of trying to make what Ollie North called a ''neat'' deal with Ayatollah Khomeini's Iran. Relations have now been broken and the French are hunkering down against the possibility of reprisals that could come anywhere - against French diplomats in Teheran, hostages in Lebanon, ships in the Persian Gulf or in France itself.

title: Not Protectionism
description: To the Editor:

title: BOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MARY SHELLEY: A Biography. By Muriel Spark. Illustrated. 248 pages. A William Abrahams Book/Dutton. $19.95.

title: Clark's Homers Power Cards to Victory
description: Jack Clark hit two home runs today, including a tie-breaking shot in the top of the 10th, to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to a 5-4 victory over the San Diego Padres.

title: LSB BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share figures have been restated to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in June.

title: BINKS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CANCER SOCIETY RECONSIDERS PLAN TO LEAVE NEW YORK TO CUT RENT
description: The American Cancer Society is reconsidering its decision to move its headquarters from New York City and, in search of cheaper rents, is looking at buildings in the city, as well as Westchester and New Jersey.

title: Advertising; A Thompson Account
description: Now, here for a change, is some plain, ordinary, positive news about the J. Walter Thompson Company: Its Atlanta office has won the $4 million account of the Georgia Federal Savings and Loan. The institution, the largest savings bank in Georgia and a subsidiary of Fuqua Industries, was formerly served by Fahlgren & Swink.

title: 15TH PRESIDENT INSTALLED AT DARTMOUTH
description: Dartmouth College yesterday inaugurated a president who used his first official speech to set a new tone for the college, which is known in the Ivy League for strong school spirit and adherence to tradition.

title: HOME FEDERAL FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
In London, an Old Craft Keeps Heads in Fashion
description: Horse riders and racegoers might have more in common than they suspect when they gather at the Goodwood racecourse in West Sussex at the end of July for ''Glorious Goodwood,'' an informally elegant meet that is prized for its lovely country setting and special English ambiance. Notes will doubtless be compared on hunts, jumps and horse hands. But if bowlers and riding caps are compared, the name Patey will probably come up most often. S.Patey (London) Ltd. is regarded as one of the finest custom hatmakers in Britain, the last of 70 such workshops that once flourished here.

title: Toshiba Caught Between Tokyo and Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DENNISON MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $9,802,000, or 62 cents a share, from the sale of Hygeia Sciences Inc. common stock and an after-tax loss of $7,123,000 on the disposition of two wholly owned subsidiaries.

title: Advertising; Xerox Billings Given to Lowe
description: The Xerox Corporation is switching about $25 million in billings to Lowe Marschalk, from Ted Bates Advertising, which last week became Backer Spielvogel Bates. A Xerox spokesman said that the switch was on the fire before the merger.

title: GORMAN-RUPP COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RESERVE INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
FIDELITY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN OF TENNESSEE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a credit of $685,000 from tax loss carryforwards. Year-ago share earnings aren't available because the company went public Sept. 24, 1986.

title: GALLAGHER, ARTHUR J & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Beirut Report On Economy
description: A committee appointed last week by the Government to undertake a thorough examination of the country's worsening economic crisis is due to present its recommendations on Monday.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday Consumer Prices June Treasury Statement June Thursday Durable Goods June Friday GNP 2d qtr.

title: BANK OF BOSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After the effect of a $300 million increase in the reserve for possible credit losses from less developed countries' debt. c-Net income

title: SINGAPORE DETAINS THREE MORE
description: The Government of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew detained for a year without trial today three more young Singaporeans accused of being involved in a Marxist conspiracy.

title: Ex-Rep. Dominick V. Daniels; Held Jersey Seat in Congress
description: Dominick Vincent Daniels, a former Representative from New Jersey who wielded much power over education and labor legislation until he retired in 1976 after 18 years in Congress, died Friday at Christ Hospital in Jersey City after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Union City, N.J.

title: Cuomo Announces Work Safety Grants
description: Governor Cuomo has announced the award of 81 local grants totaling $4.5 million to teach workers about potential health and safety hazards and to raise standards in those areas.

title: Greenspan Talent Search
description: Townsend-Greenspan & Company, the economic consulting firm owned by Alan Greenspan, would be dissolved if a well-known economist is not found by midweek to replace Mr. Greenspan, who has been nominated to be chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Motivation Keys Pitino Game Plan
description: RICK PITINO is no different from most other headstrong young coaches intent upon changing the world. Like many of them, he draws his inspiration, his motivation and even some of his techniques from some successful predecessor.

title: U.S. Seen Easing Stance on Toshiba
description: Despite strong sentiment in Congress to punish the Toshiba Corporation for illegal sales of high technology to the Soviet Union, key lawmakers are now convinced that a ban on Toshiba imports approved last month by the Senate will be softened considerably before it reaches the President's desk.

title: Miss Kenworthy Wed To T. R. Dyer in Seattle
description: Lise Kenworthy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Atlee Kenworthy of Colonia, N.J., was married yesterday to Thomas Ralph Dyer, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Dyer of Astoria, Ore. The Revs. Craig Rennebohm and Michael Litaker, United Church of Christ ministers, performed the ceremony at the Pilgrim Congregational Church in Seattle.

title: ISIDORE LEVIN
description: Isidore Levine, a former Family Court judge appointed by Mayor John V. Lindsay, died of a heart attack Friday at Long Island Jewish Hospital in Queens. He lived in Flushing, Queens, and was 75 years old.

title: Barbara C. Todd Is Married to David A. Heiner Jr.
description: Barbara Carrie Todd, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Todd of Sarasota, Fla., was married yesterday to David Allen Heiner Jr., a son of Nancy Ann Heiner of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., and Mr. Heiner of Greenwood Lake, N.Y. Msgr. Edward T. Kavin performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Gabriel the Archangel in Saddle River, N.J.

title: Israel to Shift Policy on Tourists After Complaints of Harassment
description: Israel, responding to complaints about official harassment of black and Palestinian-American tourists, plans some changes that may make it easier for the tourists, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Caren Herman Married
description: At Temple Sinai in Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday Caren Herman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Riback of Forest Hills, was married to Laurence Zucker, a son of Selma Zucker Hofher of Flushing, Queens, and the late Harry Zucker. Rabbi Jay Rosenbaum officiated. The bride is a broadcast traffic supervisor at Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton, an advertising agency in New York. Her previous marriage ended in divorce, as did that of the bridegroom, who is an electrical engineer for the Eaton Corporation in Deer Park, L.I.

title: COLONIAL AMERICAN BANKHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Liberal Group Makes Waves With Its Contra Lawsuit
description: In a drab row house within sight of Capitol Hill, a team of lawyers and researchers are conducting another investigation of clandestine pro-contra activities that is attracting its own share of publicity.

title: Jacob Kaplan, Philanthropist, Is Dead
description: Jacob Merrill Kaplan, a merchant and self-made financier who shared his wealth to become one of New York's foremost philanthropists, with beneficiaries ranging the gamut of worthy causes, died Saturday at his Manhattan home. He was 95 years old and also kept a home in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Postal Service Resumes Talks With 2 Unions
description: Bargaining between the Postal Service and its two largest unions resumed today following a four-day impasse.

title: City Opera: 'La Rondine' Is Revived
description: THE New York City Opera revival of ''La Rondine'' is worth a visit, but be prepared for frustration if by chance you know and love this bittersweet, subtly fragile sister of the more familiar Puccini operas.

title: Mattingly Is a Bargain
description: EVEN in the glow of his home-run streak, Don Mattingly has displayed his usual devotion to duty. He's talked about how ''it would be selfish'' to try for the record at the expense of the Yankees' ambition to finish in first place. He's explained his home runs by saying: ''I've found a swing that gets the ball in the air. All of a sudden, without even trying, something has clicked.'' But when the 26-year-old first baseman was asked if he had thought yet of asking George Steinbrenner for a raise next year above and beyond his $1.975 million salary, he laughed.

title: LOSS OF TRADITIONS FOR A TINY ETHNIC GROUP
description: The beach beckoning, many of the younger Kalmuks went out to the Jersey Shore today. But here in the shade of the salmon-colored Buddhist temple that is the spiritual center of one of America's smallest ethnic groups, Noron Adianov sat and wondered whether any of the younger generation would take up religion.

title:
Market Place;
The Lagging Broker Stocks
description: LEAD: THE stock market this year has confounded the experts, many of whom expected it to run out of steam by now. But there is one sector that probably cannot run out of steam - because it just does not have any.

title: LEXICON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Immigration Amnesty Won't Alter America
description: To the Editor:

title: EMHART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,400,000 from the sale of shoe machinery operations for both the quarter and 6 months; and the 6-month also includes a gain of $5,100,000 from liquidation of a subsidiary in Switzerland.

title: City Opera: 'Boheme'
description: THERE may be no sure things in life, but in opera, we know, the world is a different place.

title: Advertising; Honors for Dailey Head In Anti-Drug Effort
description: Philip Joanou, the chairman and chief executive of Dailey & Associates, Los Angeles, will be recognized for developing the concept for the advertising industry's anti-drug campaign. On Thursday he will accept one of the 1987 Awards for Private Sector Initiatives from President Reagan.

title: Off-Duty Officer Stabbed in Dispute
description: An off-duty Port Authority police officer was stabbed and seriously wounded yesterday by two men after a dispute in an elevator in the Polo Grounds housing project in upper Manhattan, the police said.

title: HUBBELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LOUISIANA EXECUTES MURDERER AS APPEALS ARE TURNED DOWN
description: Willie Lawrence Celestine, who confessed he beat, raped and strangled an 81-year-old woman six years ago was put to death early this morning in the Louisiana electric chair.

title: Advertising; Ammirati & Puris Gets All of Chiquita's Work
description: Chiquita Brands, part of United Brands, has consolidated all of its advertising at Ammirati & Puris, which began handling Chiquita Pops in December 1985.

title: New York Pollutes Itself
description: At a press conference in Poughkeepsie the other day, the New York State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, announced that New York, six other Northeastern states and five environmental groups had joined in filing a suit in Federal court in Maine on air pollution. The suit asked that the Environmental Protection Agency be ordered to write regulations forcing Middle Western utilities to cut back on emissions of sulfur dioxide, which cause regional haze (and acid rain) in the Northeast.

title: Queens Man Slain at Home
description: A 37-year-old man was fatally shot last night while sitting on the front steps of his home in South Jamaica, Queens, the police said. The shooting occurred about 6:45 P.M. at 170-110 118th Road, a police spokesman, Sgt. Raymond O'Donnell, said. The victim, James Green, was approached by a man who got out of a black van. The two men exchanged words and the unidentified man pulled a gun and fired, Sergeant O'Donnell said. The gunman, who was being sought by the police, shot Mr. Green six times.

title: TV Review; ARTHUR RUBINSTEIN IS REMEMBERED
description: ARTHUR RUBINSTEIN, who would have been 100 years old in January, embodies a paradox of the century. He cultivated an image of Old European opulence, dressing in fedoras and smoking jackets and puffing expensive cigars. We imagine him in Paris, perhaps, dining with Cocteau or fending off the affections of an admiring countess. And yet Rubinstein's direct style at the keyboard reflected the tastes of a modern era. His playing stripped away many of what have come to be considered the affectations and exaggerations that characterized Chopin interpretation before his arrival.

title: IN BASEBALL, THE RUSSIANS STEAL ALL THE BASES
description: Consider the predicament of a Soviet baseball writer. How do you explain to red-blooded Russians that Soviet athletes have suddenly taken up the American national pastime?

title: Determined Pro Career
description: Medically, Mark Sobel never had a chance for a professional football career. As a 165-pound walk-on at the University of Maryland in 1978, he was lucky to survive his tryouts, let alone make the team. Even after he bulked his 5-foot-10-inch frame up to 210 (by working himself up to four training-table steaks a sitting) the Matawan, N.J., native was still a quarter of a defensive end shy of professional models.

title: Black Is Miss Mississippi
description: A 22-year-old graduate of Mississippi University for Women has become the first black to be crowned Miss Mississippi. Toni Seawright of Moss Point won the state pageant Saturday night and will represent Mississippi in the Miss America contest in Atlantic City in September. ''I'm glad I made history,'' Miss Seawright said after being crowned.

title: Opera: Britten's 'Midsummer Night'
description: Benjamin Britten's operas are, on the whole, the best extant in the English language, and ought to be in regular repertory with all American companies. But - being British and being difficult - they are not quite ''ours'' in the way that vintage Broadway musicals are. The Chautauqua Opera production of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' on Friday night illustrated the rewards and the problems of attempting this brilliantly conceived work.

title: Saxophones Speak in Hemphill's 'Long Tongues'
description: The Bohemian Caverns, a club in Washington, heard a good stretch of black American music - from the 40's, when it was the Crystal Caverns, the capital's equivalent of the Cotton Club, to the 60's.

title: Metro Matters; For Attendants, Poverty at Home And on the Job
description: ''I had a client once, I brought her sheets from my own house,'' Odessa Powell remembered. ''She was a diabetic who collected S.S.I., and her boyfriend would take her check and buy his supply of vodka for a month and give her whatever money he wanted her to have. She was sleeping on just a mattress.'' ''Some of those that have families,'' she said, ''they don't come around until the first or third of the month when the checks come.''

title: Plainfield: Compact, but Complicated
description: The Plainfield Country Club, where the United States Women's Open will begin Thursday, ranks as one of the best courses in New Jersey, which boasts as many outstanding courses as any state.

title: ASSEMBLY SPEAKER IS SUSPENDING FIGHT WITH CUOMO
description: Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, whose efforts to bypass Governor Cuomo and assert the State Legislature's dominance set off a bitter six-month power struggle, indicated yesterday that he had suspended the fight, saying he would reach out more to the Governor.

title: FORTUNE FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $3,382,000 primarily from the prepayment penalty on a Federal Home Loan Bank advance. c-After charges of $299,000 and $2,769,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, primarily from the prepayment penalty on a Federal Home Loan Bank advance.

title: A.T.&T. Unit to Get Japan Job
description: A subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will be awarded a contract next month to research communications systems for Japan's second major international airport, a spokesman for the Kansai International Airport said Friday.

title: ADAMS-MILLIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in December 1986. The company said the increase in sales was due primarily to sales generated by Maro Hosiery Corp., which was acquired in April 1986.

title: Fellini Film Wins Prize At Moscow Festival
description: ''The Interview,'' a film by Federico Fellini about a day in the life of a movie studio, won the grand prize Friday at the 15th Moscow Film Festival.

title: R.O.T.C., SHUNNED NO MORE, GROWS INCREASINGLY SELECTIVE
description: The Army's Reserve Officer Training Corps, having recovered from its post-Vietnam enrollment slump, has become far more selective in commissioning new officers and calling them to active duty - to the dismay of some student cadets.

title: Cerone Takes to Mound
description: The evening began with Lou Piniella, the manager of the Yankees, explaining that Dennis Rasmussen had been sent to the minors because of the limited work offered to those in the Yankee bullpen. The laughter began with Rick Cerone on the mound. In a move to relieve the relievers, Cerone pitched in a professional game for the first time in the eighth inning of the 20-3 loss to Texas. After entering with the bases loaded and none out, he permitted only two runners to score -one on a ground ball and one on a balk.

title: America as a Safe Haven, From Politics
description: It sounds like a sensible and humane use of discretionary power: Attorney General Edwin Meese has directed the Immigration and Naturalization Service to be more generous in considering the claims of undocumented Nicaraguans for political asylum in this country.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Drip, Drip, Drip

title: Man, Struck in Head In a Park Fight, Dies
description: A Bronx man died yesterday after he was struck on the head, apparently with a pipe, during a dispute with four men in Bronx Park, the police said.

title: FLORIDA STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $2,575,000 for the estimated cost of hazardous waste removal.

title: PENTAGON NURSING AN AGING NETWORK OF KEY SATELLITES
description: The American military, concerned because of the potential loss of some satellites, is taking precautions to prevent the breakdown of space systems essential for reconnaissance, secret communications and early warning of missile attack.

title: 18-Year-Old Drowns At Amusement Park
description: An 18-year-old youth drowned at an amusement park attraction here yesterday, the authorities said.

title: PEOPLES HERITAGE BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains from securities of $891,000 for the quarter and $1,554,000 for the six months. c-Includes gains from securities of $1,277,000 for the quarter and $2,450,000 for the six months. The company completed its conversion from a mutual to a stockholder- owned savings bank in December 1986.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Tickets, Parking for Open
description: Tickets will be available at the gate for all seven days of the United States Women's Open. Practice-round tickets (July 20-22) are $8 each; tickets for the championship rounds (July 23-26) are $16 each.

title:
U.S. WOMEN'S OPEN;
For Geddes, a Golf Career With Late Starting Time
description: LEAD: JANE GEDDES, the 27-year-old native of Long Island's North Shore who will defend her United States Women's Open title this week at the Plainfield Country Club in New Jersey, grew up in an area where she could well have been a golf brat, but wasn't. She was a Mets fan, and a rough-and-tumble child-athlete, into ''anything and everything - any game with a ball, except golf.

title: The U.N. Today: July 20, 1987
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Kohlberg, Kravis Plans Place for Walter Officers
description: The story is a familiar one in entrepreneurial annals: James L. Walter got out of the Navy, went back to his hometown of Tampa, Fla., and with his savings and money borrowed from his father bought a shell house for $895. He put it up on a lot owned by his father and sold it at a profit.

title: GRACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AIDS DRAMA TRIES TO REACH YOUNG
description: When CBS-TV began production of ''An Enemy Among Us,'' a drama about a teen-ager who contracts AIDS from a blood transfusion, it was intended as an afternoon ''Schoolbreak Special.''

title: STAGE: ROBERT WILSON'S 'DEAFMAN'
description: LINCOLN CENTER'S two-week program of Serious Fun! got off to a seriously gloomy start Friday night, when Robert Wilson brought a two-night engagement of ''Overture to the Fourth Act of Deafman Glance'' to Alice Tully Hall. Even audiences who know better than to seek levity from the apocalypse-minded Mr. Wilson had good reason to be dispirited.

title: Mattingly And Yanks Thwarted
description: Don Mattingly had the most unsatisfying 2-for-4 game of his career tonight.

title: Nekoosa Chief Busy With New Strategy
description: William R. Laidig, chairman and chief executive of the Great Northern Nekoosa Paper Company, says he has a lot of woodworking machinery in his basement that he doesn't get much of a chance to use.

title: South Africa Crash Kills 10
description: Ten people died in a collision between a small bus and a truck carrying gasoline, the South African Broadcasting Corporation reported today. The radio said the bus, carrying 14 people, crashed into the truck in Kwamashu, near Durban on the southeastern coast Saturday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Baseball is the younger brother of lapta. This old, spirited game was taken to America by the first Russian settlers, and has now returned to us in a different form and with a strange, foreign name.'' - Sergei Shachin, Izvestia sports writer. [ A1:2. ]

title: FIRST WISCONSIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge related to the $96 million addition to loan loss reserves for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income

title: FIRST ILLINOIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FAMILY MUTUAL SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank converted to stock ownership in November.

title: Man, 65, at Center of Court Case In Jersey on 'Right to Die' Is Dead
description: Murray Putzer, a 65-year-old stroke victim whose feeding tube was withdrawn 10 days ago at his insistence, died Thursday afternoon at his home in West Caldwell, N.J., the family's lawyer disclosed yesterday.

title: LO-JACK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Year-ago revenue figures are not available because the company did not have products on the market at that time.

title: VARCO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
YANKEES SEND RASMUSSEN DOWN
description: Dennis Rasmussen, whose 18 victories for the Yankees last season was tied for the fourth-highest total in the American League, was sent to the Columbus farm club today. His spot on the roster was taken by Dan Pasqua, who was scheduled to be in the starting lineup tonight against Texas before his flight was delayed. He arrived late and pinch-hit in the ninth, reaching on an error.

title: Bolshoi Ballet: 'Giselle'
description: THE Bolshoi Ballet, ending a triumphant season Saturday night amid collective curtain calls at the Metropolitan Opera House, managed to slip in a few more surprises in its three final performances of ''Giselle'' over the weekend.

title: U.S. Debt Limit Threatens Auctions
description: Because Congress has not yet raised the Federal debt ceiling, this week's Treasury bill and note auctions might be disrupted.

title: Making Layoffs Less Harsh
description: Should employers be required to give advance notice of mass layoffs? This innocent-sounding question put Big Labor and Big Business at each other's throats in the Senate; the wrestling continues in the House. If the two sides would only shed their ideological rigidity, they'd see a workable compromise in Senator Metzenbaum's modified proposal. His original plan put too many limits on management flexibility. The version the Senate has now adopted seems reasonable and humane.

title: FIRST ALABAMA BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SCHLUMBERGER LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $22,844,000 and $67,524,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: FAMILY FULFILLS QUEST IN RING
description: On June 27 in the Montreal Forum, Matthew Hilton became the new International Boxing Federation junior middleweight champion when, at the age of 21, he won a 15-round decision over Buster Drayton.

title: DUKE POWER CO reports earnings for 12mo to June 30
Jersey Construction Worker Is Killed by 5-Ton Steel Slab
description: A New Jersey construction worker was killed when a five-ton slab of steel fell on him at the site of a Long Island water tower where he was working, the police said.

title: WHEELING-PITTSBURGH STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $16,115,000 and $30,032,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes a charge of $83,242,000 related to restructuring for both periods, and for the quarter includes a charge of $1,843,000 from reversal of a tax credit.

title: NBC to Sell Its Radio Networks
description: The NBC radio networks, founded 61 years ago as the first national network but undercut by the age of television, will be sold for $50 million, NBC said today.

title: Issue in Nicaragua Isn't Communism
description: To the Editor:

title: CHICAGO PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After charges of $3,418,000 and $6,743,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from the repurchases of notes, and a charge of $432,000 on the reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and a tax credit of $2,595,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes a tax credit of $3,277,000.

title: Senator Simon
description: David Carle, press secretary for Senator Paul Simon of Illinois, is calling reporters' attention to an article in M magazine, which describes itself as a publication for ''the civilized man.''

title: Man, 21, Is Killed In Apartment Blaze
description: A man was killed and four people, including three firefighters, were injured in an apartment fire early yesterday morning, the authorities said.

title: EATON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter benefited from a $7 million gain from the sale of its industrial polymer products operations in May.

title: Where They Vote With Their Bats
description: ''On this right elbow,'' Representative Mel Levine proclaimed as he flexed his arm, ''rests the honor of the Democratic Party.''

title: STAGE: FIGHT IN 'ARATOOGA'
description: THE most exciting episode in ''The Invasion of Aratooga'' is intermission. During the break, there is always a chance of running into urban drama on the stretch of East 13th Street in front of the CSC Repertory Theater, especially on weekends when squads of rock commandos peel off from the lines outside a nearby club and try to outfox the brace of Sylvester Stallone clones barring the door.

title: Our Towns; Loving Care For Nasty Yaks And Ill Emus
description: Every zoo needs a Sue Mitschke, 20 years an animal keeper. ''I'm a swing keeper,'' she said, filling a bucket of delicious high fiber pellets for the llama. ''What a love, what a love if this llama's upset - she'll spit in your face. Good girl! Good girl!''

title: A Title Lost in The Fog
description: Golf is such a lonely game and the pain of defeat so personal. There are no teammates to share it. Usually only a spouse or fellow competitor is allowed inside that facade that must be built so a golfer can make it to the first tee the next time.

title: Geologists Turn Talents to Fighting Crime
description: Armed only with microscopes, geologists have helped convict a kidnapper, locate a stolen Cadillac and send a killer to death row. They say their methods should be used by more police departments.

title: WHEN DISK MEETS PIE
description: FEW people using personal computers today realize that the machines once utilized 8-inch floppies. My first ''home computer'' was a Sol, manufactured in kit form by Processor Technology. Even with its hand-rubbed walnut sides, the Sol was not much bigger than today's Apple II. But its disk drive was external, and it took up as much space as a filing cabinet's drawer. Within a year, those cumbersome drives had given way to the 5 1/4-inch standard still in existence.

title: The Testimony: Dialogue With 'Pragmatic Elements' in Iran
description: Members of Congress questioned Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter further yesterday, in his fourth day of testimony, about his role in the Iran-contra affair. Here are excerpts from his testimony, as recorded by The New York Times.

description: The Spingold Knockout Team Championship began here quietly Sunday at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals. An original entry of 105 teams was cut to 64 teams with all the top-ranked squads surviving.

title: MCI Down 50%, Bell Atlantic Up 6.1% in Quarter
description: The MCI Communicatins Corporation, the nation's second-largest long-distance telephone company behind A.T.&T., reported yesterday that its second-quarter profits dropped 50 percent.

title: Advertising; New Group Publisher At Hearst Magazines
description: D. Claeys Bahrenburg, 40, has replaced K. Robert Brink, 48, as one of two group publishers at Hearst Magazines. Mr. Brink went on ''an extended leave of absence'' two weeks ago without any internal or external corporate announcement. There is also no official word on when he is expected back, and the company has no comment on the change.

title: Tudor Warming Up
description: John Tudor, the St. Louis Cardinals left-hander who has been idle since April 19 with a broken leg, has the go-ahead to begin working out. Tudor will report tomorrow to Louisville of the American Association, where he will face Omaha. He is tentatively scheduled to pitch Sunday against Iowa in Des Moines.

title: 8,000 Doctors Strike in India
description: Health services in the capital and other Indian cities were crippled today as 8,000 state-employed doctors went on strike to demand better salaries and benefits. New doctors get about $160 a month. The demand for a starting salary is $240.

title: POUGHKEEPSIE SAVINGS BANK FSB reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Youth on Death Row Is Granted New Trial
description: The state Supreme Court reversed the capital murder conviction today of a teen-ager found guilty of stabbing three people to death.

title: BRITISH PLAN: REDUCING LOCAL CONTROL
description: Britain's schools are on the threshold of a major revolution.

title: BLACKMUN IS BEING TREATED FOR RECURRENCE OF PROSTATE CANCER
description: Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the Supreme Court is undergoing treatment for a recurrence of prostate cancer at the Mayo Clinic and has an ''excellent'' prognosis, the clinic said today amid speculation about the 78-year-old justice's medical condition.

title: Home-Run Hat Tricks
description: When Dale Sveum of the Milwaukee Brewers hit three home runs on Friday night, he became the ninth batter this season to drive three balls out of the park in one game. The others were Eric Davis, Tim Wallach, Cory Snyder, Joe Carter, Mike Schmidt, Mark McGwire, Bill Madlock and Brook Jacoby. Johnny Mize, the career leader in the category, hit three homers in a game six times. Batters who did it at least three times:

title: Chinese Relics Stolen From Museum Since '81
description: Thieves have stolen more than 115 cultural relics from a museum in northeastern China since 1981 and local authorities blamed lax security, a Chinese newspaper reported today.

title: E-SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
How Pigeons Think
description: Amid continuing debate over how animals perceive, remember and act upon things they see, researchers at Michigan State University have come up with a new kind of experiment that suggests, they say, that pigeons think in terms of images.

description: Mary R. Clarkin, vice president of open market activities at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, is resigning from her post to join the Nikko Securities Company International Inc. as senior vice president and sales manager of the fixed-income division, Nikko announced yesterday.

title: The Runaway Winner in Portugal
description: When he appeared at a news conference and then addressed his supporters after his election victory on Sunday, Anibal Cavaco Silva seemed to force a smile.

title: BENJAMIN F. LEVENTHAL

description: New York City's Rent Guidelines Board recently raised the allowable increase in rent of any vacant stabilized apartment from 7.5 to 10 percent. That showed integrity, in contrast to the tactics of Governor Cuomo.

title: TWO-TIER WAGE SYSTEM: FOR MANY IT LEADS TO A SECOND-CLASS STATUS
description: In 1983, when American Airlines instituted a wage scale for newly hired workers that was lower than that for other employees, executives at other airlines and in other industries thought it was a great idea. They reasoned that by taking the same approach they would be able to reduce their labor costs significantly without having to fight for major concessions from longer-term workers and their unions.

The latest quarter results also include a loss of $1,959,000 from the company's investment in De Laurentiis Film Partners L.P., with the majority of that loss also relating to a writedown from ''Million Dollar Mystery.''

title: Market Place; New Strategies On New Issues
description: IF the bull market keeps rolling along, selected companies going public for the first time are also likely to prosper, according to Standard & Poor's Outlook. ''New issues as a group,'' it said, ''tend to exaggerate the underlying trend of the overall market.''

description: WHILE some astrophysicists work on high-velocity field dwarfs or magnetohydrodynamic solitons, others have been brooding lately about an older problem: Why is the night sky dark?

description: Hospitals here in New Jersey's largest city are so strained by the number of AIDS patients that they are trying to establish the state's first hospital for people with the deadly disease.

title: Phillips-Van Heusen Rejects Rosewood Offer

title: Actor Found Dead at Home
description: The body of Kevin Marcum, who appeared as the wise old feline, Old Deuteronomy, in the Broadway musical ''Cats,'' was found last night on the living room floor of his Manhattan apartment at 752 West End Avenue, the police said. The death of the 31-year-old actor, who also appeared in the musical version of ''Les Miserables,'' was labeled suspicious, pending an autopsy.

title: Staging 'La Strada' In a Vermont Field Requires Invention
description: The theatergoers begin their evening by tramping across a field to a gaily striped circus tent surrounded by performers relaxing before the show. Jugglers practice tossing their pins and balls; a tiny ballerina in a pink tutu twirls across the grass blowing soap bubbles; a clown plays cards with a woman wearing a live boa constrictor coiled around her neck, its forked tongue flicking soundlessly at her hand of cards.

title: GEPHARDT TRADES BARBS WITH KEMP
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, a Democratic candidate for President, vigorously defended himself today against charges that he was a ''protectionist.'' In a debate with a Republican Presidential aspirant, he declared that tough action against unfair trade practices was essential to defend the ''standard of living of the American middle class.''

title: Admiral Says O'Neill Stalled Contra Funds
description: Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter, in testimony today at the Iran-contra hearings, accused Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the former Speaker of the House, of personally holding up $100 million in aid for the Nicaraguan contras last year.

description: John M. Snyder, the chief lobbyist for the Citizens Committee for the Right to Keep and Bear Arms, normally spends his time lobbying members of Congress on various issues relating to guns and gun owners. But lately he has turned his efforts toward Rome.

description: THE Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center can now be appropriately called a mostly music series. The popular summer series presented dance for the first time with ''Mostly Mozart and the Dance,'' a program shared by the New York Baroque Dance Company and the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company, which was performed Sunday and will be repeated Thursday. And the walls of Avery Fisher Hall, where the series takes place, did not crumble.

title: THE CEASE-FIRE RESOLUTION
description: Following is the text of a resolution adopted unanimously by the Security Council today urging Iran and Iraq to call an immediate cease-fire in their war: THE SECURITY COUNCIL, REAFFIRMING its resolution 582 (1986) DEEPLY CONCERNED that, despite its calls for a cease-fire, the conflict between Iran and Iraq continues unabated, with further heavy loss of human life and material destruction, DEPLORING the initiation and continuation of the conflict, DEPLORING also the bombing of purely civilian population centers, attacks on neutral shipping or civilian aircraft, the violation of international humanitarian law and other laws of armed conflict, and, in particular, the use of chemical weapons contrary to obligations under the 1925 Geneva Protocol, DEEPLY CONCERNED that further escalation and widening of the conflict may take place, DETERMINED to bring to an end all military actions between Iran and Iraq, CONVINCED that a comprehensive, just, honorable and durable settlement should be achieved between Iran and Iraq, RECALLING the provisions of the Charter of the United Nations and in particular the obligation of all member states to settle their international disputes by peaceful means in such a manner that international peace and security and justice are not endangered, DETERMINING that there exists a breach of the peace as regards the conflict between Iran and Iraq, ACTING under Articles 39 and 40 of the Charter of the United Nations, 1.DEMANDS that, as a first step toward a negotiated settlement, Iran and Iraq observe an immediate cease-fire, discontinue all military actions on land, at sea and in the air, and withdraw all forces to the internationally recognized boundaries without delay; 2.REQUESTS the Secretary General to dispatch a team of United Nations observers to verify, confirm and supervise the cease-fire and withdrawal and further requests the Secretary General to make the necessary arrangements in consultation with the parties and to submit a report thereon to the Security Council; 3.URGES that prisoners of war be released and repatriated without delay after the cessation of active hostilities in accordance with the Third Geneva Convention of 12 August 1949; 4.CALLS upon Iran and Iraq to cooperate with the Secretary General in implementing this resolution and in mediation efforts to achieve a comprehensive, just and honorable settlement, acceptable to both sides, of all outstanding issues in accordance with the principles contained in the Charter of the United Nations; 5.CALLS upon all other states to exercise the utmost restraint and to refrain from any act which may lead to further escalation and widening of the conflict and thus to facilitate the implementation of the present resolution; 6.REQUESTS the Secretary General to explore, in consultation with Iran and Iraq, the question of entrusting an impartial body with inquiring into responsibility for the conflict and to report to the Security Council as soon as possible; 7.RECOGNIZES the magnitude of the damage inflicted during the conflict and the need for reconstruction efforts with appropriate international assistance once the conflict is ended and in this regard requests the Secretary General to assign a team of experts to study the question of reconstruction and to report to the Security Council; 8.FURTHER REQUESTS the Secretary General to examine in consultation with Iran and Iraq and with other states of the region measures to enhance the security and stability of the region; 9.REQUESTS the Secretary General to keep the Security Council informed on the implementation of this resolution; 10.DECIDES to meet again as necessary to consider further steps to insure compliance with this resolution.

title: Leader of Anglican Church Believes Waite Is Still Alive
description: The Archbishop of Canterbury said today that he had heard ''nothing whatever'' from the abductors of his Middle East envoy, Terry Waite, but that he remained convinced that Mr. Waite was alive.

title: SCANDALS POINT TO WEAKNESS IN REVIEW PROCESS
description: IN an ideal world, a study of children and cholesterol by Dr. Charles J. Glueck would never have seen the light of day. The system for preventing questionable findings from being published would have seen to that.

title: War-Crimes Defendant in Israel Changes Lawyer
description: John Demjanjuk, on trial here on charges that he committed war crimes as a Nazi death camp guard, formally dismissed his chief lawyer today, just one week before the defense is scheduled to start presenting its case.

title: CONVICTIONS REVERSED IN ISLAND SLAYING
description: An appeals court has ordered acquittals for three young men convicted of murder in the 1985 assassination of the President of Palau, an American-administered trust territory in the Western Pacific.

title: Warner's Earnings More Than Double
description: Warner Communications Inc. reported yesterday that its second-quarter net income more than doubled to $104.3 million, from $51.6 million a year earlier. Earnings per share rose to 68 cents, from 37 cents.

title: Holmes a Court Backs Texaco Filing
description: Robert Holmes a Court, the Australian investor who has acquired 9.6 percent of Texaco Inc.'s stock and is seeking more, said yesterday he fully supported Texaco's management in its bankruptcy filing.

title: OCCIDENTAL HINTS AT IBP SALE
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it was considering selling to the public a minority interest in IBP Inc., the nation's largest meat processor, which the oil company acquired in 1981 for $795 million.

title: EX-AMBASSADOR FLIES WORLD WAR II ROUTE
description: Thomas J. Watson Jr., a former United States Ambassador to Moscow, flew into Washington this morning on the final leg of an around-the-world commemorative flight that took him over the old Alaska-Siberia route he flew 45 years ago as an Army Air Corps captain ferrying planes to the Red Army.

title: DOW CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Jazz: Solomonic Quartet
description: THE Solomonic Quartet plays a kind of postmodern hard bop. The tunes are rooted in blues and gospel modes, with a vocalized, crying quality; the rhythms dance and strut. The group, which appeared last weekend at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street, has a deep, throaty sound even when Ahmed Abdullah, the group's trumpeter, and Chico Freeman, its tenor saxophonist, are playing in their higher registers. The dark resonance of Charles Moffet's tom-toms and Wilbur Morris's bass seem to pull the horn lines down into a lower, richer range.

title: ALCOHOL-RELATED DEATHS SEEN UNDERREPORTED

title: WARREN P. SMITH
description: Warren P. Smith, the vice president-counsel in the law department of the Home Life Insurance Company, died of complications resulting from AIDS on Saturday at his home in Union City, N.J. He was 35 years old.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tour de France Roche Takes Lead: Stephen Roche of Ireland captured the overall leader's yellow jersey yesterday after finishing second in the 19th stage of the Tour de France cycling race. Pedro Delgado of Spain won the 115-mile mountain leg from Valreas to Villard de Lans, sprinting away on the final ascent within a half-mile of the finish.

title: Soviet Fur Auction
description: The annual auction of millions of fur and lamb pelts began in Leningrad today with the purchase of mink pelts by an American company, the official Tass press agency said. The Soviet Foreign Trade Association is selling 2 million pelts during this year's four-day sale, including 76,000 sable pelts, the highest number ever offered in the auction's 106 years. The auction has drawn 260 buyers from 22 countries in Europe, Asia and the Americas. The first lot of 200 mink pelts was purchased by the Jindo Company of New York City for $64 a pelt.

In Italy, the Staid Is Now Stylish

The three-day trade show, held this month in the massive Fortezza da Basso complex in Florence, attracted many buyers from such American stores as Macy's and Bergdorf Goodman. Many said that in Italy, where men's fashions have long been experimental, staidness is news.

title: Crazy Salad

But Sunday afternoon, both summer and year-round residents went public when a grass-roots group called People Taking Action Against AIDS raised more than $100,000 at an afternoon lawn party and auction for the People With AIDS Coalition and the Long Island Association for AIDS Care.

Vorontsov, have accused the United States of erecting last-minute obstacles to an agreement on intermediate-range nuclear forces (I.N.F.). There are new obstacles, but they are not due to American positions. Our positions are consistent with the principles we have espoused since I.N.F.

Don't Even Think of Pardons Now

Oliver North, to re-invent a discredited tool of justice - the pre-emptive Presidential pardon. Its stated purpose is to forgive officers who are presumed innocent and who haven't been found guilty or even indicted. Its effect will be to prevent further investigation.

title: Comings and Goings

A trainer, Sally Bailie, couldn't think of a name for a 2-year-old filly. Then one day, she said, ''I saw a headline where Fawn Hall said, 'I did it all for Ollie.' '' The horse has another tie to recent events in Washington: The name of All for Ollie's sire is Shredder. . . . Ken Caminiti, the Houston Astros' third baseman who played his first major league game last Thursday, was named National League player of the week after batting .500 and hitting two home runs during his first week in the majors. . . . Bill Hanzlik of the Denver Nuggets underwent an emergency appendectomy yesterday after he developed abdominal pains at home. He was said to be in good condition.

A strategic hilltop, thick walls and crenelated turrets have all helped win some battles, but when Monticchiello was threatened with becoming a dump for toxic wastes, the villagers resorted to their favorite form of self-defense. They put on a play.

Two-thirds of the jobs are management, with the remainder being union personnel. The jobs will be eliminated in Kansas City, Mo.; Salt Lake City, and Spring, Tex., near Houston, and those terminated will receive severance arrangements to be announced Aug. 1, the company said.

2 British Airlines Give Merger Plan
description: British Airways and its smaller rival, British Caledonian, asked the Government to approve the merger plan they announced last week. The companies said it would create an airline large enough to compete with American carriers.

title: SHEARSON LEHMAN BROTHERS HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $27 million charge to cover potential losses on tin and non- recurring gains of $25 million from real estate transactions and the restructuring of a pension plan by Shearson's Boston co. unit. There are no share earnings for 1986 since the company was a wholly- owned subsidiary of American Express Co. at that time. Currently, American Express owns 60.6 percent of Shearson on a fully-diluted basis.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SPYCATCHER. The Candid Autobiography of a Senior Intelligence Officer. By Peter Wright. Illustrated. 392 pages.

title: Chess: Mednis Turns Back Gambit On Way to a First Place Tie
description: The Fifth Andorra International Open Tournament at Andorra La Vella in the Pyrenees ended in a tie for first place among the grandmasters John Fedorowicz of New York and Edmar Mednis of Queens and the international master Miodrag Todorcevic, formerly of Yugoslavia who now lives in Monaco.

title: TEXAS AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Kennedy Sees Project as Forerunner of U.S. 'Literacy Corps'
description: College students in Boston will teach children and adults to read as part of a privately financed program announced today by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who called it the beginning of a ''national literacy corps.''

title: SLAYER OF AGED WOMAN EXECUTED IN LOUISIANA AFTER APPEALS FAIL
description: Willie Celestine went to his death in Louisiana's electric chair today after apologizing to the family of Marceliane Richard, the 81-year-old woman he raped, beat and strangled six years ago.

title: UPJOHN CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split April 6.

title: Transactions
description: AUTO RACING

title: TRW INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a net gain of $11,000,000 from the sale of certain facilities. Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May 1987.

title: Careers; Optimism On Women Engineers
description: BRING on the women engineers! Apparently industry is serious. The Northrop Corporation insists that ''we have a long-term commitment as we look ahead to hire women engineers,'' according to John J. Richardson, senior vice president-human resources.

title: Link Brazil's Forests to Debt Relief
description: To the Editor:

title: Key PBS Station Lags In Fund-Raising Efforts
description: Contributions to WGBH, the public-television station here whose productions are a mainstay of public stations nationwide, lagged badly in fund-raising efforts in March, leading a national trend.

title: TRUSTCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The net for the year-ago periods is prior to an accounting change recorded for the first half of 1986. An additional $4 million, or 29 cents per share, was recorded for the first half of 1986 because of the accounting change.

title: INDEPENDENT BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FUQUA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $761,000 and a gain of $9,076,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, both from discontinued operations. The company said the gain from discontinued operations in the year- ago 6-month includes an after-tax gain of $11,171,000 from the sale of the company's investment in Triton Group Ltd. Year-ago results are restated for discontinued operations.

title: Significant Hormone Found
description: Scientists have discovered a long-sought hormone that transfers calcium from the bones to the bloodstream, sometimes in excessive amounts. The substance is expected to prove valuable in studies of cancer, osteoporosis and perhaps other major health problems.

title: ANOTHER MET FILL-IN EARNS A VICTORY
description: The Mets reached the ultimate stage in their pitching shortage last night: Terry Leach, the undefeated all-purpose replacement on a staff riddled with injuries, was himself disabled by torn cartilage in his right knee.

title: Manville Profit Increases 44.7%
description: The Manville Corporation today reported a 44.7 percent increase in second-quarter earnings and said it had accumulated enough cash to meet the initial obligations of its bankruptcy reorganization plan.

title: EGYPTIAN OFFICIAL URGES TALKS AS SHARON ACTS IN WEST BANK
description: The Egyptian Foreign Minister, making the first visit to Jerusalem by any Egyptian leader since the Israeli invasion of Lebanon in 1982, appealed today for Israel to take part in an international Middle East peace conference.

title: BALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $13.1 million from the sale of a commercial glass business and a charge of $4.2 million from startup costs of a metal container plant in West Germany. c-Includes a gain of $3.3 million from the sale of the company's PLM AB packaging concern. Year-ago quarter reflects a gain of $500,000 from the sale of a plastics plant.

title: FLORIDA COMMERCIAL BANKS INC (MIAMI) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Pop: Manu Dibango
description: MUSICIANS from French-speaking Africa, blending the rhythms and song forms of diverse tribal cultures in the recording studios of Paris, have created some of the freshest pop sounds of the last decade. But some 15 years ago, long before performers like Youssou N'Dour and Kassav were heard in the United States, a musician from French-speaking western Africa, based in Paris, was already affecting the sound and rhythmic direction of American dance music. His name was Manu Dibango and in the early 1970's his record ''Soul Makossa'' was one of the first big disco hits.

title: Elderly Man Shoots An Intruder in Head
description: An 71-year-old man who found a knife-wielding intruder in his Bronx home yesterday shot and critically wounded the man, the police said.

title: Poindexter Questioned on Conflicts With North's Testimony
description: Senator George J. Mitchell, a Maine Democrat, questioned Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter yesterday over the admiral's testimony and that of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. Following are excerpts of that exchange:

title: BLACK & DECKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,239,000 from the early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Networks Now Rotate Coverage of Hearings
description: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair will be televised live beginning at 9 A.M. on the NBC television network under the network rotation system. The hearings will also be televised on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on some local affiliates of PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service, including Channel 13 in New York.

title: MEASURING MATTINGLY'S ACHIEVEMENT
description: Now that Don Mattingly's home-run streak has ended, where does the record he shares with Dale Long rank among other batting accomplishments of its type?

title: ADMIRAL DISPUTES NORTH OVER MEMOS ON FUND DIVERSION
description: Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter today disputed Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's testimony that he had sent the admiral five different memorandums discussing the use of proceeds from Iran arms sales to support Nicaraguan rebels.

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER CO INC reports earnings for 12mo June 30
description: b-After a charge of $79,055,000 for losses on the Poston Plant and Zimmer Plant disallowance. The year-ago revenue has been restated because of the reclassification of certain sales to other utilities.

title: 'Liaisons' Closing Challenged
description: Efforts are under way to prevent the American producers of the Royal Shakespeare Company production of ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses'' from closing the show Sept. 6. But sources close to the discussions, which are expected to continue at a meeting this afternoon, expressed little hope yesterday that the decision would be reversed - despite the fact that a new American cast for the show reportedly would have been headed by the well-known actors Glenn Close, Kevin Spacey and Kelly McGillis.

title: MICRO BIO-MEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $14,000 and $59,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $27,000 and $34,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Which will burn more calories, a 20-minute walk immediately after dinner or a 20-minute walk three hours later?

title: AFFILIATED PUBLICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $41.5 million on the sale of discontinued operations of an affiliate and an extraordinary credit from an affiliate of $17,879,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $104,000 and $972,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Results for the latest quarter and 6-month includes the operations of Billboard Publications Inc. from May 1. The company said the recent period special gains reflect the sale of Cable Television properties by McCaw Communications Co., in which aaffiliated Publications owns 45 percent interest.

title: Burlington Cuts 525 Jobs
description: Burlington Industries, in its first major action since undertaking a $2.9 billion leveraged buyout to prevent a hostile takeover, said today it would lay off 525 employees.

title: ABITIBI-PRICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect a change in accounting for pension costs. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: I.B.M. Computers
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said that two versions of its newest mid-range computers, the 9370, were being shipped two months earlier than planned. The machine, the smallest of I.B.M.'s System/370 family of mainframes, is considered a key element in the company's plan to regain its position in the mid-range computer market, where I.B.M.'s sales have suffered severely. The first shipment was to the Hartford-based Phoenix Insurance Company, from I.B.M.'s plant in Endicott, N.Y., the company said.

title: A Soviet Fix for NASA's Blunder
description: With the space shuttle grounded, so are many American space cargoes. Into the vacuum created by NASA's mismanagement the Soviet Union has now stepped with an offer to launch American communications satellites at cut-rate prices. Can the United States afford to accept it?

title: AHMANSON, H F & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflects a charge of $13,400,000 for the writeoff of the company's $24,020,000 investment in the secondary reserve of the Federal Savings & Loan Insurance Corp.; a charge of $5,697,000 resulting from a $10,173,000 increase in the provision for loan losses; and gains of $7 million, or 7 cents a share, on sale of adjustable- rate mortgages. c-Reflects a charge of $2,576,000 from a boost in its loan-loss provision; and gains of $32.8 million, or 34 cents a share on sale of adjustable-rate mortgages.

title: Becoming the Thing We Fear the Most
description: To the Editor:

title: NORWICH SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank went public in November.

title: Forbes Column Ended As Research Is Doubted
description: Forbes magazine announced yesterday that its longtime business psychology columnist, Srully Blotnick, had discontinued his column, a feature that frequently cited research findings based on what Mr. Blotnick said were extensive interviews and surveys.

title: Southland, JT Revise Accord
description: The Southland Corporation and the JT Acquisition Corporation, the concern formed to acquire Southland, said today that they had slightly revised their previously announced $5.1 billion merger agreement. JT Acquisition is an affiliate of the Thompson Company, a private investment firm owned by the Thompson family, the descendants of Southland's founder, Joe C. Thompson Sr. Under the amended agreement, JT Acquisition would no longer require that 1.3 million Southland Series A preferred shares be tendered, although the offer of $90.27 in cash for all of the 2.5 million preferred shares is still in effect. The offer of $77 a share in cash for 31.5 million common shares, or about two-thirds of the stock, remains unchanged.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: BRUNSWICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 9.

title: Queens Parolee Held in Murder of Parole Officer
description: A man described by a prosecutor as a ''drug kingpin'' in Queens was charged yesterday with contracting for the murder of a New York State parole officer.

title: HUNGARY RAISES CONSUMER PRICES
description: The Government of Hungary's new Prime Minister, Karoly Grosz, today implemented a far-reaching set of price increases on consumer commodities and services.

title: GREECE UNVAILS U.S. LETTER ENDING RIFT OVER TERROR
description: The Greek Government made public a letter from the United States Government today that was intended to end the friction over accusations that Greek officials had contacts with representatives of an Arab terrorist group.

title: 4 Are Killed and 11 Injured in Propane Explosion in Brooklyn
description: A thunderous explosion, triggered when workers dropped a propane tank down a basement stairwell, tore through three buildings in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn yesterday morning, killing 4 men, injuring 11 other people and setting off a frenzied hunt for trapped survivors.

title: COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Enhanced Image Is Aim Of New World Group
description: The troika that heads New World Pictures Ltd. - two entertainment lawyers and a career studio executive - is working to shake its reputation as makers of such grade-B movies as ''Reform School Girls'' and ''Godzilla 1985.''

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago second quarter and 6 months' results have been restated to include three banks acquired in pooling-of-interests transactions during 1987.

title: Little Gain Reported In NBC Negotiations
description: An effort to negotiate an end to the strike by 2,800 of NBC's writers, producers and technicians has failed after two days to bring the two sides closer together, and representatives from the striking union as well as the network said the prospects for agreement looked bleak.

title: Lesson in Pastrami
description: To The Living Section:

title: UNITED TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a special one-time charge of $108,500,000 related to the company's share of U.S. Sprint Communications Co. c-Net income

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHENEVER I offer a recipe for sauteed pork, mainly pork chops, I am besieged by letters from readers complaining that their versions turned out tough. This might be attributed to the quality of the meat. There is no way to determine the precise quality of a pork chop by looking at it; the truth is in the cooking.

title: H.J.K. Assignment
description: Henry J. Kaufman & Associates, a foreign-owned, Washington-based advertising and public relations firm, will be doing the advertising for the College Student Trainee Program of the Central Intelligence Agency. H.J.K.'s parent company is Shanwick, a publicly held London public relations company.

title: Astro's 4-2 Victory Ends Expo Streak
description: Danny Darwin threw a five-hitter over eight-plus innings, Alan Ashby hit a run-scoring double and Jose Cruz added a run-scoring single tonight, leading the Houston Astros to a 4-2 victory that ended the eight-game winning streak of the Montreal Expos.

title: JOHN QUINCY ADAMS, A DESCENDANT OF PRESIDENTS
description: John Quincy Adams, a descendent of two United States Presidents, died today at his home in Dover, Mass. He was 64 years old.

title: FIRST INTERSTATE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter includes a $500 million increase to the company's loan loss allowance to cover possible future chargeoffs of loans to lesser developed countries, and another $250 million provision for losses anticipated from an accelerated program to sell non-performing domestic loans and foreclosed property. The latest quarter also includes tax benefits of $225 million relating to the $750 million of provisions.

title: MUSIC: BEAUX ARTS TRIO
description: THE Beaux Arts Trio moved into Avery Fisher Hall Monday evening as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival and delivered a performance of uncommon grace. Menahem Pressler, pianist; Isidore Cohen, violinist, and Bernard Greenhouse, cellist, have been together for 32 years and by now they virtually blink together. Tempos ebb and flow, dynamics shift abruptly, but not the slightest hitch occurs. It is all second nature for the musicians, who seem to share a cool and elegant vision of the music they present.

title: Falling Machinery Kills Jersey Worker
description: One worker was killed and another was injured at a milling company yesterday when a 3,500-pound piece of machinery they were moving toppled onto them, the police said.

title: HART'S SUPPORTERS WIN A RULING ON HIS DEBT
description: Nearly $30,000 in contributions seized at a Hollywood fund-raising gathering for Gary Hart's 1988 Presidential campaign cannot be used to help pay his 1984 campaign debts, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: AMERICAN BRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said its latest second quarter and 6-month net income benefited substantially from a lower federal income tax rate and higher exchange rates for the British pound. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid last September.

title: AMOCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Street Heat, and Life
description: To walk around New York on a hot summer day is to realize just how old-fashioned a place it is, and how noisily human. In more modern, Sun Belt cities - Houston, perhaps, or Phoenix - serious summer heat forces windows shut to keep in the air-conditioned chill.

title: Henley Plans to Lift Santa Fe Holdings
description: The Henley Group Inc. said today that it would seek permission from Government regulators to increase its stake in the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation to 25 percent, from 5 percent.

title: On Medical Costs; Treat AIDS the Public-Private Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Kodak to Sell Fox Photo Assets
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it plans to sell the retail division of its Fox Photo Inc. unit, which it acquired last December. Kodak agreed to sell to the current Fox Photo president, Carl D. Newton 3d, whose grandfather founded Fox in 1905. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The retail divison includes 211 one-hour labs and 256 kiosks and camera shops in 23 states.

title: U.S. WARSHIPS SET TO BEGIN ESCORTS OF GULF TANKERS
description: A convoy of three Navy warships and two Kuwaiti tankers stood ready today to enter the Strait of Hormuz and traverse the Persian Gulf, inaugurating an expanded and more active American military presence.

title: We Can't Dictate the Future of the Persian Gulf
description: To the Editor:

title: CARTERET SAVINGS BANK FA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $6,529,000 for the quarter and $16,031,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also had a charge of $407,000 for the early extinguishment of debt.

title: UNOCAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue figures include consumer excise taxes of $202.2 million and $337.2 million for the latest quarter and 6 months, respectively, and $144.1 million and $277.9 million for the comparable year-ago periods, respectively.

title: KNIGHT-RIDDER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest second quarter results include a pretax loss of $2.1 million from the sale of HPBooks announced last month.

title: Europe's Plan To Cut Steel
description: The European Community commission today approved a $7 billion plan to restructure the European steel industry that could result in the loss of about 80,000 jobs.

title: SMOKING A PRIZE CATCH: NOT A TASK FOR THE TIMID
description: MOST fishermen know that no fish tastes finer than the one you have caught yourself, whether it's a trout from a mountain stream, mackerel off a dock in Maine or a fighting bluefish like those John Hersey catches off Martha's Vineyard and describes in his fine new book ''Blues.''

title: TEXAS LEGISLATURE APPROVES TAX INCREASE OF $5.7 BILLION
description: The Texas Legislature today approved a $5.7 billion increase in taxes, ending a year of fiscal turmoil brought on by the devastating downturn in the oil industry.

title: U.S. and Japan in Accord on 'Star Wars' Research
description: The United States and Japan signed an agreement today that will allow Japanese companies and research centers to take part in the Reagan Administration's program to design defenses against nuclear missiles.

title: SQUIBB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $2.7 million for the quarter, and for the 6 months includes income of $6.2 million, or 5 cents a share, from discontinued operations. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split payable to shareholders of record June 1.

title: CHRISTO IN JAPAN: HE'S AT IT AGAIN, AND AGAIN IT'S NEW
description: Christo, the artist who wrapped Paris's Pont Neuf in golden cloth and Miami's Biscayne Bay islands in pink, now plans to dot Japan with blue umbrellas.

title: CONGRESSIONAL INVESTIGATORS SAY WHITE HOUSE USED DECEPTION TO PAD STAFF ILLEGALLY
description: An investigative agency of Congress says the Reagan Administration violated Federal laws and misled Congress by padding the White House staff with political employees officially assigned to other Government departments.

title: A Face on a Poster
description: What is apparently the first political poster inspired by the Iran-contra hearings features not Lieut. Col. Oliver North but Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the Nicaraguan leader. Citizens for Reagan, a lobbying group that favors aid to the Nicaraguan contras in their effort to oust Mr. Ortega, has printed 5,000 ''Wanted'' handbills carrying his picture and yesterday began distributing them to Congressional offices.

title: Mississippi Barges Stalled
description: It will take until Sunday for a dredge to clear away a 3,000-foot sandbar that has stalled hundreds of loaded barges on the Mississippi River, officials of the Army Corps of Engineers said today. A dredge was being sent from St. Paul. Low water in the river and shifting sand blocked the channel Sunday.

title: 350 Workers to Be Idled as Dairy In Queens Orders Its Plant Closed
description: A month after most of its assets were acquired by a Canadian beer and food conglomerate, Queens Farm Dairy -one of the oldest and largest milk processors in New York City - has ordered the closing of its remaining plant and the dismissal of 350 workers.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June.

title: Hell Hath No Conflict Like the Political Wife
description: Conventional wisdom has it that the political wife is a self-sacrificing helpmate who devotes her life to raising the children and promoting her husband's career.

title: Roll-Call on Trade Bill
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today approved sweeping trade legislation: FOR THE MEASURE - 71 Democrats - 52 dams, Wash. Baucus, Mont. Bentsen, Tex. Biden, Del. Bingaman, N.M. Boren, Okla. Bradley, N.J. Breaux, La. Bumpers, Ark. Burdick, N.D. Byrd, W.Va. Chiles, Fla. Conrad, N.D. Cranston, Calif. Daschle, S.D.; DeConcini, Ariz. Dixon, Ill. Dodd, Conn. Exon, Neb. Ford, Ky. Fowler, Ga. Glenn, Ohio Graham, Fla. Harkin, Iowa Heflin, Ala. Hollings, S.C. Inouye, Hawaii Johnston, La. Kennedy, Mass. Kerry, Mass. Lautenberg, N.J. Leahy, Vt. Levin, Mich. Matsunaga, Hawaii Melcher, Mont. Metzenbaum, Ohio Mikulski, Md. Mitchell, Me. Moynihan, N.Y. Nunn, Ga. Pell, R.I. Proxmire, Wis. Pryor, Ark. Reid, Nev. Riegle, Mich. Rockefeller, W. Va. Sanford, N.C. Sarbanes, Md. Sasser, Tenn. Shelby, Ala. Stennis, Miss. Wirth, Colo. Republicans - 19 Bond, Mo. Chafee, R.I. Cohen, Me. D'Amato, N.Y. Danforth, Mo. Grassley, Iowa Heinz, Pa. Karnes, Neb. Kasten, Wis.
