Stevens, Alaska. Symms, Idaho Wallop, Wyo Wilson, Calif. Senators Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, and Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, did not vote.

title: Christo in Japan: He's at It Again, and Again It's New
description: TOKYO, July 21  Christo, the artist who wrapped Paris's Pont Neuf in golden cloth and Miami's Biscayne Bay islands in pink, now plans to dot Japan with blue umbrellas.

title: NATIONAL STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss National Steel, formerly a division of National Intergroup, is a joint venture between National Intergroup Inc. and Nippon Kokan KK of Japan.

title: Some Blue Cross Rates to Rise 25% in Jersey
description: About 1.7 individual and small-group subscribers of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey will have their premiums increased by 25 percent starting Sept. 1, the State Insurance Commissioner, Kenneth D. Merin, said today.

title: Holmes a Court And Texaco
description: THE solid support proclaimed this week by Robert Holmes a Court for the way Texaco Inc. has responded to its dispute with the Pennzoil Company underscores the Wall Street consensus that Texaco has gained the upper hand.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JULY 22, 1987
description: International A2-13

title: United Jersey Deal
description: United Jersey Banks of Princeton, N.J., said it would acquire the First Valley Corporation of Bethlehem, Pa., in an exchange of stock. Under an agreement signed by the two bank companies, United Jersey will issue 1.45 common shares for each First Valley common share. First Valley has 6.3 million shares outstanding. Based on United Jersey's closing price of $27.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, the deal would have a value of about $250 million. United Jersey has been granted warrants to purchase up to 24.9 percent of First Valley's common stock. United Jersey has $8.2 billion in assets and 195 offices throughout New Jersey. First Valley, which has 50 branches in Pennsylvania, has $1.3 billion in assets.

title: Twins Edge Yankees in 9th, 2-1
description: Under the teflon-coated fiberglass roof, at the end of the rarest of evenings in the place nicknamed the Homerdome - would you believe a pitchers' duel - the Yankees tonight failed to win the type of game that a team in a pennant race cannot afford to lose.

title: Rethinking the U.S.-Japan Alliance
description: LEAD: Even if it does not seem so these days, Japan is a military ally of the United States. There are, of course, American military bases in Japan. Both countries have a decades-old mutual security treaty that requires America to come to Japan's defense if it is attacked. And now Japan is participating in the Strategic Defense Initiative.

title: 13 Seized in Brooklyn In Waterfront Inquiry
description: Law-enforcement officials yesterday announced the arrests of 13 dockworkers in Brooklyn, including several members of the International Longshoremen's Association, on charges that included loan sharking, gambling, drug selling, grand larceny and bribe receiving.

title: IRVING BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The latest second quarter includes a provision for credit losses of $241 million, compared with a provision of $20 million in the year-ago period. The bank said the income tax benefit applicable to the second quarter provision for credit losses is $64 million.

title: BEHIND FRENCH-IRANIAN FEUD: AN IRAQI BOND
description: France's current conflict with Iran, which has led to a break in relations and differences over the repatriation of diplomats, stems at least in part from an alliance it formed with the Iraqi regime of President Saddam Hussein more than a decade ago.

title: Dr. Bruce S. Schoenberg, 44, Expert in the Nervous System
description: Dr. Bruce Stuart Schoenberg, a specialist in the prevention and control of neurological disorders, died of cancer July 14 at the Bethesda Naval Hospital. He was 44 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: 6 Major Banks Post Big Losses
description: Four more New York-based money-center banking companies - Citicorp, Manufacturers Hanover, Bankers Trust and Irving Bank - reported yesterday that they had huge second-quarter losses following their previously announced decisions to set aside additional reserves for losses on Latin American loans.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Calvin Hill, the former pro football running back, has been appointed to the Baltimore Orioles' board of directors. Hill works as a financial consultant for athletes and entertainers. . . . Mike McEwen, the veteran National Hockey League defenseman, has signed a contract to play next season in Switzerland. McEwen had been offered a one-year contract for next season by the Whalers. . . . George Raveling, the Southern Cal coach, was named assistant to John Thompson of Georgetown on the coaching staff of the United States Olympic men's basketball team.

title: Regan in Japan
description: Donald T. Regan, the former White House chief of staff who is said to have helped select Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter as the national security adviser, takes his turn behind the Iran-contra witness table next week. But this week he is in Japan, delivering speeches, seminars and interviews and playing a bit of golf.

title: Volcker Sees Price Danger
description: In one of his last appearances before Congress as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker today again sounded the alarm on a theme that has made him famous - the possibility of renewed inflation in the United States economy.

title: U.S. Premier Of Shostakovich Work
description: The United States premiere of a work by Dmitri Shostakovich will be on the program for the opening concert of the American Symphony Orchestra's 25th season, Oct. 18 at Carnegie Hall.

title: Reagan Trip to Wisconsin
description: President Reagan, continuing his campaign for an ''economic bill of rights,'' will visit a kitchen products factory, a restaurant and a park in Wisconsin on Monday, it was announced today. The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said that the President would make stops at the Broan Manufacturing Company in Hartford, at the Old Washington House restaurant in West Bend and at Lower Lake Park in Port Washington.

title: 305,000 Aliens Are Seeking U.S. Legal Status
description: About 305,000 aliens have sought legal status under the new immigration law, according to Federal officials. They deny that applications are below what they expected and that aliens are fearful of seeking legal status.

title: Top Ranger Draftee Injured in Game
description: Brian Leetch, a defenseman who was the Rangers' No. 1 selection in the 1986 National Hockey League draft, was knocked out of action early in the opening game of the hockey tournament of the Olympic Sports Festival.

title: IRAN IS HARSH
description: Iran and Iraq had sharply conflicting reactions today to a new United Nations effort to stop the war between them, and Iran accused Iraq of initiating new fighting.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday, about companies that recently sold stock to the public for the first time, incorrectly listed the share price of one of them, the Timberland Company. Its shares fell 12.5 cents on Monday, to $15.50, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Mozambique Says Rightist Guerrillas Massacred 380 Civilians
description: Anti-Government rebels massacred 380 people at a coastal town in Inhambane province last weekend, the official news agency, A.I.M., said today.

title: Carter Petitions N.F.L.
description: The National Football League has received a petition filed on behalf of Cris Carter, seeking an immediate supplemental draft for the Ohio State all-America wide receiver, who was declared ineligible because he signed with an agent two years ago.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DANILOV THE VIOLIST, by Vladimir Orlov. Translated by Antonina W. Bouis. 307 pages. William Morrow. $18.95.

title: BOATMEN'S BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''The welfare system that was designed decades ago no longer works in a country that has produced a permanent dependent class.'' - Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. (A23:1.)

title: Big Board's Uncovered Short Sales Rise
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered in the month ended July 15 rose 17.8 million, or 3.8 percent, to a record 483.6 million shares. The previous high of 470.6 million shares was set in the month ended April 15. The year-earlier period totaled 368.6 million shares.

title: Jets Sign Top Choice
description: Roger Vick, a fullback from Texas A&M who was the Jets' first-round draft choice, has signed a series of one-year contracts, the team announced yesterday. Terms of the contract were not released.

title: Facing the Ayatollah
description: To the Editor:

title: REFUGEES FLEE LEBANON FIGHT
description: Hundreds of Palestinians have fled their homes in refugee districts in Tyre in southern Lebanon after new fighting started this week between Shiite militiamen and guerrillas of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: GTE Has 27.7% Drop; United Telecom Deficit
description: The GTE Corporation, the giant telecommunications concern, reported yesterday that its second-quarter profits fell 27.7 percent, hurt mainly by continuing losses at U S Sprint Communications, the long-distance telephone company that it owns jointly with United Telecommunications Inc.

title: MCDONALD'S CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings are restated for the 3-for-2 common stock split. The systemwide sales represent sales by company-operated, franchised and affiliated restaurants.

title: Argentina and Brazil Begin Nuclear Discussions
description: The President of Brazil has visited a sensitive Argentine nuclear installation in an unusual move that American officials hope will help prevent the spread of nuclear weapons to South America.

title: IN SOVIET: RUBLES, COUPONS AND 'REAL MONEY'
description: Muscovites with ''check coupons,'' a special currency available to Soviet citizens who work abroad, had a choice Monday morning of the latest Toshiba and Panasonic color television sets at the electronics store on Astrakhansky Pereulok.

title: Resorts' Pan Am Stake
description: Resorts International Inc., which on Monday said that it had sold the common shares it owns in the Pan Am Corporation, said that at the end of trading Monday it still held the equivalent of a 3.1 percent stake in Pan Am. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Resorts said it held $37.9 million worth of Pan Am debentures and less than 1 percent of Pan Am's common shares. The Pan Am debentures are convertible into 4,356,321 Pan Am common shares at a conversion price of $8.70 a share, according to the hotel and casino chain.

title: ROCKWELL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a change in the method of accounting for the cost of pension plans in the United States which increased income before taxes by $50.1 million and $151.5 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a reduction in electronics operating earnings of amortization of intangible assets and goodwill related to Allen-Bradley of $23 million and $71 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, as compared with $25 million and $75 million, respectively, for the comparable 1986 periods. Share earnings include the effects of the company's common stock repurchase programs and have been adjusted to reflect the April 1987 Class A common stock dividend distribution which was equivalent to a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: School Coaches Commit a Foul
description: Two assistant basketball coaches who resorted to extreme measures to teach unruly players a lesson were indefinitely suspended from their jobs at Sunny Hills High School in Fullerton, Calif., yesterday.

title: Chrysler Profit, Off 12%, Tops Wall St. Forecasts
description: The Chrysler Corporation today reported second-quarter earnings of $428.7 million, or $2 a share, exceeding Wall Street's expectations.

title: Bennett Tribute Postponed
description: A tribute to the late director-choreographer Michael Bennett, originally scheduled for Monday at the Shubert Theater, has been postponed until the fall. A date will be set when Bob Avian, Mr. Bennett's longtime assistant, returns from staging a London production of ''Follies.'' Mr. Avian is to supervise the arrangements.

title: Bridge: World Champions Defeated In Vanderbilt Knockout Play
description: A stunning upset marked the second day of Vanderbilt Knockout Team play at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here Monday. Four reigning world champions, top-seeded in the event, lost to the 64th-seeded team by a margin of 22 international match points.

title: An Electronics Pioneer Hunts for Profits
description: STANFORD R. OVSHINSKY'S moment of truth as a business man is at hand. It has been almost 20 years since he startled physicists by making an electronic switch out of a glass-like amorphous material, thus drawing worldwide attention to his claim that such materials had valuable energy-handling properties they had overlooked during the crystal-based electronics revolution.

title: Raider End Arrested
description: Elvis Franks of the Los Angeles Raiders was arrested in Warrensville Heights, Ohio, yesterday on a charge of possession of cocaine with intent to distribute. Franks, 30 years old, who lives in the Cleveland suburb of South Euclid, attempted to sell the drug to an undercover agent, according to the F.B.I. The 6-4, 250-pound defensive end played with the Cleveland Browns from 1980 to 1984. He was with the Raiders and Jets last season, then signed again with the Raiders.

title: Who's on Third? Mets Finally Know
description: In their season of surprises and setbacks, the Mets seem to be making one great discovery these days: Howard Johnson, the 78th man to play third base in the club's 26-year history, may also be the best.

title: FIRST BOSTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $618,000 for the quarter and a gain of $13,754,000 for the 6 months, both from equity in an affiliate. c-Net income d-Includes gains of $7,692,000 and $18,147,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from equity in an affiliate.

title: Strawberry Guides Children
description: Judging from Darryl Strawberry's comments yesterday morning at a clinic for youngsters at Shea Stadium, the recent turmoil between the Mets' right fielder and a few of his teammates is still fresh in his mind.

title: KRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $19.4 million for the quarter and $71.5 million for the 6 months.

title: STAGE: ORWELL'S '1984'
description: AT the second-act climax of ''1984,'' the images, sounds and lights that play so large a part in the staging of George Orwell's novel at the Joyce Theater come together for terrific impact. Winston Smith is in Room 101 of Oceania's Love Ministry, where ''the worst thing in the world'' happens to those who have been thinking the wrong thoughts. The clamor, the disorienting lights, the flashing pictures on the screen that dominates Phillip Graneto's junk-metal-bordered set converge in an attack on Winston, driving toward the horrible moment when he betrays his love and himself.

title: FAKE ART PRINTS: BIG BUSINESS GETTING BIGGER
description: A network of art publishers and dealers in the United States and Europe is selling millions of dollars worth of fake lithographs, engravings and other fine-art prints each year to would-be collectors around the country, according to leading auction houses, legitimate print dealers and law-enforcement officials.

title: Talks About Sri Lanka Held in Southern India
description: Indian officials held talks in the southern Indian city of Madras today with Tamil leaders on new proposals to resolve the ethnic conflict in Sri Lanka, Indian and Sri Lankan officials said.

title: WNET TO BE ON AIR AROUND THE CLOCK
description: WNET, Channel 13, trying to rebound from years of financial crisis and conflicting visions of the station's purpose, plans to expand its broadcasting operations to a 24-hour schedule starting in mid-September, station officials said yesterday.

title: PAKISTAN REPORTS A NUCLEAR INQUIRY
description: Pakistan announced today that it had begun an investigation into an attempt to export American material to Pakistan illegally for potential use in making nuclear weapons.

title: REAGAN THREATENS A MEDICARE VETO
description: President Reagan said today that he would veto a bill on Medicare insurance against catastrophic illness that is being pushed by House Democrats if it reached his desk in its present form. But his spokesman raised the possibility of a compromise.

title: London Expels a Bulgarian, Apparently for Spy Activities
description: Britain ordered today that the Bulgarian military attache be expelled for activities ''incompatible with his status,'' the usual diplomatic code for espionage.

title: AIDES SAY BUSH EFFORT HAS RAISED $10 MILLION
description: Aides to Vice President Bush said today that their boss, the leading Republican Presidential candidate, had already raised more than $10 million and that this revenue provided a clear financial and tactical advantage over potential rivals.

title: First Boston Buys a Firm
description: The First Boston Corporation announced yesterday that it had bought Kaplan, Smith & Associates, a consulting firm that specializes in the savings and loan industry. The purchase price was not disclosed. The acquisition was part of

title: BAYBANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included net of $1.5 million from the receipt of back interest on a loan that previously had been a non-performing asset. c-After a gain of $4,820,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Kenya Accused of Torture in Drive on Dissidents
description: The police in Kenya have tortured hundreds of people suspected of opposing the Government during a 16-month-old crackdown on a dissident Marxist group, Amnesty International charged today.

title: JAPANESE ROLE IN 'STAR WARS' MAY BE SMALL
description: Now that Japanese companies are free to participate in the Reagan Administration's space-based antimissile program, the question is how many companies will do so.

title: RICHARD EGAN, FILM ACTOR, DIES AT 65
description: Richard Egan, known for his roles as a tough leading man in action films and westerns, died of prostate cancer Monday at St. John's Cancer Center in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 65 years old.

title: KEY RATES
SIMON, IN NEW YORK, GOES ON A DAYLONG HUNT FOR CAMPAIGN CASH
description: Senator Paul Simon took time out from campaigning for votes in Iowa and New Hampshire to campaign for money in New York and New Jersey yesterday.

title: Figure in 1934 Controversy Involving Huey Long Is Dead
description: Jesse H. Cutrer Jr., one of seven journalism students thrown out of Louisiana State University in a censorship dispute involving Huey P. Long, died Sunday in a Jackson, Miss., hospital. He was 72 years old. As editor of The Daily Reveille at Louisiana State, Mr. Cutrer was at the center of a 1934 controversy over a letter to the editor that was indirectly critical of Long, then a United States Senator. Long, who had been Governor of the state, saw an advance copy of the letter and ordered the school's president, James Monroe Smith, to suppress it.

title: Planned Parenthood Doesn't Advocate Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Anthony Casamento Is Dead; Received the Medal of Honor
description: Anthony Casamento, a former United States Marine corporal in World War II whose persistent efforts to win the Medal of Honor were finally rewarded in 1980, died of cancer Saturday at Veterans Medical Center in Northport, N.Y. He was 66 years old and lived in West Islip, L.I.

title: Goetz Verdict Spreads False Notion About White-on-Black Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: STATUS OF WOMEN RISES BUT PAY LAGS, STUDY FINDS
description: American women are achieving record earnings, political influence and participation in the labor force but, on average, are still paid far less than men, according to a comprehensive study released today by women in Congress.

title: CAPITAL CITITES/ABC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $279,996,000, or $17.33 a share. The company said the year-ago 6-month gain is from sale of certain broadcasting properties that were directly related to the acquisition of ABC.

title: People
description: * Thomas E. Beach has been promoted to senior vice president, McCann-Erickson.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in Science Times July 6 on the discovery of dinosaur eggs in Canada referred incorrectly to previous similar discoveries. The first such finds were made in Mongolia in 1923.

title: How Many Watch What
description: As part of its annual study of media and markets, the Simmons Market Research Bureau surveyed television sports viewing habits of adults for 1986 and found professional football scored a narrow victory over major-league baseball. The poll, which asked for televised sports programs that viewers watch ''frequently or almost always,'' was conducted through questionnaires returned by 19,146 people, whose replies were used to project nationwide totals. The top 10: Viewers Sport (in millions) 1. Pro football 63.2 2. Baseball 62.7 3. College football 48.9 4. Boxing 37.2 5. College basketball 36.2 6. Pro basketball 34.7 7. Pro wrestling 28.8 8. Bowling 28.6 9. Tennis 26.3 10. Auto racing 25.8

title: 'RASPUTIN,' AN ORIGINAL ON CITY OPERA SCHEDULE
description: Amid the rubble of aborted projects and failed commissions, New York's major opera houses do - contrary to current opinion - occasionally try again. It will surprise many, for example, that the New York City Opera has not only commissioned a new opera but also already received the (almost) finished project. Jay Reise's ''Rasputin'' has been confidently placed on the house's schedule for next year.

title: MUSIC: MEHTA CONDUCTS FINAL PARK CONCERT
description: ZUBIN MEHTA'S yearlong sabbatical as music director of the New York Philharmonic has hardly meant a complete rupture with the orchestra. He has participated in administrative decisions, he led a concert last month at Avery Fisher Hall primarily for delegates to the annual American Symphony Orchestra League convention, and Monday night he conducted the final Philharmonic parks concert of the summer.

title: MANUFACTURERS HANOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Both latest periods reflect the impact of the company's previously announced decision to increase the reserve for possible loan losses by $1.7 billion. The results for the latest periods reflect a tax benefit of $238.7 million as a result of the increase in the reserve. Those results also include a gain of $12.8 million from the sale of two residences in Japan. The year-ago results include gains of $171.7 million from the sale of Manufacturers Hanover Mortgage Corp. and $18.7 million from the purchase of annuities in connection with the consolidation of an employee benefit plan.

title: HAMILTON SCOLDS ADMIRAL ON CHECKS AND BALANCES
description: At the conclusion of yesterday's session, Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, the chairman of the House committee, addressed Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter about his testimony during the hearings.

title: In the Senate, Once More Unto the Breach
description: The trade bill that the Senate finally passed tonight, 71 to 27, has traveled a tortured legislative path. In part this was because of the unusually high political stakes. But the maneuvers and counterplays, the trade-offs and reversals, also reflected business as usual in a Senate that is increasingly difficult to run.

title: Delores Martin, 72, Is Dead; Broadway Actress and Singer
description: Delores Martin, an actress and singer, died Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. She was 72 years old.

title: LAND-USE FIGHT SHIFTS TO CALIFORNIA'S DESERT
description: Legislation introduced today to protect large swaths of California desert is touching off another battle in the long land war between conservationists and the Reagan Administration.

title: STORAGE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain on the disposition of discontinued operations of $6.5 million for both periods; a tax credit of $4,987,000 and $9,315,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; and the quarter includes the accrual of $9.6 million in interest on new debentures to be issued to creditors, a one- time gain of $4.7 million from settlement of litigation of a computer partnership and an estimated $4.1 million in additional costs related to the windup of reorganization activities. c-Includes a gain from renegotiation of a contract of $2,595,000 for both periods, and a tax credit of $4,726,000 and $6,731,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Share earnings are fully-diluted to reflect the planned issuance July 28 of about 192 million additional common shares as part of the company's reorganization plan.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The British Petroleum Company said yesterday that it planned to raise $:1.5 billion ($2.4 billion) by the sale of new stock. It will use the proceeds to reduce its debt.

title: Portugal's Passage
description: The democratic revolution now shaking up much of the world announced itself first in Portugal in April 1974. Not until this week, however, long after the consolidation of newer democratic regimes in Greece, Spain and Latin America, did Western Europe's poorest, least developed country reach a key democratic milestone: the election of a stable majority Government. After 16 wobbly coalition Cabinets in 13 often disillusioning years, the center-right Social Democrats of Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva have won a solid mandate for four full years of consistent, and accountable, rule.

title: A Sham Banking Bill
description: LEAD: Congress is on the verge of passing the first major banking bill since 1982. For taxpayers, the most important aspect of the bill addresses the growing number of insolvent savings and loan associations whose deposits are guaranteed by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. The bill is a sham.

title: FILE AND FORGET?
description: The real danger of the present inquiry into the Administration's covert warfare operations is that, after all the painful analysis, the conclusions will be filed and forgotten. This is what has happened in the past. We need to refresh our memories.

title: A Nation Incredibly Hooked on Hyperbole
description: To the Editor:

title: Lady's Secret Sets Earnings Record
description: The old gray mare may not be what she used to be, but Lady's Secret today became the richest filly or mare in racing history by scoring a seven-length victory in a minor allowance race at Monmouth Park.

title: PANEL PUTS ELLIOTT ABRAMS UNDER OATH TO TESTIFY
description: Elliott Abrams, the Assistant Secretary of State in charge of Latin American affairs, appeared before a Congressional committee today to discuss loans for the Chilean Government. His appearance prompted one Congressman to walk out and several others to insist he be put under oath.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JULY 22, 1987
description: The Economy

title: U.S. Adds 99 Sites to Toxic Cleanup Program
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today added 99 hazardous waste sites to its list of those eligible for a Federal cleanup program, including the first Federal facilities placed on the agency's priority cleanup agenda.

title: SLAVA H. LEVI
description: Slava H. Levi, a volunteer reader for the visually impaired, died of cancer of the pancreas Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 67 years old.

title: Kraft Profit Declines 6.9%
description: Kraft Inc. said today that net income in the second quarter fell 6.9 percent, largely because of a previously announced restructuring in which Kraft divested itself of most of its nonfood operations.

title: Loss Posted By First Boston
description: The First Boston Corporation said yesterday that it lost $13.2 million in the second quarter because of trading losses it suffered during the turbulence in the bond market last April, one of the toughest months on Wall Street in years.

title: Webb May Split Into 2
description: The Del E. Webb Corporation, a major real estate developer and casino operator, said it was considering splitting into two public companies or selling off portions of the parent.

title: SCOTT PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REALISM OF THE COURTROOM CAPTIVATES TV AUDIENCES
description: JEROME BECKER - veteran of New York City's Criminal Court, distinguished alumnus of the Family Court, respected partner in a respected law firm - has a confession to make. He watches ''The People's Court.''

title: Channel Tunnel Gets Legislative Go-Ahead
description: Parliament approved the Channel Tunnel Bill today, clearing the way for an $8 billion project to build a rail tunnel between Britain and France.

title: Two Unalike Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: Inquiry Is Ordered In a Hospital Death
description: An investigation into the death of a 52-year-old patient at Harlem Hospital was ordered yesterday by the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, the police said.

title: DOMINION BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Interest Rates Rise Sharply
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday in response to statements by the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Paul A. Volcker, that monetary policy had not been eased recently and to lingering fears of higher inflation.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE Great Western Winery's 1985 vidal ice wine, an ambrosial dessert wine from the Finger Lakes region, won the New York Wine Classic on Sunday. The wine was made by Patricia Herron, one of the few women who are wine makers in America, and Matthew Cookson, an assistant wine maker.

title: Banks Wins Again In Festival Boxing
description: Kelcie Banks and Kenneth Gould, two of the country's top amateur fighters, earned gold medals tonight with impressive victories in the finals of the United States Olympic Festival competition.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S.-Japan 'Star Wars' Pact

title: W.G. Williams Is Dead at 74; Owner of a Hotel in Catskills
description: Walter G. Williams, owner of the family-operated Williams Lake Hotel at Rosendale, N.Y., in the Catskills, died of cancer Saturday at Kingston (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Rosendale.

title: WALSH SEEKING ALL IRAN RECORDS OF JUSTICE DEPT.
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair has asked Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to turn over thousands of documents related to the Justice Department's inquiry last fall into the sale of American arms to Iran, Federal law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Falling in Love: A Woman's Fight In Foster Care
description: Nettie Richards set out to recruit volunteers to visit the boarder babies at Harlem Hospital.

title: Farm on a Beach
description: On his way back to being a productive member of a major league rotation, Tommy John became reacquainted with life in the minor leagues. After he was released by the California Angels in 1985, he pitched for Oakland A's farm clubs at Modesto, Calif., and Madison, Wis. Last season, he pitched for the Class A Fort Lauderdale Yankees while recovering from a strained Achilles' tendon.

title: University Finances Criticized by Regan
description: New York State Comptroller Edward V. Regan charged yesterday that the state university mishandled $17 million by putting it in special campus-run accounts instead of accounts that Mr. Regan could have supervised.

title: Plea for a Philosopher
description: To the Editor:

title: REAL ESTATE
description: A LEASE signed by the brokerage firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, announced two weeks ago, has given a lift to one of the largest office projects undertaken in the postwar period in downtown Jersey City.

title: 11 Partners Leave Crow
description: Eleven partners of the Trammel Crow Company said today that they would leave immediately to form Spieker Partners, a new real estate development company based in Menlo Park, Calif. Crow, based in Dallas, is the nation's biggest commercial real estate developer, with more than $13 billion in assets.

title: ROBERT M. DORE
description: Robert M. Dore, a New York advertising representative, died of colon cancer on Monday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 78 years old.

title: GTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a special charge of $54 million representing GTE's $75 million share of a non-recurring pre-tax write-off of its US Sprint affiliate which was partially offset by $82 million of pre-tax pension-settlement gains realized by GTE during the quarter as part of business repositioning actions initiated in 1986 for both the quarter and 6 months. Results for 1986 have been restated to report operations transferred to US Sprint on the equity basis and to present segment information consistent with 1987 classifications. These changes had no effect on net income or share earnings. Share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to give effect to the 3-for-2 common stock split in January, 1987.

title: CITICORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a $3 billion addition to the company's reserve for possible credit losses. c-Net income The latest second quarter results included pretax foreign exchange gains of $129 million, compared with $118 million for the year-ago period. For the 6 months, similar pretax gains amounted to $218 million, compared with $217 million for the year-earlier period.

title: 'WHAT'S GOING ON' WITH TEEN-AGERS
description: ''WHAT'S GOING ON'' is earnest and raises real problems, but its own sympathies do it in. The one-hour documentary seems like two. We know it's tough to be a teen-ager, but how many times can we be told that? ''What's Going On,'' a WCBS-TV production, on Channel 2 at 10 P.M., tells us again and again.

title: Tribble Admits Mistake
description: Brian Tribble, who was acquitted last month on drug charges in connection with the June 1986 cocaine-induced death of Len Bias, said he used drugs with the Maryland basketball star on the morning Bias died.

title: WELFARE IN FOCUS AT URBAN LEAGUE
description: Talk of overhauling the welfare system, once rarely heard among such groups as the National Urban League, is dominating the organization's 77th annual convention here this week.

title: Royals Drop McRae
description: Hal McRae, one of the best hitters never to win a batting title, has collected his final hit as a member of the Kansas City Royals. The 42-year-old McRae, a career .290 hitter for his 19 major league seasons, was dropped after seeing limited action this action as a pinch-hitter.

title: Mitterrand Son in Car Crash
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France and his wife, Danielle, flew to northeastern Spain today after a son, Gilbert, and two granddaughters were injured in a highway collision. Mr. Mitterrand returned to Paris by air and his wife was to fly back later with the three injured. The Spanish driver of the other car was killed in the collision.

title: LEGISLATORS IN AN INDIAN STATE CONTEST ROLE OF GANDHI PARTY
description: Dozens of local legislators from Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's ruling party in Uttar Pradesh, the country's most populous and politically important state, have pledged support to a Gandhi rival, threatening a loyalist government there.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: An Apollo Homecoming

title: SENATE APPROVES TRADE BILL, 71-27, DEFYING PRESIDENT
description: The Senate approved sweeping trade legislation tonight that threatened to set off a confrontation with President Reagan. If a compromise is not reached, the bill could become an important campaign issue next year.

title: New York Names First 10 Sites As Special Development Zones
description: Governor Cuomo today announced the selection of 10 economically depressed communities around the state, including three sections of New York City, to receive business incentives as the state's first Economic Development Zones.

title: MELVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Greenspan's Inflation Vow
description: Alan Greenspan pledged today to carry on the muscular anti-inflation policies of Paul A. Volcker when, as widely expected, he is installed as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board within the next few weeks.

title: BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and 6 months' losses reflect the special provision of $700 million, or $670 million after-tax, to the allowance for loan losses in light of recent developments related to the debt of Brazil and other refinancing countries, particularly the potential effects of the actions of other banks in increasing their loan loss allowance.

title: MARTIN MARIETTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MACMILLAN WITHDRAWS BOOK ON BINGHAM FAMILY
description: The first of four books under contract about the Bingham newspaper family, which sold The Courier-Journal and Louisville Times last year after a dispute among family members, has been withdrawn by Macmillan, the New York publisher, because the book's facts were challenged.

title: ARMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a credit of $14.7 million from favorable U.S. tax court ruling for the quarter; an extraordinary gain of $4.3 million on early retirement of debt for both the quarter and 6 months; and tax credits of $7.7 million for the quarter and $10.6 million for the 6 months. c-Net loss and after special charges of $343 million for the closing of reserve mining and restructuring of operations, primarily in the oilfield equipment segment for the quarter; losses from discontinued operations of $2.8 million and $10.1 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; and losses of $42 million for the quarter and $82 million for 6 months from provision for loss on disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Venezuela Oil Find
description: A huge oilfield with reserves of 819 million barrels of light crude was found in the western Lake Maracaibo region, where most of the country's reserves are situated, the state oil company Petroleos de Venezuela confirmed in a press bulletin. Maraven, a Petroleos affiliate operating in Lake Maracaibo, said that the new field has a potential production of 75,000 barrels a day, or almost 5 percent of the nation's current average output of 1.6 million barrels a day.

title: South African Delegation Is Met by Protests
description: A group of 40 South Africans were met by protesters today as they returned from talks with exiled black opposition figures in West Africa.

title: Boesky Trade Data Sought
description: The chairman of the House committee that oversees the securities markets has asked regulators to turn over information on Ivan F. Boesky's futures trades before and after Mr. Boesky began cooperating with Government investigators.

title: CHRYSLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a one-time net gain of $131.9 million from the sale of its equity interest in Peugeot S.A., the French automaker, for both the quarter and 6 months. Share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in April.

title: FROM BAGELS TO TACOS, PARIS EATS A L' AMERICAINE
description: LEAD: THE American way with food has arrived here. Brunch, the power lunch, chocolate-chip cookies, chili, bagels and even California wines are winning converts daily, particularly among Parisian preppies, or B.C.B.G.'s (''bon chic, bon genre''), as they are called.

title: NEW SENSE OF WANDERLUST SENDS JAPANESE ABROAD
description: The Japanese, with more money to spend and a newly discovered wanderlust to propel them, are going abroad this year for their summer vacations in record numbers, and about a third of them are likely to visit the United States for sightseeing and shopping.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Award-Winning Cheese

title: JAZZ: 'OPERA' STAGED FOR SAXAPHONES
description: JULIUS HEMPHILL calls ''Long Tongues,'' a work in progress presented Monday night at Alice Tully Hall in Lincoln Center's ''Serious Fun!'' concert series, a saxophone opera. His six main characters do not sing or speak, they play various saxophones, and while Mr. Hemphill plans to include dance, visual projections and dramatic vignettes in the completed work, Monday's ''concert version'' depended entirely on the saxophonists for character development and narrative continuity.

title: Fireman's Fund Has Large Loss
description: The Fireman's Fund Corporation today reported a surprising second-quarter loss of $115.5 million after adding substantially to its loss reserves.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective June 1.

title: LeMond Quitting Team
description: Greg LeMond, the 1986 Tour de France cycling champion, said yesterday he was planning to resume competition this winter and is quitting the French La Vie Claire team. LeMond said he has had offers from several teams and plans to sign with one this week. He said that members of the half-dozen Dutch, Italian or Belgian teams he is considering would be more apt to sacrifice, ''to give up their prospects of winning if I'm leading'' than would members of a French team. LeMond was sidelined following a hunting accident, and he recently underwent an appendectomy.

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for 1986 give effect to the 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a stock dividend declared in the first quarter of 1987 and distributed in April 1987.

title: CHILEAN ARMS MAKER HELPS FILL A WORLD DEMAND
description: The Iran-Iraq war and Washington's prohibition on arms sales to Chile have combined to help what was once a small explosives company become a significant manufacturer and exporter of armaments.

title: FMC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes after-tax gain of $95 million from the sale of the company's FMC Gold Co. subsidiary and includes a charge of $10.7 million from debt refinancing for both quarter and 6 months. The company said the change in the number of average shares outstanding reflects a recapitalization which included a 5.667-to-1 stock split and a repurchase for cash on May 28, 1986, of 4.667 of the new shares issued for each share formerly held by investors. Also included in the recapitalization was swap of 1.458 new shares issued for each share formerly held in the employee thrift plan.

title: Alexander Outpitches Gooden
description: This is how costly it was for the Mets in Shea Stadium last night: Dwight Gooden was outpitched by Doyle Alexander, who had lost five straight games, and the Mets were mauled by the Atlanta Braves, who had lost five straight games.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: HOW do you select the right pair of athletic shoes and how do you care for your investment? And what about the objects that go inside the shoes: inserts, socks and, last but hardly least, your feet?

title: Searing Heat Brings Record for Electricity
description: A record demand for electricity was set in New York City yesterday, as the temperature reached 95 degrees.

title: Fairfield Voters Nominate Two For House Seat
description: Christine M. Niedermeier, a Democrat, and Christopher Shays, a Republican, won primary contests in light turnouts tonight and will compete for the vacant Congressional seat in Connecticut's Fourth District.

title: A Loss at American Express
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it lost $47.9 million in the second quarter, a performance that largely reflected a $600 million addition to its banking unit's reserves against troubled Latin American loans.

title: Accounts
description: * Guinness Import Company to Ron Semler Advertising, New York, for its Kronenbourg beer.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Woman Is Charged With Rape
description: A woman the police had been seeking for nearly a month in the rape of a 21-year-old Irishwoman surrendered yesterday, the police said.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: I WAS a Paul girl. Still am, I suppose, at the core. It was one of four choices you had in 1964, when I was on the cusp of adolescence: a Paul girl, a John girl, a George girl or a Ringo girl, with all the attendant Beatle buttons, glossy color pictures and daydreams. Little did we know that in some broad way we were defining the sort of people we were on our way to becoming.

title: Storage of Propane in Blast May Have Broken the Law
description: The propane that exploded yesterday in a basement in Brooklyn, causing the collapse of several buildings and the loss of four lives, was apparently stored illegally, fire and gas officials said.

title: 5 From Guadeloupe Seized
description: Five people suspected of membership in an outlawed insurgent movement on the French island of Guadeloupe were arrested today, the police said.

title: McMahon Can Train
description: Jim McMahon received medical clearance yesterday to begin training camp with the Chicago Bears. The quarterback, who underwent shoulder surgery last December, was examined by his surgeon, Dr. Frank Jobe, in Los Angeles yesterday for a final checkup before the Bears begin camp Aug. 1 in Platteville, Wis.

title: Budd Has Recovered
description: Zola Budd says that a Johannesburg physician who specializes in body posture problems has cured her leg injury. The 21-year-old runner, who has been out of action for almost a year, says she is ready for a comeback.

title: Postal Service and Unions Reach Tentative Pact
description: The Postal Service and the two largest unions representing its workers reached a tentative contract settlement today that provides raises of between $1,700 and $1,866 over the next 40 months.

title: SANTA FE SOUTHERN PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $3.5 million and $4.7 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; there were no discontinued operations in the latest quarter.

title: Who's That Man Blocking the Portal?
description: Mayor Koch may have found a new strategy to prevent companies from leaving New York. He is boarding up the Holland Tunnel.

title: N.C.A.A. Reveals Basketball Shares
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association announced today that schools and conferences, led by the Big East with $3,801,697, shared $26,189,456 from the net revenues of this year's N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament.

title: AT EMBASSY PARTY, CHILI AND LETTERS ARE A GOOD MIX
description: It was a gathering for chili on one of the hottest nights of the summer. A clutch of novelists, journalists, writers and lawyers, along with a sprinkling of politicians, got together Monday in the terraced garden of the Canadian Embassy residence after a benefit performance of the play ''Chili Queen.''

title: A Police Force Is Dismissed From Suit in Arrest of Texan
description: A Federal district judge has dismissed the Plano Police Department as a defendant in an $8 million suit stemming from the erroneous arrest and conviction of Lenell Geter for armed robbery five years ago.

title: ROCKET SENDS SYRIAN AND TWO RUSSIANS ON A SPACE MISSION
description: A space capsule carrying two Soviet astronauts and Syria's first space traveler rocketed into orbit from Soviet central Asia early today, the Tass press agency reported.

title: DR. THOMAS C. McGINNIS
description: Dr. Thomas C. McGinnis, a psychotherapist, writer and radio commentator, died of lung cancer Monday at his home in Fair Lawn, N.J. He was 62 years old.

title: 'Les Miserables' Star-to-Be Dies, and Cause Is a Mystery
description: A 31-year-old actor who was scheduled to take over the lead in the Broadway production of ''Les Miserables'' in October was found dead in his Upper West Side apartment Monday night, and the authorities said yesterday they had not determined the cause of death.

title: Union Cites Pan Am 'Plan'
description: The aviation unit of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters has charged that the management of the Pan Am Corporation has a secret plan to sell its New York-London and Latin American routes and its Pan Am shuttle if the union fails to make major concessions.

title: JWT Deal Concluded
description: Britain's WPP Group announced yesterday that it had completed the acquisition of the JWT Group, parent of the J. Walter Thompson agency, having completed its tender offer and receiving 97 percent of the shares outstanding for $55.50 a share.

title: 'Robocop' in First Place In Box Office Sales
description: ''Robocop,'' the story of a half-man, half-robot police officer battling evil in a futuristic Detroit, earned $8 million over the weekend to take first place at the box office, spoiling the much-publicized 50th anniversary re-release of ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.''

title: Sallie Mae Offers $150 Million Issue
description: The Student Loan Marketing Associaton is offering $150 million of 8 percent notes, due in 1991, at a price of 99.662, to yield 8.10 percent, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Captial Markets.

title: OSHA SEEKS $2.59 MILLION FINE FOR MEATPACKER'S INJURY REPORTS
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration today proposed a $2.59 million fine against IBP Inc., the nation's largest meatpacking company, on charges that it failed to report more than a thousand job-related injuries and illnesses over a two-year period.

title: Memorial for Peter Gimbel
description: A memorial tribute for Peter R. Gimbel, a film maker and underwater photojournalist who died on July 12, will be held at 11:30 A.M. on Monday at the Kaufmann Auditorium of the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 77th Street.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
MELONS OF MANY USES
description: LEAD: AT the outskirts of the hottest part of the summer, under a thousand-watt sun, you might well experience the first stirrings of melon mania. This benign affliction causes an almost painful desire for a slice of cool, sweet cantaloupe or a plush, ripe wedge of watermelon, honeydew or cranshaw.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: At the Scene: Screams And a Beckoning Hand
description: Police Officer Robert Kearns, one of the first rescuers to arrive at the explosion in Borough Park, described a scene of devastation, tumult and desperation.

title: THE TESTIMONY: TAKING RISKS AS AN ADVISER TO THE PRESIDENT
description: Members of Congress questioned Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter further yesterday, in the concluding day of his testimony, about missiles shipped to Iran and other issues in the Iran-contra affair. Here are excerpts from his testimony, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Singer to Marquart
description: Marquart & Roche of Stamford, Conn., has become the corporate agency for its neighbor, the Singer Company, which is no longer in sewing machines but is the largest independent aerospace electronics company. The billings will be more than $1 million. The previous agency was HCM in New York.

title: ON WEEPING PRAIRIE, WILL A SHOWER OF CASH HELP?
description: They call this Issan, the vast, flat northeast of Thailand where few crops but all manner of problems grow.

title: FILM: 'SEA AND POISON,' FROM JAPAN
description: EARLY in ''The Sea and Poison,'' the harrowing Japanese movie now at Film Forum 1, a surgical team performs a lung operation on a young woman. It is probably the most graphic view that most of its audience will ever have had of the scalpel and forceps doing their work, and you may find yourself joining the young intern Suguro, who confesses, ''Today in the operating room, I had to close my eyes.''

title: US WEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results include a gain of $12 million, or 6 cents a share, on the sale of real estate by a subsidiary of Northwestern Bell Holding Co.

title: Bills, Bills, Bills
description: Politicians are sometimes said to try to solve problems by throwing money at them. But when it comes to the United States trade problem, the preferred solution appears to be throwing legislation.

title: Trade Theory From Harvard
description: FREE trade has been a venerated economic principle in the United States going back 200 years. But there have been challengers. The first was Alexander Hamilton, who in 1791 argued for government policies that would encourage native manufacturing while protecting it from British exports.

title: FILM: 'SUMMER SCHOOL'
description: CARL REINER, as a school official who gets lucky with the lottery, disappears at the very beginning of ''Summer School,'' and in doing so he has the right idea. However, Mr. Reiner also directed this strained, rambling teen-age comedy, so he can hardly be thought of as getting away scot-free. ''Summer School'' opens today at the Criterion Center and other theaters.

title: More Than Band-Aids for Air Delays
description: The Senate Commerce Committee is mad as hell about inaccurate airline schedules and won't take it anymore. The committee would require airlines to publish detailed performance information, including the frequency of delayed arrivals, canceled flights and lost-baggage claims.

title: BRUNEI REGAINS $10 MILLION
description: Brunei has recovered, with interest, its mislaid $10 million of contra-related aid and is saying it was meant for Central America's poor, not the Nicaraguan rebels, the Malaysian national news agency said today.

title: Genentech Net Rises by 89%
description: Genentech Inc., a leading biotechnology company based in South San Francisco, today reported second-quarter earnings of $5.3 million, or 6 cents a share, up 89 percent from $2.8 million, or 4 cents a share in the comparable period a year ago.

title: Few on Iran-Contra Committees Believe That Admiral Told Them the Whole Truth
description: From interviews with most of the senators, representatives and top staff members on the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair, it is clear that few believe Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter's account is the whole truth.

title: CITIZENS & SOUTHERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The net in the latest second quarter and 6 months was reduced by $9 million because of a special provision of $15 million to increase the company's reserve for possible loan losses in Latin America.

title: MARSH & MCLENNAN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Omnicom's Approach To Buying
description: APPARENTLY almost everyone in advertising with adequate buying power is anxious to test the limits of their clout. Not all in the same way, however.

title: Israel Reported to Test New, Longer-Range Missile
description: A Geneva-based defense magazine reported today that Israel had successfully tested a new intermediate-range ballistic missile over a distance of 500 miles.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tour de France Delgado Takes Lead: Pedro Delgado of Spain took the overall lead after placing seventh yesterday in the 20th stage, which finished with a climb to the top of l'Alpe d'Huez, France. Federico Echave of Spain won the 125-mile stage in 5 hours 52 minutes 11 seconds, but Delgado moved from second place to the top over all by finishing just 3 minutes 44 seconds behind. Stephen Roche of Ireland and Jean-Francois Bernard of France were 5:32 back. In the overall standings, Delgado has a time of 90:32:28 and leads Roche by 25 seconds, Bernard by 2:02, and Charles Mottet of France by 2:12.

title: RULE UPHELD FOR TV REPORTERS AS CANDIDATES
description: A federal appeals court, in an opinion by Judge Robert H. Bork, ruled today that television reporters who run for office obligate their stations to provide equal time to opposing candidates.

title: OPPOSITION FACTIONS AT KNIVES DRAWN AS SOUTH KOREANS TALK OF DEMOCRACY
description: As the Government and the opposition here prepare to negotiate a blueprint for democracy, the atmosphere is turning sour with a stream of new opposition demands.

title: PHELPS DODGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $9.6 million and $14.7 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $7.6 million and $13.8 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: ALLIED-SIGNAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an estimated net gain of $37 million, or 21 cents a share, for the quarter and $79 million for the 6 months on disposal of discontinued operations. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $15 million, or 8 cents a share and $29 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago quarter includes an after- tax gain of $43 million, or 24 cents a share, related to reversion of surplus pension funds. The company said discontinued operations represent net operating income and the estimated impact from disposal of operations discontinued as of March 31, 1987, including Linotype Group, Amphenol Products, Ampex Corp., and other smaller businesses.

title: Don't Count on Ollie
description: Has Lieut. Col. Oliver North -the Greater Communicator -swung Congress and the country behind aid for the contras in Nicaragua? President Reagan may well be counting his chickens before they're hatched if he thinks so.

title: BANC ONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MONSANTO CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Net Up 49% Up Capital Cities
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. yesterday reported a 49 percent rise in second-quarter net income, reflecting its success in holding down costs, largely in its entertainment programming activities.

title: WELLS FARGO & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Both latest periods' results include a $550 million special addition to Wells Fargo's allowance for loan losses, because of the developments in the international debt situation. The year-ago 6 months' results include a contribution from the former Crocker National Corp. for only the month of June. Wells Fargo acquired Crocker on May 30, 1986.

title: KROGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $3,864,753 for the quarter and $7,551,423 for the 6 months. Kroger said its latest second quarter and 6 months' nets increased by $3.8 million because of revisions in costs related to a 1986 third quarter charge. The share earnings for the latest and year-ago 6 months reflects the effect of preferred stock dividends of $2.7 million in 1987 and $300,000 in 1986.

title: Pilot Dies as Plane Crashes In Chicago Residential Area
description: A Cessna airplane crashed in a residential neighborhood on the city's Southwest Side on Monday night. The pilot was killed, but there were no other casualties.

title: MEMORABLE DINNER IN BASQUE BODEGA
description: LEAD: THESE people here in the north of Spain, these Basques who are lovers of the simple good life, are the butt of a thousand jokes in their country. Many of their fellow countrymen look upon them as rude and unsophisticated. Even some guidebooks make a point of their rusticity, their capacity for fun, food, frivolity, drink and bawdy songs.

title: Publisher Is Named At Inc. Magazine
description: Bernard Goldhirsh, the owner of the Goldhirsh Group, has named Wilson Harrell publisher of Inc. magazine, for which he already was a consultant and an editorial contributor.

title: RISING CANADIAN PARTY SCORES AT POLLS
description: A sweep of three by-elections in widely separated regions of Canada appears to have confirmed the rise of a Social Democratic opposition group, the New Democratic Party, from its position as a perennial third-place finisher in Canadian elections to a possible contender for power.

title: DiGiorgio Rejects Gabelli Proposal
description: The DiGiorgio Corporation said its board had voted to reject as inadequate a recapitalization proposal made June 29 by an investment group led by Mario Gabelli of New York. The Gabelli group, which holds 28.6 percent of DiGiorgio, had proposed a plan under which shareholders would receive $20 in cash plus $8 in securities including new common stock. DiGiorgio makes and distributes food products and reported sales of $281.4 million in the first quarter of the year.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a New Delhi dispatch Monday on the ouster of a critic of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi from the Congress Party misidentified a legislator who had resigned his seat at Mr. Gandhi's request. The legislator was Amitabh Bachchan, India's best-known movie actor, not Ajitabh Bachchan, his brother, who is under investigation on charges of fraud and illegal possession of funds abroad.

title: ADMIRAL REAFFIRMS MAKING HIS VIEW ON SECRECY
description: Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter completed five days of testimony before the Iran-contra committees today with the strongest exposition yet of his view that the President's most sensitive foreign initiatives need to be kept secret from the Congress and other government agencies.

title: Pitchers Do Get Lonely
description: With the Yankees losing, 18-3, in the bottom of the eighth in Texas - even after a few days, the score still reads like a typographical error - Lou Piniella did the unusual, though not the unreasonable. Rather than waste one of his regular relief pitchers in that forlorn enterprise, he saved his sirloin and served the Rangers chopped liver.

title: GUESS WHO'S COMING TO DINNER?
description: THE proposition was intriguing. Put a French chef smack in the middle of a typically minuscule New York kitchen. Deprive him of his Wolf stove and copper pots, fresh herbs ready for snipping and fish plucked wide-eyed from Long Island Sound. Could he produce? What would he produce?

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Chairmen of the Board

title: An Older Archer Is Right on Target
description: While most of the flock at Forsyth Friends Church have accepted Wilburn Wooten's occasional absences from Sunday services, they still can't understand, after all these years, what drives him to travel around the country with a bow and arrow.

title: Allen T. Klots Jr., 66, Editor at Dodd, Mead
description: Allen Trafford Klots Jr., a senior editor at the publishing house of Dodd, Mead, died of complications following surgery at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan Monday. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Lemon Candy
description: To The Living Section:

title: From Broadway to Miss Liberty, Tourism Is Rising
description: They amble while many people dash. They stand at street corners uncrinkling maps or craning their necks skyward while people scurry around them.

title:
BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: ADVANCES;
Rock Stars Are Going Cordless
description: LEAD: THERE are few things more disconcerting to the professional guitar player than twisting and shouting on stage only to find that the cord that feeds the sound from guitar to amplifier either has been yanked out or entwined with the cord of another band member.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: FIRST JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ex-Defense Official Joins a Contractor
description: Donald C. Latham, an assistant secretary of defense until last week, has become vice president of the Computer Sciences Corporation.

title: OLD SHAKERS, NEW PLATES
description: A Victorian Touch

title: Stocks Fall Broadly; Dow Off 19.77
description: Stocks fell broadly yesterday amid worries about inflation and Middle Eastern hostilities. Late selling in the credit markets also contributed to the decline.

title: Japan Rate Rise Is Called Likely
description: Japan's long-term credit banks are likely to raise their long-term prime rate by three-tenths to four-tenths of a percentage point later this week from the current record low of 4.9 percent, bankers said today.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes an $88 million after-tax gain from the sale of Fireman's Fund Corp. common stock. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $139.6 million, or 63 cents a share, from the sale of the company's interest in Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc. The company said the loss reflects a previously announced after-tax charge of $520 million against the earnings of American Express Bank Ltd. resulting from a $600 million addition to the bank's reserves for LDC loans, primarily Latin american. Revenue represent consolidated revenue.

title: New York Halts Removal Work At Former Bank
description: A turn-of-the-century building on the northern edge of Greenwich Village, under consideration as a landmark, has been stripped of some stained-glass windows and ornamental bronze work by its owner, preservationists and New York City officials said yesterday.

title: RACIAL ROADBLOCK SEEN IN ATLANTA TRANSIT SYSTEM
description: Despite the growing reach of Atlanta's rapid transit network, the system's trains and buses do not cross the county line into the booming suburbs north of the city - because the governments there have not wanted them.

title: Now a Gentleman
description: The boxing promoter Bob Arum is a partner with, among others, Gil Clancy, the CBS boxing commentator, in a race horse named Merchant of Baghdad, who is scheduled to run Friday at Belmont. Last week in Las Vegas, Nev., Arum was showing boxing people a stable area pass that had this designation on it: Owner-Gentleman. The gentleman designation tickled Arum.

title: Chief at Continental Yields to Lorenzo
description: The resignation of Thomas G. Plaskett, an experienced executive hired last November as president and chief executive of Continental Airlines, was announced today, one day after the carrier reported a larger-than-expected quarterly loss.

title: 3 Suspected In Sex Assaults In Queens
description: Thirteen women have been sexually assaulted and robbed in central Queens since last April, most of them in the last month and a half, and the police believe three separate rapists are responsible.

title: LONDONERS LOOK AT THEMSELVES THROUGH THE AGES
description: One of the great successes of this summer in London is the exhibition called simply ''Londoners'' at the London Museum. Sponsored by the Chase Manhattan Bank on the occasion of the 100th anniversary of the founding of its branch in London, the show is built up with the widest possible variety of prints, paintings and drawings, ranging in date from the Middle Ages to the present.

title: Vote Proposal Is Opposed
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission's proposal to impose a uniform one-share, one-vote standard on stock exchanges was greeted today with outright opposition from one exchange and little enthusaism by two others.

title: HEALTH WORKERS TO GET AIDS PROTECTION
description: The Federal Government will, for the first time, require private employers to protect the nation's health-care workers against infection with the AIDS virus, Labor Department officials said today.

title: Federal Investigators Gather Data at PTL Ministry Offices
description: A team of 18 Federal criminal investigators has begun gathering evidence at the headquarters of the troubled PTL television ministry, a PTL official said today.

title: Correction
description: The Home Improvement column in The Home Section on May 21 incorrectly described several steps in the connection of telephone wires. Four-conductor cable made for telephone installation is the only cable that should be used.

title: Leon B. Poullada, Ex-Envoy And Afghan Expert, Is Dead
description: Leon B. Poullada, a career Foreign Service officer who served as Ambassador to Togo during the Kennedy Administration and specialized in Afghan history, died of prostate cancer last Friday at his home in St. Paul, Minn. He was 74 years old. In his 17-year diplomatic career, Mr. Poullada, the son of a Mexican immigrant doctor, served in Ceylon, Pakistan and Afghanistan before President Kennedy named him Ambassador to the African coastal nation of Togo in 1961. In 1963, during Mr. Poullada's posting, Togo's President, Sylvanus Olympio, was shot and killed outside the United States Embassy gates.

title: FRENCH EXPEDITION TO START DIVING FOR TREASURES ON TITANIC TODAY
description: The organizers of a French expedition said today that it had reached the site of the wrecked ocean liner Titanic and would start diving Thursday to recover a strongbox and other treasures from the ship, which sank off the Newfoundland coast 75 years ago.

title: Boesky Studying Hebrew and Talmud at Seminary
description: Last winter, after Ivan F. Boesky had been fined $100 million in the insider-trading scandal, the Jewish Theological Seminary, acting at his request, took his name off its $20 million library.

title: TRANS WORLD AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said that results for the year-ago quarter and 6 months were adversely affected by the strike of its flight attendants during the first half of 1986 and do not include the results of operations of Ozark Air Lines, which was acquired by the company during the third quarter of 1986. The company also said its results in the latest periods do not take into account an unrealized pretax gain at June 30 of about $90 million on the company's investment in USX Corp. common stock.

title: TRINOVA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax provision for restructuring of $20,600,000 and a gain of $85,000,000 from discontinued operations from the sale of a glass business for both periods; the 6 months also include income from discontinued operations of $1,330,000.

title: MINNESOTA MINING & MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective May 22, 1987.

title: NBC's All-Star Baseball In 3d Place in Ratings
description: NBC's telecast of baseball's All-Star Game achieved third place in the Nielsen television ratings during a week of summer doldrums and reruns.

title: VF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: Latest periods include operations of the Blue Bell companies acquired from Blue Bell Holding Co. in November.

title: Profits Up At G.M. Units
description: Three operating units of the General Motors Corporation today reported higher second-quarter earnings. Analysts have predicted lower profits for the parent company, which is expected to report Thursday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JULY 23, 1987
description: Companies

title: DANCE: 'DANCE AND THE MUSIC OF AFRICA,' AT JACOB'S PILLOW
description: ''The Dance and Music of Africa,'' a program that opened last night at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, is not your ordinary presentation of ethnic dance.

title: The Open Museum
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST FEDERAL OF MICHIGAN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $1,311,000 for the quarter and a gain of $1,727,000 from retirement of Federal Home Loan Bank advances for the 6 months. c-After a charge of $13,832,000 from prepayment of Federal Home Loan advances for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Calendar: Art Fabrics And Indian Beadwork
description: Artworks For Wearing Gayle Willson Gallery, 16 Job's Lane, Southampton, L.I.; 516-283-7430.

title: MANY IN NEWARK HAIL CULTURE PROJECT
description: Corporate leaders, residents and out-of-towners reacted enthusiastically today to a plan to build a $300 million cultural complex in the center of the city.

title: PITNEY BOWES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,869,000.

title: PINIELLA CRITICIZES YANKS AFTER A 2D ANEMIC EFFORT
description: This time, the burn inside Lou Piniella did not come roaring out at the start, in the anger of the moment, as it has done on occasion in his 11 seasons as a Yankee player and two as a manager. Tonight, the manager exhibited a slow burn. There was no mistaking the fire.

title: MORGAN STANLEY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ALSO AT RISK IN THE GULF: U.S. DETERRENT STRATEGY
description: More than the Kuwaiti tankers sailing under the American flag were put at risk today when the United States naval escort program got under way in the Persian Gulf. The assumptions upon which the United States has based its deterrent strategy in the gulf - that its willingness to use naval might to protect the tankers and to retaliate if attacked will deter Iran from taking hostile action -will also be tested.

title: If High Court Is So Political, Let's Elect Justices; Glaring Inconsistency
description: To the Editor:

title: THE PROOF OF A PAINT JOB IS IN THE PAINTER
description: MODERN exterior paints are more durable and more mistake-proof than ever, but even the best paint will not stand up if the surface is not properly prepared first, or if the paint is carelessly applied. Most failures are not the fault of the paint - usually, the manufacturer's directions have not been followed in the application, and sometimes the wrong type of paint was used.

title: Suspension Is Asked on Military Aid to Pakistan
description: The chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee today asked President Reagan to suspend military aid to Pakistan until the two countries resolve issues raised by charges that Pakistan has tried to acquire material for nuclear weapons.

title: Correction
description: An article in Science Times on July 14 about the Indian mathematician Srinivasa Ramanujan contained several errors. He was born in Erode, a town near Kumbakonam, not in Kumbakonam itself, where he grew up.

title: MILITANTS BLOCK DIGGING IN ISRAEL
description: Fifty American volunteers pulled out of an archeological excavation site here today after a group of rigorously Orthodox Jews mobilized international pressure to halt digging in the area, which they say is an ancient burial ground.

title: ROTHSCHILD, L F HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes a charge of 13 cents a share due to the reversal of a portion of a tax credit benefit recorded in the first quarter of 1987.

title: Bristol-Myers Net Rises
description: The Bristol-Myers Company, a leading drug manufacturer, said its earnings rose 35.4 percent in the second quarter, largely because of increased international sales resulting from the declining value of the dollar. The company, which produces Bufferin and Excedrin, said it earned $161.5 million, or 56 cents a share, up from $119.3 million, or 42 cents a share, a year ago. The figures a year ago include costs of about $19 million to cover the withdrawal of non-prescription capsules after the discovery of tampering with some bottles of Excedrin. Sales for the latest quarter were up 12 percent, to $1.31 billion, from $1.17 billion a year ago.

Bork to the Supreme Court, said today that it would be ''dishonest'' for him to pretend he had an ''open mind.''

title: Rejection Leads To a 25-0 Streak
description: The Salt Lake Trappers, a 26-man team made up completely of players not selected by major league clubs in the free-agent draft, seem to be a team with a mission. The Salt Lake players, running away with the pennant in the Pioneer League for rookie professionals, seem bent on proving that the scouts who overlooked or rejected them were wrong, wrong, wrong.

title: DIAMOND SHAMROCK R&M INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Aouita Sets New Mark: Said Aouita of Morocco ran the 5,000 meters in 12 minutes 58.39 seconds at the Golden Gala meet in Rome yesterday, breaking his world record and the 13-minute barrier for the distance. The time bettered Aouita's record of 13:00.40 set in 1985. ''I knew I was doing well,'' Aouita said after the race, ''but had I realized I was in such good form, I'd have tried to run in 12:50. I could have done it.'' Aouita was ahead of his 1985 record from the start, generating wild enthusiasm from the crowd of 40,000. In addition, Aouita also owns the records in the 1,500 meters, the two miles and the 2,000 meters. He set the latter in Paris last Thursday with a time of 4:50.81. (AP) Tour de France Fignon Wins 21st Stage: Laurent Fignon of France, the cycling champion in 1983 and 1984, won his first stage in three years in this event yesterday while Pedro Delgado of Spain slightly increased his overall lead. Fignon outsprinted Anselmo Fuerte of Spain on the final climb of the 115-mile, 21st stage from Bourg d'Oisans to La Plagne, which included the three highest ascents of the race. Fignon and Fuerte broke away from the main group 15 miles from the summit finish and never were headed. They both were timed in 6 hours 7 minutes 5 seconds. Stephen Roche of Irelandr needed medical attention at the finish and was barely conscious before extra oxygen revived him. Doctors said they were not alarmed by his condition. Roche later was one of three riders penalized 10 seconds for getting food at an unauthorized point. In the overall standing, Delgado leads Roche by 39 seconds and Charles Mottet of France by 3:12.

title: Shorter Courses Derided
description: Jan Stephenson, who created a stir three years ago when she criticized courses on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour as being too short, repeated that argument today. She added that if certain women's major tournaments were not played on more suitable courses, the events should be taken off the major list.

title: Women Gain Little In Academic Jobs
description: Women who teach in colleges still suffer from discrimination, according to a study by the University of California.

title: Nissan to Sell Luxury Cars
description: The Nissan Motor Company, taking a cue from a Japanese rival, said today that it will set up a dealer network to sell its new Infiniti luxury cars by the fall of 1989.

title: AIDS-INFECTED ARE FOUND TO PRODUCE VIRUS-KILLERS
description: People infected with the AIDS virus produce cells that can kill cells containing the virus, scientists said today. They said the finding could help identify people who would benefit most from an AIDS vaccine, if one is developed.

title: BANCORP HAWAII CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
