The year-ago results are restated for acquisitions of Tennessee National Bancshares and First & Peoples Bank, accounted for as poolings of interest.

title: Consumer Prices Rose 0.4% in June
description: Easing fears of a sharp acceleration in inflation, the Labor Department reported today that the Consumer Price Index had climbed a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in June.

title: TORCHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $4,581,000 and $8,756 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and an extraordinary loss of $6,010,000 and $7,903,000 for the year-ago comparable periods, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $1,725,000 and $17,136,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Old Sturbridge Village Plans Gardening Talks
description: LECTURES on 19th-century gardens, seeds and plant varieties will be held Aug. 1 and 2 at Old Sturbridge Village, a re-creation of a New England town of the 1830's.

title: In Tunisia, A Rare Visit To a Palace And Its Owner
description: AS the stuff of romance, Edwina Prue's story was hard to beat. There she was, a poor girl from America in a railroad station in London in the 1920's when a nobleman saw her and fell in love with her. He did not introduce himself, but later traced her to her home in the United States, sent her orchids and a letter, and eventually married her.

title: RYLAND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ON ''OUR WORLD,' FEAR ON 3 FRONTS IN 1938
description: ''OUR WORLD'' tonight goes back to the fall of 1938:

SOVIET ANSWER ON ARMS PLAN IS WELCOMED IN WASHINGTON
description: The White House today welcomed Mikhail S. Gorbachev's statement that Moscow was prepared to agree to a worldwide ban on American and Soviet medium-range and short-range missiles.

title: CHRISTIE'S SALES TOTAL $900 MILLION
description: Christie's International said yesterday that it would announce record worldwide sales of $900 million for the 11-month auction season ending July 31. That is a 57 percent increase over its international sales of $573.3 million in the 1985-86 season.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''What they're doing is scaring the public to death, and we've got to do something about it.'' - Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward, on restricting bicycle traffic in New York City. [ A1:6. ]

title: SSC&B: Methodical Hunter
description: MANY agency chief executives tell their people that the pursuit of new business is everybody's job. To which Spencer Plavoukos, chairman and chief executive of SSC&B, United States division, says, ''When you say that new business is everybody's business, it ends up nobody's business.''

title: PRIME COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Looking Over a Lawn of Clover Is Sweet Pleasure
description: LAST fall, for the first time in years, I looked at my lawn with the kind of pride suburban males are expected to feel toward their expanses of grass.

title: Transamerica Active Again
description: TAKEOVER rumors are again circulating around the Transamerica Corporation, with shares in the big insurance company jumping $3.625 yesterday to close at $44.25 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: French Aides Predict A Long Iran Standoff
description: As the deadline set by France for the return home of French and Iranian diplomatic personnel passed without action, French officials warned today that the standoff could go on for months.

title: SNAP-ON TOOLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
S.E.C. Files a Brief in Texaco Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, as expected, filed a brief with the Supreme Court of Texas today urging review of the bitter court case between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company.

title: Victory Over Health Care Anxiety
description: The catastrophic Medicare health insurance bill passed yesterday by the House goes well beyond the version offered last fall by the Reagan Administration - but not so far beyond that it merits the President's threatened veto.

Year-ago second quarter includes a non-recurring gain of $12,039,000 from the settlement of a gas sale contract. The loss in the year-ago 6-month was due primarily to the decline in crude oil and refined product inventory values in the year-ago first quarter.

title: A MEDICARE SHIELD FOR COSTLY ILLNESS IS VOTED BY HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives voted today to protect 31 million elderly and disabled people against the costs of catastrophic illness by approving the largest expansion of Medicare benefits in the program's 22-year history.

title: Streets of Seoul
description: Through the iron grille guarding the entrance, the acolytes can be seen, neat in blue, standing silent in a great hall. A gentle recorded voice talks to them of their duties and aspirations and they bow seven times. A young woman walks a dozen steps, pushes a button, the grille lifts and the temple is opened.

title: Permitting More Jews To Leave
description: By freeing nearly all Jewish prisoners of conscience, allowing some prominent high-profile refuseniks -those once refused permission to emigrate - to leave the country and opening the gates slightly to Jewish emigration, the wily Mikhail S. Gorbachev has shown welcome signs of change and has scored points with his country's critics.

title: Crafts Group Mixes Art With Business
description: LEAD: A WEAVER keeps the books.

title: If High Court Is So Political, Let's Elect Justices; Best We Can Hope For
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters; After 3 Months, Ferrer Is Holding His Own in Bronx
description: ''There are no pure souls in politics,'' Fernando Ferrer was explaining. ''Somewhere along the way they have made a judgment that 'my guts tell me one thing, but I'm going to hold my nose.' ''

title: North Upsets South, 88-73
description: The South, undefeated in three games and favored to win a second straight United States Olympic Festival gold medal, was upset tonight in the title game by the North, 88-73, before a crowd of 21,203 at the Dean Smith Student Activity Center.

title: Relieving Motion Sickness
description: As terrible as it might seem at the time, motion sickness is a normal response to movement, and it rarely leads to serious complications, medical experts at the Food and Drug Administration have reported.

title: TEXAS MUSEUM TO BUY A MAJOR CARAVAGGIO
description: The Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth is to buy Caravaggio's ''Card-Sharps,'' a painting of primordial importance to the development of Italian 17th-century art and one that had been lost to view for nearly 100 years.

title: World Debt Rise Cited
description: Foreign borrowing of debtor countries is approaching $1 trillion, according to data from the Bank for International Settlements and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. In a survey of bank and official credit, the two organizations said gross claims on 159 countries totaled $896.6 billion in December, up from $850.6 billion in June 1986 and $813 billion at the end of 1985. The figures, the most complete published on indebtedness, are based on exchange rates in force at the time the data were collected.

title: JERSEY PLANS TO SHIP TAINTED SOIL TO TENNESSEE FROM MONTCLAIR
description: Some of 5,000 barrels of radium-contaminated soil that has been stored in Montclair for three years will be shipped next week to Tennessee under a pilot project announced today by environmental officials.

title: It's Time to Drop Draft Registration
description: LEAD: Jimmy Carter has been out of office for more than six years, but his legacy lives on. Gillam Kerley of Madison, Wis., has become the latest young man to be convicted for failing to register for the draft. And Mr. Kerley's sentence - a three-year prison term with a mandatory year before parole and a $10,000 fine - is the harshest yet.

title: GENERAL MOTORS ACCEPTANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 ANTI-APARTHEID LEADERS ARE ARRESTED
description: Two key officials of the anti-apartheid United Democratic Front, the biggest internal grouping resisting white rule, were arrested by the South African police early today in a pre-dawn sweep.

title: Midwesterners Love the Beauty of Their Man-Made Prairies
description: It is hardly news that gardeners across the country are currently enthusiastic about planting wildflowers. Midwesterners are no exception. But in this area the trend, with its appealing combination of ecological, esthetic and practical advantages, has taken a particular twist: planting prairies.

title: Mellon Bank Corp. Fills President's Job
description: In a step toward restoring its financial health, the Mellon Bank Corporation said yesterday that it had hired Anthony P. Terracciano, vice chairman of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, as Mellon's president and chief operating officer. In this newly created post, Mr. Terracciano, 48 years old, will oversee Mellon's daily operations.

description: International A3-15

title: TRIAL OF A MARINE IN SPY CASE OPENS
description: The trial of Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree on charges of spying for the Soviet Union opened at the Marine Corps base here today with his lawyers seeking to portray him as a persecuted American Indian.

title: CLIMBING OIL PRICES BRING SIGH OF RELIEF TO SOUTHWEST, BUT EDGINESS REMAINS
description: When the price of oil hit $20 in mid-June, they celebrated in the streets in the Texas Panhandle town of Perryton with noisemakers, nonalcoholic champagne and a giddy spirit not been seen since oil prices collapsed at the end of 1985.

title: MUSIC: VIOLIN PRODIGY AND DE LARROCHA
description: THE Mostly Mozart Festival's program Tuesday evening featured a cast of impressive guest artists, most notably the pianist Alicia de Larrocha, but the evening's most intriguing player made his appearance at a brief, pre-concert recital. Stefan Milenkovic, a 10-year-old violinist from Yugoslavia, is the youngest of several prodigiously gifted musicians appearing at the festival this season.

title: FIGHTING FAKE ART: VICTIMS' SHAME AND MUDDLED LAW
description: Federal and state authorities say an unusual array of circumstances is hindering their efforts to eliminate the multimillion-dollar counterfeit-art market that is flourishing in New York and other parts of the country.

It was the most money received by any conference. Record figures of 654,744 in paid attendance and gross receipts of $49,092,205 enabled the N.C.A.A. to send out checks totaling $26,189,456 to conferences and independent teams participating in the tournament. The conferences (with total teams in parentheses) that profited most:

description: Manhole Cover as Art

title: Swiss Clean Up Storm Ruins
description: More than 400 soldiers were called in today to help clean up the muddy aftermath of torrential rainstorms that took the lives of four people in southern Switzerland, the police said.

title: RECRUITING PRESSURE EXTENDS TO WOMEN
description: The recruiting hunt is behind her, but the high-pressure tactics she faced are a vivid memory for Daedra Charles, one of the top female basketball players in the nation's high schools last year.

description: b-After special gains of $103 million for the quarter and $122,860,000 for the 6 months. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Oliver Ramsay Pilat, Reporter And New York 'Night Mayor'
description: Oliver Ramsay Pilat, a retired newspaper reporter and author of seven books who once served as the ''night mayor'' of New York City, died Tuesday at Bellevue Medical Center of complications following surgery for a broken hip. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Steve's to Acquire 80% of Swensen's
description: The majority owner of Swensen's Inc. has agreed to sell its 80 percent stake in the ice-cream shop operator to Steve's Homemade Ice Cream Inc. The transaction between Steve's, a New York producer of expensive ice cream, and Red River Resources Inc. would consist of a stock swap, exchanging two of Steve's class A common shares and a five-year warrant to buy one Steve's share at $6 for every six Swensen's common shares.

title: WEST POINT-PEPPERELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
Opening Off Till Oct. 1 For 'Roza,' a Musical
description: The opening of ''Roza,'' a musical based on the book, ''La Vie Devant Soi'' by Romain Gary, which was also the source of the film ''Madame Rosa,'' has been postponed from Aug. 27 to Oct. 1. Previews are to begin Sept. 14 at the Royale Theater.

title: Bridge: Just Two Top Seeds Remain In Spingold Knockout Event
description: A day of carnage in the Spingold Knockout Teams here Tuesday left a group of top-ranked teams on the sidelines at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.

title: Dow, Rebounding a Little, Gains 2.23
description: Stocks ended little changed yesterday, curtailed by weakness in the bond market and the potential for unrest in the Middle East.

title: Hilton Makes Bid For Dunes Hotel
description: The Hilton Hotel Corporation said it had offered to buy the troubled Dunes Hotel and Country Club for $122.5 million in cash. It said the offer will expire on Aug. 3. Hilton said that if its bid succeeded, it would spend an additional $110 million to renovate and expand the hotel and casino. The Hilton chain already owns two other hotels in Las Vegas.

title: Up a Spiral Staircase
description: ''OUR SALES keep on going crazy each year,'' said Ron Cohen, vice president and sales manager of the Iron Shop, which manufactures and sells kits for spiral staircases. Why the increased interest? ''Because people are much more conscious of space, and conventional stairs eat up a lot of square footage,'' he said.

title: TANK ARMOR ISSUE TO BE FOCUS OF CAPITAL HEARING
description: A debate among Army experts over allegations that American infantrymen can no longer defend themselves against Soviet tanks will be aired at a bipartisan hearing next Wednesday, Congressional aides said yesterday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE FORBIDDEN ZONE. By Michael Lesy. 250 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95. ''THERE is a forbidden zone marked on the map of twentieth-century American culture, a place every citizen knows but fears to enter,'' Michael Lesy announces somewhat portentously at the opening of his latest book. ''It is the zone of death, the modern American Hades.'' Most of us would like to know this forbidden zone without getting too close to it, Mr. Lesy argues, but the only ''solution'' to our fascination is to enter it.

title: EXCERPTS FROM GORBACHEV VIEWS
description: Following are excerpts from written answers by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, to questions submitted by the Indonesian newspaper Merdeka, as provided by Tass:

title: Reorganization Plan by Hunts
description: Lawyers for the bankrupt William Herbert Hunt Trust Estate filed an initial reorganization plan today that included, for the first time, the possibility that the secretive Hunt family would soon offer stock in one of their companies.

title: ENGELHARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a special gain of $10.8 million from the sale of a 4-percent interest in Japanese subsidiary during the first quarter.

title: Drug Shootout in Peru
description: A drug trafficker was killed and a police sergeant wounded in a shootout at a cocaine laboratory in a remote Amazon basin river valley, the Interior Ministry said today. A ministry spokesman said the gun battle erupted when the police burst into the laboratory on Monday in the hamlet of Alto Limon, 275 miles northeast of Lima, and found three Colombian drug traffickers and their Peruvian bodyguards. The police destroyed the laboratory, seizing 880 pounds of liquid cocaine paste and nearly two pounds of refined paste.

title: TRANSCANADA PIPELINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the results reflect a national energy board tolls decision in June, which lowered its allowed return in its gas transportation business; the decision reduced previously reported earnings by about $8.4 million in 1986 and $3.5 million in the first quarter of 1987.

title: N.B.A. Picks Sanders
description: Tom (Satch) Sanders, who grew up in Harlem and played basketball for Seward Park High School and New York University before going on to play 13 years for the Boston Celtics, will be coming home soon. The 49-year-old Sanders, a coordinator of the National Basketball Association's rookie transitional program, was named to a full-time position as the league's director of player programs by Commissioner David Stern.

title: KIDDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LAW ON SPECIAL PROSECUTORS IS UPHELD BY A FEDERAL JUDGE
description: A Federal judge has upheld the constitutionality of the Ethics in Government Act's independent-counsel provisions, under which special prosecutors are appointed by a court.

title: Hahn to Use Playboy To Tell But Not Show
description: Jessica Hahn, the former church secretary whose tryst with the Rev. Jim Bakker set off the PTL scandal, will tell her version of the events in the November issue of Playboy magazine, her lawyer said today.

description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid May 4.

Its literature said it sold the works of some of the world's most celebrated artists. It guaranteed in writing the authenticity of every lithograph and engraving that it sold.

title: WARNER-LAMBERT COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Library of Congress Gets Loewy Papers
description: THE Library of Congress is to receive some 600 designs, letters, photographs and drawings by the industrial designer Raymond Loewy, who died last year at the age of 92 after a career that spanned nearly three-quarters of a century.

title: Times Co.'s Net Up 19.8%
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 19.8 percent, to $44.1 million, or 54 cents a share, from $36.8 million, or 45 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1986.

Hart's Collateral
description: Trying to recoup more than $500,000 owed to it by Gary Hart's 1984 Presidential campaign, the National Bank of Washington held an auction yesterday for 93 lithographs that had been specially made for Mr. Hart by the American artist Robert Rauschenberg. The prints have been held in a vault at the bank since 1984, part of the collateral for a $3.5 million loan.

title: WEYERHAEUSER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Deficit Again Falls
description: The Federal Government's budget deficit shrank to $420 million for the month of June, the Government said today.

title: Video of 'Angel Heart' Restores Edited Scene
description: The 10 seconds of ''Angel Heart'' that audiences couldn't see in theaters last spring will be available in their homes in September.

title: INSIDE
description: Next Witness: Shultz

title: Scoot-Through Shower Service
description: Frank Ortiz providing Erse Britto, left, and Francine, his daughter, with liquid relief from the 93-degree heat outside his home on West 43d Street. He should keep the hose handy; they'll need it again today and tomorrow as more heat is expected, but with higher humidity. (NYT/Jim Wilson)

title: Thompson Concerned
description: John Thompson, basketball coach at Georgetown and of the United States Olympic team for next year's Summer Games in Seoul, said he was worried about his players missing valuable school time during the event, which is scheduled Sept. 17-Oct.2.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After equity in earnings of associated companies of $3,416,000 for the quarter and $6,545,000 for the 6 months. c-After equity in earnings of associated companies of $4,456,000 for the quarter and $9,239,000 for the 6 months. The 1986 second quarter and 6-month results include a non-recurring interest charge of $8.5 million relating to litigation arising from the company's 1981 cable television acquisition.

title: Yields Are Steady
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were little changed for the week ended yesterday.

title: Ex-Louisiana Leader To Be Named a Judge
description: President Reagan will nominate David C. Treen, the former Governor of Louisiana, to be a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, the White House said today.

title: Natalie Hinderas, 60; Played Classical Piano
description: Natalie Hinderas, one of the first black artists to establish an important career in classical music and a pianist who played with most of the major American orchestras, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Philadelphia. She was 60 years old. Ms. Hinderas was born in Oberlin, Ohio, and studied with Olga Samaroff at the Juilliard School and with Edward Steuermann at the Philadelphia Conservatory. About her New York debut in 1951, The New York Times reviewer stated ''she has imagination and personality, obviously a fine musical background, and a technique in good functioning order.''

title: Networks Take Turns In Covering Hearings
description: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair will be televised live beginning at 9 A.M. on the CBS television network under the network rotation system. The hearings will also be televised on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on some local affiliates of PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service, including Channel 13 in New York.

title: A Hands-Off Takeover Stance
description: President Reagan's nominee for chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, David S. Ruder, told Congress today that he would support a hands-off approach to hostile takeovers and would favor only minor changes in the current Federal laws that govern them.

title: Turnpike Director to Retire
description: William J. Flanagan, executive director of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority for 25 years, has told the chairman of the agency, Joseph A. Sullivan, that he will resign from his $138,696-a-year job in six months.

Results for the year-ago quarter and 9-month have been restated to reflect the engineering services business as discontinued operations.

title: GERBER PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PANHANDLE EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $492,000 and $1,461,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $74,834,000 and $75,965,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a special charge of $460,350,000 for both periods.

title: Maiden Rallies to Victory
description: Morgan's Levee, the only maiden in a field of seven 2-year-olds, rallied from last place to run down Endurance and Eon and win the $72,000 Tremont Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: COOPER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'FOLLIES' RESTAGED IN LONDON
description: The English theater put its money where its affection is Tuesday night, introducing a $3 million production of Stephen Sondheim's ''Follies'' that features some of the most elaborate stagecraft of the season and four new Sondheim songs tucked amid a string of show stoppers.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Two Old Scouts Talk Baseball
description: In their 4-3 victory over the Atlanta Braves yesterday, the Mets were without Gary Carter, out now ''day to day'' with a damaged knee. Another injury for the World Series champions who have turned ''disabled list'' into household words. The Mets don't add up their injuries, but nine different players have been on the disabled list at one time or another, including six pitchers.

title: STANLEY WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $77,000 and $1,563,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $1,400,000 for both periods. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2,000 and $1,116,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: LAURA CARTER FAHY
description: Laura Carter Fahy, a former community volunteer worker, died Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88 years old.

title: KEY RATES
POPE SEEKING WAY TO REPAIR TIES WITH JEWS
description: Senior Vatican officials say that Pope John Paul II is searching for ways to repair relations between his church and Jewish organizations after the widespread Jewish protests over Kurt Waldheim's visit here.

title: NORTHERN TELECOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The results are in U.S. dollars.

title: AMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MUSIC: 'JAZZ IN JULY,' SERIES AT 92D STREET Y
description: ''JAZZ IN JULY,'' the annual two-week series of concerts at the 92d Street Y focusing on jazz of the 1920's and 30's, opened its third season Tuesday evening with three established series favorites - ''Stridemonster,'' the stride-piano duo of Dick Hyman and Dick Wellstood; the singer Carrie Smith and Vince Giordano's big band - and a newcomer to the series, the Jim Cullum Jazz Band of San Antonio.

title: Comings and Goings
description: One day after signing their number one pick, Roger Vick, a running back from Texas A&M, the Jets announced yesterday the signing of their second-round pick, Alex Gordon, a linebacker out of Cincinnati. . . . The Philadelphia Flyers have traded Jeff Brubaker, a left wing acquired from the Edmonton Oilers last season, to the Rangers for future consideration. The 29-year-old Brubaker played in 12 games for the Hershey Bears and 47 games with Nova Scotia last season. . . . Elvis Franks, a defensive end for the Raiders who was arrested in Cleveland Tuesday on a charge of cocaine possession with intent to distribute, will be allowed to to attend his team's training camp, which opens July 29 in California. . . . Joe Cowley, a former Yankee who pitched a no-hitter for the Chicago White Sox last season, then was traded to Philadelphia and eventually sent to the minors, has been given the rest of the season off by the Phillies, after working a month with a psychatrist. ''Joe tries very hard,'' said the Phillies' president, Bill Giles, ''but something is bothering him and it's best that he be home with his family at this time.''

title: ARCO, Hess Report Gains
description: ARCO and the Amerada Hess Corporation yesterday reported substantial gains in second-quarter earnings. Both companies cited sharply higher earnings from their exploration and production divisions.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
LARRY DAVIS, AT RIKERS, IS SAID TO STAB A GUARD
description: Larry Davis, who is being held in prison on charges of killing five drug dealers and wounding six police officers, stabbed a correction officer in the head with a ballpoint pen yesterday, officials said.

title: Iran Supporters Rally Anti-U.S. Volunteers
description: Moslem fundamentalists loyal to Iran urged Lebanon's Moslems today to join ''a mobilization campaign for a fight to the finish'' against the United States and its allies in the Middle East.

title: BANGLADESH IS TORN BY VIOLENT DEMANDS THAT PRESIDENT QUIT
description: Protesters demanding the resignation of the President, Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, battled in the streets today with riot police at the start of a two-day general strike called by opposition parties.

title: United Iran-Contra Report Expected From the 2 Panels
description: With the Iran-contra hearings nearing a conclusion, the chairman and vice chairman of the Senate select committee said today that they expected the Senate and House committees to be able to present a united report this fall with a statement of facts that is acceptable to all members.

title: PENNWALT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
McGWIRE CLOUTS 36TH HOMER
description: Mark McGwire had four hits, including his major league-leading 36th home run, and Dennis Lamp raised his career record against Detroit to 9-0 tonight as the Oakland Athletics beat the Tigers, 10-1.

title: Prices in New York Area Rise 0.5%
description: Consumer prices for the New York-northeastern New Jersey region rose five-tenths of 1 percent last month, driven by the rising cost of energy, food and housing, the Labor Department said yesterday.

title: Sandinistas Report Capture of Redeye Missile
description: Defense Minister Humberto Ortega Saavedra said today that Nicaraguan forces had captured a sophisticated Redeye antiaircraft weapon that was parachuted into Nicaragua for use by United States-backed guerrillas.

title: FLOOD TOLL NEAR 100, SEOUL SAYS
description: More than 100 people were feared dead after two days of torrential rain in South Korea caused floods and landslides that leveled villages, blocked roads and tore up train tracks, the state television said today.

title: ARCO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter results include a net gain of about $35 million from the favorable settlement of contract disputes and certain non-recurring charges.

title: Met Opera Changes Managerial Balance
description: THE Metropolitan Opera is evolving a new managerial structure in which Bruce Crawford, the general manager, will assume more of the artistic authority previously vested with James Levine, the artistic director.

title: WESTERN CO OF NORTH AMERCA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $90 million writedown of the carrying value of onshore oil services equipment.

title: Santo Domingo Journal; Old Hand Shows His Magic, Juggling $600 Million
description: Joaquin Balaguer is a few weeks away from his 80th birthday and virtually blind. But he is proving to be a dynamic President of this Caribbean country, fighting waste and corruption, directing a huge public works program and taxing the stamina of aides half his age.

title: Knicks, Rangers: Let's Go to the Tape
description: WWOR-TV and Madison Square Garden are discussing the possibility of limiting telecasts of most Knick and Ranger road games played on Mondays through Thursdays to the late-night hours.

title: FIRST NATIONAL CINCINNATI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GM HUGHES ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes the effect of a $37.2 million and $74.4 million adjustment to account for General Motors Corp.'s amortization of goodwill for the 1985 acquisition of Hughes Aircraft Co. for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes the effect of an adjustment to account for General Motors Corp.'s amortization of goodwill for the 1985 acquisition of Hughes Aircraft Co. of $37.2 million for the quarter and $74.4 million for the 6 months.

title: Sports People; Knight Is Sorry
description: In a letter dated June 27 and published yesterday in the Spanish-language newspaper, El Mundo, Coach Bobby Knight of Indiana said he was ''very sorry for whatever misunderstanding'' resulted following a confrontation with a policeman during the 1979 Pan American Games in Puerto Rico.

title: AT LAST, METS RESCUE DARLING
description: The Mets seemed well on their way to wasting another game yesterday in Shea Stadium, but they suddenly strung together six singles for four runs in the sixth inning and beat the Atlanta Braves, 4-3. And nobody was more impressed than Ron Darling.

title: Treasury Price Slide Continues
description: Treasury bond prices continued to slide lower yesterday, raising yields to their highest level since early June.

title: Kean Is Planning Arts Center For Newark With 8,000 Seats
description: Governor Kean presented plans today for a state center for the performing arts in downtown Newark that would be the second largest in the nation, after Lincoln Center.

title:
TWO TESTS OF THE BREADTH OF GLASNOST;
Allowing Publication of A Journal
description: LEAD: Sergei Grigoryants, who was released in February after serving 10 of his last 13 years in prison, is putting Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proclaimed policy of free expression to a critical test.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Mildew has appeared on the ceiling of my lakeside vacation cottage for the first time in many years. What will kill the mildew spores so that I can paint the ceiling?

title: AC by Superconductor
description: To the Editor:

title: G.E., a Pioneer in Radio and TV, Is Abandoning Production of Sets
description: The General Electric Company, bowing to unrelenting Japanese competition, said yesterday that it was selling its $3 billion-a-year consumer electronics business to Thomson S.A., France's Government-owned electronics giant.

title: BECTON DICKINSON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $574,000 and $5,186,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $2,738,000 for the quarter and $6,438,000 for the 6 months.

title: Icahn Plans Buyout Of T.W.A. Holders
description: Carl C. Icahn, chairman and owner of 73 percent of Trans World Airlines Inc., announced a plan yesterday to buy out the remaining public shareholders, turn the airline into a private company and give himself back practically all the $450 million he invested in the company a year and a half ago.

title: Genesis of Jewish Humor Sought in a Serious Series
description: If there is anything that is apt to prompt serious attention, it is the question of Jewish humor. As the topic of a series, it has been filling the house at the Jewish Museum for the last two years, and this weekend it returns for another annual check-up, which will take more than a month to complete.

title: HERS
description: LEAD: MY daughter has always been slight and compact, but she plants her feet firmly, heels first, as she walks. She has little hands and a small, slightly pointed face, now framed by a tumble of reddish curls. In her slim-waisted white cotton dress, trimmed with lace on the wide collar and flounced skirt, and her black ankle boots, she might be graduating in her great-great-grandmother's class of 1901.

title: LAKE'S RESCUE THREATENS EVERGLADES
description: Efforts to save ailing Lake Okeechobee are threatening to change the unique character of the Everglades, Florida's vast sawgrass marshland.

title: GREAT WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 5-for-2 stock split paid in May.

title: Great Notions Confront Small Realities
description: MANY New Yorkers cope with tiny kitchens, windowless bathrooms and inadequate closets by streamlining their lives or by just putting up with being cramped. Others have grander ideas. Instead of complaining, they make the most of their diminutive domains without sacrificing elegance or atmosphere.

title: Shultz and Others on the Iran Deal
description: Nov. 16, 1986: ''My own information about the operational aspects of what was going on was fragmentary at best.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz Nov. 17: ''There is a lot of what transpired that I don't know about.'' - Mr. Shultz Nov. 20: ''It was not kept from the Secretary of State. I'm somewhat surprised at the portrayal that it was. I told him repeatedly and often of every item that went on in this enterprise.'' - Robert C. McFarlane, former national security adviser Feb. 26, 1987: ''They simply distanced themselves from the program. They protected the record as to their own positions on this issue. They were not energetic in attempting to protect the President from the consequences of his personal commitment to freeing the hostages.'' - The Tower Commission report, referring to Mr. Shultz and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger March 5: ''I do not agree that my actions were designed somehow or other to make a record to protect myself. I don't operate that way. . . . I took the position that I wanted to know what I needed to know and the department should know what it needed to know to do our job.'' - Mr. Shultz March 14:''In the case of the Iranian arms sales, both Secretary Shultz and Secretary Weinberger advised me strongly not to pursue the initiative. I weighed their advice but decided in the end that the initiative was worth the risk and went forward. As we now know, it turned out they were right and I was wrong.'' - President Reagan July 17: ''I didn't withhold anything from them that they didn't want withheld from them.'' - Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter, former national security adviser, referring to Cabinet members

title: NAVY ENTERS GULF WITHOUT INCIDENT
description: Within striking range of Iranian bases and with their crews at a high state of alert, three United States warships escorted two re-registered Kuwaiti tankers into the Persian Gulf today.

title: FIRST EMPIRE STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
113,000 Claims On Robins Halted
description: A Federal judge has disallowed the claims of 113,000 women against the A. H. Robins Company because the claimants failed to meet a request for more information on the extent of injuries purportedly caused by the Dalkon Shield birth-control device. Federal District Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. said he would reinstate any claim if given adequate reason why a questionnaire was not returned. About 330,000 claims have been filed. Separately, Robins said that its second-quarter earnings fell 7.2 percent because of a $6.1 million after-tax charge to cover a jury award involving the device. Robins said it earned $7.7 million, or 32 cents a share, down from $8.3 million, or 34 cents a share, in the 1986 quarter. Revenue totaled $182.2 million, up 5.6 percent from $172.6 million a year earlier.

title: Software Move Set By I.B.M.
description: In its strongest move yet to become a major player in applications software, I.B.M. said today that it was forming a corporate division devoted specifically to developing computer programs for use in offices, factories and a range of industries.

title: UNION ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Year to June 30
CHARLES EBLE, FORMER CON EDISON CHAIRMAN
description: Charles E. Eble, a retired chairman and chief executive officer of the Consolidated Edison Company, died of complications of diabetes Tuesday at Saratoga Hospital in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived in Greenfield Center, N.Y.

title: UNION PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and includes a special after-tax restructuring charge of $945 million.

title: IMPERIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary after- tax charge of $179,000 for a penalty paid to the Federal Home Loan Bank for early repayment of debt and a tax credit of $59,000.

title: HOLIDAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $819,000 for the quarter and $3,456,000 for the 6 months. Results for the latest second quarter includes gains of $97.3 million from the sale of seven European Holiday Inn hotels and $30.8 million from the sale of the company's 50-percent interest in Residence Inn Co. Results also include gains from the sale of three U.S. hotels. The company said the $170 million after-tax proceeds from these sales will be used to reduce the company's debt. The company said it also recognized $22.4 million of expenses this year related to its recapitalization. The latest quarter and 6 months results include the company's share of operating income from Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino, prior to its sale in May 1986.

title: Beverly Hills Eases Its Ban On Smoking in Restaurants
description: The City Council, which put one of the toughest antismoking ordinances in the nation into effect in April, has decided to modify the new regulation.

title: Clarendon Bids For Argonaut
description: The Argonaut Group Inc. said today that the Clarendon Group Ltd. had offered to acquire the Los Angeles insurance company, for $52 a share, or about $600 million.

title: 2 Russians and Syrian Begin Orbital Flight to Mir Station
description: Syria's first man in space and two Soviet astronauts were launched today in a Soyuz spacecraft toward the Soviet Union's orbiting space station Mir, at the start of a 10-day mission.

title: An Alternative To the Rebate
description: MANUFACTURERS of consumer goods have long relied on an array of discounts and rebates to both consumers and retailers as a way of increasing sales. There are coupons, billions of them, printed every week in newspapers and magazines. There are millions of dollars in rebates. And there are the cooperative promotion programs, in which a carpet maker, for instance, pays part of a store owner's advertising costs if the store's ads mention the manufacturer's product.

title: NORTH'S TESTIMONY SET FOR RELEASE ON CASSETTE
description: At least two home video companies are racing to be the first to release excerpts of the Iran-contra testimony of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to video stores.

title: Hill Gets Oriole Post
description: Calvin Hill, the former Yale University and National Football League running back who was raised in Baltimore, has become the first black to be named to a high position in the Baltimore Orioles organization. The team owner, Edward Bennett Williams, appointed Hill, a Washington businessman, to the team's board of directors to fill the vacancy created by the death of Jack Dunn 3d.

title: 2 Black Executives Form Specialty Agency
description: Saatchi & Saatchi's vast worldwide holdings now include Jamison & Leary Advertising, an American specialty shop for advertising to black consumers. Jamison & Leary is a subsidiary of Saatchi's Backer Spielvogel Bates, which is itself the result of the recent merger of Backer & Spielvogel and Ted Bates Worldwide.

title: TELEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOVIET MAY BALK ON GULF ARMS BAN, AN OFFICIAL HINTS
description: Soviet support for a United Nations effort to end the Iran-Iraq war does not necessarily extend to a possible international embargo on arms shipments to the combatants, a Soviet official and Middle East diplomats said today.

title: Panel Votes Toshiba Ban
description: The House Armed Services Committee unanimously approved a bill today that would prohibit the Defense Department from buying the Toshiba Corporation's consumer products to sell in military exchange stores.

title: TECUMSEH PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Officials Say Inspector Cited 5th Amendment and Retired
description: The Inspector General of the New York City Housing Authority retired this month after citing his Fifth Amendment right to avoid self-incrimination before city investigators about charges that Housing Authority officials impeded a corruption inquiry, city officials said yesterday.

title: Leader Presses Blacks' Goals
description: John E. Jacob, the president of the National Urban League, today served notice that blacks would no longer be ''taken for granted'' politically, or economically.

title: Don McMahon Dies
description: Don McMahon, a relief pitcher with seven major-league teams from 1957-74, died tonight, hours after apparently suffering at heart attack while pitching batting practice for the Los Angeles Dodgers. He was 57 years old and had heart bypass surgery three and one-half years ago.

title: RYDER SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MAYTAG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $1,456,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and a loss of $2,462,000 from the sale of the discontinued ToastMaster unit for the 6 months.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alpo Petfoods, Allentown, Pa., a subsidiary of Grandmet USA Inc., named Joseph Sestek chairman and chief executive and Franklin W. Krum president and chief operating officer.

title: Contractors and Schools Agency Trade Blame for Poor Conditions
description: Dilapidated conditions in most of New York City's schools are due to the Board of Education's poorly paid building inspectors, late payments to contractors and long legal proceedings needed to dismiss unsatisfactory contractors, a State Senate committee was told yesterday.

title: TANDEM COMPUTERS INC(M) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JOSTENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After loss of $45,000 for the quarter and income of $671,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and a gain of $5,450,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations for both periods. c-After income from discontinued operations of $931,000 for the quarter and $1,824,000 for the year.

title: Gandhi Meets Gurkha Group In an Effort to End Violence
description: In an effort to end nearly a year of rising violence in eastern India, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi met today with the leader of Gurkha separatists and ruled out the creation of a special state for the group.

title: BRIDGEPORT COLLAPSE YIELDS JUST MANY THEORIES SO FAR
description: Three months after the L'Ambiance Plaza apartment complex collapsed, killing 28 construction workers, theories abound on the cause of the accident. But Federal investigators say they do not expect any answers before September.

title: THEATER: 'NOTHING BUT BUKOWSKI,' 2 ONE-ACTS
description: THERE are two running jokes in the playwright John Ford Noonan's comic tribute to the Los Angeles-based author and notoriously seedy roustabout Charles Bukowski. One is that the author, who exalts the gross, bestial aspects of life both in his writing and through his mammoth slovenliness, should be irresistibly attractive to beautiful young women. The second is that Mr. Bukowski isn't portrayed directly in either play.

title: Perpetual-Note Holders Offered Swap in London
description: Investors in the beleaguered market for perpetual floating-rate notes in London may exchange their holdings for new securities, according to a proposal announced yesterday by a group of securities dealers and an insurance concern.

title: Modest Homes, Cinderella Transformations
description: IT is a curious fact of our inflationary times that the typical two-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath house that cost $22,500 in the 1950's now often has a $225,000 price tag. While homeowners might be delighted in the decimal point's new position, the basic house - with small rooms, limited charm and cheap materials - often still looks like a $22,500 model.

title: SHIP'S INSURANCE RATES A CONCERN
description: The decision to fly American flags on two Kuwaiti oil tankers and provide them with United States Navy escorts through the Persian Gulf, has yet to raise the insurance rates that shipping operators pay to transport oil in the gulf. But shipping and insurance executives are anxiously monitoring the situation to see if that will happen.

title: PROVIDENT BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The per share earnings in 1986 are restated to reflect a change in accounting for loan acquisition costs.

title: Jewish Legislators Dine With Shultz
description: It was one of the hottest nights on record here Tuesday when Secretary of State George P. Shultz's car pulled up to the northwest Washington home of Representative James H. Scheuer, Democrat of Queens.

title: Blackmun Treatment Is Going as Expected
description: Treatment of Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the Supreme Court for recurrence of prostate cancer is proceeding as expected, a Mayo Clinic spokesman said today.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF INDIANA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain from an accounting change of $42,467,000.

title: Net at Morgan Stanley Rises
description: Morgan Stanley & Company said yesterday that it earned $62.4 million in the second quarter, up 37.1 percent from $45.5 million the year earlier, impressive results given the huge bond trading losses that hit some of the firm's competitors in April.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: F.B.I. Comes Word of a Possible New Director
description: Maybe, just maybe, the White House has found a candidate in its often embarrassing four-month search for a new Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigaiton.

title: NEWS GROUP FAULTS MILITARY DELAY ON GULF REPORTS
description: A newspaper group whose representative was among a pool of reporters traveling with the Navy convoy in the Persian Gulf sent a letter of protest to the Pentagon today about the delay in the military's release of four dispatches from the pool.

title: HUNTINGTON BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $25 million provision for possible loan losses. The figures restated for 10 percent stock dividend announced in May and acquisitions completed in 1986 which were accounted for as pooling of interest.

title: Digital Equipment Posts A 58% Rise in Earnings
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, whose profits have soared as those of other computer makers have faltered, said yesterday that net income in its fourth fiscal quarter jumped 58 percent, to $377.3 million.

title: Poindexter's Tale Stuns Lawmakers
description: Lawmakers from both parties say they are deeply dismayed at the picture of White House operations drawn by Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter in the Iran-contra hearings. They add that President Reagan must bear some measure of responsibility for the lying and deception practiced by his subordinates.

title: Boxing Notebook; HIGH ROLLERS ATTRACTED BY MAJOR FIGHTS
description: In recent years, the casinos of Las Vegas and Atlantic City have consistently won the bidding on the live rights to major fights. There's a simple enough reason for the near monopoly. Plainly put: Boxing pays.

title: Home Beat; Pairing Up With Plastics
description: IN 1986 Michel Hurst, near right, a chef, and Robert Swope, far right, a punk-rock singer, opened Full House, a shop that offers furnishings from the 40's through the 60's. They specialize in plastic objects made in the United States and Europe during the 60's. Right now, they have a collection of more than a dozen pieces of plastic furniture, including tables and chairs, and dozens more plastic accessories.

title: Fun and Games
description: A failing television station, with depressed ratings in a highly competitive market, decides to change its presentation completely. The desperate station manager, trying to find a magic formula to captivate new viewers, searches for a motif to dominate the station's programming, something with great appeal for many viewers that will be able to thrive in almost all programming environments.

title: Democrats Win, 15-14
description: Well, sports fans, the annual Congressional baseball game is over, and what a game it was.

title: New York to Ban Bicycles on 3 Major Avenues
description: In an effort to reduce accidents caused by speeding bicycle messengers, New York City will ban all bicyclists from Park, Madison and Fifth Avenues in midtown Manhattan between 10 A.M. and 4 P.M. on weekdays, under a three-month experiment announced yesterday by the Koch administration.

title: ON THE IRT: NEW RIDERS, NEW CARS, OLD COMPLAINTS
description: Even on a midweek morning, when many customers still have a supply of tokens, there is a line at the booth of the West 72d Street IRT station that would pass for a Monday morning line elsewhere in the subways.

title: Sears Profits Rise by 37%
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that its second-quarter earnings rose 37 percent, largely because of a $58 million after-tax gain from the sale of its Sears Savings Bank branch offices in California and because of record earnings from its Allstate insurance unit.

title: Harris Pleads Guilty
description: The Harris Corporation pleaded guilty in Federal court today to overcharging the Army for satellite antenna equipment and agreed to pay more than $4 million in restitution, penalties and fines. The plea-bargain agreement, negotiated for the company by former United States Attorney General Griffin B. Bell, leaves the Melbourne, Fla.-based military contractor free to continue to seek Government business. ''We are pleading guilty because we are guilty,'' Mr. Bell told Federal District Judge Patricia Fawsett.

title: PACCAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes restructuring charges totaling $9.5 million.

title: Kenner Rejects Bid; Asks S.E.C. Inquiry
description: Kenner Parker Toys Inc. rejected today a $41-a-share buyout proposal from New World Pictures Inc. and called for investigations into possible manipulation of its stock price before the bid was made.

title: NEWMONT MINING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $425,000 for the quarter and $900,000 for the 6 months. c-After a loss of $83,000 for the quarter and net of $237,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations, and extraordinary credits of $1,233,000 and $2,155,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June 1987. The year-earlier results restated to show Foote Mineral Co. as a discontinued operation, and Magma Copper Co. as an investment held for distribution. The net from operations for the latest quarter and 6 months include pre- tax gains of $338 million from sales of shares of subsidiaries to the public; in the year-ago periods that gain was $43 million.

title: Auto Emission Curbs Sought
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed two rules to reduce the emission of gasoline vapor that causes ozone pollution in many urban areas. One rule would require an upgrading of gasoline vapor recovery systems in new cars and the other would require refiners and blenders to make gasoline less subject to evaporation. Lee Thomas, the E.P.A. administrator, told a news conference that the first rule would add about $19 to the cost of an automobile. Fred Bowditch of the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association said the move could add from $30 to $80 to the cost of a car.

title: SEARS, ROEBUCK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $58 million gain on the sale of Sears Savings Bank branch offices in California and a $32 million loss resulting from the early retirement of long-term debt.

title: Two Dance Companies Set for Mostly Mozart
description: The Lar Lubovitch Dance Company and New York Baroque Dance Company are to perform tonight at 8 at Avery Fisher Hall in a program called ''Mozart and the Dance.''

title: Aquino Decrees A Compromise On Land Issue
description: President Corazon C. Aquino issued a compromise decree on land redistribution today that left open a number of crucial questions and drew immediate criticism from both landowners' and farmers' groups.

title: If High Court Is So Political, Let's Elect Justices
description: To the Editor:

title: PPG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LEWIS R. EISNER
description: Lewis R. Eisner, president and chief executive officer of Lewis R. Eisner & Company, a private investment banking and management resources company, died of a ruptured aorta Tuesday at White Plains Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Give New York Schools Real Decentralization
description: To the Editor:

title: Owner of Store Is Charged in Explosion
description: Propane was stored illegally at the Brooklyn plumbing supply store that was leveled Tuesday by a propane explosion that killed 4 people and injured 11, according to the authorities. More than 20 other tanks - of propane and acetylene - were removed from the rubble yesterday.

title: British Trade Deficit
description: Britain registered a trade deficit in May of $:561 million, or about $897 million at current exchange rates, the worst performance since last August, the Government said. The visible trade deficit of $:1.16 billion was offset by an estimated surplus of $:600 million in so-called invisible trade, including shipping, banking and tourism, the Trade and Industry Department said today. Government officials attributed the deficit to booming sales of imported goods in stores.

title: ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company attributed the improved results partly to its Signode unit, which Illinois Tool acquired in September 1986.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After one-time charges in last year's first quarter of $335 million.

title: WASHINGTON POST CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Tax 'Corrections'
description: Congressional tax-writers have been trying for months to push through a ''technical corrections'' bill, a way to fix drafting errors and make other minor changes to the sweeping Tax Reform Act of 1986. But the corrections bill has been delayed numerous times because many representatives and senators see the legislation as an opportunity to toss in a tax break for a pet interest, even if there is little chance it will end up in the bill.

title: 'Anyone' Can Help the Homeless
description: Nancy Abraham is a practical woman. The 39-year-old Shearson Lehman vice president is also impatient, tenacious and not above being a pest. She is, in other words, a person who gets things done. What Ms. Abraham wanted to do was help New York City's homeless, and in particular the group she thought most ''helpable'' - mothers and their children.

title: TWO PORTRAITS OF SHULTZ: CHALLENGE FOR IRAN PANEL
description: Two contrasting pictures of Secretary of State George P. Shultz have emerged from the Iran-contra hearings.

title: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is a unit of General Motors Corp.

title: MARION LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The prior year earnings include a gain of $2 million from the sale of two product lines. The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in April 1987.

title: Right, Let's Talk About Iran Policy
description: Like almost every witness in the Iran-contra hearings, Rear Adm. John Poindexter charged Congress with looking at the little picture, the trivia -deceit within the Administration, lies to Congress, laws twisted here and there. He challenged critics to focus on the national interest, on policy.

title: THE RECEIVER AND A POSSIBLE END-AROUND PLAY
description: Cris Carter, the all-America wide receiver from Ohio State who last week was ruled ineligible for next season because he signed with an agent, may have been lured into the arrangement by his brother, according to Carter's lawyer, who said the brother secretly received thousands of dollars from the agent.

title: Fannie Mae Appoints Chief Operating Officer
description: Roger E. Birk, who surprised many in the securities industry when he stepped down as chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch & Company a little more than two years ago, has been named president and chief operating officer at the Federal National Mortgage Association, Fannie Mae said yesterday.

title: LONGTIME CO-HOST OF 'TODAY'
description: Jack Lescoulie, one of the original stars of NBC's ''Today'' show, died of colon cancer yesterday at St. Francis Hospital in Memphis. He was 75 years old.

title: AGENCY AND CONGRESS FACE CLASH OVER PATENTING OF ANIMALS
description: Congress is heading toward a confrontation with the United States Patent and Trademark Office over a decision to allow inventors to patent animals produced by genetic manipulation.

title: Farmers Need Fair Trade, Not Just Free Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: GORBACHEV AGREES TO U.S. SUGGESTION FOR A MISSILE BAN
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said in an interview published today that the Soviet Union was prepared to accept a worldwide ban on medium-range and short-range missiles.

title: MOVE BY FRENCH SUPRISES AMERICAN EX-COLLEGUES
description: Although the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution collaborated with French oceanographers in the project that found the wreck of the Titanic two years ago, the French group's salvage expedition, announced today, has taken the Americans by surprise.

title: GENENTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $424,000 and $889,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in January.

title: Houston Overtaken by Dallas In U.S. Metropolitan Census
description: The Dallas area edged past its rival Houston in the Census Bureau's latest population estimates for the nation's 281 metropolitan areas, but New York continued to lead the list by a wide margin.

title: Auto Emission Curbs Sought
description: The Environmental Protection Agency Wednesday proposed two rules to reduce the emission of gasoline vapor that causes ozone pollution in many urban areas. One rule would require an upgrading of gasoline vapor recovery systems in new cars and the other would require refiners and blenders to make gasoline less subject to evaporation.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JULY 24, 1987
description: International A2-10

title: CROQUET OVERLOOKING THE HUDSON
description: Concerts, croquet and a nature walk are just a few of the activities available in the Hudson Valley this weekend.

title: Advertising; P.&G. Signs Fox Contract
description: Procter & Gamble has just signed a contract that will make it the biggest advertiser on Rupert Murdoch's Fox Broadcasting Company network. It is a company that is long accustomed to being the biggest advertiser in the media it uses.

title: DIME SAVINGS BANK OF WALLNGFORD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes provisions for loan losses of $59,000 for the quarter and $105,000 for the 6 months, and net securities gains of $19,000 and $309,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes provisions for loan losses of $30,000 for the quarter and $68,000 for the 6 months, and net securities gains of $219,000 and $262,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Gulf Convoy Sails On Without Any Trouble
description: The convoy of Kuwaiti tankers and American warships passed the midpoint in the gulf voyage today without incident and are expected to arrive Friday in waters off Kuwait, the Pentagon said.

title: Racing Notebook; AT SALES, A MERE $31.3 MILLION
description: Last year, the four Maktoum brothers from the Persian Gulf emirate of Dubai spent $40.2 million on horseflesh at the Keeneland select yearling sales. This year, they spent a mere $31.3 million. That difference, $8.9 million, accounted for almost the entire 9 percent drop in average prices at this year's sales, which concluded Tuesday night in Lexington, Ky.

title: U.S. Sues Integrated Housing Complex in Chicago on Use of Racial Quotas
description: The Justice Department sued a fully integrated housing complex here today, saying the racial quotas used to achieve that integration unlawfully discriminated against blacks.

title: COUTURE: WAITING FOR LACROIX
description: Christian Lacroix will open the fall and winter couture showings in Paris Sunday with his first collection under his own name. In the 40 years since Christian Dior revived the couture with the wasp waists and full skirts of the collection that was dubbed the New Look, no fashion show has evoked the same anticipation.

title: A Witness in Scandals Must Serve Probation
description: Robert Richards, a businessman who cooperated with prosecutors in the municipal corruption scandals in New York City, was given a suspended sentence yesterday and was placed on probation for three years.

title: Hugh Bryant Dies as He Sings Tribute at Lee Gaines Funeral
description: Hugh Bryant, baritone for the jazz and pop vocal group The Delta Rhythm Boys, collapsed and died while singing a tribute Wednesday at the funeral of the group's founder.

title: COMAIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Tesoro Executives Cleared in Lawsuit
description: A Texas jury has cleared top executives of the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation of claims that management lied to investors and manipulated stock prices as part of an unsuccessful secret plan to take the company private. The state court jury found Tesoro's founder and chairman, Robert V. West, and other executives of the San Antonio-based company not guilty of allegations made by shareholders in a class action lawsuit.

title: ART ON THE BEACH RETURNS, IN A NEW SETTING
description: Art on the Beach, one of the most popular and poetic of summer arts festivals, was mourned when it closed two years ago after having lost its dazzling site on a sandy landfill in TriBeCa. But Creative Time, the nonprofit arts organization that is producing the series, will reopen Art on the Beach tonight on the East River in what seems to be another perfect spot. This summer, the series will unfold beyond a green hill on six green acres at Hunters Point in Long Island City, Queens.

title: GOODEN IS FOCUS OF 'CONCERN'
description: Seven weeks after he returned to the Mets from treatment for cocaine abuse, Dwight Gooden says that his pitching and his personal life are going ''better than I expected.'' But he acknowledges that he now takes ''a beer or two with the guys,'' although beer was identified as the initial source of his problem, and the Mets concede that ''it is a matter of concern.''

title: FRUIT OF THE LOOM reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net of $5 million for both the quarter and 6 months both from discontinued operations; and the 6-month also includes a loss of $56,200,000 from repayment of debt related to restructuring. c-Includes net of $400,000 for the quarter and a loss of $1,400,000 for the 6 months both from discontinued operations. Year-ago share earnings were not reported because the company was not public at that time.

title: A FERVOR FOR FILM PAYS OFF: ANDY GARCIA
description: IN ''The Untouchables,'' Andy Garcia leads a charmed life as the rookie cop who helps Eliot Ness go after Al Capone. Unlike lots of other characters in the Brian De Palma film, he doesn't get killed.

title: Josephine Jacobsen Gets Poetry Fellowship
description: Josephine Jacobsen, the author of seven books of poetry, has been awarded the $10,000 Fellowship of the Academy of American Poets.

title: Loss at BankAmerica: A Record $1.14 Billion
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 - With a $1.1 billion special addition to its reserve for loan losses, the BankAmerica Corporation today reported its largest quarterly loss to date, $1.14 billion.

title: A Long Island 'Lucia'
description: The National Grand Opera is to present ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' tomorrow evening at 8 o'clock at the Harry Chapin Theater in Eisenhower Park, East Meadow, L.I. The cast includes Denia Mazzola, soprano, and Michael Austin, tenor. The performance is free. Information and directions: (516) 248-6772.

title: Off Center to Feature 'Street of Crocodiles'
description: The Public Broadcasting Service's usually cheerful avant-garde series ''Alive From Off Center'' takes a surrealistic spin into hell with ''Street of Crocodiles,'' a work of puppet animation created by Timothy and Stephen Quay, American graphic artists and film makers who live in London.

title: REAGAN NAMES 12 TO PANEL ON AIDS
description: President Reagan named the 12 members of a national commission on AIDS today and pledged to send the deadly disease ''the way of smallpox and polio.''

title: New Top Executive At Delta Air Lines
description: Ronald W. Allen, president and chief operating officer of Delta Air Lines Inc., has been named chairman and chief executive. He replaces David C. Garrett Jr., who recently reached age 65, Delta's mandatory retirement age for senior executives.

title: Bossy Puts Pain, Olympics Aside
description: He is still bothered by the mysteri-ous back ailment that spoiled his 10th season in professional hockey and has threatened to foreshorten his career, but Mike Bossy plans to report to the Islanders' training camp in September, anyway, and has no thought of abandoning the club in order to play for Canada in the 1988 Winter Olympics.

title: Don't Abolish Medicare
description: To the Editor:

title: 104 POUNDS OFF, A POLITICAL HEAVYWEIGHT NO MORE
description: Representative Gary L. Ackerman was startled by a stranger in his house one day last week - himself.

title: Support for Contra Aid Continues to Increase
description: Support for aid to the Nicaraguan contras continued to increase in the last week, but the latest New York York Times/CBS News poll, taken Tuesday and Wednesday, still shows 49 percent of the public opposed and only 40 percent in favor.

title: Stocks Weaken Despite Dow Gain
description: The stock market weakened again yesterday, even though the Dow Jones industrial average managed a 1.76-point gain to close at 2,471.94.

title: Kohlberg, Kravis Fund
description: Oregon and other states plan to invest millions of dollars in the $5 billion fund being raised by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company to finance leveraged buyouts, according to state officials and the New York-based investment firm.

title: A SECRETARY WHO OFFERED RESIGNATION 3 TIMES
description: During his testimony yesterday, Secretary of State George P. Shultz was asked if he had ever intended to resign.

title: The Germans Aren't Tempted
description: Thirty-eight years after the establishment of two rival states in Germany, the leader of the Communist East is coming to visit the capitalist West for the first time this September.

title: CHANGES PROPOSED IN AVIATION AGENCY
description: Experts today urged a Presidential commission to press for major changes in the Federal Aviation Administration. They warned that fundamental restructuring and strengthening of the agency were necessary for it to maintain flight safety while continuing to handle a surge in air traffic brought on by deregulation of the airline industry.

title: Union Asserts New York City Subverted a Civil Service Test
description: The union representing administrative employees in New York City government yesterday accused three agencies of subverting Civil Service tests to keep unqualified people on the job and announced it had filed papers seeking a contempt-of-court order.

title: UNIVERSAL HEALTH SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $701,000 for the quarter, and for the 6 months includes a gain of $10,178,000, including a $9.2 million gain on marketable securities.

title: Ford Posts 38.9% Rise In Profits
description: Closing the books on one of the best quarters ever for Detroit's automobile makers, the Ford Motor Company today reported a 38.9 percent rise in earnings, while the General Motors Corporation posted a 3.9 percent decline.

title: Scouting; Mattingly Hoax
description: The reporter for a national magazine must have thought he had stumbled on one of the baseball stories of the year - a 10-minute clubhouse interview with Don Mattingly in Minneapolis revealing an egotistical, boastful, obnoxious streak that the Yankee first baseman had never shown before.

title: Confinement of Marine In Spy Case to Be Eased
description: The attorney for Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree, the marine who is being court-martialed here on espionage charges, successfully sought today to have his client released from what he called a ''medieval'' solitary confinement.

title: SOO LINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes for the quarter a pretax gain of $9.7 million from the sale of the company's headquarters building.

title: 'EXTREMELY DANGEROUS' PRISONER FLEES RIKERS ISLAND
description: A 27 year old man who once served a prison term for manslaughter and was described by the authorities as ''extremely dangerous'' escaped from a dormitory-style jail annex on Rikers Island early yesterday by breaking a hole through the wall of the prefabricated structure, the police said.

title: AFFILIATED BANKSHARES OF COLORADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Comsat's President Resigns
description: The Communications Satellite Corporation said today that Marcel P. Joseph is stepping down as president of the telecommunications company, which earlier this month sold off all but two of its unregulated businesses.

title: Xerox Profits Rise by 26.2%
description: The Xerox Corporation's profits rose 26.2 percent in the second quarter, as results improved in both business products and financial services, the company said today.

title: PICKING THE RIGHT GEAR FOR SURF FISHING
description: Would-be surf fishermen are often overwhelmed by the plethora of equipment they encounter in a well-stocked tackle shop.

title: No Headline
description: A 4-year-old boy playing with a shotgun accidentally shot his mother, the authorities here said. The boy's mother, Veronica Ibarra, 35, was in satisfactory condition today with a wound in her abdomen. The boy, Pete Ibarra 4th, cried as he spoke with reporters Wednesday, shortly after the shooting. ''I shot Mommy,'' he said. The gun belonged to the child's father and had been stored in a bedroom closet, said the boy's 19-year-old brother, Jesse.

title: ADVISORY COUNCIL WARNS NASA OF 'HOLDOVER' MANAGEMENT WOES
description: The National Research Council expressed concern today that space agency managers, at least at some levels of the organization, were hiding behind review boards and failing to take individual responsibility for improving the stricken space shuttle.

title: STEINBRENNER BACKS PINIELLA'S CRITICISM
description: Are the Yankees in need of an attitude adjustment hour?

title: MORTGAGE INVESTMENTS PLUS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Allied Settles S.E.C. Charges
description: The Allied Stores Corporation has settled Federal civil charges that it had violated disclosure rules during its unsuccessful battle to avert a hostile takeover from the Campeau Corporation.

title: AMETEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $6,300,000 on the sale of properties and securities, and a charge of $4,300,000 from equipment writedowns and consolidation of certain operations for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: BIG-CITY MAYORS URGING CHANGES FOR NEXT CENSUS
description: The Mayors of New York City, Los Angeles, Chicago and Kansas City, Mo., yesterday urged the head of the Federal Census Bureau to use statistical adjustments in the 1990 Census to avoid undercounting black and Hispanic citizens.

title: FIRSTIER FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Aga A.B., Stockholm, which produces industrial and medical gases, said it would acquire two Norsk Hydro A.S. Industrial Gas units based in Sweden and would take a majority stake in the Finnish company Oy Finsk Kolsyreindustri A.B.

title: Of History and Honor: Shultz's Story
description: He is, by nature and training, a placid man who seldom raises his voice and almost never loses control of his emotions. As an academic and a labor negotiator, George P. Shultz learned to study the record deliberately, reach a conclusion and then, almost diffidently, try to persuade others to share his judgment.

title: VISUAL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $55,001, a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $19,551 and a tax credit of $45,000.

title: FIRST VALLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago results are restated to include the company's West Side Bancorp Inc. unit, which affiliated with First Valley in December 1986.

title: AMDAHL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Zydeco in the Park
description: Fernest and the Thunders, a zydeco band from Louisiana, are to play a free concert tomorrow at 3 P.M. at the Central Park Band Shell, in the middle of the park at 72d Street, presented by New York City's Summerstage series (860-1335).

title: INSIDE
description: A Quandary for Teheran

title: Scientists Promote Visits to Soviet
description: When members of Congress begin campaigning for re-election next year, a lot of them are likely to hear a new kind of personal question from their constituents: ''In the light of your comments on the Soviet Union, may I ask if you have ever been there?''

title: Respite in Conflict Needed but Feared
description: Since United States warships began escorting Kuwaiti tankers under the American flag into the Persian Gulf, the Iranians have issued a barrage of threats and statements suggesting the brink of war.

title: MUSICAL PRODIGIES STRIVE FOR HARMONY ONSTAGE AND OFF
description: ALMOST exactly one year ago, Midori, a Japanese-born, Juilliard-trained, 14-year-old violinist, dazzled a Tanglewood Festival audience by overcoming not one but two broken E strings and tossing off what was by all accounts a thrilling performance of Leonard Bernstein's Serenade. Since then, increased curiosity about prodigiously gifted musicians has focused attention on other youngsters forging careers.

title: A DEBATE ON MAKING SECRETS AND KEEPING THEM
description: How can the need for secrecy in intelligence operations be balanced against Congress's demand to oversee those operations?

title: Editor Is Found Slain At Home in the Village
description: A 57-year-old travel-magazine editor was found stabbed to death in his ransacked Greenwich Village apartment yesterday, the police said.

title: BUSINESS CARDS TOMORROW reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't think desirable ends justify means of lying, deceiving, of doing things that are outside our Constitutional processes.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz. [ A1:6. ]

title: LOWELL INSTITUTION FOR SAVNGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company converted to stock form in May 1986.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMESS
description: PSYCHIATRY AND THE CINEMA. By Krin Gabbard and Glen O. Gabbard. 304 pages. Illustrated. University of Chicago Press. $24.95

title: ART PEOPLE
description: Neo-Geo's Newest

title: Policing New York's Tailpipes
description: Why do only 7 percent of automobiles in the New York metropolitan area fail tests for pollutant emissions when the national failure rate runs 20 percent to 35 percent? The answer is inadequate testing, and it threatens air quality.

title: OHIO EDISON CO reports earnings for 12mo June 30
SHULTZ PROPOSES TO CHANGE SYSTEM
description: George P. Shultz, the Secretary of State and veteran of four Cabinet posts, used his testimony before the Iran-contra panel today to offer a wide-ranging prescription for solving the structural problems that he said had led to the Iran-contra affair.

title: NORTH KOREANS PROPOSE REDUCTION OF TROOPS IN THE NORTH AND SOUTH
description: North Korea today proposed vast troop reductions by both North and South Korea, and said that it would cut its own forces by 100,000 before the end of the year to ''open up a practical breakthrough.''

title: Sports People; Red Sox Drop Buckner
description: Bill Buckner, owner of 2,542 major-league hits and one unforgettable World Series error, was released yesterday to make room for the Boston Red Sox youth movement. Unable to trade the 37-year-old first baseman because of his $800,000 salary, the Red Sox cut him loose and promoted Sam Horn, a 23-year-old designated hitter who was leading the International League in home runs and runs batted in.

title: The Senate Trashes Trade
description: The Senate's foreign trade bill was too protectionist in overall thrust when debate began last month. Now, as approved by a resounding 71 to 27 majority, its final details are even worse.

title: REGAL-BELOIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PROTESTS PLANNED FOR POPE'S VISIT
