description: Feminists and religious groups seeking equal rights for women today announced a series of rallies to protest Vatican policies concerning women when Pope John Paul II visits the United States in September.

title: COACHMEN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TANDON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Net loss and includes for the quarter an extraordinary charge of $627,000 from reversal of a tax credit. The company said its year-ago third quarter and 9-month results did not include U.S. retail sales of Tandon brand name computers, which were introduced in U.S. dealer markets later in the year.

title: MORTGAGE & REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SENATE SHOULD CONSIDER THE OPINIONS OF HIGH COURT NOMINEES, POLL FINDS
description: Americans say the Senate should attach a great deal of importance to a Supreme Court nominee's positions on constitutional issues in weighing confirmation, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: FIRST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $2,741,000 and a net charge of $628,000 from the penalty incurred on pre-payment of debt for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $596,000 and $1,279,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Why Can't We Form a National Health Policy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Kurnit: Pro Bono For Profit
description: KURNIT COMMUNICATIONS was founded a year ago to create advertising for the public good while not going broke doing it. It's Shepard Kurnit's way of paying back a system that has been very good to him.

title: ORIOLES BEAT ROYALS FOR NINTH IN A ROW
description: Eric Bell pitched a five-hitter and Cal Ripken Jr. drove in two runs tonight as the Baltimore Orioles beat the Kansas City Royals, 2-1, for their ninth consecutive victory.

title: BANKVERMONT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LAXALT IS TRYING TO CHIP AWAY AT BUSH'S LEAD
description: How does a rival Republican Presidential candidate chip away at Vice President Bush, the party's perceived front-runner, without violating what some call the party's 11th commandment: ''Thou shalt not speak ill of any other Republican''?

title: Now Wrap Up a Missile Pact
description: Mikhail Gorbachev has thrown aside the last major obstacle to a nuclear arms treaty. He has accepted President Reagan's proposal to eliminate all medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles in Asia as well as in Europe. There is now no serious excuse for failure to resolve remaining differences.

title: Lam Jones Sent to 49ers
description: With rookies, free agents and selected veterans scheduled to report to camp today, the Jets continued their frenzied bookkeeping yesterday by trading Johnny (Lam) Jones, their often-injured wide receiver, to the San Francisco 49ers for a ''high-to-middle'' but undisclosed 1988 draft choice. The Jets also signed their third-round choice, Onzy Elam, a 6-foot-2-inch, 225-pound linebacker from Tennessee State to a series of one-year contracts.

title: Daimler-Benz Names Leader
description: Daimler-Benz A.G., the luxury-car maker that is West Germany's largest company, said that its deputy chief executive, Edzard Reuter, would replace the chairman, Werner Breitschwerdt, effective Sept. 1.

title: Union Carbide Profits Decline
description: The Union Carbide Corporarion said yesterday that it earned $69 million, or 52 cents a share, in the second quarter, down 82.2 percent from $388 million, or $3.97 a share, a year ago.

title: Thomson Seeks Size To Take On Japanese
description: Since taking the helm of the Thomson Group five years ago, Alain Gomez has been dramatically reorganizing France's largest electronics company, determined to turn Thomson into a power capable of taking on the Japanese and other East Asian competitors.

title: A FRESH BREEZE IN SUMMER
description: How to stay cool as hot air settles in for the summer on New York's streets? Some beat the heat the old-fashioned way: they churn it, fans in hand. Fans of fanning can easily find precursors. Madame Butterfly did it with delicacy. Karl Lagerfeld, the French designer, is so enamored of his fans that he carries them constantly and has even used them as the logo on his designs. There are folding fans, leaf-shaped woven fans, and, for those who can't stand to expend any effort whatsoever, battery-driven fans like the ones used by the title character in William Kotzwinkle's novel ''The Fan Man.''

title: SENATE REJECTS DEMOCRATIC PLAN FOR AUTOMATIC CUTS IN SPENDING
description: The Democratic-controlled Senate today handily defeated a proposal to give the budget-balancing law a new automatic mechanism for making spending cuts.

title: NEIGHBORS YOUNG AND OLD OFFER EACH OTHER A HAND
description: Gina Petrushka and Brenda Erskines appear an unlikely pair. One wears a bright-yellow jump suit and wraps a colored scarf around her head, while the other buttons her collar up to her chin and twists her hair into a small, prim knot. One leans on a cane for support; the other strides unaided. One is elderly; the other is 19 years old.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Sonny Rhodes and Frankie Lee, Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077). Sonny Rhodes would be a compelling blues performer even if he didn't play a lap steel guitar and wear a turban. As it is, he's unique. Frankie Lee is a soul singer with deep gospel roots. Their Texas-California Blue Revue is to play tonight and tomorrow night around 9:30 P.M. and midnight. Admission is $10.

title: Advertising; WCRS Rules Out Bid for Bozell, Jacobs
description: Britain's WCRS Group, which has been rumored to be interested in acquiring Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt from Lorimar Telepictures, which in turn has announced plans to divest itself of it, did indeed take a look at the company, according to Tim Breene, deputy group chief executive of WCRS, but decided about a week ago not to make any kind of offer.

title: CHARIOT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said share earnings reflect a 10-percent stock dividend paid last month.

title: NEWELL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lawsuit Challenges Alien Re-Entry Rule In Amnesty Program
description: An aspect of the immigration service's amnesty program that blocks amnesty for some aliens who briefly left the United States in the last five years has been challenged in Federal District Court here by a coalition of rights groups.

title: ALLTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said year-ago earnings are restated for a 3-for-2 stock split distributed in May.

title: 'EVERYBODY WAS SAYING I'M DISLOYAL
description: In his testimony yesterday at the Congressional hearings in Washington, George P. Shultz told of a period in November 1986 when he felt himself under fire from all directions.

title: ACCO WORLD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AIDES SAY NEW PROCEDURES WILL PREVENT POLICY SECRETS
description: White House officials say new procedures are in place to prevent the policy isolation that Secretary of State George P. Shultz described in testimony before the Congressional Iran-contra committees today.

title: RUSSIAN OPTIMISTIC ON MISSILE ACCORD
description: A Soviet arms negotiator said today that an accord on medium- and short-range missiles could be concluded within two months, but he reaffirmed Moscow's insistence that American warheads designed to fit West German missiles must be eliminated.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tour de France Spaniard Retains Lead: Pedro Delgado of Spain retained the overall lead yesterday after the 22d stage, a 115-mile mountain course from La Plagne to Morzine, France. Another Spaniard, Eduardo Chozas, won the stage after a solitary breakaway at the 43-mile mark. Stephen Roche of Ireland, in second place over all, reduced Delgado's lead from 39 to 21 seconds, which put him in a position to pass Delgado in the 24th stage tomorrow, a time trial encircling Dijon. The race will end Sunday in Paris. Jeannie Longo of France won the 13th stage of the women's race to regain the overall lead from Maria Canins of Italy. Longo leads Canins by 2:52. With two stages remaining, Longo is expected to win the tour in her third attempt. (AP) Baseball The Streak Goes On: The Salt Lake City Trappers ran their winning streak to 26 games, the longest in organized baseball in 41 years, by beating the Idaho Falls Braves, 14-4, last night in a Pioneer League game. The professional record is 27 straight victories, set by Corsicana of the Texas League in 1902 and matched by the old Baltimore Orioles of the International League in 1921. The Trappers will go for their 27th straight tonight against the Pocatello Giants.(AP) Boxing Snipes Wins by Knockout: Renaldo (Mister) Snipes won the Continental Americas heavyweight title last night when he knocked out Terry Anderson at 2:40 of the 10th round of a scheduled 12-round bout in Felt Forum. Snipes showed little proficiency in a fight that was frequently booed for lack of action by a crowd of 1,746. The fighters spent most of the first nine rounds standing at close range and throwing occasional punches that rarely made impact. Late in the 10th round, Snipes caught Anderson with a right uppercut to the chin. Anderson dropped to one knee and took the mandatory eight count. Snipes, who is from Yonkers, did not take much longer to finish off Anderson, who is from Tampa, Fla. He nailed Anderson with a left hook and, as Anderson began to fall, landed a grazing right. This time, Anderson fell backward onto the canvas. The referee, Arthur Mercante Jr., counted to six and then waved an end to the bout. Snipes's record is 29-6-1 with 14 knockouts. Anderson's is 15-2 with 14 knockouts. Golf Dougherty Leads: Ed Dougherty, trying to re-establish himself on the PGA Tour after working for several years as a club pro, set a first-round tournament record yesterday with an eight-under-par 64 for a one-stroke lead in the $600,000 Buick Open in Grand Blanc, Mich. Dougherty had seven birdies, one eagle and one bogey on the 7,014-yard, par-72 Warwick Hills Golf and Country Club course.(AP)

title: CRACK TO HOPSCOTCH: PURGING 107TH STREET
description: On the same block of West 107th Street where crack dealers once congregated like spice merchants in a Middle Eastern bazaar, a little girl was playing hopscotch the other day. The mothers who used to warn their children to walk down some other street were watching them roller skate and shoot baskets. And every half-hour or so, a few police officers would stroll past, just to make sure none of the illicit entrepreneurs had returned.

title: GROVE BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company went public in August.

title: JUDGE EMERGES AS CHOICE TO HEAD F.B.I.
description: Federal District Judge William S. Sessions emerged tonight as the leading candidate to head the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: 3 Innings for Tudor
description: John Tudor, the left-hander sidelined since April 19 with a broken leg suffered when Barry Lyons, the Mets' rookie catcher, crashed into him while chasing a foul into the dugout, pitched three innings for the St. Louis Cardinals' American Association club Wednesday night.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Apollo Computer Inc., Chelmsford, Mass., appointed Roland D. Pampel president and chief operating officer, succeeding Thomas A. Vanderslice, who will remain as chief executive and chairman.

title: ENDY A. ANDERSON
description: Endy A. Anderson, a manufacturer of plastics, died last Friday in an automobile accident on the Cross Westchester Expressway in Rye, N.Y. He was 72 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Sports of the Times; The Testing Of L.T.
description: The impression given in the Sport magazine excerpt of the forthcoming autobiography, ''LT: Living on the Edge,'' by Lawrence Taylor with David Falkner, is that Giants officials knew of Taylor's cocaine problem and, because he was such a good player, did nothing about it.

title: FFB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest second quarter includes a one-time writeoff of $680,000 for the FSLIC secondary reserve and a one- time after-tax gain of $2.2 million on a real estate investment. The company went public in June 1986.

title: VISTA CHEMICAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $8,012,000 on the sale of an interest in the company's Argentine affiliate.

title: Reichhold Looking
description: Repeating an announcement it made more than three weeks ago, Reichhold Chemicals Inc. said it was pursuing all superior alternatives to a $52.50-a-share offer by Dainippon Ink and Chemicals Inc. to buy the company for $473 million. It said it was studying a sale or a restructuring plan, but the announcement suggested that the Japanese offer was the only one to date. Reichhold stock slid $2.375, to $59.875, in heavy trading yesterday. Reichhold said it had received a letter from Dainippon saying it would not increase its offer at this time and urging Reichhold not to commit itself to defensive deals with bidders.

title: Try That With Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Diner's Journal
description: POOLSIDE dining near Times Square? That is just one of the many appeals of Manhattan Island, a three-week-old restaurant at the site of the former Gardenia, in the Manhattan Plaza Health Club, Ninth Avenue at 43d Street. The sunny, two-level dining room, done in a tropical theme with lots of wicker, colorful fabrics and greenery, faces the health club's rooftop pool. Umbrella-shaded outdoor tables provide a nice spot for a summer lunch.

title: LAUGH BARGAINS FOR A SUMMER NIGHT
description: IT'S only fitting that Elayne Boosler, one of the most likable standup comics in the country, should harbor a special fondness for Jackie Gleason.

title: IMPERIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes after-tax gains of $678,000, or 6 cents a share, from the sale of certain assets for the quarter and after-tax gains of $25,740,000, or $2.50 a share, principally from the sale of the company's insurance premium division in March 1986 for the 6 months.

title: LAC MINERALS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The figures include the results of Page-Williams Mine.

title: Two Giants Swap Ambitions
description: In its huge trade of businesses with Thomson S.A. of France, the General Electric Company seems to be getting the better end of the deal. On the surface, it appears to be exchanging its low-growth, low-margin consumer electronics business for a bigger piece of a much more alluring high-technology business: medical imaging.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JULY 24, 1987
description: Companies

title: Sosnoff's Caesars Stake
description: Martin T. Sosnoff, a New York investor, said today he had bought contracts to buy 445,000 shares of Caesars World Inc. common stock, equal to about 1.3 percent of the company's common stock. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Sosnoff, who recently made an unsuccessful bid for the company, said he had bought the contracts from July 20 to July 22, for $9.37 each. Mr. Sosnoff, who owns about 4.2 million Caesars World common shhares, holds contracts to buy about 2 million more, or about 6.1 percent of the total outstanding.

title: Loan Set for Argentina
description: The International Monetary Fund said its executive board had approved a $1.4 billion 14-month standby loan for Argentina. The fund said the decision followed the conclusion of financial arrangements and represented its board's approval of the country's economic policies. Last week, the fund approved $654 million from its compensatory financing facility, which grants loans to nations hurt by depressed commodity prices. Commercial banks recently agreed to lend Argentina $1.95 billion.

title: Setbacks For Data General
description: The Data General Corporation yesterday announced a $65.1 million loss in its third quarter. The computer maker also said it would close three plants and lay off 950 people, in an effort to trim $100 million from its annual operating costs.

title: At the Movies
description: The Soul of 'Robocop'

title: Thomas W.M. Smith Dies; Ex-U.S. Ambassador in Africa
description: Thomas W. M. Smith, a career diplomat who served as Ambassador to Ghana and Nigeria, died of cancer Wednesday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington, D.C. He was 57 years old.

title: GRAND (AND NOT SO GRAND) TOURS
description: The major tour-bus companies have a fairly standard menu of tours by day and night, uptown, downtown and to the Statue of Liberty, some of which include interludes on boats or helicopters. Most New Yorkers steer clear of these tours, whose clientele is made up overwhelmingly of out-of-town tourists. Nonetheless, for those who want to simulate a vacation in their own city or are new to New York, many of these big motor-coach tours offer good introductions to the city (read: Manhattan) and frequently provide unexpected insights and perspectives for even seasoned New Yorkers.

title: JOHN BRADEN
description: John Braden, a composer and lyricist, died Wednesday of complications from meningitis at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 41 years old, and lived in Manhattan.

title: BALLARD MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KEY RATES
WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday VERONESE GENTLEMEN

title: Sun Belt Renews Battle Over Federal Funds
description: Bolstered by a new study showing that Sun Belt States lag well behind other regions of the country in their share of the Federal dollar, a coalition of Southern lawmakers vowed today to wield their legislative power to send more money southward.

title: GROLIER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,800,000 for the quarter and $4,100,000 for the 6 months. c-After a charge of $1,712,000 from bond redemption for both the quarter and 6 months; and the 6-month also includes a credit of $500,000 from tax loss carryforwards.

title: BEMIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $358,000, or 3 cents a share, from restructuring activities.

title: NATIONAL INDUSTRIAL BANORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Comparable figures are not meaningful as its initial public offering was completed in April 1986, and its only operating entity, National Industrial Bank, was acquired in May 1986. The per share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May.

title: AUCTIONS
description: AN 11th-century Byzantine mosaic - removed from an Italian cathedral in the 1850's and rediscovered a year ago in a Welsh church - was bought for $427,152 this month at Sotheby's in London by a New York art dealer. The price for the work -which depicts the head of an apostle framed in a halo of gold - was a record at auction for a wall mosaic.

title: CMS ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes one-time charges of 4 cents a share and 32 cents a share for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, due to a refund ordered by the Michigan Public Service Commission. c-Net loss

title:
THE 'OLLIE' AND CONGRESS MINISERIES: FOUR POSTMORTEMS;
NORTH DESERVES A REWARD
description: LEAD: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's ordeal makes us think about dishonesty in public affairs. Few would deny that it is sometimes necessary or defensible. Good men do deceive in noble cause. Winston Churchill never told Parliament about Enigma - the decoding machine the Poles stole from the Germans - which gave the Allies access to German secrets during the war.

title: What Shakespeare Knew About Deniability
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE GAS FOUND NEAR BLAST SITE
description: Fire marshals discovered 144 small cylinders of propane yesterday in a Brooklyn building two doors away from the site of a propane explosion that killed four people Tuesday morning.

title: SCAN-OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the increase in revenue reflects the acquisitions of two new product lines; it attributed the earnings decline primarily to commitments to new-product introduction programs and expanded sales and marketing capability.

title: Palmieri and Ruiz
description: Two pianists, Eddie Palmieri and Hilton Ruiz, are leading groups in a Latin-jazz double bill tonight through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. through Sunday, plus a 1:30 A.M. show tonight and tomorrow; there is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $7.50 charge at the bar.

title: The 'T' Party
description: The Republican Party may try to pin a new alliterative label on the Democrats as the 1988 Presidential campaign unfolds. Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., the national chairman, said at a breakfast with reporters yesterday that the Democrats are a party of ''taxes, tariffs and timidity.''

title: BE-BOP REDUX: OLD IS NEW
description: FOR the seasoned jazz-lover, the lineup of performers in the downtown clubs this weekend - most weekends, in fact - has an aura of deja vu. Art Blakey and the Jazz Messengers are at Sweet Basil, Anita O'Day is at Fat Tuesday's. Alto saxophonists - Lou Donaldson at Carlos 1, Clarence C-Sharpe at Barry Harris's Jazz Cultural Theater - are flexing their Bird wings, keeping Charlie Parker's music alive and, perhaps, reminding old-timers of Charles Mingus's comment that ''if Bird was a gunslinger, there'd be a whole lot of dead copycats.'' George Coleman, who blew into New York from Chicago in 1958 as Max Roach's new saxophone colossus, is at the Village Vanguard, and Junior Mance is executing his impeccable blues piano arpeggios at the Village Gate.

title: Discrimination Suit Is Won Against Civil Liberties Group
description: A jury has ruled that the American Civil Liberties Union discriminated against a police officer who said he was ''fingered as a spy'' at a meeting of the group.

title: THOR ENERGY RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: ENGRAPH INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 10-percent stock dividend paid in March 1987.

title: ABDUCTED MAN FLEES CONTRAS AND ASKS THE U.N. FOR HELP
description: In April he was kidnapped by contras inside Nicaragua and then marched to one of their camps on the Honduran-Nicaraguan border, where he was held for three months.

title: Smiths to Buy 2 Lear Units
description: The Lear Siegler Holdings Corporation said Smiths Industries P.L.C. of London had agreed to buy two of its aerospace group units for $350 million. The concerns include Lear Siegler's international marketing arm, based in Stamford, Conn., and the Instrument and Avionic Systems Corporation, which makes weapons management and navigation systems.

title: FILM: 'LA BAMBA,' A MUSICAL BIOGRAPHY
description: WE already know as much about Ritchie Valens's brief life as we learn from ''La Bamba,'' the film biography that traces his early love of music, his dizzying rise to stardom and his tragic death in a plane crash. We know these things less specifically from Valens's own story than as conventions of this film and others like it, among them ''The Buddy Holly Story'' and ''Sweet Dreams,'' the biography of Patsy Cline.

title: BALTIMORE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
McEvoy-Willis
description: Smith International Inc. said it would sell its McEvoy-Willis unit, maker of oil and gas wellhead equipment, to Cameron Iron Works Inc. of Houston for $51 million. Smith, based in Newport Beach, Calif., said depressed conditions in the energy business would force the company to post a $33 million loss on the deal. McEvoy-Willis, also of Houston, had sales of $91 million last year. The sale needs the approval of the Federal Bankruptcy Court. Earlier this week, Smith filed a reorganization plan that would allow the company to emerge from bankruptcy proceedings by Dec. 31.

title: BOARDING A BUS FOR JAZZ, LANDMARKS AND A NOSH
description: ABOUT 75 times a year, Lou Singer gets into his blue Dodge van, picks up a hungry band of sightseers and embarks on a six-hour odyssey of eating and adventure on the Lower East Side of New York. As he navigates the van toward his caloric mecca, he announces: ''This isn't a straight pigging-out operation. We want to start with a little culture.'' And culture he provides. This former newspaper delivery agent is a human encyclopedia of New York's ethnic, architectural and culinary history, and his almost nonstop commentary ranges from immigration history and avant-garde esthetics to the pros and cons of various delis.

title: FOR 463 SUBWAY STATIONS, A PLAN FOR TOP-TO-BOTTOM SPRUCING UP
description: In what could prove to be New York's most extensive basement cleanup, the Transit Authority plans to remove old pipes and electrical lines, obsolete lighting fixtures and other hardware, misleading signs, dormant newsstands and many of the advertising billboards in an attempt to make many of the 463 subway stations look much the way they did when they were new.

title: Head of Coke's TV Unit Is Named Viacom Chief
description: Frank J. Biondi Jr, chief executive of Coca-Cola Television, will become chief executive of Viacom International Inc., the broadcast and cable company acquired earlier this year by Sumner M. Redstone, the companies said yesterday.

title: Iranian's Visit to West Germany Puts Bonn in Awkward Position
description: An official visit by Iran's Foreign Minister today underscored West Germany's privileged relations with the Middle Eastern nation, which is at loggerheads with France and other Western governments.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Home Section yesterday about the remodeling of modest homes misstated the profit made on a house in Bedford, N.Y., that was purchased for $135,000. The house, which was remodeled at a cost of $90,000, was sold for $300,000, netting the owners $75,000, or 33 percent.

title: Niagara Is Writing Off $755 Million
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation said yesterday that it would take a $755 million after-tax write-off because of cost overruns at its Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power plant in upstate New York.

title: SCOUTING
description: LEAD: Donald Trump, the New York real-estate developer, got his feet wet in yachting during the recent America's Cup series. As a major contributor the victorious campaign of Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes, he organized a ticker-tape parade through Manhattan for the winning team. Now Trump is taking a dip into powerboat racing.

title: Caramoor Baroque
description: The St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble is to present works by Haydn, Mozart, Mendelssohn and Grieg tonight at 9 in the Spanish Courtyard at Caramoor in Katonah, N.Y. Tomorrow evening at 8:30, the Canadian Brass is to play music by Purcell, Bach, Byrd, Gabrieli, Luther Henderson and Gershwin in the Venetian Theater. Also on the program: a one-act opera entitled ''Hornsmoke,'' by Peter Schickele, also known as P. D. Q. Bach. Tickets are $20 for tonight's concert, $10 to $27.50 for tomorrow's performance. For information and directions: (914) 232-5035.

title: CITIZENS BANKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $938,000 for the quarter and $1,677,000 for the 6 months.

title: HEIN-WERNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ALZHEIMER DRUG PLAN BACKED
description: A Senate committee has approved plans for a three-year study of an experimental drug heralded as possibly the first effective treatment for Alzheimer's disease.

title: A Sweeping Shift at Salomon
description: Salomon Inc., parent of one of Wall Street's most powerful securities firms, said yesterday that its earnings dropped sharply after a rocky second quarter. Then late in the day, Salomon said that it was losing its second senior executive in a week and that it had initiated a sweeping management restructuring.

title: PRECISION CASTPARTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that the year-ago first quarter was the last reporting quarter prior to the acquisition of PCC Airfoils and that most of the increases over last year came from the Airfoils division, and the balance from continued improvements in the structurals division.

title: SHULTZ ANGRILY TELLS INQUIRY CASEY AND OTHERS DECEIVED HIM REPEATEDLY OVER IRAN DEALINGS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz today laid out a chronicle of duplicity and intrigue at the highest levels of the Government, saying that he was deceived repeatedly by the Director of Central Intelligence and President Reagan's national security advisers and that they withheld vital information from him and from the President to keep the Iran arms sales alive.

title: Sonny Fortune
description: Sonny Fortune, an alto saxophonist, is to lead a group tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9, 10:30 P.M. and midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is no fourth set on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum tonight and tomorrow, a $5 cover and a $7.50 minimum on Sunday.

title: GORBACHEV OFFER FOCUSES PRESSURE ON WEST GERMANY
description: With its latest arms proposal, the Soviet Union has sought to put pressure on the United States and West Germany to give in on the issue of West Germany's short-range Prshing 1A missiles, Administration officials said today.

title: French Report on Terrorism Raises Suspicions About Iran
description: With France and Iran making no apparent progress in efforts to resolve their diplomatic crisis, reports have begun to accumulate indicating a French belief that Iran was directly involved in a series of terrorist attacks here last year.

title: UNION EXPLORATION PARTNERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
30 MILLION NIGERIANS ARE LAUGHING AT THEMSELVES
description: Uzorma Onungwa doesn't like ethnic humor.

title: ART: WHITNEY SHOWS CINDY SHERMAN PHOTOS
description: THE Cindy Sherman traveling show has reached the Whitney Museum of American Art. It has exotic characters - sultans, knights, matadors, extraterrestrials, movie actresses - all of them and none of them the artist herself. Ms. Sherman has been billed as a great deconstructor, a simulationist par excellence, a heroine of the post-modern attack on the hero, an originator of the post-modern attack on originality, one of the select few who could have been a great artist in any medium. This astounding performer, still only 33 years old, pulls out all the stops of her camera at the Whitney.

title: Science Teaching in New York City Must Also Improve by 2000
description: To the Editor:

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: The Budweiser Superfest, Madison Square Garden (563-8300). This year, Budweiser's annual pop-soul musical marathon co-stars the indefatigably exuberant Patti LaBelle, and the duo Ashford and Simpson. The big-hearted belter from Philadelphia and the love birds from Manhattan epitomize grown-up East Coast pop-soul, and always deliver solid, upbeat entertainment. Also on the bill is Atlantic Starr, the group that recently enjoyed a No. 1 hit with the creamy ballad ''Always,'' and the Whispers, the virtuosic post-doo-wop harmony group that is climbing the charts with ''Rock Steady,'' its first major hit in several years. Show time is tonight at 7:30, and tickets are $25 and $30 and can be ordered through Ticketron and Teletron outlets.

title: ROCHESTER TELEPHONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago figures are restated to reflect the acquisition of Enterprise Telephone Co. in March.

title: Beethoven at Rutgers
description: The Orchestra of St. Luke's will play an all-Beethoven program tomorrow night at 8 o'clock at the Nicholas Music Center at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J. Ilana Vered will be soloist in the Piano Concerto No. 5 (''Emperor''); other works include the Symphony No. 3 (''Eroica''). Julius Rudel will conduct. The program is part of the Rutgers Summerfest Piano Institute, of which Ms. Vered is director. Tickets are $10. Information and directions: (201) 932-7511.

title: CULLUM COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
COURT UPHOLDS A RULING AGAINST SMOKING CURBS
description: A state appeals court, in a 3-to-2 decision, upheld today a lower-court ruling that the Cuomo administration should not have issued broad restrictions on smoking without the approval of the Legislature.

title: SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND TELEOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a one-time pretax charge of $22 million for local customer service credits provided under a recent agreement with the Connecticut Department of Public Utility Control.

title: EQUIPMENT TESTED FOR TITANIC SEARCH
description: Deep-sea treasure hunters at the site of the sunken liner Titanic tested a minisubmarine and its robot craft today in preparation for a disputed salvage mission to the wreckage.

title: ON L.I., MAN'S TRAGEDY TURNS INTO HIS DREAM
description: Witold Wroblewski paused. Then, as he turned back to his interpreter, the expression on his bearded face showed that he recognized some of the irony in what he was about the say.

title: LAUER, GERMAIN EXCEL IN HEAT
description: There was little relief for the golfers exposed to hot sun and high humidity as they walked the middle of the fairways and stood on greens in the first round of the 42d United States Women's Open championship today.

title: ART: A SHOW OF ETCHINGS AT ACADEMY OF DESIGN
description: THE term ''painter-etcher'' was more than a genteelism distinguishing the ''fine'' from the commercial etcher. A coinage of the 1870's, it was also a reflection, if faint, of the growing interest in blending all the arts into one Wagnerian whole. Similarly, the American painter-etcher movement accomplished more than the estheticizing of the graphic medium. As proposed by Patricia C. F. Mandel in the catalogue to a recent traveling show on the subject, the movement was instrumental in restoring some of the esthetic confidence lost in the welter of commercialism following the Civil War. It was, nevertheless, much influenced by the work of expatriates such as Whistler and by the spontaneity of French and English etchings as a whole.

title: Our Towns; Toughest Area To Place a Home For the Retarded
description: At the start of a town meeting on a community residence home for the mentally ill, Hempstead officials always read the same statement: ''The disabled are welcomed members of the town community. And we . . . believe strongly that persons with mental disabilities should be offered every opportunity to lead productive lives.''

title: DURAKON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 50-percent stock dividend paid in February 1986.

title: POLICE AND PROTESTERS CLASH IN 2-DAY BANGLADESH STRIKE
description: A 54-hour general strike called to force the resignation of President H. M. Ershad provoked violent clashes today between the President's supporters and mobs fielded by opposition parties.

title: Forecasts: Greenspan's Grades
description: For more than 20 years, Alan Greenspan has figured prominently on all the lists of famous American economic forecasters. But now Mr. Greenspan's forecasting accuracy has been challenged in the Senate, which is about to vote on his nomination as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: PENNSYLVANIA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Year to June 30
MOZAMBICANS TELL OF MASSACRE OF 386
description: Wounded survivors of a raid by right-wing rebels on a village near here said Thursday that the rebels attacked pregnant women, children and hospital patients.

title: Harcourt Holdersv Toughen Defenses
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. shareholders strengthened the publisher's anti-takeover defenses against the British newspaper owner Robert Maxwell by doubling the number of Harcourt's common shares. The approval was granted at a special shareholders meeting at which some investors expressed opposition to a $3 billion recapitalization plan announced in late May by Harcourt to force Mr. Maxwell to withdraw his $2 billion unsolicited bid for the company.

title: REAGAN'S AIDS PANEL: WHO THE MEMBERS ARE
description: Dr. W. Eugene Mayberry . . . appointed last month as chairman of the commission . . . chief executive of the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. . . . specialist in glands with no specific expertise in AIDS . . . an acquaintance of Howard H. Baker Jr., White House chief of staff, who was a trustee of the Mayo Foundation before joining the Adminstration. Dr. Colleen Conway-Welch . . . professor and dean of nursing at Vanderbilt University in Nashville, Tenn. . . . represents the views of the nursing community that must care for AIDS victims . . . from Mr. Baker's home state. John J. Creedon . . . chief executive officer of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in New York City . . . chairman of the Business Roundtable's Task Force on Health and Welfare Benefit Plans . . . has been deeply involved in examining the implications of the AIDS epidemic for the insurance industry and for financing health care . . . company is conducting a major AIDS education program. Dr. Theresa L. Crenshaw . . . from San Diego . . . director of the Crenshaw Clinic, which specializes in treating sexual problems . . . immediate past president of the American Association of Sex Educators, Counselors and Therapists . . . argues that changes in sexual behavior are needed to stem the spread of AIDS because reliance on condoms are like ''putting a mere balloon between ourselves and a deadly virus.'' Richard M. De Vos..co-founder and president of the Amway Corporation in Grand Rapids, Mich., renowned for its expertise in door-to-door sales . . . active in Republican circles . . . chosen, an official said, because ''he represents a company that is active all over the country'' and ''we wanted to make sure we had folks on the commission with a sense for the average American.'' Dr. Burton J. Lee . . . practicing physician and former president of the medical staff at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City, a major AIDS treatment center . . . specialty is treatment of lymphomas, a form of cancer. Dr. Frank Lilly . . . chairman of genetics at the Albert Einstein University Medical Center in New York City . . . has not worked on AIDS itself but has done research on animal diseases caused by retroviruses similar to AIDS . . . picked for his expertise in biomedical research, the White House says . . . assumes he was picked to satisfy demands that the commission include a homosexual . . . past board member of the Gay Men's Health Crisis in New York City. Dr. Woodrow A. Myers Jr. . . . Health Commissioner of Indiana, a state known for starting one of the best and earliest AIDS education programs . . . the only black on the commission . . . may offer special insight into the needs of the black community. John Cardinal O'Connor . . . archbishop of New York, whose archdiocese has been active in assisting AIDS patients . . . a stern moralist who has equated homosexual practices with the Biblical sin of sodomy . . . opposes New York's efforts to promote condoms to prevent the spread of AIDS . . . chosen, an official said, ''to bring a religious values perspective to the discussion and because his archdiocese has provided good care for AIDS victims.'' Penny Pullen . . . Republican leader of the Illinois State House of Representatives . . . has sponsored bills now awaiting the Governor's signature that would require testing of marriage license applicants for infection with the AIDS virus and require health officials to trace the sexual contacts of infected people. Dr. Cory Servaas . . . from Indianapolis . . . editor and publisher of The Saturday Evening Post . . . has medical degree . . . turned the magazine into a medically-oriented journal for the common citizen, officials say, and thus should bring insights on how to educate the American public. Dr. William B. Walsh . . . founder, president and medical director of Project HOPE, which brings health care and education to areas of the developing world . . . says the world faces ''the prospect of health care rationing because of AIDS.'' Adm. James D. Watkins . . . chief of naval operations from 1982 to 1986 . . . chosen because the military services have taken the lead in testing for AIDS and developing policies for dealing with its victims.

title: ARMOR ALL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MINNESOTA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GUITAR: ABEL CARLEVARO PERFORMS AT FRICK
description: ABEL CARLEVARO is a Uruguayan guitarist who plays seldom in this country but who over many years has developed an international reputation as a performer, an innovative teacher and a creative engineer of his instrument. His brief, early-evening recital at the Frick Collection on Wednesday let us experience all three sides.

title: Views About the Supreme Court
description: ''In general do you think the United States Supreme Court is too liberal or too conservative in its decisions?'' title: Not-So-Small Change

title: Gorbachev on Arms: A Shifting Stand
description: The Soviet position on medium-range arms has changed frequently over the last year and a half. Here are several of the most significant changes, which followed President Reagan's first proposal of the so-called zero option in 1981. Jan. 15, 1986: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, offers a plan calling for, among other things, the elimination of American and Soviet intermediate-range missiles in Europe, as the first step that the British and French arsenals be reduced, along with American weapons, under a new treaty. Feb. 6: Mr. Gorbachev, meeting with Senator Edward M. Kennedy in Moscow, drops his precondition for an agreement on intermediate-range missiles that required an end to testing for ''Star Wars,'' the space defense program. Later, the Russians will link the agreement once again to ''Star Wars'' and then once again drop the condition. Oct. 11-12: At a meeting in Reykjavik, Iceland, Mr. Gorbachev and President Reagan agreed that there should be a ban on American and Soviet medium-range missiles in Europe, and included a limit of 100 warheads on medium-range missiles outside Europe. There was also an agreement in principle that shorter-range missiles should be limited. April 15, 1987: Mr. Gorbachev tells Secretary of State George P. Shultz, according to the Russian version, that the Russians are ready to ''eliminate shorter range missiles in Europe within a relatively short and clearly defined time. Mr. Shultz says the Russians said they were prepared for a global elimination of such missiles. June: Col. Gen. Nikolai F. Chervov, head of the arms control directorate of the Soviet General Staff, proposes informally a compromise that would lead to a worldwide ban on American and Soviet medium-range and short-range missiles. The United States responds favorably, and the Soviet Foreign Ministry later denies the report. The compromise is the basis for a Gorbachev statement in July. July 22: Mr. Gorbachev says in an interview that he is prepared to accept a worldwide ban on medium-range and short-range missiles, dropping Moscow's previous insistence on keeping 100 medium-range warheads in Soviet Asian territory. A day later, the Kremlin's chief arms negotiator reiterates the Soviet position that any agreement would require destruction of United States warheads earmarked for use on short-range West German Pershing 1A missiles.

title: From Tulane to Auburn

The 49-year-old Fowler coached Tulane to a 70-45 record in four years but left in the wake of scandals that prompted the Tulane president to drop basketball in April 1985.

title: Dining Out Guide; Cold Plates and Salads
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AMERICAN FESTIVAL CAFE, #20 West 50th Street (246-6699) - *(July 27, 1984) American antiques are featured against the background of light woods, glass and brass of this glittering restaurant with its outdoor umbrella-covered tables that spill onto the winter skating rink of Rockefeller Center. The summer menu offers cold main dishes as well as appetizers for diners who want to keep cool. You might choose the salamagundi, a salad of greens, bacon, ham, smoked turkey, peppered beef and cheese; poached Atlantic salmon with tabbouleh and cucumbers, or Gulf shrimp with red-leaf lettuce, avocado and salsa. Cold plates $11.75 to $15.75. Fridays and Saturdays, 7:30 A.M. to 12:30 A.M.; Sundays, 9 A.M. to 10 P.M. LAVIN'S, 23 West 39th Street (921-1288) - *(June 20, 1986) Carved oak-paneled walls and symmetrical rows of tables contribute to the classy cafe ambiance of this midtown restaurant. A comfortable wine bar up front offers an ever-changing selection of by-the-glass offerings. The summer menu features a number of salads and cold dishes: smoked duck and chicken-breast plate with rice salad and marinated baby vegetables; cold poached Norwegian salmon with fresh tomato and herb coulis, California caviar and snow peas, and mesquite-grilled carpaccio, the filet of beef sliced paper thin and served over garden relish salad. Cold dishes $7 to $16. Fridays, noon to 10 P.M.; closed Saturdays and Sundays. MENAGE A TROIS, #134 East 48th Street (593-8242) - *(Nov. 7, 1986) Diners are invited to ''graze'' at this contemporary French restaurant done in soothing beiges with wood trim, comfortable banquettes and well-spaced tables. Most portions fall between traditional appetizer and entree size. Cold-dish options from the eight-page menu include the chicken combination, which is smoked, marinated and julienne with three dressings; whole lobster tail with black truffle slices with truffle vinaigrette and warm wild mushroom salad, and poached quail eggs on artichoke with smoked salmon, oyster, scallop, lobster and Russian caviar. Two of the many salad choices are duck breast with fresh foie gras, French beans and shallots, and a seafood salad of salmon, lobster and scallops with dill and croutons. Cold dishes $7.25 to $23.75. Fridays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5:30 to 11:45 P.M.; Saturdays, 5:30 P.M. to midnight; Sundays, 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. POSITANO, #250 Park Avenue South, at 20th Street (777-6211) - **(Jan. 25, 1985) This chic and informal restaurant with dining areas on three tiers, high ceiling, mammoth columns and green marble tables has the look of high-toned Italian design. A number of cold plates are available for the summer: antipasto choices of assorted smoked fish with a mayonnaise herb sauce and rolled mozzarella and prosciutto with roasted peppers; a chilled salad of straw and hay pasta tossed with tuna and sun-dried tomato puree and walnuts; Continental salad of chicken with carrots, celery, potatoes, avocado and smoked cheese, and a main dish of carpaccio of raw beef on arugula with cheese shavings and mushrooms. Cold dishes $10 to $17. Fridays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5:30 P.M. to 12:30 A.M.; Saturdays, 5:30 P.M. to 12:30 A.M.; closed Sundays. SOFI, #102 Fifth Avenue, near 15th Street (463-8888) - **(May 22, 1987) Run by the owner of Lavin's on West 39th Street, Sofi is situated in a soaring loft space, and the dining room is long and cavernous with a rim of tables on a balcony. A number of cold dishes are offered, including eggplant caviar over ripe tomato confit and flaked roasted skate with a salad of ripe yellow and cherry tomatoes and pesto. And the gardener's salad is worth a trip - composed of arugula, chicory and other greens for nesting marinated mushrooms, lumps of eggplant caviar, thin curls of deep-fried artichoke hearts, leeks and zucchini. Cold plates $6 to $14. Fridays, noon to 2:30 and 6 to 11 P.M.; Saturdays, 6 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. TATANY, #388 Third Avenue, near 28th Street (686-1871) - **(Oct. 17, 1986) This trim, informal restaurant with sushi bar and two dining rooms is a good option for anyone looking for a cool meal on a hot summer night. The chefs turn out an exemplary array of sashimi, sushi and assorted maki to tempt any aficionado. The firm and fresh mixed sushi platter includes tuna, salmon, fluke, shrimp and maki. Another arresting composition of texture and flavor is salmon skin maki, which is brittle and oceanic, packed in rice with minced green onions and rolled in a lightly toasted seaweed sheet and crowned with tiny red lumpfish caviar. Main dishes $6.50 to $12.25. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 5:30 to 11:30 P.M.; Saturdays, 5:30 to 11:30 P.M.; Sundays, 5:30 to 10:30 P.M. What the stars mean, page C26.

Oshman's will take a stake of 19.9 percent in the company formed to acquire the stores. The Abercrombie chain has 27 stores, including two in New York City. It had $48 million in sales in the year ended Jan. 31. Oshman's bought the Abercrombie name, trademark and mailing list for $1.5 million in 1978.

Between 1974 and 1982, he was executive vice president and then president of the Bechtel Corporation. Role: He opposed the covert arms sales to Iran and says he tried his best to stop them but was opposed by some other senior officials who he says deceived him. He is an avowed supporter of the contra movement but says he was unaware of the covert program to support the contras after Congress restricted aid.

description: The San Francisco office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles has just picked up the account of Hyundai Electronics America, United States marketer of the Korean-made, I.B.M.-PC-compatible peripheral equipment. The D'Arcy people believe that the advertising was previously done in-house.

title: G.O.P. CHALLENGES BORK'S OPPONENTS
description: Senate Republican leaders made it clear today that they would challenge the Democrats' argument that the Senate should weigh Judge Robert H. Bork's judicial philosophy and political views in deciding whether to confirm him to the Supreme Court.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Robert Kuperman will join Chiat Day, Los Angeles, as executive vice president and creative director.

title: TGI FRIDAY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Advertising; Publisher Is Named For Cosmopolitan
description: Seth Hoyt, 44, who while at Rolling Stone helped D. Claeys Bahrenburg start Outside magazine, is now following Mr. Bahrenburg as publisher of Hearst's Cosmopolitan magazine.

title: Gromyko to Study Homeland For Resettled Crimean Tatars
description: Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet President, will head a Government commission to examine demands for a homeland by Crimean Tatars, forcibly transported to Central Asia in 1944, the press agency Tass said today.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted July 21 and 22 with 745 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.

title: LANDMARK BANCSHARES CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a loan loss reserve of $3,001,000.

title:
The 'Ollie' and Congress Miniseries: Four Postmortems;
Peter Pan in Power-Politics Land
description: LEAD: For six days, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North played so sweetly on the panpipes of the American Dream that he allowed the television public to believe in any and all of its best-beloved fairy tales. Eager and boyish in his adventurer's uniform of woodland green, the colonel sounded like Peter Pan telling Wendy and her little brothers about his marvelous exploits in Never-Never Land.

title: Bridge: A Father and a Son Compete In the Spingold Quarterfinals
description: A rare and perhaps unique event marked the quarterfinal stage of the Spingold Knockout Team Championship here this afternoon.

title: SALES MARK AT FESTIVAL
description: The United States Olympic Festival has set a ticket sales record of $2.6 million, far exceeding its goal, and with four days remaining could break the attendance mark, the president and executive director of the local organizing committee said today.

title: North's Legal Defense Fund Tops $1.4 Million After Panel
description: More than $1.4 million in public contributions have poured in to the Oliver North Legal Assistance Fund since the former White House aide took the witness chair at the televised Iran-Contra hearings, fund officials say.

title: Apple to Introduce Software Products
description: Apple Computer Inc. will introduce two significant software products next month, the company's chairman, John Sculley, told securities analysts. While he did not name the products, one is expected to be internal operating system software that would allow a Macintosh computer to handle several tasks at once. Such ''multi-tasking'' ability is a key feature of the new I.B.M. personal computers but will not be available on those machines until next year. The other product, code-named Wildcard, is a data base and information management program.

title: Moslems in Lebanon Join Forces With Left
description: Lebanon's leftist and Moslem militias have announced they are setting their differences aside and joining an alliance against the regime of President Amin Gemayel, a Christian.

title: WHAT WILL BE WHEN
description: Art on the Beach runs through Sept. 20 at 54-05 Second Street at Hunters Point, Long Island City, Queens. Exhibition hours are Thursdays through Sundays noon to 6 P.M., with admission free. Unless otherwise noted, all performances are at 7 P.M. and admission to each is $6; children and the elderly, $3; Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted.

title: Gondrezick in Hospital
description: Glen Gondrezick, a former forward for the Denver Nuggets, remained hospitalized in serious condition yesterday with a bullet wound in the chest after apparently trying to kill himself Wednesday, authorities in Boulder, Colo., said.

title: HUDSON FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
Volcker Plans To Head Panel
description: Paul A. Volcker, who is retiring as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that he would head a new privately financed commission on public service.

title: ARKANSAS BEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said because of the present condition of the motor carrier industry, it has reduced its capital expenditure budget for carrier operations to about $69 million from $84 million.

title: FIRST INDIANA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMERICAN FILTRONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'Faust' at City Opera
description: The New York City Opera is to present its first performance this season of Gounod's ''Faust,'' tonight at 8, at the New York State Theater. Richard Leech sings the title role, Faith Esham is Marguerite, and John Cheek is Mephistopheles; Sergiu Comissiona conducts. The production is in French with supertitles in English. Tomorrow afternoon at 2 o'clock, the company is to present ''Tosca,'' and tomorrow evening at 8, ''La Rondine.'' Tickets for all performances are $8 to $42. Information: 870-5570.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: BROOKLYN UNION GAS CO reports earnings for 12mos June 30
description: b-After a charge of $14.7 million after-taxes due to declining energy prices.

title: Taylor of Giants, in a New Book, Says He Used Cocaine Frequently
description: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' star linebacker, has disclosed in his autobiography that he used cocaine and crack, a powerful cocaine derivative, as frequently as three times a week during the 1985 season.

title: Financial Corp.'s Loss
description: The Financial Corporation of America said today that it lost $176.8 million in the second quarter, in contrast to a profit of $11.6 million, or 23 cents a share, in the period last year.

title: 100 Die in Greek Heat Wave; Hundreds Are Hospitalized
description: More than 100 people have died in a blistering heat wave in Greece in the last five days, hospital sources said today.

title:
Patents;
Technology For Cancer Diagnosis
description: LEAD: DR. JOHN R. STEPHENSON, scientific director for Oncogene Science Inc., a biotechnology company in Manhasset, L.I., and two former associates were granted a patent this week for technology described as important in the diagnosis of various forms of cancer. Patent 4,681,840 is assigned to the Department of Commerce, Dr.

title: The Road to 'Kampuchea'
description: He came to take one for the team yesterday, so that he and Tim Mayotte and the American doubles team could pour through Eric Jelen and avoid the lower depths of Davis Cup tennis.

title: Tie Vote Prevents a Decision On Political Spending Rules
description: The Federal Election Commission has left undecided a question that may provide a way for Presidential candidates to circumvent campaign spending regulations.

title: 'Our Foreign Policy Suffered; You Were Out of the Game'
description: Although Secretary of State George P. Shultz has received a favorable response from most legislators at the Iran-contra hearings, one Congressman challenged his conduct during yesterday's session.

title: No Headline
description: Even by the standards of the normally volatile Tokyo stock market, this has been a turbulent week.

title: Senate Panel Balks at Promotion of Two Generals
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee has refused to approve promotion of two Marine brigadier generals after concluding that they were singled out for special treatment by the Marine commandant and the Secretary of the Navy.

title: CONTROL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $100,000 for the quarter and $900,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss d-Includes an extraordinary loss of $600,000 and an extraordinary gain of $2.5 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Argonaut to Hold Talks on Merger
description: The Argonaut Group said that it would begin friendly merger talks with Clarendon Group Ltd. and other unidentified third parties that have expressed an interest in acquiring the insurer. Clarendon, which owns a 4.8 percent stake in Argonaut, offered on Tuesday to acquire the company for $52 a share, or $580 million, for the shares it does not already own.

title: Hollywood Summer Looking Up
description: With Superman taking his cape out of mothballs this weekend and James Bond skydiving into the nation's box offices next Friday, all of Hollywood's most awaited summer treats will have been delivered by the end of July.

title: Izn't It Tiem to Give The Betys a Braek?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexico and the U.S. - a Joint Destiny
description: Any study of our border with Mexico shows that economic actions on one side strongly afffect the other. We tend to emphasize the problems arising from Mexico's proximity - drugs, illegal migration, flight capital. But this proximity can also bring enormous benefits if the suspicious neighbors are willing to acknowledge their joint destiny and permit greater economic integration.

title: CORRECTION
description: A correction in this space yesterday, about an article Thursday on rising oil prices, misidentified a company whose chief executive officer is E. L. Williamson and the organization whose acronym is OPEC. The company is the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company; the organization is the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: 2,032 Letters Hidden By a Postal Worker
description: A postal worker here who was trying to keep pace with her workload stashed in her locker more than 2,000 pieces of mail, which were not found until three years later.

title: INSIDE
description: Sri Lanka Peace Plan Tamil guerrillas ''agreed in principle'' to a proposal that could end Sri Lanka's bitter ethnic conflict, Indian and Sri Lankan officials said. The moves, which reportedly came after intense negotiations, meant an accord could be signed next week, people close to the talks said. Page 3.

title: Stage: 'A Feast In the Plague-Time'
description: ''A Feast in the Plague-Time,'' the Russian director Yuri Lyubimov's theatrical collage based on Pushkin, portrays an eerily somber ''Last Supper'' in a time of apocalyptic pestilence. By the end of the banquet, its exhausted celebrants are shrouded corpses on a galleon that has sunk to the bottom of the ocean.

title: Movie: 'Superman IV: Quest for Peace'
description: Part of the fun of each Superman film has always been that opening credit crawl, with its hilariously grandiose lettering and its stately pace. In ''Superman IV: The Quest for Peace,'' which opened yesterday at the New Carnegie and other theaters, the credits zip by in a shaky manner, trailed by billows of unsightly glitter. This is a bad sign.

title: KELLOGG CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago second quarter includes a non-recurring loss of $9.9 million resulting from the purchase of $123.7 million principal amount of the company's $150 million of 12.25-percent debentures due Feb. 15, 2015.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday about President Reagan's appointment of 12 members to his national commission on AIDS misidentified a doctor who Mr. Reagan said had provided helpful suggestions. He is Dr. Richard Davis of Philadelphia, a stepbrother of Nancy Reagan, not Dr. Loyal Davis, her deceased stepfather.

title: Exxon Net Rises 3.6% In Quarter
description: The Exxon Corporation, the Shell Oil Company and the Occidental Petroleum Company yesterday reported higher second-quarter profits resulting from the gradual rise in crude oil prices. But the Phillips Petroleum Company and the Pennzoil Corporation reported lower profits.

title: Kellogg's Net Rises by 29.8%
description: The Kellogg Company said today that it earned $89.8 million, or 72 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1987, up 29.8 percent from $69.2 million, or 56 cents a share, a year ago.

title: Seabrook Utility Says It May Fail
description: A utility that has sunk $2 billion into the stalled Seabrook nuclear power plant risks becoming America's first public electric utility to file for bankruptcy protection since the Depression. The Public Service Company of New Hampshire acknowledged in a report that its Wall Street financing had dried up and that finding an alternative would be extremely difficult before its cash runs out by the end of the year.

title: A Sri Lanka Compromise Reported Near
description: Indian and Sri Lankan officials said today that separatist Tamil guerrillas had ''agreed in principle'' to a proposal that could end a bitter four-year ethnic conflict in Sri Lanka.

title: EXXON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A KUWAITI TANKER UNDER U.S. ESCORT HITS MINE IN GULF
description: A Kuwaiti tanker under American naval escort hit a mine today just west of an Iranian island in the Persian Gulf.

title: ALTUS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Correction
description: Because of an editing error, the main Washington dispatch Friday on Secretary of State George P. Shultz's first day of testimony before the Iran-contra panels misidentified an Iranian to whom Mr. Shultz referred.

title: After the Blast, Journey Continues
description: The mercury had hit 100 and the morning was calm and clear shortly before 6:55 A.M. today as two Kuwaiti oil tankers, with their escort of three United States Navy warships, steamed north toward Kuwait. Then came the blast. Seconds later, a Navy lieutenant, Richard Vogel, radioed from the supertanker Bridgeton: ''We've been hit! We've been hit!''

title: ROCHESTER GAS & ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UNION CARBIDE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $19 million and $21 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; gains on disposals of $333 million for the quarter and $336 million for the 6 months; and the 6-month also includes a gain of $270 million from the cumulative effect of a change in an accounting principle for reversion of surplus pension funds.

title: INDIAN HEAD BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago quarter and 6 months' earnings are after a $1.6 million net writedown of assets.

title: 2d-Quarter G.N.P. Rise Put at 2.6%
description: The economy grew somewhat faster this spring than was generally expected, the Commerce Department said today, but January-March growth was revised downward.

title: Lloyds Bank Posts Loss
description: Lloyds Bank P.L.C. said today that it had increased its provisions for possible bad third world debts by $:1.07 billion, or $1.7 billion, resulting in a net loss in the first half of the year. The loan-loss provision and resulting net loss were larger than analysts had been expecting. The increase in loss provisions was taken as an exceptional charge, producing a net loss of $:516 million, or $826 million, for the first half, in contrast to a profit of $:214 million in the period a year ago.

title: Books of The Times; Lights of the Vineyard
description: ILLUMINATION NIGHT. By Alice Hoffman. 224 pages. Putnam. $18.95. A CAN OF WORMS. By Russell H. Greenan. 214 pages. Bantam. Paper, $3.50.

title: BANKAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After provisions for credit losses of $1,337,000,000 and $1,652,000,000 for the quarter and 6 months; the provision include a special addition of $1.1 billion to the allowance for credit losses relating to developing countries. c-After provisions for credit losses of $988,000,000 for the quarter and $1,250,000,000 for the 6 months.

title: Response to Taylor: Parcells Says Little
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants refused today to confirm or even discuss statements made by Lawrence Taylor about the linebacker's past drug problems.

title: Beating the Heat: Creative Cooling
description: With the temperature climbing past 90 for the 18th time since May 1, thereby tying a record, and hitting 94 at midafternoon, tying another record, New Yorkers took to tall drinks, short haircuts and even metaphysical means to maintain their cool yesterday.

title: Women in Jazz Series To Begin on Monday
description: A performance by Abbey Lincoln Moseka, a singer, will open the annual Women in Jazz Downtown series on Monday at 12:15 P.M. at Chase Manhattan Plaza, Liberty and Nassau Streets. The series, which is free and runs through Aug. 7, is sponsored by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council.

title: Court Rejects Suit Against Harcourt
description: A Federal District Court has rejected a request by Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, to block a restructuring by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., the book publisher said. The decision by Judge John Keenan of New York's Southern District leaves the Orlando, Fla., company free to distribute its special $40-a-share cash dividend on Monday.

title: GENUINE PARTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid June 1.

title: 2 Killed as Storms Sweep Minnesota
description: Residents struggled today to clean up after storms that produced tornadoes and record rain in the Minneapolis area, killing two people and damaging hundreds of homes.

title: F.A.A. Head Says Flying Is Safe
description: T. Allan McArtor, who is to be sworn in Monday as chief of the Federal Aviation Administration, said today he was confident that air safety had not deteriorated but both pilots and controllers must become more vigilant.

title: GENERAL SIGNAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TIME AND BUSY TRAFFIC HALT FOR A MISSISSIPPI SAND BAR
description: In a rare twist of nature, a massive, shifting sand bar has paralyzed traffic on the Mississippi River, stalling hundreds of barges here with millions of tons in cargo in a nautical gridlock on the nation's busiest inland waterway.

title: Dow Shakes Off Slump, Gaining 13.39, to 2,485.33
description: The stock market moved up yesterday, with all of the major market indicators gaining.

title: CHICAGO RIVET & MACHINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CITY GAS CO OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split to be paid Aug. 17.

title: Stop Abuse of Children in Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: CARTER-WALLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Quick Approval of F.B.I. Nominee Seen
description: White House and Justice Department officials said today that they were confident of quick Senate confirmation for William S. Sessions, President Reagan's choice to be the new Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The selection of a Federal judge for the post, they said, should limit Congressional opposition.

title: Confusing Clothing Categories
description: ONLY in fashion could better be worse.

title: FINANCIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an additional provision of $165.5 million for losses on loans and real estates and a $22.7 million loss as the result of the FSLIC secondary reserve writeoff. c-Net income d-After a charge of $17,667,000 from reversal of tax loss carryforwards. The company said its gain on the sale of loans and mortgage-backed securities amounted to $18.3 million for the latest second quarter, compared with $85.1 million in the year-ago second quarter. Results for the latest second quarter include a charge of $5.5 million for the FSLIC special assessment which was charged to the entire savings and loan industry in 1985, 1986 and continues in 1987. The company also said the latest 6-month includes a charge of $10.8 million because of the special assessment.

title: CRONUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $9.6 million for increased reserves against long-term leases. c-Net income d-After a charge of $225,000 for extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Japan Trade Gain for China
description: A 50 percent cut in China's trade deficit with Japan this year has helped improve economic relations between the two countries despite a worsening of political ties, Western diplomats said today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Boxing Bugner Wins in Australia: Joe Bugner took another giant step in his bid to challenge for the World Boxing Council heavyweight title when he scored a unanimous 10-round decision over Greg Page last night in Sydney. Bugner, who was born in Hungary but was sworn in as an Australian citizen hours before the bout, dominated his opponent. There were no knockdowns. (AP) Tour de France Frenchman Wins 23d Stage: Regis Clere of France won the 23d stage of the men's cycling race yesterday, but Pedro Delgado of Spain retained the leader's yellow jersey. The victory was the second time Clere had won a stage.(AP) 14th Stage to Soviet Woman: Alla Jakovleva of the Soviet Union won the 57.4-mile 14th stage of the women's cycling race, but barring a major upset, Jeannie Longo of France was expected to cross the finish line first tomorrow in Paris. Longo leads Maria Canins of Italy by 2 minutes 52 seconds in the overall classification.(AP) Golf Coles Retains Seniors Lead: Neil Coles of England kept his lead and was the only player under par for the tournament yesterday after two rounds of the $240,000 Senior British Open at the Ailsa Course in Turnberry, Scotland. Coles added a three-over-par 73 to his opening round of 66 to stand at one-under-par 139. Two shots back were Arnold Palmer, Bob Charles of New Zealand and Harold Henning of South Africa. (AP) Wrenn Ahead by 4 Shots: Robert Wrenn shot a nine-under-par 63 yesterday to take a four-stroke lead over Ken Green after two rounds of the $600,000 Buick Open in Grand Blanc, Mich. Wrenn's 36-hole score of 16-under-par 128 tied the best 36-hole total on the PGA Tour this year.(AP) Tennis Lendl Holds On: Ivan Lendl survived 5 match points and a tiebreaker before going on to defeat Tim Wilkison, 4-6, 7-6, 6-2, yesterday at the Head Classic in Stowe, Vt. The victory advanced Lendl to a semifinal match today against Aaron Krickstein who defeated Bill Scanlon, 4-6, 6-1, 6-4. Jimmy Arias won five straight games in the second set to defeat Brad Gilbert, 6-2, 6-1, to earn a meeting with Todd Witsken in the other semifinal today.(AP)

title: A Joke on Koch: Jersey Ad Teases Plea to Business
description: Mayor Koch may have succeeded in boarding up the entrance to the Holland Tunnel, but the interlopers from New Jersey managed anyway yesterday to reach the New York companies the Mayor is trying to keep.

title: Bonds Down in Light Trading
description: Bond prices fell again in light trading yesterday following the report of a stronger-than-expected 2.6 percent rise in the nation's second-quarter gross national product.

title: WALT DISNEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Measure to Protect Benefits Of Retirees Passes Senate
description: The Senate approved a bill today that is designed to protect the health benefits of retired workers whose companies enter bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Davies Leads a Delayed Women's Open
description: Laura Davies of England, who hits a golf ball as far as any woman in the history of the game, survived another day of intense heat and humidity and a double bogey at the Plainfield Country Club to take the lead into the clubhouse midway through the 42d United States Women's Open championship.

title: Wedtech Says It Owes Millions to U.S.
description: The Wedtech Corporation disclosed yesterday that it owed ''tens of millions of dollars'' to the Government for payments made on contracts that the company had been unable to fulfill.

title: Quiche Gets the Boot on Columbus Ave.
description: Not so long ago, Columbus Avenue residents complained that it was becoming almost impossible to get their shoes fixed or their clothes cleaned, as places selling quiche and sushi and $20 bowls of pasta pushed out longtime neighborhood service stores. Now fashion foods are being pushed aside by fashion clothes, as another major wave of transformation rolls over the center of West Side Manhattan glitz.

title: AMAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After charges of $20,100,000 and $23,600,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, for the repurchases of debt; tax credits of $9,700,000 for the quarter and $43,500,000 for the 6 months, and the 6-month is also after a loss of $6,000,000 on discontinuances. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,700,000 and $10,100,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; and the 6-month also is after a loss of $10,000,000 on discontinuances and a gain of $80,100,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change related to the recovery of pension assets. The company said the latest second quarter and 6-month sharp increase in results was due to the inclusion of Alumax as a fully consolidated subsidiary, whereas prior to the acquisition in November 1986, Alumax was recorded on the basis of Amax's 50-percent equity interest.

title: HORIZON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
Trump Gets License For Skating Rinks
description: The developer Donald J. Trump, who last year restored New York City's Wollman Rink and made a profit of $500,000, received the concession to run the rink for the next four years.

title: Carter Has Regrets
description: Cris Carter, the all-America wide receiver who was dropped from the Ohio State team for signing a contract and taking money from Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom, two New York agents, said he knew he did wrong but now wanted to ''be a man'' and face his mistake. ''Don't you wish I could change it and do it a different way?'' Carter said in a story yesterday in The Dayton Daily News and Journal Herald. ''I can't.'' It was Carter's first public comment since Earle Bruce, the team's coach, suspended him and revoked his scholarship last week.

title: FAST RISE AFTER A LATE START
description: Leora Jones can trace the beginning of her athletic career to a fall evening in 1976 when she crawled from underneath her bed and told her parents that she had stayed after school to try out for the basketball team.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Announced that Jack Aker, coach, has left the club.

title: The Only Decent Thing to Do
description: It seems little enough for a citizen to expect of the Government: to provide notice if officials find there has been on-the-job exposure to substances that could pose a health danger. Yet legislation embodying that principle is stirring controversy on Capitol Hill and talk of a possible veto from the White House. It would be sad for the country and its workers if the opposition were to kill the legislation, rather than improve it.

title: Danaher Purchase
description: The Danaher Corporation said a new subsidiary would acquire Ammco Tools Inc. for about $52.8 million. The company said it expected the deal to be completed within 60 days. Danaher, a real estate investment trust based in West Palm Beach, Fla., said the acquisition reflected the company's strategy to buy established brand names in related businesses. Danaher's stock closed today at $25 a share, up 75 cents, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: O'Brien Stays Away
description: Ken O'Brien, the Jets' quarterback, did not follow the schedule and report to training camp last night, a team spokesman said. O'Brien, entering the final year of a $1.6 million, four-year contract that he signed after being a 1983 first-round draft choice, is reportedly seeking about $1 million a year. The Jets reportedly offered O'Brien a one-year deal plus an option worth about $800,000, but Leigh Steinberg, O'Brien's agent, rejected that offer.

title: Section Is Closed At Orchard Beach
description: The New York City Health Department yesterday temporarily closed the northern sections of Orchard Beach because of waste paper and plastic debris in the water.

title: JEFFERSON SMURFIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago quarter and 6 months sales restated to reflect the sale of a sawmill operation.

title: HASBRO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lawyer at Interior Dept. Is Accused of a Conflict
description: The Interior Department temporarily suspended its chief regional lawyer in California today pending a Justice Department review of a possible conflict of interest. At issue is whether the lawyer sought employment with a law firm whose client benefited from a water rights settlement he had negotiated, Interior Department officials said.

title: Pacesetter for Cruise Industry
description: At a dinner for cruise line executives nine years ago, Ted Arison, then the president of Carnival Cruise Lines Inc., made an announcement that would help turn the industry around: He was going to build a ship.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Rise by 14.7% on Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short, and not yet covered, in the month ended July 15 rose 35.7 million shares, or 14.7 percent, to 280 million shares.

title: A Tough Nominee for F.B.I.
description: The man President Reagan selected today to be the new Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Judge William Steele Sessions of San Antonio, is a minister's son who is known as a stern but scrupulously fair judge.

title: Birth Defect Seen As Death Cause
