description: The death of a Texas-El Paso basketball player stemmed from birth defects in his heart and not cocaine use, the Medical Examiner's office said today.

title: TEXTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains of $4.3 million and $3 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, both from discontinued operations. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $3.6 million for the quarter and $4.8 million for the 6 months.

title: Contamination by PCB's Is Possible in Bronx Fire
description: An underground fire in the Bronx ruptured an electrical transformer, exposing as many as 55 firefighters and police officers to possible PCB contamination, the police said yesterday.

title: KEY RATES
Trout and Yankees Fall to White Sox
description: And now for the reasonable approach.

title: Worker Turnover Said to Slow U.S. Toxic Cleanup
description: Better-paying private jobs are luring away Federal workers in the cleanup of the nation's worst toxic waste dumps, and the turnover is slowing down the project, Congressional investigators say.

title: CHUBB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $3.9 million for the quarter and $12.5 million for 6 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $20.5 million and $34.6 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said the latest second quarter and 6 months includes tax benefits of $7.2 million, or 17 cents a share, and $14.4 million, or 34 cents a share, respectively, related to a fresh start adjustment as a result of the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

title: Kinder-Care Deal
description: Kinder-Care Inc. said it had reached a definitive agreement to acquire the American Savings and Loan Association of Florida in a deal valued at about $138 million, or $17 a share. Kinder-Care, a holding company primarily involved in day-care centers, said that it would complete the transaction through a subsidiary, Centerbanc, but that American would be the surviving institution. The acquisition is subject to regulatory approval.

title: West German Intruder To Be Tried by Soviet
description: The Soviet authorities have informed West German diplomats that they will try Mathias Rust, the youth who landed his plane at the edge of Red Square, although no charges have been specified and no trial date has been set, West German Embassy officials said tonight.

title: Soviet Reports Nuclear Blast
description: The Soviet Union said it exploded a nonmilitary nuclear device today in a remote part of Siberia, its 12th since it ended a unilateral moratorium almost five months ago. Tass, the official press agency, reported that the explosion, in the Yakut Autonomous Region, had been ''conducted in the interests of the national economy,'' but it gave no other details.

title: Brazil Faces U.S. Patent Inquiry
description: Clayton K. Yeutter, the President's special trade representative, has announced an investigation into accusations that Brazilian companies have abused American pharmaceutical patents.

title: FALCONBRIDGE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $44 million gain on the sale of an interest in Western Platinum Ltd. c-Includes a $42 million gain on the sale of a Kiena Gold Mines Ltd. stake. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: COLGATE-PALMOLIVE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JET CREW MEMBERS CAPTURE HIJACKER
description: The cabin crew of a hijacked Air Afrique jet overpowered and captured a lone Lebanese gunman today after he killed a French passenger and critically wounded a steward while the plane was on the tarmac at Cointrin Airport, witnesses and Swiss officials said.

title: About New York; A Gradual Fade To Memories At the Baths
description: Hyman Cohen, the manager of the Brighton Beach Bath & Racquet Club, was sitting in his office when his assistant arrived. ''Just lost another one,'' he told Mr. Cohen. ''She went into a nursing home.''

title: GOTAAS-LARSEN SHIPPING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a foreign exchange loss of $52,000 and a foreign exchange gain of $19,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes foreign exchange losses of $31,000 for the quarter and $136,000 for the 6 months.

title: Rock: Diamono of Dakar
description: Choppy yet smooth, light yet kinetic, the Senegambian rock of Super Diamono de Dakar is an international blend that sounds effortless. The band, which has existed for two decades, has a large following in Africa and Europe for a style it calls Afro-feeling. It opened a two-night engagement Wednesday at Sounds of Brazil to a star-struck, predominantly Senegalese audience. Throughout the early set, while Super Diamono de Dakar played and sang, clubgoers climbed on stage to be photographed with the band.

title: Maxwell Closes London Paper
description: The publisher Robert Maxwell conceded defeat today in a bitter battle for London's newspaper readership and closed The London Daily News just five months after it started up. Mr. Maxwell, who also owns

title: TV: Carly Simon On HBO
description: Carly Simon is a singer who has always gone first class. In her 16-year solo recording career, Ms. Simon has collaborated with only the best producers, studio musicians and image makers to project an enviable portrait of high-powered patrician competence. And in ''Carly in Concert: Coming Around Again,'' her one-hour Home Box Office special that has its debut tonight at 11, the star exudes an indomitable confidence and glamour as she riffles through the pages of an emotion-charged musical scrapbook.

title: HAWAIIAN ELECTRIC INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Costa Ricans to Plant Trees On Airstrip North Arranged
description: Children will plant tree seedlings Saturday on an airstrip in Costa Rica that was built by the private network Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North set up to assist the Nicaraguan contras, Costa Rican officials say.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Dueling Pianos Last year a landmark Latin music concert at Lehman College featured five leading Latin pianists. Two of them - Hilton Ruiz and Eddie Palmieri - constitute the weekend bill at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, just east of Avenue of the Americas (475-8592). Mr. Palmieri represents the New York-born, jazz-influenced Latin musician, while Mr. Ruiz is the eclectic player, dipping into avant-garde and traditional styles.

title: Keep Calm About the Gulf
description: Despite the mine damage to the tanker Bridgeton and the ululations from Teheran, Washington does not have to turn injury into disaster. By refraining from retaliatory action, the Administration can insure that the ayatollahs are not diverted from contemplating their present predicament and the desirability of a cease-fire. Nor should one mine give decisive weight to panicky calls to quit the Persian Gulf.

title: Letter: On Child Welfare; Monitoring New York Day Care Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: British Novelist Wins Libel Award of $800,000
description: Jeffrey Archer, a best-selling novelist and former deputy chairman of the Conservative Party, today won a record award of $800,000 in libel damages against a London tabloid.

title: Innovative Vote Passes a Test
description: A 35-year-old Hispanic businesswoman has been elected to the Alamogordo City Commission, apparently assisted by a new system intended to help members of minority groups win public office.

title: Request Is Denied In Right-to-Die Case
description: A nursing home here yesterday lost a bid to bar the family of a woman in a comalike state from removing her life-sustaining feeding tube. The ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia came one day after the United States Supreme Court refused to interfere in the case, involving Nancy Ellen Jobes.

title: Kate Smith's Burial: Dispute Persists
description: The question, the conflicting parties agree, is if it doesn't have a door, is it still a mausoleum?

title: McEnroe Loses 6 1/2-Hour Match
description: The United States had already fallen behind West Germany, 0-1, in their Davis Cup relegation match today when John McEnroe was asked to summon some heroics for his meeting with Boris Becker, a marathon that required five sets and lasted more than six hours.

title: CAROLINA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for 12mos June 30
2 Raleigh Newspapers To Merge News Staffs
description: The head of the family that owns the morning and evening newspapers in Raleigh, N.C., has announced plans to merge the reporting and editing staffs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JULY 25, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Suit Against U.S. Attorney By Mayor Barry Dismissed
description: A Federal judge today dimissed a lawsuit filed by Mayor Marion Barry Jr. that charged the United States Attorney with prosecutorial abuse in an investigation of purported corruption in city contracting.

title: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Results for 1987 include a tax credit of $20 million and an after-tax gain of $81 million from the receipt of an additional contingent payment in connection with the 1985 sale of an oil and gas subsidiary operating on Colombia. c-Includes after-tax gains of $35 million from the sale of certain oil and gas properties and a tax benefit of $9 million, or 6 cents a share. Share earnings are fully-diluted.

title: DELTA AIR LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter reflects the acquisition of Western Airlines, effective April 1. The company said the latest year includes a gain from the sale of aircraft of $1.13 a share; and the prior year includes a similar gain of 22 cents a share.

title: Lear in Ventures
description: The Lear Siegler Seating Corporation, a unit of the Lear Siegler Holdings Corporation, said it had formed joint ventures with NHK Spring Company of Japan to build two plants, one in the United States and one in Canada. The plants will initially supply seating assemblies to Japanese automobile factories in North America. They would begin operation in Indiana in 1988 and in Ontario in 1989, with a start-up investment of about $15 million.

title: Little Rejects Plenum Offer
description: Arthur D. Little Inc., a consulting firm, today rejected an unsolicited takeover offer for $50 a share, or $128 million, from the Plenum Publishing Company., a small New York-based scientific press.

title: 27 in a Row Ties Record
description: The Salt Lake Trappers tonight equaled the longest winning streak in the history of organized baseball by winning their 27th consecutive game, a 7-2 victory over the Pocatello Giants in the Pioneer League.

title: Diamond-Bathurst Suit Charges Stock Fraud
description: Five senior officers of Diamond-Bathurst Inc., a manufacturer of specialty liquor bottles, have been accused by a former executive of manipulating the company's stock by filing false reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission in 1985 and 1986.

title: FORD MOTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reduced by $52 million to reflect costs associated with the anticipated restructuring of the company's involvement in South African Motor Corp.

title: Opposition in Bangladesh Calls an End to Strike
description: Opposition leaders today ended a 54-hour general strike but immediately announced a new series of protests intended to keep pressure on the President, Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, through next week.

title: Killer of Medical Student Dies In Electric Chair in Louisiana
description: Willie Watson went calmly and silently to his death in the electric chair early today for the rape, robbery and murder of a Tulane University medical student.

title: A Primer for Law School: Arguing in Moot Court
description: Alan Gavilanes gave up a $300-a-week summer job with A.T.&T. Gezabel A. Cortes gave up a $250-a-week job as a typist - and six weeks at home with her husband.

title: Fernandez and Teufel Lead Mets' Sweep
description: The Mets, who often have trouble winning once a day this season, won twice last night, sweeping a doubleheader from the Houston Astros and staying in distant pursuit of their long-lost first place.

title:
Patents;
Easing Measurement Of Light Polarization
description: LEAD: An electronic instrument that simplifies the measurement of light polarization is described in a patent granted this week to R.M.A. Azzam, professor of electrical engineering at the University of New Orleans. Light polarization measurements are reportedly essential in making various products, such as paints, textiles and foodstuffs.

title: Candelaria Returns
description: John Candelaria, the California Angels' pitcher who has been on the injured-reserve list for personal reasons since June 19, rejoined his team yesterday. Candelaria will work out under the supervision of Gene Mauch, manager of the Angels, and Marcel Lachemann, the pitching coach, before the Angels decide whether the left-hander should be activated. The pitcher underwent a 28-day in-patient counseling program to deal with personal problems that led to two arrests for drunken driving in May and June.

title: Clash in Haiti Leaves 10 Dead
description: Ten people were killed and 41 wounded during a march by followers of missionaries in a remote Haitian farming village today, the Information Ministry said tonight.

title: How Jose Sorzano Joined National Security Staff
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Steve Garvey won't be offered a contract with the San Diego Padres for the 1988 season, according to Chub Feeney, the team's president. Garvey, who will be 39 in December, has been sidelined since May following reconstructive surgery on a torn biceps tendon. . . . Baltimore has recalled Scott McGregor, a pitcher, from Class AAA Rochester and placed Fred Lynn, an outfielder, on the 15-day disabled list. . . . The Detroit Lions signed Reggie Rogers, the 6-foot-6-inch, 272-pound defensive end from the University of Washington who was their No. 1 draft choice.

title: The Testimony: Access to a President Who 'Relied on Himself'
description: In his second day of testimony yesterday at the Congressional hearings in Washington on the Iran-contra affair, George P. Shultz faced further questioning about high-level policy making. Here, as recorded by The New York Times, are excerpts from his testimony.

title: New York City's Unhappy Employees
description: LEAD: Unions representing doctors, firefighters, teachers, social workers, clerks and laborers - virtually all nonmanagerial New York City employees - report the same state of low morale. Employees feel there is a concerted citywide effort to dilute the civil service system and erode their working conditions and job opportunities.

title: Showtime Wins Court Ruling
description: Showtime won a skirmish yesterday against its archrival, Home Box Office, in the competition for pay-television movie subscribers.

title: The Flavors Of Smoke And Spice
description: As a child, I used to visit my aunt in the Roxbury section of Boston. She moved away more than 30 years ago, and I had not been back, until last week. I was not there to visit the old neighborhood, but to pay a call on a sausage maker who is proving that you don't have to be big to be successful.

title: Fermenta Progress
description: Fermenta A.B., the troubled Swedish biotechnology company, said it would complete its proposed restructuring following the successful issuance of 345 million common shares.

title: Tank of Acid Explodes In Alabama, Killing 2
description: A tank of sulfuric acid exploded Thursday at a chemical plant here, sending the 20,000-gallon container rocketing off its stand and killing two people and injuring at least three others.

title: Hafts Are Considering Dayton Hudson Move
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation, one of the nation's biggest department store chains, disclosed yesterday that the multimillionaire Haft family of Washington said it might be interested in buying at least half the company within the next year.

title: TRIBUNE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes one-time gains of $91,158,000 from the sale of The Los Angeles Daily News and other assets. Share earnings and shares outstanding are restated for a 2-for-1 stock split effective May 15.

title: XEROX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge relating to the sale of Century Data Systems of $13 million for the quarter and a loss of $14 million for the 6 months both from discontinued operations; and the 6-month also includes a non-recurring gain of $42 million from change in accounting for pension costs.

title: LAWMAKERS SAY SHULTZ ACCOUNT WAS FORTHRIGHT
description: Senators and Representatives on the Iran-contra committees - Democrats and Republicans alike - praised Secretary of State George P. Shultz today as an emblem of sanity and candor surrounded by folly and deceit.

title: Breeze McMennamin Becomes Bride Of Gustavus W. Hobbs 4th, Geologist
description: Marilyn Breeze McMennamin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G.Barry McMennamin of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Gustavus Warfield Hobbs 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hobbs 3d of Manasota Key, Fla., and Stonington, Conn. The Rev. Roland M. Jones performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan.

title: CHINA MAY ABSTAIN IN IRAN VOTE IN U.N.
description: China will probably not block an effort by the United Nations Security Council to impose an arms embargo on Iran, but it will continue to provide military support to the Iranians nonetheless, according to Western diplomats here.

title: Political Marketing; Campaigning to Instant Responses
description: For political strategists, one of the newest weapons in the quest to understand how Americans react to candidates and their ideas is a personal computer that measures an audience's response instantly and then calculates changes from second to second.

title: All 3 Active U.S. Minesweepers Far From Explosion in the Gulf
description: When the detonation of a mine sent a shock wave through an American convoy in the Persian Gulf today, there were no American minesweepers anywhere in the region.

title: Work Set on Tunnel Under Park Avenue
description: Construction is to begin this fall on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad's Park Avenue tunnel now that the contractor has dropped its claim that the winning bid was a mistake.

title: Delta Offers Refunds on Safety Issue
description: Delta Air Lines said today that it would offer refunds, even on restricted-fare tickets, to anyone concerned about flying the airline after its recent mishaps.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: FAIRCHILD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Includes income of $1,670,000 from discontinued operations for both the quarter and 6 months; a loss of $425,000 for the quarter and a gain of $2,794,000 for the 6 months, both from an accounting change, and tax benefits of $8,463,000 and $9,915,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After income from discontinued operations of $2,021,000 and $2,274,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; an extraordinary charge of $3,431,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $22,933,000 for the 6 months; and the 6-month also includes a gain of $22,016,000 from an accounting change.

title: TIMES MIRROR CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results include a gain of $133,800,000, or $2.07 a share, from the sale of Time Mirror Microwave Communications Co., three television stations and a cable television system.

title: They Map the Arctic to a Finer Scale
description: On the last frontier in North America, in a land of snowy mountains and ice-covered fjords, a group of Canadian soldiers is close to completing a job begun by some of the most famous names in Arctic exploration.

title: Tunisia Continues on a Moderate Course
description: To the Editor:

title: BIOSEARCH MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits $71,000 and $198,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and after tax benefits of $41,000 for quarter and $165,000 for the 6 months.

title: GENERAL MOTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JULY 25, 1987
description: International 2-7 A Kuwaiti tanker hit a mine just west of an Iranian island in the Persian Gulf. None of the 26 people aboard the 400,000-ton Bridgeton, which is traveling under American naval escort, were wounded. Page 1 No U.S. minesweepers were around when the mine detonation sent a shock wave through the American convoy in the Persian Gulf. There are only three active duty minesweepers in the entire United States Navy. 1 China is not likely to block an effort by the United Nations Security Council to impose an arms embargo on Iran, but will continue to provide military support to the Iranians nonetheless, Western diplomats said. 5 Bonn's position on an arms accord between the United States and the Soviet Union is avoiding a commitment on the fate of 72 Pershing 1A missles and their American-held warheads. 1 In the Iran-contra investigation, Senators and representatives on the committees, Democrats and Republicans alike, praised Secretary of State George P. Shultz as an emblem of sanity and candor surrounded by folly and deceit. 1 Reactions to Mr. Shultz's testimony vary at the White House. President Reagan believes it has been ''honest, sincere and helpful.'' But some officials are squirming over his portrait of disarray in the Administration. 7 A lone hijacker was overpowered by the cabin crew of an Air Afrique jet after he killed a French passenger and critically wounded a steward while the plane was on the tarmac at Cointrin Airport in Geneva. 1 Tamil guerrilas in Sri Lanka agreed in principle to a proposal that could end a bitter ethnic conflict, officials said. The move followed negotiations between India and Sri Lanka. 3 Pretoria continued its crackdown on opponents of apartheid, effectively wiping out, with detentions, the visible leadership of the country's major anti-apartheid group, the United Democratic Front. 3 Interviews with top Israeli officials will not be granted to the NBC television network in reaction to the network's failure to respond to Israeli criticism of its recent documentary about the West Bank, the Government announced. 54 Mapping the arctic 3 Henley-on-Thames journal 4 British novelist wins libel award 4 Clash in Haiti leaves 10 dead 4 American tells of massacre 11 National 8-10, 32 Man in the News: William Sessions was selected by President Reagan as the new Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. A Federal District Judge from San Antonio, Judge Sessions is known for being stern but scrupulously fair. 1 Confirmation of Judge Sessions should be relatively quick, White House and Justice Department officials said. The selection of a Federal judge for the post should limit Congressional opposition, they said. 10 A sand bar in the ississippi River has paralyzed traffic, stalling hundreds of barges with millions of tons in cargo in a nautical version of gridlock on the nation's busiest inland waterway. 1 Union Carbide will pay penalties of $408,500 in settlement of charges by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration that it committed hundreds of willful violations of Federal job health and safety rules. 8 The economy grew somewhat faster this spring than was generally expected, the Commerce Department said, but January-March growth was revised downward. The second-quarter data pointed to a modest, but better-balanced, economic expansion. 37 Delta Air Lines will issue refunds to anyone concerned about flying on the airline as a result of a recent series of mishaps, the company said. The refunds will even be given to holders of restricted fare tickets. 37 The Wedtech Corporation owes the Government tens of millions of dollars for contracts that the company did not fulfill, company officials disclosed. The failure was partly caused by the ''criminal acts of former management,'' they said. 8 The Interior Department suspended an official in California temporarily, pending a review. At issue is whether the official sought employment with a law firm whose client benefited from a water rights settlement he had negotiated. 8 A new weapon for political strategy helps candidates understand how Americans react to them and their ideas with a personal computer that measures an audience's response instantly and then calculates changes from second to second. 9 Tests of Vietnam veterans find average dioxin levels 8 Minnesota storms kill 2 8 Jacobs severed from libel suit 9 Worker turnover said to slow toxic waste cleanup 9 F.A.A. head says flying is safe 11 Promotion of two generals denied by Senate panel 32 Regional 33-35 A proposal on AIDS instruction for children in kindergarten through 12th grade will be circulated to school officials across the state for their reactions, the New York State Board of Regents voted. 33 Columbus Avenue rents are soaring, and fashionable restaurants are being pushed aside by high-priced clothing stores. Commercial real estate brokers see the transformation as part of the evolution of the center of West Side Manhattan glitz. 33 A fire released toxic chemicals, exposing as many as 55 firefighters and police officers to possible PCB contamination, the police said. The release was the result of an underground fire in the Bronx that ruptured an electrical transformer. 35 As temperatures climbed past 90, New Yorkers took to tall drinks, short haircuts and metaphysical means to maintain their cool. But much of the country was even more deeply immersed in a pressure cooker. 33 Verbal jousting over development in the region has become sharp. Mayor Koch, who has appeared in a series of humorous advertisements, was the butt of the joke in a commercial prepared by New Jersey's Public Service Electric & Gas Company. 33 After getting a taste of law school at the Summer Institute for Pre-Legal Studies at Rutgers Law School, some of the 13 black and Hispanic college students in the program have decided on law as a career. 34 New York City's top labor negotiator sought to have a mediator join talks between the city and municipal unions after declaring a lack of progress in negotiations. The move would be a possible prelude to arbitration. 35 Dispute over Kate Smith's tomb 34 Ward suggests lone suspect in Queens rapes 35

title: New Minilab From Kodak
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it would introduce a new minilab system for photofinishing, the first such system designed and built in the United States.

title: Guatemala's War Against Its Mayas
description: To the Editor:

title: AMFAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $5,637,000 and $7,723,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said the latest quarter and 6-month results reflect the adoption of FASB No. 87, which increased net by about $1,600,000 and $2,823,000, respectively. Latest quarter and 6-month share earnings reflect preferred dividends of $1,100,000 and $2,200,000, respectively; and the year-ago share earnings reflect preferred dividends of $150,000 for the quarter and $300,000 for the 6-month.

title: Restitution to Victims Works in Philadelphia
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Oil Output Low
description: Last year's slump in crude oil prices caused May production of Texas crude to fall to its lowest level in 43 years - below two million barrels a day - according to preliminary figures issued today by the Texas Railroad Commission. The commission, which regulates the Texas oil and gas industry, said oil production averaged 1.97 million barrels a day in May, down 30,000 from April and 230,000 less than in May 1986. Commissioner Jim Nugent attributed the fall to last year's price slump, noting that 20,000 oil wells and 7,000 gas wells had been taken out of production in Texas over the last year.

title: Pregnancy And Rubella
description: Women vaccinated against the disease rubella when pregnant do not risk seriously harming their babies, but Federal officials still do not recommend the vaccine for expectant mothers.

title: Sid Caesar at Met Opera
description: Sid Caesar will appear in the speaking role of Frosch, the jailer, in eight performances of ''Die Fledermaus'' at the Metropolitan Opera next season. The comedian has starred in plays and films in addition to two television series in the 1950's.

title: DATA GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Includes a $53.8 million charge for a restructuring and cost reduction program for both the quarter and 9 months; and the 9-month also includes an extraordinary charge of $18.2 million from redemption of debentures. c-Includes a charge of $3.8 million on the redemption of debentures.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''But the river, it hasn't changed a bit. It's still got a mind of its own. And when it says, 'Stop for a while and be patient,' well then, that's what you do. And you know that everything will be O.K.''

title: Top Officers Suspended In British Ferry Disaster
description: The captain and first officer of the Channel ferry Herald of Free Enterprise, which capsized March 6 with the loss of 188 lives, were suspended today and their employers censured for sloppy procedures on the vessel.

title: NIAGARA MOWAWK POWER CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a $755 million writedown for the company's disallowed costs of building its Nine Mile Point Two nuclear plant. c-Net income In the latest year, income before the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $615,000,000 was $105,213,000, or $1.22 a share.

title: DEMETRIOS OPROPOULOS
description: Retired Lieut. Gen. Demetrios Opropoulos, a leading opponent of the junta that ruled Greece for seven years, has died of a stroke, a family member said Friday. He was 66 years old. The junta headed by Col. George Papadopoulos exiled him to the Aegean island of Lesvos. He also lived in exile in London and headed a group of officers ousted by the junta.

title: EVERGREEN BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dioxin Levels Found In Vietnam Veterans Termed Not Unusual
description: Preliminary results of a study of 444 Vietnam veterans who may have been exposed to the herbicide Agent Orange show that very few veterans have unusually high levels of dioxin, the potentially harmful chemical in the herbicide, researchers said today.

title: HOOPER HOLMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Gulf Policy Critics Try to Stop Escorts
description: Congressional opponents of the United States escort mission in the Persian Gulf introduced legislation today that would force the Administration to abandon the effort in six months unless it is explicitly approved by Congress.

title: CENTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Regents Move Toward AIDS Teaching Plan
description: The New York State Board of Regents, signaling its intention to require instruction about AIDS from kindergarten through the 12th grade, voted today to circulate the proposal to public and private school officials across the state.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 11.

title: Henley Journal; A Scene of Old England: The Mute Swan Census
description: It was a frustrating morning for John Turk, a grizzled boat builder dressed in a dazzling crimson blazer that bespeaks his rank as Master of the Queen's Game of Swans, or swan master for short.

title: Basque Bombing Wounds 8
description: Eight civil guards were wounded today when a bomb exploded in a car outside their headquarters in this northern Basque town. Basque separatists claimed responsibility, the regional government said.

title: Baseball; Orioles' Streak Reaches 10
description: Cal Ripken's sacrifice fly, which was dropped by Bo Jackson in left field, drove in the tiebreaking run in the bottom of the eighth inning tonight as the Baltimore Orioles extended their winning streak to 10 games with a 3-1 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: Children's Game Show Captures Audiences
description: It's a dirty, sweaty, messy job, being a contestant on ''Double Dare,'' the only nationwide television game show for children. But, well, someone has to do it, and that someone - 13-year-old Michelle Hesse - was facing a crucial $20 question. ''All right, which of the following was not one of the seven dwarfs?'' asked Marc Summers, the charming and personable game-show host. ''Was it Grumpy, Sporty or Bashful?''

title: Bridge; Spingold Semifinal Teams Aren't From Top 11 Seeds
description: The most upset-ridden Spingold Knockout Team Championship ever entered the semifinal stage this afternoon.

title: 13 APARTHEID FOES SEIZED BY POLICE
description: South Africa continued its crackdown on opponents of apartheid today, effectively wiping out, with detentions, the visible leadership of the country's major anti-apartheid group, the United Democratic Front.

title: Telstar Also Made Legislative History
description: To the Editor:

title: DREYFUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Senate Panel Asks N.A.S.D. Study Of Stock Trading Done for Meese
description: The Senate panel investigating Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d's financial disclosures has asked the National Association of Securities Dealers to study the stock trading done by W. Franklyn Chinn on Mr. Meese's behalf.

title:
Patents;
Crystal and Welding Patents Given NASA
description: LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration received a patent this week for a crystal monitor that has been used in space to determine crystal growth. Patent 4,681,437 was obtained by Robert B. Owen and Mary H. Johnston of Huntsville, Ala. Crystals are used in semiconductors and optical devices.

title: American Tells of Mozambique Raid
description: An American, Mark van Koevering, gave a vivid account today of a massacre in Mozambique as anti-Government rebels and the South African Government repeated denials that they had been involved in the killing of 386 civilians in the town of Homoine.

title: PHILLIPS PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $54 million after-tax charge for a special separation program, which was partially offset by a $10 million gain on asset sales. In the latest quarter, preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Joan Collins Wins Suit on Prenuptial Agreement
description: A Superior Court judge ruled today that Joan Collins's prenuptial agreement with Peter Holm, a former pop singer, was valid. Mr. Holm, the judge found, was entitled to no more than 20 percent of the ''Dynasty'' star's earnings from the 13 months they were together.

title: Calls and Cables Favor Shultz In His Iran-Contra Testimony
description: Judging by calls and telegrams that have been received so far, Secretary of State George P. Shultz has strong support across the nation for his testimony in the Iran-Contra Congressional hearings.

title: Believe That? Try This
description: President Gipper knocked at Admiral Buckstopper's office door. ''Have you seen Colonel Shredder?'' he asked.

title: General to Visit Hanoi On Missing
description: President Reagan announced today that his special envoy, Gen. John A. Vessey, would travel to Hanoi next month in an attempt to revive negotiations over missing American servicemen.

title: ASHLAND OIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest 9-month includes a gain of $30,581,000 from restructuring of employee benefit plan.

title: VAN R. HALSEY
description: Van R. Halsey, a former senior partner of a Wall Street brokerage firm, died July 17 at his home in Rumson, N.J. He was 90 years old.

title: Illusions Exploded In the Gulf
description: If anyone, from the White House on down, thought the protective presence of U.S. Navy vessels would guarantee safe passage for reflagged tankers through the Persian Gulf, the mine that exploded against the Bridgeton should have disabused them.

title:
Patents;
Chips 'Spray Painted'
description: LEAD: Semiconductor wafers used in electronic circuitry can be ''spray painted'' with an apparatus patented this week for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. As many as 15 wafers can be sprayed at once with layers of silicon or other materials that do not vary by more than one atom in depth.

title: COMMERCIAL CREDIT COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $53.6 million and $52.9 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income and after a loss of $800,000 and income of $8.8 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, both from discontinued operations. The company said the loss of $53.6 million from discontinued operations reported in the latest second quarter represents an increase in the reserve against loans to less developed countries of $53 million plus $600,000 from other discontinued operations.

title: Israel Penalizes NBC Over Documentary
description: The Israeli Government has decided not to grant the NBC television network any interviews with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and two other top officials because of the network's failure to respond to Israeli criticism of its recent documentary about the West Bank.

title: Holly Board Backs Arcanum Buyout
description: The Holly Sugar Corporation's directors have unanimously approved a $130 million leveraged buyout of the company by Arcanum I partners, the sugar company announced. The proposed agreement must still be approved by shareholders. The Holly board has called a special shareholders meeting for Oct. 29 to consider the merger.

title: 15% Stake Sought In Crazy Eddie
description: Entertainment Marketing Inc. said that it ''has a good-faith intention to acquire 15 percent'' of Crazy Eddie Inc.'s 30.9 million shares outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Entertainment said that it was seeking permission under Federal antitrust laws to raise its stake to 15 percent from its present 5.5 percent.

title: Ward Suggests Lone Suspect Committed Rapes in Queens
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward told a large gathering in Queens Thursday night that he believed one person was responsible for 13 sexual assaults in central Queens in recent months. But department officials said yesterday that there could be one, two, or three rapists involved.

title: Finding Comparisons 'Unwise'
description: During yesterday's session, Secretary of State George P. Shultz was questioned on historical comparisons involving the Iran-contra affair.

title: BONN'S ARMS STAND SEEN AS KEY ISSUE IN U.S.-SOVIET PACT
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition is avoiding a firm commitment on the fate of 72 Pershing 1A missiles and their American-held warheads, a remaining issue in the efforts to conclude a Soviet-American arms agreement.

title: Milwaukee's Marine Takes Banc One Bid
description: The Marine Corporation, a banking group based in Milwaukee, said today that it had agreed to be acquired by the Banc One Corporation, a bank holding company based in Columbus, Ohio, in a stock swap valued at $546 million.

title: BAXTER TRAVENOL LABORATOIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $13 million and $27 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said all year-ago results are restated to reflect the sale of the company's flint and american critical care units.

title: ICM PROPERTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dinosaur Eggshells in West Appear to Be Oldest Found
description: Shells of dinosaur eggs found in western Colorado are believed to be the oldest ever discovered, researchers say.

title: Art Boom Slows In the East Village
description: The East Village neighborhood in Manhattan, since the early 1980's a spawning ground for new artistic trends and the fastest-growing art district in New York City, has reached a plateau of growth, with fewer new galleries opening and some of its most successful ones moving to larger spaces in SoHo.

title: PIP Rejects Offer From Kane-Miller
description: Postal Instant Press said that it had rejected as inadequate a takeover offer of $18.50 a share, or $77.3 million, made earlier this month from a group led by the Kane-Miller Corporation. Thomas C. Marotto, president and chief executive of the franchiser of 1,100 instant printing centers, said directors, who met Thursday, concluded that ''now is not the time to sell the company in terms of realizing full value for our shareholders.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the medical imaging business made an erroneous implication about the profitability of ADAC Laboratories. The company has been profitable in its last three quarters.

title: Court Date After Trip
description: Kevin Ross, a former basketball player at Creighton University, can go to California to take a job, Associate Judge Michael Bolan of the Cook County Circuit Court in Chicago ruled yesterday, a day after the police said Ross held them at bay, tossing furniture from a downtown motel room. Ross will be working with children in California, said Marva Collins, who persuaded Ross to leave the motel room. Bolan ordered Ross to return for his next court date Aug. 21. Collins taught Ross to read beyond an elementary-school level after he left Creighton.

title: Union Carbide Agrees to Pay $408,500 Fine for Safety Violations
description: The Union Carbide Corporation agreed today to pay penalties of $408,500 to settle charges by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration that it committed hundreds of willful violations of Federal job health and safety rules.

title: Titles That Aren't Titles
description: How many times do you have to read the following sentence to understand it? ''This genteel look at New England life, with a formidable circulation of 1 million, warmly profiles Hartland Four Corners, Vt., resident George Seldes, 96.'' (From a column syndicated by The Chicago Tribune.) What makes gibberish of it is a ''cute'' piece of journalese known as the false title. The five words preceding Mr. Seldes's name, beginning with ''Hartland,'' purport to be his title.

title: New York Asks Mediator to Join Contract Talks
description: Declaring a lack of progress in negotiations between New York City and more than 100 unions, the city's chief labor negotiator sought yesterday to have a mediator join the talks as a possible prelude to arbitration.

title: Ewald Nyquist, Ex-Commissioner Of Education in New York State
description: Ewald B. Nyquist, a former New York State Education Commissioner who played a key role in desegregating the state's schools, suffered a heart attack and died yesterday morning while driving with his wife near their home in Grafton, N.Y. He was 72.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on women's basketball in Thursday's Sports Pages misidentified the college put on two-year probation in 1985 for recruiting violations involving Chana Perry. It was Northeast Louisiana University, not Louisiana Tech.

title: Judge Severs Congressman From Robertson's Libel Suit
description: A Federal judge today severed Representative Andrew Jacobs Jr. from a $70 million libel suit brought by the Rev. Pat Robertson.

title: HASTINGS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HICKHAM, DOW B INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $71,000 from early retirement of indebtedness.

title: Loss, and Gain, for Smoking Limits
description: A new court decision marks an immediate setback for New York State's effort to regulate smoking in order to promote public health. But the decision also makes clear the wisdom of such regulation, leaving in doubt only the question of who should carry it out.

title: 3Com, Bridge Plan to Merge
description: The 3Com Corporation and Bridge Communications Inc., both makers of computer network systems, said today that they would merge. The combined company would retain the 3Com name and have its headquarters at 3Com's Santa Clara, Calif., facility, while Bridge would become a subsidiary and continue operating from Mountain View, Calif.

title: BIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRAND COS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: The President Praises Shultz While His Advisers Squirm
description: President Reagan believes that Secretary of State George P. Shultz's Congressional testimony has been ''honest, sincere and helpful,'' Marlin Fitzwater, the President's chief spokesman, said today.

title: PREMIER INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $2,214,000, or 7 cents a share, related to investments in oil and gas properties.

title: Your Money; Ethical Funds More Popular
description: WHEN Lee Clayton of Huntington, L.I., decided to invest in a mutual fund five years ago, she chose the New Alternatives Fund, one of the small group of what are called socially responsive funds that consider more than just the bottom line in their investment strategies.

title: Texaco Deadline Extended by Judge
description: The judge overseeing the Texaco Inc. bankruptcy case yesterday gave the company an extra four months to file a plan for paying creditors and coming out of bankruptcy.

title:
Patents;
A Teaching Apparatus And Lens to Guard Eye
description: LEAD: An audio-visual apparatus patented this week by Jerome H. Lemelson, a prolific inventor, is described as useful in teaching, training, quizzing, testing and game playing. A number of record sheets or cards are employed. The apparatus is to have recording, computing and signaling functions.

title: MCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate 1. Spending Cuts: Vote on an amendment to a bill authorizing an increase in the debt ceiling that would have given the budget-balancing law a new automatic mechanism for making spending cuts. Rejected 71 to 25, July 23. 1 Connecticut Dodd (D) Y Weicker (R) N Delaware Roth (R) N Biden (D) A Maryland Mikulski (D) Y Sarbanes (D) N Massachusetts Kennedy (D) Y Kerry (D) N New Jersey Bradley (D) N Lautenberg (D) N New York D'Amato (R) N Moynihan (D) N Pennsylvania Heinz (R) N Specter (R) N Rhode Island Pell (D) N Chafee (R) N Virginia Trible (R) N Warner (R) N House 1. Catastrophic Illness: Vote on a bill that would protect 31 million elderly and disabled people against the cost of catastrophic illness by approving the largest expansion of Medicare benefits in the program's 22-year history.

title: Worlds in Collision: From Barrio to Harvard to Jail
description: When Jose Razo entered Harvard University in the fall of 1985, he seemed to blend in easily. Like most members of the freshman class, he had a bright, inquiring mind and had earned straight A's in high school.

title: Patenting Life
description: 'We've approved the patenting of plants in 1930, seeds in 1970, microbes in 1980, and now we've moved to considering patenting animals. Next is human beings. We need to look at this and consider some ground rules for proceeding down this path.'

title: Tough, Tight Race In the 4th District Seen by Both Sides
description: WITH little time to savor their primary election victories last Tuesday, Christopher H. Shays and Christine M. Niedermeier began a four-week sprint last week toward a special election on Aug. 18 to fill the vacant Congressional seat in Connecticut's Fourth District. Politicians in both parties rated it as an intense and potentially close race.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE MAN WHO ROBBED THE PIERRE: The Story of Bobby Comfort. By Ira Berkow. (Atheneum, $17.95.) It was a caper out of a Hollywood production of the 1930's: five dinner-jacketed thieves walk into a deluxe Manhattan hotel, handcuff 19 employees and guests and walk out with more than $10 million in jewels and cash. What is more, the thieves quarrel, the loot disappears, and the planner takes the fall (in Attica). If that were the extent of the story told by Ira Berkow, a sportswriter for The New York Times, it would be by itself a solid and fascinating account of the 1972 robbery of the Pierre Hotel. But Mr. Berkow, drawing on exhaustive research and interviews with Bobby Comfort, jewel thief extraordinary and mastermind of the Pierre and other robberies, spins a dramatic tale of the meticulous planning and audacious execution of heists and the police work that follows them and ultimately foils robbers, at least some of the time. He also gives some clues as to what pushed Comfort into the criminal life (parents, of course) and describes the despairing terror of victims, including the actress Sophia Loren. As Mr. Berkow describes him, Comfort's basic flaws were a lack of responsibility and an inability to be in touch with reality for any length of time. For all the derring-do, Comfort failed when he attempted honest business and ended his days watching Phil Donahue on television and often showing up as the only father at afternoon P.T.A. meetings.

title: NET-WIELDING CENSUS TAKERS STALK THEIR FLUTTERING QUARRY
description: THEY were getting tired of stout-bodied skippers; they wanted satyrs and painted ladies, too. The five people recently searching a meadow at the Pequotsepos Nature Center in Mystic carefully recorded them all, each butterfly they could identify - numerous skippers, a few wood satyrs, a little painted lady, a swooping swallowtail and others, for a total of 64 individuals of 19 species.

title: FOR MORE INFORMATION ON HARRIMAN SOCIETY
description: As a follow-up to the article, ''Harriman Society Lists Goals'' [ July 12 ] , please be advised that anyone interested in additional information concerning The Harriman Society should telephone 723-4210. OLGA TOLL Secretary The Harriman Society Scarsdale

title: Broadway's Grand Cinemas Are Fading Away
description: WITHOUT sweeping searchlights, white-gloved ushers, mighty Wurlitzer organs - indeed, without any fanfare or protest or notice at all - Broadway is losing almost every vestige of its moviegoing past.

title: Under International Law, Reflagging Doesn't Fly; We Are Vulnerable
description: To the Editor:

title: Companies are Racing To Recycle Cycles
description: THE COMPACT DISK HAS made complete or sort-of-complete cycles of all kinds of things very fashionable, as record companies plumb the depths of their catalogues for items to entice collectors. We have been seeing extensive reissues of Rubinstein, Callas, Toscanini, Walter and Furtwangler, among others. Among the latest in this flood are the recordings of George Szell, Colin Davis's Berlioz recordings and the Dvorak symphonies conducted by Istvan Kertesz.

title: Penny Levitt Wed To David Bennett
description: Penny Aleen Levitt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julian Levitt of Mountainside, N.J., was married yesterday to David McDowell Bennett, a son of Mrs. Alfred M. Bennett of Norwalk, Conn., and the late Dr. Bennett. The Rev. Elmer Talcott, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Stronghold Mansion on the campus of the Gill-St. Bernard's School in Bernardsville, N.J.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
ON THE WATERFRONT
description: LEAD: Dr. Joseph Lauria has had a special feeling for the New Rochelle waterfront since he came to the city in 1959. Although he lives at the north end of the city, he visits the shore area whenever he can.

title: At Last a Majority Rules in Portugal
description: After 48 years of right-wing dictatorship, followed by 13 years of faltering coalitions and minority Governments, Portugal finally elected its first majority party last week. Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva's Social Democrats won 50 percent of the vote and at least 145 of the 250 seats in Parliament.

title: SALMON REACH THE HOLYOKE DAM
description: The June 28 issue carried a very fine article on the progress being made with the restoration of Atlantic salmon in the Connecticut River [ '' '87 Is Termed an Upswing Year for Salmon Restoration'' ] . However, it contained one glitch. The article erroneously said that no salmon have ever reached the top of the Holyoke dam across the Connecticut River. Actually, many have; 1,230 to date, by means of the fish elevator operated by the Holyoke Water Power Company of Northeast Utilities.

title: Twins Seek Buckner
description: BILL BUCKNER, released by the Boston Red Sox, will sign with the Minnesota Twins next week if he clears waivers, according to his wife, Jody. The 37-year-old first baseman expects to be the Twins' designated hitter, The Minneapolis Star and Tribune reported yesterday.

title: Headliners; No Penalty
description: Lawrence Taylor said he got into a lot less trouble for abusing cocaine than other professional athletes who have been caught with the drug. In his forthcoming biography, ''LT: Living on the Edge,'' excerpts of which appeared last week, the star linebacker of the New York Giants said his drug use was well known during the 1985 season. ''I made no effort to hide it,'' he maintained. Yet he contended that no one in authority tried to stop him. ''Cops and N.F.L. security people, people I knew, would follow me,'' he recalled. ''It was a joke.'' He said it was ''almost a thrill in itself knowing that people knew what I was doing and wouldn't do a damn thing to stop me.'' Taylor voluntarily entered a drug rehabilitation program in February 1986 and returned to lead the Giants to victory in the Super Bowl. The Giants' head coach, Bill Parcells, had no comment on Taylor's disclosures.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Stratton, Vt.;
A New Focus For Ski Resort
description: LEAD: REGGIE CYR has built nearly 200 units of vacation housing on Stratton Mountain. All have been designed to accommodate the tourists who each winter flock to this ski resort in southern Vermont.

title: Under International Law, Reflagging Doesn't Fly; Embargo Oil, Not Arms
description: To the Editor:

title: At a Fresh Air Fund Farm, Many Joys of Summer
description: Peter Torres swung high on the fish-net hammock strung between the maple and butternut trees. ''Just look around,'' he said, smiling. ''No cars, no pollution, no noise.'' And then, pausing for a moment, he added, ''Why can't it be like this in the city?''

title: Increase in Mortgage Fees Set
description: SPOKESMEN for the state's Department of Banking and the mortgage-loan industry say they do not know how much more borrowers might have to pay in mortgage-loan fees this fall.

title: Tigers Win in 10th On Whitaker's Homer
description: Lou Whitaker's two-out home run in the 10th inning gave the Detroit Tigers a 5-4 victory over the Cleveland Indians today.

title: Reagan's Top Aides Paint Conflicting Presidential Portraits By R. W. APPLE Jr.
description: THE Congressional committees studying the Iran-contra affair will not hear testimony from President Reagan, so they will not have a chance to form a firsthand picture of his role in the controversy. But Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter, two men who know him well and who met him often during the period in question, have drawn portraits of the President - portraits that don't always match.

title: A HERO GONE OUT OF FASHION
description: SARTRE A Life. By Annie Cohen-Solal. Edited by Norman MacAfee. Translated by Anna Cancogni. Illustrated. 591 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $24.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A SIGN OF THE EIGHTIES. By Gail Parent. (Putnam, $17.95.) In this bittersweet comic novel, Gail Parent displays her knack for transforming social trends into fiction. At the age of 35, Shelly Silver runs a successful upscale catering service, uses a personal shopper at Bloomingdales and sees herself as successful in every way but one: she is still single. Taking to heart the now-infamous finding that highly educated women in their 30's have only a slim chance of marrying, she casts aside her feminist principles to stalk a husband. The man she schemes to marry is her former lover Mickey Burke, a popular but frustrated television comedy writer who yearns to make movies. But Mickey, who is ''short, dark, and funny,'' suffers from that much-publicized affliction of the 1980's - fear of intimacy. Enter Astra Rainbow Blakely, Mickey's new secretary, ''the most serious 22-year-old in the country.'' The daughter of 1960's flower children, Astra yearns for two things: perfect normality in her life and absolution for her childhood role in a little boy's accidental death. Eventually, Astra provides the means to solve everyone's problems, including her own, and Ms. Parent finds a way to put a comic twist on a whole season of potential New York magazine cover stories. Ms. Parent, who won an Emmy for her work on the ''The Carol Burnett Show,'' is at her satiric best in the first half of the novel, when she describes Mickey's latest television series and his difficulties with network executives. In the novel's second half, however, the trendy tale loses force, as the manhunting stunts of Shelly and her friend Greta grow tiresome and tasteless.

title: A Mine Sends Shock Waves Through U.S. Policy in Gulf
description: LESS than three months after an Iraqi missile killed 37 American Navy sailors aboard the frigate Stark, the United States was plunged anew last week into a critical debate over the scope, purpose and prospects of its role in the Persian Gulf and its credibility throughout the Arab world.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
TO A MANOR BORNE
description: LEAD: ON many a summer day, 13-year-old Claire Sullivan gets up around 11 o'clock.

title: ; What Radio Is Saying . . .
description: NOTHING INVIGORATES the mass media the way reality does. When we watch Jesse Orosco pitching in the World Series, when we watch a terrorist holding a gun to the neck of a T.W.A. captain or even when we watch a winner on ''Wheel of Fortune'' jumping for joy - the television set is suddenly injected with a special drama. Because we know real people are involved.

title: Hispanic Pupils' Plight Cited in Study
description: Hispanic children around the country are increasingly attending segregated schools, and New York is the most segregated state of all for the students, according to a study of Federal data on school enrollment by researchers at the University of Chicago.
