title: STATE PONDERING CHANGES IN COGENERATION POLICIES
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY is considering strategies to provide cogenerators and small power producers greater stability in prices and predictability of payments when they contract to sell electricity to utility companies.

title: On Arms, Moscow Has a Winning Image
description: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV has again shown his flair for the dramatic, casting himself as a dynamic leader willing to make important concessions on arms control. And with his announcement last week that the Soviet Union is prepared to accept a worldwide ban on American and Soviet medium-range and short-range missiles, Mr. Gorbachev has once again caught Washington by surprise. At a hastily called press conference, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, cautiously welcomed the Soviet announcement, noting that the idea of eliminating American and Soviet medium-range missiles was first suggested by President Reagan in his ''zero option'' proposal in 1981.

title: A Degree of Detachment
description: IT'S 10:15 ON A TUESDAY MORNING. I'm at my desk, dictating out a stack of X-rays, when the phone rings. It's Carol, our C.T. (computed tomography) scan technologist. ''Dr. Shragg, we're ready to do the biopsy.'' ''I'll be right over,'' I tell her. A woman has a tumor in her pancreas. Her internist has asked me, the radiologist, to do a needle biopsy. A pathologist will study the biopsy under the microscope and render a final diagnosis.

title: RETIREMENT: IT'S EASIER SAID THAN DONE
description: I AM SITTING on an aluminum chair under a beach umbrella that's stuck in the hole of a large wooden spool that once held a roll of wire.

title: FORREST E. KENDALL
description: Forrest E. Kendall, a professor emeritus of biochemistry at Columbia University, died of a heart attack yesterday in North Shore University Hospital, in Manhasset, L.I. He was 88 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

title: DOCUMENTARY
description: Vietnam: Legacies - Volume 7 Chief correspondent, Stanley Karnow; producer, Elizabeth Deane; executive producer, Richard Ellison. Sony Video Software. 60 minutes. $19.95. The legacies of the 10-year war in Vietnam - longer than World Wars I and II together - are illustrated in the final film in the series, ''Vietnam: A Television History,'' originally presented by WGBH-Boston as a 13-hour series on public television.

title: Visiting India
description: To the Editor: There is another very satisfactory alternative to traveling like a maharajah (''A Maharajah's Rail Journey in Rajasthan,'' Travel, June 28). I covered the same distances and sites and was free to wander by myself through palaces and markets, to stay in Agra to see the Taj in different lights and spend a few nights in the Lake Palace in Udaipur.

title: STATE LINKS RISING DRUG DEATHS TO HEROIN MIX
description: STATE health specialists are concerned about an abnormally high number of deaths among intravenous drug users taking a highly addictive mixture of heroin, which might be purer than usual, and cocaine.

title: Waiting, Once Again, for Democracy
description: THINK of a man who has been married several times and several times his marriage has collapsed like a house of cards.

title: POLITICS LCANDIDATES' SPENDING BECOMES ISSUE
description: WITH the legislative races drawing closer, some lawmakers are talking about trying to limit the amount of money that candidates can spend this year.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
LANDMARK
description: LEAD: The Open Space Institute, a nonprofit organization devoted to land preservation; the Putnam County Historical Society, and the Garrison Landing Association are joining forces to restore and acquire landmark status for an 18th-century complex on the grounds of the Highlands Country Club in Garrison.

title: Cogeneration: State 'Fertile'
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY is considered fertile ground for cogeneration.

title: THE THINKING MAN'S CITY
description: NEW YORK INTELLECT A History of Intellectual Life in New York City, From 1750 to the Beginnings of Our Own Time. By Thomas Bender. 422 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: Headliners; Thinking Big
description: Molly Yard swept into office as president of the National Organization for Women last weekend with no shortage of large goals. The 70-ish Ms. Yard - she refuses to disclose her exact age - said NOW would, among other things, work to block the Supreme Court confirmation of Judge Robert H. Bork, attempt to win the Democratic Presidential nomination for Representative Patricia Schroeder of Colorado, and muster a million marchers in support of an equal rights amendment to the Constitution. ''The only war we seek is the war to end poverty, ignorance and disease,'' said Ms. Yard, whose involvement in liberal causes dates back to her years at Swarthmore College, from which she was graduated in 1933. Ms. Yard also announced plans to picket the Vatican mission in Washington next month to protest the Catholic church's positions on birth control and abortion.

title: The Undressing Of the Titanic
description: While several members of Congress stopped just short of calling them grave-robbers, a French crew dived yesterday for the treasures of the Titanic.

title: Hungry Fans Irk McEnroe
description: It is the peculiar genius of John McEnroe to reach back into the mists and discover his magic corkscrew shots again, yet to remember mainly the fleeting backs of his fellow Americans, whose hunger outweighed their patriotism.

title: MAN THE RAMPARTS! JELLYFISH ARE HERE!
description: THIS is a war story, a tale of the battle that faces Long Islanders each summer as battalions of pinkish-red jellyfish take over our bays.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: SILHOUETTES Does the name Etienne de Silhouette ring a bell? Only the last part, right? He was a controller general in the court of Louis XV who whiled away his retirement by cutting paper into landscapes and the shapes of people.

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;
GREAT EXPECTATIONS
description: LEAD: THIS AFTERNOON, WITH THE START OF the Paris couture collections for fall, Christian Lacroix is to present his first collection under his own name. Not since Emanuel Ungaro left Balenciaga in the early 1960's to create his own house, or Karl Lagerfeld took over the creative side of Chanel in 1983, has so much electricity been generated by the couture.

title: FOSTERING EFFECTIVE PARENTING
description: YOU wake suddenly and see that it is 3 A.M. The outdoor lights are still on, and you realize that your 15-year-old son hasn't come home. Fear and anger turn your legs to lead; he promised to be in by midnight. As you lie there, wondering what to do, you hear the door. He is back.

title: FARM'S SWEET CORN AND MEMORIES
description: ''ANOTHER small farmer bankrupt.'' ''Developers gobbling up farmland.'' -Newspaper headlines, June 1987. Was all this about me? No. My farm story was different. What good memories I have. Selling fresh-picked sweet corn and other Long Island vegetables in season from a farm stand on the edge of busy Route 25A in Poquott was exhausting work and also a lot of fun.

title: In Bethlehem, Focus Is on Wood
description: AN EASILY overlooked exhibition space among the tourist attractions in one of New Jersey's neighboring cities - historic Bethlehem, Pa. - is a gallery in the Luckenbach Mill. which houses the local Visitors Center.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN BOOK DISTRIBUTION
description: ERIC KAMPMANN started with three clients almost seven years ago, but now his company is the biggest, most respected distributor of books by small publishers. His 60 clients include publishers in California, Idaho, New Mexico and Florida, and three from England.

title: John DeLuca Is Dead at 43; Vice President for Primerica
description: John R. DeLuca, vice president of health care business development for the Primerica Corporation, died of bone marrow cancer on July 18 at Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. He was 43 years old and lived in Weston, Conn.

title: MARY E. HARRIS
description: Mary E. Harris, an editor, producer and director of radio and television shows for many years, died of a heart attack in her Manhattan apartment on July 19. She was 73 years old.

title: GRILLED CHICKEN, PLAIN AND SIMPLE, AS A SUMMER CENTERPIECE
description: BECAUSE it is so versatile, chicken is the most popular meat for summer cooking.

title: New Orleans Jazz With a Scholarly Beat
description: THE URGE TO CREATE JAZZ repertory ensembles has been bubbling up sporadically for the last 20 or 30 years. Orchestra U.S.A., the National Jazz Ensemble, the New York Jazz Repertory Company and the New York Jazz Repertory Orchestra have come and gone, although the American Jazz Orchestra is just completing its first year.

title: Swiss Vow to Try Hijacker Despite Terrorism Risk
description: Switzerland's President said today that a captured Lebanese hijacker would be put on trial, despite fears that the people of this peaceful and neutral country might face Arab terrorist reprisal.

title: Businessmen and Apartheid
description: To the Editor:

title: DAVIS CUP REPRIEVE FOR U.S.
description: The United States team, which had fully expected to come into this afternoon's doubles match at least even in its Davis Cup duel with West Germany, instead discovered itself on the brink of elimination from 1988 Cup contention after John McEnroe and Tim Mayotte dropped singles matches.

title: VISIONARY CURATOR, CAUTIONARY TALE
description: IF, AS PHILIP JOHNSON ONCE said, ''The first law of architecture is 'get the job!' '' the first law of American museum directorship is ''get along with the board of trustees!'' You may be scholar, connoisseur and master of forward planning. You may run a tight ship, with the love and support of your staff. You may mount loan exhibitions that give pleasure to thousands of people, and when it comes to building up the permanent collections, you may make the right decisions. But if you don't get along with the trustees, you'd better pack your bags.

title: Headliners; Moving On
description: After 10 years as the senior minister of the Riverside Church, the Rev. William Sloane Coffin has chosen another sort of pulpit. At services last Sunday, Dr. Coffin announced that he was resigning to become head of a Washington-based disarmament organization called SANE/Freeze. Dr. Coffin, who was outspoken in his support of civil rights and in his opposition to the Vietnam War while he was the chaplain at Yale University from 1958 to 1976, said his decision to leave Riverside had to do with ''the shadow of Doomsday.'' ''God presents us with choices we have to make ourselves,'' he said. ''One has to move on if you think that's what God wants you to do.''

title: SHE HAD HER LIFE TO LIVE OVER
description: THE SEARCH FOR OMM SETY A Story of Eternal Love. By Jonathan Cott with Hanny El Zeini. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $17.95.

title: WELFARE RENT IN BRIDGEPORT
description: I am writing to bring to your attention several factual errors in the June 7 article entitled ''Suit Challenges Welfare Rent'' by Sharon L. Bass. Ms. Bass states that ''a single person receives $157.72 a month for shelter and $251 for food, utilities and clothing.'' In fact, in the city of Bridgeport they would receive a maximum of $118 a month for rent for an unfurnished apartment, and a maximum of $310 a month for a furnished apartment. The city also pays $32.95 a month to assistance recipients to cover utility costs.

title: FLORIDA: WEIGHING THE REASONS TO GO
description: AFTER 42 years of living in Scarsdale, sending our four children through the entire Scarsdale school system, serving on committees that brought Scarsdale a swimming pool, ran the Christmas Carol Sing, helped a variety of funds hit that red ball at the top of the bar-chart poster, my wife and I had to face the cruel fact that a house that accommodated a family of six was now oversized for just two of us.

title: DVORAK IN THE NEW WORLD
description: SPILLVILLE By Patricia Hampl. Illustrated by Steven Sorman. 107 pp. Minneapolis: Milkweed Editions. Cloth, $25. Paper, $9.95.

title: Deregulation Of Rents Opposed
description: To the Editor:

title: Russian on Space Trip Has a Heart Problem
description: A Soviet astronaut who has spent nearly six months in space has developed a potentially serious heart problem and will be brought home next week, Soviet officials said Friday.

title: Prosecute Unstable Owners Who Abuse Pit Bulls
description: To the Editor:

title: Submarine Ball
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: PAINTED IN BLOOD: Understanding Europeans. By Stuart Miller. (Atheneum, $17.95.) The premise of this short and breezy book is that Europeans differ from Americans because of their ''background of collective violence'' - their history, according to Stuart Miller, is ''painted in blood.'' ''We must think,'' he suggests, ''of a vast South Bronx of a continent, repeatedly devastated not for ten or twenty years but, as men experience time, forever.'' He concedes that European cities are safer than ours; but what about German highway manners, he asks, and the nine-bolt security locks in Italy? He is horrified by the militarization of Western Europe (''The road signs I pass on the German Autobahn give two speed limits: one for cars and one for tanks''); he doesn't seem to realize that the United States may have a part in it. Mr. Miller's historical generalizations are no more misleading than those to be found in the average tourist guidebook, and ''Painted in Blood'' is partly a guide for American innocents abroad - especially businessmen. But Mr. Miller, the author of a novel, ''Hot Springs,'' and other works, has written a book that, like most American books about Europeans, is ultimately about Americans. He takes as one of his epigraphs Emerson's observation that ''all educated Americans, first or last, go to Europe.'' He makes it clear that he is no exception, and tells us about his student years in Italy, his Belgian wife and in-laws, his European colleagues. This gives ''Painted in Blood'' an appealing personal flavor - like a 19th-century travel sketch. He neglects to add that Emerson, in a more familiar and disturbing passage, remarked that ''it is for want of self-culture that the superstition of Travelling, whose idols are Italy, England, Egypt, retains its fascination for all educated Americans.''

title: Asian Viewpoint
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
WORKHORSES OF THE SUMMER GARDEN
description: LEAD: WHEN it comes to surviving summer heat, it's hard to beat a native.

title: BEATRICE S. DOERING TO MARRY C. L. SHEA
description: Beatrice Suzanne Doering and Christopher Lane Shea, a son of Nancy Bowditch of New York and Peter L. Shea of New York and Locust Valley, L.I., plan to marry Sept. 26, the parents of the future bride, Dr. and Mrs. Eckart G. Doering of Riverside, Conn., have announced.

title: Roberta Linda Greenberg To Wed Mark D. Shapiro
description: Dr. Julian Greenberg of Elmont, L.I., and Highland Beach, Fla., and Dr. Betty Z. Greenberg of North Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Roberta Linda Greenberg, to Mark Desmond Shapiro, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hym Shapiro of Johannesburg and Sydney, Australia. The couple plan to marry Oct. 18.

title: Undecided Democrats Reported on Increase
description: Despite the intense early campaigning of Democratic Presidential hopefuls, the percentage of Democrats undecided about their party's choice is growing, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows. It also found the Rev. Jesse Jackson still the only candidate with more than 10 percent support.

title: An East Village Comic Moves Uptown
description: THERE IS A CERTAIN POETIC justice in Ann Magnuson's being invited to perform at Alice Tully Hall.

title: DON'T MAKE TWO-FAMILY HOMES ILLEGAL
description: VIRTUALLY 1,000 out of 1,000 owners of one-family homes, through the legislative efforts of their elected county, town and village officials, are doing everything humanly possible to discourage the conversion, modification and construction of two-family homes. This is currently taking place on Long Island, at a time when, in many communities, there is no open land remaining upon which to build any more one-family homes.

title: POSTINGS: Conservation Covenant; The Untouchables
description: In a new 162-unit condominium development planned for 76 acres in Kent, N.Y., just north of Carmel in Putnam County, the developer has slipped a covenant in the deed saying that eight of the acres, zoned for commercial use, may never be touched. ''We could have built a strip center or an office building, but this will insulate the community and protect its serenity,'' said Jack C. Heller, president of Foreston Development Corporation of Lake Success, L.I.

title: Malcolm Baldrige, Cabinet Member; Businessman With a Love for Rodeo
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige, who died today in a rodeo accident in California, was a man of deeply contrasting shades who gained prominence in the Reagan Administration for his leadership on trade issues.

title: AMERICANS IN CUBA ACCUSED OF SPYING
description: With relations with the United States at one of the lowest points in years, the Cuban Government is charging in an extensive television and newspaper campaign that many American diplomats here have been spying and plotting to assassinate President Fidel Castro.

title:
GARDENING;
WORKHORSES OF THE SUMMER GARDEN
description: LEAD: WHEN it comes to surviving summer heat, it's hard to beat a native.

title: For Congress, Iran-Contra Hearings Offer Chance to Seek More Say in Foreign Policy
description: What the nation has been reading about and watching on television these last weeks is not, in the strictest sense, a Congressional investigation. Had the only purpose been to gain insights into what went wrong and to provide legislative remedies for the problem, that could easily have been done in private.

title: Pamela B. Rubin Is to Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederic P. Rubin of Old Westbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Beth Rubin, to Jon Robert Carter, the son of Arthur L. Carter of New York and Roxbury, Conn., and Linda Gordon of Newfane, Vt. An October wedding is planned.

title: BABY M COURT CASE IS DEBATED ANEW
description: ''A CONTRACT is a contract, and she should have to live up to it.''

title: Westerlies Prevail
description: It would be hard to think of two activities that are further apart, in terms of the alphabet, the equipment, the setting, or the type of effort, than bridge and yachting. The connection used to be the person of Harold Stirling Vanderbilt who brought contract bridge to the world via Newport, R.I., in the 1920's and was a triple winner of the America's Cup in the 1930's. He was not only a conspicuously successful participant but also a legislator who chaired the National Laws Commission of the American Contract Bridge League and revised the right-of-way rules for sailing ships.

title: Miss Gilbert Plans to Wed Paul J. Wallice on Sept. 26
description: Dr. and Mrs. George J. Gilbert Jr. of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Dataw Island, Beaufort, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Stacie Gilbert to Paul Joseph Wallice, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Wallice of Huntington Bay, L.I. The wedding is to be Sept. 26.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
NATURE
description: LEAD: The Great Barrier Reef Australian Conservation Foundation. Mastervision, New York. 60 minutes. $69.95. Parts of ''The Great Barrier Reef'' are all one could ask of a nature documentary. There are spectacular aerial and underwater shots of the reef itself - more than 1,000 miles of coral off Australia's northeast coast.

title: Trade Bill's Fate in 'Yes, but' Hands
description: WHEN 19 Republicans joined 52 Democrats in voting for the sweeping trade bill that passed the Senate last week, the Senate and House leadership was buoyed. The more than two-thirds majority, the Democrats said, was a strong rejection of President Reagan's renewed veto threats.

title: 'To the Sargasso Sea'
description: To the Editor:

title: Officials Cite 24 Food Outlets
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 24 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: The Next Stop for a Spruced-Up Au Printemps
description: WITH sidewalk chefs in their toques blanches pitching cookwear, demonstrators pushing vacuum cleaners, and a cacophony of voices hawking cheap cardigans, the scene in front of the Au Printemps department store sometimes looks like a Gallic parody of a Middle Eastern bazaar.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''As car sales grow weaker, it will take a lot of blood, sweat and tears on the cost-cutting side to maintain positive year-to-year comparisons.''

title: BEST SELLERS: JULY 26, 1987
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 2 5 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.)
