The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) ORPHANS: Real and Imaginary, by Eileen Simpson. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $16.95.) The author, a novelist and psychotherapist, joins her own history (orphaned before age 7) to an exploration of the painful fate of orphans in history, literature and the imagination. HEMINGWAY, by Kenneth S. Lynn. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) A sympathetic and detailed biography that sees Hemingway as a valiant and moral man and writer of his own time and place, not the macho freak of his posthumous publicity. THE HOTTENTOT ROOM, by Christopher Hope. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.95.) Mr. Hope's characters in his passionate third novel are a befuddled community of South African exiles in London, his protagonist a South African secret agent, and his thesis that the world is turning brutal, mad and claustrophobic. WILBUR AND ORVILLE: A Biography of the Wright Brothers, by Fred Howard. (Knopf, $24.95.) This comprehensive and readable account of the lives and environments of the lads from Dayton, Ohio, clarifies why and how they, of all people on earth, were the first to develop a practical flying machine. A WORLD BEYOND HEALING: The Prologue and Aftermath of Nuclear War, by Nicholas Wade. (Norton, $15.95.) A brief but thorough and far from encouraging overview of the probable upshot of nuclear warfare, by a Times editorial board member. MEDITATIONS AT SUNSET: A Scientist Looks at the Sky, by James Trefil. (Scribners, $16.95.) With superb clarity, Mr. Trefil's third book of essays on physics delivers us the great natural laws that (for instance) make sunsets red and skies blue. A SCRAP OF TIME: And Other Stories, by Ida Fink. (Pantheon, $15.95.) The short stories in Mrs. Fink's first collection, derived from the experience of the Holocaust, speak in whispers of a world where everyday life was submerged in unthinkable horrors.

title: Yorkshire's Ancient Abbeys
description: Along the edge of the north Yorkshire moors, among the beauty and seclusion of the dales, lie the sites of four abbeys that were once among the most important in England.

title: HENDERSON HURT AND LEAVES GAME
description: The Problem With Rickey, a theme that created impatience in the Yankee clubhouse this week, may have moved several steps toward mutual understanding today. Unfortunately for Rickey Henderson and his Yankee teammates, the steps he took this afternoon were painful ones.

title: 100 Killed in Iranian Flood
description: Torrential rain flooded a river in northeastern Iran, killing at least 100 people and injuring 36 others, the official Iranian press agency reported today. The river Boojhan overflowed its banks Friday in Neishabour and nearby villages, the agency said. It quoted an official of the Red Crescent relief agency in Neishabour as saying intense rescue and relief operations were under way.

title: Stranger Knocks, and a Thriller Begins
description: ASTRANGER at the door is the catalyst for Ugo Betti's play ''Crime on Goat Island,'' translated from the Italian by Henry Reed. The Arena Players Repertory Theater, which is staging the Betti play at its Main Stage, is also offering ''Victim,'' by another Italian, Mario Fratti, at its Second Stage theater, and it too opens with a stranger at the door.

title: Change of Heart
description: The lives of millions of people in Asia, the Pacific and Latin America have been touched, deeply and for the better, by a turnaround in American foreign policy.

title:
ANTIQUES;
MORVEN AND DRUMTHWACKET TO OFFER PEEK AT FUTURE
description: LEAD: ALONG that stretch of road known to commuters as Route 206 South, but to local residents as Stockton Street, are the imposing landmarks of Morven and Drumthwacket.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Art or 'Trash' In Philadelphia

title:
ART;
A SHOW COMPOSED OF 4 PRIZEWINNERS
description: LEAD: THE four artists whose work currently shares the galleries at the Smithtown Township Arts Council's Mills Pond House in St. James are the top prizewinners in last fall's annual juried exhibition.

title: Character, Truth and Television
description: A PARADOX OF TELEVISION IS THIS: IT is intrinsically more balanced, fair and open than print, but unlike print, it can determine its own agenda. Television is one on one: Someone speaks; we react, and no one gets in the way. Obviously, this is more straightforward than print, where readers must rely on reporters. Television viewers are on their own. Intermediaries can't fool them. Presumably, the televised hearings on the Iran-contra affair are right up front. Perhaps they are, but why, then, is there so much disagreement about them? In an interview on CBS, Senator Howell Heflin gave a partial answer. What do we behold at the hearings? ''It depends,'' the Alabama Democrat said, ''on the eye of the beholder.''

title:
GARDENING;
WORKHORSES OF THE SUMMER GARDEN
description: LEAD: WHEN it comes to surviving summer heat, it's hard to beat a native.

title: Smoked Fish From Maine
description: In 1806, William L. Daggett built two big brick smokehouses on Central Wharf in Portland, Me. Sixty feet tall, their walls three feet thick, they were in continuous use until 1982.

title: Opera: Mozart's 'Finta Giardiniera'
description: ''La Finta Giardiniera,'' with which the 18-year-old Mozart triumphed in Munich, is undergoing fresh evaluation. Mostly Mozart audiences heard it in concert last year, and several European houses have brought it to the stage. The Berkshire Opera Company, which hopes to establish intimate opera as a part of the summer's plentiful artistic life here, chose the piece to open its third season last week. Friday's performance revealed two problems of basic approach that forbade full success, but at the same time found enough of the work's extraordinary musical life to make for a rewarding exposure.

title: Rev. S. R. Garratt Wed to Miss Niles
description: Margaret Niles, an associate in the law firm of Garvey, Schubert, Adams & Barer in Seattle, and the Rev. Stephen Richard Garratt, the assistant to the rector of St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Seattle, were married yesterday. Bishop Robert H. Cochrane of the Diocese of Olympia, Wash., performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's.

title: SHE DIDN'T CHEAT ON CHEKHOV
description: THE PERFECT SONYA By Beverly Lowry. 242 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: Max Fortunoff, 89, Is Dead; Headed Specialty Store Chain
description: Max Fortunoff, founder and chairman of the New York specialty stores that bear his name, died yesterday at his home in Old Westbury, L.I., after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

title: Stage: Modern 'Visions of Don Juan'
description: In ''Visions of Don Juan,'' Matthew Maguire's performance collage loosely inspired by the Don Juan legend, fragments of the plot and score of ''Don Giovanni'' are swirled together with references to 18th-century revolution, the lives of Mozart and his librettist, Lorenzo da Ponte, and contemporary erotic imagery to make a frantic jumble of a play that wants desperately to say something fresh about sex and revolution. But other than reiterating the obvious fact that sex has lost much of its mystery in the late 20th century, all it does is offer a lot of bawdy energy.

title: A Classicist via Rock
description: IT WAS PROBABLY INEVITA-ble that as the generation nurtured on rock and roll came of age, some of its budding composers would attempt to create a hybrid music, blending the formal skills they learned in music school with certain rock-derived rhythmic moves, and scoring their rock-inspired works for the nonclassical timbres of electric guitars, drums, amplified keyboards and other instruments from the pop landscape. Experimentation along these lines has been in the wind for some time now. In the late 1960's and early 1970's, Philip Glass, Frank Zappa, John McLaughlin and Robert Fripp were among those who approached this amalgam from different directions. More recently, the Downtown school has spawned its own galaxy of avant-garde rockers, among them Glenn Branca, John Zorn, Laurie Anderson, Mikel Rouse and Scott Johnson.

title: Sports of Nature
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Slain in Hotel; Husband Is Detained
description: A 37-year-old Manhattan woman died after having been beaten by her husband in a midtown hotel room early yesterday, the police said.

title: SEEING RAYS OF HOPE IN MIND'S DARKNESS
description: ''IT ought to be a tough day today,'' Marion Berliner said to her staff at the 9 A.M. meeting. The four counselors offered no comment, but the visitor looked up from his note-jotting. Ms. Berliner addressed him. ''For folks who haven't been here before,'' she said, ''after a three-day holiday -well, Monday is bad enough, but Tuesday after a three-day holiday is worse.''

title: KAREN RIEGER TO WED ERNEST TRACY 3d
description: The engagement of Karen Bailey Rieger to Ernest Bell Tracy 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Tracy Jr. of New York and Old Black Point in Niantic, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harry G. Rieger Jr. of Haverford, Conn.

title: MUSIC
description: Classical Images: A Concert in Nature New Philharmonic Masterpiece Orchestra. Kultur. 45 minutes. $29.95. Stormy surf crashing to the strains of ''Swan Lake''; icicles melting to the melodies of Mozart; ducklings paddling, in slow-motion circles, to Schumann: ''Soothing'' is the word Kultur International uses to describe this program of outdoor scenes and classical favorites. Well, there's nothing much stimulating about it, so their characterization is apt enough. The pleasant orchestral and piano selections (snippets and single movements for the most part) are played without great distinction, and the hi-fi sound lacks the sparkle it should have. Had the visual aspects of the production been spectacular, one could easily have lived with the pedestrian music, but a typical PBS documentary is far more beautiful to look at - if not as relaxing.

title: Q and A
description: Spa Search Question: How do I find a list of American spas? Is there an association? I am interested in a weight-losing, physically active vacation. -P. K. V., Hermosa Beach, Calif. Answer: Jeffrey Joseph, the president of Spa-Finders, says it was the lack of an association of health spas and an up-to-date and comprehensive source book on the subject that prompted him to form his company. Spa-Finders (784 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10003; 212-475-1000 or, out of state, 800-255-7727), which he set up last year, sells a catalogue with details of more than 200 spas and makes arrangements for spa vacations.

title: 3 Manhattan Women Among Bridge Victors
description: A favored team celebrated victory in one major event at the American Contract Bridge League's summer national tournament here today while two long-shot groups fought for victory in another.

title: UP FROM SALSA
description: Ruben Blades has a lot going for him, but in the history of salsa, he is just another talented name, not a creator (''Ruben Blades: Up From Salsa,'' by Anthony DePalma, June 21).

title: ARCHITECTURAL WATCHES
description: Last year the Japanese architect Masayuki Kurokawa got together with two designers, Issey Miyake and Shiro Kuramata, to upgrade mass-market watch designs. Two of Mr. Kurokawa's designs are the first in the collection. The Rabit has subtle raised lines instead of numbers. The Delhi has a more industrial look. Both are available at State of the Art, 47 Greenwich Avenue, between Charles and Perry Streets. The Rabat costs $600; the Delhi $250.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Knicks Back on Track Now?
description: Before we judge whether the Knicks are back on track, let's give Rick Pitino a chance to do what he has done everywhere he has been: 1. Win. 2. Produce a team that plays an exciting, fun-to-watch game of basketball.

title: Job Security at Top of U.A.W. Agenda
description: THE Ford MOTOR COMPANY earned $3.3 billion last year, the fattest profit in its history, and as last week's report of $1.49 billion in second-quarter earnings indicates, is doing even better this year. General Motors Corporation had an off year in 1986, but still managed a profit of almost $3 billion and, in its second quarter this year, $977.7 million.

title: POSTINGS: On West End Ave.; Hotel Going First-Class
description: The 14-story Esplanade Hotel on the Upper West Side, which is is half transient and half residential and now under new ownership, is in the midst of a thorough renovation that will eventually turn it into a first-class operation, with first-class rates.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Knicks Back on Track Now?
description: Being die-hard Knicks fans from way back in the forgotten glory days, we're still waiting to see. With the off-court hierarchy finally in place, it's still to be proven whether a winning work attitude can be instilled in players who for three long years have been also-rans. If Gulf and Western is really serious - and it looks as if it is this year - then a good bloodletting is in order. The Knicks have the nucleus of a promising club, with the prospect of getting better through trades and free-agent acquisitions. In Rick Pitino, they have a young motivator who can make this franchise the awesome spectacle it once was, instead of the National Basketball Association's punching bag.

title: A Midtown Hospital's $450 Million Project
description: PLANNING is moving forward on a $450 million rebuilding program for St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center that would bring 1,000 new apartments, as well as 100 more hospital beds, to the Columbus Circle area of Manhattan.

title: POSTINGS: For N.Y.U. Students; Union Sq. Housing
description: Two of three new apartment buildings rising on the west side of Union Square, collectively called Carlyle Court, will soon be teeming with college students rather than the young professionals increasingly drawn to that neighborhood.

title: YONKERS POPS AT UNTERMYER FESTIVAL
description: ''CULTURE at your doorstep'' is the motto of the Untermyer Performing Arts Council, and according to the flier of the 1987 Festival, which is under way in Yonkers' Untermyer Park, ''performances bring friends and neighbors together while historic treasures, elaborate fountains and river views provide exciting backdrops.'' Not only that, everything is free, including today's 2 P.M. concert by the Yonkers Pops Band, a recital by the Elisa Monte Dance Company at 8 P.M. Saturday and three jazz programs, also starting at 8 o'clock next Sunday and Aug. 9 and 16. Should it rain, the concerts go forth as scheduled at the indoor Saunders Auditorium on Palmer Road. For further details, call 964-3513.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: PERMANENT CONNECTIONS By Sue Ellen Bridgers. 264 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $13.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: MAKING NURSING MORE APPEALING
description: I was pleased to read the article by Peggy McCarthy on state planning to increase the number of practicing nurses [ ''State Plan Urged to Gain Nurses,'' June 21 ] . That Dr. Norma Foreman Glasgow, the Commissioner of Higher Education, is calling for a broad and concerted effort to make the profession more attractive is encouraging.

title: GOVERNORS ASSERT KEY TO PROSPERITY IS A GLOBAL OUTLOOK
description: In a major initiative, the nation's governors today outlined a new philosophy, as well as specific proposals, for improving America's competitive economic position and reducing gaps in prosperity among regions of the country.

title: Hooked on 'Sot-Weed'
description: To the Editor:

title: Credit and Credibility in Science
description: After a steady trickle of fraud in academic science, there now comes a serious case of misrepresented data. Charles J. Glueck, of the University of Cincinnati, reported that children can effectively be fed a low-cholesterol diet to prevent heart disease. But the prescription may be false: a university committee found that the study was based on data that ''barely existed.'' This month Dr. Glueck resigned.

title: Correction
description: The Week in Business on July 12 incorrectly described Alan Greenspan's affiliation with the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. He was a director.

title: CHILDREN
description: The Elephant's Child From Rudyard Kipling's ''Just So Stories.'' Narrated by Jack Nicholson. Music by Bobby McFerrin. Illustrated by Tim Raglin. Produced by Rabbit Ears Productions and Random House Home Video. 30 minutes. $14.95. If Rudyard Kipling were with us today, he might be charmed by the felicitous way that some of his stories for young people have made the journey to video cassette. A case in point is ''The Elephant's Child,'' as narrated by Jack Nicholson. Mr. Nicholson offers a gentle and amusing account of how a snub-nosed baby elephant expressed undue curiosity about a crocodile and in the process helped produce countless generations of elephants with elongated trunks.

title: Keys That Open The Locks to Worlds of the Past And to Distant Cultures
description: KINGDOMS HAVE KEYS, cities have keys. Omar Khayyam, searching for an answer, came up against a door to which there was no key; Sam Weller in ''The Pickwick Papers'' had the key to the street - which is another way of saying that he knew his way around; T. S. Eliot's narrator in ''The Waste Land'' heard the key turn in the door once and once only. There are keys that solve mysteries, and keys that unlock hearts.

title: RESTAURANT OFFERS MORE THAN A MEAL
description: LEAD: PATRICIA DORRICO of Greenwich, a 25-year-old learning-disabled outpatient at the Easter Seal Rehabilitation Center of Southwestern Connecticut in Stamford, said she found inspiration working in Neat Place to Eat. Opened in April to raise money, the garden-style restaurant is a training site for the vocational clients at the center.

title: O'Brien Holds Out As Jets Open Camp
description: The advance contingent of the largest collection of football hopefuls ever invited to a Jet training camp began the countdown to the 1987 season today.

title: Meatpacker Gets Record OSHA Fine
description: IBP Inc., the nation's largest meatpacking company, was accused last week of engaging in the worst case of poor record-keeping on record in matters of worker safety and health. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration proposed to fine the company a record $2.59 million for ''willfully failing'' to record 1,038 job-related injuries an illnesses at an plant in Nebraska.

title: Taneyev Quartet At Music Mountain
description: THE cultural doors between East and West are opening. On a recent trip to the Soviet

title: Question Of the Week; Are Knicks Back on Track Now?
description: No, the Knicks are not back on track. Two things must still happen. First, each player must decide that he is coming to Madison Square Garden not to play a basketball game, but to win a basketball game. Second, Gulf and Western must sell the Knicks to a group of individuals who know and love the game of basketball. A. GIARDINA Bayside, Queens

title: TOWN SEEKS HOME FOR ART COLLECTION
description: LEAD: THERE are delicate watercolors and oil paintings that lift the spirit. There are lithographs, sculptures, seragraphs and other works that would be the envy of many collectors.

title: BOUNDARY ISSUE AT L.I. BEACH
description: THE New York State Supreme Court has been asked to rule on whether anglers have a legal right to fish from a stretch of privately owned beach on East Island in the city of Glen Cove on Long Island.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Stratton, Vt.;
A New Focus For Ski Resort
description: LEAD: REGGIE CYR has built nearly 200 units of vacation housing on Stratton Mountain. All have been designed to accommodate the tourists who each winter flock to this ski resort in southern Vermont.

title: Q & A
description: Flip Tax Question: I recently sold my one-bedroom co-op apartment and have bought another apartment in the same building. The co-op board informed me that I would have to pay a flip tax on the sale of my apartment. Since I am purchasing another apartment in the same building I want to know if it is legal to charge me this tax. . . . N. S., Bayside, Queens Answer: The charges to which you are referring are not really taxes because they are not collected by a government body. They are transfer fees on the sale of shares imposed by some residential co-ops. These fees came to be know as flip taxes when some co-op boards, looking for a way to generate income for their buildings' reserve funds, began collecting the fees on apartment sales by ''flippers,'' inside residents who sold their apartments soon after buildings were converted to co-ops. The legality of the transfer fees has been upheld in court and affirmed by state legislation.

title: GULF MINES SIGHTED SOUTH OF AREA OF FRIDAY BLAST
description: Merchant vessels in the Persian Gulf reported a new sighting of mines today, off the Saudi Arabian coast and south of the area where a Kuwaiti tanker flying the American flag and escorted by American warships struck a mine on Friday.

title: NEW PIPELINE ROUTE FACES NEW HOSTILITY L>By CHARLOTTE LIBOV
description: MANY of the faces were different, but the sentiments remained the same. A proposed natural-gas pipeline got a cold reception last week as residents living in towns along the plan's new preferred route got their first major opportunity to air their views.

title: City Hall Notes; Okra, Armadillo Races, the Alamo and Koch
description: Jim Hightower, the Texas Agriculture Commissioner known for populist politics and a razor-sharp wit, visited New York last week to promote the cuisine of the Lone Star state. Mr. Hightower dropped by City Hall for a brief talk with the Mayor.

title: Wisconsin
description: To the Editor: Susan Herrmann Loomis's excellent article ''Savoring Fish in Wisconsin'' (Travel, June 21) was marred by inaccurate directions.

title:
ART;
'MASTERS OF THE SEA' ON EXHIBIT AT YALE
description: LEAD: A GOOD lesson in ''form follows function'' is contained in ''Masters of the Sea,'' an exhibition of 154 marine paintings, sketches and illustrations from 1650 to 1930 at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven. The great bulk of the work is watercolor, something at which the English excel, and what could be better suited for depicting a watery domain?

title: Lucy Mize Wed To T.H. Brown
description: Lucy Shackleford Mize, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David W. Mize of Chelsea, Vt., and Cairo, was married yesterday to Timothy Howell Brown, a son of Elizabeth Simmons Brown of Lewistown, Pa., and the late Dr. Richard S. Brown. Sylvia Sprigg, a justice of the peace, officiated at the Chelsea home of the bride's parents.

title: Boy Dies in a Hit-Run Accident
description: A 10-year-old boy was killed Friday afternoon in Brooklyn by a hit-and-run driver, and a 19-year-old unlicensed driver was charged with leaving the scene of the accident after he surrendered yesterday, the police said.

title: A Boost for Deprived Areas
description: Ten of New York State's most economically depressed communities had reason to cheer up last week. Governor Cuomo announced that the communities would be the first to be eligible for a broad set of tax breaks and other subsidies aimed at attracting new businesses.

title: Looking Back on England's Power
description: Slowly, the northern cities of England are being transformed. The mills and factories, which, in the 19th century, clattered and smoked to make Britain the world's foremost industrial power, are being saved from decay to find new grandeur as industrial museums and monuments to the Industrial Revolution. The town councils and mayors of such places as Bradford, Sheffield, Leeds, Manchester and Liverpool are at last realizing the value of the North's industrial heritage. They are beginning to tell the story of their towns' manufacturing industries with the same energy and flair that made those industries great. Choose your city by its industry -Bradford for wool; Manchester, cotton; Leeds, tailoring and heavy engineering; Sheffield, steel, and Liverpool, maritime activities.

title:
ART;
CONTEMPORARY SCULPTURE PROGRAM RETURNS TO WAVE HILL
description: LEAD: THE EXHIBIT ''Perceiving the Garden: Robert Irwin at Wave Hill'' clearly marks the return to a contemporary sculpture program after a four-year hiatus at Wave Hill, the public art and cultural center in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HARVEST OF BITTERSWEET. By Patricia Penton Leimbach. Illustrated by Jack Homesley. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) Patricia Penton Leimbach has a double career: alongside her husband of more than 35 years she has operated End o' Way, a grain and vegetable farm near Vermilion, Ohio; her column, Country Wife, selections from which make up a portion of ''Harvest of Bittersweet,'' is published in the Elyria, Ohio, Chronicle-Telegram. Mrs. Leimbach has a nice sense of humor, which works best when she stays close to her home and hearth, farm and family, dispensing neighborliness and even, in a burst of generosity, her recipe for apple pie (in the crust ''milk is the key ingredient''). She writes of church bazaars, the making of curtains and pickles, and unending concern over weather - for reasons more important than weekend plans. Those pieces that stray from her realm, or stretch for larger meaning, show the strain. The collection is best taken at face value, as eight seasons in the life of a middle-aged woman, during which she loses a child and a parent and gains a grandchild. ''Worthy News,'' her musing on the purpose of a small-town weekly, shows exactly for whom, and why, her writing works well: ''Nothing earth shattering [ in a weekly ] ,'' she writes. ''Just a lot of chatter for sophisticated folks to poke fun at in distant suburbs.'' Her purpose, like that of the weekly, is to show people ''that they matter.''

title: France Charges 2 Lebanese Questioned on '86 Bombings
description: Two of three Lebanese being questioned about a series of bomb attacks in Paris last year were charged today with involvement in guerrilla attacks.

title: Giants Address Big Questions
description: THE Giants, who won Super Bowl XXI six months ago, will open their training camp tomorrow under a cloud.

title: Next Week; Will Taylor's Drug Story Hurt Giants?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Rebels Gain While Duarte Flounders
description: THE Salvadoran guerrillas are practicing what they call ''prolonged popular war'' with a vengeance, as the country slides into its eighth year of civil conflict.

title: Selling the Sidewalk Frank
description: ''HERE we go, first dog of the day,'' Louie Stathopoulos said jubilantly. He flipped open a silver lid and snatched a roll. He stabbed a dog off the grill and stuffed it into the bun. After swabbing on some mustard, onions and sauerkraut, he wrapped the whole thing in a napkin and handed it over. ''O.K.,'' he said. ''That dog's history.''

title: PRESSURED BY 'THE SQUEEZE,' THE MIND GIVES IN
description: WE PROFESSIONALS GO TO the movies ready to pay hawklike attention to anything that happens on the screen. It's the result of years of on-the-job training, and it's also force of habit after a while. In a perfect world, this would be the best way for anyone to watch films, but the world is not perfect, as is demonstrated weekly by each new batch of summer releases. For every one that rewards scrutiny there are five that defy it, films that are to the viewer's concentration what a sieve is to water. They're truly porous. You can't watch them closely even if you try.

title: CLARIFYING JEWISH LAW ON INTERFAITH MARRIAGES
description: The recent article ''Interfaith Bridals: Chapels in Demand'' gives the impression that there is a ''clerical stable'' of clergy - including many rabbis who will officiate at interfaith weddings. That is not the reality on Long Island.

title: A WRATHFUL 'CORIOLANUS' IS AT DREWN
description: HOW does one describe the Roman general Caius Marcius, otherwise known as Coriolanus? Was he:

title: TERESA MARSHALL WEDS
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York yesterday, Teresa Lee Marshall, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald I. Marshall of Manila, was married to Thomas Richard Watkins 3d, a son of Clare Jenkins Lambert of Washington and Mr. Watkins Jr. of New Orleans. The Rev. Timothy B. Brown performed the ceremony. The bride is an associate in corporate finance at Prudential-Bache Capital Funding in New York. Her father is a business consultant in Manila. The bridegroom is a vice president of Chemical Bank. His father, who is retired, owned two Chrysler-Plymouth dealerships in New Orleans.

title: 'FIDDLER' IN NEW FAIRFIELD
description: THE Candlewood production of ''Fiddler on the Roof'' is scheduled to run a week longer than the playhouse's other summer musicals, three weeks instead of two. May it live and be well for 120 years.

title: Street Fashion; Today's Straw Hats Conjure Captivating Jazz Age Images
description: THE jazz age is a bountiful source of inspiration for the current generation of fashion followers. Loose, low-waisted dresses, antique lace collars and T-strap shoes are among the signatures of the flapper era that have made made the transition to the late 1980's. But probably no touch from that era makes as vivid an impression as the new straw hats, with wide or narrow brims, worn low on the head, echoing the 1920's. The effect is immediate and captivating, conjuring images of faded newsreels and the Charleston.

title: Business Park With Designing Computer
description: A BUSINESS PARK under construction off Route 68 in Wallingford will offer tenants an optional service that they may share at a fraction of the cost to an individual buyer.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Knicks Back on Track Now?
description: In order for the Knicks to be back on track, the philosophy of upper-level management must change. Arthur Barron and Dick Evans, are you listening?

title: The North Beyond the Grit
description: ''Where does the North of England begin?'' I was asked the other day at a meeting in the quiet Lincolnshire town of Boston, which is itself placed uncertainly about halfway up the map, just beyond the Wash, but south of the great conurbations that lie on either side of the Pennines. None of us had an answer, though one woman declared that the North was a state of mind; if you're born with it, you can never escape. Perhaps the image most commonly summoned is of the land of the Industrial Revolution, the North of Mrs. Gaskell's ''North and South,'' of the ''Hard Times'' of Dickens and the social surveys of Engels, a heavily populated region centered on the cities that flourished in the 19th century. Their massive town halls, their parks and bandstands come to mind, and so do their hillsides of terraced artisan housing, spacious suburbs, ostentatious civic pride and network of canals.

title: KIT TOBIN WEDS IN CALIFORNIA
description: Katherine Oliver Tobin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Henry deYoung Tobin of Hillsborough, Calif., was married yesterday to George Carroll Whipple 3d, the son of Mrs. George Carroll Whipple Jr. of New York and the late Mr. Whipple. Judge William Newsom of the California Court of Appeals officiated at the Burlingame Country Club in Hillsborough.

title: Business Climates
description: To the Editor:

title: TALES OF PART-TIME TEACHING
description: Marian Chatfield-Taylor's article [ ''The Sorry Success of a Part-Time Teacher,'' Opinion page, June 21 ] summoned still-vivid memories of two experiences I had with Norwalk Community College three years ago:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: IN THE LONG RUN. By N. J. Crisp. (Viking, $16.95.) Competent thrillers may be a dime a dozen in the world of figurative speech, but in the airport bookshop they cost considerably more. That's why most of us frequent fliers look for something beyond the swift plot and pungent dollops of sex and violence that are standard in the genre. In his latest thriller, however, N. J. Crisp, author of ''The Brink,'' has failed to deliver anything more than the basics. This is particularly disappointing since his protagonist, Stephen Haden, is a potentially fascinating character. Haden is a Fluchthelfer (literally, an ''escape helper''), an expert at smuggling people across the Iron Curtain - for a price. When Haden is shot one morning in his home in Zurich, he must ask himself that always disturbing question: Who wants him dead, and why? As a member of a morally and politically ambiguous profession, he could have been shot by either side, or even by someone within his own organization. But instead of allowing the complexities of Haden's situation to develop, Mr. Crisp merely sends him off on the usual bargain-and-bludgeon escapade through the great cities of Europe. As he searches for his assailant, Haden encounters all of the expected double- and triple-crossers, says all of the expected tough-guy things and even makes love to that old favorite - the attractive female of dubious loyalty whose eyes are ''dark pools.'' This kind of bland stereotyping may not bother a reader who just wants to kill a few hours in the air. But anyone with a taste for sharper characterization and more vivid description might be better off rereading an old Graham Greene.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
MUSIC
description: LEAD: The Manhattan Transfer Live Produced by Martin Fischer. Atlantic Video. 80 minutes. $24.98. In this 1986 concert recorded live in Japan, the Manhattan Transfer once more proved its virtuosity and its frequently uncanny resemblance to groups like the Modernaires and Lambert, Hendricks and Ross, notably in Clifford Brown's ''Sing Joy Spring.

title: HUNTERS GIRD FOR LEAD BAN
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the start of the waterfowl hunting season is months away, hunters are already reluctantly preparing for a major change in regulations. set to go into effect this fall.

title: SEEKING MR. RIGHT
description: Jack Kemp has one solution for all of the country's problems, from teen-age pregnancy to school prayer: cut taxes (''Is Jack Kemp Mr. Right?'' by Maureen Dowd, June 28).

title: 'Remarkable' Theater Comes To West Berlin
description: EACH YEAR IN WEST BER-lin, the Theatertreffen (Theater Discoveries), a three-week festival of stage productions culled from theaters throughout German-speaking countries, offers a reliable, if unofficial, barometer of the type of drama currently popular in this part of the world. The event includes 12 major productions: new versions of classic works; foreign plays, old and new, and original works that have been judged important enough to be invited to this prestigious festival. The criterion, according to the festival's organizers, is that the pieces chosen be ''remarkable.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Burning Up the Course: Robert Wrenn, who started play yesterday with the lowest 36-hole total on the PGA Tour this season, shot a five-under-par 67 for a six-stroke lead after three rounds of the Buick Open at Grand Blanc, Mich. Wrenn was at 21-under-par 195. Ken Green, the 1985 champion, shot 69 on the 7,014-yard Warwick Hills Golf and Country Club course and was in second place. Trevor Dodds shot a 63 for a total of 202. He was tied with Jay Haas. If Wrenn continues his mastery of the course during today's final round, he will erase all tournament records and perhaps some Tour records as well. Green set the Buick Open record when he won with a 20-under 268 in 1985. The 72-hole record for a Tour event is 27 under par, set by Mike Souchak and Ben Hogan. Souchak shot the lowest score, 257, in winning the 1955 Texas Open at Brackenridge Park Golf Course in San Antonio. Hogan won the 1945 Portland Invitational with a 261.(AP) Palmer Five Shots Back: Neil Coles of England continued to dominate the inaugural Senior British Open championship yesterday, shooting a third-round 67 to establish a five-shot lead over Arnold Palmer at Turnberry, Scotland. Coles had a three-under-par round to move to four-under 206. Palmer stayed one over par for the tournament after an even-par 70, ''I felt like I could shoot a really good round today but, in the end, there was really nothing good about the effort,'' he said. ''I putted poorly, hit a lot of bad irons and didn't drive particularly well.'' Peter Butler of England charged into a tie for third place at three-over-par 213 with Bob Charles of New Zealand after shooting his best round so far, a two-under 68. Charles had a 72. Gary Player of South Africa was fifth with 216 after a 72.(AP) Soccer Russians Win in Shootout: Yuri Nikiforov beat Lemmy Isa, the Nigerian goalkeeper, in a penalty-kick shootout yesterday, giving the Soviet Union a 2-1 victory and the under-16 World Cup soccer championship. The match was played in Toronto. With the score tied at 1-1 after extra time, the Soviet squad won the three-of-five-kick shootout, 3-1. In the game for third place, the Ivory Coast defeated Italy, 2-1, in two overtimes Friday night in St. John, New Brunswick. Tennis Lendl Edges Krickstein: Ivan Lendl overcame the steady baseline play of Aaron Krickstein yesterday for a 7-6, 4-6, 6-2 victory in a semifinal match of the Head Classic at Stowe, Vt. After losing the first-set tiebreaker by 7-3, Krickstein broke Lendl's serve two consecutive times to race out to a 4-0 second-set lead. Lendl rallied to close to 5-4, but Krickstein served well in the final game to win the set. In the deciding set, Lendl broke Krickstein in the fourth and 10th games to push his career record against the 19-year-old to 4-0. ''It was good for me to play someone like Aaron today,'' Lendl said. ''He was hitting the ball very well from the baseline and I was able to get a really good workout.'' In today's final, Lendl will meet Jimmy Arias, who defeated Todd Witsken in the other semifinal, 6-2, 4-6, 7-6.(AP) Horse Racing Queen Sees Cauthen Win: Steve Cauthen rode Reference Point, the English Derby winner, to a wire-to-wire victory yesterday in the $320,000 King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Diamond Stakes at Ascot, England. The race was viewed by Queen Elizabeth II, who presented the winner's trophy to Louis Freedman, the owner of Reference Point. The 11-to-10 favorite won by three lengths from Celestial Storm with Triptych finishing third for the second successive year, a neck behind Celestial Storm. Nine of Europe's best thoroughbreds started the mile-and-a-half race.(AP) Yachting Swedish Boat Sweeps: The Swedish boat Spirit of Sprite, co-skippered by Per Wermelin and Pelle Petterson, completed an unprecedented six-race sweep yesterday in the world 8-Meter yachting championships off Helsinki, Finland. Petterson had upset Dennis Conner, the America's Cup winner, on Stars & Stripes in the world 12-Meter championship semifinals off Sardinia earlier this month. Golden Feather, skippered by Harry Voss of the United States, was second over all here with 17.7 points after finishing runner-up in five straight races and third in yesterday's finale. (AP)

title: Bicycling To the Job Is on Rise
description: It is said to be quicker than the subway, cheaper than a taxi, provide better exercise than a health club and give more of a pick-up than a cup of coffee.

title: The Jewel of Venice
description: LEAD: Even today Venice belongs more to water than to land. Everything moves by water in the city without cars. When there's a fire, fireboats race down the Grand Canal, their sirens screaming as they send up great arcs of spray. The ambulances are boats, as are buses, taxis and delivery vans. But these motorboats are relative latecomers.

title: Nicholas Gravante Jr. Marries Evelyn Kling
description: At St. Edward the Confessor Roman Catholic Church in New Fairfield, Conn., Evelyn Edwards Kling, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kling of Pittsford, N.Y., was married yesterday to Nicholas Andrew Gravante Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gravante of Brooklyn and New Fairfield. The Rev. Brian Gray performed the ceremony.

title: Sudan Declares Emergency Amid Wide Economic Crisis
description: The Government, plagued by a 4-year civil war, today declared a nationwide state of emergency and said it was necessary because of a rapidly deteriorating economic situation.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
Literate Urbanite
description: LEAD: Robert Klein on Broadway Vestron Video. 60 minutes. $59.98.

title: DAY GRYMES WED TO ALLEN KEEL JR.
description: Day Joanne Grymes and Allen Tison Keel Jr. were married yesterday at the Lamington Presbyterian Church in Bedminister, N.J. The Rev. Leon B. Gladdish performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. George Zabriskie 2d, an Episcopal priest and an uncle of the bride.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
DOCUMENTRY
description: LEAD: The Queen's Birthday Parade Home Vision. 88 minutes. $29.95. Armchair travelers get a front-row seat at one of Britain's most popular tourist attractions in this thoroughly professional BBC documentary, which focuses on the preparations for the 1979 trooping of the color and the event itself.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: Flight of Thunder Bird THE ROAR of an aircraft's engines over Teterboro Airport earlier this month was cause to stop and notice, even though such sounds are commonplace there. But the sounds were distinct and reminiscent of another era, a time when aircraft leaving Teterboro for Europe fought a raging war in addition to poor weather. Many never came back.

title: BUSINESSES SEEK TO COMPLY ON ASBESTOS
description: LEAD: LONG ISLAND businesses are seeking to comply with the state law on the removal of asbestos that went into effect June 1.

title: Indian History Alive at New York Site
description: Three hundred years ago this month, French soldiers destroyed the Seneca village of Ganondagan in central New York State as part of the fight for control of the lucrative North American fur trade.

title: Justice Blackmun Treated for Cancer
description: Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the Supreme Court is undergoing treatment for prostate cancer and has an ''excellent'' prognosis, the Mayo Clinic said last week. The clinic reported a ''small and localized recurrence'' of cancer that led to surgery 10 years ago. The clinic described the treatment as ''not incapacitating,'' and a Court spokeswoman said Justice Blackmun was preparing for the next term.

title: Jersey Limits Liability Suits
description: Governor Kean has signed a bill making it more difficult for consumers to sue manufacturers when their products are suspected of being harmful. It shifts the burden of proof to the consumer, who now must show a safer design was feasible at the time the product was made. The new law also makes it more difficult to collect punitive damages, forcing the victim must prove ''actual malice'' on the part of the manufacturer, instead of ''reckless disregard.''

title: Moscow Pokes at Multispeak
description: Mikhail Gorbachev seems not to be above a light and mischievous touch in his new diplomacy. In this case, the target was the well-known phenomenon of Reagan Administration multispeak.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Lenox, Mass.;
Farm Becomes Lifecare Village
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION will begin next month on Kimball Farms, a $28 million lifecare retirement community on a 63-acre former horse farm here. The nonprofit project seeks to meet the housing and health-care needs of the middle-income elderly.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article July 12 on Tuscan hill towns gave an incorrect phone number for the Hotel Villa Belvedere, near Monteriggioni. The correct number is 920966.

title: Some Close Calls At the Plate
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'WHIZ KIDS' LEARN IN MELTING POT
description: LEAD: ''I WOULD never have had this opportunity in my country,'' said 17-year-old Rita Rindlisbacher of Sweden.

title: The Grateful Dead, Most Alive on the Stage
description: IN THEORY, THE GRATEFUL Dead are irresistible. Here's what they do: They roll into town, set up, play for about four hours and move on. What they play depends on the six musicians' moods. It might be a song they just finished, anything they've recorded in the last 20 years, an affectionate version of something by Buddy Holly or by Merle Haggard, or just free-form communal noise.

title: Faith in Newark
description: Any number of New Jersey communities would covet a state center for the performing arts. Governor Kean's endorsement of downtown Newark as the site for the $200 million project therefore makes a strong statement. It demonstrates faith in a city more accustomed to cynicism, hope for a community more familiar with despair.

title: Slick Powerboats Add Safety, Speed
description: Powerboat racing has adopted space age technology, and nowhere is that technology more likely to get a thorough testing than at the national offshore circuit's fifth competition of the season today in Atlantic City.

title:
ON LANGUAGE;
Hi, Spy!
description: LEAD: ONCE AGAIN, OUR news is filled with stories of spies and turncoats and, of course, the special jargon of the so-called ''intelligence community.'' Even before Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's disclosures, as a result of the recent Moscow Embassy shenanigans we were told that our Russian ''assets,'' the general term for contacts and informants, may have been ''compromised,'' discovered, that is, when their ''cover was blown.

title: No Rush for the Mitchell-Lama Buyouts
description: ON July 18, Jamie Towers in the Castle Hill section of the Bronx became the 59th housing project in New York State's Mitchell-Lama program to reach its 20th anniversary and thereby become eligible to leave the middle-income government subsidized housing program.

title: Worthy Guides By Small Presses
description: The airport shop does not display every useful travel book out there with its murder mysteries; some valuable resources come from small presses or membership organizations and must be ordered in advance. Here are some of this season's helpful materials.

title: TRADING ONE TRYANNY FOR ANOTHER
description: CUZCATLAN Where the Southern Sea Beats. By Manlio Argueta. Translated by Clark Hansen. 255 pp. New York: Aventura/Vintage Books. Paper, $7.95.

title: Amy Louise Feldman To Marry a Physician
description: Rita Feldman of Fort Lee, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter Amy Louise Feldman to Dr. Andrew Green, a son of Alvin and Dr. Miriam Green of Great Neck, L.I. The future bride is a daughter also of the late Elliott A. Feldman, a principal in a family-owned liquor concern in Kearney, N.J. The wedding is to be next June.

title: No Olympics In North Korea
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
A REVOLUTION THAT ONE CAN'T AFFORD TO MISS
description: LEAD: FROM the first days of the deregulation movement, electric power has been the one natural monopoly, the exception to the rule that the market knows best. But no more. A revolution has come to the electric-power industry. Before it is over, electric utilities - private corporations, in fact - may be restructured and forced to compete, leading to cheap and plentiful electricity.

title:
THE TALK OF LEWISBORO;
IN LEWISBORO, THE FUTURE IS CATCHING UP TO THE PAST
description: LEAD: IN his five years as postmaster of South Salem, a hamlet in the town of Lewisboro, Daniel O. Tobin has witnessed the town's rapid growth first hand. The number of delivery routes has doubled and the post office has a shortage of mail boxes.

title: Poles Print a Poet's Lament on Insensitivity
description: In a despairing 42-year-old letter that has just come to light, Czeslaw Milosz, the Nobel Prize poet, deplored what he saw as insensitivity in his fellow Poles.

title: Trains
description: To the Editor: Did Virginia Van der Veer Hamilton have me in mind when she wrote ''Of Time and the Train,'' (Travel, May 31)?

title: TRANSPORT IS A HOT TOPIC IN FINLAND AND IRELAND
description: Stamp issuing nations are flooding the philatelic market with hundreds of new issues. Alert worldwide collectors should exercise discretion with regard to exploitative material, but there are many interesting and worthy new issues.

title: BRASS BANCROFT GOES TO WAR
description: EARLY REAGAN By Anne Edwards. Illustrated. 617 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $21.95.

title: TYRANNY OF THE BEEP
description: I AM a writer, and I work at home.

title: Puzzles Make Magical Exhibit
description: MECHANICAL PUZ-zles - brain teasers that have engaged the curious for centuries -are the subject of an exhibition described by its organizers as the largest such historical survey ever assembled. The show, titled ''Puzzles Old and New: Head Crackers, Patience Provers and Other Tactile Teasers,'' opens today at the Hudson River Museum, where it remains through Sept. 27.

title: THE CHANGING HOME
description: Carol Vogel summed up the developments in building and suburban styles over the last several decades in a piece that was well researched, carefully thought out and very readable (''Clustered for Leisure: The Changing Home,'' June 28.) It's good to see The Times showing as much interest in the way Americans are living as it has always had in life styles of more exotic countries abroad. JUDITH B. GURA New York, N.Y.

title: Dozens Reported Dead in Haiti Land Disputes
description: Peasants demanding land reform and crowds of people working for landowners have battled with machetes in a clash that may have killed 50 and wounded many more, radio stations reported today.

title: TRANSIT BRIEFS
description: LEAD: ELIMINATION of the bottleneck at the Hudson River railroad tunnel linking New Jersey with Pennsylvania Station in New York City has been targeted by regional transportation authorities in their continuing effort to move more passengers more rapidly into and out of Manhattan during peak commuting hours.

title: Wedtech Scandal Brings Civil Suit
description: The widening net of the Wedtech scandal has so far brought criminal indictments to 19 people associated with Government favors for the South Bronx military contractor. Last week, it encompassed another kind of action, a civil suit for $3.3 million, against E. Robert Wallach, a San Francisco lawyer and friend of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d.

title: NEW YORK NURSE PRACTITIONERS WONDER ABOUT FUTURE AFTER A DEFEAT
description: A major legislative defeat this summer has left New York's 3,000 nurse practitioners -nurses with advanced training in diagnosis and treatment - wondering if their calling has a future in the state.

title: Texas Kicks Its Oil Dependency at Last
description: IT took parliamentary contortions worthy of Rube Goldberg and the largest increase in state taxes in the nation's history, but Texas legislators last week finally adopted a spending and revenue blueprint that staved off financial chaos.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: FROBISCH'S ANGEL. By Doris Rochlin. (Taplinger, $16.95.) ''Do good. Quit messing up.'' An angel, looking like a Sunday school portrait of Jesus Christ, is talking to a Jewish accountant named Howard Frobisch on the Spanish Steps of Rome in 1978 as the world awaits the naming of a new pope. Usually quick with a wisecrack, Frobisch means to say ''that's a good costume.

title: L. T.'s Chilling Book
description: THE WORD for Lawrence Taylor's book is not ''controversial.'' The word is ''confessional,'' but without much repentance.

title: Charges Dismissed
description: A Federal judge in Memphis has dismissed two of 11 criminal charges filed against the former Memphis State basketball coach, Dana Kirk. The charges were dismissed because of a recent ruling by the United States Supreme Court that has redrawn the legal definition of mail fraud, said United States Attorney Hickman Ewing Jr. Kirk, who was indicted by a Federal grand jury last year, remains charged with income-tax evasion and obstruction of justice.

title: 2 Lilco Deadlines Approach
description: LEAD: THE directors of the Long Island Power Authority are expecting a preliminary report this week that will bring them nearer to deciding whether a public takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company would lower electric rates.

title: SARA JOHNSTON A BRIDE
description: The wedding of Sara Cushing Johnston to Alexander John Skene Jr. took place yesterday at the Lyman estate in Waltham, Mass. The Rev. Timothy Ashton of the Unitarian-Universalist Association performed the ceremony. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. James Gilchrist Johnston of West Boothbay Harbor, Me. Mr. Skene, who was married and divorced, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Skene of Norwood and Mashpee, Mass.

title: Shifting Gears in Pursuit of Equality
description: THE National Urban League had billed its 77th annual convention, held here last week, as one of its most important ever. Thousands of participants gathered to develop fresh approaches to the persistent problems facing black Americans. But after four days of speeches and meetings, the organization's president, John E. Jacob, said its new strategies amounted essentially to a return to basics.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JULY 26, 1987
description: International 3-19 The outlook for more contra aid has not been improved by the Iran-contra hearings, some key members of Congress say, despite the Reagan Administration's view that it has. Page 1 President Reagan was involved in a discussion last November that appeared to be intended to obscure key details of the arms sales to Iran after disclosures of the sales began to emerge, according to notes of a high-level White House meeting. 1 News analysis: The hearings into the Iran-contra affair have been more than just an investigation. Many members of Congress also wanted to rally support for legislative influence over American foreign policy. 14 The U.S. is bracing for attacks sponsored by Iran in response to American protection of Kuwaiti tankers, a U.S. official said. U.S. military planners are making a list of targets that could be attacked in retaliation. 1 New sightings of mines were reported by merchant vessels in the Persian Gulf, south of the area where a Kuwaiti tanker flying the American flag and under U.S. naval escort struck a mine Friday. 6 Smuggling rings in Mexico are responsible for the illegal traffic into the U.S. of millions of dollars worth of rare and often endangered wildlife. Officials blame a porous border and ineffective law enforcement. 1 Many U.S. diplomats in Cuba have been spying and plotting to assassinate President Fidel Castro, the Cuban Government is charging in an extensive television and newspaper campaign. 16 Nicaragua has almost completed the longest airfield in Central America, according to U.S. officials, who fear the Soviet Union might use it to extend its reconnaisance missions in this hemisphere. 14 Pakistani heroin in the U.S. and Britain increasingly arrives by an unexpected route, West Africa. Last week, 15 Nigerians were convicted of conspiring to smuggle hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of heroin. 9 Tatars stage protest in Moscow 3 Swiss vow to try hijacker 5 Poland prints poet's lament 17 Fear of AIDS in Canada's North 19 National 20-23, 30-32 The U.S. Secretary of Commerce, Malcolm Baldrige, died yesterday of injuries he received when a horse he was riding fell on him. He was 64 years old. 1 The nation's governors issued a report outlining a new philosophy and specific proposals for improving the country's competitive position in the world and reducing gaps in prosperity among regions of the country. 1 George Bush's bid for nomination as his party's presidential candidate remains shaky, despite a clear lead in public support, and money and organizational advantages, according to party leaders and a recent poll. 1 The President assailed a health bill passed by the House to protect the elderly against the costs of catastrophic illness, saying it would impose a heavy new tax on the elderly and could bankrupt Medicare. 20 A Harvard student admitted robbing at least 10 stores and restaurants. His family, friends and pyschiatrists are now trying to understand what transformed the bright Hispanic youth into ''the ski mask bandit.'' 20 The ''Saturday Night Massacre'' of 1973 and the way it was handled may affect the makeup of the Supreme Court, for the man in the middle that night, Robert H. Bork, is now a nominee to fill a critical swing seat. 23 The U.S. crime index rose 6 percent last year to the highest point since 1981. Some of the increase can be attributed to a greater willingness to report crime, but it may suggest that there is more crime over all. 21 Spouses of Soviet citizens who have been denied permission to leave the Soviet Union have formed a coaltion, hoping to make their cause a top human rights issue and an early test of glasnost. 20 Regional 23-27, 35-36 Segregation of Hispanic students is increasing throughout the nation, with New York the most segregated state, according to a new study. The segregation of black students remained almost unchanged between 1972 and 1984. 24 New York's 3,000 nurse practitioners are wondering about the future of their profession as the result of a major legislative defeat. A bill that would have authorized them to diagnose illnesses was not passed. 25 Atlantic City's free rolls of quarters may soon be a thing of the past. The Atlantis Casino is experimenting with slot-machine tokens to stop the flow of people who come for the quarters and spend them elsewhere. 27 The number of bicycle commuters is increasing. Along with the swelling numbers of commuters and bike messengers in New York City, there is a growing controversy over how to regulate them as they travel the city's streets. 24 A 40-mile path for bicyclists and pedestrians in Brooklyn and Queens is one step closer to reality. The path would link parks, museums and cultural and recreational centers. 23 City Hall notes 24 Hikers mark beginning of trail 36

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: High Point, N.C.;
More Space For Furniture
description: LEAD: A NINE-STORY showroom complex that will display expensive home and office furnishings is under construction in this city, which calls itself the ''Furniture Capital of the World.''

title: Offbeat Romance
description: Something Wild Starring Jeff Daniels, Melanie Griffith. Directed by Jonathan Demme. 1986 HBO Video. 116 minutes. $89.95.

title: SEPTEMBER WEDDING FOR LINDLEY BENNETT
description: Edith Coopersmith Bennett of McLean, Va., and Frank C. Bennett Jr., the American Consul General in Melbourne, Australia, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lindley Elizabeth Bennett, to Leonard Weinberg 2d, a son of Robert L. Weinberg and Lois M. Halle, both of Baltimore. A September wedding is planned.

title: The Radon Raiders: Turning Perils Into Profits
description: SHORTLY after Stanley J. Watras walked into work at the Limerick, Pa., nuclear power plant in late 1984 and triggered a radiation detector, he discovered that he had set off much more than a monitoring device.

title: When Troubled Companies Offer Rights
description: LAST Monday, the BancTexas Group, a beleaguered Dallas-based holding company, completed a huge financial restructuring that swung its net worth from a negative $98 million to a positive $90 million. The mechanics included a $150 million infusion of capital from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the forgiveness of substantial debt, and - perhaps most bewildering to the average investor - the use of a little-known financing technque called a rights offering, which enables existing stockholders to purchase additional shares at a discount from the market price.

title: You Can't Tell the Genre by the Label
description: AT THIS LATE DATE IN OUR musical history, interesting new compositions can come from any source, conventionally classical or otherwise. Especially in that shifting landscape formerly dubbed ''downtown'' music, meant to separate it from stiffer, more formal forms of Establishment contemporary composition, genre distinctions mean next to nothing. To be sure, different kinds of music have different traditions and often appeal to different audiences through different marketing channels. But good music and stale music, music full of individuality and music glumly indebted to somebody else, exists in every style.

title: CASINOS FACING JOB DISPUTE
description: LEAD: MAYOR JAMES L. USRY is threatening to ''go as far as I have to go'' to get the hotel-casinos here to hire more minority workers and buy more goods and services from minority businesses.

title: Bush's Presidential Bid Shaky Despite His Lead, Poll Finds
description: Despite a clear lead in public support and even bigger advantages in money and organization, Vice President Bush's bid for the Republican Presidential nomination remains shaky, according to interviews with party leaders and the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll.

title: Mexico Becomes Hub for Wildlife Smugglers
description: Mexico has become the hub for the smuggling of millions of dollars worth of rare and often endangered wildlife into the United States.

title: Opera: Richard Leech As Gounod's Faust
description: SERGIU COMISSIONA'S first season as music director at the New York City Opera is if anything an exercise in variety. He is conducting three familiar items of widely differing style. The ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and ''Pagliacci'' double bill and Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' are two, and Friday night he dipped into French Romanticism and Gounod's ''Faust.''

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title:
DINING OUT;
FARE FROM THE SEA IN ELMSFORD
description: LEAD: THE very name Westchester Trawler suggests fresh fish, that seafood served here comes from today's catch carried into the kitchen from a dock that lies not too far from the back door. The fish shop at the restaurant's entrance further suggests that the seafood here is either sold or cooked while it is still fresh (which is, more or less, the case).

title: North Star
description: To the Editor: The letter on Newport (Travel, June 14), calling attention to the Museum of Yachting, was illustrated by a picture of a yacht alleged to be Commodore Vanderbilt's North Star. The vessel pictured was not the original North Star belonging to the Commodore but one also named North Star that belonged to the Commodore's great-grandson, Cornelius Vanderbilt 3d.

title: Mark Stephen Aramburu Is to Wed Jennifer Travers
description: The engagement of Jennifer Hartman Travers to Mark Stephen Aramburu has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Michael K. Travers of Ridgewood, N.J. The future bridegroom is the son of Anthony Aramburu of North Collins, N.Y., and Mrs. Ronald Stulak of Blasdell, N.Y. An Aug. 22 wedding is planned.

title: CHILDREN CAN TEACH GARBAGE STRATEGIES
description: ''GARBAGE BARGE'': Quite frankly, I got tired of reading about the six million pounds of garbage looking for a port. For months, government officials tried to find a solution to this problem. It really wasn't necessary to go down south to Louisiana or to exotic Belize to find the answer when it was much closer to home.

title: Insurers and Gay Groups Angered by Dukakis Move on AIDS Tests
description: When Gov. Michael S. Dukakis decided earlier this month to reverse a state policy that barred AIDS testing by insurance companies, he hoped his position would satisfy insurers while protecting the rights of homosexuals and lesbians.

title: Princeton
description: To the Editor:

title: DIRECTOR IS SERIOUS ABOUT COMEDY
description: MARSHALL BRICKMAN is hooked on gadgets.

title: ELEGANT FRENCH IN STAMFORD
description: WHEN the restaurant at the Inn at Mill River opened in Stamford some two years ago, its esthetically delightful presentations, inventive menu and culinary finesse merited an enthusiastic three stars.

title: Big Field for Cane Pace
description: Racing Machine, who usually does well at Yonkers Raceway, is one of the favorites heading into the $581,540 Cane Pace Sunday night, the opening leg of pacing's triple crown for 3-year-olds.

title: Telstar
description: To the Editor:

title: The 19th Century in Its Seaside Glory
description: Today the seaside promenade is concrete and the lantern posts are topped by electric lights. But it doesn't take much to imagine Biarritz in the 19th century: ladies in long dresses sweeping down the wooden boardwalk, pausing at one end of the curving Grand Plage to gaze up at the stately palace of Napoleon III and Empress Eugenie, spinning on their heels with parasols tilted toward the summer's late sunset and walking slowly under the gas lanterns toward the flickering lights in the restaurants and hotels at the far end of the beach while the twin flashes of the St. Martin's lighthouse briefly illuminated the scene in twin bursts of light every seven seconds.

title: Glance Outrunning the Years
description: Sprinting is supposed to be a passion - and a practice - of youth: compression, explosion, quick bursts, acceleration and fast finishes. Indeed, by the time most sprinters turn 30 years old, a new generation of sprinters - or time itself - has passed them by.

title: U.N. Striving for Tact in Its Fight on Drugs
description: When the United Nations issued a report this year linking drug smuggling to terrorism and arms trafficking, it followed the rule of thumb for antidrug efforts here: never name names.

title: West Africa Becomes Route for Heroin Trade
description: Pakistani heroin increasingly reaches the streets of the United States and Britain by an unexpected route - West Africa.

title: Kramer Is Arrested
description: TOMMY KRAMER, the Minnesota Vikings starting quarterback, was arrested late Friday night and charged with drunken driving, authorities in Bloomington, Minn., said yesterday.

title: SPREADING THE CHORAL GOSPEL
description: LEAD: AS far as Martin Josman is concerned, choral music and the summer concert circuit were made for each other.

title: New Ideas In Housing The Aged
description: THE Fullerton Retirement Inn, a Spanish-style building of rental apartments in this community about an hour's drive south of Los Angeles, is the oldest of eight such complexes operated by Retirement Inns of America. It was built 10 years ago.

title: The Story Unfolds
description: Sentiment on the Iran-contra committees swung during the week from general skepticism and disapproval of Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter's final testimony on Tuesday to acceptance and praise of Secretary of State George P. Shultz's candor at week's end. Highlights of the week's developments follow. * Admiral Poindexter took issue with Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's testimony that he had sent at least five memos asking for Presidential approval of the diversion of Iran arms sales profits to the contras. The memos would have been given to the admiral, and he said he did see the one that has been made public. As for the others, he said: ''I frankly don't think those existed.'' * Many members of the Congressional committees said they did not believe the admiral's version of several key events and were skeptical of the many times he was unable to recall events. The panels released fitness reports from his years in the Navy that said he had a ''photographic memory.'' * The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair asked the Justice Department to turn over thousands of records from the Justice Department as part of his investigation into the department's much-criticized inquiry into the Iran arms sales in November. A Justice official called the request ''absolutely massive - every scrap of paper from Meese and anybody else in the department.'' Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d will testify before the committees this week or next. * In uncharacteristically blunt and angry testimony, Mr. Shultz said Admiral Poindexter and William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, had deceived him and the President over many months to keep the Iran arms sales alive. When Mr. Shultz finally told the President what was really going on late last year, he said, Mr. Reagan ''was stunned, and he was furious.'' The President reacted ''like he'd been kicked in the belly.'' * Mr. Shultz disputed assertions made over the last six months that he had deliberately kept himself uninformed of the Iran arms deals. He said he had argued forcefully against the program, was overruled and then was lied to as the sales proceeded. He called the arguments within the Cabinet over the policy ''a battle royal.'' * A White House spokesman said President Reagan had found Mr. Shultz's testimony ''honest, sincere and helpful.'' But other White House officials appeared uncomfortable with his portrayal of disarray and factional disputes in the Administration.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Sharing the quality of excellence and the honor of having been chosen to open the New York Film Festival, two of the more memorable films of the decade - ''The Big Chill'' and ''Ran'' - are scheduled for broadcast this week.

title: Putting an End to Adversarial Unionism
description: CAN unions halt their membership slide? This year, a heavy bargaining year that gets under way in earnest tomorrow with the opening of the auto industry talks, could be a turning point.

title:
GARDENING;
WORKHORSES OF THE SUMMER GARDEN
description: LEAD: WHEN it comes to surviving summer heat, it's hard to beat a native.

title: Linda J. Pitbladdo Is Married
description: At St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Corning, N.Y., yesterday Linda Jane Pitbladdo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bruce Pitbladdo of Corning and Hammondsport, N.Y., was married to Paul David Barnett, the son of Mayes Wishart Barnett of Bronxville, N.Y., and Belize, and Lawrence F. Barnett of Westport, Conn. The Rev. Richard Murphy performed the ceremony.

title: Steaks
description: To the Editor: In January 1985 you had an article about the ''best steaks in Great Britain.'' I kept it, thinking I might be near Edinburgh some time. Recently I was there looking for a good place to eat.

title: Anti-Semitic Group in Shadow of Kremlin
description: THIS spring, a Russian nationalist group emerged from the political shadows to test Mikhail S. Gorbachev's campaign for ''glasnost,'' or openness, in Soviet society. For weeks, it seemed that all of Moscow was talking about the group, called Pamyat, which means memory, and its brazen public demonstrations. While Pamyat leaders present outsiders with a patriotic, service-minded facade, in private they unleash undisguised anti-Semitism.

title: POSTINGS: St. Thomas Choir; A Larger School
description: The boys' choir of St. Thomas Church will soon have a new boarding school in which to practice its Kyrie eleisons, far larger and more elaborate than the old one on West 55th Street between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue. The 15-story structure, at 202 West 58th Street off Seventh Avenue, designed by Buttrick, White & Burtis of Manhattan and almost finished, grew out of a real estate deal between the church and Fisher Brothers, a Manhattan builder and developer.

title: 49ers Acquire Hill
description: THE San Francisco 49ers have fattened up considerably at wide receiver in the past two days, outbidding the Los Angeles Rams for free-agent Tony Hill only a day after trading for Johnny (Lam) Jones from the Jets. In fact, the position may be a little fatter than desirable - the Dallas Cowboys waived Hill last week, partly because he weighed too much.

title:
GARDENING;
AN ENCHANTMENT OF DAY LILLIES
description: LEAD: RAYMOND J. Doyle Jr. is an assistant state's attorney and a reasonable man - about everything except daylilies. ''Once you get to liking daylilies,'' Attorney Doyle explained, ''you kind of go overboard.''

title: A Chance to Find Out How High Is Up
description: LEAD: THESE are exciting days for people who love track and field, or at least the people who think in feet and inches rather than meters. We are on the brink of history's first 8-foot high jump and first 20-foot pole vault.

title:
MUSIC;
'CARMEN' TO BE OFFERED AT THE SHORE SATURDAY
description: LEAD: THE Metro Lyric Opera will present Bizet's ''Carmen'' at the Paramount Theatre here Saturday night. Curtain time is 8:15.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
IT'S TIME TO PUT AN END TO WAR
description: LEAD: IN 1986, three actions by our Government diminished the credibility and stature of the United States in our global village. They were:

title: The Job Market Opens Up for the 68-Cent Woman
description: Not long ago women's groups distributed buttons reading ''59 cents,'' the amount that working women were paid, on average, for each dollar earned by a man. The good news and the bad news, according to a study issued last week by a Congressional group, is that the figure is now 68 cents.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: THE Bedminster-based City Federal Savings Bank will begin moving some of its administrative offices late this year to Somerset Grove, a two-building office park being constructed in the Somerset County municipality of Franklin Township.

title: More Trouble For Rajiv Gandhi
description: Moving to crush a potential rival, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, expelled his former Finance Minister, Vishwanath Pratap Singh, from the ruling Congress Party last week.

title: Report From the Interior
description: Unlike architecture, much in interior design history is fleeting and unrecorded. In contrast to architects, decorators have not traditionally written philosophical treatises on their work -perhaps, C. Ray Smith suggests, because they've never had a philosophy. Then there is the matter of pioneering female decorators like Ruby Ross Wood who, owing to vanity, never divulged their birth dates; all this makes the historian's job trying, at best. In INTERIOR DESIGN IN 20TH-CENTURY AMERICA: A History (Harper & Row, Paper, $24.95), Mr. Smith performs a much-needed service by bringing together the major influences on the way American commercial and residential interiors look today. An author and editor who teaches at the Fashion Institute of Technology and the Parsons School of Design in New York City, he takes an admirably broad view, interweaving developments in art, architecture, interiors and product design, including technological innovations like air conditioning and linoleum. Though the book is written in straightforward textbook style - more suitable for the classroom than for bedtime or chaise longue reading - this is an invaluable resource. Nonprofessionals mystified by perennially obtuse design terms will probably find the glossary and pronunciation guide particularly useful. The mostly black-and-white photographs can't do justice to silver-blue foil wallpaper and other passing fancies, but what the book lacks in color it makes up for in details, such as the moment when the decorator Elsie de Wolfe laid eyes on the Parthenon and exclaimed, ''It's beige - just my color!''
