title: MISS WATERS WED TO GEORGE ORR JR.
description: The wedding of Edna Mae Waters, a daughter of Mrs. Leighton Kinsley Waters of Rumson, N.J., and the late Mr. Waters, to George Joseph Orr Jr., a son of Mr. Orr of Beverly, N.J., and Mrs. James E. Downs of Baltimore, took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity in Fair Haven, N.J. Msgr. Richard A. Behl performed the ceremony.

title: THE CHANGING HOME
description: Carol Vogel's article has confirmed one of my worst fears: it seems many of the affluent elite and, in many cases, the most powerful members of our society would rather soak in three-man Jacuzzis than confront the problems that exist beyond their meticulously maintained yards.

title: In Canada's North, Spread of AIDS Is Feared
description: If the uninhibited sexual mores of young Eskimos lead to an AIDS epidemic in Canada's far north, it will not be because Nader Barsoum didn't try to prevent it.

title: Susan Hodes Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Hodes of Katonah, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Dean Hodes to Richard Hope O'Leary, a son of Dr. and Mrs. James J. O'Leary of Oyster Harbors, Mass. and John's Island, Fla. A September wedding is planned.

title: Marli Rachman Wed To Bruce Somerstein
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Marli Frances Rachman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Jay Rachman of Great Neck, L.I., was married last evening to Bruce Somerstein, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Saul Somerstein of Manhasset Hills, L.I., by Rabbi Michael Kramer.

title: Private Nukes?
description: It seems as if private initiative in Pakistan extends even to securing materials for, and producing, nuclear bombs. That at least is what Pakistan would have the U.S. believe, in the latest and most creative of a string of alibis designed to render palatable a decade-old addiction to secret nuclear pursuits.

title: KARIN ALEXIS WED TO AN ECONOMIST
description: At Emmanuel Lutheran Church in Vienna, Va., Karin May Elizabeth Alexis, the daughter of May-Britt Alexis of Bethesda, Md., and Carl O. Alexis of Lincoln, Neb., was married yesterday to Christopher John Frenze, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley B. Frenze of Philadelphia and East Hampton, L.I., by the Rev. Benson M. Bartell.

title: SUPERSTAR, NOT SUPERWOMAN
description: LEAD: ELLEN TERRY Player in her Time. By Nina Auerbach. Illustrated. 504 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $22.50.

title: PHILIP MORGAN SMITH WEDS SUSAN SHERMAN
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Cathedral in Buffalo, Susan Sherman, the daughter of Mrs. Morton J. Sherman of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, and the late Mr. Sherman, was married to Philip Morgan Smith by the bridegroom's father, the Very Rev. Dr. Elton O. Smith, Dean of St. Paul's and of the Central City Parishes of the Diocese of Western New York.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: A GIRL OF FORTY, by Herbert Gold. (Laurel/Dell, $4.50.) The ''girl'' of Herbert Gold's novel of laid-back, contemporary life in San Francisco is trendy Suki Read, a character that The Times's reviewer, Herbert Mitgang, last year called ''a California Holly Golightly.'' The novel's ''dialogue and scenes are so accurate and, at the same time, satirical that at first a reader tends to overlook the depths of Mr. Gold's brilliant portrait of certain members of a generation that never had it so good until the big Four Oh suddenly appeared on the calendar of their lives.'' DASHIELL HAMMETT: A Life, by Diane Johnson. (Fawcett Columbine, $8.95.) Diane Johnson's biography of Dashiell Hammett, a man who was in some ways as much a mystery as anything he wrote, had the cooperation of Hammett's family and his longtime companion, Lillian Hellman. In 1983 our reviewer, George Stade, called it ''cool, steady-eyed and engrossing. . . .

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS   * ; G.E.'s Radio Days Come to an End
description: G.E. is getting out of some of the businesses it has been in since it was founded. In two major deals, it agreed to sell its consumer electronics business for about $800 million to Thomson of France, which has had some troubles in that field in recent years and needs a boost. In return, Thomson will give G.E. its medical equipment business, providing G.E. with a lift in that attractive, albeit risky, area. And NBC, part of RCA, which was purchased by G.E. last year, is selling its radio network for $50 million to Westwood One, a producer of programs based in Los Angeles.

title: AN OLDER WOMAN
description: When I read Edward Harper's article ''All Eyes on Her'' (About Men, May 24), and the subsequent letters to the editor regarding that article (June 21), I understood how he felt and I identified with him.

title: A Pugnacious Policy
description: LADIES AND GENTLEMEN, the Scrapper of the United States!

title: Question Of the Week; Are Knicks Back on Track Now?
description: The championship is as good as theirs. All they have to do is transplant a pair of healthy knees onto Ewing (and maybe throw in a heart transplant in the process); trade Cartwright for a rebounding forward such as Karl Malone of Utah (dream on); convince Mark Jackson that he will not succumb to Pearl Washingtonitis (or rookie flop syndrome); teach Bernard King how to pass; hypnotize Kenny Walker into believing he can score 15 points game in and game out, and wait for the rookie coach, Rick Pitino, to win 60 games (he'll do it, too, but not in one season).

title: Group Working to Reunify Americans With Soviet Spouses
description: They are, by their own admission, people with an obsession, a handful of Americans scattered across the United States who have waged lonely and often fruitless battles to get permission for their Soviet spouses to leave the Soviet Union.

title:
THEATER;
'Two Gentlemen' Act Up Again in Central Park
description: LEAD: THIRTY YEARS AGO, JOSEPH Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival played its first full run of a Shakespeare play in Central Park, and a new tradition was born. The play in question was the comedy ''Two Gentlemen of Verona'' - not one of the playwright's most celebrated works. It was staged in a hurry (''by the seat of my pants'') by the festival's young artistic director, Stuart

title: Mideast Peace Talks May Mean War
description: LEAD: An international conference on the Middle East with Soviet participation, widely touted as the only avenue to peace between Israel, Jordan and the Palestinians, is an ill-conceived idea. It cannot provide the proper framework and pressure-free atmosphere needed to resolve what is not merely a question of territory and borders but of Israel's very existence.

title: NIGHT LIFE, DAY TRIPPING, DUNE TROUBLES
description: THE sun beat down on Pam Glick of Manhattan last weekend as she tried to push her bike through sand drifts several feet deep, once a paved portion of Dune Road. Only the week before, Westhampton residents had been allowed back on the oceanfront road, closed since November because of severe erosion.

title: New Views Emerge Of Bork's Role in Watergate Dismissals
description: Fourteen years after the immense drama of the ''Saturday Night Massacre,'' the handling of that constitutional crisis amid the Watergate scandals is emerging as an issue that could shape the emotional constitutional questions of today.

title: STEPHANIE ARLIS IS MARRIED TO ROWLAND BROOK MAYOR
description: Stephanie Lynn Arlis and Rowland Brook Mayor, third-year medical students at the Jefferson Medical School and the University of Pennsylvania, respectively, were married yesterday. The Rev. George Passias performed the ceremony at St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church in Flushing, Queens. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Anthony T. Arlis of Plandome, L.I., and Dr. and Mrs. Michael B. Mayor of Hanover, N.H.

title: The Higher Dutch Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: When an Economy Goes Underground
description: For years, Latin American economists have attributed underdevelopment to ''dependency'' and the unfair ''exchange terms'' of third world primary goods for manufactured products from the advanced nations.

title: Miss Kaufmann Engaged to Wed
description: The engagement of Cecelia Lodi Kaufmann to David Lapham Mead has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. John Hollis Kaufmann of Somerset, Bermuda. Mr. Mead is the son of Stephen Mead of Boston and Mrs. Carl Pescosolido of Ipswich, Mass. A November wedding is planned.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
TRAPPER GAIL
description: LEAD: NOT long ago, Gail Hoffmann got a call from the Mount Vernon police telling him of a monkey on someone's porch.

title: BREEZING ALONG
description: THERE ARE SOME people who make entertaining a houseful of weekend guests seem no more strenuous than swinging in a hammock. A few extra people may drop in for lunch, and the table gently expands to fit them. One guest rises at 6 A.M., another at noon, and each is greeted with a hot breakfast.

title: S.D.S. With Blinders?
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR IMMIGRANTS, THE DREAM IS STILL ALIVE
description: THE streets may not be paved with gold, but immigrants are still setting down the career path in America, hoping to strike it rich.

title: Reagan Assails House Bill To Cover Major Illness Cost
description: President Reagan today assailed a bill passed by the House to protect the elderly against the costs of catastrophic illness, saying it would impose a heavy new tax on the elderly and could bankrupt the Medicare trust fund.

title: Concert: Iso and the Bobs In Dance and Song Show
description: THE concept of Serious Fun!, the name of Lincoln Center's adventurously eclectic performing arts series at Alice Tully Hall, could not have been illustrated more perfectly than in its Wednesday night program, which brought together two quartets - one dancing, the other singing.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last week on raising money for ''Les Miserables'' misstated the name of the attorney for Cameron Mackintosh, the show's producer. He is Paul Woerner, not Peter Woerner.

title: Showing Distaste For Panama Chief
description: Heartened by the movement toward democracy in the Philippines and South Korea, the United States was doing its bit last week to loosen yet another military leader's grip on power. Administration officials said all aid to Panama had been suspended in an effort to pressure Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who controls Panama's military and its Government.

title: Hot Turk Bites Howling Dog
description: A heat wave gripping Turkey disturbed Kemal Pala, a gunsmith, so much that he bit his neighbor's howling dog, named Lassie, three times, the semi-official Anatolian News Agency said.The dog's owner, Mehmet Ahcioglu, reported the matter to the police in the western town of Biga.

title: A Sunset Park 'Fortress' Rescued From Destruction
description: THE castlelike stationhouse of the old 18th Police Precinct has long been a landmark on Fourth Avenue in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn. When it was vacated in 1970, deterioration of the 1892 building accelerated, and a fire in 1980 seemed to have sealed its fate. But the Sunset Park School of Music purchased it at auction in 1984, after landmark designation, and it is now painstakingly collecting the $2.5 million it needs to restore the building.

title: Shane Emerson Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joe Silas Emerson of Bells, Tenn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Shane Emerson, to John Kingsley Loomis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Aubrey Kingsley Loomis of Windsor, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: DAY OF FAME FOR HUNTER, WILLIAMS
description: Billy Williams, the Sweet Swinger from Whistler, Ala., and the iron man of the Chicago Cubs, won't have to worry about his place in the baseball Hall of Fame after this weekend.

title: Trying to Save A House of Metal
description: IT is not a big house - at 29 by 30 feet and three stories high - but it is made of aluminum and glass and was put together with nuts and bolts like an object fashioned from an Erector set. Many experts say it is the country's first prefabricated house.

title: Parks Plan: a Brooklyn-Queens Path
description: An ambitious plan to link parks, museums and other cultural and recreational centers in Brooklyn and Queens by way of a 40-mile bicycle and pedestrian path is one step closer to becoming a reality.

title: Man Found Fatally Stabbed Near a Road in Central Park
description: A man was found stabbed to death early yesterday near West Drive in Central Park, the police said.

title: MEMORIALS SALUTE VIETNAM VETERANS
description: MORE than 10 years after the fighting ended, a memorial to Vietnam veterans is being constructed in Danbury. The memorial is a statue of an infantryman carrying a Vietnamese child in one arm and his rifle in another.

title: Tartars Stage Noisy Protest in Moscow
description: A group of 300 Tatars, calling for the right to return to the Crimean homeland from which they were deported in 1944, staged a noisy demonstration for several hours near the Kremlin Wall this evening as dozens of police and soldiers looked on.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: FLIGHT OF THE OLD DOG. By Dale Brown. (Donald I. Fine, $18.95.) Before turning to writing, Dale Brown was an Air Force navigator with the Strategic Air Command. And in this first novel, he never lets you forget it. Mr. Brown's basic plot, an S.A.C. raid with a Stealth-modified B-52 bomber against a Soviet ''Star Wars'' laser weapon, is all too plausible.

title: Hikers Mark Beginning Of the Appalachian Trail
description: For 50 years, the 2,096-mile Appalachian Trail has successfully dodged developers, fought off shopping centers and ducked highways from Maine to Georgia. Today hikers, trail volunteers and park officials gathered here to mark where the grand lady of American hiking trails began.

title: PORT CHESTER FEARS TRUCKS AVOIDING I-95 WEIGHT SITE
description: ''REMEMBER when the Mianus River Bridge went down? - it's going to be just like that again,'' said Mayor Peter Iasillo of Port Chester.

title:
IN THE REGION: LONG ISLAND;
Brookhaven Weighs Extensive Rezoning
description: LEAD: THE expiration Aug. 10 of a six-month moratorium on new building applications in Brookhaven is speeding consideration of zoning changes proposed in an update of the town's 1975 master plan. A private consulting company, RPPW Inc. of Tarrytown, prepared the update and made the recommendations.

title: Music: Gutierrez and Bell Play Mozart
description: JOSHUA BELL has a straight-on, modest style that reveals his Midwestern roots. His playing is neither coy nor self-aggrandizing, his sound is neither glossy nor slick. You can tell he thinks about how to shape a phrase, how to translate what he feels, and he can win over listeners by the sincerity of his convictions.

title: Dance: Creative Time Gives Mixed Bill in Park
description: AS usual, any performing situation in the great outdoors of Central Park has its special dimension. The weekly dance concert presented by Creative Time as part of Central Park's SummerStage series was provided with extra drama Friday night when lightning accompanied three pieces by Ann Carlson.

title: Vienna
description: In a formerly drab neighborhood in the eastern part of Vienna some photography addicts climb the utility poles or crouch on top of the cigarette vending machine at the corner of Keilgasse and Lowengasse, to get that special shot of the Hundertwasser House.

title: Vote Innovation Helps Hispanic Woman Win
description: A 35-year-old Hispanic businesswoman has been elected to the Alamogordo City Commission, apparently assisted by a new voting system that is intended to help members of minority groups win public office.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Gems, Baby Gifts And Figurines In celebration of its 60th year in New Rochelle, Talner Jewelers Roadside China (Roadside China was a store name in Yonkers for 30 years) is having an inventory sale through Saturday with 20 to 50 percent off regular prices. Diamond rings, pendants, necklaces, bracelets and earrings are included in the one-fifth off category and the half-price cuts change the tags on Piaget watches, costume jewelry and costume pierced earrings.

title: Notes Indicate Reagan Helped Hide Iran Data
description: President Reagan was actively involved in a discussion last November that appeared to be intended to obscure details of the arms sales to Iran after the sales were disclosed, according to handwritten notes of a high-level White House meeting.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN BOOK DISTRIBUTION
description: IF big publishers have problems getting their books to readers, their small counterparts - who cannot afford such things as sales staffs, warehouses and computers - are in even worse shape. And that problem is intensifying as the number of small publishers rises.

title: Bolo Ties, Favorite Of the West
description: Once a curiosity even among Westerners, the bolo tie has moved beyond the land of barbed-wire fences and spread around the nation and the world. At least two states - New Mexico and Arizona - have made the bolo tie their official neckwear. Bolos adorn New Yorkers, Berliners and models in fashion magazines.

title: CAIRO, IN SHIFT, FOLLOWS ISLAMIC TREND
description: The National Democratic Party of President Hosni Mubarak, in which the several contending factions range from socialists to free-wheeling capitalists, has increasingly begun to embrace Islamic symbols.

title: Marc J. Gold, Teacher, Weds Alison Ruth Paul
description: Alison Ruth Paul, the director of education at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, and Marc Jason Gold, a social studies teacher at Tenafly (N.J.) High School, were married yesterday aboard the yacht Paco Rabanne in New York Harbor. Justice Robert Stolarik of New York State Supreme Court in Rockland County officiated.

title: Data Bank: July 26, 1987
COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Foreign Developers; Learning Just How the Game Is Played in the States
description: EIGHT years ago, Brazil's largest development company, Gomes de Almeida, Fernandes, selected Manhattan for its first overseas outpost. Next month, the company will complete its first Manhattan building - a narrow, granite-and-glass tower at 590 Fifth Avenue, near 48th Street.

title: INSIDE
description: Bork and Watergate Robert H. Bork's role and motives in Watergate's ''Saturday night massacre'' provide some insights into the Supreme Court nominee. Page 23.

title: When Suburban Sprawl Meets Upward Mobility
description: THEY ARE NOT ''THE NEW downtowns,'' as some critics have called them, and they are not the suburbs, either, these strange clusters of office towers and shopping malls and hotels and condominiums that are away from downtowns but seem, at least in many cities, to have more energy swirling about them than the real downtowns. Christopher Leinberger and Charles Lockwood, who have done more thinking about these places than anyone else, have named them ''urban villages,'' but that seems a bit too quaint for places as huge in scale as Post Oak in Houston (which has one 64-story skyscraper, the largest tower outside of a downtown anywhere in America) or as sprawling as the area around the Irvine Ranch in Orange County, Calif.

title: 'ONE OF OUR BIGGEST PROBLEMS IS LONLINESS'
description: ONE in six people in the state is older than 60. By the turn of the century, the proportion may be closer to one in four, and Connecticut will have more frail elderly - older than 85 - than any other New England state. Not surprisingly, therefore, issues of the elderly - and those who must care for them - are increasingly occupying the thoughts of public officials. After a recent luncheon in Norwalk for members of the Greater Norwalk Chapter of the Retired Senior Volunteer Program, Mary Ellen Klinck, the State Commissioner on Aging, reflected on the concerns for a growing elderly population and the outlook. Following are some excerpts from the conversation:

title: GAIL V. MINOR MARRIED TO PATRICK E. SHOUVLIN
description: Gail Vance Minor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lance Cabell Minor Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Patrick Evans Shouvlin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael P. Shouvlin of New Canaan, were married yesterday at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in New Canaan. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Vincent Callahan, who was assisted by the Rev. Roland Jones, an Episcopal minister.

title: For the One-of-a-Kind Lamp Accessories
description: SUSAN LAWRENCE and Harriett Long see lamp bases wherever they go.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MUSICAL MIX In its weekly concert series at the Bayard Cutting Arboretum, the Islip Arts Council usually showcases groups or individuals who specialize in one musical genre or another: classical, jazz or pop. But today One Alternative does it all. Composed of Mark Oppenlander and Peter Sittler, guitarists, and Jill Haley, oboist and English horn player - in itself an unusual mix - the trio blends classical, jazz, pop and folk to create a sound that one member calls ''acoustic fusion.'' They'll do it at 2 P.M. at the state park in Oakdale. The performance, indoors this week, is free, but parking costs $1.50 an adult. MUSICAL ROOTS Summer-in-the-parks traditionally celebrates ethnic music, and this week, let's hear it for the Irish. They will be heard today at 8:15 P.M. at Morgan Park in Glen Cove, when Richie O'Shea and His Irish Showband perform; and Thursday, when audiences can chose between the Paddy Noonan Band and Tara Pipe and Drum Corps, who offer ''A Musical Taste of Ireland,'' also at 8:15 P.M., at Bethpage Community Park, and an Irish Festival at 8 P.M. at Brookwood Hall on, naturally, Irish Lane in East Islip.

title: ONE OF THE GRANDEST SIGHTS
description: What a nice, old-fashioned feeling amazement is. Here is Amos T. Root in 1905, describing ''the first circling flight ever made by a heavier-than-air machine.'' It is quoted in ''Wilbur and Orville: A Biography of the Wright Brothers'' (Knopf) by Fred Howard.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: PUZZLES IN YONKERS

title: Pop Music
description: Youssou N'Dour, the Senegalese singer and bandleader, has been touring the world with Peter Gabriel, playing the sorts of places he's used to at home - arenas and stadiums. But this Wednesday and Thursday, he will be dropping in to Sounds of Brazil (204 Varick Street at Houston Street; 243-4940) for club-size concerts that shouldn't be missed and that are bound to sell out.

title: Classical
description: Singers and instrumentalists seldom venture outdoors alone. The weather (when right) can be an excellent accomplice, but the haphazards of an uncontrolled environment - plus the problem of hearing one's self properly without surrounding walls and ceiling - remain very real.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Knicks Back on Track Now?
description: Only time will tell, but give Evans and Co. an A for diligence and effort. But why wasn't the same diligence and effort there when a new general manager was picked for the Garden's other team last summer? Ranger fans have good reason to wonder. WALDO HUTCHINS 3d Glen Head, L.I.

title: Los Angeles Study Foiled by Clean Air
description: Unusually clean air over the Los Angeles Basin has forced a four-week suspension of a $10 million study of smog in the nation's dirtiest air, the State Air Resources Board said Friday.

title: Waquoit Wins 5th Straight in Brooklyn Handicap
description: Waquoit, the pride of Massachusetts racing, earned his fifth triumph without a defeat this year by scoring a three-length victory over Bordeaux Bob in the $415,800 Brooklyn Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: SRI LANKA AND INDIA TO SIGN PACT INTENDED TO END TAMIL REBELLION
description: President J. R. Jayewardene said today that he would sign an agreement here next week with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India that would end the Tamil separatist fighting.

title: 'WHY DID YOU DO WHAT YOU DID TO ME?'
description: BABY HOUSTON By June Arnold. 268 pp. Austin: Texas Monthly Press.$16.95.

title: THE GUIDING STAR OF A FIRM FRIENDSHIP
description: We all live under the same sky, but each of us sees a different horizon. I am reminded of this after reading Pat Bard's excellent article, ''Mining Older Skill and Wisdom'' [ Opinion Page, June 28 ] .

title: Town Planning Job Disputed
description: LEAD: ''FOR some reason the town never established a bona fide Planning Department,'' said John J. O'Neil. And that, maintains Huntington's Supervisor, is what is at the root of the town's wrangle with the Suffolk County Civil Service Department, a dispute that he predicted will be resolved only by court action.

title: MISS GRAVES WED TO DAVID SAVAGE IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: Sara Evans Graves, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Graves of New York and Chilmark, Mass., and David Savage, a son of Sarah Olwyn Savage of Royal Leamington Spa in Warwickshire, England, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents in Chilmark by John Alley, a justice of the peace.

title: A PLACE FOR STORYTELLING INSIDE THE WALLS OF BEDFORD HILLS
description: LEAD: WITH estimates of a 50 percent illiteracy rate among American prisoners, the importance of reading is not a message that is easy to convey within the confines of a prison. But at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, several people are attempting to promote that idea and, at the same time, to bring inmate mothers and their children closer together.

title: BTTLING BUGS AND WEEDS
description: WEEDS usurp valuable soil moisture and nutrients; pull them up and add to the compost pile. Divide and replant established clumps of the early daylilies and bearded irises. Set out traps for slugs since they devour valuable garden plants. Keep after Japanese beetles which favor roses, grapevines, corn silk, zinnias and many summer annuals. Hosta

title: Kristin Chase Has Wedding
description: The wedding of Kristin Ann Chase, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Weldon Alvah Chase of West Simsbury, Conn., to Donald Beales Taylor, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Sedgwick Taylor of Locust Valley, L.I., took place yesterday at the First Church of Christ in Simsbury, Conn. The Rev. Nancy S. Taylor, a Congregational minister and a sister of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Telstar
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ROOM WHERE SCOTT DIED
description: I DON'T THINK I CAN do it,'' I said to the assistant producer, Cindy Wall. She had called me from Washington to say, ''We would like to film you in the room where Scott Fitzgerald died.'' She was speaking for The Film Company in the nation's capital, a maker of documentaries about American writers who lived and died in the 19th and 20th centuries. The film makers have won many awards all over the world for their works on Herman Melville and William Faulkner. Now, for the last two years they have been concentrating on Ernest Hemingway, Thomas Wolfe and F. Scott Fitzgerald.

title: Villager Casts Off Poverty and Strikes It Rich
description: Li Shiji propped his shoulder against a stone pillar that arched across the brick-lined corridor of the old Li ancestral hall.

title: Gay Man Named To AIDS Panel
description: When President Reagan called last month for the creation of an advisory panel on AIDS, White House officials made it clear that they felt no obligation to appoint a homosexual. To the dismay of gay rights advocates, Gary L. Bauer, the President's domestic policy adviser, said he ''would be very surprised if an Administration opposed to making appointments on the basis of race or sex would agree to make an appointment based on bedroom habits.''

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Libel Suit Dismissed ''WE won, we won; it's a big victory,'' said Donna Gallo of East Patchogue. ''This will show other civic-minded individuals that they have a right to speak out for their neighborhoods without fear of libel or slander.''

title: China Bolstering Its Non-Communist Ties in Asia
description: The prolonged war in Cambodia between Chinese-backed resistance forces and Vietnamese troops is giving Beijing the opportunity to strengthen and expand its influence in Southeast Asia, regional officials and others say.

title: Maine Town's Quiet Shattered by Strike
description: Until last month, this town of 5,000 people and the paper mill that is its dominant economic force coexisted peacefully for more than 30 years. Then 1,200 paper makers at the International Paper plant walked out over a company plan to revise work rules, and the tranquillity was shattered.

title: NURSES' NEW RAISE IS BARGAINING TOPIC
description: LEAD: A RECENT decision to give nurses working at county-owned facilities a mid-contract raise will not be a precedent for dealing with other government unions, Westchester officials say, but some union leaders disagree.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: LITA B. WICKSER ENGAGED TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roy Dikeman Chapin Jr. of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., and Geyserville, Calif., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Lita Bisbee Wickser, to John Gerard Toland, a son of Mrs. John M. Toland of Toms River, N.J., and the late Mr. Toland. An August wedding is planned.

title: MAKING OUR SCHOOLS BETTER THROUGH INVOLVEMENT
description: OUR nation needs outstanding public schools. If we are to have them, we know that we need to attract talented, bright people to become teachers and administrators. But there is another fundamental need we often overlook. We need local townspeople to become involved. We need people who are willing to consider running for the local board of education.

title: Taking First Step on Road to Olympics
description: For the next 12 months, amateur athletic competition in the United States will intensify as thousands of athletes compete for precious few berths on the 1988 Olympic team.

title: ANNE E. JANSON MARRIES LAWYER
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Shelburne, Vt., yesterday, Anne Elizabeth Janson, a daughter of Ellen G. Janson of Shelburne and Dr. Richard H. Janson of South Burlington, Vt., was married to John Hunnewell Hasen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Hasen of New York and Greensboro, Vt.

title: DRIVE TO END BEACH POLLUTION IS PRESSED
description: LEAD: WATER quality along the New Jersey shore is as good - or as bad - as it was last year, with a handful of beaches being closed each week because of high bacteria levels, state officials report.

title: SCOTT PRESTON SPECTOR TO MARRY HOLLY WARD
description: Betty Holland Ward of New Orleans has announced the engagement of her daughter Elizabeth Holland Ward to Scott Preston Spector, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Spector of St. Petersburg, Fla. The couple plan to marry Aug. 22.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: McCall, Idaho;
Rustic Homes Up for Auction
description: LEAD: THE Idaho Department of Lands plans to auction 24 state-owned lots and the private homes on them. The properties are near picturesque Payette Lake, situated in the mountains about 100 miles north of the state capital in Boise.

title: MOVIES
description: The Manhattan Project Starring John Lithgow, Christopher Collett, Cynthia Nixon, Jill Eikenberry, John Mahoney. Directed by Marshall Brickman. HBO Video. 120 minutes. $79.95.

title: Kathleen Teichgraeber Wed to Godfrey Merrill
description: At the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn., Kathleen Teichgraeber, a daughter of Bernard E. Teichgraeber of Greenwich and the late Barbara Gehring Teichgraeber, was married yesterday to Godfrey David Merrill, the son of Stanley Merrill of Hertford, England, and the late Mrs. Merrill. The Rev. Dr. Avery C. Manchester, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: AIDS CASELOAD SEEN RISING BY 25%
description: LEAD: THE number of AIDS victims in New Jersey will rise by about 25 percent in September, when the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta broadens its definition of the disease, a state health official says.

title: A Time to Settle Up With Uncle Sam
description: THE Internal Revenue Service is putting the pressure on taxpayers to settle continuing disputes. In late May, the I.R.S. began a formal program to clear up a backlog of tax-shelter cases by offering 75,000 investors a one-shot chance to settle. And in all cases, taxpayers are finding it is increasingly expensive to fight: Last year the penalty for substantial understatement of tax jumped to 25 percent of the tax owed from 10 percent. The fraud penalty has risen to 75 percent from 50 percent. ''The growth of penalties, in number and size, is putting a premium on resolving problems more quickly,'' said Gary K. Shelton, a San Francisco attorney.

title: Tyson and Tucker Stir Little Interest For Unified Title
description: THE fight is for the unified heavyweight title, and ordinarily that sort of matchup would be a hot ticket.

title: Elizabeth Reis Plans September Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Reis of Branford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Sarah Reis, to Matthew Dennis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Dennis of La Habra, Calif. A September wedding is planned.

title: THE LIGHT AT THE END OF THE NOVEL
description: SINCE the early years of this century, writers have been plagued by fundamental doubts about their craft. In individual or collective manifestoes, the most oddly assorted literary types have announced to their startled colleagues that it's no longer possible to tell stories; that the hero no longer serves as a focus of the action; that plot, character and psychology belong in the dustbin of history; that writing should cease altogether.

title: Where Maoist Slogans Fade, Tiny Factories and Farms Thrive
description: Dawn stirs gently here through bamboo groves and waist-high fields of rice. With languid ease, the pale cloud boas draping nearby hilltops unravel as a solitary farmer shooshes a water buffalo along a gravel path still damp with dew.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
NATURE
description: LEAD: Creatures of the Namib Desert Produced by National Geographic Society with WQED in Pittsburgh. Narrated by Burgess Meredith. Vestron Video. 60 minutes. $29.98. Namib may mean emptiness - no one knows for sure, Burgess Meredith intones -but according to this National Geographic Society video the Namib Desert is anything but empty of living creatures.

title: NEW FROM SEOUL: PRINTING THE NEWS
description: As portrayed in local newspapers and in television newscasts until the end of June, South Korea was a land of ribbon-cuttings, official visits, sports, harmony and not much else.

title: HELPING 'HOSTAGE' CHILDREN
description: LEAD: HOLLY PLANELLS, a 24-year-old Brentwood woman who is divorced, saw her 3 1/2-year-old son earlier this month, but it was not a typical visitation. Even though she was awarded legal custody of Yousef Bassam (Huey) Aqqad, her former husband, a Jordanian citizen, kidnapped Huey last August, she said, and Huey has been living in

title: WHEN OUTS ARE IN, WHAT'S UP?
description: BARBARA KRUGER SAYS SHE didn't have to think twice about it. Sherrie Levine says it was like coming home. But the decisions by the two artists to join the high-powered Mary Boone Gallery has unsettled the downtown art world. The tremors filled the air in May, when the gallery showcased Kruger's photomontages for the first time, and they will reverberate anew in September, when an exhibition of Levine's latest paintings and photographs leads off the gallery's fall season.

title: Giants Top Cards on Brenly Hit
description: Bob Brenly, who hit a home run earlier in the game, had a run-scoring, two-out single in the seventh inning to give the San Francisco Giants a 5-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today.

title: U.S. SAID TO BRACE FOR IRANIAN RAIDS
description: A senior Government official said this week that the United States was bracing for Iranian attacks as a possible response to United States naval protection of Kuwaiti tankers.

title: Cuomo Promotes Fryer To a New Press Position
description: Governor Cuomo has promoted his chief spokesman with the press on most issues to the title of counselor and press secretary to the Governor, Mr. Cuomo's office announced today.

title: Habitat: A Lonely Leader in Housing
description: TWENTY years ago, at Expo 67 in Montreal, the architect Moshe Safdie presented Habitat, an experimental dwelling with an extraterrestial appearance. Seven million visitors walked through it and perhaps 100 million more saw it on television, or read about how it might be the answer to urban housing crises all over the world.

title: Settlement Is Granted Over O'Keeffe Estate
description: A judge approved a final settlement today for the disposition of the estate of the artist Georgia O'Keeffe that includes the formation of a foundation to distribute many of her paintings to museums.

title: JEWELER DELIGHTS IN MULTIFACETED LIFE
description: IN the eyes of Ralph Destino, chairman of Cartier Inc., not all gems are equal.

title: Opera: A New Rodolfo
description: ONE of the things the New York City Opera works hardest at is the development of American talent. Michael Sylvester, for example, has been singing on the company's last three tours across the country and, now adjudged ready, the young tenor made his New York house debut as Rodolfo in ''La Boheme'' on Thursday night.

title: The Two Faces Of Adelaide
description: Picture San Francisco without the hills, or Cambridge, Mass., without the river, or Savannah without the azaleas. That's Adelaide, which too has enlightened restoration of its 19th-century architecture, good food and spectacular scenery. But there is more: just one step from the outback, Adelaide embodies Australia's fragile balance between civilization and isolation.

title: Elizabeth Kerney Wed To William W. Zuehlke
description: At the Pittsford (Vt.) Congregational Church, Elizabeth Hamilton Kerney, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Caldwell Kerney of Chittenden, Vt., was married yesterday to William Woodfill Zuehlke, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard William Zuehlke of Wakefield, R.I., by the Rev. Richard T. McDonnell.

title: F.B.I. CRIME INDEX ROSE BY 6% IN 1986
description: The national crime index published by the Federal Bureau of Investigation rose 6 percent last year to the highest point since 1981, the Government reported today. Some researchers say the development may signal rising crime levels for the rest of the decade.

title: Police Psychologist Helps Peers Cope
description: A FEW weeks ago, Dr. Julia Ramos-McKay's telephone rang at midnight. It was the police. They needed her help in a hostage situation.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: PROUD MONSTER. By Ian MacMillan. (North Point, $16.95.) This luminous record of World War II resembles a volume of photographs more than a novel, presenting a series of quick, poignant images.

title: Lebanese Hijacker Captured After Killing Passenger
description: Hoping to gain the release of two brothers imprisoned in West Germany on terrorism charges, a Lebanese gunman hijacked an Air Afrique jet on Friday, apparently planning to take it to the Middle East. The 21-year-old Shiite Moslem commandeered the plane, which was bound from Brazzaville, Congo, to Paris, after a stop in Rome.

title: The Risk of Insuring Drivers
description: Like other professional sports stars, top-flight racing stars are as much businessmen as athletes. Long gone are the days of the happy-go-lucky, greasy-fingernailed vagabonds closing bars in the early morning hours and then racing off their hangovers to the accompaniment of high-decibel exhaust notes.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A large number of Americans now see the Sandinistas as a very unfortunate Government.

title: TALKING: Deposits; Handling Contract Disputes
description: IN THE DAYS before the sale price of a home started to resemble a lottery jackpot prize, the amount that a buyer had to pay a seller as a contract deposit never seemed particularly significant.

title: A DEFENSE METHOD THAT CALLS FOR QUICK THINKING
description: There is no necessity to play a tactically demanding game, but if that's your choice, you must follow it through to the end.

title: AS FAST AS A FLYING CLOUD
description: THE CHALLENGE By A. B. C. Whipple. Illustrated. 320 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

title: A Woman, Fatally Stabbed, Falls or Is Pushed From Car
description: A New Jersey woman was killed early yesterday when she fell or was pushed from a car after being stabbed once in the heart in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, the police said.

title: RUSSIA'S RESTLESS YOUTH
description: ON THE STAGE OF THE MAXIM GORKY House of Culture, beneath a red banner urging all good citizens of the Soviet Union to ''fulfill the decisions of the 27th Party Congress,'' Anatoly Krupnov, the lead singer of Black Obelisk, is howling out the lyrics to ''Disease.'' Bare-chested except for a guitar and chain, he struts through a cloud of artificial smoke. Below him, crowding the stage, ecstatic teen-agers punch the air. Gloved fists and spiked haircuts twitch in the strobe lights as Krupnov bellows: People are burning, their souls on fire! A march of empty faces.

title: Treasure Hunters Dive 2 1/2 Miles to the Titanic
description: The crew searching for treasure from the Titanic dived to the sunken liner today in a small submarine, accompanied by a robot craft named Robin.

title: Aquino's Decree On Land Reform
description: Since the end of Spanish colonial rule in 1898, many Philippine leaders have tried to bring about land reform and failed. Both the appeal and the pitfalls of redistribution were demonstrated last week when Corazon C. Aquino issued a decree aimed at breaking up some of the country's vast plantations and giving private plots to some of the millions of landless farm worker.

title: Q. & A.: RAISING SAGGING BEAMS
description: Q. Our 25-year-old house has a large living-dining area with an attractive hardwood floor that is in good condition. However, although we did not notice the problem originally, in the past few years we have discovered that there is a decided sag to this floor in the middle of the room - it seems the floor beams or joists have sagged or warped, creating a dip. A friend has told us that we should use some type of special heavy-duty jack in the basement under this floor to raise or lift the sagging beams. Where do we find such jacks, and is this a job that we dare tackle by ourselves?

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MAD LOVE. By Andre Breton. Translated by Mary Ann Caws. (University of Nebraska, $17.50.) In 1938 Maria Jolas translated a fragment from Andre Breton's ''Amour Fou,'' the purest expression of love among the Surrealists. This fragment, published in Transition, the great Parisian journal, edited by Jolas and her husband, Eugene, is all we have had of Breton's text in English until now.

title: ENGINEERS AND MANAGERS
description: Faith Jermon St. Claire's recent article, ''Conflict of Engineering vs. Management'' [ Opinion page, June 14 ] , hit on a question that has been very much on our minds here at Union Carbide since Bhopal. Despite the fact that Bhopal was clearly a case of sabotage, probably by an employee, the tragedy also led us to re-examine the relationship between the individual engineer and our organization with regard to safety issues.

title: A NEW APPRECIATION FOR THE ART OF CRAFTS
description: LEAD: CRAFTS, once a stepsister to fine art, are experiencing a resurgence, with interest building throughout the state as new shops and galleries come into being.

title: Jaimie L. Spector Engaged To David Field, a Student
description: Jaimie Leigh Spector and David J. Field are planning a December wedding, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Spector of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced. Mr. Field is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Field of Bala Cynwyd, Pa.

title: Tough Losses for Mets and Yankees; SCHULZE HIT HARD AS ASTROS WIN
description: Just when they seemed to be getting it back, just when they needed to be getting it back, the old magic eluded the Mets again yesterday afternoon as they rallied twice but still lost to the Houston Astros, 7-5.

title: The Making of Government Good Guys
description: THE insider-trading scandal has hit a lull. In Washington, the Securities and Exchange Commission is starring only in the confirmation hearings of David S. Ruder, President Reagan's nominee to replace John S. R. Shad as S.E.C. chief.

title: A. A. LEWIS WED TO VIRGINIA BOONE
description: At St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., yesterday Virginia Kathryn Boone, the daughter of Kathryn Virginia Boone of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, and William Harrison Boone of Manhasset, L.I., and Stuart, Fla., was married to Andrew Arthur Lewis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Roy Lewis of Wayne, Pa. The Rev. Calvin C. Adams performed the ceremony.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: A GROUP of sports fishermen is organizing a nationwide boycott against E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company to protest the concern's practice of dumping toxic wastes in the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Recalling Kiviat
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: An Irishman Leads Entering Final Day
description: Twenty-five days after it started and one day before it officially finishes, the Tour de France came down today to a two-man duel between the only riders who still had a chance to win the bicycle race.

title: Scouts Crisscross The State
description: THE tools of their trade are ''ray'' and ''jug'' guns and stopwatches. But, unlike most scouts, Tony Marrucco of Stamford never uses the ''guns'' to calculate the velocity of a potential major league baseball prospect's fast ball.

title: The New G.E.: Broadcasting but No Electronics
description: The remaking of the General Electric Company tells a story about the nation's transition to a service economy: G.E. acquired a television network not long ago, and now it will no longer make television sets - or any other consumer electronics products.

title: House Votes Insurance Against Catastrophic Ills
description: Few members of Congress would disagree with the assessment of Representative Claude Pepper, the 86-year-old Democrat from Florida who is the leading advocate on Capitol Hill of programs for the elderly. The measure that passed the House last week protecting 31 million elderly and disabled people against many costs of catastrophic illness, Mr. Pepper said, was ''a historic first step.'' But, as the arguments before the 302-to-127 vote and the vote itself demonstrated, there remains disagreement about how great the step should be.

title: Setting Baseball Record Straight
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Child vs. Unleashed Dog in the Park
description: For the last several years residents near Laurel Canyon Park, a four-acre patch of green in an affluent area of Los Angeles, have been divided over who should take precedence: playing children or unleashed dogs.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE FLOOD. By Carol Ascher. (Crossing Press, $16.95.) Carol Ascher's first novel attempts to set in motion some powerful themes. The Hoffmans, Jewish refugees from World War II Vienna, have settled in Topeka, Kan., where father David is a doctor at a psychoanalytic hospital. The time is the early 1950's, and Topeka's Brown v. Board of Education suit has brought racial issues into nearly everybody's lives. As told through the voice of David's 9-year-old daughter, Eva, the novel struggles to depict the intellectual isolation of the Hoffmans, their attempts at establishing themselves in the community, and their perspective, as those who have fled Hitler's terror, on racial prejudice in America. Disappointingly, Ms. Ascher's prose does not meet the demands of these complex concerns. When characters debate issues of race and religion, their voices turn as generic and sonorous as symposium panelists. And few exchanges go by without Ms. Ascher describing the gravity of gestures and facial expressions, as though straining to dramatize an urgency the dialogue itself lacks: ''A strange expression, part fear, part hope, worked the muscles of her narrow face,'' or, ''Father's grey eyes blanched in pain behind his wiry glasses.'' The novel's chief weakness, though, is Eva, a girl whose sensibility, in her best moments, is reminiscent of a Carson McCullers heroine. But for the most part Eva remains an obvious foil, an intended innocent whose questions and confusion are meant to make the world's injustices loom even larger. Without the truly animating presence of a real and complex narrator, the book itself remains only a heavy construct of themes.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN BOOK DISTRIBUTION
description: RECENT headlines about the book industry have been telling tales of consolidations and mergers. But, quietly all across the land, small publishers have been springing up. Book publishing, after all, is easy to enter. All it takes is a title or two. But it is one thing to publish a book, another to get it into bookstores and into the hands of readers.

title: Making it Easy to Fax From a PC
description: FAX, or facsimile transmission, by which documents containing both pictures and text can be transmitted practically instantaneously over telephone lines, has come to the world of personal computing.

title: Comfort Is As Comfort Does
description: Martha Miles was attempting, apparently, to be amusing in her article ''Too Close for Comfort'' [ About Long Island, June 28 ] . I found, however, nothing remotely humorous in the author's patent disregard for nature.

title: TWO-BIT SCAM IMPERILS FREE CASINO QUARTERS
description: Those free rolls of quarters now being used to lure the small gambler to Atlantic City may soon become a thing of the past.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: JULY 26, 1987
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) A rich orphan comes of age as she travels the world. 2 2 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The West tries to stave off the Russians. 3 4 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $3.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia. 4 5 THE EIGHTH COMMANDMENT, by Lawrence Sanders. (Berkley, $4.95.) The theft of a priceless Greek coin brings a dynasty's scandals to light. 5 3 A MATTER OF HONOR, by Jeffrey Archer. (Pocket, $4.95.) Nazi intrigue and a family secret. 6 5 MURDER IN GEORGETOWN, by Margaret Truman. (Fawcett, $4.50.) The mystery surrounding the death of a senator's daughter. 7 8 ACT OF WILL, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Bantam, $4.95.) These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Johannesburg Township Celebrates a Birthday
description: Fifteen months ago, this impoverished township adjoining Johannesburg's affluent suburbs witnessed grim street battles between black youths and policemen. But today, Alexandra erupted into a joyous 12-hour celebration of the 104th birthday of the Rev. Alson Dlamini. Accompanied by his 101-year-old wife, Jessie, Mr. Dlamini was seated under a green, red and yellow tarpaulin along with hundreds of guests and the white deputy mayor of nearby Sandton, Edward Coote, in the back yard of a neighbor's house. Most of the township's centenarians, ranging in age from 101 to 113, were also present as guests of honor.

title: Bostonians Hail Ebb of a Sex District
description: When the contents of the Pussy Cat Lounge, a strip joint, were auctioned here several weeks ago, the past and future of the city's adult entertainment zone were equally on display.

title: THE BATTLE TO WIRE THE CONSUMER
description: IN the old days, the only way to find out how many people were watching a network television show was to check the Nielsens. CBS, ABC and NBC, along with advertising agencies and a few consumer products companies, paid tidy sums for access to the Nielsen ratings. They used them to decide which shows would live to see another season and how much commercials on those shows would cost. It was a fairly orderly world, albeit a brutal one for television programming executives.

title: The Infamous 'Protocols of Zion' Endures
description: MEMBERS of an organization of Russian traditionalists called Pamyat are motivated in part by a conspiracy theory that was invented in France almost a century ago. Like many reactionaries in the United States, followers of Pamyat equate satanism with rock music and relativism with evil, and they believe that Zionists are scheming with, of all people, Freemasons to take over the world.

title: COUPLE GUIDE 2 OF COUNTY'S MOST ENDURING MUSIC INSTITUTIONS
description: IT is 11 o'clock on a summer Friday morning, and in a modest house in Hartsdale Howard Herring, managing director of the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts, is on the phone. While he works out the details for a weekend of concerts, his wife, Laura Calzolari, executive director of the Westchester Conservatory of Music, helps their 5-year-old daughter, Katherine, dress to have her picture taken.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: THE ART OF SOUTH NORWALK South Norwalk's Washington Street has undergone major changes since the first SoNo Summer Arts Festival was held 11 years ago. Organized by a small group of artists who had found cheap living quarters in the neighborhood, the festival became a yearly tradition.

title: Listening With Both Eyes
description: SHOULD SOME MUSICAL PERFORMERS BE heard and not seen? I am not being frivolous.

title: Sweet Bread
description: To the Editor: New Yorkers who enjoyed the article on sweet bread need not travel to Rhode Island to enjoy Portuguese culinary delights.

title: Under International Law, Reflagging Doesn't Fly; The Panay Incident
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Explorers of the New World
description: AS THE MEMBERS OF THE Taneyev Quartet prepared to visit the United States, where they will make their American debut in New York on Friday at a free concert at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and at the Music Mountain festival in Connecticut on Saturday and Sunday, they wanted to know one thing: where in the New York area they could obtain music by Aaron Copland, Samuel Barber, Charles Ives and other American composers?

title: CONGRESS LEADERS REGARD CONTRA AID AS STILL IN DOUBT
description: Key members of Congress, including Republicans who favor United States military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, say they do not share the Reagan Administration's view that the Iran-contra hearings have improved the outlook for continued aid.

title: GARDENING
description: Groundcovers Morris Video. 2730 Monterey Street 105 Torrance, Calif. 90503. (800)843-3606 60 minutes. $19.95. Northeastern gardeners should keep their own climate in mind while viewing this video. It was filmed in the Pacific Northwest, where just about anything will grow. Ed Hume, a TV personality and garden columnist for The Seattle Times, is a knowledgeable host. He provides a wealth of information on these serviceable plants, which substitute for grass, crowd out weeds and cut down on garden maintenance. Mr. Hume shows how to choose plants for foliage texture and add to a garden's appeal.

title: TIMOTHY DALTON FINDS A HAMLET IN THE HERO
description: FOR TIMOTHY DALTON, JAMES Bond is a fascinating paradox: a killer who loathes killing, a vulnerable and sensitive man-machine, an introverted extrovert, a cynical man of principle, a warm and chivalrous lover doomed to reject the women who venture into his sexual force-field. But then Timothy Dalton is a bit of a paradox himself. He's a veteran of the Royal Shakespeare Company, and he's heir to the cliffhanger kingdom of Sean Connery and Roger Moore. He's a serious actor, recently Antony to Vanessa Redgrave's Cleopatra, and he's the dashing new 007, complete with guns and fast cars and vodka martinis, ''shaken not stirred.''

title: Texas Judge Picked for F.B.I.
description: AFTER a four-month search and a reported half-dozen refusals, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d last week found for President Reagan a man who will accept nomination as Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation: William S. Sessions, 57, chief judge of the Federal District Court of the Western district of Texas. Apparently undeterred by the 10-year term, a potentially grueling confirmation processs and the prospect of service under a possibly hostile Democratic chief executive, he said he was looking forward to the job.

title: A Call for Tenants To State Incomes
description: To the Editor:

title: Karen Benson and Peter Ruben Plan Fall Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Murray Benson of Kings Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Hilary Benson, to Peter Norman Ruben, the son of Mrs. Mark Olivetti of Rutherford, N.J., and Harris Ruben of Berkeley Heights, N.J. The couple plan to marry in November.

title: EXPLANATIONS ABOUT A BLIND DATE
description: I MET Ruth on a blind date, introduced to her by Harry, a colleague of mine who got around to his accounts very efficiently, in spite of a game leg. We were working on a joint project in the accounting office of a large company, comparing notes about girls, real and fancied. ''How would you like to meet one in the flesh, a neighbor of mine, real pretty?'' he offered. ''She talks books and music, not my speed, but just for you, I think.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ALIVE AND WRITING: Interviews With American Authors of the 1980s. Conducted and edited by Larry McCaffery and Sinda Gregory. (University of Illinois, $22.50.) As presented here, the reflections of Ann Beattie, Ursula Le Guin, Thomas McGuane, Edmund White and nine others offer an intriguing but one-sided view of American writing today. Larry McCaffery and Sinda Gregory, members of the English department at San Diego State University, note that ''the struggle for greater diversification in fictional forms has been won'' and elicit interesting material on the stylistic experiments contemporary authors feel free to make in the absence of a ''dominant set of conventions.'' The writers' focus on structure is coupled with a general interest in nonliterary sources of inspiration - modern art and music are mentioned as esthetic influences at least as often as any author - and, except for passing comments by Raymond Carver and William Kennedy, there is little acknowledgment that traditional storytelling can also be a vehicle for serious literary concerns. Still, the interviewers' questions are thoughtful, and if many interviewees seem as interested in what they can leave out as what they put in, that in itself tells us much about postmodern literature.

title: THE TRIBE THAT WEARS WHITE
description: BECOMING A DOCTOR A Journey of Initiation in Medical School. By Melvin Konner. 390 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $19.95.

title: True Colors of a Classic Canvas
description: IT IS AMONG THE GREAT ITALIAN Renaissance paintings, a bacchanal, portraying earthy, pagan deities at revel. And it is the work of not one, but two of the most celebrated Venetian colorists. ''The Feast of the Gods,'' housed at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, was completed by Giovanni Bellini in 1514 and repainted in part by his student, Titian, between 1519 and 1529. Since October 1985, David Bull, the National Gallery's head of painting conservation, has been at work on a painstaking restoration of the masterpiece, liberating the color and tonality of the painting from a veil of discolored varnish.

title: Images That Express Essential Human Emotions
description: ''THE RE-EMERGENT FIG-ure: Seven Sculptors at Storm King Art Center'' is a surprise.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: JADE AND FIRE. By Raymond Barnett. (Random House, $19.95.) It is the Peking of late 1948, the twilight of the Nationalist regime. The monks of the city's largest Taoist monastery burn their prior alive in the courtyard. Bei Menjin, chief inspector of the Peking Municipal Police, tackles the case with a briskness and authority that recalls Thatcher Colt, Anthony Abbot's police commissioner, who solved similar public crimes in 1930's New York. Bei has an assistant, Yuan, who calls him Chief and chirps things like ''No problem'' and ''I'm beginning to like this assignment.'' Complicating matters is the presence of some 200,000 Nationalist troops inside Peking and about half a million well-armed Communists outside the walls. General Fu, Nationalist commander of Peking, takes over the story and educates us on military tactics as taught by Sun Tzu, and on sex, with the help of a beautiful Communist agent from another Taoist monastery. Also in the picture are the murderous thugs of the right wing Te Wu and a fiend who specializes in murdering prostitutes so gruesomely that General Fu's bedroom acrobatics may lose their charm for the reader. We never really care who murdered the shadowy prior and we know how the siege of Peking turned out. Suspense depends on connecting the murder to General Fu's much too obvious predilection to cut a deal with the Communists. The detective-story cliches and stylized Chinese love language clash disastrously and the plot labors to a melodramatic climax that is hard to believe. But the reader will learn a lot about Chinese history, Taoism, tea drinking and Peking art and architecture in this first novel by a California biologist.

title: Rock: The Replacements In Songs From 3 Decades
description: AT a circus, one act always wows the audience: an unsteady character teeters and stumbles his way across the high wire. Thursday's concert by the Replacements, at the Beacon Theater, had that kind of slapstick suspense.

title: WHO'S THE BOY AT THE COUNTER? THE BOSS
description: JOHN ANDREWS has become accustomed to new customers at the J&J Bait and Tackle Shop along the Clinton waterfront asking him the whereabouts of the owner. That is not surprising, because John is 12 years old and, at 4 feet 11 inches, can barely see over the counter.

title: MAKING IT IN BIG-TIME BRIDGE
description: IF THE TITLE OF BEST BRIDGE PLAYER in the world existed, the strongest claimant to it would be an easygoing, cool-eyed Texan named Robert Hamman. Over the past 10 years, Hamman has compiled the best record in the pressure-filled world of international tournament bridge. Close behind is his longtime partner and fellow Texan, Bobby Wolff.

title: O. P. Nicholson to Wed Miss Smitter in August
description: Announcement has been made by Leila Eliott-Burton Hadley of New York of the engagement of her daughter Caroline Allison Faith Smitter to Oliver Philip Nicholson, a son of the late Dr. and Mrs. George Nicholson of Tiverton, Devon, England. The couple plan to marry Aug. 31 in Scotland.

title: Protecting Rights Of Wild Horses
description: THE case in Federal court boiled down to this: Was the Government violating the rights of wild horses?

title:
007: A NEW BOND MEETS THE NEW WOMAN;
MARYAM d' ABO - CULTURED ROMANCE
description: LEAD: SEATED ON THE OUTDOOR patio of the Ivy, an intimate West Hollywood restaurant, Maryam d'Abo does not look like the sort of woman who carries a telescopic rifle in a cello case. Tousled blonde hair pulled back to reveal exotic, elfin features, a denim jacket draped casually over her shoulders, a scarred silver bracelet on one wrist and two watches on the other, she seems the handiwork of Vladimir Nabokov, not Ian Fleming.

title: SHORTAGE OF NURSES: PROBLEMS AND PROSPECTS
description: The article ''Shortage of Nurses Vexes Hospitals'' [ June 28 ] did an admirable job of presenting the shortage of nurses in Long Island hospitals. However, several inaccuracies created a distorted picture of the Molloy College nursing department.

title: CD'S ARE DEFYING ADAM SMITH
description: THE LAW OF SUPPLY AND demand seems to have lost some of its teeth. A glut of CD's is just around the corner, yet no price cut is in sight.

title: An Assertive Fed Awaits Greenspan
description: ALAN GREENSPAN has impeccable credentials in economics. But his talent as consensus-builder might prove to be the New York consultant's biggest asset when he takes over, as is expected, as chairman of an increasingly free-spirited Federal Reserve.

title: Sweet Bread
description: To the Editor: As a native of Fall River, Mass., and a lover of Portuguese sweet bread (massa) and doughboys (malassadas), I greatly enjoyed reading ''Sweet Bread, Portuguese Style'' (Travel, May 17). Not mentioned was what I consider to be the best sweet bread bakery in New England - Faria's Bakery on Wickenden Street, near the Brown University campus in Providence. The Providence bakery should not be confused, however, with Faria's Bakery in Fall River. The owners of the bakeries are cousins but their recipes are quite different. THOMAS J. BRAGA Plattsburgh, N.Y.

title: Art
description: The 16th show in the lobby of One Penn Plaza (33d Street and Seventh Avenue) is one of several exhibitions that have recently been organized on geometric abstraction. It is called ''Romantic Science.'' The curator is the painter and critic Stephen Westfall, one of today's most reliable guides to abstract painting.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Scranton, Pa.;
Compromise On a Rail Park
description: LEAD: A DISPUTE over the use of the long unused rail yards of the Delaware Lackawanna & Western Railway adjacent to downtown has slowed plans to develop a national railway park in this northeastern Pennsylvania city of 88,000.

title: RESIDENTIAL RESALES
description: Closings in the week ended July 11 MANHATTAN Chelsea $405,000 7 East 20th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,117-sq.-ft. loft condo in a renovated prewar building; windowed kitchen, high-ceilings, living/work area; common charges $562, taxes $1,716 (Broker:

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: THANKS to a state referral service, New Jersey parents looking for a residential camp for a disabled child will have little trouble finding one. The problem is finding one with an opening.

title: City to Test Partial Midtown Ban on Bicycles
description: Mayor Koch, who installed bicycle lanes in Manhattan in 1980 and then had to scrap them because they did not work, moved another step away last week from his one-time dream of turning New York into a cyclist's Beijing. In an effort to preserve the lives and limbs of pedestrians, he said, bicycles will be banned from Park, Madison and Fifth Avenues between 31st and 59th Streets from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. in a three-month experiment starting Aug. 31.

title: Mr. Nixon, Please Come Back
description: LEAD: Dear Richard M. Nixon:

title: The 'Glasnost' Tree Bears A Rich Musical Harvest
description: NOT SO LONG AGO, THE LIST of American musicans performing each year in the Soviet Union was as brief as a Russian summer. That was before a new Soviet-American cultural exchange agreement was signed in Geneva in late 1985 - and before Mikhail Gorbachev's glasnost. Now, performers are tripping over each other in their eagerness to board the bandwagon bound for Moscow, and hardly a week passes without media appearances by musicians returning from a tour of duty on the Russian front, having bathed in the enthusiasm of Soviet audiences.

title: CATCHING THE WORLD
description: HAPPY HOUR By Alan Shapiro. 45 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. Cloth, $16. Paper, $7.95. FORESEEABLE FUTURES By William Matthews. 50 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $8.95. THE END OF BEAUTY By Jorie Graham. 99 pp. New York: The Ecco Press. $16.50.

title: LIBRARY WINS SUIT ON EVICTION
description: LEAD: A RECENT ruling by State Supreme Court Justice Beatrice Burstein determined that the owner of a public building had no control over the use of the building. The building is the Merrick Library Annex; the owner is the Merrick Board of Education. Lawyers for both sides called the decision a landmark.

title: Cody Displays Art and Relics Of the West
description: It is fitting that the Buffalo Bill Historical Center, an eclectic center of artworks and memorabilia inspired by the Western landscape and culture, is in Cody, Wyo. For just out the door of the building, and a short drive up the road, the expansive, dun-colored Western plains rise up to meet the heavily timbered, wildlife-rich Yellowstone National Park. It is somehow easier to understand what motivated Western painters like Bierstadt, Remington and Russell after you have just driven through the mountains and meadows of the nation's first and largest park.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
EDUCATION AWARD
description: LEAD: The State University of New York Purchase/ Westchester School Partnership - which has grown from a consortium of 11 school districts in 1984 to its present 26 districts plus the Northern and Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Education Services - fosters the sharing of educational resources and helps to develop programs that will enhance instruction in the participating school districts.

title: Janet Wolf and Neil Seiden Are Married in Jersey
description: Janet Wolf, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Wolf of West Orange, N.J., and Neil Alan Seiden, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Seiden of Forest Hills, Queens, were married last evening at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. Cantor Theodore Aronson performed the ceremony.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
GOOSENECK BARNACLE
description: LEAD: Lepas fascicularis Size: Two and a half inches.

title: THE CHANGING HOME
description: For years, I have been amazed at the growing popularity of exorbitantly priced attached and semiattached development homes, marketed under euphemistic labels such as ''planned communities'' and ''townhomes,'' when they are basically glorified Levittowns, with no individuality or privacy.

title: DAWN MURRAY IS A BRIDE
description: Dawn Ellen Murray, a daughter of Bruce Wellington Murray of Rowayton, Conn., and the late Sandra Halley Murray, was married yesterday to Douglas Thomas Crumley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Thomas Crumley Jr. of Bon Air, Va. The Rev. John Livingston performed the ceremony at the United Church in Rowayton. Mrs. Crumley, a University of Richmond graduate, is employed by the Richmond, Va., law firm of Robert L. Freed. Mr. Crumley is a manager with Harding Strauss, a Richmond automobile rental company. He attended Virginia Commonwealth University.

title: Boston Is Prohibiting Liquor At Clubs That Discriminate
description: The Boston Licensing Board has adopted a rule prohibiting liquor licenses for business and professional clubs that discriminate in their membership.

title: Community College Budget in Limelight
description: LEAD: HE was a member of the first graduating class, receiving a two-year associate degree in electrical technology in 1949, but Murph Brady, as he was then known, said Westchester Community College had yet to send him an annual appeals letter for a donation.

title: Miss Haydock to Marry John Tibbetts
description: Caroline Prioleau Haydock and John Rogers Tibbetts plan to marry in September, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. W. Kent Haydock of Darien, Conn., have announced. Mr. Tibbetts is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Tibbetts, also of Darien.

title: DON'T COOK MOTHER GOOSE
description: NURSERY rhymes, Walter de la Mare wrote, ''call for as little in the way of introduction as . . . Santa Claus'' and are ''surer of perpetuity than the Pyramids of Egypt.'' They ''free the fancy, charm tongue and ear, delight the inward eye, and many of them are tiny masterpieces of verbal craftsmanship.'' Purists who applaud this viewpoint may choose, from dozens of nursery rhyme collections, an edition whose illustrator best seems to interpret the traditional verses. Fear of finding textual distortions is usually minimal.

title: Miss Hanna Bride Of Stephen Morss
description: Elizabeth Gorham Hanna, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Hanna Jr. of Old Chatham, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stephen Williams Morss, a son of Shelley Christine Morss of Concord, Mass., and Charles Anthony Morss Jr. of Lincoln, Mass., at the Church on the Hill of the United Church of Christ in Lenox, Mass. The Rev. C.Frederick Buechner performed the ceremony, assisted by his daughter Katherine A. Buechner, a recent graduate of the Harvard University Divinity School.

title: WAR HAS MADE THE DIFFERENCE
description: A HISTORY OF ISRAEL Volume II: From the Aftermath of the Yom Kippur War. By Howard M. Sachar. Maps. 319 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95.

title: Major Arts Center Urged for Newark
description: The nation's two largest centers for the performing arts will be little more than a tunnel apart if New Jersey's Governor Kean is successful in carrying out the plan he proposed last week. Before his present term ends in 1990, he said, he wants to see a performing-arts complex in downtown Newark that would be second in size only to Lincoln Center, across the Hudson in New York.

title: Bay Ridge
description: THE breeze off New York Bay blows gently over scenes of the new and the old in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. In Dyker Beach Park, a group of elderly Italian men play boccie on a Sunday afternoon. Blocks away, Asian immigrants, newcomers to Bay Ridge, window-shop along 86th Street.

title:
INVESTING;
A Close Call for Hallwood
description: LEAD: The Hallwood Group Inc., which helps distressed companies raise capital, is known for taking good care of itself and its investors - its fees run to 10 percent of a deal's proceeds and, sometimes, it gets major equity positions for its services. But this month Hallwood came close to meeting with disaster.

title: DATA UPDATE: July 26 1987
THERE ONCE WAS A HOUSE, A HANDYMAN'S SPECIAL...
description: THERE was the house rising in dilapidated splendor high on a hill. Worn and peeling from neglect, it cried for gallons of paint. The lopsided shutters trembled with each passing breeze, and rusted hinges groaned over their burden. The grounds were fields of hay waving lazily as though beckoning each passerby to intrude in its massive sanctuary. Nothing less than a scythe would be able to cut them down. Still, I had visions of rose bushes, mountain laurel and lilacs, now being strangled by vines, lifting their heads and giving off the scent of living free again. The trees called to me so old, so majestic, the branches reaching out to caress and protect the house they had grown up with.

title:
IN THE REGION: NEW JERSEY;
A 'Go Slow' Sign on the Route 1 Corridor
description: LEAD: THE Princetonpark Corporate Center, a mixed-use development in South Brunswick, N.J., was planned in the early 80's to meet the needs for first-class suburban office space.

title: WILD AND CRAZY 'SUGAR BABIES'
description: AT An Evening Dinner Theater, the director Charles Repole's speedy production of the wild and crazy burlesque musical ''Sugar Babies'' is a winner on most counts.

title: Accepting Labor as a Legitimate Partner
description: PROFITS, productivity and technological change are not fighting words for most American union leaders, provided workers are given the opportunity to share in the benefits of economic advance and as long as economic progress is achieved through strategies that respect worker rights and needs.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Strategy For Olympics In Calgary

title: Ms. Puglielli and Peter Struzzi, Lawyers, to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Riccardo R. Puglielli of Rocky Hill, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lorella Puglielli, to Peter Henry Struzzi, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruno P. Struzzi of Jericho, L.I. The wedding is to be April 16.

title: True Confessions: A Pitcher Tells How to Cheat
description: EARLIER in the season, Mike Scott of Houston and Rick Rhoden of the Yankees headed the major leagues' Scuffball Suspects list. The scrutiny of those two successful pitchers has eased, but the subject of illegal pitches is never far from the surface. Probably with good reason. One pitcher who admits privately to doing funny things with baseballs said each pitching staff has at least one pitcher who scuffs, cuts or moistens some of the balls he throws.

title: SALARY REVIEB OF 9,000 COUNTY JOBS BEGINS
description: HOPING to avert a potential employment crisis in county government, the county has begun a $469,394 job-compensation study that will include a review of all 9,000 county jobs and is designed to develop a more equitable pay program for employees.

title: . . . And Why Radio Still Sings
description: WHAT'S GOING ON? A banker outside of

title: Record 28 in a Row
description: The Salt Lake Trappers tonight established the longest winning streak in the history of organized baseball by winning their 28th consecutive game, 13-3 over the Pocatello Giants in the Pioneer League.

title: U.S. Fears Soviet Use of New Nicaraguan Airfield
description: Administration officials say the Nicaraguan Government has almost completed work on the longest airfield in Central America, which they fear the Soviet Union might use to extend its reconnaisance missions in this hemisphere.

title: DOWN WITH IGNORANCE, LONG LIVE ONOTOLGY
description: FOR a while we have had the extraordinary spectacle of two serious books that are highly critical of American life at the top of the nonfiction best-seller list, places usually held by humor, inspirational books and extraterrestrial experiences. As of this issue of The Book Review, Allan Bloom's ''Closing of the American Mind'' is in first place and E. D. Hirsch Jr.'s ''Cultural Literacy'' is second.

title: How Can Democracy and Covert Action Be Reconciled?
description: THE Iran-contra hearings have raised fundamental questions about the formulation and conduct of foreign policy by a democracy, but they have provided few answers. These questions included whether it is possible, as Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter has argued, to justify lying to and misleading Congress, circumventing the foreign policy process, and keeping the Cabinet members and even the President in the dark about major decisions to preserve secrecy. What does the Iran-contra affair say about the future of the relations between the legislative and executive branches of government? What is the proper role of covert action? Andrew Rosenthal, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, discussed some of these issues with former Government officials, academics and legal experts. BRENT SCOWCROFT Retired Air Force general who served as national security adviser under President Ford

title: The Brighter Side
description: At the end of these past two weeks of the Iran-contra hearings, the mood in Washington is much better than it was at the beginning. Secretary of State Shultz lanced the poison. He told an alarming story of corruption at the top of the Government, and by letting it all out he somehow managed to restore a sense of truth and purpose to the proceedings.

title: WELCOME URBANITY ON NORTH FORK
description: THE restaurant is called Bonnies by the Bay. The bay is the Peconic and the place is the epitome of rural North Fork Long Island: the sleepy little fishing village of New Suffolk. You might expect Bonnies by the Bay to be a quaint dining spot. Not on your life! It's urbane, sophisticated and trendy.

title: SHORTAGE OF NURSES: PROBLEMS AND PROSPECTS
description: The article misses the point of why there's a shortage.
