After interviews of several hospital administrators, their opinion is passed along that the hospital nurse shortage is due to declining nursing school enrollments. Those declining enrollments, however, are the symptom, not the cause: The shortage is being caused by the administrators themselves.

title: IT'S HARD TO GAUGE EXPOSURE AT THE BEACH
description: Keeping cameras out of harm's way isn't the only problem photographers face at the beach. There's the small matter of taking pictures.

title: Ballet Leaps Over Borders
description: DO NATIONAL STYLES IN BAL-let really exist? This season has demonstrated the question to be thornier than ever. As the annual tidal wave of visiting ballet companies from abroad begins to ebb, the differences rather than the similarities in their dance styles come to the fore. No one would mistake the Bolshoi for anything but a Soviet company. The spectacular impact of its first visit to New York in eight years has again left many wondering what makes Russian ballet so specifically Russian.

title: Helistat Is Gone; Its Concept Lives
description: ONE of Frank N. Piasecki's big ideas, the Helistat - part airship, part helicopter - went up in flames a year ago this month. Another idea has risen from the ashes.

title: Under International Law, Reflagging Doesn't Fly
description: To the Editor:

title: TAX PLAN TO BUY PINE BARRENS SPLITS LOGRANDE AND HALPIN
description: LEAD: SPARED lasting intrusions for three centuries because they were too inhospitable for settlement, the arid and sandy pine barrens of eastern Long Island are now the best and perhaps last hope for insuring water supplies in Suffolk County for the next two centuries, county officials agree.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: MUSIC, MUSIC, MUSIC

title: The Smoking Cannon
description: Secretary of State Shultz put a critical piece of a still-incomplete Iran-contra puzzle into place last week. ''I don't know where anybody got that idea,'' he said, ''that the President just sits around not paying attention.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN BOOK DISTRIBUTION
description: WHEN Warner Books, a power in paperback publishing, started publishing hardcover books a few years ago, it wanted to establish immediate credibility with booksellers. So, in an agreement drawn up on a napkin in a midtown Manhattan restaurant, it struck a deal with Random House, an old pro in the business.

title:
ART;
GUILD HALL FEATURES NEW FACES
description: LEAD: SEEKING out underrecognized talent is not just the much discussed pursuit of a new breed of aggressive collectors. There are museums, too, that feel this is part of their mandate.

title: LIZ CARPENTER: BACK ON THE TRAIL AGAIN
description: When Liz Carpenter talks, she looks at you straight in the eye and fires away in a deep Texas drawl that has roots predating the fall of the Alamo.

title: NORWALK ASKS CITIZENS TO COMPLAIN
description: A NEW citizen's memo system in Norwalk makes it easy for residents to take their complaints to the top, and hundreds of them have already availed themselves of their opportunity.

title: Marsha Diamond to Wed
description: The engagement of Marsha Diamond to Dr. Marc Jeffrey Salzman, a son of Bobi Salzman of Vail, Colo., and Dr. Robert Salzman of Miami has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley A. Diamond of Squirrel Hill, Pa. An October wedding is planned. Miss Diamond, a New York University graduate, is director of research at Camelot Entertainment Sales, a television advertising sales company in New York. Dr. Salzman is a resident in surgery at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York. He is a graduate of the University of Florida, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and the Tulane University School of Medicine.

title: Okamoto Uses Accuracy for 1-Shot Lead in Open
description: Ayako Okamoto of Japan used her finesse with the short golf strokes to counter the thundering distance of Laura Davies on the last two holes today and gain a one-stroke lead over the English golfer going into the final round of the 42d United States Women's Open.

title: D. F. MacMaster Weds Miss Carey In Pennsylvania
description: The wedding of Frances Whelen Carey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Carey of Whitpain, Pa., to Donald Francis MacMaster, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas J. MacMaster Jr. of Whitemarsh, Pa., took place yesterday. The Rev. Richard T. Hawkins performed the ceremony at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church in Whitemarsh, assisted by the Rev. Francis Bonato, a Roman Catholic priest.

title:
DINING OUT;
THE MENU ALSO LISTS THE CALORIES
description: LEAD: FOR several months, drivers on Interstate 287 North where Routes 80 and 46 cross were able to watch the construction of a large fanciful building that looked like a castle.

title: Mona Lisa's Mustache
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecutor to Deal With Subtler Crime
description: Since 1980, Bruce A. Baird has spent most of his time chasing the Mafia. He was the lead prosecutor in getting convictions against top members of the Colombo organized crime family, and since January he has been head of the narcotics unit in the United States Attorney's office for the Southern District of New York.

title: Brenda Mendoza Married To Jonathan R. Friedman
description: Brenda Marie Mendoza, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Radames Mendoza of San Juan, P. R., and Jonathan Roy Friedman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Friedman of New York, were married yesterday at the Hotel Casa Madrona in Sausalito, Calif., by Rabbi Jonathan Plaut.

title: Advertising; Nissan Winner Due
description: The two agencies in the finals for the $150 million Nissan Motor Corporation U.S.A. account expect to learn of the winner on Friday. Tatham-Laird & Kudner, Chicago, is presenting on Wednesday, and Chiat/Day, Los Angeles, on Thursday. The previous agency was the William Esty Company.

title: NIKOLAIS AND LOUIS, A DANCE PORTRAIT
description: CHRISTIAN BLACKWOOD'S ''Nik and Murray,'' on Channel 13 tonight at 9 o'clock, is a valentine to the 38-year professional and personal relationship of Alwin Nikolais and Murray Louis. The documentary suggests ways in which the work of these two major modern-dance choreographers developed. But it does not give us an idea of their place in American dance nor how their work has influenced modern dance, in general, in this country.

title: Attendance Marks Bring Satisfaction
description: Shortly after the organization was awarded this year's United States Olympic Festival, a publicist for the North Carolina Amateur Sports predicted that the festival would be ''the greatest single event in North Carolina history.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An Associated Press dispatch Friday from Santa Ana, Calif., about a bias lawsuit filed by a policeman, misidentified the group that the jury found had discriminated. It was the American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California, not the national organization.

title: FOR BANGLADESHI OPPOSITION, A CRICIAL PERIOD
description: The monsoon rains are at their most pitiless now in Bangladesh, a country regularly victimized by wind and water.

title: Strong Economy Is No Blessing for Boston House Hunters
description: By some measures, Massachusetts has the strongest economy in the country and the strongest housing market. As a result, according to state officials, it also has one of the biggest housing shortages for low-income families.

title: Beth Goldstein Married To Neil Jay Weissman
description: Beth Ellen Goldstein, who will enroll in the M.B.A. program at Fordham University in September, and Neil Jay Weissman, a fourth-year medical student at the Cornell University Medical College, were married yesterday at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, L.I. Rabbi Neil Kurshan officiated, assisted by Cantor Steven Stein.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Family Media has reassigned Discover magazine to John Emmerling Inc.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: What's the best season record for a major league team that failed to win a pennant or a division title?

title: Give Welfare Consensus a Chance
description: Welfare reform - over decades of debate, the words have sparked combat among liberals and conservatives, affluent taxpayers and families mired in poverty. Welcome, therefore, a new consensus on linking welfare to work.

title: The Pursuit of Sassafras in Central Park
description: Like it or not, Britain's chief delegate to the United Nations will be dining this week at his Beekman Place residence on sheep sorrel, lady's-thumb, poor man's pepper, amaranth and lamb's-quarters - all wild plants and weeds picked yesterday in Central Park by his enterprising chef.

title: Leibrandt's 2-Hitter Ends Oriole Streak
description: Charlie Leibrandt pitched a two-hitter and the Kansas City Royals ended Baltimore's 11-game winning streak today by beating the Orioles, 4-0.

title: French Salvage Crew Brings Back First Objects From Titanic: Dishes
description: French explorers today retrieved dishes from the wreckage of the Titanic, the first objects ever recovered from the luxury ocean liner that sank 75 years ago, killing 1,513 passengers.

title: History and Hope Given Their Due At Cooperstown
description: In this bucolic little town where one Abner Doubleday did not invent baseball, and where a lovely piece of fiction was allowed to grow into a legend, three men who performed real, and extraordinary deeds, were officially proclaimed here today as legends themselves.

title: Advertising; Jeffrey Clapp Leaving MacNamara Firm
description: MacNamara, Clapp & Klein will announce today that Jeffrey W. Clapp, its 49-year-old chairman, is resigning from the six-year-old agency to pursue other, unidentified goals. An alumnus of both Norman, Craig & Kummel and Ted Bates & Company, he was the $42 million agency's top account man.

title: 2 Bodies Recovered From Coney I. Creek
description: A police scuba team yesterday recovered the bodies of two men who apparently drowned during a futile effort to rescue an 8-year-old Brooklyn boy who had fallen into Coney Island Creek Saturday afternoon, the police said.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Lasers and 'Red Force:' Realism in War Games
description: The Red Force of 130 tanks and armored personnel carriers, looking for all the world like a Soviet regiment, roar out of Afghanistan through the Bowling Alley and across the Shelf to drop into the Valley of Death and assault the Blue Force of 150 American infantrymen and four tanks.

title: OFF L.I., A PIRATE RADIO STATION DEFIES F.C.C.
description: Protesting what they called the stagnant state of rock-and-roll radio in New York City, a group of gadfly radio enthusiasts took to the airwaves last week from a rusty old freighter anchored five miles off Long Island's South Shore.

title: Final Battles Shape Up On Major Banking Bill
description: It is reckoning time in both the Congress and the Reagan Administration for the most far-reaching banking legislation in more than seven years.

title: Why New York Extended Milk Shelf Life
description: To the Editor:

title: IT'S STILL A LONG HALL FOR WOMEN IN BASEBALL
description: WHETHER baseball is ready for the advancement of Pam Postema and the sprinkling of other women, most of whom toil in the front office in supplemental roles, is unresolved.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Profile: Evelyn Dubrow; A Capitol Hill Lobbyist Everyone Loves
description: One person on Capitol Hill gets to share the Congressional doorkeepers' chairs outside the House of Representatives chambers, a good spot to catch the eye of an arriving or departing member of Congress. Evelyn Dubrow and no one else. No one protests. This 4-foot 11-inch lobbyist for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union who began roaming the halls of Congress 29 years ago seeking support for a $1 minimum wage, and who still troops Capitol Hill in her size 4 shoes, has earned the privilege. Besides, explains a staff member in the doorkeeper's office, ''Everyone loves Evy.''

title: CONCERT: CHARLES DUTOIT CONDUCTS AT TANGLEWOOD
description: Charles Dutoit is not a hard-driving conductor. His reputation, considerable and still growing, is based in good part on performances of the big orchestral showpieces - in particular a series of sonically and instrumentally brilliant compact disks on the London label with his Montreal Symphony. But a great part of his appeal stems from the fact that he plays the blockbusters for their musical values, naturally, with blockbusting as an exciting but natural byproduct. So it was no surprise to hear him succeed Saturday evening at Tanglewood with a different kind of program, one in whose music understatement, geniality, thoughtful consideration of ideas and affectionate coloring were the cardinal qualities.

title: ROCHE VICTORY CAPS STRONG COMEBACK
description: Capping a remarkable comeback year, Stephen Roche swept into Paris today as the winner of the Tour de France bicycle race.

title: Volcker and Smoke
description: Paul Volcker, the departing chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, made a final appearance before the Senate Banking Committee last week. And although many lawmakers praised his contributions to the nation's economic policy, Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said he would definitely not miss the smoke from Mr. Volcker's celebrated cigars.

title: Action Awaited on U.S. Debt Ceiling
description: The outlook for Treasury financings remains cloudy this week, as securities dealers and investors wait for Congress to pass legislation raising the Federal debt ceiling.

title: Business's Bottom Line: Ethics
description: Ethical and moral lapses in the business and financial community, academia, politics and religion fill the daily press. But the rash of insider-trading cases on Wall Street against recent graduates of top business and law schools seems particularly disturbing because the cream of the crop, with six-figure incomes and brilliant careers ahead, is being convicted.

title: The Editorial Notebook: Einstein's Papers, and Brain; The Physicist's Legacy Remains Veiled to Millions
description: When Albert Einstein lay dying in Princeton Hospital, the nurse assigned to him spoke no German and the great physicist's last words passed uncomprehended. Strangely, for a person of such interest and eminence, the rest of his legacy has long remained almost equally inaccessible. Publication of his papers has begun only now, after a 30-year delay, and even then with an English translation supplied as a grudging afterthought. His brain was removed for a scientific study that has yet to be published.

title: Julie Hartenstein Wed in Syracuse
description: Julie Hartenstein, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Hans Hartenstein of Syracuse, was married yesterday to Jonathan W. Meyersohn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rolf Meyersohn of New York. Judge Minna Buck of Family Court in Syracuse officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Bolivians Fight Efforts to Eradicate Coca
description: Joint Bolivian and American efforts to combat cocaine exports have run into strong opposition in recent weeks from organized peasant growers of coca, the raw material of the drug.

title: PANEL CRITICIZES FIRE DISPATCHERS IN HARLEM BLAZE
description: Efforts to fight a blaze in a high-rise Harlem apartment building that killed seven people in March were hampered by fire dispatchers who mishandled calls and by firefighters at the scene who created an atmosphere of confusion, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: Rodeo Comrades Pay Tribute To Baldrige, 'a Real Cowboy'
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige spent the final two days of his life pursuing what friends said he had loved most - the life of a cowboy.

title: Brazil Seeks $7.2 Billion Of Interest-Free Loans
description: Only weeks after major banks in the United States declared that a quarter of their Latin American loans were probably worthless, Brazil has asked its bank creditors for $7.2 billion in new money at zero interest.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JULY 27, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Market Place; The Leading Bank Funds
description: THE Bank of Boston's income equity fund easily outperformed all other bank common-stock funds in the second quarter, a period in which the average bank fund just about kept pace with the overall market. The First Fidelity Bank in Newark also showed impressive gains, with funds that came second and third.

title: Tell Us if the Cheese On Our Pizza Is Fake
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Robert H. Bork's role as Acting Attorney General in the Watergate scandals misidentified the wife of Ralph K. Winter, a Federal judge who was then a Yale Law School professor. Mr. Winter's wife is Kathryn Winter. At the time Mr. Bork was married to Claire Bork, who died in 1980. Also because of an editing error, the article incorrectly attributed a statement about Mr. Bork's position on dismissing Archibald Cox, the Watergate special prosecutor. It was Elliot L. Richardson, then Attorney General, and not William D. Ruckelshaus, his deputy, who said: ''He had no personal scruples against firing Cox.''

title: WRENN'S VICTORY IN HIS FIRST ON TOUR
description: Robert Wrenn finished with a near-record 26-under-par 262 today for his first PGA Tour victory in the $600,000 Buick Open at Warwick Hills Golf and Country Club.

title: Baptist Minister Orders Staff To Convert to Faith or Resign
description: A Southern Baptist pastor here has told staff members at the church's day care center to convert to his faith or quit, prompting eight workers to resign.

title: SIKH INTRUDERS ARE ALLOWED TO REMAIN IN CANADA
description: Two weeks after 174 Indian nationals landed in Nova Scotia from a freighter, all but nine have been approved for temporary residence in Canada.

title: Long Island and Smoke
description: Smoking also figured in a debate in the House of Representatives last week over an $11 billion spending bill that covers the Department of Transportation.

title: MINERS FOUND TO HAVE HIGHEST DEATH RATE ON JOB
description: The Federal Government's first compilation of occupational deaths in the United States has found that mining and construction jobs are the riskiest.

title: Medical Resident: Life on the Crisis Shift
description: At 2:30 A.M. the corridors of New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital were dimly lighted and still. But inside the intensive-care unit the respirators pumped and hummed as usual, sustaining fragile lives.

title: U.S. GOODS IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Nearly 10 years after Wang Laboratories Inc. pulled out of South Africa, the company's computers are still widely available.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Personal Income June Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday New-Home Sales May Leading Indicators June Friday Factory Orders May

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JULY 27, 1987
description: International A2-6 U.S. ability to detect mines and destroy them in the Persian Gulf will be increased, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said. The United States is capable of retaliating against whatever side laid the mines, he said. Page A1

title: Bolshoi Scheduled to Perform in Israel
description: The Bolshoi Ballet and Red Army Chorus have scheduled performances in Israel, it was announced today. Their appearance would mark a significant upgrading of Soviet-Israeli cultural ties.

title: Cards Drop a Doubleheader
description: Will Clark hit a pair of game-winning home runs today, and the San Francisco Giants won both games of a doubleheader from the St. Louis Cardinals, 6-3 and 5-2, for a sweep of their four-game series.

title: Man Charged in Sex Attacks On Three Women in Queens
description: A convicted rapist and kidnapper, released from prison two months ago, was charged yesterday with 3 of 13 sexual assaults on women that have stirred fear and anger in Central Queens, the police said.

title: Jane Baker Becomes Bride
description: Jane Linda Baker, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Baker of Demarest, N.J., and H. Roger Segelken, a son of Mrs. H. Clifford Segelken of Phoenicia, N.Y., and the late Mr. Segelken, were married yesterday at Shotwell Memorial Park in Skaneateles, N.Y., by Linda Lavery, a justice of the peace. The bride, a former reporter for The Syracuse Herald Journal, graduated from Syracuse University and is a freelance writer. The bridegroom, a former reporter for The Syracuse Herald Journal and The Syracuse Herald American, is a science writer for the news service of Cornell University. He also graduated from Syracuse University.

title: Huston and the Man Who Might Be Traven
description: To the Editor I agree with Hank O'Neal (letter, July 12) that Woody Allen and other critics of colorization of films would do well to remember that much of Hollywood's product is the result of unfettered tampering by movie makers with the art of others. Mr. O'Neal is mistaken, however, in naming John Huston, one of the most vociferous critics of colorization, as a screenwriter who showed little regard for the artists whose work he adapted.

title: BIG THREE READY FOR HASKELL SHOWDOWN
description: The three most accomplished 3-year-olds in the country are actually five different horses: Bet Twice, Alysheba, Alysheba (on Lasix), Lost Code and Lost Code (on Lasix).

title: Tatars to Meet Gromyko Today Over Homeland
description: Crimean Tatars who staged an extraordinary 24-hour demonstration at the gates of the Kremlin this weekend will meet Monday with President Andrei A. Gromyko, one of their leaders said today.

title: Plane Flaw Ends Cuomo Trip
description: An airplane carrying Governor Cuomo made an emergency landing on one engine today after a warning light indicated the other engine was on fire.

title: WHITE SOX NEARLY PERFECT
description: The sun was shining on the South Side this afternoon. Saturday's oppressive heat was gone, and a comfortable breeze was blowing, and the White Sox were threatening to remove the Yankees from first place.

title: Debra Dickman Wed
description: Debra Lynn Dickman, the daughter of Mrs. Alfred Dickman of Cranbury, N.J., and the late Mr. Dickman, and Dr. Lawrence Mark Ratner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Ratner of Lawrence, L.I., were married yesterday at Farrington Manor in East Brunswick, N.J., by Rabbi Steven Shaw, the bride's cousin. The bride is a graduate of Hofstra University. The bridegroom, a graduate of Washington University and the St. Louis University School of Medicine, is a radiologist with the Radiology Affiliates of Central New Jersey-Bucks County in Trenton.

title: Metro Matters; Race and Crime: Beyond Statistics To Find Answers
description: When a Police Commissioner publicly blames most of the city's crime on an ethnic, racial or religious group, he had better be right.

title: Meese Role in Meeting With North
description: To the Editor:

title: Marie Daly Price Wed To Robert Crandall Jr.
description: Marie Daly Price and Robert Wilson Crandall Jr. were married yesterday at the Warren, Vt., home of the bridegroom's mother, Mrs. Crandall, who also lives in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The Rev. David Geib, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Mr. Crandall's father is deceased.

title: BECKER STOPS MAYOTTE, U.S. IN CUP
description: After John McEnroe produced a breezy singles victory that put the United States team into a tie with West Germany in the Davis Cup relegation round, it was left to Tim Mayotte to conquer Boris Becker to complete the comeback needed to keep the United States in contention for the 1988 cup.

title: George O'Day Is Dead at 64; Designer and Racer of Boats
description: George O'Day, a sailboat designer and racer who captured an Olympic gold medal in yachting, died of colon cancer today. He was 64 years old.

title: Advertising; Head of Muller Jordan Adds Creative Title
description: Jane Maas, president of Muller Jordan Weiss, started out in the business as a copywriter and, although she later got into account management, she never really gave up the writing.

title: Bronx Officials Face Churches' Power
description: Similar events for Presidential candidates have been dubbed ''cattle shows.'' For candidates running for boroughwide office in the Bronx, an appearance yesterday on the steps of the county building before a coalition of church groups was termed an ''accountability assembly.''

title: STAGE: 'THE ROVER,' FEMINIST COMEDY FROM 1677
description: From the moment Christopher Reeve swaggers on stage in 17th-century cavalier finery, shirt open and sword at the ready, it's clear why the Williamstown Theater Festival has chosen to revive ''The Rover.'' This infrequently staged Restoration comedy, written by Aphra Behn in 1677, gives Mr. Reeve and his dashing companions - Stephen Collins, Harry Groener, Edward Herrmann - a chance to duel and flirt and clown and play drunk, all in the name of culture.

title: POP MUSIC: JON HASSELL AND FARAFINA
description: THE challenge of cross-cultural collaborations such as the encounter Friday between Jon Hassell, an American composer-musician, and the African percussion group Farafina at Alice Tully Hall, is that next to the elemental integrity of the traditional music, the Westerner's contributions may simply seem irrelevant. It is not likely that any modern musician, no matter how sincere or sophisticated, will ''improve'' a richly textured traditional idiom that has benefited from generations of refinement and renewal.

title: GIANTS OPEN CAMP TODAY
description: When the Giants open their training camp here Monday at Pace University's Westchester campus, most of their 14 drafted rookies will probably be on hand, their contracts signed. Rookies and veterans alike must be signed to take part in training camp.

title: Salvation Army Opens a Center At Harlem Site
description: With a parade, prayers and speeches by politicians, the Salvation Army opened an $8 million community center in Harlem yesterday, ending a 14-year struggle with community residents who favored the construction of housing at the site.

title: U.S. ARMS AIRLIFT TO ANGOLA REBELS IS SAID TO GO ON
description: A secret airlift of American arms to Angolan guerrillas continues through southern Zaire, two Western diplomats stationed in Zaire said today.

title: Husband Is Charged In Wife's Death
description: A Manhattan man was charged with first-degree manslaughter yesterday in connection with the beating death of his wife in a midtown hotel room, the police said.

title: ADMINISTRATION MOURNS BALDRIGE, SKILLED MASTER OF ITS TRADE POLICY
description: The Reagan Administration found itself handicapped today by the death of Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige at a time when it is trying to work with Congress on critical trade legislation.

title: Advertising; Rolls-Royce Appeals To the Reader's Nose
description: The July issue of posh Architectural Digest magazine went on sale June 10 with a special insert from Rolls-Royce that had a leathery look to carry its leathery smell. That's right, with the help of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, the magazine published a scent strip with the smell of a new Rolls at a cost of about $125,000.

title: RYAN IS QUICK TO STAND BEHIND AN ABSENT O'BRIEN
description: Pat Ryan, the aggressive veteran the Jets trusted to start last season's two playoff games, insisted today that the absent Ken O'Brien still is the club's No. 1 quarterback.

title: Kuwait Debt Proposal
description: The Kuwait Finance Minister Jasim Muhammad al-Khurafi said today that the country was considering a public debt issue to finance its budget deficit and expand its domestic investment opportunities. He told Kuna, the Kuwaiti news agency, that numerous ways of financing the deficit were being studied. The nation, heavily dependent on oil revenue, has had a budget deficit every year but one since 1981-82, when world oil prices began falling. The debt, which totaled $1 billion (about $3.5 billion American) last year, has been financed through Kuwait's foreign-investment income.

title: 300 Fault O'Connor Role On AIDS Commission
description: Yelling ''Shame!'' and pointing their fingers at the great bronze doors of St. Patrick's Cathedral, some 300 demonstrators yesterday protested President Reagan's choice of John Cardinal O'Connor to serve on the national commission charged with stemming AIDS.

title: Antipollution Plan Stirs Ire of Colorado Motorists
description: By now, most residents here are accustomed to restrictions on wood-burning stoves, tough standards on automobile emissions and other measures of recent years to control the severe air pollution along the eastern slope of the Rocky Mountains.

title: Japanese Exporting to Japan
description: Thanks to the lower value of the dollar against the yen, some Japanese companies are finding it profitable to export to Japan from plants in the United States.

title: Crisis for Bombay's Exchange
description: Two years ago, India's premier stock exchange here was swept by an unprecedented buying boom. Hundreds of thousands of new investors flooded the market as public enthusiasm grew for the liberal and pro-business policies of the new Prime Minister, Rajiv Gandhi.

title: REPORTING EXACTLY WHAT IS SAID
description: It was an entrepreneur's dream: a market ripe for the picking.

title: CONCERT: THE KRONOS QUARTET AT SUMMERFARE
description: The Kronos Quartet has earned its present eminence primarily through its remarkable repertory of contemporary music of every kind, and secondarily through the excellence of its performances. But another part of this San Francisco group's very carefully crafted image has been its theatricality - heavily stylized costumes that change from concert to concert, usually flavored with bohemian-punk raffishness.

title: GUIDED ASTRONAUTS TO MOON
description: Charles Stark Draper, a pioneer in advanced guidance technology for aircraft and missiles and developer of the navigation system that steered Americans to the moon and back, died Saturday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 85 years old.

title: Work of Seven Artists At the Cork Gallery
description: ''Independent Arts,'' an exhibition of work by seven artists associated with the Queens Independent Living Center is to go on display Thursday at the Cork Gallery, at Lincoln Center. The center is devoted to helping artists with physical disabilities to become part of the main art community. The gallery, which is accessible to physically handicapped people, is on the lower concourse level of Avery Fisher Hall, Broadway and 65th Street. It is open daily from 10 A.M. until the hall closes; admission is free.

title: DAVIES GOES FOR IT
description: AT the United States Women's Open, the 17th hole flows out to an up-slope, levels off and then dips down into a swale in front of a green surrounded by three bunkers. It is 493 yards long, a par 5 where, according to the hole-by-hole description of the Plainfield Country Club, ''only the very long hitters will be able to reach the green in two shots.''

title: Home Buying Drops Sharply In the Suburbs
description: The surging market for homes in the suburbs of New York City has abruptly shifted gears. In many suburban communities, where real-estate prices have more than doubled since 1980, industry experts say there is a huge inventory of unsold homes, and a sudden paucity of buyers.

title: Family Is Awarded $380,000 In Cemetery's Burial Mix-Up
description: A jury awarded a family $380,000 Thursday after a cemetery mix-up separated a couple who had wanted to be buried next to each other.

title: THE AVANT-GARDE: MOVING FROM CULT TO THE MAINSTREAM
description: Clad in black, his face a mask of homicidal grimness, the noted avant-garde director Robert Wilson made a rare stage appearance at Alice Tully Hall recently in his ''Overture to the Fourth Act of Deafman Glance.'' Enacting a silent slow-motion scenario of ritual infanticide with his partner, Sheryl Sutton, Mr. Wilson's 90-minute performance drew a vociferous mixture of boos and cheers from a nearly sold-out house at the opening night of the Lincoln Center experimental performance series ''Serious Fun!''

title: Polo, the Sport of Britain's Princes, Now Beguiles the 'Castle Creepers'
description: It took a few thousand years, but polo is now a busy new venue for social climbing in Britain, complete with ''castle creepers'' - social overreachers - and handsome, mercenary athletes racing past a pop-culture melange that was displayed today like designer daffodils along the borders of the greensward.

title: FOR COUTURE, A FUTURE
description: With his first collection under his own name, Christian Lacroix has been catapulted into fashion's hall of fame. Like Christian Dior exactly 40 years ago, he has revived a failing institution, the haute couture, or made-to-order branch of French fashion. He has done it with verve, whimsy and a youthful air. The collection he presented today is many-faceted, but its dominant theme is folkloric.

title: NEW FINDINGS TIE BLACK HOLES TO THE FORMATION OF GALAXIES
description: Immense concentrations of mass that appear to be black holes, each with the gravity of 10 million to 100 million suns, have been detected at the cores of the two spiral galaxies closest to ours, astronomers announced yesterday.

title: TRADE DEBATE TAKES A ROLE IN CAMPAIGNS
description: Although trade is hardly ever mentioned when poll takers ask Americans to name the nation's most important problem, it has emerged as the first issue to rouse serious debate among the 1988 Presidential contenders.

title: A ROCKING BILLY JOEL BREAKS THROUGH SOVIET RESERVE
description: Billy Joel brought his rock-and-roll here today and won the souls of those in a stony Soviet audience, leaving them cheering, dancing on chairs and looking around in fearful wonder as they followed the music and not the rules.

title: Righteous Bucks Wins Cane Pace
description: Righteous Bucks rallied the last few yards and finished a half-length ahead of Golden Greek tonight to capture the Cane Pace, the first leg of the triple crown for 3-year-old pacers.

title: The Doldrums at NATO
description: Lord Carrington has decided to retire as NATO's Secretary General next year. The politicking to name his successor has begun and, typically, Peter Carrington, former British Foreign Minister, is too diplomatic to discuss the candidates.

title: Change in Ceremonies
description: The two weeks of competition are expected to be stirring, and the daily opportunities for promoting international understanding will be extensive. But when more than 4,000 athletes from 38 nations gather for the closing ceremonies of the 10th Pan American Games in Indianapolis Aug. 23, there will be a reminder that all is not sweetness and light in the Americas.

title: Family Who Lost a Child Will See Another Tried for Murder
description: Glenn Evans had drunk five, maybe six bottles of beer when he slipped behind the wheel of his 1971 Plymouth Duster and set off with three teen-age girls for a drive one hot August night last year.

title: CREDIT MARKETS A Negative Tone for Bonds
description: LEAD: Treasury bond yields have increased nearly half a percentage point since early this month, as a negative tone has spread through the bond market in advance of a heavy supply of new issues.

title: Long Family Tie Cited By Buyer of Kodak Unit
description: Carl D. Newton 3d, who is waiting to complete his purchase of the Fox Photo retail unit from the Eastman Kodak Company, says that the decision to buy the stores was based on more than just business.

title: Auto Racing
description: First for Piquet: Nelson Piquet of Brazil, driving a Williams-Honda, won the West German Grand Prix yesterday in Hockenheim. It was his first victory of the season. Piquet now has a 4-point lead in the Formula One world championship drivers' standing with 39 points. Stefan Johansson of Sweden finished in second place, and Aryton Senna of Brazil took third. Senna, who was leading in the championship standing before the race, picked up 4 points and is now second. Piquet completed the race in 1 hour 21 minutes 25.091 seconds. (AP) Elliott Edges Davey Allison: Bill Elliott ended a 15-race losing streak by holding off Davey Allison to win the Talladega 500 Nascar race yesterday on the 2.66-mile track at Alabama International Motor Speedway in Talladega.(AP) Track and Field Moses Wins; Nehemiah Falls: Edwin Moses splashed through the puddles for a victory in the 400-meter hurdles, but Renaldo Nehemiah wound up sprawling on the rain-sodden track in the 110-meter hurdles yesterday at the Pearl Assurance Invitation meet at Gateshead, England. Moses posted a modest time of 48.84 seconds. Nehemiah who, like Moses, is the world-record holder in his event, hit three hurdles and fell in a race won in 13.32 seconds by Tonie Campbell of the United States.(AP) Tennis Lendl Tops Arias: Ivan Lendl needed only 63 minutes to defeat Jimmy Arias and win the singles final yesterday at the Head Classic in Stowe, Vt. Lendl fought wind and bright sunlight to beat Arias, 6-3, 6-3. (AP) Horse Racing Lake Cecebe Takes Stakes: Lake Cecebe, ridden by Jose Santos, scored a 3 1/2-length victory yesterday in the $72,400 Mount Vernon Stakes for New York-bred fillies and mares 3-years- old-and-over at Belmont Park. Mighty Wonder was second. The winner went a mile and a quarter in 2:07 2/5 and returned $9.20 for $2 to win.(AP) Horse Show Victory for Fargis: Joe Fargis of Southampton, L.I., exhibited the form that won him a gold medal in the 1984 Olympics when he rode Abdullah to two fault-free rides for a victory in yesterday's $65,000 Cadillac Grand Prix of New Hampshire at Attitash Mountain. Only seven of 42 horses in the starting field qualified for the timed jump-off. The 39-year-old Fargis was the first rider to attempt the seven-jump, 295-yard jump-off course. He again rode without fault, finishing in 37.092 seconds. Powerboat Racing Grand Prix Cut Short: The biggest traffic snarl in Atlantic City yesterday wasn't on the road, it was in the water. Organizers of the Trump's Castle Hotel & Casino Offshore Grand Prix raised a black flag at noon, calling off the powerboat competition an hour after it had started. Officials said the decision was prompted by the meanderings onto the course of more than 200 spectator craft. The 66 high-powered boats in the competition were running at top speeds of 80 to 100 miles an hour at the time.

title: Navajo Seeks Industries
description: The chairman of America's largest Indian tribe urged private businesses to ''bring us your bottom line'' before pursuing business ventures in developing nations.

title: What if the Contras Are More Popular?
description: Fifty percent against the Administration's policy toward Nicaragua, and about 25 percent in favor - that's been roughly the public opinion scorecard for years. Now, after the emotional pleas of Lieut. Col. Oliver North, there's been an evening out. It's probably a blip. But what if the surge in support for the Nicaraguan rebels holds?

title: Advertising; Perrier Assignment For Altschiller Reitzfeld
description: The Perrier Group has assigned three of its regional bottled water brands to Altschiller Reitzfeld. Billings could reach $4 million, trade sources indicate.

title: Photos With North
description: A popular thing for tourists to do in the capital is have their picture taken next to a life-sized cardboard cutout of President Reagan. This week, a cardboard rival appeared on the Pennsylvania Avenue sidewalks in front of the White House: a 6-foot-tall portrait of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, all sparkling medals and square shoulders.

title: Carolyn Ronda Bernstein Weds Dr. Brian Waldron
description: Carolyn Ronda Bernstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Bernstein of Edenton, N.C., and Dr. Brian Joseph Waldron, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Waldron of Brooklyn, N.Y., were married yesterday. Mayor John Calabrese of Cliffside Park, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Palisadium in Cliffside Park. Mrs. Waldron, the copy chief of Esquire magazine in New York, graduated from Syracuse University. Dr. Waldron, a graduate of Tufts University and the New York College of Osteopathic Medicine, practices in New York.

title: In Albany, Assembly Turns Debate Over to the Public
description: It is perhaps a tribute to the spirit of democracy in New York State that when the Assembly opened its chamber to the public this weekend for an open debate, many participants did not hesitate to use their time at the microphone to condemn their hosts.

title: Pearson to Buy Rest of Camco
description: Camco Inc., a leading maker of oil production equipment, said yesterday that it would be taken private in a $29-a-share tender offer by Pearson Inc., the United States subsidiary of Pearson P.L.C. of Britain.

title: Danish Skydiver Dies in Fall
description: A member of the Danish national skydiving team plunged to his death Saturday after being knocked unconscious in an aerial collision with another skydiver. The coroner's office identified the dead skydiver as Allan Bergstein, 27 years old. The other skydiver, Mads Larsen, 33, suffered a broken leg.

title: Watch for a Historic Auto Pact
description: The collective bargaining that begins today between the United Automobile Workers and General Motors and the Ford Motor Company could be the most critical labor talks in the last half century.

title: DICK WELLSTOOD, A JAZZ PIANIST, IS DEAD AT 59
description: Dick Wellstood, one of the younger jazzmen who kept the traditions alive in the years after World War II, died of heart failure Friday in Palo Alto, Calif., where he went to attend the Peninsula Jazz Party. He was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bridge: Unheralded Team Captures Spingold Knockout Victory
description: An unheralded foursome snatched a victory here Saturday night in one of the most exciting Spingold Knockout finals in the event's 63-year history.

title: Jersey Hospital Costs Lower Than Average
description: The cost of a stay in a New Jersey hospital was 13 percent less than the national average in 1985, and the state showed the lowest five-year increase in daily Medicare charges, according to a New Jersey Hospital Association report.

title: Advertising; Family Circle's New Pitch
description: THE first Family Circle ad campaign from Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton breaks today in the trade press, showing off a new theme line: ''For the Women of Today Raising the Generation of Tomorrow.''

title: FEMALE UMPIRE AWAITS FAVORABLE CALL FROM MAJORS
description: WHEN Pam Postema dresses for work, she changes her clothes in a corner of a concrete locker room shared by three male co-workers. At Rosenblatt Stadium here, where the Class AAA Omaha Royals are about to face the Iowa Cubs with Postema umpiring behind the plate, her working conditions are better than in most of the other stadiums on the minor-league circuit: There is actually a door that separates the dressing room from the shower and toilet.

title: Advertising; New Softness President
description: Carol Brady Blades, 39, has been named president and chief operating officer at the Softness Group, a public relations firm, where she started in 1969 as an intern from New York University's journalism program. Mrs. Blades, who became an executive vice president at Softness 10 years later, has held every position within the account management division.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Dukakis appeals to the part of the Democratic Party that worries about the price of BMW's and cappuccino machines. Gephardt appeals to the part that worries about layoffs and plant closings. They are button A and button B on trade and the other Democratic candidates are in danger of being submerged by that polarization.'' - Kevin P. Phillips, a Republican political analyst. [ D5:1. ]

title: INSIDE
description: Backstage White House

title: BORK AT YALE: COLLEGUES RECALL A FRIEND BUT A PHILOSOPHICAL FOE
description: Harry H. Wellington, professor and former dean at Yale Law School, longtime faculty colleague and next-door neighbor here of Robert H. Bork, recalled the day he heard of his friend's nomination to the Supreme Court.

title: They Are Not Heard On Capitol Hill
description: To the Editor:

title: Lourdes Lopez of City Ballet Weds Lionel Saporta
description: Lourdes Lopez, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Felix Lopez of Miami, was married yesterday to Lionel Rene Saporta, the son of Dr. Mathilde Nicolaides Saporta of Montauk, L.I., and the late Rene Saporta. The ceremony was performed at St. Clement's Roman Catholic Church in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., by Deacon Daniel Boyd.

title: Mattingly Museum
description: In his fourth full season with the Yankees, Don Mattingly has already made it to Cooperstown. Then, again, all the Yankees will be there today when they play the Atlanta Braves in the Hall of Fame exhibition game at 9,980-seat Doubleday Field.

title: Seoul Journal; His Dream Is Democracy; His Nightmare, a Coup
description: These days, when Kim Dae Jung takes an afternoon nap as his driver goes along the Han River here, the road behind him is clear.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Rent Party

title: ROYALS STAY CLOSE DESPITE HARD TIMES
description: LEAD: AS anyone equally familiar with baseball and life knows, certainty is fool's gold and mystery is the coin of the realm. In baseball, as in life, things happen that are not always supposed to happen. Sometimes, in baseball, that adds up to an afternoon or season of charm and excitement - but sometimes, there is more in this sum than anyone ever calculated or needed.

title: U.S. CAN RETALIATE FOR MINING IN GULF, WEINBERGER WARNS
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the United States would increase its ability to detect and destroy mines in the Persian Gulf, and was ''perfectly capable'' of retaliating against whatever force put mines in the way of merchant ships bound for Kuwait.

title: ISRAELIS GAINING GROUND IN RESTORING AFRICA TIES
description: ''Shalom, Shamir'' chanted African dancers as the Israeli Star of David fluttered alongside the green-red-and-yellow flag of this West African nation.

title: Sports World Specials
description: It was Mookie Wilson's turn to conduct one of those summer sports clinics for New York youngsters, but when the Mets' outfielder got to the gym in the basement of a Bronx school one day last week, instead of facing a group of 150 budding baseball players eager for instruction, he found himself surrounded by a horde of pubescent news hounds on the scent of a scoop.

title: MUSIC: DOLLIE DE LUXE BLENDS IDIOMS
description: THOSE among us who, in their spare time, seek the meaning of life reserve a special reverence for the connection-makers of this world. When the historian Barbara Tuchman showed how closely the 14th century resembled our own, we shuddered a little at the significance of it all. Point out resonances of El Greco in the painting of Dali, and we luxuriate in the same kind of knowing irony.

title: BACKSTAGE VIEW EMERGES OF THE PRESIDENT'S MISSTATEMENT ON THE IRAN-CONTRA AFFAIR
description: The testimony of Secretary of State George P. Shultz last week and documents offered as evidence in the Iran-contra hearings provide a backstage look at why President Reagan made misleading statements about the Iran arms sales soon after they were disclosed.

title: STORM HITS OPEN, SUSPENDING PLAY
description: A violent and damaging thunderstorm with wind gusts over 60 miles an hour struck the Plainfield Country Club shortly before noon today, forcing the United States Golf Association to suspend play in the final round of the 42d United States Women's Open until Monday.

title: Tool Orders Rose 9.4% Last Month
description: New orders for American-made machine tools rose 9.4 percent in June, after strongly encouraging increases in May, and shipments increased 11.9 percent, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

title: Heart Donations Must Be Asked For
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Ad Tax Challenge
description: As they had promised they would, the Association of National Advertisers went to Circuit Court in Tallahassee, Fla., on Friday to challenge the constitutionality of Florida's 5 percent sales and use tax on advertising, which went into effect July 1. The complaint cites the state Constitution on free speech guarantees and the United States Constitution on its free speech, commerce and due process clauses.

title: Storms Bring Relief, at Last, From the Heat
description: There was a price to be paid - thunderstorms and some power failures -but the heat wave that grilled the New York region with 90-degree temperatures and worse for nine straight days came to an abrupt, and merciful, end yesterday.

title: Dollar's Fall Helps U.S. Profits
description: After screaming about being priced out of markets when the dollar soared in the first half of the decade, companies across the United States are beginning to see its decline translate into healthier earnings.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chrysler's Maserati Unit 'More Fun' to New Chief
description: LEAD: Slowing down was not what Donald P. Morrissey had in mind when he took an early retirement last Thursday from the Chrysler Corporation to manage one of its smallest subsidiaries. Now, he peels out of his driveway each morning and roars to his new job in Baltimore as chairman and chief executive of Maserati Automobiles Inc., the distributor of the Italian sports car in North America.

title: Questionable Municipal Bonds
description: In December 1985 and again in August 1986, the municipal bond market was the scene of frantic deal-making, as bond attorneys and securities dealers worked around the clock with local government officials to complete financings that would soon be banned by changes in Federal tax laws.

title: WELFARE OVERHAUL IMPERILED BY QUIBBLES
description: A historic overhaul of the welfare system appears within reach by the end of this year, but disputes over details might torpedo any agreement, key figures from both parties said today.

title: ASTROS CREATE LATE NIGHTMARE
description: The Mets lost the pennant yesterday. Not the one that's decided in October; the one that flies on the center-field flagpole in Shea Stadium, just below the American flag. Somebody sneaked over the fence between 8 and 9 o'clock yesterday morning, lowered the pennant and took it away.

title: Tempers Add to Danger Of Roads in California
description: A man in a sports car fired a gun at a pickup truck in heavy traffic today in the latest of eight highway shootings that have left two people dead and one critically wounded this summer.

title: Riot Police Quell Disturbance
description: Law-enforcement officers in riot gear used tear gas to break up a disturbance early today after 1,500 to 2,000 youths, in town to watch hydroplane races, began throwing bottles and rocks at police officers.

title: CASTRO WARNS AGAINST TRAITORS
description: Still badly shaken by the defection two months ago of a hero air force general, President Fidel Castro tonight lashed out at ''miserable and repugnant traitors'' who, he said, betray the Cuban revolution.

title: Frederick Gilland Henry Marries Sylvia Reynolds
description: At Knowles Memorial Chapel at Rollins College in Winter Park, Fla., Sylvia Ruth Reynolds, the daughter of Judge and Mrs. George S. Reynolds of Lawrence, Kan., was married yesterday to Frederick Gilland Henry, a son of Mrs. John A. Henry of Orangeburg, S.C., and the late Mr. Henry. The Rev. Dr. Robert L. Hock, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Arnold Wettstein of the United Church of Christ and dean of the chapel.

title: THE ALLURE OF LONGER HAIR
description: A QUICK flick through magazines, a brief glance around the street or a short walk through a hair salon confirms that once again longer hair is ''in'' for women. Most men insist it never should have gone out. If hair, as psychologists say, is a medium of communication between the sexes, then a woman's longer hair may ease the introductions.

title: Mayor to the Rescue In Boston House Fire
description: When a fire broke out in a neighborhood he was visiting, Mayor Raymond Flynn raced to the scene ahead of the firefighters, kicked his way into a burning house and helped an elderly, handicapped man to safety.

title: Advertising; Spy Magazine Raises Rate Base and Rates
description: Spy magazine, started as a local phenomenon, is preparing its eighth issue, with a new advertising rate base as of July. It has gone to 40,000, from 25,000, and the rates are being increased as well.

title: Miss Rowse and J. B. Spero Wed in Massachusetts
description: The wedding of Ellen Rowse, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Rowse of Acton, Mass., to Joshua B. Spero, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Spero of Great Neck, L.I., took place yesterday in Littleton, Mass. Rabbi Allan Press and the Rev. Robert Hadley, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Harvey.

title: Karen Olin Wed To J. G. Heimann
description: Karen Olin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton J. Olin of Livingston, N.J., was married yesterday to Joshua Gaines Heimann, the son of Margaret Fechheimer Heimann and John Gaines Heimann, both of New York. Rabbi Leonard Beerman, an uncle of the bridegroom, officiated at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE EUROPEAN TRIBE. By Caryl Phillips. 129 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15.95.

title: Winning Streak Reaches 29 Games
description: The Salt Lake Trappers, an independent collection of players rebuffed by the major leagues, continued to add to the longest winning streak in professional baseball history today by beating Pocatello, 8-6, for their 29th straight victory.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Fading Bosworth Fans
description: LEAD: Can a Day-Glo mohawk and a supercharged mouth find a home in a sea of flannel shirts and self-proclaimed nice guys? That's the question Seattle Seahawk fans have been asking since the team picked up Brian Bosworth, the flamboyant Oklahoma linebacker, in the June 12 supplemental draft.

title: Business and the Law; Hunts' Tactics May Pay Off
description: THE William Herbert Hunt trust estate, the largest privately held trust to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, has repeatedly used extraordinary legal tactics. The reorganization plan filed last Wednesday by the trust's attorneys was more of the same, according to lawyers involved in the case.

title: DIFFICULTY IS LURE OF SALTWATER FLY FISHING
description: SALTWATER fly fishing isn't wildly popular in the Northeast, but some of those who do turn to it lose interest in all other forms of angling.

title: General Noriega's Ugly Desperation
description: The people of Panama gave a clear cry for freedom yesterday in a nationwide general strike. The strongman, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, seeing it coming, acted brutally to snuff it out. He closed the opposition newspapers hours before the strike. Then his troops stormed the home of the army officer who had fingered him as the architect of a series of murders and frauds, and arrested the renegade colonel.

title: BILLY JOEL HAS A TANTRUM
description: Billy Joel surprised his Soviet audience at a concert tonight when he lost his temper, overturned an electric piano and smashed a microphone onstage.

title: KEY RATES
Popcorn on the Brain
description: A month of movies:

title: MOORE MCCORMACK REOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $1,603,000 for the quarter and $4,533,000 for the 6 months, and a loss on the on the disposal of discontinued operations of $89,929,000 for the quarter and 6 months. The results for the year-ago periods include a writedown of $36,680,000 of the valuation of oil and gas properties.

title: PUGET SOUND BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The figures reflect the company's merger with Puget Sound Savings Bank in July 1986 which was treated as a pooling of interests.

title: EI DU PONT DE NEMOURS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest second quarter results include a non-recurring benefit of $18 million, or 7 cents a share, for gain from the sale of businesses, offset by early redemption of debt and the writeoff of inactive coal mines and previously capitalized well costs.

title: MCA's Chief Returns
description: MCA Inc.'s chairman and chief executive, Lew R. Wasserman, returned to work today after undergoing surgery June 24 at Cedars Sinai Medical Center. Mr. Wasserman, 74 years old, controls 15.3 percent of the stock of MCA, an entertainment and real estate conglomerate.

title: Longshoremen's Union Elects Successor to Teddy Gleason
description: The executive vice president of the International Longshoremen's Association, John M. Bowers, was elected president of the union last week at its convention in Bal Harbour, Fla. He succeeds Thomas W. (Teddy) Gleason, who retired after 24 years in the post.

title: SPRINKLER FAILED LONG BEFORE FIRE THAT KILLED 7
description: The sprinkler system in a Harlem apartment tower had not been working for at least several months and possibly years before a fire that killed seven people on March 22, the head of a special Fire Department inquiry said yesterday.

title: NASA's Will to Fly Is Questioned
description: The American space agency has become excessively cautious since the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger and ''has lost the will to fly men in space,'' says the editor of the 1987 edition of Jane's Spaceflight Directory.

title: U.S. SAYS MILITARY CRACKDOWN MAY WIDEN PANAMA DISSENT
description: American policy makers said today they were expecting opposition to military rule to increase in Panama as a result of the latest crackdown.

title: Market Adds to Gains; Dow Up 8.61
description: The stock market continued to regain the ground it lost early last week, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 8.61 points, to 2,493.94.

title: Speculation Widening On Baldrige Successor
description: Deputy Commerce Secretary Clarence J. (Bud) Brown Jr. took over as Acting Secretary today in a department still in shock over the death Saturday of Malcolm Baldrige.

title: JUDGE DENIES BAIL FOR SUSPECT IN SEX ATTACKS ON 3 QUEENS WOMEN
description: A 41-year-old man who has spent half his life in prison was ordered held without bail yesterday on charges of having committed three recent sexual assaults on women in central Queens.

title: Lincoln Center Institute Gets a New Chairman
description: Edward J. Mortola, the Chancellor of Pace University, has taken over as chairman of the Lincoln Center Institute, the educational arm of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. He replaces Francis Keppel, who retired from the post last month and who is to serve as chairman emeritus of the institute's board.

title: KEEP DEMOCRACY IN BASEBALL ALL-STAR VOTE
description: To the Editor:

title: A Poll on Leaking
description: Leaking is generally defined as anonymously providing journalists with information they would not otherwise have received, often subject to verification elsewhere. It is widely believed to be one of Washington's favorite exercises, and a poll by American Politics, a local magazine, does nothing to discourage that belief.

title: RICHMOND HILL SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $1,667,000 for the quarter and $3,110,000 for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary credits of $1,018,000 for the quarter and $2,403,000 for the 6 months. The bank converted to stock form July 21, 1986.

title: Dance: Charles Moulton And Urban Bush Women
description: CHARLES MOULTON and Jawole Willa Jo Zollar, director of the Urban Bush Women, are very dissimilar experimental choreographers. But both collaborate closely and regularly with a specific composer. This aspect came impressively to the fore Sunday night when they shared the bill in the Serious Fun! series at Alice Tully Hall.

title: U.S. and Soviet Scientists Cooperate in Space
description: WHEN a Soviet biological satellite is launched in mid-September, carrying 10 laboratory rats and two monkeys, American radiation-detection sensors will be on board and American scientists on the ground will study the effects of zero gravity and space radiation on animals.

title: Harness Racing Notebook; ELITE PACING GROUP IS A DISAPOINTMENT
description: Until Sunday night's Cane Pace at Yonkers Raceway, the first leg of the triple crown for pacers, this season was considered to have the best crop of pacers in several years.

title: Where's Nicaragua?
description: To the Editor:

title: Meese and Others On the Iran-Contra Affair
description: Nov. 25, 1986: ''The only persons in the United States Government that knew precisely about this - the only person -was Lieut. Col. Oliver North. Admiral Poindexter did know that something of this nature was occurring, but he did not look into it further . . . C.I.A. Director Casey, Secretary of State Shultz, Secretary of Defense Weinberger, myself, other members of the N.S.C. staff, none of us knew.'' Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, announcing the diversion of Iran arms sales money to the contras Dec. 2: ''I discussed with the Director of the F.B.I. on Friday the whole matter of whether the F.B.I. should be involved, and we both agreed that there was no legal basis to involve the F.B.I. because there was no even suggestion of anything criminal which would justify legally their entrance into the matter.'' Mr. Meese, speaking of his investigation that discovered the diversion Dec. 17: ''I have no personal information, received no information that there was anyone higher in the Administration who authorized diversion of the money.'' Mr. Meese June 28, 1987: ''I think there's no question in my mind that I have at no time done anything improper or illegal.'' Mr. Meese July 15: ''I thought it was a very good idea. I personally approved it. . . . The buck stops here with me. I made the decision. I thought I had the authority to do it.'' Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter, testifying before the Iran-contra committees about his response to Colonel North's suggestion in February 1986 that money from the Iran arms sales be diverted to the contras. July 18: ''I tend to believe it was a case of gross incompetence, not criminalintent. I guess it is better to be dumb than crooked.'' Senator Warren B. Rudman, vice chairman of the Iran-contra committee, when asked whether Mr. Meese had mishandled the investigation or was part of a cover-up.

title: PHILIPPINES OPENS NEW LEGISLATURE
description: The first Philippine legislature of the post-Marcos era opened here today amid the chants of leftist protesters and the threat of a right-wing terrorist attack.

title: The Trouble With Charts
description: THE profusion of graphics software on the market today has made the creation of visuals a breeze. But that does not mean that the flood of graphs and charts being churned out by home computers are good visuals. In fact, many of them are downright confusing.

title: Futures Agency Post
description: Kalo A. Hineman, a commissioner with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, has been elected acting chairman of the agency. He succeeds Susan M. Phillips, who left last Thursday. Mr. Hineman will serve as head of the commission until the President names a permanent chairman. Industry and Congressional sources said that Mr. Hineman appeared to be the top candidate for the position.

title: No Adverse Effect Seen at Citicorp
description: Between April and June, Citicorp's Investment Bank ran a series of full-page advertisements in a number of publications featuring huge photographs of Thomas C. Theobald, the vice chairman who headed the unit. Apparently, the ads were as much intended to promote the 50-year-old Mr. Theobald as the bank itself.

title: Allen Saalburg, 88, Director Of W.P.A. Murals in the 30's
description: Allen Saalburg, a painter and silk-screen artist who headed a murals project of the Works Progress Administration during the 1930's in New York City, died of pneumonia and complications resulting from a stroke, in Flemington, N.J., Saturday. He was 88 years old and lived in Uhlerstown, Pa.

title: CONCRETE COMPANY GIVEN 2D CHANCE BY KOCH
description: A company that New York City helped establish to make concrete at lower prices produced its first 100 cubic yards of concrete yesterday. In doing so, the company averted a threat from Mayor Koch to cancel its contract for failure to operate.

title: New Disney Ride
description: The Walt Disney Company said that a new 100,000-square-foot exhibit, billed as a ride through the human body, would open at the Epcot Center Disney World in Orlando, Fla., by 1989. The company declined to disclose figures, but said the exhibit would be the most expensive ever built at the center. The exhibit is similar to ''Star Tours,'' a $32 million attraction that opened this year at Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif.

title: New York Reneges on Job Promise to Many Students
description: A Board of Education program that promised summer jobs to 3,500 New York City students has placed only several hundred of them.

title: PARCELLS'S DRUG VIGILANCE
description: When the Giants opened training camp yesterday, only the rookies and the quarterbacks and a few other players were there. The entire squad isn't due to report to Pace University in Pleasantville, N.Y., until Friday when all the Giants' authors will be in uniform before any of their books are in the stalls.

title: SHULTZ WILL TALK TO SHEVARDNADZE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet Foreign Minister, have agreed to hold talks in September on arms control, officials said today.

title: In Paris, Youth Is the New Wave
description: A fresh wind seems to have wafted over the world of couture fashion here, resulting in clothes that are younger, livelier and more inventive than they have been in years. It is as if the spirit of Christian Lacroix, who introduced his successful fall and winter collection Sunday, had loosened the bonds of tradition and stimulated long-established houses to take some bold, new steps. Very young-looking clothes are seen everywhere.

title: Illuminating Co.
description: The United Illuminating Company is offering $100 million of 12 percent debentures due in 2017 at a price of 99, to yield 12 1/8 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The debentures, which are rated Baa-3 by Moody's and BBB- by S.&P., were offered to yield 3 1/4 percentage points more than 30-year Treasury bonds.

title: Navy Forgoes Courts-Martial for Officers of Stark
description: The Navy said today that it would not court-martial the captain or other officers of the frigate Stark, on which 37 sailors were killed in an attack by an Iraqi jet in the Persian Gulf in May.

title: RASMUSSEN MAKES COMEBACK, OF SORTS
description: Someone asked Dennis Rasmussen what his mailing address is.

title: TOLL IN HAITI IS PUT AT 50 OR MORE
description: Witnesses to a brutal battle last week have given grisly accounts of peasants and sharecroppers fighting with machetes and metal spikes in a clash that killed at least 50 people.

title: One Case, One Judge. Then What?
description: A sensible way to judge the judges: that was how Chief Judge Sol Wachtler portrayed his new system of assigning cases. Now, too quietly to affect much judicial behavior, he has released the first report card. It offers useful information but not enough. Judge Wachtler and Chief Administrative Judge Albert Rosenblatt merit only an Incomplete.

title: MACMILLAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pretax gain on disposition of software division of $3,833,000 for the quarter and 6 months, and pretax gains on securities and dividends of $41,000 and $288,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a pretax gain of $1,898,000 on disposition of G. Schirmer for the quarter and 6 months, pretax gains on securities and dividends of $1,634,000 and $1,718,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The 6 months also includes a pretax gain of $3,723,000 on the sale of joint ventures.

title: DeLeon Injured
description: Jose DeLeon, a pitcher for the Chicago White Sox, suffered slight injuries to his jaw and back in a traffic accident yesterday and missed his starting assignment last night at Tiger Stadium in Detroit. DeLeon was treated at Hinsdale Hospital in Chicago and released yesterday afternoon, said Stuart Wade, a White Sox spokesman. Wade said DeLeon was on his way to O'Hare International Airport to catch a flight to Detroit early yesterday when the car accident occurred. DeLeon's wife and his child were in the car with him but were unhurt.

title: WESTERN UNION CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $10.3 million on the sale of a cellular telephone subsidiary and income of $2.5 million resulting from the receipt of a payment in settlement of litigation. c-After net from discontinued operations of $1,516,000 and $7,173,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; and a gain of $6,000,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations for both the quarter and 6 months; and the 6-month is also after an extraordinary loss of $1,940,000. The company said the extraordinary loss includes $4.1 million of expenses associated with the exchange of certain notes payable, partially offset by a $2.2 million gain from the termination of a subsidiary's pension plan during the year-ago first quarter.

title: Sparks Tuneup Account Is Awarded to Messner
description: Sparks Tuneup Centers, one of the more recent creations of Anthony A. Martino, father of Aamco and Maaco, has taken its advertising account to Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey. Billings should be $4 million.

title: 'Pygmalion' to Close
description: ''Pygmalion,'' a revival of George Bernard Shaw's 1914 comedy starring Peter O'Toole, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Plymouth Theater. Directed by Val May, the play will have run for 15 previews and 113 regular performances.

title: Women, Aging and Candor
description: Going public about birthdays is becoming the thing to do among a new breed of feminists - the glamour women in their 40's and 50's. Not that there isn't a lot of lying still going on, among men as well as women.

title: Genrad to Close Testing Unit
description: Genrad Inc. said today that it was discontinuing operations at its semiconductor test division in Milpitas, Calif. The company, based in Concord, Mass., is a major manufacturer of electronic test systems.

title: Profit Triples At Compaq
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation, benefiting from a major change in products by its archrival, the International Business Machines Corporation, said today that its profits more than tripled in the second quarter, to $30.7 million, or 80 cents a share.

title: SOVIET REPORTS IT EXECUTED NAZI GUARD U.S. EXTRADITED
description: Feodor S. Fedorenko, an 80-year-old former Nazi death camp guard who was deported from the United States in 1984, has been executed, the official press agency Tass reported today.

title: CRANE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $10,145,000 gain from a change in accounting. Share earnings are fully diluted and reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in May 1987.

title: A Hero's Welcome
description: O'Connell Street, the most famous thoroughfare in Dublin, was packed yesterday as an estimated quarter of a million people welcomed home Stephen Roche, the first Irishman ever to win the Tour de France bicycle race. The 27-year-old Roche, who beat Pedro Delgado of Spain by 40 seconds, was driven - on four wheels -through the Irish capital, his native city. Escorted by police on horseback, the motorcade took almost half an hour to negotiate the 200 meters of O'Connell Street because of crowds 20 deep, many waving the green, white and orange Irish flag. Side streets had to be blocked off as Roche and his French wife, Lydia, passed by carrying the Tour de France winner's yellow jersey.

title: DEMJANJUK, ON THE STAND, DENIES GUILT
description: John Demjanjuk took the witness stand for the first time today and insisted that he was not the Nazi ''hangman or henchman'' Israel was looking for.

title: NL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $34,765,000 for the quarter and $60,977,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss d-After a loss of $897,000 for the quarter and net of $36,981,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. There were no share earnings in the latest quarter because of preferred dividend requirements and net from discontinued operations not attributable to common stockholders. The year-ago results include a charge of about $247.7 million, most of which resulted from a writedown of the carrying value of certain assets and the cost of other restructuring activities.

title: Ford Tractor Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company plans to retool its tractor plant in Romeo, Mich., to produce new engines by mid-1990. Ford has completed feasibility studies on the project, expected to cost more than $900 million, and will begin conversion of the 1.4-million-square-foot plant in mid-1988, a Ford executive said. The company declined release further details on the new engines.

title: FIRST PENNSYLVANIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $5,287,000 for the quarter and $9,373,000 for the 6 months, and a special $100 million addition to reserves for possible loan losses resulting from debt in Brazil and other lesser developed countries for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income and includes tax benefits of $3,786,000 for the quarter and $7,079,000 for the 6 months.

title: Exclusionary Zoning and the Small Developer
description: To the Editor:

title: BOEING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Continental Illinois Gets New Chief
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation, the parent of the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company, yesterday named Thomas C. Theobald chairman and chief executive.

title: People
description: * Dawn Sibley has been promoted to executive vice president-director of media and communications services at Ally Gargano/MCA Advertising.

title: Using Debt to Save Nature
description: LEAD: Bolivia's commitment to protect more than four million acres of forest and grasslands in the Amazonian lowlands of the Beni River in return for foreign-debt relief of $650,000 signals a new and promising approach to two of Latin America's most pressing problems: the debt crisis and environmental degradation.

title: INTERNATIONAL FLAVORS & FRAGRANCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GOVERNORS' SEARCH FOR AGENDA LEADS TO ACTIVISM
description: Moving easily from the language of free markets to bold calls for government action, the nation's governors are seeking this week to establish a political agenda for the 1988 campaign.

title: Have the Flu? Don't Drive
description: Influenza impairs a driver's reaction time even more than does a ''moderate'' dose of alcohol, according to a group of British researchers.

title: OPPOSITION GROWS TO SRI LANKA PACT
description: Opposition against a planned peace treaty in the country's ethnic conflict grew today from both extremes as well as from within the Sri Lankan Government itself.

title: Trappers Stopped at 29
description: A three-run homer by Eddie Taubensee capped a six-run first inning for Billings, which hung on to defeat Salt Lake City Trappers, 7-5, tonight and end the longest winning streak in professional baseball history at 29 games.

title: Fatigue 'Virus' Has Experts More Baffled And Skeptical Than Ever
description: MEDICAL experts are struggling, with only limited success, to understand a mysterious illness that leaves its victims exhausted for months or years at a time.

title: ASARCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses of $8 million and $29.8 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from its equity in the results of associated companies located in Australia, Mexico and Peru. c-Net loss The company said in the latest second quarter preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income. Year-ago second quarter results included income of $4 million from the liquidation of excess metal inventory valued on a LIFO basis; and year-ago 6-month results also benefited from first-quarter income of $9 million from a rights offering by M.I.M. Holdings Ltd., an associated company, and $3.9 million from a reduction of Asarco's interest in the Wiluna Gold project in Australia.

title: CONCERT: ACADEMY OF ST. MARTIN PLAYS AT FESTIVAL
description: THROUGH no direct fault of their own, the Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields and its conductor, Neville Marriner, have achieved a certain ubiquity in our country. Darlings of public radio stations across the land, they are never far from the lips of American classical disk jockeys, who find in their frequent and competent recordings of the 18th-century orchestral literature just what their contributing customers like.

title: ON CONGESTED HIGHWAYS, CALIFORNIA MOTORISTS TURN TO VIOLENCE
description: Motorists here, displaying hair-trigger impulses reminiscent of the frontier West, have tangled with each other in a string of highway shootings that have left two people dead and four injured over the past five weeks.

title: Oil Rig Count Falls by 5
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States this week totaled 917, down five from the previous week, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. ''It's just a random fluctuation; I wouldn't read that much into it,'' said Ike Kerridge, a spokesman for Baker Hughes. In the long term, he said, ''I think it will continue to rise, but it could go up or down week to week.'' A year ago, the count totaled 716.

title: TWO JERSEY OFFICIALS GRANTED A NEW TRIAL IN CORRUPTION CASE
description: A Federal judge granted a new trial today to two convicted New Brunswick officials because a recent United States Supreme Court decision invalidated an important part of the case against them.

title: SOUTHLAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes pretax gain of $23.3 million from the sale of a half-interest in Citgo. c-Net loss

title: Davidson Is Expected To Get Kennedy Post
description: Ralph P. Davidson, a publishing executive, is expected to be named Tuesday to succeed Roger L. Stevens as chairman of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: CUMMINS ENGINE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Du Pont Net Climbs 10.5%
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's largest chemical concern, reported yesterday that its second-quarter profits climbed by 10.5 percent. At the same time, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's leading tire producer, announced a 30.6 percent gain.

title: American Express In Buyback
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it would buy back up to 40 million shares of its own stock, or 9.3 percent of the total outstanding, over the next two to three years.

title: PANAMA MILITARY ARRESTS KEY CRITIC IN NEW CRACKDOWN
