description: Attacking with guns and tear gas, security forces in Panama arrested a leading critic of the military leader today, hours after the main opposition newspaper was shut down and all radio and television stations put under censorship.

title: Cracks in a Great Dome in Florence May Point to Impending Disaster
description: AS the lofty cupola atop this city's Duomo, or cathedral, was being completed in 1434, a visitor from Rome described it as ''a structure so great, rising above the skies, large enough to shelter all the people of Tuscany in its shadow, built without the help of any centering or of much woodwork, of a craftsmanship perhaps not even the ancients knew or understood.''

title: TV Review; 'Crisis on Federal Street,' Chicago Housing Disaster
description: ''CRISIS ON FEDERAL STREET'' opens and closes with the same aerial picture: a look north toward downtown Chicago from an enormous housing project only five miles away. The camera makes it appear, though, that these are two separate cities, with a great plain in between. The view may be distorted, but it is not necessarily untrue. ''Crisis on Federal Street,'' on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, examines a social disaster.

title: Outdoor Entertainment
description: ''Music on Water,'' a free series of outdoor performances on the plaza south of 55 Water Street, is to begin on Aug. 7 at 12:15 with a performance by Elise Morris, a singer and pianist. The series, sponsored by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, will present a performance each Friday at the same time through Sept. 25. Performers include the Jeff Raheb Sextet (Aug. 14); the Jones Groupe (Aug. 21); Stephen Lockwood Ensemble (Aug. 28); Adventura (Sept. 4); Tiye Giraud (Sept. 11); Bryan Carrott Ensemble (Sept. 18); and Elliot Sokolov (Sept. 25).

title: Dallas Sells 2 Bond Issues
description: Dallas sold two general obligation bond issues totaling $71.1 million, divided between two underwriting groups led by the Chase Manhattan Capital Markets Corporation and Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: NETWORKS TAKE TURNS IN COVERING HEARINGS
description: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair will be televised live beginning at 9 A.M. today on the NBC television network under the network rotation system. The hearings will also be televised on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on some local affiliates of PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service, including Channel 13 in New York.

title: Seabrook Owner Plans Restructuring
description: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire, pushed to the brink of bankruptcy by a $2 billion investment in a nuclear reactor that may never operate, announced today that its directors had approved a capital restructuring plan.

title: AMOSKEAG BANK SHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NATIONAL BANCSHARES OF TEXAS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a non-recurring gain of $6.1 million from a land sale. c-Net income

title: INSIDE
description: Jobs Program Falls Short

title: CALIFORNIA FIRST BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GENERAL DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
National City Elects A New Chairman
description: The National City Corporation, Ohio's second-largest bank-holding company, said yesterday that Edward B. Brandon, its president, would become chairman and chief executive, effective Sept. 1.

title: U.S. Issues Little Changed
description: With investors staying on the sidelines and waiting for a flurry of Treasury auctions over the next two weeks, prices of Government securities were little changed yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JULY 28, 1987
description: Companies

title: Contras Kill Children
description: To the Editor:

title: 3Com's Chief Confident About Deal With Bridge
description: When the 3Com Corporation announced Friday that it would merge with Bridge Communications Inc., some analysts were skeptical, despite generally favorable reactions. In the last two years, 3Com had attempted two other mergers, with Convergent Technologies Inc., and then with Centram Systems West, only to have both fall through.

title: Despite Setbacks, World Control of Trade in Wildlife Expands Influence
description: DIPLOMATS from 86 nations have just banned international commerce in the world's largest parrot, the hyacinth macaw, as well as in the Corsican swallowtail butterfly, Ursini's viper, and the star cactus, among other endangered species.

title: Titanic Survivor Sees Salvagers as 'Vultures'
description: A survivor of the Titanic sinking said today that salvagers were greedy ''vultures'' for taking artifacts from the wreck, which became a grave for her father and 1,512 other people 75 years ago.

title: 6-Year-Old Girl Fatally Shot
description: A 7-year-old boy shot and killed his younger sister Sunday in an accident that occurred while they played with a pistol their parents kept in the house, the police said. The sister, Jennifer Olivera, 6, was critically wounded by a shot from a .22-caliber semiautomatic pistol, according to a police spokesman, Lieut. Ken Jeske. He added that the pistol was kept in a gun case on a top closet shelf and the children somehow got it down. The girl died in a hospital. The police declined to make public the name of her brother.

title: Judge in a Right-to-Die Case Backs Treating AIDS Patient
description: In a decision that right-to-die advocates said could affect thousands of AIDS patients, a judge yesterday ruled that Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan could continue drug treatments on a man suffering from an AIDS-related brain infection.

title: TIMKEN COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a gain of $85,474,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting methods in prior years. Year-ago figures are restated to reflect the change in accounting method.

title: JIM BISHOP, A COLUMNIST, DIES: POPULAR AUTHOR OF 21 BOOKS
description: Jim Bishop, a reporter and columnist who wrote his way onto the best-seller lists with his hour-by-hour formula and you-are-there style, died Sunday of respiratory failure at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 79 years old.

title: TOUGH QUESTIONING IS AWAITING MEESE
description: When Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d made his startling announcement last November that profits from the Iran arms sale had been diverted to Nicaraguan rebels, he drew praise from even longtime detractors.

title: JETS LAUD ROOKIE; VICK STANDS OUT
description: Who were those 100 people wearing Jets' uniforms today, flexing their muscles, growling and trying to look good?

title: COMPAQ COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Telegraphed Punches
description: To the Editor:

title: Chess: Is It Really Luck That Wins For Vaganian - or Insight?
description: The Leningrad International Tournament, celebrating the 70th anniversary of the October Revolution, was won by Rafael Vaganian of the Soviet Union, who scored 8-4.

title: Stride Rite Picks President
description: The Stride Rite Corporation, which makes children's shoes, has elected Michael W. Rayden president and chief operating officer, effective next Monday.

title: CARNER, DAVIES, OKAMOTO IN TIE
description: JoAnne Carner missed the chance to win her third United States Women's Open championship today when she three- putted the final hole for her only bogey of the round and fell into a tie after 72 holes with Ayako Okamoto of Japan and Laura Davies of England.

title: Careers; View From Top and The Middle
description: IS your boss - your company's chief executive officer - average?

title: International Network Nourishes Avant-Garde
description: As experimental performance work attracts a growing audience around the country, a loosely affiliated network of producers, festivals, performing spaces, museums and broadcasting outlets has sprung up to nurture and promote what is often called ''interarts'' work or ''new theater.''

title: Pickens May Buy Into Boeing
description: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman and corporate raider, has indicated his intention to acquire as much as a 15 percent stake in the Boeing Company, the aircraft maker said today.

title: Long Meatpacker Strike Ends
description: Members of the United Food and Commercial Workers will begin returning to work at the IBP Inc. meatpacking plant on Aug. 3 after a seven-month walkout.

title: African Art Settling In at New Home
description: For most of its 23 years, the Museum of African Art has lived a stepchild's existence among the grand museums of Washington, making do in a row of nine town houses on Capitol Hill, a few blocks behind the Supreme Court.

title: The Decency of Malcolm Baldrige
description: Malcolm Baldrige, the Secretary of Commerce, who died in a rodeo accident Saturday, brought decency and a cool head to the upper reaches of politics. In an Administration often marred by zealotry, he stood for soft-spoken reason.

title: Bankers Trust
description: The Bankers Trust Company is offering $100 million of 8.35 percent deposit notes due in 1990 at a price of 100 through Goldman, Sachs & Company as sole underwriter. The notes are rated Aa-1 by Moody's and AA+ by S.&P., and were offered to yield about 57-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury notes of similar maturity. The notes are not callable before February 1989.

title: Bork as Stranger
description: Despite all reports that President Reagan and Judge Robert H. Bork, his choice for the Supreme Court vacancy, are political and ideological soul mates, the two scarcely know each other. Mr. Bork told an interviewer that he had met the President only once before he went to the White House this month to be formally offered the post. That was at a private dinner in a Washington home in December 1980. ''That's the extent of my acquaintanceship,'' said Mr. Bork, who has said he was not asked about legal issues or his personal views at any time in pre-nomination interviews.

title: Britain's TV for Children
description: COMPARED with American programming, British television is a children's paradise. But broadcasters and educators are worried that it might turn into a paradise lost if the Thatcher Government's plans to deregulate the industry materialize.

title: NORANDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes unusual gains of $900,000 for the quarter and $26.5 million for the 6 months. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Marva Collins to Open 2d School in California
description: Marva Collins, whose education efforts on behalf of inner-city students have earned her national attention, is planning to open a second school in California with the help of a local fund-raising committee.

title: A PRIVATE PANEL DUE TO EXAMINE NEW YORK CRIME
description: City Councilman Wendell Foster, a Bronx Democrat who is also president of a coalition of black ministers, said yesterday that the group would create a commission next month to look into the causes of crime, racism and poverty in New York City.

title: A Trove of Faulkner Film Scripts
description: William Faulkner worked on 17 film scripts in the 30's and 40's -originals, adaptations and collaborations with more seasoned screenwriters. His Hollywood output added up to 2,500 typescript pages - the length of a very thick, unwritten novel.

title: Browning-Ferris Aiding Inquiries
description: Browning-Ferris Industries said it was cooperating with several Federal grand juries investigating possible illegal pricing practices in the trash-hauling industry. The antitrust division of the Justice Department said that 11 grand juries, primarily in the South and Northeast, were investigating charges of bid-rigging, price-fixing and the splitting up of customers and territories.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JULY 28, 1987
description: International A2-9

title: New F.A.A. Chief Sworn In
description: T. Allan McArtor was sworn in today as chief of the Federal Aviation Administration and promised to take steps designed to reduce delays and improve safety. Mr. McArtor, 45 years old, who had been a senior vice president for Federal Express, issued a warning to airline employees. ''Pilots, co-pilots, flight engineers and other crew members are also on notice,'' he said. ''If you are not medically qualified, if you are not drug-free, if you are not technically proficient, if you cannot demonstrate your skills, you will not fly.''

title: The U.N. Today: July 28, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: At G.E. Plant, Familiar Fears
description: At the Third Base Lounge, down the road from the General Electric Company's television assembly plant, the conversation between gulps of beer is about the recent buyout of the plant by a European electronics giant.

title: 7 Reported Killed as Israelis Raid South Lebanon
description: Seaborne Israeli commandos killed seven Lebanese Moslem militiamen and wounded four others today in a predawn ambush near Sidon, the police said.

title: MACK TRUCKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $1,003,000 for the quarter and $3,062,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $1,906,000 for the quarter and $2,832,000 for the 6 months. The quarter also includes a $5.9 million gain on the sale of unused service parts facility.

title: Nominee Airs Views on Debt
description: David S. Ruder, the White House nominee for chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told Congress today that he was not overly concerned about the level of debt building up on the balance sheets of American corporations.

title: JOHN C. SACCO
description: John C. Sacco, a composer and conductor, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: OLIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago second quarter net includes a non-recurring benefit of $16.8 million, or 74 cents a share, from surplus land sales.

title: Hero and Villain
description: To the Editor:

title: NALCO CHEMICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $3.2 million for the quarter and 6 months related to the cost from redemption of debentures.

title: On the Boardwalk: Panel Considers Access to Jersey Beaches
description: Several lawmakers pulled out folding chairs in front of a snack stand today and sat along the boardwalk to find out how the public feels about its access -or lack of access - to New Jersey's 127 miles of beachfront.

title: June Spending Up 0.7% As Incomes Gained 0.4%
description: Consumer spending climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent in June, the best showing in two months, even though Americans' incomes rose a much more modest four-tenths of 1 percent in the month, the Government reported today.

title: Fluor Head Leaves
description: The Fluor Corporation said its president and chief operating officer, John A. Wright, would step down to head a group bidding for the St. Joe Gold Corporation, a Fluor subsidiary put up for sale in May. Terms of the expected bid were not disclosed. David S. Tappan Jr., Fluor's chairman, will assume Mr. Wright's duties. The investor group includes executives from St. Joe Gold of Clayton, Mo.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Bill Aiding Farm Credit Pushed by House Chiefs
description: Leaders of the House Agriculture Committee plan to introduce legislation this week that would provide a multibillion-dollar line of credit with the Treasury to rescue the crippled Farm Credit System, committee staff members said today.

title: ALABAMA BIAS CASE NEAR RESOLUTION
description: A tentative settlement was announced today in a 15-year-old Federal lawsuit that accused the Alabama state police of discriminating against blacks in its hiring and promotion policy.

title: Elders Plans 4 New Units
description: Elders IXL Ltd., the big Australian conglomerate, said today that it planned to restructure itself, creating four public companies in brewing, finance, agribusiness and investments.

title: Loosening Up
description: Eamonn Coghlan and Marcus O'Sullivan, first- and second-place finishers, respectively, in the Wanamaker Mile at this year's Millrose Games, will run in the Bob Roggy Memorial Invitational track meet tomorrow at Holmdel High School in New Jersey. Coghlan, who will run in the two-mile race, is tuning up for the World Championships next month in Rome, where he will be defending his world championship record in the 5,000 meters. O'Sullivan will run in the 800 meters in New Jersey but, like Coghlan, will be looking ahead to Rome, where he will run in the 1,500 meters.

title: Bridge: Top-Seeded Team Is Winner Of Knockout Championship
description: Form prevailed last week in the Women's Knockout Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals in Baltimore. The title was won by the top-seeded group, all reigning world champions.

title: 'Verona' to Start Later
description: Tonight's performance of ''Two Gentlemen of Verona'' at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park will begin at 8:30 P.M. instead of the normal 8 P.M., the New York Shakespeare Festival has announced.

title: Vast Effort Aims to Reveal Oceans' Hidden Patterns
description: USING an observation method analogous to brain scanning, oceanographers are in the early stages of a bold new effort to chart the oceans' flow for clues to the world's future climate.

title: Four Theme Park Executives Are Ousted to Allay Fears
description: Four executives at the Six Flags Great Adventure theme park have been ousted after several accidents this summer that left one person dead and two others injured, corporate officials announced today.

title: Tatars Are Told by Gromyko To Cease Political Pressure
description: A group of Crimean Tatars who held a 24-hour protest in Red Square met in the Kremlin today with President Andrei A. Gromyko and were told it was not in their interest to put more pressure on the Government, the Soviet press agency Tass said.

title: Jim Walter Offer
description: The Jim Walter Corporation, among the nation's top home-building companies, said it was considering alternatives to a $2.03 billion takeover bid offered earlier this month by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the leveraged buyout specialists. Jim Walter said that other parties, which it declined to identify, had expressed interest in acquiring the company. Jim Walter's stock closed unchanged at $58.50 a share today on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Who Swung the Wrecker's Ball at the Old Met
description: To the Editor:

title: HERSHEY FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 5
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for the 3-for-1 stock split effective Sept. 15, 1986, and reflect the corporation's purchase and retirement of 3,825,000 common stock shares effective Nov. 14, 1986.

title: Tax Watch; Policy Expert Locates Flaws
description: LOOKING at the tax system he helped revamp as the Reagan Administration's chief tax policy adviser, J. Roger Mentz sees a few flaws that still need fixing. The ''crazy-quilt'' patchwork of Internal Revenue Service penalties is one of them. Some of the new tax law's foreign provisions are another.

title: NORTHEAST SAVINGS FA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $4,032,000 for the latest first quarter and $2,895,000 for the year-ago period.

title: HUGH WHEELER, AWARD WINNING PLAYWRIGHT
description: Hugh Wheeler, a playwright, novelist and screen writer who won Tony Awards for the books for the hit musicals ''A Little Night Music,'' ''Sweeney Todd'' and ''Candide,'' died of lung and heart failure yesterday. He was 75 years old and lived in Monterey, Mass.

title: Sale by Goldsmith
description: The British-French investor Sir James Goldsmith sold a major share of his press and retail group, Generale Occidentale, to the recently privatized French engineering giant, Compagnie Generale d'Electricite. Under the agreement, Sir James's 51 percent of a holding company, Trocadero Participations, was sold, and the deal gave the French company 34 percent of Generale Occidentale. Terms were not disclosed.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: GEOFFREY BEENE abruptly interrupted his vacation in Nice this month and returned to New York bearing news. He must have missed the south of France, however, because the place he chose to explain his return was Provence, the restaurant at 38 MacDougal Street that captures the essence of that lavender-scented land.

title: Koch Joins Channel 31 for Program on AIDS
description: For more than four hours tonight, New York-area television viewers can ask questions and receive information about AIDS on Channel 31, WNYC-TV. Mayor Koch, Surgeon General Dr. C. Everett Koop and Dr. Lloyd M. Moglen, a psychiatrist, will answer calls from viewers during ''AIDS in New York: An Open Dialogue.''

title: Warning on Leetch
description: Despite the fact that he was knocked out of the United States Olympic Festival with a knee injury after 40 seconds of play, Brian Leetch, the Rangers' No. 1 draft pick last season, was one of 29 players selected from the festival for the 1988 United States Olympic team training camp that begins Aug. 7 in Lake Placid, N.Y. A Ranger spokesman said, however, that Leetch had been examined by Dr. Norman Scott, the team physician, who recommended that Leetch not skate until after Labor Day. Leetch, an all-America defenseman from Boston College, is considered the best amateur player in the country. Two National Hockey League goalies - Chris Terreri of the Devils and Cleon Daskalakis of the Bruins - have also been invited to the training camp.

title: LOCAL JOURNALISTS LOOM LARGER IN THE PRESIDENTIAL CAMPAIGN
description: While Vice President Bush huddled with North Carolina Republicans in a Raleigh hotel, Bill Nigut, a television reporter, hustled down the road for some quick interviews in a bar decorated with college pennants and a life-size cardboard cutout of the actors who appear in Bartles & James wine-cooler commercials.

title: Nuclear Monitoring
description: The Defense Department is spending $43 million for construction of a 3.3-ton satellite meant to perfect the military's ability to detect and inspect nuclear materials in orbit about the earth.

title: VICTORY NO. 6,000 IS ELUDING CORDERO
description: These are not the best of times for Angel Cordero Jr. On Sunday night, celebrating the 25th anniversary of his first victory as a New York jockey, he choked on a baked clam at a local restaurant. Yesterday, as fans expectantly waited for him to score his 6,000th career victory, he rode his ninth straight loser.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What are the two most distantly related species that produced hybrid offspring? And which of the hybrids have produced fertile offspring?

title: Former North Courier Is Said to Get Immunity
description: A former Senate aide who worked as a courier for Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North has been granted immunity by the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair, according to a law enforcement official with knowledge of the investgation.

title: DRUG MAKERS FIGHTING BACK AGAINST ADVANCE OF GENERICS
description: Some manufacturers of brand-name prescription drugs, alarmed by the success of cheaper generic versions of their products, are waging a counterattack against their competition.

title: USAIR GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Business Journals Sold
description: MCP Inc., a New Orleans-based publisher, has agreed to acquire the Boston Business Journal and Boston Business Magazine, and a half share of the Providence Business News from P& L Publications Inc. Terms were not disclosed, but analysts said the publications were recently valued at $12 million. The three publications have a combined circulation of 110,000. Robert C. Bergenheim, president and founder of P&L Publications, would continue as publisher of both Boston Business Magazine and the Boston Business Journal.

title: POLITICAL COMMITTEE FOR CUOMO REPORTS RAISING OF $18,000
description: Governor Cuomo's political action committee, established in April to finance local forums for Democratic Presidential candidates, has raised $18,000, according to a report filed today with the Federal Election Commission.

title: AUTO UNION AND G.M. OPEN TALKS ON CRITICAL CONTRACT
description: The United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation opened negotiations today on a new labor contract that both sides agreed would be critical to the future of the American automobile industry and the workers in its factories.

title: Barnaby J. Feder Wed to Ms. Lowy
description: Michele Shulamit Lowy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elie Lowy of Jamaica, Queens, and Barnaby J. Feder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Feder of Foster City, Calif., were married yesterday in Sunapee, N.H., at the home of Jean Putonen, the justice of the peace who officiated.

title: SHULTZ ASKS IRAQ TO HALT ATTACKS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz met with the Iraqi Foreign Minister today and asked that Iraq take no new offensive actions in its war with Iran, State Department officials said.

title: INTERPUBLIC GROUP OF COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Another Message
description: To the Editor:

title: Each Sibling Experiences Different Family
description: BEHAVIORAL scientists studying personality differences between siblings have discovered what they describe as the overriding influence of a unique ''micro-environment'' in the family for each child.

title: JETS LAUD ROOKIE; INGRAM HOLDS OUT
description: Six months and two days after they won Super Bowl XXI, the Giants opened training camp today at Pace University's Westchester campus. The 59 players who reported included 13 of the 14 draftees, all except Mark Ingram, the wide receiver from Michigan State chosen on the first round.

title: Alcohol Abuse Cited
description: The top problem in the National Football League is alcohol abuse rather than drug abuse, according to Mike Lynn, the general manager of the Minnesota Vikings, whose quarterback, Tommy Kramer, is undergoing treatment for alcohol abuse. After being charged with drunken driving last Friday night, Kramer entered the Hazelden Foundation in Center City, Minn., Sunday to begin 28 days of rehabilitation, his second stay in a treatment center in five years. He underwent treatment for chemical dependency in California in 1982, two years after being arrested on charges of drunken driving in Houston. ''I think our No. 1 problem is drinking in the N.F.L.,'' Lynn told The Minneapolis Star and Tribune. ''I don't think it's drugs. No question about that.''

title: INCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said second quarter and 6-month results include securities gains of $3 million in 1987 and $11 million in 1986. The year-ago results include costs totaling $6.5 million for writedowns of inventories and assets in the metals reclamation business. The results are in U.S. currency.

title: Stop Pushing Nicotine
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN SAVINGS BANK, FSB OF NY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
METS ON ROAD TO RECKONING
description: It is either a golden opportunity or a terrible ordeal. But whatever it is, the Mets embark on it tonight when they open a three-game series in St. Louis against the first-place Cardinals, to be followed by a three-game series in Montreal against the second-place Expos.

title: STUDY PUTS BORK TO RIGHT OF OTHER JUDGES NAMED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan's judicial appointees have not been much more conservative than those of other recent Republican Presidents, but Judge Robert H. Bork's voting patterns show him to be far more conservative than the average Reagan appointee.

title: DOLE SUGGESTS A WAY FOR PRESIDENT TO SEAT BORK BEFORE SENATE VOTE
description: Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, added to the atmosphere of partisan confrontation surrounding the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court by suggesting today that President Reagan use a constitutional procedure to place Judge Bork on the Court without Senate confirmation.

title: A FOE OF PRETORIA DISCOVERED SLAIN
description: A black political figure was found stabbed to death near the coastal town of East London over the weekend after associates received death threats from right-wing extremists.

title: A Matter of Power
description: THE newest I.B.M. personal computer, the PC Convertible Model 3, is the latest and best version of a machine that was initially introduced in April 1986 to mixed reviews.

title: The Music In the Lab
description: SCIENTISTS and music lovers are marking the 100th anniversary of the death of Borodin, and the occasion has prompted some musing upon the wondrous wiring of the human brain.

title: Politics and Race Cars
description: In nearly 200 years of American Presidential elections, resourceful candidates have discovered innumerable ways to get their names before the voters, from billboards and buttons to skywriting. But Alexander M. Haig Jr., who is trying to rise above a low standing in the polls for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination, may have discovered a new approach.

title: KIMBERLY-CLARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Employment Surges To a 16-Year High For New York City
description: New York City stanched its loss of manufacturing jobs in the first half of this year and reached a 16-year high in overall employment while its suburban competitors faltered, the United States Labor Department announced yesterday.

title: ARMSTRONG WORLD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Those to Whom a 'Battle Royal' Is Nothing New
description: When Secretary of State George P. Shultz testified at the Iran-contra hearings, he described life in Washington as a ''battle royal,'' full of bickering, backstabbing, backbiting and unceasing conflict over policy.

title: New York to Add Foster Care For Youngsters With AIDS
description: A second foster-care agency under contract to New York City will start recruiting parents to care for children with AIDS, Mayor Koch announced yesterday at a Congressional hearing.

title: SINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $45 million pre-tax charge for higher than expected costs required to complete the development phase on three aerospace electronics programs which relate to development programs for the joint tactical information distribution system, new- generation ring-laser cyroscope guidance and navigation equipment, and another category of advanced guidance and navigation systems. c-Net income and includes income of $34.4 million and $31.6 million from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; an extraordinary credit of $18 million and a charge of $27.2 million from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting methods for both periods.

title: Pennzoil Drops Its Texaco Plan
description: J. Hugh Liedtke, chairman of the Pennzoil Company, said yesterday that his company had formally withdrawn its proposals to settle the $10 billion dispute with Texaco Inc. over Texaco's 1984 purchase of the Getty Oil Company.

title: FOUNDATIONS WIDEN EFFORTS ON AIDS
description: The nation's philanthropies have substantially increased their support for AIDS patients and programs to combat the disease in recent months, according to foundation officials.

title: Our Towns; Agony of Patients Of Mental Health Is Finding a Bed
description: In March 1986, Will Smith was medically ready to leave the Pilgrim State Psychiatric Hospital and move to a community residence home. He was anxious to get a job, to start life again. But there wasn't a bed for him in his home county, Nassau.

title: Prof. Donald R. Cressey, 68, Expert on Sociology of Crime
description: Dr. Donald R. Cressey, one of the nation's leading experts on the sociology of crime, died July 21 in Solvang, Calif. He was 68 years old. As a professor of sociology at the University of California at Santa Barbara for 26 years, Dr. Cressey wrote several highly regarded books on the causes and prevention of crime.

title: HOWARD SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The per share earnings were adjusted for 2-for-1 stock split effected in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend paid in February.

title: Opera: 'Giovanni' in Salzburg
description: SALZBURG, Austria, July 27 -In a year when all the world is celebrating the 200th anniversary of ''Don Giovanni,'' sometimes in distressingly cavalier if not actually criminal ways, Mozart's hometown could hardly overlook the opportunity to pay the respect it neglected to give the opera in the composer's lifetime.

title: ALLEGHENY POWER SYSTEMS INCALLEGHENY & WESTERN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SCHOLAR LOSES HER WAY IN BRITAIN'S 'NEW PUNJAP'
description: The scholar seems more street-smart than bookish as she barges in with all the trust of kith and kin on the humble homes of what she calls New Punjab in Old England, speaking Urdu and checking on the children, the health, the love lives of the families who are the stuff of her scholarship.

title: SALOMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said year-ago second quarter and 6-month revenue were restated to include commodity transactions on a gross profit basis.

title: John Bernard Myers, Dealer In Artworks and Literature
description: John Bernard Myers, an art dealer and writer who presented and published the work of many well-known New York artists and poets, died of cancer of the bladder Sunday night at the Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Dancing on the Green Across the roadway from the Sheep Meadow in Central Park, on the site of a former sheep pen, is 53-year-old Tavern on the Green (873-3200). It is a large restaurant, able to accommodate 1,000 people.

title: U.S. IS EASING BENEFITS POLICY ON AIDS CASES
description: The Federal Government has reversed itself and will automatically extend Social Security disability payments to victims of AIDS who meet the newly expanded Federal definition of the deadly disease, a top Social Security Administration official said yesterday.

title: HAIG DISCLOSES LIST OF 79 'NATIONAL ADVISORS'
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr. today announced a list of 79 ''national advisers'' to his campaign for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination that was long on business executives and relatively short on prominent politicians.

title: IMPERIAL OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-After special charges of $155 million for the quarter and 6 months. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: House Votes Toshiba Curb
description: The House of Representatives voted today to ban sales of Toshiba products from stores on American military bases in retaliation for illegal sales of advanced technology by a Toshiba subsidiary to the Soviet Union.

title: Will the Leopard Coat Return?
description: Could leopard fashion make a comeback - coats and hats of real leopard skin, not the spotted prints now enjoying a certain chic? Conservationists' nightmares were prompted by a new report that the African leopard is surprisingly robust. Far from endangered, the scrappy animals even live inside several capital cities in Africa, said Rowan B. Martin, ecologist with the Zimbabwe parks department and coauthor of the study. He estimates that 700,000 leopards inhabit sub-Saharan Africa, enough to sustain an annual ''harvest'' of at least 30,000 without harm.

title: Keep Democracy in Baseball All-Star Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Cancer Patients Should Get Marijuana
description: LEAD: The widespread abuse of drugs is obviously one of America's most severe social problems.

title: Iran-Contra Lies Fester Within the Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LAST LETTERS. Prisons and Prisoners of the French Revolution 1793-1794. By Olivier Blanc. Translated by Alan Sheridan. 250 pages. Michael di Capua Books: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.50.

title: PATCH OF BRONX WATERFRONT WARILY AWAITS RENAISSANCE
description: Never mind the junked cars that ring the shore or the thunderous planes that soar overhead from nearby La Guardia Airport. John Pache would not live anywhere but along the East Bronx waterfront.

title: DIRECTOR OF HARLEM MUSEUM SEEN AS MYERSON SUCCESSOR
description: The director of the Studio Museum in Harlem, Dr. Mary Schmidt Campbell, is expected to be New York City's new Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, leaders in the city's arts community said yesterday.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NATIONAL DISTILLERS & CHEMIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $105.9 million for the quarter and $112.9 million for the 6 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $6.1 million for the quarter and $9.3 million for the 6 months. The 1987 results include income from the discontinued spirits and wines businesses.

title: GOODYEAR TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $199.2 million. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $10 million and $20.6 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said the latest 6-month includes gains of $13.6 million from the sale of its Zaire subsidiary and the company's joint venture interest in Toyobo Petcord of Japan in the second quarter as well as another portion of the gain onthe installment sale of the Arizona properties. The company also said year-ago 6-month includes $110.8 million after- tax in writedowns of oil and gas reserves.

title: Surprised Again in the Gulf
description: After the tanker Bridgeton was damaged by a mine in the Persian Gulf last week, the Navy's vulnerable escort ships lined up behind it in single file, since the tanker was better able to withstand further mines. The inaugural voyage of Kuwaiti tankers bearing American flags thus ended in bizarre inversion, with the tanker protecting the warships meant to defend it. To avoid further inglorious setbacks, the Navy needs now to suspend convoys until it gets a handle on the mining threat.

title: PROGRESSIVE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net realized gains on securities sales of $3,462,000 and $10,224,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes net realized gains on securities sales of $7,415,000 and $8,731,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: COSTLY, UNEASY KUWAIT
description: At a smart hotel here, it is possible for a person of some wealth to be served Swiss food by a waiter from Southeast Asia costumed as an English fox hunter while a Polish trio plays string music of vaguely Viennese extraction.

title: HARTFORD BRACES FOR JAMS FROM 4-YEAR ROAD PROJECT
description: One of New England's best-known highway mazes - where Interstates 84 and 91 intersect, but don't quite connect, in downtown Hartford - is being rebuilt, and businesses and commuters are preparing for four years of trouble.

title: TIGERS CLOSE IN ON YANKEES
description: Bill Madlock's eighth-inning single scored Tom Brookens with the tie-breaking run as the Detroit Tigers beat the Chicago White Sox, 4-1, tonight and moved within a half game of the Yankees in the American League East.

title: LAWRENCE L. PREISS
description: Lawrence L. Preiss, a former New York investment broker, died Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach, after a series of heart attacks. He was 83 years old and lived in Miami Beach.

title: Advertising; Creating Names for Products
description: AN Englishman named Murphy (saints preserve us!) was working for Dunlop Tire back home about 14 years ago when the challenge of naming a new product came up. His ad agency could not quite handle it so he scouted the scene for a specialty firm and, as the story goes, came up empty-handed.

title: Goldome Sets Repricing As Demand Falls Short
description: Goldome's well-publicized and costly campaign to convert from a mutual savings bank to stock ownership has apparently been met with apathy from key institutional investors.

title: Market Place; Likely Targets For Ford Cash
description: THE Ford Motor Company has more than $9 billion in cash and an inclination to latch onto some earnings independent of the cyclical automobile industry. But, like a careful car shopper, it has avoided impulse buying, particularly with the stock market at its current high level.

title: Judge, Citing Sloth, Orders Lawyers to School
description: Exasperated by what he considered sloppy legal work in a case before him, Federal District Judge Walter Jay Skinner has ordered two lawyers to attend an all-day seminar on Federal practice sponsored by the Masssachusetts Council for Legal Education.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Czechoslovakia Advances: Hana Mandlikova and Helena Sukova won their singles matches yesterday as second-seeded Czechoslovakia defeated Sweden to advance to the second round of the Federation Cup women's team championship in Vancouver, British Columbia. Mandlikova, coming back after a foot injury that forced her to miss Wimbledon, defeated Caterina Lindqvist, 6-3, 6-2, after Sukova won against Carina Karlsson 6-4, 6-4. Also advancing was third-seeded West Germany, which got singles victories from Steffi Graf and Claudia Kohde-Kilsch in defeating Hong Kong. Graf, the world's second-ranked woman player, struggled before beating Patricia Hy, 6-7, 6-2, 6-4, while Kohde-Kilsch defeated Paulette Moreno, 6-0, 6-2. The top-seeded United States team was scheduled to begin competition today against Japan. The Americans will be playing without Martina Navratilova, the top-ranked player in the world, who suffered a badly sprained ankle last week while playing basketball.(AP) Swimming Record in 800-Meter Freestyle: Fifteen-year-old Janet Evans knocked two seconds off the world record in the women's 800-meter freestyle at the United States Long Course National Championships yesterday in Fresno, Calif. The mark had lasted nearly a decade. Evans finished with a time of 8 minutes 22.44 seconds. That broke the record of 8:24.62 set by Tracey Wickham of Australia in 1978 and the American record of 8:24.70 set by Kim Linehan of Longhorn Athletic Club in 1979. Evans, who will be a junior at El Dorado High School in Placentia, Calif., this fall, beat her previous best time by more than 10 seconds. (AP)

title: VIEWS OF TOUR GAVE WHOLE PICTURE
description: The Tour de France, CBS frequently told us, is the most grueling, painful bicycle race on earth. Well, the pain was all in the backs, legs and lungs of the riders, for watching on television didn't hurt much at all.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Each day we are living in a more typical repressive dictatorship led by a military chief who is rejected by society but who maintains himself by force.'' - Ricardo Arias Calderon, Panama's main opposition leader. [ A1:6. ]

title: Pan Am Warm-Up
description: David Robinson, the all-America center from Navy, will lead the United States Pan American Games team in its first exhibition game against a squad of National Basketball Association players tonight at Market Square Arena in Indianapolis. Besides Robinson, the United States team includes Dean Garrett and Keith Smart of Indiana, the National Collegiate Athletic Association champion, Rex Chapman of Kentucky, Jeff Lebo of North Carolina, Fennis Dembo of Wyoming and Danny Manning of Kansas. The N.B.A. squad includes Isiah Thomas of the Detroit Pistons, Rodney McCray of the Houston Rockets and four players from the Indiana Pacers - Herb Williams, Chuck Person, Scott Skiles and Reggie Miller, a rookie.

title: FIRSTBANK OF ILLINOIS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
House Passes Refugee Bill
description: The House of Representatives today passed legislation that would suspend for two years the Government's deportation of Salvadoran and Nicaraguan refugees to their countries. The vote was 237 to 181. A similar measure passed the Senate Judiciary Committee on July 15 and awaits action by the full Senate. The bills' sponsors estimate that 500,000 Salvadorans and 200,000 Nicaraguans are living illegally in the United States.

title: The Witness File
description: Name: Edwin Meese 3d Age: 55 Position: Attorney General of the United States since February 1985. Mr. Meese has worked on and off for Ronald Reagan since he was Governor of California, including as chief of staff to Governor Reagan, adviser on the Reagan-Bush campaign committee, director of the transition team for President-elect Reagan, and counselor to the President since the beginning of 1981. Role: Mr. Meese directed the first investigation into the arms sales to the Iranians, and questions have been raised about the aggressiveness of that inquiry. Members of his staff found a memo outlining the diversion of funds to the Nicaraguan rebels three days before Mr. Meese asked the F.B.I. to begin a criminal investigation.

title: Banks' Foreign Lending
description: Foreign lending by the world's leading banks rose in the early months of this year, the Bank for International Settlements said today, but the debt-laden developing countries saw little of the money. It said total new lending in the first three months of 1987 rose $60 billion, compared with a rise of $25 billion a year ago. The growth in lending was almost entirely within the bank's reporting area, which took up some $57 billion of new loans. The area includes Luxembourg, Austria, Denmark, Finland, Ireland, Norway, Spain, the Bahamas, Bahrain, the Cayman Islands, Hong Kong, the Netherlands Antilles, Singapore and the branches of American banks in Panama.

PERSONAL HEALTH
description: MOST of us grew up thinking of cheese as healthful, a food high in protein and calcium at an affordable price. Adding to the attractiveness of cheese is its versatility. It can be used as is or in recipes for every course from appetizer to dessert. It is a popular snack for young and old because it is portable, can be eaten with the fingers, is widely available and easy to digest. Cheese is a favorite with parents, who offer it as meals and snacks, and carry it on outings to provide instant, nutritious satisfaction for the ''hungries'' that often beset young children when there is nothing but junk food to buy.

title: Not Reassuring on Rape

title: Dark Clouds Over Japan's Economy
description: Many economists say that the United States today is in a situation alarmingly similar to that of 1929. But Japan, far more than America, is close to plunging into a depression that, with double-digit unemployment, could severely strain a society that counts lifetime employment as a virtual right of citizenship.

title: FIRST TENNESSEE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DETROIT EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Results Plus; Diving
description: Louganis Leads Qualifiers: Greg Louganis was the leading qualifier yesterday in the 3-meter springboard competition of the United States outdoor championships at Bartlesville, Okla. For the first time in a decade, Louganis, 27 years old, of Boca Raton, Fla., is not defending a title. His score of 638.61 points on 11 first-round dives gave him an 18-point margin over the second-place qualifier, Ron Meyer of Baton Rouge, La. Meyer's score was 620.64 and Doug Shaffer of Boca Raton was third with 614.73. Kent Ferguson of Boca Raton, the defending champion, was sixth with 584.70. The top 12 qualifiers from among 37 competitors move into the men's 3-meter finals Friday.(AP) Tennis U.S. Defeats Japan: Chris Evert and Pam Shriver won straight-set victories to advance the top-seeded United States team past Japan in a first-round match in the Federation Cup in Vancouver, British Columbia. Evert, ranked No. 3 in the world, defeated Etsuko Inoue, 6-2, 6-4, and Shriver, the No. 5 player who was pressed into action as Martina Navratilova's replacement, beat Akiko Kijimuta, 7-6, 6-1. Navratilova, the top-ranked player in the world, is nursing a sprained ankle. Also advancing into the second round were Bulgaria, seeded fourth, Italy, seeded seventh, and unseeded Britain. (AP) Connors and Arias Advance: Third-seeded Jimmy Connors routed Kelly Jones by 6-3, 6-4 and Jimmy Arias, seeded seventh, eliminated Michael Kures, 7-5, 6-2, to move into the third round of the $232,000 D.C. Classic in Washington. Todd Witsken, seeded 12th, beat Ken Flach by 6-2, 6-1 and Bill Scanlon upset Jaime Yzaga of Peru, seeded 11th, 6-3, 0-6, 6-0.(AP) Swimming 2 American Records: Steven Bentley and Amy Shaw set American records in winning the finals of the 200-meter breast-stroke events at the United States long course national championships in Fresno, Calif. Bentley sprinted on the last lap to finish in 2 minutes 15.30 seconds, surpassing the record of 2:15.38 set by Steve Lundquist in 1983. Shaw swam 2:30.77 in her preliminary race to break a mark of 2:31.15 set by Susan Rapp in the 1984 Olympics. Eight hours later, she beat her morning mark by almost a second in 2:29.78. Shaw is the second 15-year-old woman to set a record in the nationals, which run through Friday at Clovis West High School. Janet Evans of Placentia, Calif., set a world record in the 800-meter freestyle on Monday with a time of 8:22.44. (AP)

It just seemed as if men got all the good stuff.

Sports People; Cade Is Sentenced
description: Mossy Cade, a defensive back for the Green Bay Packers, was sentenced yesterday to two years' imprisonment and fined $15,000 on two counts of second-degree sexual assault, a sentence the prosecutor called ''woefully inadequate.'' Cade, 25 years old, will be eligible for parole in six months and will be taken to the Dodge County reception center in Green Bay before being assigned to a penal institution. The maximum penalty for each count of second-degree sexual assault is a $10,000 fine and 10 years in prison. ''With that sentence, he'll probably be sent to some camp,'' said Royce Finne, the prosecutor in the case. ''He won't do any hard time.'' Cade was convicted May 23 by a seven-woman, five-man jury of sexually assaulting a 44-year-old Houston woman - a relative by marriage - at his home in November 1985. He was acquitted on a third count.

description: In different ways, two major designers electrified their audiences Monday as the fall and winter couture openings reached the halfway mark. Meanwhile, Karl Lagerfeld has updated the venerable house of Chanel so successfully in the last five years that with this year's collection he has virtually banished its image of quiet, staid and predictable clothes.

title: Americans Will Suffer
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: A Salzburg 'Abuduction'
description: Those dogmatic idealists who hold that there can be no significant connection between a composer's life and his music have some serious explaining to do when it comes to Mozart's operas. The youngster who hastily married the sister of the woman he really loved spent the rest of his short life torturing himself over questions of love and fidelity. He also went on to struggle with the problem in one opera after another. The conflict between the desire for freedom and the need to keep faith with one person figures prominently, of course, in such mature works as ''Cosi Fan Tutti,'' ''The Marriage of Figaro'' and ''Don Giovanni.'' However, the issue turned up immediately after his marriage to Constanze as the whole point of ''Die Entfuhrung aus dem Serail,'' which the Salzburg Festival presented last night in a whimsically designed but soberly meant new production.

title: Ohio Man With AIDS Is Dead After Flight Back From China

Its offerings range from savory stews, paellas and delicately deep-fried vegetables to mashed-fruit porridges and melanges soaked in pepper sauces so incendiary that fire is the only sensation the initiate can distinguish on his palate.

title: Sports People; Krickstein Is Injured
description: Aaron Krickstein withdrew from the D.C. Tennis Classic in Washington yesterday after trainers discovered an apparent stress fracture in his left leg. Krickstein, seeded sixth for the tournament and ranked 29th in the world, said he would return to his home in Grosse Point, Mich. Tournament officials said that he is uncertain whether he would be able to play in the United States Open beginning next month. ''He appears to have a stress fracture of the tibia of the left leg,'' said Todd Snyder, trainer for the Association of Tennis Professionals. ''X-rays have just been taken. It has not been definitely confirmed.''

Mr. Van Tieghem will share a Serious Fun! double bill with Scott Johnson, an innovative guitarist-composer who uses rock instruments in classical-scale pieces.

title: House Endorses Arias Plan
description: The House today approved a non-binding resolution supporting a Central American peace proposal sponsored by the Costa Rican President, Oscar Arias Sanchez. The approval was by voice vote with no objections. The Arias peace plan, which proposes a regional cease-fire and a negotiated settlement of grievances in Nicaragua, El Salvador and Guatemala, has already won overwhelming support in the Senate.

Music: Mostly Mozart
description: UNTIL shortly before 10 P.M., Monday evening's ''Mozart on Original Instruments'' program at Avery Fisher Hall sounded like a worthy but lackluster continuation of the Mostly Mozart Festival's experiments with historical performance. But it quickly became apparent that attention and rehearsal time had been focused -reasonably enough - on the groundbreaking final event: what appears to be the first local performance of a Beethoven piano concerto (No. 1 in C) on the kind of piano Beethoven played and rendered obsolete.

title: Jets' Vick Needs Breather
description: Roger Vick was stopped today, but not by any burly linebacker. Instead, Vick, the Jets' No. 1 draft pick, a runner who has been a terror in training camp, was badly dehydrated and forced to watch practice. It happened because of the way Vick drove himself during the camp's first two-a-day sessions Monday. ''I was just blowing and going,'' he said today. But Bob Reese, the Jet trainer, said: ''He was woozy and lost concentration. He started showing those symptoms late in practice, but he didn't say anything.'' Reese said, ''his muscles tightened.'' ''In college they didn't work him this hard,'' the trainer said. ''After he'd be in, they'd take him out and put in a second-stringer. They also gave you a break every half hour for water. Here, I've told the guys they have to drink enough water, and it's up to them to do it.''

The notes are rated Aa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation and yield about 52 basis points more than comparable Treasury issues.

title: GLAXO EXPANDING
description: Glaxo Holdings P.L.C., said it would acquire Biogen Inc.'s biotechnology research facilities in Geneva. It said in a statement that the agreement, once completed, provides for the acquisition to be completed by the month of August. Glaxo would take over all assets at the Geneva site. it would also give Glaxo marketing rights to certain pharmaceutical compounds in the early stages of investigation and transfer Biogen's Geneva-based research staff, which is engaged in molecular genetics, to Glaxo's payroll. A Glaxo spolesman would not disclose the price of the laboratory, where about 100 researchers are currently employed. He said Glaxo would aim to expand there once the acquisition was completed.

title: British Airports' Shares Up Sharply
description: Shares in BAA P.L.C., formerly the British Airports Authority, jumped 42 pence, or 67 cents, above the offering price when the stock started trading today on the London Stock Exchange. About 2 million people bought shares in the company, which manages seven major British airports. Small investors seeking to buy up to 1,000 shares were limited to a maximum 100 after the subscriptions to buy stock came to 10 times the amount available.

title: Masco Adding
description: The Masco Corporation, a maker of home furnishings based in Taylor, Mich., said it had agreed to buy three furniture companies with combined annual sales of more than $200 million. Masco declined to disclose the size of the transactions, which it said were to be made in cash and stock. The three acquisitions are the Lexington Furniture Industries group of companies, based in Lexington, N.C., Maitland-Smith Ltd. of Hong Kong and Marge Carson Inc. of Los Angeles.

title: HANDWRITTEN DRAFT OF A BILL OF RIGHTS FOUND
description: A handwritten working draft of the Bill of Rights -the only such document known to exist - has been found and identified in the most likely of places: the Library of Congress.

title: PROTEST AND ROCK FETE ARE TESTS OF GLASNOST
description: A joyous rock concert and an angry public demonstration in the last few days have pushed out new boundaries for spontaneous public behavior and protest in Soviet society. In different settings and for reasons that could hardly have had less in common, a group of Crimean Tatars seeking to redress grievances and the audience at a Billy Joel concert threw away the rule book that has governed public activities in the Soviet Union for decades.

title: Sports People; Grunfeld Offer Denied
description: Rick Pitino, the Knick coach, yesterday denied a report that he had officially offered Ernie Grunfeld, a former Knick player, the job of assistant coach and that Grunfeld had turned it down. ''Ernie is someone I'm very close to and was very interested to sit down and talk to about the job,'' Pitino said, ''but we never got together to talk about it. I spoke to Ernie on the telephone and explained the salary restraints of the job and it never got any further than that.'' Pitino, who brought along Stu Jackson, his aide at Providence College last season, said he did not have a leading candidate for the other coaching position. He said he wanted to talk to a lot of people, including Phil Jackson, a former Knick who spent the last five seasons coaching the Albany Patroons in the Continental Basketball Association. Grunfeld is the commentator for Knick games on radio. He said it would not have been financially worthwhile for him to take the job. ''I'm flattered that Rick thought of me and it was a very tough decision but I'm very excited about the upcoming season. I'll be doing more games.'' In addition to his broadcasting, Grunfeld cited his family and business interests as reasons for not expressing interest in the job. He owns an advertising and promotions company, Ernie Grunfeld Enterprises. Pitino will give the keynote address today at the opening ceremonies of the 10th annual New York State Games in Syracuse.

title: Sports People; Angels Sign Buckner
description: Bill Buckner, the goat of the 1986 World Series who was released by the Boston Red Sox last week, signed yesterday with the California Angels. The 37-year-old Buckner was scheduled to be in uniform for the Angels last night in their game against the Athletics at Oakland, Calif. Buckner, who broke into the majors with the Los Angeles organization in 1969, played for the Dodgers in the 1974 World Series. In last year's World Series against the Mets, he let a grounder by Mookie Wilson go through his legs at first base to allow the Mets to win Game 6 and go on to take the Series. Buckner was hitting .273, with 2 home runs and 42 runs batted in for Boston when it was decided to place him on waivers last Thursday to make room for Sam Horn, who was recalled from Pawtucket. A .292 career hitter, Buckner had six game-winning runs batted in for the Red Sox this season.

title: 19 SRI LANKANS ARE KILLED IN RIOTING OVER INDIAN PACT
description: At least 19 people were killed today in rioting over an accord with the Indian Government of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi that would grant more autonomy to the Tamil minority in Eastern and Northern Provinces of Sri Lanka.

description: b-Net income Both latest periods include a charge of $122 million as a result of a previously announced decision to write down certain production and refining assets to their current net realizable value.
