MEESE TELLS PANEL HE HAD NO REASON TO PRESS INQUIRY
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d testified today that he had not asked probing questions last November during his three-day preliminary inquiry into the Iran-contra affair because he had no reason to disbelieve other top officials.

title: SHELL OIL COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shell Oil is a unit of Royal Dutch Petroleum Co.

title: PEOPLES SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank converted to stock form in October.

title: MEESE'S WHITE HOUSE: PAINTED IN KIND COLORS
description: If George P. Shultz painted a picture of a White House that was a Borgia palace on the Potomac, riddled with deceit, feuds and usurpations of power, Edwin Meese 3d offered a much more benign view of the same scene.

title: FIRST OAK BROOK BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORNERSTONE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Don't Punish Toshiba
description: To the Editor:

title: SUBMARINE CASE TO LIFT U.S. COSTS
description: A classified Defense Department study estimates that developing new technology to re-establish America's edge in tracking Soviet submarines will cost at least $8 billion over 10 years, Pentagon officials who said they had read the report disclosed today.

title: CROSS & TRECKER CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $104,000 and $4,385,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income d-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $513,000 for the quarter and $1,677,000 for the 9 months.

title: Mrs. Aquino's Oft-Promised Land
description: Promising land reform in the Philippines is the easy part; politicians have been doing it for decades. If President Corazon Aquino wants the world truly to take notice, she'll have to do more than ask a newly elected Congress to take the hard decisions. She is giving Congress 90 days to put into effect a very general decree on breaking up baronial estates. If nothing happens, she says she'll name a panel to do the job - a delaying scheme reminiscent of her wily predecessor, Ferdinand Marcos.

title: REUTER LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Optimism in Britain
description: British businessmen are optimistic that output and orders will continue to rise, but they also expect the recent rapid growth to taper off to a more sustainable rate, according to a report from the Confederation of British Industry. Fewer companies are working below capacity now than at any time since 1974, while a shortage of skilled labor is increasingly seen as a problem, the report said. A fourth of the business respondents said they were more, rather than less, optimistic about the outlook for their businesses than they were four months ago. This was slightly below the previous quarter's 29 percent.

title: Blood Donors' Anonymity Is Upheld
description: Blood donors must be allowed to remain anonymous, even if hospital patients who receive the blood later die of AIDS, according to recent court decisions in New York and Florida.

title: AUTO-TROL TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: ILLINOIS POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Pop Life
description: LEAD: Marianne Faithfull was working on a big-budget rock album in 1986, a record that was to feature synthesizer-heavy treatments of her own wry and rueful songs. ''And it was a nightmare,'' the British pop singer recently recalled. ''I've worked well with synthesizers before, but I have a problem understanding why anybody would want to work with a machine when they could be sitting there with a real person.

title: BY THE BLACK SEA, A WORKERS' PARADISE (OF SORTS)
description: On a hot summer weekend that Mikhail S. Gorbachev spent pleading with his comrades to make better machine-building equipment, thousands of Russians settled under the sun in Sochi and surrounding communities with nothing more urgent on their minds than a game of cards and a desire for a golden tan.

title: Heard but Unseen, Seven Actors Share 'Talk Radio' Roles
description: Eric Bogosian's new play ''Talk Radio,'' about a nighttime phone-in-show host teetering on the edge of dementia, could just as well be called ''Voices Off.''

title: Ex-Chief Files Guinness Suit
description: The former chairman of Guinness P.L.C., Ernest Saunders, has begun a legal counteroffensive in his bitter battle with the brewing giant.

title: OUTBOARD MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $1,248,000 for the quarter and $3,495,000 for the 9 months.

title: Cleveland-Cliffs
description: Cleveland-Cliffs Inc. said it had agreed to acquire $126 million worth of Tilden Mine long-term debt from eight lenders for a minimum of $75 million. The company said that buying this debt would remove its subsidiary, the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company, from its current default status. The unit owns 39 percent of Tilden, an iron mine in Michigan.

title: NORTHERN INDIANA PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NORIEGA IS ADAMANT DESPITE CALL FOR OUSTER
description: Hoisted on banners carried in Government-organized demonstrations, posted on billboards, scrawled on walls, a single slogan is seen everywhere in Panama these days: ''Not one step back.''

title: Dr. Dean McKee, Who Served As Head of Biblical Seminary
description: Dr. Dean G. McKee, a former president of the Biblical Seminary in New York, now the New York Theological Seminary, died of lymphoma of the liver on July 19 at his home in Decatur, Ga. He was 82 years old.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chairman Named By Westinghouse
description: LEAD: The Westinghouse Corporation's board of directors yesterday named John C. Marous, 62 years old, as the successor to Douglas D. Danforth, the current chairman and chief executive. Mr. Marous is president and chief operating officer.

title:
HOME BEAT;
A Rescue Operation
description: LEAD: ''WHEN an important concert hall, hotel or church is torn down in a city it is like a death in the cityscape, and owning a fragment of the building is another way for the building to live on,'' said Steven Corwin, above, co-owner of the Great American Salvage Company, who is now selling six brass sconces from the original recital hall at Carnegie Hall and three dozen porcelain sinks and chrome towel bars removed from the Plaza Hotel in a renovation.

title: BABI YAR WAS A SOVIET, AND A JEWISH, TRAGEDY
description: To the Editor:

title: STARTERS ARE KEY TO AMERICAN LEAGUE EAST RACE
description: The Yankees have used 10 different starting pitchers this season, shedding some as quickly as they could find replacements. The Toronto Blue Jays have been almost as busy, using nine pitchers in starting roles. The Detroit Tigers, on the other hand, have basically had the same starting five all season, making only one exception and finding three starts for a sixth pitcher.

title: BANNISTER BLANKS TIGERS ON 5 HITS
description: Floyd Bannister pitched a five-hitter tonight as the Chicago White Sox beat Detroit, 4-0, ending the Tigers' five-game winning streak.

title: Flurry of U.S. Issues Expected
description: The logjam in Government security auctions that has disrupted the credit markets the last two weeks will soon begin to break up, the Treasury announced yesterday after Congress temporarily raised the Federal debt ceiling.

title: Advertising; Promoting Movies Via Cable
description: THE Movietime Channel, conceived as a less expensive way to advertise films, is all set to make its debut on cable television tomorrow.

title: Life With 3,000 Mechanical Toys
description: A FEW years ago, when Dr. Athelstan Spilhaus was on his way from Florida to the Bahamas, he was asked to fill out a customs form that, among other things, asked for his occupation. As the friend who was traveling with him tells the story, in that space Dr. Spilhaus wrote ''retired genius.''

title: Kodak Reports a Profit As Sales Increase 19.3%
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's largest producer of photographic equipment, yesterday announced a record second-quarter profit of $361.9 million, or $1.60 a share. In the corresponding quarter a year ago, the company had a loss of $12.2 million.

title: Leahy Confession: Fallout
description: The top Republican on the House committee investigating the Iran-contra affair said today that Senator Patrick J. Leahy's unauthorized release of a Senate Intelligence Committee report last January illustrated why the Reagan Administration felt it needed to keep some information from Congress.

title: Net Slips a Bit At Primerica
description: The Primerica Corporation, formerly the American Can Company, said yesterday that its second-quarter net income slipped six-tenths of 1 percent, although operating earnings were up sharply.

title: AMERIANA SAVINGS BANK OF NY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago per share earnings are unavailable; the bank converted to a stock savings institution on Feb. 25, 1987.

title: KEYSTONE FINANCIAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SECURITY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Transactions; BASEBALL
description: KANSAS CITY (AL) - Traded Buddy Biancalana, shortstop, to the Astros for Mel Stottlemyre Jr., pitcher. Assigned Stottlemyre to Memphis of the Southern League.

title: A.C.L.U. Agonizes
description: For 51 years, the American Civil Liberties Union has maintained a policy of not taking positions on nominees for judicial or other offices. But feelings are running so high against the nomination of Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court that Norman Dorsen, the organization's president, this week called a special board meeting to decide whether the policy should be revised to enable the A.C.L.U. to weigh in against President Reagan's nominee.

title: WESTMORELAND COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $3,318,000.

title: MEESE SAYS NORTH LIED EITHER TO HIM OR TO COMMITTEES
description: Under sharp questioning by the Iran-contra committees, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d reluctantly conceded today that Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North must have lied either to him or in sworn testimony before the committees.

title: Order for Boeing
description: The Boeing Company said it had received an order valued at about $400 million for 15 of its 737-300 twin-jets from Nordstress Ltd. of Hong Kong. Nordstress is a subsidiary of Ansett Transport Industries of Australia. Boeing said the aircraft are scheduled for delivery between June 1988 and June 1989.

title: NBC Is First in Ratings For 26th Straight Week
description: ''The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd,'' a new summer situation comedy starring Blair Brown, tied for ninth place in the A. C. Nielsen Company ratings for the week ended July 26, helping NBC to win its 26th straight week in the ratings.

title: Advertising; Johnson & Johnson Ends Its Florida Ban
description: Johnson & Johnson, which had suspended its network advertising in Florida beginning July 1 to protest a new state sales tax that affected advertising, has resumed running the ads there. None of its other advertising, either spot TV or print, was affected by the ban.

title: DEMOCRATS TRADE GOWING REMARKS
description: On an island of unworldly peacefulness where cars are banned and the horse and buggy vies with the bicycle as the means of transportation, eight Democratic Presidential candidates told Democratic governors today how they would lead their party to victory and the nation into the 21st century.

title: Mergers Thin the Ranks of Corporate Givers
description: To the Editor:

title: BESSIE BRIMBERG
description: Bessie Brimberg, widow of Louis Brimberg, founder of the brokerage firm Brimberg & Company, died of pneumonia Monday in Doctors Hospital in Manhattan. She was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Issue Backed By Auto Loans
description: Western Financial Auto Loans 2, a unit of Westcorp's Western Financial Savings Bank, is offering $110 million of bonds collateralized by a pool of car-loan receivables. Drexel Burnham Lambert is the sole underwriter.

title: THE SOBER SECTION
description: All baseball fans of a certain age will swear that yesterday was exactly like the first time they went to a ball game - bright sun lighting the open decks of a huge major league stadium, a large and mostly responsible crowd, and a home-team victory, of course.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS IS FINED BY U.S. SAFETY AGENCY
description: The Labor Department fined the General Dynamics Corporation $615,000 today for willfully under-reporting job injuries and illnesses at its submarine shipbuilding yard in Quonset Point, R.I.

title: RAMADA INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $1,365,000 and a pretax gain of $16,180,000 from the sale of hotel property. c-Net income d-Includes a pretax gain of $3.4 million and $4,109,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from the sale of hotel properties.

title: Concert: National Chorale
description: ONE effect of the National Chorale's Bernstein-Weill program Tuesday at Damrosch Park was to remind one how seriously a few excellent composers have investigated the Broadway musical as a potential forum for sophisticated work. A corresponding effect, however, was the reminder that basic standards of craft and execution cannot be neglected without peril in light music.

title: Using Surplus Again For Monetary Clout
description: Since its founding during New York City's financial turmoil of 1975, the Municipal Assistance Corporation's role has been, in part, to use its money to force changes it felt necessary upon sometimes unwilling public agencies and public employees. The city's financial crisis is long gone, but the assistance corporation remains willing and able to use its monetary clout to bring change.

title: LAFARGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Greenspan's Firm Is Closing
description: Townsend-Greenspan & Company, the economic consulting firm that Alan Greenspan ran for nearly 30 years, is notifying clients that it will cease operations tomorrow - a casualty of Mr. Greenspan's nomination to be chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: GREAT ADVENTURE TRYING TO REGAIN LOST CUSTOMERS
description: Ray Williams has been living out of a suitcase here since he received orders Sunday to take over the presidency of the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park and reverse its troubled image and sagging attendance.

title: LINCOLN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TAMBRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mexican Attacks U.S. Policy
description: Foreign Minister Bernardo Sepulveda Amor of Mexico said today that the Reagan Administration's policy of aiding Nicaraguan rebels violated international law by blocking Central American peace efforts. ''Not only does it deal with a violation of international law, but it also deals with an attack on the rights and the legitimate interests of Latin American countries,'' he said at a news conference.

title: WESTERN DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,217,000 for the quarter and for the year a tax credit of $5,402,000. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $256,000 for the quarter and the year includes a tax credit of $1,612,000. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the acquisition of Paradise Systems, which was accounted for on a pooling of interests basis.

title: JET VETERANS TO GET MUCH COMPETITION
description: For a team that has produced 21 victories the last two seasons, and made the playoffs each time, the Jets' veterans will find a startling number of roster openings when they report to camp Friday.

title: SUMITOMO BANK OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Babi Yar Was a Soviet, And a Jewish, Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: MEESE CONCURS: IT WAS NOT LIKE AGATHA CHRISTIE
description: The Senator talked to the Attorney General as though he were the driver of a fire engine who had decided to take the scenic route to a five-alarm blaze.

title: 'THE ESSENTIAL FACTS REMAIN THE SAME'
description: Attorney General Meese was repeatedly questioned about the credibility of witnesses. In one such exchange, Senator Daniel K. Inouye, chairman of the Senate committee, asked him about lies to investigators and their consequences.

title: FAIRFIELD FIRST BANK & TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FOUNDER OF NATIONAL REVIEW
description: James Burnham, an influential American conservative who was a founding editor of The National Review, died Tuesday of cancer at his home in Kent, Conn. He was 82.

title: SUN CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
USLICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a capital gain of $2,800,000 and $5,700,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a tax credit of $1,200,000 and $2,200,000 for the same periods, respectively. c-Includes a capital gain of $5,700,000 and $6,100,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Japan Most Expensive
description: Japan said today that its domestic goods and services were the most expensive in the industrialized world. The costliest items include food, cigarettes, education and recreational services. Prices in Japan are 57 percent higher than in Britain, 49 percent costlier than in Italy, 30 percent up on the United States and 22 percent higher than in France, according to a report by the Economic Planning Agency, a Government organization. It attributed Japan's high prices, in part, to Government rules that discourage competition.

title: TANAKA VERDICT CHANGES FACE OF POWER IN JAPAN
description: Japanese politics moved toward a generational change today when an appellate court upheld the conviction of former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka for taking bribes from the Lockheed Corporation.

title: SOUTHDOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $6.7 million charge for the company's repurchase of about 28 percent of its shares at a premium price as well as a $2.2 million net gain from a change in pension plan accounting. c-Net loss and includes a pretax writedown of $55 million for capitalized oil and gas costs in accordance with full-cost accounting requirements.

title: CONGRESS HEARS REPORTS ON IMPOTENCE OF U.S. MISSILES AGAINST SOVIET TANKS
description: With representatives of American and European missile manufacturers watching uneasily from the sidelines, experts at a packed Congressional hearing asserted today that American infantry missiles might be virtually useless against the latest generation of Soviet tanks. But an Army spokesman said that the seriousness of the problem had been exaggerated.

title: Manila Debt Easing Asked
description: Philippine senators cautioned today against any arbitrary repudiation of foreign debts and proposed instead that the Government seek better repayment terms from foreign creditors.

title: ATCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $17,467,000 for the quarter and $21,965,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $1,607,000 and $1,155,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said figures for discontinued operations include interest expense allocated of about $700,000 and $1.8 million for the latest quarter and 9 months, respectively; and $850,000 for the year-ago quarter and $1.5 million for the 9-months.

title: IU INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,660,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $3,374,000 for the 6 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $10,176,000 for the quarter and $12,857,000 for the 6 months; a gain of $12,181,000 on disposal of discontinued operations for both periods and an extraordinary credit of $24,549,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $29,780,000 as well as an accounting change gain of $1,787,000 for the 6 months.

title: Critic's Notebook; Vividly Staged 'Cerceau' Takes London by Surprise
description: Though Victor Slavkin's ''Cerceau'' evokes memories of ''The Cherry Orchard'' and Renoir's ''Rules of the Game,'' it is a play with its own vivid contemporary Russian flavor. Presented for one week at the Riverside Studios as part of the annual London International Festival of Theater, the play is one of the most remarkable dramatic events of the current London season.

title: CONGRESS PASSES EMERGENCY RISE IN DEBT CEILING
description: Congress approved a one-week extension of the Government's borrowing authority today as Senate negotiators said they had reached a compromise on a new mechanism for automatic spending cuts under the budget-balancing law.

title: A HOME AWAY FROM HOME: CABINS GET PERSONAL TOUCH
description: HERE are 17 Kirk Camerons, the young star of the television show ''Growing Pains,'' on the wall of Bunk 26 at Point O'Pines Camp for Girls in Brant Lake, N.Y.

title: 50 Reportedly Killed By Train Blast in Syria
description: An explosion on a train killed more than 50 people in northern Syria a few days ago, a Lebanese Christian radio station here reported today.

title: HOME SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $698,000 for the quarter and $1,720,000 for the 6 months. The year-ago share earnings are unavailable; the bank converted to stock form in November 1986. The bank said its results for the latest periods reflected tax credits of $2.6 million for the quarter and $5 million for the 6 months, as a reduction of goodwill rather than an extraordinary credit.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Maxie Baughan, who coached the Cornell University football team to an 8-2 record and a second-place Ivy League finish in 1986, has signed a contract that extends his current pact for three years. Baughan had one year left in his five-year contract. . . . In a minor league transaction, the Kansas City Royals have traded an infielder, Buddy Biancalana, to the Houston Astros for a pitcher, Mel Stottlemyre Jr. Biancalana was sent outright by the Royals to Omaha of the American Association July 21 after hitting .213 in 37 games. Stottlemyre, son of the former Yankees pitcher and current Mets pitching coach, was 7-6 at Columbus of the Class AA Southern League.

title: Charges Disputed
description: Keith Hernandez of the Mets and the former major league infielder, Dale Berra, dispute charges by Lonnie Smith of the Kansas City Royals that baseball's crackdown on drugs is ''a joke.'' Hernandez, Berra and Smith were among seven players disciplined by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth in February 1986 for their involvement with drugs.

title: 63d St. Tunnel Is Termed Safe In M.T.A. Study
description: Despite floods, cracks and other problems, the 63d Street subway tunnel has always been structurally sound, according to a report released yesterday by the Inspector General of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Calendar; Craftmen's Exhibits And Fair
description: Creative Works Inspired by the Garden

title: SHOWDOWN IN GULF: IRAN'S ACTION DURING RETURN OF CONVOY WILL BE CRUCIAL
description: Iran holds the initiative in the Persian Gulf, and its actions will determine whether it is on a collision course with the United States as a result of the mine that damaged the supertanker Bridgeton last Friday in a convoy to Kuwait to pick up oil. The return of the convoy could be critical. Unconfirmed reports out of Kuwait indicate that the damaged Bridgeton and the Gas Prince will sail Friday.

title: FIRST MIDWEST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $119,000 for the quarter and $208,000 for the 6 months. The company said year-ago results are restated to reflect the acquisition of Bancorp of Mundelein.

title: Beck Near Decision
description: Barry Beck, the former Ranger defenseman and captain, who went into semi-retirement partly because of an injured shoulder and partly because of the turmoil under his former coach, Ted Sator, plans to make a decision on whether he wants to return to hockey in the next couple of weeks, according to his agent, Rob Ingraham.

title: The Joy of 'Mystery' Plants
description: I KNOW that many people live their lives in perfect contentment knowing the names of not a single plant, except maybe oaks and crab grass, but they certainly are not gardeners. Ever since Adam was put to the task of naming the beasts of the field and the flora of Eden, gardening has been a matter of nomenclature as well as sweat and pleasure.

title: 7 ARE ARRESTED AFTER INQUIRY AT CREEDMOOR
description: Six workers and a former employee at the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens were arrested yesterday after a yearlong undercover investigation. Three were charged with abusing mentally retarded patients and the rest with selling drugs to fellow employees.

title: COWBOY WASN'T LONESOME IN DEATH
description: With a eulogy from the President, a full contingent of the diplomatic corps in attendance and altogether more pomp and protocol than Mac Baldrige would have thought necessary, official Washington said goodbye to him today in a brief service at the Washington Cathedral.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday of George A. McDermott, a retired medical publisher, misstated the date of a memorial service for him. It is scheduled for Aug. 30 - not today - at the Memorial Church at Harvard University.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The people who come over here go back with brand new ideas, and that is the real danger for East Germany. This transfer of ideas and information, this is what East Germany has tried to prevent for years.'' - Horst Schumm,of West Berlin. [ A6:4. ]

title: Milwaukee Bank Chief Is Silent on Takeover
description: As the chairman and chief executive of the Marine Corporation, a Milwaukee-based banking group with assets of $4.3 billion, George R. Slater, 63, built a reputation for shrewd and aggressive acquisitions. To enter the high-priced Chicago market, for example, he arranged the purchase of a retail branch of Banco Di Roma for $1.4 million more than the value of its assets, just for the sake of its charter.

title: MCGWIRE'S 37th TIES RECORD
description: Mark McGwire hit his 37th home run of the season today to tie the American League record for rookies.

title: Fed Official Warns Of Inflationary Acts
description: The vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board warned today that passage of protectionist trade legislation or a higher minimum wage would unleash inflationary forces - actual and psychological - that the Fed would have to counter by tightening credit, perhaps severely.

title: OLD NATIONAL BANCORP (INDIANA)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: BLACK HILLS CORP reports earnings for 12mo June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,248,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Hungary Seeks Way to Cut High Suicide Rate
description: Worried by the highest recorded suicide rate in the world, the Hungarian Government is encouraging an extensive study of its causes to seek ways of prevention.

title: Airline Drops Charge On Angry Passenger
description: Continental Airlines has dropped charges against a New Yorker who was accused of shouting obscenities and inciting a disturbance among passengers after their flight was delayed for three hours here at O'Hare International Airport.

title: HAWTHORNE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ROLAND F. MARSTON
description: Roland F. Marston, who started as an insurance salesman and worked his way up to chairman of the State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company, has died. He was 63 years old.

title: CANADIAN OCCIDENTAL PETEROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The company said second quarter revenue results weren't immediately available.

title: 20 DIE IN BRAZIL PRISON UPRISING
description: The police stormed a maximum-security prison where about 250 armed inmates were holding hostages today and ended the uprising in a seven-hour battle. Officials said 20 people were killed and dozens injured.

title: Wierton's New Steel Can
description: The Weirton Steel Corporation, trying to regain a share of the food-can market, said today that it had topped the aluminum industry's ''easy-open'' containers with a steel version. The new can, developed over two years, is easier to open than other products, said William T. Saunders, the vice president of product development and research.

title: THE FORGIVER MIGHT NOT BE FORGIVEN, POLITICALLY
description: If a number of prominent conservatives have their way, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North will soon share a distinction with Richard Nixon, Jimmy Hoffa and a Confederate sympathizer in the Civil War, Augustus H. Garland.

title: Rudman Is Rigorous
description: Few other members of the Congessional Iran-contra committees have worked as hard or been as rigorous in their questioning of witnesses as Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire, the Republican vice chairman of the Senate panel. Many people who have followed Senator Rudman's career assumed he hoped to use the national prominence he has gained through the hearings as a springboard toward a Republican leadership position in the Senate. The current minority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, is running for President, and he is expected to resign from the leadership before long.

title: Court Rebuffs Magazine On Use of 'Yale' in Title
description: A Federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit filed by the American Literary Society in an effort to keep ''Yale'' in the title of its Yale Literary Magazine.

title: WESTPORT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The per share earnings adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May 1987.

title: LOCTITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PENTAGON AND CONTRACTORS SAID TO AGREE TO UNDERSTATE COST OF WEAPONS
description: The Defense Department allowed military contractors to understate the costs of developing weapons, with both sides knowing a contractor could dip into other public funds to avoid abandoning the project, a Justice Department document says.

title: US BANCORP (PORTLAND, ORE)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $7.6 million on redemption of an investment in Old National Bancorp. All amounts reflect the pooling of interests for accounting purposes resulting from the acquisition of Valley National Bank of Forest Grove, Ore.

title: ANCHOR SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $200,000 for the quarter and $43 million for the year. c-After extraordinary gains of $7.4 million for the quarter and $11.8 million for the year. The latest fourth quarter net includes a writeoff of $2.7 million of FSLIC secondary reserve. Anchor converted from mutual to stock form on April 1.

title: JERRICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
METROBANC FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
On New York's Legislature; Assembly vs. Senate in Albany
description: To the Editor:

title: Recalling Key Lessons Of the Church Committee
description: Twelve years ago, the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Agencies - known as the Church Committee after Frank Church, its chairman -issued its report on the attempted assassination of foreign leaders. A rereading of that report in light of today's Iran-contra investigation demonstrates anew our extraordinary inability to learn from past mistakes.

title: Saving a Civil Rights Symbol
description: The U.S. Commission on Civil Rights used to be at the forefront of government efforts against racial abuses. No more. After years of domination by the Reagan Administration, it has fallen into such disrepute that the House of Representatives recently voted to stop further funding.

title: U.S. IS CRITICAL OF SOVIET ARMS PROPOSAL
description: The Soviet Union today presented what Soviet officials called a new proposal to restrict the testing of anti-missile defensive systems. But the United States called the proposal disappointing because it did not mark an important change in the Soviet position.

title: FIRST INTERSTATE OF IOWA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: COUNTY SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SANDOR LORAND, 95, A PIONEER IN FREUDIAN PSYCHOANLYSIS
description: Sandor Lorand, a psychiatrist and prominent disciple of Freud, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Long Beach, L.I. He was 95 years old.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Paris yesterday on the investigation of terrorist bombings in France gave an incorrect location for warships the French Government had alerted for possible duty in the Persian Gulf. The ships are based in the Mediterranean port of Toulon.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Advertising; People
description: * Sharon Mosse has been appointed executive vice president, management representative at Backer Spielvogel Bates.

title: ORANGE & ROCKLAND UTILITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Turning Back
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTH FORK BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REAGAN, OPENING BORK FIGHT, CALLS JUDGE A MODERATE
description: President Reagan opened his campaign today to win Senate confirmation of Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court, and he stressed themes that differ sharply from the views of the President's hard-line conservative supporters.

title: PRESIDENTIAL PARDONS: A SAMPLER
description: Confederate Senator: The scope of the Presidential power to pardon was defined 120 years ago in a Supreme Court decision involving Augustus H. Garland, right. The Confederate sympathizer had been pardoned by Andrew Johnson. His effort to have his right to practice law restored was succesful. Union Boss: Citing his pardon powers, President Nixon commuted the prison tem of Jimmy Hoffa, the former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, in 1971. Mr. Hoffa had been convicted of jury tampering and fraud. Former President: In an enormously unpopular act in 1974, President Ford granted a ''full, free and absolute pardon'' to Mr. Nixon, who had resigned as a result of the Watergate scandal. The pardon is thought to have been a key factor in Mr. Ford's loss to Jimmy Carter in the 1976 Presidential election.

title: Fuel Supply Notes
description: The Mountain Fuel Supply Company is offering $50 million of 9 1/2 percent notes due in 1997 at a price of 99.60 to yield 9.56 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. Rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P., the notes yield about 95-hundredths of a percentage point more than 10-year Treasury notes.

title: BYCHKOV TO HEAD L'ORCHESTRE DE PARIS
description: Semyon Bychkov, the Russian-born conductor of the Buffalo Philharmonic, will leave in 1989 to succeed Daniel Barenboim as music director of l'Orchestre de Paris, officials of the Buffalo orchestra said yesterday.

title: No Trade Pact on Pasta As U.S. Deadline Nears
description: The six-year-old pasta war between the United States and the European Community may escalate this week, as Reagan Administration trade officials come up against a self-imposed Aug. 1 negotiating deadline with no resolution in sight.

title: Bridge: A Tall Expert Has Achieved His First Big National
description: The world's tallest bridge expert won his first major national title in Baltimore last week.

title: Key Models Expected From I.B.M. and Tandy
description: Tandy and I.B.M., two of the leading makers of personal computers, are expected to make significant product announcements next week, company officials and industry analysts said today.

title: LOUISIANA LAND & EXPLORAION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chernobyl Officials Are Sentenced to Labor Camp
description: The head of the Chernobyl nuclear power station at the time of the world's worst nuclear power accident and two of his aides were sentenced today to 10 years in a labor camp, the maximum possible in the disaster.

title: SKIN FROM REAGAN'S NOSE REMOVED FOR TESTS
description: President Reagan had a small piece of skin removed from his nose this afternoon in what his doctor described as a ''routine procedure.''

title: MICROSOFT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The results in the latest quarter and year reflect two programs under which employees are paid a bonus for producing tax benefits for the company. If the programs had not been adopted, the company said, latest fourth quarter net would have been about $20.4 million, or 72 cents a share, and latest year net would have been about $78.1 million, or $2.79 a share.

title: Soviet Craft, With 3 Aboard Returns From Space Station
description: The Soyuz spacecraft carrying Syria's first astronaut and two Soviet companions landed safely on Earth today after a five-day visit to the orbiting space station Mir, Moscow radio said.

title: PUGET POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Year to June 30
In Africa, a Rush to Privatize
description: John M. Moore watched with satisfaction as red-hot steel bars snaked through his successful rolling mill here.

title: Jacobs Stake In Allegheny
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, said yesterday that he owned about 900,000 shares of Allegheny International, or about 9 percent of the financially troubled company that makes Sunbeam, Oster and Mixmaster appliances.

title: Maryland Wins Thrift Ruling
description: The State of Maryland has won a key ruling in its bid to recover some of the $100 million it lost after the failure of the Community Savings and Loan Association in 1985. Judge Joseph H. Kaplan of

title: Israel Tries to Discredit An Alibi of Demjanjuk
description: The Israeli prosecutor seeking to prove that John Demjanjuk was a Nazi war criminal tried today to discredit his alibi that he was in a prisoner-of-war camp during the 1942-43 period that the Treblinka death camp was in operation.

title: FAMILY MUTUAL SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank converted to stock ownership in November.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: KEY RATES
Architectural Details
description: WHEN Helen Ballard of Atlanta went looking for an inexpensive table base, she had a hard time. Finally, she found a local artist who had designed a base with a dolphin motif that he was producing one at a time in his garage. Miss Ballard and her table base were subsequently featured in a decorating magazine, and ''people saw the base and went mad,'' she said. ''They were calling me at all hours of the day and night.''

title: North Testimony Top Seller as Book
description: ''Taking the Stand,'' the complete transcripts of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's testimony before the select committee of Congress, is the No. 1 selling paperback nonfiction book in the United States.

title: OFFICIAL URGED MEESE TO WIDEN STAFF IN INQUIRY
description: Last November, on the eve of Edwin Meese 3d's inquiry into the Iran arms dealings, the Justice Department's senior prosecutor argued at a meeting of Mr. Meese's senior aides that it was inappropriate for the Attorney General to work as a ''gumshoe.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a brief article on June 27 about the Stein & Day publishing house filing for protection under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code incorrectly stated when the company's troubles began. They started in 1984. The article also misidentified R. R. Donnelley & Sons. It is Stein & Day's former printer.

title: REGAN TESTIFIES TODAY ON ROLE IN 'BATTLE ROYAL'
description: When Donald T. Regan, the former White House chief of staff, begins testifying before the Iran-contra committee on Thursday, committee members hope he will be able to explain how a ''battle royal'' erupted in the White House over the sale of arms to Iran.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Outdoor Artistry

title: AMERICAN STANDARD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss on the sale of discontinued operations of $6,200,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2,200,000 and $3,900,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; gains on the sale of discontinued operations of $40,800,000 for the quarter and $71,700,000 for the 6 months and an extraordinary loss of $4,700,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Concert: At the Marlboro Festival
description: The Marlboro Music Festival is not, its directors are careful to explain, a festival in the ordinary sense, nor is it the school that its makeup seems to suggest. It is an institution in which younger professional musicians come to learn from older ones, and it is an organization that produces concerts - both for an eager audience here in the summer and for syndication in the form of an annual ''Music From Marlboro'' tour in the fall.

title: Fight for Crazy Eddie Urged
description: The chairman of Entertainment Marketing Inc., who on Tuesday said he had dropped his offer for Crazy Eddie Inc., said today that he had been contacted by a number of Crazy Eddie shareholders who urged him to begin a proxy fight for the electronics retailer.

title: BUSINESSLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $911,000 and $2,070,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE BOYS OF WINTER. By Wilfrid Sheed. 280 pages. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Ben & Jerry's
description: Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc., an ice cream maker, said it had signed a licensing agreement with Jerry Garcia, lead guitarist and vocalist of the San Francisco rock band The Grateful Dead, allowing the company to use the name ''Cherry Garcia'' for one of its ice cream flavors. The Waterbury, Vt., company will pay a royalty on all sales of the flavor.

title: McLean Has Surgery
description: Kirk McLean, the Devils' goalie who injured himself running this month, had arthroscopic surgery on his left knee yesterday morning at New York University Medical Center. The surgery was performed by Dr. Barry Fisher. The Devils are expecting McLean to be ready for training camp in early September.

title: Dance: Juilliard Program
description: TWO dancers in the New York City Ballet and one former company member showed off their own choreography Tuesday as part of a showcase presented by the company's school, the School of American Ballet.

title: Securing the Hill
description: Efforts to protect the United States Capitol from terrorists have resulted in an ever-changing tableau of barricades and checkpoints scattered across the Capitol plaza.

title: Tyson Stock Is Up For Tucker Fight
description: Since the early betting line established him as a 7-1 favorite against Tony Tucker in the fight for the undisputed heavyweight title here Saturday, Mike Tyson's stock has gone up at sports books across this city. Depending on the vagaries of the wagering hour, Tyson has been favored lately at odds from 10-1 to 14-1.

title: How the U.S. Is Doing Better at the U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: Earnings Up at Reuters
description: Reuters Holdings P.L.C., the news and information company, said that its earnings in the first half of 1987 rose 44.3 percent, on a 49.3 percent increase in revenues. Reuters said that net income in the latest six months advanced to $82.2 million, or $1.18 per American depository share, from $57 million, or 83 cents per depository share, a year ago. One depository share equals six class B ordinary shares. Revenues climbed to $644.6 million from $431.8 million, the company said.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: M.D.C. Asset Investors Trust has issued nearly $345.7 million of collateralized mortgage obligations in a seven-part financing through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The trust is a financing subsidiary of M.D.C. Holdings, a Denver home builder.

title: 2 Men Given 5-to-15-Year Prison Terms in Slashing of Model
description: A Manhattan judge, rejecting last-minute proclamations of innocence by the defendants, sentenced two men yesterday to maximum terms of 5 to 15 years in prison in the Marla Hanson slashing case.

title: RIO ALCOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds. The company attributed the lower earnings in the latest second quarter and 6 months mainly to a substantial loss incurred by its 86 percent owned Potash Co. of America.

title: GALAXY CARPET MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
Taipei Asked to Revalue
description: The United States has asked Taiwan to revalue its currency upward to help the Reagan Administration fight protectionist bills and reduce its large trade deficit, officials said today. If the Taiwan dollar rose against the American dollar, American goods would be cheaper for Taiwanese buyers, and Taiwanese goods would be more expensive for American consumers, helping redress the current trade imbalance.

title: First 2 Loads of Radium Soil Removed From Jersey Lawns
description: Eighty-four rusting drums of radium-contaminated soil were loaded onto two trucks today and driven away from the lawns of four homes where they and thousands more drums have been stored for two years.

title: FIRST NEW HAMPSHIRE BANKS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a writedown of about $4.5 million from the writedown of the residential mortgage portfolio of the company's mortgage company subsidiary. c-After a credit of $2,887,000 resulting from a change in accounting. The per share earnings reflect a 25 percent stock dividend to be paid Sept. 1.

title: Half a Policy On Welfare Reform
description: LEAD: The welfare reform bill introduced by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, raises the always difficult political question of whether half a policy is better than none. The proposal would make some major changes in the nation's welfare system, and there can be no doubt that those changes should become law.

title: FIRST NATIONAL CORP (CALIF) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflects $330,000 in pre-tax expenses related to the acquisition of National Bankshares of La Jolla and National Bank of Fairbanks Ranch.

title: 'AW SHUCKS' PREMIER FOR ITALY: GIOVANNI GUISEPPE GORIA
description: Giovanni Goria likes to recall that his first big move into national politics, his appointment as Treasury Minister in 1982, came so unexpectedly that he had to borrow a friend's dark suit for the swearing-in ceremony.

title: Chelsea Residents Fight Plan For 1,000-Bed Men's Shelter
description: Several hundred angry residents of the Chelsea section of Manhattan expressed vehement opposition last night to a proposal by the city to use the former National Maritime Union building on West 17th Street as a 1,000-bed men's shelter and work-release jail site.

title: House Acts on Land Claim
description: The House has authorized spending $2.25 million to help settle a land battle between an Indian tribe and a town on Martha's Vineyard. Under the legislation sent to the Senate on Tuesday, the Federal Government and State of Massachusetts would split the $4.5 million purchase price of 180 acres on the island. Land bought with the money, plus 238 acres of public property, would be transferred to the Gay Head Wampanoag Indian Tribal Council. In exchange, the tribe would drop its claim to another 3,000-plus acres.

title: No Rerun in California
description: For a while it looked as though the California Congressional delegation was about to see a repeat of what happened last year, when a member gave up his House seat to challenge an incumbent Senator of the other party.

title: NEWORLD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $949,000 for the quarter and $1,791,000 for the 6 months.

title: Yields Rise On C.D.'s
description: Yields on certificates of deposit rose slightly last week as auctions of Treasury bills were again postponed.

title: Brazil Softens I.M.F. Stance
description: President Jose Sarney, signaling a more conciliatory tone toward Brazil's foreign creditors, has indicated his country could return to a formal agreement with the International Monetary Fund.

title: HOW THE U.S. IS DOING BETTER AT THE U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: WICOR INC reports earnings for 12mo to June 30
description: The company said that the revenue figures do not include costs of gas purchased directly by customers from gas producers.

title: U.S. ACTS TO RUSH COPTERS TO SWEEP MINES IN THE GULF
description: The Pentagon has ordered eight minesweeping helicopters to be flown immediately to the Persian Gulf to assist American naval forces in searching for mines in shipping channels and destroying them, officials said today.

title: HERITAGE-NIS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank went public in October.

title: Pauley Petroleum, Hondo to Merge
description: The Hondo Oil and Gas Company has agreed to merge with Pauley Petroleum Inc. in a deal analysts valued at about $150 million. Under terms of the transaction, Pauley, an oil refiner based in Los Angeles, would issue 10 million new shares in exchange for the stock of Hondo, a private concern based in Roswell, N.M.

title: Alysheba Will Forgo Lasix
description: Jack Van Berg confirmed yesterday that Alysheba will not race with Lasix in the $500,000 Haskell Handicap at Monmouth Park Saturday. Alysheba won the Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes with Lasix, an antibleeding drug that often improves overall performance, and was beaten by 14 1/4 lengths in the Belmont Stakes without it.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Based on information supplied by the designer's representative, the Discoveries column in Wednesday's Living Section gave an incorrect price for a Judith Lieber handbag at Saks Fifth Avenue. The correct price is $280.

title: FLAGLER BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Jack Clark Is a Mystery Pitchers Cannot Solve
description: Jack Clark. It has the ring of Jack Armstrong, or maybe Clark Kent or some other legendary hero. And that's what Jack Clark is becoming this summer in the uniform of the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: By the Seaside, Old-Fashioned Charm
description: ACTUALLY, Eric and Annie Gleacher already had a perfectly good home in the Hamptons - not on the beach, to be sure, but near it. But then they took a walk one day and saw three wonderful houses on a large pond that opens into the ocean. ''My husband looked up and said, 'Someday, my dream would be to own one of those houses,' '' Mrs. Gleacher recalled.

title: Q&A
description: Q.My home is quite close to the beach, so it gets lots of salt spray. The windows on the side of the house that faces the beach have salt spots on the glass that I can't seem to clean off. What can I do to get rid of these spots? A.If you can get to them while they are still fresh, the mineral deposits you are referring to can often be washed off with soap and water. They are more difficult to remove if you are unable to get to them until after they harden or ''set''.

title: LANE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Cabaret: Judy Tenuta
description: LIKE Emo Philips and Pee Wee Herman, Judy Tenuta, who is one of the country's fastest-rising stand-up comedy stars, plays a childlike eccentric who presides magisterially over her own twisted little empire of the imagination. Ms. Tenuta, who dresses like a tatty fairy princess and totes an accordion instead of a wand goes by several self-designated titles, including ''the petite flower,'' ''the living saint'' and ''the princess of power.'' From this regal altitude, she dispenses vengefully bratty complaints about the state of the world, reserving a special contempt for relations between the sexes.

title: PEOPLES SAVINGS (BROCKTON) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank converted from mutual to stock form in October 1986.

title: On Schedule
description: When he was last seen in these parts, on June 10, Stephane Peyron, a 26-year-old Frenchman, was skimming across New York Harbor on a 24 1/2-foot sailboard, hoping to become the first windsurfer to make a solo voyage across the Atlantic, a trip, he said, that should take about 50 days.

title: FIRST COMMERCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMERICAN GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $14,451,000 and $19,219,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes realized investment gains of $10,242,000 for the quarter and $26,118,000 for the 6 months.

title: STANDARD PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JULY 30, 1987
description: International A2-15

title: Kenneth L. Muse Dies at 75; Animator for Major Studios
description: Kenneth L. Muse, a Hollywood animator who drew Mickey Mouse for Walt Disney, Tom and Jerry for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and the Flintstones for Hanna-Barbera, has died. He was 75 years old.

title: IMASCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: NEW ON 6:25 FROM LEIPZIG, YOUNG EAST GERMANS
description: The train from Leipzig that rolls into Cologne's main station at 6:25 P.M. carries a new category of passengers these days - young East Germans who are being allowed to visit relatives and friends in West Germany.

title: FIELDCREST CANNON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the LIFO charge for the latest second quarter was $6 million and the 6-month was $8 million.

title: PEOPLES WESTCHESTER SAVNGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $1,841,000 for the quarter and $4,411,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $1,639,000 for the quarter and $3,222,000 for the 6 months.

title: LOUISIANA EXECUTES MURDERER OF 11-YEAR-OLD GIRL
description: John Brogdon was executed early this morning in the Louisiana State Penitentiary electric chair for the rape and torture murder of an 11-year-old girl.

title: NASA TEAM PLANS TO INVESTIGATE OZONE HOLE ABOVE THE ANTARCTIC
description: An international team will investigate the mysterious ozone hole over the Antarctic to see whether man-made chemicals, nature or both are destroying the gas vital to life on earth, space agency scientists announced Tuesday.

title: MESA LIMITED PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding are in units.

title: PEOPLES BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Houston Offers Sewer Bonds
description: Houston is offering $240 million of prior-lien sewer revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8.19 percent for bonds due in 2017. The offering is being made through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: HENRY HIRSCH
description: Henry Hirsch, a founder and chairman emeritus of the Welbilt Corporation, died yesterday at the New York University Medical Center. A resident of Manhattan, he was 84 years old.

title: VETERANS' RADIATION BENEFITS
description: The House has approved legislation that would require the Veterans Administration to pay disability benefits to veterans with certain types of cancer who were exposed to radiation in postwar atomic test explosions or in the occupation of Japan after World War II.

title: Conferees Approve Bank Bill
description: House and Senate conferees today approved a compromise between Congress and the White House on major banking legislation that has long been the subject of fierce Congressional debate. Administration officials said that President Reagan had promised he would sign the bill into law.

title: Music: Clarinet Pieces On Mostly Mozart Bill
description: TUESDAY evening's Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra program at Avery Fisher Hall was pretty much business as usual - or business as usual as it used to be, before performance standards were subtly but steadily upgraded over the last couple of summers. Tuesday's concert, repeated last night, was not bad by any means. But the orchestra's performance was still a little rough and perfunctory.

title: PENNBANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The per share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March.

title: HERS
description: LEAD: MY husband is forever running away from home. Though the pattern is familiar to me, I never consciously recognized it until a couple of months ago, when my daughter and I borrowed his car for a trip to a nearby town. We were gone perhaps four hours, during which, George told us later, he went to a local park to sit under a tree and read a book and listen to Bach on my little tape player.

title: Philharmonic Negotiating Concert Tour Of Soviet
description: The New York Philharmonic has been invited to tour the Soviet Union next spring. If negotiations with Goskontsert, the official Soviet concert agency, are successful, the orchestra will play three concerts in Leningrad and four in Moscow between May 28 and June 9.

title: Jazz: Threadgill Sextett
description: THE Henry Threadgill Sextett, appearing through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at 10th Street, could spoil listeners for most other small-group jazz. After the Sextett, more conventional groups sound hidebound and unimaginative.

title: TENNECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $27,000,000, or 18 cents a share, and $98,000,000, or 66 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Bethlehem Net Highest In 6 Years
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's third-largest steel company, yesterday reported a second-quarter net profit of $46.8 million, or 79 cents a share - its highest quarterly profit in six years. In the corresponding period last year, the company reported a loss of $23.8 million.

title: Bar Exam: Ordeal and a Rite of Passage
description: After seven years of college and law school, two months of cramming and 12 1/2 hours hunched over a test booklet, Franz Paasche was disappointed.

title: Removing Tarnish From Silverware
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH removing tarnish from silverware is not difficult, it is easy to prevent the problem by taking simple precautions.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JULY 30, 1987
description: Markets

title: GENERAL BINDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BATTLE MOUNTAIN GOLD CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HORIZON BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank went public last August.

title: Treatment by Yankees Upsetting to Henderson
description: He was a lone figure in the clubhouse yesterday, the one player who seemed unable to enjoy the brilliant afternoon in the Bronx and the victory that by day's end would increase the Yankees' first-place lead to 1 1/2 games over Detroit and 2 over Toronto. Rickey Henderson angrily stalked from the shower to the trainer's room to his locker. His teammates had already dressed and departed, but Henderson lingered.

title: Correction
description: Because of a mechanical error, some editions of Wednesday's Living Section contained incomplete preparation and cooking times for Tiebou Dienn, a dish from Senegal. The correct preparation time is 20 minutes and the cooking time is 1 hour, 15 minutes.

title: Foreign-Bank Status in Peru
description: President Alan Garcia excluded foreign banks today from a decree regarding a state administrative takeover of Peru's banks and lending companies, which precedes a proposed nationalization.

title: KINDER CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SENDS SOLDIERS
description: Sri Lanka and India signed an accord Wednesday intended to end four years of ethnic violence, and early this morning, military officials said, an Indian peacekeeping force began arriving in northern Sri Lanka.

title: Networks Take Turns In Covering Hearings
description: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair will be televised live beginning at 9 A.M. on the ABC television network under the network rotation system. The hearings will also be televised on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on some local affiliates of PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service, including Channel 13 in New York.

title: Henley Group
description: Bassak Ltd., a Bermuda-based investment firm, said it had lowered its stake in the Henley Group Inc. to 3.45 percent from 7.6 percent. On July 22, Bassak sold 4.5 million shares in the New York-based diversified manufacturer to Salomon Brothers Inc. for $28.75 a share, or a total of $129.4 million. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Bassak gave no reason for selling the Henley shares. Last week, Henley announced it would repurchase 25 million of its shares for $28 a share in cash.

title: 1 of 3 Saved Whales Is Sighted by Curator
description: One of three young whales that beached themselves on Cape Cod in December and were rescued and returned to the sea by the New England Aquarium last month has been spotted for the first time swimming with a pod of 50 whales about 60 miles south of where the three were released, aquarium officials said today.

title: G.O.P. SENATE UNIT CALLED METZENBAUM A COMMUNIST ALLY
description: The Republican Senate campaign committee prepared and distributed a report describing Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, as a man whose ''Communist sympathies have found their way onto the Senate floor.''

title: Sun Microsystems
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. and National Advanced Systems said they had agreed to develop an operating system and other software to allow common applications between Sun's computer work stations and National's mainframe computers. Both Sun and National Advanced, a subsidiary of the National Semiconductor Corporation, are based in Mountain View, Calif. The National computers are made in Japan by Hitachi Ltd. d it would repurchase 25 million of its shares for $28 a share in cash.

title: Jazz: Henry Butler
description: THE audience at Sweet Basil on Tuesday was dotted with well-known pianists, there to check out a flashy player who grew up in New Orleans and now lives in Los Angeles, Henry Butler. Leading a quartet with three first-rate sidemen - Alvin Batiste on clarinet, Ron Carter on bass and Joe Chambers on drums - Mr. Butler revels in fluency and facility, splashing chords all over the keyboard and streaking through solos with machine-gun articulation. At the moment, though, he gets carried away with his technique.

title: DIXIE YARNS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Increased by $3,087,000, or 27 cents a share, and $3,087,000, or 32 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from gains on termination of one of the company's overfunded retirement plants. c-Increased by $3,604,000, or 64 cents a share for both the quarter and 6 months from plant sales.

title: BERKLEY, W R CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $210,000 and $632,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; and the 6-month also includes a tax benefit of $4,181,000. c-Includes realized investment gains of $267,000 for the quarter and $586,000 for the 6 months; and tax benefits of $1,268,000 and $2,589,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: REAGAN CAMPAIGN AIDE IS FOCUS OF NEW INQUIRY
description: A 1980 Reagan campaign official shared hundreds of thousands of dollars with a former personal assistant to the President who was paid to arrange private meetings at the White House between Mr. Reagan and conservative contributors to the contras.

title: 'JAKE'S M.O.,' WITH A LINK TO REALITY
description: DETECTIVE stories suffer from exhaustion; stories about reporters who help detectives grow tired, too. ''Jake's M.O.'' revives both genres. It is modest, literate and good humored, even if people do get shot in the back. The one-hour movie will be seen on NBC, Channel 4, at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: A Flurry Of Records On Wall St.
description: The stock market surged again to new highs yesterday, after shrugging off some early profit taking and an unsubstantiated rumor that a Navy ship had hit a mine in the Persian Gulf.

title: NATIONAL CITY BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rangers Sign Duguay
description: Ron Duguay, the Ranger center who was traded to the Detroit Red Wings in 1983 and then reacquired last season in a trade with the Pittsburgh Penguins, has signed with the Rangers for next season. No terms were announced.

title: CILCORP INC reports earnings for 12mo June 30
Executive in Drunken Driving Death Is Out of Jail
description: A liquor company executive who pleaded guilty to murder in a drunken driving case was ordered released from the Jefferson County jail Tuesday after serving one month of his 20-year sentence.

title: Crossing Atlantic To Get to N.H.L.
description: Brothers have been common enough in hockey, but with such exceptions as the six Sutter brothers, all of whom have made their marks on the National Hockey League, and the Richards, sets of siblings have generally played at different levels. Vic Howe, for example, was never the star his brother, Gordie, was, and Dennis Hull always lived in the shadow of Bobby. Even so, Vic Howe and Dennis Hull both had more than decent careers at the top level.

title: VALUE LINE INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Includes net investment income of $4,792,000 for the latest year and $1,836,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Credit-Card Rules Tightened in 12 States
description: Twelve states passed laws this year restricting the advertising practices, fees and interest rates for credit cards, but similar measures died in 24 legislatures, a consumer group said Tuesday.

title: Star of 'The Equalizer' Hospitalized in England
description: Edward Woodward, the British actor who plays the title role in the CBS television adventure series ''The Equalizer,'' was being treated today for a suspected heart attack, and a hospital official said the actor's condition was improving.

title: Hawker Siddeley Deal
description: Britain's Hawker Siddeley Group P.L.C. said today that it agreed to buy Aerospace Avionics Inc., a private New York concern, for $:17.5 million, or $28 million, in cash. Aerospace Avionics supplies electronic subsystems to leading makers in the American aerospace industry.

title: Market Place; The Asbestos Cleanup Push
description: THE embryonic asbestos abatement industry, which is taking on the task of removing the potentially harmful mineral from hundreds of thousands of buildings, is seen by many analysts as holding vast investment potential over the long term.

title: Candidate List for Commerce
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the White House chief of staff, asked his aides today to pull together a list of candidates to fill the Commerce Secretary's job vacated by the death of Malcolm Baldrige, a senior Administration official said.

title: HAITIAN SOLDIERS KILL 8 AT A RALLY
description: Soldiers fired into a crowd of about 2,500 protesters today, killing at least 8 people and wounding 15, as the demonstrators marched to condemn the disbanded private militia known as the Tontons Macoute, witnesses said.

title: TRAVELERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment losses of $8.5 million and $19.4 million in the latest and year-ago periods, respectively. c-Includes investment gains of $25.2 million and $23 million in the latest and year-ago periods, respectively. The latest quarter's net from operations includes a tax benefit of $10.4 million from property casualty ''fresh start'' provisions.

title: Intel to Resell Japanese Chips
description: The Intel Corporation, which has long accused Japanese semiconductor companies of unfair trade practices, has reached an agreement to sell computer memory chips made by Japan's Mitsubishi Electric Corporation.

title: 283 Years Later, Dispute Over Gibraltar Persists
description: Patrons at dockside cafes covered their ears to block the engine noise as the Boeing 737 jetliner roared down the runway, which thrusts like an aircraft carrier into Algeciras Bay, and up into the sky toward England.

title: The U.N. Today: July 30, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ACCOUNTANT BACKED A SIMPLER TAX CODE
description: Jacob S. Seidman, a senior partner of the accounting firm of Seidman & Seidman and a longtime proponent of simplifying the tax system, died Monday at Doctors Hospital. He lived in Manhattan and was 86 years old.

title: Far Afield
description: It may be awhile before it rivals basketball, soccer or even field hockey, but there is a budding sport on the collegiate scene, and if Smith College has its way, it shouldn't be long before the campus of the women's school in Northampton, Mass., is the scene of the fiercest competition.

title: WALTHAM SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank converted to stock form of ownership in May 1986.

title: New York City Police Need More Cells at Central Booking
description: To the Editor:

title: Rock: The Howlers
description: AUSTIN, Tex., exports a lot of blues-based rock bands -lately, the Fabulous Thunderbirds, Stevie Ray Vaughan and now Omar and the Howlers, who performed Tuesday at the Bottom Line. The Howlers are a taut, forceful quartet that plays blues, rockabilly and occasionally a pop song with a bridge; they keep the music tough and basic.

title: JEFFERSON BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains of $732,238 from the sale and leaseback of properties and a gain of $2,329 on security transactions. c-Includes a gain of $656,234 on security transactions.

title: Tobacco Unit's Officers
description: The American Tobacco Company, a division of American Brands Inc., said yesterday that Charles H. Mullen had been appointed president and chief operating officer. Mr. Mullen, 59 years old, succeeds Thomas C. Hayes, who was elected chairman and continues as chief executive. Mr. Hayes will also become president and chief operating officer of American Brands. The company, based in Stamford, Conn., also announced these appointments: Cleveland C. Kern Jr., 46, to executive vice president; William J. Moore, 60, to senior vice president, marketing, and Robert S. Sprinkle 3d, 52, to senior vice president, research and development.

title: GERMANTOWN SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $1,125,000 for the quarter and $2,022,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $817,000 for the quarter and $1,278,000 for the 6 months. The bank converted to stock form from mutual form in April.

title: Fraternity Bans Hazing
description: A college fraternity with 700 chapters and 125,000 members in the United States and abroad has banned hazing. At the end of its national convention Tuesday, the fraternity, Alpha Phi Alpha, ordered its affiliates to halt ''abusive physical contact or mental harassment of pledges.'' J. Herbert King, a spokesman for the convention who is a Chicago educator, winced at the memory of the ''brutality'' he says he suffered at the University of Chicago. He said unspecified disciplinary action would be taken against fraternity members who ignore the ban.

title: BELDING HEMINWAY CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GENERAL RE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $7.3 million and $13.4 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; and the 6-month also includes an extraordinary credit of $11.7 million. c-Includes realized investment gains of $6.6 million for the quarter and $13.4 million for the 6 months.

title: Pacificorp in Talks With Utah Power
description: Pacificorp, an electric utility and telecommunications concern, said today that it had held merger discussions with the Utah Power and Light Company, but added that it had not made a formal offer.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Year to June 30
Connecting With the Constitution
description: The site of the first Capitol of the United States, the building where the Bill of Rights was drafted, the site where George Washington was inaugurated and the chapel where he prayed - all of this can be seen by strolling through Lower Manhattan.

title: CHURCH & DWIGHT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Manufacturing Reclaims Pasture In East New York
description: Vacant land has been so abundant for so long in the East New York section of Brooklyn that the horse grazing until recently in a pastoral lot on Williams Avenue hardly seemed out of place.

title: Thorn to Buy Rent-A-Center
description: Thorn E.M.I., a British consumer products company, said today that it had agreed to buy the Rent-A-Center chain in the United States for $594 million.

title: Foreign Aid From the Bottom Up
description: Many Americans nurse the myth that economic development aid to third world countries goes to relieve the plight of the very poor. In truth, the money too often turns up in the pockets of the rich or in showy projects with questionable trickle-down effect. Are there no good ways efficiently to help the poorest of the world's poor? A handful of loan programs begin to provide a heartening answer. Congress has a chance to increase their impact.

title: CAPITOL BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
