title: Moscow Ballet's Tour Dates
description: The Moscow Ballet is to open its first American tour Sept. 24 at the Lyric Opera House in Baltimore. The company, under the direction of Vacheslav Gordeyev, a principal dancer with the Bolshoi Ballet of Moscow, is to perform in 21 American cities during a one-month tour that ends with performances at the War Memorial Auditorium in Trenton on Nov. 27 and 28.

title: DIVERSION OF FUNDS: CONFLICTS ON WHO KNEW
description: According to testimony before the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North made conflicting statements concerning who else in the Government knew about the diversion of profits from sale of arms to Iran to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Cracks in Tank Motors Are Traced to Maker
description: Cracks that have appeared in 22 engines in recent months, causing a sudden drop of power in the Army's top tank, apparently resulted from faulty welding at the engine-maker's plant.

title: RORER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains of $1,095,000 and $140,622,000 on disposal of discontinued businesses for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: CORROON & BLACK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $4,672,000 from discontinued operations.

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK OF GEORGIA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Modern Ceramists Break Out of Mold
description: SO patent is the message in the exhibition that opens at the American Craft Museum tomorrow that it fairly jumps off the display modules. How, the show asks, can you get people to look at ceramics as sculpture if all they see is pots?

title: MIDWAY AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $3,288,000 for the quarter and $3,708,000 for the 6 months.

title: Occidental Deal
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said it plans to buy an idled chemical plant in Corpus Christi, Tex., from E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, and put 200 workers back on the job when operations resume next year. Occidental declined to give specific terms of the transaction.

title: NEWMONT GOLD CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Emma Hawes, Winner Of World Bridge Titles
description: Emma Jean Hawes, one of the world's leading women in tournament bridge, died of breast cancer Tuesday at her home in Fort Worth after a long battle with the disease. She was 75 years old.

title: UNITED SAVERS BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOUSE RETAINS LIMIT ON UTILITIES' NUCLEAR LIABILITY
description: The House of Representatives voted 300 to 119 today to retain a limit on the liability of public utilities in accidents at their nuclear reactors.

title: HISTORY TEXTS FAIL TO TEACH IDEAS OF DEMOCRACY, STUDY SAYS
description: History curriculums in most American schools are woefully inadequate and fail to teach students to understand and appreciate democracy, a report released today by the American Federation of Teachers concluded.

title: ALCO STANDARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After the reversal of 1986 investment tax credits of $1,150,000. c-Includes a gain of $2,164,000 on the sale of Health Services stock.

title: THE TESTIMONY: 'DIFFERENT PEOPLE WITH DIFFERING RECOLLECTIONS'
description: In his second day of testimony yesterday at the Congressional hearings in Washington, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d was questioned further on his conduct of the investigation into the Iran-contra affair. Here, as recorded by The New York Times, are excerpts from his testimony.

title: Advertising; Beth Israel Hospital Plans Marketing Effort
description: Beth Israel Medical Center, one of New York City's 10 largest hospitals, is responding to the increasingly competitive nature of the health care industry by retaining Berenter Greenhouse & Webster to set up a marketing communictions program that will probably include advertising.

title: The Forgotten War
description: Remember the war against narcotics? You know, when our top officials were talking about how drug abuse and the flood of drugs into the country were poisoning the nation and how we had to get together and use all our resources in a real war to lick the drug problem?

title: FIRST AMERICAN BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company converted to stock form of ownership July 24, 1986.

title: MID MAINE SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank converted to stock ownership in December.

title: Public TV Series to Commission and Produce Plays
description: After six years of showcasing top American theater, ''American Playhouse,'' the weekly public television series, is branching out into theater production.

title: Standard Brands May Get New Bid
description: Entregrowth International Ltd., the American subsidiary of a New Zealand company whose $308 million takeover offer for Standard Brands Paint Company was rejected Monday, said it might revise its bid for the California company. Entregrowth, a subsidiary of the Chase Corporation, said it was considering whether to make a new bid directly to shareholders or to make a new offer to the board.

title: British-French Tunnel Treaty
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and President Francois Mitterrand of France formally ratified the Channel Tunnel treaty in a ceremony at Elysee Palace today, clearing the way for construction to go ahead after nearly two centuries of debate.

title: EG&G INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said results for the year-ago second quarter and 6-month have been adjusted to reflect the 1987 first quarter acquisition of KT Aerofab Inc.

title: Ward Makes Apology For Comment on Rape
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward apologized yesterday for telling a woman who expressed fears for her safety after a series of rapes in Queens that she was the type of young, attractive target a rapist would attack.

title: Qualities Of Algae Are Odd
description: The brown tide in the bays of Long Island is, in many ways, no different from the hundreds of algae blooms that discolor waters around the world.

title: CARDS LOSE GAME AND CLARK
description: ''As far as I'm concerned, we're back in it,'' Dave Johnson said. ''As far as I'm concerned, he was never out of it,'' Whitey Herzog replied.

title: HANNAFORD BROTHERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: The company said sales in the year- ago second quarter and 6-month reflect a retroactive reclassification of certain income items previously treated as a reduction of selling, general and administrative expense.

title: FIRST MUTUAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

Advertising; Magazine Pretax Profits Were 11% in 1986
description: Things looked better for magazine profitability last year than the year before, according to the results of a Price Waterhouse survey conducted among members of the Magazine Publishers Association. With 181 magazines responding, the average pretax operating profit came out at 11 percent, compared with 9.7 percent for the 169 responding in 1985 and 11.3 percent for 174 in 1984.

title: FEAR INFRINGES ON SANCTITY OF AIDS PATIENTS' PRIVACY
description: When a Boston man was recently told he was infected with the AIDS virus, he asked his doctor to keep the information confidential. The man said he planned to file for divorce and that if his wife were told, it would complicate matters.

title: Three ABC Cameramen Lose Discrimination Suit
description: Jurors rejected $3.5 million in claims by three black cameramen who said ABC-TV discriminated against them by barring them from working in the network's highest-paying jobs.

title: ALGAE TIDES AGAIN AFFLICT L.I., AND SCIENTISTS STILL WONDER
description: From one end of Long Island to the other, tides of algae are overwhelming harbors, bays and the Sound this summer, suffocating or starving marine life.

title: Scotch Account Given to Grace
description: Obviously pleased with the fresh and smart advertising Grace & Rothschild has recently been supplying for its J & B Scotch, the Paddington Corporation has now assigned the agency its Knockando single-malt Scotch. As a category, single malt and imported vodka are the only distilled spirits exhibiting growth. Madison Avenue magazine in

title: Plea on Firearms Charge
description: A man who led a paramilitary patrol along the Mexican border that reportedly held 16 illegal aliens at gunpoint pleaded guilty Tuesday to a Federal firearms charge under a plea agreement. The man, J. R. Hagan, 37 years old, of Tucson, former regional director for Arizona and Utah in the conservative group Civilian Materiel Assistance, pleaded guilty before Federal District Judge William D. Browning. Sentencing was set for Sept. 21.

title: Security Guard is Held in 3 Rapes and 4 Burglaries on Staten Island
description: A suspect was arrested yesterday in connection with at least three early-morning rapes committed at knife point and four burglaries on Staten Island in the last three weeks, the police said.

title: Grand Jury Will Investigate Fire Fatal to Seven in Harlem
description: A grand jury will investigate the blaze at the high-rise Schomburg Plaza that killed seven people last March, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said yesterday.

title: Charm School for Children
description: ''Please'' and ''thank-you'' can be passwords to a better life, said a city alderman here who has hired a consultant to teach etiquette to poor children.

title: Military Worried by Pickens's Interest in Boeing
description: Pentagon lawyers and financial managers are worried about the implications of a possible investment in the Boeing Company by T. Boone Pickens. They are examining whether such a move might damage the performance of the military's eighth-largest supplier, and whether the Defense Department has any power to intervene.

title: UNIBANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $654,000 for the quarter and $1,170,000 for the 6 months.

title: SUN ENERGY PARTNERS LP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The share earnings are in units.

title: Dance: Douglas Dunn, at 'Serious Fun!' Festival
description: DOWNTOWN dance, theater and music have been transported to Lincoln Center in the ''Serious Fun!'' festival, which runs through Sunday at Alice Tully Hall. The premise is that uptown audiences deserve a look at what is going on at the experimentalist theaters south of 14th Street. But the festival's dance program on Tuesday suggested that such work - or the dance component of it, at any rate - looks better in its home environment.

title: Huston Is Hospitalized; His Condition Is Good
description: John Huston was in good condition today after an ambulance carried him to a hospital for emergency treatment of emphysema, a hospital spokeswoman said.

title: No Grounds to Prosecute in Overturned Case
description: A special state prosecutor has found no grounds to prosecute members of the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, the Police Department or a witness for their roles in the conviction and imprisonment of a Brooklyn man in 1980 on murder and robbery charges that were later overturned.

title: Transtar Air To Close Down
description: The Transtar Airlines Corporation, a small Houston-based regional air carrier owned by the Southwest Airlines Company, said today that it will discontinue operations on Aug. 9 and liquidate its assets.

title: FIRST FEDERAL OF THE CAROLINAS FA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
At Saint Laurent, A Bold Collection
description: Yves Saint Laurent delivered fashion back to the 20th century this morning and received a standing ovation for his effort. To an audience surfeited with heavy doses of grandeur since the fall and winter couture showings began Sunday, his clean, crisp classics were welcome.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: Although a brick wall is thought of as a permanent structure requiring little or no maintenance, that is not entirely true. Good-quality bricks will ordinarily last almost indefinitely, but the mortar joints between them may start to crack and crumble after a number of years.

title: FIRST FIDELITY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest second quarter was attributable almost entirely to a special provision of $56 million for possible future uncollectable loans.

title: Talking Deals; Price Goes Up For Magazines
description: MAGAZINE buyouts keep getting more expensive. As recently as five years ago, deals for well-established publications were done at eight to 10 times cash flow. But recently a management-led group agreed to pay $650 million, or 14 times cash flow, for CBS Inc.'s 21 consumer magazines. Even those publishing executives accustomed to ever-escalating prices were surprised.

title: INSIDE
description: East Germans Allow Visits

title: MULTIBANK FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Leaks, Lies and Other Excuses
description: Hardly a day goes by in the Iran-contra hearings that witnesses and legislators don't trade charges about divulging confidential information to the press. Some of the most prominent witnesses have employed the accusation to justify their having lied to Congress. Members of Congress resent the charge and reply that most leaks come from the other end of Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis U.S. Sweeps Singles: The United States swept both singles matches against France yesterday to move into the quarterfinals of the Federation Cup tournament in Vancouver, British Columbia. Pam Shriver, playing singles because of an injury to top-ranked Martina Navratilova -her doubles partner - defeated Isabelle Demongeot, 6-0, 7-6. Chris Evert, who expects to play doubles in Navratilova's absence, easily downed Mathalie Tauziat, 6-1, 6-0.

title: PRIMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring credit of $29.1 million which includes a net gain of $37 million from the sale of certain timberlands and a net gain of $15.2 million from the public offering of common stock by the company's subsidiary, Musicland Group Inc., less a net reserve of $23.1 million related to the participation of one of the company's former subsidiaries in a joint venture engaged in real estate syndication and property management. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $19.1 million and includes a non-recurring charge of $4.9 million. d-Includes net from discontinued operations of $26.8 million and a nonrecurring credit of $24.4 million which includes a net gain of $800,000 from sale of certain timberlands, a net gain of $42.1 million from the public offering of the common stock of American Capital Management & Research Inc. and a net charge of $13.6 million resulting from a strike at the company's discontinued packaging business. The net for the year-ago quarter includes a net gain of $2.5 million from the sale of certain timberlands, a net gain of $5.8 million from the exercise of an overallotment option by the Underwriters of American Capital Management & Research stock and a net charge of $13.2 million resulting from the redemption of four debenture issues.

title: Times Co., Time in Deal
description: The New York Times Company and Time Inc. agreed in principle yesterday to form a partnership for national magazine distribution.

Money Separating Giants and Stars
description: If everything goes right, all of the Giants will be in training camp here Friday. But don't bet on everything going right.

title: New York Investigators Say State Senator Took a Bribe
description: State investigators said yesterday that New York State Senator Richard E. Schermerhorn accepted about $6,000 from an organized-crime figure to help obtain state construction contracts at Stewart Airport in Orange County.

title: EASTMAN KODAK CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 14
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $31 million from the sale of properties abroad and $17 million from a change in pension accounting for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss d-After extraordinary charges of $167.8 million and $210.7 million, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, relating principally to a reduction- in-force program and inventory and equipment writedowns and writeoffs.

title: Crafting Modern Rugs That Look Like Antiques
description: ''WE wanted handwoven rugs of the kind they made in the 18th and 19th century, but new and fresh-looking instead of old ones,'' said William Diamond, the interior designer who supervised the decoration of Annie and Eric Gleacher's country house. He noted that it is almost impossible to find antique rugs in the large sizes he needed.

title: INDEPENDENCE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago results reflect merger with Third National Bank of Scranton in March 1987.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Lendl Forced to Rally: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl rallied to beat 18-year-old David Wheaton, 6-7, 6-3, 6-2, yesterday to advance to the quarterfinals of the $232,000 D.C. Tennis Classic in Washington. Boris Becker and Jimmy Connors moved into the final eight with straight-set victories. Becker, the second seed, rallied from a 3-4 first-set deficit to beat John Ross, 6-4, 6-2. Connors needed only 70 minutes to defeat Jim Pugh, 6-3, 6-1.

title: Allegheny Secures New Credit Line
description: Allegheny International Inc., the troubled industrial and consumer products company, said it had reached a new revolving-credit agreement with a consortium of banks. The company said the agreement prohibits payments of dividends and requires it to maintain certain levels of net worth.

title: EPSILON DATA MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss The company said fiscal 1986 fourth quarter and year results reflect a pre- tax charge of $1,837,000 due to the expected termination of the company's role as servicing agent or Pan Am's worldpass program.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't mind spears in the breast. It's knives in the back that concern me.'' - Donald T. Regan. [ A9:2. ]

title: ISRAELI PROPOSES OUSTER OF ARABS
description: A furor has erupted in Israel over a Government official's proposal that the 900,000 Palestinian Arabs living in the occupied West Bank be sent to Jordan.

description: DIVERTIMENTO 1889. By Guido Morselli. Translated from the Italian with an Introduction by Hugh Shankland. 145 pages. E. P. Dutton. $15.95.

description: b-Net loss The latest 9 months' net is after writedowns of $90,000 in idle equipment.

From Reagan: 'This Didn't Happen'
description: In the frantic weeks after the American arms shipments to Iran were exposed, President Reagan told aides to protect the American hostages in Lebanon by limiting disclosure and instead make statements that pointed up inaccuracies in press accounts, according to notes made public today.

title: 'THE SPIRIT,' ON ABC, BASED ON COMIC BOOK
description: WE haven't had a comic-book character on television for a while. Batman and Robin long ago went the way of syndication, while Superman flew off years ago. Comes now, however, the Spirit, who is the crime-fighter in a domino mask. Will Eisner's comic-book creation socks thugs in a 90-minute movie, ''The Spirit,'' on ABC tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: A Better Way to Save the Thrifts
description: LEAD: A compromise bill worked out this week between Congressional leaders and the Treasury to rescue the battered savings and loan industry is inadequate, at best. In fact, by reinforcing the mistakes of the past, it could make matters worse.

Washington Talk: Single-Issue Lobbying; Caustic Debate on Acid Rain Letter
description: The letterhead says the appeal is from ''Citizens for Sensible Control of Acid Rain.''

title: AIDS TESTING MEASURES OFFERED IN BOTH HOUSES
description: Key Congressional leaders on health policy, supported by many of the country's most influential health organizations, introduced legislation today in the House and Senate that would greatly expand testing for the AIDS virus. The testing would be done on a voluntary basis with strict civil rights guarantees.

title: Microsoft Buys Software Unit
description: The Microsoft Corporation announced its first significant software acquisition today, paying $14 million for Forethought Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif.

title: BRITAIN'S TOP COURT BANS SPY'S MEMOIRS IN ALL PRESS REPORTS
description: Britain's highest court, backing the Government in a confrontation with the press, barred newspapers today from reporting the memoirs of a retired intelligence agent even though his book is available on the streets of London, fresh from its American publisher.

title: Opera: 'Troades' Debut
description: If Aribert Riemann's ''Troades'' does not go on to find a place in the international repertory, it will be no fault of the Bavarian State Opera or the Jean-Pierre Ponnelle production that introduced the work here as part of the Munich Opera Festival. No effort or expense was spared, evidently, to shine the best light on this difficult new work, which re-tells in one two-hour act of unrelieved agony and tension the Homeric tale of the Trojan women whom the victorious Greeks took as concubines after capturing and burning Troy.

description: b-Net income

title: Houston Person
description: Houston Person, an alto saxophonist, and Etta Jones, a singer, will lead their group tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9, 10:30 P.M., midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is no fourth set on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum tonight and tomorrow, a $5 cover and a $7.50 minimum on Sunday.

title: Tito Puente's Ever-Fresh Old Songs
description: TITO PUENTE has been performing his composition ''Oye Como Va,'' a call-and-response tune steeped in Afro-Cuban tradition, for the last 30 years. The tune itself hasn't changed, but its surroundings have, in ways the composer could hardly have foreseen.

title: U.S. Is Considering Ending Suspension of Aid to Panama
description: The Reagan Administration is reviewing whether to resume military and economic aid to Panama, the State Department spokesman, Charles A. Redman, said today.

title: Focus of Blame
description: In a forthcoming autobiography, Lawrence Taylor of the New York Giants admits he was hooked on cocaine during the 1985 season. He implies that, because of his star status and the Giants' wish not to lose his services, his coaches didn't try very hard to discipline him.

title: U.S. Copter Crashes in Gulf; 1 Is Dead and 3 Are Missing
description: An American helicopter serving in the naval force deployed to escort Kuwaiti oil tankers crashed in the Persian Gulf today, killing one man and leaving three others missing at sea, according to military officials. Five were rescued. The crash of the Sea-King helicopter occurred as it approached the La Salle, the command vessel of the escort fleet.

It is to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the playwright's birth.

description: b-Includes a $6 million gain. Year-ago results are restated. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Film: 'Living Daylights,' With the New Bond
description: IT'S a tough job, keeping the world's waiters and butlers and bathing beauties apprised that he takes his martinis ''shaken, not stirred.'' But somebody has to do it, and in ''The Living Daylights'' - a great title, from a 1966 Ian Fleming short story - that somebody is Timothy Dalton. Mr. Dalton, the latest successor to the role of James Bond, is well equipped for his new responsibilities. He has enough presence, the right debonair looks and the kind of energy that the Bond series has lately been lacking. If he radiates more thoughtfulness than the role requires, maybe that's just gravy.

title: Computers Replace Coziness as Republicans Stress Iowa Caucuses
description: Republican Presidential front-runners are already waging a fierce battle with 3-by-5 cards and personal computers to identify and perhaps lock in supporters now to help them in February.

title: FIRST OHIO BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: First Ohio said the decline in earnings results is from a $3.9 million increase in its loan loss provision in the latest quarter related to the FSLIC secondary reserve.

title: Sports of The Times; Carter's Right at Home
description: Gary Carter, that old showoff, is up to his old tricks again.

title: GREYHOUND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reduced by extraordinary charges of $2.7 million and $5.7 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, reflecting premiums paid on early retirement of debt. c-Includes gains of $89.5 million, or $1.90 a share for the quarter and $91.7 million, or $1.95 a share, for the 6 months on the sale of 5.1 million common shares of Conagra common stock. Revenue represents combined revenue. Combined revenues include the unconsolidated Financial Group.

title: CHIPS & TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $273,000 for the quarter and $432,000 for the year.

title: PIONEER FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INTERNATIONAL MINERALS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,800,000 and $11.3 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and a charge of $4,800,000 from the early retirement of debt for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss d-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $141,200,000 for the quarter and $137,400,000 for the year.

title: JUSTIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PORTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and 6 months includes a gain of $2,772,000 from pension plan termination.

title: NU-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
COLUMBIA FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest fourth quarter earnings were reduced by 16 cents a share by the addition of $383,000 to reserves for possible losses on real estate owned through foreclosure. The net was further reduced by 3 cents a share for writeoff of the FSLIC secondary reserve.

title: MINUTES WITH KEMP WITHOUT KEMP
description: A dozen people gathered in the home of Blanche and Roger Sirois, sipping coffee and soft drinks and examining a new campaign product.

title: Festival Latino Puts an Accent On Global Themes
description: IT'S not Christmas yet, but a pinata filled with rich artistic gifts is about to burst on this city. The 11th Festival Latino in New York - the biggest Latin American cultural event in the United States and one of the most important showcases anywhere for Latin talent - begins tomorrow. Fifty thousand people attended the festival's events last year, and at least as many are expected this time.

title: A Portion of L.I. Sound Has No Oxygen or Fish
description: Earlier this week, a group of scientists and environmental officials trolled Long Island Sound and made a rare, if not unprecedented, discovery off Hempstead Harbor: water with no oxygen, and no fish.

title: KINNARD INVESTMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago quarter and 6-month share earnings are adjusted for a 6-for-5 stock split in January 1987.

title: MCDONNELL DOUGLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest second quarter earnings include a pre-tax gain of $48.6 million from a change in accounting method and an increase in the actuarial rate of return on the pension plan. The latest 6 months' results were favorably impacted by the conversion of several short-term leases on MD-80 jetliners to long-term leases, resulting in a pre-tax gain of $38 million. This period also includes a pre-tax gain of $91.4 million from changes in accounting procedures and increases in the actuarial rate of return on pension assets.

title: Band's Quest For Stardom
description: By 7:45 P.M. Madison Square Garden was filling with young, excited rock-and-rollers. A good omen, thought Steve Mountain, manager of the opening act, the Hooters, as he looked at the 18,500 seats.

title: JOHN A. MAYER
description: John A. Mayer, former chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Mellon Bank Corporation, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Wednesday at Latrobe Area Hospital in Latrobe , Pa. He was 77 years old and lived in Ligonier, Pa.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CITIZENS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LOMAS & NETTLETON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DeVEREN BOOKWALTER
description: DeVeren Bookwalter, the actor and director, died of stomach cancer July 23 at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: TUCSON ELECTRIC POWER COMPANY INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring credit of $9,332,000 and $14,150,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Lineup of Large Questions
description: The Haskell Handicap at Monmouth Park tomorrow should answer three important and intriguing questions: Can Alysheba win without Lasix? Was Bet Twice's Belmont Stakes victory a fluke or the start of a championship season? Is Lost Code as good as the division's leaders?

title: First Chicago to Curtail Its Overseas Operations
description: The First Chicago Corporation said today that it planned to reduce its overseas presence substantially and indicated that it would close its branches in a number of cities, such as Paris, Frankfurt and Rome.

title: Brief by Feminists Opposes Surrogate Parenthood
description: A group of well-known feminists joined today in filing an amicus brief in the Baby M case, arguing that the commercialization of surrogate parenthood violates the Constitution and the dignity of women.

title: Sports People; Theismann Tells of Bets
description: Joe Theismann admits that he lost more than $35,000 gambling in one season and more than $10,000 during a single training camp, but the former Washington Redskin quarterback said he never bet on games. In his book ''Theismann,'' written with Dave Kindred, Theismann said that he lost money in card games with his teammates and drinking buddies and at the casinos in Las Vegas, Nev., and that his wife, Cathy Lee Crosby, broke him of the habit.

title: Board Worried Thrift Units Might Quit F.S.L.I.C.
description: Four of the nation's 10 largest savings and loan associations may be planning to leave the crippled deposit insurance system for thrift institutions for a much stronger Government agency that insures deposits at commercial and savings banks, officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board are warning.

title: FIRST GEORGIA SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
General Cinema's 61% Neiman Stake
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. disclosed that the General Cinema Corporation will control more than 60 percent of Neiman-Marcus Group Inc., the new public company created in Carter Hawley's restructuring plan. In a proxy statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Carter Hawley said that General Cinema plans to buy an additional 471,012 Carter Hawley shares before the restructuring, raising its stake to 48.9 percent, from 46.6 percent.

title: Walter T. Skallerup, Counsel For Navy Dept., Dies at 67
description: Walter T. Skallerup Jr., the general counsel of the Navy Department and a former deputy assistant secretary of defense, died of cancer Wednesday at the Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 67 years old and lived in McLean, Va.

title: Baseball; Fitzgerald Powers Expos Past Cubs, 6-1
description: Mike Fitzgerald went 3 for 3, scored twice and drove in two runs today as the Montreal Expos beat the Chicago Cubs, 6-1.

title: ANTHONY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses of $436,000 for the quarter and $602,000 for the 6 months.

title: FIRST LIBERTY FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Film: 'Treadmill,' From Hungary
description: ''SINGING ON THE TREADMILL'' is a frolic with an edge - which may be why it was banned by the Hungarian authorities for a decade after it was made in 1974. Gyula Gazdag, who directed and did some of the writing, has blended the froth of operetta and the grit of reality into a concoction that is creamy on the outside, tart on the inside. It can be savored, with subtitles, at the Public Theater.

title: FOR WEINBERGER, A TALE OF CONFLICT
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's involvement in the Iran-contra affair is a tale of conflict between his stated conviction that selling arms to Iran was folly, and his submission to Presidential authority, no matter how misguided he believed it to be.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JULY 31, 1987
description: International A2-10 Donald T. Regan testified that President Reagan felt he had been repeatedly ''snookered'' by Iranians into believing that continued arms sales would lead to the release of more American hostages. Page A1 President Reagan told aides to protect American hostages in Lebanon by limiting disclosure and instead make statements that pointed up inaccuracies in press accounts, according to notes. A10 India said peacekeepers will stay in northern Sri Lanka until New Delhi decides their mission has been completed. Sri Lanka had said the Indian contingent would report to the local commander. A1 A bomb exploded in Johannesburg outside a military barracks. The blast wounded 70 people, including several soldiers, and caused extensive damage to surrounding buildings. A6 A U.S. helicopter crashed into the Persian Gulf, killing one man and leaving three missing, military officials said. The copter was not under attack, and officials offered no explanation for the accident. A3 The Kremlin accused U.S. diplomats of fomenting demonstrations by Cri-mean Tatars. Several hundred Tatars have staged demonstrations in Moscow seeking to return to Crimea, from which they were deported by Stalin in 1944. A3 Kenneth L. Adelman is resigning as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. He expressed satisfaction that Washington and Moscow were moving toward a ban on medium-range and shorter-range arms. A3 Britain's top court barred the press from reporting the memoirs of Peter Wright, a retired intelligence agent, even though his book is available in London, fresh from an American publisher. A1 Mexican plane crashes; 39 die A3 U.S. reconsiders Panama aid A3 London journal A4 Israeli proposes ouster of Arabs A5 National A12-13, B6-8, B20 Abortion counseling would be barred from Federal funding in family planning clinics under new rules proposed by President Reagan. Mr. Reagan has repeatedly failed to win Congressional approval of measures to ban abortions. A1 The abortion rules proposed by President Reagan could severely limit the services provided by more than 4,000 clinics that receive Federal funds, according to family planning professionals. B8 Newly found natural antibiotics first detected in frogs apparently kill a wide variety of bacteria, fungi, parasites and possibly viruses. The antibiotics hold promise of treating many human infections. A1 Foreign investors are helping to push American stock market indexes to historic highs, according to traders and experts. They credited not only the Japanese, but also Europeans and Australians. A1 Leading indicators rose in June for the fifth consecutive month, the Commerce Department reported. The gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent was slightly higher than had been generally expected. D1 The nation's poverty rate eased last year to 13.6 percent, the lowest level since President Reagan took office, the Census Bureau reported. A bureau official acknowledged a rise in income inequality. A12 The President will be hospitalized today to have a skin cancer removed from the tip of his nose, the White House said. Experts say such cancers are almost never life-threatenting and are easy to cure by cutting away the cancerous skin. A1 Testing for the AIDS virus would be greatly expanded on a voluntary basis with strict civil rights guarantees under legislation introduced by Congressional leaders, backed by many major health groups. A12 A new spending cut mechanism for the budget balancing law that could put off major decisions on the deficit and tax increases until after the 1988 elections has been endorsed by Senate Democratic and Republican leaders. A12 The fabled King Ranch is struggling through one of the toughest eras in its 134-year history. The vast South Texas ranch has laid off or given early retirement to more than half of its employees. A1 Washington Talk B6 M.I.A.'s and the politics of hope Acid rain lobby stirs debate Byrd assails Reagan's stance A12 Minutes with Kemp without Kemp B7 Computers replace coziness for Republicans in Iowa B7 Significance seen in Guam disease B20 Regional B1-5 New York's biggest crack ring was broken, officials said. A Federal indictment named 29 people, including a 26-year-old Dominican identified as the leader. The authorities said the group distributed up to 10,000 vials of crack a day, primarily in Washington Heights and the Bronx. B1 Oxygen levels are dangerously low in several parts of western Long Island Sound and constitute a serious threat to the region's fishing industry, according to scientists and environmental offficials. B2 A labor leader will serve as a temporary ''observer'' on the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority until Governor Cuomo appoints a permanent member. Labor leaders said Sonny Hall would be the observer because Mr. Cuomo refused to appoint another leader, Victor Gotbaum, to the seat. B3 A bill to enhance jury service by raising the daily pay to $15 and doubling to four years the time between summonses had been endorsed by court officials but was vetoed by Governor Cuomo as too costly. B3 Sharply higher garbage disposal fees in the 22 municipalities in Essex County, N.J., were approved by state regulators. An official said the soaring charges represented a major emergency. B2 A jury cited hopeless deadlock on charges that three reputed Mafia figures had slain a police detective on a Queens street. After nine days of deliberation the jury foreman said the vote was 9 to 3 for acquittal. B1 B3 O'Connor defends AIDS role A12 In Manhattan, panhandlers sometimes seem ubiquitous B1 Solitude lapse for spurned statue B1 176 apparent food poisonings at municipal hospital B3 Feminists file Baby M brief B3 Man triumphs over monkey B3

title: A Rebound in Metals Prices
description: Rising metals prices, an important factor in the gain reported yesterday in the Government's index of leading economic indicators for June, are expected to be a fact of industrial life for the rest of this year, according to economists and traders.

description: b-Net loss The losses in year-ago periods include a charge of $353,521,000 related to the reserve for nonrecovery of investments in generating facilities.

title: Byrd Says Reagan Tries to Deflect Attention From a 'Debacle'
description: The Senate Democratic leader accused President Reagan today of seeking to deflect public attention from the ''great national debacle'' over the Iran-contra affair by adopting a confrontational strategy intended to make Congress the ''fall guy.''

title: SOUTHERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Peru Clarifies Banking Policy
description: The Government will not expropriate foreign bank branches in Lima as part of its plan to nationalize Peru's private banks, the Prime Minister, Guillermo Larco Cox, said today.

title: Volcker Sees Nations in Bank Pact
description: In his last appearance before Congress as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker said today that an international banking agreement would likely be reached by the end of the year to provide uniform banking regulation among many industrialized countries.

title: Advertising; Ogilvy Profit Up 26.6%
description: The Ogilvy Group, parent of Ogilvy & Mather, reported yesterday that it had second-quarter revenues of $181 million, a 31.3 percent gain from $137.9 million in the comparable period last year. Net income grew 26.6 percent, to $8.1 million, or 57 cents a share, from $6.4 million, or 45 cents.

title: ALLEGHANY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4.7 million and $5.1 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $600,000 for the quarter and $700,000 for the 6 months. The company said results include pretax gains on security transactions of $200,000 in the latest quarter and $1 million in the latest 6-month; and $9.7 million and $10.3 million in the year- earlier quarter and 6 months, respectively. Results for the latest second quarter and 6-month also reflect the operations of Shelby Insurance Co., which was acquired by Alleghany in December 1986.

title: Texaco Advocate
description: A wealthy Colorado rancher who once was the ''Marlboro man'' was chosen as chairman of a committee to represent the interests of Texaco Inc. shareholders in the oil company's bankruptcy proceedings. Robert Norris, 58 years old, of Colorado Springs, owns 650,000 shares of Texaco and is a descendant of one of the company's founders. Mr. Norris appeared as the Marlboro man in the cigarette's magazine advertisements, according to Don Reeves, curator of the National Cowboy Hall of Fame.

title: U.S. and Greece Ease Dispute And Open Way to Base Talks
description: Greek and American officials indicated today that their countries had overcome a crisis that had reportedly jeopardized the future of United States military bases.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Bob Brookmeyer with Joe Roccisano's Big Band, Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Bob Brookmeyer, the valve trombonist who played a key role as both arranger and sideman with Gerry Mulligan's Concert Jazz Band 25 years ago and currently is an arranger for Mel Lewis's big band, is adding his big-band background to a 15-piece group led by Joe Roccisano, an alto saxophonist and arranger, that is playing its first major engagement in the East this weekend at Fat Tuesday's. Mr. Roccisano, who has played in and written for the bands of Woody Herman, Buddy Rich and Louis Bellson (he was in Mr. Bellson's big band when it appeared at Fat Tuesday's in May), organized his own group when he was working in Los Angeles. He put together a New York edition when he moved here a year ago. Mr. Brookmeyer, who has been Mr. Roccisano's mentor as an arranger, will be a featured soloist with the band. The band plays tonight and tomorrow at 8, 10 and midnight, and Sunday at 8 and 10 P.M. There is a $12.50 cover charge tonight and tomorrow and a $10 cover Sunday, with a $7.50 minimum all three nights.

title: LYDALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CINCINNATI MICROWAVE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CURIOSITY ON HEALING IN FROGS LEADS TO A GAIN IN ANTIBIOTICS
description: Curiosity about the way wounds in frogs healed quickly from surgical cuts has led a Federal researcher to the discovery of a new family of natural antibiotics that appear to kill a broad spectrum of microbes and may have uses in human therapy.

title: Latin Festival: What, Where and When
description: Festival Latino in New York, a theater and film series, begins tomorrow and runs through Aug. 23 at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. Unless otherwise noted, all theater performances are at 8 P.M. and are $15. Four theaters - LuEsther Hall, the Newman Theater, the Susan Stein Shiva Theater and the Little Theater - will be used for the festival; on some days, more than one show will be presented. Performances with simultaneous translation are noted. The film series features movies from Argentina; tickets are $5. A free concert at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park is also part of the festival. Theater information: 598-7155; film information 598-7171.

title: MUNSINGWEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and after a tax credit of $664,000 for the quarter and a tax benefit of $1,583,000 for the 6 months. The latest quarter loss includes a non-recurring charge of $2,717,000, compared with a gain of $1,982,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Essex County, Caught in Bind, Quadruples Garbage Disposal Fees
description: State regulators approved sharply higher garbage-disposal fees today for the 22 communities in Essex County and two in Union County that are to be shut out of a landfill in the Hackensack Meadowlands starting Friday.

title: Queens Jury Is Split on Murder of a Detective
description: After nine days of deliberations, a Queens jury yesterday declared itself ''hopelessly deadlocked'' on charges that three reputed Mafia figures shot a New York City police detective to death on a Queens street.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JULY 31, 1987
description: Markets

title: U.S. PROSOSES CURB ON CLINICS GIVING ABORTION ADVICE
description: President Reagan proposed a new set of regulations today that would bar family planning clinics that get Federal funds from counseling clients about abortion.

title: Diner's Journal
description: ASIA MINOR meets Major Trendies at Anatolia, a pastel-washed, designer-label Turkish restaurant on Third Avenue at 80th Street. If it weren't for the gleaming brass samovar and zealous young waiters flapping around in billowing costumes, you might think you had stumbled into yet another hip Italian trattoria.

title: Legendary Oilman Has a New Venture
description: Robert O. Anderson spent two decades building ARCO into the nation's sixth-largest oil company, and now, less than two years after retiring, he plans to take the top job at yet another oil company.

title: Oslo Expels 3 Russians
description: Norway said today that it had asked three Soviet officials to leave the country, saying they had tried to obtain sensitive submarine technology. It said the Soviet Union, in turn, had expelled a Norwegian diplomat.

title: PAR PHARMACEUTICAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
Tabou Combo
description: Tabou Combo, a Haitian band, will perform tonight at Sounds of Brazil, 204 Varick Street (243-4940). Sets begin at 11 P.M., 1 and 2:30 A.M.; there is a $15 cover and a two-drink minimum.

MACMILLAN BLOEDEL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: The net for the year-ago quarter includes a net gain of $2.5 million from the sale of certain timberlands, a net gain of $5.8 million from the exercise of an overallotment option by the Underwriters of American Capital Management & Research Inc. common stock and a net charge of $13.2 million resulting from the redemption of four debenture issues.

title: KINARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $345,000 and $382,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Sports People; Surgery for Gedman
description: Rich Gedman, the Boston Red Sox catcher, has been placed on the 21-day disabled list, and will undergo surgery Monday for torn ligaments in his left thumb. He could be lost for the remainder of the season, and the Red Sox have called up John Marzano from the Pawtucket Red Sox. Gedman hurt his thumb Monday night in a tag play on Jesse Barfield at home plate in Toronto.

title: THE TESTIMONY: 'COULDN'T SEEM TO GET THEIR ACT TOGETHER
description: Following are excerpts from the testimony of Donald T. Regan, the former White House chief of staff, before the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''WE'RE two gents from Verona,'' George Delacorte said, wrapping an arm around Joseph Papp's shoulder. ''I've never seen Verona, never hope to see it, but I understand Joe here has a little play about it.''

title: Film: 'A Man In Love'
description: A MAN LOVE'' is an unaccountably bad film from Diane Kurys, who at other times (with ''Peppermint Soda'' and ''Entre Nous'') has seemed one of the most promising new directors around. The story centers around a very important American film star played by Peter Coyote, which is to say that ''A Man in Love'' is misconceived from the very start.

title: NUVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Art: Met Favorites, Outdoors and In
description: EVERY time the Metropolitan Museum of Art gets bigger, we cherish all the more the glimpses of the world outside that it has to offer. Not only do they remind us of the Met's uniquely privileged position in Manhattan, but they give us a sense of space and air and light that can come as a welcome break.

description: Besides the mosaics and, of course, one another, subway riders have precious little to look at, which makes New York's underground good for conveying messages as well as people.

title: Washington Talk: Issues With a Tenacious Hold; The Politics of Hope on Americans Missing in Vietnam
description: The ghosts of Vietnam haunt Senator John McCain and Colleen C. Shine. And they are not alone. ''There is no way, absolutely no way, that we'll ever close the chapter on that unhappy part of America's history, the Vietnam War, unless we have a full accounting for those who are still listed as missing in action,'' said Senator McCain, a leader in Congress on the issue. The Arizona Republican, a former Navy pilot who was shot down over Hanoi in 1967, spent nearly six years in a prisoner-of-war camp and knew ''a couple of guys'' still listed as missing.

title: 4 Die in Collision With Train
description: A 14-year-old boy drove his family's pickup truck into the path of a freight train in a crash that left his mother and three of his siblings dead, the authorities said. The driver, Adam Taylor, and his 1 1/2-year-old brother, Benedict, were injured in the accident Wednesday afternoon at the intersection of U.S. Highways 24 and 59 in eastern Kansas. Killed in the crash were Linda Taylor, 37 years old, of Perry, Claire Taylor, 8, Marcel Taylor, 6, and Maryjean Taylor, 4. Another brother, Cameron, 15, was not injured, the Highway Patrol said.

title: Project Interrupts Solitude Of Statue F.D.R. Spurned
description: A mundane construction project - expanding the parking lot at the Franklin D. Roosevelt National Historic Site here - has uncovered a monument to the 32d President's quest for a representation of feminine beauty recalled from his younger days.

title: TONGUE-CHEEK-COUTURE
description: A new name was added Wednesday night to the 24 couture houses. Patrick Kelly, an American whose whimsical ready-to-wear has been attracting attention here for the last few seasons, decided to make clothes for private clients. So he sent out invitations, decorated with his signature buttons, to all of Paris, and all of Paris seemed to have accepted.

title: Voice of Dissent in South Korea Speaks in Verse
description: Some angry South Korean dissidents battle the Government with bricks and gasoline bombs; others hurl verse.

description: A mentally retarded man who said he was the victim of child abuse went to his death calmly in Louisiana's electric chair early today for raping, torturing and murdering an 11-year-old girl in 1981.

title: FOREIGN INVESTORS PROPEL U.S. STOCKS TO RECORD LEVELS
description: Foreign investors, buoyed by a renewed confidence in the stability of the dollar, are helping to push prices of American stocks to historic highs, according to traders and international market experts.

title: Arthur D. Little
description: Arthur D. Little Inc. said the trustees of its major shareholder, the Memorial Drive Trust, had rejected the proposed purchase of the trust's stake in the company by the Plenum Publishing Corporation. The trust is Little's employee retirement fund and it owns more than 70 percent of the company's stock. Directors of Arthur D. Little, a technology and management consulting concern, had rejected Plenum's offer of $50 a share, or a total of about $128 million. Plenum is a scientific publisher based in New York.

title: Regan Takes the Stand, Looking Mellow and Quite at Ease
description: Donald T. Regan, with the mellow smile of a Washington survivor, got a little of his own back today.

title: 'Chronology? I Was the Guy Looking for the Chronology'
description: Donald T. Regan was asked about being the ''fall guy'' in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Sports People; Task Force on Tennis
description: Concerned about what he called a current malaise in American tennis, Arthur Ashe announced yesterday that the United States Tennis Association's committee on player development, of which he is a member, has formed six ''task forces'' to improve the caliber of American players.

title: Networks Take Turns In Covering Hearings
description: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair will be televised live beginning at 9 A.M. on the NBC television network under the network rotation system. The hearings will also be televised on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on some local affiliates of PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service, including Channel 13 in New York.

title: Article 971687 -- No Title
description: A civil lawsuit was filed yesterday seeking $100 million in damages from the owners and managers of the Schomburg Plaza apartment tower in Harlem, where seven people died in a fire last March.

title: De Larrocha and Hager
description: Leopold Hager will conduct the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra tonight and tomorrow evening at 8 in Avery Fisher Hall. The performances include works by Haydn, Mozart and Schubert; soloists will be the pianist Alicia de Larrocha and Delores Ziegler, a mezzo-soprano. Tickets are $8 to $16. Information: 874-6770.

title: CONSOLIDATED-BATHURST INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after a $47.4 million writedown of oil and gas investments. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in February 1987. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Montreal Stock Exchange.

title: Market Place; Analysts See Utility Mergers
description: THE Utah Power and Light Company, whose financial performance has been weak in the last year, is turning out to be a utility whose stock has been put into play. The shares rose 75 cents, to $27.75, yesterday after climbing $2.50 on Wednesday.

title: NEW PROCESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ARCHIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
PHONEMATE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $94,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $75,000 and $125,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Luther Johnson
description: Luther (Guitar Jr.) Johnson will play the blues tonight at Speakeasy, 107 Macdougal Street (598-9670). Sets are at 8:30 and 11; admission is $7 with a two-drink minimum.

title: ON THE ROAD TO A CABBY'S LICENSE, NO SHORT CUTS
description: The life of the London taxi driver has long been an arcane process, beginning with its two-year memorization of ''the Knowledge'' - the city's 600-square-mile anatomy - and the dozens of examinations that wash out seven of eight hopefuls before they ever get to ask a paying customer, ''Where to, Guv'nor?''

title: ITEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said Anixter Bros., which it acquired at year-end 1986, had sales of $205.5 million in the latest second quarter. The latest 6-month preferred stock dividends exceeded net income.

title: Sibling Solidarity
description: A Long Island woman belatedly showing up to register her household for the community pool found herself looking at an application form that wanted to know who else would be swimming. Under ''family,'' she crossed off ''husband'' and ''wife'' -she neither is one nor has one - and wrote in ''sisters.'' The pool attendant frowned. ''Sisters are not family,'' she declared. ''You have to fill in the line by 'Independent Adults.' ''

title: In Struggle Of Primates, A Man Wins
description: It was a battle, but man triumphed over monkey yesterday at Kennedy International Airport.

title: TRANSIT WORKERS' CHIEF TO SIT ON MTA BOARD
description: The president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, Sonny Hall, will serve as a temporary observer on the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority until Governor Cuomo appoints a permanent labor representative to the board.

title: John, 44, Sends Royals Into Retirement
description: If things had worked out differently, Tommy John would not have won his 10th game last night for the Yankees. He would have been somewhere in Chapel Hill, N.C., his career having turned from pitcher to pitching coach for the University of North Carolina baseball team.

title: CROWN CENTRAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Share earnings for the year-ago quarter are fully diluted.

title: PLM COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OGDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,497,000 for the quarter and $3,135,000 for the 6 months.

title: Art: Celadon in 'Ice and Green Clouds'
description: THE title ''Ice and Green Clouds: Traditions of Chinese Celadon'' accurately reflects the two sides of an unusual ceramic exhibition. On the one hand, some of the 87 examples of Chinese green-glazed ware at the Asia Society have a touch of poetry, a metaphorical charge that suggests not only ice and green clouds, but also jade, stained glass and repositories in which seeds and souls are invited to settle.

title: Mitsubishi C.D.'s
description: The Mitsubishi Bank Ltd.'s New York branch is offering $50 million of 8 5/8 percent certificates of deposit due in 1990 at various prices through Morgan Stanley & Company. The notes are rated Aaa by Moody's and AA+ by S.&P.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Needling the Lawyer
description: At the Congressional hearing on the Iran-contra affair the other day, Representative Jim Courter needled the chief Senate counsel, Arthur Liman, who has questioned some Government officials sharply.

title: 70 Hurt in Explosion Near Johannesburg Barracks
description: A bomb exploded today outside a military barracks in downtown Johannesburg, wounding 70 people, including several soldiers, and causing extensive damage to surrounding buildings.

title: LEGGETT & PLATT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ARTEL COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a writedown of $267,000 of excess and obsolete inventory.

title: POLK AUDIO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Art: Red Grooms Show At Whitney Museum
description: THE exhibition of Red Grooms's work at the Whitney Museum of American Art seems at first like too much to handle: too much to look at and too much to listen to, as well. There are among this exhibition's several environmental ''sculpto-pictoramas'' no less than four separate soundtracks. Blaring in tandem, they enhance the carnival spectacle of the work itself. There are also stairs to climb, bridges to cross, ramps to scale and strange floors to traverse. With its fun-house atmosphere, this exhibition does not impress one as the kind that will shed the best light on Grooms, an artist who, as John Ashbery writes in his catalogue essay, ''has been called everything but serious.''

title: SCEPTRE RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ON CHOOSING THE PEOPLE
description: A former European leader who was in a position to know about nuclear decision-making asked the other day about Rear Adm. John Poindexter's role in the nuclear chain of command when he was in the White House.

title: SIGNIFICANCE SEEN IN A GUAM DISEASE
description: An international research team has found strong evidence that a poisonous substance in a plant eaten widely on Guam during World War II was the cause of a mysterious and devastating nerve disease that appeared years afterward among natives of that Pacific island.

title: BDM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOGAN SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $887,000 for the latest quarter and $450,000 for the year-ago period. Results for 1986 have been restated to include operations of GDK Systems Inc., acquired in May 1987.

title: AUGAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Clergyman Faces Panel On Attack on His Wife
description: There is not enough evidence ''at this time'' to indict a prominent minister whose wife has been comatose since an attack by an unknown assailant in April, a prosecutor who called the clergyman before a grand jury said Wednesday.

title: He Took Wider View
description: To the Editor:

New Jersey Can Have Both Its Bottle Bills and Its Glass Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Leaders Seek Stiffer Export Penalties
description: Japan's Government has agreed on legislation to toughen penalties for illegal exports of militarily sensitive technology to Communist bloc countries, although approval by the parliament is uncertain.

title: AST RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LEXINGTON SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago per share earnings are unavailable; the bank converted to stock form of ownership in December 1986.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Helms Aides Join Kemp
description: Two of Senator Jesse Helms's top political operatives are joining Representative Jack F. Kemp in his drive for the Republican Presidential nomination. Mr. Helms, a North Carolinian who is a leader in the conservative wing of the party, has said he will not back anyone in the primaries, but his key people would be unlikely to join Mr. Kemp without some acquiesence from Mr. Helms.

title: COASTAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes charges of $750,000 and $1,400,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, for relocation of the company's headquarters. The latest period share earnings are calculated on 7,328,000 shares outstanding for the quarter and 7,285,000 shares outstanding for the 6-month. Year-ago results are pro-forma; the company went public July 2.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Tainted Food Possible in Patient's Death
description: One patient has died and 175 more have suffered apparent food poisoning at Coler Memorial Hospital on Roosevelt Island, New York City hospital officials said yesterday.

title: To See Reagan: $20,000 a Month
description: Donald T. Regan, the former White House chief of staff, told the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair today that he had been shocked to learn that a former personal assistant to President Reagan was paid $20,000 a month to arrange meetings between the President and wealthy contributors to the contras.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: PROVENCAL is one of those terms that is tossed around with abandon on restaurant menus these days, a nifty and sophisticated-sounding label attached to just about any dish that calls for tomato, mixed herbs and garlic. Anyone who has had the good fortune to visit that magically fragrant region of southern France knows that Provencal food is far more diverse.

title: SUMMIT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CIT Group Notes Have 8.44% Yield
description: CIT Group Holdings, a finance company subsidiary of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, is offering $150 million of 8 3/8 percent notes due in 1990 at a price of 99.825, to yield 8.44 percent, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: John B. Bremner, Journalism Teacher, Is Dead
description: John B. Bremner, a professor of journalism at the University of Kansas and an expert on writing consulted by newspapers across the country, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Ponce Inlet, Fla. He was 66 years old.

title: Our Towns; Elysian Days At Helen Keller: A Special Camp
description: Why is it that day-camp vans always honk five minutes before you are ready? If anyone knows, would they please give Matt Brazezicke a call.

title: The Witness File
description: Name: Donald T. Regan Age: 68 Position: Mr. Regan was Secretary of the Treasury under President Reagan for four years beginning in 1981, then spent two years as chief of staff, resigning in February. Previously with Merrill

title: Leading Indicators Had 0.8% Rise in June
description: The Government's index of leading indicators, a widely followed economic forecasting tool, climbed in June for the fifth straight month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: USF&G CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After realized investment gains of $133,000 for the quarter and realized investment losses of $94,502,000 for the 6 months, and tax credits of $2,383,000 and $5,814,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After realized investment gains of $15,360,000 for the quarter and $65,613,000 for the 6 months, and tax credits of $12,570,000 and $55,328,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Few Champions Can Go Distance
description: It has been nearly 10 years of ever-changing heavyweight champions, an era when ordinary fighters became, in effect, king for a day.

title: U.N.'s Panel on War Crimes Will Weigh Opening Its Files
description: The 17 former members of the United Nations War Crimes Commission will meet in mid-September with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to consider opening the group's files on war criminals to the public, a top United Nations official said today.

title: Beirut Names Bomb Suspect
description: A soldier was charged today in the slaying of Prime Minister Rashid Karami last month by a bomb hidden in a military helicopter, judicial sources said. Lebanon asked Interpol to issue a warrant for Pvt. Elie Salibi, a Christian, who fled abroad shortly after the killing. Mr. Karami was Moslem.

title: Regan on Arms Shipment: 'Bigger Than a Breadbox?'
description: Donald T. Regan was asked about earlier characterizations of the arms shipments to Iran.

title: LIMITS ON ABORTION COUNSELING OPPOSED
description: Family planning professionals said today that the abortion regulations proposed by President Reagan could severely limit the services provided by the more than 4,000 clinics in the United States that receive Federal funds.

title: REAGAN TO HAVE SURGERY ON NOSE FOR SKIN CANCER
description: A scraping of skin that was removed from the tip of President Reagan's nose on Wednesday was found to be cancerous under microscopic examination, the White House announced today.

title: A Second Stake In Del E. Webb
description: Hecco Ventures, an investment partnership here, said today that it owns a 9.1 percent stake in the Del E. Webb Corporation and that it might seek control of the Phoenix-based gaming and real estate concern.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Borge Heard From
description: Victor Borge, the Danish-American pianist-comedian, first appeared in Washington in 1943 and has been making annual appearances practically ever since, in recent years at the Kennedy Center. So yesterday the Danish Ambassador, Eigil Jorgensen, gave what has become practically the annual Victor Borge luncheon at the Danish Embassy.

title: Advertising; Calet, Hirsch & Spector Gets Rorer Assignment
description: Calet, Hirsch & Spector/New York has been assigned Myoflex analgesic cream by Rorer Consumer Pharmaceuticals. No budget has been set yet, but last year's spending was on the $2 million level.

title: OWENS & MINOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Baker's Dozen Of New York City's Urban Masterpieces A BAKER'S DOZEN OF NEW YORK CITY'S URBAN MASTERPIECES; 13 Gems
description: SO persistent is the onrush of new construction in New York that the first temptation for the architecture buff is to track down the latest things, be they good or bad: the office towers and apartment blocks of Battery Park City, for example, or the glitzy new office buildings of the East 50's. But as the new buildings often physically overwhelm the old, a fixation on the most au courant architecture can overshadow the classic structures of the city, those works of architecture that, though they be neither the biggest nor the newest, remain the greatest, the works that transform our vision of what architecture and the city can be.

title: Maryland Democrats Set Back
description: The Maryland Democratic Party's plan for electing delegates to the Democratic National Convention has been held unconstitutional in a ruling that could affect the party in up to seven other states, including New York and New Jersey.

title: N.F.L. Camps; 5 Teams Offering AIDS Testing
description: In addition to the Dallas Cowboys and the Houston Oilers, at least 3 other of the 28 National Football League teams are offering free, confidential AIDS tests to players, coaches and staff members at their training camps, club officials said yesterday.

title: MONTGOMERY STREET INCOME SECURITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Motorola Expects U.S. Indictment
description: Motorola Inc. expects to be indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of overpricing and improper billing in two Defense Department contracts for electronics equipment, company officials said. Motorola's vice chairman and chief operating officer, William J. Weisz, said the company was considering a plea agreement on some of the charges. The jury is also reportedly investigating whether the company improperly charged the Government for certain labor costs, officials said.

title: Gooden Helps Mets Sweep, 5-3
description: The Mets, who seemed reasonably dead when the week started, showed signs of a remarkable revival tonight when they completed a three-game sweep of the St. Louis Cardinals, sent them to their seventh straight defeat and closed to 5 1/2 games out of first place.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Jim Lampley, who recently left ABC Sports because of unhappiness over his assignments, is likely to go to work for CBS as a sports anchor in Los Angeles and as a broadcaster on National Football League games. Eric Ober, the president of CBS's owned and operated stations, said KCBS was ''reasonably close'' to signing Lampley as its local anchor. . . . Dave Gagner, a center who played 10 games with the Rangers last season, has been re-signed.

title: Iranians Take a Tour of the West Wing
description: Donald T. Regan was asked about how representatives of Iran were able to gain access to the White House.

title: GEODYNE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
3 Prison Esapees Captured
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have recaptured the last three of seven prisoners who escaped from the state penitentiary on the Fourth of July. the authorities said today. The three, David B. Gallegos Jr., 33 years old, William Wayne Gilbert, 37, and James Kinslow, 27, were arrested in Garden Grove, Calif., said a Public Safety Department spokesman, Robert Kemble.

title: Textile-Import Bill Advances
description: The Senate Finance Committee today forwarded a bill to curb textile imports to the Senate, where it faces almost certain approval, and afterward the possibility of a Presidential veto.

title: A Strategy for Handling Nicaragua
description: President Reagan will ask Congress this fall for $100 million or more to carry on the contra war in Nicaragua against the Sandinista regime. This raises a central question: Do United States interests require the removal of that regime from power?

title: What Mussolini Knew and When He Knew It
description: To the Editor:

title: Music: Five Scott Johnson Works
description: SCOTT JOHNSON plays the electric guitar and writes music for his own ensemble of guitars, saxophones and percussion. But he is a classical composer through and through, his music steeped in the heritage of the concert hall. Sharing a Serious Fun! concert with David Van Tieghem at Alice Tully Hall on Monday, Mr. Johnson presented five compositions, three for his ensemble, Scott Johnson and Musicians, and two for his own electric guitar, augmented by electronics and pre-recorded tape.

title: Sports People; Patriotic Bonus
description: Fred Lebow, the director of the New York City Marathon, announced yesterday that any American citizen who wins the men's or women's competition will get an extra $10,000 and that there will be an extra $5,000 for an American finishing second or third in either division. The incentives are being offered because no American has won the race since Alberto Salazar in 1983.

title: Agency Approves Plan For Holocaust Museum
description: The National Capital Planning Commission today approved the general design for the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, which will honor millions of victims of Nazism.

title: AMERICA WEST AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dining Out Guide; Lincoln Center Area
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAFE DES ARTISTES, #1 West 67th Street (877-3500) - *(May 30, 1986) Dark burnished-wood walls, lead-paned windows and bucolic murals contribute to the gracious and romantic look of this West Side restaurant. You might start with cold duck-liver terrine in black-pepper crust; home-cured bresaola with figs, Parmesan shavings and olive oil, or salmon four ways: smoked, poached, dill-marinated and tartare. Main-dish choices include rare-roasted rack of lamb with basil; swordfish paillard with mustard sauce; hot smoked Norwegian salmon with sauce choron, and sauteed soft-shelled crabs with almond butter. Three-course prix-fixe $30. Entrees $13.50 to $29.50. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 3 and 5:30 P.M. to 12:30 A.M.; Sundays, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and 5 to 11 P.M. CAFE LUXEMBOURG, #200 West 70th Street (873-7411) - **(May 9, 1986) A stylish restaurant in the Lincoln Center area, this Art Deco cafe has a gleaming bar up front and sleek tile dining room with period sconces, Parisian cafe chairs and red banquettes. The menu is straightforward and essentially American, and starter options include a country salad of chicory with bacon, Roquefort cheese and garlic croutons; crab cakes with tomato coulis and pesto sauce, and chicken-liver terrine with grenadine and onion jam. For a main dish, you might order grilled warm breast of chicken salad with fresh herbs, chevre and sweet pepper julienne; grilled tuna with aioli sauce, roasted red peppers, fennel, zucchini and eggplant, or roasted crispy duck with red-wine sauce and ginger baked pear. Entrees $15 to $23. Fridays and Saturdays, 5:30 P.M. to 1:30 A.M.; Sundays, 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 6 P.M.to 12:30 A.M. CAVALIERE, #108 West 73d Street (799-8282) - *(May 22, 1987) Diners at this Italian restaurant may choose seats in the casual bar area, the more formal main area with a marble fireplace and lavish flowers or the breezy skylighted back room. The menu is large and complicated, but recommended appetizers are fried shoestrings of zucchini; squid and potato salad with mint, and mussels steamed with leeks, tomatoes, white wine and cream. The best pasta choices are fusilli with pesto and pine nuts; buckwheat pasta with sweet Gorgonzola sauce and walnuts, and fusilli in tomato sauce with garlic, basil, calamari and swordfish. Other good options include grilled veal chop, rack of lamb and halibut steak with Pommery mustard sauce. Entrees $12.50 to $22. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 4 P.M. and 5 P.M. to 1 A.M.; Sundays, noon to 4 P.M. and 5 to midnight. LA BOITE EN BOIS, #75 West 68th Street (874-2705) - *(Sept. 27, 1985) Just off Columbus Avenue is this small French country-style restaurant offering well-prepared bistro-type food in a cheerful setting. The kitchen's strength lies in seafood, and you might start with the Marseilles-style fish soup thickened with flecks of fish. Other appetizers include snails with wild mushrooms, and garlic sausage with lentil salad. Main-course choices include snapper in parchment with basil-butter sauce; fricassee of baby chicken braised with onions, bacon and mushrooms; scallops and shrimp in puff pastry, and fillets of lotte in lobster sauce. Three course pre-theater dinner $21.75; entrees, $14.50 to $20.75. Fridays and Saturdays, 6 to 11:30 P.M.; closed Sundays. SHUN LEE, #43 West 65th Street (595-8895) - *(Jan. 16, 1987) One of the more stylish and comfortable uptown Chinese restaurants is this one almost across the street from Lincoln Center. The main room with a sunken center is done in black, and red-eyed, tongue-thrashing papier-mache dragons encircle the room on a high ledge. The best appetizers are panfried Peking dumplings filled with well-seasoned pork; thin slices of duck with spicy Hunan sauce, and sliced kidneys with ginger, hot pepper and soy sauce. Main-dish options include freshwater prawns sauteed with rice wine, ginger, scallions and oyster sauce; lemon chicken, and red-cooked duck, which is marinated in soy sauce and sugar, fried to crisp the skin and served over a bed of sauteed spinach. Entrees $8.95 to $19.50. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 12:30 A.M.; Sundays, noon to 10:30 P.M. What the stars mean, page C26.
