title: EMC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Poems of Protest: A Sampler
description: THE WINTER REPUBLIC By Yang Song U (Translated by Ko Won) Is it now winter? The middle of night? With what, my friend, Shall we comfort ourselves This winter time when our fields are frozen? Is our great land still livable? Is the land still as beautiful as silks? That's a lie; that is a lie. We are serfs, scarecrows Lending our ears silently to lies In a pretense of knowing nothing every day And having to tolerate whips that cut our bones. Crying out in our own dear language, Why don't we make azaleas, azaleas, azaleas Come alive and bloom out of this frozen land, Blooming all over the paddies? My friend, Why don't we have our sad winter Spoken of, time and time again? And mustn't we, shackled tight, struggle on To the last, while waiting for the spring, My friend? DAILY INSPECTION OF THE SCENE OF THE CRIME By Hwang Chi U (Translated by Sol Sun Bong) Yesterday I came back with stakes driven into my ears. Today I installed a fence of barbed wire over my eyes And bound it with bandage. Tomorrow I will throw a scoop of dirt into my mouth And plug it with a ball of cotton. Day after day, Night after night, I bury a part of me In order to annihilate the evidence of my living In order to obtain my survival. DIALOGUE BETWEEN AN AMERICAN DOG AND A KOREAN DOG By Mun Bong Ran Korean dog: Hello, American dog. Your country is a bizarre society, a dogs' paradise, where dogs live luxuriously; How ridiculous that a dog's life is pampered, while your neighbors like El Salvador have no human rights. Our master's country has been trampled by Yan- kees, Japanese and Russians who divided the territory. Hello, American dog. We are willing to sacrifice our lives for our master. We are happy. We can't un- derstand civilized Americans putting the rights of dogs over those of people. Murderous human- ism! Goodbye, happy American dog. I CANNOT FORGET By Chong Hui Song I recall The lament of the poet arrested last night . . . . He dropped his head, Weighed down by the ''poet'' Prefixed to his name. I dread the night when he returns no more. I dread the land to which he returns no more.

title: Panhandlers' Numbers Seem to Rise
description: Kenneth Jackson, 48 years old, sat on a plastic milk crate in front of the Chemical Bank at Broadway and 81st Street with his hand out. The shade was yielding to sun, and he had yet to collect enough for a decent meal.

title: NICHOLS-HOMESHIELD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Currency Options Shift
description: In an unusual move, the Chicago Board Options Exchange said today that it was turning over its currency options contracts to the Philadelphia Stock Exchange, already one of the nation's leading currency options exchanges. Currency options, which give the owner the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell a fixed amount of foreign currencies at a set price, began trading on the Chicago Board in September 1985 but never captured a significant portion of the currency options market. The contracts to be transferred to the Philadelphia exchange include options on the Canadian dollar, pound, Swiss franc, West German mark, French franc, Japanese yen and Australian dollar.

title: Advertising; Media Costs in 1988 Are Seen Rising by 6.1%
description: In its August issue, Marketing & Media Decisions magazine will forecast that media costs will increase 6.1 percent in 1988. This is the publication's 17th Media Cost Forcast survey, and it is based on responses from 200 agency media directors nationwide.

description: After a huge decline in May, new-home sales rose 3.5 percent in June as a turnaround in mortgage rates bolstered a sagging sales market, the Government reported today.

description: Federal authorities yesterday said they had smashed a drug ring that they described as the biggest distributor of crack in New York City.

POVERTY RATE DIPS AS THE MEDIAN FAMILY INCOME RISES
description: The proportion of Americans living in poverty dropped a bit last year, to 13.6 percent, the lowest level since President Reagan took office, the Census Bureau reported today, while median family income grew faster than inflation.

title: The Record Stock Rally Continues
description: The summer stock market rally continued yesterday, as strong institutional buying, both from within the United States and from abroad, pushed the leading market indexes further into record territory.

title: The Bucolic Pleasures Of Van Cortlandt Park
description: ASK even the most city-smart New Yorker to free-associate about the Bronx, and you're not likely to hear of forests and wetlands, horse trails and farmhouses. Yet, in the borough that boasts the city's largest proportion of parkland, all this and more can be found in one of New York's greatest natural and recreational treasures: Van Cortlandt Park.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 390 money market mutual funds increased $1.05 billion, to $241.9 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 100 institutional funds were up $478.3 million, to $67.66 billion. Assets of the 200 general purpose funds were down $111 million, to $68.23 billion.

description: b-Includes tax benefits of $532,000 for the quarter and $1,303,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax benefits of $1,399,000 and $2,313,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Bob Clark and Meryl Fischman have been elected senior vice presidents and members of the executive committee at Kallir, Philips, Ross.

title: REGAN TESTIFIES REAGAN FELT IRAN 'SNOOKERED' HIM
description: Donald T. Regan, who was closer to President Reagan than anyone else who has testified before the Iran-contra committees, said today that the President felt he had been repeatedly ''snookered'' by Iranians into believing that continued arms sales would lead to the release of more American hostages.

title: Carlton Fredericks, 76, Host Of Radio Program on Health
description: Dr. Carlton Fredericks, a well-known radio commentator and writer on nutrition and health, died of a heart attack Tuesday at St. John's Riverside Hospital in Yonkers. He was 76 years old and lived in New City, N.Y.

title: HOUSE APPROVES LIABILITY LIMIT FOR ATOM PLANTS
description: The House of Representatives today approved a 10-year extension of the law that sets a limit on the liability of nuclear reactor operators in case of accident.

title: AUCTIONS
description: WINE collectibles - corkscrews, coasters, funnels, tasters, decanting devices and cellarets - will be auctioned Oct. 27 at Christie's in the first major wine-accessories sale held in New York in memory. According to the Christie's specialist in charge of the auction, Christopher Hartop, 800 items will be offered in 250 lots, the largest and most comprehensive selection of such material ever auctioned in the United States.

title: NETWORK SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Stage: 'Gentlemen of Verona'
description: WHAT does love do to its victims? According to the young William Shakespeare in ''Two Gentlemen of Verona,'' love leaves one ''metamorphosed,'' ''humbled,'' ''deformed.'' Lovers are driven to betray their friends, defy their parents, write bad poetry, and, in general, to behave with a great deal less decorum than the play's one indisputably chaste character, the sour dog Crab. In Stuart Vaughan's staging at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, the smitten young men and women of Verona and Milan are every bit as silly as Shakespeare intended them to be, and yet, for all their incontestable inanity, they are impossible to dislike. Mr. Vaughan understands that the playwright is sending up romance, not excoriating it. By opting for a light touch and a youthful, guileless acting company, the director uncorks the fresh humors of a comedy in which innocence, rather than love, can conquer all.

title: 39 Killed as Cargo Plane Crashes in Mexico City
description: A commercial cargo plane carrying 12 people and 18 horses today crashed on a crowded highway, rammed into a restaurant and exploded. Officials said at least 39 people were killed and 17 were injured.

title: Citing Cost, Cuomo Vetoes a Pay Raise for Jurors
description: Governor Cuomo announced today that he had vetoed a bill intended to make jury service more attractive through features such as an increase in pay and a reduction in the number of times a resident may be summoned to jury duty.

title: An 'F' for School Bureaucrats
description: It sounded like a sensible and practical idea: a summer program of remedial classes and part-time work for 3,500 youngsters. They were bound for New York City high schools this fall and considered ''at risk'' of dropping out. But the Board of Education reneged on the promise of jobs for all but several hundred; hundreds more left the program - a new class of summer dropouts.

title: TRW Contract
description: TRW Inc. has been awarded a $743.5 million military contract to build and launch five early-warning satellites, the Air Force said. The company was also awarded a second Air Force contract for $33.6 million for work on a space surveillance and tracking system. title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the new play ''Talk Radio'' incorrectly described the situation shown in the picture. The picture did not show a scene from the play, but rather actors offstage telephoning to an actor onstage. Also, the actress at the right was misidentified. She is Susan Gabriel.

title: Senate Plan Could Leave Key Budget Decisions for Next President
description: Senate Democratic and Republican leaders have endorsed a new proposal to amend the budget-balancing law that could put off major decisions on the deficit and tax increases until after the 1988 elections.

title: McDonnell Net Is Up 19.6%
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, helped by strong gains from its space and missile systems operations, said yesterday that second-quarter earnings rose 19.6 percent on a 9.7 percent increase in revenues.

title: Film: 'Wolf at the Door'
description: At first sight as he struts haughtily through the streets of Paris beneath a broad-brimmed straw hat, behind a macho mustache, throwing a small secret smile to a pretty girl along his route, Donald Sutherland's Paul Gauguin might be returning in triumph from his two years in Tahiti. But the hat is ratty as well as natty, the way his paintings are loaded on the cart being trundled before him hints that not everybody considers them masterpieces, and his eyes carry anxiety as well as arrogance. We soon learn that he has only four francs in his pocket.

title: Disinvestment Weighed
description: Britain's Standard Chartered Bank is discussing the sale of its shares in South Africa's second-largest bank as a prelude to disinvestment, bankers said today. Standard Chartered's stake is the last major foreign shareholding in the South African banking sector. South Africa's Standard Bank Investment Corporation said in a brief statement that it was ''aware that discussions are taking place concerning the future'' of the British banking group's 39 percent stake but gave no details.

The performers include Jaki Byard on piano, Bill Hardman on trumpet, Sahib Shihab on saxophone and many others. In case of rain, the concert will move indoors to East Islip High School at Redman Lane in East Islip.

Certainly no operatic production of ''Sweeney Todd'' has attracted more attention in this regard than that of the New York City Opera.

description: Kenneth L. Adelman announced today that he would leave his post as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency later this year, or after a possible summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: Advertising; Another Top Officer Returns to Thompson
description: W. Lee Preschel, the 53-year-old international specialist who was dismissed from the J. Walter Thompson Company by its old management in May, will be back on Monday to a bigger job than the one he left.

title: Cherkassky and Horne
description: Shura Cherkassky will give a piano recital of works by Bach-Busoni, Beethoven and Chopin, tonight at 9 in the Spanish Courtyard at the Caramoor Festival in Katonah, N.Y. Tomorrow evening at 8:30 in Caramoor's Venetian Theater, Marilyn Horne will sing works by Vivaldi, Beethoven, Schubert, Debussy and Copland; Martin Katz will be her accompanist. And Sunday afternoon at 5:30, Christopher Parkening will play a program of works for the guitar, in the Spanish Courtyard. Tickets for Ms. Horne's performance are $10 to $27.50; tickets to performances in the Spanish Courtyard are $20 and unreserved. For information and directions: (914) 232-5035.

title: Bill Auction Is Well Received
description: The Treasury's long-delayed auction of new three-month and six-month bills elicited good investor demand yesterday, spurred by the availability of interest rates well above 6 percent.

title: Economic Scene; China's Debate On Reforms
description: DEBATE in China among economists, politicians and Marxist theoreticians remains intense on future changes in the economic and political system. A group of American economists, led by Prof. M. Jan Dutta of Rutgers University, in recent meetings with Chinese economists and public officials in Shanghai, Beijing and at the Huazhong University of Science and Technology in Wuhan, found a remarkable boldness and willingness to discuss needed economic reforms - but strong inhibitions against proposing political change.

title: Blacks Get a Voting Majority On the City Council in Selma
description: Twenty-two years after the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. led a historic voting rights march in Selma, a veteran of the civil rights movement has been sworn in to give the City Council its first black voting majority.

POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Henry Butler, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). For his New York debut, the formidable young pianist from New Orleans has put together a quartet featuring Alvin Batiste, a clarinetist and one of that city's most accomplished and original instrumentalists. Mr. Batiste does it all, from keening sonics to the richly elegant bluesiness of Barney Bigard. With a rhythm section of Ron Carter on bass and Joe Chambers on drums, this band should soar. The quartet is performing through Sunday around 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. There is a $12 music charge and a food or drink minimum of $6 per person.

title: Film: 'The Lost Boys'
description: FILL a bathtub with holy water and garlic, load a plastic water pistol and aim at the vampires. In ''The Lost Boys,'' Joel Schumacher's hip, comic twist on classic vampire stories, practical reactions to the unnatural seem normal. These lost boys are not Peter-Pan innocents, but teen-agers who dress like rock stars, roar through town on motorcycles and happen to fly through the air and drink blood. The hero is a boy who's trying to save his older brother before the brother becomes a total vampire and before their mom comes back to see what a mess the house is.

title: SHAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
'Stranger Than Fiction'
description: ''It may seem strange to you, it may strike you as truth being stranger than fiction, but I take offense at the idea that it's hard to accept because what I have told you is the absolute truth of what happened.'' Thus did Attorney General Edwin Meese defend his early inquiry into the Iran-contra affair. Most members of the investigating committees understandably found Mr. Meese's November inquiry, if not his accounting of it, hard to accept, as Senator George Mitchell put it.
